Opinion", "title": "11 of Our Best Weekend Reads", "authors": ["Kaly Soto"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m never ever going to see my kid again,\u201d Mr. Pollack told the president. \u201cNever ever will I see my kid. I want that to sink in. It\u2019s eternity. My beautiful daughter, I\u2019ll never see again.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\n\u2018Never again should I feel guilty to be alive\u2019\n\nStudents at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School flooded the Florida State Capitol in Tallahassee on Wednesday to urge lawmakers to pass legislation addressing gun violence in the two weeks that remain in the legislative session.\n\nOne of the students, Sarah Chadwick, a junior at the school, said she had a simple message for legislators: \u201cNever again.\u201d\n\n\n\n\u201cNever again should a child be afraid to go to school,\u201d Ms. Chadwick said, speaking in the Capitol\u2019s rotunda. \u201cNever again should students have to protest for their lives. Never again should an innocent life be taken while trying to gain an education.\u201d\n\n\u2018How is it that easy to buy this type of weapon?\u2019\n\nAt the White House gathering on Wednesday, Samuel Zeif, a student at the school in Parkland, fought back tears as he demanded to know why the country tolerated one mass school shooting after another. He said his best friend had been killed.\n\n\u201cI turned 18 the day after, woke up to the news that my best friend was gone,\u201d Mr. Zeif said. \u201cI don\u2019t understand why I could still go into a store and buy a weapon of war.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe mentioned the massacre at Columbine High School in 1999, and the killing of 20 children at Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012.\n\n\u201cHow is it that easy to buy this type of weapon?\u201d he said. \u201cHow did we not stop this after Columbine, after Sandy Hook?\u201d\n\nVideo\n\n\u2018But now, we\u2019re angry, we\u2019re pissed\u2019\n\nSpencer Blum, one of the Stoneman Douglas High students who traveled to Tallahassee for demonstrations, said his friends were still mourning the loss of their classmates. But he said so many of the school\u2019s students had mobilized because they are angry.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re angry, we\u2019re pissed, we\u2019re ready for action,\u201d Mr. Blum said in an interview on CNN. \u201cWe are ready to make ourselves be heard.\u201d\n\n\u2018These people are trying to stop us\u2019\n\nOne of the most outspoken Stoneman Douglas High students, David Hogg, has been attacked by right-wing provocateurs pushing conspiracies, including that he is a \u201ccrisis actor.\u201d\n\nMr. Hogg addressed the lies on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cThese people are trying to stop us, and they are actually helping us out a lot,\u201d Mr. Hogg said on MSNBC. \u201cFor that, I\u2019m honestly kind of thankful.\u201d\n\nHe noted that his followers on Twitter had tripled.\n\nLawmaker says \u2018so many\u2019 gunmen turn out to be Democrats\n\nRepresentative Claudia Tenney, a Republican from Central New York, said in a radio interview on Wednesday that the news media ignores that \u201cthe mass murderers end up being Democrats.\u201d Her comments were swiftly condemned by her colleagues in the House.\n\nAlso, it does not appear that anyone tracks the political affiliation of mass killers.\n\n\u201cObviously there\u2019s a lot of politics in it,\u201d Ms. Tenney said. \u201cAnd it\u2019s interesting that so many of these people that commit the mass murders end up being Democrats. But the media doesn\u2019t talk about that either.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018The next person who dies \u2026 will be on you\u2019\n\nOutside the Florida State Capitol, Sheryl Acquaroli, another student at Stoneman Douglas High, shouted into a microphone, laying blame squarely at the feet of federal lawmakers.\n\nUsing a series of rhetorical questions, she demanded action from congressional leaders, as supporters screamed in response and a drummer beat out a rhythmic reply.\n\n\u201cDear Congress,\u201d Ms. Acquaroli yelled, \u201chow can you claim to stand for the people but let your kids get slaughtered like animals in their own school? Why is it that every time we make a step forward you force us back?\u201d\n\n\u201cHow many of the thoughts and prayers I have received do I have to check in for some damn action?\u201d she continued.\n\n\u201cThe next person who dies because of an AR-15,\u201d she said, \u201cwill be on you.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\n\u2018This is not the wrong time\u2019\n\nBefore a crowd of fellow students in Tallahassee, Florence Yared said it was not too early after the latest mass shooting to discuss changing gun laws. \u201cI\u2019m not trying to take away your Second Amendment rights, nor am I trying to eliminate all guns, but we cannot protect our guns before we protect our children,\u201d Ms. Yared said.\n\nVideo\n\n\u2018I understand what it is like to fear for your life\u2019\n\nInside the Florida State Capitol, Alfonso Calderon assailed the notion that, as young people, students would be unable to understand the situation well enough to speak out about it.\n\n\u201cTrust me, I understand,\u201d said Mr. Calderon, a Stoneman Douglas High student. \u201cI was in a closet, locked, for four hours with people who I would consider almost family, crying and weeping on me, begging for their lives.\n\n\u201cI understand what it is like to text my parents: \u2018Goodbye, I might never ever, ever get to see you again. I love you,\u2019\u201d he added. \u201cI understand what it is like to fear for your life.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nStudents formed a heart on a Florida football field\n\nStudents at schools across the United States walked out of class on Wednesday to honor the victims of the Stoneman Douglas High shooting. At Coral Springs High School in Florida, hundreds of students stood on a football field to form the shape of a heart.", "title": "11 of the Most Dramatic Moments in a Day of Confrontation Over Guns", "authors": ["Matthew Haag", "Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to new art shows \u2014 and some that will be closing soon.\n\n\u2018THE BEAUTIFUL BRAIN: THE DRAWINGS OF SANTIAGO RAM\u00d3N Y CAJAL\u2019 at Grey Art Gallery (through March 31). The first United States museum exhibition devoted to the scientific illustrations of this Spanish giant of neuroscience is among the new year\u2019s best. Its 80 freehand renderings of different brain cells, as viewed through a microscope, helped prove that they are unconnected, communicating across tiny gaps called synaptic clefts, which earned Cajal a Nobel Prize in 1906. His exquisite images, still used in textbooks, ignite synaptic charges throughout 20th-century art, from Surrealism onward. (Roberta Smith)\n\n212-998-6780, greyartgallery.nyu.edu\n\n\u2018BIRDS OF A FEATHER: JOSEPH CORNELL\u2019S HOMAGE TO JUAN GRIS\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through April 15). This small, hyper-specialized, stunning exhibition brings together a grand total of only 13 works \u2014 a dozen shadow boxes by Joseph Cornell, the Queens-based assemblage artist, and the Cubist masterwork that he cited as their direct inspiration, Gris\u2019s \u201cMan at the Caf\u00e9\u201d (1914). It might seem like a surprising obsession for Cornell, who was not a painter nor a Frenchman. He and Gris never met. But Cornell was deeply moved by Gris, the overlooked, tag-along third wheel in the Cubist movement that also included Picasso and Braque, and the show succeeds in tracking the fluttery ways of artistic inspiration. (Deborah Solomon)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018DIAMOND MOUNTAINS: TRAVEL AND NOSTALGIA IN KOREAN ART\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through May 20). Mount Kumgang, or the \u201cDiamond Mountain,\u201d lies about 90 miles from Pyeongchang\u2019s Olympic Stadium, but it\u2019s a world away: The august, multipeaked range lies in North Korea and has been impossible to visit for most of the past seven decades. This melancholy beauty of a show, featuring stunning loans from the National Museum of Korea and other institutions in Seoul, South Korea, assembles three centuries\u2019 worth of paintings of the Diamond Mountain range, and explores how landscapes intermingle nostalgia, nationalism, legend and regret. The unmissable prizes here are the painstaking paintings of Jeong Seon, the 18th-century artist who is perhaps the greatest of all Korean painters. And later impressions of the mountains, including a blotchy vision from the Paris-based modernist Lee Ungno, give a deeper historical weight to very live geopolitics. (Jason Farago)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018THE FACE OF DYNASTY: ROYAL CRESTS FROM WESTERN CAMEROON\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Sept. 3). In the African wing, a show of just four commanding wooden crowns constitutes a blockbuster in its own right. These massive wooden crests \u2014 in the form of stylized human faces with vast vertical brows \u2014 served as markers of royal power among the Bamileke peoples of the Cameroonian grasslands, and the Met\u2019s recent acquisition of an 18th-century specimen is joined here by three later examples, each featuring sharply protruding cheeks, broadly smiling mouths and brows incised with involute geometric patterns. Ritual objects like these were decisive for the development of Western modernist painting, and a Cameroonian crest was even shown at MoMA in the 1930s, as a \u201csculpture\u201d divorced from ethnography. But these crests had legal and diplomatic significance as well as aesthetic appeal, and their anonymous African creators had a political understanding of art not so far from our own. (Farago)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org", "title": "12 Art Exhibitions to View in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nEvery month, as various licenses expire, streaming services lose movies and TV series from their catalogs. Here are 12 great movies and TV shows leaving Netflix in March.\n\nA scene from \u201cJaws.\u201d Universal Pictures\n\n\u2018Jaws\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 1\n\n: March 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis 1975 horror thriller from Steven Spielberg did nothing less than revolutionize the movie industry \u2014 once studio executives realized exactly how much money could be made by a single summer blockbuster, it changed the way movies were released and advertised. But that\u2019s not the reason to see it (or see it again); it was a hit then, and it has endured for more than four decades because it is a masterfully constructed adventure ride, filled with bruising set pieces, eerily convincing effects, quotable dialogue (they are, in fact, gonna need a bigger boat), and memorable characters. Ultimately, we care about this ragtag crew of would-be shark hunters, which renders their breathless encounters with the great white all them more compelling.\n\n\u2014\n\nGuy Pearce in \u201cMemento.\u201d Danny Rothenberg/Newmarket Films\n\n\u2018Memento\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 1\n\n: March 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nChristopher Nolan\u2019s second feature \u2014 and first big hit \u2014 is an expertly constructed windup toy of a movie, spinning an exhilarating 113 minutes out of a fairly simple premise: A man with short-term memory loss (Guy Pearce), tries to solve his wife\u2019s murder. But Nolan augments the storytelling with an appropriate stylistic flourish, presenting it in reverse chronological order, so that in each new scene, the viewer is as uncertain about what\u2019s happening as the protagonist. Replete with neo-noir styling and a cast of top-notch character actors (including Joe Pantoliano, Carrie-Anne Moss, and Stephen Tobolowsky), \u201cMemento\u201d is a deliciously inventive mystery with a potent dose of melancholy right under its surface.\n\n\u2014\n\nKitty Winn and Al Pacino in \u201cThe Panic in Needle Park.\u201d 20th Century Fox\n\n\u2018The Panic in Needle Park\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBefore \u201cSerpico,\u201d before \u201cDog Day Afternoon,\u201d before even \u201cThe Godfather,\u201d Al Pacino made his big-screen breakthrough in this 1971 drug drama from director Jerry Schatzberg (\u201cStreet Smart\u201d). As a heroin addict and street hustler whose nights and days are an endless search for money, drugs or both, Pacino is both scarily convincing and offhandedly charismatic; you get a sense of why his new girlfriend, Helen (Kitty Winn, also terrific), would fall for him, and also why she should stay far away. Joan Didion and John Gregory Dunne\u2019s low-to-the-ground script and Schatzberg\u2019s gritty, neorealist-inspired photography create scenes that feel less written and staged than overheard and captured, resulting in an uncomfortable but powerful viewing experience.\n\n\u2014\n\nNatasha Lyonne in \u201cSlums of Beverly Hills.\u201d Fox Searchlight Pictures\n\n\u2018The Slums of Beverly Hills\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAmerican comedies don\u2019t deal in matters of class nearly as much as they could (and should), which is part of what makes this 1998 comedy from the writer-director Tamara Jenkins (\u201cThe Savages\u201d) unique, and valuable. Set in 1976, it concerns a lower-income family\u2019s attempts to keep the kids in good schools by dwelling in sketchy apartments right on the edge of Beverly Hills. Alan Arkin is a marvel as the hyper-neurotic patriarch, and David Krumholtz is uproariously funny as the unreasonably confident older son. But the showcase performer is Natasha Lyonne, warm and winning as the teenager daughter in the midst of a poorly-timed sexual awakening.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nA scene from \u201cThe Craft.\u201d Columbia Pictures\n\n\u2018The Craft\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nMisfits and weirdos will love this 1996 supernatural thriller-drama, in which a nervous new girl (Robin Tunney) at a Catholic boarding school turns to a trio of outcasts (Neve Campbell, Fairuza Balk and Rachel True) for friendship, and their tight-knit group turns into a witches\u2019 coven. The witty script (by Peter Filardi and director Andrew Fleming) nicely quenches one\u2019s thirst for teenage vengeance, with all the proper parties getting their deserved comeuppance. But it\u2019s not just a gimmick movie; all four protagonists create distinctive characters of genuine depth, lending weight to what could have been a throwaway genre exercise.\n\n\u2014\n\nEva Mendes and Will Smith in \u201cHitch.\u201d Columbia Pictures\n\n\u2018Hitch\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBetween \u201cIndependence Day,\u201d \u201cMen in Black\u201d and \u201cI Am Legend,\u201d Will Smith got so good at saving the world, he rarely got the chance to flex his considerable romantic charm. This 2005 hit filled that niche a bit, casting Smith as a relationship expert and one-on-one date coach whose latest client (a sweet and likable Kevin James) is something of a challenge \u2014 one that arrives just as he meets (and finds himself atypically tongue-tied around) the woman of his own dreams (Eva Mendes). Director Andy Tennant mines plenty of laughs from Smith\u2019s built-in swagger and James\u2019s customary oafishness, and he also has a great time turning those personas inside out. Smith and Mendes generate real chemistry, provoking a genuine rooting interest in the midst of this lightweight romp.\n\n\u2014\n\nMarlon Brando in \u201cThe Chase.\u201d Horizon Pictures\n\n\u2018The Chase\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA knockout ensemble cast \u2014 including Marlon Brando, Jane Fonda, Robert Redford, Robert Duvall and Angie Dickinson \u2014 assembles for this swampy, boozy, atmospheric thriller, in which a small town is rocked by a prison escape that unlocks their secret affairs, desires and lesser instincts. The pacing is a little punchy and the proceedings are a tad overheated, but it\u2019s worth a watch for the skill of the performers (Brando is particularly strong as a sheriff who\u2019s rapidly approaching the end of his rope) and for the inventive direction of Arthur Penn, whom we see tinkering with some of the thematic and stylistic interests he harvested to greater effect for his next film, \u201cBonnie and Clyde.\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\nMireille Enos and Joel Kinnaman, right, in \u201cThe Killing.\u201d Chris Large/AMC\n\n\u2018The Killing\u2019 (Seasons 1-2)\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 13\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNormally, the removal of the first two seasons of a mystery serial would be a real bummer. But this four-season crime drama is something of an exception, as the split between Season 2 and Season 3 signaled the end of one story (and the end of an era, changing out all but two of the key cast members, which happened again for the fourth) and the beginning of the next. The first two years of the series, based on the Danish crime show \u201cForbrydelsen,\u201d tell a story about the murder of a Seattle teen in meticulous detail \u2014 each episode covers just 24 hours of the investigation. Taut and disturbing, intricate and moody, \u201cThe Killing\u201d is the kind of meaty crime drama that sticks to your ribs.\n\n\u2014\n\nClockwise from top left: Cyril Figgis, Krieger, Cheryl, Pam Poovey, Sterling Archer and Ray Gillette in \u201cArcher.\u201d FX\n\n\u2018Archer\u2019 (Seasons 1-7)\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 14\n\n: March 14 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWhen it began in 2009, this animated FX comedy from Adam Reed sounded like a one-joke premise, and not exactly a fresh one either: an extended spoof on James Bond-style spy stories, set at a secret intelligence agency during an indeterminate and anachronistic pseudo-Cold War period. And yet it took flight (eight seasons and counting) thanks to the show\u2019s frisky writing, winking self-awareness, willingness to reboot itself entirely (full seasons have reset the narrative as a \u201cMiami Vice\u201d spoof and a private eye yarn), and most of all, the skills of the uproarious voice cast, including the \u201cArrested Development\u201d star Jessica Walters as another unstable mother and the \u201cBob\u2019s Burgers\u201d gem H. Jon Benjamin as the boozing, womanizing title character.\n\n\u2014\n\nFrom left, Judy Hopps (voiced by Ms. Goodwin) and Nick Wilde (voiced by Jason Bateman) in \u201cZootopia.\u201d Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures\n\n\u2018Zootopia\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 20\n\n: March 20 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOn the surface, there shouldn\u2019t be anything particularly revelatory about a Disney movie with cuddly talking animals. What\u2019s fresh and fascinating about this 2016 smash Byron Howard and Rich Moore, however, is the way it takes the conventions of those movies and injects them with a subtle dose of social commentary \u2014 without turning preachy or detracting from its surface pleasures. Ginnifer Goodwin is plucky and charming as Judy Hopps, a bunny cop in a utopian city who is drawn into a mysterious case wherein tame animals are reverting to their wilder instincts. Jason Bateman is a marvelous counterpoint as the con-artist fox who leads her into the city\u2019s criminal underworld, creating a buddy cop dynamic that recalls \u201c48 HRS.\u201d as much as \u201cBambi.\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\nFrom left, Roger Rabbit (voiced by Charles Fleischer) and Bob Hoskins in \u201cWho Framed Roger Rabbit.\u201d Walt Disney Studios\n\n\u2018Who Framed Roger Rabbit\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 24\n\n: March 24 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cZootopia\u201d wasn\u2019t Disney\u2019s first tale about crime-solving anthropomorphic mammals in the big city. One of its biggest hits of the 1980s was this clever story about cartoon animals and cynical humans who exist together in 1940s Los Angeles, where the movie star Roger Rabbit is accused of murdering a local tycoon. He hires Eddie Valiant (Bob Hoskins), a hard-boiled private eye, to clear his name, and they embark on a hilarious investigation of the animated movie industry, with cameo appearances by iconic characters from not only the Disney stable but also those of Warner Brothers, Max Fleischer and Walter Lantz. It\u2019s a treat for movie buffs and cartoon aficionados. It\u2019s also an entertaining potboiler, dipping into the juicy, \u201cChinatown\u201d-like mysteries and scandals of postwar Hollywood.\n\n\u2014\n\nFrom left: Waris Ahluwalia, Michael Gambon, Anjelica Huston, Noah Taylor, Bud Cort, Bill Murray, Matthew Gray Gubler, Seu Jorge, Jeff Goldblum, Cate Blanchett, Willem DaFoe in \u201cThe Life Aquatic With Steve Zissou.\u201d Phlippe Antonello/Touchstone Pictures\n\n0\n\n\u2018The Life Aquatic With Steve Zissou\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: March 26\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBill Murray stars as Steve Zissou, a Jacques Cousteau-style oceanographer and documentarian, in this frisky yet bittersweet comic drama from director Wes Anderson. Working for the first time with Noah Baumbach (\u201cThe Squid and the Whale,\u201d \u201cFrances Ha\u201d) as his co-writer, Anderson indulges in an absurdist streak that meshes nicely with the familial discord and dry wit of his previous pictures. He also marshals one of his most impressive casts to date, which includes Cate Blanchett, Willem Dafoe, Michael Gambon, Jeff Goldblum, Anjelica Huston and Owen Wilson, who is both touching and goofy as Zissou\u2019s estranged son.\n\n\u2014\n\nInterested in getting suggestions on what to watch? Sign up for our newsletter, which we send out every Monday, Wednesday and Friday.\n\n\u2014", "title": "12 Great Titles Expiring From Netflix in March", "authors": ["Jason Bailey"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSometimes a book grabs you because it\u2019s especially topical, or relevant to your life. Other times the appeal is more idiosyncratic: a strong voice, a great story, a brilliant mind at play. This week\u2019s recommended titles offer distinctive and wide-ranging pleasures \u2014 beginning with a couple of distinctive and wide-ranging essay collections from Martin Amis and Zadie Smith, celebrated novelists who also rank among the best literary critics of their generations. Read them, and you\u2019ll come up with your own recommendations. Or read more of ours! There\u2019s a harrowing autobiographical novel about birth and death all at once, along with memoirs from a Chinese filmmaker and an indigenous Canadian writer. (I told you the list was wide-ranging.) For good measure we also offer a couple of World War II thrillers, one fiction and one non, and deep dives into French food, Israeli politics and the roots of environmentalism.\n\nGregory Cowles\n\nSenior Editor, Books\n\nTHE RUB OF TIME: Bellow, Nabokov, Hitchens, Travolta, Trump: Essays and Reportage, 1994-2017, by Martin Amis. (Knopf, $28.95.) FEEL FREE: Essays, by Zadie Smith. (Penguin Press, $28.) The fourth collection of Amis\u2019s nonfiction and Zadie Smith\u2019s new book of essays find these two celebrated writers, friends from different generations, addressing politics, aging, art and more. \u201cAmis\u2019s new book, like the collections that preceded it, is the product of a ferocious yet sensitive mind,\u201d our critic Dwight Garner writes. \u201cEven when he is considering writers he\u2019s assessed many times before, his aim is so unerring that he resembles a figure out of Greek myth, firing arrows through ax-heads lined up in a row.\u201d Garner writes that Smith\u2019s \u201cFeel Free\u201d is a \u201cgentler ride,\u201d but in the best pieces, she \u201cpresses down hard as a cultural critic, and the rewards are outsize.\u201d\n\nHEART BERRIES: A Memoir, by Terese Marie Mailhot. (Counterpoint, $23.) Mailhot, whose early life on Seabird Island Indian Reservation in British Columbia was pocked with poverty, addiction and abuse, began working on this memoir when she had herself committed after a breakdown. In it, she reckons with the wages of intergenerational trauma. Members of her family had passed through Canada\u2019s brutal residential school system, which separated indigenous children from their families and cultures, and, in some cases, subjected them to physical and sexual abuse. The book is a \u201csledgehammer,\u201d our critic Parul Sehgal writes. It has \u201ca mixture of vulnerability and rage, sexual yearning and artistic ambition, swagger and self-mockery that recalls Chris Kraus\u2019s \u2018I Love Dick.\u2019\u201d\n\nRISE AND KILL FIRST: The Secret History of Israel\u2019s Targeted Assassinations, by Ronen Bergman. Translated by Ronnie Hope. (Random House, $35.) Bergman, a journalist based in Israel, conducted a thousand interviews with political leaders and intelligence operatives for this history of Israel\u2019s secretive program of targeted assassinations. The result is \u201can exceptional work, a humane book about an incendiary subject,\u201d our critic Jennifer Szalai writes. \u201cBlending history and investigative reporting, Bergman never loses sight of the ethical questions that arise when a state, founded as a refuge for a stateless people who were targets of a genocide, decides it needs to kill in order to survive.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIN EVERY MOMENT WE ARE STILL ALIVE, by Tom Malmquist. (Melville House, $25.99.) Based on a true story, this searing autobiographical novel, translated from the Swedish by Henning Koch, depicts a father struggling to cope with the tragic loss of his partner just as their daughter is born. \u201cThis is narrative as raw material,\u201d Katie Kitamura writes in her review. \u201cA novel about permeability, \u2018In Every Moment We Are Still Alive\u2019 captures the jumbled sensory experience of being profoundly, catastrophically overwhelmed. \u2026 It\u2019s clear that Malmquist is explicitly interested in what can\u2019t be contained, what continues to trouble.\u201d", "title": "12 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nFebruary is typically the dreariest month on the American sporting calendar, with football wrapping up, baseball still dormant and basketball and hockey grinding through their regular seasons. So this is a great month for the Winter Olympics to arrive, filling our TV screens with hours and hours of skating, skiing and, yes, even curling.\n\nThe downside for television viewers who don\u2019t care about sports is that many of the networks and basic cable channels will effectively take this month off, rather than try to compete with the NBC Olympics juggernaut. (One major exception? NBC itself, which will be using the games as a launching pad for new series.)\n\nStreaming services and premium channels seem determined to fill in the gaps. From new series by the creators of \u201cSix Feet Under\u201d and \u201cThe Killing\u201d to hard-hitting looks at opioid-dealing and the rise of Al Qaeda, here\u2019s what else we\u2019ll be talking about this month:\n\nA.P. Bio\n\n\u2018A.P. Bio\u2019\n\nStarted: Feb. 1, on NBC\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nGlenn Howerton took a leave of absence from \u201cIt\u2019s Always Sunny in Philadelphia\u201d to star in this dark, strange sitcom, playing an accomplished academic who\u2019s forced to take a job as a high school teacher. Created in part by the quirky \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d writer-filmmaker Mike O\u2019Brien, \u201cA.P. Bio\u201d also stars Patton Oswalt, as the school\u2019s principal, who stands in the way of the new teacher\u2019s plan to turn the most gifted students into his minions in a mission of revenge. The series started airing Thursday, but the first episode is already streaming on Hulu, and the first three are on NBC.com.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nHBO\n\n\u20182 Dope Queens\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 2, on HBO\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe comedians Phoebe Robinson and Jessica Williams adapt their popular podcast and live stage show to television, in four one-hour episodes that tackle topics relevant to the hosts\u2019 experiences as young, black New Yorkers. Robinson and Williams will share screen time with some of their friends and favorite comics, along with high-profile guests including Sarah Jessica Parker, Jon Stewart and Tituss Burgess from \u201cUnbreakable Kimmy Schmidt.\u201d The hybrid of talk show and stand-up showcase looks to offer fresh, funny insights into modern life in a diverse metropolis.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix\n\n\u2018Altered Carbon\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 2, on\n\nFeb. 2, on Netflix Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIf the recent \u201cBlade Runner\u201d sequel didn\u2019t satisfy your thirst for futuristic detective tales, this adaptation of the novelist Richard Morgan\u2019s 2002 cyberpunk classic should do the trick. Joel Kinnanman (\u201cThe Killing\u201d) plays Morgan\u2019s gruff, tough action hero Takeshi Kovacs, a mercenary whose consciousness was stored away for hundreds of years before being slipped into a new human \u201csleeve\u201d and employed to solve a murder. The series combines stunning science-fiction imagery with a traditional film noir plot, putting both in service of disturbing speculation on how humanity might evolve \u2014 and in some cases become more depraved \u2014 in the centuries ahead.\n\n\u2014\n\nSHOWTIME\n\n\u2018The Trade\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 2, on Showtime\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe documentarian Matthew Heineman has shown an uncanny ability to gain access to hard-to-reach people and places, from the militias on the American-Mexican border in \u201cCartel Land\u201d to the Syrian citizen activists in \u201cCity of Ghosts.\u201d For Heineman\u2019s new five-part series \u201cThe Trade,\u201d he tackles the reality of America\u2019s opioid crisis by embedding with the people profiting from the problem \u2014 including the criminals and the cops \u2014 while also spending time with the users and their families, who\u2019ve seen their lives torn apart by addiction.\n\n\u2014\n\nNFL\n\n\u2018Super Bowl LII\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 4, on NBC\n\n\u2018XXIII Olympic Winter Games Opening Ceremony\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 9, on NBC\n\nThe TV audience has fragmented so much over the past several decades that pretty much the only broadcast Americans still watch en masse is the Super Bowl \u2026 even if much of that audience will be tuning in this year for the commercials and the Justin Timberlake halftime show. A week later, NBC will begin broadcasting the Winter Olympics from Pyeongchang, South Korea, and while Olympic viewership lagged for the most recent Games, in Rio, NBC should still dominate the prime-time ratings from the Feb. 9 through 25 \u2014 starting with an opening ceremony that should feature the kind of awe-inspiring pageantry even the sports-averse can enjoy.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix\n\n\u2018Queer Eye\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 7, on Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA new roster of lifestyle experts replaces the groundbreaking \u201cFab Five\u201d of Bravo\u2019s original \u201cQueer Eye for the Straight Guy,\u201d a series which, back in the early 2000s, helped diversify programming and establish the vibrancy of gay culture on television. The Netflix revival will venture beyond the New York home of the original, taking the panel\u2019s tips on how to dress, cook and behave to the rest of America.\n\n\u2014\n\nHBO\n\n\u2018Here and Now\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 11, on HBO\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe writer and producer Alan Ball (\u201cSix Feet Under,\u201d \u201cTrue Blood\u201d) returns to HBO with a new series that arrives shrouded in mystery. Described as a family drama set in Portland, Ore., \u201cHere and Now\u201d stars Tim Robbins and Holly Hunter as an upper-middle-class married couple who raises multiracial adopted children alongside their biological offspring. The show also contains some supernatural elements, with a character who begins experiencing visions. Regardless of whether \u201cHere and Now\u201d is ultimately filed under fantasy, melodrama or something else entirely, expect it to express Ball\u2019s usual fascination with dysfunctional relationships, and how they connect to our communal search for deeper meaning.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix\n\n\u2018Seven Seconds\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 23, on Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nVeena Sud, who created \u201cThe Killing,\u201d is back with another gritty crime story combined with a moody study of urban life, this time based on the Russian movie \u201cThe Major.\u201d Regina King stars in this series as a Jersey City mom whose son is accidentally run over and killed by a police officer, exacerbating tensions between law enforcement and local black residents. The aftermath of the accident draws the private lives of several local citizens out into the open, exposing the fragility of a society riven with conflict.\n\n\u2014\n\nTBS\n\n\u2018Final Space\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 26, on TBS\n\n\n\nNot to be confused with Yahoo! Screen\u2019s dearly missed science-fiction sitcom \u201cOther Space,\u201d the wry animated genre parody \u201cFinal Space\u201d has the popular YouTube vlogger Olan Rodgers voicing both an astronaut named Gary and his cute-but-destructive pal, Mooncake. Conan O\u2019Brien\u2019s production company developed the series, which also features the voices of the geek TV favorites David Tennant (\u201cDoctor Who\u201d), Gina Torres (\u201cFirefly\u201d), Steven Yeun (\u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d) and John DiMaggio (\u201cFuturama\u201d), in a story about interstellar adventurers investigating the outer limits of the universe.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nGood Girls\n\n\u2018Good Girls\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 26, on NBC\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe subversive \u201980s movie \u201cHow to Beat the High Cost of Living\u201d gets an update in writer Jenna Bans\u2019s \u201cGood Girls.\u201d This cockeyed crime drama follows some desperate suburbanites who pull a heist at their local market. In familiar \u201cBreaking Bad\u201d fashion, what starts out as a desperate quick-fix becomes more complicated when the mob gets involved. The core cast includes Christina Hendricks, Mae Whitman and Retta, which should make it a lot easier to root for these antiheroines to succeed.\n\n\u2014\n\nHulu\n\n\u2018The Looming Tower\u2019\n\nStarts: Feb. 28, on Hulu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe prolific documentary filmmaker Alex Gibney and the Oscar-nominated screenwriter Dan Futterman assemble top-shelf character actors \u2014 including Michael Stuhlbarg, Bill Camp, Peter Sarsgaard, Jeff Daniels, and Tahar Rahim \u2014 for this dramatization of Lawrence Wright\u2019s Pulitzer-winning book, \u201cThe Looming Tower: Al Qaeda and the Road to 9/11.\u201d Set mostly in the late 1990s, the ten-part series will look at how the turf wars between the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. left the United States scandalously unprepared for the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cTalk Show: The Game Show\u201d (truTV, Feb. 1), \u201cAbsentia\u201d (Amazon, Feb. 2), \u201cCoach Snoop\u201d (Netflix, Feb. 2), \u201cStrike Back\u201d (Cinemax, Feb. 2), \u201cChannel Zero: Butcher\u2019s Block\u201d (Syfy, Feb. 7), Feb. 23), \u201cNotes from the Field\u201d (HBO, Feb. 24), \u201cAsh vs. Evil Dead\u201d (Starz, Feb. 25), \u201ciZombie\u201d (the CW, Feb. 26), \u201cLiving Biblically\u201d (CBS, Feb. 26), \u201cMcMafia\u201d (AMC, Feb. 26), \u201cUnREAL\u201d (Lifetime, Feb. 26), \u201cThe Voice\u201d (NBC, Feb. 26) and \u201cUnsolved: The Murders of Tupac and The Notorious B.I.G.\u201d (USA, Feb. 27).\n\n\u2014", "title": "12 Shows We\u2019ll Be Talking About in February", "authors": ["Noel Murray"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages \u2014 and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.\n\nPreviews and Openings\n\n\u2018THE AMATEURS\u2019 at the Vineyard Theater (in previews; opens on Feb. 27). Jordan Harrison\u2019s new play is a comedy about a group of actors who wander medieval Europe performing cycle plays. It\u2019s also a serious-minded exploration about what art can and should do in times of plague. In the Vineyard\u2019s production, directed by Oliver Butler, Quincy Tyler Bernstine, Thomas Jay Ryan and Michael Cyril Creighton star as the players.\n\n212-353-0303, vineyardtheatre.org\n\n\u2018AMY AND THE ORPHANS\u2019 at the Laura Pels Theater at the Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater (in previews; opens on March 1). In this new play from Lindsey Ferrentino (\u201cUgly Lies the Bone\u201d), a father dies and two adult siblings (Debra Monk and Mark Blum) set out to inform their sister, a woman with Down syndrome. For Roundabout Theater Company, Scott Ellis directs the road trip, which stars Jamie Brewer of \u201cAmerican Horror Story.\u201d\n\n212-719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org\n\n\u2018ANGELS IN AMERICA\u2019 at the Neil Simon Theater (previews start on Feb. 23; opens on March 25). The great work begins. Again. The National Theater\u2019s production of Tony Kushner\u2019s \u201cA Gay Fantasia on National Themes\u201d arrives on Broadway, starring Andrew Garfield, Lee Pace, Denise Gough and Nathan Lane as the crooked lawyer Roy Cohn. Reviewing the two-part work in London, Ben Brantley wrote that the director Marianne Elliott\u2019s production confirms the play\u2019s place \u201cin the pantheon of dramas that stretch toward the heavens.\u201d\n\n800-745-3000, angelsbroadway.com", "title": "13 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018GOOD FOR OTTO\u2019 at the Pershing Square Signature Center (previews start on Feb. 20; opens on March 8). Good for the New Group. In this new David Rabe play, a fine cast, including F. Murray Abraham, Ed Harris, Amy Madigan, Rhea Perlman and Mark Linn-Baker, has been assembled to play doctors and patients at a New England mental health center, a metaphor for a troubled United States.\n\n212-279-4200, thenewgroup.org\n\n\u2018IS GOD IS\u2019 at Soho Rep (in previews; opens on Feb. 18). A revenge tragedy, a spaghetti western and an Afropunk drama, Aleshea Harris\u2019s play, a winner of the Relentless Award for adventurous playwriting, follows two sisters tasked with a violent mission by their dying mother. Taibi Magar directs the epic, which inaugurates the newly renovated Soho Rep.\n\n866-811-4111, sohorep.org\n\n\u2018KINGS\u2019 at the Public Theater (in previews; opens on Feb. 20). In Sarah Burgess\u2019s contemporary comedy, Aya Cash and Gillian Jacobs are lobby heroines, rival Washington advocates with ties to Eisa Davis and Zach Grenier\u2019s competing politicians. Directed by Thomas Kail, who also led Ms. Burgess\u2019s \u201cDry Powder,\u201d the play takes on power, principles and make-your-own-s\u2019mores events.\n\n212-967-7555, publictheater.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018JERRY SPRINGER \u2014 THE OPERA\u2019 at the Pershing Square Signature Center (in previews; opens on Feb. 22). Can the worst show on television become a great musical Off Broadway? In this 2003 work from Richard Thomas and Stewart Lee, directed by John Rando for the New Group, Jerry (Terrence Mann) faces off against a star guest: the devil (Will Swenson). Fight, fight, fight!\n\n212-279-4200, thenewgroup.org\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2018RELEVANCE\u2019 at the Lucille Lortel Theater (in previews; opens on Feb. 25). In JC Lee\u2019s play of equal rights and unequal wrongs, an old-school feminist (the invaluable Jayne Houdyshell) responds to a younger rival (the talented Pascale Armand). Molly Camp and Richard Masur also star. Liesl Tommy directs the intersectional drama for MCC.\n\n866-811-4111, mcctheater.org\n\n\u2018A WALK WITH MR. HEIFETZ\u2019 at the Cherry Lane Theater (in previews; opens on Feb. 20). Was the perfect violinist also a political influencer? James Inverne\u2019s Primary Stages play imagines a conversation between Jascha Heifetz and the composer Yehuda Sharett in 1926, then traces its influence on the founding of the state of Israel two decades later. Yuval Boim, Adam Green and Erik Lochtefeld star.\n\n866-811-4111, primarystages.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018THE HOMECOMING QUEEN\u2019 at Atlantic Stage 2 (closes on Feb. 18). In Ngozi Anyanwu\u2019s drama, directed by Awoye Timpo, a Pulitzer Prize finalist (Mfoniso Udofia) returns to her native Nigeria. Now her trip at the Atlantic comes to an end. As Jesse Green wrote, this play about separation and reunion \u201cwrings all the pleasure possible out of its familiar tropes even as it revamps their meaning entirely.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, atlantictheater.org\n\n\u2018LATIN HISTORY FOR MORONS\u2019 at Studio 54 (closes on Feb. 25). John Leguizamo\u2019s solo show, an attempt to educate himself and his son about their shared origins, holds its final classes. Jesse Green noted that while the show is a \u201clong and often hilarious parade of injustice,\u201d for the first time in his Broadway career, \u201cMr. Leguizamo is unable to make a convincing cartoon of himself.\u201d\n\n212-239-6200, LatinHistoryBroadway.com\n\n\u2018MILES FOR MARY\u2019 at Playwrights Horizons (closes on Feb. 25). The Mad Ones\u2019 devised theater work, about a group of high school teachers in the late 1980s meeting to plan a fund-raiser, ends its telethon. Ben Brantley described this production, directed by Lila Neugebauer, as \u201ca priceless portrait of accumulating anger in the workplace.\u201d\n\n212-279-4200, playwrightshorizons.org\n\n\u2018UNTIL THE FLOOD\u2019 at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater (closes on Feb. 18). Dael Orlandersmith\u2019s solo show, directed by Neel Keller, finishes its Rattlestick deluge. Ms. Orlandersmith assembled the play from interviews with citizens of Ferguson, Mo., the city where Michael Brown was shot, then created composite characters who speak to questions of race and power. Jesse Green described the piece as \u201can urgent moral inquest.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, rattlestick.org", "title": "13 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "HOVVDY at Baby\u2019s All Right (Feb. 16, 8 p.m.). Tempos stay slow and voices tender in this Austin, Tex., duo\u2019s music, which is well suited to anyone who\u2019s ever loved Yo La Tengo\u2019s quieter moments. Their latest album, \u201cCranberry,\u201d unfolds like an afternoon whose warm mood you remember long after the details have faded. Hovvdy (pronounced \u201cHowdy\u201d) will mark the LP\u2019s release with this Brooklyn show.\n\n877-987-6487, babysallright.com\n\nINTERFERENCE AV at AMC Empire 25 (Feb. 19-21, 8 p.m.). This free festival will turn the AMC Empire 25, a large Times Square movie theater, into a temporary hub of avant-garde music. On Monday night, the Midwestern electronic producer Jlin will headline; on Tuesday night, the long-running noise-rock act Lightning Bolt will take over; and the Sun Ra Arkestra will close out the event on Wednesday night. Experimental video projections, D.J. sets and more will round out the festivities.\n\nwithfriends.co/clocktower\n\nDAMIAN \u2018JR. GONG\u2019 MARLEY at PlayStation Theater (Feb. 22, 8 p.m.). Bob Marley\u2019s youngest son has been a noteworthy reggae standard-bearer in his own right since the early 2000s, scoring an enduring solo hit with \u201cWelcome to Jamrock\u201d in 2005 and collaborating prominently with Nas and Mick Jagger, among others. Last year, he had a scene-stealing turn on Jay-Z\u2019s Grammy-nominated album \u201c4:44.\u201d CyHi the Prynce and Stefflon Don open.\n\n212-930-1940, playstationtheater.com\n\nSIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON\n\nPhoto\n\nJazz\n\nANDY BEY at Minton\u2019s Playhouse (Feb. 22, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). With his round and crinkled baritone, Mr. Bey can turn jazz vocals into a vessel for close inspection and surprise (that beats the more typical role they play: delivering comfort and emotional payoff, without much work from the listener). Audiences in the 1960s knew him for his work in Andy and the Bey Sisters, a vocal trio, and in the \u201970s he staked out distinctive terrain in the funk-fusion landscape. But since the 1990s, Mr. Bey, who doubles on piano, has thrived as a soloist. He performs jazz standards and his own poetic originals, letting the songs open up and slow down and sometimes nearly dissolve on his tongue.\n\n212-243-2222, mintonsharlem.com\n\nGERALD CLAYTON QUARTET at Jazz Standard (through Feb. 18, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Mr. Clayton, a pianist with a lissome and prayerful touch, leads a quartet here featuring the bassist Yunior Terry, the drummer Obed Calvaire and the percussionist Gabo Lungo. The group is joined during this run by two special guests: On Friday, it\u2019s the young vibraphonist Joel Ross; on Saturday and Sunday, the alto saxophonist Yosvany Terry. All of these musicians can play with ease and assurance, as if submitting to some ecstatic momentum, but they get there by different routes. Mr. Clayton\u2019s piano playing cascades, illustrates and embellishes, whereas Mr. Ross likes to interpose and chatter, like a kinetic conversationalist. And Mr. Terry, on saxophone, treats the tousled rhythmic logic of Cuban rumba as his foundation, moving in arcs and dashes and sweeps of color.\n\n212-576-2232, jazzstandard.com\n\nCORCORAN HOLT at Ginny\u2019s Supper Club (Feb. 17, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Mr. Holt, a bassist known for his work alongside the saxophonist Kenny Garrett, moved to New York from Washington, D.C., more than a decade ago. The title of Mr. Holt\u2019s newly released debut album, \u201cThe Mecca,\u201d nods to the idea that New York is jazz\u2019s promised land. But the record\u2019s sound suggests something else: the proud complexity of his hometown\u2019s own musical history. (For much of the 20th century, after all, Washington was a jewel of black arts and letters nearly on par with Harlem.) There\u2019s the sturdy, Southern-tinged swing feel; the proud, muscular harmonies beneath the lead lines; the occasional hand-drum rhythms, suggesting a lifelong exposure to go-go music. He\u2019ll play songs from \u201cThe Mecca\u201d here with Keith Loftis on tenor saxophone, Ashlin Parker on trumpet, Benito Gonzalez on piano and McClenty Hunter on drums.\n\n212-421-3821, ginnyssupperclub.com\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nALLEN LOWE at Dizzy\u2019s Club Coca-Cola (Feb. 20, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Mr. Lowe doubles as an alto saxophonist and a kind of alternative cultural anthropologist. His histories of American popular music (\u201cThat Devilin\u2019 Tune: A Jazz History 1900-1950\u201d and \u201cGod Didn\u2019t Like It: Electric Hillbillies, Singing Preachers and the Beginning of Rock and Roll, 1950-1970,\u201d among others) reflect a fathomless musical knowledge and an iconoclastic streak. Those elements define his music too: a loose meld of American folklore, halcyon pop and free jazz. For this concert, Mr. Lowe has convened a 13-piece band to honor the heavy influence of John Coltrane\u2019s 1960s work. He\u2019s doing it in decidedly unconventional fashion, reaching back to the polyphonic sound of early-20th-century New Orleans.\n\n212-258-9595, jazz.org/dizzys\n\nMIN XIAO-FEN WITH REZ ABBASI at Roulette (Feb. 18, 4 p.m.). Ms. Min plays the traditional pipa and other Chinese lutes with a hard-bitten, unflinching power. A conceptualist as well as a folklorist, she will present a new, original score for \u201cThe Goddess,\u201d a seminal silent film from 1930s Shanghai. The music she has written draws from across the spectrum of Chinese heritage, including references to Tibetan chants as well as other folk forms, while remaining in contact with her jazz influences. Accompanying her is the prodigious guitarist Rez Abbasi.\n\n917-267-0368, roulette.org\n\nJAY RODRIGUEZ AND SPECIAL GUESTS at Le Poisson Rouge (Feb. 20, 9:30 p.m.). Mr. Rodriguez plays with an unreserved flexibly on the tenor, alto and soprano saxophones; flute; and bass clarinet. Originally from Colombia, he has worked with artists from Prince to Elvis Costello to Marc Ribot. On his own forthcoming album, \u201cYour Sound (Live at Dizzy\u2019s Club Cola-Cola),\u201d Mr. Rodriguez moves between idioms and energies as easily as he switches instruments. He celebrates the album\u2019s release with this concert, featuring a powerhouse band: J. D. Allen on tenor saxophone, Arturo O\u2019Farrill on piano, Melissa Slocum on bass, Victor Jones on drums and Billy Martin on percussion.\n\n212-505-3474, lpr.com\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "13 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Justice Department charged 13 Russians and three companies on Friday in a sprawling indictment that unveiled a sophisticated network designed to subvert the 2016 election and to support the Trump campaign. It stretched from an office in St. Petersburg, Russia, into the social feeds of Americans and ultimately reached the streets of election battleground states.\n\nThe Russians stole the identities of American citizens, posed as political activists and used the flash points of immigration, religion and race to manipulate a campaign in which those issues were already particularly divisive, prosecutors said.\n\nSome of the Russians were also in contact with \u201cunwitting individuals associated with the Trump campaign,\u201d according to court papers. Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel leading the investigation, made no accusation that President Trump or his associates were knowingly part of the conspiracy.\n\n\u201cThe indictment alleges that the Russian conspirators want to promote discord in the United States and undermine public confidence in democracy,\u201d Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general overseeing the inquiry, said in a brief news conference. \u201cWe must not allow them to succeed.\u201d", "title": "13 Russians Indicted as Mueller Reveals Effort to Aid Trump Campaign", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "It was a daunting doubleheader.\n\nThe conductor Yannick N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin, the next music director of the Metropolitan Opera, had spent the day leading a dress rehearsal of Richard Strauss\u2019s dense \u201cElektra,\u201d which opens on Thursday. And it wasn\u2019t long before he was due back in the pit to conduct the evening performance of Wagner\u2019s nearly six-hour, stamina-testing \u201cParsifal.\u201d\n\nAs he walked back to his hotel near Central Park during his brief break last Friday, Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin considered fitting in a nap. Instead, he opted for a workout \u2014 using a smartphone app to connect with a personal trainer \u2014 and a light supper.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very simple moves,\u201d he said of his exercising afterward, as he walked back to the opera house. \u201cMostly stretching, just to make sure that tonight is good.\u201d", "title": "14 Hours With the Met Opera\u2019s New Maestro", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "DAVE DOUGLAS at Jazz at Lincoln Center (Feb. 23-24, 7 and 9:30 p.m.). An eclectic trumpet virtuoso who\u2019s been a leading voice on his instrument since the 1990s, Mr. Douglas presents \u201cDizzy Atmosphere,\u201d a program of improvisations and extrapolations based on Dizzy Gillespie\u2019s compositions. He\u2019s joined onstage by a cast of prodigious comrades: the trumpeter Ambrose Akinmusire, the pianist Gerald Clayton, the guitarist Bill Frisell, the bassist Linda May Han Oh and the drummer Joey Baron.\n\n212-721-6500, jazz.org\n\nAMIRTHA KIDAMBI at Roulette (Feb. 27, 8 p.m.). As a vocalist, Ms. Kidambi is vast and blustery and open, but always sure of step. As a composer, she is often minimal, using songs to establish some general shapes and then letting improvisation do the rest of the work. At least, that\u2019s how things work in Elder Ones, her excellent quartet, in which she sings and plays the harmonium. That group will perform at this concert. But first Ms. Kidambi will deliver something different: \u201cYajna,\u201d a new suite for solo vocals meant as a musical ablution for trying times.\n\n917-267-0368, roulette.org\n\nCARMEN LUNDY at Jazz Standard (through Feb. 25, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Ms. Lundy, a widely respected vocalist, is possessed of an enthusiastic delivery and a thick vibrato. Last year she released \u201cCode Noir,\u201d an album of 12 simmering originals that address subjects of romantic commitment, political resistance and solidarity. This weekend she appears with a stellar band of accompanists: the pianist Patrice Rushen, the guitarist Andrew Renfroe, the bassist Kenny Davis and the drummer Kendrick Scott.\n\n212-576-2232, jazzstandard.com\n\nMACEO PARKER at the Blue Note (Feb. 27-March 4, 8 and 10:30 p.m.). More than any saxophonist, Mr. Parker has helped define the sound of funk music. He threw splashes of grease into James Brown\u2019s music as a prominent soloist in that band for most of the 1960s, then moved on to the subversive, psychedelic funk of Parliament and Funkadelic, George Clinton\u2019s ensembles. Since the 1990s, Mr. Parker has been stomping across the globe with his own groups, delivering a satisfying, hip-swiveling m\u00e9lange of funk and soul classics and his own repertoire.\n\n212-475-8592, bluenote.net\n\nBEN WENDEL SEASONS BAND at the Village Vanguard (Feb. 27-March 4, 8:30 and 10:30 p.m.). Mr. Wendel is a tenor saxophonist of cool, even tone and steam-engine momentum. In 2015 he created a work titled \u201cThe Seasons,\u201d inspired by Tchaikovsky\u2019s set of short pieces by the same name. It includes 12 tunes \u2014 which Mr. Wendel released over 12 months \u2014 each dedicated to another fellow musician. Here he presents that music with Gilad Hekselman on guitar, Aaron Parks on piano, Matt Brewer on bass and Eric Harland on drums.\n\n212-255-4037, villagevanguard.com\n\nJOHN ZORN\u2019S \u2018IMPROV NIGHTS\u2019 at the Stone (Feb. 23-25, 8:30 p.m.). For almost 13 years, this one-room venue in Alphabet City has been New York\u2019s truest and coziest \u2014 if not its comfiest \u2014 home for experimental improvising. This weekend marks the end of an era: After these performances, John Zorn, the saxophone luminary and Stone proprietor, is moving the establishment to a small theater space at the New School. Mr. Zorn closes things out with a series of \u201cImprov Nights,\u201d bringing together an overspill of top-shelf collaborators to improvise in a loose, valedictory rotation.\n\nthestonenyc.com\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "14 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOther countries, big countries, India, and others, we had to pay because they considered them a growing country.\u201d\n\nThis is misleading.\n\nMr. Trump is likely referring to the Green Climate Fund, a United Nations program to help poorer countries mitigate the effects of climate change.\n\nThe voluntary program has been in place since 2013, and was not mandated under the Paris agreement. The United States pledged $3 billion to the fund, but Mr. Trump halted contributions, with $2 billion still outstanding. Developing countries, including Mexico, Indonesia and Mongolia, also are putting money into the fund.\n\n\u201cCompanies are pouring back into this country, pouring back. Not like \u2014 when did you hear about car companies coming back into Michigan and coming to Ohio and expanding? You never heard that.\u201d\n\nFalse.\n\nThe Reshoring Initiative is an advocacy group that works with manufacturing companies to return jobs to the United States from overseas. Its website lists dozens of instances when car companies returned manufacturing jobs to the United States over the past decade. For example, Ford announced it would move production of pickup trucks from Mexico to Ohio in 2015, and General Motors said it would build a type of Cadillac in Tennessee instead of Mexico in 2014.\n\n\u201cWe declined to certify the terrible one-sided Iran nuclear deal. It was a horrible deal. Whoever heard you give $150 billion to a nation that has no respect for you whatsoever?\u201d\n\nThis is misleading.\n\nThe Iran nuclear deal released about $100 billion \u2014 not $150 billion \u2014 in previously frozen Iran assets; the United States did not cut Iran a check. Much of that money is also tied up in debt obligations. For example, $20 billion is owed to China for financing projects in Iran. Estimates for the actual amount available to Iran range from $35 billion to $65 billion.\n\n\u201cYou saw Apple just brought $350 billion in.\u201d\n\nNot quite.\n\nMr. Trump has previously claimed that Apple\u2019s $350 billion investment is the direct result of his tax cuts. But Apple, according to reporting in The Times, \u201cwas already on track to spend $275 billion over the next five years. After the $38 billion tax payment is subtracted, that leaves its new investment at roughly $37 billion over the next five years.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re not giving us their best people, folks. They\u2019re not giving us \u2014 use your heads. They\u2019re giving us \u2014 it is a lottery.\u201d\n\nThere is no evidence to support this.\n\nMr. Trump is referring to the diversity visa lottery. But foreign governments do not select entrants; rather, millions of individuals enter of their own volition. A computer chooses winners at random and, before receiving a visa, those selected must undergo a screening process that bars criminals and the indigent. In fact, those who have been admitted through the program have higher rates of employment and of finding work in professional or managerial occupations than most other immigrants.\n\n\u201cThis guy came in through chain migration. And a part of the lottery system. They say 22 people came in with him.\u201d\n\nThere is no evidence to support this.\n\nIt is implausible that Sayfullo Saipov, the suspect in the October 2017 truck attack in Manhattan, enabled 22 to immigrate to the United States. He is a green card holder who immigrated to the United States in 2010 from Uzbekistan, married another Uzbek immigrant in 2013 in Ohio and fathered three children in the United States. Under current law, he is not eligible to sponsor any extended family to immigrate to the United States.", "title": "15 Claims From Donald Trump\u2019s Speech to Conservatives, Fact Checked", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Part of its strategy is to make this Los Angeles studio a hub for actors, musicians and social-media influencers on promotional tours, where they will film reaction shots based on terms that Giphy users often plug into search boxes. The dissemination, it is hoped, will make them \u201cGIF-amous.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI really want it to be a stop on a press tour,\u201d said Samantha Scharff, Giphy Studios\u2019 C.E.O., offering a tour of the space. \u201cYou go to \u2018Kimmel.\u2019 You go to Giphy.\u201d There is a miniature golf course that winds through the office and most of the conference and meeting tables double as Ping-Pong tables, as is de rigueur at start-ups. Pillows on couches are stitched with \u201cLMAO\u201d and \u201cOMG.\u201d There are a few different filming rooms, including one with a brick wall that the staff thinks of as its \u201cNew York stage.\u201d\n\nAnd upstairs is a steep slide that visitors are encouraged to try. You never know where GIFs might happen. \u201cWe wanted people to come here and hang out and make content,\u201d said Ms. Scharff, whose career path has tracked the decreasing attention span of viewers (from \u201cSaturday Night Live,\u201d to \u201cThe Colbert Report,\u201d to producing YouTube videos, to Giphy).\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt is a risky strategy; part of the appeal of GIFs is that they are organically referential to collective nostalgia for previous pop-culture touchstones \u2014 not choreographed and overtly promotional. She and Mr. Zeff, however, have high hopes that they can change the form from a repurposed clip of existing content into an entertainment medium in its own right. \u201cWe want to be the MTV of the messaging generation,\u201d he said.\n\nIn the summer, Martellus Bennett, then a tight end for the Green Bay Packers, came to check out Giphy Studios and toss ideas around with Mr. Zeff. Giphy then decided to send staff members to Green Bay, Wis., to GIF-ify Mr. Bennett and teammates including Aaron Rodgers as they pantomimed popular hashtagged gestures (#thumbsup, #letsgo and #middle finger). The clips racked up 150 million views in 48 hours, according to Mr. Zeff.\n\nThis December day at Giphy Studios was an unusually busy one, with Gwen Stefani stopping by at the last minute to film holiday-themed GIFs, and three other scheduled shoots: with Mr. Santos, a band called Portugal. The Man, and the actress Amber Stevens West.\n\nPhoto\n\nAgainst another green screen, Ms. West filmed tarot-card-theme GIFs, under the direction of Ms. Millar-Blanchaer and Michael Bruno, an associate producer and director at Giphy Studios. Best known for her role in the 2014 film \u201c22 Jump Street,\u201d Ms. West stood behind a white rectangular cutout that was suspended from a rod. She wore a blue cape and then a white robe over her jeans and T-shirt. This was the first time Giphy had used a costume for a shoot.\n\n\u201cHow about a \u2018You are awesome\u2019?\u201d Ms. Millar-Blanchaer said. Then: \u201cLet\u2019s do a \u2018You Got This!\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. West posed gamely and emoted as directed.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s kind of like an acting exercise,\u201d she said.\n\nFor nonactors, preening in front of a camera with directors calling out emotions to convey merely with facial expressions and gestures can be cringe inducing.\n\nThis was the case with Portugal. The Man, who are originally from Wasilla, Alaska, and who won a 2018 Grammy for best pop duo/group performance for \u201cFeel It Still.\u201d They arrived at Giphy Studios toward the end of the day and sat down with the production staff to get organized.\n\nThe idea was to make GIFs connecting to \u201cinternet holidays,\u201d which tend to be popular among Giphy users \u2014 in this case National Doughnut Day, Pizza Day, Beer Day, Video Game Day/Gaming Day and Earth Day.\n\nMr. Bruno asked if anyone would object to these. \u201cWe have no reservations or moral compass whatsoever,\u201d one of the bandmates said. \u201cWe\u2019ll do anything.\u201d The group laughed. That was before they knew they\u2019d be asked to juggle doughnuts and pose next to slices of pizza.\n\nIn the studio, each of the four musicians took his turn and was a good sport, hamming it up for the camera as producers shouted hashtags.\n\nZach Carothers, the bassist, went first, and seemed relieved when he was done posing with doughnuts placed over each finger like rings. He sat down in the back of the studio and shrugged. \u201cOur record label is always looking for interesting ways to shovel us into all sorts of crap,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t know if you\u2019ve heard, but these GIF things are pretty popular on the interwebs.\u201d", "title": "15 Minutes of Fame Is Too Much. Try 6 Seconds.", "authors": ["Katherine Rosman"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "REBEL SPIRITS: ROBERT F. KENNEDY AND MARTIN LUTHER KING JR. at New-York Historical Society (through May 20). Delve into the ties that bound these progressive standard-bearers through photographs that document their rise to the national stage in the 1950s and \u201960s and the struggle for the societal changes they championed, and ephemera such as magazines, campaign buttons, protest placards and an R.F.K.-M.L.K. spinning pendant. You can even listen on a transistor radio to the song Dick Holler wrote after their assassinations in 1968, \u201cAbraham, Martin and John.\u201d (Danielle Dowling)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\n\u2018ALBERTO SAVINIO\u2019 at the Center for Italian Modern Art (through June 23). The paintings of this Italian polymath have long been overshadowed by the brilliant work of his older brother, Giorgio de Chirico. This show of more than 20 canvases from the late 1920s to the mid-1930s may not change that, but the mix of landscapes with bright patterns and several eerie portraits based on family photographs are surprisingly of the moment. (Smith)\n\n646-370-3596, italianmodernart.org\n\n\u2018SCENES FROM THE COLLECTION\u2019 at the Jewish Museum. After a surgical renovation to its grand pile on Fifth Avenue, the Jewish Museum has reopened its third-floor galleries with a rethought, refreshed display of its permanent collection, which intermingles modern and contemporary art, by Jews and gentiles alike \u2014 Mark Rothko, Lee Krasner, Nan Goldin, Cindy Sherman and the excellent young Nigerian draftswoman Ruby Onyinyechi Amanze \u2014 with 4,000 years of Judaica. The works are shown in a nimble, nonchronological suite of galleries, and some of its century-spanning juxtapositions are bracing; others feel reductive, even dilletantish. But always, the Jewish Museum conceives of art and religion as interlocking elements of a story of civilization, commendably open to new influences and new interpretations. (Farago)\n\n212-423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org\n\n\u2018CAROLEE SCHNEEMANN: KINETIC PAINTING\u2019 at MoMA PS1 (through March 11). Some say that #MeToo has gone too far. What modern misogynist will be yanked from museums next? Gauguin? Picasso? I say, sure, why not? Set them aside, give them a rest and make room for what we never see, which means art by almost any woman you can name. Carolee Schneemann is one I\u2019d move right into the cleared-out spotlight, not just because she has star quality, which she does, or because she has majorly shaped art history, which she has. I\u2019d put her there because, in a career of some 60 years, she\u2019s been one of the most generous artists around \u2014 generous with her presence, her thinking, her formal and political risk taking and her embrace of embracing itself. You\u2019ll find evidence of all of this in her first comprehensive retrospective. (Cotter)\n\n718-784-2084, momaps1.org\n\n\u2018THE SCULPTURE OF GONZALO FONSECA\u2019 at the Noguchi Museum (through March 11). The Uruguayan-American sculptor Gonzalo Fonseca (1922-97) pioneered an architecturally inflected, whimsically literary style of relentless ambiguity. Whether covering large pieces of Italian travertine with incised circles and tiny pyramids, fixing a small red sail to a flat chunk of limestone or titling a tabletop-size pillar of dark gray stone \u201cSelf-Portrait,\u201d Fonseca made his work live by putting it almost entirely in the power of the viewer\u2019s imagination. This modest but jampacked mini retrospective \u2014 aptly sited in the museum built by his friend and fellow stone carver Isamu Noguchi \u2014 is worth taking in slowly. (Will Heinrich)\n\n718-204-7708, noguchi.org\n\n\u2018THE VIETNAM WAR: 1945-1975\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through April 22). In contrast to the PBS series \u201cThe Vietnam War,\u201d this exhibition delivers historical data, a lot of it, quick and dirty, through labels, film and audio clips and objects, some of which fall under a broad definition of art. Along with paintings by contemporary Vietnamese artists, there\u2019s graffiti-style drawings on combat helmets and Zippo lighters, and period design in album covers and protest posters. Words and images work together in murals labeled \u201cHome Front\u201d and \u201cWar Front\u201d that put you in the middle of the war\u2019s primary issues and events. (Cotter)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018DAVID HOCKNEY\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Feb. 25). This gorgeous retrospective is a strand of perfectly curated, self-contained galleries. Each concentrates on a specific period and style, from the often homoerotic faux-na\u00efve figuration of his early fame to the taut geometry of the houses, pools and lawns of Los Angeles and the dry but intimate portraits. Then it\u2019s on to the interiors, still lifes, landscapes and garden views, all rendered in heated color and teasingly offhand brushwork. Mr. Hockney\u2019s greatness has never been put so clearly. (Smith)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org", "title": "16 Art Exhibitions to View in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 To show that their threatened resistance to Home Rule is not an idle boast, and that if the measure be passed civil war will result, Irish Unionists are preparing to arm and equip themselves.\n\nIt is stated that they are arranging for the simultaneous withdrawal from the Post Office Savings Bank of all moneys deposited by them, and that these moneys are to be employed in the purchase of weapons and accoutrements.\n\nAlready inquiries have been made at Birmingham, with a view to contracts for the supply of arms, and yesterday a Dungannon club received from a Birmingham manufactory an offer of 1,000 Martini rifles at a low price.\n\nMeanwhile pacific and persuasive endeavors will be made to avert the apprehended trouble.\n\nIt is proposed in Belfast that a deputation of 5,000 Ulster-men should go to London at their own expense, and demand from Mr. Gladstone that he and his party should not separate Ulster from the rest of the Empire, by his Home Rule Bill, without their consent.\n\nNo threats or violent language to be used, but the demonstration is to act as a warning to the Premier.\n\n\u2014 The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 23, 1893", "title": "1893: Ulster Men Prepare for Civil War, Planning Mass Bank Withdrawal to Buy Arms", "authors": ["The International Herald Tribune", "International Herald Tribune"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Original headline: \u201cStealing a Smoke, in Good Company,\u201d from March 1999.\n\nThe story: For those too young to remember, the early \u201990s were a strange time in New York. At the start of the decade, there were nearly eight times as many killings in the city as there are now, but you could find a choice one-bedroom in Greenwich Village for under $100,000. Weirdest of all? When you were out with friends, you wouldn\u2019t have to step outside to smoke. That\u2019s right: You could legally fire up a cigarette in a bar or a restaurant.\n\nIt would not last. By 1995, the city had begun conceding to nonsmokers, leaving the city\u2019s unrepentant tobacco heads searching for chic night spots where they could puff in peace, away from angry stares.\n\nEnter Circa Tabac, which opened in 1998, billing itself as the city\u2019s only \u201ccigarette lounge.\u201d This was a smoker\u2019s speakeasy, basically, with a Deco-tinged d\u00e9cor hearkening back to \u201cCasablanca\u201d and a battery of industrial-strength air purifiers. It also, if you can imagine, had a menu featuring more than 100 brands of international cigarettes, catering to the black-clad Europhiles (and actual Europeans) who frequented SoHo back then.\n\nThe big, smoky picture: Smoking became a battleground issue in New York throughout the Giuliani and Bloomberg years, and not just for health reasons. At stake was the soul of the city, or so some smokers insisted. The city had evolved from an anything-goes dystopia that only Martin Scorsese could love (but such a fun one!) to a playground for rollerblading professionals, a macrocosmic \u201cFriends\u201d set. And, with that, a vocal segment of New York\u2019s smoking class insisted that certain changes (ahem, the Smoke-Free Air Act) were wiping out all that made New York exceptional, turning it into just another rule-bound, salad-nibbling American city. Were we going to continue on as a Western satellite of Paris, with its brooding, Gauloises dragging intellectuals, or just a very cold San Diego?", "title": "1999: When Smokers in New York Made Their Last Stand", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The trial was dominated by four former detectives who testified that the Police Department\u2019s elite Gun Trace Task Force was made up of thugs with badges who stole cash, resold looted narcotics and lied under oath to cover their tracks. They detailed acts of police criminality including armed home invasions stretching back to 2008.\n\nThe acting police commissioner, Darryl DeSousa, said in a statement immediately after the verdict that the department would move to fire Mr. Hersl and Mr. Taylor, who have been suspended without pay since being indicted and arrested in March.\n\n\u201cWe recognize that this indictment and subsequent trial uncovered some of the most egregious and despicable acts ever perpetrated in law enforcement,\u201d Commissioner DeSousa said.\n\nWilliam Purpura, Mr. Hersl\u2019s lead lawyer, said that the Hersl family was disappointed in the verdict but noted that the jury \u201cdid acquit him of one of the more serious crimes.\u201d He said a decision about a possible appeal would be made later.\n\nBoth men were cleared of possessing a firearm in pursuance of a violent crime.\n\nMr. Taylor\u2019s defense team and his relatives did not immediately speak to reporters after the verdict.\n\nMuch of the testimony during the trial focused on Gun Trace Task Force members who had pleaded guilty, including the unit\u2019s onetime supervisor, Sgt. Wayne Jenkins. He was portrayed as leading his unit on a tireless quest to shake down civilians and find \u201cmonsters\u201d \u2014 big-time drug dealers with lots of loot to steal.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The task force has been disbanded.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is not clear when Mr. Jenkins and the other former detectives who pleaded guilty will be sentenced by a federal judge. Four ex-officers testified for the government in hopes of shaving years off their sentences.\n\nThe defense teams for Mr. Hersl and Mr. Taylor had asked jurors to doubt the motivations of the government\u2019s witnesses, including a number of convicted drug dealers who received immunity for their testimony.\n\nMr. Schenning said he was thankful the jurors saw through that.\n\n\u201cThat was the business model for this organization: They thought if you rob drug dealers they have no place to go,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Purpura did not deny that his client took money but said the thefts did not rise to the more serious charges of robbery or extortion. The two defense teams also attacked the truthfulness of the four disgraced detectives, noting that they had admitted to lying for years to juries, judges, colleagues and their families.\n\nAssistant United States Attorney Leo Wise reminded jurors that the central question in the trial involved the actions of the rogue police unit and that whether some of its robbery victims made money \u201cselling drugs or Girl Scout cookies\u201d was irrelevant.\n\nPublic defenders say there could be a few thousand tainted cases stretching back to 2008 involving the jailed members of the Gun Trace Task Force. So far, roughly 125 cases involving the eight indicted Baltimore police officers have been dropped.\n\n\u201cBeyond the sheer credibility issues that should have been raised at the time, given how embedded their crimes were in their police work, all cases involving these officers are tainted,\u201d said Debbie Katz Levi, head of special litigation for Baltimore\u2019s Office of the Public Defender.", "title": "2 Baltimore Police Detectives Are Convicted of Racketeering", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "At least two students were shot in a middle school classroom in Los Angeles on Thursday, and a female suspect was taken into custody, the police said.\n\nThe police received a call about the shooting at 8:55 a.m. local time and responded to Salvador Castro Middle School, in the Westlake North neighborhood. The school shares its campus with Belmont High School.\n\nOfficer Drake Madison of the Los Angeles Police Department said that two 15-year-old students had been shot. One, a boy, was in critical but stable condition after being shot in the head, and the second, a girl, was in fair condition after she was shot in the wrist. Three other people suffered minor injuries. The police found a gun on the scene.\n\nThe police said that a 12-year-old girl was in custody and that they believed the shooting was unintentional.
