Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe more statements there are, the worse it is,\u201d said Mr. Carter, a former United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York. In the long run, \u201cpeople remember the result but nobody remembers how long it took.\u201d\n\nDevin M. O\u2019Malley, a spokesman for the Department of Justice, declined to comment on the status of the Garner investigation.\n\nThe city has moved swiftly recently to bring administrative charges against other officers accused of misconduct.\n\nTwo officers, Edward Martins and Richard Hall, quit the Police Department in November, three days before they were scheduled to face an administrative trial. The officers\u2019 trial on charges of sexually assaulting an 18-year-old woman in Coney Island, Brooklyn, after a drug stop had just begun. A crucial difference between the case of the two officers and Officer Pantaleo is that Mr. Martins and Mr. Hall have been charged.\n\nRather than hurt the federal case, Susan M. Karten, a lawyer who represented the Baez family in their civil suit against the city, said testimony gathered for Mr. Livoti\u2019s administrative trial helped reveal discrepancies among the statements of officers at Mr. Baez\u2019s arrest. While Mr. Livoti claimed that Mr. Baez\u2019s struggling set off an asthma attack, another officer said that Mr. Baez was not struggling and was handcuffed on the ground when she arrived.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe departmental trial was the first time Mr. Livoti had testified.\n\n\u201cI think the more prior testimony you have,\u201d Ms. Karten said, \u201cthe better in these cases where there are several people involved and they get together and get their story together.\u201d\n\nTwo officers were fired after an administrative trial in 2003 for perjuring themselves in testimony about Mr. Baez\u2019s death.\n\nThe actions of other officers as Mr. Garner was being subdued for reportedly selling illegal cigarettes, and the reports they filed, could be under scrutiny in any investigation, Ms. Karten added.", "title": "3\u00bd Years After Eric Garner\u2019s Death, Family Still Waits for Closure", "authors": ["Jeffery C. Mays"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "A group of Olympic athletes is attending the 2018 Winter Olympic Games, but they won\u2019t be competing for medals.\n\nInstead, they will travel to Pyeongchang, South Korea, as Olympic artists in residence, the International Olympic Committee announced today.\n\nThe four artists, who have competed in a combined seven Olympic Games, include the Greek-American distance runner Alexi Pappas, the British javelin thrower Roald Bradstock, the Swiss fencer Jean-Blaise Ev\u00e9quoz and the American biathlete Lanny Barnes.\n\nThe modern Olympic Games, in their earliest decades, relied on creative competition. Between 1912 and 1948, the I.O.C. awarded gold, silver and bronze medals to artists in five categories: painting, sculpture, architecture, literature and music. The Irish author Oliver St. John Gogarty won a bronze medal in literature at the 1924 Paris Olympic Games. The architect of the Jefferson Memorial, John Russell Pope, won a silver at the 1932 Los Angeles Games.", "title": "4 Athletes Selected as Artists in Residence at the Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Powerful winds and heavy rains delivered flooding and property damage to the central and southern United States this weekend, leading to at least four deaths, officials said.\n\nIn separate cases in Kentucky, two men were found dead in cars that appeared to have been swept away from flooded roadways. Also in Kentucky, a woman died after a tornado struck her home. In Arkansas, a man was killed after his trailer home was blown into a pond.\n\n\u201cThe flooding and tornadoes are loosely related in that the same overall weather pattern led to both,\u201d Bill Bunting, the chief of forecast operations for the Storm Prediction Center at the National Weather Service, said in an email on Sunday.\n\nThe tornadoes were caused by a storm system that showered eastern Oklahoma to the Ohio Valley with heavy rainfall. It has also been a rainy month for Pittsburgh, where the Ohio River begins. That contributed to the overflows that flooded properties and closed roads in the river basin downstream.", "title": "4 Dead After Tornadoes and Floods Rip Through Central and Southern States", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.\n\nALAN BATES: THE AFFABLE ANGRY YOUNG MAN at the Quad Cinema (Feb. 16-22). Beginning on Feb. 23, the Quad will present a new digital spruce-up of \u201cKing of Hearts\u201d (1967), the cult classic and antiwar fable in which Alan Bates plays a British soldier at the end of World War I who finds that the loosed asylum inmates in a French town are more sane and peaceful than the society he knows. But this week, the theater will offer a fuller sampling of Mr. Bates\u2019s charm and smarm with a career-spanning retrospective. In Jerzy Skolimowski\u2019s eerie \u201cThe Shout\u201d (Tuesday), Mr. Bates plays a mental patient himself. Over the course of the film, he relays the story of how he upended the marriage of an English couple (John Hurt and Susannah York) with possible supernatural help. The nerve-jangling sound design should play exceptionally well in a theater.\n\n212-255-2243, quadcinema.com\n\nDOC FORTNIGHT 2018 at the Museum of Modern Art (through Feb. 26). Boasting more than two dozen features, MoMA\u2019s annual survey of the nonfiction filmmaking landscape is as topical as ever. Like past editions, this year\u2019s lineup takes a broad perspective on what constitutes a documentary. Monday\u2019s showing of the multiplatform \u201cH\u00edbridos, the Spirits of Brazil,\u201d an examination of music and mysticism that strives to give a sense of what a trance state is like, will consist of a live performance and presentation. The Doc Fortnight program will also pay tribute to Jonathan Demme, who died last year, and whose documentary work included the beloved Talking Heads concert film \u201cStop Making Sense\u201d (Feb. 23) and the Spalding Gray monologue \u201cSwimming to Cambodia\u201d (Feb. 25). The \u201cSwimming to Cambodia\u201d screening will feature a discussion with Laurie Anderson.\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u2018LUMUMBA\u2019 at Spectacle (Feb. 20 and 28). As preparation for \u201cThe Young Karl Marx,\u201d a new biopic from the director Raoul Peck (\u201cI Am Not Your Negro\u201d) that opens on Feb. 23, Spectacle is screening his acclaimed, engrossing feature about Patrice Lumumba (played by Eriq Ebouaney), the first democratically elected leader of what is now the Democratic Republic of Congo, who was assassinated in 1961. \u201cIt\u2019s a flat-out thrill to see a movie about African politics that doesn\u2019t condescend to audiences by placing a sympathetic white African at the center,\u201d Elvis Mitchell wrote in his review of the film for The New York Times in 2001.\n\nspectacletheater.com\n\nST. CLAIR BOURNE at the Metrograph (Feb. 16-19). A documentarian known for his multifaceted, politically conscious studies of black American life, St. Clair Bourne (1943-2007) made portraits of Paul Robeson (Friday and Saturday), Amiri Baraka (Saturday and Monday) and Langston Hughes (Sunday and Monday) and a chronicle of the filming of \u201cDo the Right Thing\u201d (Friday, Saturday and Monday). One of his most provocative documentaries is among the most difficult to see: In \u201cThe Black and the Green\u201d (Friday), shown in 1983, Mr. Bourne follows black American activists to Northern Ireland, where they meet with Catholic separatists and discover commonalities and differences. The film includes riveting talk about the nature of violence and the rights of individual groups to set the terms of their own protests.\n\n212-660-0312, metrograph.com", "title": "4 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.\n\nATHENA FILM FESTIVAL at Barnard College (through Feb. 25). Named for the goddess of wisdom, this weekend-long film festival is devoted to movies in which women are the driving narrative force. The lineup features several films from the past year, including \u201cLady Bird\u201d and \u201cPatti Cake$\u201d (both Friday); \u201cBombshell: The Hedy Lamarr Story\u201d (Saturday), which remembers the actress\u2019s contribution to a communication system during World War II; and the New York premiere of \u201cI Am Not a Witch\u201d (Saturday), which won praise last spring at Directors\u2019 Fortnight, a festival that runs parallel to the main Cannes Film Festival slate.\n\nathenafilmfestival.com\n\nFILM COMMENT SELECTS at the Film Society of Lincoln Center (Feb. 23-27). The staff members of Film Comment magazine (whose editor in chief, Nicolas Rapold, has contributed to The New York Times) share some of their below-the-radar favorites from the festival circuit and elsewhere. The program opens on Friday with \u201cLife and Nothing More,\u201d the story of an African-American teenager and his single mother that unfolds with documentarylike immediacy. Other titles are \u201cGutland\u201d (Saturday), a sedate sort-of noir about a German thief (Frederick Lau) who crosses the border to hide from police and falls into the arms of a local played by Vicky Krieps (\u201cPhantom Thread\u201d), and \u201cSarah Plays a Werewolf\u201d (Sunday), about a high school actress who begins to mix fiction and reality in her own life. The revivals include a retrospective of the confrontational cinema of Nico Papatakis and a 25th-anniversary screening of \u201cSilverlake Life: The View From Here\u201d (Sunday), a landmark AIDS documentary that influenced the recent \u201cBPM.\u201d\n\n212-875-5601, filmlinc.org\n\n\u2018PHANTOM THREAD\u2019 WITH LIVE SCORE at BAM Howard Gilman Opera House (Feb. 24-25). Purists beware. All Radiohead fans, do not miss? The latest entry in Paul Thomas Anderson\u2019s gallery of impossible men (\u201cPunch-Drunk Love,\u201d \u201cThere Will Be Blood\u201d and \u201cThe Master\u201d), starring Daniel Day-Lewis as an intransigent fashion designer and Vicky Krieps as the muse who finally gets him to bend, will screen with Jonny Greenwood\u2019s Oscar-nominated score performed live by the Wordless Music Orchestra and members of the London Contemporary Orchestra, which played a similar event across the pond last month. Your ears will be dazzled, your eyes maybe less so. Note that for technical reasons, the movie will screen in HDCAM, which has a lower resolution than conventional digital projection.\n\n718-636-4100, bam.org\n\n\u2018SEE IT BIG! BEST CINEMATOGRAPHY IN BLACK AND WHITE AND COLOR\u2019 at the Museum of the Moving Image (Feb. 24-March 11). Given the degree to which digital postproduction has blurred the line between cinematography and special effects, it may be time for the Academy to create a new Oscar. Call it Best Visual Design? Such a move wouldn\u2019t be unprecedented. For years, the Academy gave two cinematography Oscars, one for black-and-white and one for color. This series puts some of the winners head-to-head: The Technicolor \u201cGone With the Wind\u201d and the black-and-white \u201cWuthering Heights,\u201d which both won in 1940, each screen on Saturday and Sunday. \u201cBlack Narcissus\u201d and \u201cGreat Expectations,\u201d the winners in 1948, show the following weekend.\n\n718-784-0077, movingimage.us", "title": "4 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "2. How They Make Money: \u201cFrom a consumer\u2019s standpoint, it\u2019s important to understand what the monetization model is for the company that makes these apps,\u201d added Kowsik Guruswamy, chief technology officer at Menlo Security. \u201cThat alone can be very revealing in how the companies plan to use their data.\u201d For example, an app might make money through sponsorships with the brands it partners with or it might offer customers paid upgrades. However, it\u2019s also likely it makes money selling your data to advertisers or other third parties, which is why it\u2019s important to note what kind of data it tracks and how it uses it.\n\n3. What Other Users Have to Say: Beyond reading the fine print, you can also research the app\u2019s reputation via online reviews. Pay special attention to reviews that address privacy issues. \u201cWhile many apps offer legitimate means to make money \u2014 taking surveys, snapping photos of local businesses, lock screen ads and reviewing products \u2014 be wary of apps that seem too good to be true,\u201d Mr. Bischoff said. \u201cSometimes an app combines a legitimate cash-for-task model with background data collection, so watch out for that, too.\u201d\n\nMoneymaking Apps That Make the Grade\n\nWe looked at dozens of apps that promise to help you make money from the comfort of your smartphone, and most of them aren\u2019t worth your time. Some, however, do what they promise, even if the trade-off is a good bit of your personal data.\n\nIf you\u2019re willing to trade, the following (free) apps are well established and can legitimately help you earn cash back. No, you won\u2019t fund your retirement or put a down payment on your home, but you can earn a few bucks to pay for your latte \u2014 or dare we suggest avocado toast?\n\nIf you don\u2019t mind searching the web, answering surveys or watching videos, you can earn a few \u201cSwagbucks,\u201d which you can then trade in for gift cards at places like Amazon, Starbucks and Home Depot.\n\n\u201cI typically cash out the Swagbucks for gift cards that I use on Amazon to buy household goods,\u201d said Cherie Lowe, a personal finance writer and author of the book \u201cSlaying the Debt Dragon.\u201d Ms. Lowe has used the app for nearly eight years, earning around $3,000 worth of gift cards over all. \u201cI did save up enough to get $600 to put toward a laptop at the Apple store at one point in time,\u201d she added.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYou can earn one Swagbuck for every dollar you spend at certain online retailers, too. According to the Swagbucks website, this is the equivalent of earning 1 percent cash back. With online surveys, you typically earn 40 to 200 Swagbucks (100 Swagbucks = $1), according to the site. You can also earn a few Swagbucks for watching videos, and the app will tell you how long you can expect to spend watching. You\u2019ll spend about half an hour and earn a few points.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen it comes to privacy, Mr. Guruswamy says apps like Swagbucks often use cookies to track your information. \u201cSo by using Swagbucks, not only is the user giving away a lot of their personal information, they are also opening themselves to being monitored and tracked by all of the Swagbucks affiliates,\u201d he said. \u201cThe bottom line is that you have to read the fine print.\u201d Swagbucks is available in the U.S., U.K., Ireland, Canada, and Australia. You can check out the privacy policy here.\n\nShopkick rewards you for shopping at stores you probably visit anyway: CVS, Marshalls and Best Buy are a few of its partner retailers.\n\n\u201cShopkick I primarily use in Target,\u201d Ms. Lowe said. \u201cBecause why not get rewarded when you\u2019re there? I like that you can cash out your rewards at as little as $2 in gift cards, too. Every little bit helps. I typically stockpile and cash out around Christmas to supplement our budget.\u201d\n\nOnce you download the app, you earn points, or \u201ckicks,\u201d every time you spend at partner retailers. You can earn kicks without spending, too, by checking into stores or scanning certain items. While you won\u2019t get cash back directly, you can trade the points for gift cards to dozens of partner retailers. In short, Shopkick essentially works like any other rewards shopping site except there\u2019s no need to hop through a portal to earn your points. Just spend with your card as you normally would.\n\nOf course, you have to link your credit or debit card to earn points with your spending, so if you\u2019re worried about your privacy with this app, keep that in mind. With so many data breaches lately, you might be apprehensive to connect your card to the app. While it does collect data about your transactions (which is necessary to automatically earn \u201ckicks\u201d), it doesn\u2019t store your actual credit card information. \u201cIf a user has a linked credit or debit card associated with his or her Shopkick account, that information solely and securely remains with Visa or Mastercard,\u201d said Bill Demas, the app\u2019s chief executive officer. Read the privacy policy here. Shopkick is U.S. only.\n\nIbotta is a couponing app, but instead of getting a discount on your purchases, you get cash-back rebates. You check the app for offers \u2014 $1 cash back on a pizza brand, for example \u2014 and then either scan your receipt or link the app to your store loyalty cards so your savings are automatic. Ibotta accepts receipts only from participating stores and retailers, but most of the big players are listed: Whole Foods, Walmart, Ralph\u2019s, Kroger, HEB. Some offers will apply to only one retailer; others might be valid at several.\n\n\u201cI use Ibotta regularly and have made $253 so far,\u201d said Jessica Landon, an avid Ibotta user who\u2019s been using the app for about a year and a half. \u201cI usually look up offers before I head in the store, then upload and scan the products right when I get in my car so I don\u2019t forget.\u201d She said staples like produce usually earned only about 25 cents cash back, but it can add up. \u201cBuying beer for my husband usually gets me larger amounts. Diapers is another item that can earn you cash back faster.\u201d\n\nIn its privacy policy, Ibotta is clear about the information it collects, which includes your contact information, search queries, transaction information and location, and why it collects it. Ibotta also places cookies on your device to \u201crecognize you when you return, and track and target your interests in order to provide a customized experience,\u201d according to the privacy policy. The app is available to residents of the U.S. and Puerto Rico only.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith UserTesting, you get paid to offer feedback on a website. The pay is $10 per test, and it involves visiting a website, completing some tasks, then recording your feedback about the user experience. While you\u2019re visiting the app, UserTesting uses software to record your mouse movements, clicks and your voice. The tasks take about 10 to 20 minutes to complete.\n\nTo use the software, you will need an internet connection and a microphone and to be able to download their testing software. If you want to take mobile tests, you\u2019ll need an iPhone, an iPad, an Android phone or an Android tablet. You\u2019re paid via PayPal, which means you can live and use the service to make money as long as you live in a country where PayPal works.\n\nPrivacy-wise, you want to be extra careful with apps that track your behavior in this way. Of course, UserTesting needs to track your experience, as that\u2019s the entire point of the service.\n\nAccording to its privacy policy, when you participate in a test, the app will \u201ccapture video or photographic recordings of your face, audio recordings of your voice, screen recordings of your actions on the device on which you downloaded the Screen Recorder, and video or audio recordings of any other sights or sounds that are captured by your device camera or microphone during a Usability Test.\u201d To protect the data you share, they use SSL technology to encrypt your information.", "title": "4 Free Apps That Can Earn You Extra Cash", "authors": ["Kristin Wong"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Tensions have been building for months between Israel and Hamas, the Islamic militant group that rules Gaza, as a humanitarian crisis intensifies in the cramped coastal enclave of two million Palestinians.\n\nAlready beleaguered by Israel\u2019s decade-old blockade of the strip, Gazans were made to suffer even more last year when the Palestinian Authority, run by Fatah, imposed harsh new restrictions in a power struggle with Hamas, its archrival. An attempt at reconciliation between the two last fall has since bogged down, and a standoff over salaries and revenue has sent the territory\u2019s economy into free-fall, with many expecting a war with Israel as a result.\n\nColonel Conricus said the Israeli soldiers, whose injuries were not life-threatening, were hurt as they inspected a Palestinian flag that had been placed along the Gaza-Israel fence Friday morning amid a chaotic riot of hundreds of protesters, who were throwing rocks and trying to tear down the fence \u2014 and who were also obscured from view by a morning fog.\n\nHe said the episode showed that Israel was right to treat protests at the Gaza fence as a military threat.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been speaking about these staged riots for a long time,\u201d unarmed, they\u2019re rioters \u2014 and among the rioters are actual terrorist operatives who have other things in mind.\u201d\n\nMr. Netanyahu, who wished the wounded soldiers a speedy recovery from Munich, where he was attending a security conference, also responded angrily to remarks by the prime minister of Poland, Mateusz Morawiecki, after he stirred new controversy in defending a Polish law their cash to work in the economy \u2014 for example, by buying corporate stocks and bonds. The theory is that the fresh flood of money would make it easier for companies to raise capital, invest in their businesses and hire workers.\n\nThat strategy, in many ways, paid off. For the first time since the financial crisis of 2008, the world\u2019s largest economies are growing in unison.\n\nAsk A Question News about the stock market can be confusing. Thank you for your submission.\n\nBut what\u2019s good for the economy isn\u2019t always good for the markets.\n\nCentral banks, led by the United States Federal Reserve, have started to remove some of the supports that helped supercharge stock prices over the last decade.\n\nThe Fed started raising rates two years ago. With rates going up, money is not as cheap. The robust jobs report last week fueled hopes that wage growth would follow. But higher wages could lead to higher inflation, creating new challenges for the Fed to manage, perhaps prompting it to raise rates more quickly.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDespite the drops, there have been far blacker Mondays\n\nMeasured by points, Monday\u2019s drop was the largest on record for the Dow and the S.&P. 500.\n\nThe previous biggest point declines for the two indexes occurred on Sept. 29, 2008, at the height of the financial crisis.\n\nWeeks after Lehman Brothers failed in September 2008, lawmakers in the House of Representatives rejected a $700 billion economic rescue plan. The move sent markets tumbling.\n\nBut over the past three-plus decades, investors have endured a number of bigger percentage drops in the stock market.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe S.&P. fell 8.81 percent that day in 2008. That was more than twice as much as Monday\u2019s fall.\n\nKeep one important idea in mind: Take the long view\n\nThe way we sometimes think \u2014 and the news media talks \u2014 about markets can make sell-offs like Monday\u2019s seem more dramatic than they are.\n\nOur perceptions are distorted, in part, by thinking about swings in terms of points rather than in terms of percentages. The problem with that thinking is that our idea of big point moves was most likely shaped when the Dow was much smaller \u2014 and a drop in several hundred points would have made up a greater share of the average than it does today.\n\nThis recent decline so far has returned the market roughly to its level in mid-December, less than two months ago. That doesn\u2019t mean markets won\u2019t keep dropping, as they are wont to do. But it may not be time to sell.", "title": "4 Takeaways From Monday\u2019s Stock Market Sell-Off", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI never sell the entire production,\u201d Mr. Duiveman explained. \u201cWe always keep all the principals. If I have 40 chorus members, I sell 30 and save 10. Anything that might be useful for a future exhibition \u2014 something from a famous singer, or a world premiere, or something that has a special material \u2014 those things I will keep. We build up our archive, but at some point we just have to say goodbye to some of them.\u201d\n\nKnown for commissioning interesting, postmodern new work with collaborators such as the artists Anish Kapoor and William Kentridge and the director Peter Sellars, and with a history of both starkly minimalist and classical productions, the Dutch National Opera has an in-house department that builds hundreds of costumes a year.\n\nThe costume sales are incredibly popular \u2014 the 2,000 available tickets for this one sold out online in 37 minutes. Often shaped as triangles, they can also be oblong. At Yotel, they\u2019re now featured to go at the Espresso Bar and are served in the Green Fig restaurant, both on the fourth floor. Sami Boztepe, Green Fig\u2019s new pastry chef and a native of Turkey who lived in Israel, is fashioning shatteringly flaky long bourekas. Think ministrudels filled with potato, mushroom, cheese, or spinach and cheese. Serve them as is or slice them to accompany drinks: Bourekas, $4.95 each, Green Fig, fourth floor, 570 10th Avenue (42nd Street), 646-449-7790, greenfignyc.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Wirecutter suggests three different knives for the average cook: chef\u2019s knife, paring knife and serrated knife. The chef\u2019s knife I registered for was Wirecutter\u2019s pick for most cooks, the Mac MTH-80. It\u2019s on the higher end of cheapish, so if you\u2019re looking to save a few dollars, Wirecutter\u2019s budget knife pick is the W\u00fcsthof Pro 4862-7/20. For a serrated bread knife, Wirecutter recommends the Victorinox Fibrox Pro 10\u00bc-Inch Serrated Curved Bread Knife, and for a paring knife its favorite is the Victorinox 3\u00bc-Inch Paring Knife.\n\nCutting Board\n\nYou need a good cutting board to go with that knife. It exists to help you learn.\n\nA Doctor\u2019s Guide to a Good Appointment Going to the doctor is part of staying healthy (the other major parts are what you eat and how much you exercise). Here\u2019s what you need to know about this year\u2019s events.", "title": "5 Cheap(ish) Things to Put on Any Gift Registry (Or Just Buy as Gifts)", "authors": ["Erin Seims"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Belated recognition came when Mel Brooks was nominated for best adapted screenplay for his 1974 spoof \u201cYoung Frankenstein,\u201d and Ian McKellen competed for best actor for his sly performance as Mr. Whale in the 1998 biopic \u201cGods and Monsters.\u201d\n\n\u2018Psycho\u2019 (1960): Four nominations, no wins\n\nShockingly, Alfred Hitchcock never won a best director award. Although he was awarded an honorary Oscar in 1968, he was nominated for this mother of a creepfest. He lost to Billy Wilder for \u201cThe Apartment,\u201d which also beat \u201cPsycho\u201d for best black and white art direction.\n\nJanet Leigh was in the hunt for best supporting actress, but perhaps because her part was cut so short, she was passed over in favor of Shirley Jones in \u201cElmer Gantry.\u201d That film\u2019s lead, Burt Lancaster, took home the best actor prize for his portrayal of the titular charlatan. Despite his daring, gender-fluid turn as Norman Bates, Anthony Perkins wasn\u2019t among the finalists.\n\nJohn L. Russell\u2019s brilliant cinematography was recognized but judged inferior to Freddie Francis\u2019 work in \u201cSons and Lovers.\u201d Most horrifying: Bernard Herrmann\u2019s slashing score wasn\u2019t considered sharp enough to earn a nomination.\n\n\u201cRosemary\u2019s Baby\u201d (1968): Two nominations, one win\n\nMaybe the devil made them do it? The Academy snubbed this satanic satire from Roman Polanski, choosing not to nominate it for best picture or director, both of which were won by Carol Reed\u2019s more upbeat \u201cOliver!\u201d\n\nMia Farrow\u2019s affecting, tremulous work as the mother of the devil\u2019s spawn was left out of the best actress race, which ended in a tie between Barbra Streisand for \u201cFunny Girl\u201d and Katharine Hepburn for \u201cThe Lion in Winter.\u201d That royal saga\u2019s screenplay, by James Goldman, bested Mr. Polanski\u2019s adaptation of Ira Levin\u2019s novel.\n\n\u201cRosemary\u2019s Baby\u201d found favor only in the best supporting actress category, where 72-year-old Ruth Gordon snagged the prize for her hysterical portrayal of a buttinsky neighbor who leads a coven of Upper West Side witches. The opening line of Ms. Gordon\u2019s acceptance speech, \u201cI can\u2019t tell you how encouraging a thing like this is,\u201d brought down the house.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Exorcist\u201d (1973): 10 nominations, two wins\n\nIt\u2019s enough to make your head spin. What could have possessed the Academy to spurn the director William Friedkin\u2019s terrifying tale of a pea soup-spewing little girl played by Linda Blair in favor of George Roy Hill\u2019s con-men comedy, \u201cThe Sting,\u201d for best picture, director, art direction and editing?\n\nWilliam Peter Blatty did win for adapting his own novel into a screenplay, but he didn\u2019t have to compete with \u201cThe Sting,\u201d which fell into the original screenplay category. Ms. Blair lost best supporting actress to a less demonic youngster, Tatum O\u2019Neal, for \u201cPaper Moon,\u201d while Ellen Burstyn, who played Ms. Blair\u2019s mother, was defeated for best actress by Glenda Jackson for \u201cA Touch of Class.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Exorcist\u201d did win for best sound, and I can offer personal testimony as to its effectiveness. I was too young to see the movie while it was in theaters, but when I was in junior high school, I tried to watch it on HBO \u2014 except my family didn\u2019t subscribe to the channel, so I could see only scrambled images. Still, the sound alone scared the bejesus out of me \u2014 to the point where I never watched the film until I was assigned this story. The horror, the horror!\n\nThe Shining (1980): No nominations\n\nWhere was Johnny \u2014 er, Jack \u2014 on Oscar night when Stanley Kubrick\u2019s loose interpretation of Stephen King\u2019s haunted-hotel novel was eligible? Nowhere to be seen.\n\nThe ceremony was dominated by \u201cOrdinary People,\u201d which won best picture, a best director award for Robert Redford, best adapted screenplay and best supporting actor for Timothy Hutton. Robert De Niro knocked out voters for best actor in \u201cRaging Bull\u201d and Thelma Schoonmaker won for best editing. The Academy dug Sissy Spacek\u2019s take on Loretta Lynn in \u201cCoal Miner\u2019s Daughter\u201d for best actress. Mr. Polanski\u2019s version of Thomas Hardy\u2019s \u201cTess\u201d cleaned up in the categories of cinematography, art direction and costume design.\n\n\u201cThe Shining\u201d did earn the dubious distinction of garnering two Razzie nominations: Shelley Duvall for worst actress and Mr. Kubrick for worst director. It\u2019s almost enough to make you want to commit redrum.", "title": "5 Classic Horror Films That Didn\u2019t Get Much Oscars Acclaim", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\n\u2018EVERYTHING IS FALLING APART\u2019 at QED Astoria (Feb. 22, 7:30 p.m.). The name of this event divulges its underlying premise, which is that once a month its host, Molly McGaughey, interviews a guest over a game of Jenga, wherein the guest answers questions that are written on the blocks. When the Jenga tower falls, though, that signals the end of the interview. This time the delightfully deprecating comedian Aparna Nancherla plays the game, while Melissa Diaz, Chanel Ali and Savannah DesOrmeaux provide stand-up and storytelling.\n\n347-451-3873, qedastoria.com\n\nNORE DAVIS \u2018TOO WOKE!\u2019 ALBUM RECORDING at Union Hall (Feb. 16, 8 and 10 p.m.). The comedian Nore Davis, whose credits include such shows as \u201cBoardwalk Empire,\u201d \u201cLuke Cage,\u201d \u201cInside Amy Schumer\u201d and Jerry Seinfeld\u2019s \u201cComedians in Cars Getting Coffee,\u201d excels in the space between toeing the line and delivering a clean set. During this performance, he\u2019ll be recording the follow-up to his 2015 album, \u201cAway Game,\u201d joined by the witty and insightful comedian Aminah Imani.\n\n718-638-4400, unionhallny.com\n\nDEMETRI MARTIN at the Bell House (Feb. 22, 7:30 and 10 p.m.). The comedian Demetri Martin is a thrill to try to keep up with. His razor-sharp wit moves at the speed of light: By the time one joke sinks in, he\u2019s already onto the next. His pure talent truly shines when he reframes the ordinary, everyday objects or occurrences that most of us take for granted in a new, hilarious light. He\u2019s also very good with flip charts.\n\n718-643-6510, thebellhouseny.com\n\nRAISE THE ROOF AND HELP SYRIAN CHILDREN at the Bell House (Feb. 20, 8 p.m.). This benefit is the antidote to the predictable silent auctions or the unexciting musical performances from the local grade school choir (no offense, kids). Featuring a fantastic lineup of comedians like Phoebe Robinson, Todd Barry, Chris Gethard, Aparna Nancherla and Michelle Buteau, and hosted by the easygoing and amiable Maeve Higgins, this event will raise money for the nonprofit Inara, which provides medical care to children who are unable to access it because of war.\n\n718-643-6510, thebellhouseny.com\n\n\u2018THE UNEMPLOYED SHOW\u2019 at Littlefield (Feb. 18, 8 p.m.). Following a three-month residency at MoMA\u2019s Queens campus, choreographer Kim Brandt presents \u201cProblems,\u201d a kind of human sculpture in motion that takes place under the museum\u2019s white geodesic VW Dome. In recent years, Ms. Brandt has been working with larger ensembles. Here, 16 dancers repeatedly come together and separate to pursue their own physical tasks, putting into motion Ms. Brandt\u2019s interest in the relationship between the individual and the collective and how that shifting dynamic affects the surrounding environment.\n\n718-784-2084, momaps1.org\n\nBEBE MILLER AND SUSAN RETHORST at New York Live Arts (Feb. 21-24 at 7:30 p.m.). The elusive art of making a dance is the central theme of this double-bill program, featuring new works from the veteran dance makers Bebe Miller and Susan Rethorst. \u201cIn a Rhythm,\u201d by Ms. Miller, takes inspiration from authors like Gertrude Stein and Toni Morrison and uses text, music and gesture to explore how structure breeds meaning. In \u201cStealing From Myself,\u201d Ms. Rethorst revisits 30 years of her own work and borrows from those moves and memories to create a fresh duet for Gabrielle Revlock and Gregory Holt.\n\n212-924-0077, newyorklivearts.org", "title": "5 Dance Performances to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Sitting comfortably in my living room, I had every intention of listening to the boxed set that had recently landed with a thud in my mailbox. For Bach lovers, Glenn Gould fans and pianists (I\u2019m all three), here was perhaps the ultimate find of recording history, finally available: the nearly five hours of Gould\u2019s complete recording sessions for his momentous debut album, Bach\u2019s \u201cGoldberg\u201d Variations.\u201d\n\nBut I couldn\u2019t make it through, not even close. Let me explain.\n\nIn four intense sessions in a Manhattan studio in June 1955, the 22-year-old Gould recorded his breathless, uncannily clear account of the \u201cGoldbergs.\u201d The release turned what had previously been considered a lengthy piece for harpsichord, of interest only to Bach specialists, into a runaway hit. It also made the gangly, eccentric Gould an unlikely classical superstar.\n\nThe tapes of those sessions were stored for years in the archives of Columbia Records, now Sony Classical. But in a 2004 interview, the recording\u2019s producer, Howard H. Scott, said it would be a \u201cdisgrace\u201d to make them public.", "title": "5 Hours of Glenn Gould Outtakes. Why? Listen and Find Out.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "London\n\nMaddie Williams\n\nMaddie Williams, at just 22, is already making her debut at London Fashion Week this season. Fashion Scout, the international platform that nurtures and showcases young designers, invited Williams to be part of its fall/winter 2018 \u201cOnes to Watch\u201d runway show in London. \u201cCurrently, my brand is just me on a sewing machine in my parents\u2019 front room,\u201d says Williams, who recently interned with Vivienne Westwood. For inspiration, she imagined a group of goddess-like figures whose purpose is to fight the capitalist patriarchy. \u201cI hope the feeling will be almost warrior-esque,\u201d she told T. Accordingly, her garments are designed to celebrate women\u2019s bodies. \u201cWhy should women broaden their shoulders like men to feel powerful? Why not do the opposite?\u201d she asks. Her fall/winter 2018 collection, an expansion of her graduate collection, is defined by exaggerated silhouettes and intensely textured, handcrafted textiles, which are made of mostly renewable or repurposed materials such as plastic bags. \u201cI want my work to show that eco-fashion can still be visually exciting and push concepts and ideas beyond the fact of its sustainable ethos,\u201d she says.", "title": "5 New Designers to Watch This Season", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "TEHRAN \u2014 Three Iranian police officers and two paramilitary troops were killed overnight during clashes with members of a Sufi Islam order in Tehran, Iranian news outlets reported on Tuesday, the most casualties the security forces have suffered in one evening since the height of antigovernment demonstrations in 2009.\n\nState news media reported that the police arrested more than 300 protesters, most of them members of the Gonabadi dervishes, a mystical Sufi strain of Islam that the clerical government has designated a challenge to mainstream Shiite theology.\n\nThe confrontation started Monday night when the dervishes, recognizable by the thick mustaches they wear by religious decree, gathered in front of a police station to demand the release of some members who had been arrested. Violence broke out when security officers arrived.\n\nPhotographs posted on social media showed several dervishes who had been severely beaten, though the authenticity of the images could not be independently verified. The clashes were also captured on a murky video spread on social media and broadcast by the semiofficial Fars news agency, which has links to the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps.", "title": "5 Security Officers in Iran Killed in Clashes with Dervishes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "February is always a quiet month on Broadway, but this year, it\u2019s totally dead. Nothing is scheduled to open there until mid-March, when the deluge of award-seekers \u2014 15 shows in six weeks \u2014 begins.\n\nThat lull is good news for Off Broadway, allowing the most unusual new works a chance to get attention. The Republican memo said it formed \u201can essential part\u201d of the application, and in a separate memo, Senators Charles E. Grassley and Lindsey Graham, Republicans of Iowa and South Carolina, stated that \u201cthe bulk\u201d of the application was Mr. Steele\u2019s information.\n\nThe Democratic memo also says that what the F.B.I. did use from Mr. Steele did not include the salacious parts of his dossier. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNotably, the Democratic memo also said that in subsequent renewals of the wiretap application, the Justice Department \u201cprovided additional information obtained through multiple independent sources that corroborated Steele\u2019s reporting.\u201d\n\nThe surveillance court knew that Mr. Steele\u2019s clients had a political motive.\n\nThe Republican memo complained that the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court was not told that the Clinton campaign and the D.N.C. had financed Mr. Steele\u2019s research, suggesting that the judges were misled about the credibility of his information. Democrats have called that claim misleading because the judges were told of a political motive, just without specific names.\n\nThe Democratic memo provides a verbatim excerpt from the application, which stated that the F.B.I. believed that Mr. Steele had been commissioned by someone \u201clikely looking for information that could be used to discredit Candidate #1\u2019s campaign,\u201d referring to Mr. Trump.\n\nThe Yahoo News article was not used to corroborate Mr. Steele.\n\nThe wiretap application included a Yahoo News article from September 2016 that discussed the investigation into Mr. Page\u2019s Russian ties. The Republican memo portrayed the application as having improperly used that article as corroboration of Mr. Steele\u2019s claims, even though it later emerged \u2014 in a spring 2017 court filing \u2014 that Mr. Steele had been a source for it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Democratic memo calls that a false claim by the Republicans. Instead, it says, the Justice Department referred to the Yahoo News article \u2014 as well as another one the Republican memo failed to mention \u2014 \u201cnot to provide separate corroboration for Steele\u2019s reporting, but instead to inform the court of Page\u2019s public denial of his suspected meetings in Moscow.\u201d\n\nRepublican-appointed judges approved the surveillance of Mr. Page.\n\nThe Republican memo portrayed the wiretapping of Mr. Page as a partisan conspiracy. Notably, the Democratic memo reveals that all four judges on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court who approved the initial surveillance \u2014 which began in October 2016 \u2014 as well as three 90-day renewals were appointed by Republican presidents.\n\nTo approve such a wiretap of an American, a judge must decide that there is sufficient evidence that the target is probably an agent of a foreign power, or knowingly aiding foreign agents.\n\nThe wiretap of Mr. Page generated useful intelligence.\n\nWhen the Justice Department repeatedly sought the court\u2019s permission to renew the surveillance of Mr. Page, the Democratic memo said, it cited new information it was gathering through the wiretap.\n\n\u201cThe court-approved surveillance of Page allowed F.B.I. to collect valuable intelligence,\u201d the Democratic memo said. It asserted that the repeated renewals \u201cdemonstrate that the F.B.I. collected important investigative information and leads by conducting court-approved surveillance.\u201d\n\nWhat that intelligence was, however, was redacted.", "title": "5 Takeaways From the Release of the Democratic Memo", "authors": ["Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "A Beloved Label\u2019s New West Coast Store \u2014 and Flower Shop\n\nWhen Mansur Gavriel presented its spring 2018 apparel collection during New York Fashion Week, the jaunty see-now-buy-now lineup of summery colors and easy silhouettes transported a rain-soaked audience to sunny California.\n\nHow fitting, then, that the label\u2019s founders, Rachel Mansur and Floriana Gavriel, have opened their third store (and their first outside of New York City) in Los Angeles this week, where the brand\u2019s cultish, coveted leather bags and shoes currently sit alongside that breezy new collection.\n\nThe sprawling, blush-toned, 5,000-square-foot space on Melrose Place doesn\u2019t stop at ready-to-wear. True to the label\u2019s affinity for flowers (documented in the brand\u2019s very own photography book, aptly titled \u201cLA Flower Market\u201d), there\u2019s a floral shop on site, as well as an outdoor garden and an adjoining eatery: Caf\u00e9 Flora, which serves up pastries, salads and light pastas.\n\nIn keeping with the brand\u2019s expansion further into the lifestyle category, there\u2019s also a marketplace stocked with handpicked goods from Gavriel\u2019s and Mansur\u2019s travels: craftsy-chic woven place mats and baskets made from locally harvested papyrus in England, as well as a signature label of hand-pressed Corsican olive oil. \u201cIt is harvested by hand by the family of one of our MG team members, so it\u2019s very special to us,\u201d says Mansur. 8475 Melrose Place, Los Angeles, (323) 591-0434 \u2014 LAURA NEILSON", "title": "5 Things T Editors Like Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Don\u2019t fret. Here are five tips from professionals that could help ensure that a volatile ride doesn\u2019t derail your financial planning.\n\nPick individual winners. With wild swings in the markets, active investment managers \u2014 those who buy and sell individual stocks instead of allocating money to an investment fund that tracks an index \u2014 say their skills are more in need now.\n\nThey argue that stocks are going to begin to show differences and that their skills at stock selection will keep investors\u2019 portfolios from being dragged down with an entire index. In other words, in a market where everything isn\u2019t going up, selecting the best individual companies makes more sense.\n\nFrancisco Bido, the head of quantitative research and a portfolio manager at Cognios Capital, said he had reduced the number of stocks he invested in after the recent volatility. The move came out of conviction, not fear, he said.\n\n\u201cA lot of those big passive vehicles out there buy so many stocks because they have a mandate to track an index,\u201d he said. \u201cI think it helps to be a bit more concentrated. It allows investors to find a different avenue.\u201d\n\nHis strategy is also an argument to know what you own. That\u2019s good advice in any market.\n\nBut an indexing behemoth like Vanguard says that is an overused argument. Nearly 90 percent of active managers have underperformed the indexes they track, Mr. Kinniry said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not an active versus index story,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s high cost versus low cost. They underperform because they\u2019re charging too much for the \u2018alpha\u2019 they generate,\u201d he added, referring to the return in excess of the market return.", "title": "5 Tips to Weather a Turbulent Stock Market", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Six educators were killed this week in the Central African Republic, Unicef said on Wednesday, the latest of several attacks on aid workers as that fragmented and war-torn nation slides deeper into chaos.\n\nThe attack occurred near Markounda, a small town in the northwest, near the border with Chad \u2014 a remote part of a sparsely populated country that is sometimes described as the least developed in the world. Like most of the nation, the area is beyond the control of the central government in the capital, Bangui, and power is wielded instead by an array of militias that often fight one another.\n\nLast August, six Red Cross volunteers were killed in the southeastern part of the country, and there have been other acts of violence against aid workers since then. Days after the August attack, the United Nations warned of rapidly escalating violence and a worsening humanitarian crisis in the Central African Republic.\n\nEven the most intrepid aid groups have reconsidered whether it is safe to work in the country. In November, Doctors Without Borders shut down a major operation after a string of attacks and threats.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnicef, the United Nations Children\u2019s Fund, said the latest victims were attacked on Sunday while traveling to Markounda, where about 7,000 people have taken refuge from the fighting, to establish a program to train teachers who would, in turn, teach refugee children. It identified the dead, all Central African Republic nationals, as a Unicef education consultant, two officials from the central government\u2019s Ministry of Education, and three members of a local group that works with Unicef, Bangui Sans Fronti\u00e8res.", "title": "6 Aid Workers Killed Amid Chaos in Central African Republic", "authors": ["Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Morikami Museum and Japanese Gardens\n\nThe land for Delray Beach\u2019s Morikami Garden was the gift of the Japanese immigrant George Morikami, a successful farmer who in the mid-1970s donated 200 acres to Palm Beach County. That land now features six discrete gardens created by the designer Hoichu Kurisu, whose credits include the Anderson Japanese Gardens in Rockford, Ill. His vision in Florida was inspired by gardens in Japan; each of Morikami\u2019s six gardens reflects a style from a different epoch, beginning with the 9th century.\n\nIn Mr. Kurisu\u2019s words, which are featured on the park\u2019s website, the intention is for visitors \u201cto lay aside the chaos of a troubled world.\u201d He has accomplished that with the use of small lakes and paths that wind among pine forests, bamboo groves and rock arrangements throughout the gardens.\n\nThe gardens at Morikami are informed as much by religion as by plant life.\n\nWith its two landscaped islands joined by a bridge, Morikami\u2019s Shinden Garden was inspired by the gardens that were adapted for the estates of Japanese nobles from Chinese garden design. The Shinden style was popular from the 9th to the 12th century.\n\nThe park\u2019s Paradise Garden has paths for strolling the perimeters of its two small lakes in a style that recalls gardens that appealed to the new Samurai class of the 13th century.", "title": "6 Great Gardens to Visit in Florida", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "A heavily armed young man opened fire on terrified students and teachers at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., on Wednesday, leaving a death toll of 17.\n\nIt is the third mass shooting in the past four months in the United States.\n\nThis pattern has led to a familiar cycle of mourning, introspection and questioning about what can be done to end the violence. Below is a selection of six stories The Times has previously reported around these shootings that give context to this latest tragedy and best inform conversations about the trends in gun violence and potential gun policy considerations.", "title": "6 Stories and Charts to Help You Better Understand Gun Violence in the U.S.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "LUNAR NEW YEAR FESTIVAL: YEAR OF THE DOG at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (Feb. 24, 11 a.m.-5 p.m.). Can you smell as well as a dog? It will probably also help to have a nose for art at this festival, where the family attractions will include a scent tour of the Met\u2019s galleries in honor of this zodiac animal\u2019s keen olfactory sense. Children can also learn about service dog etiquette with representatives from the Guide Dog Foundation, hear Asian music performances and take part in a wide variety of activities, including making Indonesian shadow puppets, attending a Wu-Wo tea ceremony, listening to bilingual stories and joining in a hand-pulled noodle demonstration.\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\nNEW YORK WILD FILM FESTIVAL FAMILY PROGRAM at the Explorers Club (Feb. 25, noon-4 p.m.). It\u2019s hard to disappear into the wild when you\u2019re in Manhattan. But this weekend will offer an opportunity, and it\u2019s even indoors. The New York Wild Film Festival will hold its first family program for children 8 and older. The eight films will spotlight creatures ranging from the small, cartoonishly cute burrowing owl, which shows off some funky moves in \u201cOwl Dance-Off Part 2,\u201d to the gawky yet graceful giraffe, the object of a Ugandan rescue mission in \u201cGiraffes: Gentle Giants.\u201d The subjects also include interesting human beings: \u201cBreak on Through\u201d focuses on Margo Hayes\u2019s quest to become the first woman to scale a route of the highest difficulty in rock climbing, and \u201cBreakthrough: The Killer Snail Chemist\u201d examines Mand\u00eb Holford\u2019s research into using snail venom to cure disease. Dr. Holford and others involved in the films will take part in audience discussions, aiming to turn curious young cineastes into serious future conservationists.\n\nnywildfilmfestival.com\n\n\n\nTEKNOPOLIS at BAM Fisher (Feb. 24-March 11). Imagine bringing cartoon characters to life, turning yourself into a rain forest tree or entering the world of a story you\u2019re reading. Those are some of the adventures promised by this four-floor showcase, which the Brooklyn Academy of Music bills as a two-week digital playground. Strictly limited to children 6 and older, the experience offers timed-entry sessions during which you can create live-action or animated films with the Cinekid Storymaker, transform shapes into tuneful compositions with Fingerlab\u2019s Musyc app and explore children\u2019s fiction in the Augmented Reality Story Corner.\n\n718-636-4100, bam.org", "title": "6 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "More than 18,000 have been admitted as refugees since October 2011. But the Trump administration has significantly thinned the flow of refugees, and officials said this week that those from Syria and several other countries will be let in only after undergoing new vetting on top of the screening they already receive.\n\nThe temporary status is granted to certain groups of people in the wake of natural disasters, wars, outbreaks of disease and other catastrophes that would make it difficult for them to return safely to their home countries. Government officials periodically review the program to decide whether to extend it, and most groups have received regular extensions in the past. The administration ended protected status for people from Haiti and El Salvador on the grounds that both countries had recovered sufficiently from the earthquakes that were the reason for their original inclusion in the program.\n\nThe protections can be extended for 6, 12, or 18 months at a time. The Obama administration extended them for Syrians three times, and each time it allowed new applicants to join. Homeland security officials did not say on Wednesday evening why they had decided to offer an extension to Syrians who already had the status, but not to offer it to those who did not.\n\nSyria was originally included in the program in 2012 because of the armed conflict among government forces, anti-government insurgents and the Islamic State. According to the United Nations refugee agency, more than 5.4 million people have fled Syria since 2011, when the civil war began, and that number climbs every month. Another 6.1 million Syrians have been forced from their homes, but are still living within Syria\u2019s borders.\n\nJust this month, the United States accused the government of Syria\u2019s president, Bashar al-Assad, of attacking its own people with chemical weapons, a war crime, in the same region that was devastated four years ago by the deadliest chemical attacks of the entire Syrian conflict.\n\n\u201cThere is no way to go back,\u201d said Radwan Ziadeh, a prominent Syrian dissident who was denied political asylum last year, but has been allowed to remain in the United States under the program. \u201cI have a death sentence from the Assad government, I\u2019m on the top of their list.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cIt\u2019s common sense actually to do the right thing, to renew T.P.S.\u201d\n\nIt was not clear that Syrians could be deported from the United States, even if immigration officials tried, said Robert S. Ford, an American ambassador to Syria during the Obama administration who is now a senior fellow at the Middle East Institute. There is no direct air service between the two countries, and neither country maintains an official diplomatic presence in the other, which may complicate any efforts to obtain the documentation required before anyone can be deported.\n\nAdvocates for extending protected status for Syrians had been hopeful that the administration understood the depths of the challenges still facing Syria. They had seized on remarks made recently by Rex W. Tillerson, the secretary of state, who pledged to keep American troops in Syria even after the Islamic State is eradicated there in order to stabilize the country.", "title": "6,900 Syrians Win Permission to Stay in the U.S., for Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "TEHRAN, Iran \u2014 A commercial plane crashed on Sunday in a foggy, mountainous region of Iran, most likely killing all 66 people on board, the state news media reported.\n\nThe Iran Aseman Airlines plane went down near its destination, the city of Yasuj, about 485 miles south of the capital, Tehran.\n\nMohammad Taghi Tabatabai, a spokesman for Aseman Airlines, initially told state television that everyone aboard the ATR-72, a twin-engine turboprop used for short-distance regional flights, had been killed.\n\nThe airline later issued a statement saying it could not reach the crash site and could not \u201caccurately and definitely confirm\u201d everyone had died.\n\nThe plane was carrying 60 passengers, including one child, and six crew members, according to The Associated Press. The cause of the crash was not immediately clear.\n\nThe Iranian Red Crescent said it had sent people to the area, and the authorities said they would be investigating.\n\nBut fog prevented rescue helicopters from reaching the site in the Zagros Mountains, state TV reported. Mr. Tabatabai said the plane had crashed into Mount Dena, which has an elevation of about 14,500 feet.\n\nNews reports said the plane disappeared from radar screens 50 minutes after taking off from Mehrabad International Airport, in western Tehran, which mainly serves domestic flights but has some international routes.", "title": "66 Feared Dead After Iran Plane Crash", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "To Dr. O\u2019Neill, an economist, this was something of a surprise. \u201cWhen we started, we kind of thought, \u2018surely, out of 150 different countries, there will be some shining star\u2019\u201d with a high quality of life and moderate resource use. \u201cWe really didn\u2019t find that,\u201d he said, pointing only to Vietnam as coming close to meeting both measures.\n\nThe United States, on the other hand, provides a relatively high quality of life but fails on every measure of sustainability in the study. For example, it emits 21.2 metric tons of carbon dioxide per person per year, while the study\u2019s sustainability threshold is 1.6 metric tons.\n\nProviding a good quality of life to everyone on the planet would require \u201ctwo to six times the sustainable level for resources,\u201d Dr. O\u2019Neill said. \u201cSomething has to change.\u201d\n\nHe did not say, however, that these findings doom humanity to poverty or environmental ruin. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t tell us what\u2019s theoretically possible,\u201d he said, noting that the study only projects the results of continuing with business as usual.\n\nThe conclusions have caused a stir, especially in conservative circles. National Review denounced the paper as a call for \u201cglobal wealth distribution,\u201d saying \u201cthe goal clearly is a technocracy that will undermine freedom, constrain opportunity, not truly benefit the poor, and materially harm societies that have moved beyond the struggle for survival.\u201d", "title": "7 Billion People, One Planet. Can Everyone\u2019s Needs Be Met?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nANN CLEARE at the Miller Theater (March 1, 8 p.m.). Hailing from Ireland, this young composer was trained at Harvard and Ircam, and receives a prestigious composer portrait here with the best of advocates on hand, the International Contemporary Ensemble. Led by Steven Schick, they play \u201cTeeth of Light, Tongue of Waves,\u201d which is a premiere, and three other works.\n\n212-854-7799, millertheatre.com\n\nDANISH STRING QUARTET at Alice Tully Hall (Feb. 25, 5 p.m.). This foursome of three Danes and a Norwegian is one of our most energetic and effervescent young quartets \u2014 beards, line of craft beer and all. They stick to the Austro-Germanic tradition in this performance, but with a neat trick in the first half: three quartets dealing with the subject of hunts, by Haydn, Mozart and J\u00f6rg Widmann. There\u2019s Brahms, too.\n\n212-875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org\n\n\u2018ELEKTRA\u2019 at the Metropolitan Opera (March 1, 8 p.m., through March 23). There has been no more electric night at Carnegie Hall in recent years than the one that witnessed Christine Goerke\u2019s Elektra with the Boston Symphony in 2015, and here, finally, is a chance to see her sing the role onstage. In Patrice Ch\u00e9reau\u2019s devastating production, Ms. Goerke is joined by Elza van der Heever as Chrysothemis, Michaela Schuster as Klyt\u00e4mnestra and Mikhail Petrenko as Orest. Yannick N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin, the future music director, is on the podium.\n\n212-362-6000, metopera.org\n\nNEW YORK PHILHARMONIC at David Geffen Hall (Feb. 28, 7:30 p.m., through March 3). Another program from the music director designate Jaap van Zweden, and a rather simple one. Yuja Wang is the soloist for the tumultuous Brahms Piano Concerto No. 1; after that comes Prokofiev\u2019s Symphony No. 5.\n\n212-875-5656, nyphil.org\n\nMITSUKO UCHIDA at Carnegie Hall (Feb. 26, 8 p.m.). Whenever I want to listen to Schubert\u2019s piano sonatas, more likely than not I will turn to Mitsuko Uchida\u2019s recordings. She plays this music with such poise, with such glow, but never stints on its dark, psychological side. This concert, as well as a second on March 2, begins a two-season survey at Carnegie, setting off with the harrowing C minor, D. 958, the earlier D. 664 in A, and the grander D. 894 in G.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nVIENNA PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA at Carnegie Hall (Feb. 23-24, 8 p.m.; Feb. 25, 2 p.m.). Gustavo Dudamel, the conductor whose widely heralded success in Los Angeles has sat awkwardly alongside persistent questions about his stance on political issues in his native Venezuela, is the chosen leader of this orchestra\u2019s annual trip to New York. For the most part, the programs are staid. On Friday, there is an all-Brahms program; on Saturday, Mahler and Berlioz. On Sunday, there\u2019s Tchaikovsky\u2019s Fourth and, quite surprisingly, Ives\u2019s Second \u2014 what on earth these urbane Viennese will make of that raucous piece of Americana is probably worth investigating.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org", "title": "7 Classical Music Concerts to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["David Allen"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\n\u2018BALANCHINE\u2019S ETERNAL PRESENT: THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF PAUL KOLNIK\u2019 at the 92nd Street Y (Feb. 27, 7:30 p.m.). This special presentation honors the photographer who has spent more than 40 years capturing New York City Ballet. In an evening of conversation with the company\u2019s former principal Darci Kistler \u2014 regarded as George Balanchine\u2019s last ballerina \u2014 Mr. Kolnik talks about Balanchine\u2019s ballets and his images, which he refers to as \u201cilluminated documents.\u201d Mr. Kolnik\u2019s work is currently on view in the Y\u2019s Weill Art Gallery through May 8.\n\n212-415-5500, 92y.org\n\nJ\u00c9R\u00d4ME BEL at N.Y.U. Skirball Center for the Performing Arts (March 1-2, 7:30 p.m., March 3, 3 p.m.). For \u201cGala,\u201d the French choreographer showcases 20 New Yorkers, some professional dancers and others amateurs, ranging in age from 8 to 80. This structurally simple work, in which performers cross the stage while enacting specific actions, emphasizes, in the end, the power of movement in humorous and poignant ways. The matinee on March 3, a production of N.Y.U. Skirball\u2019s Serious Fun Family Matinee series and the third annual Tilt Kids Festival, is for children ages 7 and up and includes special preshow activities beginning at 2 p.m.\n\n212-998-4941, nyuskirball.org\n\nCOMPANY WAYNE MCGREGOR at the Joyce Theater (Feb. 27, 7:30 p.m., through March 3). How can you tell your story in a dance without resorting to narrative? In \u201cAutobiography,\u201d the British choreographer and director creates a movement palette inspired by the sequence of his own genome as well as by moments from his personal history. The work includes set design and projections by the visual artist Ben Cullen Williams, an electronic score by Jlin and lighting by Lucy Carter. The March 3 matinee at 2 p.m. is part of a new Joyce initiative called \u201cPay What You Decide,\u201d in which spectators are able to first watch the show and then decide how much to pay.\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org\n\n\u2018DANCING PLATFORM PRAYING GROUNDS: BLACKNESS, CHURCHES AND DOWNTOWN DANCE\u2019 at Danspace Project at St. Mark\u2019s Church and other locations (Feb. 28-March 24). The choreographer Reggie Wilson serves as the guest curator for this exploration of the intersection of race, religion and dance, as well as the architecture and history of St. Mark\u2019s Church, the home of Danspace Project. Conceived by the organization\u2019s executive director and chief curator, Judy Hussie-Taylor, as a way to delve deeper into a subject, the \u201cPlatform\u201d series is always worth paying attention to, but this one, opening at the Great Hall at the Cooper Union, promises to be especially rich. Included are performances, discussions and walking tours.\n\n866-811-4111, danspaceproject.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNEW YORK CITY BALLET at the David H. Koch Theater (through March 4). The company wraps up its winter season with a week of repertory, including \u201cStravinsky and Balanchine,\u201d a splendid showcase of ballets choreographed by George Balanchine and set to music by Igor Stravinsky, including \u201cAgon\u201d and Symphony in Three Movements. As part of that program, on Feb. 27, Erica Pereira and Joseph Gordon make their debuts in Balanchine\u2019s 1972 \u201cDivertimento From \u2018Le Baiser de la F\u00e9e.\u2019\u201d And the \u201cHere/Now\u201d program, which opens on Feb. 24, is topped by Alexei Ratmansky\u2019s \u201cNamouna, a Grand Divertissement.\u201d It\u2019s a delight.\n\n212-496-0600, nycballet.com\n\nPANTA REI DANCE THEATER at the Schimmel Center (Feb. 23-24, 7:30 p.m.). This company from Oslo makes its debut in the United States with \u201cLullaby,\u201d a work from 2015 for three men. Featuring choreography by Anne Holck Ekenes, Pia Holden and H\u00e9l\u00e8ne Blackburn and a live score by the Norwegian musician and composer Sverre Indris Joner, the production explores, in part, the relationship between brutality and masculinity while juxtaposing aggression with vulnerability. Mr. Shapiro did not elaborate about the possible conflict, though he said that prison officials had been aware of assault allegations but that there was no evidence they had been fully investigated.\n\nMr. Shapiro said the state\u2019s investigation remained open and hinted that investigators were looking into whether Lackawanna County officials ignored the abuse allegations.\n\n\u201cWhenever you see this kind of scope, whenever you see this kind of pervasive culture that was allowed to exist, you have to wonder how far up the chain this goes,\u201d Mr. Shapiro said. \u201cI want this community to know we are continuing to work to answer that question.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
