Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSeveral female inmates told the grand jury that the guards offered them cigarettes, commissary goods and additional time on the phone in exchange for sex, according to court documents. While some guards took the inmates into closets to have sex, others showed little fear of getting caught and propositioned inmates in their cells.\n\nAt least one guard, who worked at the Lackawanna County Prison from 1999 to 2013, devised a system with other officers to alert one another if they were about to be caught, officials said. If the sexual acts inside the jail cell needed to be cut short, the court documents said, guards inside a jail monitoring room would remotely \u201cclick\u201d the cell lock to alert the guard.\n\nSome of the allegations are from more than a decade ago, a period during which several other Lackawanna correction officers were accused of assault. A former guard pleaded guilty in 2015 to sexually assaulting five inmates from 2002 to 2011. Several female inmates filed a lawsuit in 2016 claiming that they had been sexually abused by guards.\n\nIn the lawsuit, one of the inmates claimed that she reported allegations of sexual abuse to an assistant warden at the prison, who \u201csent officers into her cell to destroy her complaints.\u201d Some guards named in the lawsuit were among those charged on Thursday.\n\nA county spokesman told The Associated Press that many of the allegations \u201coccurred many, many years ago,\u201d and that the prison was safe.", "title": "7 Prison Guards in Pennsylvania Charged With Sexually Abusing Inmates", "authors": ["Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "A sprinkling of lesser-known figures are included, as well, such as Bruce Ohr, who was a top Justice Department official before being sidelined, and his wife, Nellie Ohr, who monitored Russian news media for Fusion GPS, the firm that paid Mr. Steele.\n\nThroughout the memo is a veritable who\u2019s who of F.B.I. and Justice Department officials who have been portrayed as corrupt partisans in Republican circles: Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general who is overseeing the Russia investigation; Sally Q. Yates, who briefly served as acting attorney general before being fired by Mr. Trump; and Peter Strzok and Lisa Page, the F.B.I. officials whose anti-Trump texts are being examined by the bureau\u2019s inspector general.\n\nAnd, of course, there is Hillary Clinton, whose campaign paid for the dossier.\n\nThe F.B.I. Apparently Fired Someone Who Was Not an Employee\n\nThe memo described Mr. Steele as having been \u201csuspended\u201d and \u201cterminated\u201d by the F.B.I. as a source for \u201can unauthorized disclosure to the media.\u201d It is curious language given what we know about Mr. Steele\u2019s relationship with the F.B.I.: He voluntarily approached the bureau, he never had any kind of formal arrangement with it and he was never paid.\n\nAs far as Mr. Steele was concerned, the F.B.I. had no claim to the information he was sharing, and he was free to do with it as he pleased.\n\nSpy Agencies Worry They Might Be the Next Targets\n\nThe past few weeks have been the F.B.I.\u2019s and the Justice Department\u2019s time in the barrel, to paraphrase Roger J. Stone Jr., a Trump ally and self-described Republican dirty tricks master. But the ruckus on the House Intelligence Committee has not gone unnoticed in the intelligence community, including at the C.I.A. and the National Security Agency.\n\nIntelligence officials are expressing concerns that House Republicans, having succeeded in releasing the memo, could continue to selectively release sensitive intelligence when it suits their political needs \u2014 and that next time, it might be C.I.A. or National Security Agency intelligence that is compromised.\n\nIntelligence Oversight Just Got Harder\n\nWhen the House and Senate Intelligence Committees were created in the 1970s after Watergate, they came with an implicit understanding: Americans spies would share secrets with a select group of lawmakers and senior congressional staff, and in exchange that information would not be used for political gain.", "title": "7 Takeaways From the Release of the Secret Memo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\n\u2018THE GRUFFALO\u2019 LIVE ONSTAGE at Flushing Town Hall (Feb. 17-18, 2 p.m.). What happens when the fearsome creature you\u2019ve invented to scare away your enemies turns out to be real? That\u2019s the situation the mouse confronts in \u201cThe Gruffalo,\u201d the best-selling 1999 picture book written by Julia Donaldson and illustrated by Axel Scheffler. In this musical adaptation by Tall Stories, a London theater company, young audiences can help provide sound effects for the Gruffalo, the beast that can\u2019t seem to be contained by the mouse\u2019s imagination. This Queens organization is also offering tickets for a postshow workshop at 3:45 p.m. in which children collaborate to create their own stories using pictures, movement and theater games. (Space is limited.)\n\n718-463-7700, ext. 222; flushingtownhall.org\n\nKIDS WEEK at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum (Feb. 18-24, 10 a.m.-5 p.m.). This former aircraft carrier once transported the military, but this week the guests on board will include everyone from the baseball mascot Mr. Met to the zoologist Jarod Miller to the NASA spacewalk flight controller Allison Bolinger. They will all demonstrate \u201cScience Is Everywhere!,\u201d the theme of this year\u2019s Kids Week, which fills the public school midwinter break with programs, experiments and talks. Sunday and Monday will be devoted to the science of sports and games, with topics like fastball physics and baseball stats; Tuesday and Wednesday will explore the science of arts and music, including puppetry workshops and excerpts from Broadway shows; and Thursday through Feb. 24 will focus on science and the natural world, with opportunities to meet live animals and investigate astrophysics.\n\n212-245-0072, www.intrepidmuseum.org\n\nLEGO LIVE NYC at Pier 36 (Feb. 16-18 at various times). You haven\u2019t earned your stripes as a parent if you\u2019ve never accidentally stepped shoeless on a Lego brick. But if you think those plastic building units are forever underfoot in your home, imagine 4.66 million of them in 65,000 square feet of space. That\u2019s what this extravaganza, the first of its kind in the United States, offers on the Lower East Side, with Lego contests, demonstrations, character appearances, advice from experts and themed play zones that include Minecraft, Star Wars, Ninjago and a coding corner for constructing robots. (Advance ticket purchase is recommended.)\n\n888-512-7469, liveevent.lego.com\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLOSAR FAMILY DAY at the Rubin Museum (Feb. 18, noon-4 p.m.). Would your children climb any mountain to pet a dog? Then on Sunday send them to the Himalayas, which they can experience mentally and spiritually at this museum. The Rubin will honor Losar, the Tibetan New Year, with some cuddly canine guests from New York Therapy Animals, visiting because it\u2019s the Year of the Earth Dog. During this free program, children can also paint with mud (a way to embody the Earth Dog), add messages to a wishing tree (inspired by Tibetan prayer flags), explore Tibetan forms of divination and go on a Losar-themed scavenger hunt.\n\n212-620-5000, rubinmuseum.org", "title": "7 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Laurel Graeber"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nANNA CATERINA ANTONACCI at Zankel Hall (Feb. 20-21, 7:30 p.m.). Accompanied by Donald Sulzen, the leading soprano gives a rare, double recital at Carnegie, presented by the New York City Opera.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nEMANUEL AX, LEONIDAS KAVAKOS AND YO-YO MA at Carnegie Hall (Feb. 22, 8 p.m.). Trios do not come much starrier than this, and unlike many celebrity ensembles, this one has a real connection. Together, they play all three Brahms Piano Trios, a program that they have been presenting since 2015 and was released on a recording last year. If the performance sells out, which it probably will soon, try for returns.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nCHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER at Alice Tully Hall (Feb. 20, 7:30 p.m.). An unusually interesting program from the Chamber Music Society, comprising three quintets, which are all responses, in one way or another, to World War I. Ravel\u2019s \u201cLe tombeau de Couperin\u201d is the best known, even when arranged for five winds; it comes with Dohnanyi\u2019s Piano Quintet No. 2 and Elgar\u2019s Piano Quintet, with its typically sublime slow movement.\n\n212-875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org\n\nNEW YORK PHILHARMONIC at David Geffen Hall (Feb. 22, 7:30 p.m., through Feb. 24). The Philharmonic\u2019s assistant conductor, Joshua Gersen, leads as American a program as it is possible to think of, at least in one particular idea of what American music might be. Barber\u2019s \u201cAdagio for Strings\u201d leads off, followed by the Symphonic Dances from Bernstein\u2019s \u201cWest Side Story,\u201d before Copland\u2019s Symphony No. 3, with its rousing \u201cFanfare for the Common Man.\u201d\n\n212-875-5656, nyphil.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEMMANUEL PAHUD AND ALESSIO BAX at the 92nd Street Y (Feb. 17, 8 p.m.). Mr. Bax is a strong pianist in his own right, but Mr. Pahud is the real attraction here, perhaps the world\u2019s most distinguished flutist, and the principal of the Berlin Philharmonic. Flute Sonatas by Bach and Poulenc come with transcriptions of Schubert\u2019s \u201cArpeggione\u201d Sonata and Mendelssohn\u2019s F major Violin Sonata.\n\n212-415-5500, 92y.org", "title": "8 Classical Music Concerts to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["David Allen"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Image\n\nMeghan Roche\n\n17, United States\n\n\u201cI was a total tomboy growing up,\u201d says the Pennsylvanian. \u201cI played for the best ranked soccer club in the country and later moved on to playing for a top volleyball club \u2014 never did I think I would get into the fashion world!\u201d And Roche\u2019s first two gigs haven\u2019t been that bad: a Givenchy campaign photographed by Steven Meisel and walking as an exclusive in the house\u2019s spring/summer 2018 show. \u201cIf I weren\u2019t modeling I would have my head in the books, she says. \u201cI take school very seriously. If I hadn\u2019t found my calling so young I would have dedicated myself to my education and getting into an Ivy League.\u201d She\u2019s always wanted to become a criminal lawyer.\n\nRepresented by Women Management.\n\nImage\n\nNaomi Chin Wing\n\n18, Trinidad and Tobago\n\nWing made her runway debut in September at Saint Laurent\u2019s spring/summer 2018 show \u2014 the one held at the foot of the Eiffel Tower \u2014 and rounded out her first season with appearances at Rochas, Altuzarra, John Galliano, Giambattista Valli and Alexander McQueen; we also spotted her taking turns in the haute couture shows last month, and she\u2019s posed for British Vogue, POP and i-D. \u201cI may have a very reserved exterior, but I am a really easygoing person,\u201d Wing shares. \u201cI enjoy every experience I have on the job, and wherever it takes me.\u201d That\u2019s sometimes the fictional town of Hawkins, Indiana \u2014 Wing says that to pass the time backstage she watches (and rewatches) episodes of \u201cStranger Things\u201d and the \u201cVampire Diaries.\u201d\n\nRepresented by IMG Models.\n\nImage\n\nEmily Viviane\n\n23, United Kingdom\n\nThe South Londoner walked as an exclusive at the Louis Vuitton spring/summer 2018 show in October \u2014 and nabbed an invite to the after-party, also attended by Michael Fassbender. \u201cI had no idea who he was at the time, as I\u2019m obviously not very clued up on my actors and ended up loudly exclaiming, \u2018But who is Michael Fassbender?\u2019 not realizing he was standing right behind me,\u201d she says. Backstage, she likes to pass the time chatting (\u201ceveryone has such interesting stories of how they got to where they are now\u201d) and if she weren\u2019t modeling, she says she would probably be a struggling artist or designer.\n\nRepresented by Women Management.\n\nImage\n\nDemy de Vries\n\n18, the Netherlands\n\nDe Vries debuted at Prada as a spring/summer 2018 exclusive and walked again for the house in Shanghai at its 2018 resort show in October. She says that was her most memorable experience from the fashion world thus far \u2014 especially because her mother came along too. The self-described control freak also booked a handful of slots in Paris last month (the Dior, Giambattista Valli and Valentino haute couture shows, and Kenzo and Ellery ready-to-wear), but says of her next big project (aside from fashion month), \u201cI have no idea. I just let everything come to me and see what happens.\u201d\n\nRepresented by DNA Models.", "title": "8 Models to Watch This Season", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJOHANNESBURG \u2014 Nearly 1,000 miners who were trapped in a South African mine for more than 24 hours after a power outage have been safely evacuated, company officials said on Friday.\n\nThe Sibanye-Stillwater company, which manages the Beatrix gold mine in Free State Province, said that the miners would be subjected to medical tests and counseling. The mine is expected to resume operations on Monday, the company said.\n\n\u201cEveryone is fine. There were minor injuries and a bit of dehydration, but that\u2019s all,\u201d said James Wellsted, a company spokesman. He said that 955 workers had been rescued, Reuters reported.\n\nUnions for mine workers expressed concern that there was no functioning backup plan for evacuation after a storm knocked out power Wednesday night. They also said that the episode underscored long-running problems with safety and oversight at South Africa\u2019s mines, where workers at some sites operate at depths of more than two miles below the surface.\n\nFood and water were delivered to the trapped miners while they waited for power to be restored so that elevators could ferry them to the surface.", "title": "955 Workers Rescued from South Africa Gold Mine", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The authorities in China have detained a wealthy investor who went into business with relatives of the previous prime minister, a sign that the anticorruption campaign initiated five years ago by President Xi Jinping may again be closing in on a former top leader.\n\nDuan Weihong, 49, who set up companies with relatives of Wen Jiabao, China\u2019s prime minister from 2003-13, was detained before a Communist Party congress last year, according to three friends and business associates who spoke on the condition of anonymity for fear of reprisals by the authorities.\n\nMs. Duan, also known as Whitney Duan, was a central figure in a 2012 investigation by The New York Times that showed Mr. Wen\u2019s relatives controlled assets worth at least $2.7 billion.\n\nThere has been no official acknowledgment of Ms. Duan\u2019s detention, and it is not clear who detained her, why and whether she is still being held. Emails and phone calls to her offices were not returned.", "title": "Corruption Inquiry Draws Nearer to Former Chinese Prime Minister", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s what to expect in the week ahead:\n\nECONOMY\n\nWhite House budget to reflect new spending bill.\n\nThe White House will release its 2019 budget request on Monday, but the big spending bill passed by Congress and signed by President Trump on Friday morning means that the outline of the Trump administration\u2019s spending priorities is largely seen as irrelevant.\n\nThe White House budget office said on Friday that it would modify its request to reflect the new budget cap levels established by the agreement reached in Congress. The budget request will also come with an \u201caddendum\u201d that will offer guidance to \u201caccount for the increased spending caps in a responsible manner.\u201d\n\nThe budget addendum will also come with a \u201climited set\u201d of administrative priorities and ideas for fixing budget gimmicks that the administration says are being used to circumvent the spending caps. Alan Rappeport\n\nTrump\u2019s infrastructure plan to be unveiled\n\nPresident Trump is expected to unveil on Monday his plan to rebuild, restore and modernize the nation\u2019s aging infrastructure. As one of the administration\u2019s main legislative ambitions, the $1.5 trillion proposal is expected to include upgrades to public works like roads, bridges, railways and airports. The plan calls for $200 billion in federal spending over the next decade to spur, administration officials said, an additional $1.3 trillion in spending from cities, states and private companies. Will Dudding", "title": "A (Largely Irrelevant) Budget, a Report on Prices and an Infrastructure Plan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe stylist and interior designer Paola Moretti\u2019s son Orso started agitating for his own place when he was only 6. Like many young boys, he was enamored of cowboys, known as butteri in Italy, where the 59-year-old Moretti works for clients including the kitchen and bathroom designer Boffi and Milan\u2019s avant-garde design firm Dimore Studio. \u201cHe had a fantasy of being on his own, near horses, of having a rifugio in nature,\u201d she says.\n\nSo in 2015, when a friend was cleaning his villa\u2019s property and offered Orso a midcentury canned-ham-shaped camper, the kind that might have once been hitched to a Chevy Bel Air, the boy was immediately smitten. Moretti and her son, now 14, live in Brescia, east of Milan, in a restored 15th-century parsonage filled with vintage furniture by Hans Wegner and Arne Jacobsen alongside family antiques. But once the camper \u2014 a dilapidated Roller Super 3, built in Italy around 1960 \u2014 was fixed up, Orso could spend summers living out his dream.\n\nThe romance of a tiny portable home is forever linked to images of open highways during America\u2019s postwar leisure era, but such transient dwellings in fact made their way into the public imagination in Europe much earlier. In the late 19th century, William Gordon Stables, a famed Scottish author of books for boys, commissioned the first \u201cgentleman\u2019s caravan\u201d to travel the United Kingdom, based on wagons used at that time by the Romani people who had immigrated to the British Isles centuries before. Stables, who modeled himself after Jules Verne, called his horse-drawn cabin \u201cThe Wanderer.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nUnlike the author, Moretti wanted to keep her caravan in one place. She had spent her own childhood summers in Maremma, in seaside Tuscany, where butteri continue to herd cattle on horseback nearby, and she knew the perfect spot: a secluded beach in Punta Ala on a 12-acre tract, where a retired polo player named Marco Semprini keeps about a dozen ponies. He was happy to lend her space to park the 11-by-7-foot camper.\n\nFor the renovation, the stylist and her son \u2014 her \u201caccomplice,\u201d as she calls him \u2014 drew on their shared passion for the outdoors, the history of caravans and Moretti\u2019s own peripatetic career. She had collaborated with Barnaba Fornasetti, who now runs the decorative-arts line created by his father, Piero, so she lined the ceiling, doors and cabinets with the company\u2019s iconic clouds in a wallcovering by Cole & Son, to create a dreamy atmosphere. The complementary Fornasetti owl motif, in paper and fluttering fabric, adds a \u201cnocturnal element,\u201d she says; at night, the camper and grounds are lit only by solar-powered lanterns. A friend of Moretti\u2019s hand-dyed the vintage linen that covers the benches, which double as bunks \u2014 Orso can host two friends at a time \u2014 and painted the aluminum shell the dark green of an old English Land Rover, which blends into the lush surroundings, thick with oak and pine.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe family spent most of last summer in Punta Ala, and plans to for years to come. Orso sleeps in the caravan or in a hammock outside, and helps take care of the polo player\u2019s horses, occasionally leading tourists on riding excursions to the beach. He showers with the hose hooked up to the animals\u2019 stalls. His mother also sleeps in the caravan, a surprisingly ad hoc arrangement for someone who makes a living conjuring high-gloss perfection.\n\nAs the burnt-orange Tuscan moon sets in the navy sky, Orso chars steaks on the grill and Moretti pours herself a glass of Brunello. They listen to the water lap at the rocks on the nearby shore. \u201cWe pretend we are in a magic tiny house abandoned in a forest,\u201d she says. \u201cAnd, really, there is no reason not to believe it.\u201d", "title": "A (Teenager\u2019s) Caravan in Tuscany", "authors": ["Nancy Hass"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "The extinct Tasmanian tiger, or thylacine, bears an uncanny resemblance to today\u2019s canines.\n\nLike dogs, wolves and dingoes, it was a carnivore with a svelte body, long, narrow snout and strong hind legs. But the Tasmanian tiger was a marsupial, meaning it had a pouch like a kangaroo. And despite the similarities, the Tasmanian tiger last shared a common ancestor with the placental pack some 160 million years ago during the Jurassic period.\n\n\u201cOne of the things we were interested in was how come they look so much like dogs even though they are distantly related?\u201d said Andrew Pask, a developmental biologist at the University of Melbourne and Museums Victoria who sequenced the thylacine genome last year.\n\nHe said it was one of the most apparent cases of convergent evolution, where two unrelated organisms evolve to look or function alike because of the similar niches they fill in their environments.", "title": "A 3-D Look Inside the Tasmanian Tiger\u2019s Pouch, Long After Extinction", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThat was great, Jamie,\u201d Mr. Ellis said. \u201cBack it up one more time,\u201d\n\nAnother stop, more direction and then repeat. Mr. Ellis kept offering words of encouragement to the cast, while Ms. Ferrentino sat nearby, taking notes on a notepad smaller than her hand. Occasionally, she would whisper to Mr. Ellis. Throughout the rehearsal, Ms. Brewer cracked jokes; nearby, Mr. Barbanell quietly observed.\n\nThe play is based on Amy Jacobs, Ms. Ferrentino\u2019s aunt, who also had Down syndrome and is now deceased. When Ms. Ferrentino began writing the play, her process was complicated by the limits of her aunt\u2019s verbal skills, which made creating dialogue a challenge. In 2015, she reached out to Ms. Williamson, whose entire client roster is made up of performers with disabilities. Ms. Williamson connected her with Ms. Brewer, who had just become the first person with Down syndrome to walk the runway at New York Fashion Week. The playwright and the actress met for coffee and hit it off immediately.\n\nMs. Brewer told Ms. Ferrentino that when she had played characters with Down syndrome, she often had to cater to an audience\u2019s expectations, regardless of her abilities. Immediately, Ms. Ferrentino decided that the play would be as much about Ms. Brewer as about her aunt.\n\n\u201cThat informed how I wrote the play,\u201d she said. She wanted to give Ms. Brewer room \u201cas an actor, and a person, a chance to step outside that role and show the audience who she actually is.\u201d\n\nMs. Brewer, an only child, grew up in Orange County, California, before moving near Houston, where she was involved with a local theater. She said she started performing around eighth grade, with her family\u2019s support.\n\n\u201cIndividuals with disabilities have different ways of coping with things,\u201d Ms. Brewer said. Her way, she explained, was plunging into the arts, like her character, who must handle her father\u2019s death.", "title": "A Barrier Breaks: An Actress With Down Syndrome Plays the Lead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cGrown\u201d diamonds \u2014 a term the Diamond Producers Association disputes as misleading \u2014 cost consumers 30 to 40 percent less than natural diamonds.\n\nNot surprisingly, companies like De Beers, Rio Tinto and other members of the Diamond Producers Association have cried foul, saying lab diamonds are inauthentic. The manufacturers of synthetic diamonds, on the other hand, are promoting the environmental benefits of their process, hoping to attract millennials more concerned about being green and saving money than embracing the tag line \u201ca diamond is forever.\u201d\n\nBut it may turn out that the buyers of these synthetic diamonds, particularly those trying to get more diamond for less money, may lose out in the end.\n\nLet\u2019s start with how synthetic diamonds are made. The process can be completed in as little as three months. There are two approaches. One simulates the crushing force of the earth by applying high temperature and high pressure to dissolve carbon into a diamond seed. The other is akin to a 3-D printing approach, with pieces of carbon being layered on a diamond seed in a vacuum chamber.\n\nThe result is a diamond that has the same properties as a natural diamond but different and distinguishable crystal patterns.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis is not the first time gemstones have been manufactured. In the late 1800s, Auguste Verneuil, a French chemist, manufactured the first synthetic rubies. His process has also been used to make synthetic sapphires. Cultured pearls, where an irritant is placed into the oyster to create a pearl, have been made since the 19th century in Japan.\n\nThe first synthetic diamonds were created in the 1950s for industrial uses by companies like General Electric. They did not approach gem quality until the 1970s and 1980s, beginning with colored diamonds.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTom Moses, who oversees the laboratories and research at the Gemological Institute of America, said it was not until the past five years that synthetic diamond producers began to create stones that could compete with natural diamonds \u2014 and fool people buying them.\n\nThey look the same to the naked eye, but many in the diamond trade say they are deceiving buyers.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s almost a fraud on the buying public to say they\u2019re the same thing as diamonds from an economic standpoint,\u201d said Tom Gelb, a co-founder of the Diamond Durability Laboratory and a consultant to the diamond industry.\n\nMr. Gelb bets that the value of synthetic diamonds will drop as production costs fall. It is a gem\u2019s rarity, he says, that maintains its value. If price is the issue, he suggests sticking with a proven fake, cubic zirconia: \u201cYou can get one for $25, so why would you pay $3,500 for a synthetic diamond?\u201d\n\nBut not all jewelry designers agree with the industry\u2019s rarity argument.\n\n\u201cDiamonds are a commodity with tightly controlled sourcing and marketing,\u201d said Jeffrey D. Feero, managing partner of Alex Sepkus, a high-end jewelry designer. \u201cI don\u2019t consider most diamonds rare and unusual, except for rare, natural-colored diamonds in green, red, pink, purple and vivid yellows.\u201d\n\nThat argument aside, there are two primary areas where buyers could be hurt financially. The first is in their ability to resell manufactured diamonds. One argument for buying gemstones is that they are a store of wealth.\n\nThis holds true for large, rare diamonds \u2014 or rubies or sapphires, for that matter. But small diamonds, like ones in engagement rings, are too widely available to appreciate in value and do not often maintain the price paid for them at a retail store.\n\n\u201cMaybe 2, 3, 4 percent of diamonds have the opportunity to appreciate over time,\u201d said Alan Bronstein, a diamond trader who is president of the Natural Color Diamond Association, a trade group.\n\nThat\u2019s bad enough for natural diamonds. But there is at least a willing buyer at some price. Mr. Bronstein said there was no secondary market for manufactured diamonds, largely because diamond traders will not deal in them.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf people think they\u2019re getting a bargain when they buy a synthetic diamond, the discount that they\u2019re getting is not considerable enough when you think of the possibility that they won\u2019t be able to recover some financial benefit if they need to sell it,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe second risk, though, is that a buyer might purchase a manufactured diamond believing that it is a natural diamond.\n\nMr. Feero, who said he used only gemstones that occurred in nature, said he worried about fakes because the quality of manufactured diamonds had improved so rapidly. \u201cI have no problem with lab-created gemstones, but I have a problem with a lack of disclosure,\u201d he said. \u201cDisclosure will be the saving ingredient.\u201d\n\nThe Gemological Institute of America and other groups have created tools to distinguish between the two types of diamonds.\n\nKelly Good, director of marketing at Pure Grown Diamonds, said the company favored disclosure. It inscribes each diamond with a laser to note it was grown in a laboratory. She said these synthetic diamonds had value, and she encouraged buyers to insure them just as they would a natural diamond.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not like you can turn on a machine and just keep pumping out diamonds,\u201d Ms. Good said. \u201cYou need a sustainable amount of money to produce them. These labs are not cheap to run, and this product isn\u2019t cheap, either.\u201d\n\nJames Shigley, head of research at the Gemological Institute, said the more common risk to consumers was with tiny diamonds, known as melee, that are used as accents for jewelry. \u201cThey\u2019re hard to test,\u201d he said. \u201cThousands of them could be a couple of carats.\u201d\n\nThere are machines to test them, but trade buyers worry that someone could mix small synthetic stones in with real diamonds and that they would go undetected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMark Michaels, the fifth-generation chief executive of the jewelry retailer that bears his name, said his company moved gingerly into selling synthetic diamonds in September. He was not worried about the manufactured diamonds being confused with the natural ones because his company is upfront about distinguishing the two, but he was concerned that the less-expensive option could cannibalize sales of natural diamonds.\n\nBut in the holiday season, more than half of the sales of synthetic diamonds in his stores were to people who might not have otherwise bought a diamond. Much of the rest were to people who had a set budget and opted for a larger, manufactured diamond.\n\nThat switch is what diamond producers fear now. But down the road, it could mean less \u2014 or no \u2014 value for the owner of that diamond.", "title": "A Battle Over Diamonds: Made by Nature or in a Lab?", "authors": ["Paul Sullivan", "Wealth Matters"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "As for art, she continued, \u201cAbstract paintings, framed botanicals and large-scale nature photography all work well for a child\u2019s room. It doesn\u2019t have to be all ABCs and zoo animals.\u201d\n\nIn the twins\u2019 nursery, she and Ms. Abney hung side-by-side pieces created by Alex Mason. \u201cThe \u2018Ribbon and Eucalyptus\u2019 diptychs are whimsical enough to be featured in a children\u2019s room,\u201d she said, \u201cbut also have a timeless quality that will allow the children to use the paintings in any room as they age.\u201d\n\nSAVE ON ACCESSORIES When you\u2019re decorating for children, don\u2019t forget how messy they are, advised Donna Mondi, an interior designer in Chicago: \u201cKeep the rug, bedding, lamps and accessories affordable, so you won\u2019t freak out with the first nail polish spill.\u201d\n\nAs time goes on, and children\u2019s interests change, they will want to personalize their rooms to incorporate their favorite things. \u201cMy rule,\u201d Ms. Mondi said, \u201cis to do it in a way that isn\u2019t so permanent or expensive.\u201d\n\nIn her son\u2019s room, for example, she created a feature wall using pieces of millwork arranged in a geometric grid, and painted it in earthy tones. \u201cThis backdrop lasted for years,\u201d she said. \u201cThe changes came with the items that were hung within the grid. It started with colorful skateboard decks and later transitioned into guitars and Jimi Hendrix artwork. This was easily adaptable for a guest room once he was in college.\u201d", "title": "A Bedroom Your Child Won\u2019t Outgrow", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "So in 2009, a group of mothers in Massachusetts organized a simple, before-school activity program in their local grade school. They opted for the before-school start because they hoped to add to the total amount of time their kids spent moving and not displace existing physical education classes or after-school sports. It also struck many of the working parents as convenient and, apparently, did not lead to bitter complaints from their children about early rising times.\n\nThe original one-hour sessions consisted of a warm-up, running, calisthenics and rousing group games like tag, led by parent volunteers. The workouts proved to be so popular that other parents began asking if they could start a similar program at their children\u2019s schools\n\nToday, the program has gained a formal curriculum, a name and acronym, Build Our Kids\u2019 Success (BOKS), along with corporate underwriting from the shoe manufacturer Reebok. (The similarity of the nomenclature is intentional.) It also has become one of the world\u2019s most widely disseminated, free, school-based exercise programs. According to a BOKS spokeswoman, it is used at more than 3,000 schools worldwide.\n\nBut popularity is no guarantee of efficacy. So researchers at Harvard University and Massachusetts General Hospital, some of whom have children enrolled in a BOKS program, began to wonder about the measurable impacts of the exercise.\n\nThey also were aware that a number of school districts in Massachusetts had plans to allow BOKS at their elementary and middle schools during the 2015 or 2016 school years and, for the new study, which was published this week in the American Journal of Preventive Medicine, asked if they could piggyback their research onto the start of those programs. Principals at 24 schools agreed. The schools included students from a broad spectrum of incomes.\n\nThe researchers then asked those families planning to participate in BOKS, which is always voluntary, if they and their children would join a study.\n\nSeveral hundred students in kindergarten through eighth grade and their parents consented. Other children, who would not be joining the exercise program, agreed to serve as a control group.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe researchers measured everyone\u2019s heights, weights, body mass indexes and, through brief psychological surveys, general happiness, vigor and other signs of well-being.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor 12 weeks, the students then played and ran during before-school exercise. At some schools, the program was offered three times a week, at others twice.\n\nAfterward, the researchers returned and repeated the testing.\n\nAt this point, those students who had exercised before school three times per week had almost all improved their B.M.I.s and fewer qualified as obese. (Many had gained weight as children should while they are growing.) They also reported feeling deeper social connections to their friends and school and a greater happiness and satisfaction with life.\n\nThose students who had exercised twice a week also said they felt happier and more energetic. But the researchers found no reductions in their body mass.\n\nThe students in the control group had the same B.M.I.s or higher and had no changes to their feelings of well-being.\n\nThe upshot is that a one-hour, before-school exercise program does seem likely to improve young people\u2019s health and happiness, says Dr. Elsie Taveras, a professor at Harvard and head of general pediatrics at Massachusetts General Hospital, who oversaw the study and whose children have participated in BOKS. (The experiment was partially funded by the Reebok Foundation, as well as the National Institutes of Health and other sources. None of the funders had control of the design or results, Dr. Taveras says.)\n\nBut the benefits are most noticeable if children exercise \u201cat least three times a week,\u201d she says.\n\nThis study was short-term, though, and looked only at a few, narrow physical and emotional impacts. Dr. Taveras and her colleagues hope soon to track the program\u2019s impacts, if any, on academics and on aerobic fitness.\n\nPerhaps most important, the study was not randomized. It involved self-selected students and families who chose to join. The results, in theory, would apply only to the kinds of children who will get up early and run and hop and skip and squeal for an hour before school.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut, Dr. Taveras says, those should be all children.\n\n\u201cIn my experience as a pediatrician and parent, kids naturally love to move,\u201d she says. \u201cThey revel in it. We have socialized that love out of them.\u201d\n\nShe believes that programs such as the one in this study might help to re-instill some of our children\u2019s instinctual pleasure in motion, she says.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve watched\u201d sessions, she says. \u201cYou can see the kids light up with joy.\u201d", "title": "A Before-School Exercise Program May Help Children Thrive", "authors": ["Gretchen Reynolds", "Phys Ed"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nFirst: What does Mueller know? You should have low expectations for how much new information Robert Mueller\u2019s Russia investigation will still uncover, writes Politico\u2019s Blake Hounshell.\n\nNo, you should have high expectations, writes Vox\u2019s Matthew Yglesias.\n\nA form of flattery. Why are some conservative media figures criticizing survivors of last week\u2019s mass shooting in Florida? Because the students\u2019 activism is powerful and effective, Ana Navarro argues. The students are \u201cnot political hacks. Not paid shills. Not indoctrinated. Not character actors,\u201d Navarro writes. \u201cThey are young people of character compelled into action by a horrible crime that cost 17 lives.\u201d\n\nMedicare for all. A new single-payer health care proposal has just come out, and I think it has a better chance of eventually becoming law \u2014 in whole or in part \u2014 than Bernie Sanders\u2019s plan.", "title": "Opinion | A Better Single-Payer Plan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "The country and Congress need assurances that the special counsel Robert Mueller\u2019s investigation will continue unimpeded. Unfortunately, legislation by Congress to protect Mr. Mueller is incompatible with the Constitution\u2019s separation of powers.\n\nInstead, there is another way, firmly grounded in the nation\u2019s history, to provide assurances to all Americans \u2014 both supporters and opponents of the investigation \u2014 that the rule of law will prevail. It comes out of a forgotten part of the story, which came in the wake of President Richard Nixon\u2019s so-called Saturday Night Massacre: President Trump and his Justice Department should follow the path of none other than Robert Bork.\n\nLet\u2019s begin with the problem. Prominent voices continue to urge President Trump to take various ill-considered steps: to pressure Attorney General Jeff Sessions to resign, making room for someone who can fire Mr. Mueller; to dismiss Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who has the power to fire Mr. Mueller but has so far refused to consider doing so; and otherwise to denounce the entire investigation. All of that predictably has led to bipartisan calls for legislation to protect Mr. Mueller\u2019s job.\n\nBut the proposed legislation is imperfect. Putting aside the question of whether Congress could muster the political will to pass such legislation, in our view a legislative fix would probably be unconstitutional. The Constitution vests the president with the power over prosecutors, and it is hard to imagine courts permitting Congress to place serious restrictions on that power. Imagine if the shoe were on the other foot: The president shouldn\u2019t be able to place restrictions on whom Congress can hire or fire, or whom federal judges can hire as their law clerks. A similar principle generally applies to Congress.", "title": "Opinion | A Better Way to Protect Mueller", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "But not everywhere. Several states are considering whether to adopt their own versions of the individual mandate, Obamacare\u2019s rule that people who can afford insurance should pay a fine if they don\u2019t obtain it. A few are looking to tighten rules for short-term health plans. Some states are investing heavily on Obamacare outreach and marketing, even as the federal government cuts back.\n\nThe result is likely to be big differences in health insurance options and coverage, depending on where you live. States that lean into the changes might have more health insurance offerings with small price tags, but ones that are inaccessible to people with health problems and don\u2019t cover major health services, like prescription drugs. States pushing back may see more robust Obamacare markets of highly regulated plans, but the price of those plans is likely to remain higher.\n\nLegislation to replace the individual mandate has already been introduced in Maryland and New Jersey with prominent sponsors. Political leaders in other states, including California, Washington, Rhode Island, Vermont, Connecticut as well as the District of Columbia, are weighing options for replacing the mandate this year, as Stephanie Armour reported in The Wall Street Journal. The mandate was designed to give healthier people an incentive to buy insurance before they fell ill, lowering the cost of insurance for everyone who buys it.\n\n\u201cClearly, I think the federal administration and Congress are moving in one direction,\u201d said Brian Feldman, a Maryland state senator who leads the state health subcommittee and was the primary sponsor of mandate legislation there. \u201cAnd I think states like Maryland would like to move in a different direction.\u201d\n\nMr. Feldman and his colleagues aren\u2019t planning simply to replicate the federal individual mandate. Instead, they are trying a new strategy. People who fail to obtain insurance would still be charged a fine, but they would be allowed to use that money as a \u201cdown payment\u201d on a health plan if they wished. Legislators estimate that many people subject to the penalty would not owe anything more to buy health insurance, after federal tax credits are applied.", "title": "A Big Divergence Is Coming in Health Care Among States", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "HAMMONS\u2019S ENTIRE OEUVRE seems to have been created with a knowing wink, but his works are ultimately motivated less by irony and more by an eerie sense of the uncanny, an understanding of what art is or can be that is so cosmic he once managed to sell snowballs to passers-by on an East Village street corner in the middle of winter (\u201cBliz-aard Ball Sale,\u201d 1983). No artist has made use of New York quite like Hammons, whose work is constructed from the city itself, and is often a part of it \u2014 he\u2019s placed empty bottles at the ends of bare branches of trees in abandoned Harlem lots (in unnamed pieces from the early 1980s) and rolled condoms onto the arms of a subway turnstile in Queens (\u201cFour Beats to the Bar,\u201d 1990) \u2014 and yet for an artist so energetically engaged with the outside world, he himself has remained curiously absent. As Hammons became more and more successful, Cannon \u2014 along with a few other surrogate egos, like a homeless man known as Junior who lived for a number of years in the East Village\u2019s Tompkins Square Park \u2014 became a crucial link to the city that inspired him. In turn, Hammons made works for Cannon\u2019s magazine, like the cover of issue eight, from 1997, which featured a photograph of an original sculpture of a pair of boxing gloves next to an ear of corn with a bite taken out of it \u2014 a reference to Mike Tyson and Evander Holyfield\u2019s infamous rematch fight earlier that year.\n\nThe art world rewards cults of personality, and for that reason Cannon and Hammons exist on its fringes \u2014 Cannon for his warmth, Hammons for his refusal to participate on anyone\u2019s terms other than his own. But it is as if Hammons\u2019s self-determined unreachability requires the balance of Cannon\u2019s accessibility. Where Hammons will not appear, Cannon does: writing poems about his work and attending his openings on Hammons\u2019s behalf.\n\nHammons was always a looming presence at Tribes, even when he wasn\u2019t physically present. For a time, a kind of social realist painting of Avenue C at night sat behind the couch in the gallery section of Cannon\u2019s house. Hammons \u201ccouldn\u2019t stand it,\u201d Cannon says. In 1995, he painted an ornate red-and-gold pattern directly onto the wall, attaching to it a makeshift shrine constructed from wire and human hair. Hammons didn\u2019t name or sign the work, but it became the gallery\u2019s centerpiece, and so associated with Tribes that Cannon had it cut out and took it with him when he moved out of the building in 2015 following a dispute with his landlord. (The piece is now in storage in a Brooklyn warehouse.)\n\nCannon\u2019s current apartment is three blocks away from Tribes\u2019 original home. It\u2019s much smaller \u2014 just two rooms and a bathroom. There\u2019s no space to organize shows or concerts. But visitors still drop by at all hours \u2014 Reed when he\u2019s in town from California, Henderson, who was among the dozens of Tribes regulars who helped Cannon move into the apartment, and, of course, Hammons. After the Whitney Museum of American Art\u2019s announcement in late 2017 of Hammons\u2019s proposed major public art installation on the Hudson River \u2014 a sculpture that will depict the outline of an enormous shed that used to stand on a pier at the site, and would be one of the largest public art installations in the city \u2014 he is more in demand than ever. (Hammons, unsurprisingly, has made no public statement about the project and has declined all interviews.) And yet he continues to visit Cannon, who may no longer have his gallery, but who still publishes his magazine online. He also published a print anthology of Tribes last year, with contributions from Hammons, Myles and Reed, among many others. And his apartment remains a salon of sorts, with Cannon sitting on the same sofa, chatting with his guests. When Hammons visits, he occasionally brings along a sketchpad, asking Cannon \u2014 who does not draw \u2014 to make portraits: of the Obamas, of himself. \u201cHe figures if he gets me in a show I\u2019ll stop asking him for money,\u201d Cannon says. \u201cYawn, yawn, yawn, yeah right, David.\u201d", "title": "A Blind Publisher, Poet \u2014 and Link to the Lower East Side\u2019s Cultural History", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s important to note that both parties have abused gerrymandering in recent years. Democrats have done so in Illinois and Maryland. Republicans have done so in Pennsylvania, North Carolina, Ohio and Wisconsin, among other places. Republicans have been able to do more gerrymandering mostly because they control more state governments \u2014 not because Democrats are above gerrymandering.\n\nBut I think that this shared blame should make the problem easier to address. In some states, less gerrymandering would benefit Democrats. In other states, it would benefit Republicans. In almost all states, less gerrymandering would make the electoral system fairer. It wouldn\u2019t solve all of our political problems, or anywhere close to all of them, but it would represent progress worthy of celebration.\n\nNext up in Pennsylvania: Either the state legislature or the courts will draw a new map. Next up nationwide (and even more consequential): The Supreme Court is likely to issue rulings on cases from Maryland, North Carolina and Wisconsin, which could eventually affect the entire country. It probably won\u2019t be in time for this year\u2019s elections, though.\n\nIf you want to dive in and read one long piece on the issue, I recommend Emily Bazelon\u2019s in The Times Magazine, focused on Wisconsin. To understand how gerrymandering is likely to affect the 2018 elections, Nate Cohn and Dave Wasserman \u2014 who are both active on Twitter \u2014 are probably the best guides.\n\nPlaying the autocrat. Trump called Democrats \u201cun-American\u201d and \u201ctreasonous\u201d yesterday for not clapping for him during the State of the Union. \u201cThe charge that members of the other party are un-American or treasonous,\u201d responded the conservative writer Bill Kristol, \u201cis disgraceful enough that anyone in his own party who doesn\u2019t denounce Trump for this shares in the disgrace.\u201d\n\nIrony alert. Alongside the digital version of my column yesterday on the scam of \u201cemotional-support animals,\u201d some readers pointed out that they saw an advertisement for a company that helps people register \u2014 yep \u2014 an \u201cemotional-support animal.\u201d\n\n\u201cWant to fly with your pet for free?\u201d the ad asks. You can see a version of it in this tweet.\n\n\u201cThe ad language basically admits this is a fraud!\u201d as the journalist Ed Johnson noted.", "title": "Opinion | A Blow Against Gerrymandering", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The fort is now the centerpiece of several historic buildings in San Ygnacio owned by the River Pierce Foundation. Its oldest room was built in 1830 as a ranching outpost when families lived on the south side of the Rio Grande and farmed their cattle to the north. In the face of constant raids from Native Americans, its thick fieldstone walls became a refuge and its gunports a defense. Over 70 years, five rooms and a walled courtyard were added. Those additions reflect a changing world. It became a permanent home for ranchers when land north of the Rio Grande became part of the United States after the Mexican-American War ended in 1848.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Trevi\u00f1o-Uribe family moved to the northern banks to secure their land,\u201d said Mario Sanchez, a former architect with the Texas Historical Commission. He called the fort \u201can exceptional survivor of the time.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nEach piece of the structure tells that grander story. The poorly constructed stone walls in the original room hint at the area\u2019s isolation and the need to use nearby materials. A sundial over the northern door installed by the fort\u2019s early inhabitants is a celebration of the return of two men who were kidnapped during a Native American raid. In one room, a prayer is inscribed on a ceiling beam. \u201cEn Paz y Libertad Obremos\u201d is its request \u2014 May we work in peace and freedom.\n\nFor Mr. Tracy, the fort communicates a shared history and blurred boundaries between two countries. \u201cThe idea that we have this problem with the frontier and with immigration and illegality and illegal aliens and children being torn apart and their mothers being arrested and incarcerated in these big holding tanks and I don\u2019t know if there is any solution,\u201d Mr. Tracy said. Customs and Border Protection trucks often roam the town. Residents say they\u2019ve seen people crossing the river before disappearing into waiting cars.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe River Pierce Foundation acquired the other half of the fort in 2008. It took several more years and about $600,000 to restore it. Most of that money came through grants and private donations, according to Mr. Tracy. Last June, the foundation began tours on the first Sunday of the month. An abstract sound experience created by the composer Omar Zubair installed in December brings each room to life with the noise of the fort\u2019s early life. In the coming months, the foundation will ramp up efforts to draw more people interested in heritage tourism, according to Christopher Rinc\u00f3n, its executive director.\n\nYet, few San Ygnacio residents have been involved in the fort\u2019s restoration. It\u2019s hard to know who is to blame: Mr. Tracy\u2019s temperament or the insular nature of small towns. On a recent Tuesday afternoon at Pepe\u2019s Grocery, one of the few stores in San Ygnacio, the consensus was that the work of the River Pierce Foundation is good for the town, but Mr. Tracy is odd.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe can be warm, hospitable and funny, but also hotheaded and bossy \u2014 a cyclone of a person. \u201cI don\u2019t know anyone that loves him,\u201d said Eduardo Botello, 66, a retired school maintenance worker who had a run-in with Mr. Tracy when he installed sound equipment for an event. Another man, who said he was Mr. Tracy\u2019s neighbor, recalled in hushed tones seeing nude participants at a performance art piece in 1990. The performance, which mimicked San Ygnacio\u2019s annual Good Friday procession, culminated with a burning cross floating on the Rio Grande. Titled \u201cRiver Pierce: Sacrifice II, 13.4.90,\u201d it protested the toxic state of the river, and was a collaborative effort between artists from Chile, Mexico and the United States, according to Mr. Tracy, who spent eight years organizing it.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s created a lot of enemies,\u201d said Frank Briscoe, an architectural conservator who worked on the Trevi\u00f1o-Uribe Rancho and experienced Mr. Tracy\u2019s intense micromanaging. However, without Mr. Tracy\u2019s vision and attention to detail, he added, \u201cI don\u2019t think that building would have had much of a future.\u201d", "title": "A Bold Artist, a Quiet Texas Town and the Heritage of the Borderland", "authors": ["Serena Solomon"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 An airport in London was shut down Sunday night and Monday by a relic of World War II: a 1,100-pound unexploded German bomb discovered during construction work.\n\nThe airport, London City, is in the Docklands, an industrial area considered crucial to Britain\u2019s war effort, and many banks and other financial institutions today have their offices in the nearby Canary Wharf neighborhood.\n\nLondon was peppered with thousands of German bombs in 1940 and 1941, a period known as the Blitz. Unexploded devices from that era, including grenades, are removed every year from backyards, fields and construction sites. The docks were hit particularly hard.\n\nThe latest bomb was found on Sunday at the King George V Dock on the River Thames, one of the docks between which the runway sits, airport officials said.", "title": "A Bomb From World War II Shuts Down a London Airport", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "BANGKOK \u2014 A bomb exploded at a bank in northern Myanmar on Wednesday, killing at least two people and wounding 22 others, military officials said. The explosion occurred in the often lawless city of Lashio, in northern Shan State, which has been torn apart by ethnic strife and battles to control smuggling networks.\n\nYoma Bank, one of Myanmar\u2019s largest commercial banks, confirmed that two of its employees, Ma Maw Maw and Ma Sandar Tun, had been killed. \u201cI heard the bomb blast and it felt like it also exploded my house,\u201d said Min Nyunt, whose home is next to the Yoma Bank branch where the bomb went off. \u201cAlmost all of the bank has been destroyed.\u201d\n\nNo one has claimed responsibility for the bombing, but such violence occasionally strikes Myanmar\u2019s frontier region, where armed groups from a patchwork of ethnic minorities, including the Kachin, the Shan, the Ta\u2019ang and the Wa \u2014 have battled the Myanmar military for decades.\n\nFliers were distributed publicly about a month ago in Lashio, the main city in northern Shan State, quoting a warning by Senior Gen. Kyaw Than Swe from the Myanmar Military Security Department that two ethnic militias, the Kachin Independence Army and the Ta\u2019ang National Liberation Army, were preparing to attack the city.", "title": "A Bombing in Northern Myanmar Signals Strife Beyond the Rohingya", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Scientists have developed a brain implant that noticeably boosted memory in its first serious test run, perhaps offering a promising new strategy to treat dementia, traumatic brain injuries and other conditions that damage memory.\n\nThe device works like a pacemaker, sending electrical pulses to aid the brain when it is struggling to store new information, but remaining quiet when it senses that the brain is functioning well.\n\nIn the test, reported Tuesday in the journal Nature Communications, the device improved word recall by 15 percent \u2014 roughly the amount that Alzheimer\u2019s disease steals over two and half years.\n\nThe implant is still experimental; the researchers are currently in discussions to commercialize the technology. And its broad applicability is unknown, having been tested so far only in people with epilepsy.", "title": "A Brain Implant Improved Memory, Scientists Report", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Act I. The Party\n\nONE EVENING NOT long after \u201cThe Boys in the Band\u201d had its Off Broadway premiere in April 1968, Laurence Luckinbill, who played Hank, brought his tool kit to work. Theater Four, as the joint was called, was a dowdy old converted church in a part of Manhattan that the play\u2019s author, Mart Crowley, called a \u201csenseless-killing neighborhood.\u201d But Luckinbill wasn\u2019t lugging tools to make repairs. Instead, he drilled a hole in a piece of the set called a tormentor flat, about waist-high, so that he and his eight castmates, standing backstage, could get a glimpse of whoever was sitting sixth row center: the best seats in the house. Over the coming weeks the actors took turns peeping at the likes of Jackie Kennedy, Marlene Dietrich, Groucho Marx and Rudolf Nureyev. Even New York City\u2019s glamorous mayor, John Lindsay, showed up.\n\nThis was an unexpected turn of events. \u201cThe Boys in the Band\u201d was very much a ghetto play, a peephole aimed at gay men. In writing it, Crowley had deliberately taken up the challenge tossed down by the theater critic Stanley Kauffmann, who in a 1966 New York Times essay headlined \u201cHomosexual Drama and Its Disguises\u201d asked why that era\u2019s most famous gay playwrights \u2014 meaning Edward Albee, Tennessee Williams and William Inge \u2014 didn\u2019t write about themselves and leave straights alone. His premise was faulty: Characters like Martha and George in \u201cWho\u2019s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?\u201d are not, as he suggested, gay couples in masquerade. Nor do homosexuals suffer from an \u201cemotional-psychological illness,\u201d as he casually mentions \u2014 for this was an era in which such public slurs were chic and permissible, especially in the guise of literary criticism. (In The New York Review of Books, Philip Roth derided Albee\u2019s 1964 drama \u201cTiny Alice\u201d for its \u201cghastly pansy rhetoric.\u201d) Still, there was no denying that frank plays about gay male life had never reached the mainstream, never penetrated the circles in which Kauffmanns and Roths and socialites frolicked.\n\nSo Crowley wrote the best and funniest and gayest play he could, about nine gay men (or maybe eight and a half) at a birthday party. Though some of the men finesse the ambient homophobia of the time better than others, almost all of them suffer from the self-hatred that seemed then, and maybe now, to infiltrate even the best-defended personality. (\u201cI had enough self-hatred built up in me to go around,\u201d Crowley says. \u201cI didn\u2019t need Stanley Kauffmann to tell me that.\u201d) And no one is spared the pressure cooker of the play\u2019s dramatic construction: When the well-oiled host forces the guests to play a painful game \u2014 requiring them to phone someone they have loved and confess their feelings \u2014 the tart humor of the first half turns bitter. In a Times review that thought nothing of flinging phrases like \u201cscreamingly fag\u201d and \u201cfairy queens shouting bitchicisms,\u201d Clive Barnes nonetheless acknowledged that \u201cThe Boys in the Band\u201d was \u201cquite an achievement\u201d and \u201ca gripping, if painful experience.\u201d", "title": "A Brief History of Gay Theater, in Three Acts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "But his decision to create a web series with a first episode that jabs pointedly at the president is striking because of Mr. Roth\u2019s history with Mr. Trump. Mr. Roth\u2019s father, Steven, a prominent real estate magnate in New York City, has been politically and financially allied with Mr. Trump.\n\nThe future president attended Jordan Roth\u2019s wedding in 2012 to Richie Jackson. In a 2015 interview, Mr. Trump cited the event when asked if he had ever attended a same-sex wedding, and called Jordan Roth a \u201cgreat guy.\u201d\n\n\u201cYes, he was at my wedding, but when it became clear what his politics were, and what his priorities were, and what his administration would do to things I hold dear \u2014 that was the change,\u201d Jordan Roth said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not meant to be personal,\u201d he added. \u201cIt\u2019s saying something about where we are right now, and the language and the potential shock value of it is part of the point, because we are numb.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Roths have remained a close family even as Steven Roth, who jointly owns a skyscraper in New York and one in San Francisco with Mr. Trump, has counseled the president \u2014 he was the member of an infrastructure advisory council before it disbanded last summer \u2014 and Jordan Roth has criticized him. \u201cWe have different political opinions and beliefs, and we can talk about them, but they are not the basis of our relationship,\u201d Jordan Roth said. \u201cI know for some people that may be difficult to understand, but he is my father and I am his son and that matters more. I love him.\u201d\n\nSteven Roth did not respond to an email seeking comment on his son\u2019s video.\n\nDaryl Roth \u2014 Steven\u2019s wife and Jordan\u2019s mother \u2014 is a prominent Broadway producer who has gravitated toward progressive plays that often call attention to challenges facing women and gay people. She attended the Trump inauguration with her husband and has avoided publicly taking sides on the administration.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
