Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Roth, in an email, gave the video a positive review, calling it \u201chilarious, really clever and witty, and certainly timely.\u201d \u201cI love it,\u201d she added. \u201cIt will definitely get people talking.\u201d\n\nA White House spokeswoman did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nJordan Roth, who has had a longtime interest in performing and has dabbled in video production previously, conceived of this new series months ago, with the idea of developing \u201ca kids\u2019 show for adults,\u201d modeled on \u201cMister Rogers\u2019 Neighborhood\u201d and \u201cPee-wee\u2019s Playhouse.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf we can take our frustration and confusion and dismay and fear and create with it, that\u2019s what we need to do,\u201d he said.\n\nThe video, which includes off-color language, features an animated character voiced by Billy Porter, an actor who won a Tony Award for his role in \u201cKinky Boots\u201d (a show produced by Ms. Roth and housed in a theater owned by Jordan Roth). Mr. Porter\u2019s animated avatar, shown alongside a sketch of Mr. Trump, says \u201ceven though they say he has tiny hands, they\u2019re actually making fun of something else,\u201d as an arrow points to the Trump image\u2019s crotch.\n\nBut the animated Billy Porter then says there are better ways to criticize the president.\n\n\u201cWe grown-ups should know better than to make fun of people\u2019s appearances, even the people we hate,\u201d Mr. Porter says. \u201cThere are far, far better, things to debase, like his flabby punctuation, comb-over obfuscation. It\u2019s his shameful bigotries that look so dumpy in his khakis.\u201d\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Porter said he agreed to participate as an expression of his opposition.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about the resistance,\u201d he said. \u201cJames Baldwin says it\u2019s the artist\u2019s job to disturb the peace, and I take that very seriously. I\u2019m not a community organizer, I\u2019m not a politician, but with creative energy I can help change hearts and minds with my stuff.\u201d\n\nMr. Porter has also made his own video, reinterpreting the Rodgers and Hammerstein standard \u201cI\u2019m Gonna Wash That Man Right Outta My Hair\u201d as a form of opposition to the Trump administration. He said the tone of the videos is in keeping with the tone of the moment.\n\n\u201cI thought it has to be as irreverent as he is,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s no pulling any punches any more. Yes, it\u2019s on the nose, but that\u2019s where we are, so let\u2019s vomit it all out there.\u201d\n\nMr. Roth said he hopes to introduce a new video every other week, focused on current affairs and \u201chow we talk to each other, behave toward each other, and care for each other, or not \u2014 the big stuff.\u201d", "title": "A Broadway Bigwig Lampoons Trump, Despite Family Ties", "authors": ["Michael Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "He assured his followers that there was no reason to eliminate anything essential: email for work, checking finances, staying in touch with family. Don\u2019t get rid of anything that would jeopardize work or family.\n\nWith Silicon Valley under pressure to address the addictive quality of its innovations, Mr. Newport described his informal experiment as a way for people to control their digital intake, particularly since the 2016 presidential election. It sought to address what he described as a widespread complaint: There\u2019s too much news. I need a break.\n\nThat is a particularly dominant complaint in Washington, he said, where President Trump\u2019s proclivity for one certain online medium \u2014 Twitter \u2014 can dictate at least a day of news and reaction.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot of complexity and uncertainty in the role that these technologies should play in personal and professional life,\u201d Mr. Newport said. \u201cWe\u2019re past the stage where they\u2019re novel, but not to the point where they\u2019re stable.\u201d\n\nHe estimated that nearly 2,000 people worldwide said they would participate in his challenge, tailoring their restrictions to match their work demands but hoping to at least limit their daily diet of news and social media.\n\nAt her university in Boras, Sweden, Elin Hedin, 23, stopped using Facebook, Snapchat, Twitter, Messenger and Instagram. She also tried to limit the amount of time she browsed websites.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the first week, it felt like a vacation and she slept better. But then, she said, the loneliness kicked in.\n\n\u201cI\u2018ve often felt isolated, and kind of lonely,\u201d she wrote in an email. \u201cI miss reading about people\u2019s days, seeing what they\u2019re up to on Instagram, reading about their opinions on the latest news, and so on.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI guess I\u2019m just used to getting that extra bit of socializing,\u201d she added.\n\nFor Anya Mushakevich, a 20-year-old Belarusian studying at the University of Pennsylvania, the lack of online socializing made clear which of her friends abroad would make the effort to stay in touch outside the convenience of Facebook. Who among her circle in Belarus or in Singapore, where she attended high school, would take the time to find her email or phone number?\n\n\u201cI feel more invested in the time I spend with people. And because we interact less frequently, we have this idea that we want to make the most of the experience,\u201d said Ms. Mushakevich, who says she is unlikely to reinstall the Facebook app on her phone. \u201cThat makes it seem more meaningful than if we had all of the time in the world, like we do on Facebook.\u201d\n\nMr. Newport continues to send messages of daily encouragement to readers who participated in his challenge. It made most realize, he said, how dependent they had become on websites and mobile phone apps.\n\n\u201cTheir role in your life has grown without your permission,\u201d he said. \u201cNo one had that in mind when they signed up for Facebook to stay in touch with their college roommate.\u201d\n\nA majority of the people who reported back to Mr. Newport with their results in unplugging noted that they had picked up new hobbies: painting, exercise, the opportunity to write a book. They said they also imposed strict guidelines to keep themselves from slipping: Keep the phone charger in another room. Ask the people texting to instead please call. Stop the reflex click to a favorite sports website instead of focusing on work.\n\nMs. Kremers, who gave up early in the challenge, says she plans to try again later in the year, with a better understanding of how easy it is to slip into old habits.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s a beautiful idea, really,\u201d she said. \u201cIt demands a new form of resilience from us.\u201d", "title": "A Call to Cut Back Online Addictions. Pitted Against Just One More Click.", "authors": ["Emily Cochrane"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "With some dismay, Dr. Blau had observed that he was better equipped to analyze the condition of his lab mice than his wife was to comprehend the state of her patients with metastatic triple negative breast cancer, an incurable condition.\n\nIn the lab, he had the time and expertise to analyze the data of every mouse\u2019s cancer and compare it to that of all the other mice he has studied. With human subjects, most oncologists don\u2019t have data on the evolving tumors of each individual patient and of a cohort group. Dr. Blau wanted a way to characterize the effect of various treatments on malignancies in humans at a molecular level.\n\nTo address the problem, he helped create the Center for Cancer Innovation at the University of Washington in 2013 and the next year he helped design a new type of clinical trial.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt brought together clinicians and researchers with nurses, geneticists, specialists in information technology, computational biologists and statisticians, not only at one hospital but globally. Each breast cancer patient would be closely monitored. There would be multiple biopsies of tumors from multiple sites on each patient \u2014 many enrolled as a last-ditch effort to help themselves and future patients \u2014 as well as DNA and RNA sequencing to produce huge databases. Hypotheses about treatment were put on the cloud; experts around the world could provide input and feedback. Dr. Blau said he discovered that most scientists appreciated the opportunity to offer their arcane knowledge to aid people in dire straits.\n\nAfter Dr. Blau\u2019s myeloma was diagnosed in 2015, he decided to apply this approach to himself. \u201cI had 22 biopsies of the tumor in my left pelvis, as well as bone marrow biopsies,\u201d he said, \u201cand we compared the genomic profile of the myeloma cells in my pelvic tumor with that of myeloma cells in my bone marrow.\u201d In the process, he learned about a molecular feature that kicked him out of the most favorable prognostic category.\n\nBecause he still had a tiny percentage of myeloma cells in his bone marrow after an arduous autologous stem cell transplant, which uses the patient\u2019s own cells, he rejected the advice of specialists and underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplantation, using cells from a genetically matched person. His donor, a brother and a Methodist minister, believes that he infused Dr. Blau with the Holy Spirit.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWith (possibly related) zeal, Dr. Blau soon started All4Cure, a knowledge-sharing platform for clinicians, researchers and myeloma patients who register (without cost) to allow their medical records to be accessed. Once names are replaced by numbers, these files can be tapped to create \u201ca personalized dashboard\u201d: a graph depicting all treatments, tests and responses as well as tumor sequencing. Beneath the graph, a discussion panel enables participants to comment on the particular patient\u2019s situation. To date, about 150 myeloma patients, 30 clinicians and 20 researchers have enrolled.\n\nPersonalized medicine depends upon information technology and knowledge sharing. Since every cancer contains a singular collection of mutations that can vary significantly across patients or over time within a single patient, computational analysts map how mutations interact within a specific individual, Dr. Blau explains. When a physician reviews data about a faraway patient, that doctor may draw upon her experience \u2014 for example, with the synergy of combining three drugs in a similar case \u2014 to propose an alternative approach.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSuch global networking has the capacity to break down geographic and institutional barriers to communication. It also enables patients to report outcomes immediately so that protocols with deleterious side effects can be quickly changed. Patients can compare their treatment with those of others; researchers can broadcast breakthroughs. The growing database should help predict which regimens might be most effective for a particular person.\n\nOf course maintaining and extending the platform could be expensive. When I asked Dr. Blau how his for-profit company was financed, he said that the initial investment came from a house he and his wife sold three years ago. He hopes that future revenue might come from pharmaceutical companies. All4Cure could accelerate the approval of investigational drugs and provide feedback on approved drugs.\n\nDr. Blau\u2019s enthusiasm sparks my realization that the sort of networking available to myeloma patients through All4Cure would transform the lives of the women in my gynecological cancer support group. Most of us feel only tenuously connected to an oncologist who often does not specialize in ovarian or uterine disease.\n\nIt is paradoxical that personalized medicine involves crowdsourcing. You need not understand all that Dr. Blau knows about cancer to revel in his survival and to thrill at the promise of the maxim underscoring the work it makes possible: \u201cAll for one and one for all.\u201d", "title": "A Cancer Researcher Takes Cancer Personally", "authors": ["Susan Gubar", "Living With Cancer"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Milam said she figured she would never do anything in the music business to top that, and it freed her to pursue other ventures. She had been taking distilling classes at Koval, which operates out of Chicago\u2019s first distillery, and booked a trip to the Kentucky Bourbon Trail.\n\nIt was all so seductive \u2014 the bluegrass and the beautiful horses, but especially the big, old rick houses, where the whiskey reels in the years in wood barrels.\n\n\u201cI really thought about coming home, selling everything I have, and moving to Kentucky and getting a job there,\u201d Ms. Milam said.\n\nShe continued apprenticing at Koval, and in June 2016 acquired property in Blanco about 100 yards off U.S. 281, behind an auto parts shop.\n\nInside Ben Milam, a modest bar area is accented with periwinkle boots, a typewriter, a cow skull, and a canvas bearing two old photographs, of her mother, Rosie, and her father, Merle. The Austin artist Bob Wade, known as Daddy-O, had spliced the photos together to appear as one, which he then tinted by hand.\n\nMr. Munroe, the head distiller, visited with South African tourists, while Jordan Osborne, the head brewer, tended to the mash in a production space decorated with a giant Texas flag. Ms. Milam will not disclose how much she has invested in Ben Milam, saying only \u201cmucho grande.\u201d She said her \u201ctrends are good,\u201d in financial terms, but she contends that she has never pursued money, only experience.\n\nStill, she is riding a national trend toward profitability. Fifteen years ago, the United States had roughly a dozen distilleries. Today it has more than 1,700, said Dan Garrison of Garrison Brothers Distillery in Hye, Tex., a board member of the American Craft Spirits Association.", "title": "A Career Change? I\u2019ll Drink to That!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "In 2015, Conchy the flamingo showed up at Florida\u2019s Naval Air Station Key West, and he wouldn\u2019t leave. Normally managers on the grounds lethally remove feathered troublemakers \u2014 it can be very dangerous with birds flying around million-dollar fighter jets \u2014 but Conchy was a charmer. Instead, they called the zoo.\n\nThe zoo slapped a satellite tracker on one leg and a band on the other. They nursed Conchy back to health. But when it came time to release him, the state asked: Did Conchy even belong here?\n\nYou see pink flamingos in Florida on T-shirts, hotel signs, lottery tickets and even the opening credits of Miami Vice. But it\u2019s very rare to spot one like Conchy in the wild. Over the past 70 years or so, as more American flamingos seem to be showing up in the Sunshine State, a debate has emerged about the origin of these birds. Most think they\u2019re escapees from captive populations, introduced to the state starting in the 1920s and 1930s. But others think they could be a returning population from Mexico, Cuba or the Caribbean reclaiming a lost part of its natural territory.", "title": "A Case for Wild Flamingos Calling Florida Their Home", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "By the end of the third quarter of 2017, Mr. Triantaphyllis had raised the most money \u2014 more than Mr. Culberson. Ms. Fletcher came in second and Ms. Moser third. At the same time, Ms. Moser, who somewhat resembles a taller and younger Carol Burnett, was more colorful in person and better at grass-roots organizing than her competitors. If her politics were a little squishy, she was more entertaining \u2014 supporters could take a spin class with #MeToo\u2019s Alyssa Milano!\n\nIt wasn\u2019t hard to figure out how threatening that could be, especially to the old-line Clinton Democrats who lost to Mr. Obama in 2008 and remembered the betrayal of Bernie Sanders in 2016. Those people undoubtedly influenced the political action committee Emily\u2019s List to endorse Ms. Fletcher \u2014 and should have listened to the grumbling among female voters here, who thought the organization should not have chosen between two female abortion-rights supporters.\n\nThen came the D.C.C.C., with its high-stakes gamble of attacking Ms. Moser on its website. Maybe it believed, along with The Houston Chronicle, that Ms. Moser was too liberal to beat Mr. Culberson. (The paper endorsed Ms. Fletcher and another Democratic candidate, an oncologist.) Maybe the committee thought its gripes were legitimate \u2014 it complained that Ms. Moser was a \u201cWashington insider\u201d who had used her husband\u2019s firm as her political consultants. But the first wasn\u2019t true, and the second showed only that her husband worked cheap. Ms. Moser stated publicly she wouldn\u2019t want to live in Paris, Tex.? Wow. Most urban Texans wouldn\u2019t either.\n\nBesides, there is nothing Texans hate more than East Coast political operatives meddling in their business. Especially those who don\u2019t know anything about Texas.\n\nVirtually overnight, the story of interference from real Washington insiders went viral, and Ms. Moser became a glorious martyr, quoting Michelle Obama (\u201cWhen they go low \u2026\u201d). Her profile is skyrocketing, her fund-raising is booming. And no doubt John Culberson is ecstatic about the Democrats being in disarray.\n\nNote to the D.C.C.C.: Next time you think about sticking your nose where it doesn\u2019t belong, try believing in the democratic process instead.", "title": "Opinion | A Certain Party\u2019s Gift for Self-Immolation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Gearing up for another half-marathon or marathon may not provide the motivation that runners who have hit a plateau need. So a growing number are turning to challenge races like the Speedway Challenge in Daytona Beach (a half-marathon and 5K on one day), the Clam Chowdah Challenge on Cape Cod (a half-marathon and marathon over two days), the Empire State Building Run-Up in New York City (up 86 flights of stairs) or the Bear Race in Linville, N.C. (a five-mile run up a mountain road with a 1,000-foot elevation gain in the last two miles).\n\nChallenge races aren\u2019t designed to be nearly impossible to complete, like the Barkley Marathons, which entails running 100 miles over rough terrain and which only 15 people have finished since first put on in 1986, or the Yukon Arctic Ultra, which had one finisher this year. But by combining a different kind of running with a novelty hook, they do \u201cpresent a new way to challenge yourself. The drive that you need to train and do these things sometimes requires raising the bar,\u201d Dr. Jordan said.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019ve done 10 marathons, there\u2019s some uncertainty but you might not have as many butterflies in your stomach anymore\u201d about doing another marathon, said Alex Hutchinson, author of \u201cEndure: Mind, Body and the Curiously Elastic Limits of Human Performance.\u201d \u201cIf you\u2019re trying to climb the Empire State Building, you have no idea what you\u2019re going to feel like after the 50th floor. There\u2019s a different frisson of fear.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cPeople who are high achievers, once they\u2019ve made this determination that they\u2019ve mastered some sort of task, it\u2019s no longer a challenge and it loses some of its motivational qualities,\u201d said Jeffrey Martin, professor of kinesiology, health and sports studies at Wayne State University. Thrill seekers might look for \u201can element of danger and excitement\u201d in these races, while older athletes who can\u2019t realistically hope to chase a new personal record anymore might find renewed motivation from the novelty. Mr. Martin, who has run multiple marathons over the past four decades but never one outside of North America, plans to run the Prague Marathon in May as his challenge race.\n\nIn January, Sabrina Little, a professional trail and ultrarunner based in Waco, Tex., which is relatively flat, ran the sold-out Dallas Vert Mile, which required 12 laps up the stairs of the city\u2019s 561-foot Reunion Tower. (Runners take the elevator back down between each lap.) There are about 100 such \u201ctower races\u201d around the world.\n\nMrs. Little often competes against trail runners who train in the mountains and thought a stair race would be a new and different way to help her prepare for the Rocky Raccoon 100, the oldest 100-mile trail race in Texas.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s easy to get jaded if you run the same things over and over again,\u201d she said. \u201cI thought it would be fun to try something wild that I didn\u2019t have anything to compare it to.\u201d\n\nShe enjoyed meeting a different batch of runners at the Vert Mile, including groups who travel the country to do stair races, and the 6 a.m. start time gave her a one-of-a-kind way to experience the sunrise. \u201cEvery time we ascended, it was a little bit brighter and we watched the whole sky turn pink to white,\u201d she said. She went on to win the Rocky Raccoon 100 three weeks later and has started using a stair climber at the gym to incorporate into her year-round workouts.\n\nThings went a little rougher for Ms. Han during the Dopey Challenge. She tripped and fell in the 10K on the second day, and during the final day\u2019s marathon developed tingling and numbness that required a trip to the medical tent. But two days after finishing and back in Vancouver with a handful of medals and two sore legs, Ms. Han began dreaming about completing the Dopey Challenge again next year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s something really amazing about pushing through a challenge like this, doing a physical feat that you didn\u2019t think you could do,\u201d she said. \u201cBeing able to do this challenge is everything that I needed to come out a mentally stronger person too.\u201d", "title": "A Challenge Race Shakes Up the Running Routine", "authors": ["Jen A. Miller"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Pierre Thiam, an American chef from Senegal, still remembers how when he was growing up in Dakar, some families in the countryside sent their children off to school with a little fonio tucked into their bags for luck. An ancient, sandy-colored grain, fonio was cultivated for thousands of years across West Africa and still is. Thiam remembers eating the grain too, though it wasn\u2019t really prized, at least not in the way it used to be.\n\nStanding barefoot in a friend\u2019s apartment in Manhattan, where we met before a recent snowstorm to make lunch, Thiam explained how local grains like fonio lost some cultural currency around the time of French colonization. That\u2019s when the country began importing broken rice \u2014 fragmented grains, kept aside during the milling process \u2014 from Vietnam and other parts of Asia. \u201cWe make so many amazing dishes from broken rice, it absorbs all the flavors, it tastes good,\u201d Thiam said, \u201cbut we\u2019ve been independent for more than 50 years. Why are we the largest importer of broken rice in the world?\u201d\n\nAs the U.S. market for ancient grains has grown, Thiam has become a champion for fonio. In New York, he cooks fonio to serve under whole roasted fish and meaty stews, in warm vegetable salads, mashed into fritters and in oatmeal-like bowls with fruit and yogurt. He hosts multicourse feasts, centered on the grain, eager to expand its audience and fuel its demand, and he talks about it with devotion and authority at conferences. \u201cFonio is considered country-people food,\u201d he said, shooing away a cat that had tiptoed into the kitchen. Traditionally, fonio was pounded in a large mortar and pestle, to remove its armorlike husk, then washed and dried outdoors. \u201cAnd because it was so difficult to process, it became unpopular.\u201d\n\nThough fonio is often referred to as a forgotten grain in marketing materials, it wasn\u2019t forgotten by everyone. \u201cWomen-run cooperatives put fonio back on the map,\u201d Thiam told me. He recently founded Yolele Foods, which imports the grain, grown and processed by these cooperatives, to the United States, and he plans to open a large-scale mill in Dakar. Thiam\u2019s dream is that as fonio finds more fans in the U.S., it will do the same in Senegal, and that one day in Dakar, fonio will be just as easy to find as a baguette.", "title": "A Chef\u2019s Dream to Restore an Ancient West African Grain", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The nostalgia-laden spot caters to a more mature crowd longing for familiar music, less raucous ambience, and old-fashioned cocktails served without irony. \u201cI wanted to bring people back to the day where they enjoyed dancing to great music,\u201d said the owner Jeff Wittels, 57, who previously worked in music entertainment, investment banking and wine sales. \u201cPeople want to hear things they\u2019re familiar with. \u2018Oh, I remember those songs. I was younger.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe Place\n\nThe club, which is next to the Malibu Diner on West 23rd Street, is fronted by a glass window encasing three disco glitter balls, the word \u201cBar\u201d jutting above the entrance. Inside, the narrow banquette leads to a long bar, the walls featuring a butterfly-and-floral motif that looks borrowed from a TV movie version of a 1970s uptown disco. Farther back is the dance floor, where three more glitter balls hang over the crowd, as strobe lights and sometimes fog effects recreate that old disco feeling without any of the decadence.", "title": "A Chelsea Dance Club That Caters to the Olds (or at Least Those Over 30)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "I mostly recall having chicken potpies when my mother didn\u2019t feel like cooking. We children, fascinated by anything that came from the freezer section of the supermarket, were always thrilled. We each had our own little pie, baked in its own diminutive aluminum foil pan. Even if it was generic, bland chicken stew (and it was) encased in not very distinctive pie dough, it seemed wonderful. There was something attractive about the pies\u2019 soggy bottoms, a contrast to the crisp tops.\n\nFor me, the frozen potpie has long since lost its attractiveness, but I confess to sometimes longing for a made-from-scratch version. Fortunately, in the era of frozen pastry dough, it\u2019s not really very difficult to put together.", "title": "A Chicken Potpie Fit for a Party", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "I had eaten approximately 300 miles of cold sesame noodles before I knew they had a story. If I\u2019d thought about them at all, I would have reflected that everything has a story, but I didn\u2019t. Back in the 1980s, when I came to New York, they were simply a thing you had to order with Chinese takeout because somebody always wanted them, even though they usually tasted like leftover spaghetti with Skippy.\n\nBefore this, though, cold sesame noodles in New York were the specialty of one particular Sichuan-born chef, Yu Fa Tang. Called Shorty by everybody, Tang came here in the early \u201960s after working for more than a decade in Taiwan. By 1967 he had his own restaurant on East Broadway, Hwa Yuan Szechuan Inn, where among other renditions of Sichuanese food he made cold sesame noodles that would lodge themselves in the memories of generations of New Yorkers and be imitated, lamentably, by takeout cooks all over town. At its peak it reportedly went through 500 pounds of noodles a day.\n\nFor more details on the background of the dish and its life after the restaurant closed, I refer you to a 2007 treatise that Sam Sifton wrote in The New York Times Magazine. For a taste of the original and unexpurgated recipe, I refer you to the very good new restaurant that opened on the site of the original in October. Its name now shortened to Hwa Yuan Szechuan, it is worth visiting for reasons that go well beyond nostalgia.\n\nHwa Yuan is an imposing restaurant, built by Shorty\u2019s son Chien Lieh Tang and his grandson James Tang to plant the family name solidly in this century. To the left of the entrance is a lounge where translucent backlit panels cast everything in a streaked-marmalade glow. Straight ahead is the first dining room, and there are more up the stairs to the right.", "title": "A Chinatown Noodle Dynasty Returns in Style", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "In a December document first reported by ProPublica, the Department of Justice argued that inquiring about citizenship status in the decennial census was critical to enforcing Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, which protects against racial discrimination in voting. Measuring the total number of citizens of voting age in a region is vital to understanding voting rights violations, the department argued.\n\nOn Monday, 19 Democratic and independent state attorneys general and one governor, John W. Hickenlooper of Colorado, sent a 10-page letter to Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, who oversees the Census Bureau, arguing that the change to the census could \u201crisk an unconstitutional undercount.\u201d The decennial census has not had a citizenship query since 1950, they said.\n\nAnd, they argued, \u201cadding a citizenship question at this late date would fatally undermine the accuracy of the 2020 census, harming the states and our residents.\u201d\n\nThe Justice Department is standing by its request.\n\n\u201cThe Justice Department is committed to free and fair elections for all Americans and has sought reinstatement of the citizenship question on the census to fulfill that commitment,\u201d a Justice Department spokesman, Devin M. O\u2019Malley, said in a statement.\n\nEven without the citizenship question, minorities have been undercounted in the national census, with undocumented immigrants and their legal relatives among the least responsive. Amid a fiery immigration debate \u2014 including Immigration and Customs Enforcement raids nationwide \u2014 the inclusion of a citizenship inquiry could make it worse.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s all about trust,\u201d said Mr. Hunter, who earlier in his career oversaw confidentiality policy at the C.D.C.\u2019s National Center for Health Statistics. \u201cThe government is legally bound not to reveal the identities of individuals who participate \u2014 and yet at a time like this, you would need the individual to believe that.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen census results are released, scientists often measure the impact of a disease by comparing its prevalence to the total population. With skewed census data, public health officials may invest in solving a problem that does not exist \u2014 or worse, may overlook one that does.\n\n\u201cThis is completely foundational,\u201d said Michael Fraser, the executive director of the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials. \u201cWe take for granted that we have a really accurate understanding of who lives in this country: their ages, ethnicities, where they live.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Fraser added, \u201cThe bottom line is, if we are handed baseline numbers that aren\u2019t accurate, everything we do for program planning and what we do for implementation will be inadequate.\u201d\n\nPublic health officers use demographic data to model neighborhoods before launching preventive programs, like tracking old housing in low-income communities where they expect to find lead-based paint. The same is true for preventing asthma, a condition often correlated with substandard housing. By targeting the right homes for remediation early, officials can prevent disease and save millions of public dollars in treatment down the line.\n\nThe results of the census determine how more than $600 billion is appropriated across state and local governments each year, including federal block grants for children\u2019s health and preventive care services. An immigrant-heavy region that underreports its total population could lose public health dollars \u2014 as well as funding for food programs, school programs and transportation services.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not as if immigrants going into the woodwork would solely harm services for that group. It would throw the whole system off,\u201d said Dr. Georges C. Benjamin, the executive director of the American Public Health Association. \u201cA representative census is what\u2019s best for everyone.\u201d\n\nBut Representative Steve King, Republican of Iowa, argued that counting noncitizens caused other problems.\n\n\u201cOnly U.S. citizens should be represented in Congress,\u201d he said Tuesday. \u201cIf we counted only citizens for redistributing seats, California would give up several congressional seats to states that actually honor our Constitution and federal law.\u201d\n\nThe top two Census Bureau seats have interim occupants, and financial constraints have led the bureau to skip two of its three trial runs of its overhauled process for 2020. Experts worry that the funding constraints will hinder the bureau\u2019s ability to adjust the data for low participation rates or deploy adequate enumerators to low-response communities.\n\n\u201cAttorneys from the Department of Commerce are currently examining the justification for the data needed by the Department of Justice,\u201d Albert E. Fontenot Jr., the associate director for decennial census programs at the Census Bureau, said in a briefing last month. \u201cTechnical experts at the Census Bureau are also looking at the issues.\u201d", "title": "A Citizenship Question on the Census May Be Bad for Your Health", "authors": ["Emily Baumgaertner"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Gene Norden, a high-end real estate broker, said: \u201cPeople are very conflicted about where to go now. And to toast the medalists, you might serve this cocktail, the golden torch, created by Devin Kennedy, the head mixologist at Cote, the Korean steakhouse in the Flatiron district. For two drinks, muddle the peels of one lemon and one orange with one tablespoon simple syrup in a mixing glass, and let sit for 30 minutes. Add 3 ounces a\u00f1ejo tequila, an ounce of gentian liqueur and a tablespoon of St- Germain elderflower liqueur, stir vigorously with ice and strain into two coupe glasses. Garnish each with a twist of citrus peel: Cote, 16 West 22nd Street (Fifth Avenue), 212-401-7986, cotenyc.com.", "title": "A Cocktail That Goes for the Gold", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "There is a national poet laureate, but you might be surprised to learn there is a national youth poet laureate as well.
