I put a magazine in my 9-millimeter handgun and locked it in my hip holster. I put a 30-round magazine in my M4 and slung it over my shoulder. If the day included a patrol, I put on my body armor. I usually carried a knife and at least one tourniquet. Every day, our team discussed base security to identify where we were most prone to attack.\n\nThat was my standard procedure while serving with the United States Army in a combat zone. When I left active duty in 2014, I never expected that those skills would be applicable to my next job, as a high school teacher in San Jose, Calif.\n\nBut the reality is that much of what I learned in the Army is horrifyingly relevant in the classroom. My school conducted drills similar to those that took place at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., even before a gunman opened fire last week and killed 17 people. Our first drill, during which staff practiced sheltering students and barricading doors, exposed countless weaknesses, making it obvious to me that we were woefully unprepared to protect our charges.\n\nMy classroom would be one of the first an attacker coming through the front entrance would see. So I set out to make it a \u201chard target\u201d \u2014 a place that would appear difficult to attack \u2014 to deter an intruder.", "title": "Opinion | A Combat Zone, With Desks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Benjamin recalled Mr. Friedman came across as \u201ca character\u201d with \u201ca strong presence\u201d in 2011 as he interviewed her for a job at the Seasteading Institute.\n\n\u201cHe leaned as far back as he could go in his chair in these crazy pants with his arms crossed,\u201d she said, and wore a T-shirt that said \u201cI Am John Galt\u201d (a nod to the hero of the Ayn Rand novel \u201cAtlas Shrugged\u2019\u2019) and wild yoga pants with flames, moons and stars.\n\n\u201cI loved the idea of seasteading and wrote about it for part of my thesis,\u201d said Ms. Benjamin, who wore a more sedate pink cardigan over a peach A-line dress with a pearl necklace and matching earrings for the interview.\n\nShe got the job, and showed up her first day, Valentine\u2019s Day, with a plateful of home-baked pink heart-shaped cookies, and soon developed an intellectual rapport with Mr. Friedman over subjects including seasteading, transhumanism, rationalism and Paleo diets.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cShe was really enthusiastic about the political movement, which I started,\u2019\u2019 said Mr. Friedman of seasteading, and added with a laugh that Ms. Benjamin, who identifies as a feminist, coined the term shesteading. \u201cI liked her positive energy.\u2019\u2019\n\nToward the end of his marriage at the time, Mr. Friedman, by summer, had separated from his wife and was no longer working at the Seasteading Institute. At that point, he had no misgivings about asking Ms. Benjamin on a date of sorts \u2014 to join him on a 10-hour trip to Burning Man, an annual weeklong festival in Nevada\u2019s Black Rock Desert, where they would hang out with Future Camp, a group of futurists and transhumanists.\n\nThey hauled some gear for the group in a red pickup truck he rented, and she brought along costumes, art supplies, and her guitar. They arrived in the desert at 3 a.m., and set up separate shelters.\n\n\u201cIt was my first Burning Man,\u201d said Ms. Benjamin, who saw it as an adventure and not a date at all. \u201cIt\u2019s a blank canvas for an experience that you want to have.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHalfway through the festival they had their first kiss while drinking coffee and watching the early morning scene from atop a lifeguard tower.\n\n\u201cOh yes, this is a date,\u2019\u2019 Ms. Benjamin recalled thinking, and said that once they returned home, she soon got to know and came to love his two young children, Tovar and Izzy.\n\nIn 2015 after Mr. Friedman proposed at Chez TJ, a French restaurant in Mountain View, they knew their commitment was long-term, really long-term.\n\n\u201cWe were committing to marriage to multiple human lifetimes if we have that opportunity,\u201d said Mr. Friedman, taking cryogenics and life-extension technology into consideration. She added: \u201cTwo hundred years of being married to Patri isn\u2019t enough. I\u2019d rather have 1,000.\u201d", "title": "A Commitment for More Than One Lifetime", "authors": ["Rosalie R. Radomsky"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "And the beans! Mottled red kidney beans boiled until velvety soft and mashed with pungent raw garlic, browned onions and a thrilling-sounding mountain herb called blue fenugreek.\n\nWhile I couldn\u2019t get my hands on spectacular Georgian tomatoes or those creamy Tushetian potatoes, I could make the beans, or at least try to simmer up something similar.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlice has a lobio recipe in her book, and the internet has plenty of variations, so I cobbled together a recipe that, while not necessarily authentic, somewhat represented the deeply comforting beauty of the dish.\n\nIn Georgia, the word lobio can refer to any kind of bean, from fresh green beans to the many different varieties of dried beans, which are made into stews like this one or mashed into salads often topped with walnuts: a staple ingredient in Georgian kitchens.\n\nWhen stewed (usually in earthenware crocks), the beans are traditionally served with mchadi \u2014 flat cakes of fried, polentalike cornbread \u2014 and fresh white suluguni, a strong brined cheese rather like feta. However, thick slices of sourdough and a mild feta or ricotta salata also make great accompaniments.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne thing to note is the (optional) use of two traditional Georgian ingredients in this recipe.\n\nThe first is tkemali, a sharp and fruity sauce made from sour plums. Pomegranate molasses, or even a good balsamic vinegar, provides a similarly tangy kick.\n\nAnd then there\u2019s blue fenugreek, an herb that grows wild in the Caucasus Mountains. You can mail-order it, but the stew is nearly as good without it, so don\u2019t worry about leaving it out (regular fenugreek seeds have a different flavor, so they are not a good substitute). The combination of coriander and black pepper give the dish a backbone of spice, strong enough to stand up to the onions, herbs and hit of pungent garlic.\n\nYou can serve lobio as a meatless main dish, or as a side dish with roasted or grilled meats or fish. Either way, its mix of sharp raw onion and soft, sweet browned onion, along with plenty of fresh green herbs, makes it hard to stop eating once you start.\n\nRecipe: Red Bean Stew With Fried Onions and Cilantro\n\nAnd to Drink \u2026\n\nThe ideal accompaniment to this Georgian bean stew would naturally be a Georgian wine, preferably made in the traditional manner, fermented and aged in a qvevri, like an amphora. If you have access to these wonderful wines, saparavi, a dry, sturdy red, might go well and would certainly be in the right spirit. A dry white from Georgia, which may more accurately be described as amber, would also be delicious. It derives both color and tannic structure in the qvevri by macerating and aging with the grape skins. If you can\u2019t find any traditional Georgian wines, other options include a good Cahors, perhaps an Etna red from Sicily or a Ribeira Sacra from Galicia in Spain. Or you could select from the genre known as orange wines, whites made not too differently from the Georgian whites. ERIC ASIMOV\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A Complex Red Bean Stew From Georgia", "authors": ["Melissa Clark", "A Good Appetite"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "I learned you can be still. That it\u2019s O.K. to depend on someone. That when David praised me I should realize it\u2019s not to flatter me, he really means it. I learned to see what David saw in me, and that helped a lot. He\u2019s very generous and devoted and selfless. He\u2019s a wonderful father. His love and security keep me here. I\u2019d be lost without him.\n\nMy life began with David. It took a long time to realize that. I\u2019ve learned a lot about myself by being with him. When I come home and he\u2019s not there, I have an empty feeling. I\u2019m attached. I realized I needed the structure of the marriage, and to be recognized as part of a couple. We complement each other and have achieved a balance because we are so different. I\u2019ve learned you can\u2019t run away from things. I didn\u2019t want to be conventional, but it helped me in the outside world to say I have a husband and a family. Our love is really deep. It\u2019s carried over into our children and their spouses and their kids.\n\nMr. Knoebel: I was 26 when we got married. She was 22. These were the Joni Mitchell years. We don\u2019t need a piece of paper. Marriage was not the goal. We were going to live together and prosper. Then the parents got involved and both gave the same advice: Get married.\n\nWe didn\u2019t exchange rings at the ceremony, or for the first 15 years. Our daughters bought us them. It\u2019s the only piece of jewelry I can bring myself to wear. It\u2019s a symbol of commitment and I\u2019m shy of symbols that reflect society at large. Laurie is the same. That I can wear this ring and feel that way about it, makes it all that more significant. We both wear them. It\u2019s a connection to each other.\n\nWe were two hardheaded people learning to cooperate, and that was a learning process. Stepping back was hard to learn, but I did. She challenged me. I learned I wasn\u2019t the one to make all the decisions. Even now I have to stop and remind myself I\u2019m not the only one here. I also had to let her be her. She thrives on big projects; I don\u2019t. I\u2019m a solo worker so I learned to lend a hand and get involved. I don\u2019t want to be left behind. I learned I want to share what she\u2019s doing. I learned that it\u2019s fun to work with a partner I love. I found I could do both.\n\nShe\u2019s a fascinating woman. Her kindness, her willingness to go the extra mile, with me and with others, are things I love. I\u2019m never sure what\u2019s going to come out of her mouth, but it\u2019s usually something I\u2019m glad to hear. I was not lonely before I met her, but I discovered how great a partnership could be. I didn\u2019t feel incomplete before I met her, but I did feel more complete, and that feeling has continued through the years.", "title": "A Conventional Marriage for a \u2018Counterculture\u2019 Couple", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "How will you fund all of this? This is the most important part: Shun advertising. Instead, ask readers to pay for it with real money \u2014 $5 or $10 a month, or perhaps even more. It will take time, but if you build it right, you just might create the next great metropolitan news organization.\n\nThis plan may sound simplistic, almost like a joke. Wait, Sherlock, your big idea is to create a really good product and charge people money for it? Haven\u2019t people tried this before?\n\nLess than you might think. The short history of digital media is lousy with advertising, which promotes all the wrong incentives for online news \u2014 volume over curation, aggregation over original coverage, speed over accuracy.\n\nMore recently, there has been a surge in online subscriptions. Netflix is doing it for TV, Spotify for music, and Patreon for podcasters and YouTubers. And many news outlets \u2014 big companies like The New York Times and start-ups like The Athletic, which covers sports \u2014 are making subscriptions the center of their journalism.\n\nYet few entrepreneurs have jumped on the subscription bandwagon for local news. The reluctance makes sense; local markets are by definition small, and journalism is expensive.\n\nBut after studying Ms. Lessin\u2019s and Mr. Thompson\u2019s methods, I suspect there\u2019s a market for subscription-based local coverage. Someone just has to build it.\n\nHow? Consider Ms. Lessin\u2019s plan for The Information, the tech news service she started in 2013 after spending eight years at The Wall Street Journal. Back then, online subscriptions seemed antiquated; many companies had experimented with charging users, but most had failed to win large numbers of subscribers, and the big money in media was in ad-supported sites aiming for rapid expansion through viral traffic.\n\n\u201cPeople thought no one would pay for news, especially tech news,\u201d Ms. Lessin told me last month. \u201cThe problem was the news business hadn\u2019t been focused on a key question: How do I deliver a differentiated product that people would pay for?\u201d", "title": "A Crazy Idea for Funding Local News: Charge People for It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Before Natacha Ramsay-Levi made her debut as Chlo\u00e9\u2019s creative director in September, the 38-year-old\u2019s aesthetic was, in many ways, a mystery. Preceding her appointment to the French house, the Paris native had spent 15 years working under her mentor Nicolas Ghesqui\u00e8re, first at Balenciaga and then at Louis Vuitton, as his right hand and prot\u00e9g\u00e9e. Ghesqui\u00e8re, Ramsay-Levi says, taught her to create with a democratic touch; arriving at Balenciaga as an intern in 2002, she was struck by his equal love for classical paintings and the music of Mariah Carey.\n\nThe confident, sexy collection she sent down the runway last fall \u2014 full of \u201970s citrus and earth tones, easy prairie dresses in micro floral prints, sharply tailored A-line miniskirts and denim, and insouciant, heavy-metal combat boots \u2014 revealed Ramsay-Levi\u2019s deep understanding (and personal mastery) of French cool-girl chic. It\u2019s that same, endlessly worshiped je ne sais quoi that the brand was built upon, when its founder Gaby Aghion introduced Chlo\u00e9 \u2014 and the concept of luxury pr\u00eat-\u00e0-porter \u2014 to the world in 1952, at a time when most fashion houses were exclusively creating couture. \u201cI always like to have something that is a bit wrong \u2014 nothing too bourgeois,\u201d says Ramsay-Levi of her sensibility, which is informed by everything from New Wave cinema to Cycladic artifacts. \u201cI call it vintage in the future.\u201d\n\nThe first Frenchwoman to take the helm at Chlo\u00e9 since Martine Sitbon in 1987, Ramsay-Levi was raised on the Left Bank in a literary family (her father was a book and magazine editor) and now lives in the Second Arrondissement with her 5-year-old son, Balthus. She pursued her childhood fantasy of becoming an archaeologist by getting a history degree before enrolling at the esteemed fashion school Studio Ber\u00e7ot in 2000. There, she quickly became known as \u201cthe Balenciaga fan,\u201d for her obsession with Ghesqui\u00e8re, the house\u2019s then-creative director. Once she landed a job with him, she says, \u201che helped me understand that being a fashion designer is not only to design clothes, it is to develop a 360-degree vision of everything.\u201d", "title": "A Creative Director Who Defines Effortless Cool", "authors": ["Alice Newell-Hanson", "Profile In Style"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Francesco Risso\u2019s childhood was straight out of a Fellini film. The fashion designer, who has been the creative director of Marni since 2016, was born near Sardinia and spent his first four years living on a wooden schooner with his parents, sailing around the Mediterranean. Next, they settled into a grand 16th-century villa in Genoa with three of Risso\u2019s grandparents and an ever-rotating cast of glamorous houseguests from abroad. \u201cMy family was extremely eclectic,\u201d says the 35-year-old, who, craving stability, \u201cescaped\u201d at 16 to study fashion at the Polimoda school in Florence before attending the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York and Central Saint Martins in London. \u201cIt was a vertigo way of life \u2014 I was always outside my comfort zone,\u201d he says. \u201cThat forced me to be adventurous and open-minded.\u201d\n\nIn 2008, Risso landed a job working on women\u2019s design and special projects for Prada, where he remained for eight years. Since taking the helm from Marni\u2019s founder, Consuelo Castiglioni, who started the label in 1994, he\u2019s upheld the Milanese house\u2019s reputation for explosive floral prints and prim but off-kilter silhouettes. But he has also added his own diverse aesthetic, informed by everything from Disney cartoons to 18th-century tartan hunting jackets. \u201cI\u2019m driven by a concept I call \u2018retrovolution,\u2019 \u201d he says. \u201cIt\u2019s about taking everything you\u2019ve learned in the past about tradition and moving beyond it.\u201d", "title": "A Creative Director With a Keen Sense of Play", "authors": ["Lindsay Talbot", "Profile In Style"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "T Introduces: The Nomad\n\nWhat is a hotel for? For most of history, it did only what it had to: provide a home when you were away from yours. Then, in the last century, a hotel became a place meant not just for shelter, but a destination; a place that embraced its not-homeness by being better than your home could ever be.\n\nNow, a new project is defining the hotel anew. In September, 700,000 Heures will become the world\u2019s first nomadic hotel. The idea is that a hotel is not an actual structure, but a state of mind, a series of experiences, a respite from your life. Every six months, 700,000 Heures (the approximate length of an average human life in the developed world) will change locations, occupying different buildings in different places \u2014 sometimes an existing building will be reimagined or refit for the hotel\u2019s needs; other times, it might even be built from scratch. First up will be a four-room, 19th-century stone palazzo in Gagliano del Capo, a small town in Salento, Italy, known for its wild beaches and groves of knotted olive trees. Then, after this trial run, the palazzo will be returned to its owner, and 700,000 Heures will move to northwestern Cambodia, where guests will stay in a series of locations, among them an ancient Buddhist temple. Most of the structures the company inhabits will be small \u2014 likely no more than eight rooms in any one location \u2014 and first priority will be given to its several hundred members, who\u2019ll pay an annual 500 euro fee and will be able to opt into destinations as they please. (Those wanting to join can apply through one of 700,000 Heures\u2019 50 approved travel agents.) The company is the invention of a French hotelier named Thierry Teyssier, who over the years has operated small, exquisite hotels in Morocco, Portugal and Brazil. \u201cI want to be able to spend real time with my guests,\u201d he says. \u201c700,000 Heures is personal. It\u2019s the hotel I would like to find, if I were the traveler.\u201d\n\nAlthough 700,000 Heures will be the first impermanent hotel, it finds its origins in a dining and hospitality culture that has become ever more attracted to the ephemeral, the rootless and the rare. The past decade or so has seen a proliferation of pop-up restaurants and shops \u2014 Teyssier made his own contribution to this trend in the form of a pop-up hotel in Paraty, in southern Brazil, which operated for six months in 2014 before shutting down. At the same time, there\u2019s been an embrace of what might be called subscription-based hospitality: In London, there\u2019s Carousel, a restaurant with a constantly rotating series of guest chefs and a set menu each night for which tickets must be purchased in advance, or the membership-based Soho House, which now has 18 locations worldwide. Teyssier\u2019s company speaks to a certain kind of traveler\u2019s desire for both novelty and consistency \u2014 the location might be different, but the mood must always feel familiar.\n\nOne of the ways 700,000 Heures plans to achieve this is through Teyssier\u2019s presence; indeed, he\u2019ll act less as hotelier and more as impresario, remaining on-site through each of the hotel\u2019s incarnations, and organizing excursions and events for all of the guests. In Salento, this might mean a fishing-boat ride through hidden coves along the Adriatic, or a sunset picnic at Santa Maria di Leuca, a little-known Roman sanctuary. In Cambodia, destinations will include Tonle Sap Lake, a biosphere reserve with a floating village of wooden houses, or the French colonial city of Battambang, where travelers can train with acrobats at the renowned Phare Circus. The goal, Teyssier says, is for the guest to feel like an actor in a theatrical production: the natural outgrowth of an age in which vacations are presented like biopics on social media. And, as for an actor, 700,000 Heures also provides props: Along with the physical spaces, Teyssier has created a series of leather trunks \u2014 each filled with objects to create a different mise-en-sc\u00e8ne, from cocktail bar to art studio \u2014 that will appear at all of the hotels and will provide an aesthetic through line. The hotel will also present members with a mock passport, which will be stamped after each trip. \u201cSome people make sculpture,\u201d Teyssier says. \u201cI\u2019m in the business of creating memories.\u201d \u2014 GISELA WILLIAMS", "title": "A Cultural Compendium of What\u2019s New", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Fashion Plate\n\nInside Florence\u2019s newly renovated Gucci Garden \u2014 which is not a garden but, rather, a museum for the storied fashion house, set in a 14th-century palazzo \u2014 visitors will find galleries filled with archival Gucci looks, a boutique styled to resemble a rambling antique shop and what may be the world\u2019s most enticing museum cafe, thanks to a menu designed by Massimo Bottura. Apart from Bottura\u2019s five nonprofit Food for Soul soup kitchens, Gucci Osteria is the triple-Michelin-starred chef\u2019s first restaurant beyond his native Modena. It\u2019s still a hometown collaboration, though, as Gucci C.E.O. Marco Bizzarri is an old friend from high school. There\u2019s also a natural affinity between him and Gucci creative director Alessandro Michele, both of whom specialize in artful deconstructions of the past. \u201cWe\u2019re looking back not in a nostalgic way but to create something new,\u201d Bottura says. \u201cItalians have the gene of the artisan and the poet.\u201d Yet the restaurant is not strictly Italian: Its menu features such varied dishes as lingua in salsa verde and grilled lettuce (above), steamed Japanese buns with pork belly and apple, and even a hot dog made with Tuscany\u2019s prized Chianina beef. \u2014 LAURA RYSMAN\n\nHere, Bottura shares his recipe for a classic French bouillabaisse turned Italian-style pasta dish \u2014 from his menu for the Gucci Osteria \u2014 exclusively with T.\n\nMarseille and Naples Are Not So Far (serves four)\n\n\u2219 1 lb snapper, grouper or other small white fish (descaled and gutted but still intact with heads and bones)\n\n\u2219 \u00bd lb clams\n\n\u2219 \u00bd lb mussels\n\n\u2219 1 carrot\n\n\u2219 1/2 stalk of celery (no leaves)\n\n\u2219 1 medium yellow onion\n\n\u2219 1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil", "title": "A Cultural Compendium of What\u2019s New", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "But amid all of that is the puzzle of curling, a sport that Canada used to own at the Olympics. The women\u2019s team, led by Rachel Homan, a native of Ottawa who now lives in St. Paul, Alberta, didn\u2019t make the playoffs. Then on Friday, the men, skipped by Edmonton\u2019s Kevin Koe, lost the bronze medal game to Switzerland.\n\nThe only curling bright spot was the gold medal performance of John Morris and Kaitlyn Lawes in mixed doubles. That event made its Olympic debut in Pyeongchang and many curling purists aren\u2019t completely sold on it.\n\nScott Cacciola, my colleague from Sports who is covering curling at the Games, dug deep into Canada\u2019s curling debacle.", "title": "A Curling Collapse Amid Olympic Success: The Canada Letter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "On Wednesday afternoon, for the first time in years, \u201cThat\u2019s All, Brother\u201d took to the skies.\n\nThe aircraft, a C-47 military transport plane, was the leader of the formation that dropped thousands of American paratroopers into Normandy on June 6, 1944, or D-Day, paving the way for the liberation of northern France from Nazi Germany.\n\nIn the decades since, the plane cycled through a series of private owners and eventually landed in an aircraft bone yard in Oshkosh, Wis. Its historical significance was in danger of being forgotten.\n\nWith the help of two Alabama historians and a little bit of luck, the Commemorative Air Force, an organization based in Dallas that collects and restores historical aircraft for flight, bought \u201cThat\u2019s All, Brother\u201d in 2015 and began a restoration with help from the technicians at Basler Turbo Conversions. (Theirs was the bone yard where the plane had been found.)", "title": "A D-Day Plane Is Flying Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "DZONGSAR MONASTERY, China \u2014 The monks, dressed in crimson robes and wielding blue plastic swords, were rehearsing a dance they would perform the next day in celebration of the Tibetan New Year. Then a uniformed police officer appeared in the temple and said there were a few questions to answer.\n\nSo began nearly 17 hours in police custody for me and a French photographer, Gilles Sabri\u00e9, a long though not uncommon experience for foreign correspondents in China. It was hardly an ordeal, to be clear; journalists face far worse threats and abuse in China and elsewhere. It was, rather, a bother.\n\nFor the Chinese, though, it was a self-inflicted embarrassment. We had traveled high into the mountains of the Tibetan plateau last week to write about holiday traditions in that part of China. By detaining us, and ultimately expelling us from the region, the authorities succeeded in preventing that. So I am writing this instead.\n\nChina is a country that exudes confidence in its rising place on the world stage \u2014 and yet its officials belie that confidence with their hypersensitivity to what a foreign correspondent might encounter traveling untethered, and thus uncensored.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJournalists in China are, as a result, alternately ignored and followed. They are harassed, detained and even assaulted, according to the latest survey by the Foreign Correspondents\u2019 Club of China, an organization not recognized by the government.", "title": "A Dance for Tibetan New Year, Then 17 Hours in Custody", "authors": ["Steven Lee Myers"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Even though movement from the West Bank is restricted by a security barrier, a few terrorists even now manage to enter Israel. With Area C annexed, identifying the few bad guys seeking to kill Israelis among the 300,000 new Palestinian Israelis from Area C (who would have unfettered access to Israel) would be difficult and costly.\n\nThe physical barriers required to prevent residents of Areas A and B from filtering into Area C en route to Israel would be a security nightmare. The perimeter of each of the 169 Palestinian islands would have to be treated as an international border. To separate the annexed land from the islands it encircles, 1,200 miles of new barriers would be required, along with hundreds of security gates that would allow controlled Palestinian movement from one enclave to another or from their enclaves to land of theirs in Area C (where 75 percent of the land is owned by Palestinians). The cost of building such a barrier system would be about $10 billion, and constructing the gates, along with associated security measures, would cost far more.\n\nPalestinians would view Israeli annexation as a game-changer, foreclosing the option of a viable Palestinian state. The Palestinian Authority would collapse, and Israel would have to impose martial law and provide basic services to all Palestinians in the West Bank. Defense Minister Avigdor Lieberman has estimated the annual cost of social security alone for Palestinians at $6 billion. The yearly cost of health, education and other government services could be $5 billion more.\n\nWith the collapse of the Palestinian Authority, Palestinian-Israeli security coordination would vanish. Many of the Palestinian troops would turn their weapons on Israelis, and the Palestinian street would most likely explode. This would leave Israel\u2019s military and its domestic security agency, Shin Bet, to take full security responsibility not just in the newly annexed Area C, but also for the millions of Palestinians in Areas A and B, where Palestinian security agencies now operate in close coordination with the Israel Defense Forces.\n\nThis, in turn, would necessitate an increase in the I.D.F.\u2019s presence throughout the West Bank; the standing army could not do the job alone and a mobilization of reserves would be required. This, too, would tax the Israeli economy and severely diminish military preparedness for other security threats, most directly from Syria, where Iran seeks to establish a presence, and Lebanon, where Hezbollah has become more experienced at combat.\n\nArab governments might not be able to ignore potentially violent domestic expressions of outrage at Israel\u2019s actions. Accordingly, Israel\u2019s diplomatic and security relationships with Egypt and Jordan might not survive, and chances for additional relationships would vanish.\n\nIsrael\u2019s relationship with the American Jewish community would also be jeopardized, with annexation attempts further alienating large numbers of American Jews and accelerating the alarming trend of Jewish youth distancing themselves from Israel \u2014 a trend that undermines a major pillar of Israel\u2019s long-term national security.\n\nAnd not only Israel would suffer. All of this would come back to haunt the Trump administration, by undermining its efforts to forge an American-led regional coalition harnessing the resources of Israel and moderate Arab states to check Iran\u2019s hegemonic ambitions \u2014 a goal that serves the strategic interests of all.", "title": "Opinion | A Dangerous Course Israel Should Avoid", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "It fell to Mr. Rubio, as the lone Republican senator at the town hall \u2014 and one highly rated by the N.R.A. \u2014 to grimly take much of the scolding. It wasn\u2019t just a conflict between liberalism and conservatism, it was a clash between the established dogma of the gun debate and a newly engaged, enraged audience.\n\nOne exchange in particular summed up this disconnect. Mr. Rubio was challenged by Mr. Guttenberg, who seemed to support a ban on weapons like the AR-15 that the shooter killed his daughter with. The problem, Mr. Rubio said, was that in order to eliminate every weapon with that sort of capability, \u201cYou would literally have to ban every semiautomatic rifle that\u2019s sold in America.\u201d\n\nThe crowd cheered, which did not seem to be the effect Mr. Rubio desired.\n\nMr. Rubio, after years of political argument, may have assumed that his answer was sufficient: You can\u2019t ban that many guns because \u2014 well, you just can\u2019t. Everybody knows it. It has been deemed outside the universe of practical solutions.\n\nSuddenly, Mr. Rubio\u2019s rehearsed comebacks wilted like a wizard\u2019s magic wand that had been transformed into a noodle. Pressed on whether he would reject campaign donations from the N.R.A., he kept repeating, \u201cThey buy into my agenda,\u201d to no avail.\n\nBut Mr. Rubio did get praise from his Senate colleague, Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida (who received a friendlier reception), for showing up. Florida\u2019s governor, Rick Scott (a Republican), declined.\n\nAlso invited was President Trump, who instead counterprogrammed the CNN special with a \u201clistening session\u201d earlier in the day at the White House, for survivors and family members from Parkland and other shootings.", "title": "A Day of Raw Mourning and Rare Accountability on TV", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "THE AFTERLIVES\n\nBy Thomas Pierce\n\n384 pp. Riverhead Books. $27.\n\nIn Thomas Pierce\u2019s warm and inventive debut novel, \u201cThe Afterlives,\u201d reality is slippery, time is out of joint and profound disorientation is a feature of daily existence. In other words, pretty much how the world feels to a lot of us right now.\n\nThe narrator, Jim Byrd, is a 33-year-old loan officer who\u2019s already leading a liminal existence when the book opens. He\u2019s just woken up after a cardiac arrest that left him clinically dead for several minutes, with no memory of the other side: \u201cNo lights, no tunnels, no angels.\u201d The doctors install in his chest a high-tech defibrillator called the HeartNet, whose accompanying smartphone app chimes whenever the device restarts his heart \u2014 a digital bell that tolls for him \u2014 and then send him home to Shula, N.C.\n\nPierce renders Jim\u2019s hometown with a gloss of Phildickian satire. There is a \u201cboutique virus\u201d one can have injected into one\u2019s eyes to change their color, condoms that turn green when they detect disease and free-range holograms, all of which make Jim wonder if he\u2019s \u201cbeen brought back to life on the wrong planet.\u201d When he runs into Annie, his high school sweetheart who has moved back to town with her 12-year-old daughter, he confesses, \u201cSometimes I feel like maybe I\u2019ve had a brain injury and didn\u2019t realize it.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nThose holograms aren\u2019t the only ghostly presences in the novel. Annie\u2019s a recent widow, and her dead husband is never far out of mind as Jim and Annie fall in love and eventually marry. And then one day Jim hears a tape of a disembodied voice recorded in a nearby house, which leads to more supernatural experiences, including one that involves Jim\u2019s conspiracy-loving father. Jim begins following the writings of Sally Zinker, a physicist whose \u201cdaisy theory\u201d \u2014 a lovely bit of rubber science that Pierce previously used in a story from his fine collection, \u201cHall of Small Mammals\u201d \u2014 may explain the apparitions. At any given moment, Zinker explains, \u201cthe universe only 93 percent existed. You only 93 percent existed.\u201d", "title": "A Debut Novel Traces the Boundary Between Life and Death", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDAPHNE\n\nBy Will Boast\n\n266 pp. Liveright Publishing. $25.95\n\nMidway through Will Boast\u2019s debut novel, \u201cDaphne,\u201d I had to take a quick break to Google \u201cfainting goats.\u201d O.K., they\u2019re adorable, and, if they get spooked, they stiffen and fall over, flat as a board. Daphne, the novel\u2019s heroine, also experiences these spells when she\u2019s startled. In fact, Daphne has troubles when she feels any emotion, be it love, ecstasy, horror, gaiety or anger. Her head lolls and her knees buckle. She goes bum over teacup. The condition is debilitating, and thus Daphne has had to arrange her life incorporating many fail-safes. First off, she dulls her emotions by drinking \u2014 a lot. She hardly ever drives. She belongs to a support group for similarly afflicted people, and she\u2019s adopted a \u201cgrinding, deadening\u201d routine \u2014 work, home and Pit Stop, her neighborhood bar \u2014 that keeps her \u201csurviving.\u201d At home, Daphne\u2019s an expert cook, spends lots of time perusing an interior design publication and leaves NPR on low volume. \u201cPattern, repetition, small, comforting tasks \u2014 with the constant low buzz of stimuli, there just isn\u2019t time or space enough to really feel.\u201d Just like that, Boast seems to have captured today\u2019s cultural zeitgeist.\n\nPhoto\n\nDaphne\u2019s profession is also chosen to temper emotional responses. She works at the pharmaceutical laboratory MedEval, where she tests heart devices on, wait for it, dogs \u2014 adorable, lonely dogs with names like Biscuit. Where you or I might train our bodies at a gym, Daphne instead toughens up by watching a loop of heart-wrenching videos of global disasters and starving children on the internet. It\u2019s difficult to feel compassion for Daphne\u2019s condition given her brutal coping strategies.\n\nHowever, even the best-laid plans are no match for the heart. Daphne meets and falls in love with Ollie, a sensitive construction worker who pushes her outside her comfort zone. He takes Daphne for long walks in Golden Gate Park, to concerts inside enormous cement drainage pipes where, \u201cin the close, echoing confines, the notes seemed to sound directly in my ears,\u201d and on a particularly dangerous outing to a protest march. Watching Ollie and Daphne fall in love is both sweet and fraught. Their romance provides the novel\u2019s first opportunity for the reader to empathize with Daphne \u2014 love and sex are tricky for all of us. Her humanizing is not without its costs: She finds it harder to shut out a co-worker\u2019s worries over his ailing daughter, or the suffering of the dogs. A friend at her support group keeps arriving with bruises from his recent collapses. Daphne\u2019s concern about all of it begins to trigger her own episodes. Her plight is universal; risk losing control over one\u2019s own life by embracing human intimacy, or remain in the safe isolation of a hermetically sealed existence.\n\nThe novel is a loose retelling of Ovid\u2019s myth of Daphne and Apollo, in which the forest nymph prefers her freedom over the greedy love of the sun god. In the myth, as she flees Apollo, Daphne cries out to her father, the river god, to save her. Suddenly her legs stiffen, bark encircles her body and she turns into a laurel tree. Boast\u2019s own Daphne experiences a reverse evolution: As she comes to know Ollie, and to make timid forays into the politics and pain and tenderness of the world, she sheds her bark, her roots loosen. In the throes of new love, she thinks: \u201cSometimes I pray I could just stop dead in the middle of the street, in the middle of the day, and root myself fast in place. Then, almost immediately, I want him again.\u201d", "title": "A Debut Novel Upends the Myth of Apollo and Daphne", "authors": ["Natalie Serber", "Will Boast"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "NOVEL INSPIRATION: Maya, the main character in Samira Ahmed\u2019s debut, \u201cLove, Hate & Other Filters\u201d \u2014 which hit the young adult list two weeks ago and is still selling briskly \u2014 is a Muslim Indian-American teenager and budding documentary filmmaker struggling to balance her own dreams with the expectations of her immigrant parents. She also must confront some terrifying Islamophobia, just as Ahmed herself once did. \u201cMy first experience with Islamophobia was during the Iran hostage crisis,\u201d Ahmed says, describing how a man began hurling obscenities at her. \u201cI was a young child. I was stunned, truly frozen. I had never heard that kind of language, had never had that kind of hate directed at me. It was a shattering moment, an event that changed my worldview.\u201d She adds: \u201cThat is part of what I wanted to capture in \u2018Love, Hate & Other Filters\u2019 \u2014 that moment when a young person\u2019s life is shattered by an event that has nothing to do with them.\u201d Maya\u2019s main narrative is shot through with a secondary tale, an unfolding act of domestic terrorism. \u201cThat story was inspired by two very specific references,\u201d Ahmed explains, \u201cthe interstitial chapters in \u2018The Grapes of Wrath\u2019 in terms of craft and structure, and a line from \u2018In Cold Blood,\u2019 by Truman Capote: \u2018Presently, the car crept forward.\u2019 That inspired the tone, the tension I wanted to capture.\u201d\n\nDARK STAR: As you can tell from her novel, \u201cThe Hazel Wood,\u201d a fantasy that features a 17-year-old drifter and enters the young adult list at No. 3, Melissa Albert read a lot of fairy tales as a child. \u201cThe ones I loved best included \u2018The 12 Dancing Princesses,\u2019 which is the closest the classic fairy-tale canon comes to portal fantasy,\u201d she says. \u201cAlso \u2018The Juniper Tree,\u2019 which mixes up filicide, madness, cannibalism and revenge into fairy-tale Grand Guignol, and \u2018Beauty and the Beast,\u2019 which I love best in retellings that work at expunging the whiff of Stockholm syndrome from the romance.\u201d The frightening side of fairy tales always appealed to her: \u201cBeing afraid of a wicked queen or a robber bridegroom is delicious and distant, miles away from, say, watching a slasher flick.\u201d Albert says she was also influenced by Yeats. \u201cI took the book\u2019s title from the first, haunting line of Yeats\u2019s wonderful poem \u2018The Song of Wandering Aengus,\u2019 which is also my epigraph: \u2018I went out to the hazel wood, because a fire was in my head.\u2019 It\u2019s the name of the grand, isolated estate belonging to my heroine\u2019s grandmother, a self-mythologizing author of dark fairy tales.\u201d", "title": "A Debut Novelist Takes On Islamophobia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think the situation is untenable, and that there has to be a solution now, not later,\u201d Ms. Taylor said of Mr. Assange. \u201cHe\u2019s at risk of an ongoing prosecution by the United States.\u201d\n\nRecently, Ms. Taylor tried to bolster the case for Mr. Assange\u2019s release by writing a brief for the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, which is expected to issue a ruling, at the behest of Ecuador, in the coming months.\n\nMs. Taylor was among a group of attorneys who represented Mr. Assange at a 2016 hearing before a United Nations human rights panel, which ruled that he had been arbitrarily detained in violation of international law.\n\nBorn in Brisbane, Australia, Ms. Taylor studied law at the University of Queensland, graduating in 1997.\n\nSoon after finishing there, while backpacking through Europe at the age of 22, she learned she had landed a coveted internship with Antonio Cassese, an Italian lawyer who was the first president of the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. Ms. Taylor had read Mr. Cassese\u2019s speeches as a student.\n\nCarrying only a backpack filled with shabby clothes, Ms. Taylor asked her father to mail her something she could wear to her first job in The Hague. \u201cThey were completely inappropriate,\u201d she said, recalling those outfits.\n\nPhoto\n\nSpeaking from her home in The Hague, Ms. Taylor said she was drawn to defense work because it was essential to maintaining rights for everyone.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTo have justice, it\u2019s two sides of the coin,\u201d she said. \u201cYou need defense. You can vindicate rights for someone when no one else might want to vindicate rights for them.\u201d\n\nNo willing client should be denied a defense, she said, no matter how horrendous his crimes. \u201cThey\u2019re the ones I think you should take. I would never not defend someone because of who they are.\u201d\n\nIn June 2012, those principles were tested when she represented Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, who was accused of war crimes \u2014 a decision that led to her incarceration in a Libyan military facility.\n\nWhile conducting interviews with Mr. Qaddafi, after the coup that resulted in his father\u2019s ouster and death, Ms. Taylor and three of her colleagues were arrested by Libyan security forces.\n\nThe Libyans accused Ms. Taylor of carrying coded messages to her client and claimed she had used a \u201cspy pen\u201d with an embedded camera when meeting with him.\n\nIt was the first time lawyers working for the International Criminal Court, who have immunity from arrest, had been detained.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAt the beginning, it was incredibly frightening,\u201d Ms. Taylor recalled, \u201cbut it was also the kind of thing you think, \u2018Oh, this will just be over in an hour.\u2019\u201d\n\nInstead, her detention lasted 26 days. Unbeknown to Ms. Taylor and her colleagues, representatives from Australia and the International Criminal Court and lawyers from around the world were campaigning for their release.\n\n\u201cIt was a great shock,\u201d said Anthony Cassimatis, a law professor at the University of Queensland who had taught Ms. Taylor 15 years earlier. \u201cShe felt very strongly that he was entitled to a fair trial. I think she would do it again, in terms of ensuring that he was given appropriate defense protection.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe detained lawyers were each allowed a single five-minute phone call. Ms. Taylor spoke with her husband, Geoff Roberts, who is also a lawyer in The Hague, and her daughter, who was 2 years old at the time.\n\n\u201cNothing in my legal training had readied me for it,\u201d she said of her arrest, adding that the experience had made her more sympathetic to detainees.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think, until you\u2019ve been in detention, you can appreciate what it\u2019s like. You have no ability to know what\u2019s happening \u2014 those four walls control your life.\u201d\n\nSafely back in the Netherlands, Ms. Taylor took a single day to acclimate before returning to work. Two years later, she was offered a meeting in London with another Australian: Mr. Assange.\n\nThe pair met at the Ecuadorean Embassy for two hours.\n\n\u201cIt was quite surreal, actually, to compare our experiences,\u201d she said.\n\nIn the years since that first meeting, Ms. Taylor has seen Mr. Assange\u2019s public standing change. Many who once saw him as a champion of liberal transparency now consider him a lawless partisan who enabled Russian meddling in the 2016 United States presidential election on Donald J. Trump\u2019s behalf.\n\nThough she has represented only Mr. Assange, not WikiLeaks, Ms. Taylor defended the organization\u2019s decision to publish the emails of John Podesta, Hillary Clinton\u2019s campaign chairman, at a key point in the race.\n\n\u201cWikiLeaks was not seeking to put someone in power. WikiLeaks was seeking to empower people to make informed choices,\u201d Ms. Taylor said. \u201cHow can you hold your politicians to account unless you know their views?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe leaked emails published by WikiLeaks, like the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape of Mr. Trump\u2019s crude remarks published by The Washington Post and Mr. Trump\u2019s leaked tax return obtained by The New York Times, demonstrate the importance of transparency, Ms. Taylor said.\n\n\u201cWhen liberals criticize WikiLeaks, they\u2019re not looking at the bigger picture. WikiLeaks has actually given birth to this idea that this information should come out, that we should hold people to account,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen you look at something like the #MeToo campaign, it\u2019s a similar idea \u2014 the system was broken. WikiLeaks has encouraged a process.\u201d\n\nAsked how, as a feminist, she could defend Mr. Assange, a man who has been accused of rape and frequently called a misogynist, Ms. Taylor implied that the question was itself misogynistic.\n\n\u201cThat seems to have an implicit assumption that women can\u2019t be defense counsel,\u201d she said. \u201cThat we can\u2019t make impartial choices about representation issues, that we can\u2019t see issues of process. I would have an issue with that.\u201d She added that she believed that Mr. Assange\u2019s accusers had a right to be heard.\n\n\u201cAs a female, I think women should be able to do whatever we want to do,\u201d Ms. Taylor said. \u201cI\u2019m passionate about fair trial, and I\u2019m passionate about female rights.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd I can reconcile the two,\u201d she added, \u201cbecause I don\u2019t have to choose.\u201d", "title": "A Defender of Assange Says She\u2019s Fighting for All", "authors": ["Adam Baidawi"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "This is what you\u2019re up against, this is what\u2019s coming, the instructor says.\n\nExcept it isn\u2019t. The job is often boring, chasing footprints, staring at monitors, shuffling paper. \u201cYou don\u2019t want to bring in any bodies with your dope if you can help it,\u201d Cant\u00fa is told. \u201cSuspects mean you have a smuggling case on your hands, and that\u2019s a hell of a lot of paperwork.\u201d The aliens we encounter are not narco bosses and murderous kidnappers but their victims: bewildered, disoriented, helpless migrants. Some are dead. They don\u2019t fit the terror profile.\n\nA weeping woman tells the agents arresting her that it\u2019s her 23rd birthday. She wants to be like Selena, and sings \u201cBidi Bidi Bom Bom\u201d on her way to detention. A man found in the fetal position has been drinking his urine for four days. A fat teenager lies sobbing in a mesquite thicket; the group left him behind.\n\nEach migrant has a wrenching story, but to agents these are just \u201cwets,\u201d or \u201cPOWs,\u201d \u201cplain old wets.\u201d Salvadorans are \u201cel sals.\u201d \u201cQuitters\u201d are just that. Cant\u00fa finds two of them huddling in a church, a man and a woman. They had been lost for days, surviving on filthy water from cattle tanks. She is six months pregnant. Cant\u00fa gives them water bottles and asks their names, which he soon forgets.\n\nIn case you think compassion is the rule, Cant\u00fa makes a confession.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s true that we slash their bottles and drain their water into the dry earth, that we dump their backpacks and pile their food and clothes to be crushed and pissed on and stepped over, strewn across the desert and set ablaze. And Christ, it sounds terrible, and maybe it is.\u201d\n\nMaybe?\n\n\u201cBut the idea is that when they come out from their hiding places, when they regroup and return to find their stockpiles ransacked and stripped, they\u2019ll realize their situation,\u201d he adds, is hopeless. \u201dAnd they\u2019ll quit right then and there, they\u2019ll save themselves.\u201d That, says Cant\u00fa, is \u201cthe sense in it all.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRobbing migrants of water in 115-degree Sonoran heat to save them sounds like exquisitely tortured rationalizing. Recent news accounts and videos of agents destroying water caches suggest that Cant\u00fa\u2019s account is accurate, though the Border Patrol has also said it does not condone life-threatening vandalism. So whose logic governs? Who is lying, who has gone rogue \u2014 Cant\u00fa and his buddies, or the agency itself?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLater Cant\u00fa tips us to a secret he couldn\u2019t tell his own family \u2014 that he and his brother agents ran like a mob of teenage vandals:\n\n\u201cI wanted to tell my uncle that I had known men to engage in senseless acts of defilement, depositing car seats and furniture on far-off hillsides and in remote washes, decorating cacti with women\u2019s undergarments, hanging twisted bike frames from the towering arms of saguaros, dislodging massive boulders to tumble down sloping mountainsides, and setting fire to anything that would burn \u2014 abandoned automobiles and trash piles and proud desert plants left to smoke and smolder through the night.\u201d\n\nThey sound like poorly trained men with not enough to do. Yet this is a glancing admission, slipped passively into the narrative without elaboration. Cant\u00fa recounts moments of tender connection with frightened, injured border crossers. But he seems unwilling to look too closely at his complicity in despicable behavior, leaving a reader to worry about the fate of that close-up quest for enlightenment he told his mother he was after.\n\nWe surmise early on that Cant\u00fa, his psyche under strain, is not long for the job. He loses sleep, he grinds his teeth, he has bad dreams about wolves.\n\nThen the book shifts abruptly. Cant\u00fa leaves the agency. Now he\u2019s a barista and studying for a master\u2019s degree. But here, finally, he takes us deep into a border story \u2014 that of his new friend Jos\u00e9, 30 years in the United States, nabbed by the Border Patrol after returning from Mexico, where he had gone to see his dying mother. The last third of the book, as Jos\u00e9 and his family desperately fight his deportation, with Cant\u00fa\u2019s considerable help, makes a useful contribution to the literature of today\u2019s border. It lays bare, in damning light, the casual brutality of the system, how unjust laws and private prisons and a militarized border have shattered families and mocked America\u2019s myths about itself.\n\n\u201cWe mostly arrested the little people,\u201d Cant\u00fa tells Jos\u00e9. \u201cSmugglers, scouts, mules, coyotes. But mostly I arrested migrants, I confessed. People looking for a better life.\u201d He should have listened to his mother.", "title": "A Different Perspective on the Border", "authors": ["Lawrence Downes", "Francisco Cant\u00fa"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Women\u2019s rights advocates have long warned that male supervisors exploit the country\u2019s command-and-compliance work culture, where an employee\u2019s personal relationship with her bosses often determines her chances for promotion.\n\nMr. Lee\u2019s admission on Monday attested to the lasting nature of the problem. \u201cThis is a very bad thing that has been happening customarily for the past 18 years,\u201d he said.\n\nSouth Korea has made strides on women\u2019s rights in recent years, as more women have moved into the government, judiciary and corporate world. Long gone are the days when women in a Korean family were not allowed to eat at the same table as men or had to wait until men were finished. Government agencies and big corporations have instituted mandatory classes on harassment in recent years.\n\nStill, in this deeply patriarchal society, sons in many families still get the lion\u2019s shares of inheritances from parents, and in workplaces, women are often treated like temporary employees expected to quit once they marry.\n\nThe World Economic Forum ranks the country 118th of 144 in terms of gender equality. Men earn 37 percent more than women on average, a gap in wages that puts South Korea at the bottom of member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. (The gap is 18 percent in the United States and 26 percent in Japan.)\n\nAs elsewhere, sexual abuse victims often remain quiet for fear of losing their jobs or being ostracized in the workplace. In 2009, a young actress named Jang Ja-yeon committed suicide, leaving behind a handwritten note saying she had been forced to provide sexual favors to entertainment executives.\n\nBut as the #MeToo movement has erupted around the world, complaints in South Korea have trickled out. In November, a 25-year-old employee of the furniture maker Hanssem posted a detailed account of being sexually assaulted by male colleagues. In another episode, nurses at Hallym University Medical Center in Anyang, south of Seoul, said they were told to dance in skimpy outfits at work-related events.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA broader outcry and lasting reforms, however, have been slow to materialize. A tipping point appears to have come last month when a prosecutor named Seo Ji-hyeon asserted that a senior male prosecutor groped her at a funeral in 2010.\n\nWriting in an internal web log for prosecutors, she said she had been so deeply traumatized that she had a miscarriage.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI wanted to speak out but many discouraged me, saying: \u2018It will be a piece of cake for them to turn you into a fool. If you speak up now, they will make you look like an inefficient, problematic, weirdo prosecutor,\u2019 \u201d she wrote in her posting. \u201cThey said, \u2018Keep your mouth shut and go back to your work.\u2019 \u201d\n\nAfter taking the rare step of appearing on TV to describe how she had been suppressed in the male-dominated legal world, Ms. Seo drew a wave of public support, forcing the Justice Ministry to open an investigation. Other women, including graduate school students and corporate employees, have since come forward with their own stories of sexual assault.\n\nIn this newly open environment, news outlets have resurfaced a poem published last fall about an unidentified literary giant, accused of serially groping young women.\n\nIn \u201cThe Beast,\u201d the poet Choi Young-mi did not name her subject, but the media quickly singled out Ko Un, a South Korean poet often cited as a candidate for the Nobel Prize in Literature.\n\nKim Myoung-in, the editor of the magazine that published Ms. Choi\u2019s poem, lamented, \u201cI myself cannot avoid the accusation that I aided and abetted because I had never tried to stop it.\u201d In a Facebook post, he said that female writers were often sexually harassed by senior writers and publishing executives and that Mr. Ko\u2019s pattern had been well known for decades.\n\nMr. Ko has not commented publicly on the accusations, but the new attention to male behavior seems to suggest that a wall of silence in South Korea is being eroded.\n\nMs. Seo, the prosecutor whose case set off the #MeToo wave here, said that after she first sought an investigation, she was transferred to an obscure post in a provincial town. She spoke up publicly after the senior prosecutor she accused, Ahn Tae-geun, was fired last year in a corruption scandal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Ahn told reporters, \u201cIt happened so long ago, and I was heavily drunk, so I don\u2019t remember, but if such an act happened, then I sincerely apologize.\u201d\n\nIn November, Parliament improved protections for victims of sexual harassment, increasing penalties for employers who discriminate against them or fail to investigate abuse.\n\nStill, a fresh reminder of the obstacles victims have faced in South Korea came only minutes before Mr. Lee held his news conference on Monday.\n\nIn a Facebook post, another former actress, Lee Seung-bi, wrote that she had been subjected to a \u201cwitch hunt\u201d after she rebuffed Mr. Lee.\n\n\u201cEven my boyfriend, who was a member of his theater group, kept silent,\u201d she wrote.", "title": "A Director\u2019s Apology Adds Momentum to South Korea\u2019s #MeToo Movement", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Gene Sharp died last week. What Sun Tzu and Clausewitz were to war, Sharp, who was 90, was to nonviolent struggle \u2014 strategist, philosopher, guru. An American academic who worked from his modest Boston home, Sharp studied and cataloged examples of nonviolent resistance, looking at why they succeeded or failed.\n\nHis most influential work was \u201cFrom Dictatorship to Democracy,\u201d a pamphlet written for Burma\u2019s opposition in 1993. It has been translated into dozens of languages \u2014 often clandestinely \u2014 and became a handbook for civic resistance movements around the world. (Much of Sharp\u2019s writing is available free on the website of his organization, the Albert Einstein Institute.)\n\nSharp is best known as a strategist for movements in the most dire circumstances \u2014 those trying to create political change when there is no institutional path. But his ideas have shaped civic protest movements in the United States and other democracies, and they contain some surprising advice for the resistance to President Trump.\n\nFirst, here\u2019s a brief summary of what Sharp taught the world:\n\nNonviolence is usually the most effective strategy for winning power.\n\nWhen Sharp began studying the history of nonviolence, it was seen \u2014 and dismissed \u2014 as a tactic used by saints and pacifists: sitting in front of bulldozers, appealing to the consciences of men with none.", "title": "Opinion | A Dissenter\u2019s Legacy: How to Win Without Violence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Could I fire her as my patient? I went to see the chief of my training program. He offered to help, but there was little that he could do; part of our work, he said, was to deal with \u201cdifficult patients.\u201d\n\nOver the next six months, I received hundreds of pages, phone calls, threats and entreaties from S. I tried prescribing methadone through a hospital program. It helped \u2014 it would turn out to be the only thing that helped \u2014 but she refused to continue the program. I referred her to a psychiatrist. I read books on headaches, on addiction, migraines, malingering, the ethics of abandoning the ill and the breakdown of a doctor-patient relationship. Late one night that fall, one of the E.R.s in the city paged me. S. had come in with a headache. By the time I spoke on the phone with the doctors, they had discharged her with a handful of Vicodins. A week later, she was in a walk-in clinic in northern Boston. Fed up with her yelling in the clinic, they had sent her home with a week\u2019s cache of Percocets.\n\nI\u2019m not writing this to expiate the guilt of doctors or excuse my complicity but as a testimony of the 12-odd months of mutual assured destruction that characterized my first encounter with addiction. We had no training in this kind of medicine. If the addict was helpless, then so, too, was the young physician: To try to treat addiction was to discover an inverted form of doctoring, in which the patient and doctor turned into wary, suspicious aliens circling and jabbing at each other. Medicine depends implicitly on a therapeutic alliance between a doctor and a patient, but addiction, I learned, distorts that alliance. The doctor shifts from healer to dealer. To the addict, the doctor is contorting the truth; to the doctor, it\u2019s the addict who is constantly inverting reality. The doctor is, at first, the enabler and the supplier, and then the tormentor, the withholder, the liar, the enemy. Perhaps the reason that the methadone clinic had worked for S., albeit fleetingly, I realized, was not only because of the drug\u2019s pharmacological effect but also because the clinic had forcibly re-established the alliance: There was, at least, a transactional transparency in what she was giving and getting. Rather than trying to fix her, here, at last, was a doctor who would willingly give her a fix.\n\nA few months ago, I was a visiting professor at the hospital in Boston where I first met S. I skipped the usual tradition of delivering a long, didactic lecture and joined the interns on their medical rounds. Every one of their medical practices, I learned, had an addicted patient. The residents now possessed the vocabulary and skills that I had lacked. They had learned the street slang for the drugs; they understood how to navigate some of the legal dilemmas of treatment and relapse. Some had visited methadone clinics in Boston, and they had memorized the complications of co-dosing with molly and China white. But many of them seemed to be reliving the fundamental uncertainties that I encountered 16 years before: How do you establish an alliance with a patient when the relationship is scarred by suspicion and mistrust? It was reassuring, yes, to see them trying to understand the impulses that drove an addict. But I wondered whether we also needed to understand the impulses that drive a doctor\u2019s relationship with an addicted patient: the failure of our credibility, our bizarre circumlocutions, our helplessness, the chronic relapses into self-doubt and disappointment. It was as if they had seen a fragment of a torn map, or solved only half of a puzzle.\n\nSometime in the fall of 2002, S. vanished. The pages stopped; the scheduled appointments were missed. I tried to call her at home; the phone rang insistently, as her pages had, but there was no response. Perhaps she had moved to another city, or found another doctor. I never saw her again. In 2006, I heard that she had died of an overdose. I\u2019m still trying to figure out how I might have treated her differently.", "title": "A Doctor\u2019s Painful Struggle With an Opioid-Addicted Patient", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe right-wing United Kingdom Independence Party voted 867 to 500 to oust its leader, Henry Bolton, in a vote of no-confidence on Saturday, making him the fourth party leader to step down in the space of 18 months.\n\nThe party, which put its stamp on history by goading a reluctant prime minister into calling for a referendum to leave the European Union, has since drifted to the ideological fringes, struggling to cope with debts and a fractious membership.\n\nMr. Bolton, a married former army officer, was brought down by a matter of the heart.\n\nIn January, he was badly damaged by revelations that his girlfriend, Jo Marney, had used racist language to deride the actress Meghan Markle, who will marry Prince Harry this spring.\n\nIn text messages to a friend that were published by The Mail on Sunday, a tabloid, Ms. Marney expressed her distaste for interracial marriage, saying Ms. Markle\u2019s \u201cseed\u201d would \u201ctaint our royal family\u201d and lead to a \u201cblack king.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough Mr. Bolton swiftly announced the end of their affair, he continued to defend Ms. Marney, and told a radio announcer this past week that he might give her a card for Valentine\u2019s Day.", "title": "A Drifting UKIP Ousts Leader at Center of Racism Row", "authors": ["Ellen Barry"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "On Monday morning, Doug Schifter, a livery driver in his early 60s, killed himself with a shotgun in front of City Hall in Lower Manhattan, having written a lengthy Facebook post several hours earlier laying out the structural cruelties that had left him in such dire circumstance. He was now sometimes forced to work more than 100 hours a week to survive, he said; when he had started out in the 1980s, a 40-hour week was fairly typical. He blamed politicians \u2014 mayors Michael R. Bloomberg and Bill de Blasio, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo \u2014 and their acquiescence to the rich for permitting so many cars to flood the streets. He blamed the Taxi Commission for the fines and hassles it imposed.\n\nHe had lost his health insurance and accrued credit card debt and he would no longer work for \u201cchump change,\u2019\u2019 preferring, he said, to die in the hope that his sacrifice would draw attention to what drivers, too often unable to feed their families now, were enduring. He had forecast all of this doom in columns he had written for a trade publication called Black Car News, he wrote, but few had listened to him.\n\nImplicit in his testament was the anger he felt over the de-professionalization of his life\u2019s work. Mr. Schifter had driven more than five million miles throughout his tenure, through five hurricanes and 50 snowstorms. He had chauffeured celebrities and worn a suit. He was not driving a car to supplement the income he was getting from his crepe business and he was not trying to make a little extra money for a gym membership. He was not a participant in the gig economy; he was a casualty of it.\n\nFor at least a century, the suicide as spectacle, prompted by a reversal of fortune, has typically been the practice of the wealthy. In the months after Wall Street\u2019s crash in 1929, four people threw themselves out windows in New York (leading to the folklore that there had been many, many more such deaths). Decades later, Bernie Madoff\u2019s son Mark hanged himself from a dog leash in his SoHo apartment. In 2016, Sanjay Valvani, a hedge fund manager accused of insider trading, slashed his throat in the bedroom of his Brooklyn townhouse, to much sensation in the tabloid and financial press. Poverty too often kills you without making you try.\n\nIn response to Mr. Schifter\u2019s death, Mayor de Blasio showed little sensitivity to the psychic harms of economic deprivation. \u201cLet\u2019s face it, for someone to commit suicide there\u2019s an underlying mental health challenge,\u201d he said. His asking price: $175 million.\n\nSo when the I.R.S. agents \u2014 who posed as Russian mobsters interested in buying Mr. Rafael\u2019s business \u2014 came along, Mr. Rafael was quick to talk to them.\n\nExplaining why his business was worth even more than it might appear to on paper, Mr. Rafael laid out all that he had done to misreport what fish he was catching. At points, he seemed to worry that he might be getting set up. \u201cYou could be the I.R.S. in here,\u201d Mr. Rafael said in one recorded conversation, though he swiftly dismissed the idea, noting that he didn\u2019t think the I.R.S. employed Russians. \u201cThat would be some bad luck!\u201d\n\nLast year, in a case that married international financial crime with flaky fish fillets, he pleaded guilty to conspiracy, tax evasion, bulk cash smuggling, false labeling and falsifying records. In September, he was sentenced to about four years in prison as he stood before a courtroom packed with fishermen who had worked for him.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI did it because I wanted to make sure my people kept getting a paycheck,\u201d Mr. Rafael wrote in a statement read by his lawyer. \u201cThe waterfront is a hard world we work in.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe judge, William Young, of the Massachusetts U.S. District Court, seemed unmoved. \u201cThis was not stupid,\u201d the judge said, \u201cthis was corrupt.\u201d\n\nMr. Rafael\u2019s lawyer, William Kettlewell, did not respond to messages seeking comment.\n\nMr. Rafael\u2019s punishment was cheered by environmentalists, regulators, and fishermen up and down the coast who saw him as having muscled out smaller boats and having marred the whole region. The case also raised questions about the effectiveness of a regulatory system that allowed one man to become so dominant and to skirt the rules for so long.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. He said he had banned ground fishing in Mr. Rafael\u2019s sector through at least the beginning of the next fishing season in May because the industry there had failed to accurately report its catches and stay within fishing limits. \u201cThey have a very basic job to do, to count fish, and they didn\u2019t do it,\u201d said Mr. Bullard, who is also a former mayor of New Bedford.\n\nThe future of Mr. Rafael\u2019s empire is a matter of intense debate. Federal authorities have seized some of his boats and fishing permits, and they are seeking to revoke more permits in a civil action that also asserts misreporting in Mr. Rafael\u2019s scallop fleet.\n\nFishermen in other ports hope Mr. Rafael\u2019s permits will be transferred to their areas, while fishermen in New Bedford are fighting to keep them local. Some boat captains worry that they may face scrutiny, even though they say they had no part in Mr. Rafael\u2019s crimes.\n\n(Mr. Rafael told the undercover agents that the captains knew of his schemes; Mr. Lelling, the prosecutor, said a decision was made to go after Mr. Rafael, and not the fishermen working for him.)", "title": "A Famed Fishing Port Shudders as Its Codfather Goes to Jail", "authors": ["Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "It was one of the more striking responses from the news media to Wednesday\u2019s killings at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., an attack that quickly revived the national debate over restricting access to guns, and why politicians have taken few steps to do so.\n\nThe shift by The Post, among the friendlier news organizations toward Mr. Trump, was seen by proponents of gun control as a potentially favorable development.\n\nIn October, after a gunman killed dozens of people at a concert in Las Vegas, the paper editorialized that a 1990s-era assault weapon ban was merely \u201ccosmetic,\u201d and noted that mass shootings accounted \u201cfor a fraction\u201d of domestic firearm-related deaths.\n\nIn Friday\u2019s paper, The Post devoted two full pages to an editorial that called for, among other gun-control measures, the reinstatement of the 1994 federal ban on various assault weapons, which expired in 2004. \u201cMr. President, this is your moment,\u201d the paper wrote, urging Mr. Trump to \u201cprove how much you truly want to curb the carnage.\u201d\n\nAnother Murdoch-owned outlet, however, showed no sign of championing gun control measures.\n\nFoxNews.com published a tough critique of other networks\u2019 coverage of the shootings, noting that the major network newscasts cited a statistic from an anti-gun group, Everytown for Gun Safety, that 18 school shootings had occurred this year. As other outlets, including The Washington Post, have pointed out, that statistic included a suicide at a closed school and an incident when gunshots were fired in a high school parking lot but no one was injured.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe FoxNews.com story charged that news networks had \u201cheld up the statistic to slam America as the gun crime rampant hell-scape.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn fact, gun violence remains a significant challenge in American life; since the 2012 shooting at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn., at least 239 school shootings have occurred nationwide.\n\nStill, as so often occurs after major news events, false reports gained steam on social media \u2014 and in some major news outlets \u2014 before the authorities debunked them hours later.\n\nThe Associated Press, ABC News and even the neo-Nazi site Daily Stormer repeated a claim by a Florida white nationalist group that it had ties to the Parkland killer, Nikolas Cruz. Law enforcement officials later said they had no evidence linking Mr. Cruz to extremist groups. The initial claim was traced to online forums like 4chan, where commenters appeared to gloat about deceiving journalists.\n\nMore familiar divides among the news media also emerged.\n\nThe right-leaning Breitbart.com framed coverage of the shooting as a critique of the F.B.I., which Trump supporters have frequently derided as biased against the president. Breitbart took pains to suggest a seemingly damning contrast: the F.B.I.\u2019s fumbling of a tip about the Parkland shooter and the agency\u2019s work investigating allegations of collusion between Russians and Mr. Trump\u2019s presidential campaign.\n\nS.
