Grynbaum"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNational Sawdust, the performance space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, announced the winners of its first Hildegard Competition for rising female and non-binary composers. The winners, Emma O\u2019Halloran, X. Lee and Kayla Cashetta, will each receive $7,000, mentoring from prominent artists and a performance at National Sawdust on June 12.\n\nThe winners were selected from 140 submissions from around the world; the judges, all composers, were Paola Prestini, the co-founder and artistic director of National Sawdust; Du Yun, the winner of the 2017 Pulitzer Prize; and Ang\u00e9lica Negr\u00f3n. The judges, who will also serve as the winners\u2019 mentors, sought to reward composers at the start of their careers, prioritizing artists who had never received a large commission, released a commercial recording or composed for a professional ensemble.\n\n\u201cI am deeply moved by the volume of responses to the Hildegard Competition,\u201d Ms. Prestini said in a statement. \u201cThe future of composition is bright and the need for opportunity, vast.\u201d\n\nMs. Cashetta is based in the Bay Area; X. Lee, in Los Angeles; and Ms. O\u2019Halloran is Irish. On June 12, their works will be performed by the Refugee Orchestra, along with pieces by five runners-up.\n\nSince National Sawdust opened in 2015, it has been committed to presenting work by female composers and other underrepresented voices. Its current season includes fifteen female composers; a New York Philharmonic program there last month, for example, featured five works by women.", "title": "A Female and Non-Binary Composers\u2019 Competition Announces Its First Winners", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "LITTLE REUNIONS\n\nBy Eileen Chang\n\n332 pp. New York Review Books. Paper, $16.95.\n\n\u201cLittle Reunions\u201d follows Julie Sheng from her teenage years into adulthood as she navigates a series of, yes, reunions, with her various family members and lovers \u2014 all set against the backdrop of a tumultuous time in Chinese history, the Sino-Japanese War. Julie splits her time between Hong Kong, where she goes to school, and Shanghai, where she, her family and extended family reside. Later she meets Chih-yung, a charming but mysterious man who works for the Japanese regime during the occupation. They become lovers, despite the fact that Chih-yung is not only married to more than one woman, but also romantically involved with still others besides Julie. The protagonist spends the latter half of the novel waiting for Chih-yung to commit to her; however, even when he does, their marriage is doomed: After the Japanese defeat, Chih-yung is forced to flee to the countryside.\n\nWhile one might expect \u201cLittle Reunions\u201d to chart Julie and Chih-yung\u2019s affair and subsequent marriage, and then her later affair with Yen Shan, it does not. In fact, the novel resists tracing any one particular relationship in a focused way. Eileen Chang (1920-95) uses broad brush strokes to take the reader through decades of a crumbling family. At this time in Chinese history, the aristocracy is falling out of favor. Looming on the horizon a few decades ahead is the Cultural Revolution. Readers should expect an extensive cast and speedy transitions, and take stock of the character index, a helpful 10-page, alphabetized list of everyone in the novel. And, given these quick transitions, be prepared to jump from event to event; for example, from an intimate conversation between mother and daughter to a sudden bombing.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s exactly why I say we Chinese know nothing about romance and still never learn,\u201d says Julie\u2019s mother, Rachel, gloomily. \u201cWho would take a visitor at the gate straight to the inner chamber?\u201d\n\nImage\n\n\u201cWhen the bombing began, everyone said that the hotel staircase was the safest place. Julie sat on a step reading \u201cThe Story of a Noble Family,\u201d a popular novel that her cousins had borrowed. She was happy.\u201d", "title": "A Fictional Heroine\u2019s Fitful Upbringing Is Set Against the Sino-Japanese War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cI have Jessica Lange on the line. Please hold.\u201d\n\nI suppose I could pretend that I didn\u2019t experience a tiny thrill when I heard that, and a bigger one a few seconds later when that unmistakably smooth and smoky voice said, \u201cHello.\u201d Who am I kidding? I saw \u201cKing Kong\u201d when I was 10, and just about everything she has done since, and a critic is really nothing more than a fan with a dubious professional credential. In spite of what some people might imagine, it\u2019s not often that I find myself in conversation with great actors. The customs of The New York Times keep critics at a distance from the people we write about. I prefer it that way, too. I don\u2019t want my own sympathies \u2014 my desire to like and be liked \u2014 to get in the way of the rigor and impersonality of the job.\n\nBut I am always curious about their jobs. For Sunday\u2019s newly redesigned issue of T Magazine, its editors asked me to talk to a bunch of artists \u2014 three bunches in fact, including composers, film editors, actors, directors and theater producers \u2014 about their work. Specifically about the ways they work together, collaborating on successive projects in a fashion that recalls the traveling troupes of the olden days. The assignment gave me a chance to indulge that curiosity, while also staying away from the kinds of personal inquiries that make profile-writing my least favorite journalistic exercise. (Except as a reader.)\n\nSo I talked to Ms. Lange (along with Evan Peters, Sarah Paulson and Sterling K. Brown) about Ryan Murphy, whose \u201cAmerican Horror Story\u201d and \u201cAmerican Crime Story\u201d series are specimens of the modern troupe sensibility. I talked with John Leguizamo and Oscar Isaac about Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater in Lower Manhattan, and with Adam Driver and Greta Gerwig about Noah Baumbach, whose films include \u201cThe Squid and the Whale\u201d and, recently, \u201cThe Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected).\u201d\n\nBut I didn\u2019t talk to only well-known actors, and I wasn\u2019t looking for the usual quotes about what kind of \u201cjourney\u201d a particular project represented. I was after something more elusive, and a thing that might have been hard to capture over the phone: the logic of collaboration itself, the particular alchemy that endows a body of work with its own personality, one which is not just that of a single artist. The signatures of the director, the showrunner or the theater\u2019s boss may be on the shows and the films, and their authority and vision may keep the wheels turning, but what magnetizes the interest of audiences is not just a singular voice. It\u2019s a chorus finding new arrangements and harmonies each time it assembles. As a critic, you observe the patterns (and take note of the recurring names in the credits), but all you see is the finished product of efforts that remain fundamentally mysterious. It\u2019s intriguing to ask the magicians about their tricks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf course, all of them had much more to say than I could ever hope to fit into 2,000 words or so. Mr. Eustis treated me to a 40-minute lecture on three decades of American theatrical history that made me wish for another hour. Jeanine Tesori, who wrote the music for \u201cFun Home,\u201d sat with me for more than an hour in a noisy Manhattan restaurant patiently explaining how the musical took shape. Jen Lame, Mr. Baumbach\u2019s editor, in her ninth month of pregnancy, walked me through the Baumbach method from script to postproduction. And then I heard it again, a bit differently, from Mr. Baumbach himself.\n\nThe most challenging interview was with Ms. Gerwig, who has co-written three films with Mr. Baumbach, appeared in four and lives with him in New York. When we spoke on the phone, she was in Sacramento and I was in Rome. The time difference was ridiculous, time was tight, and I felt a little awkward about the fact that I had just filed my review of Ms. Gerwig\u2019s movie, \u201cLady Bird.\u201d I ducked into a doorway on a semi-quiet street and took notes by the light of a streetlamp, managing to record her perfect metaphor for creative collaboration, which I won\u2019t spoil by paraphrasing here.", "title": "A Film Critic\u2019s Fan Boy Comes Out to Play", "authors": ["A. O. Scott"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cMetropolitan Opera Fires John Copley\u201d (Arts pages, Feb. 2):\n\nI was deeply disturbed by the Metropolitan Opera\u2019s firing of John Copley, described as \u201cone of the opera world\u2019s foremost directors.\u201d I am not an opera fan, but I was dismayed to read that he was fired because \u201ca member of the chorus reported that Mr. Copley had made him uncomfortable at a rehearsal on Friday with a sexually charged remark.\u201d\n\nThere is no longer any doubt that our culture is in the grip of a moral panic the likes of which we haven\u2019t seen since the day care child abuse hysteria of the 1980s, and, before that, the congressional witch hunts to root out supposed Communists nearly 70 years ago.\n\nIn ordinary times, a possibly inappropriate remark at a rehearsal would have warranted, at most, advice from a superior that it not be repeated. But these are not ordinary times.\n\nAs quickly as you can say \u201cHarvey Weinstein,\u201d we have moved from an overdue cultural wake-up call about sexual predation to the frightening point where a comment or gesture, no matter how casual or innocent, can destroy a brilliant career. What matters is not the intent, but whether the recipient felt \u201cuncomfortable.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | A Firing at the Opera, and \u2018a Moral Panic\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI guess if he whispered it,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I never saw anything that shows one of them was whispering. Harrison and Young have a history of acrimony, and Harrison is known on the tour for his aggressive and abrasive manner, often incurring the ire of opponents and tournament officials.\n\nBruno said he generally likes Young more than Harrison because Young is more approachable on court. But should he?\n\nWhen Mr. Stephens writes about the American president, he has been eloquent about why he\u2019s a \u201cNeverTrumper.\u201d \u201cCharacter does count, and virtue does matter, and Trump\u2019s shortcomings prove it daily,\u201d Mr. Stephens wrote in a Dec. 29 column.\n\nMr. Netanyahu displays daily many of the characteristics that Mr. Stephens finds objectionable in President Trump. Mr. Stephens courageously attacks fellow conservatives who pretend Mr. Trump\u2019s personality doesn\u2019t matter. Yet despite their rapid growth, index mutual funds and exchange-traded funds still represent just 12 percent of the United States\u2019 equity market. Globally, this number is 7 percent.\n\nEven so, exchange-traded funds act as forces of stability on high-volume trading days. This is because they allow buyers to meet sellers efficiently, often without underlying stocks or bonds changing hands at all.\n\nAs markets gyrated recently, investors directly exchanged about $1 trillion of United States-listed, exchange-traded funds. Yet all equity E.T.F.s experienced less than $30 billion in outflows; bond E.T.F.s had withdrawals of roughly $468 million.\n\nInvestor asset-allocation decisions drive market prices, not the vehicles that investors choose to express those decisions. The rising popularity of E.T.F.s contributes to the smooth functioning of our capital markets by delivering greater price transparency across assets, particularly during periods of stress.", "title": "Opinion | A Force for Market Stability", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Political advisers to Mr. Menendez said the senator would not comment on Mr. Hugin\u2019s remarks.\n\nMr. Menendez is emerging from a monthslong politically damaging corruption trial that ended in a mistrial after a jury was unable to reach a verdict. After saying they were going to retry Mr. Menendez, federal prosecutors reversed course after a federal judge acquitted him of several of the charges.\n\nMr. Menendez, who has not formally declared his candidacy but has given every indication that he plans to run again, has a $4.1 million campaign fund and is unlikely to face a serious challenge in the Democratic primary, having locked up nearly every key Democratic endorsement in the state.\n\nMr. Hugin, a U.S. Marine veteran who was born in Union City, just like Mr. Menendez, pledged that he was a \u201cfiscal conservative,\u201d but would not be beholden to the Republican Party on issues that hurt New Jersey, like capping state and local tax deductions under the new tax law.\n\n\u201cIf President Trump or any other Republican has an idea or a view that is bad for New Jersey, I will forcefully stand up and disagree with them,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Hugin has strong ties to former Gov. Chris Christie, having donated $250,000 to a super PAC that supported Mr. Christie\u2019s presidential bid and has also donated more than $100,000 to groups linked to President Trump.\n\nMr. Christie\u2019s lieutenant governor, Kim Guadagno, who was at the rally, said there \u201ccouldn\u2019t be a bigger contrast between Bob Hugin and Bob Menendez.\u201d\n\nThe trial of Mr. Menendez offers Mr. Hugin plenty of fodder for attacks. After the first trial ended in November, 51 percent of New Jersey residents said that Mr. Menendez should not be re-elected, according to a Rutgers-Eagleton poll.\n\nBut Mr. Hugin has his own potential liabilities. Celgene, the company that helped make him wealthy, recently settled a $250 million lawsuit claiming that it marketed cancer drugs for unapproved uses. And his ties to Mr. Christie and Mr. Trump, both of whom are unpopular in the overwhelmingly Democratic state, could hurt him in the statewide race.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Hugin praised Celgene, claiming it \u201cis one of the leading biopharmaceutical anticancer companies in the world, does amazing things for patients lives, has transformed multiple cancers to chronic disease and is on the verge of curing several cancers.\u201d\n\nMr. Hugin will likely win the Republican nomination, as no major challenger has emerged and his personal wealth amounts to a considerable war chest, but he faces a steep challenge in the general election. A Republican has not won a Senate seat in New Jersey since 1972, and there are about 900,000 more registered Democrats than Republicans in the state.\n\nAnd Mr. Menendez has show an ability to battle back from negative press and poll numbers before, as he did when news first broke about the charges being filed against him.\n\nMr. Hugin was not always exclusively a Republican donor and supporter. During Mr. Menendez\u2019s 2010 re-election bid, Mr. Hugin donated $4,800 to his campaign, according to Federal Election Commission records.", "title": "A Former Pharmaceutical Executive Is Running for U.S. Senate in New Jersey", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere\u2019s been a lot of pushback, but things are getting better now,\u201d Mr. Perillo said. He had expected to be able to appoint his choice for borough administrator and borough attorney quickly, but the Council was not moving as fast as he hoped.\n\nIt took more than a month, but he finally has his administrator, Michael Skudera, though he is still waiting for the borough attorney to be approved. He calls his experience with the Council a \u201cbothersome thing,\u201d but chalks some of it up to a political miscalculation.\n\n\u201cWhen I ran for mayor, there were two people who ran for Council unopposed, and that was a big mistake,\u201d he said. \u201cI mean, I should have had two people run with me \u2014 at least I would have had two people on the Council that I could count on.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTinton Falls has a nonpartisan government so the Council does not caucus as political parties or proclaim allegiance to Republicans or Democrats. Mr. Perillo is a registered Republican, though he said that was because of a single vote long ago, adding that he has always been an independent.\n\nThe battle with the Council has quickly enveloped the entire town. Mr. Perillo\u2019s supporters have launched a Facebook group to back him, while his campaign Facebook has also been pushing his arguments.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSoon, hundreds of people were flooding the normally staid Council sessions, loudly cheering on their new mayor. It elicited a rare emotion from Mr. Perillo: surprise.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know what was going on,\u201d he said. \u201cThe public was doing more than I was. There were people who thought I wasn\u2019t being treated fairly.\u201d\n\nSome Council members have described their early dealings with Mr. Merillo as \u201cchallenging,\u201d attributing it to the mayor\u2019s inexperience.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe is very new at politics, and the things that go on in the internal side of it,\u201d said Christopher Pak, a councilman. \u201cBut he\u2019s working hard toward making it work.\u201d\n\nIf there is a starting point for Mr. Perillo\u2019s decades-long, relatively unplanned drift into politics, it might be sometime in the last year, when he finally reached a breaking point with his property tax bill, and grew increasingly angry at what he viewed was opaque spending by the town\u2019s administration. A whistle-blower lawsuit involving the Police Department that cost his town $1.1 million further motivated him.\n\n\u201cI wanted to find out what was going on actually,\u201d he said. \u201cThat kind of ticked me off a little bit.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo he made up his mind to run. Or, more precisely, walk.\n\n\u201cI asked a previous mayor, I says, \u2018Mayor so-and-so, how\u2019d you get elected, what was your secret?\u2019\u201d explained Mr. Perillo.\n\n\u201c\u2018Vito,\u2019 he says, \u2018You gotta walk.\u2019\u201d\n\nIn a stroke of luck in a campaign marked by good fortune, Mr. Perillo\u2019s campaign manager, Steve Leech, was a former postal worker. Perhaps no one was better suited to canvass the 15-square-mile borough.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe didn\u2019t really see the point of mailing a flier out if we could walk them to people\u2019s doors,\u201d said Mr. Leech, 60, who has also been Mr. Perillo\u2019s next-door neighbor since 1992.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo the two men with no political experience (Mr. Leech says did technically serve as campaign manager for a student council president in high school \u2014 \u201cI\u2019m two-for-two now\u201d) set out for a monthslong walkabout.\n\nSometimes they just left fliers, while other times visits led to extended conversations. Mr. Perillo was always proud to end an encounter with a handshake, a grip that even after 93 years \u2014 38 of them as an electrical engineer for the Department of Defense, plus a tour in the South Pacific during World War II \u2014 can still crack a knuckle.\n\nHis vigor, he says, comes from keeping his body in motion. He tries to play golf at least two times a week, though he laments that he uses a golf cart now, and considers himself a consistent player (\u201cSometimes I wish I could hit it like him,\u201d said his grandson, Mike Perillo-Gentile). Mr. Perillo also belongs to the local Y.M.C.A., regularly completing a demanding circuit of \u201cabout 10 to 12 machines.\u201d\n\n\u201cI think that\u2019s why I\u2019m here today, is because I keep active,\u201d he said.\n\nHis campaign was a sparse operation \u2014 aside from Mr. Leech, he relied on his family, especially Mr. Perillo-Gentile, who managed a lot of the online efforts and helped book his interviews. The two men are close; Mr. Perillo was the best man at his grandson\u2019s wedding last October. Though he passed on the bachelor party, he gave a \u201cstandup comedy shtick\u201d toast that Mr. Perillo said had the crowd shouting his name.", "title": "A Freshman New Jersey Mayor, at Age 93, Tackles Same Old Problems", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "It was my job, after all, as a single parent, as the \u201cgrown-up\u201d (which will forever have air quotes), to sweep up the feathers, to deal with the aftermath. That\u2019s what I had been doing all day every day for weeks now \u2014 dealing with the aftermath.\n\nI thought about the day of Don\u2019s funeral, the moment when eight of my female friends, from different parts of my 40-year-old life, ended up on that very porch with me.\n\nWe talked and drank wine, grimacing over how many of us wished we still smoked. At one point I was standing at the top of the front steps, looking out, and I could feel those women behind me. I stayed quiet and just listened to the sound of their talking more than their words, and I could feel myself getting stronger for it, my spine filling with liquid steel, and I knew I would be able to go on.\n\nWhen my children were born, other people wanted to be in the birthing room \u2014 my sister, sister-in-law, mother. For me, the birth experience was as intimate as the conception, and we made a decision that felt automatic: Of course it would be just the two of us in the room.\n\nBut from now on, parental and household decisions would be mine alone. I hadn\u2019t known what to do with Don\u2019s body. We hadn\u2019t discussed his funeral wishes because his prognosis, up until his final hours, had been so good. And now I didn\u2019t know what to do with this destroyed bird.\n\nI got a garbage can lid and swept the feathers and bird up into it, and again was struck by its beauty. Her eyes were not closed and I made a mental note to look that up: Do birds have eyelids? Echo whined at the front door to be let inside, and I ignored her. They are confusing and \u2014 for many voters the Democrats need \u2014 beside the point. Let Robert Mueller do his business and support him throughout. Otherwise restrain yourself. There may turn out to be not much there. There certainly aren\u2019t many votes.\n\nERIC WEINBERGER\n\nCAMBRIDGE, MASS.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAs a progressive member of the party who has consistently felt dismissed and belittled by mainstream Democrats, I would strongly recommend that they treat the progressives as though we matter, and that our opinions and positions have value. To disregard or ridicule our interests and then to insist that we must vote Democratic is demoralizing. We have enough trouble motivating people to vote without treating them as though their only importance to the party is pulling the Democratic lever.\n\nIt\u2019s true that both sides of the party need to compromise and work together in order to win, but so far \u201ccompromise\u201d seems to mean \u201cprogressive people, do as you\u2019re told.\u201d\n\nT. COLE, BOSTON\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI have been a registered Democrat since being able to vote, and I come from a very progressive family. Nonetheless, the Democrats\u2019 persistent pushing of identity politics has made it nearly untenable for me to vote for my party in 2018 \u2014 yes, even in the face of Trumpism. The Democrats need to ease off the \u201ccis white male bashing\u201d and foster a narrative not based on identity politics, lest they lose their centrist base to appease a vocal radical fringe. Continuing doing what the party is currently doing is not convincing any middle-class and poor Rust Belt voters that we are the party that is best for them. We can\u2019t afford another \u201cdeplorables\u201d gaffe in 2018.\n\nMARC GRIFFIN\n\nST. GEORGE, UTAH\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe Democrats need to focus on a positive, inclusive and simple issue. I would suggest \u201cfairness,\u201d which strongly resonates with most people, including with many Trump voters who constantly complain that the system is rigged. Many people on the right feel that they have been left behind while others (immigrants, minorities, \u201cwelfare queens,\u201d etc.) are cutting the line and unfairly using the government to their advantage. This anger needs to be redirected toward the real source of unfairness: the rich who take advantage of the poor and the middle class. The Democrats should above all explain as clearly as possible the causal link between the Republican tax cuts (very generous to the rich) and the Republican budget (very cruel to the poor and middle class).\n\nPATRICK SINGY, NISKAYUNA, N.Y.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nWhen I was growing up (I\u2019m 71), the Democratic Party was a bold, brash big tent of diversity representing the working class, bursting at the seams with a plethora of viable and colorful candidates. It was the party that conceived Social Security, Medicare and the Civil Rights Act and was willing to fight for those programs, damn the consequences, because they were right and just. Flash forward to now.\n\nThe Democratic Party needs to begin by replacing the likes of the House minority leader, Nancy Pelosi, the Senate minority leader, Chuck Schumer, and the Democratic National Committee chairman, Tom Perez, with new, exciting, dramatic figures. It needs to persuade young Democrats to run for leadership roles and national office. It needs to fully re-establish itself as the party of the working class and the forgotten, willing to pursue its ideals, damn the consequences.", "title": "Opinion | A Game Plan for Democrats (Actually, 16 of Them)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "I\u2019ve been going around to campuses asking undergraduate and graduate students how they see the world. Most of the students I\u2019ve met with so far are at super-competitive schools \u2014 Harvard, Yale, the University of Chicago and Davidson \u2014 so this is a tiny slice of the rising generation. Still, their comments are striking.\n\nThe first thing to say is that this is a generation with diminished expectations. Their lived experience includes the Iraq war, the financial crisis, police brutality and Donald Trump \u2014 a series of moments when the big institutions failed to provide basic security, competence and accountability. \u201cWe\u2019re the school shooting generation,\u201d one Harvard student told me. Another said: \u201cWall Street tanked the country and no one got punished. The same with government.\u201d\n\nI found little faith in large organizations. \u201cI don\u2019t believe in politicians; they have been corrupted. I don\u2019t believe in intellectuals; they have been corrupted,\u201d said one young woman at Yale. I asked a group of students from about 30 countries which of them believed that the people running their country were basically competent. Only one young man, from Germany, raised a hand. \u201cThe utopia of our parents is the dystopia of our age,\u201d a Harvard student said, summarizing the general distemper.\n\nIt\u2019s not that the students are hopeless. They are dedicating their lives to social change. It\u2019s just that they have trouble naming institutions that work. A number said they used to have a lot of faith in the tech industry, but they have lost much of it. \u201cThe Occupy strategy was such a visible failure, it left everyone else feeling disillusioned,\u201d one lamented. \u201cWe don\u2019t even have a common truth. A common set of facts,\u201d added another.", "title": "Opinion | A Generation Emerging From the Wreckage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Selling Girl Scout cookies is meant to accomplish more than just distributing Samoas and Thin Mints to the world. Ideally, the girls would learn about setting goals, teamwork, money management and communicating with adults, among other things.\n\nIf the girls can develop some business acumen, all the better. And one young scout in San Diego has received nationwide plaudits for her shrewd entrepreneurial sense, setting up shop last week outside a marijuana dispensary.\n\nThe girl, who has not been publicly identified, sold more than 300 boxes in six hours, her father told ABC 10. Boxes now sell for as much as $5 in parts of the country, so she probably raised more than $1,500. Yes, there\u2019s money in the munchies.\n\nWhile some have praised the plucky scout for figuring out where the demand would probably be, the Girl Scouts organization has been wrestling with how to handle marijuana-adjacent sales as more states have legalized the drug.", "title": "A Girl Scout Sold 300 Boxes of Cookies Near a California Marijuana Shop", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "After documenting life in impoverished communities in Mexico, the United States, and her home country, Spain, Anna Bosch needed a break from misery.\n\nShe found it in Beirut, Lebanon.\n\nThat may sound odd, given that the city has been wracked by decades of civil war and conflict with Israel that has claimed thousands of lives and uprooted over a million more. Indeed, in Spain, Ms. Bosch said, \u201cIf you ask anyone what they know about Lebanon, they will say war, conflict and trouble.\u201d\n\nShe sought out a less obvious story: How do Beirut\u2019s elite live in a country that\u2019s constantly on the brink of collapse?", "title": "A Glimpse Into the World of Lebanon\u2019s 1 Percent", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Some big companies have made efforts to curb prices, with some effect. The supermarket chain Safeway has deployed a technique called \u201creference pricing,\u201d in which it calculates a price sufficient to pay for a high-quality lab test and radiology test. Employees must select a provider that comes in under that bar or pay the difference. Providers have an incentive to drop prices for this big pool of employees. With reference pricing, Safeway saved $2.6 million on lab tests over three years.\n\nBoeing also contracts directly with health systems in Washington and California for some employee care, bypassing insurers. But neither Boeing nor Safeway is likely to have the fearsome arm-twisting clout of this new conglomerate.\n\nThe pharmaceutical industry knows it will need Amazon to deliver drugs. Hospitals might want Chase to finance equipment purchases. And who would dare alienate Warren Buffett, who has called health care costs \u201ca hungry tapeworm on the American economy\u201d? The three titans are also likely to insist that the best hospitals \u2014 the Sloan Ketterings and Cleveland Clinics \u2014 be available to their workers.\n\nYes, they may use technology in smarter ways to benefit patients. This might include home monitoring of heart rhythms and blood sugar; diagnosing via telemedicine and iPad; delivering prescription medicines to doorsteps; and bringing medicine into the 21st century with online billing and payment. They may also be able to provide employees some degree of pricing transparency so that they can make better choices.\n\nIn doing so they will probably be able to reduce the high administrative costs associated with our health care system, an estimated 25 percent of hospital spending, and give patients more control of their care.\n\nHow can the rest of us get in on the deal? If the new health care company permits outside firms and individuals to buy into whatever they create, that could set off a revolution. That new company would, essentially, become a novel insurer \u2014 although one that is cheaper, more efficient and patient-friendly. And that could be good for the entire health care system.\n\nBut what if the three corporations try to turn their health care company into a profit center? This week\u2019s announcement said the new company is \u201cfree from profit-making incentives and constraints.\u201d That doesn\u2019t quite say \u201cnonprofit.\u201d If the long-term game plan of the Amazon-JPMorgan-Berkshire offshoot is to function as a business that is sold to the rest of us to please shareholders, then we may end up pretty much back where we started. And that is not where we want to be.", "title": "Opinion | A Good Health Care Deal, but Only for Some", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "But the charge itself \u2014 invasion of privacy \u2014 is drawing intense scrutiny. Lawyers for the governor have asked a judge to dismiss it, saying it is being applied in a way lawmakers who wrote the statute never intended. And observers of the case and commentators in Missouri have dissected the language of the little-used statute in an effort to understand precisely what prosecutors are asserting that the governor did. Some were asking: Who else has been charged with this?\n\nThe law\n\nBack in the 1990s, Jim Kreider\u2019s constituents in southern Missouri were aghast when prosecutors said that they could not charge the tanning salon owner who was thought to have recorded dozens of naked women. So Mr. Kreider, a Democratic state representative, sponsored a bill that made invasion of privacy a felony.\n\n\u201cIt got a lot of press and it got a lot of coverage and letters to the editor, and people were pretty outraged about it,\u201d Mr. Kreider, now a lobbyist in the state capital, said of the tanning salon case. Of the bill, he said, \u201cit passed with relative ease.\u201d\n\nThe law makes it a felony to knowingly photograph or film a nude person without consent in a place where they would reasonably expect privacy, and to then distribute that recording or transmit it so it could be seen on a computer.\n\nThe law was too late for the tanning salon case from Buffalo, though. Prosecutors found a different route to charge the salon owner. He was accused and convicted of child abuse when it was revealed that some of the people he filmed were minors.", "title": "A Governor Is Charged With \u2018Invasion of Privacy,\u2019 but What Does That Mean?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nMy husband has a ritual when I leave for work each day. \u201cHave an easy commute,\u201d he says. It\u2019s a blessing of sorts, since the subway system can leave much to be desired.\n\nOne recent morning, he raised the ante. \u201cHave a great commute,\u201d he said. We laughed about what such a thing could possibly be.\n\nOff I went downtown on the A train, which was unusually empty for rush hour. At 145th Street, a woman got on and sat down next to me. She resembled a woman I sometimes chat with via Twitter, usually about our mutual subway debacles.\n\nNot wanting to stare at her to confirm my suspicions, I pulled out my phone and sent a message: \u201cNina,\u201d I wrote, \u201care you sitting next to me on the train right now?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWithin moments, the woman next to me turned in my direction, wide-eyed and a bit spooked. Upon realizing what was happening, she burst out laughing.\n\n\u201cNice to meet you!\u201d she said.\n\nWe parted ways at 59th Street, and as a result of our serendipitous meeting, we got together for dinner the next week.", "title": "A Great Commute", "authors": ["Sarah Sweeney", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "MACAU \u2014 Six dog handlers, each escorting a greyhound, stepped onto the wet sand of Asia\u2019s only legal dog-racing track to little noise except a subtropical rain.\n\nIn the stands, about two dozen men watched as the greyhounds were led to their starting positions and then released to sprint after a rabbit-shaped lure around a ring. If any of the men had placed bets, none of them showed elation.\n\nIn an otherwise empty betting hall, a security guard patrolled listlessly as staff members sat behind glassed-in counters, napping or tapping away on their smartphones.\n\nThe racing track in this Chinese gambling hub no longer sees the excitement it did in its 20th-century glory days. The greyhounds that ran on that recent Saturday were among the last to compete here before the track shuts down in July.", "title": "A Greyhound Racetrack Meets Its Demise", "authors": ["Patrick Boehler"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOutliers\u201d opens with a two-walled area featuring four artists, carefully, and promisingly, positioning together taught and self-taught artworks of relatively recent vintage united by color, found materials and a degree of abstraction. Three works by the outsider sculptor Judith Scott (1943-2005), known for creating evocative misshapen presences by wrapping found objects in layers of yarn , share a low platform with the work of the mainstream artist Nancy Shaver, whose delicate assemblage-boxes covered with found papers and fabrics, resemble folk-art updates. An airy assemblage by Jessica Stockholder, also mainstream, takes elegant charge of one wall. On another hangs a large provocative quilt by Rosie Lee Tompkins (1936-2006) made of found fabrics, including segments of an American flag and towels, one depicting Jesus. It has the bold color and scale of a James Rosenquist Pop art painting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is just the overture. Because of the volume of material here, it\u2019s best to view the show the way Ms. Cooke intended, by tackling the three periods chronologically.\n\n1924 to 1943: Folk Aesthetics Reconfigured\n\nPhoto\n\nThis section traces the growing understanding of folk art\u2019s formal simplicity as implicitly modern. It includes the work of trained artists who were early appreciators, among them, Charles Sheeler, Yasuo Kuniyoshi, Marsden Hartley, Florine Stettheimer and Elie Nadelman. There are also unfamiliar works that mesmerize, including two from around 1930: \u201cAdam and Eve and the Garden,\u201d a carved wood tableau by Jos\u00e9 Dolores L\u00f3pez that buzzes with medieval sprightliness, and Palmer Hayden\u2019s \u201cUntitled (Dreamer),\u201d which depicts a black man sleeping in a pose and simplified style reminiscent of both Henri Rousseau and Paul Gauguin. The man\u2019s head rests sweetly on a fringed pillow, while a trumpet, a guitar and a drum are played by disembodied hands.\n\nThe Museum of Modern Art collected and exhibited some of the self-taught artists found here under the leadership of its founding director, Alfred H. Barr Jr. \u2014 a folk-art true believer. Perhaps the most surprising is the presence of work by Edward Hicks, the early-19th-century Quaker painter of sentient animals, including a \u201cPeaceable Kingdom,\u201d from about 1834, similar to the one the Modern once owned.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt times the allegiance to chronology curtails chances to surprise. Lonnie Holley\u2019s wonderful 1985 sculpture in carved sandstone is marooned just outside the show; it should have been with its (mostly) 1930s precursors, among the carved stone sculptures of William Edmondson and John B. Flanagan whose pairing is by now a bit tired. And there are strange missed opportunities: \u201cMilky Way,\u201d a luminous dripped-paint abstraction from 1945 by the self-taught Ukrainian-American artist Janet Sobel, should have been paired with one by Jackson Pollock (who was aware of her work). But Ms. Cooke consistently skirts canonical figures; her vanguard artists are also in different ways outliers, except for art stars like Kara Walker and Cindy Sherman, both of whom appear later without much justification, though Ms. Sherman collects and has written about some of the outsider photographers grouped around her.\n\n1968-1992: Commensurables and Incommensurables\n\nPhoto\n\nThe second section gives the show a combustible center; its title alludes to the debate over whether self-taught artists could be compared to trained ones or are incomparable. \u201cOutsider art\u201d supersedes \u201cfolk art,\u201d connoting a more jarring, free-range aesthetic usually from outside the Northeast, as demonstrated here. Starting in an almost too spacious gallery this section contains the most intense visual conversations between taught and self-taught.\n\nFirst, it\u2019s between the idiosyncratically figurative Chicago Imagists (Roger Brown, Jim Nutt, Gladys Nilsson) and some of the outsider greats they discovered, recovered or championed: Ram\u00edrez, Joseph Yoakum and P.M. Wentworth. The back and forth between Brown\u2019s meticulous landscape forms and Yoakum\u2019s is especially rewarding.\n\nNext, there is also a dialogue regarding visceral materials and sometimes painful themes between self-taught and taught African-American artists. The first group gained wider attention with \u201cBlack Folk Art in America: 1930-1980,\u201d a landmark exhibition at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in 1982. They included David Butler (1898-1997), who fashioned animals, angels and people from cut and painted tin and other found items; the religious painter Sister Gertrude Morgan (1900-1980); Steve Ashby (1904-1980), who made raw figurative assemblages out of scavenged materials; and Elijah Pierce (1892-1984), whose carved and painted wood reliefs depict biblical scenes and national figures like the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.\n\nThen the show turns to work by the second group, an imposing cadre of trained artists working in Los Angeles like Betye Saar, John Outterbridge, Senga Nengudi and Noah Purifoy, who worked for decades at the margins of the mainstream, exploring aspects of assemblage and found materials as well as political expression in often abstract forms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n1998-2013: Determining Difference Differently\n\nPhoto\n\nThe show starts to unravel as it rushes through its final section, despite the title\u2019s koan-like optimism. Mr. Holley\u2019s two delicate assemblages may make you yearn for something bigger and more ferocious from this versatile Southern outsider, and also for the obstreperous painted or rusted metal reliefs by his friend Thornton Dial, who is inexplicably absent. Two formally educated artists especially make sense in the \u201coutlier\u201d zone. One is Greer Lankton, whose drawings, photographs and dolls allude to her transition to womanhood and celebrate various glamorous icons, including the first lady Jacqueline Kennedy, who remains unforgettably elegant amid tragedy, in the famous pink Chanel suit she wore on Nov. 22, 1963. The other is Matt Mullican, whose large drawings on paper-backed bedsheets covered with numbers, words and images has a \u201cdrawing in tongues\u201d quality, and were partly achieved through hypnosis. It is however unclear what \u2014 besides being two-sided \u2014 his work has to do with the big watercolors of the towering outsider talent Henry Darger (1892-1973), whose illustrated epic about the Vivian Girls used enlarged images from children\u2019s coloring books and would be better compared with Warhol.\n\nIn the last gallery you can revel in the vibrant geometric quilts of Mary Lee Bendolph and Annie Mae Young, who emerged in the rapturously received exhibition \u201cThe Quilts of Gee\u2019s Bend,\u201d which toured the country in 2002. Also here are two more quilts, made of small irregular squares of color, by the great Rosie Lee Tompkins. Ms. Tompkins may belong to the string of geniuses who emerged in the last three decades of the 20th century. But who knows, there always seem to be more, expanding and improving the story of American art.\n\nLooking for More Information? Here\u2019s a History\n\nPhoto\n\nThe first section of \u201cOutliers and American Vanguard Art\u201d includes a memorable glimpse of the MoMA\u2019s early devotion to self-taught artists. This involvement is known, but seeing it made flesh with wonderful works of art is a different order of magnitude \u2014 at once exciting and saddening. We see a museum that might have been: more open and democratic, less bound up in the rigid Francophile narrative that defined the Modern in the later decades of the 20th century.\n\nBarr, the museum\u2019s founding director, viewed self-taught and educated art as equally essential to 20th-century modernism. Ultimately, this didn\u2019t sit well with the museum\u2019s blue-blooded trustees, and it was among the main reasons he was fired in 1943.\n\nBarr, who might well have embraced the \u201coutliers\u201d term, is the de facto hero of Ms. Cooke\u2019s National Gallery exhibition: a historic figure and early adopter of the integration that her exhibition proposes. It\u2019s enticing to consider how different the Modern and the art world might be had his directorship continued. \u201cOutliers\u201d and its predecessors might not even have been necessary.\n\nDuring the 1930s and early 1940s, Barr and his curatorial staff mounted several shows of self-taught artists and included them in more general exhibitions. Rousseau, the French na\u00efve painter who is represented in \u201cOutliers\u201d by three silent, hallucinatory canvases, was arguably the cornerstone of Barr\u2019s self-taught faith. An American favorite was John Kane, known for his dense paintings of life and industry in and around Pittsburgh, like the one in \u201cOutliers,\u201d and also for his startling 1929 self-portrait. One of six Kanes still in the Modern\u2019s collection, it shows a bare-chested strongman going soft, seemingly deified by three thick white bands that frame his head.\n\nOne of the \u201cMoMA-owns-this?\u201d surprises in \u201cOutliers\u201d is Dominique-Paul Peyronnet\u2019s \u201cThe Ferryman at Moselle,\u201d from around 1934. This polished vignette freezes forever a moment from World War I: its protagonist has just cut the ferry\u2019s rope, capsizing his boat and its load of German soldiers while others watch from the bank. A great artist who got away is also here: a dozen of Bill Traylor\u2019s taut silhouettes of town and farm life. Barr tried to buy a group of Traylors in 1941 for such a pittance that his offer was spurned. No one gets every great thing that comes along, not even Alfred Barr.\n\nIn 1941, a new installation of the museum\u2019s permanent collection began with a gallery of \u201cmodern primitives,\u201d but Barr\u2019s time was running out. One of the last straws was an exhibition of the paintings of the retired tailor Morris Hirshfield, represented in \u201cOutliers\u201d by \u201cGirl With Pigeons\u201d (1942), which shows a statue-like figure reclining on a splendid red couch. Today the most prominent vestige of Barr\u2019s folk-art advocacy is Rousseau\u2019s work, such a familiar part of the Modern\u2019s identity that it barely registers as \u201cself-taught.\u201d", "title": "A Groundbreaking Show Presents a New, Inclusive Vision of American Art", "authors": ["Roberta Smith"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Snapchat is fun, and millions use it to stay in touch and share their lives with one another every day. It has an unearned reputation for being difficult to use, but it\u2019s not, after you get the basics. Once you\u2019re in and have a few friends to share with, it\u2019s easy. If you don\u2019t have anyone to show you, you don\u2019t get it, or you\u2019re just wondering what the fuss is about, let us help.\n\nLet\u2019s approach this from an angle you may already be familiar with: A slide show. We know, slide shows are boring. Stick with us, this one\u2019s worth it.", "title": "A Guide to Snapchat for People Who Don\u2019t Get Snapchat", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cHow Much Do Calories Count?\u201d (news article, Feb. 21):\n\nIt was encouraging to learn that the war between high-fat and high-carbohydrate diets may have reached a cease-fire.\n\nThe critical finding of this new study is that when the basic tenets of a healthy diet, long advocated by most health care sectors, were adopted, a modest weight loss resulted (about 12 pounds over one year), and so did improvement in risk factors for heart disease and diabetes.\n\nThese included choosing minimally processed foods, increasing vegetable intake and decreasing sugar and refined carbohydrate intake.\n\nCumulatively, over the course of multiple years, these changes could have a significant favorable effect. But these benefits did not come easily.", "title": "Opinion | A Guide to Weight Loss", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "There was a standoff. The federation began hunting for replacement players for worlds. The national team players began calling those potential replacements, asking them to take their side for the good of the game\u2019s future \u2014 for all the women and little girls who hoped to be treated equally in the future.\n\nA lot was at stake. The world championships were being held in Michigan. An American boycott would have been a huge embarrassment. The players risked ruining their shot at these Olympics, and derailing their careers. But their effort resonated outside the sport. Billie Jean King lent her support, and so did a group of United States senators. No matter the consequences, the hockey players wouldn\u2019t \u2014 and didn\u2019t \u2014 back down.\n\nU.S.A. Hockey was forced to give up, and it was a pivotal moment in the history of women\u2019s sports.\n\n\u201cWe bonded so much over it, and it brought us together,\u201d Duggan said on Friday. \u201cI don\u2019t think we\u2019d be here right now if we hadn\u2019t stuck together.\u201d\n\nThree days before the world championships last year, the players and the federation signed a new deal that provided athletes a salary of about $70,000 a year. That off-ice victory has given the players so many options now.\n\nThey don\u2019t have to quit the sport because they can\u2019t support themselves. Before their new contract with U.S.A. Hockey, players were paid $6,000 in an Olympic year \u2014 and nothing in between Olympic years. Now the women don\u2019t have to worry about their finances when making the decision of sticking with the game or not.\n\nJocelyne Lamoureux-Davidson, who scored the winning goal in the shootout, said she could now consider staying with the game because she still loved it and was still good at it.\n\n\u201cTo have that choice, I think means the world to us,\u201d she said.\n\nTo have a gold medal around their necks isn\u2019t so bad either.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen Lamoureux-Davidson scored in the sixth round of a tiebreaking shootout, her shot resonated throughout the sport.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDuring Thursday night\u2019s celebration, Duggan said she and her teammates watched video of the winning goal \u201ca thousand times,\u201d because as far as they were concerned, it was the most beautiful goal they\u2019d ever seen in the history of hockey. With a couple of deft fakes and a whir of her stick, Lamoureux-Davidson sent the puck skittering past Canada\u2019s goalie, giving the United States the 3-2 victory and their first Olympic gold medal since 1998.\n\n\u201cI feel like the gold medal adds more credibility to what we\u2019re trying to do with women\u2019s sports in our country,\u201d forward Hilary Knight said. \u201cI\u2019m not saying our voice or our skills are any less if we didn\u2019t win. I just think more people start paying attention, and we\u2019re 100 percent trying to inspire the next generation.\u201d\n\nThe team spent Friday being interviewed by reporters from morning until evening, and they could barely stop to breathe.\n\nDuggan told me that this whole year has been \u201cfor women\u2019s hockey in America,\u201d and so much more.\n\n\u201cThis is a moment for women in other sports and women in business and in every single walk of life,\u201d she said. \u201cWe need to show our power and what women can do, so we can work more toward equality.\u201d\n\nThinking about that responsibility can be overwhelming, Knight said. She spent all night Thursday and all Friday thinking about the bigger picture of this Olympic victory.\n\nShe thought about it so much, and celebrated it so much as she sipped Champagne and chatted with friends and family members, that she never even fell asleep Thursday night.\n\nFriday she kept her gold medal in the pocket of her Team U.S.A. jacket. She said she didn\u2019t wear the medal because its ribbon pulls on her neck too much. It\u2019s heavy.\n\n\u201cYou want to hold it?\u201d she asked me, opening up my hand and placing the gold medal in my palm.\n\nAnd it was surprisingly heavy. About a pound and a quarter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s so cool, right?\u201d she said, explaining how she\u2019d place it, safe and sound, next to her pillow Friday night. Maybe she will even get some sleep.", "title": "A Hockey Goal and a Medal That Will Resonate Beyond the Ice", "authors": ["Juliet Macur", "Sports Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt worked,\u201d said Frederick Brewer, 55, one of the five elected leaders of the camp here, known as Tent City 3 or TC3, which is one of three tent cities managed by a nonprofit group of homeless and formerly homeless people called Share/Wheel. But, Mr. Brewer said, \u201cit didn\u2019t solve the problem.\u201d\n\nNational advocates for the homeless say much the same thing. The city of Seattle helps fund some tent camps, they said, through financial or logistical support, but the city also continues practices of sweeps and evictions for unsanctioned camps that it doesn\u2019t want.\n\n\u201cSeattle is doing some things that are fairly innovative,\u201d said Maria Foscarinis, the executive director of the National Law Center on Homelessness & Poverty, a nonprofit legal group in Washington, D.C. \u201cBut the encampments are there because of the failure to create affordable, decent housing. I absolutely fear that they will be seen as the solution.\u201d\n\nStill, over the 15 years that the Seattle area has allowed some camps \u2014 some anchored in one place, others, like TC3, roving from host to host \u2014 the arrangement has often affected the permanent residents they wound up living beside. Nowhere was that more true than at Seattle Pacific. The idea of a university hosting the homeless at all, let alone for months, is all but unheard-of around the nation, education experts said.\n\n\n\nThe university, which was founded by Free Methodist Church members in 1891, has allowed TC3 on campus for three 90-day stays over the last six years. Two other Seattle schools, the University of Washington and Seattle University, have also hosted camps.\n\n\u201cIt does change the institutional DNA,\u201d said Nate Mouttet, Seattle Pacific\u2019s vice president for enrollment management and marketing. Prospective students, he said, know right from the time they first tour the campus that \u201csometime in their experience here, they\u2019re going to encounter what it means to be around homelessness.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd homeless people, who in some cases come from generations of poverty, can be changed as well.\n\n\u201cThe students have become our friends,\u201d Ms. Deserley said. She said that she and her daughter had fled an abusive relationship, and that it made her hopeful seeing Genny explore the campus and understand what education might offer.\n\nBut on a religious university campus where discussions of theology and morality are part of the curriculum, interactions across the camp/campus line were complicated, too.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe want people to know about tent cities,\u201d said Karen Snedker, an associate professor of sociology. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to do it with no exploitation if at all possible,\u201d she said. \u201cBut there is a power differential, there is a status differential, and you can\u2019t completely get away from that.\u201d\n\nSally J. Clark, a former member of the Seattle City Council, said she had long wrestled with the question of whether supporting sanctioned camps was an openhearted city response, or a failure that looked good only in the moment. The population of the 11 sanctioned camps fluctuates, but their total capacity of about 500 to 600 people constitutes only a small fraction of the need here. Experts say that there are more than 11,000 homeless people in the region. Some say the sanctioned camps have created something of a hierarchy among the homeless, between people in the permitted tent cities and those in camps deemed illegal.\n\n\u201cMy thinking has evolved,\u201d Ms. Clark said. \u201cIf the world were a better place, I would never support funding or policies that make outdoor camping \u2014 tent cities \u2014 a permanent part of the response to homelessness.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cBut as I look around at the scale of the crisis in the Seattle area, I don\u2019t have a better solution.\u201d\n\nInside TC3, alcohol or drug intoxication, violence, or failure to work volunteer security shifts can get residents banished by camp leaders, one of the relatively elaborate camp rules that cover 14 pages.\n\nStill, sometimes there is no clear path. Last fall, when Micailah Moore, a 20-year-old sociology major, arrived in the camp for an interview with a resident who was living there with his 6-year-old daughter, she found that the father had taken ill and was headed by ambulance to the hospital.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nHe pleaded with Ms. Moore: Could she drive his daughter there and meet them? She immediately said yes, but on the way, she became unsure about the ethics and liability at issue. She knew that her professors were having a meeting that day in a nearby doughnut shop, so she pulled over and ran in.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018What do I do?\u2019\u201d Ms. Moore said.\n\nThe situation was soon resolved. The little girl got a doughnut and was reunited with her father, who recovered from what turned out to be food poisoning.\n\nBut a bigger problem, Ms. Moore said, emerged more gradually, as she spent more time in the camp. She was raised Baptist in North Carolina, the daughter of a pastor. But now, she said, she was identifying with members of the tent camp and beginning to have questions about her faith.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a Christian, and I think it\u2019s O.K. to struggle and have doubts, but I\u2019ve had a lot more,\u201d she said. \u201cI want so badly for these people to be miraculously helped \u2014 I\u2019ve gone through placing that blame on God, and being frustrated.\u201d\n\nPatricia Malone, 57, a TC3 resident who has been through four moves now, leaned against a stack of boxes as the camp broke down at Seattle Pacific University on a recent Saturday morning.\n\nMs. Malone spent 40 years waiting tables, which she said took a toll on her back and legs. She came to Seattle in 2012 seeking better medical care and has been homeless on and off since. Around her, student volunteers were helping to load the trucks for the camp\u2019s next home \u2014 a grassy lot owned by a small Baptist church across town. \u201cHard, and getting harder,\u201d Ms. Malone said, of life on the move.", "title": "A Homeless Camp in Our Back Yard? Please, a University Says", "authors": ["Kirk Johnson"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "The high-pressure ridge tends to shunt storms north toward British Columbia, said Marty Ralph, director of the Center for Western Weather and Water Extremes at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very normal to have a ridge,\u201d said Dr. Ralph, who studies so-called atmospheric rivers, trails of tropical moisture that in a normal year are responsible for much of California\u2019s precipitation. \u201cIt usually breaks down at some point and packs of storms break through.\u201d\n\nA few studies have suggested that the persistence of such blocking ridges in certain parts of the world may be linked to climate change. But a range of conditions in the Pacific Ocean not necessarily related to climate change, including El Ni\u00f1o and La Ni\u00f1a, can contribute to the formation and positioning of a ridge, Dr. Swain said.\n\nThe thin California snowpack is also a function of high temperatures. Following a record warm summer and fall in the state, temperatures have continued well above normal this winter. In the Sierra town of Truckee, Calif., on Thursday the high temperature, 64, was 21 degrees above the historical average.\n\n\u201cWhat we\u2019re seeing is more precipitation as rain than as snow,\u201d said Doug Carlson, a spokesman for the state Department of Water Resources. The warmer temperatures raise the snow line, the elevation above which it is cold enough that precipitation falls as snow. They also cause what snow there is to melt faster.\n\nRain runs off immediately, while snowpack serves as a reservoir of water that is released over time as it melts. So, changes in the proportions of snow and rain and the rate of snowmelt can affect the availability and timing of water for people, industry and agriculture.\n\nThe snowpack conditions in the Sierra this year may be an extreme example of what scientists suggest will be the case with climate change \u2014 that as average temperatures rise, average snowpack will decline, perhaps by as much as 25 percent by midcentury.", "title": "A Hot, Dry Winter in California. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.\n\nTell me about the process of building this home.\n\nGERUN RILEY It was a classic California 1,400-square-foot bungalow. My dad is an architect. We built the house we grew up in. My brother is an architect. He came up with the design. When I was two months pregnant, we tore down the entire house. And we rebuilt it ourselves. Jason, my two brothers and I built it.\n\nJASON WILBORN At the time, I was working on this television show that didn\u2019t have a traditional writer\u2019s room, so I was here with a tool belt on. I\u2019d get a call from a producer and then step back and work on the house.\n\nJust you two and Gerun\u2019s brothers?\n\nRILEY It\u2019s very empowering. I have no clue how my car works. My house, I know how it works. We know every nail, every piece of plumbing, every wire. I grew up in a family where all of my parents\u2019 friends were artists. We were close enough to New York that we went to museums a lot. My dad took us to museums, my mom took us to protests.\n\nHow else did New England influence the pieces you chose?\n\nRILEY There\u2019s a watercolor here of the woods in Connecticut where I grew up running around \u2014 that was my backyard. Reminds me of the wilderness.", "title": "A House as a Frame for Handmade Contents", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "KARUIZAWA, Japan \u2014 At 14, Aito Iguchi is already an internet stickhandling sensation and a household name in Japanese youth hockey. The question wherever he plays is typically not whether, but when, he will stickhandle his way to a goal. But Iguchi wants more than goals.\n\n\u201cI want to set my sights on being a pro hockey player,\u201d he said, quietly but firmly, after collecting three goals and three assists during an 8-5 win in Karuizawa, a town about an hour northwest by bullet train from his home in the Tokyo suburbs.\n\nTop men\u2019s hockey prospects from Japan primarily hope to play for the country\u2019s top universities or club teams, veteran coaches say. Some have played in the now-defunct Japan Ice Hockey League or a newer outfit, the Asia League, whose eight teams are based in Japan, Russia and South Korea.\n\nBut today, more of Japan\u2019s top teenage players are eyeing youth, collegiate and professional leagues in North America. The buyer: Carolyn Barry, a doll collector who, with her husband, Richard, provided the funds to create Old Dominion University\u2019s new Barry Art Museum, which is set to open in October. She has given 81 dolls to the museum, and in January she had set out with a purpose: to add the Rochard doll.\n\nPale, delicate and elegantly dressed, the 30-inch-tall Rochard doll is unlike any of its porcelain contemporaries, said Theriault\u2019s president, Stuart Holbrook.\n\nWorking with a doll manufacturer of the era, Rochard, a crafter prized for his dolls\u2019 rarity, designed the lips to be parted (unusual for that time). Peering through the mouth, one sees a kaleidoscope effect. The doll\u2019s breastplate has a necklace of 28 Stanhope gems, all but two still intact. Twenty-four of these contain microphotographs \u2014 some only a millimeter wide \u2014 showing images of Paris and surrounding France and Europe.", "title": "A Jeweled 19th-Century Doll Sets a Record and Heads for a New Museum", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The last time the Olympics came to South Korea, in 1988, Korean pop music was awash in soft-focus ballads, a gentle and demure version of the sounds that were taking hold elsewhere in the world. This year, the country is hosting the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, and is greeting it with a vastly evolved approach to pop music and culture.\n\nSouth Korea\u2019s prime export is K-pop, the umbrella term used to describe the ecstatic, vibrant, outrageously polished and often hyperreal version of pop music that dominates the country\u2019s music industry, thanks to entertainment conglomerates that aggressively recruit and train young talent. The genre is known for pinpoint precision, flamboyant fashion and smoothed-over borrowings from American R&B and hip-hop that, taken in total, have amounted to the creation of a style and sound that\u2019s unmistakable, and without global peer. Along with K-drama and various other youth-driven pop culture offsprings, it\u2019s become essential to South Korea\u2019s global image.\n\nK-pop will reportedly have a limited presence at the Olympics opening ceremony on Friday, which will feature performances from Ha Hyun Woo of the indie rock band Guckkasten, Ahn Ji Young of the K-pop duo Bolbbalgan4 and Jeon In Kwon of the long-running Korean rock band Deulgukhwa.\n\nIt will, however, be more prominently featured at the closing ceremony on Feb. 25, with performances by CL, who got her start in the essential girl group 2NE1, and the boy band EXO. Other K-pop performances \u2014 including a reunion of the boy band 2PM \u2014 are scheduled for events throughout the Games. And last month, the North Korean singer Hyon Song-wol led a delegation of North Korean officials to the South to prepare for the cultural performances that will be a part of the events.", "title": "A K-Pop Primer for Olympic Listening", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Thousands of children perished while attending these schools, and the physical, mental and sexual abuse many endured is well documented. In Saskatchewan, tensions between indigenous and non-indigenous people run several generations deep.\n\nYet for many people in Canada, the reaction to the Boushie verdict has come as a surprise. A study in 2016 found that Canadians have only recently begun to understand the discrimination faced by indigenous people, and many feel it is no different from that faced by other minority populations in the country.\n\nThis can be explained partly by an urban-rural divide. Eighty percent of Canadians live in cities, and half of indigenous people reside in rural areas, leaving many urbanites unaware of the systemic and longstanding racism plaguing indigenous people. But if you look beyond the urban enclaves to Canada\u2019s rural backyard, you see a more complete picture.\n\nI grew up in a small Saskatchewan town two hours east of where Mr. Boushie was killed. As a Dene girl of 7, I was accused of stealing while I was browsing the aisles of a girls\u2019 accessories store. I was 15 when a friend, a Cree hockey player, said a white man spat on him during a game.\n\nWhen I was in college, a young man (whose father, brother and uncle were members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police) declared one night that he wanted to be a police officer so that he \u201ccould shoot\u201d some Indians. I was young, trying to make friends, and didn\u2019t challenge the comment. Later, when I mentioned the incident to a person there that evening, he told me that the comment wasn\u2019t about race, but the fact that \u201cnatives just commit more crime.\u201d\n\nFailing to call out racism makes it easier for people to believe there isn\u2019t any. Worse yet, racism becomes so acceptable we stop being able to recognize it. In November, a major political candidate said that when he was growing up in Saskatchewan he \u201cdidn\u2019t even know that racism existed.\u201d\n\nIt took me years to find the courage to call out racism when I see it. Canada doesn\u2019t have that long. One in three indigenous people is under the age of 14, and these young people are growing up facing discrimination at every turn. While Canadians debate the role of racism in the Boushie trial and verdict, indigenous people are losing faith in the justice system, the government and the idea of reconciliation.", "title": "Opinion | A Killing in Saskatchewan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "As of Wednesday evening, the South had not decided whether to supply the fuel. \u201cWe will closely discuss with the United States and other related nations the matter of providing convenience to the Mangyongbong ferry so that no problem regarding sanctions would occur,\u201d said Baik Tae-hyun, a spokesman for the Unification Ministry, which is in charge of relations with the North.\n\nSince last month, when North Korea agreed to send 22 athletes and hundreds of supporters to the Olympics, sanctions questions have repeatedly vexed organizers in the South.\n\nPhoto\n\nSamsung, the South Korean electronics company that is one of the Olympic sponsors, donated 4,000 Galaxy Note 8 phones for athletes and officials at the Games. It had been a welcome and uncontroversial perk \u2014 until North Korea decided to come.\n\nThen the question arose: Would the $1,100 smartphones violate the United Nations ban on exporting luxury goods to the North? What\u2019s more, could they be defined as one of the \u201cdual use\u201d goods that are banned because they could potentially serve military purposes?\n\nSome Olympic officials suggested that the North Koreans could use the phones while in Pyeongchang, and return them before going home.\n\nBut in the end, it seemed a moot point: The athletes\u2019 minders from the North Korean government were unlikely to let them use phones with unfettered, high-speed access to the internet, which would be strictly forbidden in their isolated home country. South Korean officials said the athletes were unlikely to receive the phones.\n\nThe sanctions problem even extends to hockey sticks. Last year, when North Korea\u2019s ice hockey team brought battered wooden sticks to an international tournament in Auckland, New Zealand, organizers presented them with high-tech carbon fiber equipment. But the North Koreans had to give it back before going home, because the luxury goods ban specifically includes \u201crecreational sports equipment.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe same solution will be applied in Pyeongchang, where the two Koreas are to field a joint women\u2019s hockey team. The International Ice Hockey Federation will lend new Finnish sticks to the North Korean players, to be returned after the Games.\n\nWhat\u2019s more, the hockey team will wear uniforms made by a Finnish company \u2014 not by Nike, another Olympic sponsor \u2014 for fear of violating United States sanctions. (It has also been reported that the North Koreans did not want to wear American-made uniforms.)\n\nPhoto\n\nSouth Korean officials have taken pains to consult with their American allies as they pursue their sports d\u00e9tente with the North.\n\nLast week, South Korea sought and was granted an exception from Washington after an Asiana Airlines charter plane took South Korean players to North Korea for joint training, and returned to the South with North Korean Olympic athletes. Normally, planes are barred from landing in the United States for six months after a visit to North Korea. (Asiana used an Airbus jet, not an American Boeing, for the trip.)\n\nThe joint ski training was held at North Korea\u2019s Masik Pass resort, a choice that drew heated criticism from South Korean conservatives. The resort is one of the signature projects of the North\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, who has ostentatiously supplied it with snowmobiles and other pieces of sports equipment considered luxuries in the impoverished North.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe combination of the ever-tightening international sanctions and the North\u2019s usual unpredictability has been a particular source of stress for South Korean officials.\n\nNorth Korea did not reveal until the last minute who would be included in its government delegation to the Olympics, leading to worries that it might test South Korea by trying to send one of the top officials blacklisted by Washington. Those fears were borne out when the names were announced on Wednesday: Kim Jong-un\u2019s sister, Kim Yo-jong, who is part of the delegation, was blacklisted by the United States Treasury in January 2017 over accusations that she was involved in North Korea\u2019s \u201congoing and serious human rights abuses and censorship activities.\u201d\n\nAnother member of the delegation, Choe Hwi, chairman of the North\u2019s National Sports Guidance Committee, was put on the same sanctions list, as well as on the United Nations Security Council sanctions list.\n\nSouth Korean officials said Thursday that they were talking with Washington and the United Nations to clear the North Koreans\u2019 visit to the South.
