Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe gunman was still at large, and yet those in hiding kept trying to make sense of it all.\n\n\u201cIf you looked around this closet and saw everyone just hiding together, you would know that this shouldn\u2019t be happening any more,\u201d said another female student, her eyes wide and fear visible on her face.\n\nInterviewed later, Mr. Hogg offered remarks that captured the sentiments of many of his classmates.\n\n\u201cOn a national scale, I\u2019m not surprised at all,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd that\u2019s just sad. The fact that a student is not surprised that there was another mass shooting \u2014 but this time it was at his school \u2014 says so much about the current state that our country is in, and how much has to be done.\u201d\n\nThe violence must stop, he said.\n\n\u201cWe need to do something. We need to get out there and be politically active,\u201d he said. \u201cCongress needs to get over their political bias with each other and work toward saving children\u2019s lives.\u201d\n\nExpressing his frustration on CNN, he said: \u201cWe\u2019re children. You guys are the adults.\u201d", "title": "A Mother Weeps for Her Angel: \u2018I Hope She Didn\u2019t Die for Nothing\u2019", "authors": ["Julie Turkewitz", "Audra D. S. Burch", "Liam Stack"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The Sun Ra Arkestra, the fabled free jazz ensemble, embraces volcanic bursts and entropic rambling; the electronic musician JLin creates skittish footwork beats that favor only the bravest and most experienced dancers. And the Rhode Island-based noise rock band Lightning Bolt is famed for concerts that often occur in tiny, clandestine spaces, where a crush of jittery bodies surround the band on all sides.\n\nBrian Chippendale, its drummer, plans to lean into the strange contrast between this performance space and his scrappier ventures: He and the bass guitarist Brian Gibson will devise an improvised and likely more sedate set to match the mood from those seated in the plush red seats.\n\n\u201cI think the scene will most definitely be off in some way; I don\u2019t mind that,\u201d Mr. Chippendale said. The band is prepared to find its own source of energy rather than depend on a rowdy crowd, he added. \u201cWe\u2019re just this little band that drove over in our rickety van, and we\u2019re battling it out in the belly of the beast. I could conjure up some \u2018Moby Dick\u2019 scenario to get energized.\u201d\n\nHe also plans to draw inspiration from the video projections, which will be created by the artists Peter Burr and Sabrina Ratt\u00e9 from the Undervolt & Co. arts collective. Using digital and analog equipment, they will take turns mixing videos on the fly to match the music\u2019s mood; Ms. Ratt\u00e9\u2019s work is often characterized by serene, colorful undulations, while Mr. Burr opts for twitchy, near-seizure-inducing patterns.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve always wanted my work to be scalable: You can rock out a basement, but can also rock out the MoMA or a multiplex in Times Square,\u201d Mr. Burr said.\n\nFestivalgoers will be given wristbands in the lobby to differentiate themselves from the rest of the crowd. But the culture clash is sure to be startling: curious tourists and couples on a date night mixing with devout jazz heads, punks and artists venturing to the heart of the city.\n\n\u201cMaybe for an hour, it\u2019ll feel like there\u2019s some kind of zombie apocalypse, and this is the only place left,\u201d Mr. Chippendale said.", "title": "A Multiplex Where \u2018Black Panther\u2019 Plays Next Door to Experimental Music", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "For the past 17 months, the case had been hotly debated in Battleford, stirring deep feelings here about the treatment \u2014 both past and present \u2014 of the province\u2019s Indigenous population.\n\nMr. Stanley\u2019s supporters have used the episode to call for American-style \u201cstand your ground\u201d self-protection laws. Meanwhile, online vitriol has exposed the province\u2019s divide between the Indigenous and non-Native communities with a torrent of overtly racist comments that led to a call from the province\u2019s premier for everyone to \u201crise above intolerance.\u201d\n\nBen Kautz, a member of the municipal council in Browning, Saskatchewan, wrote, under his full name, in a Facebook page for farmers, now defunct, that Mr. Stanley\u2019s \u201conly mistake was leaving three witnesses.\u201d He has since stepped down from the council.\n\nAt the same time, many non-Indigenous people in Saskatchewan view Mr. Boushie\u2019s death as an injustice, including a group that stood in front of the courthouse on Thursday in bone-chilling cold holding signs and banners calling for justice.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Boushie\u2019s family and their supporters were angry about the police inquiry, which they called flawed and inadequate, contending that it initially focused more on the actions of the five young Indigenous people than on the killing of Mr. Boushie. They also said the case exposed a lack of progress in Mr. Trudeau\u2019s reconciliation effort.\n\n\u201cIf we are making progress why would it have exploded so much when he got shot?\u201d Jade Tootoosis, Mr. Boushie\u2019s cousin, asked the other day in the living room of their grandmother\u2019s house at Red Pheasant. \u201cI pity them because I don\u2019t understand why they feel so much hate for someone they don\u2019t know.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEleanore Sunchild grew up in the Thunderchild Cree First Nation north of Battleford. Now she runs a legal practice in town that specializes in resolving claims by former pupils of mandatory boarding, or residential, schools the federal government established in the 19th century.\n\nIn 2015 a national truth and reconciliation commission found the program to be \u201ccultural genocide\u201d against Indigenous people. Saskatchewan had more of the notorious schools than any other province, which both the commission and Ms. Sunchild blame for destroying Indigenous families for generations.\n\nMs. Sunchild, 45, said her home province was the national laggard on reconciliation.\n\n\u201cSaskatchewan is just beginning, I don\u2019t even know if we have really started on reconciliation,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m not saying that Indian people deserve a break because we\u2019ve been victimized. I\u2019m saying that both sides have to take accountability and responsibility for what got us into this situation in the first place.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe area is also an outlier on crime. Using data from Statistics Canada, a government agency, Maclean\u2019s magazine found that North Battleford, Battleford\u2019s sister community across the North Saskatchewan River, is the most dangerous place in Canada.\n\nCar theft is common, and farmers in the sparsely settled region complain about agonizingly slow wait times for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to arrive. A Facebook group, Farmers With Firearms, appeared after Mr. Boushie\u2019s death to call for allowing citizens to arm themselves, and also to support Mr. Stanley\u2019s actions on that fateful day.\n\nLast year, an association of rural municipalities in Saskatchewan passed a resolution asking the federal government to expand self-defense laws.\n\nBoth groups say their efforts are directed against criminals, not Indigenous people.\n\nAlvin Baptiste, Mr. Boushie\u2019s uncle, gave a tour of Red Pheasant to visitors this week. He acknowledged that some of the reserve\u2019s young people, along with white youths in the area, passed too much of their time with drinking, drugs and petty crime. For that he blamed the lack of job opportunities since the decline in oil prices, the lingering effects of the residential schools on families and the general dysfunction of the reserve.\n\nA relatively new and well-maintained school is an exception in the area. No footprints lead through the snow to a hockey arena seemingly too large for the 500 or so people who live there. Money and energy to keep it operating ran out some time ago.\n\nPhoto\n\nPointing to the community center across the street, Mr. Baptiste said that its basketball programs had stopped and that the building was used only for wakes and ceremonial occasions. Next to it are the abandoned gas pumps and building of what had been Red Pheasant\u2019s only store.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s nothing much to do on this reserve, there\u2019s nothing for them,\u201d he said, referring to young people.\n\nEvidence presented at the trial showed that the group in the car, while driving on a flat tire, had tried to steal a car at another farm before going to the Stanleys. In court, Mr. Stanley\u2019s lawyer acknowledged that a toxicology report showed that Mr. Boushie was \u201cso impaired it\u2019s hard to believe that he could function at all.\u201d\n\nChris Murphy, a lawyer retained by the Boushie family, said that a junior constable was initially put in charge of the investigation, forensic experts were not brought in and the car in which Mr. Boushie died was left uncovered, its doors open, for two rainy days, washing away evidence.\n\nThe police force declined to comment.\n\nMr. Stanley testified at trial that he grabbed his semiautomatic pistol to fire two warning shots. He said he was trying to turn off the engine of the car the men were driving while holding the pistol when the fatal bullet fired in what he testified was a complete surprise.\n\nExperts brought in by Mr. Stanley\u2019s lawyer said that on rare occasions, bullets can briefly linger inside guns and rifles after a trigger is pulled \u2014 although neither those experts nor ones with the police were able to recreate the flaw using Mr. Stanley\u2019s gun and ammunition.\n\nFor Ms. Tootoosis, the social media hatred prompted by the killing of her cousin may also prove to be his legacy.\n\n\u201cUltimately Coco\u2019s death needs to have a purpose,\u201d she said using the family\u2019s nickname for Mr. Boushie. \u201cIt\u2019s brought to light such a divide, and the question now isn\u2019t what is the government do about it, what are the courts going to do about it? It\u2019s, \u2018What am I going to do about it?\u2019 \u201d", "title": "A Murder Trial Stirs Emotions About Canada\u2019s Relations With Indigenous Population", "authors": ["Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Despite their trappings of wealth, Mr. Russo and Mr. Giuca, prosecutors said, were members of a wannabe street gang, the Ghetto Mafia, which was obsessed with \u201cThe Sopranos.\u201d As the night wore on, the two men became increasingly annoyed at Mr. Fisher, the authorities said: Mr. Fisher was a suburban kid who could not hold his liquor; he had been flirting with Ms. Denihan whom Mr. Giuca appeared to like as well; and he seemed to be an \u201ceasy target,\u201d someone the Ghetto Mafia could use to boost its credibility on the streets.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the root of the case\u2019s ambiguous nature was that a single, clear motive for murder was never established. But one thing was clear: when the sun came up a few hours after the group had piled into a cab Mr. Fisher was dead.\n\nThe investigation went nowhere for a year.\n\nWhen the police found Mr. Fisher\u2019s body, the only thing that he had on him was $12 in cash. But they quickly discovered his wallet in a nearby sewer and identified him. They also learned that Mr. Fisher\u2019s Fairfield friends had reported him missing. The friends told the police that Mr. Fisher had gone off with Ms. DiPietro and her own friends. That was how investigators learned about the party at Mr. Giuca\u2019s house.\n\nBut most of the young people who had been there were \u201cuncooperative,\u201d said Raymond W. Kelly, the city\u2019s police commissioner at the time \u2014 an accusation disputed by their parents.\n\nThe body had been found been across the street from Mr. Cleary\u2019s house. And Mr. Cleary, whose mother, Susan Cleary, was a top official in the Kings County Republican Party, hired a lawyer almost instantly. Investigators said that Ms. DiPietro, who had slept at Mr. Cleary\u2019s house that night, was at first \u201cdifficult to locate.\u201d But her father, James DiPietro, a prominent defense lawyer, said she made herself available.\n\nWithin minutes of the shooting, police records maintain, Mr. Russo rushed home and chopped off the dreadlocks he had worn for years. Two days later, when he was interviewed by the police, he implicated Mr. Giuca and Mr. Cleary in the murder. A few days after that, Mr. Russo, who had not been charged yet, bought an airline ticket and went to California. At more or less the same time, the police used his statement to arrest Mr. Giuca. Without more evidence, however, the district attorney\u2019s office declined to prosecute.\n\nPhoto\n\nForensic evidence, in fact, was slim. While a gun was never found, the police had recovered two of the five .22-caliber shell casings. Mr. Cleary\u2019s neighbors on Argyle Road reported hearing the shots, and police records show that some said they also heard a distinctly female voice on the street. Others claimed they saw a white car speeding up the block. Mr. Bederow, Mr. Giuca\u2019s lawyer, contends that Mr. Fisher was likely shot in the car and that the missing shell casings landed in it. In early reports, the police themselves said that Mr. Fisher had been dumped in the driveway from a car.\n\nAll of this \u2014 the kaleidoscopic theories, the stalled investigation, the constant media coverage \u2014 went on for months as no one was indicted. It took a toll on Mr. Fisher\u2019s parents, who lived in the bucolic town of Andover, N.J. Michael Fisher, an engineer for I.B.M., and Nancy Fisher, a real-estate agent, had never heard of Prospect Park South until they were told their son had been killed there. But on Feb. 4, 2004, four months after the murder, the Fishers joined the police at a news conference across the street from Mr. Giuca\u2019s house, urging his friends to share what they knew. Two days later, echoing their plea, The Daily News published a scathing editorial saying it was \u201cbeyond pathetic\u201d that the witnesses in the case had \u201clawyered up.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSomeone who was at that party knows something,\u201d The News opined. \u201cThe question: Does he or she have compassion and conscience enough to come forward?\u201d\n\nBy May 2004, having already offered a $100,000 reward, the Fishers met with Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. They were furious with how Mr. Hynes was handling the case and demanded changes. They soon got what they wanted. That same month, The Daily News later reported, Mr. Hynes created an \u201celite team\u201d to reinvestigate the killing, largely by going after the uncooperative young people. \u201cThey thought they could wait us out and thumb their nose at us,\u201d Mr. Hynes told The News. \u201cAnyone who saw pictures of that kid lying on the pavement with all the bullet wounds and did not feel a tinge of empathy is a cretin.\u201d\n\nJoe Hynes, as everyone in the Brooklyn courts called him, had been in office for nearly 15 years. But in 2004, he was anxiously anticipating a tough re-election campaign as several candidates were lining up to challenge him in the 2005 Democratic primary. The Fisher investigation was becoming a political albatross. Mr. Hynes needed a conviction.\n\nSo his new team went to work. In July 2004, nine months after Mr. Giuca\u2019s first arrest, he was arrested again, accused of having shot at a group of men in Florida while he was on vacation. Law-enforcement officials said at the time they hoped the arrest would pressure Mr. Giuca to cooperate in the Fisher case, which he did not. The Florida charges were ultimately dropped.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe prosecutors also empaneled an investigative grand jury that took testimony from nearly 100 witnesses. But by the end of the process, only two of them \u2014 Mr. Cleary and Lauren Calciano, Mr. Giuca\u2019s girlfriend at the time \u2014 offered any direct evidence of his involvement in the murder. In an odd move, Ms. DiPietro, who had seemed so central to the case, was never asked to testify.\n\nIn what was now his fourth interview with law enforcement, Mr. Cleary had completely changed his story, suddenly confessing that hours after the killing, he and Ms. Calciano had met with Mr. Giuca at his house on Stratford Road. Mr. Giuca, he said, told the two that he had given a gun to Mr. Russo, wanting him to show Mr. Fisher \u201cwhat\u2019s up.\u201d The testimony not only contradicted a polygraph test that Mr. Cleary had previously taken, showing he knew nothing about the murder; it also contradicted what Ms. Calciano said.\n\nIn her own testimony \u2014 the fifth time she had talked to the authorities \u2014 Ms. Calciano changed her story, too, admitting for the first time that she and Mr. Cleary had indeed met with Mr. Giuca after the murder. But her version of the meeting was different. She claimed Mr. Giuca had told them that Mr. Russo had approached him \u2014 not vice versa \u2014 asking for the gun because he wanted to rob Mr. Fisher. Mr. Cleary had also accused Ms. Calciano of hiding evidence after the shooting, a claim she denied.\n\nThis evidence, while far from ideal, was enough to secure indictments. And on Nov. 23, 2004, 13 months after Mr. Fisher\u2019s body was found, Mr. Russo was arrested. Mr. Giuca was arrested the following month.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut before the case went to trial, a surprise witness emerged: John Avitto, a career criminal who met Mr. Giuca when they were housed together in a jail on Rikers Island. Mr. Avitto, who had a history of drug abuse, had just been released to a treatment center and almost immediately relapsed. When a warrant was issued for his rearrest, he called the police, telling them that Mr. Giuca, in a jailhouse buddy way, had confessed to the murder. Offering to help the investigation, Mr. Avitto said that Mr. Giuca had not only admitted to furnishing the gun that killed Mr. Fisher, but was actually present at the murder scene himself.\n\nTantalizing as it was, this new account had a curious problem: It was notably different from all of the other stories the prosecution had heard.", "title": "A Murder, a Conviction and a Never-Ending Case", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "BORDEAUX, France \u2014 Bordeaux, the region, is unrivaled historically as the greatest, most prodigious producer of fine wine in the world.\n\nBordeaux, the port city on the Garonne river, has played a crucial role as the center of the wine trade. Historically, though, it has lacked charm and lovability, and paradoxically, beyond its commercial ties, Bordeaux has had little connection with the wine producers in the growing regions that define the region and practically surround the city.\n\nBut an ambitious wine museum that opened in the city of Bordeaux on the west bank of the river in 2016 is working to change that. While capturing the worldwide culture of wine in a modern, immersive, multimedia style, La Cit\u00e9 du Vin hopes to serve as a critical link between the urban center of the wine trade and the myriad producers who have historically stood apart.\n\nSimply as a cultural center, the City of Wine succeeds brilliantly in many ways. As a symbol, the curvaceous, contemporary building designed by XTU, a Parisian architecture firm, swirls up from the riverside not unlike the Guggenheim Museum flowing upward on staid Fifth Avenue. As a statement, it says that hidebound, conservative Bordeaux is no more.", "title": "A Museum Bridges the Divide Between Two Bordeaux", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cRespect First, Then Gun Control,\u201d by David Brooks (column, Feb. 20):\n\nNo, Mr. Brooks! Absolutely not! The influence the gun lobby has had on this country is not respectable; it is shameful, and the suggestion that we should first concern ourselves with Red America\u2019s feelings and only then with the lives of our children is frankly breathtaking.\n\nMy sincere best wishes to Better Angels, the nonprofit mentioned by Mr. Brooks, and its effort to rationalize political discourse in this country, but red-versus-blue stereotyping is simply not the issue when it comes to guns.\n\nMass shootings have become an everyday occurrence in the United States, and that horrific fact clearly correlates with the fact that the country is flooded with firearms, and flooded with firearms that have nothing to do with self-defense, or hunting, or any rational form of gun enthusiasm.\n\nFurthermore, it is simply not the case that the country is in any way evenly divided over this issue. In any popular vote, stricter background checks, waiting periods, bans on assault weapons and other reasonable gun control measures win in a landslide.", "title": "Opinion | A Nation Awash in Guns, and Outrage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "ZHOUSHAN, China \u2014 A fiery collision that sank an Iranian tanker in the East China Sea a month ago has resulted in an environmental threat that experts say is unlike any before: An almost invisible type of petroleum has begun to contaminate some of the most important fishing grounds in Asia, from China to Japan and beyond.\n\nIt is the largest oil spill in decades, but the disaster has unfolded outside the glare of international attention that big spills have previously attracted. That is because of its remote location on the high seas and also the type of petroleum involved: condensate, a toxic, liquid byproduct of natural gas production.\n\nUnlike the crude oil in better-known disasters like the Exxon Valdez and the Deepwater Horizon, condensate does not clump into black globules that can be easily spotted or produce heart-wrenching images of animals mired in muck. There\u2019s no visible slick that can be pumped out. Experts said the only real solution is to let it evaporate or dissolve. Absorbed into the water, it will remain toxic for a time, though it will also disperse more quickly into the ocean than crude oil.\n\nExperts say there has never been so large a spill of condensate; up to 111,000 metric tons has poured into the ocean. It has almost certainly already invaded an ecosystem that includes some of the world\u2019s most bountiful fisheries off Zhoushan, the archipelago that rises where the Yangtze River flows into the East China Sea.", "title": "A Nearly Invisible Oil Spill Threatens Some of Asia\u2019s Richest Fisheries", "authors": ["Steven Lee Myers", "Javier C. Hern\u00e1ndez"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cNew Jersey Rejoins Regional Emissions Program It Quit Under Christie\u201d (news article, Jan. 31):\n\nWhen it comes to cutting carbon emissions, participating in a cap-and-trade program like the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative is important, but it\u2019s only a partial solution. After all, the initiative covers emissions solely from power plants, whereas transportation produces the bulk of New York\u2019s emissions. And so far, the initiative has not cut carbon at the speed science tells us is required to avert dangerous warming.\n\nTo do that, we\u2019ll need a more comprehensive and aggressive form of pollution pricing. Your article highlights the laudable effort by Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington State to tax fossil fuel pollution directly and reinvest the revenue in renewable energy. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York will soon have the same opportunity.\n\nNY Renews, a coalition of 140 environmental, labor and community groups across New York State, has been developing a proposal \u2014 likely to be introduced in Albany this year \u2014 to invest in job-creating clean energy and resiliency projects for coastal communities, using revenue from a polluter fee.\n\nWe need Governor Cuomo to be a real climate leader and embrace this common-sense idea, and lead the country in passing it into law.", "title": "Opinion | A Need for a Pollution Tax", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "But the three partners began making plans early last year, before any of those developments.\n\n\u201cYou know, the time has been right for this conversation for a long time,\u201d Ms. Allison said. \u201cYesterday was the right time. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A New Cocktail Conference With a Political Twist", "authors": ["Robert Simonson"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "CAMBRIDGE, Mass. \u2014 Few people have experienced as dramatic a life as Angela Davis.\n\nNearly 50 years ago, she was transformed from an obscure 26-year-old philosophy instructor into one of the world\u2019s most famous activists, an instantly recognizable icon of the global left whose image, complete with her signature full Afro, was emblazoned on T-shirts, buttons and banners.\n\nNow she has achieved canonization of a more scholarly sort. The Schlesinger Library at Harvard University\u2019s Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study is announcing Tuesday that it has acquired her personal archive, more than 150 boxes of papers, photographs, pamphlets and other material that spans her entire life.\n\nThe acquisition comes as scholars are telling a less male-dominated, top-down story about the Black Power movement and the left in general. It also sheds light on the rise of intersectional feminism (which takes into account women\u2019s overlapping identities) and the campaign against mass incarceration, to name two causes Professor Davis helped pioneer before there were quite words for them.", "title": "A New Home for Angela Davis\u2019s Papers (and Her \u2018Wanted\u2019 Poster)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cGood morning all! Have a nice day!\u201d\n\nThe seven words stopped Lina Shah as she scurried through the subway turnstiles under Times Square on a recent morning, in the thick of rush hour. The words are more typically heard when entering a department store, the automaton drone of a hired greeter. But they seemed so incongruent in the dour tunnels of the New York City subway that Ms. Shah paused in the middle of her commute to find their source.\n\nThen she heard the voice again: \u201cGood morning to you! Have a good day, now!\u201d\n\nThere, standing on a busy passageway connecting the Port Authority Bus Terminal with the A, C and E lines was Tonya M. Cooper, a longtime employee of the agency that runs the subways, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, rattling off good morning salutations at a rate of 32 a minute.\n\nSince November, Ms. Cooper and 40 other transit workers have been shifted into a job that is based largely on the notion that being unrelentingly nice can go a long way to help bolster the image of a flagging, frequently curse-inducing subway system.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re so friendly!\u201d Ms. Shah, an accountant, told Ms. Cooper, after watching her direct a man to the A train, and kneel to tell a little boy, and his mother, which exit to use. \u201cIt\u2019s nice to know somebody cares.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe position, officially a customer service ambassador, or Wayfinder, is a pilot program introduced as part of the Subway Action Plan, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo\u2019s $836 million initiative to begin addressing the problems riddling the subway system. The plan, which followed Mr. Cuomo\u2019s declaration of a subway emergency last year, focuses on substance, like repairs to infrastructure signals and tracks, as well as on less-tangible elements, like the system\u2019s ambience.", "title": "A New Job Description for M.T.A. Kathleen Tracey, a former company member turned ballet master, has coached Ms. Woodward in several roles including this one. She said she has come to realize how right Mr. Martins was to pick Ms. Woodward.\n\n\u201cIndiana has depth,\u201d Ms. Tracey said. \u201cWhile on the surface she is a very bubbly, lovely, charming kind of person, she is starting to be able to find her way through the harder scenes, which are when she refuses Paris and when she actually has to be faced with \u2018Do I drink this potion, do I not?\u2019 \u201d\n\nMs. Tracey says this is a ballet for a dancer to evolve in, asking a profound question of its lead: How much do you do for love? \u201cIt\u2019s about finding those real human feelings and showing the pain she would feel or the despair,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re getting there.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a matter of braiding dancing with nuanced acting, in which a quick glance or hesitation can make the story come alive. As a coach, Ms. Tracey is understated and deceptively casual. When, at one point during a recent rehearsal, Ms. Woodward was struggling with spacing, Ms. Tracey told her: \u201cCenter schmenter. Be where you are.\u201d\n\nThe two have a lighthearted back and forth, which was evident as Ms. Tracey, who is known as Katey, focused on helping Ms. Woodward give her reactions more texture. In an early scene in which Juliet\u2019s parents tell her that marriage to Paris is on the horizon, Ms. Tracey wanted Ms. Woodward to show how Juliet was part girl, part woman. \u201cDon\u2019t be afraid to use your face,\u201d she said. \u201cI love the moment when you cross over and pause, like, no, I\u2019m just a kid.\u201d She smiled encouragingly. \u201cI\u2019m just planting seeds.\u201d\n\nMs. Tracey mimicked pouring from a pitcher and added, \u201cWater.\u201d\n\nThrowing her arms in the air, Ms. Woodward said, \u201cBlooming.
