But a month later, Ms. Long and Mr. Scott watched its two fiercest rivals, Georgia and Alabama, advance to the national championship game, while Auburn finished its season by losing in the Chick-fil-A Peach Bowl to unbeaten University of Central Florida.\n\nMs. Long and Mr. Scott know something about the longevity of streaks. Both spent more than 50 years in the glow of what they describe as near-perfect marriages, then were brought low by the deaths of their spouses. But love, as Ms. Long, 83, and Mr. Scott, 80, learned late in life, has a way of winning.\n\n\u201cThis was not supposed to happen,\u201d said Mr. Scott of his relationship with Ms. Long, which turned romantic in 2015 after decades of friendship. \u201cI never intended it to happen, and Judy never intended it to happen. But together we have 105 years\u2019 worth of experience being married. So we like to tell people we\u2019re pretty sure we know what we\u2019re doing.\u201d", "title": "A New Life for an Old-School Couple", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "L\u2019Atelier de Jo\u00ebl Robuchon may be the world\u2019s most expensive restaurant chain. Each time I ate in the newest one, which opened across 10th Avenue from Chelsea Market in November, I listened to people around me compare notes on which of the 11 other locations they\u2019d visited. Tokyo was popular, as were Las Vegas and, of course, the original in Paris.\n\nAs they reeled off their Atelier achievements, these people always sounded contented. And it must be soothing to know that as you travel the world you will find an Atelier waiting for you to climb up on a comfortable red leather stool, watch the cooks dressed in what look like black pajamas, admire the slightly supernatural colors of the vegetables and fruits submerged in water inside glass vases, recline into a menu filled with Robuchon classics and small variations on the same key ingredients (eggplant, quail, squab, lobster), all at prices that most people can\u2019t afford, but you can.\n\nLulling familiarity was not Jo\u00ebl Robuchon\u2019s aim when he built the first Atelier almost 15 years ago. Having won just about every honor the French gastronomic world offers at his first restaurant, he had officially retired, and when he came back it was only to knock the whole system on its side. His idea was a restaurant where the food, made to his excruciatingly precise standards, would be served not at tables but at a U-shaped counter. The format may have been borrowed from Japan or Spain, but in France the effect was radical, as were the late-night closing hours and no-reservations policy.\n\nThe proof of L\u2019Atelier\u2019s success is how un-shocking this sounds today.\n\nEarly on, as R.W. Apple reported in The New York Times, the prices could be modest \u201cif you avoid caviar and foie gras.\u201d This was less true by the time of L\u2019Atelier de Jo\u00ebl Robuchon\u2019s initial New York run, at the Four Seasons Hotel in Midtown from 2006 to 2012, where Frank Bruni awarded it three stars. I remember feeling distinct pain there each time I paid the check.", "title": "A New Link in the World\u2019s Most Expensive Restaurant Chain", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Plenty of people regularly ate sandwiches as kids. But few, if any, have spun that experience into culinary gold like Mason Hereford, whose restaurant Turkey and the Wolf in New Orleans was lauded by Bon App\u00e9tit as America\u2019s best new restaurant in 2017.\n\n\u201cI sure enough ate my share,\u201d said Mr. Hereford, 31, who grew up Charlottesville, Va., before moving to New Orleans in 2008 and working his way from line cook to chef de cuisine at Coquette, a respected contemporary Southern bistro. \u201cBut it wasn\u2019t until I came to this city of po\u2019 boys that I began to consider the creative potential of a sandwich.\u201d\n\nSandwiches are the stars at this 40-seat, no-reservation restaurant with street-front patio seating for 25 more, a former barbecue joint and a wings shop in the Irish Channel neighborhood. Inside, cinder block walls are painted sea-foam green and d\u00e9cor runs to thrift store whimsy. Patrons order at the counter and eat at sundry chrome dinettes off mismatched dishes (including plastic Disney plates), seasoning their food with kitschy vintage salt and pepper shakers.", "title": "A New Orleans Restaurant Offers Creativity Between Bread Slices", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "But like its predecessors, the new service is targeted at business travelers. \u201cThese were unique opportunities,\u201d Mr. Mann said, \u201cto do something that was much more generous than you would typically get.\u201d\n\nEastern Air Lines was the first to operate air shuttles, beginning in 1961, with service every other hour from La Guardia to Washington and Boston. Over the next four decades or so, shuttle services increased in frequency and, crucially, offered unlimited capacity on every departure.\n\nIf, for example, 100 people could fit on the plane at the gate in New York for the 8 a.m. departure to Boston but 101 passengers showed up, a second plane would be rolled out. \u201cIt\u2019s a very expensive proposition,\u201d Mr. Mann said, because airlines had to have planes and crews on standby. (Frequently, though, those standby aircraft never left the ground.)\n\nPhoto\n\nAirlines, however, still try to distinguish their shuttle flights to appeal to business travelers. \u201cThe word \u2018shuttle\u2019 has a really distinct meaning to our most frequent business travelers,\u201d said Vasu Raja, the vice president for network and schedule planning at American Airlines.\n\nAmerican\u2019s shuttles to Boston and Washington still follow a more consistent schedule than flights on other routes and tend to leave from the same gate. Passengers can also check in for the flights closer to departure time. Because of that consistency, Mr. Raja said, travelers \u201ccan be on autopilot\u201d while going through the airport.\n\nHe said the company had decided to expand its shuttle in response to customer demand. Chicago is a particularly strong market for business travel, he said, and the airline\u2019s frequent fliers in New York have long wanted the shuttle to fly there.\n\nDelta Air Lines is the only other airline that offers shuttle service. Like American, it operates out of La Guardia with flights to Boston, Washington and Chicago.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Delta shuttle caters to business travelers with similar in-flight amenities and check-in rules, and has dedicated security lanes at La Guardia. The schedule is aimed at accommodating travelers who want to fly round-trip in one day.\n\n\u201cThose shuttle markets are designed for a customer to leave in the morning and come back in the afternoon or evening,\u201d said Henry Kuykendall, Delta\u2019s senior vice president for Northeast airport operations. \u201cOther markets you have to overnight.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen Eastern Air Lines sold its shuttle routes to Donald J. Trump in 1989, the real estate mogul doubled down on the idea of luxury service, installing faux marble counters in the lavatories and chrome-plated seatbelt buckles embossed with the airline\u2019s logo on the rebranded planes. Flight attendants wore faux pearls and served a cold meal and sometimes as many as two rounds of drinks on the 40-minute flights to Washington.\n\nThe company even had a concierge service during the week. Passengers could drop off their dry cleaning before departing in the morning and have it waiting for them when they returned in the evening. The concierge would even arrange a dinner reservation.\n\nThe Trump Shuttle was sold a few years later to USAir Group, which operated it as a separate entity for five years before folding it into US Airways. The shuttle moved to American Airlines when the two carriers merged in 2013. Delta acquired its early shuttle routes to Boston and Washington from Pan Am in 1991.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile flying is the fastest way to get to Chicago from the East Coast, shuttle flights face stiffer competition from Amtrak in the Boston-New York-Washington corridor. Frequent travelers tend to gravitate to one mode of transportation over another, and fans of the air shuttle are more than happy to make a case for their preferred way to travel.\n\n\u201cI definitely take the shuttle more than I take the train,\u201d said Justin Nelson, a co-founder and the president of the National L.G.B.T. Chamber of Commerce. \u201cI do both, but I definitely prefer the shuttle.\u201d He lives and works in Washington, but has to travel to New York about twice a month and, he said, most often takes the American shuttle.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m an American Airlines frequent flier, and part of that is just loyalty and doing good by companies that are doing good by you,\u201d Mr. Nelson said. \u201cI have found that the airlines fight hard for your business. They want to provide a service, and they\u2019re by no means perfect, but they\u2019re fighting for you as a customer.\u201d\n\nHe said he found the service on Amtrak to be more impersonal. He also likes that he can accrue frequent flier miles on the shuttle that apply to the airline\u2019s whole network. In addition, he said, American and Delta both support Mr. Nelson\u2019s organization.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEric Schwartz, the president and chief executive of Atavis Jet, a private plane charter company, also said he preferred to fly in the Northeast. \u201cThe shuttle is more efficient for my needs,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Schwartz lives in New York and frequently flies Delta to Washington for business or to visit family. \u201cI can get door to door from Manhattan to downtown D.C. in two hours,\u201d he said, adding that that\u2019s faster than the train.\n\n\u201cThe fact that Amtrak calls Acela a \u2018high-speed\u2019 train is silly to me,\u201d Mr. Schwartz said. \u201cIt\u2019s slow, it\u2019s lumbering, you\u2019re stopping every 20 minutes or so in little towns that don\u2019t warrant high-speed service.\u201d\n\nAirlines and railroads have gone toe to toe to win over customers in the Northeast corridor for decades, boasting of their own unique efficiencies. Amtrak stresses how train stations are more centrally located than airports.\n\nBut many shuttle fans prefer the speed of flying over taking the train.\n\nMr. Schwartz said one ad he saw more than a decade ago really drove the point home.\n\n\u201cI remember maybe 10 to 15 years ago when Amtrak was really trying to push Acela,\u201d he recalled, \u201cthere was an advertising war on the tops of taxicabs, and Delta had one that said: \u2018Planes are faster than trains. Period.\u2019 That stuck with me.\u201d", "title": "A New Shuttle Service, Minus the 1980s Frills", "authors": ["Zach Wichter"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor the past two years, Icelandic Provisions has been making skyr, a thick, custardy fermented milk similar to yogurt, in upstate New York. For its ninth flavor, the company asked the chef Gunnar Gislason, who has been advising the company, to devise a flavor. Mr. Gislason, who owns a restaurant in Reykjavik and is also the executive chef of Agern in Grand Central Terminal, dipped into his childhood and the Icelandic countryside for an elegant mauve-colored cherry-black currant skyr. Icelandic Provisions\u2019s skyr, which is made with cultures from Iceland, is creamier and not as tart as what he grew up eating, he said. \u201cSkyr like this is an amazing development,\u201d he said: Skyr Cherry-Black Currant, $1.75 to $1.99 for 5.3 ounces, icelandicprovisions.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A New Skyr From an Icelandic Chef", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis one is really worrisome to us,\u201d Mr. Lemons said. \u201cScammers are getting a government deposit into your account.\u201d\n\nIn the past few years, the I.R.S. said, its Security Summit \u2014 a collaboration with state tax agencies and makers of do-it-yourself tax software \u2014 has helped reduce incidents of tax-related identity fraud, in which someone files a fake return in your name to collect a refund.\n\nBut now, criminals are increasingly targeting businesses, including tax professionals and human resource departments, because they are rich sources of sensitive personal information \u2014 including W-2 forms, bank statements and tax returns \u2014 that thieves can use to impersonate taxpayers and file bogus returns with authentic data.\n\n\u201cCriminals go where the data is,\u201d said Jonathan Horn, senior manager for tax policy and advocacy with the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.\n\nHow does putting the money in your account benefit the criminals? The thieves think you\u2019ll give it to them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe crooks, for example, will call victims and pretend they\u2019re a collection company for the I.R.S., which has deposited the funds in error. They then demand that victims transfer the money to a different account. \u201cThey say, \u2018We made a mistake; send it back to us,\u2019\u201d Mr. Lemons said.\n\nOr, they will leave voice messages threatening the taxpayer with criminal fraud charges or an arrest warrant if they don\u2019t call the number provided to return the \u201crefund.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt signifies the ingenuity of the fraudsters out there,\u201d said Russell Schrader, executive director of the National Cyber Security Alliance, which promotes online safety and security.\n\nThe scam has the ring of truth for victims, as there is actually an erroneous deposit sitting in their bank account (or in some cases, a paper check in the mailbox). That can frighten victims into acting, especially if a caller is bullying them. But it\u2019s always best to hang up and independently check whether the information you were given is valid, said Eva Velasquez, chief executive of the nonprofit group Identity Theft Resource Center. \u201cAlways go to the source when you get these kind of contacts,\u201d she said. Look up a public number for the I.R.S. online, she advised, and contact the agency to ask if the call was legitimate. (The I.R.S. identity theft unit\u2019s number is 1-800-908-4490).\n\nHere are some questions and answers about tax refund fraud:\n\nWhat should I do if an erroneous tax refund is deposited in my account?\n\nIf it seems too good to be true, it probably is, Mr. Lemons said. Don\u2019t forward the money, he said, and don\u2019t spend it: \u201cDon\u2019t go out and make a down payment on a new car with the cash.\u201d\n\nIf the refund arrived as a direct deposit, the agency said that you should contact your bank\u2019s automated clearinghouse department and have the funds returned to the I.R.S. (Consumers may also need to close their account.) Call the I.R.S. to explain why the money is being returned, notify your tax preparer and file a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission.\n\nIn the case of paper checks, the next steps depend on whether you have cashed the check. The agency provides details on its website.\n\nWhat questions about security procedures should I have for my tax preparer?\n\nMr. Horn with the accountant association recommended that consumers ask whether their tax preparer uses encrypted email \u2014 standard email isn\u2019t secure and should never be used for sensitive financial information \u2014 and where the agency stores its paper files.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Lemon offered his own suggestions: Do you update security protocols regularly? Do you train employees to recognize phishing attacks? How is information shared securely with clients?\n\nDavid Thomas, chief executive of Evident ID, an information security company based in Atlanta, suggested asking which employees have access to your files, and inquiring whether the firm offers extra login security. He particularly likes YubiKey, a token that authenticates a user\u2019s identity.\n\nThe tax preparation firm \u201cshould have confident answers\u201d to your questions, Mr. Thomas said.\n\nDoes a bogus refund in my account mean a fake tax return was filed in my name?\n\nMost likely yes, but you should contact the I.R.S. to verify if it has accepted a return using your Social Security number, Ms. Velasquez said. In some fraud cases overseas, she said, criminals have been known to mix and match stolen information. So it may be possible that criminals used one person\u2019s data to file a tax return, but someone else\u2019s bank account to deposit the refund. If a fraudulent return was filed in your name, she said, you\u2019ll probably have to file a special affidavit with the I.R.S. explaining that you are a victim of identity theft. Victims can contact the resource center for free help, she said.", "title": "A New Tax Scam, and Tips on How to Deal With It", "authors": ["Ann Carrns", "Your Money Adviser"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The cheerleaders have been eating their meals in one of the ballrooms of the adjacent hotel, about 100 meters from their accommodations, Kim said. The women arrived for meals in staggered groups of 30 or so, with two older male chaperones accompanying each group. They enter the ballroom in neat, double-file lines, and when they are finished eating they line up again for the two-minute walk back to their rooms.\n\nSuch military precision has been one of the visual hallmarks of their visit this month. At the stadium on Monday, the North Koreans carried identical bags with cheering props, including the white-and-blue unification flag. They wore matching red snowsuits \u2014 which swished loudly as they walked in packs \u2014 and white sneakers that looked vaguely similar to Adidas. They yelled slogans about unity and sang old Korean folk tunes.\n\nThe North Koreans do not make a move without at least one other compatriot and a South Korean government monitor. Trips to the restroom before and after the hockey game, for instance, took place in groups. And the older North Korean men chaperoning the squad who left the stadium during the game for cigarette breaks did so in groups of three.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt times the cheerleaders seemed perfectly engaged with their surroundings, inching forward with anticipation whenever the Korean team made a rare foray toward goal, waving back at times to curious passers-by. The arena was never louder than it was after Sweden scored the first of eight goals and the North Korean cheer squad immediately sparked a rousing, flag-waving chant of \u201cCheer up!\u201d that was joined by nearly everyone in the stadium.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut at other times they seemed utterly oblivious, or indifferent, to their surroundings. In the second period, an American man proposed to his girlfriend on the arena\u2019s video board, earning raucous cheers, and then a long round of warm applause, from the rapt crowd. All the while, the North Koreans, staring straight ahead, never stopped chanting, \u201cWe are one!\u201d\n\nDuring a stoppage later on in the game, when four scantily clad South Korean cheerleaders gyrated to the song \u201cGirlfriend,\u201d by Avril Lavigne, the North Koreans swayed, clapped and sang their own song in a completely different beat.\n\nSuch moments of dissonance combined to a dreamlike effect.\n\n\u201cThey will stick on message,\u201d said Jenny Town, assistant director of the U.S.-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins\u2019s School of Advanced International Studies. \u201cThey are basically unflappable.\u201d\n\nTown said cheerleaders in North Korea were groomed much like athletes and other entertainers, who are seen as symbols of national strength and discipline, and came from elite families in Pyongyang.\n\nHan Seo-hee, 35, a North Korean defector to the South, who was picked to be a cheerleader 16 years ago, said squad members were drawn from various performance troupes around the capital. She said many, herself included, belonged to a band associated with the Ministry of People\u2019s Security, a national law enforcement agency, which she joined after high school. Though it was not a year-round job, the women could be called in for months of full-time training before a major event.\n\nHan explained the selection criteria: \u201cThose who are well assimilated to the North Korean regime, those who are exemplars of working collectively, those who are from the right families, and of course those who meet the height and age standards,\u201d she said.", "title": "A Night Out With North Korea\u2019s Cheerleaders: Matching Snowsuits, Military Discipline and Chaperoned Bathroom Trips", "authors": ["Andrew Keh"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "A Diagnostic Consensus\n\nLike the patient herself, her doctors assumed all her symptoms were connected to the can she\u2019d dropped on her foot. Why hadn\u2019t that injury healed? And why was the entire right leg \u2014 and some of the left \u2014 so painful? None of the tests conducted in her nearly two weeks in the hospital explained it. Eventually her first Mass General doctors concluded that she had an unusual disorder called complex regional pain syndrome (C.R.P.S.). This disorder, which usually affects a limb after some trauma, is thought to be caused by injury to the nervous system. That damage in turn causes pain, swelling and changes in skin color and temperature. No one knows why the body has this extreme overreaction. Treatment has to focus on reducing pain rather than on treating the disorder. Recovery takes months, even years. Having made this diagnosis, the doctors sent the patient home to follow up with specialists to treat the pain.\n\nIn the days after this second hospitalization, the patient worsened. She felt exhausted and cold all the time. One morning upon waking, she felt so weak and tired that she couldn\u2019t stand. She scooched herself along the floor toward the bathroom. Halfway there, she was so incapacitated that she lay down and called her sister. I think I\u2019m dying, she told her. Her hand dropped weakly to the floor. Her sister asked for 911, and the E.M.T.s came and took her to the emergency room for the third time.\n\nLoss of Blood\n\nA blood test showed that she was bleeding internally again. She had less than half the blood she should have in her circulatory system. No wonder she was cold and tired and out of breath \u2014 these are classic signs of severe anemia. She was given more blood and then transported back again to Mass General.\n\nAs Naranbhai read through the records, he compiled a list of diseases that could bring this woman to the hospital three times over a month with severe pain and blood loss. It was a scary collection. At the top were cancers that could keep her from making blood. Next: diseases that interfered with her body\u2019s ability to form clots and stop bleeding. All were terrible possibilities.\n\nPhoto\n\nDr. Leigh Simmons, the internist supervising Naranbhai, usually waited to see patients until after the resident developed his own thoughts about the case. But it was late, and this patient sounded particularly sick, so Simmons and Naranbhai went to visit the patient together.\n\nSeeing the Patient Anew\n\nShe was a small woman, quite thin and pale beneath a dark Mediterranean complexion. Her 15-year-old daughter stood holding her hand. Simmons introduced herself and then stepped back to let Naranbhai lead the investigation. Rather than focus his questions on her foot and leg, he cast a much wider net. Tell me everything that\u2019s going on, he asked. She\u2019d had her period for nearly a month now, the woman said. That had never happened before. And, her daughter added, she had these weird dots on her legs. They just popped up a few weeks before. Naranbhai looked carefully at the mother\u2019s legs. They were covered with tiny freckle-size dots of blood trapped under the skin at the hair follicles.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNaranbhai looked at Dr. Simmons. Was she thinking what he was thinking? He looked back at the patient. Did her gums ever bleed when she brushed her teeth, he asked. All the time, she exclaimed.\n\nCan I see? the young doctor asked. Her gums were swollen and beefy red. He felt as if they might start bleeding just by looking at them. He looked up to Simmons, who smiled back encouragingly. He knew what she had. And so did Simmons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nClues in the Diet\n\nWhat kind of foods do you eat? he asked. Every morning she had two scrambled eggs. For lunch she had tuna on crackers. And for dinner she had more scrambled eggs and rice. Did she ever eat any fruits or vegetables \u2014 especially oranges or lemons? Never, she told him. They gave her wicked heartburn.\n\nShe had something known as gastroparesis, she explained. Her stomach and intestines didn\u2019t move food forward normally, and so food stayed in her stomach for hours. When food moves that slowly, you have to be careful that what you eat agrees with you.\n\nNo citrus for years. It was clear to Naranbhai that this modern woman had an ancient disease. She had scurvy \u2014 a disorder caused by a severe deficiency of vitamin C.\n\nIn the mid-18th century, a naval surgeon named James Lind proved that the juice of oranges and lemons would cure the bony aches, strange bleeding and sudden death of sailors afflicted with the illness, and the British Navy later mandated the use of lemon juice on all vessels. But it wasn\u2019t until the 20th century that researchers recognized that the cause of scurvy was the lack of a certain nutrient, which they named vitamin C. Without this organic chemical, new connective tissue, essential for the repair or replacement of damaged or dying cells, cannot be made, and that causes the bleeding, the bruising, the telltale little red dots and the terrible fatigue. Our bodies can\u2019t make vitamin C, and so we rely on the foods we eat to provide it. Avoiding these foods \u2014 as this woman did \u2014 can deplete the body\u2019s supply in just a few months.\n\nThe Miracle of Vitamin C\n\nThe doctors sent off a blood test to measure her vitamin C, and they started the woman on large doses of the required vitamin. The improvement was almost immediate: her gums stopped bleeding within days; her bruises started to turn yellow and fade. And she started to feel stronger and less fatigued.\n\nThat was two months ago. Now she feels great. She still can\u2019t eat oranges. But she takes her vitamin C tablets every single day.", "title": "A Painful Bruise Wouldn\u2019t Heal. It Took Several Hospital Visits to Discover Why.", "authors": ["Lisa Sanders"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAbout 80 percent of patients with a hip fracture are never treated\u201d for osteoporosis, Dr. E. Michael Lewiecki, director of the New Mexico Clinical Research & Osteoporosis Center in Albuquerque and lead author of the study, said in an interview, \u201calthough almost all have osteoporosis and are at risk of another hip fracture.\u201d\n\nAlthough bone-sparing medication has been shown to reduce the risk of a second hip fracture, one study of 22,598 patients found that use of the drugs declined from \u201can already dismal 15 percent in 2004 to an abysmal 3 percent in the last quarter of 2013,\u201d Dr. Sundeep Khosla, a bone specialist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., wrote in an editorial in 2016 in the Journal of Bone and Mineral Research. He likened the situation to not treating patients for high blood pressure or elevated cholesterol following a heart attack.\n\nCalling it \u201ca crisis in the treatment of osteoporosis,\u201d Dr. Khosla said, \u201cDespite the development of several effective drugs to prevent fractures, many patients, even those who unequivocally need treatment, are either not being prescribed osteoporosis medication at all, or when prescribed, refuse to take them.\u201d\n\nThe problem is hardly trivial, both for patients and society at large. Considering hip fractures alone, depending on how they are treated, average direct medical costs for the first six months range from $34,509 to $54,054, most of which is paid for by Medicare, the study authors wrote. Each year more than 300,000 people over 65, three-quarters of them women, are hospitalized with a fractured hip.\n\nThe personal costs are far greater. About 20 percent to 30 percent of patients die within a year following a hip fracture and, the researchers reported, \u201cOf those who survive, many do not regain their pre-fracture level of function. About 50 percent of patients with hip fractures will never be able to ambulate without assistance and 25 percent will require long-term care.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA number of factors may have contributed to the downward trend in hip fractures that ended in 2012, according to Dr. Ethel Siris, a co-author of the new study and director of the Toni Stabile Osteoporosis Center of the Columbia University Medical Center in New York.\n\n\u201cThe population may be getting healthier, people are doing more exercise and may be more careful about falling,\u201d she suggested in an interview. But most likely a leading factor, she and her co-authors believe, was the introduction in 1995 of the drug Fosamax, a bisphosphonate that slows or prevents the loss of bone density, resulting in stronger bones.\n\nFosamax is now available generically as alendronate, and has been joined by several other medications capable of promoting stronger bones. However, Dr. Siris said, \u201cThere is clearly a treatment gap. Prescriptions have fallen off, and even when people at risk are offered medication, they are refusing to take it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMillions of prospective patients who could benefit from bone-preserving drugs are now afraid to take them. The fear probably has its roots in overly aggressive marketing and doctors who overprescribed bisphosphonates for every patient in the beginning stages of bone loss, a condition called osteopenia, with treatment often continued years longer than now considered appropriate.\n\nThen in the early 2000s, alarming news reports began to appear linking extended use of bisphosphonates to two uncommon bone problems: a very rare fracture of the femur and an even rarer condition called osteonecrosis of the jaw. A fear of these complications resulted in more than a 50 percent decline in bisphosphonate use from 2008 to 2012, Dr. Khosla said.\n\nAt the same time, Medicare reimbursements for bone density tests were sharply reduced, and doctors who did them in private offices could no longer afford to, which limited patient access and diagnosis and treatment of serious bone loss despite major improvements in treatment guidelines, Dr. Lewiecki said.\n\nIn the more than two decades since bisphosphonates were introduced, \u201cwe\u2019ve learned a lot about how to treat and whom to treat,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re much wiser now about selecting patients for treatment.\u201d No longer is osteopenia a condition that by itself warrants medication unless other factors indicate the patient has a significantly increased risk of breaking a major bone.\n\nPatients should be treated if their bone density measurement indicates osteoporosis in the hip, spine or forearm, the experts said. But even if the test indicates only osteopenia, Dr. Siris said, \u201cpatients should be considered osteoporotic if they already sustained a nontraumatic fracture in the hip, spine, shoulder, pelvis and sometimes the wrist or if they score high enough on FRAX,\u201d an online fracture risk calculator to estimate one\u2019s risk of breaking a hip or other major bone in the next 10 years. Her advice is three-pronged: \u201cmedication when appropriate, an adequate intake of calcium and vitamin D, and don\u2019t fall.\u201d \u201cTreatment should be individualized,\u201d Dr. Khosla said. \u201cEach patient is different, with different family history, risk factors, how fast they\u2019re losing bone and their personal concerns. If the focus is on patients with a high risk of fracture, the evidence is clear that the benefits of drug treatment well outweigh the risks.\u201d", "title": "A Perfect Storm for Broken Bones", "authors": ["Jane E. Brody", "Personal Health"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "The trick of Gast\u00f3n Acurio\u2019s latest restaurant, El Bodeg\u00f3n, is to make you believe it has always existed on this quiet corner in the Miraflores neighborhood. Mr. Acurio, Peru\u2019s most famous chef, with a global empire of 50 restaurants, kept the name and much of the design of the previous restaurant in order to evoke a classic Lime\u00f1a taberna. The walls are covered in old portraits of famous footballers and Peruvian celebrities. Classic rock \u2014 Sting, Clapton, the Beatles \u2014 plays in the background. Mostly local workers fill the intimate space, textured with dark wood, brick and marble tables, during a late lunch.\n\nWith nearly 50 dishes, the ever-evolving menu at Bodegon (which, in fact, opened in July) is a deep dive into casera home-cooking and Lima\u2019s multicultural cuisine. Over 20 years ago, Mr. Acurio lit the fuse for the boom in Peruvian cuisine, and here he is again, offering a new statement of possibilities. The chef said he is remembering and recovering the food from his childhood, \u201call the dishes that I lost in time because they were only made by my grandmother or my family or because they were just made in the \u201970s.\u201d While this effort could easily descend into an exercise in twee nostalgia, Mr. Acurio\u2019s playfulness and sincerity grounds things in the present: The menu follows seasonal, local ingredients and he solicits food memories from his customers and on social media.\n\nDuring a recent visit, baffled by options, we depended on the friendly and knowledgeable waiters to decipher the menu. We started with the salty and rich crab causa, poetically named \u201cmore crab than causa,\u201d which arrived as a Pop Art provocation of golden mashed potato layers overflowing with a crab and egg salad, drenched in a Pepto-Bismol-pink sauce. A salad of lima beans was fresh and tasty. A whole cauliflower did something new with a vegetable oft overlooked in Peru, subbing here for chicken in the popular dish aji de gallina; cooked in a rich creamy sauce spiked with Parmesan and peppers, the cauliflower melted in my mouth. The huatia de res \u2014 an ancient pre-Columbian preparation of braised beef in herbs \u2014 was succulent, accentuated by sides of beans, rice and fried yuca.", "title": "A Peruvian Legend Goes Old School at a New Lima Taberna", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "His original choreography had Juliet\u2019s father knocking her down with a loud slap at one point \u2014 a moment of jarring violence that drew gasps when the ballet was new in 2007, and the condemnation of some critics. Alastair Macaulay, the chief dance critic for The New York Times, wrote that the slap left a \u201cdisproportionately awkward aftertaste,\u201d and said that it raised troubling memories of a 1992 incident in which Mr. Martins was arrested and accused of assaulting his wife, the ballerina Darci Kistler \u2014 charges that were later dropped.\n\nCompany officials worried how the slap would be received this year, given the accusations of physical abuse that had been detailed against Mr. Martins in articles in both The New York Times and The Washington Post, not to mention the growing national conversation about the abuse of women. So Jonathan Stafford, a ballet master and former principal dancer with the company who is at the head of its interim leadership team, telephoned Mr. Martins. (The choreography for City Ballet productions is protected by contract, so changes must be authorized by the choreographer or the entity that holds the rights to the work.)\n\n\u201cIt seemed like he had definitely been thinking about it already, because he had a solution teed up and ready to go,\u201d Mr. Stafford said in an interview.\n\nThere will be no slap this year. When they came to the scene in the rehearsal last week, the dancer playing Juliet\u2019s father, Adrian Danchig-Waring, raised an arm as if thinking of slapping her \u2014 but did not strike. The Juliet, Lauren Lovette, touched her face and cowered.\n\nKathleen Tracey, the ballet master responsible for staging of \u201cRomeo + Juliet,\u201d said that Mr. Martins\u2019s tweak echoes a piece of City Ballet history.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHe took a page \u2014 and I think this is amazing \u2014 he took a page from Balanchine\u2019s book, and another Shakespeare that we do here, \u2018A Midsummer Night\u2019s Dream,\u2019\u201d she said. In that ballet, she added, Balanchine has an angry Demetrius prepare to kick Helena \u2014 but then restrain himself. \u201cThat\u2019s the same idea that Peter said we should do this season.\u201d\n\nCity Ballet is still associated above all with Balanchine, one of the all-time great choreographers, who co-founded the company in 1948 with Lincoln Kirstein. But it has now been a post-Balanchine company for as long as it was a Balanchine company \u2014 35 years. Now the company is once more at a turning point, just as it was when Balanchine died.\n\nBack then there were questions about whether the company would survive Balanchine. Mr. Martins, who had been a star dancer at the Royal Danish Ballet and then in New York under Balanchine, initially ran the company in tandem with the celebrated choreographer Jerome Robbins; Mr. Martins became its sole leader in 1990. He was widely credited with keeping its dancers strong in the core Balanchine repertoire; raising the quality of its dancing in recent years; and helping discover and establish some of today\u2019s most acclaimed choreographers, including Alexei Ratmansky, Christopher Wheeldon and Justin Peck. He also choreographed more than 80 ballets \u2014 though many failed to find favor with critics.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow the ballet world is pondering the fate of the Martins ballets in the post-Martins era. Mr. Stafford, who is leading the interim leadership team, said that more Martins works would be programmed in the 2018-19 season. Several of the company\u2019s biggest moneymaking story ballets were choreographed by Mr. Martins, including \u201cSwan Lake,\u201d and \u201cThe Sleeping Beauty\u201d \u2014 and Mr. Stafford said he could not imagine the Martins productions leaving the repertory. He also cited the power of other Martins works, including \u201cBarber Violin Concerto,\u201d \u201cHallelujah Junction,\u201d and \u201cFearful Symmetries,\u201d which is often used to test the mettle of young dancers to see of they can handle it.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs the company considers its future \u2014 and who the permanent successor to Mr. Martins should be \u2014 it is weighing the strengths and weaknesses of the company he is leaving behind. One area where City Ballet has not kept pace in recent decades is the diversity of its casts. More than 60 years after Arthur Mitchell became the company\u2019s first African-American dancer, there are few dancers of color in the company, and very few seen in certain kinds of roles. There have been signs of change in recent seasons under Mr. Martins, and Mr. Stafford said that a diversity effort begun several years ago by the School of American Ballet, a feeder school that trains nearly all the company\u2019s dancers, had helped put more young dancers of color into the pipeline. But he said that it was an issue that the interim leadership team had been discussing.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to just make sure that the organization is really a place that anyone can feel safe working, and comfortable and confident that they\u2019ll be allowed to flourish,\u201d he said.\n\nThese days the dancers are keeping their noses to grindstone, and just trying to get on with the physically taxing work of rehearsing by day and performing by night in the spring season \u2014 without the only boss any of them have ever known. If some former dancers have cheered his departure, and said that the episode had begun a long-overdue discussion about power dynamics and abuse in the insular ballet world, some current dancers felt bereft when he left.\n\nSterling Hyltin, who premiered the role of Juliet in 2007 and will be in the opening night cast this week, said that it had been tough at her dress rehearsal last week not to be able to confer with Mr. Martins.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve tweaked acting things, I\u2019ve come up with new moments,\u201d she said. \u201cMy Juliet has changed as I\u2019ve matured, I would hope. And just not having him tell me \u2018This reads, this doesn\u2019t read\u2019 \u2014 it\u2019s really hard.\u201d", "title": "A Peter Martins Ballet Loses Peter Martins, and a Slap", "authors": ["Michael Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The execution happened on Feb. 1, 1968, two days after Vietcong and North Vietnamese forces launched the coordinated attacks of the Tet offensive. Suddenly, insurgents were in dozens of cities, in almost every province of South Vietnam. They were in the streets of Saigon, the capital. They were even inside the heavily guarded compound of the United States Embassy.\n\nIt was a shocking sight for Americans, who had been assured by President Lyndon B. Johnson and his top general in Vietnam, William C. Westmoreland, that the enemy was on its last legs.\n\nMeredith H. Lair, a Vietnam War expert at George Mason University, said the offensive \u201ccaused people to question whether they\u2019d been fed lies by the administration, and to question whether the war was going as well as they\u2019d been led to believe, and to question whether the war could be won if the enemy was supposed to be cowed and appeared so strong and invigorated.\u201d\n\nIf the broader Tet offensive revealed chaos where the government was trying to project control, Adams\u2019s photo made people question whether the United States was fighting for a just cause. Together, they undermined the argument for the war on two fronts, leading many Americans to conclude not only that it could not be won, but also that, perhaps, it shouldn\u2019t be.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe photo \u201cfed into a developing narrative in the wake of the Tet offensive that the Vietnam War was looking more and more like an unwinnable war,\u201d said Robert J. McMahon, a historian at the Ohio State University. \u201cAnd I think more people began to question whether we were, in fact, the good guys in the war or not.\u201d\n\nA police chief had fired a bullet, point-blank, into the head of a handcuffed man, in likely violation of the Geneva Conventions. And the official was not a Communist, but a member of South Vietnam\u2019s government, the ally of the United States.\n\n\u201cIt raised a different kind of question to Americans than whether or not the war was winnable,\u201d said Christian G. Appy, a professor of history at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. \u201cIt really introduced a set of moral questions that would increasingly shape debate about the Vietnam War: Is our presence in Vietnam legitimate or just, and are we conducting the war in a way that is moral?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the months after the Tet offensive, public opinion shifted more rapidly than at any other point in the war, Dr. McMahon said. Adams\u2019s photo won a Pulitzer Prize, and Time magazine called it one of the 100 most influential ever taken.\n\n\u201cYou can talk about \u2018the execution photograph from the Vietnam War,\u2019 and not just the generation who lived through it but multiple generations can call that image to mind,\u201d said Susan D. Moeller, the author of \u201cShooting War: Photography and the American Experience of Combat,\u201d and a professor of media and international affairs at the University of Maryland. \u201cIt was immediately understood to be an icon.\u201d\n\nYet the decisions on how to display this photo and other graphic Vietnam war imagery were matters of debate in the newsroom of The Times. \u201cI remember certain pictures,\u201d the influential photo editor John G. Morris, who died at 100 last year, said, \u201cwhich I was just determined to get on page one.\u201d This was one, as was the 1972 picture of a naked 9-year-old, Phan Thi Kim Phuc, fleeing a napalm attack. That ran at the bottom of the page.\n\nIn South Vietnam, the execution image resonated in a different way. To Americans in 1968, it conveyed that North Vietnam and the Vietcong were far stronger than they had been led to believe. To South Vietnamese, it conveyed the opposite: Those forces \u201cno longer had the kind of aura of omnipotence that they had had before,\u201d said Mark Philip Bradley, a historian at the University of Chicago.\n\nThen there was the fallout for the person for whom viewers had the least sympathy: General Loan, the executioner, who would eventually move to the United States. In 1978, the government tried unsuccessfully to rescind his green card. He died 20 years later in Virginia, where he had run a restaurant.\n\nAdams himself, before his death in 2004, expressed discomfort with the consequences of his photo. He noted that photographs, by nature, exclude context: in this case, that the prisoner had killed the family of one of General Loan\u2019s deputies.\n\n\u201cTwo people died in that photograph: the recipient of the bullet and Gen. Nguyen Ngoc Loan,\u201d he wrote in Time magazine. \u201cThe general killed the Viet Cong; I killed the general with my camera.\u201d\n\n\u201cStill photographs,\u201d Adams wrote, \u201care the most powerful weapon in the world.\u201d", "title": "A Photo That Changed the Course of the Vietnam War", "authors": ["Maggie Astor"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "The couple read about Suburban Jungle, a free service that advises city dwellers making the switch to the suburbs. The service seemed ideal \u201cfor people like us who don\u2019t know where to go,\u201d said Brad, who is from the Hudson Valley.\n\nPhoto\n\nSuburban Jungle suggested a few towns in New Jersey, and the couple settled on Maplewood. They noticed that Morrow Memorial United Methodist Church displayed a gay pride banner, \u201cand that meant something to us,\u201d Brad said.\n\nMaplewood also had a lively downtown and was filled with charming houses that \u201care slightly larger than a starter home without being too large,\u201d said Amy Owens, the agent at Keller Williams in Montclair with whom Suburban Jungle matched them. The relatively small yards were appealing as well.\n\nBut they wanted to be within walking distance of the New Jersey Transit station, and \u201cthat was a big ask,\u201d Brad said.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen they realized that property taxes for the homes they were looking at were generally around $15,000 a year, they lowered their target price, dropping into the $600,000s. And at that price point, sellers had the upper hand, Ms. Owens said, with most properties snapped up in a matter of days.\n\nEarly on, the couple saw a modestly sized house they liked with three bedrooms, listed at $549,000, but they decided to hold out for something bigger. They were confounded when it sold quickly, for $623,000.\n\nThen they saw a lovely center-hall colonial with an asking price of $629,000. They offered $660,000, but it sold for $720,000.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe clearly had no idea what was going on,\u201d Brad said.\n\nListing prices seemed to have little meaning, with houses being bid up by tens of thousands of dollars. \u201cA house would go on the market on a Thursday, and by Monday they were going with 10 offers,\u201d Brad said. \u201cIt created a lot of stress.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLater, the couple saw another center-hall colonial they liked, with an attic that had been turned into a master suite. But it was listed for $719,000 \u2014 more than they wanted to spend \u2014 so they bid less than the asking price. When it sold for $730,000, they were both frustrated and relieved.\n\nLast summer, a listing for a side-hall colonial appeared for $639,000. It had four bedrooms, two bathrooms and a detached garage. And it was a 10-minute walk from the train station, which made the house even more appealing, although by then they had discovered that the town has what the couple call an \u201cadult school bus\u201d \u2014 a jitney that runs to and from the station.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere were several offers, Ms. Owens said, but theirs was the highest, at $687,000.\n\nTheir first thought was \u201cHave we actually just done this after two years?\u201d Ross said. \u201cIt was a scary moment, but we loved the house.\u201d\n\nThey arrived in the fall with their Boston terrier, Olive, still wondering whether they had paid too much or gotten a great deal.\n\nIn the beginning, the house seemed too large. \u201cIt was weird, having to go downstairs for your coffee before you went back upstairs,\u201d Brad said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond.
