A dishwasher pipe had burst.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNobody tells you about the bad stuff,\u201d Brad said. \u201cHow could I make it to 38 years old and be so ill-equipped to live in a house? Our life used to be so simple and straightforward.\u201d They shut off the water, contacted their insurance company and hired a plumber.\n\nAs they expected, the town is a good fit. Mr. Ross has even found British treats for sale at a nearby store, the Wine Barrel, \u201cso I can get my fill of digestive biscuits,\u201d he said.\n\nAnd while they are still furnishing their home, they can envision children there. \u201cWe can actually have a family here and not feel constrained,\u201d Brad said. \u201cI can see our future happening.\u201d", "title": "A Place With Room to Grow", "authors": ["Joyce Cohen", "The Hunt"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "The owners had decorated the house in a Southwestern style, but when Mr. Bonetti looked in the basement, he saw that they had saved the home\u2019s original furniture \u2014 much of it collectible chrome-and-leather pieces from the Pace Collection and custom seating by the designer Jacques Charpentier \u2014 and was elated to learn that it was included in the sale.\n\nThere was also a thick file of information, including the original architectural plans, by RKR Associates, and complete specifications for the house, which would be provided to the buyer.\n\nMr. Bonetti urgently dialed Mr. Kozerski with news of his find, and the pair abandoned their idea of building a showpiece from scratch. Instead, they bought the property for about $1.2 million, with the idea of restoring the original architect\u2019s vision, as well as expressing their own sense of style.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a series of renovations over the next decade, they spent about $500,000 replacing the deck; returning the second floor layout to its original configuration with two master suites; removing part of a bathroom to create a mudroom; adding a new tiled bar facing the redwood-paneled games room; and replacing carpets and refinishing floors.\n\nAnd they continually played with finishes, lighting and furniture.\n\nAs Mr. Kozerski put it, \u201cWe think of it as an experimentation lab,\u201d where they can try out new ideas without subjecting clients to things that might not work out \u2014 from risky paint mixes to a billiards table finished in purple felt.\n\nFor the exterior, which was painted a pinkish hue when they bought the house, they first tried to mimic the natural color of the original redwood cladding before realizing their error. \u201cWe had painted it brown, and a brown-painted house is never too good,\u201d Mr. Bonetti said.\n\nSo they went darker and repainted the house in Benjamin Moore\u2019s off-black Deep Caviar, which helped highlight the strong geometry of interlocking boxes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn the snow, it looks really black against the white,\u201d Mr. Kozerski said. \u201cIn the summer, it appears more charcoal and warm.\u201d\n\nIndoors, they installed a series of mismatched LED bulbs to see which ones provided the most pleasing glow at various times of day, before installing the winners in their clients\u2019 homes.\n\nIn the process, they were disappointed to discover that reflections on the glass obscured their views at night, so they tried painting some interior walls Deep Caviar and found that it significantly reduced the glare. Then they increased outdoor visibility with landscape lighting, trying out several colored filters before settling on an orange tint that made the greenery pop.\n\nThese days, they mostly take turns using the house. Mr. Bonetti visits one weekend with his wife, Francesca Forcella, 52, their wire-haired dachshund, Mina, and occasionally their teenage children, and Mr. Kozerski visits the next with his wife, Yoon Chang, 46, and their twin 8-year-old daughters, Ana\u00efs and Colette.\n\nBut the two men still sometimes go out together to tackle the biggest jobs, Mr. Kozerski said, \u201clike cutting down trees and drilling fence posts.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe have a caretaker who helps a lot, but there is still so much to do,\u201d Mr. Bonetti said. With such an expansive property, he added, \u201cwe have to work hard to maintain it, both financially and physically.\u201d", "title": "A Place to Experiment in the Poconos", "authors": ["Tim Mckeough", "On Location"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "At least one million people in Ethiopia were internally displaced in 2017, according to the United Nations, amid widespread unrest and an economy in free-fall. In a December meeting, the party\u2019s executive committee blamed Mr. Hailemariam\u2019s poor leadership for the country\u2019s and the party\u2019s woes \u2014 thereby sealing his fate. As the humanitarian, political and security crisis turned into calamity, he took personal responsibility for failing to stabilize the country rocked by stubborn protests from Oromo and Amhara ethnic groups, who together make up two-thirds of the population.\n\nThese protests, initially started by the Oromo, Ethiopia\u2019s largest ethnic group, began in 2014 over opposition to a controversial plan to expand the jurisdiction of the capital, Addis Ababa. Security forces responded to peaceful protests with excessive force, provoking outrage and further protests, which eventually spread to the Amhara region. This culminated in the declaration in October 2016 of a state of emergency lasting 10 months. Tens of thousands were arrested in the ensuing crackdown. However, as soon as martial law was lifted in August 2017, the protesters, mostly young, returned to the streets, demanding regime change and the release of political prisoners, estimated to number in the tens of thousands.\n\nMr. Hailemariam resigned a day after some of these prisoners were released, including prominent opposition leaders and journalists. (More than 6,000 detainees have been freed in the past month in a government amnesty that Mr. Hailemariam and his party promised in January.) The pardoned leaders were met with euphoric freedom rallies and homecoming celebrations across the Oromia region and in the capital, Addis Ababa. The outpouring of support for the freed leaders showed that the country can no longer be governed as it has been for the past 27 years \u2014 in the palm of one party.\n\nMore than Mr. Hailemariam\u2019s departure, what is important is how the transition will shake out. The E.P.R.D.F. needs a leader who can unify the party, gain popular legitimacy and calm widening political and ethnic tensions. Moreover, beyond the change of guard at the top, a major policy shift is needed. Repression has outlived its usefulness. Unfortunately, the restoration of martial law suggests that the E.P.R.D.F. is still not prepared to learn its lesson. But continued authoritarianism in the face of fierce and determined protests will be futile.\n\nTo end the succession battle, the choice is clear: The new reformist leaders of the Oromo People\u2019s Democratic Organization, led by Lemma Megersa, enjoy substantial public support. Everywhere they go, Mr. Lemma and his entourage receive a hero\u2019s welcome, on a par with that received by the just-released opposition leaders \u2014 itself a significant change for a party whose support is often either bought or coerced. The O.P.D.O.\u2019s youthful leaders relate easily to a generation now in revolt. Their support base cuts across political, ethnic and religious fault lines partly because they adopted the demands of the protesters and made bold commitments to democratization and unity.", "title": "Opinion | A Placeholder Prime Minister Departs. What Comes Next?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "During the play\u2019s 2 hours and 30 minutes, free market watchwords \u2014 not to mention, religious piety, racism, judicial corruption and well-intentioned liberals \u2014 all come in for a drubbing. But the central theme is one that runs through all the playwright\u2019s work: humanity\u2019s irredeemable flaws.\n\n\u201cI probably write the way I do because I\u2019m disappointed,\u201d Mr. Norris said. \u201cI was a very optimistic child and I had a very close relationship with my mother who promised me good things, and then, as I said in another play, she smoked herself to death. So that was a mixed message.\u201d\n\n\u201cClybourne Park,\u201d which won the Pulitzer Prize in 2011, the Olivier Award, and later the Tony, picks up where Lorraine Hansberry ended her seminal 1959 play, \u201cA Raisin in the Sun.\u201d Its subject is inescapable racism, class bias and anxiety.\n\nSimilarly, \u201cThe Low Road\u201d trains its sights on the species\u2019 inherent failings. The conclusion is that our greed, hypocrisy and ruthlessness will ultimately bring doom \u2014 even if there are a few laughs to be had along the way.\n\nHuman nature is both noble and ugly. Mr. Norris said his mother was intensely devoted to him and thus \u201cwas very excusing of all faults in me and very much encouraging me to cheat other children.\u201d\n\nAny misbehavior could be explained away. \u201cWhenever I would do badly in school, she would tell me the teacher\u2019s angry because I won\u2019t date her daughter,\u201d Mr. Norris said. \u201cShe did that out of her love for me. And we all do that to each other.\u201d\n\nMrs. Trewitt, the brothel madam who adopts the abandoned baby Jim on her doorstep, has the same instincts. \u201cTwas never my mother\u2019s wish I should be the equal of others,\u201d Jim says when he\u2019s grown, \u201cbut that I should exceed them.\u201d", "title": "A Political Satire on Stage, and Not About Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Mung bean cakes, left, and herbal jelly with taro balls are among the treats at Meet Fresh.\n\nCredit Caitlin Ochs for The New York Times", "title": "A Popular Taiwanese Chain Opens an Outpost in the East Village", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "For more coverage of race, sign up here to have our Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.\n\nThere are many lenses with which to view African-American history, but what about through the evolution of postcards? While it may not be a common vantage point, the narrative is a natural one for Marilyn Stern, a photographer and graphic artist who is a member of the Metropolitan Postcard Club of New York City.\n\nNot surprisingly, the vast majority of postcards that feature black people in the United States from the 19th and 20th centuries were very racist, she said.\n\n\u201cI was so sick of seeing these horrible racist stereotypes,\u201d said Ms. Stern, a collector since the mid-1970s. \u201cWhenever I came across something that was not racist or not stereotypical, or even went so far as showing romance between the races, I wanted to save it and collect it.\u201d", "title": "A Postcard View of African-American Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The lack of a car had begun to grate on the nerves of Jacqueline Troccoli and Alberto Pomello.\n\nThe couple lived in a high-rise in the Midtown West neighborhood of Manhattan. And most days, she walked to her downtown office, while he took the subway to work downtown. But anytime they left the city \u2014 which they frequently did \u2014 traveling was a challenge, as they usually took the train and were beholden to a schedule.\n\nWhenever they visited Ms. Troccoli\u2019s parents near Princeton, N.J., she said, \u201cWe would inevitably have to wait at Penn Station, because there was always something going on with New Jersey Transit.\u201d And once they got there, they had to be picked up at the station and driven back to catch the return train.", "title": "A Postcard View of Manhattan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 Tonga began cleaning up on Tuesday from the most powerful storm to hit the South Pacific island nation in at least 60 years, which flattened its Parliament building, damaged houses and left thousands without power.\n\nTropical Cyclone Gita was measured as a Category 4 storm, with sustained winds of up to 145 miles per hour, when it crossed south of Tongatapu, Tonga\u2019s main island, late Monday.\n\nThe storm knocked down the kingdom\u2019s century-old Parliament building and tore off roofs in the capital city of Nuku\u2019alofa.\n\n\u201cIt was a terrifying night,\u201d Graham Kenna, an adviser to Tonga\u2019s National Emergency Management Office, told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. \u201cWe\u2019re on the third floor of one of the safest buildings in Nuku\u2019alofa and the building was shaking and getting pounded by debris from missing roofs.\u201d", "title": "A Powerful Storm Leaves Tonga\u2019s Parliament Homeless", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Within a few months of The Times article, a headline in The Detroit News asked whether Mr. Dawkins should be allowed to profit from tragedy. Not long after that story appeared, Mr. Dawkins received the court summons, demanding partial \u201creimbursement to the state for Defendant\u2019s cost of care while incarcerated.\u201d\n\nImage Kimberly Knutsen says the deal her partner, Mr. Dawkins, landed for \u201cThe Graybar Hotel\u201d has helped support their family. Credit Leah Nash for The New York Times\n\nMichigan is one of more than 40 states where prisoners can be forced to pay for the cost of their incarceration, according to the Brennan Center for Justice at the New York University School of Law. Laws that allow the government to charge prisoners \u201croom and board\u201d or \u201ccost of care\u201d fees have proliferated in recent decades, as states charge inmates and parolees for everything from medical care, clothing and meals to police transport, public defense fees, drug testing and electronic monitoring.\n\nSince so many prisoners are impoverished to begin with, states typically don\u2019t raise much money by charging inmates room and board fees, and in some states, the enforcement of these laws is conditional on the prisoner\u2019s ability to pay. But as the cost of mass incarceration has soared, with more than 2.2 million adults in prisons and jails across the United States, some states have grown more aggressive in seeking money from prisoners and formerly incarcerated people.\n\nDuring the last fiscal year, Michigan collected some $3.7 million from 294 prisoners, who account for just a fraction of the state\u2019s nearly 40,000 inmates. Around the country, some 10 million people owe $50 billion in fees stemming from their arrest or imprisonment, according to a 2015 Brennan Center report.\n\nStates often take a percentage of the earnings inmates receive through prison work programs. But some states have also sought money from prisoners who have received larger sums, through an inheritance or legal settlements or, as in Mr. Dawkins\u2019s case, money they acquire through their own initiative. After an Illinois inmate who was serving a 15-month sentence for a drug conviction received a $31,690 settlement for his mother\u2019s death, he was forced to pay the state nearly $20,000 for the cost of his imprisonment, leaving him nearly destitute when he was paroled in 2015.\n\nIn Florida, a convict named Jeremy Barrett who received a $150,000 settlement from the Department of Corrections for negligence, after he was attacked in 2011 by another inmate who gouged out his eye, was forced to pay the state nearly $55,000 from the settlement as reimbursement for his three years in prison.\n\nWhen prisoners and former inmates fight such charges, courts often rule in the state\u2019s favor. In 2000, Connecticut\u2019s Supreme Court ruled that Eric Ham, who was serving a 50-year sentence for murder, had to pay nearly $900,000 toward the cost of his incarceration, after he won a settlement of around $1 million from the city of New Haven for falsely arresting him for another crime that he didn\u2019t commit.\n\nProponents of such laws argue that convicted criminals should pay for their own imprisonment when they have the financial means to do so. But some prisoners\u2019s rights advocates say saddling inmates and parolees with fees can hinder their rehabilitation by making it harder for them to support themselves and their families, and could violate the Eighth Amendment, which bars cruel and unusual punishment and excessive fines.", "title": "A Prisoner Got a Book Deal. Now the State Wants Him to Pay for His Imprisonment.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "The telenovela touches keep coming. When people are upset or frightened in this novel, their teeth chatter. Or they faint. Or froth at the mouth. Or retch. Or pee in their pants. This novel is no austere orgy of minor-chord emotion. Vargas Llosa, now 81, is playing to the balconies.\n\nBelow and beyond the tragicomedy, in this translation from the Spanish by Edith Grossman, Vargas Llosa is pressing a familiar point. He has long been a critic of tabloid excesses in Latin America, particularly so when the tabloids are manipulated by authoritarian political leaders in order to silence their critics.\n\nVargas Llosa has himself felt the sting of tabloid headlines in recent years, after he left his wife of 50 years and picked up with Isabel Preysler, the pop singer Enrique Iglesias\u2019s mother, and when his name appeared (erroneously, he has argued) in the Panama Papers, which exposed international tax havens.\n\nNo deep soil is overturned in \u201cThe Neighborhood,\u201d but two things keep one turning the pages. For one, it\u2019s a confident book and confidence is contagious. It\u2019s filled with cliffhangers \u2014 when the journalist is murdered, Enrique is the prime suspect \u2014 and over-the-top incident. For another, it is warm to the touch, particularly as regards sex.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis novel chronicles, in detail as damp as the bad guy\u2019s handshake, an unexpected lesbian affair that develops between Enrique\u2019s wife and the wife of his best friend and lawyer. The author seems to agree with Eve Babitz, who wrote that having affairs is the only creative thing most people will ever do.\n\nVargas Llosa\u2019s novels have always been enlivened by earthy detail. I tend to think of him during flu season, recalling that John Updike praised one of his early novels for the way his characters caught colds realistically.\n\nIn \u201cThe Neighborhood,\u201d the sex is hot and the beer is cold. His characters happily consume ceviche and tripe and pork rind sandwiches with onions and chili peppers. They drink Campari and pisco sours. They eat at a seafood place called Seven Deadly Fins. In a novel as contrived and uneven as this one, the human touches go a long way.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nArriving alongside \u201cThe Neighborhood\u201d is \u201cSabers and Utopias: Visions of Latin America,\u201d a book of essays, most of them political, written over the past five decades.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn these pieces, Vargas Llosa considers the dubious legacies of leaders such as Fidel Castro and Augusto Pinochet and Papa Doc Duvalier. He champions free speech and liberal democracies. He deplores homophobia and applauds laws to legalize marijuana.\n\nThis book is, sad to say, all but unreadable. Vargas Llosa\u2019s op-ed voice is not his best voice (it is few people\u2019s best voice) and these pieces, read years after they were composed, are essentially dead on the page.\n\nThere are a handful of alert moments in these essays, which have been translated by Anna Kushner. In a 2012 essay, he deftly sticks a hatpin into Julian Assange. In another essay he considers the effects his generation \u2014 the so-called Latin American Boom writers \u2014 had on the literary world. He notes, in a moving aside, that he\u2019s among the few members of that group still standing.\n\nVargas Llosa has been a frequent critic of Latin America, but he sorely misses it when he is away. In one essay, composed in Switzerland, he asks what that country has given us except cuckoo clocks and fondue.\n\nLatin America, on the other hand, has given the world \u201ca Borges, a Garc\u00eda M\u00e1rquez, a Neruda, a Vallejo, an Octavio Paz, a Lezama Lima, a Lam, a Matta, a Tamayo, and we\u2019ve invented tango, mambo, boleros, salsa, and so many rhythms and songs that the whole world sings and dances.\u201d\n\nVargas Llosa is too humble, a rarity for him, to add his own name to this list of cultural treasures. So I will do it for him.", "title": "A Pulpy New Novel and Juiceless Old Essays From Mario Vargas Llosa", "authors": ["Dwight Garner", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nThe renewed bipartisan push to lift a ban on Pell Grants for people in prison (news article, Feb. 16) is a common-sense move worthy of praise.\n\nIt\u2019s clear that the ban on Pell Grants is not working. More than 90 percent of people who are in prison will eventually be released. Despite this, only 22 percent of people in state prison have had some form of postsecondary education, a virtual requirement for new job applicants.\n\nExpanding access to postsecondary education and training to people while incarcerated will better equip them to find jobs that lead to other education and economic opportunities upon their release. In turn, it will also help improve their and their family\u2019s future, as well as help them avoid returning to crime.\n\nLifting the ban would also help create safer communities and cut costs. In fact, a study by the RAND Corporation estimates that every dollar invested in correction education yields $4 to $5 in savings from a reduction in recidivism rates.", "title": "Opinion | A Push to Lift a Ban on Pell Grants for Prisoners", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "It has been five years since Marina Krim opened her bathroom door to a scene of unspeakable horror. Her two children, ages 2 and 6, lay in the bathtub, stabbed to death. The nanny she had trusted for two years to watch over them stood nearby with a knife, which she proceeded to plunge into her own neck.\n\nThe nanny, Yoselyn Ortega, 55, had slaughtered the two children in her care in the family\u2019s apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan while Ms. Krim was out picking up a third child from a swimming lesson.\n\nBut the question that has haunted Ms. Krim and her husband, Kevin, as well as innumerable other New York parents who must rely on others for child care, from babysitters to au pairs, is this: Why did Ms. Ortega do it?\n\nMs. Ortega survived her own self-inflicted wounds and in November 2012 was indicted on two counts of first-degree murder. Her trial was delayed repeatedly as her lawyer laid the groundwork for an insanity defense and sought to suppress the statements she made to the authorities while delirious in a hospital.", "title": "A Question Hangs Over a Trial: Why Did a Nanny Kill 2 Children in Her Care?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Then, on Friday, the White House said that it wanted to open a temporary embassy in Jerusalem in time for the 70th anniversary of the creation of the state of Israel, on May 14. As a first step, the State Department said, the consular building in the Arnona neighborhood would carve out some office space for Ambassador David M. Friedman and a small staff, and would become the interim Embassy.\n\nBy the end of next year, the compound is to be expanded to include an interim embassy annex providing more office space for the ambassador and his team. Mr. Friedman is expected to commute from his seaside residence in Herzliyya, north of Tel Aviv, until a secure residence can be found in Jerusalem.\n\nA search is underway for a site for a permanent embassy to be built, but for the foreseeable future, the face of the United States government will be in Arnona.\n\nVideo\n\nThe consular section there, which opened in 2010, is the newest and most secure United States facility in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, according to a State Department official. The official added that there was no change to the mandate of the consulate general, which is housed in a separate, historic building in central Jerusalem and engages in a wide range of political, economic, cultural, and educational contacts in the West Bank and Gaza, as well as in Jerusalem, and also serves American citizens there.\n\nLife in Arnona seemed to be continuing quietly Sunday morning. Across the street from the American consular compound, Naomi Elook, 63, an Israel cosmetician, runs a small beauty salon in the basement of the apartment building where she has lived for 30 years. A young Muslim woman in a flowered head scarf was waiting for a treatment, and Ms. Elook said that 80 percent of her clients were Palestinians from East Jerusalem.\n\n\u201cI am happy about the embassy move,\u201d she said. \u201cIt will enrich the neighborhood and bring more security.\u201d\n\nThe Arnona compound sits between the predominantly Jewish West Jerusalem and East Jerusalem, which Israel captured from Jordan in the 1967 war and then annexed in a move that was never internationally recognized. But the compound has always been in Israel\u2019s possession and so is not, experts say, considered occupied territory.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere are infinite ways in which the embassy move is horrible, counterproductive, destructive,\u201d said Daniel Seidemann, an Israeli attorney who specializes in Jerusalem affairs. \u201cBut the site is not the problem.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWithin the compound sits a decades-old former hotel, aptly named The Diplomat, which the Americans rent out as a facility for elderly Russian-speaking immigrants. Laundry hangs on lines outside some of the windows. One resident, Charna Kommar, 80, who arrived from Moscow in 2004, seemed pleased with the prospect of her new neighbor, saying it was \u201cvery important\u201d to have the embassy in Jerusalem.\n\nAnother small stone building in the compound houses the head office of \u201cBurgers Bar,\u201d a popular Israeli food chain.\n\nSome in Arnona worry that the temporary embassy could prove disruptive. Among them is Michael Frisher, 52, a driving instructor who has been taking students into the neighborhood for 20 years because it is on the city\u2019s test route. \u201cFor us, it\u2019s not good,\u201d he said. \u201cIt could disturb us. They could close the roads.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA fellow driving instructor, Ovadia Tamir, also 52, said that while Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is mired in corruption investigations, might get a political lift from the embassy move, no one else was benefiting.\n\n\u201cThis will only help Netanyahu, nobody else,\u201d Mr. Tamir said.\n\nWorried about Palestinian anger over the coming embassy, he added, \u201cWe don\u2019t want trouble.\u201d\n\nOn Sunday, the prime minister commended the news from Washington about the earlier embassy move. \u201cThis is a great moment for the citizens of Israel, and this is an historic moment for the state of Israel,\u201d Mr. Netanyahu said. (American officials also said on Friday that Sheldon G. Adelson, an American known for his hawkish support of Israel, had offered to help pay for the new embassy building.)\n\nThe Palestinians issued more condemnations. \u201cThe United States has become part of the problem and not the solution,\u201d Husam Zomlot, who leads the Palestinian delegation to Washington, told Voice of Palestine Radio.\n\nThe United States may have the anniversary of Israel\u2019s founding in mind as it times the embassy relocation, but the Palestinians view things through a different lens. For them, May 14 is the 70th anniversary of the Nakba, or \u201ccatastrophe,\u201d when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians were expelled or fled their homes amid the hostilities surrounding Israel\u2019s establishment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs it happens, this year\u2019s anniversary could also fall on the eve of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of fasting, which, depending on the sighting of the new moon, is expected to start at sundown on May 15. Days later, Palestinians are likely to flock for Friday Prayer to the holy site in the Old City that contains Al Aqsa Mosque, which has often been a flash point in the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.\n\nThe calendrical coincidence combining nationalism and religion encapsulates the seething divide over Jerusalem, the seat of Israel\u2019s government and the location of major holy sites sacred to Muslims, Christians and Jews. When the United States recognized Jerusalem, said, Zakaria al-Qaq, a Palestinian professor at Al Quds University in East Jerusalem, \u201cThat was the major headline.\u201d\n\nThe relocation of the ambassador, he said, is \u201ca detail\u201d that has not moved many Palestinians. But the combination of the Nakba commemoration and Ramadan could change things.\n\n\u201cThis,\u201d Mr. Qaq said, \u201cis the complexity and delicacy of the issue.\u201d", "title": "A Quiet Jerusalem Neighborhood Gets a U.S. Embassy, and a Spotlight", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe artist and musician Rammellzee created a vast and eclectic body of work, from graffiti to sculptures to paintings to elaborate costumes, which he wore when assuming any of a variety of cosmic characters. But much of his art never made it to galleries, instead remaining in his renowned TriBeCa loft, nicknamed the Battle Station.\n\nBut on May 4, Rammellzee\u2019s artwork and artifacts will come into view in a retrospective at Red Bull Arts New York that will showcase the versatility and theatricality of this hip-hop pioneer.\n\nRammellzee, who died in 2010, was involved in several aspects of the burgeoning hip-hop cultural movement in New York in the 1970s and \u201980s. He appeared in the seminal graffiti and hip-hop film \u201cWild Style\u201d; he rapped on the single \u201cBeat Bop,\u201d a collaboration with K-Rob and Jean-Michel Basquiat; he had a cameo in the Jim Jarmusch movie \u201cStranger Than Paradise\u201d; and he hosted parties in the Battle Station, where luminaries from the music and art world marveled at his artwork.\n\nThis exhibition unearths many works from that era, including large canvasses, sculptures, and an installation of Rammellzee\u2019s \u201cletter racers,\u201d spacecraft-like sculptures shaped like letters of the alphabet created from toy bits and ephemera.\n\nVisitors can also listen to oral histories about Rammellzee recorded by his contemporaries and collaborators, including Charlie Ahearn, who directed \u201cWild Style,\u201d and the filmmaker Henry Chalfant.\n\nThe show will coincide with the Red Bull Music Festival New York, and remain on view until Aug. 26.", "title": "A Rammellzee Exhibition Is Coming to New York", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "But a year later, Mr. Friederwitzer made a successful legal motion for primary custody, claiming that the children\u2019s mother, who had moved to Manhattan, had begun letting a non-Orthodox man sleep over and going out socially at night, leaving the girls alone.\n\nAt a time when courts typically awarded mothers custody, a state Supreme Court judge on Long Island ruled that the father was a more fit custodian. The mother challenged the ruling to the Court of Appeals, the state\u2019s highest court, which upheld the decision, ruling that the mother put her own interests over the best interests of her children.\n\n\u201cI can quote it,\u201d Judge Friederwitzer said, reciting the decision\u2019s wording that custody agreements could be altered \u201cwhen the totality of circumstances\u201d is \u201cin the best interests of the child.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s what made this case so different \u2014 it changed the way things usually went,\u201d she said. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t just a knee-jerk reaction where the mother gets custody.\u201d\n\nThe case \u2014 something of a real life \u201cKramer vs. Kramer,\u201d the 1979 film that involved a painful courtroom custody battle and was emblematic of the surge in divorces at the time \u2014 seemed to follow young Lisa through her life, from the many classmates in school who knew about it, to her law school professors, to legal professionals over the years who recognized her last name.\n\nAfter graduating from Queens College, and then Touro Law Center on Long Island, she began working at age 24 in Queens Family Court as a court-appointed law guardian, often on behalf of children.\n\nIn 1998, Judge Friederwitzer began working for the state court system in Queens Family Court, first as a court attorney assisting a judge, and then conducting hearings in child support and paternity cases.", "title": "A Real Life \u2018Kramer vs. Kramer\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGETTING OFF\n\nOne Woman\u2019s Journey Through Sex and Porn Addiction\n\nBy Erica Garza\n\n210 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.\n\nIs sex addiction real? I was never particularly convinced, until one afternoon spent in a dark theater in Si Racha, Thailand, changed my mind. It was the spring of 2014, and the movie onscreen was called \u201cThanks for Sharing.\u201d It starred Mark Ruffalo, Pink and others as addicts fighting to maintain sobriety \u2014 from pornography, from masturbation, from intercourse before commitment. They attend 12-step groups; they have televisions removed from business trip hotel rooms so pay-per-view won\u2019t tempt them; they struggle for intimacy. They relapse (they hole up and order hookers); then they find strength anew and start counting days again.\n\nI was overseas at a place called Hope Rehab, receiving my own treatment for what was, in my mind back then anyway, a much more \u201cnormal\u201d addiction to prescription drugs; the excursion to the cinema was a field trip. My dates for the flick were other clients: a whole row of junkies, alcoholics and even one video game addict from Australia. In the car ride back to campus, we all agreed: It was an interesting movie \u2014 an educational movie \u2014 and we were glad to have seen it.\n\n\u201cGetting Off,\u201d the debut book by the 35-year-old Mexican-American essayist Erica Garza, is comparably affecting. The memoir shines light on the lonely (albeit impressively multi-orgasmic) world of a woman who binges not on food or pills, but on hookups and \u201cgetting off.\u201d Oh, and porn. Lots of porn. Teenage-cheerleader-and-her-stepdad-on-the-kitchen-counter porn. Wasted-girls-getting-walked-around-on-leashes-at-parties porn. \u201cBukkake\u201d porn. You get the idea.\n\nGarza, a native of Montebello, Calif. (\u201cthe Mexican Beverly Hills\u201d), holds a swaggy M.F.A. in nonfiction writing from Columbia, but her prose is appealingly no-frills and accessible. She writes in the style of one who knows better than to linger too long on the eroticism of her memories \u2014 one who has learned the hard way how crucial it is to keep dangerous rushes of euphoric recall in check. She recalls, flatly but in explicit detail, a tequila-ridden sexual episode with a Colombian waiter named Andres while on a trip to Hawaii \u2014 despite being in a committed relationship with another man back home in New York. Such boudoir scenes abound in this book, and they are both good and mercifully brief. She beds dudes all over the world (naturally, the S.T.D. that pops up on Page 123 is only her first): Los Angeles, London, Paris, Bali and Shanghai. But these encounters are not without their consequences for her, emotionally. \u201cThe adrenaline racing through my body made me feel invincible at the time,\u201d she writes. \u201cAnd the shame I felt afterward was even better.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAs a narrator, Garza is a master of identifying such dark, postcoital feelings as these. She wallows in the aftermath of sex with a gnarly older man (also in Hawaii), an act she has engaged in not because she wanted to, really, but because he has given her free dinners at his restaurant. \u201cKeeping my eyes on the red taillights of some distant car ahead, I felt the erotic thrill of that moment with Luc slowly drain from my system, leaving behind a big black hole.\u201d We\u2019ve all been there, and in reading Garza\u2019s insight into her own experiences, we better understand ourselves.\n\n\u201cThis disease is a \u2026 bitch,\u201d Tim Robbins\u2019s character tells Ruffalo\u2019s in \u201cThanks for Sharing.\u201d He gestures at his crotch. \u201cIt\u2019s like trying to quit crack while the pipe is attached to your body.\u201d When Garza \u2014 at last humbled, exhausted by years of compulsion and spiritual disease \u2014 finally makes moves to get it together, the road isn\u2019t easy. For the person in recovery, triggers are everywhere, even Sex and Love Addicts Anonymous sessions. (\u201cI came so hard I thought my heart would explode,\u201d she writes of one post-meeting masturbation session. \u201cAfterward, I crawled under the covers and cried.\u201d) But the strong final chapters, sublimely set in Southeast Asia, are both inspirational and, dare I say it, still pretty kinky. God bless a lost person who has found her way. Thanks for sharing, Erica.", "title": "A Recovering Sex and Porn Addict Tells All", "authors": ["Cat Marnell", "Erica Garza"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "There was also some long-awaited pushback, as the players\u2019 union filed a grievance with Major League Baseball against four teams \u2014 the Miami Marlins, the Tampa Bay Rays, the Oakland Athletics and the Pittsburgh Pirates \u2014 charging that the clubs are not spending their revenue-sharing money on improving the on-field product, as they are required to do.\n\nThe Marlins, Rays and Pirates traded away their franchise players this winter \u2014 Giancarlo Stanton, Evan Longoria and Andrew McCutchen, respectively. Those three teams issued statements disputing the charges, which were first reported by the Tampa Bay Times. Pirates President Frank Coonelly dismissed the grievance as \u201cfrivolous.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe union\u2019s executive director, Tony Clark, who watched Tuesday\u2019s five-inning scrimmage, confirmed that the union had filed the grievance but declined to comment on it.\n\nBut earlier, while speaking to a handful of reporters, Clark said this was not a case of a select few teams doing a tear-down \u2014 a strategy the Astros and Chicago Cubs employed on their way to winning the last two World Series.\n\nClark said at least 10 of baseball\u2019s 30 teams were not trying to win in the coming season, suppressing the free-agent market. If the Marlins, for example, had not put Stanton on the trading block, the Yankees most likely would have dipped into the free-agent market for more offense, even though they have a mandate from the owner Hal Steinbrenner to stay below the $197 million luxury tax threshold.\n\nNearly one-third of the 166 players who became free agents after last season remain unsigned, and Clark said that 17 teams were at least $50 million below the luxury tax threshold.\n\nClark was asked if, given hindsight, he had seen any of this coming while negotiating the collective bargaining agreement, which was ratified in December 2016 and runs through the 2021 season.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFor me,\u201d Clark said, \u201cif we had known that there was going to be upwards of a third of the league that may not be as interested in being the last team standing and therefore wouldn\u2019t value experience on some level, then I would say yes.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cBut that was never the assumption. The entire C.B.A. is grounded and fundamentally focused in on creating as many opportunities for all 30 teams as possible. I don\u2019t know how many years you heard competitive balance, competitive balance, competitive balance.\u201d\n\nIn the last two labor agreements, teams have won the right to cap how much they spend on the draft and on most international signings, essentially allowing them to peg the cost of a rebuild.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAgainst the backdrop of not competing, yeah, that can be a huge issue,\u201d Clark said.\n\nAn increasing reliance on analytics has also reshaped how teams value players and construct their rosters, placing a premium on younger and cheaper players. But Clark and others at Camp Jobless, including catcher Jarrod Saltalamacchia and Tom Gordon, the former pitcher who is coaching here, said that the qualities a veteran could provide \u2014 leadership and grooming \u2014 were not being accurately accounted for. That has led to a great deal of frustration among free agents still looking for work.\n\n\u201cThey start to lose hope, and it\u2019s humiliating,\u201d said Dave Gallagher, a former outfielder who is serving as a coach at the camp.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo that end, the camp, which had been closed to the news media and accessible only by appointment for scouts, opened its doors on Tuesday.\n\nA little before 9 a.m., the players took the field in gray pants, black jerseys with a players\u2019 association patch on the chest, and plain black caps. They played catch to warm up, took batting practice and prepared for a game \u2014 much the same way teams have at 30 sites around Florida and Arizona during spring training.\n\nAbout six scouts showed up to watch, their iPads and radar guns at the ready behind home plate. Familiar names like Luke Scott, Omar Infante, Chris Johnson and Nolan Reimold took their swings, and Clippard, Tom Gorzelanny and Jim Henderson pitched against Japan Railway East, whose coach, Horii Tetsuya, said his players were below Class AAA level.\n\nWhen the teams scrimmage again, on Thursday, Walker could be playing with them. A week ago, Walker \u2014 who last season played for the Mets and then the Milwaukee Brewers on a one-year, $17.2 million deal \u2014 thought he would end up with the Yankees as their second or third baseman. Then the Yankees acquired Drury, who will make the major league minimum this season.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMaybe it\u2019s something that\u2019s being lost in translation with teams \u2014 how are we valuing guys?\u201d Walker said. \u201cAre we strictly valuing them on numbers, or are we not able to quantify how they\u2019re making an impact, not only on the field but in the clubhouse? I\u2019ve always felt like I\u2019ve been somebody that\u2019s been a leader. I guess in terms of dollars and cents, teams are not seeing that as a value at this point.\u201d\n\nClippard, who made $6.15 million last season, said he had only received offers for a minor league contract so far, which he has rebuffed. He chafed at what he sees as a double standard.\n\n\u201cAs players, if we took a year off, we\u2019d be out of the game,\u201d Clippard said. \u201cBut it\u2019s O.K. for owners and organizations to take years off, and it\u2019s actually accepted.\u201d", "title": "A Reluctant Team of Free Agents Scrimmages at \u2018Camp Jobless\u2019", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Instrument makers responded by building beautifully ornamented hurdy-gurdys that were often coveted by women; Marie Antoinette is known to have played one. (The French term is \u201cvielle \u00e0 roue\u201d; the English name imitates the instrument\u2019s sound.) There were virtuosos on the instrument who also wrote sophisticated dance arrangements and concertos for it.\n\nBut by the 19th century, hurdy-gurdys were predominantly seen in the hands of beggars. Certain regions, like Savoie in France and the area today belonging to Poland and Ukraine, produced large numbers of itinerant musicians \u2014 often blind \u2014 who played for a few coins.\n\nMr. Loibner said that many of the Eastern European hurdy-gurdy players spent the warm months playing on the streets of Austria and Germany and returned home for the winter with what little they had earned. For Schubert\u2019s audiences, then, the pathos of the Leiermann would not have been lost.\n\nA Master Reinvents the Hurdy-Gurdy\n\n\u201cIf you saw a hurdy-gurdy player on the ice in winter,\u201d Mr. Loibner said, \u201cyou knew he had no reason to go home anymore.\u201d\n\nBlind hurdy-gurdy players producing a ceaseless, penetrating sound also came to be endowed with clairvoyant powers in the popular imagination. Mr. Loibner recalled perhaps the darkest hurdy-gurdy story: Stalin, said to have been fearful of the subversive power of these itinerant musicians, invited hundreds of them to a festival, where he had them rounded up and sent to their deaths.\n\nElisabeth Harnik is working to overcome these tragic associations. She is one of the composers commissioned to write songs for Mr. Loibner and Ms. Mirkovic\u2019s song cycle. It was a challenge to create \u201ca light mood,\u201d she said, \u201cbecause the instrument has an inherent melancholy.\u201d But through experimentation, she had hit upon a technique for producing seagull-like whoops in the instrument\u2019s high register that evoked a summer sky.\n\nPhoto\n\nAdvances in instrument-making have helped expand the range of what\u2019s possible on a hurdy-gurdy. Robert Green, an American player and Baroque specialist, said in an interview that \u201cthe reason it survived so well is that it managed to reinvent itself.\u201d Part of its latest reinvention is an electronically enhanced version, which can function like a one-man band or sound like a whole posse of electric guitars. Mr. Loibner often partners with D.J.s and folk ensembles from different traditions, and with a trumpeter and percussionist in Brot und Sterne, a trio known for trancelike jazz improvisations.\n\nBut despite his crossover experiments, the iconic figure of Schubert\u2019s Leiermann remains at the core of his conception of the instrument. When he was 17, Mr. Loibner and a friend ran away from home, planning to busk their way to India. They only made it as far as Greece, but the experience of being a street musician living hand to mouth stayed with him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFor me, the closest thing to Schubert\u2019s Leiermann are the groups of punks you sometimes pass on the street,\u201d he said. \u201cThey may have a dog, and there\u2019s always one who plays the guitar. And he\u2019s so drunk he plays only one chord over and over \u2014 and the instrument is out of tune. But there is this freedom and \u2014 for me, for a moment \u2014 the longing to cross over and leave behind all the rules of society.\u201d", "title": "A Renaissance for an Instrument of Melancholy Magic", "authors": ["Corinna Da Fonseca-Wollheim"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "The New York Times has learned that an employee of the organization was paid $25,000 in 2015 as part of an agreement that concealed her allegations that Mr. Martin had groped and propositioned her in his apartment during what was supposed to be a work meeting.\n\nWe Want to Hear From You We\u2019d like to hear from readers who have seen institutions and organizations develop responses to sexual harassment after #MeToo.
