Here, they were clean.\n\n\u201cI think people, when they come here, they see how nice it is, and they tell their guests not to disrespect the building,\u201d she said.\n\nA number of features have struck her as unexpectedly thoughtful. On Halloween, people giving out candy sign up with the management, which distributes a list so children can go door-to-door in the complex, rather than going around to nearby stores, as they would otherwise. There are outdoor movie nights in the summer and events for children like face-painting and slime-making. And there are benches in the courtyard where she can sit and get some fresh air if she doesn\u2019t have time to go to a park.\n\nMs. Daniels\u2019s younger daughter later moved in with her, bringing a son who is now 4. They share one of the bedrooms; her older daughter and granddaughter share another; and Ms. Daniels has the third. Last month, her son moved in as well, and has been sleeping on the sofa. But the apartment is large enough, and their schedules different enough, that it hasn\u2019t been an issue. \u201cEveryone is comfortable, happy, working,\u201d she said.\n\nThey trade off cooking and grocery shopping, as well as laundry days, and keep a shared savings account for paying the electric and cable bills. Ms. Daniels admitted that she is looking forward to having a little more space when her children move on. Even so, it has been nice to be under the same roof again for a little while.\n\n\u201cWe all get along.\u201d she said. \u201cWell, except for the grandkids. They kind of get into it every now and then.\u201d", "title": "A Sustainable Home in the South Bronx", "authors": ["Kim Velsey"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen \u201cEverything Sucks!\u201d joins \u201cThe End of the ____ing World\u201d on the Netflix Originals roster on Friday, the streaming service will have two new coming-of-age comedies with more in common than their confrontational titles. On paper, at least.\n\nEach show centers on a pair of high school outsiders, a boy and a girl, each of whom has one absent parent. (In the 10-episode American series \u201cEverything,\u201d the boy\u2019s father and the girl\u2019s mother are gone; in the eight-episode British \u201cEnd,\u201d it\u2019s the other way around.) The missing moms are dead, the missing dads are deadbeats. Each show plays teasing games of will-they-or-won\u2019t-they, finding endless last-minute ways to forestall kisses or worse. Each boy gallantly takes full responsibility for a crime the corresponding girl was complicit in.\n\nBut no matter how many standard features of the teenage comedy the two series share, they\u2019re as different as night and day, and there\u2019s no question which one\u2019s the dark one. Here\u2019s a hint: In \u201cEverything,\u201d the boy takes the rap for pulling a fire alarm in the school gym. In \u201cEnd,\u201d the boy takes the rap for an extremely bloody killing committed with a hunting knife.\n\nIt\u2019s worth noting here that \u201cEnd,\u201d which is jarring, aggressively morbid and by far the better of the two shows, was originally made for good old broadcast television \u2014 it was shown on Britain\u2019s Channel 4 last year before arriving on Netflix in January.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEverything\u201d was made directly for Netflix (it was created by Ben York Jones and Michael Mohan), but it doesn\u2019t make much use of the license that allows, beyond some strong language. Though perhaps if it were on American broadcast TV, it wouldn\u2019t include the implicit joke of setting its story in an Oregon town called Boring and naming the high school sports teams the Beavers.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe show\u2019s primary characteristic, which might reflect American provenance, Netflix roots, or both, is its manufactured quality. Tiffins are the stacked boxes with a carrying handle used in India mostly for delivered lunches or snacks, though the word can also mean the food itself. At the Pierre, part of the India-based Taj Hotels, an elegant three-tiered copper tiffin comes filled with a bountiful assortment of savory and sweet tidbits, including samosas, shami kebabs and mango cr\u00e8me br\u00fbl\u00e9e. Essential to the government\u2019s case is the credibility of those agents as they testify to material facts in the government\u2019s case. The standing of the department, moreover, is critical to the independence and effective functioning of its lawyers.\n\nIn trying cases for the government, I developed great respect for the competence, integrity and dedication of the agents with whom I worked as well as my colleagues. To witness that and to be able to capture those moments is a great gift to me and a privilege to be able to do it.\u201d\n\nHis obsession with capturing the perfect moment at the Olympics at times rivals the obsession of the athletes themselves. Two thirds of his job, he said, is making sure everything is working so he can actually take the pictures the rest of the time.\n\nAt these Olympics, his focus will be on figure skating and ice hockey. I would get there between 4 and 4:30 a.m., rain or shine. I was picking and selling to other dealers.\n\nPhoto\n\nWas it sad to see those flea-market lots become apartment towers?\n\nYeah, it was. She had paid the shaking little mind even as it seemed to grow worse every year \u2014 after all, her shop is one of 12 built along a roughly 100-year-old train overpass that is the de facto main street of this Tudor pocket of Queens.\n\nThen she found the hole that had opened up in her storeroom.\n\n\u201cYou could see the train tracks below,\u201d Ms. Reid said, standing between boxes of organic soap in the back of her store, Thyme Natural Market, and on the spot where workmen had laid a plywood patch over the one-square-foot hole after it appeared a few years ago. \u201cThrough the floor in my shop!\u201d\n\nThe bridge over the railroad tracks is Queens\u2019s rickety answer to the store-packed Ponte Vecchio in Florence. It doubles as the hub of the bedroom community, with restaurants and stores on either side of the crossing on Lefferts Boulevard. But it is also a crumbling mess, in dire need of drastic repairs, according to the agency that owns it, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. To the dismay of the tight-knit neighborhood, the M.T.A. says that the best way to fix it is to tear the bridge down as well as the shops.", "title": "A Troubled Bridge Over Kew Gardens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "This is the kind of book in which the Alaskan cabin is a horrible mess until, practically overnight, it\u2019s fresh and clean \u2014 not easy without running water. That\u2019s because the tiny outpost near Homer, where the Allbrights homestead (in real life, Hannah\u2019s family runs a travel lodge in the same general area) has citizens who help one another and show up to share the work. This setup suits Ernt for about five minutes. Then he starts bonding with Mad Earl (\u201cfolks call me Mad Earl\u201d), the biggest paranoid white supremacist survivalist nut around, whom Ernt will soon best when it comes to crazy. Ernt also starts hating Tom Walker, the local rich person, who has no discernible bad qualities and does his best to help the Allbrights. Walker\u2019s big crime is that Cora finds him attractive.\n\nPhoto\n\nNow to the main event: Ernt goes from intimidating his wife and daughter to seriously beating Cora. And in a one-room log cabin, Leni can\u2019t not see what\u2019s going on. Hannah presents a sickeningly codependent marriage in which Mama makes excuses for Dad\u2019s violence and refuses to tell anyone what\u2019s happening to her, no matter how bad it gets. Cora is covering for Ernt for emotional, not practical, reasons. Still, she wouldn\u2019t get anywhere by going to the police; as the book points out, 1974 was a time when a woman with a job couldn\u2019t get a credit card without a man\u2019s permission.\n\nHannah manages to keep all this from getting too repetitive by steadily raising the stakes. By the middle of the book, Leni is 17, and there is a boy \u2014 Tom Walker\u2019s son, of course. (In this backwater, there\u2019s only one boy around anyway.) But Dad would prefer that Leni jump out of bed in the middle of the night and clean her gun than socialize with anybody, ever. So she begins to face the major questions of if or how she will ever have a life of her own.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Great Alone\u201d is packed with rapturous descriptions of Alaskan scenery, which are the most reliably alluring part of it. Hannah remembers and summons an undeveloped wilderness, describing a gloriously pristine region in the days before cruise ships discovered it. One of the fighting points in the book is whether the little enclave the Allbrights call home should be opened up to tourists. Hannah presumably has mixed feelings about this, what with her family\u2019s travel lodge. But she keeps it simple in the book, making Ernt the purist and Tom Walker the guy who sees tourism as inevitable. Tom shuts Ernt down by saying, \u201cI got boots that have covered more ground in Alaska than you have.\u201d\n\nHannah also uses an oversupply of Alaskan hokum: \u201cTwo kinds of folks come up to Alaska, Cora\u2026\u201d And: \u201cYou know what they say about finding a man in Alaska...\u201d And: \u201cI think it was Jack London who said there were a thousand ways to die in Alaska.\u201d And: \u201cMarge, you got a mouth on you like a king salmon.\u201d Worst of all: \u201cThis is our home. We want it to stay wild and free.\u201d The book takes its title from \u201cThe Shooting of Dan McGrew,\u201d a poem by Robert W. Service, also known as the \u201cBard of the Yukon.\u201d\n\nCharacters are good or bad in \u201cThe Great Alone,\u201d happy or miserable. Ernt\u2019s PTSD consists of nightmares, violence, paranoia and excessive drinking. Cora says that his capacity for love has been destroyed by war, but that\u2019s it for nuance. Large Marge, the African-American woman who runs the local grocery, is always a force for good, and she can be counted on to help the Allbright women whenever they need her. And Leni\u2019s problems are dramatic enough to keep readers hooked, but she herself is good every minute of the day. Hannah gives her a kind of afterword, in which Leni writes: \u201cSomeone said to me once that Alaska didn\u2019t create character; it revealed it.\u201d Maybe so. But we know who she is right from the start.", "title": "A Troubled Dad Takes His Family Into the Wild", "authors": ["Janet Maslin", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "GANGNEUNG, South Korea \u2014 It may not have been the most obvious choice for Yura Min and Alexander Gamelin, the American-born ice dancing pair representing South Korea at the Olympics, to skate on Tuesday to \u201cArirang,\u201d a Korean folk song whose roots go back hundreds of years.\n\nThere was concern in their camp that the international judges at the Winter Games would not respond to a tune unfamiliar to them. But for Ms. Min \u2014 and for any Korean watching \u2014 the significance of the choice was clear.\n\n\u201cEven though it could be difficult to get high scores from foreign judges, I wanted to perform with \u2018Arirang\u2019 at the first Winter Olympics in Korea, and I did,\u201d Ms. Min told Korean reporters on Tuesday. \u201cI was born in the United States, but I am proud to be Korean.\u201d\n\nIn an 1896 essay, Homer B. Hulbert, an American missionary in Korea, wrote: \u201cTo the average Korean, this one song holds the same place in music that rice does in his food \u2014 all else is mere appendage. You hear it everywhere and at all times.\u201d", "title": "A Tune Heard Often at These Olympics Gets to the Heart of Being Korean", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "There was an uptick in rural Hilleman Scholars in 2017 after the university\u2019s agricultural extension agents, who get to know agrarian youngsters advising 4-H clubs, got involved in recruitment. The program\u2019s application asks candidates to enumerate their chores so as to explain uneven report cards.\n\nErik Kalsta, a fourth-generation cattle and sheep rancher in the Big Hole Valley who attended M.S.U. in the 1980s and plans to send his daughter there this fall, told me he was often pulled out of school as a boy. \u201cI was raised under a simple but fierce dictum: The animals come first, fed and watered before you get breakfast,\u201d he said \u201cRound-the- clock care during calving and lambing, and when the cattle go to summer pasture with a rider, then all focus goes to growing and harvesting their food for the winter.\u201d\n\nAccording to my dad, Pat, who worked as a machinist in M.S.U.\u2019s mechanical engineering department for 26 years: \u201cA farmer\u2019s kid is probably going to be a better engineer than an engineer\u2019s kid. The engineer\u2019s kid is given a problem and sees a piece of paper. The farmer\u2019s kid sees a problem and thinks back to that time the bridge washed out.\u201d Josh Carter, a 2017 Rhodes scholar from M.S.U., double-majored in mechanical engineering and microbiology; he grew up on a South Dakota potato farm. Hilleman incubated the viruses for his vaccines in chicken eggs, a medium he was familiar with from his Great Plains boyhood.\n\nIf I had to predict the M.S.U. graduate who might be my generation\u2019s Maurice Hilleman, which is to say the most effective at fighting our greatest common enemy \u2014 death \u2014 it would be a classmate who did not major in microbiology but rather graduated with a B.A. from the same art department as Peter Voulkos.\n\nLeilani Schweitzer, the progeny of German homesteaders in Denton, was always a Faberg\u00e9-level good egg. Then the worst thing that can happen to anyone happened to her when her 20-month-old son, Gabriel, died at Stanford\u2019s children\u2019s hospital. A kind nurse intended to disable one alarm that was preventing the boy and his mother from getting any sleep and unwittingly turned off the alarms on all of Gabriel\u2019s monitors.\n\nAfter this fatal mistake, Leilani told me that she spent years doggedly sending the hospital suggestions for what might help other people. \u201cI didn\u2019t do it with any intention of it turning into anything,\u201d she said. \u201cI just wanted something good to come from something terrible.\u201d The hospital eventually hired her to be a liaison among lawyers, physicians and families. She has become the leading advocate of medical transparency in a country where medical errors are arguably the third leading cause of death.\n\nHer mission is to teach the medical establishment what she learned in her M.S.U. design classes: how to draw three-point perspectives. \u201cEssentially,\u201d she said at a presentation, \u201cthis process bends space and time, allowing us to see an object from three perspectives with a single drawing. This is what we need to do to fully comprehend our health care environment. We need to see multiple views\u201d \u2014 from doctors, nurses, patients, administrators and volunteers \u2014 \u201cat one time.\u201d Only then, she said, will health care providers understand problems fully enough to \u201cfind true, long-term solutions.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | A University of, by and for the People", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAlong with a raft of new winter flavors like oatmeal chai, Wylie Dufresne is introducing a couple of Valentine\u2019s Day specials. Pink raspberry-flavored cake doughnuts are glazed with either vanilla or chocolate, and decorated with raspberry and white chocolate crumbles. The doughnuts can be ordered starting Tuesday online for delivery or for pickup in Brooklyn: Du\u2019s Donuts and Coffee, Valentine\u2019s Day doughnuts, $3.50 each through Feb. 14, 107 North 12th Street (Wythe Avenue), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, dusdonuts.com.", "title": "A Valentine for Homer Simpson", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "But today, my family cheers, then winces when we see the replay. We try to ignore the shame boiling up inside, knowing what affect it could have on the player\u2019s future. We say things like, \u201cThat\u2019s a shame.\u201d And keep watching.\n\nTo prohibit defenders from behaving like assassins, referees penalize players on the field and fine them off it, but the game won\u2019t really change. And part of me doesn\u2019t want it to change. The chance of violence is why we tune in.\n\nIn Philadelphia, we enjoy the carnage as long as it\u2019s not on our team. If there were a chance the players\u2019 heads would literally pop off like Rock \u2019Em Sock \u2019Em Robots\u2019, we\u2019d still watch. Maybe even more. We\u2019re like spectators in the Colosseum watching gladiators in A.D. 200, saying, \u201cIf it\u2019s not to the death, it won\u2019t be the same sport!\u201d\n\nI was trained since Pee Wee football to strike with precision and power. The Drexel Hill Raiders was an athletic boot camp for kids who were currently reading \u201cWhere the Wild Things Are.\u201d We sat on our hands, keeping our legs straight and heels six inches off the ground until a fire burned away our bellies. Everyone ran laps when one kid fumbled. If you were overweight, they wrapped you in trash bags and made you run.\n\nWe had a drill where two of us would lay on our backs, helmet to helmet. Then a \u201ccoach,\u201d who for 22 other hours a day was a carpenter, would blow a whistle. We\u2019d scurry to our feet in fear and race to smash each other first. We\u2019d run full speed and slam foreheads into each other until things tasted different for a few hours.\n\nPlaying football, I got the wind knocked out of me about once a week for a decade. I\u2019d lie on my back and struggle to suck in air while looking at the clouds, thinking, \u201cAs soon as this is over, I\u2019ll finish my fruit roll-up.\u201d Coach Millison would run on the field and kneel over me with a lit cigarette, snowing ashes all over my face. He\u2019d pull my waist a foot off the ground to allow air back into my lungs and I\u2019d slowly come back to life while my friends stood over me like little football angels.\n\nThe game is changing and I feel bad for kids who will never know what it feels like to make a big hit or score a game-winning touchdown. Once when I was 10, both happened. I ran down the sideline and just as I approached the goal line, I was hit so hard I blacked out. I awoke on the sideline to see Coach and asked, \u201cDid I get in?\u201d He smiled and said: \u201cYeah, kiddo. You scored.\u201d The pain disappeared as the team lifted me to the sky.\n\nOn Super Bowl Sunday, if you want to discuss C.T.E., I\u2019ll be screaming at the television in a bar, with strangers dressed in green. Regardless of the score, I just want the sport of football to know \u2026 the Cowboys are losing.", "title": "Opinion | A Very Conflicted Football Fan\u2019s Notes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The American military did not grant permission to visit its small base in Manbij, located about 10 miles west of the city, but small convoys of Humvees and armored vehicles were a frequent sight on the highways in the area. The base appeared much smaller than the other two main bases for American troops in northern Syria. It is unclear how many American soldiers are stationed there, but the Pentagon in December confirmed that about 2,000 American troops were in Syria fighting the Islamic State. (Colonel Dillon declined to say how many of those troops were in Manbij.)\n\nManbij is a predominantly Arab city in northern Syria, which the American-backed Syrian Democratic Forces retook from ISIS. Its current population of 300,000 includes about 120,000 refugees from other parts of Syria, again mostly Arabs, according to the head of the civil administration in Manbij, Ibrahim Kaftan, an Arab himself.\n\nPeople in Manbij were initially alarmed because Manbij is mostly flat terrain, unlike the more rugged area around Afrin. \u201cThe first week of the Turkish offensive, there was concern about it, but soon it was like the shepherd boy who cried wolf,\u201d Mr. Kaftan said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Now our allies are committing to work with us, and Erdogan can\u2019t cross that line.\u201d He said American coalition officers had assured Manbij authorities that they would not abandon them.\n\nColonel Dillon said that contacts with the Turkish military and government continued at all levels and had not been hampered by reaction to the Afrin offensive. There are Turkish officers in the coalition\u2019s headquarters in Kuwait, for instance. \u201cWe have dialogue on a daily basis in our headquarters, and we maintain dialogue with liaison officers in Ankara,\u201d Turkey\u2019s capital, \u201cand there are other leader engagements that go all the way up to President Trump and President Erdogan,\u201d he said.\n\nLast week, in fact, Mr. Trump and Mr. Erdogan spoke by telephone about Syria, although the two governments had dramatically different readouts of their conversation. A White House official said Mr. Trump asked Turkey to \u201cde-escalate, limit its military actions and avoid civilian casualties\u201d in Afrin, while Turkey claimed that Mr. Trump did not discuss the violence in Afrin.\n\nKurdish leaders have been upset that the Americans have not done more to restrain Turkey in Afrin. \u201cIn Manbij we and the coalition worked together and took ISIS out,\u201d said Shervan Derwish, the spokesman for the Manbij Military Council. \u201cBut now they are attacking us in Afrin and we have to reduce our forces against ISIS to defend Afrin.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Gherde, on the front line near the Sajur River, is now 32 and has been at war since 2011. For 50 years Windhoek, the capital of nearby Namibia, has been recycling at least 80 percent of its daily water use.\n\nWindhoek, a city of about 400,000, sits on a high desert plateau. No more than 14 inches of rain falls annually, sometimes far less. Yet Windhoek has no water crisis and keeps its people and its tourists hydrated by cleaning and reusing wastewater of all kinds over and over.\n\nThe recycled water that is too gray for human consumption is used for industrial purposes or in agriculture. As little as possible is wasted. What a resident of Windhoek drinks today she will drink again in recycled form tomorrow.\n\nFor its long-term survival, Cape Town could adopt the Windhoek method. It is less expensive, too, to recycle than to desalinate or to build an aqueduct to carry water from the distant Orange River. Cape Town needs to plan for a future that could be even more distinctly arid than its present.", "title": "Opinion | A Water Crisis From Climate Change", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "For decades, The Charleston Gazette-Mail in West Virginia has exposed corruption, greed and incompetence with a tenacity that was rewarded last year with journalism\u2019s highest honor, a Pulitzer Prize. But the newspaper now faces a painful reality: No matter how strong its journalism, no publication is immune to the economic pressure on the industry.\n\nOn Monday, staff members learned that the newspaper was filing for bankruptcy ahead of a sale, ending the Chilton family\u2019s century-long role in shepherding its journalism. A prospective buyer is lined up, but the move raises questions about the future both of a relentless local watchdog and its more than 200 employees, including Eric Eyre, who accepted the Pulitzer last year for his reporting on the state\u2019s opioid crisis.\n\n\u201cNever in a million years would I think that eight months later we would be in bankruptcy and I\u2019d be reapplying for my job,\u201d said Mr. Eyre, who plans to remain in West Virginia no matter the outcome. \u201cBut I guess life is full of highs and lows, and obviously now we\u2019re at a low.\u201d\n\nThe announcement came at the end of a tumultuous period for the publication, which had weathered drawn-out legal battles stemming from a 2004 transaction in which the left-leaning Charleston Gazette acquired a controlling interest in the right-leaning Charleston Daily Mail. The newspaper \u2014 which has about 32,000 daily subscribers, according to a court filing \u2014 has also suffered circulation and advertising losses over the past decade that its publisher, Susan Chilton Shumate, described in a letter on Monday addressed to the staff as \u201cdevastating to the bottom line.\u201d", "title": "A West Virginia Newspaper Won Journalism\u2019s Top Award. Now It\u2019s Filed for Bankruptcy.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The doors at the White House have been swinging a lot lately. A deputy chief of staff moved on. A speechwriter resigned. The associate attorney general stepped down. The chief of staff offered to quit. And that was just Friday.\n\nAll of that came after the departure of Rob Porter, the White House staff secretary who cleared out his office last week amid accusations of spousal abuse. The White House had overlooked reported problems with his security clearance last year in part, officials said, because of a reluctance to lose yet another senior aide, particularly one seen as so professional and reliable.\n\nMore than a year into his administration, President Trump is presiding over a staff in turmoil, one with a 34 percent turnover rate, higher than any White House in decades. He has struggled to fill openings, unwilling to hire Republicans he considers disloyal and unable to entice Republicans who consider him unstable. Those who do come to work for him often do not last long, burning out from a volatile, sometimes cutthroat environment exacerbated by tweets and subpoenas.\n\nTo visit the Eisenhower Executive Office Building, the granite, slate and cast iron edifice across West Executive Avenue from the White House where most of the president\u2019s staff works, at times feels like walking through a ghost town. The hallways do not bustle as much as in past administrations. The budget director is doing double duty as the acting head of the consumer protection agency. The personnel director is doing triple duty, also overseeing the offices of political affairs and public liaison.", "title": "A Whirlwind Envelops the White House, and the Revolving Door Spins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Straight off a red-eye flight from New York on Friday morning, the model Adwoa Aboah steps into the thick of London Fashion Week. She stops briefly at her parents\u2019 house \u2014 she lives in Brooklyn, but stays with her family in Notting Hill when she\u2019s in town \u2014 to change into a Molly Goddard tulle dress before heading to 180 Strand, the official venue of LFW, to deliver a rousing speech on the treatment of models, diversity and the importance of supporting emerging talent as the British Fashion Council\u2019s newly appointed ambassador for positive fashion.\n\nUnlike many in her line of work, Aboah is an activist first, model second. Her list of projects includes Gurls Talk, a charity she set up with the intention of raising awareness around mental health and female empowerment; working with Times Up and Save the Children; art directing, alongside the photographer Juergen Teller, the Burberry campaigns in which she stars; writing a monthly column for British Vogue, where she is a contributing editor; and, over the next few weeks, walking in the fashion shows of both emerging and established designers. In London, many of them are her friends.\n\nFresh from the podium, she\u2019s ready for a day of fittings and shows, taking opportune moments to nap in her car in between. First up is the emerging designer Ashley Williams, a friend of Aboah\u2019s, who is hosting fittings in her Hackney home because of a flood in her studio. After Aboah arrives, the stylist Julia Sarr-Jamois pulls out a tie-dye hoodie printed with the words \u201cDon\u2019t Know, Don\u2019t Care.\u201d \u201cThat is so you right now,\u201d teases Sian Steel, Aboah\u2019s agent, as the model stifles yawns. A sequin jacket catches her eye. \u201cCan I wear this to the reception at the palace on Monday?\u201d she asks Williams. \u201cThe last time I went to the palace I came straight from the Tate gift shop in a yellow tracksuit.\u201d\n\nNext, Aboah departs for the industrial Truman Brewery in Shoreditch for a fitting with the York-based designer Matty Bovan. Both Bovan\u2019s and Williams\u2019s shows are later that day, but before that, Aboah will also squeeze in a visit to Burberry HQ (stopping at Pret a Manger on the way) for a final fitting before the big show the following night, Christopher Bailey\u2019s last as creative director of the house. Inside Burberry\u2019s corporate-looking building, giant pictures of Aboah line the slick reception area. She pauses to pose for a picture with herself. The billboards are unretouched except for the removal of the diamond Chanel tooth jewel she has on her front tooth. \u201cI got it three years ago,\u201d she smiles. \u201cBefore this, it was a Playboy bunny.\u201d", "title": "A Whirlwind London Fashion Week With Adwoa Aboah", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Music is a daily part of life for the Sudanese, whether it is during a blessing ceremony or declaring victory in a wrestling match.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s bragging rights,\u201d said Kuol Kuol, a 23-year-old member of the Melbourne Lion team, explaining the tradition of winners earning the right to compose songs.\n\n\u201cIf you lose, you just got to go away and get better,\u201d he said. \u201cWin next time, then you can make up your own song.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe members of the team all come from South Sudan, the world\u2019s youngest country, and are ethnically Dinka.\n\nSince the ministers\u2019 comments about \u201cAfrican gangs,\u201d the men said they had dealt with increased racial profiling and offensive slurs.\n\nMr. Mading, the wrestler who works at a library, said a teacher told him he would not have a career in academics and would find work only as a basketball player or model. \u201cTo me, that was a mockery,\u201d said Mr. Mading, who is pursuing a degree.\n\n\n\nSitting on the grass between matches on a Wednesday afternoon in January, Mr. Kuol, who moved from South Australia to Victoria in 2017, said even going to the supermarket had become fraught.\n\n\u201cIt made it hard,\u201d Mr. Kuol said of the ministers\u2019 remarks.\n\n\u201cYou get bad looks from people on the road,\u201d Mr. Kuol added. \u201cI have a supermarket near my house. When I go inside, I feel like there\u2019s so much attention on me.\u201d\n\nAsked if he considered himself Australian, and if he considered the country his home, Mr. Mading hesitated.\n\n\u201cI love to call it a home, but it\u2019s not really quite,\u201d he said. \u201cWe want to embrace Australia, but we keep getting rejected. I call myself a Sudanese in Australia, not a Sudanese-Australian.\u201d\n\nMr. Mading said a white woman on a train once shouted racial slurs at him.\n\n\u201cThis lady called herself a \u2018real Aussie\u2019 She kept saying: \u2018This is my country! You don\u2019t belong here!\u2019 \u201d he said. \u201cI keep asking myself: What\u2019s a real Aussie?\u201d", "title": "A Wrestling Team in Australia Fights to Prove It\u2019s Not an \u2018African Gang\u2019", "authors": ["Adam Baidawi"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "There was more to Peter\u2019s crise than his worry about Patsy or growing distaste for his surreptitious assignment. He was 25, almost 26. Impatiently, he reflected that his life didn\u2019t make sense to him, a feeling that had gnawed at him for a long while. What was he doing here? He began a second novel, called \u201cPartisans.\u201d The protagonist is a journalist working under cover in Paris on an investigative story about an elusive Communist. The journalist\u2019s name is Barney Sand \u2014 initials B.S. Listening to the sound of his own voice, Sand broods that it \u201cbelonged to a man in mirrors whose face seemed more foolish every day.\u201d Waiting to undertake the next move in his mission, Sand thinks: \u201cTo wait, to wait, as it now seemed to him he had waited all his life: for graduation from school, for enlistment in the Army, for combat that never came, for the war to end, for college to end, for promotion in two jobs he did not want, for a love that did not exist \u2014 waiting for a raison d\u2019\u00eatre which never arrived because he could not recognize it.\u201d\n\nMy grandparents were wealthy. Like the etiolated hero of \u201cPartisans,\u201d my uncle believed that his privileged background and private schooling had stunted his personal growth. To use today\u2019s psycho-parlance, Peter didn\u2019t like himself very much. Before he married and went off to Paris, he was often in one sort of trouble or another without really knowing why. He dodged a court-martial while in the Navy. He blew up his own engagement party \u2014 insulting Patsy\u2019s mother and making out with a bridesmaid. To paraphrase St. Augustine on his own bad-boy phase, Peter became to himself a place of unhappiness in which he could not bear to be, but he could not escape himself. Time and again he would bring himself to the lip of a crisis and, meaning to leap over, leap in.\n\nBut at this juncture he acted wisely. Quitting the C.I.A., Peter took his wife and newborn son, my cousin Lucas, back home. He settled in Sagaponack, on Long Island, still and always a footloose man but more focused. In midlife he produced two fine novels, \u201cAt Play in the Fields of the Lord\u201d and \u201cFar Tortuga,\u201d and a glorious spate of nonfiction about the natural world. His best nonfiction works are \u201cUnder the Mountain Wall,\u201d \u201cThe Tree Where Man Was Born\u201d and especially \u201cThe Snow Leopard,\u201d which appeared in 1978. Matthiessen is the only writer to win National Book Awards in both nonfiction, for \u201cThe Snow Leopard,\u201d and fiction, for his 2008 novel, \u201cShadow Country.\u201d\n\nIf he were alive, he might voice one regret about his sterling career. His time in Paris kept bobbing to the surface, both the good part about The Paris Review, as the magazine\u2019s stature among intellectuals increased, and the negative part about his role in the C.I.A. Well before the C.I.A. story became public, Peter had acknowledged the connection to Plimpton and Humes, and after the revelation he tried to placate other friends for having been less than candid. He protested that he was young and had no politics to speak of, other than a vague, Ivy League sense of patriotism. \u201cPeople tend to forget,\u201d he wrote in his memoir notes, \u201cthat 60 years ago, at the start of the Cold War, the C.I.A. had not yet earned the evil repute it has today, and I look back on my own brief participation with more chagrin than shame.\u201d He also wrote, \u201cI was no good at this low work and hated the deception that went with it, which I found nerve-racking and disagreeable and made worse by the fact that it all seemed petty and pointless as well as an idiotic waste of public money.\u201d\n\nPutting on a pained smile, Peter would observe that by introducing him to socialists the C.I.A. had educated him in the wrong direction. My uncle, don\u2019t forget, became a champion of left-wing causes. He wrote books in support of the farmworkers leader Cesar Chavez and the Native American activist Leonard Peltier, and he regularly chastised big corporations and the government for harming the environment. The occasionally shrill vein in his writing cost him both money and credibility.", "title": "A Writer\u2019s Controversial Past That Will Not Die", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "And from that sprouted my own voice \u2014 the voice of an unashamed black woman who also by way of a speech impediment understood what it was like to be silenced, and didn\u2019t wish this fate on any other soul. To hone my voice, I read everything, from books to cereal boxes, three times: once for fun, the second time to learn something new about the writing craft, and the third time was to improve that piece. I woke up early every day and basically did \u201cliterary dress up,\u201d where I\u2019d wear another writer\u2019s voice like clothing and move onto the next one, until I\u2019d gone through a stack of 10 different books. I wore ephemeral versions, copying their sentence constructions, verbiage, and tones. Then I\u2019d step out of them and choose the best characteristics of those styles, until I created a voice that was mine.\n\nThis was before I started thinking about publishing, which came in early high school when I started attending free poetry workshops at Beyond Baroque and the nonprofit WriteGirl.\n\nWhat is it that gets you started on a poem? Is it an idea, an image, a rhythm, or something else? Do you rely more on your ears or your eyes?\n\nBoth the external and the internal trigger me. If I\u2019m writing about something internal, say past experiences, I\u2019m writing about it in relation to an external reality, like the ocean. When that connection happens in my mind, I grab a pen and find the closest excuse for sunlight. I usually begin with a word cloud, where I write down the best words I\u2019ve heard that week \u2014 like plum, stone, spoon \u2014 I don\u2019t know why but I love words like that.\n\nI then take those words and begin to write. I think about the content of what I\u2019m writing first, just getting the lines out and choosing the most necessary ones. Only then do I think about a shape that comes out of that meaning. Where do I want this line to break? Do I want the stanzas to be shaped like a girl, or a house? Maybe it\u2019s because of an auditory processing disorder, but I depend a lot on sight. But that also means I\u2019m hypersensitive to sound \u2014 I just see it, rather than hear it, if that makes sense. For example, in order to write, I must have music. Without. Music. I. Can. Not. Write. I\u2019ll play an instrumental track that speaks to my mood, usually something by Lin-Manuel Miranda, Ludwig G\u00f6ransson or Michael Giacchino, and then my poem becomes a visualization of that sound.", "title": "A Young Poet\u2019s Inspiration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "They marry, despite Alice\u2019s misgivings. They buy a house overlooking the Atlantic, but Alice is at loose ends. Every morning her husband goes off to work, and she doesn\u2019t know what to do with herself. She drinks too much \u2014 everybody does in McCloskey\u2019s novel \u2014 she and Eddie wrangle about her aimless afternoons, about the way she has fallen back in with the unemployed musicians she hung out with pre-marriage, pre-respectability. This is a place where everything is seen, reported, judged, which is one reason Ireland is such a good setting for an adultery novel. When Alice tells a new acquaintance that she\u2019s married, it\u2019s as if Meghan Markle were explaining to an attendant at Kensington Palace that she\u2019s the American actress who\u2019s engaged to Prince Harry: \u201cThere are few things on earth smaller than this country.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOne day Alice meets Cauley, a young playwright who is both ambitious and puppy-soft. Almost immediately, she knows she\u2019s going to sleep with him; she just doesn\u2019t know what it will mean: \u201cI had imagined that it would bring me to my senses, remind me that I was a grown-up now, with a cupboard full of wedding china and candlesticks that matched.\u201d Instead, it turns her into someone \u201cferal, like an addict, all stealth and unreason.\u201d\n\nYet the love affair whose rhythms she describes \u2014 sitting on her front steps, savoring the arrival of a letter from Cauley; engaging in furtive sex on a bus \u2014 recalls nothing so much as a teenage passion. No wonder, when Alice\u2019s husband confronts her, it\u2019s \u201cas though it were all simply beneath him, Cauley and I nothing more than naughty children who had embarrassed him in front of the other grown-ups.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nToward the end of the affair, there\u2019s an emblematic encounter. The circumstances are seedy: Cauley is scrounging money from his mother, a disreputable figure because she\u2019s living with the lover for whom she broke up her marriage. (Ireland only legalized divorce in 1996.) They meet in a suburban pub, Alice and Cauley painfully hung over, the mother and her boyfriend \u201cdeeply and committedly alcoholic. \u2026 It wasn\u2019t only the drink, though, that dishonored them, it was the legal limbo of the undivorced. They had about them a fugitive air, and an uncertainty about how much their transgressions mattered.\u201d When Alice and Cauley make their escape, Cauley says, \u201cWell, there\u2019s us in 30 years!\u201d and they laugh \u201cas though the voicing of it had rendered it impossible.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt is impossible \u2014 both because Ireland is changing so fast and because there\u2019s a wild card in McCloskey\u2019s pack, a third mother inhabiting this novel, whose example is far more nourishing than that of either Eddie\u2019s mother or Cauley\u2019s.\n\nAlice, of course, doesn\u2019t come from \u201cnowhere.\u201d Her own mother is a woman \u201cin some respects ahead of her time,\u201d an administrator in a university philosophy department in Oregon who, when she became pregnant after a brief romance with a visiting professor, chose to raise the child on her own. This woman is instantly familiar: a mixture of the na\u00efvely wonder-struck and the old-lady ordinary (happy evenings watching \u201cJeopardy\u201d in her retirement condo; a compulsion to keep her new cellphone charged, accompanied by fear of actually using it). But although Alice feels perhaps excessively adored by her mother, she\u2019s never been able to compensate for her lack of a father. \u201cStraying,\u201d it turns out, means straying not just from one\u2019s partner but from a parent who, for all her delight in the world\u2019s possibilities, couldn\u2019t give her child the stability she craved. It\u2019s only after Alice\u2019s own marriage has ended that Alice finds herself \u201cfalling in love\u201d with her mother \u201cover and over again,\u201d that she\u2019s able \u2014 at a distance \u2014 to learn from this surprising woman\u2019s blend of practicality and joy.\n\nIn \u201cConversations With Friends,\u201d the Irish writer Sally Rooney\u2019s first novel, her young heroine tells a friend\u2019s husband, \u201cWe can sleep together if you like, but you should know I\u2019m only doing it ironically.\u201d\n\nAlice, we may come to feel, has been approaching both her marriage and her affair semi-ironically, playing at being the stay-at-home wife with matching candlesticks, playing at being the adulteress addicted to secrecy and ruin. The real heartbreak in this wise, discomfiting novel turns out to be the love between mother and daughter \u2014 a daughter early damage has driven to exile in a hard place.", "title": "A Young Wife Toys With Adultery", "authors": ["Fernanda Eberstadt", "Molly Mccloskey"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The re-enfranchisement of most former felons in the state is potentially much more significant. And while there\u2019s considerable evidence that ex-convicts have a low turnout rate, they don\u2019t need to have a very high turnout rate to make a difference if there\u2019s roughly 1.5 million of them.\n\nFlorida is one of a few states with a permanent voting ban for people with felony convictions, a policy that goes back to the Jim Crow era. A discharged felon can apply individually for clemency to a board that includes the governor, but Florida\u2019s rules are restrictive. (On Thursday, a federal judge declared unconstitutional the state\u2019s clemency system; the governor\u2019s spokesman hinted at an appeal.)\n\nThe ballot initiative would automatically allow felons to vote once they completed their sentences, except those convicted of murder or a felony sexual offense.\n\nEx-convicts tend to have very low educational attainment, and they tend to be young and nonwhite, with low incomes \u2014 all factors that correlate with a low turnout. The ex-convict turnout rate might not be expected to be much higher than 30 percent, based strictly on demographic characteristics.\n\nThere\u2019s evidence the actual turnout rate among this group is even lower. Over the last decade, several studies have matched discharged felons to voter registration files in the states where they\u2019re permitted to vote. Most studies find that around 20 percent of them turn out in battleground states in presidential elections.\n\nMany of these studies were conducted with data from the 2008 and 2012 presidential elections, when black and youth turnout were particularly high and Democratic registration rates were particularly high as well. On the other hand, these studies were of recently discharged felons, who might be less likely to register and vote than the broader felon population.\n\nA 20 percent turnout rate is pretty low, but it could produce a meaningful effect over 1.5 million newly eligible voters. It would mean 300,000 new voters \u2014 more than three times the estimated number of new Puerto Rican voters.", "title": "A \u2018Blue\u2019 Florida? There Are No Quick Demographic Fixes for Democrats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "There was just one hitch in moving the story to the stage: It had no role for Ms. Hoss. So she and Mr. Ostermeier \u2014 whose explosive \u201cRichard III\u201d was at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in October \u2014 devised a radical adaptation.\n\nIn the play, Ms. Hoss, 42, takes center stage as Katy, an actress recording the voice-over for a documentary based on Mr. Eribon\u2019s book. About 45 minutes in, she starts questioning the decisions of the film\u2019s director (played by Bush Moukarzel), who has been hovering in the sound booth. The book, the fake movie (which includes footage of Mr. Eribon chatting with his mother, filmed by Mr. Ostermeier and S\u00e9bastien Dupouey) and Ms. Hoss\u2019s own life merge as she brings her father, Willi Hoss, into the story.\n\n\u201cEverybody who read the Eribon book ended up talking about their own family, background or history, so I thought it might be a good idea to make that fruitful in the production,\u201d Mr. Ostermeier said. \u201cNina was happy to do it, even though it took her a lot of work and energy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA key difference between Mr. Eribon\u2019s upbringing and Ms. Hoss\u2019s is that his was miserable, and hers decidedly less so. \u201cI had a fantastic childhood,\u201d she said. \u201cI had two parents who had a lot of belief in humanity and people, and always fought with enthusiasm \u2014 never for themselves but always in a group.\u201d Her father started as a welder and trade unionist, then was elected to Germany\u2019s Parliament and was a founder of the Green Party. Her mother, Heidemarie Hoss-Rohweder, ran a theater company.\n\nIn the play, Ms. Hoss makes this activism come to life by showing pictures and home videos of her father, including some from trips he made to help save the Brazilian Amazon\u2019s rain forest. In a recent telephone conversation, Ms. Hoss described spending several summers there as a teenager, watching her father take measurements for pipes or wells.\n\nEventually, though, she took her mother\u2019s route and attended drama school. Her association with Mr. Ostermeier dates to 1999, and \u201cReturning to Reims\u201d is their third collaboration at the Schaub\u00fchne, following Yasmina Reza\u2019s dark comedy \u201cBella Figura\u201d and a revival of Lillian Hellman\u2019s \u201cThe Little Foxes.\u201d\n\nIn a move indicative of Ms. Hoss\u2019s process, a mix of research and intuition, she tweaked her take on the wicked Regina Giddens nightly in \u201cThe Little Foxes.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSometimes I felt the world is really mean to her,\u201d Ms. Hoss said with a chuckle \u2014 she laughs a lot in conversation, as if happy to be taken on a ride by her own quicksilver mind. \u201cHer brothers treat her horribly, so she becomes a horrible person. Other nights, she\u2019s like the men: She just wants it the way she wants it, and that\u2019s horrifying. Women can be horrible, too, and they should be allowed.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOne of Ms. Hoss\u2019s greatest strengths as an actor is a deceiving calm that somehow suggests both confidence and vulnerability. \u201cEven when she whispers, she captures the audience,\u201d Mr. Eribon said by telephone. Early in \u201cReturning to Reims,\u201d he said, \u201cshe speaks low to herself, rehearsing the reading, yet we\u2019re fascinated.\u201d\n\nThis quality allows Ms. Hoss\u2019s presence, at once cryptic and warm, to resonate even in small roles. It was such a supporting part, in fact, that led to \u201cHomeland.\u201d That series\u2019s showrunner, Alex Gansa, first spotted her alongside Philip Seymour Hoffman in the spy thriller \u201cA Most Wanted Man\u201d (2014), then confirmed his hunch by watching her carry the period melodrama \u201cPhoenix\u201d (2015), and cold-called her.\n\n\u201cOne of the things Nina loved about Astrid, more than anything, is that she had a sense of humor,\u201d Mr. Gansa said by telephone. \u201cWe spent a lot of time in the writers\u2019 room giving her that color because she can be so wry and funny in the most understated way. Being grown-up never seemed so sexy.\u201d\n\nThe \u201cHomeland\u201d job has opened doors for Ms. Hoss, who recalled, with a smidgen of incredulity, being recognized by passers-by in New York. Because the Schaub\u00fchne runs on a time-consuming repertory model, with yearlong commitments, she\u2019s decided to put the stage aside for a while after this summer, and focus on her screen career.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve done theater for a very long time,\u201d Ms. Hoss said, \u201cand I feel more and more these two systems just don\u2019t work with each other, especially if I want to work in the U.S. So now I\u2019m available.\u201d She laughed, again. \u201cBut I\u2019m always going back to theater, I know that.\u201d", "title": "A \u2018Homeland\u2019 Spy Opens Up Onstage in \u2018Returning to Reims\u2019", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cPeople say it\u2019s too early to talk about it,\u201d Mr. Kasky said. \u201cIf you ask me, it\u2019s way too late.\u201d\n\nHis argument reflects the words of other students who want action: The issue is not an abstraction to them. These are their murdered friends, their bloodstained schools, their upended lives.\n\nStudents said they did not want to cede the discussion over their lives to politicians and adult activists.\n\n\u201cWe need to take it into our hands,\u201d Mr. Kasky said.\n\nDavid Hogg, a 17-year-old student journalist who interviewed his classmates during the rampage in Parkland, said he had thought about the possibility of a school shooting long before shots from an AR-15 started to blast through the hallways. As he huddled with fellow students, he stayed calm and decided to try to create a record of their thoughts and views that would live on, even if the worst happened to them.\n\n\u201cI recorded those videos because I didn\u2019t know if I was going to survive,\u201d he said in an interview here. \u201cBut I knew that if those videos survived, they would echo on and tell the story. And that story would be one that would change things, I hoped. And that would be my legacy.\u201d\n\nIt is a stark change from the moments that followed the Columbine shooting in April 1999, said Austin Eubanks, who survived the shooting. Mr. Eubanks and a friend hid under a table when the two teenage gunmen walked into the library and started shooting. Mr. Eubanks was wounded. His friend, Corey DePooter, was killed.\n\n\u201cThere was nobody who took an activism stance,\u201d Mr. Eubanks said of Columbine\u2019s immediate aftermath. He said he began abusing opiates shortly after as a coping mechanism. \u201cI just wanted to be left alone. Yes, he\u2019ll almost certainly step down, but not right now. Instead, it\u2019ll be sometime in the near future, or, to use a quintessential South African expression, \u201cnow-now.\u201d\n\nNegotiations between Mr. Zuma and his deputy and probable successor as president, Cyril Ramaphosa, over South Africa\u2019s presidency entered their second week on Monday after days of premature reports that Mr. Zuma\u2019s exit was imminent. The lack of clarity surrounding his future \u2014 and the nature of the talks themselves \u2014 deepened the anxiety and frustration among many South Africans.\n\nBut a marathon meeting on Monday of leaders of the African National Congress raised the possibility that the drawn-out negotiations were finally coming to an end. The leaders met late into the night on Monday. Around midnight, the state broadcaster said that party leaders had directed Mr. Ramaphosa to personally deliver to Mr. Zuma a demand that he resign within 48 hours.\n\nBut that report could not be independently confirmed, and hours earlier, Mr. Zuma\u2019s spokesman had called reports that Mr. Zuma\u2019s resignation was imminent \u201cfake news.\u201d", "title": "A.N.C. Debates Zuma\u2019s Fate in South Africa: Will He Go Now or Now-Now?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "JOHANNESBURG \u2014 Top leaders of South Africa\u2019s governing party ordered President Jacob Zuma to step down on Tuesday, saying that his continued presence was eroding the \u201crenewed hope\u201d felt since the election of new party leaders in December.\n\nAce Magashule, secretary general of the African National Congress, said that the party had not given Mr. Zuma a deadline to respond, but added that he was certain that the president would deliver a reply the next day. \u201cLet\u2019s leave it to President Jacob Zuma,\u201d Mr. Magashule said at a news conference at party headquarters in Johannesburg.\n\nThe extraordinary confrontation between Mr. Zuma and A.N.C. leaders heightened a power struggle within the party that has governed South Africa since the end of apartheid and has become less known for its heroic past than for widespread corruption and mismanagement. The power struggle has paralyzed South Africa.\n\nIn what appeared to be a turning point, the A.N.C., for the first time, moved decisively against the leader it had shielded for the past nine years against a seemingly endless series of accusations of misconduct. But in an indication of what may be the limits of the A.N.C.\u2019s self-inquiry, party leaders stated that Mr. Zuma was being dismissed because he was harming the A.N.C.\u2019s prospects \u2014 not because of the ethical issues surrounding him.", "title": "A.N.C. Tells Jacob Zuma to Step Down as South Africa\u2019s President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The Justice Department has also submitted a list of witnesses, along with other documents from AT&T and Time Warner, said the people. During the pretrial discovery period, the parties notify the court of requests such as witness lists, documents and interviews. A judge will intervene only when there is a dispute over the demands.\n\n\u201cWe will reserve comment on it for the courtroom,\u201d Daniel M. Petrocelli, lead trial counsel for Time Warner and AT&T, said in a statement on Wednesday, referring to the reports about Mr. Delrahim being put on AT&T\u2019s witness list.\n\nA spokesman for the Department of Justice declined to comment.\n\nAT&T has amassed a considerable army of litigators and more than 100 lobbyists to win its case. Its top litigator, Mr. Petrocelli, defended Mr. Trump in a lawsuit involving Trump University. Time Warner has hired Christine A. Varney, the former head of the Justice Department\u2019s Antitrust Division.\n\nThe decision by Mr. Delrahim, a former White House counsel, to deny a merger of two companies that do not directly compete was unexpected given that similar deals have previously been approved. The Justice Department has argued that the merger of two giant companies that both produce content and distribute those shows will lead to higher prices for consumers.\n\nAT&T has claimed that Mr. Delrahim unfairly singled out its deal. The company described the government\u2019s decision as \u201cselective enforcement\u201d and as evidence, it pointed to a 2011 decision by the Justice Department to approve a similar deal, Comcast\u2019s merger with NBCUniversal.\n\nAT&T is expected to also claim Mr. Delrahim has flip-flopped on his views of the deal. Before he was appointed to the Justice Department, Mr. Delrahim said in an interview with a Canadian broadcaster that he did not see clear problems with the deal. The company may present a video of that interview in the trial.\n\nMr. Delrahim has said Comcast had a much smaller reach into American homes than AT&T\u2019s nationwide wireless and satellite television network. He has added that Comcast and NBC were allowed to merge with several so-called behavioral conditions that were hard to enforce. Mr. Delrahim has vocally opposed such conditions that constrain a company\u2019s business practices, saying he prefers selling off assets to solve competition concerns.\n\nAT&T\u2019s strategy of putting Mr. Delrahim on the witness stand is risky.\n\n\u201cIf AT&T\u2019s strategy is to call Delrahim to testify for the purpose of showing political motivation, it could blow up in their face if the assistant attorney general is a credible witness for the legitimate challenge of the merger,\u201d said Gene Kimmelman, a former senior antitrust official in the Justice Department who has been critical of the deal. \u201cUnless they have a smoking gun, I think Delrahim has a convincing argument.\u201d", "title": "AT&T Is Said to Want Antitrust Official on Witness List for Trial", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement, the Justice Department said, \u201cWe are pleased with and respect today\u2019s decision, which will permit the parties and court to focus on the case at hand.\u201d\n\nAT&T has argued that the Justice Department has unfairly singled out its proposed merger with Time Warner partly to stay in favor with the White House. President Trump has been a vocal critic of Time Warner\u2019s news network, CNN, and said before the election that the deal should be stopped.\n\nAT&T\u2019s lawyers have requested emails and phone and other communications logs between Justice Department officials and the White House, to see if the White House influenced the agency\u2019s decision. The company also put Makan Delrahim, the head of antitrust for the Justice Department, on its witness list.\n\nLast week, the Justice Department asked Judge Leon to block the company\u2019s demands for communications with the White House, saying they were a \u201csideshow\u201d to the antitrust concerns the government held about the merger. The Justice Department has argued that consumers would be harmed by the deal, saying it would stifle competition and lead to higher prices for consumers.\n\nIn a hearing on Friday, AT&T agreed to remove Mr. Delrahim from its witness list on the condition the company could call him to testify during the trial if evidence emerged to support its arguments of political interference.\n\nThe blockbuster trial will begin March 19. It is expected to help set the course for mergers and acquisitions in coming years.\n\nThe Justice Department\u2019s suit to block AT&T\u2019s merger with Time Warner was unexpected, because the government has a history of allowing mergers between companies that don\u2019t directly compete. Those deals, including Comcast\u2019s merger with NBCUniversal in 2011, contained several conditions to resolve competition concerns. Mr. Delrahim has argued that conditions that restrain a company\u2019s business practices cannot effectively resolve antitrust issues.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the opinion on Tuesday, Judge Leon said that AT&T was able to point only to the Justice Department\u2019s approval of Comcast\u2019s merger as proof of discrimination toward AT&T and Time Warner.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe defendants have mustered only one specific transaction,\u201d Judge Leon said.\n\nThe focus on political interference is highly unusual. AT&T told Judge Leon last week it was reluctant to raise the topic. The Justice Department countered that the company was trying to use the argument as a \u201cget-out-of-jail card.\u201d\n\n\u201cEverything about this case has been unusual from the beginning,\u201d said Larry Downes, a project director at Georgetown University\u2019s Center for Business and Public Policy.\n\nThe result of the trial could set the nation on a new, stricter direction on antitrust policy.\n\n\u201cThere has not been this kind of a challenge to a vertical merger of companies that don\u2019t compete in decades and this is hugely significant in that it suggests the Justice Department may be going in a radically new direction on antitrust,\u201d Mr. Downes said.\n\nAT&T could still focus on its argument of so-called selective enforcement that singles out its proposed merger with Time Warner. But the judge may not be swayed.\n\nIn his opinion, Judge Leon said the Justice Department\u2019s lawyer explained at length that there was a history of the government\u2019s blocking somewhat similar deals.\n\n\u201cSo while it may, indeed, be a rare breed of horse, it is not exactly a unicorn,\u201d Judge Leon said.", "title": "AT&T Loses Bid to Obtain White House Call Logs", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "About 30 minutes after the match, Harrison said, the ATP supervisor for the tournament, Tom Barnes, called him into his office and, with Young present, notified Harrison of Young\u2019s charge.\n\n\u201cI was totally shocked,\u201d Harrison said. \u201cI begged him to find a tape of the broadcast. I said I would sign a document right there on the spot saying I would accept a three-month suspension, without appealing, if it\u2019s true.\u201d\n\nThe video recording of the match shows Harrison and Young arguing almost to the brink of fighting, but no clear audio recording of their conversation has emerged.\n\n\u201cThe chair umpire witnessed and was a part of the entire exchange,\u201d Harrison said in a statement released by the ATP on Tuesday afternoon. \u201cThe argument occurred directly in front of him. Anyone who follows the sport of tennis knows that if anything of a racial nature occurred, the chair umpire would be required to give me an immediate code violation. The fact that no code violation occurred is further proof that no disparaging racial comments were made or said. Any audio of this exchange will confirm this and I encourage anyone with the available resources to find it.\u201d\n\nHarrison said that he and Young had engaged in \u201ctrash talk\u201d about tennis only.\n\n\u201cI know for a fact that I didn\u2019t say it,\u201d he said. \u201cThis isn\u2019t an incident that I have a cloudy or vague memory of. I remember it word for word. It\u2019s why I was so adamant about a video or audio coming into play, because I knew I was 100 percent in the clear there.\u201d\n\nHarrison and Young have a long history of on-court acrimony, and the grudge appeared to escalate in Monday\u2019s first-round match at the Veterans Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y., the new home of the NY Open.\n\nHarrison has a reputation as a hotheaded player and acknowledged that he has made many missteps on the court, but added that it was never anything like this.\n\n\u201cI am very passionate on the court I know there are times when I have been wrong,\u201d he said. \u201cBut this is not one of those times.
