The authorities shut down internet service in the area for hours.", "title": "After Religious Clash in India, Rumors Create a False \u2018Martyr\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "GIRL ON FIRE: Lisa Gardner committed to her writing career after setting her hair on fire. She was waitressing, it was the \u201980s \u201cand there was a lot of Aqua Net involved,\u201d she recalls. \u201cI had to serve an appetizer involving flaming cheese. Except I kind of poured the brandy down my arm, meaning when I lit the match, the fire raced up my limb and melted my highly permed and poofed bangs. I took the hint. No more food service. Lots more time at the keyboard.\u201d\n\nNow Gardner has just published her 20th novel, \u201cLook for Me,\u201d which debuts at No. 5 on the hardcover fiction list. \u201cIt\u2019s based on a ripped-from-the-headlines kind of crime \u2014 a family is murdered and their daughter missing,\u201d she explains. Gardner talked to homicide detectives about how they\u2019d approach such a case. \u201cIn real life, it\u2019s a 50/50 proposition: Half of the time the teen assisted in her family\u2019s demise. But the other half, the family is killed in order to abduct the teenager,\u201d she says. \u201cYou need to know everything about this family, and you need to know it yesterday. Yet you still can\u2019t answer the most basic question: Are you searching for a killer, or a victim? The detectives I spoke with impressed upon me the need to have no preconceived judgments. Start with the crime scene, work your way out.\u201d\n\nIN SICKNESS: Everything changed for Kate Bowler \u2014 a professor at the Duke Divinity School who studies the prosperity gospel \u2014 when she was diagnosed with stage 4 cancer. \u201cThe hardest part about this diagnosis was feeling eclipsed by something I did not choose,\u201d she says. \u201cI chose my career. I chose my husband. I like to imagine that I willed my beautiful son into existence, even though that can\u2019t be biologically accurate. But cancer doesn\u2019t care if I want it or not. Cancer doesn\u2019t care if I\u2019m special or I\u2019m boring, if I have things I want to live for or I\u2019m wasting every opportunity. The randomness of tragedy is hard to get used to and requires a whole new imagination for how to live after certainty is no longer an option.\u201d As Bowler grappled with her situation, first she wrote a New York Times Op-Ed that went viral and then a memoir, \u201cEverything Happens For a Reason,\u201d which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 8.\n\n\u201cThis book poured out of me in a summer that I thought would be my last,\u201d she says. \u201cI wanted to come to grips with the basic questions of my life. What did I hope for? What am I allowed to expect? And did I really think I was running this show? I started writing to make sense of my own outrageous certainties.\u201d", "title": "After Setting Her Hair on Fire, Lisa Gardner Decided to Become a Writer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 Nearly a year after accusing Uber of stealing its driverless car technology, Waymo agreed on Friday to settle a closely watched lawsuit filed against the ride-hailing company.\n\nNow for Waymo, which grew out of Google\u2019s seminal autonomous vehicle project and is nearly a decade into an effort that aims to change the very nature of transportation, a much bigger fight looms outside the courtroom.\n\nWaymo\u2019s competition extends well beyond Uber \u2014 and a good part of that competition is directed by engineers it used to employ. Much of the artificial intelligence technology that has come out of Waymo\u2019s work and from research run by Google\u2019s parent company, Alphabet, is now available from other sources, making it easier for companies, even start-ups, to compete.\n\n\u201cWaymo may have a technical advantage,\u201d said Jason Doran, who helped run the delivery service Sidecar and joined General Motors when the carmaker acquired the start-up. \u201cBut they have to figure out a business model.\u201d", "title": "After Settling With Uber, Waymo Faces Bigger Challenges", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "A years-long battle over whether Idaho would require its science teachers to teach about global warming was resolved Thursday when the State Senate education committee voted to adopt standards that included sections on human-caused climate change.\n\nIdaho\u2019s legislature had scrubbed all mentions of human-caused climate change from its teaching standards last year. The State Department of Education then put forth revised standards, but this month the House education committee voted to gut the supporting content, which was designed to help teachers assign coursework and included multiple mentions of climate change. On Thursday, the Senate committee approved the revised standards in full, including the supporting content, on a 6 to 3 vote that drew support from both parties. Because both chambers did not agree to reject the standards, they will go into effect.\n\nState Senator Janie Ward-Engelking of Boise, a Democrat on the education committee, said the supporting content was important to include. \u201cWhen a new teacher comes in, they need to see all the concepts that they\u2019re responsible to teach,\u201d Ms. Ward-Engelking said. \u201cTo be honest, it\u2019s kind of embarrassing that it\u2019s been so controversial.\u201d\n\nEmily Her, 17, a senior at Timberline High School in Boise who started a petition and appeared with her classmates at hearings to support the revised standards, said she was glad that all students in Idaho would learn about climate change. \u201cIt was definitely a group effort, and I was really happy that it paid off and that they decided to listen to us,\u201d she said.", "title": "After Years of Fighting, Idaho Retains Climate Change in Its Education Guidelines", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe best the government could ever hope for was a hung jury,\u201d said Lawrence S. Lustberg, a defense lawyer in Newark, where the first case was tried and, in fact, ended in a mistrial when jurors said they could not reach a unanimous verdict. \u201cThe summation is, \u2018If exchanging gifts between friends is a crime, then we\u2019re all in trouble.\u201d\n\nJustice Department officials in Washington had debated whether to even retry Mr. Menendez, but eventually reached a consensus. Attorney General Jeff Sessions, a Republican who served alongside Mr. Menendez in the Senate, signed off on a recommendation from the deputy attorney general and the criminal division to try again to win a conviction.\n\nSome in the department had been uneasy with the case from the beginning. It started with an investigation into salacious rumors that Mr. Menendez and Dr. Melgen had visited underage prostitutes in the Dominican Republic. The charges had been peddled to news outlets for years by an anonymous informant who adopted his pseudonym from a former congressman from New Jersey, Pete Williams, who was convicted of bribery in the Abscam case of the 1970s.\n\nReporters and government investigators alike could never substantiate those rumors. The government shifted instead to more complex, less sexy matters involving Medicare billing and port security contracts.\n\nThe Justice Department\u2019s Public Integrity Unit, which had suffered through an embarrassing string of losses and missteps involving prosecutions of high level politicians like former senators Ted Stevens of Alaska and John Edwards of North Carolina, was eager to burnish its once-lofty reputation.\n\nThe prospect of a corruption case against another sitting senator, especially for bribery, proved tantalizing.\n\n\u201cI think that there was a little bit of zealousness in trying to find the next big fish in order to set things right reputationally about the public integrity section,\u201d said Brian Fallon, who worked as a spokesman for the Department of Justice before joining Hillary Clinton\u2019s presidential campaign in 2015. He also briefly worked for Mr. Menendez. \u201cI think that certain people were seeking some kind of big name that they could deliver a case all the way to a conviction.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJustice Department officials declined to discuss any details of their initial decision to retry the case.\n\nThe indictment was handed down in April 2015. But less than a year later, before a trial date had even been set, the Department of Justice was dealt the first blow to their case: the Supreme Court overturned a corruption conviction against former Virginia governor Bob McDonnell, extremely narrowing the definition of official acts that would qualify for a bribery conviction.\n\nStill, prosecutors were not overwhelmingly concerned about how the ruling affected the Menendez trial, thinking that their burden was more on proving that Mr. Menendez had accepted bribes than it was on proving that he had taken actions.\n\nPhoto\n\nJudge Walls, though, repeatedly questioned whether the McDonnell decision would allow the introduction of certain evidence in the first trial. And the question of whether the senator\u2019s actions were official acts added another level of complexity for the jury.\n\nEarly in the trial, Judge Walls made it clear that he was not going to let any of the salacious rumors work their way into his courtroom, nor what he viewed as loaded references to Mr. Menendez\u2019s decisions to stay in luxury hotels with a female friend.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not going to be a tabloid trial, and I am not going to let you just swish and swash nonsensical, you know, nonsensical substances \u2014 not substances, scenarios that really don\u2019t even make for a good pulp fiction story,\u201d he told a prosecutor at one point.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGerald Krovatin, a lawyer in Newark who had worked with Mr. Menendez\u2019s defense team, said, \u201cThey had really criminalized a relationship. It had its seamy underside with the Melgen girlfriends, but it was kind of a bloodless case once Walls cut all the sex out of it.\u201d\n\nFederal prosecutors saw their case slip away. The jury was deadlocked. Judge Walls tried to encourage them to reach a decision but eventually had to declare a mistrial. Jurors told reporters afterward that they were stuck at 10-2, with the majority for acquittal. It was unusual insight into a jury\u2019s deliberations, and it made some in the Justice Department unenthusiastic about a retrial.\n\nThe government was facing other hurdles.\n\nJudge Walls had said he would not preside over the retrial, and the case was expected to go to Judge William Martini. Reflecting Mr. Menendez\u2019s long and deep involvement in New Jersey politics, every other federal judge in Newark, where the first trial was held, had either passed or recused from the case; Mr. Menendez had helped sponsor several of the judges for the bench.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProsecutors had reason to feel anxious about arguing the case before Judge Martini. A former Republican congressman \u2014 he served in the House with Mr. Menendez in the mid 1990s \u2014 he has been an outspoken critic of government overreach.\n\nIn one of the most prominent public corruption cases in the state\u2019s recent history, against Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, Judge Martini questioned whether Mr. James\u2019 actions had been different than what any public official would do for a constituent. He sentenced Mr. James to 27 months in prison, a fraction of what the United States attorney in the case \u2014 a future governor named Chris Christie \u2014 had sought.\n\nJudge Martini, too, decided to pass on the case, which would have moved it to Trenton. That move might have hurt the defense, because the pool of jurors would be less likely to include many Hispanics, who were considered sympathetic to Mr. Menendez.\n\nThe government risked looking small with a case based primarily on a relatively lesser offense, of failing to report trips and gifts on disclosure forms. There was the chance that jurors would have decided the matter was not a federal crime, and better handled by the Senate Ethics Committee, which is conducting its own investigation.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know if they thought \u2018small potatoes,\u2019 or they would look petty if all they got out of it was a false statements case,\u201d Mr. Krovatin said. \u201cYou have to believe that Judge Walls\u2019s decision became the tipping point in terms of their decision.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe knocks out the six-figure dollars in the case,\u201d Mr. Krovatin said. \u201cThey must have thought that made a retrial much more consistent with the defense theme of friendship and exchange of mutual friendship-related favors as opposed to bribery.\u201d\n\nAfter the years of headlines, months of courtroom battles and the surprising decision to retry the case, federal prosecutors delivered the news to the defense that they were abandoning all the charges almost casually.\n\nPeter Koski, the lead prosecutor, walked over to the defense table during a procedural hearing, out of earshot of the judge, leaned over and said they were dropping the case.\n\nAs much as Judge Walls\u2019s decision to toss some of the charges hobbled the prosecution, it also handed the government a public relations lifeline.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe case got harder, and the politics of dismissing it got a lot easier,\u201d said Matt Miller, a former spokesman for the Department of Justice who also closely counseled Mr. Menendez during the investigation. \u201cNow you have a graceful exit.\u201d", "title": "After Years of Investigation, a Sudden Folding of the Case Against Menendez", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti", "Kate Zernike"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Although now she\u2019s calm, cool and collected, she also recounted being \u201cvery angry\u201d with the Prospect organizers in the fall when she got their email questioning the cost of shipping the piece from New York to New Orleans and its presentation. Fences were eventually mended, Prospect paid, and \u201ceverything has been on track\u201d since the beginning of the year, she said.\n\n\u201cIt was a learning experience,\u201d Ms. Walker added. \u201cHow far do I need to go with my work for it to do what I need it to do, and how much support do I need for that?\u201d\n\nFor his part, Trevor Schoonmaker, Prospect.4\u2019s artistic director, said, \u201cThere were headaches and heartaches going through it all. But having a great presentation at the end is magnificent.\u201d\n\nIt seems like a lot of agita for a work whose own creator describes it as having \u201can auditory element that is extremely irritating.\u201d (It\u2019s so loud that Ms. Walker recommends ear protection.) But it\u2019s very much in keeping with Ms. Walker\u2019s habit of using the cultural past to make a point about race and power \u2014 as she showed to great acclaim in 2014 with her 35-foot-tall sphinxlike figure, \u201cA Subtlety,\u201d at the former Domino Sugar factory on the Brooklyn waterfront.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cSilhouettes and steam calliopes,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019ve been going backward the whole time!\u201d She added, \u201cIt\u2019s similarly retrograde, gazing into obscure histories.\u201d\n\nThe explanatory pamphlet that will be distributed to viewers has a playful text in which Ms. Walker refers to herself as the \u201csideshow-barker-in-chief,\u201d a phrase that riffs on President Obama\u2019s reference to Donald Trump as a \u201ccarnival barker\u201d back in the days when Mr. Trump was questioning whether Mr. Obama was born outside the United States.\n\nRace is a central theme of Mr. Schoonmaker\u2019s vision for Prospect.4, which features 73 artists in all, and Ms. Walker\u2019s work fits right in. \u201cShe\u2019s mined antebellum America for a long time, but this takes it a step further,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Schoonmaker and Ms. Walker have known each other for more than 20 years, having met when, in her words, \u201che was an intern.\u201d Mr. Schoonmaker recalled that he was a lowly gallery employee and \u201cKara was already a MacArthur winner.\u201d (She is one of the youngest to win the MacArthur Fellowship, at 27.)\n\nIn 2016, the two visited several New Orleans sites on a scouting trip. One of them was Algiers Point, which features a historical marker that Ms. Walker said \u201chalfway commemorates\u201d a 1720s holding area for slaves where they were kept before being shipped to auction across the river. \u201cIt felt like an entry point\u201d to another grand work, conceptually and physically.\n\nShe heard music during that visit and wondered where it was coming from; it turned out to be a calliope on the Steamboat Natchez. She started researching the instrument, which had its heyday just after the Civil War. (Calliope is the mythological Greek muse of epic poetry.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI started thinking about music and mind control \u2014 happy music being a way of keeping a certain level of peace, placating everyone,\u201d Ms. Walker said. \u201cThe more I looked into it, the more it piqued my interest.\u201d\n\nOn the internet she found Kenneth Griffard, a Michigan-based calliope specialist, who had a partly completed one, and that\u2019s when the project started to sprout.\n\n\u201cThe more I talked to him, the bigger it got,\u201d Ms. Walker said. \u201cA 10-note calliope? I was like, \u2018Ehh, that doesn\u2019t sound like enough notes.\u2019\u201d The final product has 38 notes, which, Mr. Griffard said, makes it \u201cone of the biggest calliopes out there.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Griffard also held a testing session that Ms. Walker attended in Hesston, Ind., at the Hesston Steam Museum. The wagon\u2019s body was fabricated in Kingston, N.Y., and the wheels in Letcher, S.D. The journey into what she called \u201cAmerican manufacturing at its fringiest\u201d appealed to her love of the arcane.\n\nMs. Walker noted that she often works in inexpensive materials, like paper. \u201cI\u2019m a little bit of a cheapskate, but I also wanted it to be done right,\u201d she said.\n\nBy early 2017, Ms. Walker understood that the financial burden of fabricating the piece would be on her shoulders. But in the middle of October \u2014 just a month before the opening of Prospect \u2014 \u201cfireworks\u201d started, in Mr. Schoonmaker\u2019s words.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn email balking at the shipping and presentation cost \u2014 which was $90,000 in the end \u2014 was sent to Ms. Walker from a Prospect staffer. (Mr. Schoonmaker declined to say who.)\n\n\u201cThe issue was what they were willing to do, but also a communication breakdown,\u201d Ms. Walker recalled. \u201cI just said, forget it. If we can\u2019t get it there, we can\u2019t get it there. And I\u2019m not leaving my thing there for four months with no oversight.\u201d She paused. \u201cThat apparently got everybody\u2019s attention.\u201d A flurry of phone calls followed, and the last-weekend plan emerged.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t want to have to be a diva about it,\u201d Ms. Walker explained. \u201cBut I made this piece to respond to this site, and without that it feels it\u2019s lacking something.\u201d\n\nMr. Schoonmaker and Ms. Walker don\u2019t agree on exactly what happened. He said he followed up within a half-hour of the original email to say that the money was there, but \u201cthe damage was done,\u201d he added, because \u201ctrust was broken.\u201d\n\nHe said \u201cKatastw\u00f3f Karawan\u201d is unusually complicated and that the interruption probably provided valuable testing time. \u201cI maintain that had this never happened, we would have hit a major snag in the 11th hour that may have been worse,\u201d he said. Mr. Schoonmaker added that he and Ms. Walker were \u201cin a good place now.\u201d\n\nAfter the work\u2019s brief weekend appearance is over, Ms. Walker will be back in possession of a loud calliope in a large wagon. She said that the piece could now be sold, preferably to a museum, and that there were already requests to exhibit it.\n\nBut the imagination that brought her this far was still at work. \u201cI have a fantasy about hauling it across the United States,\u201d Ms. Walker said, \u201cfollowed by a parade of interested people while it\u2019s tootling away.\u201d", "title": "After a Blowup, Kara Walker Lets Off Steam in New Orleans", "authors": ["Ted Loos"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf it were my daughter, I would want to personally kill my client, make no mistake about it,\u201d said Howard Finkelstein, the public defender, an elected position.\n\nPhoto\n\nLater, though, he said that perhaps he would \u201ctry to go on and build a future. I don\u2019t know what I would do. I just don\u2019t know.\u201d\n\nAlready, Mr. Finkelstein\u2019s office has offered a way to avoid a trial: Mr. Cruz\u2019s guilty plea in exchange for a punishment of 17 consecutive life sentences without parole. But Mr. Finkelstein recognizes that for some victims, that might not be enough: \u201cI\u2019m a father. I don\u2019t know whether I would take my offer.\u201d\n\nRelatives of the victims of the massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., have not yet made their feelings about the death penalty widely known. And it is not clear where Michael J. Satz, Broward County\u2019s prosecutor, is in his deliberations. He declined to comment.\n\nMr. Satz, who was elected state attorney when Gerald R. Ford was president, is regarded as a hard-edged prosecutor, but he is still likely to consider an array of factors, including the odds of persuading a jury.\n\nAlthough jurors condemned men for massacres in Charleston, S.C., where nine churchgoers were killed, and at Fort Hood, Tex., where there were 13 fatalities, they spared the life of the Aurora gunman who killed 12, citing his history of mental illness. In the Huntsville shooting, the prosecutor said his conversations with the families of the victims were a reason he did not seek execution.\n\nGeorge Brauchler, the lead prosecutor in the Aurora case, said he had engaged in \u201cserious soul-searching\u201d about whether to pass up a plea deal and seek the death penalty. \u201cThis is as much a moral decision as it is a decision about justice, and that is not an easy decision to make,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cUntil you are signing your name to a piece of paper that starts the machinery of government against another human being to take their life, whether it\u2019s deserved or not, you don\u2019t know what you\u2019re talking about.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Brauchler said he had met with his Roman Catholic priest, and conferred with family members of the victims as well as survivors of the attack. Some of the conversations were tense and punctuated by yelling. Some people urged a measure of mercy for the gunman, Mr. Brauchler recalled, while others said, \u201cI want to put the needle in his arm.\u201d In the end, Mr. Brauchler said, he did not find the gunman\u2019s mental illness defense credible.\n\nDeath penalty cases are the criminal justice system\u2019s most complex, expensive and emotionally taxing. It can take weeks or even months to present volumes of evidence that can include autopsy after autopsy and the painstaking recollection of every crack or boom of gunfire and every word the killer uttered.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe trials can wear down even the most experienced experts. When it came time to cross-examine a survivor of the Charleston attack, a defense lawyer, David I. Bruck, said only: \u201cMs. Sheppard, I\u2019m so sorry. I have no questions.\u201d\n\nA crucial consideration in potential capital cases, prosecutors and defense lawyers said, is whether failing to seek the death penalty in a mass shooting would set a precedent, making it more difficult to seek it in cases with lower death tolls.\n\nIn Charleston, the federal government had a sharp internal debate, and met with resistance from family members of victims, before it decided to seek the death penalty against Dylann S. Roof.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe death penalty itself becomes a participant in the decision, almost as if the death penalty is given a seat at the table,\u201d said Mr. Bruck, who represented Mr. Roof during the guilt phase of his trial but was sidelined by the defendant during the penalty phase, when jurors decide whether a death sentence is appropriate. \u201cThere are plea agreements in a lot of cases,\u201d Mr. Bruck said. \u201cWhen there are, it\u2019s usually because the prosecution recognizes \u2014 and sometimes the larger community recognizes \u2014 that there are things to consider outside of just whether or not we can kill this person.\u201d\n\nFor defense lawyers seeking to spare their client\u2019s life, an appeal to efficiency is one of the few cards they can play \u2014 particularly when, as Mr. Finkelstein says, the \u201ccase is not a whodunit.\u201d\n\nExpecting that Mr. Satz will seek the death penalty, Mr. Finkelstein and his deputies are already preparing for a \u201clong, arduous legal battle\u201d and intend to concentrate on jury selection. Because juries must unanimously recommend death sentences in Florida, a single juror could prevent execution. Mr. Finkelstein said the defense would likely focus on mental health and the accumulation of failures by government agencies to stop Mr. Cruz from opening fire.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMelisa McNeill, the assistant public defender who has appeared with Mr. Cruz in court and would likely be the lead lawyer if there is a trial, did not respond to a message on Friday.\n\nIn Florida, where 347 people are on death row after an execution on Thursday night, state law spells out a roster of aggravating factors and mitigating circumstances that jurors may consider in capital cases. Aggravating factors, at least one of which must be proven for someone to be eligible for a death sentence, include a finding that a defendant \u201cknowingly created a great risk of death to many persons\u201d or that a homicide was \u201ccommitted in a cold, calculated and premeditated manner.\u201d\n\nMitigating circumstances, like a defendant\u2019s age and whether he or she was under the \u201cinfluence of extreme mental or emotional disturbance\u201d at the time of the crime, can legally tilt jurors toward a punishment of life in prison.\n\nMr. Finkelstein made plain that he is dreading any trial here, and not just for legal reasons. In his dimly lit office, he raspily declared a hope that \u201cdivine intervention\u201d would persuade Mr. Satz to avoid a trial and an airing of the tragic details.\n\n\u201cThis is the most awful thing, not only that I\u2019ve ever seen \u2014 that I\u2019ve even imagined in some sick movie or imagination. This was hell on earth,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s awful because of what was done to these poor kids. It\u2019s awful because of the families that will never be the same. It\u2019s awful because of the community, and it\u2019s awful to be involved representing anybody when the community hates and hurts so much because of that person.\u201d", "title": "After a Massacre, a Question of One More Death: The Gunman\u2019s", "authors": ["Alan Blinder"]} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "CAIRO \u2014 Egypt said its warplanes struck militant targets in North Sinai on Friday night, destroying weapons dumps as ground forces raided militant hide-outs, as part of a major offensive against the Islamic State in one of the group\u2019s most enduring Middle East strongholds.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah-el Sisi, who is standing for re-election next month, ordered the offensive after Islamic State militants killed at least 311 people in a ruthless gun-and-bomb assault on a mosque in North Sinai on Nov. 24, in Egypt\u2019s deadliest terrorist attack. Soon after, Mr. Sisi set a three-month deadline for the army to defeat the militants. The operation began on Friday morning.\n\nBut although the military prepared the Egyptian public for large-scale casualties, with hundreds of hospital beds set aside and doctors recalled from leave, it provided scant detail on the operation. Williams crushed certain shots with customary power and precision but mistimed many others, muttering to herself and shadow-stroking between rallies.\n\nShe was in a playful mood, dancing as she walked to the baseline and cracking jokes in her chair during breaks and between deep breaths, but she was all business between the lines.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sure she does want it to go faster,\u201d Rinaldi said of the process. \u201cShe\u2019s got high expectations obviously, and it\u2019s tough to manage those in the beginning and be patient with herself. But as you can see, I think that\u2019s what makes her so great, too, is that she is tough on herself and has that drive. She wants to be back, wants to be playing and wants to be winning titles, it seems, and absolutely nobody knows how to do that better than she does.\u201d\n\nSo what is reasonable in terms of expectations? A few months for Williams to get her bearings, drop some more weight and potentially pose a threat at Wimbledon in July? More of them, it stood to reason, would be open to a Western hygiene product.\n\n\u201cWe had created established markets for Rexona from scratch in many countries, and we did not see any reason why we couldn\u2019t do the same in China,\u201d Frank Braeken, Unilever\u2019s former China head, said by telephone from Dubai, where he now works as an investment consultant.\n\n\u201cWe had an extremely ambitious plan at the time,\u201d Mr. Braeken said.\n\nBut cultural differences and simple biology \u2014 scientists have shown that many East Asian people don\u2019t have Westerners\u2019 body odor issues \u2014 scotched those plans. Sales totaled only a fraction of the Chinese marketing budget for Rexona, Mr. Braeken said. Today, by some estimates, less than 10 percent of China\u2019s population uses deodorant, and it can be hard to find outside major cities.", "title": "Aiming at China\u2019s Armpits: When Foreign Brands Misfire", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Akram Khan\u2019s much talked-about reworking of \u201cGiselle,\u201d created for English National Ballet in 2016, will come to the United States next year, the company\u2019s first trip across the Atlantic in 30 years. The Harris Theater in Chicago will present English National Ballet in four performances of Mr. Khan\u2019s work, Feb. 28 to March 2, 2019.\n\n\u201cGiselle\u201d was commissioned by Tamara Rojo, the former Royal Ballet principal who became director of English National Ballet in 2012. It was seen as a gamble for both the company and for Mr. Khan. Known for his fusion of contemporary dance and Indian kathak, he had not previously created a full-length work for a ballet company. Although it is loosely based on the story of the famous 1841 classic, Mr. Khan updates the story to a world of migrant workers and powerful landlords.\n\nThe production, set to music by Vincenzo Lamagna, was an immediate success with both critics and the public, and recently returned for an equally applauded second run at Sadler\u2019s Wells Theater in London.\n\nPatricia Barretto, the president and chief executive of the Harris Theater, said that although she had not seen a live performance, she had been following the work\u2019s success online. \u201cI was enthralled by how stunning it was, with the melding of traditional kathak dance and ballet,\u201d Ms. Barretto said in a telephone interview. \u201cI felt we had to do it.\u201d", "title": "Akram Khan\u2019s \u2018Giselle\u2019 Coming to Chicago", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIn Charm Offensive, Qatar Is Pushing for a Comeback in Washington\u201d (news article, Feb. 10):\n\nYou say \u201cAlan Dershowitz, a prominent lawyer, called Qatar the \u2018Israel of the Gulf States.\u2019 \u201d In my article in The Hill, I made it clear that I was comparing Qatar to Israel in only one way: insofar as Qatar is \u201csurrounded by enemies, subject to boycotts and unrealistic demands, and struggling for its survival.\u201d\n\nI never intended to compare Israel, a vibrant democracy, to any Gulf monarchy. The thrust of my article was that a \u201cgood idea might be the establishment of an independent commission of credible experts to resolve the conflicting factual claims about what Qatar is and is not doing.\u201d\n\nALAN M. DERSHOWITZ\n\nMIAMI\n\nThe writer is professor emeritus at Harvard Law School.", "title": "Opinion | Alan Dershowitz, on Qatar and Israel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAre there any \u201cdumb\u201d devices \u2014 or devices not connected to the internet \u2014 that you think are better than some \u201csmart\u201d devices?\n\nIf so, what are they and why do you prefer these old-fashioned versions over their more technologically advanced counterparts?\n\nIf not, why not?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out what one Technology writer\u2019s opinion.", "title": "Alarm Clocks", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cGrocery is being hit by multiple factors,\u201d said Gerald Storch, the former chief executive of the retailer Hudson\u2019s Bay.\n\nThe pharmacy business, too, is undergoing major changes, with the nation\u2019s largest operators of drugstores pursuing mergers to control costs and increase profits.\n\nIn December, the drugstore giant CVS Health said it would merge with the health insurer Aetna in a $69 billion deal that could reshape the way health care is delivered in the United States. That deal came together after a federal judge blocked Aetna\u2019s proposed merger with rival Humana last year.\n\nRite Aid had previously sought to bulk up by merging with Walgreens. Negotiations between two of the biggest drugstore chains in the United States ended after antitrust authorities indicated they were unlikely to approve the combination. Instead, Rite Aid agreed last year to sell 1,932 stores and three distribution centers to Walgreens for $4.38 billion.\n\nAmazon\u2019s specter also looms over the health care field. The company recently teamed up with Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase to form an independent health care company to serve the three firms\u2019 employees and potentially revamp the broader industry.\n\nFor Albertsons, the Rite Aid deal is just the latest step to draw in more customers.\n\nIn November, the company reached an agreement with Instacart to provide on-demand grocery-delivery services. It also invested last year in El Rancho Supermercado, a Texas-based retailer focused on stores for Latino customers.\n\nOriginally founded by Joe Albertson in Boise, Idaho, in 1939, Albertsons grew primarily across the West. In 2013, it was acquired by a group of investors led by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management for about $3 billion.", "title": "Albertsons Is Buying Rite Aid. Walmart\u2019s Stock Falls. There\u2019s a Common Rival.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s worse, these critics say, is that in this #MeToo moment, Mr. Baldwin epitomizes a classic insincere male ally: With his star turns on \u201cS.N.L.,\u201d his scalding portrayal of Mr. Trump and his own pledges to be more conscientious about how he treats women, he has enjoyed the benefits of associating with this progressive, female-positive movement while falling short of its values.\n\n\u201cHe is in a position of power and he has a prominent platform, and he has to figure out if he\u2019s contributing to the conversation in a productive manner,\u201d Jessica Coen, editor in chief of the digital culture site Mashable, said.\n\nShe added, \u201cAlec Baldwin is socially aware, but only to a limit. He doesn\u2019t know what he doesn\u2019t know, and that\u2019s a big problem.\u201d\n\nMr. Baldwin declined requests to be interviewed for this article, and also declined an invitation to have people speak on his behalf. Several of his friends and colleagues also declined to comment this week.\n\nLast fall dozens of women came forward to say that Mr. Toback, the filmmaker, had harassed or abused them. At that time Mr. Baldwin \u2014 who worked with Mr. Toback on films like \u201cSeduced and Abandoned\u201d \u2014 offered a circumspect defense of his friend, telling The Los Angeles Times that he \u201calways heard Jimmy was peculiar\u201d and adding, \u201cI don\u2019t know that Jimmy has done anything criminal.\u201d Explaining why he had not yet condemned Mr. Toback, Mr. Baldwin said, \u201cWell, I\u2019m going to get around to that in my own way and in my own time.\u2019\u2019\n\nHe added, \u201cI just hope people proceed with this very carefully.\u201d\n\nA few days later, Mr. Baldwin seemed to cast blame on Ms. McGowan, who said she was raped by the film mogul Harvey Weinstein. In a PBS interview, Mr. Baldwin said, \u201cRose McGowan took a payment of $100,000 and settled her case with him. And it was for Rose McGowan to prosecute that case.\u201d\n\nOn Twitter, Mr. Baldwin has defended Dustin Hoffman from accusations of sexual misconduct, and gone after late-night TV hosts like Stephen Colbert and John Oliver, who he believes have persecuted men like Mr. Hoffman and Mr. Weinstein. Their shows \u201care beginning to resemble grand juries,\u201d Mr. Baldwin wrote.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast Sunday Mr. Baldwin took aim at Ms. Farrow, who has said that Mr. Allen, her adoptive father, molested her in 1992 when she was a child. (Mr. Allen has denied these claims and was not charged with any crime.) Mr. Baldwin said in a tweet that one of \u201cthe most of effective things Dylan Farrow has in her arsenal is the \u2018persistence of emotion.\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nComparing her to Mayella Ewell in \u201cTo Kill a Mockingbird\u201d \u2014 a white woman who falsely accuses a black man of raping her \u2014 Mr. Baldwin said of Ms. Farrow in the tweet, \u201cher tears/exhortations r meant 2 shame u in2 belief in her story.\u201d\n\nHe continued, \u201cBut I need more than that before I destroy some1, regardless of their fame. I need a lot more.\u201d\n\nOnline and in interviews, many people said they were appalled by what they saw as Mr. Baldwin\u2019s belligerence toward Ms. Farrow and his wading into circumstances about which he has no firsthand knowledge.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWhy somebody would confidently go on the offensive against someone brave enough to speak out about having been sexually abused is completely beyond me,\u201d Julie Klausner, the creator and star of the Hulu comedy series \u201cDifficult People,\u201d said in an interview.\n\nMs. Klausner added, \u201cThere is loyalty to friends, and then there is unsolicited outspoken denial of an abuse survivor\u2019s truth. It seems very strange to me that somebody who wasn\u2019t there is so compelled to pipe up.\u201d\n\nAt \u201cSaturday Night Live,\u201d Mr. Baldwin\u2019s recent comments have gone publicly unaddressed. Press representatives for NBC declined to make anyone from \u201cS.N.L.\u201d available to comment for this article and would not say if Mr. Baldwin was to appear as Mr. Trump in this weekend\u2019s new episode.\n\nHaving played Mr. Trump on \u201cS.N.L.\u201d since the fall of 2016, Mr. Baldwin, 59, has brought acclaim and renewed energy to this 43-year-old late-night series. Last September, he won an Emmy Award for playing the president on the show, adding to the two he had won playing Jack Donaghy, an oblivious, domineering TV executive on the NBC comedy \u201c30 Rock.\u201d\n\nBut as his critics consider his statements of the past several months, they are uncomfortably reminded of Mr. Baldwin\u2019s long history of aggressive behavior.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2007, he apologized after the release of a phone message to his daughter Ireland, then 11, in which he called her a \u201crude, thoughtless little pig.\u201d In 2011, he was removed from a plane for refusing to turn off his cellphone after the plane\u2019s doors were closed for departure, and its crew members said he treated them with \u201cinappropriate names\u201d and \u201coffensive language.\u201d\n\nLast November, at a tribute honoring him at the Paley Center for Media, Mr. Baldwin said he was aware he had mistreated women in the past.\n\n\u201cI certainly have treated women in a very sexist way,\u201d he said at the tribute. \u201cI\u2019ve bullied women. I\u2019ve overlooked women. I\u2019ve underestimated women.\u201d\n\nMr. Baldwin added, \u201cI really would like that to change.\u201d\n\nBut his more recent behavior has some people wondering if he is genuinely committed to or capable of self improvement.\n\n\u201cIt requires a lot of us to look back on our life and our experiences and acknowledge that either we experienced something terrible, or we were part of enabling a terrible situation, knowingly or unknowingly,\u201d Beth Newell, the creator and editor of Reductress, a feminist comedy website, said.\n\nMs. Newell said that men like Mr. Baldwin are \u201cthrowing their weight around as a way of feeling powerful.\u201d She added, \u201cHe doesn\u2019t want to do the emotional labor of figuring out what that means.\u201d\n\nNell Scovell, a writer for TV shows like \u201cLate Night With David Letterman,\u201d \u201cThe Simpsons\u201d and \u201cMurphy Brown,\u201d said that Mr. Baldwin\u2019s support of people like Mr. Toback and Mr. Allen \u201csmacks of overlooking and underestimating women while overvaluing the men.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Scovell, who writes about the sexism she encountered in the TV industry in a coming memoir called \u201cJust the Funny Parts,\u201d said she was not calling for Mr. Baldwin to be punished or removed from his role at \u201cSaturday Night Live.\u201d If anything, she said, the parallels between the men made Mr. Baldwin a more qualified stand-in for Mr. Trump. Both men came from the outskirts of New York City (Mr. Baldwin from Long Island, Mr. Trump from Jamaica, Queens); both had previous marriages and are now married to younger wives; both are wealthy and prone to issues of impulse control.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a hypocrite and Trump\u2019s a hypocrite,\u201d Ms. Scovell said. \u201cTechnically, he might be the best person to capture the hypocrisy.\u201d", "title": "Alec Baldwin Skewers Trump. And Supports Allen and Toback.", "authors": ["Dave Itzkoff"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Dombrowski was careful not to criticize Farrell, citing his achievements in Boston. But he added: \u201cI think we needed a different voice, a younger voice, a connectivity voice between the manager and the players, with everybody. We have a lot of young guys, and the ability to connect even deeper than what we did in the past, in the clubhouse, I think is important.\u201d\n\nYoung managers are nothing new, even in Boston. Joe Cronin, a longtime player-manager, was 39 when he guided the Red Sox to the 1946 World Series. Dick Williams was 38 when he did so in 1967. Both are in the Hall of Fame. So is Tony La Russa, now a special assistant to Dombrowski, who will be available as a resource for Cora. (He also will have a veteran bench coach in Ron Roenicke, the former Milwaukee Brewers manager.)\n\nLa Russa got his first major league managing job at 34, with the 1979 Chicago White Sox. He survived, he said, by following the advice of a team executive, Paul Richards: \u201cTrust your gut and don\u2019t cover your butt.\u201d\n\nLa Russa said he believed in Cora, Boone and others in that mold.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s high-profile and people are paying attention, so that\u2019s an obstacle to overcome,\u201d La Russa said. \u201cBut if you\u2019ve got an open mind and your instincts are good, that, to me, is why I would bet on these young guys, that they\u2019ll make it. Their gut, based on their experiences, is going to carry them, and they\u2019ll just get better and better.\u201d\n\nHinch saw progress in Cora throughout last season. At the start, he said, Cora was mainly a liaison to players, and helped with infield positioning. As the season went on, he expanded his role to revamp the Astros\u2019 base running and scout pitchers\u2019 tendencies. In the postseason, Hinch said, Cora was vital to his in-game decision-making.\n\n\u201cWhen you see him interact with players and you see the buy-in that he gets, it\u2019s very easy to see why he was a good teammate, and why he\u2019s beloved around the league,\u201d Hinch said. \u201cAnd he has such a great baseball mind, he\u2019s ahead of the inning the game is in. He can see all the things a manager would.\u201d\n\nThe task now is to hold off the Yankees in the division, and then try to unseat the Astros. Apparently, Rodriguez found the work so agreeable he agreed to return \u2014 for what figures to be a relative pittance.\n\nRodriguez worked for the Yankees last season while fulfilling the final year of a 10-year, $275 million contract after being released late in 2016 and eventually retiring.\n\nThe Yankees did not say what Rodriguez, 42, will earn this year, but he will return to a role that the former Yankees Reggie Jackson, Hideki Matsui and Nick Swisher will also serve in. It also virtually assured that Kirk Cousins would not return as Washington\u2019s quarterback.\n\nIn return for Smith, the Chiefs received a third-round pick and the third-year cornerback Kendall Fuller, according to multiple news media reports.\n\nBut beyond those immediately affected, the deal will have ramifications for virtually every quarterback seeking a new team or a revamped contract, as well as any team trying to make a change at football\u2019s most vital position.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor the Chiefs, the move was straightforward. Smith went 50-26 in his five seasons with the team, made three Pro Bowls, and was at his best early in the 2017 season. But he was 1-4 in the playoffs, and, at 33, he has a very limited chance of significant improvement.\n\nPhoto\n\nMahomes\u2019s professional experience is fairly limited, but in Week 17 he completed 22 of 35 passes for 284 yards against the Denver Broncos. Quarterbacks", "authors": ["Benjamin Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "These are edited excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Joel on a sunny winter day with jazzy music playing in the background.\n\nEvery piece in your apartment has a family connection or memory. Tell me about the painting over the bed of a woman looking out the window to the water.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt reminds me of Matisse, my favorite artist. I\u2019m not sure who the painter is. It was given to me my grandmother, Marge \u2014 Marjorie Marie Brinkley. My mom\u2019s mom. It\u2019s a bittersweet story. When my grandmother \u2014 I was really close to her \u2014 was sick and not feeling well, before she passed, she said, \u201cI want you to have this because it reminds me of you.\u201d I have this hanging right over my head, because I want her with me always.\n\nYou seem to like art where the viewer is invited to supply the context, or story, of what\u2019s going in the picture.\n\nI do. I do. It\u2019s because I like to personalize things. In this one, I always see a \u201cPride and Prejudice\u201d Jane Austen character. She\u2019s dreaming and she\u2019s looking out. And that\u2019s kind of me. My head is always in the clouds.\n\nThis shadow box \u2014 a framed dollhouse room with a woman, red curtains and a fortuneteller\u2019s globe \u2014 is so eerie and mysterious. It looks Victorian. Where is it from?\n\nNo one knows too much about it. My mom got this for me from an old flea market in the Hamptons when I was 16 years old. I was in a phase when I was obsessed \u2014 I still am \u2014 with fortunetellers and psychics. The piece has a fortuneteller and haunted, ghostlike reflection hanging on the wall. I always imagine this woman as living in New Orleans. And around the same time, my father was in New Orleans and got me the crystal ball on the shelf below. Everyone knew I was on this psychic kick and my parents are so thoughtful.\n\nThe lamp in the room fell just few years ago, but I see it as being a part of the story: The piece is haunted, and the magical spells were so powerful that it caused a ruckus. I\u2019m very kooky with this stuff. My mother teases me, \u201cYou are more polished, but you are like 20 steps from a \u2018Grey Gardens\u2019 moment.\u201d It\u2019s true.", "title": "Alexa Ray Joel, Downtown Girl, Is Surrounded by Memories", "authors": ["Mary Billard", "Show Us Your Wall"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAlexandra Kennerly Wolfe, the daughter of Sheila Wolfe and Tom Wolfe of Manhattan, was married Feb. 23 to Dr. Andrew Newman Schiff, a son of Lisa Schiff and David T. He graduated from the University of Miami and received a medical degree from St. George's University School of Medicine in St. George\u2019s, Grenada.\n\nHe is the son of Joanne Katz Schosheim and Dr. John P. Schosheim of Boca Raton. His mother, a speech pathologist, is a partner in Speech Associates of Boca Raton.
