Now, those goods are delivered to the warehouses by UPS, FedEx and other companies.\n\nAmazon\u2019s test, which could start in several months, will probably include only a handful of independent Amazon sellers in Los Angeles. Eventually, the test could encompass more delivery services handled by established carriers. A person briefed on the program, who asked for anonymity because the plans are confidential, provided details about the project.\n\nWhen asked about the program, Amazon said in a statement, \u201cWe\u2019re always innovating and experimenting on behalf of customers and the businesses that sell and grow on Amazon to create faster, lower-cost delivery choices.\u201d", "title": "Amazon to Test a New Delivery Service for Sellers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "The essay, co-written by the then-director of the National Center for Injury Prevention and Control at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, continued: \u201cWe were on opposite sides of the heated battle 16 years ago, but we are in strong agreement now that scientific research should be conducted into preventing firearm injuries and that ways to prevent firearm deaths can be found without encroaching on the rights of legitimate gun owners. The same evidence-based approach that is saving millions of lives from motor-vehicle crashes, as well as from smoking, cancer and H.I.V./AIDS, can help reduce the toll of deaths and injuries from gun violence.\u201d\n\nWe also must allow the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives to track gun sales, and keep the data it collects electronically and also searchable. At present, it is prevented from doing so.\n\nAs Kate Irby wrote last week for McClatchy: \u201cNo one has any idea how many assault rifles are in circulation. That\u2019s intentional.\u201d Knowing would require a registry, and the N.R.A. and conspiracy-minded anti-government groups see this as a step toward confiscation, or at least facilitating the possibility.\n\nAs Irby put it: \u201cThe National Firearms Act forbids \u2018any system of registration of firearms, firearms owners, or firearms transactions or dispositions be established.\u2019 Several restrictions added to congressional appropriations bills also prohibit A.T.F. from requiring gun dealers to submit their inventories to law enforcement. The effect is to prevent A.T.F. from setting up a system that would allow electronic retrieval of gun owners\u2019 personal identification information, and from consolidating or centralizing records provided by firearms dealers.\u201d\n\nStill, she writes, \u201cThe N.R.A. estimates that between 8.5 million and 15 million assault rifles are in circulation, based on manufacturer data.\u201d\n\nFinally, we need to empower a permanent commission, possibly under the Department of Homeland Security, to bring all the data together, in consultation with law enforcement, the Department of Health and Human Services, the Department of Education and any other relevant parties, to make ongoing policy and regulatory recommendations to reduce gun violence.\n\nAnd yet, I know well that none of this is likely to happen. The American idea is caught up in carnage. Its very beginning is rooted in gun violence. It is by the barrel that this land was acquired. It is by the barrel that the slave was subdued and his rebellions squashed. And that is to say nothing of our wars.\n\nWe have venerated the gun and valorized its usage. America is violent and the gun is a preferred instrument of that violence. America, in many ways, is the gun.", "title": "Opinion | America Is the Gun", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "On a Sunday evening a few weeks back, Shobana Ram was loading the dishwasher in her kitchen in Queens when her 85-year-old father-in-law rose from the dinner table, carrying his cane in one hand and an empty plate in the other.\n\n\u201cFrom the corner of my eye, I saw him stumble and lose his balance,\u201d recalled Ms. Ram. \u201cI saw the cane fly out of his hand. His head hit the corner of our granite countertop.\u201d\n\nShe dialed 911 and thought, not for the first time, how fortunate it was that in 2016 she and her husband sold their house and bought one big enough to accommodate six people: themselves, their two teenagers and his ailing parents, plus the family dog.\n\nHer mother-in-law, who has dementia, would not have been able to phone for help. In this case, after emergency room scans, her father-in-law was \u201cmiraculously OK,\u201d said Ms. Ram, 48.", "title": "America at Home: Grandparents in the Attic, Children in the Basement", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Amy Chua has Donald J. Trump\u2019s number. Not literally (I\u2019m guessing), but unlike some of her elite peers at Yale University, where she teaches law, Chua isn\u2019t endlessly flummoxed by the president\u2019s ability to brag about how rich and \u201cvery greedy\u201d he is while also resonating with his working-class supporters.\n\nAs she explains in \u201cPolitical Tribes: Group Instinct and the Fate of Nations,\u201d what Trump has figured out, whether through cynical deliberation or primordial reflex, is how tribalism works. As much as progressives try to define elitism in terms of money, the establishment that Trump and his supporters rail against is culturally \u2014 not economically \u2014 defined.\n\n\u201cThe tribal instinct is all about identification,\u201d Chua writes. The president\u2019s base \u201cidentifies with him at a gut level.\u201d And it\u2019s not as if elites get severed from their own gut feelings by their Ivy League degrees. \u201cWhat these elites don\u2019t see is how tribal their cosmopolitanism is,\u201d she writes. \u201cFor well-educated, well-traveled Americans, cosmopolitanism is its own highly exclusionary clan, with clear out-group members and boogeymen \u2014 in this case, the flag-waving bumpkins.\u201d\n\nWith \u201cPolitical Tribes,\u201d Chua \u2014 who is perhaps best known for \u201cBattle Hymn of the Tiger Mother\u201d (2011), a not entirely ironic memoir about her severe \u201cChinese-style\u201d (her words) parenting methods \u2014 is on familiar terrain. All of her books revolve around culture and identity. In \u201cWorld on Fire\u201d (2003), she described how introducing free markets and democracy to a country can inflame existing ethnic divisions. \u201cDay of Empire\u201d (2007) posited that global powers gained strength through cultural tolerance rather than exclusion. In \u201cThe Triple Package\u201d (2014), she and her husband, Jed Rubenfeld, argued that specific cultural traits made for group success (a problematic provocation, to say the least).", "title": "American Blindness, Abroad and at Home", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "They include that he attended college in Louisiana \u2014 apparently studying electrical engineering \u2014 but did not earn a degree there. He is married and has a 3-year-old daughter, and he took two trips to the United States in 2014, shortly after her birth, in an effort to register her as an American citizen.\n\nThe filing also contends he likely went to Syria in 2014 for several months and then returned there in March 2015. It says that he lied to the F.B.I. about several details, noting that travel records contradict his account of how long he was in the United States. And it cites Twitter posts and YouTube and Google searches that it portrays as indicating that he was a supporter of the Islamic State.\n\nLast September, as the Islamic State\u2019s self-declared caliphate in Syria and Iraq was collapsing, the man was captured by a Syrian militia at a checkpoint and identified himself as an American citizen before being turned over to the United States military. The filing said he was carrying $4,200 in American currency, a Global Positioning System device, a Quran, thumb drives with numerous files about weapons, and \u2014 in an odd detail it did not explain \u2014 a scuba mask and snorkel.\n\nThe evidence \u201cis more than enough to carry the government\u2019s burden of showing by a preponderance of the evidence that petitioner is part of or substantially supported ISIL and is thus properly detained as an enemy combatant,\u201d the filing said, using an acronym for the Islamic State.\n\nThe American Civil Liberties Union has filed a habeas corpus lawsuit challenging the man\u2019s detention, winning a right to speak with him and gain his consent to represent him. It is asking a Federal District Court judge to order the Justice Department to either charge him with a crime or release him.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPeople familiar with the case have said that the government lacks sufficient courtroom-admissible evidence to charge the man. Although he spoke freely during an initial interrogation conducted for intelligence purposes \u2014 a summary of that conversation is attached to the new court filing \u2014 he stopped talking and asked for a lawyer after being warned of his Miranda rights for a law-enforcement interrogation.\n\nThe Trump administration is now trying to persuade Saudi Arabia to take custody of him, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations. A judge has ordered the government to give the A.C.L.U. three days notice before any such transfer so that he could challenge it, if he wants \u2014 an order the Justice Department is appealing.\n\nMeanwhile, the underlying case is continuing. In a filing rebutting the government\u2019s factual account, the A.C.L.U. argued for a more favorable interpretation of the disputed facts about the scope and meaning of his involvement with the Islamic State, which is also called ISIS.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cContrary to the thrust of the government\u2019s contentions that petitioner is an ISIS fighter, and as petitioner told the government, he sought to understand firsthand and report about the conflict in Syria; was kidnapped and imprisoned by ISIS; and tried numerous times to escape \u2014 and not even the government alleges that he ever took up arms against the United States or anyone else,\u201d the A.C.L.U. rebuttal said.\n\nIn an interview on Thursday, Jonathan Hafetz, the lead A.C.L.U. lawyer on the case, maintained that the Trump administration lacked the legal authority to keep holding his client indefinitely in military custody.\n\n\u201cThe government has made numerous allegations which are inaccurate and misleading in many respects,\u201d he said. \u201cBut the fundamental flaw in its position is that it has no legal authority to hold this citizen in military custody. If the government wants to detain him, it needs to charge him with a crime. Otherwise it must release him.\u201d\n\nBut the Justice Department filing argued that the government has legal authority to hold Islamic State members as wartime detainees \u2014 even if they are citizens. It cited laws enacted by Congress in 2001 and 2002 to authorize using military force against the perpetrators of the Sept. 11 attacks and Saddam Hussein-era Iraq, saying they cover the Islamic State. That theory was first put forward by the Obama administration and has been disputed, but no court has ruled on whether it is correct.\n\nThe Justice Department\u2019s court filing also backstopped that theory by claiming that President Trump, as commander in chief, wields inherent constitutional authority, independent of any act of Congress, to detain wartime enemies when they are captured on a battlefield where American forces are fighting.\n\nThat claim recalled sweeping assertions of executive power made by the George W. Bush administration after the Sept. 11 attacks. The Obama administration shied away from invoking purported commander-in-chief powers \u2014 instead generally relying only on congressional statutes \u2014 but it also did not disavow them.", "title": "American ISIS Suspect Said He Wanted to Report From Syria, Filing Shows", "authors": ["Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe warrior was a symbol of martial strength, molded from terra cotta and buried more than 2,000 years ago with China\u2019s first emperor to defend him in the afterlife.\n\nThe statue was helpless, however, against a man in a green sweater and a Phillies hat who, the authorities say, sneaked into a closed-off area during a party at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia and stole its thumb.\n\nThe man, who was attending the museum\u2019s after-hours ugly-sweater party on Dec. 21, entered the terra-cotta warrior exhibition room and used his cellphone\u2019s flashlight to view the displays. Then, according to an affidavit by Jacob B. Archer, a special agent assigned to the F.B.I.\u2019s art crime team, the man put his arm around the statue and took a selfie.\n\nThe authorities said the man, later identified as Michael Rohana, then went for a more permanent memento. He grabbed the left hand of the statue, which is valued at $4.5 million, and broke off its thumb. Taking the piece with him, he left with friends for his home in Bear, Del.\n\nMr. Rohana, 24, was charged last week in Philadelphia with theft of an artwork from a museum, concealment of the artwork and interstate transportation of stolen property. He was released on bail.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA lawyer for Mr. Rohana could not immediately be reached for comment.\n\nMr. Archer said he had visited Mr. Rohana at his home. When asked if he had anything he wanted to hand over, Mr. Rohana said he had a finger, which the F.B.I. agent retrieved from a desk in the man\u2019s bedroom.", "title": "American Is Charged With Stealing Terra-Cotta Warrior\u2019s Thumb", "authors": ["Austin Ramzy"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "The American quartet of Chrishuna Williams, Raevyn Rogers, Charlene Lipsey and Aje\u00e9 Wilson set a world indoor record in the 4x800-meter relay on Saturday at the 111th Millrose Games in Upper Manhattan.\n\nTheir time of 8 minutes, 5.89 seconds topped the mark of 8:06:50 set by the Russian team of Aleksandra Bulanova, Ekaterina Sharmina, Elena Kotulskaya and Anna Balakshina on Feb. 18, 2011.\n\nKendra Chambers, Lynsey Sharp, Ce\u2019aira Brown and Cecilia Barowski of the United States finished second in 8:11.45, and the Jamaican team of Fellan Ferguson, Simoya Campbell, Kimarra McDonald and Natoya Goule came in third at 8:17.75.", "title": "American Relay Sets Indoor World Record at the Millrose Games", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "The fertility rate has increased for women over 40, and the generation of women finishing up their childbearing years now had more children than their mothers did, but that isn't likely to be true for their daughters. The key factors driving down the birthrate are not mysterious: The pregnancy rate among young women is falling, and has been for years.\n\nBut what began as sharp declines in pregnancy and childbearing among teenagers \u2014 typically considered a socially desirable result \u2014 has slowly spread up the age cohorts, first to women in their early 20s, then to those in their late 20s. And now fertility decline has set in for women even in their 30s. Far from reversing as America grew out of economic recession, this lost fertility has worsened.\n\nA key factor is that marriage is increasingly being postponed. Total fertility rates controlling for marital status have not changed very much over the last 15 years. But with marriage coming later, the share of women at peak childbearing ages (20 to 40) who are married has steadily fallen.\n\nAs millennials in particular take their time to pair up, the average age of first birth is rising steadily. Today, the average age of a woman at first birth is over 26 years old. And while that is much higher than in the past, many European countries have an average age of first birth over 30, so there seems a lot more room to rise. In fact, the United States has the youngest age of first childbirth of any developed country.", "title": "American Women Are Having Fewer Children Than They\u2019d Like", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Explorers have searched for the wreckage off and on for years. Finally, last month, Ben Raines \u2014 a reporter for the website AL.com \u2014 exploited a period of abnormally low tides to search out the charred remains of a schooner whose dimensions and design match those constructed in the mid-19th century, when the Clotilda was built.\n\nThe wreckage \u2014 yet to be excavated and formally verified \u2014 has galvanized historians and reawakened the pain of enslavement among African-American descendants of the Clotilda captives, some of whom still live in what is called Africatown, a community not far from downtown Mobile that was founded by their forebears. This sudden rush of emotion underscores yet again the continuing impact of slavery on contemporary American life.\n\nTo find the wreckage, Mr. Raines relied partly on new information gleaned from a local man who had seen it as a child, but also acknowledges a debt to the historian Sylviane Diouf, whose book \u201cDreams of Africa in Alabama: The Slave Ship Clotilda and the Story of the Last Africans Brought to America\u201d offered clues as to the whereabouts of the wreckage as it documented the lives of the Clotilda Africans during enslavement and after Emancipation.\n\nThe Clotilda captives had come from an area in West Africa where enslaved people could rise to influential positions in society once they became free. That experience would have left them utterly unprepared for a life in which slave status was inherited, based on ethnicity and punishingly cruel.\n\nThe captives clung to African identities in the face of a system that was intended to erase them. They became a force to be reckoned with in plantation life by remaining united and showing that they would use violence to protect themselves. In one particularly vivid instance, they pounced on an overseer who tried to whip an African woman, lashing him instead, bringing such predations to an end.", "title": "Opinion | America\u2019s Last Slave Ship, and Slavery\u2019s Stain", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "In 2004, Dimitri Christakis of Seattle Children\u2019s Hospital wrote in the medical journal Pediatrics that \u201cearly exposure to television was associated with subsequent attentional problems.\u201d Even when controlling for socioeconomic status, gestational age and other factors, he discovered that an increase of one standard deviation in the number of hours of television watched at age 1 \u201cis associated with a 28 percent increase in the probability of having attentional problems at age 7.\u201d\n\nEvery additional hour of TV increased a child\u2019s odds of attention problems by about 10 percent. Kids who watched three hours a day were 30 percent more likely to have attention trouble than those who watched none. A 2010 article in Pediatrics confirmed that exposure to TV and video games was associated with greater attention problems in children. Meanwhile, Paul Morgan at Penn State and George Farkas at the University of California, Irvine, have found that black children are more likely to show symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder than their white peers.\n\nUnfortunately, too often the message we send low-income and less-educated parents is that screen time is going to help their children. Fifteen years ago, when I was a Big Sister to a girl who attended one of Brooklyn\u2019s worst middle schools, her mother was given strict instructions by teachers to purchase a faster computer as soon as possible to get her daughter\u2019s grades up. Today, thanks to lucrative contracts with school districts, tech companies are happy to bring screens into the classroom and send them home.\n\nBut there is little evidence that such programs are helping students. Take Maine, which guarantees a tablet for every student. According to NPR, \u201cat a cost of about $12 million annually,\u201d the state \u201chas yet to see any measurable increases on statewide standardized test scores.\u201d\n\nWhen politicians and policymakers talk about kids and technology, it is usually about \u201cbridging the digital divide,\u201d making sure that poor kids have as much access as wealthier ones. But there is no evidence that they don\u2019t. According to a 2015 Pew report, 87 percent of Americans between the ages of 13 and 17 have access to a computer. For families earning less than $50,000 a year, that number is 80 percent. As for a racial divide, Pew finds that African-American teenagers are more likely to own a smartphone than any other group of teenagers in America.", "title": "Opinion | America\u2019s Real Digital Divide", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Jessie Diggins fell in love with snow as a child.\n\nDiggins is a member of the United States women\u2019s cross-country skiing team, which is favored to win a medal at the Pyeongchang Olympics. It would be only the second medal in the sport for the United States and the first for the women\u2019s team.\n\nBefore Diggins was an Olympic skier, before she had even taken her first steps, her parents strapped her into a baby carrier and took her cross-country skiing near her hometown, Afton, Minn. But she worries that future generations of American children might miss that opportunity.\n\nThe risk is real. In the United States, the average time between the last frost of the spring and the first of the winter has expanded by 10 days since the first half of the 20th century.\n\nWinter is shrinking in places like Hayward, Wis., a town of 2,300 that swells to more than 12,000 people in late February during the American Birkebeiner, North America\u2019s largest cross-country ski race. Last year, organizers canceled the event for lack of snow.", "title": "America\u2019s Ski Trails Are Vanishing. This Olympian Has Taken Up the Cause.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAnd we need them to finish this \u2014 to finish this fight,\u201d General Votel told the House Armed Services Committee.\n\nWithout the Kurds, the Arab forces and their American military advisers have largely been forced to halt clearing operations and taken up mostly defensive positions, United States officials said. That has left American air power to pick up the slack.\n\nThe development is another major consequence of the fighting that has rapidly unfurled in recent weeks in Syria\u2019s tumultuous northwest.\n\nIt threatens not only to slow progress against several hundred Islamic State fighters who are hiding along the Euphrates River or in nearby deserts, but also could allow battle-hardened foreign fighters to escape deeper into western Syria and eventually into Turkey or Jordan \u2014 and possibly to return home to Europe or Africa to commit mayhem there, American commanders and analysts said.\n\nThousands of foreign fighters have already fled unfettered to the south and west through Syrian Army lines, these officials said.\n\n\u201cThe campaign to defeat the Islamic State is at risk,\u201d said Jennifer Cafarella, a senior intelligence planner with the Institute for the Study of War in Washington. \u201cThe S.D.F. is unlikely to clear remaining ISIS-held areas of the Euphrates River and could even begin to take losses due to the shift in Syrian Kurds\u2019 main effort.\u201d ISIS is another name for the Islamic State.\n\nThe turn of events has the potential to upset a triumph that President Trump has held out as one of his administration\u2019s signature national security accomplishments so far.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cISIS land has been largely recaptured \u2014 almost 100 percent,\u201d Mr. Trump said last week during a news conference with Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia. \u201cThey are on the run.\u201d\n\nYet senior Trump administration officials and American commanders have been watching, with growing trepidation, as Kurdish troops and commanders divert from the fight against the Islamic State.\n\nInitially, they sought to play down its significance. On Feb. 11, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis called the development \u201ca distraction\u201d and said it was \u201cnot a significant number right now.\u201d\n\nMaj. Gen. Jamie Jarrard, the Special Operations commander for the American-led coalition in Iraq and Syria, said in an interview in early February that the elimination of the entire caliphate was \u201cvery close.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnything that disrupts us or takes our eye off that prize is not good,\u201d General Jarrard said.\n\nMr. Mattis, Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson and Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, the White House national security adviser, all have met with Turkish officials in recent days to seek an end to the clashes with Kurdish militia in northwest Syria and prevent the fighting from spreading.\n\nBut by last week, Heather Nauert, the State Department\u2019s spokeswoman, acknowledged to reporters on Feb. 22 that \u201cwe can no longer fight ISIS the way that we would fully like to be able to do.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe diversion of Kurdish fighters and lower-level commanders, who play a pivotal role in directing battlefield operations against the Islamic State, has increased from a trickle to a torrent, according to five American military officials who are monitoring the situation and spoke on condition of anonymity. It is difficult to estimate precisely how many Kurdish fighters have withdrawn.\n\nThe Syrian Democratic Forces number about 50,000 Kurdish and Arab fighters throughout eastern and northern Syria, American military officials have said. Several thousand have been fighting the Islamic State in the Euphrates River Valley, with Arabs making up as much as 80 percent of that force, reflecting the demographics of the region.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut as they have elsewhere in the fight against Islamic State in Syria, the Kurds have taken on a disproportionate role in front line fighting and command skills, American officials said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNow some of those gains against the Islamic State are in jeopardy. As of two weeks ago, Kurdish officials said more than 20,000 Kurdish defenders had rallied to Afrin to confront Turkish troops. That number includes fighters who were already there, as well as newly arrived reinforcements.\n\n\u201cThe Turkish invasion to occupy Afrin has terribly influenced our fight against ISIS,\u201d Shahoz Hasan, co-president of the Syrian Democratic Union party, said in an interview on Monday. \u201cAfter we managed to get ISIS in a choke hold,\u201d he said the Turks \u201care attacking our forces in that region.\u201d\n\nFor many Kurdish militia and their commanders, the call to defend family and friends in Afrin and a Kurdish enclave in the city of Manbij that is also threatened by Turkish troops has taken precedence over what many consider to be an American war against the Islamic State.\n\n\u201cThose fighters find it more urgent to be in their areas on the Syrian-Turkish border rather than on the front lines with ISIS,\u201d said Arin Sheikhmos, a Kurdish journalist based in Qamishli. The city is the de facto capital of Kurdish areas of northern Syria, which the Kurds call Rojava.\n\n\u201cTo them, it is a priority to defend their land rather than liberating others\u2019 land,\u201d Mr. Sheikhmos said.\n\nThe American-led coalition appears to have intensified airstrikes on the Islamic State in areas east of the Euphrates River to fill the battlespace the Kurdish fighters had left, Mr. Sheikhmos said. The approach was not working, he said.\n\nHe said the Islamic State carried out a car bombing in Qamishli a few days ago, resulting in the deaths of four civilians, including a child. It was the first bombing in the city by ISIS in over a year, he said.\n\nShervan Derwish, a spokesman for the Manbij Military Council, said 250 Kurdish fighters had arrived in the ethnically mixed area in just the past few days. He said they came from Deir al-Zour, an Arab-majority city and former Islamic State stronghold in the Euphrates River Valley that is now contested by Russian-backed Syrian government soldiers and the American-backed Arab-Kurdish coalition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cUnfortunately, our fighters who joined the rest of S.D.F. on the front lines with ISIS in Deir al-Zour had to retreat to Manbij upon hearing the Turkish threats of attacking us here, doing ISIS a favor,\u201d Mr. Derwish said. The military council is a Kurdish-led component of the Syrian Democratic Forces in Manbij.\n\nAs late as Feb. 8, there were still S.D.F. forces in Deir al-Zour, according to the coalition, which bombed pro-Syrian regime forces who had attacked an S.D.F. base and its American advisers there. The airstrikes, it later turned out, killed dozens of Russian mercenaries in the process, American officials said.\n\nSome analysts, including Ms. Cafarella, have assessed that the Russian-backed attackers gave the Kurdish fighters safe transit to Afrin across government-controlled territory and exploited their departure to strike the less experienced Arab partners in the S.D.F.\n\nAgid Ahmed, commander of the Northern Sun battalion of the Manbij council, said he and his fighters were ordered to return from the front lines in Deir al-Zour on Feb. 6. That, in turn, freed up other S.D.F. fighters defending Manbij to reinforce Afrin. Mr. Ahmed fought with American forces in 10 offensives in northern and eastern Syria, including retaking of Raqqa from the Islamic State.\n\nSome of the S.D.F. and Manbij council leaders expressed disappointment with American forces for not preventing last month\u2019s Turkish attack on Afrin.\n\n\u201cAmericans on the ground do a good job and we learned a lot from them, data sharing, GPS techniques, but politically we\u2019re not very sure about them. Especially since the situation in Afrin,\u201d said Maher Al Ony, who has four Manbij council brigades \u2014 about 2,500 fighters \u2014 under his command. \u201cWe didn\u2019t expect the coalition would allow the Turks to attack Afrin.\u201d\n\nMuhammed Abu Adel, the Manbij council\u2019s top commander, insisted the commitment to fight the Islamic State remains strong, even as his forces have left Deir al-Zour.\n\n\u201cWe sacrificed thousands of lives of our soldiers, we sacrificed so many to finish ISIS,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd now this, while fighting the most terrible terrorist group, and suddenly there is a state member of NATO come to fight you.\u201d", "title": "Amid Turkish Assault, Kurdish Forces Are Drawn Away From U.S. Fight With ISIS", "authors": ["Eric Schmitt", "Rod Nordland"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Even some of his top advisers sounded surprisingly passive this week on different issues. Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson said that Russia was already trying to interfere in the midterm congressional elections this year, but there was not much the United States could do to stop it. \u201cIf it\u2019s their intention to interfere, they are going to find ways to do that,\u201d he told Fox News. \u201cWe can take steps we can take, but this is something that, once they decide they are going to do it, it\u2019s very difficult to pre-empt it.\u201d\n\nVice President Mike Pence, who is in South Korea for the opening of the Olympics, likewise sounded relatively detached from the spending debate involving his former colleagues in Congress back home. Asked whether he had called any lawmakers, he said he had only talked with the White House unit that lobbies Congress. \u201cI\u2019ve been in touch with the legislative office and the president and I have talked frequently,\u201d he told reporters, \u201cbut we\u2019re on standby as the vote approaches.\u201d\n\nOther presidents have discovered that there can be benefits from staying on standby. When President Bill Clinton assigned Hillary Clinton to lead an effort to pass universal health care, she and a task force crafted a highly detailed plan that died on Capitol Hill. The lesson that Mr. Clinton and his successors took from that is that sometimes it is better to set a broad goal but let Congress figure out how it wants to proceed. President George W. Bush did that with his No Child Left Behind education program and President Barack Obama did that with health care and some spending fights.\n\nBut Mr. Trump has proved a divisive force so that even his broad direction is now sometimes ignored. Just this week he declared that he wanted Congress to let the government shut down rather than pass spending measures if there were no agreement on immigration. But Senate leaders of both parties disregarded him altogether and drafted their own deal without immigration.\n\n\u201cThe other players in Washington, whether it\u2019s Congress or the Senate leadership, really have come to the conclusion: Let\u2019s ignore him, because we have things to do,\u201d said Maria Echaveste, a former deputy White House chief of staff under Mr. Clinton. \u201cThe budget deal is a perfect example of that. He\u2019s not constructive so they\u2019re ignoring him.\u201d\n\nSpeaking after reaching the budget deal with his Republican counterpart, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic minority leader, said he had learned to proceed without bothering with the president. \u201cOften times we can get a lot more done working with one another and let the White House just sit on the sidelines, because you don\u2019t know what their positions are,\u201d he said.\n\nThe president\u2019s hands-off approach on the budget deal worked for him to the extent that it included the boost in military spending that he has been demanding, but it also included a large increase in domestic spending as well.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs a result, the federal deficit will balloon to nearly $1.2 trillion by 2019, despite Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign promise to get the nation\u2019s fiscal house in order. At one point during the campaign, Mr. Trump even promised to eliminate not just the annual deficit but the entire national debt accumulated over decades and now totaling more than $20 trillion. Instead, at this rate, he will pile up trillions of dollars of additional borrowing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nConservatives complained that he should have played a more active role in the negotiations to avoid that. \u201cI think it would have made a big difference if Trump had pushed hard for lower spending numbers, particularly if he had pushed a consistent message,\u201d said Chris Edwards, the director of tax policy studies at the Cato Institute. He noted that Democrats backed down during the last government shutdown. \u201cThat would have given Trump power,\u201d he said.\n\nThe White House was, again, not engaging on Friday. It held no news briefing and a spokesman did not respond to a request for comment on the president\u2019s approach. But on Twitter, Mr. Trump blamed Democrats for the spending increases in the budget deal. Even though Republicans control both chambers, they need Democratic votes to end filibusters in the Senate.\n\n\u201cWithout more Republicans in Congress, we were forced to increase spending on things we do not like or want in order to finally, after many years of depletion, take care of our Military,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote. \u201cSadly, we needed some Dem votes for passage. Must elect more Republicans in 2018 Election!\u201d\n\nStill, some Republicans said Mr. Trump may be most successful by setting the larger goals and then backing off. \u201cDifferent presidents have different interest levels in being in the weeds on policy details,\u201d said J. Scott Jennings, who was a special assistant to Mr. Bush and is now a fellow at the Harvard Institute of Politics. \u201cThis one, it seems to me, works best when he lays out broad priorities \u2014 more defense spending, cut taxes \u2014 and then allows the tacticians to engage and make it so.\u201d\n\nAfter a fractious first year between Mr. Trump and Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican majority leader, Mr. Jennings said the president seemed to have finally found traction in the relationship, trusting the leader to manage legislative strategy. \u201cOnce they found their groove, things started working,\u201d he said. \u201cTrump\u2019s job approval has gone up, the numbers on the economy have improved and the generic ballot has begun to shrink.\u201d\n\nStill, there is the danger of looking as if he is too removed. He did not sound particularly aggressive about domestic violence after his staff secretary, Rob Porter, was accused of physically abusing two former wives and resigned. Instead, his only public comment was to praise Mr. Porter and express sadness for him. In private, advisers said Mr. Trump was angry both that he had not been informed earlier about the allegations and that he had not been consulted on the initial White House response.\n\nHe likewise remained generally quiet about the tumble of the stock market, which has now reached an official correction, after lauding its increases for a year. Critics said he could not have it both ways, claiming credit when share prices rise while avoiding blame when they fall.\n\nDemocrats and some Republicans said Congress is dysfunctional enough without Mr. Trump getting involved. \u201cI am absolutely convinced that at this point in time the best thing for everyone involved is for this president to stay as far away as possible,\u201d said Jim Manley, a former top Democratic aide in the Senate. \u201cThe last thing this chaotic institution needs is for him to wreak more havoc by getting involved.\u201d\n\nThe one exception, he added, would be immigration, where Mr. Trump should play more of a role. \u201cThe issue is so toxic,\u201d he said, \u201cthat they\u2019re never going to get anything done unless he leans in and gives some cover to the Republicans.\u201d", "title": "Amid Turmoil From Washington to Wall Street, a Surprisingly Passive President", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "You wrote a memoir, \u201cBattle Hymn of the Tiger Mother,\u201d that touched on many issues around parenthood. What are your favorite books on child rearing?\n\nI never read any child rearing books when I was raising my daughters; maybe that was my problem! I actually didn\u2019t intend for \u201cBattle Hymn\u201d to be a parenting book either. I had totally different hopes for the book. I\u2019ve always loved books with wacky unreliable narrators. Believe it or not, my models for \u201cBattle Hymn\u201d were \u201cPale Fire,\u201d by Vladimir Nabokov; \u201cZeno\u2019s Conscience,\u201d by Italo Svevo; and \u201cA Confederacy of Dunces,\u201d by John Kennedy Toole. Also Dave Eggers\u2019s \u201cA Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius,\u201d which, come to think of it, is a child-rearing book of sorts.\n\nWhich books do you think best capture the current social and political moment in America?\n\nWell, I think the obvious answer is, on the one hand, books like J. D. Vance\u2019s \u201cHillbilly Elegy\u201d and Nancy Isenberg\u2019s \u201cWhite Trash\u201d and, on the other hand, Ta-Nehisi Coates\u2019 \u201cWe Were Eight Years in Power.\u201d But I actually think many of the main dynamics roiling our society today were captured decades ago, by books like Neil Postman\u2019s 1985 \u201cAmusing Ourselves to Death,\u201d about the media\u2019s damaging effect on public discourse, Paul Fussell\u2019s 1983 \u201cClass,\u201d Richard Hofstadter\u2019s 1963 \u201cAnti-Intellectualism in American Life,\u201d and Walter Lippmann\u2019s 1922 \u201cPublic Opinion,\u201d which talks about how out of touch America\u2019s cosmopolitan elites are with ordinary Americans.\n\nWhich novelists do you especially enjoy reading?\n\nI love classics. Some of my favorites are Tolstoy\u2019s \u201cWar and Peace,\u201d Eliot\u2019s \u201cMiddlemarch,\u201d Flaubert\u2019s \u201cSalammb\u00f4,\u201d James\u2019s \u201cThe Golden Bowl\u201d and Faulkner\u2019s \u201cThe Sound and the Fury.\u201d \u201cDream of the Red Chamber,\u201d by Cao Xueqin, is also amazing. It took me a while (and at least five false starts) to get into it, but I ended up loving Gabriel Garc\u00eda M\u00e1rquez\u2019s \u201cOne Hundred Years of Solitude.\u201d Julio Cort\u00e1zar\u2019s \u201cHopscotch\u201d made a big impact on me \u2014 how ingenious to write a book whose chapters you could read in two different orders.\n\nWhich genres are you drawn to and which do you avoid?\n\nThis is so embarrassing, but I can\u2019t read poetry. Try as I might, and I really have tried, I just don\u2019t get poems. I love novels and short stories, but for some reason poetry evades me. I consider it a deep moral failing in myself, especially because my husband and daughters are avid poetry lovers. A good friend gave me Edward Hirsch\u2019s \u201cHow To Read a Poem,\u201d which I read and still have on my shelf, but it didn\u2019t work. Also, I\u2019m not a fan of rambling books about traveling across the country while experimenting with psychedelic drugs. I need a plot.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHow do you like to read? Paper or electronic? One book at a time or several simultaneously? Morning or night?\n\nI read books related to my work in the morning, when I have my best concentration, and books for fun at night. I always read paper books \u2014 I don\u2019t even know how to use Kindle.\n\nWhat book might people be surprised to find on your shelves?\n\nMaybe all the funny books I have, starting with Laurence Sterne\u2019s \u201cThe Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman,\u201d which starts off with the narrator as a homunculus (sperm) at the moment of his ill-conceived conception. Kingsley Amis\u2019s academic satire \u201cLucky Jim\u201d is possibly my all-time favorite book. I still occasionally burst out laughing just thinking of the protagonist\u2019s nemesis Bertrand Welch, a pompous pseudo-intellectual who wears a beret and says \u201cYou sam\u201d \u2014 a stretched out version of \u201cYou see.\u201d More recently, David Sedaris\u2019s \u201cMe Talk Pretty One Day,\u201d B. J. Novak\u2019s \u201cOne More Thing,\u201d and Ali Wentworth\u2019s \u201cHappily Ali After\u201d all had me on the floor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhich books were you most eager to introduce to your children? And which books have they introduced to you?\n\nSome of my own childhood favorites like Robert McCloskey\u2019s \u201cMake Way for Ducklings,\u201d Maurice Sendak\u2019s \u201cPierre\u201d and \u201cWhere the Wild Things Are,\u201d Crockett Johnson\u2019s \u201cHarold and the Purple Crayon\u201d and Esphyr Slobodkina\u2019s \u201cCaps for Sale.\u201d Then, as the girls got older, \u201cCaddie Woodlawn,\u201d \u201cBlack Beauty,\u201d \u201cCharlie and the Chocolate Factory,\u201d \u201cThe Witch of Blackbird Pond\u201d and \u201cFrom the Mixed-up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler.\u201d My husband was in charge of reading Tolkien, \u201cThe Chronicles of Narnia\u201d and Lloyd Alexander\u2019s \u201cThe Chronicles of Prydain\u201d with my daughters, and it was through the three of them that I got introduced to science fiction books like \u201cDune.\u201d\n\nOf the books you\u2019ve written, which is your favorite or the most personally meaningful?\n\nA 2007 book called \u201cDay of Empire: How Hyperpowers Rise to Global Dominance \u2014 and Why They Fall.\u201d It argued that, relative to the societies around them, all of history\u2019s greatest powers were strikingly pluralistic and tolerant on their rise to power, and that in every case their decline coincided with a stark turn to intolerance and xenophobia. If only it had come out a decade later! But I\u2019m an optimist. As I explore in my new book, \u201cPolitical Tribes,\u201d I think America has self-correction mechanisms built into our identity and our institutions.\n\nWho would you want to write your life story?\n\nMy daughters, Sophia and Lulu, jointly. Or maybe Elif Batuman, who I think is supersmart and really funny. I love her idiosyncratic way of looking at things. She\u2019s the daughter of Turkish immigrants \u2014 and studied violin at the Manhattan School of Music \u2014 so I think she\u2019d relate. Also, she seems like a generous spirit, and I could definitely use that!\n\nAnd if you could ghostwrite someone else\u2019s?\n\nArguably, I already did that.\n\nWhat do you plan to read next?\n\n\u201cTurtles All the Way Down,\u201d by John Green, and \u201cThe House of Government,\u201d by Yuri Slezkine.", "title": "Amy Chua: By the Book", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "FORT WASHINGTON, MD. \u2014 When Hailu Mergia releases his album \u201cLala Belu\u201d on Friday, it will be this Ethiopian piano luminary\u2019s first collection of new music in two decades. And it will be his first ever aimed largely at a worldwide audience.\n\nUntil recently, Mr. Mergia, 71, was hardly known outside of his home country, where he is seen as a musical pioneer. For most of the past 20 years, he has lived in the Washington area and driven a taxi, picking up passengers at Dulles Airport and toting an electric keyboard in his trunk. He still drives the cab for extra cash. In idle moments, he hauls out the keyboard and sits alone in the back seat, his eyes closed, improvising.\n\nMr. Mergia had long given up performing publicly when the 2013 reissue of \u201cHailu Mergia and His Classical Instrument,\u201d a mostly forgotten gem from 1985, turned him into a cult celebrity among music obsessives across the globe, and set him off on tours of the United States and Europe. He has kept up a consistent schedule of international performances ever since.\n\nOn a recent Saturday, Mr. Mergia sat in an easy chair at his home here, describing how he relates to the audience he\u2019s garnered in the past few years. \u201cThe idea of \u2018Lala Belu\u2019 is, it\u2019s a composition you can sing with everybody,\u201d he said, referring to the new album\u2019s title track. \u201cIt\u2019s simple. No Amharic lyrics, no English lyrics. Just \u2018lala.\u2019 Whenever we have a show, we just play that song, and everybody\u2019s singing with us.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Ethiopia, Mr. Mergia\u2019s music has never been forgotten. In the 1960s and \u201970s he led the Walias Band, one of the country\u2019s best-known groups and a guiding force in Addis Ababa\u2019s freshly invigorated music scene. The Walias Band welded the slanted minor modes and hovering grooves of Ethiopian music onto a wriggling, electrified sound. In it you could hear the funk of the Meters, the Afro-Latin rock of Santana, the Afrobeat blowing over from Nigeria and Ghana.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe band graduated from Addis Ababa nightclubs to a coveted residency at the city\u2019s Hilton, which it held for roughly 10 years. In 1977 it recorded \u201cTche Belew,\u201d an album that became an Ethiopian classic. But the band broke up in the early 1980s, at the end of its only international tour, and Mr. Mergia settled in the Washington area, home to the world\u2019s largest expatriate Ethiopian community. As the years went on, gigs became scarcer, and in 1991 he stopped playing music professionally altogether.", "title": "An African Funk Pioneer Gets a Second Chance on a Global Stage", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Dani Cameranesi and Kelly Pannek knew about Maddie Rooney long before they became teammates on the United States Olympic women\u2019s hockey team. They were part of the reason Rooney, a goaltender, made the team in the first place.\n\nEleven months ago, Cameranesi and Pannek, forwards for the two-time defending N.C.A.A. champion Minnesota hockey team, were facing Rooney and Minnesota-Duluth in the semifinals of the Western Collegiate Hockey Association tournament.\n\nHardly anyone outside the Midwest had heard of Rooney, a 5-foot-6 sophomore. But she made a team-record 61 saves, many of them acrobatic, in a 2-1, double-overtime upset of the Golden Gophers.\n\nRooney followed it up with 51 saves the next day against top-ranked Wisconsin. That was not enough to deliver the championship; the Badgers won, 4-1. The blackboards still hang against the ochre-colored classroom wall. Even the morning ritual is familiar: Two students walk through the rows of tiny desks to collect the exercise books, which are still stacked inside in the same storage closet used during the late 1980s, when I was a primary school student in Castellina in Chianti.\n\n[Leggere in italiano]\n\nAUSTRIA SWITZerland ITALY Castellina in Chianti FRANCE Grosseto CORSICA Rome SARDINIA 100 miles\n\nWhat has changed are the students. When I was growing up, only one of my classmates was from somewhere else, a boy who arrived from Grosseto, roughly 60 miles away, to our ancient walled town of 2,800 people. Like me, he was from Tuscany, but he seemed like an exotic stranger.\n\nPhoto\n\nToday, more than half of the 23 second graders have parents from Afghanistan, Albania, Bosnia, Macedonia, Morocco, Pakistan or Tunisia. Five were born in their family\u2019s country of origin or in transit to Europe. This is the new Italy.\n\nInitially, I didn\u2019t pay close attention to what was happening in my village. I was part of a different migration: the flood of Italians in their 20s, 30s and 40s who had earned college degrees and then left villages or small towns, where job options are limited. Some had moved to Berlin, Denver, London or Paris, where one of my closest childhood friends now lives. I landed in Rome, among those who moved to Italy\u2019s big cities in search of work.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor many visitors, a great allure of Italy is the sense that nothing changes, whether the timeless beauty of Rome or Florence, or of villages like Castellina, where the castle and the original fortification were built in the 1400s. But change is now rippling through the country as Italians prepare for national elections on March 4 \u2014 the first in five years. No issue is more inflammatory than migration. No issue is more deeply felt than the weak economy that has plagued my generation.", "title": "An Ancient Tuscan Village, Like Italy, Is Reshaped by Migration", "authors": ["Gaia Pianigiani"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019ve always carried one since I started driving,\u201d Mr. Myrick said. \u201cI always kept a gun or pistol of some kind in my truck. Unloaded, stowed away. Not ready to fire.\u201d\n\nHe loaded and took aim at Mr. Woodham, but did not fire out of fear of hitting someone in the background. \u201cI knew not to shoot because the backstop was not safe,\u201d he said. \u201cI didn\u2019t just go blasting away.\u201d\n\nAfter seeing Mr. Myrick pointing his gun, Mr. Woodham retreated from campus, got in his car and began to drive away. As Mr. Myrick ran after him on foot, the car spun out and came to a stop 20 steps from Mr. Myrick. He had his gun trained on Mr. Woodham when the police arrived.\n\nTwo students, including Mr. Woodham\u2019s former girlfriend, were killed and seven others wounded. Mr. Woodham is serving a life sentence at the Mississippi State Penitentiary.\n\nDespite Mr. Myrick\u2019s firm stance against arming faculty members, he has long advocated placing trained personnel, possibly retired law enforcement officers, in every school, as a deterrent. \u201cWe protect our banks that way,\u201d he said. \u201cWe protect things we love. America protects things it loves. We don\u2019t care if it\u2019s expensive.\u201d\n\nMr. Myrick said he was not a member of the National Rifle Association. \u201cAnd not because I don\u2019t think the Second Amendment is important, but there\u2019s got to be some common sense,\u201d he said.\n\nGrief and shock after school shootings have long given way to fierce debates over gun control and firearms in schools. He completed hundreds of paintings and drawings there, and the estate, Ekely, has become a pilgrimage site for fans of his art. Although Munch\u2019s villa was demolished in 1960, and an artists\u2019 colony now exists on the site, his enclosed winter studio remains, and visitors can walk among the nearby trees to discover the surroundings that inspired many of his later works.\n\nRecently, however, plans by a Norwegian artist and an architectural firm to build an unusual home on a nearby hillock have set off a heated debate over the preservation of the \u201cScream\u201d painter\u2019s legacy. Next to Edvard Munch\u2019s Studio", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 One of the most powerful moments during President Trump\u2019s meeting with survivors and relatives of the Florida school shooting this week came when a student pleaded with the president to do what Australia did after a similar tragedy.\n\nAs it happened, Mr. Trump had an opportunity on Friday to get a firsthand report on Australia\u2019s crackdown on guns when he hosted the country\u2019s prime minister at the White House. But both men quickly discounted any comparisons, saying their nations are too different.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a completely different context, historically, legally and so forth,\u201d Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said when asked about his country\u2019s example during a news conference. \u201cWe are very satisfied with our laws,\u201d he added. \u201cBut we certainly don\u2019t presume to provide policy or political advice on that matter here. You have an amendment to your Constitution that deals with gun ownership. Trump and Turnbull Reject Comparisons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Movies fascinated Nandita Raman growing up in Varanasi, India, an interest fostered while hanging out in the movie theater owned by her mother\u2019s family, the first in the city to show talkies. She visited often, watching films and exploring behind the scenes, captivated by the visual environment, from the movies themselves to watching her uncle select vivid posters for coming attractions.\n\n\u201cIt felt like a miniature world within a world,\u201d Ms. Raman recalled. \u201cMore than a dozen people were on staff. Because I came from the owner\u2019s family, I had access. I really loved to go up into the projection room. I would hang out in the ticket booth.\u201d\n\nBut when Ms. Raman visited the theater in 2006, she encountered the empty shell of what had once been a flourishing business, with the seats and projection room gone and dust covering everything. The sight inspired her to spend the next three years photographing India\u2019s vanishing single-screen movie houses for the resulting series \u201cCinema Play House.\u201d Now on view at the George Eastman Museum in Rochester, N.Y., the photographs tell a story that is both deeply personal and acutely aware of greater culture issues.", "title": "An Elegy to India\u2019s Vanishing Cinemas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPINAMAR, Argentina \u2014 A former Russian diplomatic worker and an Argentine police officer were among six people arrested on Thursday after a 14-month investigation triggered by the discovery of hundreds of pounds of cocaine at the Russian Embassy in Buenos Aires.\n\n\u201cWe have dismantled an international cocaine trafficking organization operating between Argentina, Russia and Germany,\u201d Patricia Bullrich, Argentina\u2019s minister of security, said in a televised news conference.\n\nShe said the seizure of 389 kilograms of cocaine, more than 850 pounds, was made at a school on the grounds of the embassy in December 2016, leading to an investigation by Argentine border guards, the Buenos Aires police and the Russian Interior Ministry. The cocaine, she said, was valued at more than $60 million.\n\nThe Russian ambassador to Argentina, V\u00edktor Koronelli, and three members of Russia\u2019s Federal Security Service alerted Ms. Bullrich on Dec. 13, 2016, to what they thought were 16 pieces of luggage filled with drugs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Bullrich said Mr. Koronelli gave Argentine border guards a key to enter the school through a side door.\n\nPhoto\n\nArriving hours later, at 2 a.m., the guards confirmed the contents of the bags and took them to a separate location, where they replaced the cocaine with flour they bought at 3 a.m. at a wholesale food market outside Buenos Aires, Ms. Bullrich said. They returned to the embassy an hour or so later with the bags, which were also fitted with tracking devices, she said.", "title": "An Embassy, 850 Pounds of Cocaine and Now 6 Arrests", "authors": ["Charles Newbery"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Little has been done to repair the damage of three hugely destructive wars in the last decade.\n\nLast year, the Palestinian Authority, seeking to win back control over Gaza, slashed the salaries of thousands of workers still on its payroll and halted payments to Israel for Gaza\u2019s fuel and electricity. That pushed Hamas into a much-heralded agreement with the Palestinian Authority in October, but nothing has come of it.\n\nMost recently the Trump administration waded in with a vindictive decision to cut funding for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which supports Palestinian refugees, including 1.2 million in Gaza.\n\nWhile the blockade and Israeli military attacks have ruined Gaza, there is no defending Hamas, which regularly fires rockets across the border into Israel. Money that should have gone to hospitals and medicine has been spent on futile confrontation with Israel and digging tunnels that the Israelis are now spending a small fortune to block.\n\nBut holding two million people hostage is not the way to fight Hamas, and the suffering only nurtures more rage and militancy. A majority of Gaza\u2019s two million people are simply trying to survive against lengthening odds and can do little to alleviate their plight.\n\nIf, as General Eisenkot warned, another uprising lies in the future, that would likely prove futile. It would cause great suffering and destruction again, and might not even rouse the world to Gaza\u2019s plight. The Palestinians no longer seem to be a serious concern even for Arab nations.\n\nIsrael recently called on donor countries to fund $1 billion in desperately needed water and energy projects in Gaza.
