But the comparison is obvious, if invidious, given their family pedigrees.\n\nAnd Ms. Trump may benefit by another comparison: to Vice President Mike Pence, who sat near Ms. Kim during the opening ceremony of the Olympics and seemed unable to strike the same chord as she did with South Koreans. He later missed out on a meeting with North Korean officials after they canceled at the last minute.", "title": "An Envoy Who Can Rival \u2018North Korea\u2019s Ivanka\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Singapore is a country of countless hawker stalls and beloved mom-and-pop restaurants that serve up excellent renditions of local dishes. So when its notoriously discerning eaters pack into a chic hotel lobby to seek out traditional fare, take note.\n\nOn a recent weeknight at Folklore, at the Destination Singapore Beach Road hotel, table after table was filled with locals tucking into dishes like pork belly braised in tamarind gravy and eggplant sambal. The cuisine here is Singapore\u2019s so-called heritage food \u2014 and the chef behind it, Damian D\u2019Silva, is something of an evangelist on the matter. \u201cOur heritage food is dead or dying \u2014 a lot of the dishes that I used to eat as a kid, today, they\u2019re no longer available,\u201d said Mr. D\u2019Silva, who learned to cook as a child by watching his grandparents whip up Peranakan (descendants of Chinese immigrants to the Malay Peninsula) and Eurasian classics at the stove. \u201cIt\u2019s very important to keep them alive.\u201d\n\nMr. D\u2019Silva, who ran the kitchens at various restaurants in Singapore before opening Folklore last July, has amassed a loyal following. In 2008, when he took a break from restaurants to offer Peranakan dishes and Western fare like his signature anchovy pasta in a tiny coffee shop stall, the well-heeled followed, pulling up in pricey cars for takeout or sitting on a stool to sweat over a Wagyu steak.\n\nStandouts at Folklore include singgang, a Eurasian wolf herring dish, and the must-try fried rice, which stars the deliciously rich chocolate-like insides of buah keluak, a Southeast Asian nutlike fruit. There are also standards done well, including chap chye, a Peranakan dish of vegetables and glass noodles cooked in pork and prawn stock.", "title": "An Evangelist of Singaporean Food Has a New Pulpit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nOn the wall in my office is a 1996 photograph taken in Budapest. Among the 10 portrayed facing the camera are a former president of Hungary, Arpad Goncz; Louis Freeh, then the F.B.I. director; Janet Reno, then the attorney general; and me. We were celebrating the first anniversary of the 1995 founding of the International Law Enforcement Academy.\n\nThe brainchild of Mr. Freeh, the Budapest-based academy supports training for law enforcement personnel from 26 countries in Central and Eastern Europe and in Central Asia. In 2005, Robert S. Mueller III, then the F.B.I. director, attended the academy\u2019s 10th anniversary celebrations.\n\nMr. Freeh, the Hungarian government and I had two goals in mind: training law enforcement personnel in the former Soviet bloc in appropriate policing and investigative methods, as enjoyed by the United States and Western Europe, and encouraging these disparate police officials to begin to talk to one another, a practice unknown in the Communist days.\n\nThe results in uprooting crime and heading off terrorism have been outstanding. I am persuaded that neither President Trump nor Devin Nunes, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, who released the memo critical of the F.B.I., has ever heard of the academy, but the American public deserves to know how its interests are being effectively served by the F.B.I. throughout Central and Eastern Europe.", "title": "Opinion | An F.B.I. Contribution in Eastern Europe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "And here in Illinois, Chief Illiniwek has retained a stealth role on campus for years, neither officially sanctioned nor altogether gone. Though most of today\u2019s undergraduates were in elementary school when he was formally retired, the chief has maintained all his power to impassion and infuriate.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI think the people within the university were hoping the issue would just go away,\u201d said Ivan Dozier, a former Chief Illiniwek and a board member of the Honor the Chief Society, which wants to restore the mascot\u2019s official role. \u201cI think that\u2019s made things worse on campus.\u201d\n\nMr. Dozier said he and the current Chief Illiniwek were in a bathroom last week at the State Farm Center, the basketball arena on the Champaign campus, during the most recent and most peculiar flare-up in the long-running debate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJay Rosenstein, a professor of media and cinema studies at the university, who once made an award-winning documentary about opposition to native mascots, had been scouring the arena trying to find and film the latest unofficial Chief Illiniwek. When Mr. Rosenstein recognized Mr. Dozier and saw him heading toward a bathroom, he followed him inside, figuring Chief Illiniwek might also be there.\n\n\u201cI was done with the urinal, headed over to the sink, and at some point I look up and there\u2019s Jay Rosenstein at the end of the bathroom with his camera rolling,\u201d Mr. Dozier said in an interview.\n\nThey argued. Security guards arrived. Soon Mr. Rosenstein, 57, was handcuffed and hauled to jail by a campus police officer.\n\n\u201cI was only a couple steps in \u2014 never even advanced past the sink area,\u201d said Mr. Rosenstein, who was jailed on suspicion of unauthorized video recording but released the next day when the county prosecutor declined to file charges.\n\nJulia Rietz, the state\u2019s attorney of Champaign County, said in an email that her office had in the past pressed charges in cases that involved cameras hidden in bathrooms or locker rooms \u201cto record unknowing victims for the offenders\u2019 sexual gratification.\u201d Ms. Rietz added, \u201cWhile the arrest was technically appropriate, there was no evidence of such intent here.\u201d\n\nMr. Rosenstein insists he never filmed anyone undressed, and said he was acting as an investigative journalist. He said he wanted to see if university employees were helping the chief to appear at the basketball game, which, he said, would be \u201ca very big story.\u201d\n\nThe incident has added fuel to a larger fight that seems far from over. Mr. Rosenstein was placed on administrative leave pending an internal investigation, prompting dueling calls for him to be fired and to be reinstated. Chief Illiniwek supporters touted plans to \u201cstand together and show how many of us there really are\u201d at a basketball game later this month.\n\n\u201cThere will be some discourse at that event,\u201d said Raneem Shamseldin, the student body president, who helped organize the protest of the chief during the homecoming parade.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s not a threat. That is a promise.\u201d\n\nThough changing a Native American nickname or mascot almost always sets off debate, some institutions move on. At the University of Louisiana at Monroe, where sports teams known as the Indians were renamed as the Warhawks more than a decade ago, the issue long ago faded from the headlines. Lisa Miller, an administrator, said the new name was popular and that some current students might even be unaware of the old one.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s difficult for a university to have a mascot that you can\u2019t 100 percent embrace,\u201d Ms. Miller said. \u201cYou\u2019re always being cautious about doing things that may be offensive to others.\u201d\n\nSuzan Shown Harjo, a Native American activist who has sought to get such nicknames and mascots changed all over the country, said Illinois might have had more success if it had picked a replacement mascot and dropped its nickname: the Fighting Illini. Instead, there is no official mascot. The team logo, once an image of the chief\u2019s face, is now an orange letter \u201cI.\u201d\n\nShe said the Cleveland Indians should also have gone further by changing the team name instead of just removing Chief Wahoo from uniforms.\n\nHere in Illinois, the chief\u2019s vehement opponents and steadfast defenders seem to agree on one thing: They believe the university\u2019s leaders have repeatedly failed to act decisively on Chief Illiniwek, making matters worse. A university spokeswoman did not respond to multiple requests for an interview with an administrator.\n\nMr. Dozier, the former Chief Illiniwek, said everyone ought to be able to air their views more openly on campus. He said some people on both sides of the debate had become \u201cmore passionate\u201d and \u201cmore ignorant\u201d about the chief in recent years \u2014 a potentially \u201cdangerous combination,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Rosenstein, the suspended professor, said Chief Illiniwek and its history were like \u201ca bullet wound to the University of Illinois.\u201d He called for the naming of a new mascot.\n\n\u201cA bullet wound can\u2019t heal if you just put a Band-Aid over it,\u201d he said. \u201cYou\u2019ve got to go in there. You\u2019ve got to dig around.\u201d", "title": "An Indian \u2018Chief\u2019 Mascot Was Dropped. A Decade Later, He\u2019s Still Lurking.", "authors": ["Mitch Smith"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "#SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.", "title": "An Intimate Conversation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The image is one erased from official Iranian history books. Two women, both unveiled, have just been detained by Islamic volunteers with automatic rifles slung on their shoulders. The Iranian photographer Kaveh Kazemi, 28 at the time, followed the women walking home after they had participated in a protest against the introduction of the compulsory veil. Dressed in denim, so fashionable at the time, they are escorted away.\n\nThat picture, from 1979, captured the end of an era. Soon, Iran\u2019s parliament passed a law making the Islamic veil compulsory for all women, even visiting dignitaries and tourists. The country remains one of the few in the world to ask people to dress according to the state\u2019s wishes.\n\nFour decades later, some women have again taken to the streets, removing their veils in protest. Feb. 11 is the 39th anniversary of the revolution that ousted the Shah and led to the Islamic republic\u2019s creation. But instead of celebration, there is general dissatisfaction, as well as tensions over the economy and the political system. Nationwide protests that started in December lasted more than a week, leaving 25 people dead and nearly 5,000 detained.", "title": "An Iranian Photographer\u2019s Unflinching Look at His Country\u2019s Revolution", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "It never can be. The only tense we live in is the past; the present moves so fast that it becomes the past even as it\u2019s observed and experienced. And the future is, well, the future. And since the people, events and objects of our little histories are never commonly agreed upon \u2014 I saw it one way, you saw it another \u2014 the past becomes endlessly interesting, as changeable and unnerving as any work of art. Perhaps childhood never leaves us because we were pure artists then, unfettered by much personal history. Childhood fascinates Banville because it\u2019s \u201ca state of constantly recurring astonishment.\u201d When the astonishment ebbs, the past clouds over into itself. \u201cThe process of growing up,\u201d he writes, \u201cis, sadly, a process of turning the mysterious into the mundane.\u201d Only when the adult artist revives it are we excited at the prospect of what is long behind us.\n\nYet memory is oddly selective. \u201cI recall so many trivial things,\u201d Banville proclaims, \u201cand forget so many very momentous ones.\u201d In memory, the seemingly insignificant becomes so insistently prominent, who can tell if we have any idea of what is really important? One of the points of Bruegel\u2019s\u201cLandscape With the Fall of Icarus,\u201d perhaps the main one (pace Auden), is that the ordinary townspeople who ignore the divine hotshot\u2019s spectacular plunge are also suffering. To Banville, an apostle of the ordinary, the deep appeal of city life is that here the ordinary may be made magical.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis book is about the past, and about people worth bringing back. Not just the members of his family but figures like the kind and sympathetic assistant librarian Miss Flushing, \u201cwith her magnificent conical breasts poking against a pale-blue angora jumper.\u201d And, most movingly, the actor Micheal MacLiammoir, who, along with his partner, Hilton Edwards, a theater impresario, founded the Gate Theater, where Orson Welles got his start. The two men went about as \u201cthe most prominent, not to say the most flagrant, representatives of the homosexual life of Dublin.\u201d The city, Banville says, was unusually accepting of gays, and MacLiammoir and Edwards were beloved public figures. In an age like ours, when the streets are paved with eggshells, Banville does something that\u2019s both touching and embracing \u2014 especially with MacLiammoir, who never went out in public without wearing \u201cmakeup and a black wig that glistened like wet coal.\u201d He shows the actor\u2019s brilliance and wit within his gayness, not apart from it.\n\nOf all the people Banville has given us, Cicero, though omnipresent, exhibits the least personality. He is introduced as a sort of scholar-about-town, with his little car and his arcane knowledge of the city. There\u2019s not enough of him to suggest any personal importance to the author, so it\u2019s possible that he\u2019s merely a handy means of delivering information. Yet just when one begins to suspect that Cicero doesn\u2019t exist at all, who shows up in a photograph toward the end of the book but Cicero \u2014 seen from the back, sitting next to Banville on the driver\u2019s side of the two-seater, parked at a beach and aimed at the sea. Then again, it might be a dog in a sweater. Is Banville playing with us? I mean, who outside ancient Rome is called Cicero? It says a lot about Banville\u2019s ability to hold our attention that we accept his companion for whatever or whoever he is. Or if he is.\n\nPhoto\n\nPity the fool who\u2019s reading this book to get a clear and orderly picture of Dublin. But oh, what a topographical map has been drawn by Paul Joyce\u2019s evocative photographs and Banville\u2019s observant eye. Like Max Morden in his Man Booker Prize-winning novel, \u201cThe Sea,\u201dBanville remains willfully and gloriously disorganized. The tour he takes us on, while offering a handful of interesting facts about Dublin, is more about moods and states of mind and how they shape, even create, the so-called real world. \u201cI have never in my life paid much attention to my surroundings,\u201d Banville writes, alert, in the way of Joyce, not to what people do but rather to \u201cwhat they are.\u201d As he puts it, \u201cArt is a constant effort to strike past the mere daily doings of humankind in order to arrive at \u2026 the essence of what it is, simply, to be.\u201d\n\nSo, like the more thoughtful Romantics, Banville sees into the life of things. Autumn, he concludes, is more expectant than spring because the \u201cstealthy tumult of the dying season\u201d causes it to tremble with love. A fringe of gray curls on the head of a nearly bald man looks like \u201ca fallen-down halo.\u201d Standing by the canal at Lower Mount Street Bridge, he watches a heron, \u201cawe-struck by the clean sharp dangerous lines of the thing.\u201d (He makes \u201cthing,\u201d that most unmoored of words, sound precise.) On a May morning, \u201cthe pale sky shines and shimmers like the inner skin of a vast soap bubble.\u201d He recalls Stephanie, an alluring young woman whom he spotted when he too was young. She was \u201cslight, with an almost boyish figure,\u201d and her long dark hair was parted in the middle. It was love at first sight \u2014 his, alas, not hers. Years later, when he meets her again, his swain\u2019s heart gives an \u201canguished quack.\u201d And once again he feels \u201cthe unutterable enormity of love pressing hotly behind one\u2019s breastbone like a hot lump of lead.\u201d\n\nBanville\u2019s soarings, like a hawk\u2019s, are both wild and comprehensive, taking in everything and imagining more. One can\u2019t distinguish his descriptions from the things described, the dancer from the dance. See how he gives us the Great Palm House of the Botanic Gardens with its walkways \u201chigh above our heads, among the upflung fronds, narrow, perforated metal platforms that must surely lead to diving boards.\u201d One \u201cwould not be surprised should there come a sudden splash followed by a swimmer streaking down in an arc and skimming past us, making fish-mouths with his hands \u2014 his palms! \u2014 pressed together above his head.\u201d In that same Palm House, the philosopher Wittgenstein is commemorated by a plaque for the time he lived in Dublin in the 1940s. Banville cites him on several occasions in \u201cTime Pieces.\u201d Wittgenstein believed that language isn\u2019t separate from reality.\n\nThe better memoirs tend not to be principally about the suffering of the author but rather about what the author has noticed in his or her life, what is cherished or abhorred \u2014 often about pure information worth imparting. The better memoirs are the more generous, looking outside the self. I don\u2019t think it\u2019s an accident that the photographs of Banville in this book are shot from behind, showing him looking away. \u201cTime Pieces\u201d is subtitled \u201cA Dublin Memoir\u201d to signal that the author is focusing on the city. Here Banville feels at home, just as I did all those preposterous years ago. Banville says he was once told at a dinner party that there\u2019s no such thing as a coincidence. So I am given a book to review, written by the splendid novelist with whom I shared a wondered staring at Lord Nelson\u2019s detached head, both of us standing on the imbricated layers of the past and each about to blunder hopefully into our separate unimaginable lives.", "title": "An Irish Fl\u00e2neur, Greeting the Past on His Present Wanderings", "authors": ["Roger Rosenblatt", "John Banville"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Mostly, we agreed, they were not.\n\n\u201cThe thing is,\u201d Chang said at one point, his voice ascending, \u201cit\u2019s peak snow crab season right now. I don\u2019t know if people understand. This is the best red snow crab! You can\u2019t eat it like this anywhere else in the world. It\u2019s so sweet. Go eat the snow crab!\u201d\n\nSo I went to eat the snow crab.\n\nAt a restaurant near Gangneung Olympic Park, a colleague and I slipped on plastic gloves and each grabbed scissors. (When I\u2019m president, scissors will replace knives on everybody\u2019s dinner tables.) We pulled crab parts from a bubbling pot as deep and wide as a witch\u2019s caldron. We broke our busy silence only to marvel at the ribbons of red and white meat dangling between our fingertips: They were feathery soft and, yes, so sweet. When all the legs were gone, we asked for a couple packs of instant noodles to repurpose the cloudy russet broth.", "title": "An Olympic Challenge: Eat All the Korean Food That Visitors Won\u2019t", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Even at her young age, her prose reveals that she was a pro, seriously and carefully laying out the news of every event, even if it was low in the sports pecking order. Within the limits of The Times\u2019s strict rules and sometimes stiff house writing style, she managed to impart some flavor to her coverage.\n\nIn reporting on an outdoor swim meet in Manhattan Beach in 1935, she wrote, \u201cIt was not a water hazard but a mental hazard that Miss Rawls had to face in the medley race. For the sprightly, laughing Southerner is literally \u2018frightened to death\u2019 by lightning, and it must have been small comfort to see a telephone pole a block away struck by a bolt and burning merrily away.\u201d\n\nHer bylines almost always appeared over accounts of women\u2019s sports. No one sent Vinson to write about a glamorous event like a bowl game, a prize fight or the World Series (although Carroll says she often attended such events with her male colleagues). Instead, she plied her trade at places like the Heights Casino in Brooklyn for squash, the Pelham Country Club for golf and Jones Beach for archery.\n\nDaley acknowledged that while Vinson was \u201cnever completely accepted\u201d by The Times\u2019s boys\u2019 club, she was eventually \u201cwarily admitted to the gang.\u201d\n\nAmazingly, Vinson juggled full-time sportswriting with full-time athletic pursuits. On Jan. 13, 1936, she reported a squash story from the Cosmopolitan Club in Manhattan. On the 15th, she sailed for Germany and the Winter Olympics on the liner Washington. (It was an era when boat sailings were big news. The Times reported that Sergei Rachmaninoff was also on board; Vinson made the boat by just 10 minutes and forgot her uniform.)\n\nOn Feb. 2, her byline appeared again, over a story about the women\u2019s ski team. On the 13th, she finished fifth in her third Olympics. She also placed fifth in the pairs competition alongside George Hill. On March 3, she was back on the squash beat, reporting from London, and before the month was out she was back reporting on badminton from New York.", "title": "An Olympic Figure Skater Who Also Made History for The Times", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 The men\u2019s Olympic downhill ski event was postponed from Sunday to Thursday because of high winds that were expected to continue for about a day and a half.\n\nThe severe conditions caused organizers to shuffle other parts of the Alpine skiing schedule. The men\u2019s super-G, which had been scheduled for Thursday, was moved to Friday.\n\nThere were reasons besides the forecast for moving the men\u2019s downhill four days later in the week. It allowed Olympic organizers to preserve part of the schedule that featured two prominent women\u2019s Alpine races, the giant slalom and slalom. They are set for early Monday and Wednesday here, which will be Sunday and Tuesday nights in the United States.\n\nThose events are the first races at these Games for the American Mikaela Shiffrin, the overall women\u2019s World Cup champion and a defending Olympic champion in slalom. That made the decision to delay the men\u2019s downhill to Thursday a victory of sorts for NBC Universal, which paid nearly $1 billion for the Pyeongchang Olympics media rights in the United States and has heavily promoted Shiffrin in the run-up to the Games. Her opening event can now still be broadcast on a night when television viewing is generally high.", "title": "An Olympic Ski Race Is Blown 4 Days Off Course, but Onto a TV-Friendly Path", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The volatile music suggests the unpredictable ways racial prejudice manifests itself in daily life. \u201cEvery day that my feet hit the floor, I have to know that I\u2019m going to encounter some of these small minuscule, minute things,\u201d Mr. Brownlee said. \u201cAnd the decisions you make in an instant can change the course of your life.\u201d\n\nThe music of \u201cCycles of My Being\u201d reflects both the changeability and the gravity of that life, and puts an emphasis on empathy, even from the musicians. Mr. Sorey asks all the players to read from the full score, instead of from individual parts.\n\n\u201cI want them to see the actual lyrics,\u201d he said. \u201cI want all of the players to have a total experience of what it means to sing the music. Imagining themselves as the vocalist, and them singing the music. That\u2019s how I like to try to frame it.\u201d\n\nThough Mr. Brownlee spoke with clear pride about a song cycle entirely created by black men, he also said he wanted the work to reach out to many different communities and audiences.", "title": "An Opera Star\u2019s Song Cycle Conjures a Black Man\u2019s Life in America", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "On opening day, Mr. Wachner and Jonathan Ambrosino, Trinity\u2019s organ consultant, will demonstrate the instrument, which was purchased (from the Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass.) and installed for $1 million; there will also be a concert with Mr. Wachner conducting the Choir of Trinity Wall Street and Trinity Baroque Orchestra in works of Durufl\u00e9 and Bach; and an organ recital by the noted performer Peter Sykes. On Feb. 22, Paul Jacobs, himself a grand New York institution, will play concertos by Poulenc, Christopher Rouse and Mr. Wachner, who will also conduct Novus NY, Trinity\u2019s contemporary-music ensemble.\n\nAs Lower Manhattan grows ever more residential, Trinity has become more intimately entwined with the life of its neighborhood. It was pulled in by the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, an event that ended up spurring this frenetic organ activity.\n\nSt. Paul\u2019s, across Church Street from the World Trade Center, somehow survived the conflagration without significant structural damage. But its contents were coated with dust, grime and debris, and in the case of the Schlicker organ, with its intricate inner workings and its use of degradable materials, like leather, the damage proved disabling.\n\nThough slightly farther from ground zero, the Aeolian Skinner organ in Trinity Church, dating from 1923, suffered similar damage, and it lay idle and dismantled for several years as the church awaited an insurance settlement. Finally, realizing that reconstruction or the manufacture of a new pipe organ could take another five years, Trinity Wall Street, which was in constant use, arrived at a radical solution: the manufacture of a new digital instrument by Marshall & Ogletree, with sampled sound reproduced by ranks of large speakers, 74 in all, hidden behind dummy pipes in the choir loft. The instrument was developed quickly, at a cost of $300,000.\n\nElectronic organs have been slow to gain respect from pipe organ enthusiasts. The sound emerging from speakers can be tacky, flat and superficial, and typically lacks the gut-wrenching impact of the roar that mighty pipes can produce. Avi Stein, the associate organist and chorus master at Trinity Wall Street, allows that the Marshall & Ogletree \u201cfakes a pipe organ very well\u201d but adds that it \u201clacks some of the tangible singing quality that turns a machine into a work of art.\u201d He agreed with Mr. Wachner that playing the instrument is, in a way, like listening to a recording.", "title": "An Organ \u2014 and Soon Another \u2014 Lands on Broadway", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Yance Ford is the first transgender director to receive an Oscar nomination, for his documentary \u201cStrong Island.\u201d The film is a brutal, intimate portrait of the unraveling of his tight-knit family following the death of his brother, William Ford Jr., in Suffolk County, Long Island, in 1992, and an all-white grand jury\u2019s decision to not indict the white man who shot him.\n\nWhile Mr. Ford was a somber, deeply sorrowful presence in the film, he flipped out when the Oscar nominations were announced; we know this because he recorded his gleeful reaction and it made the local news. I recently spoke with him about how the film has helped shift his lifelong grief, and his hope that other transgender people will be more accepted as a result of his nomination. Here are excerpts from our phone chat this month.\n\nWhat kind of feedback are you getting to the film?\n\nI\u2019m hearing from people who were former students of my mother at Thomas Jefferson High School in East New York in the \u201970s and \u201980s [where she was the principal], and from school at Rikers [where she started a school for women]. I\u2019m hearing from people who were friends of my brother in high school who didn\u2019t realize he was dead. Friends of mine from elementary school and high school.\n\nNetflix opened the door for the rest of the world to see the movie. It just so happened the rest of the world includes people who have written to say my mother changed their lives. People saying yes, thank you for showing that this is not something that black people have been imagining. It\u2019s really humbling.\n\nI interviewed you this past summer, and now you sound so much lighter, less burdened.\n\n\u201cStrong Island\u201d has been doing more and more of the work. I think that\u2019s the shift you hear in my voice. That I haven\u2019t been the one to have to carry it all. It\u2019s out in the world and can speak for itself. It does take the pressure off me in a way. I definitely feel like I\u2019m more present than the 1992 Yance or the 2012 Yance, when I walked away from a very stable job into what felt like a great unknown. Being out as a trans man isn\u2019t new in my personal life, but it\u2019s new in the public sphere. I started part of my transition before the film was complete, and now I\u2019m further along in my transition. I\u2019m also more comfortable in my skin. The past 10 years has been about the movie, the, movie, the movie. And then I get to be in the world as my authentic self. I think that\u2019s the lightness that you hear.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow does it feel to be so inspiring for people?\n\nI have been gender nonconforming my entire life. One of the things I discovered last year was my brother knew that I was gay, and he had told all of my friends, \u201cListen Yance is gay, and off limits. I\u2019m taking Yance to everything, prom, this thing, that thing.\u201d It reaffirms that my brother saw me for who I was. I can with this nomination remind people that trans people in general and trans people of color in particular are subject to violence at higher rates than most any other group. There was just an article about how trans women feel targeted by the N.Y.P.D., and were assumed to be engaged in sex work. If my nomination helps people at all think about the transgender folks in their lives, in their communities, and treating them as humans and equals deserving of protection, I\u2019m happy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHave you heard any reaction from law enforcement in Suffolk County?\n\nSuffolk County criminal justice is in disarray. [Its former police chief is in prison, convicted in 2016 of conspiring to obstruct justice among other charges. The former district attorney faces charges of trying to derail a federal investigation.] I haven\u2019t heard a peep, and I honestly didn\u2019t expect to. One thing I learned in making the film is that the people involved think they asked all the questions. They think they\u2019re right. This is what happens with not having a mechanism for review of the grand jury system, when you have a system that assumes every decision is correct, that doesn\u2019t include a mechanism for review no matter how many studies reveal racial bias.\n\nDoes the film\u2019s release and success ease the weight of your grief, or change it at all?\n\nGrief for me is a moment-to-moment experience. I wish my parents were here to see it. I wish my mother were here to see this because she participated in the film. I have a lot of surrogate parents, but there\u2019s no one like your mother. At the Gotham Awards they played a clip of my mom; it was incredible. The entire room came to a standstill. It was amazing to see the effect my mother has on people. On the other hand, it really magnifies how absent she is.", "title": "An Oscar-Nominated Transgender Director on His \u2018Authentic Self\u2019", "authors": ["Cara Buckley", "The Carpetbagger"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 The Paris Opera usually invites only journalists to the news conferences where it unveils its coming plans. But last month, as it announced a boldly ambitious 2018-19 season, the company brought in 200 people under the age of 28 to the event at the Palais Garnier here.\n\nThis was not just for show. It was a dramatic way of highlighting the Paris Opera\u2019s extraordinary success in attracting younger audiences. According to the company, it had 95,000 audience members younger than 28 last season \u2014 more than 10 percent of tickets sold and 30,000 more than just two years before.\n\nThe company, which celebrates its 350th birthday next year, is an unlikely contradiction to the worldwide trend of an aging audience at operas. The average age of an audience member in Paris is 45 \u2014 48 for the opera, 43 for the ballet \u2014 compared with 58 at the Metropolitan Opera and 54 at the Staatsoper in Berlin. The largest segment of the Houston Grand Opera\u2019s audience is between 65 and 72.\n\nWhen St\u00e9phane Lissner was appointed as the Paris Opera\u2019s general director in 2014, he set about implementing measures focused on fostering younger attendance.", "title": "An Unlikely Youth Revolution at the Paris Opera", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Over the years, and helped by financing from friends and family, Nanushka nurtured a large following in Hungary, where the label has a store in Budapest, and a growing global audience. It sells at influential boutiques like Bird Brooklyn and is worn by celebrities like Charlize Theron.\n\nIn 2012, Ms. Sandor took on an investor, who in turn was bought out by Mr. Baldaszti and the venture capital firm GB & Partners, which purchased a majority stake in November 2016 and injected $3 million into the business. Mr. Baldaszti orchestrated a change in Nanushka\u2019s identity \u2014 everything from its logo to its shoe boxes \u2014 and Nanushka\u2019s revenues have nearly tripled in the last two years.\n\nLast year, Nanushka received its first orders from \u201cthe majors\u201d \u2014 department stores like Browns and online retailers like Net-a-Porter. When the label noted a large uptick in orders of its pre-fall 2018 collection, the team decided the time was right for a show.\n\nIn previous seasons, Nanushka would spend $20,000 on a \u201clook book,\u201d a series of professional photographs of models wearing the collection. For the presentation, which will be held on Feb. 11, that\u2019s just a drop in the bucket.
