View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. McSally is likely to benefit from the party\u2019s right wing being divided. But should the McCain seat come open, or should Mr. Arpaio, 85, not go through with his bid, she may face a more daunting one-on-one race with one of the anti-establishment candidates, both of whom sound Trumpian notes.\n\nThe president pardoned Mr. Arpaio last year for criminal contempt, and Ms. Ward said in an interview that she met with the president in December and discussed the race. (She cornered him at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida during the holidays, according to one Republican familiar with the encounter.)\n\nMs. McSally has been helped by an aggressive backstage effort from Republican officials in and out of the White House to keep the president from backing Mr. Arpaio or Ms. Ward. Before she entered the race, Ms. McSally won assurances from an intermediary that Mr. Trump would not endorse her rivals, according to a Republican directly familiar with the conversation, and she and her advisers met last week in the White House with the president\u2019s political team, an opportunity not afforded the other candidates.\n\nTo further inoculate herself from the right, Ms. McSally is declining to say whether she would support a comprehensive measure that offers legal status to undocumented immigrants and is publicly showering Mr. Trump with praise, though she will not reveal whom she voted for in 2016 or any election.\n\nIs he a good man? \u201cI think he has done a lot of amazing things in his life,\u201d she said.\n\nIs he a role model? \u201cI think he is, yeah. I mean, look, everybody has got their strengths and weaknesses,\u201d she offered.\n\nAnd about that report that Mr. Trump had an affair with a porn star shortly after his wife gave birth and later paid her more than $100,000 to stay quiet? \u201cAlleged this and alleged that,\u201d she replied.\n\nMs. McSally also said \u201csure, absolutely\u201d she would campaign with Mr. Trump in the general election, a step Mr. Flake said offered far more risk than reward.\n\n\u201cYou create ads that will be run,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd particularly if there happens to be two senatorial elections, you\u2019re going see just a wave of money.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet Ms. Sinema, who began her career in politics as a Ralph Nader supporter and has become a member of the centrist Blue Dog coalition, is stepping gingerly around Mr. Trump in ways that may irritate the left.\n\nIn a brief phone interview, she declined to offer even the most gentle of criticism of a president who many in her party believe is a threat to American democracy.\n\nMs. Sinema noted that she and Mr. Trump \u201cworked together very well\u201d on veterans\u2019 issues and sidestepped questions about his character.\n\n\u201cI mean, I\u2019m happy to work with anyone at any time,\u201d she said with a nervous laugh. \u201cI don\u2019t spend my time worrying about, you know, personality stuff. That\u2019s not my issue.\u201d\n\nAs for her own politics, Ms. Sinema would not say whether she was a progressive or a moderate. \u201cI would say I\u2019m an Arizonan,\u201d she said.\n\nIt is a risk-averse approach that her allies believe could pay dividends in a state that still leans Republican, should Democrats enjoy a wave election year.\n\nBut to some Arizona liberals, Ms. Sinema\u2019s pragmatism is bitterly disappointing.\n\n\u201cWe already know that we can\u2019t trust her,\u201d said Tomas Robles, who led protests at Ms. Sinema\u2019s office to push her to stand up for the so-called Dreamers, young undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children.\n\nThe perennial challenge for Democrats here is that Hispanics do not vote anywhere near to the level of their population.\n\nMr. Robles said his and other groups intended to register 200,000 new voters this year.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s going to have to really work to earn those votes,\u201d he said. \u201cIf you\u2019re alienating the largest minority group in Arizona, you\u2019re going to have a tough time winning an election as a Democrat.\u201d", "title": "Arizona G.O.P. Tiptoes Between a Trump-Loving Base and a Leery Wider Electorate", "authors": ["Jonathan Martin"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI had no contribution to what Paddock did,\u201d Mr. Haig said. \u201cI had no way to see into his mind. The product that I sold him had absolutely nothing to do with what he did. I\u2019m a vendor. I\u2019m a merchant whose name was released.\u201d\n\nOne of his lawyers, Marc Victor, said at the news conference that Mr. Haig, \u201cto the best of his knowledge, has never sold ammunition to anybody who has ever used it for any unlawful purpose whatsoever.\u201d Federal and Arizona laws allow people to resell ammunition and do not require buyers to complete background checks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nInvestigators from the F.B.I. and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives contacted Mr. Haig about 11 hours after the Oct. 1 shooting, he said. He spoke with them \u201cwithout any hesitation\u201d and gave them examples of the ammunition he had sold to Mr. Paddock. He spoke with investigators three additional times.\n\nMr. Haig did not even know about the shooting until investigators contacted him, he said, because he had gone to work at 6 a.m. and had not seen the news. When he heard the news he said he felt \u201crevulsion\u201d and was \u201chorrified that this man would do something like that.\u201d\n\nMr. Haig said that he had no suspicion about Mr. Paddock at all in what he called \u201ca routine type of transaction\u201d for a \u201cvery common\u201d amount. The two met at a Phoenix gun show and Mr. Paddock called him the next week. \u201cHe pulled up very well dressed, very well groomed, very polite, respectful,\u201d Mr. Haig said. \u201cHe paid me, put it in his car, went on his way \u2014 at no time did he seem suspicious.\u201d\n\nThe product was surplus military tracer ammunition, Mr. Haig said, and Mr. Paddock said he planned to go to the desert to \u201cput on a light show\u201d with his friends.\n\nHe said that he did not believe any of the ammunition was used in Las Vegas. If it had been, he said, it would have left an obvious trail of red streaks in the sky, which might have made it easier for police officers to detect where the gunfire was coming from.\n\nMr. Haig\u2019s lawyer repeatedly said at the news conference that his client had nothing to hide and that \u201cthe reason he opts to speak to the press today is basically to protect his reputation.\u201d Mr. Haig\u2019s lawyers did not immediately respond to phone calls seeking further comment.", "title": "Arizona Man Is Charged With Making Armor-Piercing Bullets Found in Las Vegas Gunman\u2019s Room", "authors": ["Rebekah Zemansky", "Jennifer Medina"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "The new courses at Arizona State focus on Western thinking from the ancient Greeks to the Founding Fathers and beyond, with an emphasis on free-market philosophy. They draw heavily from original texts rather than modern interpretations.\n\n\u201cThere is too much revisionism being taught in universities today,\u201d said State Representative Jay Lawrence, a Republican from Scottsdale who backed the new programs. \u201cIt\u2019s a big deal to those of us who feel very strongly about a more conservative education.\u201d\n\nBut many liberal arts professors view these efforts as reviving an antiquated and Eurocentric version of history, one that they have tried to balance with viewpoints of women and racial minorities.\n\nA number of longtime Arizona State faculty members, as well as Democrats in the Legislature, also complain that the millions appropriated for the new programs could have been better spent. Steady cuts left state universities with $390 million less in taxpayer support in 2017 than they had before the 2008 recession, requiring steep tuition increases. \u201cHere you want to create these freedom schools for whatever reason, and there are so many other pressing needs,\u201d said State Representative David Bradley, a Democrat from Tucson.\n\nThe initial debate over funding the Arizona State program broke along party lines, reflecting the increasing polarization around higher education nationwide.\n\nA Pew Research Center poll last year found that 58 percent of Republicans or Republican-leaning respondents believed that colleges had a negative effect on the country, up from 37 percent just two years earlier. Among Democrats last year, 72 percent believed colleges had a positive effect.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think part of the problem is a perception or reality that we got a bunch of libs indoctrinating your children, and there\u2019s not a lot of balance,\u201d said Margaret Spellings, the president of the University of North Carolina system, which has asked to send a delegation to observe the Arizona State program.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLawmakers are also reacting to protests that have roiled college campuses in recent years.\n\nIn Nebraska, a bill introduced last month would establish a special committee to monitor \u201cbarriers or incidents of disruption\u201d to free speech on campus. It and similar bills in other states are modeled after a proposal by the Arizona-based Goldwater Institute, inspired by episodes in which conservative speakers on campus were heckled or disrupted.\n\nLouisiana State University said its president, F. King Alexander, received a phone call from someone in the Legislature threatening to withhold funding if football players \u201ctook a knee\u201d during the national anthem. \u201cThat\u2019s the type of intrusion that we deal with politically even on something that\u2019s the issue of the week, or the issue of the month,\u201d Dr. Alexander said.\n\nAs universities go, Arizona State hardly appears to be a liberal bastion. The palm-shaded main campus in Tempe, which has about 52,000 students, has been immune from the divisive protests at places such as Berkeley, Evergreen State College and Middlebury. Students wander around in military garb, evidence of a sizable R.O.T.C. presence. On a recent day, students zoomed through the center of campus on skateboards, taking little notice as a pro-gun group set up a booth nearby on a manicured plaza.\n\n\n\nPrivate donors, including the Charles Koch Foundation and the Jack Miller Center, have been funding conservative campus programs around the country for years, and the programs at both Arizona universities are absorbing earlier Koch-funded initiatives at each school.\n\nThe Legislature has approved $7 million for the Arizona State school so far. In addition to paying for six new professors with intellectually conservative pedigrees, $430,000 has been set aside for attention-grabbing rare manuscript acquisitions, including first editions of the Federalist Papers and Adam Smith\u2019s \u201cWealth of Nations.\u201d\n\nAn additional $75,000 is paying for spring break trips to India for 12 students, a carrot to encourage enrollment in the school, which stands at about 50. Students had to take at least one of the school\u2019s classes as a condition of winning a spot on the trip.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOfficials of the school, which currently operates in the university\u2019s Social Sciences building, said they expected enrollment to increase once its major was fully approved by the Board of Regents, permitting the school to grant degrees.\n\nThe new program has not been well received by some professors elsewhere at Arizona State, who view it as duplicating existing classes and too heavily focused on white male thinkers from the United States and Europe.\n\n\u201cThey don\u2019t seem to be interested in looking at diverse political theorists in this country, Booker T. Washington, W.E.B. DuBois, Ida B. Wells, Native scholars or Asian-American scholars,\u201d said Karen Kuo, a professor of Asian Pacific American Studies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith the school cognizant of concerns that it focuses only on \u201cdead white men,\u201d its director, Paul Carrese, has sought to diversify the curriculum, adding women and minority thinkers to the readings. Last month, the school sponsored an unveiling of two more rare books, inscribed editions of works by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.\n\n\u201cThe program is not pursing a party line or dogma,\u201d said Dr. Carrese, who was recruited from the Air Force Academy. \u201cIt\u2019s making space for debate.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA look at two economics courses \u2014 one in the new school and another offered by the university\u2019s School of Social Transformation \u2014 provides an example of the contrasting approaches.\n\nIn the new school, Peter McNamara, who has published on the free-market economist F.A. Hayek, teaches \u201cClassics of Modern Economic Thought,\u201d a survey of 20th-century economists. Four of the 30 sessions are devoted to inequality and moral issues, according to the syllabus.\n\nThe other class, \u201cGlobalization and Socioeconomic Justice,\u201d covers some of the same thinkers but focuses on why \u201cinequality and poverty exist,\u201d with discussions that include colonialism and imperialism, \u201cenduring economic injustice\u201d and environmental issues associated with capitalism.\n\n\u201cI teach the students to actually look at what\u2019s happening around the world when these economic theories are applied in practice,\u201d said LaDawn Haglund, who teaches the globalization course.\n\nAmong students in the new program is Justin Heywood, a sophomore from Phoenix who took a course titled \u201cGreat Debates in American Politics and Economics\u201d last fall. This semester, he is enrolled in \u201cFederalists and Anti-Federalists.\u201d\n\nMr. Heywood, 20, who wrote in House Speaker Paul D. Ryan for president, said that he was drawn to the program by its deep exploration of topics, and that he believed the new school was attracting a political mix of students.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome, he acknowledged, were enticed by the chance for the free India trip. \u201cI know a lot of students who signed up just for that,\u201d he said.\n\nMichael Crow, the university\u2019s president, has embraced the program. \u201cThey were interested in having a broader set of curricular offerings than the one we presently have, particularly as it related to economic thought or political theory, philosophy,\u201d Dr. Crow said.\n\n\u201cThe fact that someone from the state came along and gave us money for it, O.K., good,\u201d he said. Yet, he complained, the Legislature has not fulfilled his request to pay half the cost of the university\u2019s in-state students. \u201cThe fact that they weren\u2019t giving us money for other things, bad.\u201d\n\nMr. Bradley, the Democratic lawmaker, said there was some mystery surrounding the origin of the funding request for the schools. \u201cThe governor\u2019s budget appears at 11 o\u2019clock at night and we vote two hours later,\u201d he said.\n\nA spokesman for Gov. Doug Ducey said that he did not think the request was generated by their office. But in the governor\u2019s most recent State of the State speech, on Jan. 8, he said he was pleased with the efforts to promote a range of viewpoints at state schools.\n\n\u201cHere in Arizona, on our campuses, debate is encouraged, free speech is protected, and diversity of thought isn\u2019t just a platitude,\u201d Mr. Ducey said. \u201cIt\u2019s alive and well in lecture halls, on debate stages and in the pages of college newspapers.\u201d", "title": "Arizona Republicans Inject Schools of Conservative Thought Into State Universities", "authors": ["Stephanie Saul"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "By the time Arkady Wajspapir killed a Nazi during the historic uprising at the Sobibor death camp in Poland in 1943, he had endured great misery.\n\nWhile he was serving in the Soviet Red Army in World War II, his family was killed by Nazis in a massacre near his hometown in Ukraine. And after being seriously wounded in fighting in Kiev, he was taken to a prisoner-of-war hospital and later to a concentration camp in Minsk.\n\nWhile interned there he was one of 75 prisoners, patients and doctors \u2014 all Jewish \u2014 who were sent to a separate prison in the woods nearby, where they were confined in dark cells and fed bits of bread.\n\n\u201cIn the mornings they\u2019d open the doors and ask how many of us had died,\u201d Mr. Wajspapir told the Netherlands Institute for War Documentation in an interview in 1984. Within a few weeks, he said, only 30 of the men were alive.", "title": "Arkady Wajspapir, 96, Is Dead; Escaped Death Camp in Uprising", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "And at a news conference Tuesday about gun safety in schools, Gov. Philip D. Murphy announced that the New Jersey State Police would start regular, but unannounced, officer visits to the 107 schools in districts where it has jurisdiction.\n\n\u201cAny parent watching should feel that we are doing everything we can,\u201d Mr. Murphy said during the news conference, which was carried live by local television stations.\n\nNew Jersey has some of the toughest gun laws in the country. But at the news conference, Mr. Murphy, a Democrat who has been a staunch gun control advocate, vowed to work with the state Legislature, controlled by Democrats, to sign several bills that had been vetoed by his predecessor, Chris Christie, a Republican.\n\nEast Brunswick is adding armed police officers to complement its 71 school resource officers \u2014 all of them retired law-enforcement officers \u2014 throughout its 11 schools. The officers will not necessarily be assigned to a specific post, but rather move around different areas, and be a visible presence, talking to students and teachers and other staff. And while the district did not specify the number of officers being hired, Victor Valeski, the schools superintendent, said that the district would spend $434,000 on the initiative, a small increase in a budget that exceeds $150 million.\n\n\u201cThey were saddened to make this decision but they knew it was the right decision to make,\u201d he said about the school board.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. But after consulting with police officials and others, the township came up with its proposal.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m just hoping that it\u2019s a deterrent,\u201d Mr. Cohen said. \u201cWhat angers me is the negative people out there who say you\u2019re arming schools, you\u2019re going to create a hostile working environment for students. I\u2019m sorry, if someone is murdered in the schools, they\u2019re going to be scarred for the rest of their lives.\u201d\n\nEast Brunswick\u2019s move comes as other schools contemplate additional security. Around the country, more than 42 percent of schools now have school resource officers, law enforcement officers who have arrest authority and have specialized training, according to a 2017 report from the National Center for Education Statistics.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPatrick Kissane, executive director of the New Jersey Association of School Resource Officers, praised East Brunswick\u2019s decision, but said that it was crucial that the police officers be able to work with teenagers.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re there as a mentor, as a role model, they\u2019re building relationships,\u201d said Mr. Kissane, who is also deputy chief of the Fort Lee Police Department.\n\nIn East Brunswick, Frank Tornabene, 50, was waiting after school in his BMW convertible for his son, a fourth-grader, outside Central Elementary School.\n\nLike most people interviewed, he praised the new policy, saying \u201cit\u2019s about time. You can\u2019t put a price on anything that has to do with the safety of kids.\u201d\n\nBut he also worried about whether things would truly be safer, in the long run.\n\n\u201cI hope it\u2019s not just gung ho in the beginning and things dwindle down,\u201d he said.", "title": "Armed Officers Will Patrol New Jersey Town\u2019s Schools", "authors": ["David W. Chen", "Ethan Sterenfeld"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTrump Suggests Armed Teachers Get \u2018Bit of Bonus\u2019 \u201d (front page, Feb. 23):\n\nPresident Trump urges that teachers be armed with weapons in school settings. I am outraged by the suggestion, and the cavalier, contemptuous disrespect for some of the most noble professional citizens in our society.\n\nTeachers are required to have graduate degrees in most states; they go through rigorous programs in philosophy of education, psychology and the content of a variety of academic disciplines. There is no place in the teacher education curriculum for Marksmanship 101.\n\nThis suggestion shows ignorance of educators and of public education. American teachers do sacred work, are underpaid and are under frequent political attack.\n\nEnvisioning teachers as an armed militia, as a corps of guards with military discipline ready to do effective battle, is not reassuring. It is a fantasy masquerading as a solution.", "title": "Opinion | Arming Teachers? The Idea Gets an F", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWHEN THEY CALL YOU A TERRORIST\n\nA Black Lives Matter Memoir\n\nBy Patrisse Khan-Cullors and asha bandele\n\n257 pp. St. Martin\u2019s Press. $24.99.\n\nPhoto\n\nPick a social justice campaign from the last few years \u2014 Black Lives Matter, #MeToo or Fight for $15 \u2014 and notice that behind it stand black women, whose physical and emotional labor helped lay roots and build movements now largely considered socially acceptable or \u201cwoke.\u201d Not too long ago these individuals could expect only obscurity and misattribution, but the United States is having a moment that includes the rehabilitation of black women\u2019s public image. Nevertheless, the conditions of this uplift are murky, and at times depend on generalizations \u2014 like \u201cmules of the world\u201d and \u201cBlack Girl Magic\u201d \u2014 that have eerie historical parallels and leave little room for growth.\n\n\u201cWhen They Call You a Terrorist,\u201d by Patrisse Khan-Cullors, a co-founder of Black Lives Matter, written with asha bandele, a former features editor at Essence, abandons such abstractions for details \u2014 at times one wishes there were even more \u2014 to help readers understand what it means to be a black woman in the United States today.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKhan-Cullors\u2019s memoir begins in Van Nuys, Calif., in \u201ca two-story, tan-colored building where the paint is peeling and where there is a gate that does not close properly and an intercom system that never works.\u201d Her language is poetic even if her childhood wasn\u2019t. Joy comes in the form of family. Her mother is a survivor focused on the well-being of her children; her birth father, Gabriel, whose stints in prison leave him often unable to participate in her life, encourages everyone to \u201cchoose love\u201d; and her older brother Monte, who will later be imprisoned and told he has schizoaffective disorder, has a \u201cginormous heart.\u201d But love cannot save her family from external forces, and Khan-Cullors does her best to contextualize their circumstances. \u201cIn 1986 when I am 3 years old, Ronald Reagan re-energizes the drug war that was started in 1971 by Richard Nixon by further militarizing the police in our communities,\u201d she writes. At 9, she watches officers harass her 11- and 13-year-old brothers. At 12, she is arrested for smoking weed even though students at her suburban school \u201clight up in the bathroom\u201d and \u201cno one gets in trouble.\u201d\n\nPart 2 introduces Khan-Cullors the organizer and activist. Titled \u201cBlack Lives Matter,\u201d these chapters outline her partnership with Alicia Garza and Opal Tometi, the other founders of the network. After the acquittal of George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who fatally shot Trayvon Martin in 2012, Khan-Cullors logged onto Facebook and responded to a post Garza had written. Her message, \u201c#BlackLivesMatter,\u201d catalyzed the now international movement against police violence and racism. But while the title of this section (and the subtitle of the book) promises an insider account, the details of their partnership are sparse, mostly concentrated at the end of one chapter. While Khan-Cullors outlines the reasons for some of Black Lives Matter\u2019s tactics, particularly its emphasis on inclusivity and a decentralized organization, readers won\u2019t find Situation Room-style play-by-plays here.\n\nIn \u201cWhen and Where I Enter,\u201d an influential history of black female activists in the United States, Paula Giddings, a professor of Africana studies at Smith College, wonders about those women \u2014 from Anna Julia Cooper to Ida B. Wells and Mary Church Terrell \u2014 who gave up much of their lives to fighting for justice and liberation. \u201cWho are we when no one yearns for us, or when we are in full possession of our sexuality? Who are we when we are not someone\u2019s mother, or daughter, or sister, or aunt, or church elder, or first black woman to be this or that?\u201d she writes. \u201cWhen They Call You a Terrorist\u201d is the beginning of an answer to these questions. While its importance will not be in doubt, for the significance of Black Lives Matter cannot be overstated, the book\u2019s necessity comes from its other subject. \u201cI am Patrisse Marie Khan-Cullors Brignac,\u201d its author writes in her introduction. And indeed, between the moments spent serving everyone else, the rest of the book \u2014 chronicling her evolving sexual identity, her radical redefinition of love, her relationships and eventually the birth of her child \u2014 uncovers just who she is.", "title": "Arrested at 12, She\u2019s Now an Activist Fighting for Social Justice", "authors": ["Lovia Gyarkye", "Patrisse Khan-Cullors", "Asha Bandele"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "On Tuesday evening, Arsenal suffered another one of those indignities that tend to pockmark its seasons. This time, the humiliation came in the driving rain of South Wales and at the hands of Swansea City: facing a team at the bottom of the Premier League table, Arsenal dominated the game, monopolized possession and then went and lost anyway, 3-1.\n\nFor Arsenal\u2019s fans, these defeats have become wearily familiar in the last decade or so, as Ars\u00e8ne Wenger\u2019s two-decade reign at the club has drifted into a sort of managed decline. They have turned Arsenal into a place hard-wired to treat every disappointment as an existential crisis.\n\nThe reaction, now, is so habitual that it is almost comforting, one of the few fixed points in soccer\u2019s ever-changing landscape. There are the calls for Wenger to abandon \u2014 or be relieved of \u2014 his post with immediate effect. There are the videos, drawn from Arsenal\u2019s compelling YouTube fan channels, of despair and rage, going viral. There are the fuming calls to phone-in programs, the cascade of former players bemoaning a great institution on its knees. Occasionally, when things get really bad, there are light aircraft.", "title": "Arsenal Is in Crisis, but a Signing Changes the Mood", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMuseums have really undergone a cultural revolution,\u201d said Corinne Bouchoux, a former senator who wrote a 2013 report on France\u2019s handling of looted artwork. \u201cWe\u2019ve gone from an era where these paintings were either hidden or forgotten, to one where this history is accepted.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut for the paintings that we are certain were despoiled, the real question is: What is being done to find the descendants?\u201d she said.\n\nAn estimated 100,000 objects in France alone were looted by the Nazis or sold under duress and transferred to Germany \u2014 paintings, but also drawings, sculptures and antiquities. Many had belonged to Jewish families whose homes were raided during the Nazi occupation, or who were forced to sell art to survive or to flee the country.\n\nFrom 1945 to 1949, over 61,000 of those objects were returned to France, and about 45,000 were claimed by their owners. Many of the unclaimed pieces were sold at auction.\n\nBut the French state kept 2,143 of them \u2014 even today, experts say it is unclear how they were chosen. The government placed them in an inventory called the Mus\u00e9es Nationaux R\u00e9cup\u00e9ration, or M.N.R., and entrusted them to museums. The Louvre has 807 such paintings.\n\nA little over 100 looted objects, including about 50 paintings, have been returned to their legitimate owners or their descendants, since the 1950s, after the first wave of restitutions. The French authorities acknowledge the pace is slow.\n\n\u201cIf you just look at the number of restitutions, there is obviously still a lot to do,\u201d said Thierry Bajou, a curator at the Culture Ministry who works with a small team to identify the origins of looted art by combing through museum collections and archives, and by looking for markings, notes or labels on the backs of paintings.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cFor a long time, the administration merely waited for the beneficiaries to claim a given work of art,\u201d he said. \u201cNow, we try to study the origin of the works and to identify who was despoiled at the time.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAuthorities collaborating on that effort include museums, the Culture and Foreign Ministries and the Commission for the Compensation of Victims of Spoliation, which was established in 1999 to examine reparation claims made by victims of France\u2019s anti-Semitic laws during the war.\n\nIn 2015, the French government also struck a deal with a national organization of genealogists to help track down the heirs of despoiled families.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut French officials say the work is filled with obstacles, including the refusal of some art galleries to open their wartime archives. While some families saw their possessions looted by the Nazis, others were forced to sell their paintings, meaning the initial transaction can appear legitimate and can involve multiple intermediaries.\n\n\u201cWe have a responsibility to give the right painting to the right person,\u201d said Vincent Delieuvin, a curator at the Louvre who oversees looted or force-sold paintings. He said that museums did their best to retrace the history of their paintings, but that in many cases only families could provide proof that one was theirs.\n\nAn official catalog of the M.N.R. inventory was published in 2004, and a detailed online database is kept, named after Rose Valland, the French Resistance operative who kept a ledger of Nazi thefts.\n\nCurators at the Louvre say the new exhibition rooms are another step in the effort to make information about looted artworks more accessible to the public, and to the victims or their heirs.\n\nSome experts praised the idea \u2014 Ms. Bouchoux, the former senator, said it was \u201csymbolically and politically positive\u201d \u2014 but others said the exhibition rooms lacked context and failed to lay out the complex history that had left the paintings orphaned.\n\nEmmanuelle Polack, an art historian who did her doctoral thesis on the Parisian art market under Nazi occupation, noted that the explanatory text in the exhibition rooms did not say that most of the looted artwork belonged to Jewish families.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNor do the plaques beneath the paintings explain where and how each one was found in Germany, like the 19th-century portrait of two sisters by Jacques Augustin Pajou that was taken by the Nazi regime\u2019s foreign minister, Joachim von Ribbentrop.\n\nMr. Allard, the Louvre curator, acknowledged that the plaques and an existing sign were \u201cinsufficient,\u201d but said the museum planned to put up a larger banner at the entrance to the rooms. He also said the Louvre would look into ways of encouraging visitors to use their smartphones to search the Rose-Valland database.\n\nStill, Ms. Polack said the Louvre had missed an opportunity to create an interactive or educational space that visitors might seek out, rather than accidentally stumble on it while in search of the \u201cMona Lisa.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhat is interesting is their history, the fact that they belonged to people, that they were taken to Germany and then returned,\u201d Ms. Polack said of the paintings. Their special interest, she added, is not in their aesthetic qualities.\n\n\u201cThey are removed from their historical context, and so you can\u2019t understand the enduring necessity of returning them,\u201d she said. \u201cThey were witness to a story \u2014 tell us that story!\u201d", "title": "Art Looted by Nazis Gets a New Space at the Louvre. But Is It Really Home?", "authors": ["Aurelien Breeden"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to new art shows \u2014 and some that will be closing soon.\n\n\u2018THE BEAUTIFUL BRAIN: THE DRAWINGS OF SANTIAGO RAM\u00d3N Y CAJAL\u2019 at Grey Art Gallery (through March 31). The first United States museum exhibition devoted to the scientific illustrations of this Spanish giant of neuroscience is among the new year\u2019s best. Its 80 freehand renderings of different brain cells, as viewed through a microscope, helped prove that they are unconnected, communicating across tiny gaps called synaptic clefts, which earned Cajal a Nobel Prize in 1906. His exquisite images, still used in textbooks, ignite synaptic charges throughout 20th-century art, from Surrealism onward. (Roberta Smith)\n\n212-998-6780, greyartgallery.nyu.edu\n\n\u2018BIRDS OF A FEATHER: JOSEPH CORNELL\u2019S HOMAGE TO JUAN GRIS\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through April 15). This small, hyper-specialized, stunning exhibition brings together a grand total of only 13 works \u2014 a dozen shadow boxes by Joseph Cornell, the Queens-based assemblage artist, and the Cubist masterwork that he cited as their direct inspiration, Gris\u2019s \u201cMan at the Caf\u00e9\u201d (1914). It might seem like a surprising obsession for Cornell, who was not a painter nor a Frenchman. He and Gris never met. But Cornell was deeply moved by Gris, the overlooked, tag-along third wheel in the Cubist movement that also included Picasso and Braque, and the show succeeds in tracking the fluttery ways of artistic inspiration. (Deborah Solomon)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018THE FACE OF DYNASTY: ROYAL CRESTS FROM WESTERN CAMEROON\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Sept. 3). Upstairs, the Michelangelos continue to knock \u2019em dead; downstairs, in the African wing, a show of just four commanding wooden crowns constitutes a blockbuster of its own. These massive wooden crests \u2014 in the form of stylized human faces with vast vertical brows \u2014 served as markers of royal power among the Bamileke peoples of the Cameroonian grasslands, and the Met\u2019s recent acquisition of an 18th-century specimen is joined here by three later examples, each featuring sharply protruding cheeks, broadly smiling mouths and brows incised with involute geometric patterns. Ritual objects like these were decisive for the development of Western modernist painting, and a Cameroonian crest was even shown at MoMA in the 1930s, as a \u201csculpture\u201d divorced from ethnography. But these crests had legal and diplomatic significance as well as aesthetic appeal, and their anonymous African creators had a political understanding of art not so far from our own. (Jason Farago)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018MILLENNIUM: LOWER MANHATTAN IN THE 1990S\u2019 at the Skyscraper Museum (through April). This plucky Battery Park institution transports us back to the years of Rudy Giuliani, Lauryn Hill and 128-kilobit modems to reveal the enduring urban legacy of a decade bookended by recession and terror. In the wake of the 1987 stock market crash, landlords in the financial district rezoned their old skyscrapers for residential occupancy, and more than 20 towers were declared landmarks, including the ornate Standard Oil building at 26 Broadway and the home of Delmonico\u2019s at 56 Beaver Street. Battery Park City flowered; yuppies priced out of TriBeCa came down to Wall Street; a new Guggenheim, designed by a fresh-from-Bilbao Frank Gehry, nearly arose by South Street Seaport. From this distance, the 1990s can seem almost like a golden age, not least given that, 16 years after Sept. 11, construction at the underwhelming new World Trade Center is still not finished. (Farago)\n\nskyscraper.org", "title": "Art and Museums in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018THE FACE OF DYNASTY: ROYAL CRESTS FROM WESTERN CAMEROON\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Sept. 3). Upstairs, the Michelangelos continue to knock \u2018em dead; downstairs, in the African wing, a show of just four commanding wooden crowns constitutes a blockbuster of its own. These massive wooden crests \u2014 in the form of stylized human faces with vast vertical brows \u2014 served as markers of royal power among the Bamileke peoples of the Cameroonian grasslands, and the Met\u2019s recent acquisition of an 18th-century specimen is joined here by three later examples, each featuring sharply protruding cheeks, broadly smiling mouths, and brows incised with involute geometric patterns. Ritual objects like these were decisive for the development of western modernist painting, and a Cameroonian crest was even shown at MoMA in the 1930s, as a \u201csculpture\u201d divorced from ethnography. But these crests had legal and diplomatic significance as well as aesthetic appeal, and their anonymous African creators had a political understanding of art not so far from our own. (Farago)\n\n\u2018MILLENNIUM: LOWER MANHATTAN IN THE 1990S\u2019 at the Skyscraper Museum (through April). This plucky Battery Park institution transports us back to the years of Rudy Giuliani, Lauryn Hill and 128-kilobit modems to reveal the enduring urban legacy of a decade bookended by recession and terror. In the wake of the 1987 stock-market crash, landlords in the financial district rezoned their old skyscrapers for residential occupancy, and more than 20 towers were landmarked, including the ornate Standard Oil building at 26 Broadway and the home of Delmonico\u2019s at 56 Beaver Street. Battery Park City flowered; yuppies priced out of TriBeCa came down to Wall Street; a new Guggenheim, designed by a fresh-out-of-Bilbao Frank Gehry, nearly arose by South Street Seaport. From this distance the 1990s can seem almost like a golden age, not least given that, 16 years after 9/11, construction at the underwhelming new World Trade Center is still not finished. (Farago)\n\nskyscraper.org\n\n\u2018MICHELANGELO: DIVINE DRAFTSMAN AND DESIGNER\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Feb. 12). A monument to a monument. With 133 drawings by the beyond-famous artist on loan from some 50 front-rank collections, this show is a curatorial coup and an art historical tour de force: a panoptic view of a titanic career as recorded in the most fragile of media: paper, chalk and ink. And it demands that you be fully present. Drawing is more than a graphic experience; it\u2019s a textural one, about the pressure of crayon and pen on a page; the subliminal fade and focus of lines; the weave and shadow-creating swells of surfaces. These are effects that can\u2019t be captured by a smartphone. (Holland Cotter)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018SCENES FROM THE COLLECTION\u2019 at the Jewish Museum. After a surgical renovation to its grand pile on Fifth Avenue, the Jewish Museum has reopened its third-floor galleries with a rethought and refreshed display of its permanent collection, which intermingles modern and contemporary art, by Jews and gentiles alike \u2014 Mark Rothko, Lee Krasner, Nan Goldin, Cindy Sherman, and the excellent young Nigerian draftswoman Ruby Onyinyechi Amanze \u2014 with 4,000 years of Judaica. The works are shown in a nimble, non-chronological suite of galleries, and some of its century-spanning juxtapositions are bracing; others feel reductive, even dilletantish. But always, the Jewish Museum conceives of art and religion as interlocking elements of a story of civilization, commendably open to new influences and new interpretations. (Farago)\n\n212-423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org\n\n\n\n\u2018THE VIETNAM WAR: 1945-1975\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through April 22). In contrast to the PBS series \u201cThe Vietnam War,\u201d this jammed exhibition delivers historical data, a lot of it, quick-and-dirty, through labels, film clips, audio bytes and objects, some of which fall under a broad definition of art. Along with paintings by contemporary Vietnamese artists, there\u2019s graffiti-style drawing on combat helmets and Zippo lighters, and period design in album covers and protest posters. Words and images work together in murals labeled \u201cHome Front\u201d and \u201cWar Front\u201d that put you in the middle of the war\u2019s primary issues and events. (Cotter)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org", "title": "Art and Museums in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "In 1959, he served on a Navy team that monitored the heart rhythms of one of two monkeys that were sent into space and then safely returned after a 16-minute flight. The monkey, a female named Baker, survived for years. (An Army monkey named Able died in surgery four days later.)\n\n\u201cOur successful experience with monkey Baker set the stage for the human astronaut spaceflight program,\u201d Dr. Moss wrote.\n\nIn 1970, when he was a cardiologist at the University of Rochester Medical Center, a woman in her 40s was referred to him because she had mysteriously been fainting, once while bowling.\n\nAfter diagnosing a malfunction in the heart\u2019s electrical system called long QT syndrome (LQTS), Dr. Moss helped develop a treatment that blocked signals to her heart from one side of her brain. Electrical impulses from the other side let her heart beat normally.\n\nThe woman, Ruth Pontera, is now 88. The syndrome she survived is inherited; three of her grandchildren were also successfully treated for the condition.\n\nHis work on LQTS led Dr. Moss to create a patient registry in 1979 that identified people with high risk of death from the disorder. The registry allowed researchers to identify risk factors, enabling doctors to make early diagnoses.\n\nThe registry also helped develop alternative regimens that reduced life-threatening episodes by as much as 80 percent. One treatment involved implanting defibrillators to detect an abnormal heart rhythm and correct it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the 1990s, Dr. Moss pioneered the same defibrillator treatment for heart attack patients. He later conducted trials in the combined use of defibrillators and cardiac resynchronization to improve the heart\u2019s ability to pump blood.\n\n\u201cArthur was a man of absolute integrity, both of science and of character, and an amazing visionary who could see where the field of electrophysiology was headed long before others,\u201d Dr. Wojciech Zareba, director of the Heart Research Follow-up Program at the University of Rochester Medical School, said in a statement.\n\nArthur Jay Moss was born on June 21, 1931, in White Plains to Abraham Moss, a millinery store owner, and the former Ida Bank.\n\nHe graduated from Yale University in 1953 and from Harvard Medical School. He joined the faculty of the University of Rochester Medical Center in 1966. When he died, he was a distinguished professor of cardiology there.\n\nIn 2008, Dr. Moss received the Glorney-Raisbeck Award in Cardiology from the New York Academy of Medicine in Manhattan.\n\nHe is survived by his wife, the former Joy Folkman; their children, Dr. Deborah R. Moss, an associate professor of pediatrics at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center; Dr. Katherine M. Lowengrub, a psychiatrist and instructor at the Sackler School of Medicine in Tel Aviv; and David A. Moss, a Harvard Business School professor; nine grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren.", "title": "Arthur J. Moss, Who Pioneered Heart Treatments, Dies at 86", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "He resumed his deliveries, giving away the produce on his first trip around the recovering city free of charge.\n\nArthur James Robinson was born in New Orleans on June 8, 1943, the youngest of 14 children. His father, Nathan Robinson, known as Okra Man, delivered fruits and vegetables by wheelbarrow and horse and buggy.\n\nArthur was, naturally, \u201cLil\u2019 Okra\u201d for a time. But after dropping out of school, he moved into other lines of work, running a gas station, traveling as part of the merchant marine and repairing the tires of 18-wheelers. Still, on Sunday afternoons he would bring groceries to some of the elderly people he knew, Ms. Robinson said.\n\n\u201cThen it turned out to be everybody in the neighborhood got used to coming to him,\u201d she said.\n\nSo, some three decades ago, he affixed a metal roof over the bed of his truck and started making the rounds, on his way to becoming a local celebrity.\n\nWhen the truck he was using in 2009 broke down, the owner of a local Ford dealership offered a replacement at a steep discount, and Mr. Robinson\u2019s fans and customers raised the money to pay for it. Dr. Bob painted it again.\n\nIn recent years, Mr. Robinson was the subject of an award-winning documentary titled \u201cMr. Okra\u201d and the main character in a children\u2019s book. His singsong delivery was sampled in a song by the Dave Matthews Band. A recording of his fruit seller\u2019s calls can also be heard on a key chain sold at checkout counters all over the city. And the Louisiana Children\u2019s Museum plans to put a re-creation of his truck on permanent display. (Ms. Robinson is holding on to the actual truck to continue her father\u2019s rounds.)\n\nBesides her, his survivors include six sons and another daughter as well as \u201ca bunch of grandchildren,\u201d Ms. Robinson said.", "title": "Arthur J. Robinson, Known as \u2018Mr. Okra\u2019 to New Orleans, Dies at 74", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "The team behind \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d the film featuring the first black superhero to appear in mainstream comics, is facing allegations by a British-Liberian artist that her work was used without permission in Kendrick Lamar\u2019s just-released music video for \u201cAll the Stars,\u201d a song from the movie\u2019s soundtrack.\n\nOn Saturday, Christopher Robinson, a lawyer for the artist Lina Iris Viktor, sent a letter to Mr. Lamar\u2019s mentor and label head, Anthony Tiffith at Top Dawg Entertainment, alleging a copyright violation of the 24-karat gold, patterned artworks in her series of paintings \u201cConstellations.\u201d Ms. Viktor had been contacted twice by the film\u2019s creators for permission to feature her work, the letter says, but she decided not to participate.\n\n\u201cThe infringement of Ms. Viktor\u2019s rights is willful and egregious,\u201d the letter says, adding that the artist is willing \u201cto discuss a resolution of all her claims, consisting at a minimum of a public apology for the unauthorized use and a license fee.\u201d\n\nIn a telephone interview, Ms. Viktor said, \u201cWhy would they do this? It\u2019s an ethical issue, because what the whole film purports is that it\u2019s about black empowerment, African excellence \u2014 that\u2019s the whole concept of the story. And at the same time they\u2019re stealing from African artists.\u201d", "title": "Artist Says Kendrick Lamar Video for \u2018Black Panther\u2019 Song Stole Her Work", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Housing Authority residents in the audience were asked not to interrupt the proceedings and they frequently waved their hands over their heads in a show of support for pointed questions or comments by Council members. Yet there were occasional outbursts at remarks by the authority officials who testified. \u201cThat\u2019s a lie!\u201d one woman called out. \u201cNo one wants to take responsibility,\u201d said another.\n\nRitchie Torres, the chairman of the Council\u2019s oversight and investigations committee, said that he had obtained data from the Housing Authority showing that during the current heating season, 323,098 residents had gone without heat at some time. That is more than 80 percent of the Housing Authority\u2019s residents.\n\nHousing officials said that those numbers covered the period from Oct. 1 to Jan. 22, and involved 143,000 apartments. The average heat outage lasted 48 hours.\n\n\u201cYou saw a huge increase in the duration of the outages due to the extreme cold spell, which compromised our aging infrastructure,\u201d said Cathy Pennington, the authority\u2019s acting executive vice president for operations.\n\nMr. Torres had several testy exchanges with Ms. Olatoye, who has had strained relations with the Council since it was revealed last year that the authority had failed for years to conduct required lead tests in apartments.\n\n\u201cNycha has a chairperson whose credibility has sustained irreparable damage,\u201d Mr. Torres said. \u201cShe has haplessly presided over a humanitarian crisis.\u201d\n\nHe also seemed to blame the mayor for Nycha\u2019s problems, although not by name. \u201cThe administration and Nycha can rightly fault the federal government for defunding public housing, but it cannot fault the federal government for the people it hires and the people it fails to hold accountable,\u201d Mr. Torres said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn another extraordinary exchange, Mr. Johnson and Mr. Torres clashed with the corporation counsel, Zachary W. Carter, who intervened as they were pressing Ms. Olatoye about a false statement she made to the Council in December regarding the training of lead paint inspectors.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Carter even objected to being sworn in, as other witnesses had been. \u201cI\u2019m not testifying,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m here advising.\u201d But Mr. Torres insisted on swearing him in anyway.\n\nMr. Carter said that Ms. Olatoye was given incorrect information by her staff in December, when she told the Council that the Housing Authority\u2019s lead inspectors had the proper federal certification \u2014 when they did not. He said it was a mistake, and referred to a January letter to Mr. Johnson from Paul Rodriguez, the acting counsel to the mayor, that he said \u201cprovides a fulsome explanation\u201d of the incident.\n\nMr. Johnson retorted: \u201cWe are going to do oversight in a fulsome manner.\u201d\n\nThe presence of Mr. Carter, the city\u2019s lead lawyer, at the hearing was highly unusual and Mr. Johnson and Mr. Torres pressed him to explain why he was there. He said he came because it was an important hearing.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address.
