View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe authority\u2019s heating problems came into sharp relief during a period of extremely cold weather in January, which Ms. Olatoye said was the longest stretch of days with temperatures below freezing in nearly 60 years. Many of the authority\u2019s aged boilers failed and officials scrambled to restore heat.\n\nMr. Torres said that there were 2,395 heat outages in calendar year 2017, compared to 1,360 the previous year. There were 4,112 hot water outages in 2017, compared to 916 in 2016.\n\nThe residents who spoke at the start of the hearing told of sleeping in sweatpants and sweatshirts or getting up in the morning to put on a coat and huddle in front of stoves in frigid apartments.\n\nCarmen Qui\u00f1ones, a tenant leader at the Frederick Douglass Houses in Manhattan, referred to the \u201cdeficit of funds and the surplus of incompetence\u201d at the authority. Calvin Drumgo, a tenant leader at the Breukelen Houses, said, \u201cWe are not refugees, we are not third-class citizens, we will not be treated like savages.\u201d\n\nSeveral Council members questioned Ms. Olatoye and other officials over the authority\u2019s computer systems and its ability to track the heating apparatus at its far-flung real estate. Under questioning by Mr. Johnson, authority officials revealed that maintenance logs for boilers were filled out by hand and the information was not entered into a computerized database, making it difficult to conduct an analysis of the effectiveness of maintenance and the performance of the system.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI would agree that our move toward technology is \u2014 we have a lot more to do,\u201d Ms. Olatoye said.\n\n\u201cThis is madness! This is crazy in 2018!\u201d Mr. Johnson exclaimed. \u201cThis should be fixed immediately.\u201d\n\nThe Council members also forced Ms. Olatoye and other officials to acknowledge the decrease in the number of boiler maintenance workers, to 248 at the end of last year, from 391 in 2013. The workers are paid an average of $49,835 a year and stay on the job for an average of three years, the officials said.\n\nLast week, Mr. de Blasio proposed spending $82 million to install replacement boilers at 10 housing developments, but the money must be approved by the Council.\n\nAt an unrelated news conference at the Police Headquarters to discuss crime statistics, Mr. de Blasio was asked whether people who live in public housing deserve the same standard of living as people in private housing.\n\n\u201cPeople in public housing deserve the very best living standard we can give them with the money we have,\u201d Mr. de Blasio said, stressing the deep financial challenges of the Housing Authority. \u201cDo I think that we in the public sector can achieve everything that a private sector can achieve, with much greater resources in the private sector? No, I don\u2019t have that illusion. Our job is to constantly do better with what we have.\u201d", "title": "As 4 of 5 in Public Housing Lost Heat, a Demand for an Apology Is Unfulfilled", "authors": ["William Neuman"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 You did not have to be a technophobe to worry that the virtual-currency boom of the past year papered over plenty of problems.\n\nThe scale of those problems is starting to become clear as digital tokens have slid more than 50 percent in value from their peaks in early January, with steep drops on Monday pushing the value of Bitcoin specifically below $7,000.\n\nHackers draining funds from online exchanges. Ponzi schemes. Government regulators unable to keep up with the rise of so-called cryptocurrencies. Signs of trouble have appeared at nearly every level of the industry, from the biggest exchanges to the news sites and chat rooms where the investment frenzy has been discussed.\n\nOn Tuesday, the leaders of the two main regulatory agencies in the United States that oversee the technology, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, are to testify before the Senate banking committee about their efforts to police virtual currency markets. In the past two weeks, both have brought major cases, but people in the young industry said regulators had barely made a dent.", "title": "As Bitcoin Bubble Loses Air, Frauds and Flaws Rise to Surface", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "As the political stalemate drags on, and with business leaders issuing ever more urgent alarms about the threats to the economy, growing public doubts are beginning to register in some opinion polls. And opponents of Brexit are quietly cultivating what they see as that rising sentiment in their campaign to soften, if not reverse, the whole process.\n\nThey even picked up support from an unexpected quarter when Nigel Farage, the former U.K. Independence Party leader and the leading proponent of Brexit, recently suggested that there might be a second referendum.\n\nProminent \u201cleavers,\u201d as supporters of Brexit are known, dismiss that possibility out of hand, but it may not be as far-fetched as they would have people believe.\n\nSome time later this year Parliament is likely to face a fateful vote on the actual terms of any agreement Mrs. May can reach with the European Union on Britain\u2019s withdrawal. A defeat in Parliament would prompt a political crisis, very likely topple Mrs. May and possibly prompt a general election. Potentially, that could open the way to a rethink, to new Brexit options, or to a second referendum.\n\nThat is what people like the local Swansea lawmaker, Geraint Davies, from the opposition Labour Party, are banking on. He believes the tide is turning against Brexit in Wales, where a majority opted to quit, although Wales is a big recipient of European development aid, and has several industries that might lose from Brexit.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhat I am sensing is that people who voted Brexit in good faith are now saying, \u2018Hold on, that\u2019s not what I voted for, and I want a final say,\u2019\u201d Mr. Davies said, listing promises made during the 2016 referendum, including one \u2014 later ruled misleading by the country\u2019s statistics authority \u2014 that quitting would free up 350 million pounds a week, or about $486 million, for health spending.\n\n\u201cYou should have the right to look again, and say: \u2018You ordered a steak and you ended up with a bit of chewed up bacon. Do you want to accept that?\u2019\u201d Mr. Davies added, arguing that Britain faces higher inflation and slower growth, and that, far from getting money back, it has offered around 39 billion pounds, or about $54 billion, in divorce payments to the European Union.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Davies and others have also pounced on recent reports that the areas in Wales and central and northern England that voted most strongly for Brexit are set to suffer the greatest economic harm from the rupture.\n\nExperts say they have detected a subtle shift, in Wales and elsewhere. Though few people admit to changing their views, there is growing support for a vote on the terms of any Brexit deal, according to Roger Awan-Scully, a professor of political science in the Wales Governance Center at Cardiff University.\n\n\u201cThere is some change on whether there should be another referendum on the issue,\u201d he said. \u201cWe have seen a move towards the idea of the public having a greater say.\u201d\n\nHard-line supporters (and opponents) of Brexit remain steadfast in their views, but many of the less committed have yet to fully focus on what it will mean and have been turned off by the stream of complex, sometimes contradictory, reports emerging from the tortuous negotiations. \u201cIt\u2019s a bit like the O.J. Simpson trial: It keeps going on and on and people tune out of it,\u201d Mr. Awan-Scully added.\n\nAnd with signs that public opinion is volatile and could be shifting, the political ice is starting to crack.\n\nWhen Tony Blair, a former prime minister, called last month for another plebiscite, Brexit supporters derided him as a pillar of a failed, elitist, pro-European establishment.\n\nBut it was hard to say the same when Mr. Farage suggested there should be another vote. Though Mr. Farage appeared later to retreat on the idea, Arron Banks, a big financial supporter of one of the Leave campaigns, endorsed it as well. For hard-line leave supporters, a referendum is a chance to once and for all kill off the argument to stay, and precipitate a clean break with the bloc.\n\nPro-Europeans, by contrast, would like a plebiscite on the specific terms of any deal negotiated by Mrs. May\u2019s government, with the option to remain in the bloc if voters prefer.\n\nPhoto\n\nSeveral things would have to happen to make that a reality, including a change of government policy and, almost certainly, of prime minister.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome say it is too late to rethink the withdrawal, given that Britain has invoked its two-year exit clause. Others say that to date the shift in British public opinion, if any, is simply not big enough, and that Brexit support remains strong outside the big cities and in many working-class communities.\n\nBut the logic of having a second referendum is compelling. The 2016 vote was a choice between leave and remain, yet was silent on the path that Britain should take thereafter.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the two extremes, these are starkly different prospects. A so-called soft Brexit could keep Britain integrated within the European Union\u2019s economic model and part of its single market and customs union, accepting all its rules, albeit without having a say over them.\n\nA hard Brexit might cut most of those ties, and take the country toward a low regulation, low tax economy \u2014 \u201cEurope\u2019s Singapore\u201d \u2014 for example.\n\nThe problem is that there is no specific democratic mandate for either option, or even for Mrs. May\u2019s preferred (though probably unobtainable) idea of something in between. So any outcome is likely to be contested for years to come.\n\nWithin Mrs. May\u2019s government, the implications of Brexit are causing concern, even as hard-line Brexit supporters step up their campaign for a clean break from the bloc.\n\nFollowing the leak of a government analysis that predicted the British economy would suffer under all of the most likely scenarios, one minister, Phillip Lee, wrote on Twitter that, if the figures were anywhere near right, \u201cthere would be a serious question over whether a government could legitimately lead a country along a path that the evidence and rational consideration indicate would be damaging.\u201d\n\nOne obstacle to another referendum is the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, a lifelong Euroskeptic, who currently rejects the idea \u2014 despite arguing that, unlike Mrs. May, he would negotiate a withdrawal that would protect British jobs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet, if Mrs. May reaches a Brexit deal that takes Britain out of the bloc\u2019s economic structures, Mr. Corbyn would face overwhelming pressure to oppose it, a move that, if successful, could bring down the government.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Davies argues that the Labour Party\u2019s large number of youthful members \u2014 the bedrock of Mr. Corbyn\u2019s support \u2014 are strongly pro-European and want a second referendum.\n\nCalls for a reconsideration of Brexit have come not only from Labour\u2019s centrist lawmakers, but from some of Mr. Corbyn\u2019s allies on the left, like Paul Flynn, a leading Labour member of Parliament from Wales.\n\n\u201cIsn\u2019t it time to rethink this whole nonsense and plan for a second referendum where the nation comes to its senses?\u201d Mr. Flynn recently asked at a parliamentary committee hearing.\n\nLen McCluskey, a union leader and a close ally of Mr. Corbyn, wants Labour to oppose any Brexit deal that Mrs. May puts to Parliament, and has not ruled out supporting another referendum.\n\nOf course, even if there were a second vote, it is far from clear that it would reverse the original verdict. Taking a break in central Swansea, Robert Hughes, a bus driver, said that as far as the Brexit talks are concerned, the public are \u201clike mushrooms \u2014 we are kept in the dark.\u201d\n\nBut he still supports Brexit. \u201cWe had a vote, it\u2019s not best of three. Once it\u2019s run, it\u2019s run,\u201d he said.\n\nBack at the mall in Fforestfach, a spirited debate was going on in the coffee shop between two people whose views encapsulate some of Britain\u2019s divisions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGerard Turley, director of an investment company and a Conservative Party voter, felt the pull of Brexit but concluded that the economic price would be too high.\n\n\u201cWith my heart I wanted to go, but my head said stay,\u201d he said, adding that he feels his decision to remain had been vindicated.\n\nHis wife, Christine Turley, a housewife, said that she voted to quit to stop \u201cpeople in Brussels making our laws,\u201d though she believes that, in fact, it was \u201ctoo complicated a subject\u201d for a straight yes or no vote.\n\n\u201cNow I\u2019m not sure I made the right decision,\u201d she added. \u201cThere is so much doom and gloom about how badly off we will be.\u201d", "title": "As Britain Stumbles Over \u2018Brexit,\u2019 Support Grows for 2nd Vote", "authors": ["Stephen Castle"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 In July, China unveiled a plan to become the world leader in artificial intelligence and create an industry worth $150 billion to its economy by 2030.\n\nTo technologists working on A.I. in the United States, the statement, which was 28 pages long in its English translation, was a direct challenge to America\u2019s lead in arguably the most important tech research to come along in decades. It outlined the Chinese government\u2019s aggressive plan to treat A.I. like the country\u2019s own version of the Apollo 11 lunar mission \u2014 an all-in effort that could stoke national pride and spark agenda-setting technology breakthroughs.\n\nThe manifesto was also remarkably similar to several reports on the future of artificial intelligence released by the Obama administration at the end of 2016.\n\n\u201cIt is remarkable to see how A.I. has emerged as a top priority for the Chinese leadership and how quickly things have been set into motion,\u201d said Elsa Kania, an adjunct fellow at the Center for a New American Security who helped translate the manifesto and follows China\u2019s work on artificial intelligence. \u201cThe U.S. plans and policies released in 2016 were seemingly the impetus for the formulation of China\u2019s national A.I. strategy.\u201d", "title": "As China Marches Forward on A.I., the White House Is Silent", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Chinese officials are showing signs of annoyance, and raising accusations that the United States is interfering in what Beijing considers one of its redline issues. \u201cIt is horrible that the present situation of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will probably be turbulent,\u201d said a commentary earlier this month on Huaxia, a Beijing-controlled news service on Taiwan issues.\n\nSenator James Inhofe of Oklahoma, the second-ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Forces Committee after Senator John McCain of Arizona, is in Taiwan this week, leading a large delegation of House and Senate committee members and staff.\n\nThey have been meeting with President Tsai Ing-wen and her senior ministers, a dialogue likely to offend Beijing officials. In an emailed reply to questions, Senator Inhofe endorsed continued American support for Taiwan, including a bill pending in the Senate that would encourage senior administration officials to visit the island. The bill has already passed the House.\n\n\u201cWith China becoming more aggressive and intent on expanding its influence globally, the United States-Taiwan security relationship is now more important than ever,\u201d the senator said. \u201cBy ensuring they have the ability to defend themselves, Taiwan will continue to be an important part of promoting regional stability.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPresident Trump signed separate legislation in December, bitterly opposed by Beijing, that included a provision encouraging mutual port calls by naval vessels from Taiwan and the United States. The president has long had the authority to order port calls and dispatch senior officials, so both measures are somewhat symbolic but nonetheless irritate China, said Richard C. Bush, a former head of the American Institute in Taiwan, which handles the United States government\u2019s contacts with the island.\n\nTwo events coming up in Taiwan may further annoy Beijing.\n\nOne is a luncheon and meeting in southern Taiwan in early May for a handful of executives from American military contractors and their Taiwanese counterparts. They will discuss a proposal by President Tsai to develop Taiwan\u2019s components industry by selling more parts to military contractors, said Rupert Hammond-Chambers, the president of the United States-Taiwan Business Council, the host of the event.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe development was initially reported by Taiwanese, mainland Chinese and Hong Kong news media as a decision to move a big annual military contracting conference from the United States to Taiwan, potentially triggering a further chasm between Beijing and the United States. But the business council, which has organized the much larger event since its inception 16 years ago, has consistently held it in the United States and plans to keep doing so, Mr. Hammond-Chambers said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe other event that could trigger Sino-American disagreement is expected in mid-June. That is when the American Institute in Taiwan is scheduled to open a new complex of elegantly designed buildings in Taipei, the capital, consolidating operations that are currently scattered among several dilapidated sites around the city. The institute is staffed mainly by State Department employees and local workers.\n\nThere has been no suggestion that President Trump, who skipped the opening of the new American Embassy in London last month, would come to the Taipei event. Instead, the unanswered question is how senior an American official might attend.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe first Bush administration, the Clinton administration and the Obama administration all sent cabinet officials to Taipei at various times. But they chose the United States trade representative, the secretary of transportation and the chief of the Environmental Protection Agency, rather than higher-profile officials like the secretary of state or the secretary of defense.\n\nIn each case, Beijing complained that the visits happened at all. Global Times, a nationalistic, Beijing-controlled newspaper, said earlier this month, \u201cIf any U.S. high-level official pays an official visit to Taiwan, Beijing will treat it as severe provocation and adopt all possible countermeasures, including uniting Taiwan by military force.\u201d\n\nPresident Xi Jinping has put more emphasis than his recent predecessors on China\u2019s goal of eventual political unification of Taiwan with the mainland. During his 205-minute speech last October at the start of the Communist Party\u2019s twice-a-decade national congress, Mr. Xi received his loudest, most enthusiastic applause \u2014 particularly from army generals in uniform among the delegates \u2014 when he declared, \u201cWe will never allow anyone, any organization, or any political party, at any time or in any form, to separate any part of Chinese territory from China.\u201d\n\nMr. Xi conspicuously failed to say, as past Chinese leaders sometimes have, that unification should be achieved by working with the people of Taiwan. But he did say that unification should be peaceful, and he did not mention a previous commitment by Beijing to use armed force should Taiwan ever declare formal independence.\n\nBeijing officials have pursued a more confrontational policy toward Taiwan ever since Ms. Tsai, of the Democratic Progressive Party, was elected president two years ago. Her party has a long history of favoring formal independence for Taiwan, although Ms. Tsai herself is a technocrat who has emphasized trying to strengthen the economy.\n\nBut Beijing officials have been biding their time about confronting Taiwan too publicly this year as they await the results of Taipei\u2019s mayoral election in November. The race is likely to be closely contested by the Nationalist Party, which favors a more cooperative relationship with the mainland, and which Beijing officials are eager to see back in power in Taiwan.", "title": "As China Puts Pressure on Taiwan, Signs of a U.S. Pushback", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMany in legacy media love mass shootings,\u201d Ms. Loesch said, eliciting nods and approving shouts. Addressing the reporters in the room, she said:\u201cYou guys love it. I\u2019m not saying that you love the tragedy, but I am saying that you love the ratings. Crying white mothers are ratings gold.\u201d\n\nThe incendiary dig was not much of a surprise at a conference that attracts a wide spectrum of right-wing groups and news outlets, many of which have honed the provocation of liberals into a fine, and sometimes profitable, art.\n\nStill, some of Ms. Loesch\u2019s other remarks \u2014 reiterating the N.R.A.\u2019s arguments for defending the Second Amendment and calling for more guns in schools \u2014 drew a more tepid reaction from the audience, perhaps a sign of how the national outcry after the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., has become a backdrop for this week\u2019s gathering.\n\nIt was her media attacks that played best, like when she said that she needed a security detail to leave the televised CNN town hall with gun violence survivors where she spoke on Wednesday night.\n\n\u201cThere were people rushing the stage and screaming, \u2018Burn her,\u2019\u201d Ms. Loesch said.\n\nA CNN spokesman said on Thursday that the network\u2019s security personnel accompanied all the town hall speakers, including Ms. Loesch, from the stage, and that Ms. Loesch also had her own private security. The spokesman did not say whether she had been threatened.\n\nAfter Ms. Loesch\u2019s remarks on Thursday, some journalists chafed at the idea that they were exploiting the deaths of children.\n\n\u201cThe point of all of this is to say that people in the media aren\u2019t real human beings with souls and families and feelings, which is disgusting,\u201d Elise Foley, a reporter at HuffPost, wrote on Twitter.", "title": "As Conservatives Gather, Anger at the News Media Runs Deep", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Georgia\u2019s Republican governor, Nathan Deal, said his state\u2019s plan \u201cdoes not take full advantage of the opportunities for flexibility and innovation, nor does it set adequately high expectations for Georgia\u2019s students.\u201d In Wisconsin, Gov. Scott Walker, another Republican, said the state\u2019s plans for improving failing schools amounted to little more than \u201cbureaucratic paperwork\u201d and \u201cdoes little to challenge the status quo.\u201d\n\nIn perhaps the most contentious case, Maryland\u2019s moderate Republican governor, Larry Hogan, is engaged in a bitter battle with the Democrat-controlled Legislature over the state\u2019s education goals, which a spokesman called \u201ca farce.\u201d\n\nAs Maryland was compiling its plan, the Legislature passed a bill to limit strategies championed by the governor that would allow state leaders to implement major changes for persistently low-performing schools. The Legislature was seeking to protect against what lawmakers saw as privatization efforts, such as expanding charter schools and vouchers \u2014 what a teachers union called the \u201cDeVos playbook.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a letter to Ms. DeVos, Mr. Hogan wrote that he could not support his own state\u2019s plan given the \u201cimpossible circumstances\u201d that the Legislature had imposed.\n\n\u201cThe governor\u2019s not going to put his name on something that he doesn\u2019t think actually helps students,\u201d said Douglass V. Mayer, a spokesman for Mr. Hogan. \u201cIt\u2019s frankly disgusting.\u201d\n\nWhile governors\u2019 signatures were not required for approval, Congress went to great lengths to identify the state executives as key stakeholders in the next wave of education reform. Not only did they get their own signature box, but governors were mentioned 23 times in the law, which calls for plans to be assembled with \u201ctimely and meaningful consultation with the governor.\u201d\n\nThe bill was the first to be endorsed by the National Governors Association since the welfare overhaul of 1996. The organization, which has helped governors navigate their new role in the law, said the small group of governors who withheld their signatures illustrates the larger tension around the transfer back to local control.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s such a fundamental shift that it\u2019s actually going as well as it can,\u201d said Anna Davis, the director of government relations at the National Governors Association. \u201cGovernors feel now more accountable. It\u2019s an exciting time.\u201d\n\nFederal Education Department officials said the governors\u2019 protests did not factor into the decisions about whether to approve state plans.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cUnder E.S.S.A., the secretary\u2019s job is to ensure that state plans comply with the law, not to provide her opinion on the state\u2019s approach,\u201d said Liz Hill, a spokeswoman for the Education Department. \u201cShe hopes that these plans will be seen not as a ceiling but as a foundation upon which states can improve education for all students.\u201d\n\nBefore signing the law in December 2015, Mr. Obama called it a \u201cChristmas miracle\u201d because it had achieved the tricky task of allowing state flexibility within a federal framework. It replaced the top-heavy No Child Left Behind Act from the George W. Bush era. That law had become unpopular because of its emphasis on testing and prescriptive mandates, though it is still widely praised for unmasking the nation\u2019s achievement gaps, particularly for black, poor and special education students.\n\nMs. DeVos has drawn criticism from both parties for her department\u2019s approach to the new law, particularly from its chief architects, Senators Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, and Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington. Ms. Murray has criticized Ms. DeVos as a rubber stamp for plans that fail to execute the law\u2019s intent to hold schools accountable for struggling students, even while Mr. Alexander balked at what he saw as the Education Department\u2019s heavy hand in attempting to enforce the new law.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Maryland, the law has become a political football. The heavily Democratic state has a Republican governor, powerful teachers unions and a high-profile, low-performing school district, Baltimore, that holds the bulk of the state\u2019s charter schools.\n\nCiting the new law\u2019s charge for governors to be involved in education planning, Mr. Hogan submitted to the State Board of Education several suggestions for overhauling schools performing in the bottom 5 percent, such as creating separate school districts, expanding charter schools run by private companies and increasing funding for a state voucher program for private schools.\n\nShortly thereafter, a bill emerged in the Maryland General Assembly, the Protect Our Schools Act, that banned every intervention the governor had suggested. The bill also said academic indicators such as test scores could account for no more than 65 percent of a school\u2019s performance rating, among the lowest percentages proposed in the country.\n\nMr. Hogan vetoed the bill, but the Legislature overrode his veto. Mr. Hogan plans to back legislation seeking to reverse the bill\u2019s provisions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Maryland State Education Association, the union that represents most Maryland teachers, was among the major champions of the legislation. Union officials praise the state\u2019s plan as a step in the right direction and away from the \u201ctest-and-punish\u201d culture of No Child Left Behind. Limiting the weight of academic standards reflects the reality that there is more than one way to gauge the success of a school, they said.\n\nCheryl Bost, the vice president of the state union, said it was \u201cunfortunate\u201d that the governor chose not to sign the state plan.\n\n\u201cIt also signals he has prioritized vouchers, takeover districts, for-profit charters over the value of public education in Maryland,\u201d she said.\n\nThe state school board, which includes several appointees of the governor, echoed Mr. Hogan\u2019s concerns about the legislation, which, the board wrote, \u201cdramatically de-prioritizes student achievement.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s understandable why the governor didn\u2019t sign off,\u201d said Andy Smarick, the president of the board. \u201cIf anything, his action helps keep alive the serious debate about how best to serve kids.\u201d\n\nWhile the state plan does call for identifying consistently low-performing schools for \u201ctargeted support,\u201d such as staffing changes and resource reallocation, it is scant on details for what happens if a school fails to improve after a number of years. Green"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "As Mr. Trump hopped from city to city, Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, sought assurances from the United States Embassy in Delhi that it was not helping Mr. Trump. And ethics experts seemed unable to overstate the incongruity of a sitting president\u2019s son drumming up business overseas.\n\n\u201cNothing like this \u2014 no, never,\u201d said Marilyn L. Glynn, who served as general counsel at the Office of Government Ethics during parts of the Clinton and Bush administrations. \u201cUnprecedented, unheard-of.\u201d\n\nThe controversy only grew as word spread that Mr. Trump planned to give a speech in New Delhi on Friday, taking the podium before Prime Minister Narendra Modi speaks. The topic: \u201cReshaping Indo-Pacific Ties: The New Era of Cooperation.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe title sure sounds like something you would hear from a diplomat,\u201d said Joshua White, who worked in the Obama White House as director for South Asian Affairs at the National Security Council. \u201cIt is not illegal, but it would muddy the waters and I think make life rather difficult for those in the United States government who are being measured about how they articulate what the administration\u2019s Indo-Pacific strategy is and will become.\u201d\n\nOn Wednesday, Mr. Menendez said in a letter to the embassy in New Delhi, \u201cGiven the potential to confuse Mr. Trump\u2019s private business visit with having an official governmental purpose, I write to ensure that the U.S. Embassy presence in India will have no role in supporting Mr. Trump or the Trump Organization during his time in India, other than that necessary to provide any security support for the U.S. Secret Service.\u201d\n\nThe embassy said it had no role in the visit other than helping with his security.\n\nIn his comments on the stage in Mumbai on Thursday, Mr. Trump defended his actions, and said his father\u2019s job had actually been bad for business.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t want any kind of conflict of interest,\u201d he said. \u201cWe don\u2019t want anyone to say that we\u2019re taking advantage. From a business perspective, it\u2019s clearly a negative. There will be a time after politics where we will be able to get back into that market.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter the talk was done, many in the audience excitedly rushed the stage to shake his hand before he disappeared.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf India loves the president\u2019s son, he appears to love it back.\n\n\u201cI think there is something about the spirit of the Indian people that is unique here to other parts of the emerging world,\u201d Mr. Trump said in a local television interview earlier in the week. He said, \u201cI don\u2019t want to be glib but you can see the poorest of the poor and there is still a smile on a face.\u201d\n\n\u201cI know some of the most successful people in the world and some of them are the most miserable people in the world,\u201d he added.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
