View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn their years together, Ms. Hicks has helped write pugilistic statements on Mr. Trump\u2019s behalf, including one that delivered a blow to Stephen K. Bannon, the president\u2019s former chief strategist: \u201cSteve pretends to be at war with the media, which he calls the opposition party, yet he spent his time at the White House leaking false information to the media to make himself seem far more important than he was,\u201d that statement read.\n\nDuring the campaign, Ms. Hicks also stepped forward to defend Corey Lewandowski, Mr. Trump\u2019s onetime campaign manager. She said Mr. Lewandowski had \u201cnothing to apologize for\u201d after he grabbed a reporter who later filed battery charges against him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think the president always likes somebody who looks like they\u2019re out of central casting,\u201d Chris Ruddy, the chief executive of Newsmax Media and a friend of the president, said in an interview. \u201cBut he does want people to know what they\u2019re doing. He also puts a high value on loyalty. And she\u2019s been extremely loyal.\u201d\n\nFor the last several months, Ms. Hicks and Mr. Porter have been seen around Washington, attending group dinners together. One person close to Ms. Hicks, who spoke on condition of anonymity out of loyalty to her, said Mr. Porter had made his way into the small circle of people she felt she could trust after several years in an often chaotic work environment.\n\nOn Friday aides throughout the West Wing were still struggling to reconcile Mr. Porter\u2019s accused private behavior with the person they knew at work, according to a senior administration official.\n\nBut in the Oval Office, Ms. Hicks was there as Mr. Trump offered praise and support for Mr. Porter.\n\n\u201cWe absolutely wish him well,\u201d the president said, as Ms. Hicks stood nearby.", "title": "As Other Aides Face Trump\u2019s Ire Over Rob Porter\u2019s Departure, Hope Hicks Is Praised", "authors": ["Katie Rogers"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "They also showed the resignation shared by many A.N.C. supporters: They had lost hope in the party but could not bring themselves to leave it.\n\nMany in Soweto, the black township south of Johannesburg famed for its resistance to apartheid, cannot imagine leaving the party because of the indisputable good it brought to their lives. Maponya Mall itself, built a decade ago, was proof of that.\n\nInside the mall, SUVs from Mazda, Kia and Renault were on display. The storefronts were mostly South African brands and restaurants, but McDonald\u2019s, Burger King, Timberland and Le Coq Sportif, the French manufacturer of sportswear, had also set up shop there.\n\nSnooks Estates, a real estate agent, advertised properties for sale across Soweto, including a two-bedroom ranch-style house with a fitted kitchen, a carport, and a wall and gate, for $82,000.\n\nDipuo Kalodi, 34, a domestic worker, said she had cast ballots for the A.N.C. in every election since the end of apartheid in 1994. Mr. Ramaphosa is \u201cthe same as Zuma,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cThey\u2019ve been together for quite a long time. So what can you expect from that?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI keep thinking it might change, it might change, let me give him some time \u2014 but there\u2019s no change,\u201d she said, adding with a laugh, \u201cI\u2019m a strong fighter.\u201d\n\nLebo Ngema, who came to the mall with her three children, said that the political change \u201creally doesn\u2019t have that much impact on me. No matter what you can do, you can vote, you can speak out, nothing much is going to be done.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBut I guess we\u2019ll see with this new one,\u201d she added.\n\nImmediately after he was sworn in as South Africa\u2019s president on Thursday, Mr. Ramaphosa, who had served as Mr. Zuma\u2019s deputy for more than three years, began trying to change perceptions. Mr. Ramaphosa went for a walk along Cape Town\u2019s waterfront in an exercise of calculated spontaneity.\n\nStartled witnesses took photographs, and Mr. Ramaphosa posed for selfies. The images were shared so widely that the new president went jogging the following morning. The contrast was stark: Mr. Zuma traveled only in motorcades, surrounded by a phalanx of bodyguards.\n\nIn his state of the nation address, Mr. Ramaphosa said that \u201ca new dawn is upon us.\u201d He promised to resurrect the economy and create jobs.\n\n\u201cThis is the year in which we will turn the tide of corruption in our public institutions,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cWe are determined to build a society defined by decency and integrity, that does not tolerate the plunder of public resources, nor the theft by corporate criminals of the hard-earned savings of ordinary people.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA onetime anti-apartheid labor leader, Mr. Ramaphosa went into business in the late 1990s; thanks largely to his ties to the A.N.C., he quickly became one of the richest men on the continent, with a fortune now estimated at $450 million. He returned to politics full time in 2012.\n\nIn December, Mr. Ramaphosa was elected leader of the A.N.C., defeating Mr. Zuma\u2019s preferred candidate. He and his allies then pushed Mr. Zuma to resign from the presidency, though his term did not expire until mid-2019. The A.N.C. was split in two factions.\n\nMr. Ramaphosa eventually prevailed with an argument that spoke to the party\u2019s sense of self-preservation: Getting rid of the unpopular Mr. Zuma as soon as possible would help efforts to rebuild the party before national elections in 2019.\n\nTo many, the back-room deals that ultimately led to Mr. Ramaphosa\u2019s elevation reinforced the belief that a handful of A.N.C. elites had decided the country\u2019s future with little regard for the people.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThey were talking among themselves; there was no information we were receiving,\u201d said John Baloyi, 43, a postal worker. \u201cI was uncertain about the future of our country. I thought maybe there would be violence, and there would be loss of life. I was scared actually.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Ramaphosa, he said, was preferable to his predecessor.\n\n\u201cThat man was a businessmen,\u201d Mr. Baloyi said. \u201cHe understands what he\u2019s talking about.\u201d\n\nTeboho Sephohle, 30, was waiting to open a bank account \u2014 his first \u2014 at the mall. He said he worked odd jobs in the clothing and construction industries.\n\nIn the 2016 municipal elections, Mr. Sephohle said he had volunteered for the local A.N.C. ward leader after he was promised a job. But he was still waiting.\n\n\u201cMaybe we can get jobs or something with Ramaphosa,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019ll wait and see.\u201d\n\nMr. Ramaphosa\u2019s state of the nation address, and the pageantry surrounding the annual speech, also raised eyebrows in Soweto.\n\nA few days after threatening to remove Mr. Zuma through a humiliating no-confidence vote in Parliament, Mr. Ramaphosa thanked Mr. Zuma for his service \u201cduring which the country made significant progress in several areas of development.\u201d\n\nIn South Africa, the state of the nation address has become an extravagant annual party for the governing class, a mixture of politics and entertainment. The evening starts as officials walk into Parliament on a red carpet where they pose for the cameras and answer questions about their designer clothes.\n\nParliament officials said that about $370,000 was budgeted for this year\u2019s address, though opposition officials have said that the real cost was nearly three times as much.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re spending a lot of money just on catering, the money that\u2019s supposed to be helping people,\u201d said Nett Phamotse, 45, who is employed as a school maintenance worker.\n\nSome of the dresses worn on the red carpet, he said, were the equivalent of \u201csix months\u2019 salary.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re just doing each other favors,\u201d he said.", "title": "As Ramaphosa Hails a \u2018New Dawn,\u2019 South Africans See More of the Same", "authors": ["Norimitsu Onishi"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPARKLAND, Fla. \u2014 For the latest on the Florida school shooting, read our Thursday live updates.\n\nPARKLAND, Fla. \u2014 One student hit her record button while being led out of the school to safety by sheriff\u2019s deputies. On her way, her cellphone\u2019s shaking camera lens passed over several bodies sprawled on the floor.\n\nIn another cellphone video, several dozen gunshots were audible not far away. \u201cOh my God! Oh my God!\u201d one student shouted.\n\nLike many school districts, Broward County\u2019s allows high school students to bring cellphones to school, so long as they don\u2019t interfere with class work. On Wednesday, many students at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School held onto their phones for dear life as a 19-year-old gunman, Nikolas Cruz, stalked the grounds and fatally shot 17 people. They used them to keep their terrified parents informed about what was happening. And they used them to keep a visual record of an awful crime.\n\nSarah Crescitelli, a freshman, was in drama class rehearsing for a coming run of the musical \u201cYo, Vikings,\u201d when gunshots rang out.\n\nHiding in a sweltering storage room with about 40 other students, she typed out a text message to her mother, Stacy, for what she thought might be the last time.\n\n\u201cIf I don\u2019t make it,\u201d she wrote, \u201cI love you and I appreciate everything you did for me.\u201d\n\nSome of the alarming videos of the mass shooting were passed around via text message, while others quickly made their way to Twitter, where they triggered \u201csensitive material\u201d warnings.\n\nOne video showed officers with guns drawn, rushing into a classroom full of cowering students. The officers told students to put up their hands. One officer bellowed: \u201cPut your phones away! Put your phones away!\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Safest Community in the County\u201d\n\nParkland is the type of community where affluent young parents move to find verdant parks and pristine sidewalks for their children. Most everybody knows somebody at Stoneman Douglas High, home of the Eagles.\n\nA famous alumnus of M.S.D., as the school is widely known, is Anthony Rizzo, who plays first base for the Chicago Cubs. Sheriff Scott Israel, who was briefing journalists on the tragedy inside the school, has triplets who graduated from M.S.D. and played football and lacrosse and ran track there. Sheriff Israel said one of his deputies had learned that his son had been injured in the attack.\n\nState Representative Jared Moskowitz, who graduated from M.S.D. in 1999, sends his 4-year-old to a preschool down the street.\n\nThe high school, with more than 3,000 students, is almost a city within a city, with airy breezeways and an open courtyard. It bears the name of Stoneman Douglas, the famed environmentalist who crusaded against paving over the Everglades.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s surreal,\u201d Mr. Moskowitz said. \u201cPeople don\u2019t come to Parkland to open a business. They come to Parkland to raise a family. They come to Parkland to send their child to an A-rated school. They come to Parkland to live in the safest community in the county.\u201d\n\nA Day That Began With \u201cLife\u201d\n\nEvery morning at Stoneman Douglas High begins with an affirmation, which is read over the intercom. On Wednesday morning, the affirmation began with the word life.\n\n\u201cLife supports me in every way possible\u201d were the first words students heard that day.\n\nThe announcement went on to speak of Valentine\u2019s Day, and how everyone \u201cdeserves a safe and healthy relationship.\u201d\n\nThe Astronomy Club announced that it was celebrating Black History Month on Thursday night with a showing of the movie \u201cHidden Figures.\u201d But that event was postponed, as Stoneman Douglas canceled all school events and called in grief counselors.\n\nThe Drill That Wasn\u2019t\n\nMelissa Falkowski was teaching a journalism class when the fire alarm went off at about 2:30 p.m. It had been activated shortly before the shots began, perhaps an effort by the gunman to sow confusion.\n\nAnd it was the second time the alarm went off Wednesday, after a fire alarm earlier in the day.\n\n\u201cEveryone is annoyed because we\u2019d already had one today,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s unusual but it\u2019s not unheard-of, because sometimes someone in culinary burns something and it might go off three times in a day.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Breaking News Emails Sign up to receive an email from The New York Times as soon as important news breaks around the world. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere also had been a drill a few weeks before: an active-shooter drill, the kind many schools now do.\n\nDutifully, Ms. Falkowski followed the fire drill protocol and filed her students out of the classroom to their appointed gathering spot. One of the school\u2019s security officers told her: \u201cNo, it\u2019s a code red. Go back.\u201d\n\nIn geometry class, Gabriella Figueroa, 16, a junior, had been working on angle bisectors when the alarm sounded. As she neared the exit doors, she heard the first gunshots and ran back to class. \u201cI was shaking and praying and saying, \u2018God, please get me out of here,\u2019\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Falkowski took 20 students into a closet reserved for photo gear. Some of the students began to sob, but most stayed quiet, texting in the dark. It got so hot that they had to crack the door open periodically to get enough air.\n\nFinally, after 35 minutes, they heard noises inside the classroom, and then a voice: \u201cThis is the police. Is anyone in here?\u201d\n\nThe shooting had happened in a different building. None of them had heard gunfire.\n\nMost of the 17 children and adults who died remained unidentified by the authorities as of Wednesday night. One of the complications, the sheriff said, was that the students\u2019 identifications were still in their backpacks, which they had left behind in the havoc.", "title": "As Shots Ring Out, a Student Texts: \u2018If I Don\u2019t Make It, I Love You\u2019", "authors": ["Audra D. S. Burch", "Patricia Mazzei"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Such proposals reflect a \u201cvery American\u201d view \u2014 that only those who are severely disabled or struck by tragedy deserve government assistance, and that anyone else who gets it is shirking, said Mark Rank, a professor of social work at Washington University in St. Louis.\n\n\u201cOur social safety net is, in general, the weakest of any of the Western industrialized countries because we have these kinds of views,\u201d Mr. Rank said.\n\nDifferent Paths\n\nThe Affordable Care Act was supposed to help, and did, but not for those who earn too much to get financial assistance but are still on a tight budget. About 25,000 New Hampshire residents paid full freight for Obamacare plans last year, according to a legislative report, and their premiums increased by an average 52 percent this year. This group earns more than four times the poverty level \u2014 for a family of three, like the Hurds, that\u2019s about $82,000 a year.\n\nAnother 29,000 were getting subsidized coverage through the Affordable Care Act marketplace, and many of them have seen their out-of-pocket costs drop this year. That is because when Mr. Trump forced premiums higher by cutting off a type of payment to insurers last fall that the law had guaranteed them, subsidies rose, too. About 53,000 are getting free Medicaid coverage through the health law\u2019s optional expansion of the program.\n\nMs. Hurd remembers watching a documentary about people signing up for Obamacare coverage last year and bristling when someone who got a big subsidy gushed about the low price.\n\n\u201cI was like, \u2018It\u2019s not expensive for you because everybody else is paying for it,\u2019\u201d she said.\n\nShe also has problems with the Medicaid \u201cexpansion population,\u201d made up of working-age adults who have no disability \u2014 particularly those who aren\u2019t working as hard as she and her husband are. Cut off from the help Obamacare provided to everyone under a certain income level, as well as the contributions that employers make toward their employees\u2019 health coverage, she was caught in what she saw as an unduly penalized subset.", "title": "As Some Got Free Health Care, Gwen Got Squeezed: An Obamacare Dilemma", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "CAIRO \u2014 When it comes to securing a second term in power, Egypt\u2019s president is leaving little to chance.\n\nPotential rivals in the March election have been sidelined, jailed or threatened with prosecution. The news media is largely in his pocket. On polling day, Egyptians will have a choice between President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and one of his most ardent supporters \u2014 an obscure politician drafted at the 11th hour to avoid the embarrassment of a one-horse race.\n\nAs he cruises toward victory, Mr. Sisi need not worry either about foreign censure: President Trump has hailed the Egyptian leader as a \u201cfantastic guy,\u201d and most other Western leaders have been largely silent.\n\nAcross the world, autocratic leaders are engaging in increasingly brazen behavior \u2014 rigging votes, muzzling the press and persecuting opponents \u2014 as they dispense with even a fig leaf of democratic practice once offered to placate the United States or gain international legitimacy.", "title": "As Strongmen Steamroll Their Opponents, U.S. Is Silent", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "A Dwindling Sense of Urgency\n\nSo risky is the security situation in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, that the United States embassy has been temporarily relocated across the border in Tunisia. In late May, at a dinner party at the American ambassador\u2019s residence there, General Waldhauser was grilled by the attendees on the Trump administration\u2019s lack of a coherent Libya policy. He had no real answers, one American guest said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump, in fact, had supported intervening in Libya before he took to the campaign trail and began calling the military operation a \u201cdisaster\u201d that left the nation in \u201cruins.\u201d\n\nThere appeared to be some sense of urgency early on. American officials working out of the Libya Embassy in Tunis said they had been assured that Defense Secretary Jim Mattis would make Libya a top priority, several officials said in interviews. And then there were the warnings from some of Mr. Trump\u2019s top military advisers, including General Waldhauser\u2019s testimony to the Senate Armed Services Committee.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s lack of sustained attention caused consternation in some quarters not just because of the terrorism threat but also because Libya remained a primary transit route for refugees and human traffickers.\n\n\u201cYou had this country that was the topic of a lot of campaign rhetoric, and at the same time those of us who had been working on Libya issues in government felt an urgency to build pockets of stability,\u201d said Joshua A. Geltzer, a former senior counterterrorism official at the National Security Council under Presidents Obama and Trump. \u201cBut over the past year, I haven\u2019t seen much momentum to do that.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nLast spring, two months after General Waldhauser testified on Capitol Hill, a suicide bomber detonated a shrapnel-laden explosive device during a concert in Manchester, England, killing 22 people and injuring 250 others. The bomber was of Libyan descent and had recently traveled to Libya to meet with an Islamic State commander.\n\nBy early summer, there were ominous signs that the Islamic State was recovering from a B-2 bomber attack that, according to the Pentagon, killed more than 80 militants at a Libyan training camp just days before Mr. Trump took office. Amanda J. Dory, who had just stepped down as the Pentagon\u2019s top Africa policy official, warned that \u201cwe\u2019re seeing some signs\u201d that the Islamic State was further \u201cregrouping in Libya.\u201d\n\nSome aides urged the president to increase the modest number of military advisers in Libya \u2014 roughly two dozen Special Operations soldiers at any given time. But the effort was stymied by Stephen K. Bannon, then Mr. Trump\u2019s chief strategist.\n\nMr. Bannon clashed frequently with Mr. Trump\u2019s national security adviser, Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, who, Mr. Bannon said, kept pushing for more American involvement in a variety of places, including Afghanistan, Syria and Yemen. \u201cEvery day there was a new ask with no overarching strategy,\u201d Mr. Bannon recalled in an interview after leaving the White House but before his recent public break with Mr. Trump over his comments in a book about the administration\u2019s first year. \u201cLibya was what pushed me over the edge.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Bannon was more open to an idea pitched by Erik D. Prince, a founder of the private security firm Blackwater Worldwide whom he had gotten to know when he oversaw the conservative website Breitbart News. Mr. Prince had proposed relying on contractors to tackle Libya\u2019s security problems. It seemed, at least to Libyan officials, that the idea was gaining steam: One said Mr. Prince had approached them about it at a conference in London where he was seen with Sebastian Gorka, a Bannon ally and White House adviser at the time.\n\nHow was sending American troops to Libya in America\u2019s interest? Mr. Bannon wanted to know.\n\nAt a wide-ranging Saturday morning meeting on July 8, Mr. Bannon took his complaints to Mr. Mattis, a retired Marine general. The country was a mess, Mr. Bannon said he told the secretary, and greater American involvement could only backfire.\n\nMr. Mattis listened politely, Mr. Bannon said, but pointed out that Libya, along with parts of Syria and the Philippines, was a critical battlefield in the global fight against the Islamic State. Mr. Bannon responded that if the president was going to be asked to get more deeply involved in Libya, he at least wanted Mr. Trump to have a \u201cstrategic overview of U.S. commitments around the globe, everything from military to trade agreements, so that all these requests could be put in a larger context.\u201d\n\nA three-hour follow-up meeting with the president took place on July 20 at the Pentagon. As Mr. Bannon had hoped, once the National Security Council convened to discuss hot spots around the world where the Pentagon might need to bolster its presence, Libya fell farther down the priority list.\n\nAt least for the moment, Mr. Bannon had won the day.\n\nBut if Mr. Trump\u2019s Libya policy seemed unintelligible to some, the president of another world power had a far clearer vision.\n\nPhoto\n\nOil and Arms\n\nMr. Putin has had Libya in his sights for years. Ever since he became convinced that the United States, and specifically Mrs. Clinton, then the secretary of state, had double-crossed Russia by toppling Colonel Qaddafi in what had been billed as a limited, humanitarian intervention, the Russian president has been working to regain influence there.\n\nBasit Igtet, a Libyan oil entrepreneur married to the Seagram heiress Sara Bronfman, recalled in an interview that, after announcing in 2014 that he would run for prime minister, he was invited to meet privately at a conference in Greece with Vladimir Yakunin, then the head of the state-owned Russian Railways.\n\nDuring the Qaddafi era, Libya signed a deal to have the Russians build a high-speed rail between Benghazi and Tripoli, one segment of an envisioned North African corridor. But the project had stalled after the 2011 intervention and, Mr. Igtet said, Mr. Yakunin pressed him to move it forward if elected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Igtet said Mr. Yakunin seemed \u201cdesperate,\u201d even offering what appeared to be a bribe to restart the project. \u201cThey offered to give me a percentage of the contract as a commission,\u201d he said. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to offend anyone, but I just wanted to leave.\u201d\n\nA spokesman for Mr. Yakunin, Grigory Levchenko, said that while Mr. Yakunin could not comment on specifics of confidential talks, he denied \u201cthe suggestion of any wrongdoing or ethical misconduct related to those discussions.\u201d He added: \u201cMr. Yakunin never offered Mr. Igtet anything that \u2018appeared to be a bribe to restart the project,\u2019 nor did he ever offer Mr. Igtet \u2018a percentage of the contract as a commission.\u2019 These claims are simply false.\u201d\n\nThe same year, the Russians also approached Ibrahim Jathran, a militia leader who controlled Libya\u2019s key oil ports before General Haftar. United States Navy SEALs had recently boarded a North Korean-flagged ship and disrupted a plot by Mr. Jathran to bypass Libya\u2019s government and sell oil directly on the international market.\n\nTwo of Mr. Jathran\u2019s top deputies, who asked that only their first names, Osama and Ahmed, be used, for fear of reprisals, described how the Russians then stepped in with a \u201creally amazing\u201d proposal to help Mr. Jathran sell the oil \u2014 and arm his militia.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Russians, Osama and Ahmed said, would market the crude oil, moving it through Egypt to Russia. Mr. Jathran would be paid in weapons for the first six months, and in cash thereafter.\n\n\u201cThe weapons included everything we have, plus armored cars, antiaircraft missiles, heat-seeking shoulder-held weapons, light weapons and comm gear including Hetra wireless,\u201d Osama said.\n\nBut when the Russians demanded exclusivity, Ahmed and Osama said, their boss balked. Fearing that the Russians could not be trusted, Mr. Jathran, who is now in hiding and could not be reached for comment, walked away from the deal.\n\nThe next year, in 2015, the Russians came back, Ahmed and Osama said. The same weaponry was on the table, but this time they wanted Mr. Jathran to throw his support behind the Russians\u2019 choice for defense minister: Libya\u2019s ambassador to Saudi Arabia at the time.\n\nOfficials in the U.N.-backed Libyan government convinced Mr. Jathran that it would be far more productive to align himself with the West. A meeting was set up between Mr. Jathran and Jonathan Powell, then the British envoy to Libya, after which \u201cIbrahim instructed me to close the file on Russia,\u201d Osama said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen, in September 2016, General Haftar\u2019s Libyan National Army seized the oil terminals from Mr. Jathran\u2019s forces. Ahmed, who served as a commander during the fighting, recalled being stunned by the sophistication of the weapons General Haftar seemed to have acquired overnight.\n\nFast-moving desert vehicles. Self-guided heat-seeking missiles. A newfound ability to launch airstrikes by day and night. Osama and Ahmed, who said he was injured by Russian-made munitions, came to believe that the Russians had begun facilitating arms shipments to General Haftar after their boss turned them down.\n\n\u201cYou could notice the difference, and it definitely tilted the balance,\u201d Ahmed said.\n\nThat assessment, based on anecdotal evidence and informants, was backed up by American and British intelligence reports. A former senior American national security official and a former senior British official said evidence gathered in late 2015 and 2016 indicated that the United Arab Emirates were cooperating with Russia to provide Russian weaponry to General Haftar\u2019s forces with Egypt\u2019s help.\n\nThe British official recalled landing at the airport in Tobruk, controlled by the Haftar-allied Eastern government, in late 2014 or early 2015. A giant Antonov cargo plane was on the runway, and people were unloading crates of what looked like military equipment, he said, adding that the pilot said the mat\u00e9riel was from Belarus.\n\nThe official described the weapons shipments as a way for the Russians to expand their influence, and tweak the United States, without being too deeply involved.\n\nFor its part, Russia has maintained that it is in compliance with a United Nations embargo on transferring weapons into Libya. Only the United Nations-backed government, which General Haftar refuses to recognize, can import weapons, and only with the approval of the United Nations.\n\nTo be sure, Russia\u2019s involvement in Libya pales in comparison to that in Syria, where punishing Russian airpower has been deployed to crush rebel factions fighting to oust Mr. Assad, and Russian and American aircraft are jousting in the eastern skies at cross purposes.\n\nIn Libya, the heavy lifting of providing military support to General Haftar has fallen largely to the United Arab Emirates and Egypt, which are engaged in a proxy war for regional influence with Qatar, which supports Islamic factions in the country that the general has vowed to eradicate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, it wasn\u2019t until after Mr. Trump\u2019s election that the Russians were brazen enough to give General Haftar a full-dress parade aboard their aircraft carrier.\n\nOver the last year, Russian assistance has generally been subtler. Russian military advisers and intelligence officers have regularly gone in and out of General Haftar\u2019s area of control, American intelligence officials said. Other Russian support personnel have provided spare parts, equipment repairs and medical care.\n\nPrivate Russian contractors have guarded factories in Benghazi and provided demining equipment to General Haftar\u2019s troops, the officials said. Russian special forces are using an air base in western Egypt, just over Libya\u2019s border, in an early sign of recent basing agreements between Russia and Egypt.\n\nIn August, General Haftar said he had raised the issue of Russia\u2019s providing military assistance with Russia\u2019s foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov. And last month, Aguila Saleh Issa, the speaker of the Tobruk-based House of Representatives and an ally of General Haftar, told the Russian news agency Sputnik that Russia had in fact provided military training to Haftar\u2019s army.\n\n\u201cPutin is pushing the envelope, and will keep pushing and pushing until he is stopped,\u201d said Gerald M. Feierstein, who was the State Department\u2019s second-ranking diplomat for Middle East policy from 2013 to 2016.\n\nAppearing to hedge his bets on Libya\u2019s political future, Mr. Putin has also reached out to the Government of National Accord, welcoming its prime minister, Mr. Serraj, in addition to General Haftar, to Moscow.\n\nAccording to Western officials, Russia is seeking a political settlement \u2014 a central government favorable to its economic interests, especially on arms contracts, energy deals and a railway project.\n\n\u201cIf they can give the E.U. a black eye along the way, so much the better,\u201d said Frederic Wehrey, a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and author of the forthcoming book \u201cThe Burning Shores: Inside the Battle for the New Libya.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, despite evidence in Syria and elsewhere that Russia and the United States have sharply divergent interests in the region, some senior administration officials have appeared open to the idea that Russia could be part of the solution in Libya.\n\nAri Ben-Menashe, a Canada-based Israeli security consultant who has a contract to lobby on behalf of General Haftar and his ally Mr. Issa, helped arrange the aircraft carrier visit.\n\nHe said he had spoken to several top administration officials and his impression was that they believed Moscow could play a useful role.\n\n\u201cWhere they are, at least my sense is, is that any settlement is a good settlement and they are kind of happy if someone gets that done,\u201d he said. \u201cThey feel the Russians could help.\u201d\n\nPerhaps that explains the reaction of several officials the administration made available for this article. When asked about Russian interference in Libya, a senior State Department official refused to condemn or even comment on it, saying, \u201cThat\u2019s a topic I don\u2019t really want to get into today.\u201d\n\nThat official referred questions to White House national security aides, who also refused to comment. Then, just days ago, another State Department official suggested Russia was being more helpful in \u201cpromoting a stable, unified and prosperous Libya.\u201d\n\nBut at least in some quarters, suspicions linger about Moscow\u2019s intentions. \u201cWe remain concerned, and it should be no surprise Russia is trying to develop relationships in their best interests,\u201d General Waldhauser said in response to questions from The Times.", "title": "As Trump Wavers on Libya, an ISIS Haven, Russia Presses On", "authors": ["Jo Becker", "Eric Schmitt"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Desperate for a strong regional ally in the fight against the Islamic State, both the Trump and Obama administrations eagerly worked with Kurdish forces in Syria, even though allies of those forces were waging an insurgency across the border in Turkey, a NATO ally.\n\nNow, American successes against the Islamic State are threatened by Turkish attacks on the Syrian Kurds. The clash, long feared, could provoke a wider war and a division of Syria into zones of influence. But stopping it would require a diplomatic commitment on all sides that has so far been lacking.\n\nThe confrontation began last week when Turkish forces crossed the border into Syria and attacked Kurdish troops, who control the northwestern town of Afrin. Since then, events have escalated, with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey threatening to take the fight to the Kurdish-controlled town of Manbij, where American Special Operations forces are based. He is also talking about expelling the Kurds and resettling the area with Syrian refugees.\n\nThe Kurds, known as the People\u2019s Protection Units, dominate the Syrian Democratic Forces, an umbrella organization that receives American training, weapons and air support. The Turks consider them terrorists, indistinguishable from the Kurdistan Workers\u2019 Party that has waged a separatist war in Turkey for more than 30 years. While the Syrian group plays down its ties to the organization in Turkey, and there are differences, links do exist. The two groups have common roots, but experts say the Syrian contingent has largely kept a 2012 promise not to provide material support to the Turkish Kurds, who are formally recognized as a terrorist group by the United States and Europe.", "title": "Opinion | As U.S. Allies Clash, the Fight Against ISIS Falters", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 After years of losing money, Uber is inching toward profitability.\n\nUber said it lost $1.1 billion in the last three months of 2017 on revenue of $11.05 billion \u2014 results that reflect a steady improvement in the company\u2019s financial position, with revenues growing and losses narrowing. In the preceding quarter, Uber lost $1.46 billion on revenue of $9.7 billion.\n\nUber disclosed its quarterly results less than a week after it settled a trade secrets lawsuit with Waymo, the self-driving car unit of Google\u2019s parent company, Alphabet. The settlement and Uber\u2019s improving finances indicate that the company is pushing to meet its goal for an initial public offering as soon as next year.\n\nAs a private company, Uber is not obligated to disclose its financial results. It provides a fairly comprehensive earnings statement, but it omits some data that would be revealing, like user growth and a breakdown of the performance of its ride-hailing service versus its food-delivery business.\n\nBased on a financial earnings criteria excluding expenses like stock-based compensation \u2014 a significant portion of how Uber rewards its employees \u2014 the company said it lost $475 million in the fourth quarter compared with a loss of $607 million in the prior three-months period.", "title": "As Uber Eyes I.P.O., Its Losses are Slowing. Their mission is to pivot America\u2019s long-running gun control debate \u2014 which tends to flare up with each mass shooting and then dissipate \u2014 toward meaningful action.\n\n\u201cWe want this to stop. We need this to stop. S. Burch", "Nick Madigan", "Richard Fausset", "Julie Turkewitz"]} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOrban has pioneered a new model of single-party rule that has spread through Eastern Europe, which is unlikely to spread west because civil society, independent institutions and the rule of law is too strong in Western Europe,\u201d said Mr. Ignatieff, who is also a human rights scholar and a former leader of the Liberal Party in Canada. He added, however, that it \u201ccould break the E.U. apart if this conflict between liberal democracy in the West and single-party states in the East can\u2019t be resolved.\u201d\n\nZoltan Kovacs, the Hungarian government spokesman, and the only current official who agreed to speak on the record for this article, defended Mr. Orban\u2019s actions as a determined effort \u201cto get rid of the remnants of communism that are still with us, not only in terms of institutions but in terms of mentality.\u201d\n\nMr. Orban is undeniably popular with many Hungarians, and recent polls show that roughly 50 percent of decided voters support Fidesz. A weak, divided opposition helps him, as does a pliant news media. In a small nation troubled by historical anxieties, he also has positioned himself as a buffer against what he portrays as modern-day threats: such as European Union bureaucrats; or George Soros, the liberal Hungarian-American philanthropist; or, above all, migrants who seek to settle in the country.\n\n\u201cMigration fits into a wider agenda about the protection of the Hungarian people,\u201d said Andras Biro-Nagy, a politics lecturer at Corvinus University of Budapest. \u201cHe\u2019s protecting us from everything.\u201d\n\nTo understand how Mr. Orban has reshaped Hungary, start with the private meetings in 2010. Fidesz had just won national elections by a margin that qualified the party for more than two-thirds of the seats in Parliament, even though it had only won a slim majority of votes. Party leaders had a mandate. But to what extent could they legitimately wield it?\n\nWeeks later, Mr. Orban and his lieutenants began a legislative assault on the Hungarian Constitution, curbing civil society and, to less fanfare, diverting billions of euros in European Union and federal money toward loyal allies.\n\nFirst, he moved simultaneously to curb the Hungarian media and the judiciary. Next came the erosion of the country\u2019s checks and balances, which has helped Mr. Orban share the spoils of power with close friends and important businessmen.", "title": "As West Fears the Rise of Autocrats, Hungary Shows What\u2019s Possible", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "In Chicago, 601W bought the old postal structure in May 2016 from a British investor. Since then, workers have been replacing windows, hauling away debris and preparing to install new building systems inside.\n\nThe redevelopment will turn former mail-processing areas into uncommon office spaces, taking advantage of expansive spaces with 19-foot-high ceilings, said Brian Whiting, president of Telos Group, a Chicago brokerage firm looking for tenants to fill the building. The biggest floor space stretches 285,000 square feet.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very simple,\u201d Mr. Whiting said. \u201cWe\u2019re building a building to attract a younger work force that is calling for more open, collaborative, neighborhood-feeling space.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nAmenities will include a \u201cGatsby-esque\u201d lounge, a big gym and a quiet working area modeled after a university library. The former lobby will serve as the main entrance for office workers.\n\nThe scale of the property, about three city blocks long, will allow for \u201cenvironments that smaller buildings can\u2019t possibly do,\u201d Mr. Whiting added. \u201cIt literally allows us to create an entire neighborhood in the building, or multiple neighborhoods in the building to give people that work community they\u2019re really looking for.\u201d\n\nTwo developers, the Related Companies and Vornado Realty Trust, are making a similar bet on the James A. Farley Building in Manhattan, a building completed in 1913 that features a facade with Corinthian-style columns along one side. Across Eighth Avenue from Pennsylvania Station, the property will be turned into a train hall named after Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, who died in 2003.\n\nAmtrak and the Long Island Rail Road will use the rail capacity that Skanska, the Swedish construction contractor, has been constructing at the site. Vornado and Related will focus on about 588,000 square feet in the building\u2019s second through fifth floors and on bringing in new tenants to retail areas on the first and concourse levels. The Postal Service will retain offices on the third floor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe prospect of converting the upper-floor mail-processing areas into offices made the Farley property stand out, said Andrew Rosen, a senior vice president at Related. Such spaces are rare in New York, he said, but in demand from technology, media and other companies.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s two full city blocks. It\u2019s up to 200,000 square feet on a floor and a really open space with great light\u201d and transportation links, Mr. Rosen said. \u201cYou end up with something that\u2019s very unique.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLovett Commercial, a developer in Houston, plans to turn the former Barbara Jordan Post Office near that city\u2019s downtown into a commercial hub as well. Lovett acquired the property, built in 1962 in the Brutalist style, from the Postal Service in 2015.\n\nThe building is \u201csort of a relic of Houston\u2019s golden age,\u201d said Kirby Liu, director of development at Lovett. \u201cThat\u2019s a heritage we wanted to preserve. It\u2019s an orientation of the past that we want to bring into the future.\u201d\n\nIn a former two-story warehouse on the property, Lovett wants to create spaces for shops, artists and food purveyors on the ground level and office areas geared toward creative companies on the second floor. The old five-story office component is slated for a hotel.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot of quirkiness to the building,\u201d Mr. Liu said. \u201cIt\u2019s something that\u2019s both extremely familiar but also extremely alien to most people in Houston, because most never realized how much stuff was behind the curtain.\u201d\n\nOne example of that: multiple nuclear fallout shelters in the property.\n\nDevelopers have reimagined postal buildings into new uses for years. Completed projects include a prominent building that dates to 1884 in downtown St. Louis and the Old Post Office in Washington, which President Trump\u2019s real estate company leased in 2013 from the General Services Administration and converted into a hotel.\n\nThe Postal Service owned 8,448 properties as of September, according to its 2017 annual report, down about 2 percent from 2011. The post office leases the vast majority of its facilities, a total of 23,184 properties, the annual report said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOver its last seven fiscal years, the agency has sold an average of 32 properties annually, according to its financial statements and reports. Sales can be contentious. In some cases, communities have fought to ensure buildings remain in public hands and open to serve customers. The agency has also faced criticism for selling buildings with historic elements.\n\n\u201cPlaces that have a sense of neighborhood usually don\u2019t like it,\u201d said Steve Hutkins, a New York University professor who operates a website, Save the Post Office, that tracks building dispositions and other agency news.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Postal Service consolidates and sells property to adapt to business and financial circumstances, including falling mail volume, Kimberly Frum, a spokeswoman for the agency, said in an email.\n\n\u201cIn some locations, we have excess capacity,\u201d Ms. Frum wrote. \u201cGiven our financial condition, selling property in these circumstances is a sound business decision.\u201d\n\nBefore any sale, the agency always solicits and considers community input, she added. It also must comply with preservation laws and rules before it can sell historic properties.\n\nNot every postal facility has a second life. The service\u2019s distribution center near downtown Portland, Ore., is slated for demolition under plans by a local economic development agency, Prosper Portland.\n\nThe organization bought the property in 2016, eager to take control of a site that connects several neighborhoods in and near downtown, said Sarah Harpole, a project manager at Prosper Portland.\n\nThe building on the site \u2014 a 400,000-square-foot structure built in 1962 \u2014 is unable to accommodate local priorities, she said, like developing new housing to meet expected population growth in Portland and creating affordable units in a central location.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re looking a high-density development that necessitates that demolition of the building,\u201d Ms. Harpole said. \u201cIt has limited functionality.\u201d", "title": "As Work Space, Old Post Offices Have a Timeless Allure", "authors": ["Micah Maidenberg", "Square Feet"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 A few weeks after Stephen K. Bannon left the White House in August, he was invited to a dinner at the Council on Foreign Relations to discuss American policy toward China. With his unbridled China bashing and dark talk of a looming conflict in the Pacific, Mr. Bannon expected to be roughed up by the group, which included China scholars, writers and veterans from past Republican and Democratic administrations.\n\nMr. Bannon\u2019s hosts were hard on him, but not in the way he expected. Rather than faulting him or his former boss, President Trump, for their hostile approach, they pressed him on why Mr. Trump had not followed through with his tough talk about trade and North Korea. \u201cI walked out of there thinking, \u2018Something has changed with the elite,\u2019\u201d he recalled.\n\nChina\u2019s relentless rise and its more recent embrace of repressive tactics that recall the Mao era \u2014 a process accelerated by President Xi Jinping\u2019s bid to stay in power indefinitely \u2014 have fractured a deeply rooted consensus in Washington about the long-term direction of its relationship with Beijing.\n\nGone is a widespread agreement among diplomats, scholars and businesspeople that China is gradually converging with the United States and, therefore, that Americans should work to manage any flare-ups between the two countries. With China now unabashedly charting its own course \u2014 one that diverges rather than converges with the liberal democracies and market economies of the West \u2014 conflict, many say, is inevitable.", "title": "As Xi Tightens His Grip on China, U.S. Sees Conflict Ahead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Wargo has an unusual background for a principal. She moved to New York City in 2000 to be a visual artist after finishing her master\u2019s degree at Rutgers University. To pay the rent, she worked with nonprofit organizations that sent artists into schools. DreamYard Project was one of them.\n\n\u201cI got to see so many different schools and had to collaborate directly with teachers,\u201d Ms. Wargo said. \u201cI got to see what a well-run classroom looks like, and what a not-well-run classroom looks like.\u201d\n\nWhen DreamYard Project was starting a school, the founders suggested she become its visual arts teacher. She thought she would stay for a year, she said, but loved it. At the end of her second year teaching, her principal asked if she would like to become an assistant principal.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d never thought about it before, but I said yes immediately,\u201d Ms. Wargo said as she sat in her office, where the standard-issue education department desk and computer were augmented by a colorful rug and a purple beanbag chair. She said she did not miss painting \u2014 people ask her all the time \u2014 because running a school requires plenty of creativity.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re taught to really think outside the box when you\u2019re educated in the arts,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd it teaches you to take criticism very well. In grad school in particular, you put your painting on the wall you just get ripped to shreds. So I\u2019m able to listen when people say this is or isn\u2019t working.\u201d\n\nWhen Ms. Wargo took over as principal in the spring of 2012, the young school had yet to find its footing. Just a few months later, DreamYard was designated one of the lowest-performing schools in the state, so Ms. Wargo was not surprised when the de Blasio administration put it into the Renewal program.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs part of Renewal, Ms. Wargo and her staff were trained to use a Harvard University method of analyzing student data. A nonprofit group, Counseling in Schools, began helping to push students to come to school regularly, though attendance remains a challenge. DreamYard and its partner organizations were able to start paying students minimum wage for internships. And crucially, Ms. Wargo said, school was extended by an hour every day. Three days a week, that time is spent on academics. The other two days a week, students experiment with professional and vocational possibilities that interest them, while their teachers work with one another to improve instruction.\n\nOn a recent afternoon during that added hour, a group of students heated noodles on a hot plate in cooking class. Down the hall, six of their classmates sat in a circle discussing how they might sell a sugar scrub to manicure customers. In another room, a music production instructor played two clips of music, one with an additional effect, and asked students if they could hear the difference.\n\nThere has been concern among some educators that the Renewal program might become an albatross for schools. Once they were branded as troubled, would teachers and families avoid them? At DreamYard, enrollment has fallen since the school was placed in the program. But students and teachers say the issue predates Renewal: Families are wary of any school in the Taft building, which has a long and troubled history. Teachers there threatened to walk out in 2002 because the school was so violent, according to the InsideSchools website. In 1997, a Taft teacher was tortured and shot to death in his home, and a former student was convicted of the murder.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhen I was an eighth grader and told people I was going to Taft, people said, \u2018Oh, you\u2019re going to get jumped!\u2019\u201d said Carlos Abreu, a senior theater major who started wearing ties to school every day this year, even though the school has no uniform. \u201cBut it\u2019s not like that at all. If you ever hear someone say don\u2019t go to DreamYard, don\u2019t listen to them.\u201d\n\nOf the 94 schools originally in the Renewal program, the education department has decided to close or merge 32 of them; 21 have made enough progress to graduate into Rise.\n\n\u201cRenewal isn\u2019t a formula,\u201d Ms. Wargo said. \u201cIt isn\u2019t like if you do this and do this and do this, your school will be better \u2014 you\u2019re dealing with real people. A curriculum doesn\u2019t turn around a school, a community does.\u201d\n\nThe big question now for schools like DreamYard is whether they can continue to improve. As a Rise school, not much will change at first. The school will be funded at the same level as when it was in Renewal, and will be able to keep its extra hour per day \u2014 time that, at DreamYard, will cost $170,615 this school year alone. For now, the main differences will be a bit more independence, and things like instructional support will come through regular Education Department channels rather than the Renewal Schools office.\n\n\u201cMy understanding of being a Rise school is that it\u2019s a vote of confidence: You have enough systems and supports in place to maintain improvement,\u201d Mr. Wargo said.\n\n\u201cOur data is what it is; I know we\u2019re not a perfect school,\u201d she added. \u201cThere are a lot of challenges. But we are working hard and I really think the staff is doing a great job. We just want to keep moving.\u201d", "title": "As a School Moves Out of Renewal, Can Its Progress Be Sustained?", "authors": ["Elizabeth A. Harris"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWere the Disney deal to have never happened, I think he would have been close to a new deal with us,\u201d said Ms. Walden, the Fox executive who has worked closely with Mr. Murphy. \u201cIf the Disney move happened a year ago, and the transaction was completed by now and we were part of the Disney Company, I think he would be part of us.\u201d\n\nMr. Murphy declined to comment for this article.\n\nDisney \u2014 a part-owner of Hulu that is building new streaming services under its chief executive, Robert A. Iger \u2014 has repeatedly cited 21st Century Fox\u2019s ability to create popular programming as one of the main reasons it sought to acquire it from Rupert Murdoch. Disney\u2019s own television studio has not been a reliable supplier.\n\nThe day after losing Mr. Murphy to Netflix, John Landgraf, the chief executive of FX, which is part of 21st Century Fox, pointed to his cable network\u2019s long record of producing talent, including Donald Glover (\u201cAtlanta\u201d) and Pamela Adlon (\u201cBetter Things\u201d).\n\n\u201cWith more than 20 scripted original series on our schedule or upcoming, FX has a very successful track record of identifying and developing talented writers who have produced award-winning hit shows, and it will continue to do so,\u201d he said.\n\nThe money aside, Mr. Murphy may have decided that he had a better chance of creating new shows with minimal interference from above at Netflix, rather than at a Disneyfied version of 21st Century Fox. Referring to Disney\u2019s agreement to acquire much of the company at a news media event last month, the producer said: \u201cWhen this deal first went down, I got a call from the Murdochs and I got a call from Mr. Iger. And I said point-blank, you know, the stuff that I do is not specifically Disney, and I\u2019m interested in that and I\u2019m concerned about that.\u201d", "title": "As the Streaming Wars Heat Up, Ryan Murphy Cashes In", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Jahangir was exposed to politics and activism at an early age. Her father, Malik Ghulam Jilani, was a civil servant and a left-wing politician who was frequently jailed for opposing military dictators. Ms. Jahangir initially appeared in court to represent her jailed father.\n\nPhoto\n\nHer first foray into politics was in 1969, when she participated in a women\u2019s march to the residence of the governor of Punjab and clashed with the police. In 1983, she was put under house arrest and later imprisoned when she campaigned for women\u2019s rights and democracy during the rule of Gen. Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq.\n\nIn 2007, Pervez Musharraf, then a general, also put her under house arrest as the country\u2019s lawyers and politicians began a movement to restore democracy.\n\nMs. Jahangir also worked for the rights of bonded laborers, especially brick kiln workers.\n\n\u201cIn bonded labor cases, judges would ask me why I had brought those people to the courts who stank,\u201d she told Herald, a local magazine. \u201c \u2018You are here precisely for them,\u2019 I would respond.\u201d\n\nWhile Ms. Jahangir was respected internationally, she endured bitter criticism from the military and right-wing nationalists. She was attacked for advocating peace with India, and was often accused of being an Indian agent or a traitor.\n\nHer criticism of the country\u2019s military and its intelligence agencies made her a target of campaigns on television and social media.\n\nSome Pakistanis accused her of looking the other way when it came to the corruption of two mainstream political parties, the Pakistan Peoples Party and the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz. They complained that she was single-mindedly focused on criticizing the military.\n\nIn 2012, Ms. Jahangir said that an assassination plot against her had been hatched \u201cat the highest level of the security establishment.\u201d She refused to leave the country despite the threats, however, and told the British newspaper The Telegraph that she would not follow other activists out of the country.\n\nPhoto\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI will not leave,\u201d she said. \u201cMy ancestors are buried here, and my life is here.\u201d\n\nMs. Jahangir is survived by her husband, two daughters, a son, two sisters and a brother.\n\nAn active member of bar politics, she was the first female president of the Pakistan Supreme Court\u2019s Bar Association. Till her death, she spoke out against corruption in the legal community and advocated judicial reform.\n\nShe was critical of the proliferation of suo motu notices \u2014 a legal provision that empowers a judge to start a hearing on virtually any matter. Ms. Jahangir, along with other lawyers and critics of the courts, believed that the justices were overreaching and interfering in the executive sphere.\n\nTo many women in the country, she was an inspiration.\n\n\u201cAsma Jahangir was a voice of the oppressed and an icon of courage and valor,\u201d said Maryam Nawaz Sharif, the daughter and political heir of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif. \u201cShe endured so much but chose to be on the right side of history.\u201d\n\nCritics often questioned her focus on the country\u2019s minorities and on women\u2019s rights. She fended off such criticism as misplaced.\n\n\u201cYes, I am very unhappy, extremely anguished at human rights violations against Kashmiris in India or against Rohingyas in Burma or, for that matter, Christians in Orissa,\u201d Ms. Jahangir told Herald. \u201cBut obviously I am going to be more concerned of violations taking place in my own house because I am closer to the people who I live with. I have more passion for them.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cI think it sounds very hollow if I keep talking about the rights of Kashmiris but do not talk about the rights of a woman in Lahore who is butchered to death.\u201d", "title": "Asma Jahangir, Fearless Pakistani Rights Activist, Dies at 66", "authors": ["Salman Masood"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cGaps Found in Scrutiny of Assisted Living Homes\u201d (news article, Feb. 4):\n\nThe Government Accountability Office\u2019s landmark report on the lack of effective monitoring and quality assurance in assisted living facilities is a wake-up call for all of us in the baby boom generation.\n\nIn recent decades, the assisted living industry has experienced rapid growth by responding to our aging population\u2019s desire to avoid institutional nursing home placement in favor of residential care in a setting that promises safety and monitoring in a more homelike environment.\n\nAs the G.A.O.\u2019s findings indicate, too often providers fail to keep this essential promise. Why? In the absence of meaningful standards and enforcement, vulnerable seniors are susceptible to providers that can prioritize profits over quality with virtual impunity.\n\nWe owe our growing senior population more than \u201cbuyer beware\u201d when their safety and dignity are at stake.", "title": "Opinion | Assisted Living Lapses", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "If so, as the universe grows, it will expand faster and faster and run away from itself. Eventually other galaxies would be flying away so fast that we couldn\u2019t see them. The universe would become dark and cold. The cosmologist Lawrence Krauss of Arizona State once described this as \u201cthe worst possible universe.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf on the other hand, some previously unsuspected force field is tinkering with the galaxies and space-time, the effect could shut off or even reverse over the eons.\n\nOr maybe we just don\u2019t understand gravity.\n\nDark energy, said Frank Wilczek, a Nobel laureate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, \u201cis the most mysterious fact in all of physical science, the fact with the greatest potential to rock the foundations.\u201d\n\nThe astronomers who made this discovery were using the exploding stars known as Type 1a supernovae as cosmic distance markers to track the expansion rate of the universe.\n\nSince then, other tools have emerged by which astronomers can also gauge dark energy by how it retards the growth of galaxies and other structures in the universe.\n\nWay back in 1999, Saul Perlmutter of the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, one of dark energy\u2019s discoverers, proposed a space mission known as SNAP (Supernova Acceleration Probe) to do just that.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2008, NASA and the Energy Department budgeted $600 million, not including launching costs, for a mission and the call went out for proposals. But NASA and the Energy Department found it hard to collaborate and a working group of dark-energy scientists could not come up with a design that would fit in the budget.\n\nIn 2010, a committee of the National Academy of Sciences cobbled together several competing proposals that would do the trick. Paul Schechter, an M.I.T. astronomer involved in the work called it Wfirst, for Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope. The acronym had a double meaning: \u201cW\u201d is the name for a crucial parameter that measures the virulence of dark energy. But the telescope would also search for exoplanets \u2014 planets beyond our solar system.\n\nIn its report, \u201cNew Worlds, New Horizons,\u201d the committee gave this mission the highest priority in space science for the next decade.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut NASA would have no money to start on this project until it finished building the James Webb Space Telescope, the successor to the vaunted Hubble Space Telescope. Shortly after the academy\u2019s deliberations, the space agency admitted that the Webb project had been mismanaged. The telescope, which had been set for a 2014 launching, would require at least another $1.6 billion and several more years to finish. The Webb will search out the first stars and galaxies to have formed in the universe, but is not designed for dark energy. It is now on course to be launched next year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWfirst would have to wait.\n\nTo take up the slack until 2025 \u2014 or whenever the American mission can finally fly \u2014 the space agency bought a share in a European dark-energy mission known as Euclid, now scheduled to launch in 2021. But Euclid is not as comprehensive as Wfirst would be; it will not use supernovas, for example.\n\nThe story took another dramatic twist in June 2012, capturing headlines when the National Reconnaissance Office, which operates spy satellites, offered NASA a leftover telescope, essentially a close relative of the Hubble, that had been designed to look down instead of up.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt had a wide field of view, which could enable inspecting large areas of the heavens for supernovae.\n\nIts primary mirror \u2014 like the Hubble 94 inches in diameter \u2014 is twice as big as the one that was being contemplated for Wfirst, giving it four times the light-gathering power and a deep reach into the cosmos.\n\nThe gift would save them the cost of fashioning a whole new telescope, but it was not without strings. As several astronomers pointed out, using a bigger telescope would mean a bigger, more expensive camera and more complicated back-end optics would have to be built. Nevertheless, the Academy bought into the idea.\n\nLately another controversial element has been added to the mission, a coronagraph, which could be used to block the light from a star so that faint planets near them can be discerned.\n\nLast summer an independent review panel appointed by NASA and led by Fiona Harrison, a professor at the California Institute of Technology, endorsed the mission\u2019s basic science goals and methodology while cautioning against mission creep that could cause its costs to balloon.\n\nThe ball is now in Congress\u2019s court.\n\nMichael Turner, a cosmologist at the University of Chicago, said, \u201cWhile one never wants to hear that someone important has recommended cancellation of your favorite project, I believe that like last year, Congress will be doing the budget writing. I hope and believe that Congress will be wiser.\u201d", "title": "Astronomers\u2019 Dark Energy Hopes Fade to Gray", "authors": ["Dennis Overbye", "Out There"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The turmoil sparked a war of words within the I.O.C.\u2019s usually clubby meeting room ahead of these Games. Richard Pound of Canada, the longest-serving I.O.C. member, warned his fellow members on Tuesday that the organization was in trouble.\n\n\u201cI believe that in the collective mind of a significant portion of the world, and among the athletes of the world, the I.O.C. has not only failed to protect athletes, but has made it possible for cheating athletes to prevail against the clean athletes,\u201d said Pound, the former president of the World Anti-Doping Agency.\n\n\u201cWe talk more than we walk,\u201d Pound added. He said the athletes and the public \u201cno longer have confidence that their interests are being protected. Our commitment to both is in serious doubt. With respect, I don\u2019t think we can talk our way out of this problem.\u201d\n\nPound\u2019s intervention proved unpopular. He was berated by Argentina\u2019s Gerardo Werthein before all but two members \u2014 Pound and Adam Pengilly of Britain \u2014 voted in support of the I.O.C\u2019s handling of the Russian doping affair.\n\nIn his news conference after the two-day meeting, Bach said members \u201ccleared the air\u201d and engaged in \u201clively debate.\u201d\n\nThe organizers of the Paralympics, which will take place here a few weeks after the Olympics conclude, have continued their hard-line approach to Russia. The country has been barred from next month\u2019s Paralympics. Bach has taken a more conciliatory approach, favoring what he calls individual justice over collective punishment, despite describing Russia\u2019s actions as an \u201cunprecedented attack on the integrity of the Olympics.\u201d\n\nSome of the group of 15 Russians who filed appeals Thursday are already in Korea in anticipation of being permitted to compete.", "title": "At 11th Hour, Status of Russian Olympians Remains Uncertain", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "At the entrance to the Armory Show, opening March 8 in New York at Piers 92 and 94, a line of silhouetted figures rising 25 feet on scaffolding will be visible from the West Side Highway. The piece, called \u201cSo Close,\u201d is the work of the French artist JR, known for siting monumental photographic portraits in public spaces around the world to humanize political problems, and it is based on an archival image of immigrants waiting at Ellis Island. Their faces have been superimposed with recent portraits of Syrians photographed by the artist at the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan.\n\n\u201cThis super-scaled line of people is standing at a pier on the waterfront of New York City, a symbolic entry point into the country,\u201d said Jen Mergel, curator of \u201cThe Contingent,\u201d the art fair\u2019s second edition of its \u201cPlatform\u201d section, with 15 site-responsive works installed throughout the two piers. JR\u2019s marquee piece is intended to prompt \u201call who enter to think about issues of access, entry, ease or difficulty therein,\u201d she said, \u201ceven the inconvenience of having to wait, if you\u2019ve ever been to the Armory.\u201d\n\nInspired by the theme of collective assembly or force, \u201cThe Contingent\u201d includes a new installation by Tara Donovan that groups tens of thousands of vertically stacked clear plastic tubes of different lengths in a luminous sea, rippling across the central gathering space in Pier 94. Other new works are by the Bruce High Quality Foundation, Sarah Cain, Beth Campbell, Leonardo Drew, Jeffrey Gibson, Amalia Pica, Alex Schweder and Ward Shelley, Berndnaut Smilde and Wilmer Wilson IV.\n\nFour projects \u2014 by Elmgreen & Dragset, Richard Long, Mary Sibande and Wang Xin \u2014 will be exhibited for the first time in the United States. Ms. Sibande, an artist based in Johannesburg who has never shown in New York, will anchor Pier 92 with \u201cCry Havoc,\u201d a sculpture of a woman in a regal purple dress and waving a white flag, with a pack of red dogs jumping out from around her skirts.", "title": "At Armory Show, Global Art and a JR Installation Will Cover Two Piers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Fanned out on a platter are swirled bouquets of salo (cured fatback), in three varieties: Belarusian, plush and quick to liquid on the tongue; smoked, its flavor shading toward aged Cheddar; and Hungarian, aflutter with paprika. Stalks of green onion, cherry tomatoes and a broken-down head of garlic crowd around, with splendidly fuming potatoes in a skillet alongside. (A more modest, singular helping of salo is accompanied by batons of rye bread as fat as French fries, crisped in butter, rubbed with garlic and tumbled into a cone of newspaper.)\n\nIn borscht, the sweetness of the beets is kept in check by salty nubs of pork and beef. Yellow split pea soup, soothing and mild, lands on the table with a pork rib jutting out, the hilt thoughtfully wrapped in foil and the meat smoke incarnate.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe main courses bring more pork. For machanka, hunks of rib, shoulder and a peasant-style sausage made in-house are left to commune in a pot for hours and presented with draniki or kerchiefs of blini, the better to soak up the stew. Neat bundles of cabbage divulge pork, beef and carrots, gently sweet. A monumental pork knuckle is braised and then baked until the fat wobbles off its flanks, calling to mind a slow avalanche.\n\nThe first Belarussian Xata opened in 2012 in the Basmanny District of Moscow, a few blocks from the Belarusian Embassy. Its Brooklyn outpost followed this past September, taking over a two-story building once home to Cafe Glechik, a Ukrainian spot. Marat Novikov, a businessman from Minsk who brought his family to Brooklyn in 1989, as the Soviet Union was reeling from internal unrest, runs both restaurants with the help of his son, Andrey; his daughter, Olga; and her husband, Steve Palanker, a native of Moldova.\n\nA few recipes come from Mr. Novikov\u2019s mother, like a perfect dessert of little orbs of tangy yogurt cheese, flecked with poppy seeds and simmered in sour cream. Room, too, should be made for sour cherry dumplings in crimson-stained skins and a trompe-l\u2019oeil chocolate salami conjured out of crushed biscuits, cocoa, hazelnuts and prunes.\n\nThis is plenty, to be embraced and shared. A night at Belarussian Xata can feel as though you\u2019ve crashed a dozen parties at once, all in full swing. One night, a group of women lingered for hours in a corner, deep in talk and growly laughter; only around 10 p.m. did their first zakuski arrive. They were in no hurry. They knew the value of time.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. He also admitted that in applying in 2014 for a disability insurance policy, he checked a box stating that he had never been convicted of a felony, even though that was not true.\n\nMr. Howe\u2019s admissions and his revocation of bail would seem to pose a significant midtrial challenge to the government. It also threatens to overshadow some of the trial\u2019s testimony, which to this point has been focused on the behind-the-scenes deal making and name-dropping that prosecutors have said typified Albany for far too long.\n\nMr. Percoco is charged with accepting bribes in return for official actions on behalf of upstate developers; Mr. Howe claims he facilitated the bribes.\n\nBoth knew the sway that the governor\u2019s name held over the other. As federal prosecutors tell it, as Mr. Percoco and Mr. Howe hatched a complicated corruption scheme, both bandied Mr. Cuomo\u2019s name to spur the other to action or to press their own advantages.\n\nMr. Cuomo, a Democrat, has not been accused of any wrongdoing, and he has distanced himself from Mr. Percoco \u2014 the man he had once called his father\u2019s third son \u2014 since his arrest in 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the governor\u2019s omnipresence in the testimony suggests that both men were highly cognizant of the power of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s name, and of how even the suggestion of his approbation could help get the results they wanted.\n\nIn 2013, one of Mr. Howe\u2019s clients, an executive with the energy firm Competitive Power Ventures, was eager to win a state contract. Mr. Howe reached out to Mr. Percoco, asking him to try and ensure the client\u2019s success. (The executive, Peter Galbraith Kelly Jr., is one of Mr. Percoco\u2019s three co-defendants.)\n\nMr. Howe told Mr. Percoco that a competing firm had enlisted \u201csome former Pataki guy\u201d to lobby on its behalf \u2014 an apparent reference to someone with ties to former Gov. George E. Pataki. It was well-known that Mr. Pataki, a Republican, was a persona non grata in the Cuomo world, having unseated the governor\u2019s father, Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, in 1994.\n\nBarry Bohrer, Mr. Percoco\u2019s lawyer, suggested that Mr. Howe had included the Pataki detail to \u201clight a fire\u201d under Mr. Percoco, who was known for his fierce loyalty to the Cuomo family.\n\n\u201cBy invoking the Pataki name, you thought that Joe might see red?\u201d Mr. Bohrer asked Mr. Howe on Thursday.\n\nMr. Howe parried, saying he could not recall the name of the \u201cformer Pataki guy.\u201d But, he acknowledged, \u201cI knew it certainly would \u2014 Joe would look into it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nApparently, he did. \u201cI need that guy\u2019s name right away,\u201d Mr. Percoco replied, according to Mr. Howe.\n\nMr. Cuomo has demurred when asked about the trial since it began last month. At an appearance on Long Island on Thursday, Mr. Cuomo said he had \u201ca great deal of respect for the legal process\u201d and would not comment on continuing testimony.\n\nFor his part, Mr. Percoco used Mr. Cuomo\u2019s name to nudge Mr. Howe to help him find a lucrative job in the private sector.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Howe testified that when he seemed to equivocate on finding Mr. Percoco a position with Whiteman Osterman and Hanna, the Albany-based lobbying firm for which Mr. Howe worked, Mr. Percoco told him that \u201che had gotten approval from the governor himself\u201d to work for the firm.\n\nWhen Mr. Howe suggested that his firm in particular might not be the right fit, Mr. Percoco tried a different tack.\n\n\u201cThe governor said it was O.K. for me to be hired by your clients,\u201d Mr. Howe said Mr. Percoco had told him.\n\nAsked about Mr. Howe\u2019s claims, Richard Azzopardi, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, pointed to a news conference in 2016 in which Mr. Cuomo said that he had known Mr. Percoco might take private consulting work after leaving the executive chamber in 2014, but that he did not know with whom or the nature of the work.\n\nMr. Howe has testified repeatedly to the financial and professional benefits he saw in highlighting \u2014 and, according to the governor\u2019s office, exaggerating \u2014 his ties to Mr. Cuomo. He would often forward emails that he received from Mr. Percoco to his clients, but not before editing them to make it seem as if Mr. Percoco had described Mr. Howe\u2019s importance to the governor.\n\nIn May 2010, for example, when Mr. Percoco sent Mr. Howe an email asking him to join Mr. Cuomo\u2019s campaign for governor, Mr. Howe forwarded it to several associates, but only after doctoring it to make it seem as if Mr. Percoco had also written, \u201cI need to tell A.C.
