ASAP\u201d \u2014 an attempt to make it seem as if Mr. Cuomo was eagerly awaiting Mr. Howe\u2019s decision.\n\nHe also edited emails to make it seem as if Mr. Cuomo had asked him to speak to people on his behalf, or had invited him to dinner, Mr. Howe admitted.\n\n\u201cYou did it in simple terms for self-promotion, right?\u201d Mr. Bohrer asked on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cProbably, yes,\u201d Mr. Howe replied.\n\n\u201cTo give the impression that you had greater access to the governor than you really did, right?\u201d Mr. Bohrer continued.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYes,\u201d Mr. Howe replied.", "title": "At Bribery Trial, Focus Expands From Cuomo to a Witness\u2019s Clothes", "authors": ["Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPorter Z. Long, 25, is a research and development scientist for Chobani at its yogurt factory in Twin Falls, Idaho.\n\nWhat does your job entail?\n\nI create flavors for yogurt, taking an idea, such as mint chocolate, and developing it into a commercial product. Right now, I\u2019m working on Flip products, which have mix-ins like nuts or seeds to add to the yogurt cup.\n\nHow did you get into this line of work?\n\nI graduated from Brigham Young University in 2016 with a bachelor\u2019s in food science. After Chobani gave a presentation on campus, I decided to apply. After the second interview, they invited me to Twin Falls and asked me to create some yogurt products. I offered up a sesame-miso-flavored Greek yogurt dressing and an avocado-lime-cilantro yogurt dip. Those ideas haven\u2019t turned into a Chobani yogurt, but I did get a job offer.\n\nWhat did you work on first?\n\nI started as an intern, working three days a week until I graduated, and first worked on what Chobani calls its core platform, which includes the fruit-on-the-bottom yogurt. I later transferred to the Flip platform.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat was your first flavor at Chobani?\n\nWe wanted to make a s\u2019mores-flavored yogurt, so our team experimented \u2014 we try to use only natural ingredients and sweeteners \u2014 to create the taste of campfire s\u2019mores. S\u2019more S\u2019mores Flip consists of vanilla yogurt with a side compartment of graham crackers, milk chocolate and caramelized toffee to combine for a toasted-marshmallow taste.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow much science is there in deciding on a flavor?\n\nWe select the ingredients for the flavor we\u2019re preparing, then the science comes in so the product can be tested for safety and to make sure it can be reproduced on a large scale.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen you settle on a flavor, do you worry whether it\u2019s adding calories, sugar or fat?\n\nSugar is a topic of daily discussion, sometimes even 10 times a day. Yogurt needs some sugar for taste, but our goal is to make the sugar content as low as possible. That has been the company\u2019s approach since it was founded, and we are always aiming to use less. The fat content varies by the percentage of milk, so 2 percent products like Flip will have fewer calories than whole-milk yogurt. We list the nutritional information and calorie count on each cup\u2019s label.", "title": "At Chobani, Adding Flavor to Yogurt While Watching Calories", "authors": ["Elizabeth Olson", "As Told To"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. \u2014 In this case, in the 60th running of the Daytona 500, numbers did lie.\n\nNascar\u2019s most famous racecar numbers \u2014 3 and 43 \u2014 finished in first and second place on Sunday at Daytona International Speedway. But it wasn\u2019t stock car racing\u2019s two best-known names \u2014 Dale Earnhardt Sr. and Richard Petty \u2014 who took the checkered flag and finished runner-up.\n\nInstead it was Austin Dillon (No. 3) and Darrell Wallace Jr. (43).\n\nA generation ago, Nascar would have loved a one-two finish from Earnhardt, who raced in the No. 3 car, and Petty, who had No. 43. But the sport will gladly embrace the two story lines it got on Sunday.\n\nA rookie, Wallace is the only African-American driver in Nascar\u2019s top level and has been promoted as one of the sport\u2019s bright young stars. This off-season, Petty hired him to drive his old No. 43 car, and already that decision is paying off. By taking second, Wallace became the highest-finishing African-American in the history of the Daytona 500, bettering Wendell Scott\u2019s 13th-place finish in 1966.", "title": "At Daytona, Austin Dillon and Darrell Wallace Jr. Break Through Behind Familiar Numbers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "MILAN \u2014 The shoulder pad is shaping up to be the symbol of the season.\n\nIt\u2019s easy to understand, amid #MeToo and Time\u2019s Up; maybe a little too easy. Women to the barricades! Battering-ram them down! Even in the European fashion week city where the discussion has been most muted, perhaps because it has been so muted (despite the fact that Asia Argento, one of the original women to spoke out against Harvey Weinstein, is Italian), the linebacker proportion has become a thing. Let your clothes do the talking for you.\n\nBut do designers have to do that with cliches? Think harder, you want to shout at some.\n\nOn Thursday, finally, two of them did, wrestling with the ideas of female strength and female identity without resorting to the obvious tropes of another era.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no need for it to be gigantic,\u201d Silvia Venturini Fendi said before the Fendi show, when the topic of shoulders came up. \u201cIt just needs to demonstrate control.\u201d She would know: As the only member of the third generation of her family in the business, she has a lot resting on hers.\n\nSo the designer Karl Lagerfeld eschewed false underpinnings in favor of the tidy and exactingly square; trading size for structure. Who doesn\u2019t want some of that in her life?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLittle white-collared capelets embroidered like antique handkerchiefs \u2014 genteel versions of the superhero standard that also appeared, longer and with a beaded Art Deco argyle for evening \u2014 were the focus of swirling mid-calf dresses and coats. Shaggy shearling gave them a feral air; a spread knit over a glazed glen-plaid puffer wrap with matching skirt added a utilitarian warmth. The point was a framework that could support anything \u2014 responsibilities, strategic planning, tote bags \u2014 that might get tossed on top.", "title": "At Fendi and Prada, Moving Beyond the Shoulder Pad", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "NIAMEY, Niger \u2014 In a bare suite of prefab offices, inside a compound off a dirt road, French bureaucrats are pushing France\u2019s borders thousands of miles into Africa, hoping to head off would-be migrants.\n\nAll day long, in a grassy courtyard, they interview asylum seekers, as the African reality they want to escape swirls outside \u2014 donkey carts and dust, joblessness and poverty, and, in special cases, political persecution.\n\nIf the French answer is yes to asylum, they are given plane tickets to France and spared the risky journey through the desert and on the deadly boats across the Mediterranean that have brought millions of desperate migrants to Europe in recent years, transforming its politics and societies.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re here to stop people from dying in the Mediterranean,\u201d said Sylvie Bergier-Diallo, the deputy chief of the French mission in Niger.", "title": "At French Outpost in African Migrant Hub, Asylum for a Select Few", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "To maximize their usefulness, clubs have long signed players not just from around Britain, but from across Europe (and sometimes farther afield). All clubs cherish homegrown players \u2014 not least because, in the Premier League and the Champions League, a squad must contain a set number of them \u2014 but few care anymore where home actually is. Cesc F\u00e0bregas was born and raised in Barcelona, but counted as a homegrown player at Arsenal. Andreas Christensen, a Dane, is the apogee of Chelsea\u2019s youth system.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat unapologetically internationalist, industrial approach is understandable, given the intensely competitive environment in which clubs exist, but it means one significant element has been lost. Local players are not desirable because they are cheap, or plentiful, but because they bond a club to its community. They give it a sense of place.\n\n\u201cMy house is just over there, the one with the purple bins,\u201d Alexander-Arnold said as he drove to another appointment with An Hour for Others, at a community center not far from Liverpool\u2019s Melwood training facility.\n\nLiverpool, the city, is not simply a place where Alexander-Arnold works; it is his home. He has a curious family connection to Manchester United: His maternal grandmother, Doreen Carling, is mentioned in Alex Ferguson\u2019s autobiography as the great manager\u2019s \u201cfirst steady girlfriend.\u201d\n\nThey dated for 18 months or so as teenagers in Glasgow \u201cbefore it suffered the fate of most first romances and petered out,\u201d Ferguson wrote, and ended completely when Carling moved to New York and married. (Because of this, Alexander-Arnold, technically, is eligible to play for the United States national team.) More remarkably, one of his mother\u2019s cousins, John Alexander, was for a long time Manchester United\u2019s club secretary.\n\nFerguson once asked Alexander-Arnold, not long after he had first signed to join Liverpool, why he had not tried to join United instead. \u201cMy mum doesn\u2019t drive on motorways,\u201d was the immediate response. In reality, though, Alexander-Arnold wanted to be a homegrown player, in the truest sense of the term. He is from this city and he is of it, too.\n\nHe points to the park where he used to play soccer after school, where there were \u201calways a few people looking for trouble.\u201d He has friends who found it, and whose lives have diverged drastically from his as a result. He still lives with his mother, albeit in a slightly more upmarket suburb, but still feels the pulse of the city.\n\nThat is part of the reason he wanted to help Morland and Watkins. Even while leading the relatively sheltered life of a professional soccer player, he \u201csees the challenges people face, hears about things people are going through.\u201d He is aware that if he were not giving back, his friends \u201cwould ask me, \u2018Why not?\u2019\u201d\n\nThough he is not yet used to the smiles and the stares, he feels the responsibility, \u201cas a local lad, to get involved,\u201d just as the likes of Carragher and Gerrard did before him. \u201cI can relate to the kids,\u201d he said. \u201cI know what impact it can have just to show that it is possible.\u201d\n\nIn the ruthless, globalist Premier League, such considerations seem quaint. What fans, owners, managers and players want is success \u2014 this weekend, this season. A team having a local heart is no more than a sweet anachronism. What matters more is that clubs have top-class players, not where those players are from.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet the enthusiasm with which Liverpool has embraced Alexander-Arnold suggests that something, in the rush to industrialize youth systems, has been lost, and is being missed. Clubs are now international brands, with worldwide appeal and distant horizons. At heart, though, they are still local institutions. They do not exist on a different planet. They represent a place, and sometimes, still, they reflect one, too.", "title": "At Global Clubs, Local Players Serve as Connective Tissue", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Riddles, when they are good, make you think: They stick in your craw and keep you up at night mulling the answer. Mr. Michele\u2019s Gucci may be absurd in many ways, but it\u2019s impossible to ignore \u2014 and not just because it is so ubiquitous that it has become an adjective unto itself (\u201cthat\u2019s so Gucci\u201d), but because he has managed to encapsulate a messy moment of transition. It\u2019s a period of \u201cwhat if\u201d-ing and magical thinking; horror stories and alternative facts. Why not try on a new reality, literally and metaphorically, and see how it plays out?\n\nAlberta Ferretti did, and it went like this: What if a woman were at the center of the universe? What would we all look like then?\n\nIt\u2019s a relevant question and, to underscore it, Ms. Ferretti put an enormous metal sculpture by the Italian artist Lorenzo Quinn in the middle of her show space. Titled \u201cGravity,\u201d it depicted a naked women hanging by her hands from a crouching man. Gone was the fragile Ferretti woman of yore, all floaty chiffon filigree frocks and fairy tales; welcome the new, football pad-shouldered 1980s Ferretti, with a leather cape, a studded belt and a bit of disco shine amid a whole lot of black and dark denim. Also, some grape and burgundy suede.\n\nIt was a step in a different direction, for sure. And she was not alone \u2014 Max Mara also had an \u201980s moment, with a cacophony of corporate punk in pinstripes, leather (a lot of leather: bomber jackets and pencil skirts and pegged pants and gloves), angora print leopard and branded concert-type tees. Not to mention leather suspenders hanging off pretty much everything. They were supposed to be provocative, but mostly looked pointless.\n\nAfter all, the woman in the sculpture faced the future, and these clothes faced the past. Looking backward to go forward may be a strategy, but that does not make it an advance. We\u2019ve been there, worn that, bashed against that glass ceiling. Let\u2019s not repeat it, please.", "title": "At Gucci, Dressing for the Post-Human World", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "The final score \u2014 41-33 \u2014 will lodge deep into the memory banks of a frenzied pro-Eagles crowd at U.S. Bank Stadium and the millions of delirious fans across the Delaware Valley, who will belt it out at work or family gatherings or watering holes as calculable proof that, yes, the Eagles did, in fact, win the Super Bowl.\n\nIt was Philadelphia\u2019s second major sports championship since 1983, after the Phillies\u2019 World Series victory in 2008. The last time the Eagles earned an N.F.L. championship, in the pre-Super Bowl era, they also conquered an iconic coach in Vince Lombardi and a Hall of Fame quarterback in Bart Starr, but that win came before Green Bay\u2019s reign of dominance. In Brady and Bill Belichick, bidding for their sixth title together, these Eagles outdueled the N.F.L.\u2019s premier comeback artists to avenge a defeat from their last Super Bowl meeting 13 years ago.\n\nBefore that game, Belichick inspired his players by relaying the victory parade route \u2014 of the Eagles. If Philadelphia has not been reduced to rubble, that parade will finally meander down Broad Street this week.\n\nWhat made it possible was an unforgettable performance by Foles, who has started for Philadelphia since its star quarterback Carson Wentz tore up his knee on Dec. 10 in Los Angeles. Foles earned the Super Bowl\u2019s Most Valuable Player Award for catching one touchdown and throwing for three more, including an 11-yarder to Zach Ertz with 2 minutes 21 seconds remaining that put the Eagles ahead, 38-33. The aggressiveness of Coach Doug Pederson, a former Eagles quarterback, helped outsmart Belichick en route to winning a championship that Pederson\u2019s mentor, Andy Reid, never could in Philadelphia. And an improbable late stand by a defense that yielded 613 yards \u2014 505 passing by Brady \u2014 produced the most critical play at the most critical moment of the season.\n\nThe seconds feel like minutes, and the minutes feel like hours, when Brady jogs onto the field in the fourth quarter of a Super Bowl with his team trailing. After an entertaining first half featuring nearly 500 passing yards, a missed field goal, two shanked extra points, a bungled 2-point conversion, a Brady drop and a Foles touchdown reception, the second half contained multitudes \u2014 if not much defense. The Patriots, who had scored on their first three second-half possessions, now needed to go 75 yards in 2:21 for a dynasty-extending touchdown.", "title": "At Long Last, the Eagles Capture Their First Super Bowl", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "That enterprising approach has not necessarily been matched online. United latched onto Facebook\u2019s significance early, and the club regularly boasts about its social imprint in its quarterly calls with investors. But it was not until 2013 that United decided that Twitter was not just \u2014 or not only, anyway \u2014 a self-indulgent fad. It was the last team in both the Premier League and the Champions League to join.\n\nIt waited five more years to decide that YouTube, too, is here to stay. Quite why United has been so reticent to enter this brave new world is not clear, though the most obvious explanation may also be the most convincing: If something does not directly drive revenue, the club\u2019s hierarchy \u2014 and the Glazer family that sits at its head \u2014 has tended not to be especially interested.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt last, though, United has taken the plunge. Its channel is already replete with the staples of social media: videos offering exclusive access and behind-the-scenes footage, as well as a raft of famous matches \u2014 wins, all of them, obviously \u2014 condensed into two-and-a-half-minute highlight reels. Like all social media, YouTube prizes brevity, immediacy, punchiness. The world United has finally entered is one of bite-size content, easily shared hits of pleasure.\n\nWhether that is a world this United vintage is suited to is a different matter. As soccer, and sports in general, pivot toward the bright digital horizon, it is worth considering Marshall McLuhan\u2019s adage that the medium is the message. Clubs cannot hope simply to exploit the power and reach of social media without being shaped by them in some way, too.\n\nThe way audiences consume soccer \u2014 and everything else \u2014 is changing. Fans no longer have to watch a whole 90-minute match. Often, they do not even need to see extended highlights. United\u2019s audience, and those of its peers, may be time-rich, but it is attention-poor. The minute we are not entertained, there is a powerful temptation to skip forward.\n\nYou can see goals, in clips of no more than a few seconds, on Twitter. The best tricks or the most egregious errors are replicated in the form of even briefer GIFs. A player can now be reduced to a YouTube compilation lasting barely a couple of minutes. This is the future, and in the future, nobody will pay attention to anything for 15 minutes.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat is significant for the way all clubs \u2014 and superclubs like United, in particular \u2014 are run. Fans and owners of soccer\u2019s great names have always demanded not just success, but style, too. That is ever more pressing now, in an age when teams must not only be beautiful for all 90 minutes, but look spectacular in bite-size chunks, too.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere is a reason teams are prepared to spend unimaginable sums on individual players capable of moments of magic, or those who might create some social media buzz. There is a reason, too, beyond some intangible philosophical preference, that more and more teams are choosing to employ coaches who can deliver an adventurous, expansive approach, rather than simply those with the most trophies on their r\u00e9sum\u00e9s.\n\nThat, of course, is where Jos\u00e9 Mourinho comes in, though in truth much the same could be said of his counterpart at Chelsea, Antonio Conte. Neither is an attacking coach in the same way that Pep Guardiola, of Manchester City, or even Liverpool\u2019s J\u00fcrgen Klopp or Tottenham\u2019s Mauricio Pochettino is. Mourinho and Conte preach a tactically astute, but inherently cautious, approach.\n\nThat is not to say that either Mourinho or Conte is a bad coach, or that United or Chelsea is a bad team. But watching United recover to beat Chelsea, 2-1, on Sunday, it was hard not to wonder if this was enough, now, given how much soccer\u2019s priorities have changed. Is it enough, as Mourinho said, for a club of United\u2019s scope and scale to have a \u201chumble attitude,\u201d to be diligent and determined, to eke out victory through gritted teeth?\n\nIt might be, of course, if the reward at the end was a polished silver trophy with ribbons attached. In the Premier League, at least, though, it will not. United\u2019s win here returned Mourinho\u2019s team to second place in the table, above Liverpool, but it remains far adrift of City. Defeat meant Chelsea fell behind Tottenham Hotspur, into fifth.\n\nThere are still prizes to play for, of course: Both United and Chelsea might soon reach the quarterfinals of the Champions League; one or both might return to that stage next year, too.\n\nBut if the worst happens, then what can Mourinho and Conte fall back on? For Klopp and Pochettino \u2014 neither of whom, it should be said, has won a trophy with his current team \u2014 there is a style and a swagger, a sense that these are teams fans want to watch, teams that make waves, and go viral.\n\nNeither United nor Chelsea can say the same. Both have fallen behind City \u2014 that much is clear \u2014 but in a sense, they are losing ground to Liverpool and Spurs, too, if only in intangibles: They are not as compelling, not as entertaining, not as much fun. There is a desire, at times, to skip ahead. That is at odds with the demands of the YouTube age. This is the world United has stepped into. Now, it is at its mercy.", "title": "At Manchester United, a Win to Celebrate but Not to Savor", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "It was a dreary late Saturday morning in New York, but Prabal Gurung\u2019s garment district studio \u2014 where the designer was conducting fittings for the next day\u2019s show \u2014 was bursting with vibrant hues and textures. Design assistants buzzed around as models arrived one after another, each to be fitted into their look for Sunday\u2019s show. But Gurung himself was calm and upbeat. \u201cI\u2019d say, it\u2019s never been that frantic. We plan in advance,\u201d he said, noting that the season before was an exception: \u201cCertain things didn\u2019t show up \u2014 embroideries from India that didn\u2019t make it into the show at all, so we had to think quickly.\u201d\n\nThe following night\u2019s runway presentation showcased a collection largely inspired by the Mosuo, a small matriarchal tribe living in parts of China near Tibet. \u201cWhat I really found fascinating \u2014 especially in today\u2019s time when we\u2019re talking about solidarity and women coming together \u2014 is that in parts of the world, it\u2019s been an existing part of life that we don\u2019t even think about,\u201d Gurung said, pointing to a nearby wall scattered with images of Mosuo women swathed in layers of bright fabrics, cinched and secured with thick belts.\n\nGurung, who grew up in Nepal, had known of the Mosuo for some time. \u201cWhen I started working on the fall collection, they just spoke to me,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat I really loved was the absolute celebration of the femininity and empowerment. There is no suppression \u2014 it\u2019s full on,\u201d he said, referring to their customary colors and textures.\n\nGurung\u2019s own collection is full on, too. And a striking contrast to the designer\u2019s all-black gowns worn by Kerry Washington and Issa Rae at the Golden Globes in January, in solidarity with the recently formed Time\u2019s Up movement. \u201cWhen I see women wearing all black, I respect that solidarity. But I also don\u2019t ever want to forget the power of color. It can be quite impactful,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs this week marks the first fashion season in the wake of the #MeToo movement, there\u2019s been much speculation over how designers would address the current climate. But for Gurung, feminism and female empowerment have always been core ideas since before the launch of his brand in 2009.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRaised by a single mother, and surrounded by strong female figures throughout this life, Gurung credits his upbringing and a group of close girlfriends for how he\u2019s always designed with empowered women on his mind. His fall 2013 collection, for example, drew inspiration from Ukraine\u2019s Asgarda, a modern-day tribe of female warriors. On Saturday, he wore a sweatshirt printed with the phrase \u201cLove is the resistance,\u201d similar to the T-shirts bearing feminist slogans worn down the runway for his finale last season. This time around, the models would hold white roses, a gesture to invoke the act of listening as a necessary counterpart to vocal declarations. \u201cEveryone\u2019s been asking if I\u2019m going to do another T-shirt,\u201d Gurung said. \u201cYou know, I\u2019ve already done it. Especially this time around, especially as a man, my job is to listen. If any man or men are to learn anything from this, it is to really listen to women. That\u2019s it.\u201d\n\nIt is now Sunday evening at Spring Studios in TriBeCa. As frenzied hair and makeup preparations take place upstairs, Gurung is seated in the main gallery where the show will take place, silently watching the sand artist Joe Mangrum, create the show\u2019s only set design: three intricately detailed \u201csand paintings\u201d sprawled across the runway floor. \u201cIt\u2019s about the idea of impermanence, which I\u2019m really fascinated by,\u201d the designer says. \u201cBuddhist monks spend hours and days creating something like this, and once it\u2019s done, they blow it away. It\u2019s this idea of not holding onto anything,\u201d he said, explaining that the models would walk through the sand for the show-ending finale.", "title": "At New York Fashion Week, 48 Hours With Prabal Gurung", "authors": ["Laura Neilson"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Finally scrambling out of the bush of New Zealand\u2019s South Island, I paused, surveying the alpine valley in the foreground. Then I saw it. Nestled against a slab of moss-covered schist stood a modest structure, no larger than my 8 feet by 12 feet college dorm room. With excitement and relief, I clambered toward Cameron Hut.\n\nAs a 10-year-old, entranced by the cinematic landscapes of Peter Jackson\u2019s \u201cThe Fellowship of the Ring ,\u201d I wouldn\u2019t have guessed that backcountry huts would become a focal point of my travels in New Zealand. Sixteen years later, I had come for the forests of Lothlorien, the peaks of the Misty Mountains, the hills of the Shire. But it was in the huts that I immersed myself in the culture of those landscapes and spent time with the people who know and value them most. New Zealand\u2019s wild spaces deserve their fantastical reputation, but it is the country\u2019s commitment to this vast network of public huts that fosters something unique: a community of strangers even in the most remote backcountry.\n\nApproaching Cameron Hut, I wondered what I would find inside. No two huts are the same. Some are blaze orange, others beige. Some are over a century old, others less than a decade. Even if they look similar from the outside, each hut has its own quirks, stories and memories. They are a product of their environment, the people who use them, and their moment in history, all of which define a hut\u2019s character.", "title": "At New Zealand Trail Huts, Shelter, Conversation and Community", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The team was too imbalanced and the squad, loaded up on attacking talent, too thin; managers came and went too frequently, and the latest incumbent, Zinedine Zidane, was regarded cruelly by some of his contemporaries as an \u201centrenador de palmas\u201d: a coach who did nothing more than clap.\n\nAnd yet it all worked, spectacularly. That night in Cardiff, Real completed what P\u00e9rez would later describe as \u201cthe best season, in terms of title triumphs, in our 115-year history.\u201d To the European Super Cup, the World Club Championship and the Spanish title was added a second consecutive Champions League crown. Real Madrid became the first team in the modern era to retain the trophy. To P\u00e9rez, it was \u201cthe latest symbol of our legendary status: achieving something that had previously seemed impossible.\u201d\n\nQuite how abnormal that season was has been laid bare in the months since. When Real Madrid returns to Champions League action on Wednesday, it will do so with its season in ruins: Zidane\u2019s team sits fourth in La Liga, 17 points adrift of Barcelona. A spokesman for the Asociaci\u00f3n de Socios de Real Madrid (SRM) \u2014 an advocacy group representing the 100,000 member-owners of the club \u2014 described it as \u201cpossibly the worst season in the club\u2019s history, an absolute failure of monumental proportions.\u201d\n\nThis time, Europe, as it so often has under P\u00e9rez, provides no balm. Real\u2019s whole season may hinge on its Round of 16 tie against a surging Paris Saint-Germain and the usual bulletproof confidence that Ronaldo and the rest will deliver in the Champions League has melted away. Defeat, and elimination, is a real possibility.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt Real Madrid, that would mean only one thing: change. In P\u00e9rez\u2019s two spells as president \u2014 from 2000 to 2006 and from 2009 onward \u2014 he has transformed his club into a sort of sporting Disneyland, a Panglossian paradise where everything is for the best, an endless victory parade. The image has to be maintained at all costs. \u201cAny voice that is critical of his thinking is crossed out immediately as \u2018anti-Madridista,\u2019 \u201d SRM said of P\u00e9rez in an email. It is a mentality that also applies to fans and journalists.\n\nDefeat, meanwhile, simply does not exist. Real Madrid TV, available for free to viewers throughout Spain, covers every Real game but does not hold live broadcast rights. It shows games Real has won in the days that follow. Footage of defeats \u2014 and sometimes ties, too \u2014 is quietly forgotten.\n\nP\u00e9rez\u2019s view of Real simply does not countenance the idea that it might lose games, at least not deservedly. When he first met Aleksander Ceferin, the then-recently installed president of UEFA, P\u00e9rez\u2019s opening gambit was to ask why Real Madrid endured so many injustices at the hands of referees. Any setback, in P\u00e9rez\u2019s eyes, could only be attributed to officials\u2019 incompetence or to dark conspiracy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf course, fostering this ruthless, relentless culture has brought Real \u2014 and by extension its president \u2014 no little reward: the European trophies; the title, bestowed by Forbes, of the most valuable sports brand on the planet; more than 200 million followers on social media.\n\nBut it all comes at a cost. Failure is not tolerated. Players who do not perform are replaced. Managers who do not deliver are fired. The question that lingers, ahead of the game against P.S.G., is whether the same goes for presidents.\n\nEven within his Disneyland, there are those who feel that would not be a bad thing. Throughout P\u00e9rez\u2019s reign, there has been a constant murmur of dissent from a small but significant section of Real\u2019s socios, who look beyond the glistening trophies to see a disturbing future ahead.\n\n\u201cThere is a perception that Florentino\u2019s cycle has come to an end,\u201d said Eugenio Mart\u00ednez Bravo, a leader of Plataforma Blanca, one of a number of groups that has sprung up in recent years to defend the interests of the socios.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe members feel that the club is losing its identity,\u201d he added. \u201cThey do not feel close to Real Madrid. There is a lack of democracy and of transparency. Florentino has been in power for nearly 10 years, and nobody has ever voted for him.\u201d\n\nWhen P\u00e9rez returned as president in 2009, he did so unopposed (and to widespread popular acclaim). He has since called elections in 2013 and 2017, but again, has not had to face a rival candidate.\n\nSome socios argue that was by design; Real\u2019s statutes have been tightened under P\u00e9rez\u2019s aegis, and now dictate that any candidate for president has to have been a member of the club for more than 20 years \u2014 P\u00e9rez is socio 2486 \u2014 and must provide a bank guarantee for personal wealth of \u20ac75 million (more than $92 million).\n\nPhoto\n\nIn theory, the changes were designed to protect Real from being taken over by a foreign owner; in reality, Mart\u00ednez Bravo joked, the effect has been that now \u201cto be president of Real Madrid, you have to be called Florentino.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf you ask outside Madrid who owns Real, probably 70 percent would say Florentino, and not its members,\u201d said a spokesman for another socios group, Movimiento Ambar, which was formed in 2015 to press for P\u00e9rez\u2019s resignation and new elections.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNone of these groups dispute that P\u00e9rez has brought Real considerable success; Steven Mandis, author of \u201cThe Real Madrid Way,\u201d even argues that the stability brought about by P\u00e9rez\u2019s infallibility has been a root cause of that success, inuring Real to the uncertainty \u2014 experienced by Barcelona, for one \u2014 brought about by executive power shifts.\n\nThe fear, though, is that P\u00e9rez is now so firmly ensconced that Real Madrid is no longer, in any real sense, a club owned by its own fans. \u201cIn practice, that has been completely forgotten,\u201d a spokesman for SRM said. Movimiento Ambar\u2019s spokesman was even more emotive. \u201cWe have gone from being members to being customers and viewers,\u201d he said.\n\nRumors swirl that P\u00e9rez plans to take the club out of the hands of the socios entirely, to list it on the stock exchange; Movimiento Ambar said it \u201cwill fight until the last moment\u201d to prevent that happening.\n\nEven if it does not, Mart\u00ednez Bravo fears what will happen to Real Madrid when P\u00e9rez, 70, decides to retire, since there is no evidence of a succession plan. None of P\u00e9rez\u2019s opponents hold out any great hope for immediate change, however: no elections are scheduled until 2021.\n\n\u201cWe have spoken to big businesses, to banks, to see if they would back a candidate to run against him,\u201d Mart\u00ednez Bravo said. \u201cBut they all said the same thing: he is too powerful.\u201d\n\nA glance at the directors\u2019 box at the Bernabeu at almost any game bears that out: the seats are filled by owners and editors of news media outlets and television stations, politicians, captains of industry. One newspaper has described it as \u201cthe Court of King Florentino.\u201d\n\nJust how widespread the disaffection actually is may be hard to assess. Movimiento Ambar claims to speak for \u201cthousands\u201d of fans, but Mart\u00ednez Bravo, for one, admits that the pressure for change has eased in recent years, thanks to all those Champions League victories.\n\nHe knows \u2014 though he takes no pleasure in saying it; he is a Real Madrid fan, after all \u2014 that losing to P.S.G. might change that. Early elimination from the Champions League, and failure on the domestic front, might draw more rebels to his cause.\n\n\u201cThis year may be a turning point,\u201d he said. P\u00e9rez has retained his power by achieving things that are simply not normal. Whether he can do so when Real looks very ordinary is a different question.", "title": "At Real Madrid, a Reign Fueled by Wins, and Dependent on More", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Every few months, the menu will shift to explore different regions of the continent. For now, Liberia is its heart. One dish harks back to summers on the farm in Grand Bassa, where Mr. Caranda-Martin picked leaves off the sweet potato vines. Decanted palm oil is brought to high heat until it loses its blood-red hue and turns the color of high noon. Then sweet potato leaves, dark and iron-rich, relax in the pan, soaking up the oil, and come out a creamy pulp with a faint smack of garlic.\n\nAnother touch of memoir: a jelly jar filled with duck liver p\u00e2t\u00e9, which Mr. Caranda-Martin\u2019s grandmother used to make and call \u201cliver butter.\u201d (Ducks wandered the farm.) It\u2019s simple and forthright, accented by rosemary, cloves and Ethiopian sea salt, with sesame oil for extra velvet.\n\nIn his art, Mr. Caranda-Martin has used heirloom African textiles as canvases, painting over them, refusing to allow the past to remain static. With food, too, he nods to tradition but faces forward.\n\nPhoto\n\nA thick soup of zucchini and bunapi mushrooms is cooked down with muan-muan (fermented fish) in a broth of forest bark, melding sea and earth. Roasted guinea hen, customarily served whole, is here represented by its best part, thighs, deboned and tied with string to hold in the juices, and half-submerged in a deep, mellow stew of sweet African peppers.\n\nNo meal is complete without tea, served in a glass kettle that\u2019s perched over a candle to keep it warm. Each has a story, like one that Mr. Caranda-Martin described as \u201cdrunk by fishermen,\u201d composed of wache (red sorghum leaves) and root grass from the West African coast.\n\nFor dessert, hot chocolate is inflamed by dehydrated Scotch bonnets; truffles are laced with suya spice, a flare-up of ginger, chile and kuli-kuli (spiced groundnut paste), more often slapped on meat before grilling. Other treats are hidden on the tea list, including apple cake, baked by an aunt and so rich it\u2019s almost damp, and a lush pudding born of a childhood prank of throwing kelewele (ginger-fried plantains) in a blender.\n\nThere are more stories. And to book the $65 tasting menu, which features rarer ingredients like loofah, a gourd from Botswana, you must call ahead and share your own. \u201cWe have to have a conversation, like Grandma and Grandpa when you\u2019re coming over,\u201d Mr. Caranda-Martin said. \u201cWe need to have a sense of who you are.\u201d\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "At Serengeti Kitchen, Touches of Memoir Dot the Menu", "authors": ["Ligaya Mishan", "Hungry City"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSome 7,300 years ago, a supereruption devastated the southern islands of what is now Japan, burying most of the archipelago in thick ash. Known as the Akahoya eruption, the blast was so powerful it caused the volcano\u2019s magma chamber to collapse, leaving a 12-mile wide scar called Kikai Caldera, which is mostly underwater.\n\nNow in a study published Friday, scientists have discovered that a dome of lava lurks beneath the caldera. By studying its magma plumbing, volcanologists could gain insight into the entire caldera system, which could help them better predict when another eruption in the Japanese archipelago might occur.\n\n\u201cThe most serious problem that we are worrying about is not an eruption of this lava dome, but the occurrence of the next supereruption,\u201d said Yoshiyuki Tatsumi a volcanologist at Kobe University in Japan and lead author of the study that appeared in the journal Scientific Reports.\n\nDr. Tatsumi\u2019s previous work has suggested that the chances of a supereruption happening in the Japanese archipelago in the next century are only about 1 percent. But if a volcano in this area erupts, it could eject nearly 10 cubic miles of magma, covering almost all of the country and its 120 million people in nearly eight inches of thick ash, he found.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe and his colleagues at the Kobe Ocean Bottom Exploration Center conducted three surveys of the caldera, during which they used remotely operated vehicles to observe the depression. On their trips they investigated the caldera using seismic analysis as well as geological and electromagnetic tests. They found the lava dome using an acoustic survey.\n\nMore Reporting on Volcanoes\n\nThe dome \u2014 a trapped buildup of viscous lava \u2014 is estimated to have a volume of about eight cubic miles, a diameter of about six miles and a height of almost 2,000 feet. While other volcanic remnants, like the Yellowstone caldera and the Long Valley caldera, have also been brewing with activity, the paper noted that this dome has a much more immense volume of lava.", "title": "At Site of Japanese Volcano\u2019s Supereruption, an Immense Lava Dome Lurks", "authors": ["Nicholas St. Fleur"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The pork is stained red, shading from carmine to vermilion, and a beautiful ruin. It\u2019s been braised for two hours, tugged apart and crisped in lard, its flavor betraying a softening touch of vinegar and musty sweetness from cumin and cloves. The chiles are legion: guajillo, pasilla, ancho and arbol, a confluence of smoke and berries, raisins and chocolate, pine and grass.\n\nAll this is delicious, but the texture is the wonder: the tangled strands juicy and yielding and then holding back, with buried knots of crunch where the meat took hard to the pan, popping at intervals like a string of firecrackers. The name of the dish is chilorio, and it is reason alone to come to Taqueria El Sinaloense in Elmhurst, Queens.\n\nThe restaurant, with its purple awning framed in dashes of neon, opened in November just off the 90th Street-Elmhurst Avenue stop. Inside, the dining room is narrow and bright; at every table stands a red cloth heart in a silver vase. A map of Mexico sprawls over the wall, with the northwestern state of Sinaloa painted green.", "title": "At Taqueria El Sinaloense, Regional Dishes Worth an Early Trip", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA figment of H. P. Lovecraft\u2019s wicked imagination, Miskatonic University is the Harvard of his horror stories. It appears to be a typical New England college, but elements of the occult are never far from the surface.\n\nIn contrast, at the Miskatonic Institute of Horror Studies, which takes its name from the fictional university, frights are the reason it\u2019s alive.\n\nDuring a recent class in the darkened hall at Film Noir, a Greenpoint, Brooklyn microcinema that houses the real Miskatonic, the topic was \u201cPenda\u2019s Fen,\u201d an obscure 1974 film about a sensitive boy who has encounters with an angel and a crucified Jesus. A ghost light illuminated the instructor\u2019s face.\n\nFormed eight years ago in Canada but now existing in branches in New York and London and one set to open this fall in Los Angeles, Miskatonic is the brainchild of Kier-La Janisse, a film writer and programmer. Ms. Janisse started it after she grew tired of people dismissing horror \u201cbecause they thought it was for complete morons,\u201d as she put it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe institute has operated out of its current Brooklyn location since September, offering courses led by writers, scholars, directors and others with a passion for the genre. This spring, classes in New York are about two and a half hours, and cost $12 (in advance), $15 (at the door), or $50 for a semester pass. Teachers are paid. There are no homework assignments or tests, and students who attend every class both semesters are considered graduates.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhen I was a teenager, I hated school,\u201d Ms. Janisse, who lives in Toronto, said. \u201cBut I read Lovecraft and became obsessed with this idea of how we romanticized academic life, with scholars that worked in libraries and solved mysteries. It made me want to go back to school.\u201d", "title": "At This Film Institute, the Course Material Is Killer", "authors": ["Erik Piepenburg"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "ISLAMABAD, Pakistan \u2014 At the urging of the Trump administration, an international task force has decided to place Pakistan on a terrorism-financing watch list, a decision that has stunned and alarmed Pakistani officials and one that could deliver a major blow to the nation\u2019s economy.\n\nThe Paris-based organization, the Financial Action Task Force, which conducts much of its business in secret, concluded its meetings on Friday with no public statement on Pakistan\u2019s status.\n\nBut Miftah Ismail, a financial adviser to Pakistan\u2019s prime minister, Shahid Khaqan Abbasi, said he expected Pakistan to be placed on the list in June, after the country and the task force agreed on an action plan.\n\nIn addition, a former high-level Pakistani official, speaking on the condition of anonymity so as not to jeopardize relationships with current negotiators for the government, said that members of the task force had decided to place Pakistan on the list as of June.", "title": "At U.S. Urging, Pakistan to Be Placed on Terrorism-Financing List", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Instead, the case has revealed just how difficult it is to separate the two.\n\nYale, like many other large universities, employs its own police force, which investigated the accusation against Mr. Khan and arrested him; the prosecution is being carried out by the Connecticut state\u2019s attorney\u2019s office. Mr. Khan\u2019s lawyers say the university covertly influenced the police inquiry, working hand-in-glove with officers in a way that has compromised Mr. Khan\u2019s right to a fair trial. They argue that Yale, under fire for not taking sexual assault on its campus seriously, blurred the line between school and law enforcement in the name of proving that it did.\n\nAs universities across the country face mounting pressure \u2014 if not from the federal government, then from public opinion, amid the #MeToo movement \u2014 to act on sexual misconduct, that line may become even blurrier.\n\n\u201cThis isn\u2019t about which institution is better,\u201d said Janet Halley, a Harvard Law School professor who has written about the legal implications of Title IX enforcement. \u201cIt\u2019s about what happens when you put two institutions into the same process and they have different rationalities, different institutional cultures \u2014 but above all different rights attached to them.\n\n\u201cThis is oil and water flowing in together.\u201d\n\nAccording to an affidavit signed by a Yale police officer, Mr. Khan and his accuser, who is identified only as \u201cthe victim,\u201d were seniors who lived in the same dormitory. She considered him an acquaintance, the victim said, and they had never been in a romantic relationship.\n\nOn Oct. 31, 2015, the victim ate dinner with Mr. Khan, then attended an off-campus party, where Mr. Khan was also present. After the party, the victim and her friends returned to campus to watch the student orchestra\u2019s Halloween show, a school tradition.\n\nBy that point, the victim said, she had at least four drinks and was so drunk that Yale staff asked her to step out of line after she struggled to pull up her orchestra ticket on her cellphone. When she rejoined the line, her friends had disappeared. Mr. Khan was by her side instead.\n\nThey sat together during the show, during which she vomited several times. Afterward, Mr. Khan walked her back to her dorm room, where she vomited again. She said she remembered lying on her bed, fully clothed, and that Mr. Khan lay down next to her.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt some point in the night, she said, she found Mr. Khan on top of her, and she struggled to push him off. When she woke up the next morning, she was naked. There were used condoms on the floor, and bruises on her thighs and knees.\n\n\u201cWhat you did to me last night was wrong,\u201d she told Mr. Khan, according to the affidavit. \u201cYou should leave.\u201d Mr. Khan replied that she had vomited so much that she had become sober, and that she had consented to sex.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter Mr. Khan left, the victim said, she looked through her phone and found that he had sent messages to her friends on her behalf the night before, declining their invitations to meet up after the show.\n\nThe next day, the victim visited Yale\u2019s sexual harassment and assault resource center, where an administrator called the police. Officers interviewed Mr. Khan on Nov. 6 and arrested him six days later. He was also suspended from Yale on Nov. 9.\n\nAt the heart of defense lawyers\u2019 argument is the Yale Police Department, which, like its municipal counterpart, the New Haven Police Department, has full policing powers and responsibilities. But unlike the New Haven Police Department, Mr. Khan\u2019s lawyers contend, the Yale force is an arm of the university. Yale\u2019s internal sexual misconduct panel uses a lower standard of evidence than the \u201cbeyond a reasonable doubt\u201d requirement of the criminal justice system.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn court filings, Mr. Khan\u2019s lawyers laid out an extensive list of collaborations between the department and school officials, including a meeting between a lawyer for Yale and an assistant police chief around the time of witness interviews, and the possible disclosure by university administrators of Mr. Khan\u2019s confidential educational records to the police without his consent.\n\nAll of which, the lawyers said, was detailed in notes that the Yale police hid from prosecutors and defense attorneys, until the very day testimony was supposed to begin last fall. A judge declared a mistrial, delaying the case until this month.\n\n\u201cThe fundamental question in this case is whether the Yale Police Department operates in accordance with constitutional duties incumbent on all law enforcement,\u201d Mr. Khan\u2019s lawyers wrote, \u201cor whether it is a de facto arm of the campus bureaucracy and, vicariously, politics.\u201d\n\nThe state prosecutor on the case, Michael Pepper, declined to comment, as did a Yale spokesman. Daniel Erwin, a lawyer for Mr. Khan, also declined to comment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Halley, the Harvard law professor, said the collision \u2014 and alleged collusion \u2014 between the Yale and police investigations was inevitable.\n\nUniversity administrators have long worked closely with their campus police forces on issues such as robbery or substance abuse, she said. That the two would work together on sexual assault was a natural outgrowth.\n\nSamantha Harris, vice president of policy research at the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education, a free-speech advocacy group that has criticized the now-rescinded Obama-era guidelines, called the case \u201cExhibit A\u201d for why universities should leave rape investigations to independent police departments.\n\n\u201cIt seems like kind of the worst-case scenario, where the university\u2019s processes may have affected the ability of the criminal justice system to function properly,\u201d Ms. Harris said.\n\nYet the case has also illustrated some of the reasons activists say victims avoid the criminal justice system.\n\nThe case has dragged on for more than two years, prolonged in no short degree by the mistrial. The plodding pace of prosecutions is a frequently cited deterrent to reporting. The trial has also made the incident far more public than an internal investigation would have. Public court records lay out in stark detail the victim\u2019s account of the night, her friends\u2019 names, and details such as how much she had to drink and what she was wearing.\n\nJennifer Long, chief executive officer of AEquitas, a group that advises prosecutors on trying accusations of violence against women, said victims often fear that those details, if publicly disclosed, would invite attacks on their credibility.\n\nThe debate around who should handle investigations seems unlikely to fade. Even as Ms. DeVos has permitted universities to more closely align their hearing processes with those the criminal justice system, she has also retained the requirement that schools investigate claims of sexual misconduct, rather than simply hand them off to law enforcement.\n\nAs a result, Ms. Halley said of the Yale trial, \u201call of this was inevitable.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis may be the tip of an iceberg that we\u2019ll see more of,\u201d she said. \u201c This is a new frontier of cooperation.\u201d", "title": "At Yale, Trying Campus Rape in a Court of Law", "authors": ["Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "We handed our questionnaires back to Ms. Sudofsky and Mr. Minhas Singh, who announced that along with three body treatments, our retreat included a consultation with an ayurvedic doctor. The doctor would be tailoring our treatments after identifying our dosha \u2014 the Sanskrit term used for a person\u2019s biological constitution, which is made up of a combination of elements: vata (air and ether), pitta (fire and water) and kapha (earth and water).\n\nPhoto\n\nNicole and I checked into our room, one of 24 clustered Konkan villas made with local laterite stone, clay tiles and thatched roofs. Our villa had its own mini grass courtyard, a bathroom and shower open to the sky, an enclosed air-conditioned bedroom and a second-floor deck ideal for practicing yoga, napping or taking in the black-faced langur monkeys that catapulted from tree limb to limb. Unpacking our pricey leggings and fitted tank tops, we answered the door for a hotel worker who delivered two pairs of off-white cotton drawstring pants and matching boxy tops \u2014 a yoga apparel set for each of us. We joked at the idea of putting them on, coming to realize after one yoga class the benefit of sweating in those loose, breathable garments rather than our own.\n\nFour miles from Gokarna village, SwaSwara resort sits alongside the Arabian Sea and extends across 26 acres, although more than half of its land is left untouched and protects the surrounding ecosystem. Devoted to sustainability, the hotel, its farms and swimming pool use only harvested rainwater \u2014 accumulated each year during the monsoon season \u2014 which is then treated and filtered.\n\nchina pak. 1 mile New Delhi Gokarna india Mahabaleshwar Temple Gokarna GOA Gokarna india SwaSwara Paradise Beach Om Beach Arabian Sea Map data by OpenStreetMap\n\nEntering the ayurveda building for my scheduled consultation on our arrival day, I was greeted by Dr. Firoz Varun, a thirtysomething, mustached man, whose wife, Dr. Kripa Krishnan, is also one of the resort\u2019s three staff doctors. After taking my pulse and blood pressure, he asked me if I had any \u201cbody disturbances.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf you mean injuries, I have a few,\u201d I answered, a bit confused. We discussed my tight muscles, hip pain and hypermobility, and how lifestyle, diet and relationships are all influenced by our dosha. Dr. Varun went on to explain that every person has a combination of the five elements \u2014 fire, earth, water, air and ether \u2014 but some combinations are more prominent, determining your primary, and often a secondary, dosha. Reaching for the questionnaire I\u2019d completed on the bus ride, Dr. Varun marked in all capital letters: Pitta-Kapha.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo beat the intense heat, our days began with yoga at 6 a.m. Mats were waiting when we entered the yoga shala, Sanskrit for house, and Ms. Carlson led us in breathing exercises, meditations, chanting and poses to awaken our bodies. She encouraged us to pause and be mindful of the sounds \u2014 we heard many chirping kingfisher birds \u2014 smells and sights outside the open windows. For cooling down the body\u2019s temperature, Ms. Carlson taught us sheetali breathing, during which we exhaled through a curled tongue or gritted teeth. Her teaching and crisp voice were a consistent, calming presence in a place where the heat, aromas, sounds and flavors felt, at times, overwhelming. \u201cI\u2019m here to invite in reminders to be and not just do, to pause and take time to reflect,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s an invitation to slow down and taste test India with some Kripalu-style yoga.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith more limber bodies and quieter minds, we went each morning from yoga to breakfast at the Cocum, the open-air dining room at the center of the resort \u2014 named after the reddish-purple fruit used in aruyvedic medicine to treat sores, improve digestion and lessen arthritis pain. All meals were included in our retreat, and breakfast included a daily selection of eggs to order, oatmeal and freshly cut fruit. In an effort to stay hydrated, I refilled my water bottle frequently from the large water tanks located at the yoga shala and domed meditation hut. I quickly learned, though, that ayurvedic doctrine recommends lukewarm water for optimal absorption into the body, so at meals, the water is served slightly warm with added natural flavors, such as fenugreek or cumin, that changed daily.\n\nPhoto\n\nFood \u2014 what, when and how much \u2014 plays an important role in ayurveda. Lunch and dinner at SwaSwara \u2014 served at either the Cocum or by the beach in a shady grove called the Beach Grill \u2014 began with a juice of the day (blueberry-lime blast anyone?), followed by an appetizer such as cucumber peanut salad or garden almond gazpacho, a choice of two main dishes, like fish curry cooked in Indian spices and cocum, or vegetable korma made with mixed vegetables, coriander, mint and coconut paste. Desserts were lacking in chocolate for my taste, but some, like ginger-baked banana and date squares, went over well with guests. The food is organic and every meal consisted of fresh, locally grown or sourced ingredients \u2014 mainly vegetables and fish \u2014 with a plated amount meant to leave you satiated, but not full, which, according to ayurveda, is easier on digestion.\n\nOur days at SwaSwara were unhurried and spacious, sprinkled with yoga, a late-morning group activity \u2014 bird-watching, nature walk, boat ride \u2014 a body treatment, a swim in the pool, or a walk along Om beach, where cows amble aimlessly, leaving hoof prints in the sand alongside those of vacationers\u2019. Gathering in the meditation hut in the late afternoon, our Kripalu group \u2014 save for those who were napping \u2014 sat for a guided meditation or a gentle yoga class, led by Ms. Carlson or a resident teacher. I tried hard not to doze during a yoga nidra class led by Jayalakshmi Moily, whose melodic voice brought me right to the intended dreamy state of consciousness between waking and sleeping.\n\nOn Thursday morning, we left the hotel grounds for an outing to Gokarna village, a 15-minute ride via tuk-tuk, a three-wheeled motorized rickshaw. Our guide, Matthew Raj \u2014 who doubles as SwaSwara\u2019s art teacher \u2014 led us to Mahabaleshwar, a sacred 4th-century Hindu temple and pilgrimage site; to the Koti Tirtha, a sacred water tank used for ritual bathing; and to some shops where we could buy mala bead necklaces, traditionally used in prayer and meditation, and pretty fashionable in yoga and meditation circles.\n\nThursday is market day, and we joined the meandering cows and throngs of locals, perusing the fresh fruits, vegetables and mounds of ginger piled atop tarps on the ground. Mr. Minhas Singh gave each of us 100 rupees (about $1.50) to buy some fresh ingredients, which the SwaSwara chef would use later that afternoon in a cooking demonstration. I spent 60 rupees on a kilogram of purple eggplants, and the rest on crisp, white daikon radishes. Nicole and another guest, Dana Rhoden, a publicist from Miami, pooled their cash to buy some cauliflower, a pricier choice than mine, costing about 150 rupees, or $2.30.\n\nAfter our morning in the crowded village, returning to SwaSwara was a chance to fall back into serenity. That afternoon, I was scheduled for a rejuvenation body treatment, with the addition of murivenna oil, made from a blend of herbs, which Dr. Varun selected because, he said, it increases circulation, and would help heal my muscle and joint soreness. All three of my treatments were given with four hands by Anchu Ajikrishna, a petite 20-year-old massage therapist, and an assistant. I held in my laughter as the assistant farted loudly \u2014 in ayurveda, passing gas is encouraged for colon health \u2014 while heating herbs and oil over a small flame. Ms. Ajikrishna tied a disposable undergarment around my waist and guided me to sit on a stool, before placing her hands over my head to chant a Sanskrit prayer, which, translated by Dr. Varun, asks \u201cthe unknown supreme God and great physician to heal the body from all miseries, body and mind.\u201d\n\nThe four hands swept in unison up and down my body \u2014 front and back \u2014 in what felt like a choreographed dance during each treatment. Once the oil rubbing or salt scrubbing part was over, Ms. Ajikrishna instructed me to wash my face and body in an outdoor shower with green mung bean powder, an herbal exfoliant used to cleanse the skin without removing the oil\u2019s benefits. Dry and wrapped in a green robe, I was led back to the stool where Ms. Ajikrishna had recited the prayer. While I sipped a cup of herbal tea with honey, she rubbed rasna churna powder \u2014 a mix of plant roots and herbs \u2014 into my scalp to maintain the temperature of my body. To finish off the treatment, she placed an orange bindi (a dot, in Sanskrit) made from sandalwood paste, at the center of my forehead, an additional ayurvedic strategy for cooling down the body in the summertime heat.\n\nOur group had its final gathering in the meditation hut on Saturday afternoon, where Ms. Carlson asked us to reflect on our experience and share what we hoped to take home with us. \u201cI\u2019d like to make regular space for a yoga practice that is gentle and nurturing, and not one where I am pushing my body too hard,\u201d I said. A few of us shed tears, touching on feelings of loss and resilience. \u201cAs the baby of the group, I\u2019ve gained so much from the wisdom of these women who have shared some of their life experiences with me,\u201d said Nicole, the youngest guest by nearly two decades.\n\nOn the morning of our departure from SwaSwara, I unintentionally woke up at 4:30 a.m. Like the dolphins who leapt from the water earlier in the week, I felt some sort of magnetic pull from the outside. Trying not to awaken Nicole, I put on clothes, grabbed a flashlight and made my way along a path in the darkness to Meditation Hill, an open-air cliffside structure with straw mats and a view overlooking the Arabian Sea and Om beach. I sat down, closed my eyes, and listened to the waves, thinking of my brother, and the healing and nurturing this place provided. I opened my eyes and the morning light was just beginning to shine.", "title": "At a Yoga Retreat in India: Beach Walks, Body Treatments and Healing", "authors": ["Caren Osten Gerszberg", "Personal Journeys"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Amenities\n\nThe hotel has a two-story gym with up-to-date equipment, a library, an outdoor garden with four swings, even an in-house flower shop. The best amenity by far is the concierge team, which has extensive local knowledge. After check-in a concierge will walk you to your room and give you an overview of the hotel and recommendations about what you should do during your time in Amsterdam. I emailed the team when I was walking around the city with a question, and they responded within minutes.\n\nThe hotel has exclusive walking and canal boat tours for its guests. The latter takes place on a classic salon boat from 1909 \u2014 the captain said that Winston Churchill rode on it in 1946 \u2014 and it has polished teak and brass, marble, leather, even carpeting. It\u2019s worth staying in the hotel just for this. The captain handed me a glass of wine and took me and the other guests on a lively and informative water tour of the city. He knew everything from where John Adams lived when he was an ambassador to the Netherlands to where Justin Bieber likes to party when he\u2019s in town. It felt like a steal for 38 euros a person.", "title": "At an Amsterdam Hotel, Canals and Character", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 The path to equality in winter sports is long and winding, caught up in questions of funding, assumptions about female strength, and international sports federation politics.\n\nWhen women\u2019s bobsled begins here on Tuesday, the athletes will ride in a two-man sled, as they have since the inaugural Olympic women\u2019s bobsled competition took place in 2002. Unlike the men, who have four-man and two-man competitions, there is only one bobsled event for women at the Olympics.\n\nBobsled is not the only Olympic sport in which women get unequal treatment. Female ski jumpers were not included in the Olympics until 2014, and there is still only one event for women, an individual competition on the normal hill. The men compete in three: normal hill, large hill, and team large hill. Women in biathlon, cross country and speedskating still compete in races shorter than their male counterparts.\n\nThe world\u2019s top female bobsledders \u2014 and some top male executives in the sport \u2014 say it is past time to put women on equal footing with the men, but they say they are facing pushback from international officials. Opponents of expansion argue that there are not enough female bobsledders in most countries to justify a second event for women, and they fear adding one to the Olympic program would come at the expense of male athletes.", "title": "At the Bobsled Track, Women Push for Equality", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Rates\n\nRooms start at about 165 Canadian dollars (about $131 at 80 cents to the U.S. dollar).\n\nBasics\n\nFor her first hotel project, the Montreal property developer Marie-Jeanne Rivard wanted to mix the coziness of homestays, the services of a hotel and the downtown feel of loft living. The result, open since last winter, is something new for Montreal: Twenty high-ceilinged, clean-lined rooms equipped like small apartments, complete with top-end appliances, tableware and cutlery. Abstract photomontages of Montreal street life adorn the whitewashed walls. A sleek aesthetic extends through Boxotel\u2019s airy, poured-concrete lobby and to 175B, a subterranean gallery showcasing Quebec and Canadian artists. On Boxotel\u2019s sixth floor, a tiny gym and sauna open to a sprawling outdoor terrace with panoramic downtown views. A reality-TV star in Quebec \u2014 she renovates and sells homes on the hit show \u201cFlip a Fille\u201d \u2014 Ms. Rivard often checks guests in herself at Boxotel\u2019s tiny front desk, called \u201cThe Box Office.\u201d\n\nLocation\n\nWith shabby residential buildings nearby, Boxotel\u2019s block can feel bleak. But its Ontario Street location, a five-minute stroll from buzzy Blvd. St-Laurent to the east and the Quartiers des Spectacles zone of cultural attractions just south, makes Boxotel an ideal home base.", "title": "At the Boxotel in Montreal, Life Is Lofty", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "If New Orleans is an aging beauty queen drunk on the fumes of her glorious past, Plaquemines Parish, to the southeast, is plain old sloshed \u2014 not to mention saturated, striated, slivered and surrounded by water. And no wonder: The peninsula that comprises most of the parish was born many years ago, when the Mississippi River shifted, creating a sliver of land melding into its extensive wetlands.\n\nEven on the peninsula itself, things aren\u2019t so solid, not with the Mississippi chugging down its middle at approximately the equivalent of 166 semitrailers of water a second, and the Gulf \u2014 flat, blue-brown and dotted with oil rigs \u2014 on both its eastern and western flanks. Route 23, the main road in and out, gets you just past Venice, the peninsula\u2019s last town. Go a bit farther on Tidewater Road and you come to the sign that tells you that you have reached the \u201cGateway to the Gulf,\u201d or \u201cthe southernmost point in Louisiana.\u201d", "title": "At the Mouth of the Mississippi, a Weird and Fragile Beauty", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "For that piece, Fonseca, who arrived in New York in 1958 after dropping out of an architecture program in Montevideo, made a small wooden frame filled with cement and divided the piece with incised lines into seven irregular vertical stripes. He also incised a drawing of a ladder, and outlined other simple shapes, including a window, a cross and two human silhouettes; painted most of the surface maroon; and scraped away some of that surface again to reveal the dingy gray color underneath. In the bottom near the right corner is a small blackened doorway.\n\nIt\u2019s a hallucinatory vision, equal parts surreal, symbolic, modern and faux-primitive, and the fact that the two human figures are of dramatically different sizes makes it very difficult to get a bead on. There\u2019s a roof marked out, too, as well as a window, and thin gray lines between the red stripes that could be walls, but if you start to imagine yourself entering the doorway, like a worshiper into a smoky kiva, you get stuck on just how big you\u2019re supposed to be. The key to it all, though, is that ladder. Hanging in the air, leading nowhere, it\u2019s emblematic of Fonseca\u2019s relentless ambiguity.", "title": "At the Noguchi Museum, Worlds of Stone Fuse the Physical and the Dreamlike", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cInvitation to South Korea May Undercut the U.S.\u201d (front page, Feb. 11):\n\nWhat a pity that our nation spurns a potential opportunity for dialogue about Korea at such a joyful gathering as the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea. Thankfully, we have a spirited team of wonderful athletes there to show the world \u2014 and especially the two Koreas \u2014 who Americans can really be, even while Vice President Mike Pence can only stoop to finger-wagging, symbolic and otherwise.\n\nMeanwhile, the two Koreas themselves seem to be flirting, tentatively at least, with what could become more overt overtures to peace. It is too early to foretell what might happen, of course; the arc of history does not bend toward peace on the Korean Peninsula. But the tentative steps taken by the two Koreas are much more positive developments than is the sour bellicosity of the Trump administration.\n\nAt the moment, at least, there is a small glimmer of hope for peace between the Koreas, while there is none while Mr. Trump elects to inject his bellicosity into the problem.\n\nKARL J. HITTELMAN\n\nCORTE MADERA, CALIF.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cSibling Emissary From North Korea Overshadows Pence and His Message\u201d (news article, Feb. 12):\n\nAdmittedly, international diplomacy is highly complex. However, it seems that a great opportunity was missed when Vice President Mike Pence failed to acknowledge and shake hands with Kim Yo-jong, the sister of North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un.", "title": "Opinion | At the Olympics, Mike Pence\u2019s Missed Opportunity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "After their pregnancies, Randall and her fellow competitors shared parenting advice about sleep training and getting back into shape. It seems to have worked. Two of the women ended up on top of an Olympic podium at these Games and two more came close.\n\nThey also worked together to persuade the International Ski Federation to support them. Randall and Finland\u2019s Aino-Kaisa Saarinen were able to get federation officials to provide credentials for caregivers and to find space for baby rooms \u2014 stocked with diapers and toys \u2014 that doubled as a warm place for children and the people watching over them during long events.\n\n\u201cMen can have families, and they don\u2019t ever have to miss a single race,\u201d said Randall, who has pink highlights in her blond hair and is as ripped as a ninja warrior. \u201cKnowing we were all having babies, we lobbied to have some support for moms that first season back. It\u2019s the first time the international federation has provided that kind of support.\u201d\n\nWhile those changes helped, all of the other mothers lived in Europe and didn\u2019t face the same challenges Randall did in packing up her family and traveling for six months out of the year. For Randall, the only way to make the ski season successful as both an athlete and a parent was to enlist the support of her teammates.\n\nTheir buy-in was never in doubt. Randall has long been at the elite level of cross-country skiing, and several of her current teammates idolized her when they were teenagers. The goal was for Randall to spend time training with the team and still be there for her family. It helped that her husband, Jeff Ellis, a former Canadian ski racer, worked as a media coordinator for the International Ski Federation. Both sets of grandparents have also provided extensive caregiving during the racing season.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe made this deal where I wanted to be as much a part of the team as I could, but I didn\u2019t want to be disruptive to the athletes,\u201d Randall said. \u201cKids bring extra germs, and he might be crying at night.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter talking with the coaches, her family adopted ground rules \u2014 sitting at separate tables in the dining hall to allow the athletes to decide how much or how little they wanted to interact with the baby. Randall and her family stayed in separate quarters, but sometimes those rooms were still within earshot of teammates, creating extra worry about whether a crying baby might wake someone up.\n\nThere were bumps in the road. It took a month for Breck to adjust to the time difference in Europe, resulting in multiple wake-ups at night. And it was also a challenge to be on the road with a growing baby. \u201cThere was a lot of gear,\u201d Randall said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe toughest part was dividing her time between the needs of her family and her own desire to be with her team. \u201cHow do I be the best mom and best athlete? That part I hadn\u2019t anticipated,\u201d she said.\n\nHer teammate Diggins said the cross-country team knew that having a baby along during training and competition wouldn\u2019t always be ideal. Sometimes the Americans stayed in small hotels with thin walls, and team members would hear Breck crying in the middle of the night or when they were trying to nap, she said, speaking last fall at an event in Park City, Utah.\n\nBut Diggins said the team didn\u2019t want Randall to have to choose between being a mother and being a world-class skier, and they wanted to help her create something approaching a work-life balance. \u201cWomen shouldn\u2019t have to choose,\u201d Diggins said. \u201cThis team only works when everyone buys in.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd there were benefits to having Breck along for the ride, said Sadie Bjornsen, another team member. Bjornsen, who calls herself a \u201csucker for kids,\u201d said playing with Breck on the road helped keep her from thinking about skiing every waking hour.\n\n\u201cSometimes I will come in after a race and be bummed out about how I\u2019ve done, and I\u2019ll just go over and hug Breck, and it will make me feel better,\u201d she said.\n\nRandall, who plans to retire after this Olympics, recently won election to the International Olympic Committee Athletes\u2019 Commission. She hopes she can use her experience as a mother and an athlete to help other Olympic families.\n\nIn the end, she did not bring her son to the Olympics because the cost was so prohibitive. Instead, Breck stayed in Toronto with her husband\u2019s parents, and the separation was painful, said Randall. She said she wanted to work with the I.O.C. to create affordable housing for family members at future Olympics.\n\nShe hopes that seeing women like herself and Bjorgen on the Olympic podium will convince a new generation of athletes that it doesn\u2019t have to choose between an Olympic medal and motherhood. In fact, she asserted, the two can work well together. She recalled sharing a moment with Bjorgen when they were each presented a stuffed white Soohorang tiger, the Olympic mascot, during the podium ceremony.
