They looked at each other with a knowing laugh.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018Well, this is for Breck,\u2019 and she said, \u2018This is for Marius.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "At the Olympics, Motherhood Skis Away With a Gold and a Bronze", "authors": ["Tara Parker-Pope"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "THURSDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Sometimes a theme clue can seem to be so disconnected from its answer that you need to sit and stare at your finished puzzle in order to fully understand exactly what the constructor hath wrought. \u201cThis has to be a mistake,\u201d you think. \u201cI\u2019m going to write a strongly worded email to The New York Times.\u201d\n\nBefore you do that, stare a while longer. Look for commonalities in the entries. They make perfect sense, I promise. In this puzzle by Damon Gulczynski, all will eventually be revealed, even if it might not seem that way initially.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nI\u2019ll bet you, like me, counted squares at 17A to see if the answer to \u201cRoman of Hollywood?\u201d was POLANSKI. Sorry, there are one too many squares for that. So where is Mr. Gulczynski going with this?\n\nOnce you solve the crossings, you see that the answer is the actor RYAN O\u2019NEAL, and I can hear a collective \u201cHuh?\u201d from some of you.", "title": "At the Start", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s a hairdresser\u2019s fashion week,\u201d said Dwight Eubanks, who had just stepped off the stage from judging the Champion of Weaves competition at the Bronner Bros. International Beauty Show in Atlanta. Mr. Eubanks is a Bronner Bros. devotee and has been coming to the event since he was 16. \u201cThe future is looking really good, the students are really excited about the craftsmanship.\u201d\n\nMr. Eubanks and 30,000 other attendees came together over a three-day stretch this month to what is now the largest multicultural beauty trade show in the world. They are part of a community that has formed around this event, which offers hairstylists, makeup artists and attendees the space to create and showcase the styles that reflect a celebration of the versatility of black hair. On view at a recent show this month were playful weaves and extensions in vivid hues, natural cuts, dreadlocks and braids that were structures as much as styles.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t have a show on this level where we, as stylists, are able to get educated like this,\u201d said Anya Parker, who has been attending the show for 10 years from Memphis. \u201cI will probably come here until I\u2019m dead and gone .\u201d", "title": "At the \u2018Hairdresser\u2019s Fashion Week,\u2019 Celebrating Black Beauty", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "ATLANTA \u2014 Drew Findling, a 58-year-old cool dad with a taste for gingham blazers, is more likely to be recognized by a famous rapper than to recognize one himself. Within the current nerve center of hip-hop \u2014 especially here in Georgia \u2014 he is known, somewhat mythically, as a \u201cwitch doctor,\u201d a \u201cmagician,\u201d a \u201cgod in the streets.\u201d He is also \u201cthe illest.\u201d\n\nBackstage at concerts, Mr. Findling often finds himself being approached by young people \u2014 \u201call these hip-hop stars that I\u2019ve never heard of in my life\u201d \u2014 who thank him for all that he\u2019s done for the culture. At Gucci Mane\u2019s televised wedding last year, Mr. Findling recalled, 2 Chainz singled him out with a pointed finger. \u201cSee that guy right there,\u201d the rapper told his wife. \u201cHoney, we don\u2019t ever want to be in his office.\u201d\n\nThis is the surreal life of the #BillionDollarLawyer, a reputation and hashtag Mr. Findling developed years after becoming an indispensable, behind-the-scenes fixture in the world of Atlanta rap \u2014 which, with the rise of the trap sound and dominance of streaming, is basically the heart of the musical universe.\n\nA criminal defense attorney by trade, Mr. Findling has little to do with the career planning or creative output of Migos, Gucci Mane or Waka Flocka Flame, all of whom he\u2019s successfully represented in court. But given that those artists\u2019 lyrical subject matter and biographical credibility stem from their proximity to, or past participation in, grim netherworlds of drugs and guns \u2014 and, more plainly, given their status as vulnerable black men under 40 \u2014 Mr. Findling\u2019s services are nonetheless a key ingredient in their success.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s the biggest lawyer in the game, man,\u201d said Offset, 26, whose trio, Migos, topped the Billboard album chart for the second time in a row with its new release, \u201cCulture II.\u201d \u201cI\u2019m a young black kid that made my dreams come true. A lot of people that I run into try to use me for what I don\u2019t know.\u201d But Mr. Findling, \u201che\u2019s never, ever done that, from Day 1.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTodd Moscowitz, a veteran music executive and the founder of Alamo Records, stressed the importance of having a reliable advocate for his artists. Mr. Findling invests in \u201chow people turn out, not just in the particular case he\u2019s handling,\u201d he said. \u201cHe stays in touch with everybody.\u201d", "title": "Atlanta\u2019s #BillionDollarLawyer Is Looking Out for Your Favorite Rappers", "authors": ["Joe Coscarelli"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "One thing that is clear to me following the special counsel\u2019s indictment of 13 Russians and three companies for interfering with our election is that the black vote was specifically under attack, from sources foreign and domestic. And this attack appeared to be particularly focused on young black activist-minded voters passionate about social justice: The \u201cWoke\u201d Vote.\n\nThe tragic irony is that these young people, many of whom already felt like the American political system was failing them, were encouraged to lay down one of the most powerful political tools they have, thereby ensuring an amplification of their own oppressions.\n\nThe indictment proclaims that the defendants acted as Americans to create social media pages and groups \u201cwhich addressed divisive U.S. political and social issues.\u201d But that is a phrase so broad and bland as to obscure the piercing truth that the indictment reveals: Referencing actual voter suppression, it says that \u201cin or around the latter half of 2016, Defendants and their co-conspirators, through their personas, began to encourage U.S. minority groups not to vote in the 2016 U.S. presidential election or to vote for a third-party U.S. presidential candidate.\u201d\n\nIndeed, the indictment includes some examples of that effort to suppress:\n\n\u201cOn or about October 16, 2016, Defendants and their co-conspirators used the Instagram account \u2018Woke Blacks\u2019 to post the following message: \u2018Particular hype and hatred for Trump is misleading the people and forcing Blacks to vote Killary. We cannot resort to the lesser of two devils. Then we\u2019d surely be better off without voting AT ALL.\u2019 \u201d Coincidentally (or not!) this was the exact same tack being taken by the Trump campaign during that time. Just before the election, a senior Trump campaign official told Bloomberg Businessweek, \u201cWe have three major voter suppression operations under way,\u201d in which Hillary Clinton\u2019s \u201c1996 suggestion that some African-American males are \u2018super predators\u2019 is the basis of a below-the-radar effort to discourage infrequent black voters from showing up at the polls \u2014 particularly in Florida.\u201d This suppression may well have worked better against black people than other targets.", "title": "Opinion | Attacking the \u2018Woke\u2019 Black Vote", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Auction houses such as Christie\u2019s, Sotheby\u2019s and Phillips are companies with high overheads whose way of doing business hasn\u2019t changed that much since the 18th century. Their challenge is to keep up with the growth of global wealth \u2014 and make money out of it. Each of the three is pursuing a distinctively different strategy.\n\n\u201cIt is a key moment for auction houses, which have struggled for significant profitability,\u201d said Edward Dolman, chief executive of Phillips. Mr. Dolman was referring to the way that in recent years, auction houses have sacrificed large portions of their fees to sellers in order to secure high-value consignments.\n\nMr. Dolman said that Phillips, owned by the Mercury Group, a luxury goods distributor based in Moscow, had decided to \u201cfocus on areas of the market showing significant lines of growth that follow the evolution of taste.\u201d\n\nTwentieth-century and contemporary art is the company\u2019s key selling category, raising $421.8 million at auction in 2017, or 60 percent of the annual total. The top auction price was the $28.8 million given in May in New York for the 1991 painting \u201cRosedale,\u201d by the Scottish-born artist Peter Doig.\n\nPhillips\u2019s art auctions are complemented by sales of 20th- and 21st-century design, photography and prints, with further revenue generated by luxury items such as watches and jewelry. In October, the company set a record for a wristwatch sold at auction when Paul Newman\u2019s Rolex Daytona sold for $17.8 million.\n\nPhillips is banking on live auctions of art and of luxury goods from the past 100 years to deliver growth from the global 0.1 percent. The company has preferred to invest in high-profile specialists, such as its new chairman, Cheyenne Westphal, formerly worldwide head of contemporary art at Sotheby\u2019s, than in technological innovation. Last year, Phillips held just two online-only auctions, both in collaboration with the web platform Artsy.\n\nBy contrast, Christie\u2019s, owned by Artemis, a company controlled by the French luxury retail magnate and art collector Fran\u00e7ois Pinault, looks to its own well-established program of online-only auctions to attract new buyers. It held 85 digital sales of luxury goods and lower-value collectibles in 2017, raising \u00a355.9 million, or about $80 million. This represented 1 percent of annual overall sales, but 37 percent of Christie\u2019s new buyers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe realized the primary advantage of online is not the revenue generated, but the clients we attract through digital,\u201d said Mr. Cerutti, the chief executive.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe art trade is \u201ca market of unique goods and not so many buyers,\u201d Mr. Cerutti said. Last year Christie\u2019s sales were fairly evenly spread across the Americas, Europe and Asia. Looking to expand its global client base to places where new wealth is being generated, Christie\u2019s opened a gallery in Los Angeles in April. It then closed its second London salesroom in July. Underperforming categories have been rationalized. Christie\u2019s decorative arts departments have lost 45 employees worldwide, Mr. Cerutti said, 38 percent of their work force, and no longer hold traditional specialist auctions of English or French furniture.\n\nLast year, auctions generated about 90 percent of sales at both Christie\u2019s and Phillips. How can this market expand significantly when traditional collecting areas are falling out of fashion and when just 25 artists generate almost half of all auction sales of contemporary art?\n\nObviously, valuable, one-off consignments will always boost the figures. Christie\u2019s estimates that its forthcoming estate sale of the collection of Peggy and David Rockefeller will raise about $500 million.\n\nOtherwise auction houses \u201chave to be very creative,\u201d Mr. Cerruti said, pointing to Christie\u2019s inclusion of Leonardo\u2019s \u201cSalvator Mundi\u201d in a New York postwar and contemporary art sale. Nineteen minutes of bidding duly confirmed that this had been a marketing masterstroke. But it was also significant to note that last year, Christie\u2019s regular auctions of old master, 19th-century and Russian art were down 11 percent at \u00a3205.4 million, or about $293 million.\n\nAnd, of course, the market can also grow by buyers simply paying more. An extreme case in point occurred in May at Sotheby\u2019s, when the Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa gave $110.5 million for a 1982 Jean-Michel Basquiat painting of a skull.\n\n\u201cNew buyers are attracted by well-known brands,\u201d said Anders Petterson, managing director of the London-based analysts ArtTactic. \u201cHigh prices signal a sense of quality, which reinforces the brand, creating a circuit at the top end of the market,\u201d he added.\n\nIn December, Sotheby\u2019s said that it sold $4.7 billion of art and collectibles at auction in 2017, a 13.1 percent annual increase. That was short of the $6.6 billion of auction sales achieved by Christie\u2019s. But unlike its longtime rival, Sotheby\u2019s has diversified into areas such as financial services; art advice, including managing artists\u2019 estates; and even image recognition technology. Forthcoming full-year results will reveal how much of its revenue is now derived from such 21st-century business models.\n\nBut for the moment, the 18th-century model of live auctions continues to do nicely, tracking global economic growth.\n\n\u201cThe market has rebounded in all categories and all geographical areas,\u201d said Mr. Petterson of ArtTactic, which published a review last month of auctions worldwide in 2017. \u201cBut we just don\u2019t know how technology is going to change things. No one knows the endgame.\u201d", "title": "Auction Houses Thrived in 2017, in an 18th-Century Way", "authors": ["Scott Reyburn"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Clients and their friends will be able to use the lounges without charge but only by appointment. Although \u201cwe don\u2019t want to be too rigid if there\u2019s a customer in town and wants to show up,\u201d said Antonio Seward, president of Audemars Piguet North America. He added that the brand intends to use the spaces for lunches and cocktail parties that previously would have been held elsewhere.\n\nMr. Bennahmias said the lounge concept was part of the brand\u2019s efforts to learn more about its clients. \u201cStill today, when people buy watches, we don\u2019t know who the buyers are,\u201d he said. \u201cWhy? Because we have retailers in between.\u201d (Other watchmakers have been testing similar ventures, like IWC Schaffhausen\u2019s Les Aviateurs bar, located next door to its Geneva boutique.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe company also has ventured into the used watch business, an arena that other brands like MB&F and F. P. Journe are trying.\n\nLast summer Audemars Piguet began selling pre-owned watches \u2014 mostly trade fair samples and models worn by employees \u2014 at its boutique in the Grand Hotel Kempinski in Geneva. \u201cThe entire watch industry has left that world to outsiders, completely,\u201d Mr. Bennahmias said. \u201cNow, more than ever, we understand that securing the integrity of your brand is not only when you sell your watch as new, but when you resell it as well.\u201d\n\nThose familiar with the pre-owned watch market urge caution. \u201cIt\u2019s not so simple to just flip the switch on a completely different business,\u201d said Steve Hallock, a Los Angeles-based dealer who specializes in secondhand timepieces by independent watchmakers. He said trade-ins, in particular, could be tricky (something Audemars Piguet does not allow now).\n\n\u201cThey can\u2019t impose their will on the secondary market like the primary market; they can\u2019t set the prices,\u201d Mr. Hallock said. \u201cWhat if you bring in your watch to A.P. and it\u2019s worth 30 percent of retail value? Do they tell you they\u2019re not interested? Do they give you 60 percent and eat the rest of it?\u201d\n\nMr. Bennahmias shared few details about the experiment, but emphasized that as an independent brand, Audemars Piguet could take its time. \u201cWe\u2019re going to keep doing it in Switzerland,\u201d he said. \u201cThen maybe a little in Japan, then in Singapore, then in New York, in a very subtle and discreet way.\u201d", "title": "Audemars Piguet Says \u2018Be Our Guest\u2019", "authors": ["Victoria Gomelsky"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHarry Clarke has made another conquest. David Cale\u2019s \u201cHarry Clarke,\u201d a one-man show about a Midwestern boy who masquerades as a seductive Englishman, will return Off Broadway on March 7, at the Minetta Lane Theater, again starring Billy Crudup in what Jesse Green in The New York Times called \u201ca sly role terrifically suited to his gifts.\u201d\n\nThis time, the show has an unusual sponsor: Audible Inc.\n\nAudible, the leading provider of audiobooks, is going visual, for 10 weeks anyway. Producing a limited run of \u201cHarry Clarke\u201d is the latest step in Audible\u2019s recent investment in contemporary theater.\n\nIt follows the company\u2019s announcement that it will transform both \u201cHarry Clarke\u201d and John Leguizamo\u2019s \u201cLatin History for Morons,\u201d which closes on Broadway on Feb. 25, into downloadable products. Audible has also commissioned 15 early career playwrights to create new audio dramas.\n\nDonald Katz, Audible\u2019s founder and chief executive, is a four-times-a-week theatergoer who was wowed by \u201cHarry Clarke\u201d at the Vineyard Theater, where it started previews in October and closed Dec. 17. \u201cI couldn\u2019t be more proud to be associated with a play that smart and that intense,\u201d he said in a phone interview. \u201cThere\u2019s stuff going on in that play that is just electrifying.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAudible\u2019s sponsorship gives audiences who missed the play in its Vineyard run a chance to see it. But it\u2019s also a high-profile way for Audible to announce its commitment to live theater and the artists who make it. \u201cIt\u2019s a way of getting into the world and associating ourselves with some of the best creative output,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a new venture,\u201d he added. \u201cWe\u2019re just going to see it become bigger and bigger.\u201d\n\nThe company has always included plays among its offerings. \u201cLook how many \u2018Hamlets\u2019 we have!\u201d said Mr. Katz. (Eighteen, plus scattered scenes.) But these recent initiatives hope to both attract new ears to audio drama and to challenge playwrights and actors to explore what the downloadable form can be.\n\nAudible declined to comment on how much money it has invested in \u201cHarry Clarke.\u201d But last year it established a $5 million fund to commission one-voice and two-voice plays by emerging playwrights, and on Monday it announced its first class of commissioned artists, including the playwright Leah Nanako Winkler.", "title": "Audible Will Bring Back \u2018Harry Clarke\u2019 Off Broadway", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "We never had a revolution. We never fought foreign troops on our soil. There was no antipodean civil war. From the moment the First Fleet arrived in Botany Bay in 1788 in what is now Sydney, security was provided by the British Army.\n\nThe indigenous population was displaced by force of arms, disease and appropriation of land, crimes for which many Australians still feel guilty. Prosperity, universal health care and unemployment benefits helped suppress crime. The few race riots that took place didn\u2019t involve shooting.\n\nAustralia\u2019s founding fathers, attempting to unify six colonies, didn\u2019t mention guns in the Constitution. They weren\u2019t worried about government oppression.\n\nOver time, Australians came to view firearms with suspicion. Most Australians have never held one. Recreational shooting is regarded as a fringe sport. Unlike many Americans, who might proudly show off their latest pistol or rifle, Australians who own and enjoy using firearms, like me, try to be discreet.\n\nAfter working in the same office for almost a decade, I\u2019ve never admitted to colleagues that I enjoy hunting, although I\u2019m always happy to discuss my last beach vacation. My preteen children don\u2019t know that I own a small-caliber hunting rifle. Only a few close friends have seen it.\n\nI am legally obliged to store the rifle in a gun safe. Bullets must be kept in a separate compartment. A police officer visited my home to ensure that the safe was bolted into my garage\u2019s brick wall. I gave a vague answer when a neighbor asked why there was a patrol car in the driveway.\n\nThis ingrown cultural hostility toward firearms explains why there was no fear and only isolated anger at the government, even among owners, when it took away people\u2019s guns in 1996. In the United States, even if the political opposition could be overcome, such widespread appropriation of private property and limits on personal liberties would most likely be met with fierce, even physical, resistance.\n\nAustralian political leaders are rightly proud of our tight gun laws, which have also reduced criminal homicides and suicides. But it is unfair to grieving and distressed Americans to pretend that the Australian solution to mass shootings can be carried out in the United States. A homegrown plan is needed.", "title": "Opinion | Australia\u2019s Gun Laws Are Not a Model for America", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s been 90 years since Lady Chatterley adulterously wove flowers into her lover\u2019s pubic hair in D.H. Lawrence\u2019s book, to the scandalized delight of readers wily enough to score early samizdat copies. But now that anything goes, now that we\u2019ve seen it all, now that we have PornHub to amuse us on demand, is there anything left to get excited about? Should novelists try to counteract the numbing aspects of porn, as Gurganus advised in an interview, by giving the characters the gift of more active sex lives?\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s an inverse ratio between the abundance of pornography and the scarcity of sex in modern fiction,\u201d he said. \u201cWe talk about where people live, what they earn, what they eat, what they drive, but we\u2019re leaving out the question of their sexual pleasure, and that\u2019s depriving them of something extremely important.\u201d\n\nSex is notoriously tricky to describe. A writer\u2019s tumescent member is a reader\u2019s risible euphemism. \u201cNo throbbing manhoods,\u201d declared Jennifer Weiner, who wants her fictional sex to be consistent with what her characters would normally do and say: \u201cYou try to make the way people behave toward one another when they\u2019re in bed line up with the way they behave when they\u2019re out of bed.\u201d\n\nIn a climactic sex scene in the novel \u201cGolden Hill,\u201d set in mid-18th-century Manhattan, Francis Spufford\u2019s narrator briefly steps outside the story to grumble to the reader. \u201cHow hard it is to describe a desirable woman without running into geography! Or the barnyard. Or the resources of the fruit-bowl,\u201d he complains. \u201cI do not want to write this part of the story.\u201d\n\nStephen King agrees. \u201cEvery part of writing a novel is daunting, but very few novelists deal with sex very well,\u201d he wrote in an email. \u201cThe act is usually far better than writing (or reading) about the act.\u201d\n\nPerhaps it was better in the old days, he added. \u201cWhen I was a kid, reading my first adult paperbacks, the guy would take off the gal\u2019s blouse \u2026 they would kiss \u2026 then there would be a double space, after which the story would resume the following morning.\u201d\n\nNot so much now. As luck would have it, lots of writers are up for writing about sex \u2014 even, or maybe especially, when the sex isn\u2019t that good. (With her short story \u201cCat Person,\u201d Kristen Roupenian has perhaps created a new vernacular for expressing the particular ways it can be not-good for women who think they want it, but who become repelled mid-encounter by the weird or sloppy or selfish or alarming behavior of the men they go home with.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIndeed, a lot of literary fiction seems to feature glum lovers \u201cwho have two reluctant orgasms\u201d before, basically, calling it a night, said Carmen Maria Machado, who relishes a saucy sex scene, especially from the point of view of women who like to have it with other women. \u201cOften I feel when I\u2019m reading sex scenes by men, there\u2019s a sense of disdain for the female body, a sense of its alienness, its otherness,\u201d she said in an interview. \u201cBut I like to write about sex,\u201d she continued, \u201cand I feel there\u2019s a real joy to clear, joyful sex.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe novelist Tom Perrotta said via email that he favors characters who \u201cthink and talk about sex all the time, but don\u2019t have a lot of it.\u201d (In his latest book, \u201cMrs. Fletcher,\u201d his main character mostly sticks to porn.) Meanwhile, Anthony Marra\u2019s story collection \u201cThe Tsar of Love and Techno\u201d includes a scene between a pair of desperately-in-love teenagers who have sex as if they were the first to discover it. Their age \u201callows for a little descriptive leeway, because so much of adolescent life is overwrought to begin with,\u201d Marra said in an email.\n\nWriting with pungent frankness about sex in \u201cJeff in Venice, Death in Varanasi,\u201d Geoff Dyer was inspired by the lyrical yet matter-of-fact gay eroticism in such Alan Hollinghurst novels as \u201cThe Line of Beauty.\u201d \u201cI was struck that he was writing this classical prose and then without any change of register suddenly he was writing in this very explicit, up-to-date way,\u201d Dyer said. \u201cI wondered whether it was possible to do a heterosexual version of that.\u201d\n\nHe also wanted to be sure everyone knew who was doing what when, how and to whom. \u201cGenerally speaking, I get frustrated and irritated when I can\u2019t tell what\u2019s happening\u201d in a novel, Dyer said. \u201cI want to know who\u2019s speaking and where they\u2019re going and all that.\u201d So for his sex scenes, \u201cI wanted it to be, \u2018This goes there and he does this. \u2026\u2019 Just the sort of mechanics of it. It was technically interesting because even moving people around \u2014 getting them in and out of rooms \u2014 is difficult.\u201d\n\nWhat doesn\u2019t work? \u201cOcean metaphors \u2014 those are terrible,\u201d said Daniel Handler, whose latest book, \u201cAll the Dirty Parts,\u201d fulfills the promise of its title.\n\nThis brings us to the Bad Sex in Fiction Award, which since 1993 has been given annually by Literary Review magazine in Britain to \u201cdraw attention to poorly written, perfunctory or redundant passages of sexual description in modern fiction.\u201d\n\nOver the years, writers have been cited for their overly creative synonyms for male genitalia (\u201chis bulging trousers,\u201d \u201chis old battering ram,\u201d \u201cthe billiard rack,\u201d \u201ca plank,\u201d \u201chis peg,\u201d \u201cmy pole,\u201d \u201chis big generative jockey,\u201d \u201cthe Hound\u201d) and female genitalia (\u201cher sap,\u201d \u201cher viscera,\u201d \u201cher relief map of mysteries,\u201d \u201cher assemblage,\u201d \u201cher pelvic saddle,\u201d \u201cher most unmentionable body part\u201d and \u201cthe no man\u2019s land between her \u2018front parlor\u2019 and \u2018back door\u2019\u201d).\n\nPlaced in elaborate metaphorical forests, seascapes, gardens, transformative celestial planes and ecstatic alternative universes, the characters can be found in various convoluted configurations, biting, gasping, whacking, smacking, glugging, grabbing, grinding, gripping, grunting, scratching, swallowing, squeaking, sucking, stroking, lathering, panting, prodding, moaning, thrusting, tugging, rubbing and rattling. If they\u2019re lucky, they might achieve a \u201cWagnerian crescendo,\u201d or at least a \u201cpuny muscular spasm.\u201d\n\nAs in real life, the male ego is disproportionately large. \u201cMale writers often have vaginas squeezing the sides of penises to show how into it the women are,\u201d said Frank Brinkley, assistant editor of the magazine, speaking of nominees for the prize. \u201cFor men, it often needs to be bigger and larger and the best sex ever and better than the sex before, and it\u2019s clear that the man\u2019s penis is brilliant and the woman loves it and it\u2019s the best one she\u2019s ever seen.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s hard to pick the best (worst) Bad Sex winner. But many people familiar with the prize have a soft spot for the 2015 recipient, Morrissey, former lead singer of the Smiths, for a passage in his debut novel, \u201cList of the Lost.\u201d Not only does he use the phrase \u201cbulbous salutation,\u201d but also he describes how it \u2014 the bulbous salutation, that is \u2014 \u201cwhacked and smacked its way into every muscle of Eliza\u2019s body except for the otherwise central zone.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat made people think of the London Underground, which they found especially amusing.\n\nAs Jonathan Beckman, a Literary Review editor, wrote at the time: \u201cFor future reference, the best way to reach the otherwise central zone is almost certainly by getting off the Victoria Line at Oxford Circus.\u201d", "title": "Authors of Fiction Confront a Problem: How to Write About Sex", "authors": ["Sarah Lyall"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWith an eye toward helping young women and people of color break into the entertainment business, the city of Los Angeles is hoping to lend a hand.\n\nEric Garcetti, the mayor of Los Angeles, and Ava DuVernay, a filmmaker who has rocketed up the ranks in Hollywood, are teaming up with the producer Dan Lin (\u201cThe Lego Movie\u201d) to start a public-private partnership that would fund 150 internships for women, people of color and those from low-income households, they announced on Monday. The goal is to support 500 interns a year by 2020 \u2014 which, incidentally, might be when Mr. Garcetti follows through on his consideration to run for president.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe program is called the Evolve Entertainment Fund, and it is partnering with top Hollywood powerhouses like DreamWorks and the Creative Artists Agency to place Hollywood aspirants on a track for a film career.\n\nHollywood has been the subject of criticism for decades about inequality in its ranks, both in front and behind the camera. In 2017, a Milken Institute study showed people of color in Hollywood were underrepresented compared to the racial demographics of Los Angeles as a whole, and underpaid compared to their white counterparts. It reported similar findings for women.\n\n\u201cWhen \u2018Oscars So White\u2019 and \u2018Time\u2019s Up\u2019 put a spotlight on inequality in Hollywood, they captured the frustrations of people shut out of opportunity in what the world knows as L.A.\u2019s signature industry,\u201d Mr. Garcetti said in a news release.\n\nAdded Ms. DuVernay in the statement: \u201cReal change happens when we take tangible action \u2014 and that means giving young women and people of color opportunities in the industry early on.\u201d", "title": "Ava DuVernay Helps Start a Diversity Initiative for Hollywood", "authors": ["Sopan Deb"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe are witnessing a slow but insistent and intentional process of undermining the courts so that they will not enforce the Constitution against the executive and the legislature,\u201d Sarah Cleveland, the American member of the Venice Commission and a law professor at Columbia University, told me. \u201cIt\u2019s a process of death by 1,000 cuts.\u201d\n\nThe death involved could be that of constitutional governance and Poland\u2019s democracy itself.\n\nSeveral things need to be said here. The first is that Poland, by far the largest of the formerly Communist Central European nations that joined the European Union and NATO, has gone from poster child of liberty to standard-bearer of nationalist reaction, propelled by the phantasms of migrant waves and European Union \u201cinterference\u201d manipulated by Kaczynski. It is an extraordinary volte-face. It is also testimony to how illusory the triumph of liberalism in 1989 has proved under the pressure of globalization.\n\nThe second is that Donald Trump\u2019s United States, potentially the chief bulwark against illiberalism\u2019s rise, has gone AWOL. He gave Kaczynski and the nationalists a pass during his visit to Poland in July. Indeed, the president has been conducting his own campaign against an independent judiciary. He\u2019s called the American criminal justice system a \u201claughingstock\u2019 and \u201ca joke,\u201d dismissed the legal system as \u201cbroken,\u201d insulted judges, called for quick \u201cstrong justice\u201d (read the death penalty), and labeled courts as \u201cpolitical.\u201d The impression Trump leaves is that he\u2019d be happy with Vladimir Putin\u2019s law courts, Xi Jinping\u2019s press, and Rodrigo Duterte\u2019s war on drugs.\n\nAll this, of course, has empowered the likes of the Polish government. Anyone who seriously believes Trump is innocuous through incompetence on the world stage should think again.\n\nThe third is that Poland and Hungary, countries for which the European Union was a sanctuary from oppression as they emerged from Communism, now pose a direct challenge to a Union that rests on the principles of \u201cdemocracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights.\u201d\n\nA formal European procedure has been initiated that could lead to the loss of Poland\u2019s voting rights within the Union; it should be pursued with vigor. Poland and Hungary cannot be allowed to sabotage without cost the club of which they have been, and remain, such conspicuous beneficiaries.\n\nThe fourth is the most serious. Independent courts (like a free press) hold power to account; they establish facts and truth. In their absence, the way is opened to Michnik\u2019s \u201cguillotine and the gulag.\u201d When truth goes, so does freedom.\n\nPoland\u2019s grotesque \u201cDeath Camp\u201d law, signed this month by President Duda, must therefore be seen as of a piece with a broader assault on truth. The law makes it a crime to accuse \u201cthe Polish nation\u201d of complicity in the Holocaust or any \u201cNazi crimes committed by the Third Reich.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Awaken, Poland, Before It\u2019s Too Late", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEveryone always says, \u2018What could possibly go wrong?\u2019\u201d said Ginger Flesher-Sonnier, 49, the owner of Kick Axe, a new bar where guests toss shiny silver axes at big wooden targets. This sporting club has 10 metal-caged ax ranges in which groups of up to 10 are assigned an \u201cax-pert\u201d who, in addition to providing basic throwing lessons, goes through safety guidelines that separate axes from alcohol (no drinks on the range) and people from targets (all ax retrieval happens at the same time, so no one is throwing).\n\nHowever, once you hold that little ax, which is a bit heavier than it looks, fears of errant blades dissipate and it becomes all about the thrill of \u201csticking it\u201d \u2014 that is, getting the ax to hit the target with a deeply satisfying wood-splintering thwack. \u201cWhen they get that first one to sink in, it\u2019s great,\u201d said Ryan Lynch, 24, one of the aptly bearded \u201cax-perts.\u201d \u201cIt\u2019s such a gratifying experience.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Place Kick Axe is just off Fourth Avenue, down a semi-industrial street lined with graffiti-covered warehouses. Look for the big plastic bull out front. Inside, there\u2019s a lounge resembling a midcentury-modern mountain lodge. There are big leather couches and tartan chairs, taxidermy and cow skin throw rugs, but also some sparkling satellite chandeliers to remind you that you\u2019re still in Brooklyn.\n\nThe Crowd Mostly 20-somethings out in packs for a night of group fun in the Gowanus Industrial Playground; archery, rock climbing and shuffleboard are nearby. There are also some braver, slightly more timid 30-somethings paired up on adventurous date nights. (No ax-murderer jokes, please.) There seems to be an unofficial dress code of country-casual, with the majority wearing plaid or flannel shirts and grungy jeans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Playlist The constant thump and clang of axes hitting and missing the targets provide the beat of the night, complemented by the high-pitched squeals and guttural screams of boisterous team competition. Though no one is actually getting hit with an ax, it can sure sound like it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGetting In Anyone can walk in and sign up for time on a range, if it\u2019s available. But reservations are recommended, especially on weekend nights, which book up quickly with birthday parties or big groups. The rate is $35 per person for 75 minutes. It\u2019s a minimum of eight people to book your own range, otherwise you\u2019ll have to share with strangers. But making new friends is part of the fun here, too.\n\nDrinks Beer and wine only, for obvious reasons: a dozen canned beers (starting at $3) and a small selection of reds and whites ($7.50). Bar snacks include Pop-Tarts and microwave soups (from $4).", "title": "Ax Throwing and Beer, a Fun New Combo in Brooklyn", "authors": ["Brian Sloan"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cJunk\u201d \u2014 the sprawling, weighty drama by Ayad Akhtar exploring the underhanded world of junk bonds and Wall Street in the 1980s \u2014 is this year\u2019s winner of the Edward M. Kennedy Prize for Drama Inspired by American History.\n\nThe play, which ran on Broadway at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center and closed last month, was an ambitious undertaking, using a cast of 19 characters to deeply examine various capitalist perspectives. In his New York Times review, Ben Brantley wrote that the show \u201cunfolds with the crispness and legibility of a conscientiously assembled spread sheet.\u201d\n\nThe prize jury, made up of playwrights, scholars and others, said that \u201cJunk\u201d \u201ctrenchantly examines the financial behavior and the flawed system of thought in the 1980s that paved the way for the polarized world in which we now live \u2014 manufacturing debt.\u201d It added that the play \u201cspeaks directly to the aims of the prize, enlisting theater\u2019s power to explore America\u2019s past, and through that, speak to our present, so crucial to the health of our democracy.\u201d\n\nMr. Akhtar, who won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize for Drama for \u201cDisgraced,\u201d will receive $100,000. The award was created by Jean Kennedy Smith, a former United States ambassador to Ireland, in honor of her brother, Edward M. Kennedy, the former senator from Massachusetts. It is awarded yearly on or around his birthday. Past winners include the performance artist Taylor Mac and Lin-Manuel Miranda.", "title": "Ayad Akhtar Wins Kennedy Prize for Drama Inspired by American History", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIt happened like this: The cabdriver, an older man, had an earphone in and was talking on his phone. I thought I heard a Haitian accent. I prefer that cabdrivers not talk on their phones.\n\n\u201cIf you get off the phone,\u201d I said, \u201cI\u2019ll sing you an old Creole song.\u201d\n\nHe hung up immediately. I sang the song.\n\n\u201cLovely,\u201d he said, \u201cbut I\u2019m from Nigeria.\u201d\n\n\u201cDo you know a Nigerian song you could sing me?\u201d I asked.\n\nHe turned around and smiled, and sang a nice song. While he was singing, I remembered an African song I had learned years before at the Omega Institute. When he finished, I sang it for him.\n\n\u201cBeautiful,\u201d he said. \u201cNot my dialect, but I could hear the trees. Here\u2019s another.\u201d\n\nAnd he began to sing me a song as we started down my block. I began to learn it and started to harmonize (it was a long block!). A first for me, but at my age, you can toss a lot of caution to the wind.", "title": "Back-Seat Singer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "With each mass shooting, calls rise from gun control advocates for tighter rules on firearms. The go-to policy prescription involves background checks. But a measure passed by the House and being considered in the Senate to expand the National Instant Criminal Background Check System would not only fail to fix major flaws in the system but would also probably introduce new ones.\n\nLawmakers from both parties acknowledge that errors in the background check system let felons obtain guns, as we saw when a deranged man, Devin Kelley, killed 26 people at a church in Sutherland Springs, Tex., in November. The killer, while in the Air Force, had been convicted of domestic violence in 2012, involuntarily committed to a mental health care center and given a bad conduct discharge. Yet the Air Force failed to follow policies to ensure that his conviction was reported to federal law enforcement, which allowed the killer to pass the check. The military has failed to report other such cases.\n\nThe background check measures before Congress aim to improve enforcement of existing law and increase such reporting by imposing financial penalties on government officials whose agencies fail to provide required information. That\u2019s a good goal, but any proposal should also fix another major problem with the background check system: false positives that stop law-abiding people from getting weapons that they might need to protect themselves and their families.\n\nThe background check system confuses the names of law-abiding individuals with those of criminals, resulting in thousands of \u201cfalse positives\u201d every year. Relying on phonetically similar names along with birth dates just doesn\u2019t allow for much accuracy.", "title": "Opinion | Background Checks Are Not the Answer to Gun Violence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nIn \u201cMaking Background Checks Work\u201d (Op-Ed, Feb. 13), John R. Lott Jr. desperately tries to push one of the gun lobby\u2019s favorite narratives: that background checks are bad for public safety.\n\nThe main pillar of Mr. Lott\u2019s argument is that our underfunded, underresourced and broken background check system prevents \u201cgood guys\u201d from getting guns.\n\nIn reality, the system fails the other way too often and allows too many \u201cbad guys\u201d to get guns. In December, the Federal Bureau of Investigation issued more than 4,000 requests to retrieve guns from prohibited buyers.\n\nOnce again, Mr. Lott and others ignore reality to push a dangerous narrative that prevents any action to save American lives.", "title": "Opinion | Background Gun Checks and Public Safety", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "THURSDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Brains are funny. You can sit me down in front of a rebus puzzle like Wednesday\u2019s by Ori Brian and Zach Spitz and I won\u2019t make much headway for a long time. But you want me to write the answers into the grid backward? I got you. I\u2019m there. I see what you\u2019re doing.\n\nYour mileage, as always, may vary. I admire people who can spot a rebus a mile away. But today was my day. Today I raced through a Thursday puzzle as if it were written for me, and maybe you did, too. My point is this: We all have days when we own the puzzle, and we all have days when the puzzle owns us. Don\u2019t give up.\n\nThat doesn\u2019t mean it was easy. It took some doing to get where Zhouqin Burnikel was going with this theme, but once I got it, a whoop escaped my mouth and I was off. This was a very clever theme with a terrific \u201cAha!\u201d moment. And I didn\u2019t need to backtrack at all.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nThe revealer in Ms. Burnikel\u2019s puzzle is at 60A, a great place for the punch line of a puzzle where the grid has some weird stuff going on above it. The clue is \u201cBacktracking \u2026 or what 17-, 27- and 46-Across are doing?\u201d and the answer is REVERSING COURSE.", "title": "Backtracking", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 A court in Bahrain sentenced a prominent democracy advocate on Wednesday to five years in prison for tweets about abuses in prisons and the Saudi-led war in Yemen, continuing the crackdown that crushed the Arab Spring uprising there seven years ago.\n\nThe sentencing of the advocate, Nabeel Rajab, is the latest step in a long crackdown on dissent in Bahrain, a tiny island kingdom that is home to the United States Navy\u2019s Fifth Fleet. Backed by rulers in neighboring Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain\u2019s Sunni Muslim royal family has used tanks, riot police officers, sweeping arrests and tight censorship to thwart demands for democracy among the Shiite Muslim majority, and the resulting conflict has inflamed sectarian tensions around the region. The repression has presented Washington with one of the most awkward conflicts between its professions of support for human rights and its military commitments in the Persian Gulf.\n\nMr. Rajab, 53, president of the Bahrain Center for Human Rights, is a leader of the pro-democracy movement that came to life in 2011, during the Arab Spring uprisings across the region. He was sentenced to three years in jail the next year, on charges of inciting protests against the government, and he has spent much of the intervening time in and out of prison on a series of charges related to his criticism of the monarchy. He is already serving a two-year sentence handed down in July for comments he made in television interviews, and faces more charges related to an Op-Ed published in The New York Times in 2016, \u201cLetter From a Bahraini Jail.\u201d\n\nIn it, Mr. Rajab recounted a recent meeting with John Kerry, then the secretary of state \u201cI would like to ask Mr. Kerry now: Is this the kind of ally America wants?\u201d he wrote. \u201cThe kind that punishes its people for thinking, that prevents its citizens from exercising their basic rights?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Rajab was sentenced on Wednesday for statements he posted on Twitter in 2015. He was charged with \u201cinsulting national institutions\u201d for accusing the authorities of torture at Jaw Prison, and sharing a report by Human Rights Watch that detailed conditions at the prison. He was charged with \u201cinsulting a neighboring country\u201d for criticizing Saudi Arabia\u2019s war against an Iranian-allied faction in Yemen, and he was accused of spreading false or malicious news during wartime because he faulted Bahrain for its participation in the Saudi-led coalition bombing Yemen.", "title": "Bahrain Activist Gets 5-Year Sentence for \u2018Insulting\u2019 Tweets", "authors": ["David D. Kirkpatrick"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "The N.R.A. did not immediately respond to a request for comment late Thursday afternoon.\n\nMany of the bank\u2019s customers had used social media to threaten to stop doing business with the company if it maintained its ties to the firearms trade group.\n\nOn Wednesday, a web page describing the card was taken down. A cached version of the website describes the card as \u201cthe official credit card of the N.R.A.\u201d and offers a $40 credit with the first purchase made on the card.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s enough to reimburse your one-year N.R.A. membership!\u201d the page said.\n\nVisa, in a statement, said that it had no contractual or financial relationship with the N.R.A.\n\n\u201cVisa co-branded cards do not represent an endorsement by Visa of that cause or organization,\u201d the company said. \u201cWe strive to make our payment services available to all people in all places, for uses consistent with local, national, and international laws.\u201d\n\nEnterprise announced its decision on Twitter, saying it was responding to recent messages it had received objecting to the company\u2019s ties to the N.R.A.", "title": "Bank and Enterprise Rent-a-Car to Cut Ties to N.R.A. After Customer Outcry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Under Pew\u2019s guidelines, small bank loans should have payments of no more than 5 percent of a borrower\u2019s paycheck, payments should not be allowed to cause overdraft fees, and annual percentage rates should be no more than \u201ctwo digits\u201d \u2014 not the triple-digit rates offered by payday lenders. \u201cA.P.R.s with three digits are unnecessary for profitability,\u201d Mr. Horowitz said.\n\nTo make such loans workable for borrowers and profitable for banks, underwriting \u2014 the review that borrowers undergo to determine if they qualify for a loan \u2014 should be automated, the report said. That means banks would mainly make the loans through online and mobile banking applications, and may need to factor in criteria other than traditional credit scores. For instance, banks might consider the length of the customer\u2019s relationship with the bank and the frequency of the customer\u2019s deposits.\n\nSpeed is crucial, Mr. Horowitz said, because unless the loans are available quickly and easily, borrowers will go elsewhere, since they typically seek payday loans when they are in distress. \u201cBorrowers will choose payday loans,\u201d he said, \u201cif banks aren\u2019t fast.\u201d\n\nBanks are in a good position to offer such loans, if regulators approve, Pew suggested. The average payday loan customer borrows $375 over five months and pays $520 in fees, while banks and credit unions could profitably offer the same amount over the same period for less than $100.\n\nPew said certain components of its proposal, including the 5 percent payment cap, had been supported in the past in public comments by several banking groups.\n\n\u201cMany people want and rely on small-dollar credit, and banks are eager to expand their offerings of trusted and responsible services to these borrowers,\u201d said Virginia O\u2019Neill, senior vice president of the American Bankers Association\u2019s center for regulatory compliance.\n\nAlexander Monterrubio, director of regulatory affairs for the National Association of Federally-Insured Credit Unions, said his organization supported more options for its membership base, \u201cincluding responsible small-dollar lending options.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA spokesman for one large bank, Fifth Third, said in an email that \u201cwe believe banks need to be able to meet their customers\u2019 short-term, small-dollar\u201d needs.\n\nProposals for small installment loans could face opposition from the payday lending industry. Regulators under the Trump administration have also become more favorable to the industry, which would face new competition.\n\nThe major lobbying group representing payday lenders, the Community Financial Services Association of America, didn\u2019t immediately respond to a request for comment. In the past, the group\u2019s chief executive, Dennis Shaul, has said that the payday industry welcomes competition, but that he is skeptical that many banks actually want to enter the small-dollar loan market.\n\nHere are some questions and answers about small installment loans:\n\nDidn\u2019t banks try something like this before?\n\nSome banks offered \u201cdeposit advances\u201d before regulators halted them in 2013. The advances were due in a lump sum on the borrower\u2019s next payday, often at a fee of 10 percent per pay period, or an annual percentage rate of 260 percent. Pew said it opposed allowing banks to offer such \u201cunaffordable\u201d advances again.\n\nWhat sort of fees might banks charge for small installment loans?\n\nAccording to Pew, 70 percent of Americans said they would look favorably on their bank or credit union if it offered a $400, three-month loan for $60, and 80 percent said they believed such a loan would be fair.\n\nWhere can I get a small loan now if my credit isn\u2019t great but I don\u2019t want to use a payday lender?\n\nSome small credit unions offer payday alternative loans, or PALs, in amounts from $200 to $1,000. Typically, borrowers must be a member of the credit union for at least one month before becoming eligible for the loans.", "title": "Banks Urged to Take On Payday Lenders With Small, Lower-Cost Loans", "authors": ["Ann Carrns", "Your Money Adviser"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Another son, Siamak, 46, a businessman and dual citizen who had been an advocate for improved American-Iranian relations, remains imprisoned as well. Babak said his brother had been abused while in prison, including through electric shock. In a secretive October 2016 trial, the two men were convicted of collaborating with a hostile power \u2014 the United States. Their convictions and 10-year sentences were upheld last November on appeal. The details of the charges against them have never been fully explained.\n\nImage Baquer Namazi Credit Namazi family, via Reuters\n\nAt least two other American citizens are known to be imprisoned in Iran: Xiyue Wang, a Princeton graduate student who was seized while working on his doctoral thesis, and Karan Vafadari, a Tehran art gallery owner. Another American, Robert Levinson, has been missing in Iran for more than 10 years. Other foreign citizens have also been detained, including Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a Briton of Iranian descent employed by the Thomson Reuters Foundation, who was sentenced to five years.\n\nThese detentions have worsened tensions between Iran and the West following the 2015 deal under which Iran agreed to curb its nuclear program in return for a lifting of economic sanctions. The result is that some Westerners, especially those with dual Iranian citizenship, are now more cautious about visiting Iran, fearing arbitrary arrest. Iranian officials say that the United States or its allies have unfairly imprisoned or prosecuted at least 14 Iranians, mostly for what the officials call unfounded charges of sanctions violations.\n\nGranting Mr. Namazi a short-term medical leave and then extending it seemed like one possible way to break the logjam. The Trump administration has reportedly asked Iran to set up a private channel to discuss such humanitarian issues, but there has been no response from Tehran. The speculation is that the hard-liners who control Iran\u2019s judiciary and intelligence services are refusing to budge.\n\nMr. Trump and his State Department should continue trying to engage Iran. It\u2019s not in the interest of either country for Mr. Namazi, or any other political prisoner, to die in jail.", "title": "Opinion | Baquer Namazi Shouldn\u2019t Have to Die in an Iranian Prison", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHeadliner\n\nBAR FREUD Freud has hit the bottle. Or, rather, the cocktail hour. What was simply Freud, an Austrian restaurant, is now Bar Freud. The chef, Eduard Frauneder of Edi and the Wolf, who opened the restaurant about two years ago, has teamed up with his fellow Austrian Albert Trummer, the ever-inventive mixer of elixirs, and Mr. Trummer\u2019s son, Jakob. Mr. Fraudener said he had searched for a way to collaborate with the elder Mr. Trummer for a number of years. The new restaurant has a dramatic painting on the ceiling, a drift of theatrical drapery and a large central bar with vintage scales, beakers and bottles, artifacts that have become Mr. Trummer\u2019s trademark. Mr. Frauneder\u2019s food will include small plates, like tea-smoked trout, deviled eggs, chicken liver mousse and homemade dill tofu. More substantial fare will include Wiener schnitzel and hanger steak with pumpkinseed chimichurri. Paired with the food will be Mr. Trummer\u2019s Freudish cocktails, like the Dream Interpreter, made with absinthe, saffron elixir and Cognac; and the Dreamer, with Champagne and elderflower essence: 506 LaGuardia Place (Houston Street), 212-777-0327, bar-freud.com\n\nOpening\n\nBASEMENT Capitalizing on the space beneath his new TriBeCa restaurant, Tetsu, Masayoshi Takayama has turned it into an intimate enclave for special kaiseki dinners served Wednesday, Thursday and Friday evenings, at $350 per person plus tax, tip and beverages. A counter facing the open kitchen is fashioned of the same bubinga wood used in the main restaurant upstairs. The space also has some plush seating at tables, and Corinthian columns from the 1865 landmarked building. Each night, the multicourse menu will offer elaborate preparations of meat, seafood, poultry or game, including top-quality Wagyu beef, whole squab and whole fish with all sorts of embellishments. The menu will change daily, and the chef expects to be behind the counter (Opens Thursday): 78 Leonard Street (Church Street), 212-207-2370, tetsunyc.com.\n\nBAKE CULTURE This bakery, founded in Taiwan by the music celebrities Chun Wu, Vanness Wu and Calvin Chen, and expanded to Brunei and Chongqing, China, has opened two locations in New York, which offer cafe seating. It\u2019s known for its vast array of international baked goods from croissants to Russian bread to Taiwanese pineapple cakes: 160-06 Northern Boulevard (160th Street), Flushing, Queens, and 48 Bowery (Canal Street), 646-858-2898, bakecultureus.com.\n\nTHE BOMBAY BREAD BAR Floyd Cardoz recently closed Paowalla, his Indian restaurant in SoHo. He has replaced it with Bombay Bread Bar, closely inspired by the bread bar he ran on the ground floor of Tabla years ago: 195 Spring Street (Sullivan Street), 212-235-1098, thebombaybreadbar.com.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOXALIS The chef Nico Russell, who worked at Daniel, has run this pop-up restaurant with tasting menus at various Brooklyn locations for the past two years. This year, it will be on the Lower East Side, on Saturdays and Sundays in March. There will be four dinners (at $95 for five to seven courses, including beverage pairings) each evening with food that the chef describes as seasonal European-style \u201cneo-bistro.\u201d Colors NY, 178 Stanton Street (Attorney Street), 929-367-1507, exploretock.com/oxalisnyc.\n\nChefs on the Move\n\nSYLVAIN PORTAY, who has been the corporate chef for Alain Ducasse\u2019s empire, has taken on the same role at Le Bilboquet on the Upper East Side. He will also lend his expertise to the restaurant\u2019s outpost in Sag Harbor, N.Y., when it reopens on May 1.", "title": "Bar Freud, Serving Inventive Cocktails, Opens in Greenwich Village", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Off The Menu"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Streisand\u2019s third dog, Miss Fanny, is a distant cousin of Samantha\u2019s, the magazine said. (Miss Fanny\u2019s mother, the story noted, had been named Funny Girl.)\n\nPhoto\n\nIf the possibility of cloning your dog intrigues you, there is good news: You do not have to be an incredibly famous and highly acclaimed actor, director, producer and writer to have it done.\n\nYou do, however, need at least $50,000. But first, a little context.\n\nWe can clone dogs? Since when?\n\nEven if you are not a close follower of clones, you may recall Dolly the Sheep, who was born in 1996. Since then, researchers have cloned about two dozen other mammal species, including cattle, deer, horses, rabbits, cats, rats \u2014 and yes, dogs.\n\nSouth Korean researchers announced that they had cloned a dog for the first time in 2005, after almost three years of work and more than 1,000 eggs. With help from a yellow Labrador retriever who served as the surrogate mother, a cloned male Afghan hound named Snuppy was born. (Snuppy, of course, stood for \u201cSeoul National University puppy.\u201d)\n\nBy 2008, a California company had partnered with a South Korean laboratory and made plans to auction off chances to clone five dogs. Later that year, The New York Times reported that the first three puppies from the group had been born in South Korea.\n\nTwo 2015 reports \u2014 from Business Insider and NPR \u2014 detail the work of Sooam Biotech, a lab in South Korea, and said the lab, on its own, had cloned more than 600 dogs.\n\nHow much does it cost?\n\nBoth articles say Sooam Biotech charged about $100,000 to attempt the process. ViaGen Pets, a company based in Texas, says it charges $50,000 for the cloning or $1,600 to merely preserve your pet\u2019s genes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nReports and information on ViaGen\u2019s website suggest that the cloning process \u2014 specifically a dog\u2019s pregnancy \u2014 usually takes about 60 days.\n\nIt was not clear which company Ms. Streisand used to create her clones. A publicist for Ms. Streisand did not immediately respond to an email or phone message on Tuesday night.\n\nMore Reporting on Dogs\n\nBut will the cloned dog actually be similar?\n\nThat depends.\n\nSooam told Business Insider that it can clone any dog, regardless of age, size or breed. NPR, though, reported that cloned animals aren\u2019t exact replicas of original dogs.\n\nResearchers at the South Korean lab told the station that the dogs it had cloned have been healthy \u2014 and had almost always looked and acted like the dogs they were cloned from.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cCats and dogs delivered by cloning have the same genes as their donor pets and will be the closest match possible to the donor,\u201d ViaGen said on its website. \u201cThis is best described as identical twins born at a later date.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe environment does interact with genetics to impact many traits such as personality and behavior,\u201d the company continued.\n\nIs it safe?\n\nThat also depends \u2014 mostly on how you define \u201csafe.\u201d\n\nIn essence, the process involves getting a genetic sample from your dog, sending the sample to the lab, and letting the scientists put the sample through a process that fuses it with an egg. Eventually, the egg develops into an embryo; and that embryo is then transferred to the surrogate, who surgeons hope will give birth.\n\nAt the Korean lab, the process requires operating on the egg donor and the surrogate mother \u2014 two dogs rented from a lab-animal provider. And, at least in the case of Sooam Biotech, it\u2019s not clear what happens after those dogs are no longer needed.\n\nThe company also told the media outlets that the cloning process works only about 33 to 40 percent of the time, which means there is strong potential for miscarriages.\n\nFar from the medical labs, Ms. Streisand told Variety that she loves sharing her Malibu home with Miss Violet and Miss Scarlett. At least from that vantage point, the process seemed to work out just fine. Because, really, whatever your genes, who wouldn\u2019t want to live in a place with an ocean view?", "title": "Barbra Streisand Cloned Her Dog. For $50,000, You Can Clone Yours.", "authors": ["Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "SYDNEY, Australia \u2014 Barnaby Joyce officially resigned Monday as Australia\u2019s deputy prime minister, clearing the way for a replacement \u2014 Michael McCormack, the veterans affairs minister \u2014 who was named to the post in an awkward news conference that included Mr. Joyce sulking in the back of a National Party gathering he had grown used to leading.\n\nIt was an embarrassing public comedown for Mr. Joyce, a brash conservative closely identified with the country\u2019s rural voters. He has been battling scandals that started earlier this month with his admission of an affair with a former staff member, who is pregnant with his child.\n\nHis trouble continued with accusations of misspending of public funds, in part to abet that relationship, along with at least two separate accusations of sexual harassment that have stirred up demands for a #MeToo reckoning across Australian politics.\n\nMr. Joyce has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing. He has said he plans to stay in Parliament. But questions about his behavior continue to swirl.", "title": "Barnaby Joyce Is Replaced as Australia\u2019s Deputy Prime Minister", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The back-and-forth between the government\u2019s two most senior figures was the latest twist in a turbulent week in Parliament, in which the culture of Australian politics has been called into question.\n\nIn announcing the ban on sex between ministers and their subordinates, Mr. Turnbull said that ministers, whether married or single, must lead by example.\n\n\u201cMinisters must recognize that while they are entitled to privacy in personal matters, they occupy positions of great responsibility and public trust,\u201d he said. \u201cThe public have high expectations of them in terms of their personal conduct and decorum.\u201d\n\nMr. Turnbull had appeared to resist the idea of a formal ban when it was suggested last week by Cathy McGowan, an independent politician. But on Thursday he said that the five-year-old code of ministerial conduct did not adequately reflect modern workplace values.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day in Australia, delivered to your inbox. Though he has spent much of the past week offering remorse to his family, he has denied ministerial misconduct and refused to resign.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf Mr. Joyce resigns, Mr. Turnbull\u2019s government will lose its one-seat parliamentary majority. Mr. Turnbull said on Thursday that it was up to Mr. Joyce whether to step down.\n\nMr. Joyce will not serve as acting prime minister during Mr. Turnbull\u2019s White House visit next week, a decision that critics said suggested the prime minister had lost confidence in him. all that is going to do is basically once more pull off the scab for everyone to look at.\u201d\n\nHe also pushed back against what he called \u201cimplied comments about the leadership of the National Party,\u201d saying that \u201cwe make our own decisions.\u201d Mr. Turnbull said later on Friday that he was not seeking to interfere with the party\u2019s decision making.\n\n\u201cI understand it\u2019s a very stressful time,\u201d Mr. Turnbull said of his deputy\u2019s earlier comments.\n\nThe Australian tabloid newspaper The Daily Telegraph reported the affair last week alongside a photograph of a pregnant Ms. Campion, fueling a fierce debate about privacy, sex and the news media.\n\nSharri Markson, the national political editor at the newspaper, said she had been surprised by the initial pushback from other news outlets on whether the story was in the public interest.\n\nThe debate has since grown to include questions about gender and abuse of
