Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWitnesses saw a man throw an object over the wall of the embassy property shortly before the initial explosion, officials said.", "title": "Bomb Thrown at U.S. Embassy in Montenegro; Attacker Kills Himself", "authors": ["Barbara Surk"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHearing you, Mr. Rahimi, in court, you sound reasonable enough,\u201d the judge said. \u201cAnd yet your actions are totally at odds with how you\u2019re speaking in court. It\u2019s really puzzling.\u201d\n\nMr. Rahimi planned an attack that was simple, with devices made from household goods, and potentially lethal. On Sept. 17, 2016, he traveled to Manhattan from his home in Elizabeth, N.J., pulling suitcases on rollers with each hand. He went on to place a homemade bomb \u2014 packed into a pressure cooker and wired to a flip-phone detonator \u2014 on a stretch of the Chelsea neighborhood\u2019s West 23rd Street, busy with pedestrians on a warm Saturday night. The blast from that device sent shrapnel flying and launched a construction waste container across the street. More than 30 people were injured, and they described that night in testimony at Mr. Rahimi\u2019s trial.\n\nHe placed a second bomb on West 27th Street, but a passer-by on edge from the blast four blocks away noticed it and called the police, and the bomb squad took the device away without incident. Earlier that day, Mr. Rahimi had placed a bomb in a garbage can at the finish line of a United States Marine Corps charity race in Seaside Park, N.J. The race\u2019s start time had been delayed, however, and no one was hurt when the bomb exploded.\n\nHe had planned more attacks. The day after the Chelsea explosion, Mr. Rahimi returned to New Jersey and left a backpack containing six pipe bombs in an Elizabeth, N.J., train station. One exploded after it was detonated by a police robot, but the bombs caused no injuries.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Rahimi was portrayed as a loner drawn to calls of jihad in online publications like Inspire.\n\nOn Tuesday, wearing a long beard and a kufi, a cap worn by many men in South Asia and parts of Africa, Mr. Rahimi complained in his statement about past harassment in airports over his traditional dress, and even before, when he did not have a beard and wore shorts \u201cas if I\u2019m going to the beach.\u201d\n\nHe focused most of his brief statement on his father and a misconception that he believes had taken hold that the older man supported terrorism. \u201cMy house does not harbor any terrorist-type activities,\u201d he said. Of his father, Mohammad Rahami, who attended Tuesday\u2019s hearing in the rear of the gallery, he said, \u201cHe wants to give us a better future. I commend him for that.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe mentioned the call his father made to the authorities in 2014 to report that the convicted man was behaving suspiciously. \u201cWe had our differences in life,\u201d Mr. Rahimi said. \u201cMy father did his best to try to quell everything down.\u201d\n\nAt this, Mr. Rahami, who spells his name slightly differently than his son, bowed his head in court and quietly sobbed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn December, prosecutors said Mr. Rahimi had been giving other inmates access to speeches and lectures by Osama bin Laden and Anwar al-Awlaki and the same sort of bomb-making instructions from Inspire that were used as evidence at his trial. In his statement, Mr. Rahimi avoided discussing his part in these infractions, instead blaming the government for locking up the other inmates in the first place.\n\nOf his own life, he said, \u201cI have American friends and I also have Muslim friends.\u201d\n\nJudge Berman called his crimes \u201cheinous, wanton, life-threatening\u201d in handing down the maximum sentences for the eight crimes of which he was convicted. Mr. Rahimi already faced an automatic life sentence for one of the crimes, and Judge Berman added a second life term and, on top of them both, an additional 30 years in prison, all to be served consecutively. The redundant sentences would serve the same end \u2014 Mr. Rahimi is unlikely to ever leave prison \u2014 but could have individual practical implications should he prevail on an appeal of one or more of the convictions in the future.\n\nHe was also ordered to pay $562,803 in restitution to victims and businesses whose storefronts were mangled in the blast. The money would come out of his prison wages, should he work.\n\nGeoffrey S. Berman, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said in a statement, \u201cRahimi\u2019s conviction and sentencing are victories for New York City and our nation in the fight against terror.\u201d\n\nPauline Nelson, who was injured in the bombing while driving in a car with her daughter and grandson, spoke at the end of the hearing and addressed Mr. Rahimi.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m an immigrant just like you,\u201d she said. \u201cGod forgive you, that\u2019s all I have to say.\u201d", "title": "Bomber Sentenced to 2 Life Terms for Manhattan Attack", "authors": ["Michael Wilson"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s not to like? Scores of companies, including some of the country\u2019s biggest employers, are handing out bonuses, announcing with a flourish that they are sharing the windfall from corporate tax cuts with their workers.\n\nA look at the fine print, though, shows that some of the largess is not nearly as large as company news releases suggest.\n\nConsider retailers like Walmart, Lowe\u2019s and Home Depot. They\u2019ve tied the size of bonuses to tenure, so that only employees who have been with the company for 20 years or more will receive the $1,000 maximum that was highlighted in their announcements. Few employees meet that requirement.\n\nThe median tenure for retail workers, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, is three years. At Walmart and Home Depot, that work history results in a $250 bonus, and at Lowe\u2019s, $200. And nearly a quarter of American wage and salary workers have logged less than a year with their current employer. For them, bonuses at these big retailers will range from $150 to $200.", "title": "Bonuses After Tax Cut Don\u2019t Always Live Up to Their Billing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "The moral of this story is that unless the economy is deeply depressed, there will always be some companies, somewhere, raising wages and offering bonuses. Which brings me to the Trump tax cut and the very bad, no good job much of the media initially did of covering its effects.\n\nEvery card-carrying economist agrees that cutting corporate tax rates will have some trickle-down effect on wages \u2013 in the long run. How much of a trickle-down effect depends on a bunch of technical factors: what share of corporate profits represents monopoly rents rather than returns to capital, how responsive inflows of foreign capital are to the U.S. rate of return, what share of the capital stock is even affected by the corporate tax rate. Enthusiasts claim that the tax cut will eventually go 100% to workers; most serious modelers think the number is more like 20 or 25 percent.\n\nWhatever the number, however, it\u2019s about the long run. It requires a chain of events: lower taxes -> higher investment -> higher stock of capital -> higher demand for labor -> higher wages. And this chain of events should take a number of years, probably decades, to fully work itself through. Even in the most favorable analyses, there is no reason to expect any wage gains in the first few months after a tax cut.\n\nYet for a while there the news was full of stories about companies announcing that they were giving their workers bonuses thanks to the Trump tax cut. Why were they doing this?\n\nWell, the tax cut provided no immediate incentive to raise wages. It did, however, give companies that benefited from the tax cut a strong political incentive to claim that the tax break was the reason for bonuses or wage hikes they would have given in any case. Why not? They want the tax cut to look good, since it\u2019s good for them. And hyping its benefits is a cheap way to make a de facto campaign contribution to an administration that can do a lot to help companies it likes, say by removing pesky safety or environmental regulations.", "title": "Opinion | Bonuses and Bogosity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQueens has taken its place alongside cities like Paris, Venice, Hong Kong and San Francisco in the \u201c111 Places\u201d series of global travel books, crammed with insider tips. About a third of the one-page recommendations will direct you to something to eat in New York\u2019s most ethnically diverse borough. The book reveals watering holes like the Anable Basin Sailing Bar & Grill in Long Island City, sources for Romanian charcuterie in Astoria, the story behind \u201cSpaghetti Park\u201d in Corona and even advice on the Malaysian hawker food menu at Curry Leaves in Flushing: \u201c111 Places in Queens That You Must Not Miss\u201d by Joe DiStefano (Emons, $19.90).\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Book Highlights Queens in All of Its Deliciousness", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Brown\u2019s statements highlight California\u2019s distinction as a state of high highs and low lows. From the recession of the early 1990s to the 2001 dot-com crash to the housing collapse of a decade ago, downturns often end up being more pronounced in the state than elsewhere. The next recession, whenever it comes, will almost certainly land harder here than it does in the rest of the country. And that boom-bust pattern is especially tough on California\u2019s budget \u2014 something that Mr. Brown, who was first elected governor more than four decades ago, knows well.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2009, as the last recession took hold, California state revenue fell 19 percent, versus 8 percent for state revenues nationwide, according to Moody\u2019s Analytics. There has been a strong rebound since then, but the gains are unlikely to last. That is because California\u2019s government relies on a heavily progressive income tax that generates most of its revenue from a relatively small number of wealthy taxpayers whose incomes are erratic.\n\nEven a blip in the stock market can punch holes in the state\u2019s budget. And because stock prices have more than doubled during Mr. Brown\u2019s term, it seems like a good bet that whoever succeeds him will face challenges. If and when that day comes, any proposal to increase taxes will probably be unpopular. Mr. Brown already raised income taxes to address the state\u2019s last budget mess, and California taxpayers took a further hit as a result of the new tax bill, which curbed the deductibility of state and local taxes on federal returns.\n\n\u201cHis successor gets a world in which revenues are more volatile,\u201d without the option of raising taxes, said David Crane, a lecturer in public policy at Stanford University and a former adviser to Mr. Brown\u2019s predecessor, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger. \u201cThat\u2019s a really tough world to operate in.\u201d\n\nBig Swings The economy and job market are more volatile in California than in the nation as a whole. The state\u2019s job losses are more severe in bad times, and the gains are more pronounced in good times. California\u2019s employment volatility, relative to the U.S. average INDEX: U.S. = 100 170 160 150 140 130 120 110 100 \u201980 \u201985 \u201990 \u201995 \u201900 \u201905 \u201910 \u201915 California\u2019s employment volatility, relative to the U.S. average INDEX: U.S. = 100 170 160 150 140 130 120 110 100 \u201980 \u201985 \u201990 \u201995 \u201900 \u201905 \u201910 \u201915\n\nA recession would also further expose problems that have festered for decades. Across California, cities and school districts are having trouble keeping up with ballooning pension obligations, squeezing teacher salaries and state services. In warning about budget troubles to come, Mr. Brown was making a case for adding more of today\u2019s surplus to the state\u2019s rainy day fund to cushion the blow of the next downturn.\n\nMr. Brown\u2019s final State of the State speech also included plenty of optimistic notes and pushes for big spending in the future on items mostly outside the state\u2019s general fund. He talked about \u201csetting the pace for the entire nation\u201d and embracing big infrastructure projects like a high-speed rail line despite doubts about its viability as costs mount.\n\n\u201cYou have all of these projects that he wants to do,\u201d said Stephen Levy, the director of the Center for Continuing Study of the California Economy, an independent research organization. \u201cHe\u2019s saying, this year may be rosy, but watch out, it ain\u2019t going to continue. And I agree.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nEven in prosperity, California has plenty of problems. The bulk of its recent gains have flowed to wealthier coastal cities, leaving inland areas behind, and a severe housing shortage has led to punishing rent increases and rising homelessness.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, economists generally agree that the state\u2019s long-term prospects are bright. It is home to many of the world\u2019s most valuable and innovative companies, and it attracts an outsize portion of the skilled work force and venture capital financing, helping it create new industries as old ones slow down or fade away.\n\nAnd recession forecasting is a tough business even for those whose livelihoods depend on it, like Ed Del Beccaro, a senior managing director in the Walnut Creek office of Transwestern, a commercial real estate brokerage. He manages a team of brokers and travels around the Bay Area giving speeches and forecasts to chambers of commerce and other business groups.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cTwo years ago I was predicting a recession in September of 2017, and in October I said we were going to have a recession at the end of 2018,\u201d he said. \u201cToday I think that unless we get bombed by North Korea, we will have a pretty amazing two years of growth.\u201d\n\nWith a sudden spurt in demand for office space, Mr. Del Beccaro said, he is hiring new workers and spending more on marketing to prospective clients. \u201cI was just authorized to go out and get more brokers and offer them incentives to hopefully get them to switch over from other companies,\u201d he said.\n\nBut winter will come eventually, and when it does, Mr. Brown\u2019s counsel about planning ahead may help shape how California weathers it.", "title": "Boom and Gloom: An Economic Warning for California", "authors": ["Conor Dougherty"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "AT 12 MINUTES 46 SECONDS\n\nSalvaged Dance\n\nLast weekend, St\u00e9phane Den\u00e8ve led the New York Philharmonic in selections from Prokofiev\u2019s \u201cRomeo and Juliet.\u201d The suite followed the ballet\u2019s plot, which meant it excluded diverting interludes like \u201cDance With Mandolins.\u201d This wasn\u2019t the first time moments like that were left out: Before the ballet had its Russian premiere in 1940, several years after Prokofiev wrote the score, he was forced to revise it heavily. The ending, once happy, became tragic, and a series of divertissements were cut. Still, Prokofiev found ways to recycle some of the music elsewhere \u2014 such as in his Fifth Symphony, which you can hear in this video of Valery Gergiev conducting the Mariinsky Orchestra. The exhilarating opening of the second movement is a scherzo passage originally meant for the ballet. If only we could hear more lost moments like this. Where is the suite of discarded \u201cRomeo\u201d dances? JOSHUA BARONE\n\nRead more about the history of Prokofiev\u2019s \u201cRomeo and Juliet.\u201d", "title": "Border Percussion: The 8 Best Classical Music Moments of the Week on YouTube", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe idea that he has traction with remain voters is absurd,\u201d said Tim Bale, a professor of politics at Queen Mary University of London, \u201cso it has to be about something else, and that has to be about keeping himself in the public eye.\u201d\n\nIt would not be the first time. Last year he caused a stir before the Conservative Party\u2019s annual conference by publishing a lengthy essay on his Brexit vision. More recently, he made headlines with calls for higher health spending, perhaps seeking to justify his widely debunked claim that quitting the European Union would free up around $500 million a week for the National Health Service.\n\nYears ago, Mr. Johnson\u2019s famously dismissed his prospects of becoming prime minister as being \u201cabout as good as the chances of finding Elvis on Mars, or me being reincarnated as an olive.\u201d\n\nBut more recently \u2014 and plausibly \u2014 he admitted his ambitions, likening his approach to becoming leader to grabbing a football if it \u201ccame loose from the back of the scrum,\u201d a term from Rugby football akin to a fumble in American football.\n\nIn 2016 that ball slipped, agonizingly, from his grasp after the Brexit referendum, when Mr. Johnson was abandoned by key allies and forced to withdraw from the contest to replace the former prime minister, David Cameron, who quit after the plebiscite. Theresa May went on to take the crown.\n\nBut Mr. Johnson may be sensing another moment of opportunity, as Mrs. May struggles to control her cabinet amid calls from some of her own lawmakers for her to step aside.\n\nBrexit has caught her in an unforgiving political vise. A \u201csoft\u201d, departure, protecting business by retaining close economic ties to the bloc, is being opposed by Brexit enthusiasts in the cabinet, including Mr. Johnson.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut a \u201chard Brexit,\u201d or clean break, of the type such right-wing and Brexit supporters favor, could be rejected by Parliament, plunging Mrs. May\u2019s government into a terminal crisis.\n\nThat conundrum has paralyzed decision making in London, leaving Mrs. May looking weak, unable to tell European Union negotiators (or the British public) what future relationship she wants with the bloc.\n\nMr. Johnson\u2019s was the first in a series of speeches by ministers \u2014 including one by Mrs. May scheduled for Saturday \u2014 designed to fill that vacuum. But if this speech is any indication, the British public and European negotiators may be disappointed.\n\nMr. Johnson provided little in the way of new ideas or approaches in his remarks, which a Labour lawmaker, Yvette Cooper, dismissed as \u201cwaffly, bumbling, empty.\u201d\n\nSome believe that Mr. Johnson is looking for a pretext to quit the cabinet over Brexit and cause a leadership crisis, and on Wednesday he avoided a reporter\u2019s question about whether he would stay in the government if he should lose the internal debate over the terms of withdrawal.\n\nThese are nervous times for Mr. Johnson. He has been weakened by his performance as foreign secretary, which has been criticized as accident-prone and lightweight.\n\nMeanwhile, he has encountered unexpected competition for the Brexit spotlight in the form of Jacob Rees-Mogg, a caricature patrician with impeccable manners, a socially conservative philosophy and hard-line pro-Brexit views.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf there is a contest to succeed Mrs. May, the top two contenders will be chosen by Conservative lawmakers, but the final choice is up to party members, now thought to number around 80,000 people.\n\nAmong these activists, hard-line Brexit supporters, mainly from an older age category, are thought to be overrepresented. They seem to be warming to Mr. Rees-Mogg, who has transformed himself from a political curiosity to a front-runner for the leadership, finishing above Mr. Johnson in some surveys of party members.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Rees-Mogg\u2019s rise was accelerated last month when Mrs. May\u2019s botched cabinet reshuffle inadvertently opened a vacancy for him to lead the European Research Group \u2014 a gathering of hard Brexit lawmakers \u2014 giving him a platform unencumbered by any need to toe the government line. His brand of direct, upper-class speaking has given him celebrity status and won him a set of followers now nicknamed the Mogglodytes.\n\n\u201cHe is on your TV, he is on your Instagram feed, he is at the Cambridge Union,\u201d wrote one newspaper columnist, referring to the ancient university\u2019s debating society, and joking that it was only a matter of time before Mr. Rees-Mogg was helping draw the numbers on the National Lottery.\n\nMr. Johnson\u2019s allies put the best gloss on the rise of Mr. Rees-Mogg, suggesting that his more extreme views (he opposes abortion even in the case of rape, for example) allow Mr. Johnson the political space to promote himself as a more generally acceptable Brexit supporter.\n\nMr. Bale believes that this new competition has unnerved Mr. Johnson, but also notes that the foreign secretary once wrote a book about Winston Churchill, who was regarded as something of a maverick before he came to power.\n\n\u201cPerhaps the lesson he has drawn is that you can blow it several times, and still, in its hour of need, the country will turn to you,\u201d said Mr. Bale, who added that while the Churchill analogy was very far from apposite, \u201cso many strange things are happening in British politics that it would be unwise to count him out.\u201d", "title": "Boris Johnson Warns Against a Brexit Do-Over", "authors": ["Stephen Castle"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "[READ: Indonesia\u2019s Orangutans Suffer as Fires Rage and Businesses Grow]\n\nThat would leave the surviving number at around 148,000, according to the report. However, the World Wildlife Fund estimates that the remaining population of Borneo orangutans is much smaller, at around 105,000.\n\nTo identify the likely causes of orangutan population losses, the researchers relied on maps of estimated land cover change on Borneo during the 16-year period.\n\nThe comparison of orangutan and habitat losses suggested that land clearance caused the most dramatic rates of decline. However, a much larger number of orangutans were lost in areas where there was less logging and deforestation. While the rates of decline were less in those areas, the additional forest cover means far more orangutans are found in them, the researchers said.\n\n[READ: A Refuge for Orangutans, and a Quandary for Environmentalists]\n\nBy 2015, they reported, about half of the orangutans estimated to live in Borneo in 1999 were found in areas in which human resource use has caused significant changes to the surrounding environment. Based on predicted future losses of forest cover and the assumption that orangutans ultimately cannot survive outside forest areas, the researchers predicted that more than 45,000 additional orangutans will die during the next 35 years.\n\n\u201cOrangutans are flexible and can survive to some extent in a mosaic of forests, plantations and logged forest, but only when they are not killed,\u201d said Serge Wich, a professor at Liverpool John Moores University in Britain and a member of the research team.\n\n\u201cSo, in addition to protection of forests, we need to focus on addressing the underlying causes of orangutan killing. The latter requires public awareness and education, more effective law enforcement, and also more studies as to why people kill orangutans in the first place,\u201d he said.", "title": "Borneo Lost More Than 100,000 Orangutans From 1999 to 2015", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Prada shirt, $690, (212) 334-8888. Recently, it was the unexpected site of a jewelry presentation: Stephanie D\u2019heygere launched her eponymous accessories brand in one of the market\u2019s hothouse-like green steel pavilions where a variety of seasonal and exotic flowers are sold daily.\n\n\u201cI really wanted a showroom that represented the heart of the collection and brand,\u201d says the Belgian-born, Paris-based designer, who has spent the past seven years at an array of major fashion houses. Laid out on the flower shop\u2019s shelves were D\u2019heygere\u2019s designs: a line of diminutively sized leather bags, semitransparent belts and cleverly conceived jewelry \u2014 pieces that feel playful and delightfully idiosyncratic. \u201cI\u2019ve had this idea of designing jewelry that can carry flowers for a very long time. It never really felt right to propose this idea to one of my clients, which made me realize that it\u2019s a very personal idea that I\u2019d rather keep to myself.\u201d\n\nThis first collection is titled \u201cThe Flower Shop,\u201d and flowers are central to the D\u2019heygere brand. \u201cI love buying fresh flowers,\u201d says D\u2019heygere, \u201cand I kept on thinking, how cool would it be if I could go to the flower shop and just pick a flower to match my outfit?\u201d\n\nImage Pieces from Stephanie D\u2019heygere\u2019s fall/winter 2018 collection. Credit Arnaud Lajeunie\n\nD\u2019heygere is something of an industry insider. She studied at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp with hopes of working at Chanel. Then, she recounts, she \u201caccidentally ended up at Margiela, a brand I would never have considered at first. It turned out to be the best opportunity ever. When I left school, I was trained to be a fashion designer \u2014 it never occurred to me that I would become an accessories designer.\u201d", "title": "Brand to Know: An Innovative Jewelry Line Inspired by Flowers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "People often ask the artist and designer Pierre Davis how to wear the intricate, largely handmade clothing she creates for her Los Angeles-based line, No Sesso. \u201cThere\u2019s this joke I have that maybe I\u2019ll start putting directions in the garments on how to put them on,\u201d she says. In fact, there\u2019s no right answer. \u201cA lot of the pieces can be worn different ways. It\u2019s all good. Who\u2019s to say there\u2019s one way to wear something?\u201d\n\nChallenging traditional ideas of dress \u2014 who wears a thing, and how it\u2019s worn \u2014 is central to both the design and politics of No Sesso (\u201cno sex/gender\u201d in Italian), which has developed something of a cult following in L.A. and attracted the attention of boundary-pushing musicians like Kelela, Erykah Badu and Kelsey Lu since its launch in 2014.\n\nTied, stitched, knotted or delicately embroidered, No Sesso\u2019s unisex pieces seem to be constantly shifting and evolving. Seams undulate like lines of music and burst open, colors clash and loose, irregular knits transition into sleek, sharply tailored lam\u00e9 or billowing nylon. Even geometric patterns, constructed from pieces of vintage fabric, vibrate with life. Denim waistbands are layered into a fitted sheath dress, and white painter\u2019s coveralls become a delicate silk jumpsuit.\n\n\u201cSome of the pieces are almost like Transformers, or convertible cars,\u201d says Davis. \u201cEveryone has different shaped bodies, so it makes the garments a bit more accessible.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccessibility \u2014 especially for black, brown and transgender bodies that have historically been underrepresented in the fashion industry \u2014 is at the heart of Davis\u2019s global vision for the brand, which she calls \u201ca platform for other like-minded artists who just want to be seen or represented.\u201d But when she first started making clothes, it was in answer to a personal need. \u201cI was designing for myself,\u201d she says. \u201cI wanted garments that I connected to. Sometimes it\u2019s really hard to find things you actually want to spend your money on.\u201d", "title": "Brand to Know: a Gender-Neutral Line Challenging Norms", "authors": ["Merrell Hambleton", "On The Verge"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Drury flew here from Arizona on Wednesday, met Nevin for dinner that night \u2014 the coach picked up the tab \u2014 and went through workouts for the first time with his new teammates on Thursday, taking ground balls and batting practice.\n\nWhen he met with reporters on Thursday, he remarked several times that he was \u201cpumped\u201d about the trade. The Yankees were his favorite team growing up in Grants Pass, Ore., about an hour north of the California border, and he will have a chance to compete for a championship after getting a taste of the playoffs last season with the Diamondbacks.\n\nBut most enticing is a return to third base \u2014 his natural position, but one that he played only once last season as the Diamondbacks\u2019 Jake Lamb emerged as an All-Star at third.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGeneral Manager Brian Cashman, who gave up two prospects in the deal \u2014 second baseman Nick Solak went to Tampa Bay and pitcher Chris Widener to Arizona \u2014 relayed his scouts\u2019 consensus when he spoke of Drury on Wednesday: Even though Drury played well the last two seasons in Arizona \u2014 he hit .275 with 29 homers and a .775 on-base-plus-slugging percentage \u2014 he was capable of more production.\n\nAs it turns out, Drury, 25, feels the same way.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t feel like I\u2019ve done anything like what I\u2019m capable of the last couple years,\u201d said Drury, who is 6-foot-2, 210 pounds and hits right-handed. \u201cThey\u2019ve both been kind of a grind. The numbers are O.K., I would say. But I don\u2019t think that those last two seasons is half the player I am. I truly believe that. But then I have to go out and do it. That\u2019s what I\u2019m here for.\u201d\n\nDrury\u2019s reason for optimism is the changes he made to his swing over the winter.\n\nHe drove from his off-season home in Las Vegas to the Los Angeles area about six times to work with the hitting coaches Craig Wallenbrock, Tim Laker and Robert Van Scoyoc, who have transformed the swings \u2014 and careers \u2014 of Boston\u2019s J. D. Martinez, his former teammate in Arizona, and the Los Angeles Dodgers\u2019 Chris Taylor.\n\nThe idea: to turn some of the 37 doubles he hit last season \u2014 more than any Yankee, despite having only 445 at-bats \u2014 into home runs.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll take a line drive up the middle all day,\u201d Drury said. \u201cBut when I\u2019m getting a 3-1 fastball or looking for a certain pitch, I don\u2019t want that to be what I\u2019m settling for. I want to drive the ball and be able to hit some home runs.\u201d\n\nThe changes have resulted in Drury\u2019s getting the bat head into the hitting zone early and carrying it through longer so that he has greater margin for error, and also changing the plane of his swing, so it has an upward tilt, which he hopes will result in more fly balls that carry over the fence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t understand how to hit certain pitches that I was trying to get,\u201d Drury said. \u201cI was just trying to get big with my swing, and that doesn\u2019t work. It\u2019s got to be your natural swing.\u201d", "title": "Brandon Drury Begins Yankees Career With a Retooled Swing", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "While government officials and the technology companies\u2019 representatives say their discussions have been cordial and productive to date, the companies have made it clear they do not intend to become arbiters of truth.\n\nA BBC World Service poll last year found that 92 percent of Brazilians expressed concern about being able to discern between fact and falsehood online, the highest percentage of respondents in any country surveyed. But just what constitutes fake news is up for debate.\n\nThe two front-runners in the race \u2014 former president Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva, a leftist, and Congressman Jair Bolsonaro, a right-wing provocateur \u2014 have taken aim at news outlets for critical coverage, in much the same way President Trump has criticized American news organizations.\n\nMr. Bolsonaro and his surrogates, for instance, labeled fake news an article in Folha de S\u00e3o Paulo that raised questions about how he and his family afforded their real estate holdings on public-servant salaries.\n\nMr. da Silva is by far the leading target of negative fake news stories in Brazil, according to an analysis by Veja, a weekly newsmagazine, which recently published a cover story about misinformation campaigns. One example was an article falsely claiming that Mr. da Silva had said he would ascend to the presidency even if it meant trampling the federal judge who convicted him of corruption and money laundering last year.\n\nMr. Bolsonaro is the rare Brazilian public figure who is the subject of more fake news stories that cast him in a positive light than a negative one, according to Veja\u2019s analysis. A spokesman for Mr. Bolsonaro did not respond to an emailed query about whether the campaign considers the use of fake news a legitimate electoral tactic. Mr. de Silva recently said such tactics should not be employed.\n\nMarina Silva, a former environment minister who is running third in the polls, announced that she was recruiting an army of volunteers to discredit the type of disinformation campaigns that she said derailed her past two bids for the presidency, in 2010 and 2014. False stories spread on social media about Ms. Silva before those elections included a claim that, as an evangelical, she intended to ban video games and an accusation that her bodyguards once fatally beat a gay man who tried to approach her.", "title": "Brazil Looks to Crack Down on Fake News Ahead of Bitter Election", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "RIO DE JANEIRO \u2014 After months of escalating violence in Rio de Janeiro that included television coverage of tourists being chased and beaten by robbers during the famed Carnival festivities, Brazil\u2019s president on Friday ordered the military to take control of public security in the state.\n\nIt is the first federal intervention in a state since Brazil\u2019s return to democracy in the 1980s, and it is seen by some as a bid by the president, Michel Temer, to improve his favorability ratings rather than as a measure to tackle crime.\n\nThe decree signed by Mr. Temer on Friday afternoon falls short of a full intervention in the state government. While the military will take control of security, Gov. Luiz Fernando Pez\u00e3o will continue to run the state government of Rio de Janeiro.\n\n\u201cThis decision is motivated more by politics than sound public administration,\u201d said Kennedy Alencar, a political commentator and blogger in Bras\u00edlia, Brazil\u2019s capital. \u201cNow the focus of news will be on the president\u2019s federal intervention to address an issue that concerns the whole country.\u201d", "title": "Brazil\u2019s Military Is Put in Charge of Security in Rio de Janeiro", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "A researcher read aloud the words that were printed in a bubble beside the image. In one experimental group, the children followed gender stereotype: \u201cHello! My name is Sarah, and my favorite toy is My Little Pony! I have lots, and play with them every day.\u201d \u201cHello! My name is Thomas, and every day I like to play with my cars. They\u2019re my favorite toys!\u201d For the other experimental group, Sarah had the car and Thomas had My Little Pony; the language was otherwise identical.\n\nAfter they had seen the pictures, the children in the study were shown a set of toys, chosen to be stereotypically masculine and feminine (baby doll, jet fighter, tool kit, tea set) and asked who should play with which toy, and the children who had seen the counter-stereotypic pictures were more flexible in their answers, more open to the idea that both girls and boys might like toys from both sides of the conventional aisle.\n\nThey were also less rigid when they were asked which children from the pictures they wanted to play with; exposure to Sarah-with-the-car and Thomas-with-the-pony meant that children were more open to playing with representatives of the other gender. So the toys in the pictures affected who the children wanted as playmates.\n\nDr. Spinner pointed out that seeing the photos did not open up the children\u2019s preferences for what toys they themselves wanted to play with; they were more likely to say that other boys and girls could play with a variety of toys, but the two experimental groups were equally unlikely to make those counter-stereotypic choices themselves. On the other hand, she said, it was only one exposure, and it\u2019s possible, if there were more of those counter-stereotypic images around, that children might become more open to enjoying the whole spectrum of toys.\n\nLaura Zimmermann, a developmental psychologist who is a professor of psychology at Shenandoah University in Virginia, was the first author on a study published last year in the Journal of Children and Media, which looked at preschool children\u2019s responses to toy commercials. Children are showing more flexibility than they used to, she said, in terms of who they thought the ads were meant for, responding that both boys and girls, for example, could like Batman, or like the \u201cfemale\u201d line of Lego building blocks.\n\n\u201cTheir behavior got much more stereotypical when they were asked their own preferences,\u201d she said, and the boys especially were unwilling to say that they liked any of the ads aimed at girls.\n\nBut the ads themselves, she said, continue to reflect the same old stereotypes. \u201cMy concerns are that children\u2019s ads shape and reinforce stereotypes,\u201d Dr. Zimmermann said. \u201cThey are obviously not working alone; we have wider societal influences at work, but ads are powerful.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis is not about taking away the doll, or banishing the train. \u201cIf they aren\u2019t interested in engaging in non-stereotypic gender play that is O.K. too,\u201d Dr. Zimmermann said in an email. \u201cChildren should be free to play with the toys they enjoy \u2014 toys should not be \u2018assigned\u2019 by gender.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut there is also research to say that when the lines are drawn too strictly, children\u2019s worlds become not only more divided, but also more limited. Traditionally masculine toys like blocks and puzzles, Dr. Spinner said, encourage visual and spatial skills, while traditionally feminine toys encourage communication and social skills.\n\n\u201cIf children only play with one, then they are missing out on a whole host of skills,\u201d she said.\n\nThey are also limiting their own interests and the scope of their futures.\n\n\u201cWe know that these stereotypes that are being shaped and reinforced can be linked to a lot of different things from educational and occupational goals to academic ability to social development,\u201d Dr. Zimmermann said. \u201cIt is really important to have children get this broad range of experiences.\u201d\n\nAs children grow up, Dr. Spinner said, they do tend to become more flexible about what boys and girls can do; 7-year-olds are less rigid than 4- or 5-year-olds. But the messages they get from their environment are important, and so is the chance to play with toys \u2014 and with other children \u2014 in ways that don\u2019t box them in too tightly.\n\n\u201cMixed gender play is really important, getting boys and girls to play with one another and recognize behavioral similarities,\u201d Dr. Spinner said. \u201cChildren can overcome their anxieties about playing with other-gender children if you can get them to understand there are a lot of similarities in what they like to play with, rather than focusing on the gender of the child.\u201d\n\nSomewhere between the ages of 2 and 3, children figure out whether they are boys or girls, developmental psychologists say, often citing Lawrence Kohlberg\u2019s theory of gender identity development; they go on from there to identify the people around them as male or female, and to create rules and categories of what behaviors and interests and habits go with which identity.\n\n\u201cThe good news or bad news is, experience makes a difference,\u201d Dr. Zimmermann said. The images children see can reinforce stereotypes and limit their horizons, but they can also open up possibilities and lead kids to believe that they have more choices. Children are actively seeking clues about what their gender identities mean; toys and play should give them space, not narrow their choices.\n\nMany parents have stories of a girl who insisted on rocking a toy train to sleep, or a boy who pushed a doll along the floor, making train noises, foiling well-meaning parental attempts to foster non-stereotypic play. And parents don\u2019t have to \u201ceradicate\u201d all stereotypical play, Dr. Zimmermann said in an email message.\n\n\u201cAfter all, a princess can play with worms. And ninja cupcakes are quite tasty.\u201d", "title": "Breaking Gender Stereotypes in the Toy Box", "authors": ["Perri Klass", "The Checkup"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWho\u2019s Able-Bodied Anyway?\u201d (The Upshot, Sunday Review, Feb. 4):\n\nThe number of \u201cable\u201d people living in poverty represents a crisis \u2014 a crisis of opportunity.\n\nIndeed, America\u2019s able poor are not lazy. Rather, they have been handicapped by stagnant wages, costly birth control and child care, a shortage of affordable housing, and by a justice system that criminalizes poverty and race, which in turn leads to discrimination by employers.\n\nAbility is nothing without opportunity. We, as a society, have a responsibility to provide the means to break the cycle of poverty.\n\nSocial welfare programs are important, but alone they cannot lift people out of poverty. For this to happen, we must also ensure that every person, no matter his or her race or circumstance, has the opportunity to go to work and earn a living wage.\n\nOnly then can poor, able Americans climb the economic ladder and reach their true potential.\n\nGEORGE T. MCDONALD, NEW YORK", "title": "Opinion | Breaking the Cycle of Poverty", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "In a post on Twitter on Saturday, he also acknowledged \u201cmistakes I made several years ago while at Save the Children,\u201d a charity that promotes children\u2019s rights around the globe. \u201cI take responsibility for my actions and will hold myself to a higher standard in the future,\u201d he added.\n\nIn a statement, Save the Children said that it suspended Mr. Cox in 2015 and investigated accusations of \u201cinappropriate behavior\u201d against him, but that he had resigned before the inquiry was completed. The charity said its chief executive, Kevin Watkins, had ordered a review of its system for dealing with complaints about behavior in the workplace.\n\nAccording to the Cambridge police report, a woman went to a restaurant in Harvard Square with Mr. Cox on Oct. 29, 2015, and he \u201ctouched her inappropriately,\u201d grabbed her by the hips several times, pulled her hair and \u201cforced his thumb into her mouth in a sexual way.\u201d\n\nThe dinner took place a month after Mr. Cox resigned as a senior executive at Save the Children.\n\nMs. Cox, 41, was a rising star in the opposition Labour Party and a passionate advocate for causes such as the victims of the civil war in Syria when she was shot in June 2016 in Birstall, England, one week before Britain\u2019s referendum on membership in the European Union. She had supported remaining in the bloc.\n\nIn November 2016, a jury convicted Thomas Mair, then 53, of murder after a seven-day trial. He was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of a parole. In court, when asked for his name, he replied, \u201cMy name is death to traitors, freedom for Britain.\u201d\n\nOn Sunday, Kim Leadbeater, a sister of Ms. Cox, said on the Jo Cox Foundation website: \u201cAs a family, we will support Brendan as he endeavors to do the right thing by admitting mistakes he may have made in the past, and we respect him for doing so.\u201d", "title": "Brendan Cox, Husband of Murdered U.K. Lawmaker, Resigns Over Abuse Accusations", "authors": ["Yonette Joseph"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "I usually read books that are actually in the form of books, with paper, covers and binding. I like the weight of the book in my hands and I prefer the experience of actually turning pages. I like the smell of books as well. I usually have two books that I am reading simultaneously. One is normally a paperback that fits into the back of my pants and is easy to travel with when I\u2019m heading out. The other is often a hardcover and it stays at home waiting for me by my bed. That said, I do love audiobooks. I listen to audiobooks while I\u2019m drawing. For example, I\u2019ve listened to books by St. Augustine, Oliver Sacks, Jane Austen, Emily Bront\u00eb, Patti Smith and Carrie Fisher. In fact, I might even argue the last two authors have audiobooks that are better than the physical books, since Patti Smith and Carrie Fisher actually read their own books to you. And two years ago, I experienced all of the \u201cHarry Potter\u201d books as read by Jim Dale. They were glorious.\n\nWhat book might people be surprised to find on your shelves?\n\nI have a lot of Bibles. Several years ago I read both the Old and the New Testament as research for a speech I was giving in D.C. and I was very moved by the humanity of many of the stories. King David and his son Absalom especially got to me. Here was a story about a child who spends his entire adult life trying to usurp his father, yet in the end the father loves his son no matter what and mourns him deeply when he dies. Isn\u2019t there a lesson here for all parents about the meaning of love without conditions? I was also surprised to discover that the story of Onan isn\u2019t actually about onanism, and that King Solomon, the wisest of all the kings, ended his days turning against God. Who knew? Plus, there\u2019s a talking donkey like in \u201cShrek.\u201d\n\nWho is your favorite fictional hero or heroine? Your favorite antihero or villain?\n\nI\u2019ve always been drawn to stories about orphans: Pip from \u201cGreat Expectations,\u201d by Charles Dickens; Mary Lennox from \u201cThe Secret Garden,\u201d by Frances Hodgson Burnett; and of course Harry Potter from the series by J. K. Rowling. If pressed, however, I\u2019d add a few children with living parents, like Lyra Belacqua from the \u201cHis Dark Materials\u201d trilogy by Philip Pullman; Max from \u201cWhere the Wild Things Are,\u201d by Maurice Sendak; and Douglas Spaulding from \u201cDandelion Wine,\u201d by Ray Bradbury.\n\nAntiheroes or villains include Humbert Humbert from \u201cLolita,\u201d by Vladimir Nabokov; Mrs. Coulter from \u201cHis Dark Materials\u201d; and the particularly terrifying Dolores Umbridge from the \u201cHarry Potter\u201d series. I\u2019d also add Edward Gorey, who is responsible for the deaths of 26 children in \u201cThe Gashlycrumb Tinies.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s the best book you\u2019ve ever received as a gift?\n\nSome years ago I received a fan letter from Ray Bradbury that simply said, \u201cI love Hugo Cabret!\u201d I was floored, particularly because I\u2019d loved his books since high school. I wrote him back and ended up in a phone conversation with one of his daughters, who told me that I should stop by if I\u2019m ever in Los Angeles. \u201cI\u2019m supposed to be in L.A. next week,\u201d I lied. When I arrived at his house his daughter met me at the door and ushered me into a tiny room where Mr. Bradbury was sitting in a recliner surrounded by VHS tapes of old movies, piles of books and papers, and a model of the Nautilus from \u201c20,000 Leagues Under the Sea.\u201d Around his neck was a medal, which he said had recently been given to him by the president of France. We talked for a while, and I asked him if it was true that he wrote every single day. He pointed to a nearby box and told me to bring it to him. He opened the box and inside was a manuscript he\u2019d just finished typing for a new book of short stories to be called \u201cWe\u2019ll Always Have Paris.\u201d One of the short story titles jumped out at me. \u201cRemembrance, Ohio.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s a beautiful title,\u201d I said to him.\n\n\u201cThanks,\u201d he said, \u201cI made it up.\u201d\n\nSometime later a package arrived at my home. It was a copy of his new book. I\u2019ve only now realized it was Paris that had brought us together in the first place, since it was the setting for \u201cHugo Cabret.\u201d So I guess it\u2019s true for me and Mr. Bradbury: We\u2019ll always have Paris.\n\nWhat kind of reader were you as a child? Which childhood books and authors stick with you most?\n\nI usually watched the movies of books I should have read. \u201cThe Wizard of Oz,\u201d \u201cCharlie and the Chocolate Factory\u201d and \u201cTo Kill a Mockingbird\u201d are all movies I loved based on books I did not read (I\u2019ve read all of them since). The most influential book I did read was probably \u201cThe Borrowers,\u201d by Mary Norton, with exceptional line drawings by Beth and Joe and Krush. It\u2019s about a family of tiny people who live under the floorboards of a boy\u2019s house, and I basically read this as nonfiction. I made miniature furniture and left it for the Borrowers who lived in my house.", "title": "Brian Selznick: By the Book", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Al Solh often completes a portrait during a single sitting, and tries to capture sitters\u2019 individuality along with snippets of stories they share, in Arabic text. Her sketchbook is a yellow legal pad, \u201creminding us of the painstaking bureaucratic processes through which immigrants must go in order to obtain citizenship,\u201d said Hendrik Folkerts, an organizer of Documenta who also curated the Art Institute\u2019s show. He recently helped her locate Syrian immigrants in Chicago to draw.\n\nAt times Ms. Al Solh has found herself sharing her own wartime accounts with her sitters, including her experiences growing up during the Lebanese war in the 1980s, when she fled to Damascus for periods to stay with relatives.\n\n\u201cIt sounds ironic now but Syria was our refuge,\u201d she said. \u201cSo making this work has also been a way for me to understand my own childhood, a way to process the trauma we all went through.\u201d\n\nIn these edited excerpts from an interview, Ms. Al Solh recalls the encounters behind her portraits of three displaced Syrians.\n\nUm Mayssah, Beirut, 2014\n\nPhoto\n\nUm Mayssah means \u201cthe mother of Mayssah,\u201d so this is her nickname, not her real name. This naming is a traditional way of showing respect in Arab countries for elderly people. She told me she\u2019s the mother of five daughters.\n\nI met her through neighbors the year I moved to a new studio in the Raouch\u00e9 neighborhood of Beirut, on the sea. It\u2019s an exciting and very mixed neighborhood, with Lebanese, Syrians, Iraqis and Palestinians \u2014 an expensive neighborhood originally but also worn out because of war, and the wind and sea too. There\u2019s one Starbucks there, and if you go early it\u2019s not too busy, so I could draw. That\u2019s why she\u2019s carrying this walnut cake. Believe it or not, it\u2019s from Starbucks.\n\nWhat I really loved about her was her face, with all of her wrinkles, suggesting such a tough life \u2014 tougher, I imagine, because she had no sons, a problem in the Arab world. I like to carry a box of supplies and in this case I chose black and white ink, black gouache and brown watercolor to try to capture these wrinkles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe didn\u2019t talk too much \u2014 I\u2019m not a journalist, not a secret agent, I don\u2019t need to know everything about everyone. Sometimes it\u2019s more about the story, but here I just wanted to do a good drawing.\n\nWaad, Beirut, 2015\n\nPhoto\n\nI met Waad through good friends and finally I asked her if I could draw her. She reminded me of myself in some ways. She\u2019s probably 10 years younger than I am, and she\u2019s an example of all these young women in the Arabic world who are pursuing their own studies, not just waiting to get married. When I first met her she had finished her studies in Damascus, where she lived far from her family. She loved the theater and was working in film, dubbing Turkish voices into Arabic with a Syrian accent.\n\nIn the text she talks about how she\u2019s more of a Damascus person, though she\u2019s really from Sweida [a city close to the Jordan border]. It\u2019s like someone saying they\u2019re from New York, even when they didn\u2019t grow up near there.\n\nThe orange splotches I added to suggest wind. And you can see a hint of that in her clothes too. I\u2019m not a big believer in the idea or ideal of the finished drawing. The series is really performative \u2014 it\u2019s about the moment of sitting down with someone, facing each other, sharing something. The moment of making the drawing is really what matters to me.\n\nAli, Kassel, 2016\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen I was in Kassel, Germany, preparing for Documenta, I was introduced to Tamim, a Syrian restaurant owner. His restaurant, which has maybe 10 tables, became my studio. He would give us coffee or tea and we could sit for an hour or more.\n\nThat\u2019s where I met Ali, who is from Al Zabadani, a Syrian town close to the Lebanese border where there was a big battle. He told me that 60 percent of his friends in Zabadani died, and his home was destroyed. He said there\u2019s not a single stone left standing in Zabadani.\n\nI used black ink for this but I put some green watercolor on the brush. I was trying to evoke the color of ash, the feeling of when a city is burned out. We sat for a few hours, a very long meeting. He was confident and open and ready to share.\n\nThis is something I found more with the men I met in Europe than the women \u2014 the men more urgently needed to speak. While the women I met had children or husbands to take care of and were too busy to talk, these men were mostly on their own, away from family in Syria or Jordan. They carried the stigma associated with being a refugee in Europe but of course they\u2019re not supposed to cry or say they\u2019re in trouble when they call home, so this became a great platform for them. I had men telling me: It\u2019s been five years since I\u2019ve seen my children; I\u2019ve missed out on their lives.\n\nAnd some men had lost the people they love, which was very heavy. Sometimes I had to refrain from making portraits. I wasn\u2019t able to \u2014 it was too intense for me.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAli also talked about how he doesn\u2019t feel like a typical Syrian. He asked me, What\u2019s the difference between a young German man and a Syrian? He said, We all want a cool life, we all want a girlfriend.", "title": "Brief Encounters, Enduring Portraits of the Displaced", "authors": ["Jori Finkel"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "It is important for the book\u2019s readers to be aware that Holiday, the college dropout, is also a huge believer in Stoicism, an ancient Greek and Roman philosophy that preaches suffering, humility, acceptance and endurance without complaint. He became a zealot while at college after reading Marcus Aurelius\u2019 \u201cMeditations\u201d four times in a row and then affixing his favorite passages from the book to the walls of his dorm room. Holiday is nothing if not erudite; every time you turn around in \u201cConspiracy,\u201d he is trying to make profound points by quoting from a vast range of philosophers, statesmen and Great Thinkers \u2014 everyone from Machiavelli and Seneca to Kierkegaard and George W.S. Trow, and on and on.\n\nBut incessant name-dropping aside \u2014 which tends to detract from his gripping narrative \u2014 Holiday has written one helluva page-turner. He documents how, starting in 2007, the secretive Thiel sought to take revenge on Denton for outing him on Gawker just because Denton could, and because he figured the news would generate the clicks and the kind of attention Denton and his erstwhile enterprise craved. Thiel, rightly offended, began a stealth campaign to punish Denton for his callous and cavalier behavior.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt a chance meeting in Germany, Thiel enlisted the help of someone Holiday refers to only as \u201cMr. A,\u201d and then Charles Harder, the Los Angeles attorney who recently represented Donald Trump in his wildly unsuccessful legal effort to stop the publication of Michael Wolff\u2019s \u201cFire and Fury.\u201d Armed with $10 million or so from Thiel, Mr. A. and Harder dug up everything they could find about Denton, his colleagues at Gawker, Gawker itself, its parent company Gawker Media and some of the other people Gawker offended. They also needed a novel legal theory about what Denton had done, figuring that the First Amendment would protect Denton and Gawker.\n\nWhen, in October 2012, Gawker made the momentous decision to publish without permission excerpts from a sex tape involving Hogan and his former best friend\u2019s wife, Thiel not only had the perfect protagonist in an equally angry and determined Hogan but also a legal theory based on the idea that Hogan\u2019s privacy had been invaded (as had Thiel\u2019s five years earlier). Unbeknown to Denton and his company\u2019s lawyers, Thiel had decided to bankroll Hogan in his legal battle against Gawker and Denton. In classic David and Goliath fashion, Denton tragically underestimated his foes and paid the iron price: As has been well documented elsewhere, Denton lost the five-count lawsuit in a Florida courtroom and was slapped with a $140 million verdict. Gawker Media had no choice but to file for bankruptcy; its carcass was sold to the highest bidder.\n\nTo his considerable credit and for reasons that aren\u2019t entirely made clear, Holiday decided to write \u201cConspiracy\u201d after both Thiel and Denton approached him separately, wanting to share with him their views of the blockbuster case. He\u2019s less successful, it seems to me, in pushing his view throughout the book that Thiel, Mr. A, Hogan and Harder were involved in an old-fashioned \u201cconspiracy\u201d \u2014 in the Stoical sense of the word \u2014 to bring down Denton and his crew. Yes, they triumphed wildly, and beyond anything they could have expected. But couldn\u2019t that just be chalked up to having the better and more sympathetic legal argument rather than to having better tactics, strategies and a morally superior way of living?\n\nOf course, this Occam\u2019s razor approach to the Gawker case would not lend itself as easily to a public relations mastermind\u2019s skills. \u201cConspiracy\u201d was embargoed for reasons that aren\u2019t clear either \u2014 much of its contents are already publicly known \u2014 and each page of the uncorrected proof was stamped with an annoyingly large confidentiality notice. Holiday is nothing if not a new kind of clever. In keeping with Stoicism\u2019s tenets about self-effacement, in Holiday\u2019s Twitter profile photo his face is completely covered by his two hands. But make no mistake, the genius is at work, already promoting: A recent Observer column is about Harder and \u201cthe insane backstory behind the lawyer who shook down Donald Trump (and Hulk Hogan).\u201d", "title": "Bringing Down a Media Empire", "authors": ["William D. Cohan", "Ryan Holiday"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "A 2016 study in the International Journal of Fashion Design, Technology and Education found that the average American woman wore a size 16 or 18. Yet annual spending on larger-size apparel accounts for only 16 percent of the $112 billion market in the United States because the inventory was not available.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re getting bigger, but the business hasn\u2019t gotten bigger,\u201d Marshal Cohen, a retail industry analyst at the NPD Group, said.\n\nThat has begun to change. Spurred by an underserved market, along with a heightened emphasis on inclusiveness in the fashion industry, new retailers are sensing an opportunity. E-commerce businesses that rent, as well as sell, larger sizes have grown. With some focusing on moderately priced clothes and others concentrating on the designer market, these sites are finding an eager audience. Social media influencers like Jordyn Woods and Tess Holliday and actresses like Rebel Wilson and Chrissy Metz have also raised the profile of this market.\n\nPhoto\n\nRetail giants are also expanding their presence in this market. In March, for example, Walmart acquired Modcloth, an e-commerce site that sold clothing in a range of sizes. Other e-commerce sites, like Stitch Fix, have also begun to offer larger sizes. But industry experts say large retailers lack the personal touch that shoppers seek.\n\n\u201cWhile Walmart and Amazon could be formidable competitors, this customer wants a company that understands her, and isn\u2019t just selling to everyone,\u201d Mr. Cohen said.\n\nSo some retail start-ups are trying to meet those demands. Christine Hunsicker, a tech entrepreneur, and Jaswinder Pal Singh, a computer science professor at Princeton, started Gwynnie Bee, a subscription-based clothing rental service.\n\n\u201cWe became interested in apparel because of the size of the market and the need,\u201d Ms. Hunsicker said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the Gwynnie Bee model, women who wear sizes 10 to 32 receive regular shipments of clothing. Once it\u2019s worn, no laundering is required; clients simply return the options to the company for a fresh selection. If the customer loves an item, she can buy it, Ms. Hunsicker said.\n\nIn contrast, Eloquii is a reincarnation rather than a start-up. The company was originally a brick-and-mortar retailer owned by the Limited, which, despite protests from a loyal customer base, shut down the brand in 2013, Ms. Chase said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe founder and chairman, John Auerbach, who has held a number of e-commerce positions, bought Eloquii\u2019s assets from Sun Capital in 2013, including intellectual property and the customer list. Ms. Chase joined the same year. The company has already been through two rounds of venture capital financing, and now has backing of close to $40 million, Ms. Chase said.\n\nMost of these businesses are focused on online customers, but some are experimenting with physical stores. Eloquii has opened three, in Chicago; Columbus, Ohio; and Washington. Two of them are pop-ups.\n\nMost physical stores with plus-size apparel do not \u201coffer a great experience,\u201d Ms. Chase said, so Eloquii is focusing on fitting-room aesthetics and other amenities\n\nPhoto\n\nGwynnie Bee had a pop-up store on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan that \u201cwent really well,\u201d Ms. Hunsicker said, adding that her company is trying to determine what role a store plays in its business model.\n\nA bigger challenge for the companies is finding inventory. Designers have become more accommodating, spurred both by an untapped market and the desire to appear inclusive. But entrepreneurs are not waiting for manufacturers to make the first move.\n\nNew York Fashion Week, which officially began Thursday, offers an opportunity for these entrepreneurs to get noticed. Dia took out a full-page ad in The New York Times during New York Fashion Week last February, encouraging designers to look anew at the market with the line \u201cFashion she can\u2019t wear is becoming a bit unfashionable.\u201d The gamble paid off: Ms. Boujarwah said the ad had led to two new lines, one with Ms. Wilson, the actress, and the other with the designer Nanette Lepore.\n\nEntrepreneurs are learning to be more flexible, too. For instance, Gwynnie Bee will add smaller sizes to its lineup after determining that designers would be more willing to work with it if it offered a wider range. The site, Ms. Hunsicker said, will include only items that are available in all sizes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet fabrication remains a hurdle for some. As a result, founders like Ms. Boujarwah of Dia, which counts Sequoia Capital among its investors, are designing their own products. Similarly, Ms. Hunsicker said Gwynnie Bee had, \u201cfor a number of vendors, taken on a lot of pattern design,\u201d in addition to offering the site\u2019s private label clothing.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s their aesthetic and vision, and we\u2019re helping to make it fit,\u201d she said.\n\nMany, but not all, of the sites primarily feature moderately priced clothes; as a result, those seeking designer apparel in larger sizes remained underserved. Enter 11 Honor\u00e9, which opened in August, shortly before New York Fashion Week last fall. The site was created by Patrick Herning and Kathryn Retzer, whose mothers wear larger sizes and often had difficulty finding higher-end clothing.\n\n\u201cWe were adamant about building a luxury brand and bringing the best designers we could, including Michael Kors, Zac Posen, Badgley Mischka, Monique Lhuillier and Prabal Gurung,\u201d Ms. Retzer said.\n\nAs they began formulating their idea, friends encouraged him to reach out to Kirsten Green, the Silicon Valley venture capitalist known for her retail investing acumen. They pitched their idea and obtained seed financing from Ms. Green\u2019s firm, Forerunner Ventures, as well as from several others, for a total of $3.5 million.\n\nMost of the companies do not yet offer intimate apparel, although Eloquii plans to offer lingerie in the future. To reach that market, Deborah A. Christel, a co-author of the study on women\u2019s sizes, left her position as an assistant professor at Washington State University to start a company that would encompass all sizes for lingerie.\n\nMs. Christel said her company, Kade & Vos, would begin selling next summer. \u201cIt\u2019s my hope that one day, women\u2019s clothes will just be women\u2019s without referring to plus size,\u201d she said.", "title": "Bringing a Personal Touch to Plus-Size Fashion", "authors": ["Ellen Rosen"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "For years, outsourcing seemed to accomplish those goals by and large, making Britain the second-largest market for outsourcing in the world, after the United States.\n\nBut recently, relying on private contractors to deliver public services has come under fire, not only from the leader of the opposition Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn, but from parts of the British government itself.\n\nA report by the government\u2019s National Audit Office shows that taxpayers are expected to pay nearly $285 billion to private contractors for projects and services over the next 25 years. The agency also found that with changing economics, schools could cost 40 percent more, and hospitals 70 percent more, when undertaken through private-finance initiatives rather than though the government.\n\nPhoto\n\nNearly a decade of austerity budgets and declining funding for local governments, which pay for many outsourced services, has badly strained the system.\n\nThe spectacular collapse last month of Carillion, the British government\u2019s biggest outsourcing contractor, and signs of deepening financial problems at Capita, another major British contractor, which suspended its dividend on Wednesday, have only underscored the troubles.\n\n\u201cThe model is flawed, it\u2019s broken, it\u2019s got cracks from top to bottom,\u201d said Nick Hood, a social care expert and an adviser at Opus Restructuring, an insolvency specialist based in London.\n\nNowhere are the problems more glaring than in the care of the elderly and those with disabilities. A third of Britain\u2019s 5,500 care providers are at risk of failure, Mr. Hood said, a rate well above other sectors of the economy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast year, Cleeve Link, a major company providing home care in southwestern Gloucestershire, went into liquidation. The Gloucestershire County Council covered hardship payments for the staff, and even provided free gasoline for home care aides so they could continue looking after their patients.\n\n\u201cWe went into a crisis mode,\u201d recalled Margaret Willcox, president of the Association for the Directors of Adult Social Services, who was involved in the takeover of Cleeve Link\u2019s services. \u201cIf shareholders suddenly decide they want out from the business, you\u2019re completely stranded.\u201d\n\nAt the heart of the issue is whether Britain can afford high-quality services at a time of relentless budget cutting. The problem has worsened with Britain\u2019s withdrawal from the European Union, which has slowed growth and led to an exodus of young, foreign workers.\n\n\u201cThe British government allowed itself to offer a Swedish-style public sector while only being able to raise an American level of taxes, putting massive permanent pressure on the government,\u201d said Tony Travers, a professor of government at the London School of Economics.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGovernments have become good enough at driving down the prices of contracts, he added, that companies struggle to make a profit. Carillion collapsed in part because it had underbid for contracts that became unsustainable when it ran into delays and cost overruns.\n\nThat pattern seems to have played out at Millbrow, which has been taken over by the local council while the company restructures.\n\nClients in the British system fall into two broad categories: those who are self-financed, and those whose care is paid by the local council. But providers and health care experts said that local governments typically fund little more than half the actual cost, forcing providers to charge higher rates to self-funded residents.\n\nFour Seasons, the provider, says it had trouble recruiting and retaining staff, forcing it to rely on temporary workers. \u201cThe home had not been financially sustainable and had been making a loss for some time,\u201d the company said in a statement. \u201cSo we were effectively paying to provide care.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs conditions deteriorated, both care givers and the relatives of residents said in interviews, a revolving door of managers led to frequent breakdowns in communication, to the point that no one was aware the home was nearing collapse.\n\nStaffing levels on a floor caring for residents with dementia were \u201chorrendous,\u201d said Lisa Riley, a 39-year-old care giver. At one point, she said, there were only four employees to look after 35 people. This meant some could not be supervised around the clock and would wander, sometimes tripping and falling. \u201cWe tried, that\u2019s all we can say,\u201d she said.\n\nPublic inspectors found residents at risk of choking because they were not made to sit upright when they ate. Staff members were seen handling soiled laundry without wearing gloves, the inspectors added in the government report, and cushions and other material were \u201cheavily contaminated, and had a strong malodor.\u201d\n\nIn the last year, at least 13 nursing homes run by Four Seasons have either closed or, like Millbrow, been taken over by local councils.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne home in South Hampshire that closed had to transfer its elderly residents. Within a month, five had died, according to a former employee.\n\n\u201cSome of these people should not be moved because they\u2019re not going to last,\u201d said the employee, Lynne Wells. \u201cAnd they didn\u2019t. A lot of these people are in their 90s. It\u2019s just so sad really.\u201d\n\nSaddled with $700 million in debt, Four Seasons is in restructuring talks with an American hedge fund, H/2 Capital Partners, which holds most of the debt. Adult care experts worry about the ramifications if a major company like Four Seasons, which cares for about 17,000 elderly people, should collapse like Carillion.\n\nAccording to experts, care homes in Britain do not make close to the 15 percent returns that private-equity companies typically look for.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe \u201cpernicious pincer movement on profits,\u201d said Mr. Hood, the insolvency specialist, has prompted some providers to end contracts with local governments or refuse services to publicly funded residents \u201cbecause it\u2019s cheaper to leave the beds empty.\u201d\n\nLast year, Mears Group, another prominent care provider, ended a 15-year contract with the Essex Council, saying the payment rate fell short of what was recommended by an industry association. \u201cMears believes that no organization can deliver a care service at the new rate safely or legally,\u201d the company said.\n\nEventually, said Mr. Hood, \u201cthe government will have to take the care home market in some form of public partnership. It will have to.\u201d\n\nAt Millbrow, local officials say they are able to provide better care than Four Seasons had, even on the same budget, because they do not have to squeeze out a profit and be accountable to shareholders.\n\nOn a recent visit, electricians were seen installing wiring for a new fire alarm system. Schedules for \u201cinfection control training\u201d and \u201cmoving and handling refreshers\u201d were posted on a whiteboard nearby. Staff were being trained how to deal with patients with dementia. In the back garden, builders were looking at fixing what had been open sewers.\n\n\u201cEverything revolves around money,\u201d said Ms. Riley, the care giver, as she gave a resident her noon meal. \u201cBut at the end of the day it\u2019s about vulnerable people. We need to take care of them.\u201d", "title": "Britain Was a Pioneer in Outsourcing Services. Now, the Model Is \u2018Broken.\u2019", "authors": ["Kimiko De Freytas-Tamura"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Britain\u2019s jobless rate unexpectedly rose unexpectedly for the first time in almost two years and pay growth remained modest, officials figures released on Wednesday showed.\n\nThe unemployment rate rose to 4.4 percent from 4.3 percent in the three months to December, according to the Office for National Statistics, the first increase since the three months to February 2016, as the number of jobless rose for a third monthly report in a row.\n\nThe jobless rate increase left the Bank of England waiting for the stronger labor market that would justify a new interest rate hike.\n\nBritish government bond prices rose and sterling briefly fell against the American dollar according to the official figures, which showed the sharpest increase in the number of people out of work in almost five years.", "title": "Britain\u2019s Jobless Rate Rises, to 4.4%, for First Time in 2 Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "But then she said she imagined all the people watching back home. \u201cAnd I just thought, I\u2019m going to give it my best shot,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cI thought of the adrenaline and how that might take over.\u201d\n\nShe rose unsteadily, favoring her right foot, and gingerly skated over to consult with her coach before returning to the starting line for the nine-lap race. Christie was last after the first lap, last after the second, last after the third. Then, as the spectators at Gangneung Ice Arena threw their voices behind her, she made her move. \u201cThe support from Korea, the support from the U.K., has been insane,\u201d said Christie, who was second with a lap to go. In the final meters, there was some jostling for position, but Christie held her ground and finished behind Lara van Ruijven of the Netherlands.\n\n\u201cI just thought it was a normal race and I moved up and I qualified and I was so happy,\u201d Christie said.\n\nBut it was not to be. She received a yellow card for two separate minor infringements. Christie said she had no idea what she had done. All she knew was that for the second consecutive Olympics, she would leave with nothing tangible to show for four years of monomaniacal devotion to her sport.\n\nChristie stepped off the ice and was scooped up by the national short-track coach, Nicky Gooch. In 1994, Gooch won Britain\u2019s first medal in short-track speedskating.
