Christie had come here hoping to become her country\u2019s first gold medalist and second medal-winner in the sport.\n\nAs reporters waited to talk with her, they were joined by Scott Field, the head of communications for the British Olympic Association, who said softly: \u201cGo easy on her. Do me a favor.\u201d", "title": "British Speedskater Finishes on Her Feet but Goes Home Empty-Handed Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBroadcom moved the goal posts in its hostile takeover bid for Qualcomm, announcing on Tuesday that it was now seeking only a majority of the chip maker\u2019s board seats in next month\u2019s shareholder vote and raising questions about the future of the deal.\n\nBroadcom said that it would now pursue the election of six nominees it had put forward, rather than the full 11 it had originally named.\n\nWhether the shift will be enough to advance the deal in the face of Qualcomm\u2019s heated resistance to a takeover is unclear. Qualcomm shareholders vote on the board on March 6. The chip company last week rejected Broadcom\u2019s latest takeover bid, valued at about $121 billion, arguing that it was still too low and that it offered insufficient commitments in case regulators moved to block a union on antitrust grounds. Under the terms of the offer, Broadcom would pay about $82 a share in cash and stock.\n\nPutting the two companies together would create one of the world\u2019s biggest chip makers, whose products would be in a majority of the world\u2019s smartphones.\n\nBoth companies are expected to meet on Wednesday for the first time in months, raising the possibility that somehow they can bridge their differences and reach an agreement.\n\nUntil then, Broadcom is further pressuring its target. Broadcom\u2019s chief executive, Hock Tan, said in a statement on Tuesday that reducing the number of director seats that his company was seeking would help provide some \u201ccontinuity\u201d for Qualcomm\u2019s board.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShareholders, he added, \u201chave welcomed our willingness to provide for appropriate continuity on the Qualcomm board, and have also expressed a desire for a definitive mechanism of achieving such continuity. Reducing the number of nominees we are seeking to a simple majority provides precisely that mechanism.\u201d\n\nQualcomm declined to comment. Shares in both companies were lower in trading on Tuesday.\n\nAt the same time, a campaign to unseat some of Qualcomm\u2019s directors \u2014 rather than the company\u2019s entire board \u2014 could be more palatable to proxy advisory firms like Institutional Shareholder Services and Glass Lewis, whose voting recommendations can carry significant weight with investors. Both firms are expected to issue their reports on the board contest in the coming weeks.\n\nMr. Tan essentially signaled that Broadcom would seek fewer board seats in an interview on CNBC on Monday.\n\n\u201cIf at least a majority of our slate does not get in on March 6, then I guess we will get the message that this deal is not going to happen,\u201d he said. \u201cWe will walk.\u201d", "title": "Broadcom Now Seeking Fewer of Qualcomm\u2019s Board Seats", "authors": ["Michael J. De La Merced"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Consumers have a stake in the contest, because Qualcomm is likely to be closely tied to the performance of future handsets \u2014 particularly a new generation of wireless technology called 5G \u2014 and prices that users may pay.\n\nQualcomm developed technology that became a foundation for all digital cellular communications, a position that allowed the company to both sell chips and charge a patent royalty for nearly all smartphones sold. That model generated an outsize flow of profits that Qualcomm poured into developing new generations of wireless chips, as well as microprocessors that handle calculations in mobile devices.\n\nThose chips helped Apple turn the iPhone into one of the most lucrative products in high-tech history. But Qualcomm also helped South Korea\u2019s Samsung Electronics and many Chinese competitors, which churned out a flood of low-priced iPhone rivals and made smartphones affordable to many more people. Apple sued Qualcomm a year ago, attacking patent licensing practices that have also been opposed by regulators in the United States, Europe and Asia.\n\nBroadcom went after Qualcomm\u2019s business model on Monday in a voluminous set of slides, and has indicated it would seek to make peace with Apple, which is a major Broadcom customer for other types of wireless chips. But some major Chinese manufacturers have expressed concerns about the deal, reflecting Broadcom\u2019s track record of cutting spending on research and raising chip prices. Samsung also now appears to be siding with Qualcomm, which last week announced a new patent deal with the South Korean company and Samsung\u2019s agreement to stop opposing Qualcomm in court proceedings in the country.\n\nQualcomm\u2019s management team and board have consistently argued that Broadcom\u2019s takeover approach is opportunistic since it is unfolding during Qualcomm\u2019s bruising legal fight with Apple, as well as priced too low.\n\nBut the revised offer may entice shareholders to demand that Qualcomm\u2019s executives begin negotiations. Qualcomm reported a 96 percent drop in operating income last week, as Apple has refused to pay some licensing fees. It is also struggling to complete its own takeover bid, for the chip maker NXP Semiconductor, amid pushback from investors of that company.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor Mr. Tan, who built Broadcom over nearly a decade from a series of takeovers, Qualcomm\u2019s problems are ones that he and his team can fix \u2014 and that Qualcomm has not shown it can on its own.\n\n\u201cWe have a lot of respect for the tech and the innovation that comes with the 5G technology,\u201d he said. \u201cBut we believe, given our track record, we can do much more.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBroadcom did more than raise its offer price on Monday. It also pledged to pay a \u201csignificant\u201d breakup fee if regulators veto a deal, as well as to pay additional cash if the two companies have not closed a transaction a year after announcement. It also committed to other steps to closing a transaction, including selling overlapping businesses.\n\nThose moves are meant to highlight Broadcom\u2019s commitment to the deal. Such assurances may prove important, given questions among analysts and investors over whether a combination could win regulatory approval.\n\nMr. Tan argued that Broadcom had held constructive talks with regulators around the world, and that his company had a track record of quickly closing deals. He also dismissed Qualcomm\u2019s repeated concerns about antitrust issues.\n\n\u201cBased on what Qualcomm has been spinning the last six months, they\u2019ve been short on specifics and heavy on rhetoric,\u201d Mr. Tan said.\n\nIn a statement, Qualcomm said it was considering the new bid.\n\nBroadcom also said that it would withdraw its offer if Qualcomm rescheduled its annual shareholder meeting from March 6, or if it paid more than the $110 a share that it has already bid for NXP.", "title": "Broadcom Raises Its Qualcomm Offer to $121 Billion", "authors": ["Michael J. De La Merced", "Don Clark"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQualcomm on Tuesday increased its takeover bid for NXP Semiconductors, defying Broadcom\u2019s demand that it not do so.\n\nOn Wednesday, Broadcom retaliated.\n\nThe chip maker shaved $3 per share off its hostile takeover bid for Qualcomm, reducing it to $79 a share. The price remains nearly 13 percent above Broadcom\u2019s original offer of $70.\n\nIn lowering its bid, Broadcom argued that Qualcomm\u2019s higher NXP offer would transfer $4.10 a share, or $6.2 billion, in value to NXP shareholders.\n\n\u201cQualcomm\u2019s board acted against the best interests of its stockholders by unilaterally transferring excessive value to NXP\u2019s activist stockholders,\u201d Broadcom said in its statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBroadcom said its bid would automatically rise again to $82 if Qualcomm failed to complete its purchase of NXP.", "title": "Broadcom Retaliates Against Qualcomm for Raising Its NXP Bid", "authors": ["Michael J. De La Merced"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt is a substantial source of revenue,\u201d said Barry Weissler, a Broadway producer who has had some of his shows, including \u201cSeussical\u201d and \u201cFiddler on the Roof\u201d adapted for the school market.\n\nSean Patrick Flahaven, the chief executive office of the Musical Company, a partnership between Andrew Lloyd Webber\u2019s Really Useful Group and Concord Music, said a successful title in the youth market can generate $1 million or more a year in licensing revenue. The show \u201cAnnie,\u201d for example, has been licensed in various versions around the world over 13,000 times in the last five years.\n\nIn 2012, high schools spent about $300 million on theatrical productions, according to the most recent figures from the Educational Theatre Association. No one closely tracks this market, but licensers say that high schools are the largest portion of the educational market, while middle schools have grown the most. Over the last decade, middle school membership in the International Thespian Society, an honor society for theater arts students, has doubled to 7,000.\n\nMr. Flahaven says that roughly a decade ago, licenses sold to elementary and middle schools made up about 10 percent of revenue for many licensing firms. Now it can be closer to 25 percent.\n\nITheatrics works with the composers, writers or license holders to create simpler, shorter versions of musicals that are appropriate for elementary and middle schools.\n\n\u201cAnnie,\u201d when performed on Broadway, for example, is a two-act, 2.5 hourlong musical with eight principal roles and an ensemble. The middle school version is 60 minutes long and has 25 speaking roles plus the ensemble. The 30-minute elementary school version has 20 speaking roles plus the ensemble. ITheatrics\u2019 charges customers about $200,000 for its two-year-long adaptation process and has around 18 musicals in some phase of adaptation at any given time. (The adaptation kits then sold to schools usually cost between about $400 for elementary schools and $1,000 or more for high schools.)\n\nToday nearly every licensing company offers musicals tailored to this market. Theatrical Rights Worldwide has a School Edition for high school and Young@Part for middle and elementary school. Rodgers & Hammerstein offers a Getting to Know Series, Samuel French licenses 101 School Editions, Tams-Witmark has a Young Performers\u2019 Edition and Disney licenses Disney JR and Disney Kids versions.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nFreddie Gershon, the co-chairman of the licensing firm Music Theatre International, created this business more than 20 years ago when he worked with Stephen Sondheim, who was concerned about aging Broadway audiences, to adapt \u201cInto the Woods\u201d for schools. After more than a decade of adapting its own shows, MTI spun off iTheatrics in 2007 to do the same for other licensing firms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI thought Freddie was nuts,\u201d says Timothy Allen McDonald, iTheaterics\u2019 founding chairman. \u201cBut he understood that it would never take on a life of it own unless there was a \u2018Sound of Music\u2019 adaptation and others. It should be industrywide.\u201d Mr. Gershon received a special Tony Award in 2012 in part for creating these adaptations.\n\n\u201cIt has been a wonderful way to inject a lot of adrenaline into the company \u2014 making old titles, or those that did not get their due, more valuable,\u201d Mr. Gershon said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFinding the Next Generation\n\nInside the Atlanta convention center, a line of middle school students waited giddily for a chance to have their picture taken with an unlikely celebrity: Tyler Mount. Until 2015 Mr. Mount was an anonymous Broadway stage manager. Now he is a star, at least among the tween theater crowd. He interviews Broadway personalities for a show he distributes on YouTube. More than 3 million people have viewed his show.\n\nLast February, he began partnering with Playbill. The 134-year-old theater publication saw an opportunity in Mr. Mount\u2019s audience: 12- to 24-year-olds who live for Broadway.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s great to have Tyler and his energy aboard,\u201d said Alex Birsh, vice president of Playbill. \u201cHe helps us communicate with the next generation of theater-obsessed people.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPlaybill is not just hoping for future readers. It created a website called Playbillder that lets schools and theater groups create a Playbill for their shows. Schools can use it to sell ads to raise money and bring in services. In 2017, according to the company, about 2 million Playbills were produced using its software. About 85 percent of its licenses are sold to schools and about 40 percent of those are middle and elementary schools.\n\nA broad range of businesses target this youth market. According to the Educational Theatre Association, about 27 percent of a school\u2019s budget goes toward licensing the material. Sets are another 19 percent. Costumes are 17 percent. Last year nearly 4,000 high school students attended the organization\u2019s International Thespian Festival, which featured vendors offering everything from a costume inventory database to stage makeup, lighting and ticketing software.\n\nBroadway Media Distribution, a company that provides projected digital scenery, works directly with Music Theatre International and Theatrical Rights Worldwide to create backgrounds tailored to their shows. They can cost anywhere from $250 to $995 depending on the production. About 85 percent of the company\u2019s customers are middle and high schools.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn a Saturday evening at the festival, young actors from Spotlight Theatre Productions in Sarasota, Fla., wearing purple and blue billowing pants and golden vests, held hands in a circle. They passed a hand squeeze from one to another as they prepared to go on stage. They were about to perform songs from a new version of \u201cAladdin JR.\u201d in front of nearly 6,000 theater-obsessed students, parents and theater directors.\n\n\u201cAladdin JR.\u201d had an unusual path to its debut here. \u201cAladdin,\u201d the highest grossing movie of 1992, was adapted as a school musical in 2004. Its success there inspired Disney to stage it on Broadway in 2014. Now it has again been adapted for schools.\n\nThe success of musicals in this market is upending traditions in theatrical licensing, said Mr. Flahaven. Historically, musicals would not be released to the educational market until the Broadway production closed. Licensers were afraid that it would cannibalize business. But that is changing. \u201cAladdin JR.\u201d is available even though the original show remains on Broadway. And at the direction of Andrew Lloyd Webber, licenses for his production of \u201cSchool of Rock\u201d are available to schools while it too is still on Broadway. \u201cThe idea is to put it out there and to see if it drives business toward seeing the Broadway show or the tour,\u201d said Mr. Flahaven.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nEducational licensing has reversed the fortunes of some shows. \u201cSeussical: The Musical\u201d lost $10 million in six months when it debuted on Broadway in 2000. The writers reworked it and it had a successful national tour. Mr. McDonald adapted it for schools and it remains one of the most-produced school musicals in the country. In the 2016-17 season, Music Theatre International issued more than 2,500 licenses for middle and elementary school \u201cSeussical\u201d adaptations.\n\n\n\n\u201cFor a show like \u2018Seussical,\u2019 the educational market is the most important piece of the marketplace,\u201d said Mr. Weissler, one of the show\u2019s producers. Thanks to licensing revenue, he said that he has paid back millions in loans and paid down some of the show\u2019s original investment.\n\nBut musicals don\u2019t sell themselves. In the beginning, Mr. McDonald flew to teacher conferences to pitch these shows. But his approach has changed. \u201cThe more we can make the marketing experiential, the more successful it is,\u201d he said.\n\n\n\nAnd so this conference is a rousing celebration of theater. Crowds participate in mass singalongs to songs from \u201cShrek The Musical.\u201d Students perform songs from musicals and are critiqued by company representatives. Students congratulate each other on their performances, talk shop and shriek at the sight of Stephen Schwartz, the composer for \u201cGodspell\u201d and \u201cWicked.\u201d All that excitement is woven into education, marketing, networking and tween dance parties.\n\nStudents from Bravo, the performing arts program at Gwendolyn Brooks Middle School in Oak Park, Ill., who performed songs from \u201cChitty Chitty Bang Bang JR.,\u201d also workshopped the production last year for iTheatrics, which was adapting the musical for the educational market. (The school has worked on about a dozen plays for iTheatrics). Executives from the company traveled to the school, watched the students perform and incorporated feedback into the adaptation.\n\n\u201cThe people here are tastemakers,\u201d said Mr. Scott. \u201cThey go back to their communities, people say, \u2018Hey, what is Bravo doing?\u2019 And they say \u2018Wow, we want to do that.\u2019 It has a trickle-down effect.\u201d\n\nPhoto", "title": "Broadway Hits the Middle School Circuit", "authors": ["Jim Rendon"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDavid is an extraordinary combination of a very savvy, high-quality commercial producer and somebody who is passionate about boundary-breaking art,\u201d said Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater and a longtime friend. \u201cIt\u2019s a brilliant choice.\u201d\n\nBAM now operates at three venues in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn \u2014 the Peter Jay Sharp Building (with a 2,090 seat auditorium), the BAM Harvey Theater, and the BAM Fisher. Next year it is planning to open two new venues: the BAM Karen, with two cinemas, and the BAM Strong, with an art gallery.\n\nAmong its biggest events are the annual DanceAfrica and Next Wave festivals. Highlights last year included performances by Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch, Geoff Sobelle\u2019s experimental play \u201cHome,\u201d and the family friendly arts-tech weekends \u201cTeknopolis.\u201d\n\n\u201cAligning the programming with BAM\u2019s big values of being progressive and independent is a big job,\u201d said Katy Clark, the institution\u2019s president. \u201cWhat strikes you immediately about David is his breadth, and he never seemed intimidated by the whole thing that BAM\u2019s become, its place in the community, and what\u2019s happened to Brooklyn.\u201d\n\nMr. Binder will assume leadership of BAM at a time when there are a number of new venues in New York also focused on global and experimental programming, including the Park Avenue Armory, on Manhattan\u2019s Upper East Side, and the Shed, now being developed on Manhattan\u2019s Far West Side. Mr. Binder said the organizations \u201ccan all live together beautifully.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey all have different missions, different kinds of buildings and are in different parts of the city,\u201d he said. \u201cTogether they make New York one of the most exciting cities for the arts in the world.\u201d\n\nMr. Binder said among his goals would be broadening the array of performers and patrons who sustain BAM.\n\n\u201cEverything is possible,\u201d he said. \u201cI hope to introduce many new artists to BAM, and I\u2019m looking forward to continuing to expand the diversity of the audience.\u201d", "title": "Broadway Producer Named BAM\u2019s New Artistic Director", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "The theater was so small, it was named the Little Theater. That was 106 years ago, and since then it has been reincarnated many times \u2014 renamed, repurposed, rehabilitated.\n\nNow known as the Helen Hayes Theater, the smallest house on Broadway is about to reopen yet again, this time run by a nonprofit, becoming the sixth of today\u2019s 41 Broadway theaters to operate outside the commercial marketplace.\n\nThe 589-seat playhouse has a new mission: Second Stage Theater, the nonprofit group that now owns the structure, says it will be used to present work by living American playwrights, a form of counterprogramming at a time when Broadway is dominated by musicals, revivals and British imports.", "title": "Broadway\u2019s Smallest Theater Is Reopening, This Time as a Nonprofit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBrown University in Providence, R.I., announced it will fully cover tuition for students in its master of fine arts program for acting and directing.\n\nThe three-year M.F.A. program is a partnership with Trinity Rep, a Providence theater, and provides students with professional acting and directing experience in addition to classes. Alumnae include Laura Kepley, the artistic director of the Cleveland Play House, and Taibi Magar, who is currently directing the Off Off Broadway production \u201cIs God Is,\u201d a Times Critic\u2019s Pick. The university hopes that removing the financial barrier will lead to more racial and economic diversity and allow aspiring creators to enter their careers debt-free.\n\n\u201cI really think the key to diversifying the American theater is eliminating debt in arts education,\u201d Patricia Ybarra, the chairwoman of Brown\u2019s theater arts and performance studies department, said in a phone interview.\n\nThe program\u2019s tuition for the 2017-18 academic year was $52,231. Brown will cover the tuition of all current and future students beginning next fall; in order to fully cover the costs, the next class size will be reduced slightly to 10 students. (The class of 2019 has 15.) Ms. Ybarra said the decision is part of the university\u2019s ongoing efforts involving the arts, diversity and eliminating loans: \u201cIt\u2019s the synergy between those things that made this a top priority,\u201d she said.\n\nThe diversity of the program\u2019s student body has increased over the last few years. According to data provided by the university, the acting and directing M.F.A. programs were made up of 25 percent students of color in 2014-15, compared to 42 percent in 2017-18.\n\nMs. Ybarra said the university\u2019s commitment to covering tuition is open-ended. \u201cI assume we\u2019re doing this forever,\u201d she said. Brown is currently financially stable, with its endowment hitting a record high last year, valued at $3.5 billion.", "title": "Brown Will Cover Tuition for Acting and Directing M.F.A. Program", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Harper always plays \u2014 and often talks \u2014 with a defiant ferocity, a fiery edge that makes him more polarizing than genial superstars like Mike Trout, Kris Bryant and Jose Altuve. The Nationals believe Harper\u2019s looming free agency will inspire him, not distract him.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve known him since he\u2019s 16, and I know his mind\u2019s right,\u201d General Manager Mike Rizzo said. \u201cHe\u2019s going to take this as a challenge and prepare himself to have a super season. We all know when he\u2019s on the field, he\u2019s going to perform. He\u2019s not a person that\u2019s going to be distracted. His focus is intense.\u201d\n\nHarper missed more than six weeks late last season with a bone bruise in his left knee after slipping on a wet first base while trying to beat out a grounder. He still hit 29 homers with a .319 average and an on-base-plus-slugging percentage of 1.008. He said he felt fine in the playoffs, when the Nationals lost a five-game division series to the Chicago Cubs.\n\nThat has been a discouraging refrain in Harper\u2019s career. Every season has ended before his birthday, which is Oct. 16. He has helped Washington win four National League East titles but has hit just .211 in the postseason, losing each time in the first round.\n\nLast October, as the potential tying run in the bottom of the ninth inning of Game 5, Harper struck out to end the season. He insisted he flushed the loss quickly.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. The season\u2019s over; that game\u2019s over. They beat us and that was it.\u201d\n\nSeveral of Harper\u2019s teammates are also facing free agency, including second baseman Daniel Murphy, starter Gio Gonzalez, catcher Matt Wieters and reliever Ryan Madson. The Nationals could still contend without them \u2014 with Max Scherzer and Stephen Strasburg in the rotation, they will always have hope \u2014 but now could be their best chance.\n\n\u201cWhether it\u2019s Bryce\u2019s last year, Murph\u2019s last year, my last year, we feel like this team is good enough to win the World Series,\u201d Wieters said. \u201cSo that makes it easy to put away all that thought of where we\u2019re going to be in the future, because we feel like we have a chance this year \u2014 and all you want coming into spring training is a chance.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Nationals essentially return the same roster that won the division by 20 games last season. Eaton and Trea Turner should form a dynamic top of the order, ahead of Harper, Murphy, Anthony Rendon and Ryan Zimmerman.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re expected to win; that\u2019s how it is,\u201d Harper said. \u201cWe\u2019re expected to win the East. We\u2019re expected to possibly win a pennant, and we\u2019re expected to possibly win a World Series.\u201d\n\nHarper said he was eager to play for Dave Martinez, who replaced Dusty Baker as manager and could bring more emphasis on analytics. Martinez, the bench coach for Joe Maddon with the Cubs, had speakers installed on each practice field here to blast music from all corners. He wants the team to have fun, keep winning, and forget about scaling the playoff hump.\n\n\u201cFor me, they\u2019ve accomplished the hump,\u201d Martinez said. \u201cMy message to them is, \u2018Hey, when we get there, it\u2019s just playing one more game. One more game. It\u2019ll be Game 163, 164, 165, that\u2019s it.\u2019 We\u2019re good enough to finish this out. They know that. We\u2019ve just got to concentrate on the here and now.\u201d\n\nThat is Harper\u2019s approach, too. He will play, and play hard, for the Nationals, until the moment \u2014 when? if? \u2014 he walks right out the door.", "title": "Bryce Harper Doesn\u2019t Want to Talk About the Future, or the Past", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner", "On Baseball"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "(Want to get this briefing by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nBudget and political statement\n\n\u2022 President Trump has proposed steep cuts to domestic programs and large increases in military spending as part of a $4.4 trillion budget proposal that he sent to Congress on Monday.\n\nAlthough it has little chance of being enacted as written, the plan would add $7 trillion to the deficit over the next 10 years. Republicans have traditionally embraced balanced budgets.\n\n\u201cI probably could have made it balance,\u201d Mr. Trump\u2019s budget director, Mick Mulvaney, said, but \u201cit would have taken funny numbers to do it.\u201d We outlined the administration\u2019s proposal.", "title": "Budget, Chloe Kim, Gates Foundation: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Over the past couple of months Republicans have passed or proposed three big budget initiatives. First, they enacted a springtime-for-plutocrats tax cut that will shower huge benefits on the wealthy while offering a few crumbs for ordinary families \u2014 crumbs that will be snatched away after a few years, so that it ends up becoming a middle-class tax hike. Then they signed on to a what-me-worry budget deal that will blow up the budget deficit to levels never before seen except during wars or severe recessions. Finally, the Trump administration released a surpassingly vicious budget proposal that would punish not just the vulnerable but also most working families.\n\nLooking at all of this should make you very angry; it certainly infuriates me. But my anger isn\u2019t mostly directed at Republicans; it\u2019s directed at their enablers, the professional centrists, both-sides pundits, and news organizations that spent years refusing to acknowledge that the modern G.O.P. is what it so clearly is.\n\nWhich is not to say that Republicans should be let off the hook.\n\nTo be sure, American history is full of politicians and parties that pursued what we would now call nefarious ends. After all, the pre-Civil War Democratic Party \u2014 which shares nothing but a name with today\u2019s Democrats \u2014 was largely devoted to the cause of preserving slavery. But I can\u2019t think of a previous example of a party that so consistently acted in bad faith \u2014 pretending to care about things it didn\u2019t, pretending to serve goals that were the opposite of its actual intentions.\n\nYou may recall, for example, the grim warnings from leading Republicans about the dangers of budget deficits, with Paul Ryan, the speaker of the House, declaring that our \u201ccrushing burden of debt\u201d would create an economic crisis. Then came the opportunity to pass a $1.5 trillion tax cut targeted on the rich, and suddenly all worries about the deficit temporarily disappeared.", "title": "Opinion | Budgets, Bad Faith and \u2018Balance\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Some investors in Berkshire may become impatient if it doesn\u2019t do some big deals. The company\u2019s cash pile had increased to $116 billion at the end of 2017, much of which was held in United States Treasuries.\n\nStill Mr. Buffett said he and Charles T. Munger, Berkshire\u2019s vice chairman, were happy to sit on the sidelines:\n\n\u201cBoth of us believe it is insane to risk what you have and need in order to obtain what you don\u2019t need.\u201d \u201cDespite our recent drought of acquisitions, Charlie and I believe that from time to time Berkshire will have opportunities to make very large purchases. In the meantime, we will stick with our simple guideline: The less the prudence with which others conduct their affairs, the greater the prudence with which we must conduct our own.\u201d\n\nBerkshire vs. S.&P. 500\n\nMr. Buffett has long set the goal of beating the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 index and in 2017, Berkshire did just that.\n\nThe company\u2019s book value rose 23 percent, while its stock price climbed 21.9 percent. The S.&P. 500 climbed 21.8 percent.\n\nFor years, Berkshire\u2019s book value was Mr. Buffett\u2019s preferred measure for comparing Berkshire\u2019s performance to the S.&P. 500 and he highlighted the comparison on a table on the first page of the letter. But outperforming the S.&P. 500 has become more difficult as Berkshire has grown and shifted to buying whole companies. A few years ago, Mr. Buffett added Berkshire\u2019s annual stock price performance to the table.\n\nHurricanes and \u2018Mega-cats\u2019\n\nHurricanes. The insurance segment of Mr. Buffett\u2019s letter contains an interesting discussion on hurricane losses. It says that the hurricanes that hit Texas, Florida and Puerto Rico last year will lead to $100 billion of losses for insurers. Berkshire estimates that its hit will total $2 billion after taxes, or less than 1 percent of its net worth. That percentage, according to Berkshire, is far below the 7 to 15 percent losses suffered by some reinsurance companies.\n\nIntroducing the mega-catastrophe. Mr. Buffett puts a 2 percent annual probability on the occurrence of a \u201cmega-catastrophe\u201d causing losses of $400 billion or more, but he said the risk could rise. \u201cNo one, of course, knows the correct probability,\u201d he wrote. \u201cWe do know, however, that the risk increases over time because of growth in both the number and value of structures located in catastrophe-vulnerable areas.\u201d\n\nAnd according to Mr. Buffett, Berkshire need not fear a mega-cat. \u201cNo company comes close to Berkshire in being financially prepared for a $400 billion mega-cat. Our share of such a loss might be $12 billion or so, an amount far below the annual earnings we expect from our non-insurance activities,\u201d he wrote.", "title": "Buffett\u2019s Annual Letter: Berkshire Records $29 Billion Gain From Tax Law", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Joining Mr. Buffett were Jeff Bezos of Amazon and Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan. Together, the three men have revolutionized industries, forged empires and navigated all manner of crises. But can they fix health care?\n\nIn announcing they would try, they delivered an implicit rebuke of the complex and costly American health care system, suggesting that the best minds in business could do better.\n\n\u201cCompanies are now thinking much more about how to solve larger social problems,\u201d said Aaron Chatterji, a professor at Duke University\u2019s Fuqua School of Business. \u201cWhen Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan, three leaders in their industries, looked around, they realized that health care is a big issue facing them all.\u201d\n\nTheir efforts stem from a feeling that, with partisan bickering and constant campaigning consuming Washington, the onus is on businesses to fill the void left by an ineffective government.\n\nTimothy D. Cook, the chief executive of Apple, acknowledged recently that a new imperative was challenging corporations. Government has \u201cbecome less functional and isn\u2019t working at the speed that it once was,\u201d he told The New York Times last year. \u201cAnd so it does fall, I think, not just on business but on all other areas of society to step up.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe notion that big business might shape government policy is nothing new, of course. Lobbyists have been working to sway lawmakers for decades, and the corporate world was an influential force in the tax overhaul passed last year.\n\nYet for the most part, these efforts were narrowly aligned with a company\u2019s self-interest, usually in the form of lowering taxes and loosening regulations. And rarely have business leaders tried to assume operational control of a government function, let alone something as complex and unwieldy as health care.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn recent years, however, more chief executives have begun speaking out on issues that at first glance have little to do with the bottom line, including immigration policy, climate change and gay rights.\n\nCorporate leaders have banded together to protest laws targeting transgender and gay rights in Indiana, North Carolina and Texas. And last year, as President Trump rolled out strict immigration rules, executives spoke out against the effort, with some, like the Google co-founder Sergey Brin, joining protesters at airports.\n\n\u201cThe lack of leadership on the national political level has left this vacuum,\u201d said Kathleen Clark, a professor at the Washington University Law school. \u201cFortunately, there are some business leaders who see that there\u2019s a role for them to play.\u201d\n\nThe most vivid expression of this new willingness to speak out came last summer after white supremacists marched on Charlottesville, Va., and Mr. Trump equivocated in his response to the violence.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a matter of days, top executives at the nation\u2019s largest companies issued statements condemning racism and denouncing Mr. Trump\u2019s response, and the president\u2019s business advisory councils were disbanded.\n\nChief executives may seem like unlikely ethical leaders; Wells Fargo, Equifax, Uber and many more companies have faced questions from Congress about practices that have harmed consumers and in some instances cost taxpayers billions of dollars.\n\nBut companies have also been wading into moral debates for decades. General Motors and Pepsi pulled out of South Africa during the apartheid era. Apple, Disney and Xerox were early in extending health care benefits to gay and lesbian couples.\n\nSimilar efforts by chief executives today recall \u201can earlier era of corporate statesmanship,\u201d said Lee Drutman, a fellow at New America, a research and policy institute. \u201cA lot of these business leaders viewed a business as having a somewhat broader public mission.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNow, he said, thanks to \u201cthe rise, over the last 15 years, of the importance of social responsibly and social mission, there is a broad movement in business.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven Amazon\u2019s much-publicized efforts to select a city for a second headquarters could, in a roundabout way, influence local policymakers. Given that the company is unlikely to set up shop in a state with socially conservative laws that might alienate some employees, \u201cAmazon could have an effect not just on prices but on what legislators pass,\u201d Mr. Chatterji said.\n\nOther examples of ambitious efforts by top executives to tackle social problems aren\u2019t hard to find. Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, made an ill-fated attempt to reform the public schools of Newark, N.J. Elon Musk has audacious plans to build a futuristic high-speed transportation network connecting cities in the Northeast. And billionaires across the political spectrum \u2014 from Tom Steyer on the left to the Koch brothers on the right \u2014 are spending heavily to sway public policy to their liking.\n\nThe wealthiest corporate titans are also using their philanthropy to shape public policy, in the United States and beyond. Microsoft\u2019s co-founder Bill Gates, through the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, is working on myriad initiatives that might plausibly be done by governments, including efforts to curb tobacco use, slow the spread of H.I.V. and improve education in Washington State.\n\nGeorge Soros, through his Open Society Foundations, has been promoting democratic ideals around the globe. And Mr. Zuckerberg, through the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative, is working on ambitious long-term projects involving science, education and justice.\n\nThere is a big difference, though, between supporting social causes and research and operating a sprawling public works system. Critics will contend that some of these efforts smack of arrogance, and that businesses ought to stay in their lane and focus on offering excellent products and services, not meddle in public policy.\n\n\u201cThere is this hubris, thinking that they can do it better,\u201d Mr. Chatterji said.\n\nThere is also a certain irony to the fact that Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan said the new company they had formed would be \u201cfree from profit-making incentives and constraints.\u201d\n\nThe profit motive, after all, is what leads to efficiency and innovation, according to conventional business school wisdom. Operating as a nonprofit \u201cflies in the face of the logic of the capitalist economy,\u201d Mr. Chatterji said.\n\nIt most likely will take years to determine if the three companies can make good on their promise of building a better health care system. Even if they succeed, the rewards may be limited to their employees \u2014 a large figure, but a small portion of the American work force.\n\nNonetheless, the companies\u2019 push is among the most audacious efforts by the private sector to date, and Mr. Dimon did not shy away from the scope of their ambition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe three of our companies have extraordinary resources,\u201d he said on Tuesday when the initiative was announced. \u201cOur goal is to create solutions that benefit our U.S. employees, their families and, potentially, all Americans.\u201d", "title": "Businesses Look at Washington and Say, \u2018Never Mind, We\u2019ll Do It\u2019", "authors": ["David Gelles"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "BEST FOR Shoppers looking for a paint-by-number guide to hanging art on the wall who won\u2019t mind if they see the same piece of art in an office hallway or a neighbor\u2019s apartment. (While Art.com offers a selection of exclusive prints through licensing deals and partnerships, many of its posters and fine art gicl\u00e9es are reprints.)\n\nHOW IT WORKS If you\u2019re looking for something unique, Saatchi Art has more than 500,000 original paintings, drawings, sculptures and photographs from thousands of emerging artists around the world. You can sort by medium, size and price, or browse curated selections like \u201cartists of the week\u201d or \u201cnew abstract expressionist paintings.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTapping on an artist\u2019s name brings up more works by that person. Filtering by price ($100 to $500) and size (large) produced a wide selection, from limited-edition prints like a poster of Wes Anderson\u2019s \u201cThe Grand Budapest Hotel\u201d by Robotic Ewe, recreated using the film script ($210), to acrylic paintings like \u201cAmazonia,\u201d a bright abstract by Rashna Hackett, inspired by rain forest parrots ($490).\n\nTapping \u201cview in a room\u201d displays the art on your wall and allows you to save a photo on your phone. But judging size is a bit tricky, as users must estimate their distance from the wall. When I tried to view \u201cWoods II by Dimitar Hinkov\u201d on my wall, the app pulled up the $500 painting, showing its dimensions (20 inches long by 28 inches high) with the directions \u201cplease stand 5.1 feet from wall.\u201d The company plans to introduce an update in coming weeks that eliminates this step by automatically sizing the artwork to scale.\n\nUnlike Art.com\u2019s app, this one has no self-serve feature for viewing your art in frames. But if you have a budget of $1,000 or more, Saatchi Art will connect you with a curator who will put together a selection of art for you to peruse based on your space and style, and work closely with you to produce a mock-up of what that art would look like in your living space.\n\nBEST FOR Beginning and longtime collectors alike with budgets starting at $150, as well as those interested in emerging artists.\n\nPhoto\n\nHOW IT WORKS If you want to see what your own photos would look like hanging on your wall, PictureThat AR allows you to pull from your phone\u2019s camera roll by tapping a circular icon at the bottom of the screen. The app will serve up a collection of photos from artists found on Instagram; scroll past those until you see your camera roll.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter selecting an image you want to hang, place the phone against the wall and tap \u201cHang photo.\u201d Then step back to superimpose the image on your wall.\n\nYou can adjust the size with a pinch of your finger or add more images to the wall with a tap of your screen, then save the collection to your photo archive or share on social media. Tapping on your superimposed image pulls up its dimensions along with the option to buy a digital print ranging from $36 for a 4-by-6-inch photo to $84 for a 24-by-36-inch one.\n\nThe app also allows you to save an image to your camera roll from any website to view on your wall later by using the Action button (that little square icon with the upward-pointing arrow) on your iPhone.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile the app attempts to solve many of the challenges involved with trying to visualize art on a wall, the execution still has a ways to go. During a trial run in my light-deprived apartment, my attempts to virtually hang photos elicited the following response: \u201cNot enough surface detail. Try moving camera or find better lighting.\u201d Though I was able to view the photos on my wall, the images occasionally drifted off the screen. Michael Yagudaev, the chief executive of Nano 3 Labs, a mobile and web development company in Vancouver, British Columbia, which developed the app, acknowledged the issue and said he expects the app to improve as the technology evolves.\n\nBecause this app allows you to upload any image from your camera roll onto your wall, it helped with a longstanding issue of my own that the others did not address: All the framed posters and rice-paper prints I bought on vacation in Vietnam years ago that are now stashed at the back of my closet. By taking photos of them, I was able to virtually hang them on the wall to see where I might eventually put them.\n\nBEST FOR Getting an idea of how those skiing shots from your Tahoe vacation would look on your wall or as a way to view art from websites without a 3-D option.\n\nThis home renovation and design site was the flurry of home furnishing sites that began leveraging Apple\u2019s new augmented reality development platform last year to let you try out furniture at home virtually. Earlier this month it added a new feature that extends those capabilities to wall d\u00e9cor, including ready-to-hang paintings, photographs, fine art prints, clocks, mirrors and wall-mounted lighting.\n\nHOW IT WORKS After you have selected a piece of art, tapping the \u201cView in My Room 3D\u201d button opens up the camera view on your iPhone or iPad. To virtually hang the art on the wall, you scan the floor and place the phone flat against the wall. You can manipulate the item, placing it at the best position and angle to see how, say, a $127 Evelyn Wall Mirror would look in your hall.\n\nSnapshots can be saved to a Houzz \u201cideabook,\u201d where they can be shared with family, an interior designer or other collaborators. Each product viewed in 3D is automatically kept in a shopping list.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBEST FOR Shoppers who want to see more than just prints, paintings and photos displayed on the wall.", "title": "Buying Art Doesn\u2019t Have to Be Intimidating: Yes, There\u2019s an App", "authors": ["Michelle Higgins", "The Fix"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "ANAHEIM, Calif. \u2014 On Disneyland\u2019s Main Street, Emily Bertola spends hours working on her feet, embroidering names onto mouse ears at the Mad Hatter shop, where she has been an employee for the last two years. She usually offers visitors the sunny smile she was trained to give.\n\nNone of her customers know that for months, she slept in the back of her truck, showering at the park before her shift.\n\nHer struggle is hardly unique to Disneyland.\n\nOrange County is known for its affluence, and for its tourist industry. But the thousands of workers who keep its resorts, restaurants and hotels running are sometimes struggling to stay afloat.\n\nAs the state grapples with soaring housing costs, workers in California earning just above the minimum wage find it difficult to pay for basic costs. Many employees at Disneyland have moved farther inland, driving hours each day to work. Others, like Ms. Bertola, have opted to move from couch-to-couch or sleep in their cars for months at a time.", "title": "By Day, a Sunny Smile for Disney Visitors. By Night, an Uneasy Sleep in a Car.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "KOBANI, Syria \u2014 The blood moon rose over a scene of bombed-out buildings reduced to boulder-size rubble, with newly printed street signs noting the names of people who had died here in this little Syrian city of Kobani.\n\nSoon dusk would draw its cloak over the sad tableau, in a neighborhood now called The Museum. For a few minutes between the setting of the wintry sun and the rising of the fattened moon, that twilit orange was the only illumination.\n\nThere are many devastated urban landscapes in Syria \u2014 Raqqa and Aleppo, for instance. Other countries\u2019 civil wars have shorn cities of their downtowns with a similarly breathtaking savagery \u2014 Beirut in the 1980s; Sarajevo in the \u201990s; Mogadishu in the new millennium.\n\nBut the half-square-mile of the old front-line area and business district of Kobani, population 40,000, is as bad as it gets anywhere, perhaps more shocking because the place is so small. Its moment of siege and destruction by the Islamic State from September 2014 to January 2015 is already forgotten abroad, as the Syrian war lumbers on elsewhere.", "title": "By Light of a Blood Moon, Life Returns to a Bombed-Out Syrian Landscape", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOverweight mothers are more likely to have overweight babies, and the gut bacteria the babies inherit may in part be to blame.\n\nResearchers report that overweight mothers are more likely to have a cesarean section, and that babies born by cesarean to those mothers have species of gut bacteria different from those in babies born to normal weight women. And that difference in the gut microbiome \u2014 specifically an abundance of bacteria of the family Lachnospiraceae in infants of overweight mothers \u2014 may contribute to an increased risk for obesity.\n\nThe study included 935 mother-infant pairs. Compared to children born to normal weight mothers, those born vaginally to overweight women were more than three times as likely to be overweight by age 3. But C-section babies born to overweight mothers were more than five times as likely to be overweight.\n\nFor normal weight mothers, vaginal or C-section delivery made no difference in the risk for overweight babies.\n\nThe study, in JAMA Pediatrics, controlled for breast-feeding, antibiotic exposure and other factors.\n\nThe senior author, Anita L. Kozyrskyj, a professor of pediatrics at the University of Alberta, said that there is no probiotic that would lead to a positive change in gut bacteria.\n\n\u201cIf a cesarean is unavoidable, there is no easy answer,\u201d she added, \u201cbut breast-feeding is effective in helping to prevent infants from becoming overweight.\u201d", "title": "C-Sections and Gut Bacteria May Contribute to Overweight Kids", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "The authorities in Atlanta announced a $10,000 reward for information leading to an arrest and indictment in the case of a missing Centers for Disease Control and Prevention employee who disappeared about two weeks ago.\n\nThe employee, Timothy J. Cunningham, 35, was promoted to commander in the United States Public Health Service in July, his family said. According to the police, he was last seen on Feb. 12.\n\n\u201cI feel like I\u2019m in a horrible \u2018Black Mirror\u2019 episode,\u201d Commander Cunningham\u2019s sister, Tiara Cunningham, said in a phone interview on Saturday. \u201cI\u2019m kind of lost without him, to be quite honest.\u201d\n\nMs. Cunningham, 27, was the last family member to speak with Commander Cunningham before he went missing, she said.", "title": "C.D.C. Employee Is Missing Nearly Two Weeks After Leaving Work Sick", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The C.I.A. director, Mike Pompeo, pushed back on Thursday against suggestions that a visit to the United States by Russian intelligence chiefs had contributed to the Trump administration\u2019s delay in imposing fresh sanctions on Moscow, saying in a letter that American officials \u201cpull no punches\u201d when sitting down with their Russian counterparts.\n\nThe meetings were focused on how the United States and Russia could better cooperate on counterterrorism issues, not sanctions, Mr. Pompeo said, noting that previous C.I.A. directors had had similar encounters.\n\n\u201cWe periodically meet with our Russian intelligence counterparts for the same reason our predecessors did \u2014 to keep Americans safe,\u201d Mr. Pompeo wrote.\n\nThe letter was sent to Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, the top Senate Democrat, who had said it was suspicious that Russian spy chiefs were allowed to visit Washington and meet with Mr. Pompeo days before the administration declined to impose new sanctions on Russian officials and oligarchs over interference in the 2016 election.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe two Russian officials who came to Washington were Alexander V. It also features an image of Adm. Yi Sun-shin, a Korean naval commander who is celebrated for 23 victories against Japanese invaders in the 16th century.\n\nPhoto\n\nKorean schoolchildren are taught of Admiral Yi\u2019s military prowess and ingenuity.\n\nAdmiral Yi invented the geobukseon, or \u201cturtle ship\u201d \u2014 the world\u2019s first armored maritime craft. The ships were covered in protective metal and spikes, and the front had a cannon shaped like a dragon\u2019s head.\n\nIn the Battle of Myeongnyang in 1597, he defeated a Japanese fleet of hundreds with just 13 ships.\n\nUnfortunately for Mr. Dalton, the goalie, the International Olympic Committee deemed his mask political and didn\u2019t allow him to wear it during the Winter Games. I.O.C. guidelines state that \u201cno item may feature the wording or lyrics from national anthems, motivational words, public/political messaging or slogans related to national identity.\u201d\n\nThe South Korean hockey team was eliminated this week, but Mr. Dalton \u2014 and his Yi mask \u2014 have gained a loyal fan base.\n\nInyoung Kang contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. The deal would shake up the health care industry, but it is not clear whether federal regulators will approve the merger of the two giant companies.\n\nIn another sign of the stress on the retail industry, Bon-Ton Stores filed for bankruptcy on Monday, becoming the latest chain store to seek Chapter 11 protection. Bon-Ton, which operates 256 stores in 23 states in the Northeast, Midwest and Upper Plains, said it would continue operating while it worked to reorganize.\n\nWhile many retailers reported a strong holiday season, Bon-Ton said its sales fell in November and December from a year earlier.", "title": "CVS Executive Hired to Run Hudson\u2019s Bay", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSAN FRANCISCO \u2014 California regulators have given the green light to truly driverless cars.\n\nThe state\u2019s Department of Motor Vehicles said Monday that it was eliminating a requirement for autonomous vehicles to have a person in the driver\u2019s seat to take over in the event of an emergency. The new rule goes into effect on April 2.\n\nCalifornia has given 50 companies a license to test self-driving vehicles in the state. The new rules also require companies to be able to operate the vehicle remotely \u2014 a bit like a flying military drone \u2014 and communicate with law enforcement and other drivers when something goes wrong.\n\nThe changes signal a step toward the wider deployment of autonomous vehicles. One of the main economic benefits praised by proponents of driverless vehicles is that they will not be limited by human boundaries and can do things like operate 24 hours in a row without a drop-off in alertness or attentiveness. Taking the human out of the front seat is an important psychological and logistical step before truly driverless cars can hit the road.\n\n\u201cThis is a major step forward for autonomous technology in California,\u201d said Jean Shiomoto, director of California\u2019s D.M.V. \u201cSafety is our top concern and we are ready to begin working with manufacturers that are prepared to test fully driverless vehicles in California.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nThe annual California Democratic Convention is typically filled with passion and drama, though its influence is debatable. Attendees tend to be activists who don\u2019t necessarily represent a cross-section of Democrats or the state.\n\nKeeping that in mind, here are a few of our takeaways from this weekend\u2019s session in San Diego.\n\n1) Senator Dianne Feinstein is not a particularly popular figure in this crowd; she is viewed as too moderate and Old Guard. No one expected her to get the 60 percent of delegate votes needed to capture the state party endorsement.\n\nThat said, her showing \u2014 37 percent \u2014 was something of a shock and reminder of structural weaknesses in her candidacy at a time when the party is moving left and wants change. Her opponent, Kevin de Le\u00f3n, the Senate Democratic leader, got 54 percent. Still, Ms. Feinstein\u2019s lead in statewide polls, financial advantage and her good will with party leaders suggests she shouldn\u2019t be sounding alarm bells. Yet.\n\n2) John Chiang, the state treasurer running for governor, invoked in his speech high-profile affairs that involved two of his main opponents, Gavin Newsom, the lieutenant governor, and Antonio R. Villaraigosa, the former mayor of Los Angeles. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nIt is usually jazz that plays in the background at Eso Won Books, a cherished independent bookseller in Los Angeles that for almost three decades has catered to African-American readers, but sometimes it is David Bowie, Nirvana or just really loud rock music.\n\nJames Fugate came to Los Angeles from Detroit in the late 1980s, and after a short time running the bookstore at Compton College, he and his partners opened their own store in South Los Angeles. The bookstore has been open nearly every day since \u2014 only once or twice, in Mr. Fugate\u2019s memory, has it closed. Once, he said, was in 2006, when Barack Obama, then a senator, came to town for a book signing and the crowds were too large for his shop to accommodate.\n\nFebruary is Black History Month, and there are still events to catch all over the city \u2014 at the Los Angeles Public Library, which is hosting art exhibitions, dance performances and a genealogy workshop; at the California African-American Museum; and the Aquarium of the Pacific, which is hosting a festival this weekend. (For listings of events, click here and here.)\n\nAnd at Eso Won Books, whose space has long been a gathering place for black intellectual life in the Leimert Park neighborhood of South Los Angeles, every month is Black History Month. Two presidents have visited \u2014 Mr. Obama and Bill Clinton \u2014 and Ta-Nehisi Coates has called Eso Won his favorite bookstore in the world. These days the store\u2019s best-selling book is \u201cWhen They Call You a Terrorist,\u201d by Patrisse Khan-Cullors, a co-founder of Black Lives Matter. \u201cFire and Fury,\u201d the inside look at the Trump White House by Michael Wolff, has also been a big seller.", "title": "California Today: A Cherished Black Bookstore in a Changing South L.A.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "During an interview at the grocery store, which Mr. Grant now rents out, he rattled off a list of his better-known customers, a red carpet parade of rap and hip-hop stars: Dr. Dre, Snoop Dogg, Coolio and Tupac among them.\n\nFor his celebrity clients, he made special deliveries to music studios.\n\n\u201cI was the weed man,\u201d Mr. Grant said. \u201cThey smoked my weed.\u201d\n\nMr. Grant talks about his old business as a reminiscence. He recounted how for years he would drive north to Humboldt County and stuff marijuana in Samsonites for the return journey \u2014 the suitcases kept the potent smell from seeping out.\n\nHe has a vision of opening legal marijuana stores in his old neighborhood, but the residents of Compton voted in a special election in January to ban marijuana businesses within the city.\n\nMr. Grant says he will try to push through another vote in Compton within the next year.\n\n\u201cIt would create hundreds if not thousands of jobs,\u201d he said of his plan. \u201cWatch how \u2018no\u2019 will become a staunch \u2018yes.\u2019\u201d\n\nCalifornia Online\n\n(Please note: We regularly highlight articles on news sites that have limited access for nonsubscribers.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Just 48 hours after the school shooting in Florida, a high school student in Whittier was overheard threatening another school shooting. Conspirators had suggested the survivors were not students, but \u201cactors.\u201d [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 A man suspected of raping a 14-year-old girl killed himself on Highway 101 in Ventura while fleeing the authorities. He had ingested cyanide poisoning during the chase. Now District Attorney George Gasc\u00f3n is proposing a task force dedicated to finding and prosecuting offenders. The survey sought to illustrate the scope of the #MeToo movement. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 BART officials are starting to study a second Transbay Tube. [BuzzFeed News]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 A state lawmaker has introduced a bill that would let drivers take more than one photo at the Department of Motor Vehicles and then choose the one that will go on their license. Fees charged for additional photos would fund driver\u2019s education. [Capital Public Radio]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nPhoto\n\nPerhaps you have been told that losing weight is as simple as burning more calories than you consume.\n\nA new study pokes a hole in that prescription.\n\nAs The Times\u2019s Anahad O\u2019Connor reported this week, the new research supports the idea that \u201cdiet quality, not quantity, is what helps people lose and manage their weight most easily in the long run.\u201d\n\nIn other words, the study found that if you cut back on added sugar, refined grains and highly processed foods but eat plenty of vegetables and whole foods instead, you can lose significant amounts of weight \u2014 even without limiting portion sizes.\n\nThe research was led by Christopher D. Gardner, the director of nutrition studies at the Stanford Prevention Research Center and carried out on adults recruited from the Bay Area.\n\nSo thank your neighbors for the revelation.\n\n\u201cThis is the road map to reducing the obesity epidemic in the United States,\u201d said Dr. Dariush Mozaffarian, a cardiologist and dean of the Friedman School of Nutrition Science and Policy at Tufts University who was not involved in the new study. \u201cIt\u2019s time for U.S. and other national policies to stop focusing on calories and calorie counting.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Tell us what you want to see: CAtoday@nytimes.com.\n\nCalifornia Today is edited by Julie Bloom, who grew up in Los Angeles and graduated from U.C. Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: After Legalization, Dr. Dre\u2019s \u2018Weed Man\u2019 Is Thriving", "authors": ["Thomas Fuller", "Matt Stevens", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nShe\u2019s only 17, and she\u2019s never competed at an Olympics, but Chloe Kim is one of the athletes at this Winter Games whom everyone is watching.\n\nBorn in Long Beach to Korean immigrants, Ms. Kim started snowboarding before most kids learn to read. At age 4 she began taking trips to Mountain High with her father, Jong Jin Kim, where, together, they learned to navigate the slopes.\n\n\u201cWe both had no idea what we were doing,\u201d she\u2019s conceded.\n\nThat didn\u2019t last long.\n\nMs. Kim won three gold medals at the X Games, all before age 16. She qualified for the Sochi Olympics but didn\u2019t go, because, at 13, she was too young.\n\nThen, in 2016, Ms. Kim became the first woman to land back-to-back 1080s in competition. (Yep, that\u2019s three full rotations on one side of the halfpipe followed by three more on the other.)", "title": "California Today: Chloe Kim\u2019s Olympic Journey Started at Mountain High, With Her Dad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nFor years, scientists have warned that we are due for a major earthquake. But getting Californians to buy earthquake insurance was a difficult sell \u2014 only around 10 percent of households in the state have it.\n\nThen came the natural disasters of 2017. Glenn Pomeroy, chief executive of the California Earthquake Authority, the nonprofit organization that oversees the insurance program, says that fires and mudslides in California, the flooding in Houston, and the earthquakes in Mexico all helped persuade many more Californians to sign up.\n\nLast year the earthquake authority saw a record increase of 90,000 new customers, compared with an average annual increase of 7,000 over the previous decade.\n\nThe \u201chorrible run of natural catastrophes,\u201d Mr. Pomeroy said in an interview, \u201ccrystallized people\u2019s thinking about the need to be protected.\u201d", "title": "California Today: Earthquake Insurance Sales Spiked in 2017", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nThe torrential rains that ripped through the state earlier this year and created the destructive and deadly mudslides in Montecito may make California\u2019s drought seem like ancient history.\n\nBut much of California has, in reality, suffered through an unusually hot \u2014 and somewhat dry \u2014 winter.\n\nA heat wave baked Southern California this week, breaking temperature records across the region. And officials say it has been warm in Northern California, too, causing much of the area\u2019s precipitation to fall as rain instead of snow.\n\nEven so, it hasn\u2019t rained nearly as much as the previous year, which was extraordinarily wet. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\n\u201cSell off!\u201d \u201cCrash!\u201d Investors bracing for \u201cuncertainty.\u201d\n\nAfter plummeting early this week, Wall Street rallied on Tuesday, recovering some, but not all, of what had been lost. What implications does the drop have specifically for California?\n\nIn an interview on Tuesday afternoon, Annette Vissing-Jorgensen, a professor of finance at the University of California, Berkeley\u2019s Haas School of Business, put the market decline in context for the Golden State.\n\nHere are some things to keep in mind:\n\nThe market\u2019s impact on capital gains \u2013 and the state budget\n\nWhen the stock market goes down, the amount of money Californians who sell stock must pay in capital gains taxes also decreases. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\n\u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d has become the film to beat at the Oscars.\n\nAfter a year of political strife, natural disasters, immigration woes and revelations of sexual harassment, it makes sense \u2014 to a degree \u2014 that an uplifting fantasy would march to the front of the Oscars race. People are yearning for escape and signs of connection and compassion, and Guillermo del Toro\u2019s tale \u2014 a lush hybrid of \u201cBeauty and the Beast\u201d and \u201cCreature From the Black Lagoon\u201d \u2014 serves up the feels in spades.\n\nIt is extremely rare, though, for a fantasy or sci-fi film to win the Oscars race, and \u201cShape\u201d could still be bested by \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d or \u201cGet Out.\u201d The Oscars are usually held on the last Sunday in February, but this year have been bumped a week, to March 4, to avoid conflicting with the closing night of the Winter Olympics.\n\nThis means that strategists are running extra long campaigns, and the people behind \u201cShape\u201d will be working to keep the film in the fore without making it seem like the preordained winner.", "title": "California Today: Is \u2018The Shape of Water\u2019 the Movie to Beat?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "So in that spirit, here are some of the responses we got, on social media and in emails to our newsletter, California Today. They have been edited for clarity and brevity.\n\nThe entire premise \u2014 making the newspaper some sort of parable or metaphor for the city as a whole \u2014 is misguided. First of all, L.A. is not an \u201cEastern establishment\u201d city. The L.A. of today, the \u201cmetropolis\u201d that it is, is a modern (i.e. 20th century) city. Here it doesn\u2019t matter what your family name is, who you are, where you came from. L.A. was built by people coming here with a dream and trying to make a go at it. It\u2019s a spirited Western town that has grown (and matured) into a liberal, educated, cultural urban center. The writers of this article are stuck in an old N.Y.C. image of L.A. as a cultural void, spread out, no core, no heart, etc.\n\n\u2014 wehoscott Los Angeles\n\nImagine if the Upper West Side had a different mayor and didn\u2019t contribute to N.Y.C.\u2019s tax code? That\u2019s what we have here. This is not a united city, because it is separate fiefdoms.\n\nI\u2019ve always found it absurd. To really unite this city you\u2019d have to have these rogue neighborhoods return to the city of L.A.\n\n\u2014Tim, Los Angeles\n\nL.A. is a city of the future and its media is future-based: a daily paper thrown on your driveway is a thing of the past. We have KCRW, we have blogs, we have people interested in reporting and in knowing. Hopefully someone will take up the L.A. Times mantle and make it into the multimedia platform it should be that covers our state in a contemporary way.\n\n\u2014 David Law, Los Angeles\n\nWhat a bizarre article, condescending to and denigrating an entire city as well as the L.A. Times. A city that never quite came together? A lack of civic institutions? No philanthropy? Yes, L.A. has problems; every city does. But we have the L.A. Philharmonic, Lacma, MOCA and the Getty, and a government that tries to deal with the problems all cities face.\n\n\u2014 Emmy G, Los Angeles\n\nMy city needs cohesion and honesty. It needs accountability. We have real problems. The first to come to mind is homelessness. It has literally exploded before our eyes. I would love to feel like journalists are investigating and highlighting issues and holding a light to dark and thorny issues, forcing us all to see and know what is going on in this vast city and how our government is dealing with this.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Jennifer Tucker\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). [The Los Angeles Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nWhen President Trump spoke during his State of the Union address about tightening immigration laws to keep out members of MS-13, the violent transnational street gang, many Angelenos working with former gang members raised their eyebrows at one omission: MS-13 was formed in Central Los Angeles, not Central America as the president suggested.\n\nJorja Leap, a University of California Los Angeles anthropologist, lamented the common misconception that MS-13 was brought to the United States from El Salvador. The group was in fact able to thrive in the 1980s amid the intense poverty in Los Angeles.\n\nMS-13, she said, took advantage of a social situation in which young people had experienced abuse, trauma or social isolation in the United States, not abroad. MS-13\u2019s brand of violence then spread back to Central America, exported by immigrants in the United States who were deported. Its leadership, such as it is, is based in El Salvador and most of its members are there.\n\n\u201cAny gang is opportunistic. They go where the population is vulnerable,\u201d Dr. Leap said, pointing out MS-13 has particularly terrorized the immigrant community. \u201cThey stick to the communities where they can intimidate, where they can abuse and blindside people.\u201d\n\nShe said the gang has lost power in Los Angeles in recent years, part of a collaboration between City Hall and law enforcement and activists, who have stressed rehabilitation for gang members seeking an exit ramp from lives of crime. She pointed to such collaborations as the path to reducing gang violence.\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays.
