Del Real", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\nThe cycle can feel numbingly familiar: mass shooting, followed by politicians offering their thoughts and prayers, followed by others demanding stricter gun laws. So it is hardly a surprise that lawmakers from California responded to the mass shooting at a high school in Florida last week by quickly calling for more gun-control laws.\n\nStill, the comments from Senators Kamala Harris and Dianne Feinstein make the frustration clear.\n\nSpeaking on MSNBC last week, Ms. Harris described looking at autopsy photos from shootings during her time as a prosecutor, suggesting that perhaps lawmakers should do the same.\n\n\u201cWhen you see the effect of this extreme violence on a human body and especially the body of a child, maybe it will shock some people into understanding,\u201d she said, adding: \u201cWe cannot tolerate a society and live in a country with any level of pride when our babies are being slaughtered.\u201d\n\nMs. Feinstein has taken to Twitter to renew her call to support an assault weapons ban, which she has co-sponsored with other Democrats.", "title": "California Today: Senators Vent Their Frustration About Guns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nIt\u2019s not only housing prices that are sky high in San Francisco. The city\u2019s public defender, Jeff Adachi, is leading a campaign to highlight what one study found were among the highest bail levels in the state.\n\n\u201cThe judges here set bails like they are announcing the next jackpot in the lottery,\u201d Mr. Adachi said. \u201cIt\u2019s typical to see $50,000 or a $100,000 bail.\u201d\n\nIn January, Mr. Adachi was emboldened by a California Court of Appeal decision that cast doubt on the practice of setting bail above what defendants can pay. The ruling says a \u201cdefendant may not be imprisoned solely due to poverty.\u201d\n\nThe case that prompted the landmark ruling involved Kenneth Humphrey, 64, who was accused of following a 79-year-old disabled man into his apartment in San Francisco, threatening to put a pillow case over his head and demanding money. Mr. Humphrey, who has a history of substance abuse and multiple prior felony convictions, stole $5 and a bottle of cologne from the man.", "title": "California Today: Should Bail Be Set Above What Defendants Can Pay?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning.\n\nOne of this year\u2019s most eagerly awaited exhibitions has opened at the Broad museum in downtown Los Angeles: six decades of work by Jasper Johns. The Times interviewed Mr. Johns for the Arts & Leisure section last Sunday. And we talked this week to Joanne Heyler, the Broad\u2019s founding director, who co-curated the exhibition, which runs through May 13. This email interview has been edited for length and clarity.\n\nQ: How did the Johns exhibit end up at the Broad?\n\nJoanne Heyler: \u201cJasper Johns: Something Resembling Truth\u201d is the result of four years\u2019 worth of curatorial and institutional collaboration between the Broad and the Royal Academy of the Arts in London. Edith Devaney, a curator at the Royal Academy, and I had a meeting four years ago as part of her earliest explorations about a Johns show. She inquired whether Eli and Edye Broad and the Broad Art Foundation would lend artworks from our very deep Johns holdings for such a show in L.A. We felt a responsibility, as the only L.A. museum with a deep collecting relationship to the artist, to hold this show here.\n\nQ: How is this show organized?\n\nJH: This exhibition is thematic rather than chronological, which with an artist like Johns \u2014 who returns many times, over decades, to motifs and ideas \u2014 is a very rewarding way to understand the work. Eight thematic sections give you a foothold in Johns\u2019 ruminations, through his work, on the nature of perception, on literary figures, memory, mortality and more.\n\nQ: Could you point out a few of your pieces people should be sure to see? (I know, it\u2019s like asking to choose a favorite child, but indulge us.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJH: \u201cPainting Bitten by a Man\u201d (1961) is one of the smaller works in the show, yet one of the most significant. It has a deep wax surface, painted grey, except for a tooth-marked impression in the center from being repeatedly bitten by the artist. It is raw, and complicates Johns\u2019 aloof or iconic image. Another quiet yet iconic work is \u201cPainted Bronze\u201d (1960). It stands 18 inches or so high, and appears to be an old Savarin coffee can stuffed with artist\u2019s paintbrushes, as if it were casually occupying the corner of a studio.", "title": "California Today: Six Decades of Jasper Johns at the Broad", "authors": ["Adam Nagourney", "Matt Stevens", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "In late February, California\u2019s stone-fruit and nut trees wake up from their winter dormancy, begin to bloom and enter a growth spurt that stretches until the summer harvest.\n\n\u201cTrees in bloom are very, very fragile,\u201d said Ryan Jacobsen, executive director of the Fresno County Farm Bureau. \u201cFreezing temperatures can burn the flowers or harm fruit that is just being set.\u201d\n\nGrowers worked around the clock to implement frost-protection measures, such as irrigating their orchards to create a warmer environment around the trees.\n\nExtremely low temperatures have also kept bees in their hives, instead of on the job pollinating.\n\n\u201cNot only are we losing crops, but bees aren\u2019t flying,\u201d Mr. Jacobsen said, adding, \u201cThe bees make your crop.\u201d\n\nSubfreezing temperatures are more likely to impact California agriculture in December and January, when the citrus harvest is underway. Temperatures plunged to the 20s only briefly around Christmas last year, sparing this season\u2019s production.\n\nHalf of the navel orange and mandarin crop is still on trees, but citrus industry officials said they were not worried.\n\nSmaller almond and stone-fruit crops could push up prices for consumers.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re casting a wary eye on the forecast,\u201d Mr. Chandler, the grower, said. \u201cIf Mother Nature keeps going cold, there\u2019s not much that worrying is going to do to save the crop.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCalifornia Online\n\n(Please note: We regularly highlight articles on news sites that have limited access for nonsubscribers.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The Supreme Court turned down a request from the Trump administration to decide whether it was entitled to shut down DACA. [Berkeleyside]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nPhoto\n\nSmack in the middle of Los Angeles, Canter\u2019s Deli has long provided Angelenos \u2014 a few of them famous \u2014 with a comforting respite in the wee hours of a weekday morning.\n\nAfter the bars close, the decades-old landmark of a restaurant has stood ready to receive customers seeking endless coffee refills, a plate of pickles, enormous pastrami sandwiches and an entire booth they could claim for themselves.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut this month, the deli announced on Twitter that it was suspending weekday dine-in service between 3 and 8 a.m. Owners acknowledged that customers\u2019 preferences have shifted to delivery (\u201cmost of you really like to eat our delicious sandwiches and black&white cookies at home in your pjs\u201d) and appeared well aware of the need to keep sit-down dining available all night on Fridays and Saturdays (\u201cWe know you need us after the after parties\u201d).\n\nIt\u2019s a small alternation, sure, but a concerning one to some longtime locals who have watched the slow decline of Jewish delis in L.A., fretted over Gary Canter\u2019s sudden death and become disheartened over the \u201cC\u201d grade the restaurant got from health inspectors last year.\n\nGentrification has already remade the corridor in which the deli resides. Critically acclaimed restaurants, a coffee shop hawking artisanal breakfast burritos and streetwear vendors with lines out the door now fill the district, which was once considered a hub of Jewish life in Los Angeles.\n\n\u201cChange is hard,\u201d Canter\u2019s tweeted. \u201cBut our food will still be the same.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Tell us what you want to see: CAtoday@nytimes.com.\n\nCalifornia Today is edited by Julie Bloom, who grew up in Los Angeles and graduated from U.C. Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: Some Central Valley Crops Imperiled by Cold", "authors": ["Miriam Jordan", "Matt Stevens", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nToday\u2019s introduction comes from Conor Dougherty, who reports on economics from the Bay Area.\n\nLast week Gov. Jerry Brown\u2019s Office of Housing and Community Development released a much-anticipated list of cities that will be subject to a new streamlining law that will essentially force those places to approve new housing, especially low-income housing, by removing the city government\u2019s ability to block certain kinds of building permits.\n\nThe report showed that pretty much all California cities \u2014 and especially those in the coastal job centers around San Francisco, Los Angeles and San Diego \u2014 haven\u2019t built nearly as much low and moderately priced housing as they were supposed to. That wasn\u2019t very surprising, given that California is in a dire housing crisis and has the highest real estate costs in the country.\n\nWhat was surprising, even shocking, was the city that topped the very short list of places that are meeting their goal of affordable new residences: Beverly Hills. How could that be? Are Beverly Hills\u2019s residents feeling guilty about income inequality and mass building low-income housing as a result?", "title": "California Today: The Beverly Hills Affordable Housing Loophole", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Yet the transit center has ambitions to be much more. A 5.4-acre park on the roof has a half-mile walking loop, an outdoor theater and gardens populated by dozens of mature trees. It\u2019s an elevated park that has been compared to the High Line in New York. The tech offices that surround the center connect directly with the park, as does a gondola that will whisk visitors to the park for the sidewalk below.\n\nDuring a week in which the Trump administration has sought to put infrastructure on the agenda, the transit center, which was built with close to $600 million in federal money from the stimulus package during the Great Recession, is a rubber-meets-the-road test for America\u2019s infrastructure plans. The center was built on top of a giant underground concrete box designed to be the San Francisco terminus for both CalTrain, the railway that runs through Silicon Valley to San Jose, and high-speed rail, which is meant to connect San Francisco with Los Angeles.\n\nBuilding the 1.3-mile tunnel that will bring the tracks into the station will take years and hundreds of millions of dollars. San Franciscans are waiting to see whether there is both the political will and the financing to get the job done.\n\nCalifornia Online\n\n(Please note: We regularly highlight articles on news sites that have limited access for nonsubscribers.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 A heavily armed young man barged into his former high school in Florida, opening fire on terrified students and teachers and leaving at least 17 people dead. Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: The \u2018Grand Central of the West\u2019 or a Glorified Bus Terminal?", "authors": ["Thomas Fuller", "Matt Stevens", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "But a new report from the Institute of Transportation Studies at the University of California, Los Angeles, says the biggest reason is that more Southern Californians are buying cars. Between 2000 and 2015, the study says, private vehicle ownership in the area increased from 1.7 to 2.4 vehicles per household. And the study says car ownership grew fastest among \u201cforeign-born households\u201d and other low-income people who tend to take public transit the most.\n\n\u201cTransit today relies on a high rate of use by a narrow base of people,\u201d the report\u2019s authors wrote. \u201cBut if that narrow base of people is acquiring vehicles, transit\u2019s healthy future lies in reversing those circumstances, and striving for at least a low rate of use by a broad base of people.\u201d\n\nIn a region of 18.8 million people, they note that about 77 percent use public transit rarely or never. It\u2019s a pool of \u201cvast untapped potential.\u201d\n\nThe obstacle? This state\u2019s recent environmental drama might have you thinking a bit more about climate change \u2014 and about how it could affect your family.\n\nYou\u2019re not alone. The Times reporter Maggie Astor spoke with more than a dozen people from California to Cairo about how climate change is affecting their decisions to reproduce or not. Some are swearing off children because they\u2019re concerned about raising a family in a world of receding shorelines and violent fires. Others are disturbed by the idea of expanding their carbon footprint \u2014 having a child is one of the costliest environmental actions a person can take.\n\nAmong those interviewed was Cate Mumford, 28. Though her Mormon religion teaches that God has commanded followers to \u201cmultiply and replenish the earth,\u201d she will not have children of her own, she said. Instead she will adopt.\n\nShe\u2019s received some pushback from members of her church. But a few years ago she traveled to smog-filled China, and all she could think was this: \u201cI\u2019m so glad I\u2019m not going to bring a brand-new baby into this world to suffer like these kids suffer.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: Traffic Is Terrible, but Californians Keep Buying Cars", "authors": ["Matt Stevens", "Julie Turkewitz", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "But how much do big companies actually matter to a city? Not as much as small companies.\n\nBig companies certainly have their benefits. They are generous philanthropists and tend to have more stable employment, so they help cities weather downturns. But over the past 50 years economists have shown that urban growth is much more highly correlated with the prevalence of small companies, suggesting that entrepreneurship is more important than big employers for a city\u2019s long-run prosperity, according to Edward Glaeser, an economics professor at Harvard who studies cities.\n\nThe good news for San Diego is that it has entrepreneurship in spades. The city is a center of start-up activity and venture capital investment, so while it does not have big recognizable companies \u2014 like Los Angeles does with its Hollywood studios or San Francisco with its tech giants \u2014 in the long run, Qualcomm or no Qualcomm, the city seems to be doing just fine.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve lived under the shadow of L.A. and San Francisco for a long time,\u201d said Jerry Sanders, the city\u2019s mayor from 2005 to 2012 and now chief executive of the San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce. \u201cWe have chosen a different path. Small business and smaller organizations are the ones that have made their way in San Diego, and I think that we take great pride in that.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Online\n\n(Please note: We regularly highlight articles on news sites that have limited access for nonsubscribers.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 President Trump sent Congress a $4.4 trillion budget. He was 87. [The New York Times]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nPhoto\n\nThink you are bad at math? Well, it turns out that may actually be part of the problem.\n\nHaving a positive attitude has been thought to affect how much a child learns and achieves academically, and researchers at the Stanford University School of Medicine think they now know why.\n\nIn a recent study, they found that when elementary school students maintained a positive attitude about math while doing problems, an important memory center in their brains \u2014 the hippocampus \u2014 functioned better. Put another way, if you\u2019re interested in math and believe you\u2019re good at it, that attitude enhances your memory and makes your brain better at problem solving.\n\n\u201cAttitude is really important,\u201d Lang Chen, the study\u2019s lead author, said in a news release. \u201cBased on our data, the unique contribution of positive attitude to math achievement is as large as the contribution from I.Q.\u201d\n\nBut don\u2019t fire the tutor just yet. Dr. Chen cautioned that there are limits to what confidence can do.\n\nA good attitude \u201copens the door for children to do well,\u201d Dr. Chen said, but it \u201cdoes not guarantee that they will.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: Would a Qualcomm Takeover Be Bad for San Diego?", "authors": ["Conor Dougherty", "Matt Stevens", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "New York Fashion Week finally came to life Tuesday evening in the shadow of the valley of \u2014 well, not death exactly. More like a post-apocalyptic prairie seen through a B-movie lens. Toto, what happened to Kansas?\n\nRaf Simons buried it under 50,000 gallons of popcorn.\n\nOr, to be fair, he buried the floor of the American Stock Exchange building under 50,000 gallons of popcorn, trucked in for a wackadoodle Calvin Klein show. It piled up in drifts around the weathered sides of four skeletal barns hung with blood red Sterling Ruby mop heads and papered with spectral black and white Warhol reproductions. It was crushed under the shoes of guests, so little motes of popcorn dust blew through the air. They landed on the coats and skirts and hair of Michael B. Jordan and Nicole Kidman and Millie Bobby Brown (among many other famous people), making everyone look as though they had an unfortunate case of dandruff or had wandered into a Food Channel version of nuclear winter.\n\nThen a model in a bright orange hazmat suit and waders appeared. Let\u2019s rephrase: Welcome to the pop-calypse.\n\nSince he arrived at the brand that bluejeans and minimalism built, Mr. Simons, who is from Belgium, has been fixated on defining his own brand of twisted Americana, largely built on the twin pillars of Laura Ingalls Wilder and \u201cOn the Road\u201d (the Netflix versions) \u2014 after the rot set in. This season he took it even further, with women in giant tweed coats over sweeping lawn skirts and men in sweater vests that looked more like life vests over skinny suits and shirts buttoned tight to the neck. Everyone wore knit Fair Isle balaclavas and often big firefighters\u2019 gloves in silver foil, which also was used in false-front A-line cocktail dresses trimmed in white lace that turned into camper-blanket sheaths at the back.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlso the two-tone cowboy shirts and placket trousers that Mr. Simons has used in every collection since his Calvin debut, and skinny striped sweaters and sweaters with Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner knit in, plus apron dresses with nothing underneath, so the breasts were exposed (a strange segue into Naughty Nellie from the general store). Quilting squares were pieced onto crisp white shirts and reworked as bias-cut chiffon evening gowns. The effect was all very survivalist. Simon & Garfunkle\u2019s \u201cSound of Silence\u201d played in the background. So did \u201cCalifornia Dreamin\u2019 \u201d by The Mamas & The Papas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was both a reductionist view of the country\u2019s most accessible myths and also stomach-churningly right. That\u2019s where we are now: drowning in a sea of puffed corn kernels and empty calories, appropriating the appropriators.\n\nPhoto\n\nYou might not like it all (though it\u2019s not hard to imagine those homespun balaclavas becoming a thing the next time the temperatures hit minus 30 degrees Fahrenheit), but it was viscerally recognizable, the way really good fashion \u2014 which is not the same thing as wearable clothes \u2014 is supposed to be.", "title": "Calvin Klein\u2019s Electrifying Popcorn Fashion Apocalypse", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Plus, cold weather keeps people inside more. \u201cWe\u2019re more likely to be in close quarters this time of year, close together among those who are already sick,\u201d Dr. Michael L. Munger, a practicing family physician in Overland Park, Kan., said in an email.\n\nHome heating and humidity may also play a role in winter health, Dr. Spinner said. Running the heat to keep the house warm also dries it out \u2014 and can dry out our sinuses, too. \u201cWhen you don\u2019t have good nasal mucus flow, it\u2019s harder for the immune system to work against the virus,\u201d he said.\n\nResearch also suggests that low indoor humidity may promote the transmission of flu. With high humidity, flu viruses expelled in a sneeze, for example, tend to attach to water molecules and may drop out of the air before they can trigger a new infection. In a dry room, those flu viruses often continue to float around until they reach their next victim.\n\nThere are also some scattered laboratory studies that suggest being cold might weaken the immune system, making us more vulnerable to those viruses. A 2017 study found that immune cells that are chilled are less effective at fighting off viruses, at least in a lab dish, making it \"easier for the virus to infect,\u201d said Dr. Prasert Auewarakul, a co-author and professor of virology at the Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital, Mahidol University in Thailand.\n\nIn a 2005 study by other researchers, college students whose feet were soaked in cold water for 20 minutes a day were more likely to get sick than those not exposed to the cold. And research in mouse cells suggests that rhinovirus, the common cold virus, replicates faster at cold temperatures, Dr. Auewarakul added.", "title": "Can Being Cold Make You Sick?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 Can you trademark a color?\n\nThe French shoe designer Christian Louboutin \u2014 known for sky-high stiletto shoes with scarlet soles that can sell for upward of $1,000 \u2014 has been trying to do so for years. Mr. Louboutin first grabbed his assistant\u2019s red nail polish and applied it to the outsoles of a shoe a quarter-century ago. Since then, he has frequently declared the design element to be his recognizable signature, and argued it merits legal protection.\n\nOn Tuesday, the European Union\u2019s highest court dealt a blow to that effort.\n\nMr. Louboutin had filed a lawsuit in 2012 against Van Haren, a Dutch company whose retail outlets were selling affordably priced high-heeled women\u2019s shoes with red soles. Lawyers for Mr. Louboutin claimed that the shoes sold by Van Haren, part of its Fifth Avenue by Halle Berry line, infringed on his brand\u2019s trademark for footwear. That trademark, registered in Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, referred to \u201cthe color red (Pantone 18 1663TP) applied to the sole of a shoe.\u201d\n\nVan Haren had to temporarily stop making and selling the line of shoes, but the company\u2019s lawyers fought back and the case eventually made its way to the European Court of Justice.\n\nThey have now won something of a reprieve. Maciej Szpunar, an advocate general for the court, said on Tuesday that Mr. Louboutin\u2019s red soles were not a separate entity from the shape of his high-heeled shoes, and shapes typically cannot be trademarked under European Union law.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn effect, he argued in a legal opinion, Mr. Louboutin\u2019s red soles could be refused trademark protection, sending the case back to Dutch courts to consider. Judges in national courts typically, though not always, follow advice from the European Court of Justice\u2019s advocates general.", "title": "Can Christian Louboutin Trademark Red Soles? An E.U. Court Says No", "authors": ["Elizabeth Paton"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nWatch the video above. What are your reactions to what these students of Stoneman Douglas High School share?\n\nIn \u201cA \u2018Mass Shooting Generation\u2019 Cries Out for Change,\u201d Audra D. S. Burch, Patricia Mazzei and Jack Healy write:\n\nThis is life for the children of the mass shooting generation. They were born into a world reshaped by the 1999 attack at Columbine High School in Colorado, and grew up practicing active shooter drills and huddling through lockdowns. They talked about threats and safety steps with their parents and teachers. With friends, they wondered darkly whether it could happen at their own school, and who might do it. Now, this generation is almost grown up. And when a gunman killed 17 people this week at Stoneman Douglas High in Parkland, Fla., the first response of many of their classmates was not to grieve in silence, but to speak out. Their urgent voices \u2014 in television interviews, on social media, even from inside a locked school office as they hid from the gunman \u2014 are now rising in the national debate over gun violence in the aftermath of yet another school shooting. \u2026 At other high schools across the country, students rallied in solidarity with Stoneman Douglas High and staged walkouts to protest what they called Washington\u2019s inaction in protecting students and teachers. A gun control advocacy group, Moms Demand Action, said it had been so overwhelmed with requests from students that it was setting up a parallel, student focused advocacy group. \u201cPeople say it\u2019s too early to talk about it,\u201d Mr. Kasky said. \u201cIf you ask me, it\u2019s way too late.\u201d His argument reflects the words of other students who want action: The issue is not an abstraction to them. These are their murdered friends, their bloodstained schools, their upended lives. Students said they did not want to cede the discussion over their lives to politicians and adult activists. \u201cWe need to take it into our hands,\u201d Mr. Kasky said.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then watch the speech from the Stoneman Douglas High School senior Emma Gonz\u00e1lez at the Not One More rally for gun legislation held at the federal courthouse in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Saturday:\n\n\u2014 What role do you think the students of Stoneman Douglas High School and other schools may play in ending gun violence in schools? Why do you think they are having such an impact? Do you think they can do more than adults can right now? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 What do you think about Cameron Kasky\u2019s statement that students need to take the discussion \u201cinto their own hands\u201d?\n\n\u2014 As \u201cchildren of the mass shooting generation,\u201d how might young people\u2019s perspectives be different from older people\u2019s?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 What do you think about the feelings and opinions that Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez expresses? What words from her speech do you find especially notable for any reason?", "title": "Can High School Students Make a Real Impact on the Problem of Gun Violence in the United States?", "authors": ["Shannon Doyne", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "But nepotism isn\u2019t the most important source of unjustified inequality. Those who already have the advantage of better educations, better connections and better financial resources often parlay these advantages into securing more valuable opportunities and more remunerative careers. Internships are one device for doing this. They\u2019re often unpaid or low-paid, so that only those with substantial family resources can afford to do them. And access to them is often by way of connections. So, internships require both social capital and financial capital. (Charles Murray has famously pronounced them \u201caffirmative action for the advantaged.\u201d) Given all this, you might think that internships should be given to applicants with the best qualifications, but these qualifications are easier for the rich and well connected to acquire, which is why such people often have more cultural capital, too.\n\nSo, there\u2019s a real problem here. The question is what your role should be in finding a solution. If the system is as you describe it, you\u2019re unlikely to get this internship unless you agree to the pulling of the paternal strings. Should you forswear a system you rightly think unfair at the cost of not getting an internship? There are at least two worries about that.\n\nOne is that it won\u2019t make any difference. Nobody will notice that one application came without a thumb on the scale. A second is that the policy of depriving yourself of opportunities in an unfair system makes it likelier that the opportunities will be distributed among people who don\u2019t even have the virtue of being aware of the problem. Generally speaking, social problems of this sort aren\u2019t best solved by heroic individual sacrifice. They\u2019re solved by bringing attention to the issues \u2014 as you just have \u2014 and joining others in campaigning for change. I prefer your other option: Take the internship, work hard and well, get a job and rise to the level where you can reform the company\u2019s hiring practices. It\u2019s a fine thing when the virtuous prosper.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI was in a half-empty subway car in Manhattan, headed downtown one evening, returning from a \u201cYes to Love, No to Hate\u201d rally not long after the far-right gathering in Charlottesville, Va.\n\nThe door opened, and a young couple came in, attracting attention by the force of their entry and his agitated, ugly commentary about her. They sat across from me as he forcibly instructed her, shoving her, to move over. He tore open the corner of a box of cookies, stuffed several in his mouth and threw the box under the bench. She had bruise marks on her arms. He had a tattoo that said \u201cLoyalty\u201d in script over one eyebrow and other markings. The seat next to the door was vacated by a person moving to avoid them. He shoved her over to the open seat. She moved down the car to another seat; he followed. She moved again to the flip seat by the far door; he crushed in beside her. I reached my stop and got out. I looked for a police officer or transit person on the platform, found none and went home sickened by what I saw and by my inaction \u2014 my failure to protect (rescue?) this young woman.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYes, I feared violence toward myself. But also, in this time of increased racial sensitivity, I feared the added arrogance of \u201cwhite privilege\u201d had I chosen to intervene. I am a white, white-haired 75-year-old woman (though still healthy and strong); the couple were most likely in their early 20s and \u201cof color.\u201d There were many ethnicities and colors in that car, all avoiding eye contact, and at least one other woman, herself \u201cof color,\u201d aware of this situation (she was the person who changed her seat to avoid the couple).\n\nMy appraisal: He was high and violent, and she was being abused in public in front of my eyes and those of everyone else in the car. What should I have done? Name Withheld\n\nOne issue your letter raises is what philosophers sometimes call \u201cgroup agency.\u201d No individual in the car, let alone you, the white-haired septuagenarian, was obliged to confront a violent, possibly high young man; but you can still have the thought, surveying your fellow passengers, that \u201cwe\u201d should have done something.\n\nMight there have been an effective way to mobilize the disapproval of others in the subway car and perhaps trigger a sense of collective responsibility? The psychology of intervention in cases like these is quite complex, and many studies have been done on so-called bystander apathy. Generally, when people are in a crowd, they don\u2019t intervene when they see someone misbehaving. Part of the explanation is no doubt the reasonable thought that you have no special responsibility here. It\u2019s also true that people are less inclined to intervene when, as here, the victim is perceived to be in a relationship with the perpetrator. People feel it\u2019s not their business. And because the perpetrator here may have been high and seemed violent, there would indeed have been risks in intervening.\n\nStill, interventions in these circumstances might contribute to reducing spousal abuse, especially if we could establish a norm that people don\u2019t allow this to happen in public places like the subway. To get one concern out of the way: I don\u2019t think the fact that you were white and he wasn\u2019t changes much. No \u201cwhite privilege\u201d was implicated in your desire to help this young woman of color. If you said something to him and he reacted violently, he might have used the word \u201cwhite\u201d in cursing you; but had he actually attacked you, the odds that someone would have defended you would, I suspect, have reflected your gender and age, not your race.\n\nWhat were your options? You could have tried addressing the woman and asking her whether she would like help. If the man were to turn on you at that point, someone would probably have come to your aid; it\u2019s hard to rationalize doing nothing when a morally justified stranger is being menaced. But you might have worried that if she said \u201cyes,\u201d he would have taken it out on her later.\n\nAnother tack would have been to address the most vigorous-looking people in the carriage, saying something like, \u201cCome on, we can\u2019t let him do that to her.\u201d Again, though, this is likely to have been helpful only if she had been going to get away from him as a result. Your account suggests that she wasn\u2019t fleeing him: Remaining in the same car, she was perhaps trying to create temporary distance from him, until he cooled down. In that case, they\u2019ll be seeing more of each other, and he could well have exacted a penalty from her if he felt publicly humiliated.\n\nAssuming your appraisal was widely shared, then, I can see why so many of you might have felt powerless. So, let\u2019s return to your instinct to call for law enforcement. It\u2019s worth remembering that there\u2019s a conductor (as well as an operator) on every M.T.A. subway train; you could have stepped out of the car and walked up the platform waving to catch his or her attention and then communicated what you saw. You can\u2019t be reproached for your inaction, but you\u2019re right to wonder whether more could have been done.", "title": "Can I Use My Dad\u2019s Connections to Get an Internship?", "authors": ["Kwame Anthony Appiah", "The Ethicist"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Moon will face some tough choices as he tries to accomplish two goals, building on a hard-won Olympic d\u00e9tente with North Korea while also preventing a rupture with the Trump administration, which is raising the pressure on the North to give up its nuclear weapons. He also wants to pursue his own agenda of taking a leading role in defusing tensions around the Korean Peninsula, which remains technically at war.\n\nMr. Moon may see an opportunity in the surprise offer by the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, conveyed in person by Mr. Kim\u2019s sister, to hold their first summit meeting in Pyongyang. Mr. Kim seized on Mr. Moon\u2019s peace overtures before the Olympics to send his sister, Kim Yo-jong, to the opening ceremony and a large contingent of cheerleaders and athletes to the Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea.\n\nBut Mr. Moon also knows he must convince the Americans to give him a chance. In a sign of how hard that will be, and how deeply the United States and North Korea distrust each other, Mr. Pence, who was Washington\u2019s envoy to the opening ceremony, and Ms. Kim would not even look at each other despite being seated only a few feet apart.\n\nOn Friday, Mr. Moon argued for a South Korean-brokered peace and for the United States-North Korea talks when he met with President Trump\u2019s daughter Ivanka Trump, who arrived to attend the Games\u2019 closing ceremony. He told her he wanted to improve ties \u201cin parallel\u201d with efforts to denuclearize the North.\n\nAnalysts said that once the Olympics ended, Mr. Moon would be left to sort out how much of the North\u2019s so-called charm offensive, in which it refrained from provocations like missile tests, could last.", "title": "Can South Korea\u2019s Leader Turn an Olympic Truce Into a Lasting Peace?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Some removal technologies are more fanciful than others, but as for which are most viable, it could be argued that none are, at least not yet. In a report last month, the European Academies Science Advisory Council offered a pessimistic outlook for carbon removal, saying that it offered only \u201climited realistic potential\u201d to have a climate impact. The authors argued that the world should not count on removal technologies to make up for a failure to sharply reduce or eliminate emissions in the first place.\n\nThere are five major approaches to carbon dioxide removal:\n\nPlant more forests. Trees remove carbon dioxide naturally, incorporating it into their tissues as they grow. Worldwide, forests store about one billion to two billion tons of carbon annually, offsetting a chunk of the roughly 10 billion tons emitted by human activity. Reforestation and afforestation, properly managed, could remove a lot more and keep it out of the atmosphere. But planting forests is slow work \u2014 as Icelanders know well \u2014 and requires a lot of land. The world is currently much better at cutting down forests than planting new ones.\n\nCrush a lot of rock. This technique is called enhanced weathering, and is based on the fact that some types of rock weather by naturally combining with carbon dioxide in the air or water. One suggested approach would use the mineral olivine, which is plentiful, crushing it into fine sand and spreading it on land, perhaps along coastlines. But mining, crushing and transporting the billions of tons needed would be expensive and energy intensive. And the carbon removal would still be exceedingly slow.\n\nBurn plants for energy and capture the carbon dioxide. In this high-tech approach, called bioenergy with carbon capture and storage, or BECCS, vegetation would be used to naturally remove carbon dioxide. The vegetation would then be burned in a power plant and the carbon dioxide in the exhaust gases would be captured and stored. So far there are only a handful of working BECCS projects; others have been canceled. Among the many questions about the technology is whether emissions are really negative if the carbon cost of growing and harvesting the vegetation is taken into account.\n\nSprinkle iron in the ocean. Like enhanced weathering, fertilizing the ocean by putting iron particles or other nutrients in the water is among the more far-fetched approaches. The idea is that the nutrients would stimulate the growth of tiny marine plants called phytoplankton, which would incorporate carbon dioxide as they grew and then sink to the bottom of the ocean when they died, taking the carbon with them. Generally, however, putting large amounts of metal or chemicals into seawater is considered ocean dumping. There have been only a few tests of the idea, one of which was conducted without scientific oversight off Western Canada in 2012 under the pretense of helping a native Canadian community improve its salmon catch.", "title": "Can We Really Scrub Carbon Dioxide From the Atmosphere?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Income tax rates were slashed on conventional corporations (so-called C corporations), but the great majority of corporations, especially smaller ones, are in another category. They are pass-through entities, meaning their tax liability is borne by the owners on their personal tax returns. Rates were cut for pass-throughs, too, but not nearly as much, and provisions in the law, passed in late December, limit tax breaks for pass-through vehicles of certain types and sizes.\n\nThe discrepancy in headline tax rates has persuaded some owners of pass-through entities \u2014 which include partnerships, Subchapter S corporations and limited-liability companies \u2014 to consider converting to C corporations (often called C corps). In certain cases that may be the right move, tax advisers say. They encourage owners to calculate their tax liability under different structures to assess which would work best.\n\nStill, when all tax consequences are factored in, they expect most people to be better off keeping what they\u2019ve got.\n\n\u201cPeople will have to decide, \u2018Should I operate as a pass-through or as a C corp?\u2019\u201d said James Markham, a tax specialist at Ernst & Young who focuses on issues that entrepreneurs face. To determine the better way to go, \u201cyou have to run the numbers.\u201d\n\nThe basic arithmetic gives the edge to C corps, for which the top tax rate has been cut to 21 percent from 35 percent. The top rate for individuals has been cut to 37 percent from 39.6 percent, and most qualified business income \u2014 essentially net profits \u2014 for pass-through entities gets a 20 percent deduction. That brings the top rate from 39.6 percent to 29.6 percent (a 20 percent deduction applied to the new 37 percent rate), well above the top C corp rate.\n\nBut we\u2019re talking about the tax code: It\u2019s not that simple.\n\nAdvisers point out that C corp income paid out as dividends is taxable to the recipients, usually at 20 percent, from profits that have been taxed already. That double taxation more than nullifies the advantage of the lower income tax rate.\n\nSay a company earns $100 and pays $21 in tax; if it pays the remaining $79 out as a dividend, the recipient is likely to end up with an additional 20 percent tax bill, leaving a net payment of only $63.20.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIn most cases, the double taxation for C corps versus single for flow-throughs makes a lot of difference,\u201d said Ian Shane, a partner at the law firm Michelman & Robinson. \u201cIf you\u2019re going to put money into a corporation and keep it there and reinvest from it, you\u2019re probably better off in a C corp, but very few people are going to do that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChuck Hansen, founder and chief executive of Electro Scan, a Sacramento, Calif., company that uses high tech methods to seek out flaws in sewage systems, may be one of those people. Mr. Hansen is contemplating converting Electro Scan into a C corp from an S corporation.\n\n\u201cIf I\u2019m accumulating cash and won\u2019t have to pull it out, and I can make investments on the company platform, why not?\u201d he said. While a lot of details remain to be ponder concerning the tax law and its effect on Electro Scan and his other business interests, he said, \u201cI\u2019m already leaning toward that.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnother reason to convert to a C corp is that the deduction for pass-throughs is limited if the income is earned providing services that depend on the owners\u2019 reputation and skill. In that case, it can be applied only to qualified business income of $315,000 for married owners and half that for single owners, with a portion of the deduction available on the next $100,000 (for married owners) or $50,000 (for single owners) of income. Electro Scan provides \u201ctechnology as a service,\u201d Mr. Hansen said, so it may run afoul of that provision.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a coin flip on whether I\u2019m happy or mad about this thing,\u201d Mr. Hansen said of the law.\n\nThe treatment of service businesses under the new law is still unclear. For example, the deduction limit on services applies explicitly to activities like health, law, accounting, insurance, performing arts, consulting, athletics and financial services. While architecture and engineering should be eligible for the full deduction, professionals may still \u201cget caught by the \u2018reputation or skill\u2019 provision,\u201d Mr. Shane said. \u201cFollow the logic here? No, neither do I.\u201d\n\nOther provisions of the tax bill in general are clear enough but still hard to factor into tax planning. Making the most of a new rule on writing off depreciable property, for instance, might require an ability to travel back in time.\n\nAndrew Oswalt, an analyst at TaxAct, a provider of tax filing software, noted that businesses can immediately write off the full value of equipment placed in service beginning Sept. 27, nearly three months before the bill was enacted.\n\nIf you\u2019re unlucky enough to have put a big piece of machinery into service on Sept. 26, it would feel unfair, he said. \u201cIt hurts a bit.\u201d In that case, the previous regulations hold: You are entitled to write off only 50 percent of the value.\n\nAnother aspect of the law could inflict pain: the rules regarding how much pass-through owners decide to pay themselves. They are required to take a salary that reasonably reflects the work they do as employees but usually will take as little as possible so they can minimize payroll taxes. That incentive grows under the new law because salary does not receive the 20 percent qualified income deduction.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo try to curb that tendency, Mr. Oswalt said, the rules generally require that the deduction be capped at 50 percent of a firm\u2019s W-2 wages; very small salaries will result in smaller deductions. But this provision applies only to businesses with income above the $315,000/$157,500 threshold, he said.\n\nWhile the new law adds some complications, Mr. Markham at Ernst & Young said it makes life simpler for some not-very-small businesses. Ones with gross receipts below $25 million can use the simpler cash method of accounting rather than the accrual method; the previous ceiling was $5 million.\n\nProvisions such as this and the ability to write off equipment expenses fully are \u201chuge in terms of complexity for small businesses,\u201d Mr. Markham said.\n\nThe law gives business owners a lot to ponder, but Mr. Oswalt encourages them not to get carried away.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t overthink it,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s not a ton of things that need to be done.\u201d If you run a pass-through entity, he said, \u201cjust educate yourself and think about how it\u2019s going to affect your 1040.\u201d", "title": "Can You Get Rich From the New Tax Law by Becoming a Company?", "authors": ["Conrad De Aenlle"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 When she began planning her fall 2018 collection, Maria Grazia Chiuri, Dior\u2019s artistic director for women\u2019s wear, could not have known that in the days before her show, students from a Florida school would transform the debate on gun control in the United States, calling time on the status quo and reframing the national dialogue.\n\nShe could not have anticipated that six teenagers would be running for governor in Kansas on different platforms of change.\n\nAll she knew, she said in a preview, was that 50 years ago students in France took to the streets to make their voices heard, and it became a social and political turning point. The world then was at an inflexion point, as was fashion, and she thought, maybe, we were at a similar place today. She\u2019d pay homage to it on her runway.", "title": "Can You Wear Dior to the Demonstration?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cJai Ho? For Justin Trudeau and his India trade trip outfits, it\u2019s more like \u201cJai No,\u201d wrote the Toronto Star, alluding to the soaring anthem from the hit film \u201cSlumdog Millionaire,\u201d set in India. Some questioned how much the seemingly nonstop outfit changes had cost the Canadian taxpayer.\n\nIn India, the online news outlet Outlook India, wrote that the elaborate dress was \u201ctoo Indian even for an Indian.\u201d Omar Abdullah, scion of a prominent Indian political family, chided Mr. Trudeau for out-Bollywooding Bollywood.\n\n\u201cThis isn\u2019t multiculturalism,\u201d Ashish Anand, an entrepreneur from Vancouver, wrote in a tweet. \u201cIt\u2019s a desire to be popular like a rock star.\u201d\n\nBut others defended Mr. Trudeau, noting that he and his son wore orange head coverings during a Wednesday visit to the Golden Temple in Amritsar, a revered holy site for Sikhs, that are required for entry and a sign of respect.\n\nAfter all, they asked, wasn\u2019t he just trying to be culturally sensitive?\n\nDuring the visit to the Golden Temple, the Trudeau family was pictured wearing traditional outfits, their palms held together in a Namaste greeting.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a difference between culture appreciation and culture appropriation,\u201d one Twitter user wrote in defense of Mr. Trudeau.\n\nBut the elaborate attire was not just relegated to temples and shrines.\n\nDuring one event focusing on the film industry, Mr. Trudeau was decked out in a Sherwani, a dazzling and intricately embroidered golden garment, as he met with Indian movie stars.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was pictured standing next to the Bollywood actor Shah Rukh Khan, who wore an understated black shirt and jacket. One Twitter user noted sardonically that the actor appeared to be teaching Mr. Trudeau about \u201cplaying the role\u201d of a prime minister.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Trudeau topped off the week by showcasing his Bhangra moves at a dinner in Delhi on Thursday. The Indian Express wondered if the prime minister\u2019s drum-infused arm jerking was \u201cembarrassing\u201d to Canadians and questioned whether his \u201cover-Indianized clothes\u201d were out of step with a modern India.\n\nThe rebukes came during a sometimes tense trip, intended to foster closer ties between the two countries but mired in controversy after it emerged that a militant Sikh separatist convicted of attempting to murder an Indian cabinet minister in Vancouver in 1986 had been invited to a dinner at the Canadian High Commissioner\u2019s residence in New Delhi. The invitation was later withdrawn but not before it spurred anger.\n\nWhatever the reaction to his apparel choices, they were no doubt a conscious decision for Mr. Trudeau, whose eye-catching sock selection has become global news, and who has shown an acute adeptness for stage-managing his image. In recent years, he has been photographed shirtless in a selfie with a family hiking in Quebec and posed in a wet-suit during a beach wedding in British Columbia.\n\nThe Canadian prime minister remains a beloved character abroad, feted by social democrats in Europe and beyond as a liberal counterpoint to President Donald J. Trump on everything from immigration to female reproductive rights. It doesn\u2019t hurt that Mr. Trudeau is a social media darling as adept at posing with panda bears as he is at parsing quantum computing.\n\nBut lately he has been buffeted by a series of missteps. In December he was forced to apologize after a federal ethics watchdog took him to task for taking a Christmas vacation on a private yacht owned by the Aga Khan.\n\nMore recently, he was criticized after telling a woman during a town hall meeting in Edmonton, Alberta, that she should use \u201cpeoplekind\u201d instead of mankind.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Trudeau is not the first global figure whose wardrobe choices have come under scrutiny \u2014 although mostly the criticism is directed at women.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen she was first lady, Michelle Obama attracted both praise and criticism for not wearing a head scarf during a 2015 trip to Saudi Arabia; Queen Elizabeth II had covered her head during a 1979 trip to the kingdom. And in December 2016, Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain was chastised for being photographed in a $1,250 pair of leather pants.\n\nBut President Obama was scolded when he wore a summery, tan suit after Labor Day, and President Trump has been criticized for wearing ill-fitting suits, baggy trousers and too-long ties.\n\nAs for Mr. Trudeau, he may have gotten the message of critics on this trip. In a meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India on Friday, he wore a blue business suit.", "title": "Can a Canadian Carry Off Bollywood Style? Justin Trudeau Finds Out", "authors": ["Dan Bilefsky"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "When you came to the White House, what were you told from the get-go about climate change and the Paris agreement?\n\nThe guidance at that time was the campaign promise.\n\nYou mean, to \u201ccancel\u201d the Paris agreement?\n\nTo cancel that, and to cancel the funding for global warming programs. But you know, the president expressed a willingness to stay in Paris right after the election. It wasn\u2019t as if he held to the \u201cwe\u2019re getting out\u201d line. I think the first public statement that I ever saw from the president was, \u201cI would renegotiate it.\u201d So for me, coming into the job, I recognized that there was more to it than just canceling, and the president probably wanted flexibility and some options.\n\nWhat is your personal position on the Paris agreement?\n\nI\u2019m going to say something controversial. I\u2019ve said it before, in 2016. But the Paris agreement is a good Republican agreement. It\u2019s everything that the Bush administration wanted.\n\nHow widely was your view shared inside the White House?\n\nI don\u2019t think people were well-informed of the agreement. But I think that\u2019s a failure of the Obama administration. There was the narrative that the Obama team was circumventing the Congress, that this was a treaty in reality, and then the pledge. The pledge was just awful.\n\nHow so?\n\nI just don\u2019t think it was based on a real economic analysis. They weren\u2019t transparent with the pledge, they didn\u2019t bring stakeholders in. You can\u2019t move forward with a climate policy, or you should not move forward with a climate policy, without the input of those industries that are going to be heavily regulated. That was a fatal flaw and they took a big risk in doing what they did.\n\nAt this point is there any climate agreement that Congress would accept?\n\nAs long as you are pursuing a top-down approach you\u2019re going to have a problem.", "title": "Can the Games Be Green?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "The other two parties of the left, the Greens and the Left Party, appear equally devoid of optimism and direction. At the beginning of the year, Sahra Wagenknecht, the parliamentary leader of the Left, called for a \u201cleft movement\u201d in which her own party, the Social Democrats and the Greens came together. This sounds like a good idea, a way to unify Germany\u2019s fragmented progressives into a strong collective. Unfortunately, Ms. Wagenknecht is one of the impediments.\n\nIn recent years, she has made remarks on immigration (\u201cNot all the impoverished and poor of the world can come to us\u201d) and on feminism (\u201cI get hit on, too, but I\u2019m able to set boundaries and don\u2019t have to weep on Twitter\u201d) that have alienated potential allies on the left. And a divisive leader is not the party\u2019s only problem. The Left Party has historic links to the East German regime, which continues to scare off voters. Some members of the Parliament, like Diether Dehm, are reported to have ties to anti-Semitic groups. The party\u2019s soft line on Russia has also drawn censure. The result is that the party is \u2014 despite its promising left-wing program \u2014 \u201cunw\u00e4hlbar\u201d (unelectable) for many leftists.\n\nThe Greens, for their part, hardly present a better option. Last month, the party elected new leaders, choosing for the first time since its founding in the 1980s \u201crealos\u201d \u2014 a nickname for centrist \u201crealistic\u201d politicians. Meanwhile, the left-wing core of the Greens, known as \u201cfundis\u201d for their commitment to the party\u2019s fundamentals, continues to lose power. In the months after the election, the Greens entered into coalition talks with Ms. Merkel\u2019s party and the radically free-market Free Democratic Party. Those talks foundered, but that the Greens even contemplated the idea was seen as the end of an era. And this centrist drift hasn\u2019t even led to electoral success; in September\u2019s election, the party came in sixth place.\n\nAs Germany\u2019s left-wing parties fail in one way or another, a soaring number of young people are unhappy with politics. According to a recent survey, about 86 percent of Germans under 30 years do not feel represented in the current political system.\n\nThe main task for the German parliamentary left now will be to offer an alternative for both disaffected young urbanites and the alienated working class. The Social Democrats, the Left Party and the Greens all have politicians in their ranks who stand for progressive change. But these figures can come into power only with increased pressure from the base.\n\nThere is no need \u2014 or reasonable prospect \u2014 of a merging of these three parties. And yet they would be well advised to agree on three points: opposition to nationalism, to further deregulation of the economy and to the gutting of social services. With this groundwork, the first red-red-green coalition in German history could, eventually, move from a seeming impossibility into a realistic hope.", "title": "Opinion | Can the German Left Save Itself?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "At the center of this case is the Stored Communications Act, which was written when there was no modern global internet or cloud storage. It provides Fourth Amendment safeguards to prevent unreasonable searches of electronically stored communications \u2014 but says nothing about data held abroad.\n\nThe Court of Appeals concluded that the Stored Communications Act was not intended by Congress to allow searches outside the country. The ruling followed the well-established principle that American courts generally do not apply United States law beyond its borders unless Congress intended so.\n\nBut at least four federal courts have since refused to follow the ruling, mostly for practical, technology-driven reasons. The cases before those courts involved Google and Yahoo, which store data \u201cdynamically\u201d \u2014 breaking data into many small pieces and constantly shuttling it among storage centers in various countries to optimize performance and network efficiency. The text of an email might reside in Bulgaria, but the attachment in Spain.\n\nDoes it make any sense to think of this email as located in a specific country overseas? As a United States District Court judge, Juan R. S\u00e1nchez, wrote in an opinion that rejected the Second Circuit\u2019s ruling, \u201cno one knows which country to ask\u201d for the data.\n\nBecause Microsoft still frequently uses local-based storage, the Supreme Court case, though important, is of limited significance. The court has an opportunity to clarify the scope of the Stored Communications Act with respect to data stored \u201cstatically\u201d outside the United States. (When signing up for service, a Microsoft user indicates his or her country of residence and Microsoft usually stores the user\u2019s data in a nearby data center.) But the case does not address the more general question of the legal standards that govern information that crosses borders \u2014 and in particular, data stored \u201cdynamically.\u201d\n\nOnly Congress can address that larger question, by writing an urgently needed new law. (Even the Second Circuit appealed to Congress to step in.) The International Communications Privacy Act, introduced last term in Congress, is a good place to start. It provides a framework by which United States law enforcement can obtain communications of both United States and foreign citizens, consistent with the privacy protections afforded by international law.\n\nThe guiding principle should be that the reach of any new law is defined by the citizenship and geographical location of the individual whose data the government seeks, rather the physical location of the data. This would allow for the right balance between global privacy rights and the needs of United States law enforcement.\n\nNo matter how the Microsoft case is decided, if Congress fails to act, we will continue to have a legal system that inadequately governs the vast stores of electronic data that move seamlessly across international borders.", "title": "Opinion | Can the United States Search Data Overseas?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn his first practice, he didn\u2019t look very good,\u201d said Canada Coach Willie Desjardins, who coached the Vancouver Canucks in the N.H.L. from 2014 to 2017. \u201cGuys are going, \u2018This guy will never make it.\u2019 But he finally worked his way onto the team.\u201d\n\nGeneral Manager Sean Burke noticed that O\u2019Dell had been named captain of his team in Russia, and suspected there was more to him than met the eye.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re in Russia and the guys don\u2019t speak English,\u201d Burke said. \u201cHaving your captain being an English-speaking Canadian really says a lot about his character.\u201d\n\nBurke uses the word \u201ccharacter\u201d a lot in describing this team, which he said will epitomize \u201cthe Canadian Way.\u201d Usually that means having gobs more talent than any other team in the tournament. This year that means the team will not be outworked. Even the most skilled players are willing to accept lesser roles.\n\nOnly two players on the roster are without any N.H.L. experience, so Burke expects some to carry a chip on their shoulders.\n\n\u201cThe N.H.L. is the best league in the world, and I don\u2019t think anybody would disagree with that,\u201d he said. \u201cBut Canada still has a large pool of talent. Try to tell them it\u2019s not the N.H.L. players, it\u2019s not the best players in the world.\u201d\n\nIn naming his team, Burke pulled together bits and pieces from six leagues, including 13 from the K.H.L., three from the American Hockey League and the rest from the Austrian, German, Swiss and Swedish leagues. Sidney Crosby and Jonathan Toews they are not.", "title": "Canada Finds Itself in an Unusual Role: A Hockey Underdog", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Yet after the Canadian men\u2019s and women\u2019s teams filled the past 10 days with light draws (curling talk for a bad shot), stones that flashed the house (curling talk for a different type of bad shot) and losses to teams like South Korea, Denmark and \u2014 perhaps worst of all \u2014 the United States, that gold in mixed doubles probably doesn\u2019t look so shabby.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt should be noted that Canada is a curling powerhouse. Historically speaking, it is a nation of broom-wielding, rock-shoving wizards. Their Olympic trials are the most competitive curling competition on the planet. Plus, the sport is played on ice, and Canada is pretty good at stuff that involves ice.\n\nEntering these Games, Canadians had never gone without a medal in any curling event since the sport made its debut at the 1998 Winter Olympics. They were 10 for 10, a stretch of dominance that included the last three gold medals in the men\u2019s competition.\n\nSo to do what they did here (or didn\u2019t do here) would be comparable to the United States men\u2019s and women\u2019s basketball teams failing to win a medal at the Summer Olympics. But just as basketball has become a global sport, with improved competition from countries like Spain and Serbia, curling has benefited from increased popularity around the world.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nConsider the success of the South Korean women\u2019s curling team at these Olympics \u2014 and the effect its surprisingly strong showing here will have on the continued growth of the game in Asia. On Friday, the South Koreans defeated Japan, 8-7, in a semifinal thriller to advance to Sunday\u2019s gold medal final against Sweden.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s overplayed that Canada is a favorite,\u201d the Canadian curler Marc Kennedy told reporters after the team\u2019s loss to the Americans in Thursday\u2019s semifinals. \u201cWe come from a rich history of curling, where we won everything, and that\u2019s not the way it is anymore.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cAnyone that\u2019s been watching the grand slams of curling, we\u2019ve got European teams winning all the time. They spend nine months of the year in Canada training and learning our strategies and using our coaching and using our ice. So this is the new normal. People need to get used to it.\u201d\n\nEven if that takes some time.", "title": "Canada\u2019s Curling Is Crumbling! Or Something Like That", "authors": ["Scott Cacciola"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI couldn\u2019t ask for more in my career,\u201d he wrote in an Instagram post. \u201cIt\u2019s been fun dreaming my wildest dreams and having so many of them come true.\u201d\n\nIs curling attracting much attention from Koreans or is it just a curiosity for the home crowd?\n\nCurling, that great cultural institution, is still a fledgling sport in many corners of the world \u2014 including South Korea, where the Olympic curling venue has been the site of fine competition, plenty of enthusiasm and no small amount of confusion.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs many of you know, the nuances of shotmaking and even scoring can take some time to grasp for those who are new to the sport. South Korea built a competitive curling program before the Olympics, but the sport\u2019s popularity is not particularly widespread here. Fans cheer a lot, but sometimes for poor shots. In any case, the South Korean women\u2019s team is a medal contender and proved as much by upsetting Canada in its opening match of the tournament.\n\nIt was a bittersweet, if mostly bitter, result for Canadian fans: Peter Gallant, South Korea\u2019s coach, is from Prince Edward Island.\n\nIs Canada still the team to beat in men\u2019s hockey even without current N.H.L. players on its team?\n\nPhoto\n\nThe men\u2019s hockey draw seems like a total tossup. Traditional powerhouses like the United States and Russia \u2014 or the team that used to be known as Russia \u2014 lost their opening matches. Canada defeated Switzerland in its first match of the tournament in front of a mostly empty house at Gangneung Ice Arena.\n\nWithout the star power that N.H.L. players delivered at previous Olympics, the tournament is struggling to attract many eyeballs. Teams have filled their rosters with players who are toiling away in lesser leagues or are at the end of their career \u2014 and that includes Canada, which went with older players while leaving younger prospects at home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe result is that chemistry will need to be built on the fly, and nobody seems too sure how this tournament will pan out. But Canada should contend for gold. It\u2019s still hockey, after all.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis link will whisk you to all of our Winter Games coverage. Here are some of the stories and digital features that caught my eye:\n\n\u2014The Times is experimenting with something called augmented reality. Unlike virtual reality, another technology we\u2019ve been exploring, augmented reality doesn\u2019t require cardboard goggles. But, right now at least, you can only experience the full effect by using an iPhone 6S, SE or newer. For the Olympics, we\u2019ve used the technology to take a unique look at four athletes. Try it and send me an email with your thoughts about the technology and how we used it.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2014Most years I spend this weekend doing a local 51 kilometer cross country ski loppet. (Don\u2019t bother checking my past results.) My travel schedule and the on-and-off winter in Ottawa mean that I\u2019m just skiing occasionally with my wife this year. I\u2019m also the household\u2019s wax technician. But the grumbling I hear when I get the wax wrong is nothing compared with what Knut Nystad experiences. David Segal reported that Mr. Nystad, the chief of Norway\u2019s 30-strong crew of Olympic wax techs, becomes public enemy No. 1 back home when his team messes up.\n\nCross-country skiing is to Norway what hockey is to Canada. Mr. Segal looked into Norway\u2019s equivalent of Sept. 28, 1972. (For non-Canadian readers: that\u2019s the day that Paul Henderson scored the winning goal against the Russians in the Summit series.) In this case, the defining moment was the breaking of Oddvar Bra\u2019s ski pole at 1:54 p.m. on Feb. 25, 1982, which became the stuff of national legend in Norway.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2014Here\u2019s the diet of Adam Rippon, an American figure skater, from two years ago: three slices of whole grain bread topped with pats of I Can\u2019t Believe It\u2019s Not Butter spread, supplemented by three cups of coffee, each laced with six packets of artificial sweetener.
