He wore a dark suit, resting his cheek on his fist and rarely glancing in the direction of the jury.\n\nAt one point, Mr. Gitner asked Mr. Howe a question that he had asked last week, whether he was \u201cin more trouble\u201d than he had ever been in.\n\nMr. Howe\u2019s answer on Tuesday was unequivocal. \u201cI believe,\u201d he said, \u201cI\u2019m in a boatload of trouble.\u201d", "title": "Chagrined (and Jailed), a Key Witness Returns to Stand", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley", "Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "When we complain to Egypt\u2019s Western allies about whichever autocrat is in power, we are asked, \u201cBut who is the alternative?\u201d It is a question designed to frustrate. The allies, led by America, know full well that by giving billions in aid and selling billions more in weapons to our military, they are ensuring the military\u2019s continued political dominance \u2014 and in doing that, ensuring the near impossibility of our country coming up with any alternative.\n\nIn January, Vice President Mike Pence became the highest-level American official to visit Egypt since President Barack Obama went in 2009. He told Mr. Sisi the United States stood \u201cshoulder to shoulder with you and Egypt in fighting against terrorism,\u201d but he avoided giving even lip service to the need to ensure free and fair elections.\n\nSecretary of State Rex Tillerson is to visit Egypt and other countries in the region, beginning this week. He, too, is unlikely to bring up Egypt\u2019s sham elections; after all, the United States consistently puts \u201cstability\u201d at the top of its priorities for countries like ours, inevitably at our expense.\n\nSo we are caught between an American-style Sisi and an Egyptian-style Putin. Mr. Pence\u2019s \u2014 and Mr. Tillerson\u2019s \u2014 boss, President Trump, is emulating our military-backed dictator, Mr. Sisi, every time he unabashedly exercises greater executive powers than the Constitution allows, and Mr. Sisi in turn assures continuation for his own rule by emulating Mr. Putin\u2019s transparently sham elections.\n\nCaught in such a vise of global authoritarianism, it is cruelly disingenuous and willfully ignorant when the West asks us, \u201cWho is the alternative\u201d to Mr. Sisi? It is imperative instead to stop giving aid and selling weapons to a military-backed regime that is set on smothering all life out of our politics.\n\nIt has been seven years since popular uprisings swept across Egypt, forcing the ouster of another autocrat, Hosni Mubarak, who had once served as head of the air force. When the millions of Egyptians who joined that uprising chanted in Tahrir Square and throughout Egypt, \u201cThe people demand the fall of the regime!\u201d they meant not just him but the system that propped him up. Mr. Mubarak fell. But the military system remained intact.\n\nIn the most recent elections, three years ago, Mr. Sisi was said to have received a difficult-to-believe 96.1 percent of votes. According to the Arab Network for Human Rights Information, these have been the fruits of Mr. Sisi\u2019s term in office: 60,000 political prisoners, 7,513 civilians tried in military tribunals, 2,332 death sentences, 500 people barred from travel, 465 internet sites shuttered, 54 journalists and media workers jailed, 17 new prisons.", "title": "Opinion | Channeling Putin in Cairo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Families for Excellent Schools, a charter-schools organization known for its battles with Mayor Bill de Blasio and its close relationship with Eva S. Moskowitz, the mayor\u2019s frequent antagonist and head of the city\u2019s largest charter school network, Success Academy, said on Monday that it was shutting down.\n\nThe organization announced last week that it was firing Jeremiah Kittredge, its chief executive officer, after an accusation of \u201cinappropriate behavior toward a non-employee.\u201d But the decision to close seemed to reflect financial problems rather than the loss of a single employee.\n\nFamilies for Excellent Schools for years was the well-funded face of the charter school movement in New York, but its support seems to have evaporated. The organization\u2019s chairman, Bryan Lawrence, said in a statement: \u201cUnfortunately, after a series of challenges over the past year and particularly given recent events, we have determined that the support necessary to keep the organization going is not there.\u201d\n\nIn 2014, the year that Mr. de Blasio took office, Families for Excellent Schools spent $9.6 million on lobbying, more than any other organization in the state. Much of that money was spent on television advertisements criticizing the mayor for blocking several of Ms. Moskowitz\u2019s schools from getting space in city-owned school buildings. (As a candidate, Mr. de Blasio had promised to halt a practice of giving charters space in public school buildings.)", "title": "Charter School Group, Known for Battling the Mayor, Will Close", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "A 15-minute drive from downtown, for example, will take you to the top of Lookout Mountain, and its wonderful free park, Sunset Rock, rich in Civil War history. Hikes in the area lead past rifle pits where Confederate soldiers tracked the movement of Union troops on the ground, and then sent out word via communications stations on nearby Signal Mountain. Now, students from the University of Tennessee and canoodling couples of all sexual orientations come nightly to sit on cliffs and watch the Tennessee River Valley turn shades of red and pink.\n\nAfter a hectic first week on the job in New Orleans, I felt an immediate sense of relief as I drove into town and immediately onto a tranquil brick road stretch of Chattanooga\u2019s Main Street lit up with strings of white lights. Every corner I turned seemed to have an interesting bar, including the impossibly narrow Pickle Barrel; Stir, where bartenders climb ladders to reach top-shelf liquor; and the Flying Squirrel Bar, an eternal hot spot that has a lit-up wooden boat hanging from its ceiling. One actionable upside of being Gig City is that, according to Kelly Shaughnessy, a real estate agent and model I met, the dating scene is pretty good: \u201cFiber-optics brought start-ups and start-ups brought hipsters, so everywhere you go are 20- to 35-year-olds who are not married, making apps.\u201d\n\nMy first hotel, The Dwell, is the city\u2019s only boutique offering and an Art Deco gem. Seija Ojanpera, the owner, spent four months combing vintage shops, Etsy and eBay to find its period-authentic d\u00e9cor, which, along with the colorful patterned wallpaper, is different in every room. \u201cI think it\u2019s important for Chattanooga to have interesting places to go that don\u2019t feel like airport lounges,\u201d she told me. The breakfast room and bar often contain more locals than visitors. I also stayed in the town\u2019s new Westin (nice enough, but didn\u2019t blow me away) and the Choo Choo Hotel, which is far from luxurious, but worth it just because the check-in desk is in the train\u2019s old terminal waiting room, and the rooms are in actual Pullman train cars. Those not in need of lodging can have a similar experience in the newly opened American Draft, the country\u2019s first pour-your-own-beer bar in a refurbished train car.\n\nMost striking, though, is the city\u2019s civic life. A phrase that comes up constantly is \u201cThe Chattanooga Way\u201d: a reference to a cooperative get-it-done spirit that includes infusions of private foundation money making revitalization possible. Public art is impressive and everywhere, from the Sculpture Fields at Montague Park to \u201cThe Blue Trees,\u201d an ecologically themed installation consisting of rows of trees that the artist Konstantin Dimopoulos has painted a non-harmful ultramarine blue to bring attention to deforestation. Upon my arrival, Farron Kilburn, who studies inequities in nursing at the University of Tennessee, invited me to a potluck at her home in the city\u2019s hip North Shore. There, I met a chunk of the city\u2019s diverse sector of artists and community activists including Josiah Golson, who just published an illustrated poetry book called \u201cThe Souls of Free Folk\u201d (partly inspired by W.E.B. DuBois), and Rondell Crier, an artist and youth mentor, who moved to Chatt from New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, and has never felt compelled to move back.\n\nThe next night, I joined them for a big group dinner at Taconooga, one of the city\u2019s many Mexican restaurants. (The Guatemalan population is also significant and growing.) During the day, one particularly helpful local, Stephanie Hays \u2014 a self-described \u201cboomerang\u201d who has lived in China and India and moved back because she loves the city \u2014 treated me to one of the free walking tours she gives in her spare time. I came knowing no one and felt like I\u2019d left with a friend group.", "title": "Place 2 of 52: Chattanooga Is Changing. But Its Charms Remain.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "If you caught your classmates cheating on a school assignment or test, would you tell on them? Why or why not?\n\nHave you or any of your friends been in this situation before? If so, what did you do and why?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out what The Times Ethicist says is the right thing to do.", "title": "Cheating", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Aah, Funeral Wells.\n\nA gray-bearded man with sunken eyes befitting his constant state of bereavement, he specialized in picking pockets at places of mourning. One minute he\u2019d be keening beside you; the next, he\u2019d be gone and so would your wallet, intensifying the weeping and wailing over fresh loss.\n\nAnd don\u2019t forget Poodle Murphy, a slim man with the weary look of a beleaguered clerk, but perhaps the finest pickpocket in the country. Among his gifts was the ability to grow a full red beard quickly \u2014 a fortuitous talent for someone often on the lam.\n\nThere was lanky Banjo Pete Ellis, who gave up minstrelsy to star instead as a bank burglar and all-around sneak. And Little Annie Reilly, a house servant adept at flattering the lady of the house, fussing over the children and vanishing with all the jewelry. And Lord Courtney \u2014 a.k.a. Lord Beresford, a.k.a. Sir Harry Vane of Her Majesty\u2019s Lights \u2014 a suave British commoner who liked to swindle money from the wealthy belles he bedazzled. Introducing himself to Baltimore society as an officer of the Royal Navy, he so charmed its women that they cut the buttons from his fake uniform to cherish as relics of the empire.\n\nThis fraudulent nobleman, along with many other underworld denizens of late-19th-century New York \u2014 the pickpockets and hotel thieves, the forgers and confidence men \u2014 would surely be forgotten today, their distinctive faces lost to cruel time, were it not for a New York police official whose legacy straddles fame and infamy: the singular and supremely confident Inspector Thomas F. Byrnes.", "title": "Cheats, Swindlers and Ne\u2019er-Do-Wells: A New York Family Album", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "A heavily armed young man is accused of killing 17 people after opening fire on terrified students and teachers at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., on Wednesday. It was the third mass shooting in the past four months in the United States.\n\nNikolas Cruz, who has been linked to a history of mental illness, is believed to have used a legally obtained AR-15 in the shooting. The attack has led to widespread conversations about links between gun violence and mental illness, and how lawmakers and interest groups are debating potential policy responses. Below is a look at some facts and falsehoods uttered by Speaker Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin; Senator Bernie Sanders, independent of Vermont; and others in the wake of Wednesday\u2019s shooting.\n\n\u201cMental health is often a big problem underlying these tragedies.\u201d \u2014 House Speaker Paul Ryan\n\nThere\u2019s a link, but it\u2019s more limited than widely thought.\n\nMr. Ryan\u2019s claim reflects a common misconception. According to various polls, roughly half of Americans either believe that failing to identify people with mental health problems is the primary cause of gun violence or that addressing mental health issues would be a major deterrent.\n\nThat conclusion is not shared by experts or widely accepted research.\n\nIn an analysis of 235 mass killings, many of which were carried out with firearms, 22 percent of the perpetrators could be considered mentally ill.", "title": "Checking Facts and Falsehoods About Gun Violence and Mental Illness After Parkland Shooting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Chelsey Taylor Amer and Scott Benjamin Group were married Feb. 24 at the Village Club at Lake Success, an events space in Great Neck, N.Y. Cardozo School of Law in Manhattan.", "title": "Chelsey Amer, Scott Group", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Back when I was in high school, there was a cafe in SoHo I loved for its over-the-top sweets.\n\nBillowing cakes towered over the counter, the cream cheese frosting between the layers thicker than the cakes themselves. They had golden coconut macaroons as big as my palm, and soup bowls full of rice pudding, mounded with thick, cinnamon-flecked whipped cream.\n\nBut to my teenage self, the best treats of all were saucer-size dark chocolate cookies loaded with white chocolate chunks and pecans. Fudgy in the center, with a brittle, crackling crust, they were sort of like the corner squares from pan of brownies \u2014 both chewy and crisp.\n\nEven better, any white chocolate bits that seeped through the cookie batter and hit the baking pan caramelized, turning butterscotch-rich. Who cares if the cookies were sweet enough to make my gums ache? I loved them fully and completely.", "title": "Chewy Chocolate Cookies That Are Only Slightly Over the Top", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCHICAGO \u2014 A high-ranking Chicago police officer was fatally shot on Tuesday afternoon within sight of City Hall, turning some of downtown\u2019s busiest blocks into a chaotic crime scene and adding to a grim tally of officers killed across the country in recent days.\n\nThe officer, Cmdr. Paul R. Bauer, 53, was chasing a man near a state government building across the street from City Hall in the early afternoon when he was shot. Within minutes, major streets in the Loop were blocked with police tape and filled with squad cars and sirens.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a difficult day for us, but we will get through it,\u201d said Superintendent Eddie Johnson of the Chicago police, who was visibly emotional as he addressed reporters outside a hospital.\n\nCommander Bauer was the fifth American police officer shot dead since last Wednesday, and the 12th killed by gunfire so far this year, according to the Officer Down Memorial Page, which tracks incidents. In all of 2017, that organization recorded 46 officers fatally shot, a rate of about one every eight days.\n\nPhoto\n\nPolice officers have been killed recently while responding to a 911 call in Ohio, serving a warrant in Georgia and confronting a shooting suspect in Texas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThree police officers were shot and wounded in Detroit overnight Sunday, and on Tuesday, another Detroit police officer died in an on-duty crash.", "title": "Chicago Police Commander Killed on Busy Downtown Block", "authors": ["Mitch Smith"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "The Abraaj Group, one of the largest private equity firms specializing in emerging markets, said on Friday that its founder, Arif Naqvi, would no longer oversee the firm\u2019s asset management business.\n\nThe abrupt move follows claims made by clients that the Dubai-based firm, which manages $14 billion in assets, misused investor money in a fund that invests in hospitals and other health care businesses. Abraaj said on Friday that it would temporarily halt investment activities until it completed a broad corporate restructuring.\n\nThe World Bank and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation were among the prominent investors that, over the past year, have been questioning the firm\u2019s governance practices.\n\nThe investors\u2019 main fear was that Abraaj might have used cash allocated for investments in hospitals in Pakistan and Kenya for other, unauthorized purposes. The memo does not do that.\n\nBut Mr. Kelly\u2019s pledge of action comes after bipartisan pressure from lawmakers on Capitol Hill, who have in recent days demanded that the White House account for Mr. Porter\u2019s case and the broader issue of people without permanent security clearances working at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.\n\n\u201cThe committee is investigating the policies and processes by which interim security clearances are investigated and adjudicated within the executive branch,\u201d Representative Trey Gowdy, Republican of South Carolina and the chairman of the House Oversight Committee, wrote this week.\n\nMr. Kelly said that he was putting into effect changes that would address a failure of communication between the F.B.I. and senior officials in the West Wing \u2014 exactly the kind of failure that White House officials have said was responsible in Mr. Porter\u2019s case.\n\nAmong the most significant changes, Mr. Kelly ordered that F.B.I. officials would now directly report to the White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, any concerns that they uncovered during the background investigations of the president\u2019s top aides.", "title": "Chief of Staff Orders an Overhaul for Security Clearances", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cOn Family Farms, Little Hands Steer Big Machines\u201d (news article, Jan. 29), about the plight of children working in agriculture and the serious injuries they suffer driving heavy equipment, was heart-rending.\n\nImagine the equivalent behavior of grade-school children driving trucks on the open road among the rest of us. It would be intolerable. Safety standards barring children from engaging in hazardous activities on the farm are 40 years old.\n\nAn effort by the Obama administration to update them was snuffed out by House conservatives, who never saw a regulation they liked. The proposal would have restricted the operation of heavy equipment, protected migrant teenagers from picking tobacco unprotected, and prohibited the practice of sending youngsters into silos to break up clumps of grain with their feet, risking suffocation if they slip.\n\nWe are back to the vicious cycle of a laissez-faire market and human suffering on a grand scale. But this time, rebuilding government safety rules will be a long and unnecessary slog.", "title": "Opinion | Child Farm Workers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Most studies of the pay gap analyze equal pay for equal work. But in this paper, researchers examined how women changed their work in response to having children, and how that affected their lifelong pay. Mothers were paid less partly because they worked fewer hours, took longer breaks from employment and were more likely to move into lower-paying, family-friendly jobs, the paper found. Their probability of becoming a manager also declined.\n\n\u201cEqual work is in practice not an option for most women, because they have to take care of the children and therefore have different kinds of jobs and different kinds of hours,\u201d said Henrik Kleven, an economist at Princeton, who wrote the paper with Jakob Egholt Sogaard, an economist at the University of Copenhagen, and Camille Landais, an economist at the London School of Economics.\n\nAs in the United States, the pay gap in Denmark has shrunk over time as women have become better educated than men and more likely to be professionals or managers. Children, which accounted for 40 percent of the pay gap in 1980, now account for 80 percent of it. Discrimination and other factors play a role in the remaining gap, researchers say.\n\nThe same pattern is true elsewhere. In the United States, a study by Census Bureau researchers found that between two years before the birth of a couple\u2019s first child and a year after, the earnings gap between opposite-sex spouses doubles. The gap continues to grow for the next five years.\n\nTwo studies of college-educated women in the United States found that they made almost as much as men until ages 26 to 33, when many women have children. By age 45, they made 55 percent as much as men.\n\nIn Sweden, a recent study found, female executives are half as likely as men to be chief executives, and one-third less likely to be high earners \u2014 even when they were more qualifie d for these jobs than men. Most of the difference was explained by women who were working shorter hours and taking time off work in the five years after their first child was born.\n\nAs any parent knows, children come with a host of time-consuming responsibilities. Someone has to do the work. In most opposite-sex couples, that someone is the mother.", "title": "Children Hurt Women\u2019s Earnings, but Not Men\u2019s (Even in Scandinavia)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Then, after the #MeToo movement caught fire, the writer Ishta Mercurio-Wentworth told Ms. Oliver of an incident that occurred six years earlier, when Mr. Diaz had touched her hair, said, \u201cYou\u2019re kinky, aren\u2019t you,\u201d and then walked away. Mr. Diaz then sent her an apology.\n\n\u201cI do think his response was the appropriate response, and I appreciated that,\u201d Ms. Mercurio-Wentworth said, citing \u201chis honesty and humility.\u201d\n\nNonetheless, Mr. Diaz said he had felt pressured to resign from the board of the books society.\n\nSome of the complaints made public dealt with what women called \u201ccreepy\u201d comments, remarks about their bodies and persistent sexual advances in a work setting or at work-related events.\n\nMartha Brockenbrough, an author, said such behavior made it more difficult for women to succeed.\n\n\u201cThink about all of the books that haven\u2019t been created by the women who have been driven away, or silenced, or just reduced in spirit,\u201d she said. \u201cIt takes a lot of courage, focus and discipline to write a book, so when you\u2019re feeling uncomfortable, it\u2019s harder to create.\u201d\n\nThe books society released a statement Wednesday, saying it \u201cregrets that any of our members has experienced harassment or intimidation during any of our events or programs\u201d and announcing updates to its anti-harassment policy. Its amended version spells out a code of conduct and reporting mechanisms.\n\nGarren Hochstetler, the director of Valley Public Library in Valley, Neb., said he planned to buy more books from the authors speaking out about sexual misconduct, starting with an order next week.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s nothing big, but we\u2019re just trying to do a little something where we can,\u201d he said.\n\nWomen dominate the publishing industry. But its roughly 80 percent female work force has not protected members \u2014 or those who aspire to join their ranks \u2014 from lewd comments, unwanted and aggressive sexual advances, and groping.", "title": "Children\u2019s Book Industry Has Its #MeToo Moment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Sandra Neil Wallace\u2019s BETWEEN THE LINES: How Ernie Barnes Went From the Football Field to the Art Gallery (Simon & Schuster/Paula Wiseman, $17.99; ages 4 to 8), illustrated by Bryan Collier, is a beautiful testament to a quintessentially American life. Wallace and Collier celebrate both Barnes\u2019s success on the gridiron and his subsequent reinvention as an artist. As in \u201cThe United States v. Jackie Robinson,\u201d athleticism is a secondary concern; early on, we see the young Barnes in a museum, wondering where the black painters are, and the story ends with contemporary young museumgoers being shown Barnes\u2019s art. This choice makes the story so satisfying, and just what you want at bedtime.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn LET THE CHILDREN MARCH (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Books for Young Readers, $17.99; ages 6 to 9) Monica Clark-Robinson tells one girl\u2019s story of the 1963 children\u2019s march on Birmingham. Frank Morrison\u2019s illustrations are loose and modern in spirit, enlivening the history lesson. It\u2019s understandable to want to channel Martin Luther King Jr.\u2019s oratorical gifts when writing about him, but sometimes the metaphors strain. Still, the book\u2019s message is clear and bracing: King understood that it\u2019s children who will lead the way, and the man\u2019s faith in the future is reassuring even now.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTwo biographical compendiums, Vashti Harrison\u2019s LITTLE LEADERS: Bold Women in Black History (Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, $16.99; ages 8 to 12) and Jamia Wilson and Andrea Pippins\u2019s YOUNG, GIFTED AND BLACK (Wide Eyed Editions/Quarto, $22.99; ages 7 to 10) are, by contrast, not bedtime reading but texts that belong in any home library, to be revisited again and again.\n\nWilson\u2019s book celebrates a variety of black achievement; there are biographical sketches of Kofi Annan and Stevie Wonder, Solange Knowles and Naomi Campbell, accompanied by Andrea Pippins\u2019s illustrations, full of verve but also quite dignified. The candy-colored pages and straightforward stories are hard to resist, and will doubtless forever shape the way many readers think about Wangari Maathai and Langston Hughes.\n\nHarrison\u2019s book focuses on great black women, and it\u2019s lovely to see Lorna Simpson and Gwen Ifill ascend to the ranks of Marian Anderson and Bessie Coleman. Harrison wants readers to imagine themselves in such august company; her adorable illustrations depict all of these figures as a little black girl, an everygirl, in a variety of costumes and backdrops. Harrison and Wilson have similar projects. But which book is better? I\u2019d like to point out that my sons own around 40 volumes on the subject of trucks. Young readers deserve both these books.\n\nFor Older Readers\n\nPhoto\n\nThe person most qualified to tell the tale of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is the man himself, as gifted an intellect as he is an athlete. Written with Raymond Obstfeld, his autobiography, BECOMING KAREEM: Growing Up On and Off the Court (Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, $17.99; ages 10 and up) is aimed at middle grade readers but could and should be read aloud to younger kids. It\u2019s a tale by a wise elder \u2014 about basketball, sure, but also about cultural, political, social and religious awakenings, big stuff narrated in a very accessible way.\n\nMARTIN RISING: Requiem for a King (Scholastic, $19.99; ages 9 to 12) is a collaboration by two of children\u2019s literature\u2019s most well-known names, Andrea Davis Pinkney and Brian Pinkney (who happen to be married). It\u2019s a work of verse, with some prose end matter to help elucidate the poems, and it will reward a reader sophisticated enough to grapple with language and metaphor. Andrea Davis Pinkney frames her poem cycle about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.\u2019s last months with the figure of Henny Penny, the bird who either worried or prophesied, and she makes King\u2019s death feel as significant as the falling of the sky above. It is, of course, a terrible and sad story, but one in which Brian Pinkney\u2019s illustrations manage to find beauty.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKing is an evergreen subject, so significant and complex that the story of his life and death can withstand repeated tellings. James L. Swanson\u2019s CHASING KING\u2019S KILLER: The Hunt for Martin Luther King, Jr.\u2019s Assassin (Scholastic, $19.99; ages 12 and up) is a departure, less classroom text than airport thriller. It\u2019s a bit like sneaking kale into brownies: Swanson offers plenty of context on King\u2019s activism and his turbulent times, but frames the book as a manhunt for James Earl Ray. This approach makes education feel more like entertainment, and will prove seductive to even a reluctant older reader.\n\nMy children are too young, yet, for Swanson\u2019s thriller and the Pinkneys\u2019 elegiac tribute, or maybe I simply want to believe that they are. They have a lifetime of reading ahead, particularly if they are to meet Dr. King\u2019s expectations for them. For now, my boys can suspend disbelief and accept that Pippi Longstocking can lift a horse and plays with pistols. But they won\u2019t be able to believe what happened to Dr. King in Memphis. Who among us can?", "title": "Children\u2019s Books About Black History, Heavy on Biographies", "authors": ["Rumaan Alam", "Children S Books"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "The result was a visually abstract, sonically sophisticated adaptation of \u201cLittle Red Riding Hood,\u201d and Agathe wasn\u2019t the only one to like it. Since its creation in 2004, it has toured the world and confirmed Mr. Pommerat as one of the most innovative figures in contemporary French theater.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis is actually a return engagement for \u201cLittle Red Riding Hood.\u201d Tellingly, it first surfaced in New York in 2007 as part of the experimental Crossing the Line Festival \u2014 which attracts hip adult audiences.\n\n\u201cFor me it was a revolution to have someone of Jo\u00ebl\u2019s caliber create a piece for a young audience and families,\u201d said Lili Chopra, a curator of both festivals. \u201cThe French cultural landscape has changed since then, and some of the most interesting contemporary writers, directors and choreographers now create works for young audiences.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Chopra is confident that even though \u201cLittle Red Riding Hood\u201d is being presented in French with supertitles, it should compel little ones. \u201cThe staging is so powerful that the sound and lighting help you enter the play\u2019s universe,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd, of course, the story is very well known.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSince creating his troupe, Compagnie Louis Brouillard, in 1990, Mr. Pommerat has built a reputation for refined production values, which is reflected in his kids\u2019 shows. His brilliant adaptations of \u201cPinocchio\u201d (2008) and \u201cCinderella\u201d (2011) also tour regularly.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t modify my stage language at all,\u201d he said of his approach to the productions for young audiences. \u201cI worked with the same elements, the same vocabulary I use in my shows for adults. I had the same desire to accomplish something spectacular, despite the economy of means.\u201d It never occurred to Mr. Pommerat and regular collaborators like Eric Soyer, the set and lighting designer, and Gr\u00e9goire and Fran\u00e7ois Leymarie, the sound designers, to cut corners because the theatergoers\u2019 ages would be in the single digits. \u201cWe wanted to be just as demanding for kids as for adults,\u201d he said.\n\nAs for the content, Mr. Pommerat figured that there was a reason that all these stories have endured for centuries.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201c\u2018Little Red Riding Hood\u2019 and \u2018Cinderella\u2019 used to be the equivalent of films or theater,\u201d he explained. \u201cPeople gathered to tell stories, so they were meant for everybody, not just children. That\u2019s why these stories appeal to adults today \u2014 they were meant for them. What happened, I think, is that they have been adapted for children. Walt Disney totally went in that direction, with all that implies in terms of simplification and sweetening. So we\u2019ve come to think of those stories as too simple, lacking in powerful, authentic emotions.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Pommerat made \u201cLittle Red Riding Hood\u201d accessible, so the younger set could follow it, he did not try to prettify the picture. \u201cThere are scary bits,\u201d he said. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to traumatize kids, of course, but I also didn\u2019t want to water down the emotions. I wanted to take the situations at face value: the encounter with animal ferocity, with danger, with fear, with monstrous things \u2014 two people get eaten after all, that\u2019s quite violent! But that violence is symbolic. That\u2019s the virtue of art, of theater: You can experience particular emotions while being protected by the fiction of performance. You come to the theater to see something that\u2019s simultaneously fake and a description of reality.\u201d\n\nChallenging notions of what constitutes children\u2019s fare is key to Tilt, which runs through March 18. The multidisciplinary slate also includes a special matinee of \u201cGala,\u201d a new show by the renowned choreographer J\u00e9r\u00f4me Bel at the N.Y.U. Skirball Center; a lettering workshop building on the Arabic and Latin alphabets at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum; philosophical discussions led by Simon Critchley, the author of such decidedly non-young-adult classics as \u201cThe Problem With Levinas,\u201d at the Brooklyn Public Library; and a concert/jam by the jazz drummer Billy Martin at Issue Project Room.\n\n\u201cThis is the first time Issue Project Room is holding a show for kids,\u201d Ms. Chopra said, \u201cand it was just great to have preparatory conversations there. We maintain the same artistic requirements but we open up to an audience that may not otherwise have gone to Issue Project Room. I fully believe that when you put artists who are pigeonholed as niche, difficult, elitist in a new context, you can see that the labeling is not true. It\u2019s proof that this work can reach a wide audience that might have thought it wasn\u2019t for them.\u201d", "title": "Children\u2019s Fare? This \u2018Little Red Riding Hood\u2019 Tests That Notion", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA BEAUTIFUL YOUNG WOMAN\n\nBy Juli\u00e1n L\u00f3pez\n\nTranslated by Samuel Rutter\n\n147 pp. Melville House. Paper, $15.99.\n\nJuli\u00e1n L\u00f3pez\u2019s debut novel, \u201cA Beautiful Young Woman\u201d (translated from the Spanish by Samuel Rutter), begins as a rapturous portrait of a young woman in 1970s Argentina as seen through the eyes of her son, remembering back to when he was 7. His evocation of her is poetic, but ringed by menace: A military dictatorship rules the country, the school day is disrupted by bomb threats, and the mysterious phone calls she keeps taking in a neighbor\u2019s apartment suggest her involvement in a resistance movement. Given the violent ends met by so many who opposed the junta, the sense of dread surrounding mother and son grows with each chapter.\n\nL\u00f3pez\u2019s book can be seen as a kind of counterpart to Patricio Pron\u2019s 2011 novel, \u201cMy Fathers\u2019 Ghost Is Climbing in the Rain,\u201d in which a son uncovers his father\u2019s role in a leftist group during the same dark period in Argentina\u2019s history. But where Pron is forensic in his approach, L\u00f3pez is sensual. The narrator\u2019s descriptions of his mother are longing, even erotic at times, and the most moving passages describe his small, often futile attempts at intimacy, like taking a breath after she walks by \u201cas a way of embracing her.\u201d\n\nWhile L\u00f3pez\u2019s narrator is effusive about his mother (the phrase \u201cmy mother was a beautiful young woman\u201d recurs as a songlike refrain), the book leaves much unanswered. The political situation is only obliquely described, and we never discover precisely what role this young woman was performing, or what happened to her. If this is frustrating, then it is appropriately so: a fitting enactment of the ghostly silence into which so many of the desaparecidos \u2014 the disappeared \u2014 fell. As readers we must share the mysteries that still haunt the narrator, a disillusioned adult, in the book\u2019s final pages. More problematically, his fascination with his mother is not always conveyed with the urgency presumably intended: This is a short book, but it could be shorter still.\n\nIt is difficult to judge the book\u2019s quality, however, when there are such significant problems with its translation. In many cases the Spanish has been translated literally, without any restructuring, which leads to awkward phrasings like \u201che moved forward in complete slowness\u201d rather than (say) \u201che crept toward me.\u201d Elsewhere the meaning is more seriously compromised, and sometimes lost entirely. For example, a boy\u2019s face becomes \u201cmore and more concentrated,\u201d when the intention seems to be that his concentration becomes more pronounced. Similarly, L\u00f3pez nicely evokes the narrator staring at his sleeping mother\u2019s face, drawing so close that her features distort \u2014 and disturb him \u2014 like a Picasso portrait; the translation, which renders this as \u201cshe was so close that she was as unsettling as a Picasso,\u201d loses much of its impact. At one point temeroso is confused with temeridad, so we read \u201cbrazen uncertainty\u201d when L\u00f3pez probably intends \u201cfearful uncertainty\u201d; at another the adjective acerado (\u201csteely\u201d) is mistaken for encerado (\u201cwaxed\u201d), leaving us puzzling at the waxy smells of airports; and so on.\n\nThe closing section of the book describes the narrator\u2019s adult life with three women he loves in different ways, each of them an inadequate surrogate for the one he loves most of all, \u201ca beautiful young woman lost forever in horror.\u201d There are some memorable scenes, in particular two lovers sharing a last, silent breakfast as dawn breaks, and the surreal image of a concrete staircase ending in a cliff\u2019s edge: an arresting visual metaphor for the lives cut short by the Dirty War. But doubts about the translation continue to distract, as does uncertainty about how much better a writer L\u00f3pez might be than the one presented here.", "title": "Child\u2019s Eye View of the Dirty War", "authors": ["Chris Power", "Juli\u00e1n L\u00f3pez"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWaging a Sweeping War on Obesity, Chile Slays Tony the Tiger\u201d (\u201cPlanet Fat\u201d series, front page, Feb. 8):\n\nFar from being criticized by a Chilean food industry association for creating confusion, Chile should be applauded for its radical approach. Obesity may not be spread by bacteria, but it is communicated in a social sense, not least through the commercial promotion of unhealthy food and by misleading language that diverts attention from the underlying toxicity of these products.\n\nIt is an uncannily similar response to the perverse yet predictable reaction from tobacco companies when advertising was curtailed. This fall, the United Nations will include a focus on tackling chronic diseases like diabetes and cancer as well as obesity among children and adults.\n\nChile\u2019s example can help reverse the sad fact that not a single country has successfully brought down obesity rates in the last three decades.\n\nJOHANNA RALSTON, LONDON\n\nThe writer is chief executive of the World Obesity Federation.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nKudos to the Chilean government for taking the lead in fighting obesity. This worldwide epidemic cries out for leadership to fight the food industry.", "title": "Opinion | Chile\u2019s \u2018Radical\u2019 Approach to Addressing Obesity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "In late 2015, when China eased its decades-long policy limiting most couples to having only one child, some heralded the change as a move toward greater reproductive freedom. But the government was only embarking on another grand experiment in population engineering: This time it was urging women \u2014 though only the right sort \u2014 to reproduce for China.\n\nThe authorities in Beijing seemed terrified that plummeting birthrates, an aging population and a shrinking labor force might undermine the results of years of double-digit growth rates, and threaten the political legitimacy of the ruling Chinese Communist Party (C.C.P.). So they began allowing most married couples to have two children. They hoped that the new policy would bring three million additional births a year through 2020 and add more than 30 million workers to the labor force by 2050.\n\nBut there has been no baby boom. Figures released last month show that the country\u2019s birthrate fell by 3.5 percent in 2017 compared with the previous year. (The number of births had increased in 2016, the first year since the policy shift, though far less than the government had hoped.) According to official statistics, the number of children born to parents who already had one child did rise in 2017, but the number of first-child births dropped.\n\nWhy? Because a critical mass of women appears to be in no rush to have babies, particularly urban, educated women \u2014 just the category that the C.C.P. is counting on to produce and raise a new generation of skilled, knowledge-based workers.", "title": "Opinion | China Dropped Its One-Child Policy. So Why Aren\u2019t Chinese Women Having More Babies?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "The Constitution now limits Mr. Xi, who became president in 2013, to two terms in that office, amounting to 10 years. But the party leadership has proposed removing the line that says the president and vice president \u201cshall serve no more than two consecutive terms,\u201d Xinhua, the official news agency, reported on Sunday.\n\nBy moving so early in his tenure, Mr. Xi, 64, is in effect proclaiming that he intends to stay in office well past 2023, overturning rules of succession in Chinese politics that evolved as the party sought stability following the power struggles to replace first Mao, and then Deng Xiaoping.\n\n\u201cXi Jinping will certainly continue,\u201d said Zhang Ming, a retired historian at Renmin University in Beijing. \u201cIn China, he can do what he wants to do, and this is just sending a clearer signal of that.\u201d\n\nMr. Xi already serves as the party\u2019s general secretary and the military chief, positions with no term limits.\n\n\u201cThis is the next step in the continuing breakdown of political norms that had held sway in China\u2019s reform era,\u201d said Carl Minzner, a professor of law at Fordham University in New York and author of a new book on Mr. Xi\u2019s increasing authoritarianism.\n\n\u201cWhat are the risks of these shifts?\u201d Professor Minzner said. \u201cIn the short term, all the traditional dangers that arise from the excessive centralization of power in the hands of one person. But in the long term, the real question is how far the breakdown in political norms could go.\u201d\n\nJiang Zemin, the leader who succeeded Deng, was installed during the Tiananmen protests of 1989 and served two terms as president from 1993 to 2003. But he lingered in power until 2004 by retaining control of the committee that runs China\u2019s military.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis successor, Hu Jintao, stepped down from all his positions after his two terms \u2014 an example that some experts had expected Mr. Xi to follow.\n\nBut as Mr. Xi\u2019s first term comes to an end, few in China see much likelihood of his power being subdued anytime soon by rivals in the leadership elite.\n\n\u201cXi is now unfettered. He owns the entire policy process,\u201d Susan Shirk, the head of the 21st Century China Center at the University of California, San Diego, wrote in a forthcoming paper about politics under Mr. Xi. \u201cAnd Chinese domestic and foreign policy is only as restrained or aggressive as he wants it to be. The risk of policy misjudgments is greater than it has been under any other leader since Mao died.\u201d\n\nDuring his first term, Mr. Xi pressed an aggressive campaign against corruption and dissent, a crackdown that has silenced potential rivals in the leadership. At the same time, many party elders, who once held intimidating influence, have died or are too old for political intrigue. Mr. Jiang is 91, and Mr. Hu, 75, has shown no appetite for taking on Mr. Xi.\n\nOn the Chinese internet, some people eluded the party\u2019s censors and mocked Mr. Xi\u2019s ambitions by sharing images like that of Winnie the Pooh \u2014 portly like Mr. Xi, and used by critics to represent him \u2014 hugging a huge jar of honey.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut many people in China have applauded his campaign against official corruption. And harsh security measures make mass protests against a central leader nearly impossible. So any major public backlash against Mr. Xi\u2019s move appears unlikely.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t see any reasonable challenges for him,\u201d Wu Qiang, a political analyst in Beijing who formerly taught at Tsinghua University, said of Mr. Xi. \u201cHe has removed any potential political competitors. So far, there is no organized political competition for him.\u201d\n\nThe proposed constitutional changes were released in the name of the Central Committee, a council of hundreds of senior party officials, who will meet starting on Monday for three days.\n\nMr. Xi had already built expectations that he would stay in office past two terms, and some analysts said he must have decided to move while at peak political strength. Usually, authority begins to ebb from Chinese leaders as retirement nears.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI can see where his thinking is that he\u2019s riding high, he\u2019s got the momentum, and took the initiative to ram this through,\u201d said Jude Blanchette, an expert on Chinese politics in Beijing who works for the Conference Board, which provides research for companies. \u201cWhy risk diminished power three years from now if the economy tanks or there\u2019s a conflagration with North Korea, and not have the ability to do it?\u201d\n\nIn another victory for Mr. Xi, the draft amendments to the Constitution would add his trademark expression for his main ideas \u2014 \u201cXi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era\u201d \u2014 into the preamble of the Constitution, as well as adding a nod to the ideological contributions of his predecessor, Mr. Hu.\n\nThe proposed amendments would also authorize a new anticorruption commission that Mr. Xi has pushed. The commission would expand the reach of corruption investigations, which up to now have mostly been conducted by a Communist Party agency acting largely beyond the law.\n\nThe amendments are almost certain to be passed into law by the party-controlled legislature, the National People\u2019s Congress, which holds its annual full session starting on March 5. The congress has never voted down a proposal from party leaders.\n\nIn what would be another break with tradition, Wang Qishan, a close ally of Mr. Xi in his campaign against corruption and disloyalty in the party, appears set to return to power as vice president. Mr. Wang, 69, stepped down from a party position last year because of his age.\n\nThe abolition of the term limit may also explain another recent move by Mr. Xi to send one of his closest advisers, Liu He, to Washington on Tuesday. While that trip had initially looked like an attempt to discuss the Trump administration\u2019s tougher rhetoric on trade, it now seems likely to also be a mission to explain Mr. Xi\u2019s plans to American leaders.\n\nAt the Communist Party national congress in October, Mr. Xi conspicuously broke with precedent by choosing not to name a pair of much younger officials to the Politburo\u2019s ruling inner circle, the seven-member standing committee, to serve as his potential heirs. Instead, Mr. Xi chose men \u2014 no women \u2014 who were closer to his own age or older.\n\nMr. Xi\u2019s strongman style has been compared to that of the Russian president. But even Mr. Putin did not try to erase his country\u2019s constitutional limit on serving more than two consecutive terms as president when he approached that limit in 2008.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInstead, he arranged for a close adviser, Dmitri A. Medvedev, to serve as president for a single term while Mr. Putin held the post of prime minister. Mr. Putin then returned to the presidency in 2012, and is running this year for re-election.\n\nWith Mr. Xi\u2019s hold on power now seems unquestioned for the foreseeable future, the biggest question will be how he chooses to wield it.\n\n\u201cXi Jinping is susceptible to making big mistakes because there are now almost no checks or balances,\u201d said Willy Lam, an adjunct professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong who is the author of a 2015 biography of Mr. Xi. \u201cEssentially, he has become emperor for life.\u201d", "title": "China Moves to Let Xi Stay in Power by Abolishing Term Limit", "authors": ["Chris Buckley", "Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Not long ago, America and its democratic allies hoped to integrate a rising China into the political and economic system they built after the Cold War. Instead, China is creating its own institutions, or reshaping existing institutions and norms, to suit its own needs.\n\nLeaders in many of these countries are watching warily as China encourages the notion that the Chinese model of central economic and political direction could eventually supplant Western democracy and its capitalist system. The Pentagon is so concerned that it named China, along with Russia, America\u2019s top security threats for seeking to \u201cshape a world consistent with their authoritarian model \u2014 gaining veto authority over other nations\u2019 economic, diplomatic and security decisions.\u201d\n\nIt makes perfect sense that the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, wants to see his country play a greater international role. China enjoys a growing economy, substantial military strength and very stable leadership. But that does not give it license to unilaterally reorder the Indo-Pacific region to its advantage, as the Pentagon asserted. A focused and forward-looking American president would work to counter such moves. President Trump, blinded by Mr. Xi\u2019s flattery and blind to history, does nothing except cede more power to Beijing.\n\nMr. Xi, a powerful authoritarian leader, has the advantage of seeming to know where he is leading his country. It is also used to make baijiu, a clear liquor with a pungent aroma that sells well among the rich in China and is often served at banquets. More than three-quarters of the sorghum the United States exports goes to China, according to the U.S. Grains Council, a grain export industry group.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe United States exported about 4.8 million tons of sorghum, worth about $1 billion, to China in 2017, accounting for nearly all of China\u2019s imports of the grain last year, according to Chinese customs data.\n\nRetaliating against the agricultural sector is not a surprise. A United States business lobby group warned last week that Chinese officials had threatened to retaliate against American companies if the Trump administration imposed tariffs, saying that agricultural and aircraft imports may be the most at risk.\n\nMr. Bown said that some farmers would suffer but that the broader United States economy would not be substantially harmed if tariffs were to be imposed only on the sorghum industry. The worry is that, as trade frictions escalate, tariffs could spread to more economically important sectors, such as soybeans, he said.\n\nSoybean exporters are a powerful political constituency for Mr. Trump. China imported $14 billion worth of soybeans from the United States in 2016, according to data from the United States Department of Agriculture.\n\nChina, which in recent years has been increasingly assertive about protecting its economic interests, has not been afraid to use tariffs as a tool against the United States. In 2010, it said it would impose tariffs on American poultry after its own anti-dumping investigation. China opened the investigation in 2009, less than two days after former President Barack Obama imposed steep tariffs on Chinese tires.\n\nDespite Sunday\u2019s announcement, Mr. Li, of Shanghai JC Intelligence Company, said that he believes the Chinese government \u201cis still exercising restraint.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cChina still believes there\u2019s room for negotiation,\u201d he said, \u201cand hopes that the United States will return to the negotiating table.\u201d", "title": "China\u2019s Trade Investigation Takes Aim at Trump\u2019s Voter Base", "authors": ["Sui-Lee Wee"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "The Daimler stake was purchased by an investment company headed by Mr. Li called Tenaclou3 Prospect Investment, according to the Daimler filing.\n\nGeely could not be reached for comment.\n\nMr. Li is from Zhejiang, a coastal province south of Shanghai. He got his start in business in refrigerator manufacturing in 1986, and moved into motorcycles and then automobiles in the 1990s, according to biography on Volvo\u2019s website. He is now regarded as one of the wealthiest people in China. Bloomberg estimates his net worth at $13.8 billion.\n\nMr. Li has been working to acquire an array of global automotive holdings and turn Geely Auto into the dominant player in China.\n\nReports of his interest in purchasing a Daimler stake have been appearing in the German media for weeks. This month, he appeared by video at an automotive conference in Germany, but did not discuss the matter. \u201cBuilding up brands in the European market has been the goal from the start,\u201d he said, according to a translation of his remarks.\n\nLast year, Geely Holding bought a 51 percent stake in Lotus, the British sports car maker. Daimler is working on both electric cars and battery-powered trucks.\n\nVolvo announced last year that all of its models would be hybrids or electric cars by 2019.\n\nBritain and France have said they hope to halt sales of gasoline-powered cars by 2040. China says it would like to do the same, but has not given a target date.\n\nChinese automakers have long signaled ambitions to expand outside their home country. Boudette"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "In its prime, Chipotle Mexican Grill positioned itself as the paragon of cool casual dining, a darling of Wall Street, a restaurant industry innovator.\n\nBasically, nothing like Taco Bell.\n\nHow the tables have turned. Chipotle has spent the past few years struggling to recover from a string of food safety crises, abandonment by its customers and a plunging stock price. For help, the chain is turning to the quick-serve cousin that many once thought was inferior.\n\nBrian Niccol, the chief executive of Taco Bell, will replace Chipotle\u2019s founder, Steve Ells, as chief executive on March 5, Chipotle said on Tuesday. Mr. Niccol is tasked with replicating his success transforming Taco Bell from a fast food afterthought to a social media-savvy company with sleek new stores and the hugely popular Doritos Locos Tacos.\n\n\u201cHis expertise in digital technologies, restaurant operations and branding make him a perfect fit for Chipotle as we seek to enhance our customer experience, drive sales growth and make our brand more relevant,\u201d Mr. Ells said in a statement.", "title": "Chipotle Takes a Page, and a C.E.O., From Taco Bell", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. McCray said the idea for the initiative came after she hosted two baby showers on Rikers Island as part of an effort to support pregnant mothers around the city. She said the events on Rikers were different in that the interactions between the women and their children were not as warm. Some children visiting their parents looked withdrawn.\n\n\u201cAs a mother it felt so wrong. I cried the last time I went,\u201d said Ms. McCray who has two children. \u201cI said, \u2018We have to do something.\u2019 \u201d\n\nJennifer Majoy, a former Rikers inmate, recalled how the 21 days she spent at the Rose M. Singer Center at Rikers last year would have been more tolerable had her parents and daughter been able to visit.\n\nBut Ms. Majoy, now 34, told her parents not to bother bringing her daughter after a friend waited an hour before being turned away while trying to bring underwear, pajamas and slippers.\n\n\u201cWhen you are in that situation you need to have family support,\u201d said Ms. Majoy, who was charged with drug sale and possession, and is now on probation and working as an intern at a re-entry program for women. \u201cBut I did not want my 9-year-old to go through that.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe effort will build off the ThriveNYC mental health program that Ms. McCray oversees, by increasing the number of counselors for women with a domestic violence history, and creating counseling programs that focus on addressing anxiety and depression. An intensive treatment model will be used in the women\u2019s infirmary to deal with mental health issues.\n\nWomen at Rikers will also receive more career mentoring and support as they move into outside employment; receive in-home therapy; help with family court proceedings; and get a help desk to coordinate the services needed to transition from jail.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. McCray said the initiative was focused on the specific needs and issues of women in jail.\n\nAbout 630 women are detained daily on Rikers Island, many for nonviolent offenses. A survey by the Mayor\u2019s Office of Criminal Justice and the Department of Correction found that 80 percent of the women have children in their home, while 50 percent took care of young relatives who are not their children.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn June, Mr. de Blasio released a plan to close Rikers in 10 years in favor of borough-based jails. Advocates have pushed for closing the troubled jail sooner than that, citing the violence and the difficulty of visiting inmates. Criminal justice reformers have also argued that women and juveniles should not be held on Rikers Island.\n\nMs. McCray said the hope was that the women\u2019s initiative would help reduce the number of women on Rikers while creating a model that could be used when the borough jails opened.\n\n\u201cWhen we have jails in the boroughs we don\u2019t want to go back to the old model of how we care for people,\u201d she said.\n\nJonathan Lippman, the former chief judge of the State of New York who led the independent commission that recommended closing Rikers, praised the initiative but said the city needed to keep its eye on the end goal.\n\n\u201cThis accelerator of human misery has to be closed,\u201d Judge Lippman said. \u201cBut until it happens, you have to take every step possible to make it a more humane place.\u201d\n\nClaude Millery, who served 25 years for murder and robbery before being released last year, now works as an office assistant at Hour Children, which helps formerly incarcerated women reconnect with their children and families.\n\nIn spite of recently obtaining her bachelor\u2019s degree in sociology, Ms. Miller discovered that finding a job was difficult.\n\n\u201cThis job makes me feel like I\u2019m a part of society again,\u201d said Ms. Millery, who wants to become an office manager. \u201cI made bad choices. I paid for the choices I made, but now I can come to work every day and make a difference in people\u2019s lives.\u201d", "title": "Chirlane McCray to Lead Effort to Help Female Inmates at Rikers", "authors": ["Jeffery C. Mays"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Chloe Celine Wynne and George Briggs Reed III were married Feb. 3 at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Canon Carl F. Turner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.\n\nThe bride, 32, is a senior associate at UBS Wealth Management in New York. She is also the founder of Thepicurist, a food and travel blog. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania.\n\nShe is the daughter of Sophie G. Wynne and Thomas W. Wynne of Westerly, R.I. Her mother is an interior designer in Westerly. Her father, who is retired, was a senior vice president of Morgan Stanley in Greenwich.\n\nThe groom, 41, is a community solar and energy storage project developer for Auriga Capital Management, an asset management firm in New York. He graduated from Harvard and received a law degree from the University of Virginia.", "title": "Chloe Wynne, George Reed III", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "The book\u2019s trickiest maneuver comes when Hughes attempts to synthesize his two stories by explaining how his turbulent tenure at The New Republic colored his approach to the ideal of a universal income. He still believes in a universal cash-transfer policy, it seems, but no longer has the courage of his convictions: \u201cWhat went wrong at The New Republic,\u201d he says, is \u201cthe driving reason why I favor a more modest guaranteed income\u201d instead. But he never convincingly explains why his failure at the magazine plays such an outsize role in his worldview, especially compared with his successes at Facebook and in Obama\u2019s presidential campaign.\n\nHughes\u2019s proposal \u2014 which he himself describes as a \u201cprosaic and incremental\u201d expansion of the earned-income tax credit \u2014 is emphatically not a universal basic income. For one thing, it targets only the bottom 35 percent or so of earners in the country. Worse, it doesn\u2019t even reach all of them. The Hughes plan is restricted to working Americans: people who made more than $6,000 last year, who are looking after dependents under the age of 6 or over the age of 70, or who are enrolled in an accredited college. If you earned less than $6,000, you\u2019ll receive only your previous year\u2019s earnings \u2014 and if those earnings were zero, you\u2019ll receive zero. Those who live at the very bottom of the income spectrum would have to continue to rely on America\u2019s overstretched social safety net, which, in all too many cases, pays them little or nothing.\n\nBy creating a hard ceiling at $50,000 a year, Hughes also creates a nasty marriage penalty: He\u2019s effectively telling couples where each partner earns less than $50,000 that they shouldn\u2019t get married and form a household. That\u2019s because, if they do so, thereby bringing their joint earnings above $50,000, they\u2019ll lose a combined $12,000 a year in guaranteed income.\n\nHughes quotes Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the architect of a previous attempt at a national guaranteed income, as saying that it failed because it was \u201cboth too much and too little; too radical, too reactionary; too comprehensive, not comprehensive enough.\u201d Yet his plan seems to make exactly the same mistake. Opponents of no-strings cash handouts will not be particularly mollified by the fact that this plan targets merely 42 million households rather than all 120 million households in the country. Proponents of a universal basic income, meanwhile, especially those who see it as insurance for a time when robots drive us all out of work, will be exasperated at the way the plan explicitly excludes the jobless and the neediest.\n\nHughes is attracted to boldness, and played an important part in the achievements of both Mark Zuckerberg and Barack Obama. But ultimately he\u2019s a better follower than a leader. Fired up by his new cause, he could have published a rallying cry, an inspirational manifesto. Instead, he has delivered a book with more footnotes than passion \u2014 and, for the very poorest, a proposal that seems deeply unfair.", "title": "Chris Hughes Made Millions at Facebook. I\u2019ve been using Dior Diorskin Forever Undercover Concealer.\n\nLashes, I use DiorShow Pump\u2019N\u2019Volume. They\u2019re very light and you can build. And they shave the pencils flat. The Shu Uemura brow pencil is exactly that shape already.\n\nI always have Volumizing Lip and Cheek Tint by Tata Harper. It\u2019s just a stain, but you see the color, and it looks so natural. I usually wear this when I\u2019m flying because I don\u2019t want to wear makeup.\n\nAnd because I travel so much, I\u2019m all about little compacts. I like that it\u2019s a masculine rose.\n\nHair\n\nI have really, really dry, coarse hair, so I do an intensive treatment about once a week. I love the Oribe Gold Lust pre-shampoo treatment. It\u2019s heavy, but it\u2019s great for me because I have the heaviest hair ever. I also use the shampoo from the Oribe Gold Lust line.\n\nMy hair color is by my friend Justin Anderson. He works for a company called dpHUE as an ambassador. They have really healthy color options. I actually discovered dpHUE when I posted about their apple cider vinegar wash. I go to this hole-in-the-wall down the street from my house. It\u2019s not luxurious. The lady steps on my back. I also love going to the Sweat House. I do it whenever I need a detox.\n\nDiet and Fitness\n\nI\u2019m very conscious about what I eat during the week. My husband is a foodie, and we let loose on the weekends. I don\u2019t really believe in diets because they\u2019re too constraining. I do ask myself how something will make me feel afterward. And I do start my morning with a green powder drink by Hum; it gives me energy. Then I have a kombucha. I\u2019ll also have an avocado toast or oatmeal. I go heavy in the morning. Throughout the day, I don\u2019t have that much time to eat.\n\nI\u2019m really into H.I.I.T. workouts. I don\u2019t get to work out every single day, so when I do, I want it to be high intensity. Then we go to the park.", "title": "Chriselle Lim\u2019s Beauty Secret Is Prep", "authors": ["Bee Shapiro", "Skin Deep"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Certainly, the final years of Mr. Bailey\u2019s tenure at the top were tumultuous, casting a shadow over a long and starry ascent that had begun when the affable Yorkshireman, son of a carpenter and a window-dresser for the British department store Marks & Spencer, graduated from the Royal College of Art in 1994. After a stint in New York working for Donna Karan, he moved to Milan to work for Tom Ford at Gucci, the job he had when, in 2001, he met Rose Marie Bravo, then the American chief executive of Burberry.\n\nMs. Bravo was tasked with rebooting the company after decades of poorly conceived licensing deals diluted both the creative and commercial powers of the brand founded in 1856 and best known for supplying trench coats to British army officers during World War I.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe moment I met Christopher, I knew he was the right person for Burberry \u2014 it almost felt like a divine intervention,\u201d Ms. Bravo said of Mr. Bailey, then a relative unknown.\n\nWithin weeks of that initial meeting, she hired him to replace the designer Roberto Menichetti as Burberry\u2019s creative director.\n\n\u201cBurberry had a very strong history and Christopher was so passionate about it, and that of Britain too. So I said to him: \u2018How far can you push the boundaries of what Burberry stands for? What does this brand have the power to be and say about British fashion?\u2019\u201d Ms. Bravo said.\n\nMr. Bailey\u2019s answer was threefold.\n\nFirst, he imbued every collection with references and nostalgic flourishes drawn from British culture, class, experience and weather: the signature Burberry trench reinvented in every conceivable cut and color, in prints and lace and velvet; Wellington boots and Fair Isle knits; Bloomsbury-style floral prints and \u201960s-style leather with rock \u2018n\u2019 roll flair.\n\nThen he enlisted a constellation of British stars for his ad campaigns and front rows: among them Kate Moss, Naomi Campbell, Cara Delevingne and Sienna Miller and up-and-coming male singers like James Bay and Tom Odell.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd finally, he fully embraced technology long before most rivals did to reach new luxury audiences, becoming the first British brand to live-stream and live-tweet its shows, create YouTube video ads, and even create a Burberry channel on Apple Music featuring only British musical talent, which he did in 2015.\n\nAs Burberry\u2019s creative chief, working first alongside its chief executive officers Ms. Bravo and then Angela Ahrendts, Mr. Bailey came to enjoy a run as the golden boy of British fashion.\n\n\u201cFor more than a decade there was a common phrase in the industry: \u2018doing a Burberry,\u2019\u201d said Alexandra Shulman, the former editor of British Vogue. \u201cThe idea of taking a languishing and not especially desirable brand, then turning it into a global success, became the ultimate 21st-century fashion fairy tale. Much of that was down to Christopher.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough Mr. Bailey initially moved the Burberry shows to Milan to demonstrate to the fashion world that it could \u2014 and should \u2014 compete with such global names as Gucci and Versace, in 2009 he brought them home. That was the same year the brand\u2019s many offices were consolidated into a single London headquarters, Horseferry House, the better to convey a made-in-Britain message. (The building, a glossy minimalist temple kept immaculately tidy by its staff, was designed down to the last detail by Mr. Bailey himself \u2014 including the mineral-water bottles he created for the staff cafeteria.)\n\n\u201cChristopher gave an unquantifiable boost to the identity of British fashion, making London Fashion Week a must-stop for buyers and press after years of being overlooked,\u201d said Anna Wintour, editor in chief of American Vogue. \u201cHis genius was also in creating a world around Burberry where you could be any age or stage and still want a piece of it.\u201d\n\nIn 2013, Ms. Ahrendts took a job at Apple as head of retail, and less than a year later Mr. Bailey \u2014 already in charge of an enormous portfolio that ranged from overseeing 50 collections per year to store design and marketing \u2014 was given his greatest challenge to date: becoming her replacement, and the new chief executive.\n\nSome said later that Mr. Bailey was privately reluctant to take the leap, only to be vigorously encouraged by the Burberry chairman, Sir John Peace, fearful that his star designer might be getting restless. Others have suggested that as a figure whose down-to-earth modesty and witty intellect could occasionally unfurl to reveal the hallmarks of a control freak, the prospect of becoming the first designer from a major public brand to ever adopt a dual role \u2014 with such power \u2014 had proved irresistible to Mr. Bailey.", "title": "Christopher Bailey Takes a Final Walk Down the Burberry Runway", "authors": ["Elizabeth Paton"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Oh come on, I\u2019m a bore, don\u2019t be silly.\n\nYou\u2019re now the oldest actor to have ever received an Oscar and the oldest to earn a nomination. How does it feel to be such a record breaker?\n\nOh God, this age thing, it\u2019s just getting ridiculous. I\u2019ve got to start lying about my age.\n\nBut you can\u2019t. The internet doesn\u2019t forget anything.\n\nThere\u2019s no privacy anymore, no mystery, it\u2019s terrible.\n\nIt\u2019s kind of amazing that you\u2019ve been getting all of these accolades in your 80s.\n\nI\u2019ve made over 100 motion pictures, and some of them were even good. It\u2019s nice to be reborn every few decades, because then you can have another career. The nice part about awards and being nominated is the fact that it wakes everybody up again, and makes them realize you\u2019re alive and kicking and available. The roles have got more interesting as I\u2019ve got older. In theater, where I spent most of my life, I\u2019ve played all the great classic roles in England and North America, on Broadway and in Canada. So here we go again. Now I\u2019m playing big modern classic roles. J. Paul Getty is a classic-sized figure. I recently played [Kaiser Wilhelm II in the World War II drama \u201cThe Exception\u201d]. I love playing these really old guys. Though I can\u2019t play King Lear anymore, I don\u2019t think. I\u2019ve gotten too old.\n\nAre the roles getting better, have you gotten better, or both?\n\nI\u2019ve been very lucky with my writers. Simon Burke [\u201cThe Exception\u201d] wrote an excellent part. David Scarpa [writer of \u201cAll The Money in the World\u201d] did a smashing job, and gave a rather colorless character a lot of character, which I jumped at immediately. I thought there must\u2019ve somewhere been some kind of humanity in that man, and I think we found a little bit of it.", "title": "Christopher Plummer Talks Frankly About Replacing Kevin Spacey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cA New Look at Asterisks for Artwork\u201d (front page, Jan. 29):\n\nIt is highly regrettable that museums and galleries would censor artwork created by artists based on their assessment of the artists\u2019 behavior or moral character. Adults are fully capable of deciding, as individuals, whether or not we want to see an exhibition by an artist whose morality and ethics we may abhor. The same would apply to publishers and movie theaters.\n\nI detest the anti-Semitism of T. S. Eliot, Ezra Pound, Roald Dahl, Fyodor Dostoyevsky and Louis-Ferdinand C\u00e9line, but I may choose to read them because they happen to be great writers. I don\u2019t want to forbid others to read them. I am capable of deciding whether or not to watch a Woody Allen movie.\n\n\u201cHate the sin but love the sinner\u201d could translate into \u201cHate the artist but love the artwork.\u201d Leave it up to each individual to decide. And don\u2019t worry about the revenues. Enough people will choose the artwork.\n\nMERLE MOLOFSKY\n\nSLEEPY HOLLOW, N.Y.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cChuck Close Exhibition Is Canceled\u201d (Arts pages, Jan. 27):\n\nWhile Chuck Close feels he is being \u201ccrucified,\u201d in actuality, no one is stringing him up or draping any offending sections of his artworks with a tasteful diaper. His show at the National Gallery of Art has simply been canceled. The choice to feature a particular artist is a statement on the part of an institution about that person\u2019s merit and relevance. In January, Apple announced plans to bring the vast majority of its $252 billion in cash held abroad back to the United States, paying a tax of $38 billion.\n\nIn its earnings statement, Cisco reported its first rise in quarterly revenue in more than two years and forecast that profit in the current quarter would exceed the estimate by analysts.
