Citigroup said it is had notified regulators about the mistake.\n\n\u201cWe sincerely apologize to our customers and are taking every action to provide refunds as quickly as possible,\u201d the bank spokeswoman, Elizabeth Fogarty, said in a statement.\n\nCitigroup disclosed the error in its annual report, filed Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The bank said it had discovered \u201cmethodological issues\u201d in its calculations of some customers\u2019 annual interest rates.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Fogarty said the average refund would be $190 and that 1.75 million accounts were affected.\n\nMatt Schulz, a senior industry analyst at CreditCards.com, said it was rare to see a card company reveal a mistake of such magnitude.\n\n\u201cTwo hundred dollars is a significant amount of money for an awful lot of people in this country,\u201d he said. \u201cFor this to have happened for almost two million accounts is a significant thing.\u201d", "title": "Citi to Refund $330 Million to Credit Card Customers It Overcharged", "authors": ["Emily Flitter"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe question now is whether Almagro will step up and appoint a qualified and experienced prosecutor to replace Juan Jim\u00e9nez or simply appoint a diplomat disinclined to ruffle feathers in Honduras,\u201d Eric L. Olson, a Honduras expert at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in Washington, wrote in an email. \u201cThat would be disastrous.\u201d\n\nClean government groups in Honduras responded to the news with dismay. \u201cThis is the beginning of a political offensive against the fundamental pillars that are against corruption in Honduras,\u201d said Gabriela Castellanos, the director of the National Anti-Corruption Council, a private group.\n\nTensions between Mr. Almagro and Mr. Jim\u00e9nez had been rising for months, but the last straw appeared to be a letter that Mr. Almagro sent to President Juan Orlando Hern\u00e1ndez on Wednesday. In it, he complained that the panel, known by its Spanish initials as the Maccih, \u201chad not been able to produce the results and prosecutions of corruption cases that we would have wished and which we owe to the people of Honduras.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt was an odd complaint to direct at Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez. The president\u2019s allies have worked to sabotage much of the panel\u2019s efforts, freezing proposed legislation to protect witnesses and stalling the enforcement of new campaign finance laws.\n\nBut the most direct affront came last month, after the attorney general\u2019s new corruption unit, working with the panel, charged five legislators with pocketing money intended for social projects in their constituencies. In response, the Honduran Congress passed a budget decree that froze all investigations into the money for those social projects, and a judge threw out the case against the lawmakers.\n\nFurious, Mr. Jim\u00e9nez said then that the investigation had spread to about 60 current and former lawmakers, including the powerful president of the Congress, Mauricio Oliva Herrera, a close ally of the president.\n\nThe investigation also appeared to be widening beyond Congress. Last month, investigators from the panel and the attorney general\u2019s office raided a foundation that is one of many that channel the Honduran government\u2019s social spending with little oversight. The president\u2019s mother-in-law, Carlota Car\u00edas, was a former executive director of the foundation.\n\nThe panel, whose full name is the Mission of Support Against Corruption and Impunity in Honduras, also made enemies among business leaders when it began an inquiry last year into a concession for a dam opposed by members of the Lenca Indian community.\n\nBerta C\u00e1ceres, an indigenous rights activist and an environmentalist who led the opposition, was assassinated two years ago in a case that has become emblematic of the violence in Honduras against human rights defenders, political activists, journalists and environmentalists.", "title": "Citing Hostility, Leader of Anti-Corruption Panel in Honduras Resigns", "authors": ["Elisabeth Malkin"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "How much the efforts by the city have helped is unclear; some health and addiction professionals suggest that the city is apportioning too much of its money on police efforts, and not enough on extending treatment.\n\nIndeed, the Police Department is the single biggest beneficiary of the spending: $15 million a year for 84 detectives, mostly assigned to so-called Heroin Overdose Teams.\n\nAfter an overdose, narcotics detectives begin by noting any distinguishing marks on the heroin packaging \u2014 such as a stamp on the glassine bag \u2014 and poring over the cellphone records of the overdose victim to look for the source of the drugs. \u201cUsually it\u2019s the last one, or the last couple,\u201d the chief of detectives, Robert K. Boyce, said of the phone numbers, which are fed into a growing database of \u201cthousands of numbers\u201d that turned up at overdose scenes in 2,260 overdose investigations last year.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe father of a 41-year-old Queens man who struggled with heroin addiction and died at his parents\u2019 home this month, said the officers who responded were respectful. \u201cThe police are trying to find out what\u2019s going on in the neighborhood,\u201d said the father, who asked not to be named.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re trying to slow down this crisis,\u201d Chief Boyce said. In January, there were more than 60 deaths recorded by the police, who frequently see three in a day \u2014 a steep toll, but a slower pace than two years ago.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis is one day,\u201d Chief Boyce said, reviewing a stapled briefing paper from Feb. 1 on which brief summaries of seven overdoses appeared like those of any murder. One was found in his mother\u2019s house; another came first thing after sunrise. Four were saved by emergency medical workers or police officers who administered naloxone. Three died. Each resulted in a new case.\n\nYet in public materials, City Hall has seemed to de-emphasize the role of the police: The mayor\u2019s 36-page, full-color pamphlet announcing the plan offered a 12-point strategy; its new teams of detectives were listed as Strategy 11.\n\n\u201cThe stuff that they\u2019re putting out there, it\u2019s not anything bad, but it\u2019s incomplete,\u201d said Julia DeWalt, director of community engagement at Boom!Health, a harm reduction nonprofit in the Bronx. \u201cWhy are we continuing to put most of the money to law enforcement?\u201d\n\nShe added that a Health Department report on so-called supervised injection facilities, funded by the City Council over a year ago, had yet to be released. No such facilities, where heroin users can inject themselves under supervision to prevent overdoses, exist in the United States, though Philadelphia and other cities have moved to open them.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. de Blasio has so far demurred on his position, insisting the report would be made public soon. City officials acknowledged that opening even a single such center, where illicit drugs would be legally taken, in a given neighborhood could generate significant political pushback.\n\n\u201cIf our city has record-low crime but record-high overdose deaths, can Mayor de Blasio really say that his allocation of funding is smart public policy?\u201d asked Jeremy Saunders, the executive director of Vocal-NY, a nonprofit coalition of community activists. \u201cThere is only one logical answer: It is about politics.\u201d\n\nAt the same time, in a small but growing number of emergency rooms, those who survive overdoses are being approached by friendly-faced former heroin or opioid addicts in royal blue Health Department jackets, part of a $4.3 million pilot program called Relay that began in May. The approach, modeled on one in Rhode Island, is akin to one used in crime-prone neighborhoods, with former gang members seeking to intervene to head off violence before it begins.\n\nRobert Fagan, 48, whose father fatally overdosed when he was 15, began using heroin in the 1990s and later spent years in and out of treatment before he finally got clean. That experience informs his approach to the addicts he helps \u2014 with everything from a ride to a detox center to assistance with paperwork for Medicaid. He is one of 10 such peer outreach workers in five hospitals. The mayor has vowed to double the number of hospitals with Relay workers by the end of next year.\n\nOther promises have been slower to get off the ground. Most, but not all, city-run primary care clinics can prescribe buprenorphine, a maintenance drug, despite a vow to extend the offering to all such Health and Hospitals sites last year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA goal to establish site buprenorphine treatment at seven syringe exchange programs in 2017 has yet to be met: four will start prescribing by June, another three will start the following fiscal year. The delay, according to Olivia Lapeyrolerie, a mayoral spokeswoman, is because of training requirements and the necessity of a state waiver to prescribe the drug.\n\nNonetheless, New York City is better than most cities in its array of treatment facilities, \u201ca legacy of the first heroin epidemic,\u201d said Dr. Hillary Kunins, an assistant commissioner at the Health Department. \u201cUnlike many other parts of the country, we actually have available treatment.\u201d\n\nThe city, with an estimated population of 60,000 to 80,000 heroin and opioid addicts, is likely to be funding such treatment for years if not decades, she said.\n\nMr. Fagan, for his part, has helped 29 people since he started work in the spring, including a homeless man whom Mr. Fagan has already encountered twice in the emergency room after an overdose. After the second time, the man accepted his help, which includes a \u201ccare bag\u201d with a round-trip MetroCard and information about fentanyl, a potent opioid blamed for the recent surge in overdoses.\n\nOverall, since May, about 155 people accepted counseling from peers like Mr. Fagan. A smaller number accepted referrals for treatment or other services.\n\n\u201cI say I have lived experience with using drugs,\u201d Mr. Fagan said, explaining how he introduces himself to skeptical patients, who are often in the throes of a withdrawal in the emergency room. \u201cOnce you say that, a lot of barriers come down.\u201d", "title": "City Officials See Progress in Effort to Curb Opioid Deaths", "authors": ["J. David Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Imaginary people play a surprisingly large role in fashion. Designers conjure them, retailers strategize for them, and we journalists try to put ourselves in their shoes. It\u2019s not a rare feeling at a runway presentation to find oneself puzzling over who the consumer is that\u2019s being pitched a particular designer\u2019s vision.\n\nThis was certainly the case at Tom Ford\u2019s men\u2019s wear show on Tuesday, which some called the official curtain raiser for the start of New York Fashion Week.\n\nEven calling it that has something fanciful about it, since Mr. Ford\u2019s show was preceded by two full days of offerings by at least 34 other designers doing their best to meet the needs of a men\u2019s wear market that stubbornly refuses to coalesce.\n\nLike most designers, Mr. Ford is making a play for a demographic cohort half his age (he is 56). A loose consensus formed over the last month in the fashion capitals of Europe that we are nearing the end of the slob cycle epitomized by athleisure and that male consumers are drifting inexorably away from the hoodie and back to the suit.\n\nIf that\u2019s so, Mr. Ford bids to greet them with his slick slimmed-down version (though one still featuring trademark elements he adapted from Savile Row tailors, like ticket pockets and a wide lapel) and, often enough, rendered in satins, brocade or lam\u00e9. Once, in conversation, Mr. Ford talked to me about the \u201ccut and dried\u201d rules of dressing that held fast when he was growing up in Texas in what he termed a middle-class American family: \u201cYou wore black shoes with a blue suit and brown shoes with gray.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou can bet nobody in Texas went around wearing pink satin Wayne Newton suits with tasseled red sneakers or ill-fitting snakeskin-printed jeans. The likelihood is not great that many men, young or old, will want to do so now.", "title": "City Slickers", "authors": ["Guy Trebay"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "In a case that could have wide-ranging national significance for gay rights, a federal appeals court in New York ruled on Monday that a landmark civil rights law bars employers from discriminating against their workers based on sexual orientation.\n\nThe decision was a setback for the Justice Department, which under President Trump had unexpectedly interceded in a discrimination lawsuit filed by a sky-diving instructor. The department had argued that Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act did not explicitly cover sexual-orientation discrimination in the workplace, a stance that put it at odds with another federal body, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.\n\nIn rejecting the Justice Department\u2019s argument, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit became the second appeals court to rule recently that the Civil Rights Act, which outlaws bias in the workplace on the basis of \u201crace, color, religion, sex or national origin,\u201d should also be extended to include sexual orientation. A third appellate court in Atlanta has ruled differently.\n\nWhile gay rights groups hailed the decision on Monday, the ruling could create a scenario in which the issue of gay rights at work will be decided by a Supreme Court that already bears Mr. Trump\u2019s imprint, with his nomination of Justice Neil M. Gorsuch.", "title": "Civil Rights Act Protects Gay Workers, Appeals Court Rules", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nEAT THE APPLE\n\nA Memoir\n\nBy Matt Young\n\n251 pp. Bloomsbury. $26.\n\nThe trouble with writing the unvarnished truth in a memoir is that it requires you to be hard not only on others, but also on yourself.\n\nMatt Young\u2019s inventive, unsparing, irreverent and consistently entertaining \u201cEat the Apple\u201d is that, but it is also a useful corrective to the current idealization of the American soldier \u2014 or in this case a Marine. Patriotism and respect for the military is so high in this country that we have lately held a national debate over whether professional athletes should be required to stand for the national anthem. Men and women in uniform are given preference in boarding airplanes, and are so routinely thanked for their service that the expression has become rote. Each new season brings a crop of movies and glossy TV serials dramatizing the heroics of our Special Operations.\n\nYoung sees hollowness and potential harm in this.\n\n\u201cEnforcing the idea that every service member is a hero is dangerous,\u201d he writes. \u201cLike creating a generation of veterans who believe everything they did was good.\u201d Young warns of \u201ccreating an army of fanatics.\u201d\n\nService deserves respect, of course, but it does not in itself guarantee stirring and selfless acts of bravery. Young is his own case in point. He sees his experience \u2014 three tours in Iraq \u2014 as far from heroic. He is at least as disturbed by his duty as he is proud of it. These contradictory feelings are a central theme in his book. Years removed, he both loathes and pines for the man he became in the Marine Corps. What he calls his \u201cPast-me\u201d was a reckless, selfish, cruel and dangerous man.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe infantrymen are called grunts and crunchies,\u201d he writes. \u201cThey are stupid and intelligent and cruel and beautiful and black and white and brown and yellow and fat and lazy and lithe and godlike and frightening in their dedication to death.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIt is useful for many reasons to better understand the teenagers we uniform and train and send to war. That way we can better see what happens when they are deployed. Young writes less about war here than about the culture of being a Marine, one of the few and the proud. His memoir \u2014 its title, \u201cEat the Apple,\u201d refers to a vulgar Marine proverb \u2014 is in its own way a loving portrait, but it is also unsparing, ugly and outrageous. I can\u2019t see it making the commandant\u2019s reading list.", "title": "Claiming the Title of United States Marine", "authors": ["Mark Bowden", "Matt Young"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Remember when \u201cHomeland\u201d used to feel so extreme?\n\nIt\u2019s just been bonkers, right? It\u2019s hard for our show to compete with the screeching absurdity of what\u2019s happening in our actual office. It\u2019s like escapist television now \u2014 like a balm, a tonic. It used to be a harrowing, dystopic vision of the truth, and now it\u2019s relaxing.\n\nWhere do we find Carrie after such a tumultuous season finale?\n\nShe was shocked and horrified in the very last beat. She was grieving throughout Season 6; it was kind of a ghost story with Quinn as a dead man walking. And then she realizes that the president, who she had been so allied with and believed in emphatically, betrays her and reveals herself to be a fallible, potentially dangerous leader. So she\u2019s once again on the outside looking in with some disgust and a lot of concern.\n\nAnd her bipolar disorder?\n\nWe learn fairly early on that lithium, which is her panacea, her miracle drug, is no longer effective. Then she finds herself needing to save the world again, and she won\u2019t have time to experiment with other medications in a sane, scientific way. And she is forced to use street drugs and self-medicate.\n\nThe show\u2019s story lines often have uncanny parallels to real-life politics \u2014 for instance, a conspiracy theorist populating social media with fake news. How do the writers manage that feat?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEvery year we spend a week in D.C. in \u201cspy camp.\u201d We all meet in a club in Georgetown, and from morning till night, we talk to a whole coterie of characters within the clandestine world who have real insight into what\u2019s happening. And they are able to illuminate what\u2019s going to surface as relevant in a year\u2019s time. It\u2019s incredibly valuable and terrifying. We have an amazing crystal ball.\n\nQuinn\u2019s death sent fans into a tailspin, some of whom wrote an open letter criticizing the show\u2019s treatment of veterans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI think what [the showrunner Alex Gansa] wanted to do was not just \u201coff\u201d a central character. He wanted to spend time with a veteran who was wounded on a lot of levels \u2014 psychologically and emotionally and physically \u2014 and take seriously the sacrifice and the cost of making that commitment to your country. That was an earnest effort to honor the work that veterans have done.\n\nWere you on the side of fans who longed for a romance between Carrie and Quinn?\n\nI mean, everybody wants that. But I think they did have a romance. It just didn\u2019t take a conventional form. They\u2019re not conventional people. And I think it\u2019s really interesting to consider that there are some people who might not fully be able to achieve real intimacy that we all recognize as valid.\n\nYou recently squeezed in a movie, \u201cA Kid Like Jake,\u201d which debuted at Sundance.\n\nJim Parsons and I play Brooklyn parents who have a 4-year-old son obsessed with dresses and all things princess. We\u2019re applying to kindergarten, and our friend, an educator, suggests that we focus on his \u201cgender expansiveness.\u201d And it makes us suddenly aware of his being different and creates conflict in the marriage. It does talk about gender issues and these ideas that we\u2019re actively wrestling with right now. But it\u2019s about recognizing your child and finding the best way to usher them through the world.\n\n\u201cHomeland\u201d will end after Season 8. How would you like to see Carrie go out?\n\nI would like just a little relief for my girl, because I think she earned it. But we\u2019re not there yet.\n\nAnd then?\n\nWe\u2019re going to take the longest frickin\u2019 nap imaginable.", "title": "Claire Danes Could Really Use a Nap", "authors": ["Kathryn Shattuck"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEverything is loud for games,\u201d said Jean-Luc Cohen-Sinclair, an assistant professor of electronic production and design at the Berklee College of Music and New York University who has worked on games\u2019 sound designs. \u201cThey\u2019re designed to have \u2018transient-rich\u2019 sounds that have a \u2018snappy attack\u2019 \u2014 a quick, percussive buildup of energy, like someone snapping their fingers, as opposed to a fading note on a violin.\u201d\n\nWhy can you so often overhear other people\u2019s games? Prof. Cohen-Sinclair said that designers accentuate the midrange sound frequency, which translates best to earbuds and small speakers, and to which humans are most sensitive. Because mobile games often compete with external noise, they also contain louder sounds that often carry beyond the player\u2019s earbuds.\n\nConstant earbud and headphone use and high-decibel public venues have led to hearing loss (the World Health Organization estimates that over one billion teenagers and young adults are at risk), forcing listeners to crank up the volume even more. And, of course, there is the occasional altruist who eschews earbuds altogether and generously allows others to share in the melodious sounds of his game, music or video.\n\nWe tend to think of visual stimuli as the dominant forces of distraction in modern culture, but sounds too make bids on our attention in the raucous marketplace of noise. Moreover, we have been conditioned physiologically to respond to these auditory cues with dopamine spikes, especially when the alert is for the reward-based feedback of social media validation. It\u2019s hard to be nonreactive to the sound of an incoming text or new Twitter follower.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSomething similar was certainly at play with the ringing landline of yesteryear, but phone calls come at a far slower pace, take more time and rarely involve the caller (let alone hundreds of them) affirming how much they \u201clike\u201d you.\n\nDigital brands have developed imprinting strategies that pander to our shorter sonic attention spans. Television and film networks and production companies have always had audio signatures so long as there have been so-called talkies; think of the fanfare accompanying the iconic 20th Century Fox logo, the growling lion of MGM, the three-tone chime of NBC.\n\nContrast those with the popular networks of the cable and streaming age. HBO has long begun its shows with a television zapping onto a static field that resolves into an ethereal hum. Netflix has a four-second double timpani strike followed by a wash of strings. Amazon Originals offerings start with a whooshing, revolving sound and conclude with a series of vibrant chimes. The new 21st Century Fox logo forgoes the orchestral arrangement and ends in a series of R2D2-like bleeps.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhereas the old guard privileged pleasing musicality or organic sounds and tried to create distinctive signatures that somehow represented their brand, the new wave seems primarily concerned with securing the viewer\u2019s attention immediately, at a minimum of time, through jarring, synthesized noises that are ultimately interchangeable with those of other companies.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a ruthlessly corporate way of trying to coerce the attention of the viewer,\u201d said Paul Grimstad, a writer and composer in New York who has scored a number of films. \u201cThe scale of attention asked of the viewer for a Netflix episode is comparably smaller than the grand cinematic experience the 20th Century Fox orchestral fanfare sets you up for.\u201d\n\nMany digital sound effects, such as the camera shutter, can be classified as \u201cskeuomorphs,\u201d or imitation objects that unnecessarily use ornamental design features of the originals (such as fake stitching on pleather seats). Their ubiquity suggests a postmodern aural backdrop in which the artificial is increasingly replacing the real. For people who grew up hearing only the real sounds, the new distinctions are likely clearer.\n\n\u201cSomeone who\u2019s 80 and someone who\u2019s 12 are going to have different responses to a sound,\u201d said Will Mason, a visiting professor of music theory at Oberlin. But the 12-year-old isn\u2019t necessarily at a disadvantage, he said: \u201cWe want to privilege the real sounds over the synthesized ones, and we want to think a shift to a landscape characterized by these \u2018artificial sounds\u2019 is a dystopian element. But I wonder why it is that we want to call it dystopian. There seems to be some knee-jerk, intuitive way in which that\u2019s the default stance and in which the real is preferable.\u201d\n\nOne reason, aside from our longstanding skepticism over synthetic imitations, may be the preponderance of malevolent or duplicitous artificial intelligence voices in science fiction, from HAL 9000 in \u201c2001: A Space Odyssey\u201d to Samantha in the 2013 film \u201cHer.\u201d Most of us now have our own HALs and Samanthas in the form of Siri and other virtual phone assistants, which, though rudimentary at this point, should eventually approach the fluency of their fictional forebears. Their speech-simulation abilities, along with their mobility, are helping acculturate us to a future in which public spaces are flooded with digitized and recorded voices on top of all the dings and chimes to which we have grown accustomed.\n\nFor years the only automated announcement familiar to New York City subway riders was \u201cStand clear of the closing doors, please,\u201d but now there is a suite of them to replace previously garbled live messages. The new ones include the well-known imperative urging passengers to be on the lookout for packages left on the train \u2014 a common-sense post-9/11 safety announcement, to be sure, but also one that suggests our growing comfort with a surveillance state in which people regard one another with suspicion yet tolerate unseen but heard government and corporate oversight.\n\nAs we blithely send our personal data to companies on a whoosh and a bleep, we think less and less about hearing so many other disembodied and artificial noises in the background. We may not love Big Brother, but seem to be O.K. with his cacophonous little siblings.", "title": "Clap On Your Bose, Baby, \u2019Cause It\u2019s Noisy as Heck Out There", "authors": ["Teddy Wayne", "Future Tense"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Clara Isabel Alegr\u00eda Vides was born on May 12, 1924, in Esteli, Nicaragua. The country was on its way to civil war, and United States Marines were there. Her father, Daniel, a doctor, was among those who viewed the Marines as an occupying force, and while she was still a baby he moved the family to El Salvador, the native land of her mother, Ana Mar\u00eda Vides, a member of a prominent coffee-growing family.\n\nMs. Alegr\u00eda said she began writing poems when she was 6. As a child she also had thoughts of being a great dramatic actress \u2014 but not for long.\n\n\u201cThen I realized that I had a crooked face, that my left side was very different from my right side,\u201d she told Mr. Moyers, who had asked about imagery involving mirrors in her writing. \u201cWith my left side I could be glamorous, but with my right side, no \u2014 there I was always very much down to earth. From then on, mirrors haunted me.\u201d\n\nAt 18 she went to the United States to study at George Washington University, and while there she met the Spanish poet Juan Ram\u00f3n Jim\u00e9nez, who would later win the Nobel Prize in Literature. He became a mentor and, she recalled, advised her that her forays into free verse were premature.\n\n\u201cFirst you have to go through all the traditional forms,\u201d she said he told her. \u201cYou can free yourself after that. Then you will know what you are doing.\u201d", "title": "Claribel Alegr\u00eda, 93, Poet for Central America\u2019s Voiceless, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera.\n\nAXIOM at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater (Feb. 2, 7:30 p.m.). On the face of it, this is an odd duo, but Mr. Bell, the lyrical, pristine violinist, and Mr. Denk, a cheeky and offbeat pianist, make for a fine partnership. For the annual Isaac Stern Memorial Concert, they play Mozart, Strauss, Janacek and Schubert.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nJULIUS EASTMAN at the Kitchen (Feb. 3, 8 p.m.). Leif Ove Andsnes is the pianist; Kent Tritle is the organist.\n\n212-875-5656, nyphil.org\n\n\u2018PARSIFAL\u2019 at the Metropolitan Opera (Feb. 5, 6 p.m.). There is no Jonas Kaufmann this time, but Klaus Florian Vogt is a veteran replacement in the title role, and Evelyn Herlitzius may well make for a fine Kundry. Three standouts from the earlier run return: Ren\u00e9 Pape as Gurnemanz, Peter Mattei as Amfortas and Evgeny Nikitin as Klingsor. At those 1992 Olympics, Germany\u2019s first after reunification, Pechstein shared a room with Christa Luding-Rothenburger, the de facto team mom. Luding-Rothenburger was 32. Pechstein thought that was ancient.\n\nWhat does that make Pechstein now? On Friday, when she will contend for a medal in the 5,000 meters, she\u2019ll be just six days shy of her 46th birthday. She has won five Olympic gold medals, two silvers and two bronzes. She\u2019s redefining what an Olympian should look like.\n\nThis is Pechstein\u2019s seventh Olympics. A rare active athlete who can claim to have represented East Germany internationally, she\u2019s at least 20 years older than more than half of her competitors in the 5,000. Nine of the 17 athletes entered in the race weren\u2019t born when she won her first Olympic medal, a bronze at those 1992 Games in Albertville, France.", "title": "Claudia Pechstein Is a 45-Year-Old Olympian. So Why Is It So Tough to Cheer?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Q. How do you delete Kindle books you have finished on an iPad?\n\nA. When you have completed an e-book and are ready to remove it from your iPad, open the iOS Kindle app and go to your library screen that displays your collection. Tap the Downloaded button at the top of the screen to see only the books stored on the tablet.\n\nWhen you find the book you want to delete, swipe to the left and tap the red Archive button. For more options, you can instead press your finger on the cover image for a second until a menu appears. Choose Remove From Device to delete the book from the iPad. (You can dump old sample chapters and other free content from the Kindle app by selecting the Delete Permanently option from the menu instead.)", "title": "Cleaning Out the Kindle Library", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cNo Children Because of Climate Change? Some People Are Considering It\u201d (news article, nytimes.com, Feb. 5):\n\nThe decision whether or not to have children has always been a heavy one. But climate change and its catastrophic effects are shifting the question for many people.\n\nThe choice to have fewer children is one of the most effective ways we can reduce our individual carbon footprints. And it isn\u2019t just about the climate; it\u2019s about helping to protect the future for all species.\n\nUnfortunately, the ability to plan when, if and how many children is out of reach for many. Here in the United States, nearly half of all pregnancies are unplanned. Family planning faces a barrage of attacks \u2014 from abolishing science-based sex education to slashing programs that provide affordable contraception.\n\nBy restricting access to family planning, we are preventing many from making the reproductive choices that are right for them. That\u2019s bad for women, families and the environment.", "title": "Opinion | Climate Change, and the Question of Not Having Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe actor George Clooney and his wife, Amal, a human rights lawyer, said Tuesday that they would donate $500,000 to a nationwide protest against gun violence planned next month by teenage survivors of a Florida high school shooting, inspiring similar gifts from other big-name Hollywood figures.\n\n\n\nIn a statement, the couple said they were \u201cso inspired by the courage and eloquence of these young men and women\u201d from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. The police say the suspect \u2014 a 19-year-old former student, Nikolas Cruz \u2014 killed 17 people in a rampage with a semiautomatic weapon there last week.\n\n\u201cOur family will be there on March 24 to stand side by side with this incredible generation of young people from all over the country,\u201d the Clooneys said. \u201cAnd in the name of our children, Ella and Alexander, we\u2019re donating 500,000 dollars to help pay for this groundbreaking event.\u201d\n\n\u201cOur children\u2019s lives depend on it,\u201d they added.\n\nThe survivors of the Stoneman Douglas school shooting have emerged as influential new voices in the gun debate, urging lawmakers to adopt new gun control measures in protests outside schools and national television appearances that have been shared widely online.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter the Clooneys made their announcement, other Hollywood leaders said they would match their donation to help the March for Our Lives, including the producer Jeffrey Katzenberg and his wife, Marilyn, Oprah Winfrey, and Steven Spielberg and his wife, Kate Capshaw.", "title": "Clooney, Winfrey and Spielberg Donate Money for March Against Gun Violence", "authors": ["Liam Stack"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "In October, two New York City police officers were charged with kidnapping and raping an 18-year-old Brooklyn woman they had taken into custody. The facts of the case are bad enough, but they also underscore another outrage: Vaguely written statutes in many states, including New York, permit police officers to escape sexual assault charges by claiming that the victims consented to the act.\n\nThe New York State Assembly last week passed legislation to close that odious loophole \u2014 and the State Senate, which is considering the same bill, needs to swiftly follow suit. States across the country that may be letting police officers get away with rape need to revisit their statutes as well.\n\nThe New York City case was particularly disturbing. According to a 50-count indictment unsealed by the Brooklyn district attorney in the fall, two veteran plainclothes detectives took the young woman into custody for having marijuana in her car, and they drove her away from the scene in their police van.\n\nProsecutors say the detectives, who have both pleaded not guilty, raped the woman as she cried and pleaded for them to stop. Lawyers for the detectives subsequently implied that the sex could not be viewed as assault because it was consensual.", "title": "Opinion | Close the Police Rape Loophole", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "A state commission that oversees New York\u2019s correctional system expressed an increasingly common sentiment last week when it said in a report that New York City\u2019s notorious Rikers Island jail complex needed to be shut down faster than the 10-year timeline envisioned by the city. The commission also threatened to shut the complex itself if Mayor Bill de Blasio fails to move expeditiously.\n\nThe report was clearly a response to what state officials see as a lack of urgency on the city\u2019s part. But if the state truly wants to expedite this closing, it needs to do all it can to make it easier for New York City to transfer inmates to newer, smaller jails built elsewhere in the city that would be safer for both inmates and guards. Beyond that, city and state officials need to move away from the counterproductive language of mutual recrimination that will hinder this effort.\n\nThe barbaric nature of life at Rikers Island came into horrifying focus four years ago, when Preet Bharara, then the United States attorney in Manhattan, issued a report documenting a \u201cculture of violence\u201d at the complex, where teenagers in particular were battered and beaten by guards who acted with impunity, without any fear of punishment by city officials.\n\nIn 2015, the city ended a long-running legal battle over the conditions at Rikers, signing a court-enforceable agreement that called for sweeping changes there. The city subsequently decided to cut its losses and close the facility, which is too large and poorly designed to be safely used as a jail.", "title": "Opinion | Closing Rikers Has to Be a Team Effort", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey railroaded him,\u201d said Steve Blair, a retiree who worked in mines run by Mr. Blankenship when he was the chief executive of the Massey Energy Company, once the largest coal producer in central Appalachia. \u201cThe federal government turned everybody loose to testify against him, just to get rid of him.\u201d\n\nMr. Blair, 61, wearing a West Virginia University cap, forked up his steak and eggs at a Bob Evans restaurant recently in Logan. The town, once a Democratic stronghold, is emblematic of how vehemently voters in Appalachia have rejected the national party: Mr. Blair voted for Barack Obama in 2008, but four years later, the sitting president lost the Democratic primary in Logan County to a protest candidate in a Texas prison.\n\nA burly man who is certain in his views, Mr. Blair had a ready explanation for the long decline of the coal industry. \u201cOne word: Obama,\u201d he said. \u201cI was put out of business by Obama.\u201d\n\nMr. Blankenship claims that the federal government, not the coal company, is to blame for the explosion at the Upper Big Branch mine near Montcoal, W.Va. Investigators found no evidence to support his claims, but he is running for office in an era of nationwide voter credulity for conspiracy theories.\n\nAnd his candidacy is unfolding in a state where many people embrace a sense of persecution over coal\u2019s decline. Economists say that a host of factors are responsible, chiefly the abundance of cheap natural gas, which has undercut coal in the energy marketplace. But that is not what many West Virginians choose to hear.\n\n\u201cWhat hurt coal was the Obama administration and nothing else,\u201d said Denny Harton, a retired business owner who introduced Mr. Blankenship recently at one of his rallies.\n\nPhoto\n\nDianne Dewey White, chairwoman of the Republican Party of Logan County, said thousands of miners who once looked to Mr. Blankenship for work are likely to support him now. \u201cYou wouldn\u2019t believe what good parties they had, and what times they had,\u201d she said. \u201cThey spent a lot of good years with him. People don\u2019t forget that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCoal barons like Mr. Blankenship used to be despised in Logan County, a rugged region in southern West Virginia. The Battle of Blair Mountain happened here in 1921, when miners seeking to unionize clashed with a private army fielded by mine owners, and more than 50 people died.\n\nBut as West Virginia has become a deep-red state, the sympathies of many mine families have shifted from unions to mine operators, who are portrayed as job creators.\n\n\u201cI have heard people say, \u2018When Don was in charge, we always worked,\u2019\u201d said R. Booth Goodwin II, who prosecuted Mr. Blankenship as a United States attorney and then ran for governor unsuccessfully in 2016. \u201cThe coal industry is still perpetuating a lie that coal mining is coming back, and it\u2019s going to be just like it was before, when all objective evidence is to the contrary,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Blankenship, 67, is up against two more conventional candidates \u2014 Attorney General Patrick Morrisey and Representative Evan Jenkins \u2014 in the Republican primary in May. He said he is prepared to spend whatever it takes on the race, and his pockets are deep: In his last years at Massey Energy, he was reportedly paid $38.2 million. Opponents who once dismissed his candidacy now see him as a credible threat in the Trump era, positioned to appeal to many West Virginians\u2019 resentment of elites of any kind.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a pride in the state, deep inside, that comes from people dumping on it so long,\u201d said an aide to Senator Joe Manchin III, the Democratic incumbent who will face the winner of the Republican primary in November.\n\nMr. Manchin once said that Mr. Blankenship \u201chas blood on his hands\u201d because of Upper Big Branch, the worst mining disaster in the United States in 40 years. Some West Virginians speculate that Mr. Blankenship is running to pursue a vendetta against Mr. Manchin, who was governor at the time the mine exploded. Although Mr. Manchin is the most conservative Democrat in the Senate, he is still expected to face a tough re-election race in the state, where Donald J. Trump won 68 percent of the vote in 2016.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Blankenship dismisses talk of a vendetta. \u201cIf I wanted to get Senator Manchin, I\u2019d just go out and slam him, like he did me, put national TV ads on,\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cI\u2019m trying to win an election.\u201d\n\nThrough a spokesman, Mr. Manchin declined to be interviewed. \u201cOut of respect for our coal miners and their families who are still grieving the loss of their loved ones, I will not comment on Don Blankenship,\u2019\u2019 he said in a statement. \u201cWest Virginians know the facts, and the jury has spoken.\u201d\n\nMr. Blankenship was convicted of a misdemeanor count of conspiracy in 2015 after the jury heard that federal safety inspectors had written hundreds of safety violations for the Upper Big Branch mine, and former miners described unsafe conditions there.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn the campaign trail, Mr. Blankenship charges that \u201cthe Obama government blew up the Upper Big Branch mine.\u201d He maintains that the explosion happened because federal inspectors had ordered the company to install an ineffective ventilation system.\n\nPhoto\n\nNone of the several investigations conducted by state, federal and independent authorities support Mr. Blankenship\u2019s theory on the mine disaster. Instead, investigators found that mine management failed to prevent a combustible buildup of coal dust, which was ignited by faulty machinery to create a fireball.\n\nAfter completing his prison time at the Taft Correctional Institution in California, Mr. Blankenship declared in court papers that his primary residence was in Las Vegas. The car that brought him to a recent appearance in Parkersburg, W.Va., was a luxury BMW sedan with Tennessee plates.\n\nTo many relatives of the miners who were killed, his re-emergence in coal country is a source of bitter pain.\n\nGary and Patty Quarles, who are raising a grandson after their son, Gary Wayne Quarles, was killed at Upper Big Branch, described their anguish at watching Mr. Blankenship\u2019s TV ads, titled \u201cFor the Sake of Coal Miners.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re sitting here in our living room with our grandson, and there he sets up on TV \u2014 that\u2019s sickening,\u201d said Mr. Quarles, who also worked in Massey Energy coal mines. \u201cDon can say what he wants to about safety and doing all this and that for miners \u2014 there was no safety in Massey coal. None whatever.\u201d\n\n\u201cAll they know is to lie, cheat and outlaw,\u201d he added.\n\nAt a barbershop on Main Street in Logan, the county seat, customers with ties to mining tended to react negatively to Mr. Blankenship\u2019s candidacy, while the barber, Chad Browning, was studiedly neutral. \u201cCoal is king in this county,\u201d said Mr. Browning, 45. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing else here.\u201d\n\nIn his shop in the former bus station, a haircut is $10 and a poster for a Kiwanis pancake breakfast is taped to the mirror. The street outside is a shadowy canyon of tired brick buildings, with a tattoo parlor nearby and a pawnshop offering \u201cLoans, Guns, Ammo.\u201d Only one UPS truck stops to make deliveries on Main Street these days, Mr. Browning said, where once there were three.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe UPS driver, Mike Workman, 46, the son of a coal miner, watched Mr. Browning apply hot lather to a customer and shave his neck with a straight razor.\n\nMr. Workman lamented how the conflict over coal, between protecting jobs and protecting the environment, had become so bitter. \u201cIt\u2019s a political war, but to us it\u2019s not a political war \u2014 we\u2019re just trying to make a living,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t think there\u2019s nobody in West Virginia that wants to see the streams tainted. I\u2019m a fisherman and a hunter. We love this area. This is where our kids play. We drink the water here.\u201d\n\nHe said he could not vote for Mr. Blankenship. \u201cI\u2019ve had family in the mining industry; they know that he puts production above safety,\u201d he said.\n\nIn the barber\u2019s chair, Bob Lucas, 52, who works in a coal processing plant, said he could not support Mr. Blankenship, either. Mr. Lucas was once an electrician at a Massey-owned mine, where he said he was asked to take shortcuts that would compromise safety. Rather than do that, he said, he quit the job.\n\nMr. Lucas said the mine\u2019s managers lived in fear of a visit from Mr. Blankenship, who would descend on the site by helicopter. \u201cWhen Don flew in, they were terrified,\u201d he said.", "title": "Coal Country Divides Over an Unrepentant Boss\u2019s Senate Bid", "authors": ["Trip Gabriel"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Three signal flares went up for the American coal industry recently, all illuminating an inescapable conclusion: Despite President Trump\u2019s campaign promise, coal-fired power is in trouble and in all likelihood won\u2019t be reasserting itself in the United States. Nor should it.\n\nThe first signal, from the medical community, should give champions of \u201cbeautiful, clean coal\u201d like Mr. Trump and his energy secretary, Rick Perry, pause. A research letter published in the Journal of the American Medical Association on Feb. 6 said that health professionals in Appalachian coal country were now finding the highest levels of black lung disease in coal miners ever reported.\n\nThe Coal Workers\u2019 Health Surveillance Program, administered by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, or Niosh, has offered regular chest radiographs for coal miners since 1970. By the late 1990s, black lung disease was \u201crarely identified\u201d among miners participating in the program, researchers wrote. But a spike in cases in 2014, first reported by National Public Radio, prompted the federal agency to take a closer look at patients at three federally funded black lung clinics in southwest Virginia.\n\nThe agency was stunned by what it found. Black lung cases in Appalachia coal miners in those three clinics had skyrocketed. The disease was more severe. And coal miners were dying much younger than they had been two decades ago.", "title": "Opinion | Coal\u2019s Continuing Decline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Birds are not as picky about their coffee as people are.\n\nAlthough coffee snobs prefer arabica beans to robusta, a new study in India found that growing coffee does not interfere with biodiversity \u2014 no matter which bean the farmer chooses.\n\nIn the Western Ghats region of India, a mountainous area parallel to the subcontinent\u2019s western coast, both arabica and robusta beans are grown as bushes under larger trees \u2014 unlike in South America, where the coffee plants themselves grow as large as trees, said Krithi Karanth, who helped lead the study, published Friday in the journal Scientific Reports.\n\nIndia is the seventh-largest producer of coffee in the world, according to the International Coffee Organization, an intergovernmental organization. Most of the coffee grown in India is consumed there, said Dr. Karanth, an associate conservation scientist with the Wildlife Conservation Society, but the findings of her research could have implications for shade-grown coffee in other parts of the world.\n\nIt\u2019s the tree cover around the coffee plants that supports a wide range of animal species, she said. \u201cCoffee farms are actually incredible habitats for all the small critters,\u201d she said, including birds, butterflies, and amphibians.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nArabica and robusta farms proved equally good for these creatures. \u201cSome birds do better with arabica than robusta, but overall, they\u2019re both good for wildlife,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe difference is important, because data shows that more farmers in the area have been shifting to robusta in recent years, as prices rise for the variety, which is easier to grow.", "title": "Coffee Beans Are Good for Birds, Fancy Brew or Not", "authors": ["Karen Weintraub"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Colbert taunted Trump on \u201cThe Late Show,\u201d calling him \u201cchicken\u201d for not agreeing to testify.\n\n\u201cI know Trump watches this show \u2014 because it\u2019s on TV. Otherwise, everyone\u2019s going to think that you\u2019re scared. But we know you\u2019re not. Oh, oh, your fried chicken has arrived! [grabs paper bucket] But wait, it\u2019s empty. Where is that \u2014 oh, I think I know where the chicken is! Buck-aww!\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nTrump Targets Democrats Who Refused to Clap\n\nIn a speech on Monday, Trump seemed to suggest that Democrats who did not applaud during his State of the Union address had been committing \u201ctreason.\u201d Trevor Noah was dismayed.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m so shocked that the president really will just repeat anything someone random in a crowd shouts at him. Like, treason is not typically prosecuted in a call-and-response fashion. Even if you said treason to a parrot, the bird would be like, \u2018Bawk! I\u2019m not saying that, that\u2019s a serious charge! Bawk! P.S. Polly doesn\u2019t say \u2018cracker\u2019 anymore. I\u2019m woke!\u2019 \u201d \u2014 TREVOR NOAH\n\nThen Noah played a statement from the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, who said that Trump had been joking. She calls it \u201ca jolt of a movie.\u201d", "title": "Colbert Tries Taunting Trump Into Testifying Before Mueller", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "The average time of a nine-inning game last season was 3 hours 5 minutes, the highest on record and nine minutes longer than in 2015. That was Manfred\u2019s first year as commissioner, when he made pace-of-play a priority. But the players quickly learned that the league and the umpires were not really forcing them to stay in the box or deliver pitches at a brisker pace. The pace reverted to a crawl.\n\nThe biggest factor, though, is that players are increasingly incentivized to take more time. In the age of analytics, teams cultivate power hitters and power pitchers, and the amateur ranks churn out plenty every year. Strikeouts and homers reached record highs last season, and walks are rising again, too. That means more pitches, which means more relievers, which means more time.\n\nThe 2017 season included 1,196 more home runs, 1,756 more walks and 2,658 more strikeouts than the 2015 season. The number of pitches per nine-inning game rose from 283 to 292 in the same period. No wonder games were nine minutes longer.\n\n\u201cGuys are working the count; nobody\u2019s trying to just put the ball in play. Everybody wants to lift and launch and hit home runs,\u201d said Jim Kaat, the MLB Network analyst and former pitcher. \u201cSo home runs, walks and strikeouts kind of dominate the game, and that\u2019s going to make for a more boring game in terms of action on the bases. It\u2019s really a three-hour home run derby, in a lot of cases.\u201d\n\nKaat pitched 25 seasons in the majors, through 1983, when teams averaged 2 hours 36 minutes to play nine innings. It was a different game in many ways. Kaat was among his generation\u2019s best pitchers but averaged only 4.9 strikeouts per nine innings for his career. Last year, only one pitcher who made at least 25 starts, Andrew Cashner, averaged fewer. (Naturally, Cashner is an unsigned free agent.)\n\nBetween 1973 and 1980, Kaat started 11 nine-inning games that took no more than 1 hour 40 minutes. He had 31 strikeouts and 7 walks \u2014 total \u2014 in those 11 games.\n\n\u201cOur objective was to trust your stuff and make them put the ball in play,\u201d Kaat said. \u201cNow, you see fear of contact, deep counts, more pitches, and hitters diving into the ball and swinging at will.\u201d", "title": "Cold-Stove League: Baseball and Union Lament Glacial Pace on Two Fronts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s official: Returns for college and university endowments for the 2017 fiscal year are in, and while they averaged a respectable 12.2 percent for the year, over the last decade they have underperformed funds offering a simple 60-40 or 70-30 stock-fixed income allocation.\n\nWith their average returns dragged down by the weak performance of hedge funds, venture capital and private equity, you would think endowments would be fleeing these so-called alternative investments, which are costly and mostly illiquid, as some large pension funds have done.\n\nOn the contrary, endowments are holding firm, or even adding to these holdings. Last year, alternative investments accounted for an average of 52 percent of endowment assets \u2014 over 60 percent in the largest endowments \u2014 the same percentage as two years ago, according to the annual Nacubo-Commonfund study of endowments.\n\nYet over the last 10 years, the average endowment earned a 4.6 percent annualized return, lower than the 5.3 percent return for a low-cost 60-40 stock-bond index fund portfolio and 5.4 percent for a 70-30 mix.", "title": "College Endowments Opt for Alternative, and Less Lucrative, Route", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Student Loan Serenity Prayer,\u201d by Michael Arceneaux (On Campus, Sunday Review, Feb. 11):\n\nI sympathize with some of Mr. Arceneaux\u2019s comments, particularly the mountainous debt many students encounter as a result of college unaffordability. To help provide a remedy, we must improve college accountability through risk-sharing of federal student loans, as they make up 92 percent of student debt.\n\nBut there is a critical point that must be made: Today, 98 percent of private student loans are being repaid. Private lenders carefully underwrite their loans and clearly disclose loan terms. Additionally, four separate federal regulatory agencies and numerous state agencies oversee the private market.\n\nFor private borrowers who find themselves in distress, private lenders offer a variety of loan modification programs. Those facing an \u201cundue hardship\u201d may request that a court wipe out their loan balance, the same as with federal borrowers.\n\nIn contrast, the Education Department has a disastrous track record, with 22 percent of borrowers in default. This is the type of irresponsible and predatory lending that deserves scrutiny.", "title": "Opinion | College Student Loan Debt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "The peace accords, signed in 2016, ordered a vast transformation of post-conflict Colombia, including provisions for courts to settle war crimes, investments to wean farmers off the coca trade and a strong push to establish a Colombian government presence in areas that had been under rebel control. The war with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the main rebel group known as the FARC, left more than 200,000 people dead and many millions displaced. It was the longest civil conflict in the region.\n\nYet after little more than a year, much of the agreement stands paralyzed. The new courts have not begun work, coca production is still soaring and many rural towns do not have a single police officer. The National Liberation Army, a rebel group that did not sign the deal, has stepped up attacks. Public resentment simmers, with some people saying that the FARC rebels got off too easy.\n\nAnd on Friday, the FARC said it would stop campaigning for the presidency in May and 74 congressional seats to be elected in March.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve decided to suspend our campaign activities until we have sufficient guarantees\u201d of safety, the group said in a statement. It cited a \u201ccoordinated plan\u201d of attacks against FARC campaigners, including photos taken of the homes of activists by opponents, social media threats and the killing of a former fighter on Tuesday \u2014 one of dozens killed since the peace deal was signed.\n\n\u201cColombia cannot become a failed state electorally because of the enemies of peace,\u201d the former guerrillas wrote in the statement.\n\nFor the FARC, it was a turn of fortune for what had been the country\u2019s most feared rebel organization, one that had terrorized Colombians with kidnappings, killings and land mines that still plague the country. The former guerrilla fighters now find themselves fearing the voters they are meant to court.\n\nThe killing of FARC members also is a reminder of the past: In the 1980s, thousands of members were slaughtered by paramilitary groups when they last attempted to come out of the shadows, forming a party known as the Patriotic Union. That memory, many say, is behind the caution in the current election.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn an interview on Friday, Colombia\u2019s interior minister, Guillermo Rivera, said that the FARC\u2019s decision was not what the government had wanted to see.\n\nWhile Mr. Rivera said that former fighters had been killed in recent months, he noted that no candidate had died and that in some cases the FARC had declined protection.\n\n\u201cWe will keep offering the guarantees so they can safely continue campaigning,\u201d Mr. Rivera said.\n\nYet while few wished to see violence in the election, sympathy for the former rebels was hard to find among commentators in Colombia on Friday.\n\n\u201cThe FARC suffered from a guerrilla\u2019s vanity, which consisted of thinking that upon abandoning arms, signing the peace deal and becoming civilians that Colombians were going to cheer, applaud and unconditionally support them,\u201d said Jairo Libreros, a political scientist and columnist in Bogot\u00e1.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe United Nations mission responsible for monitoring the peace process reported last month that 36 FARC members had been killed since the war ended in 2016. Recent killings include the cases of two activists working for the campaign of a FARC congressional candidate who were found dead on Jan. 17, and Kevin Andr\u00e9s Lugo, a former guerrilla the FARC said had been killed on Feb. 8.\n\nThe targeting of FARC campaigners runs all the way to the top. Rodrigo Londo\u00f1o, their former top commander, was attacked by protesters who pelted his motorcade with rocks, on one occasion practically destroying his vehicle. One prominent Senate candidate, Luciano Mar\u00edn, also known as Iv\u00e1n M\u00e1rquez, canceled a campaign event this week in the face of violent protests.\n\nWho is behind the attacks is unclear. Mr. Londo\u00f1o\u2019s running mate, Imelda Daza, said in an interview with a local radio station on Friday that the violence had been instigated by \u201cpersons interested in sabotaging the FARC\u2019s campaign.\u201d The FARC also has blamed National Liberation Army rebels.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMrs. Daza singled out the hard-line Democratic Center party and its spiritual leader, Colombia\u2019s former president, \u00c1lvaro Uribe, a fierce critic of the peace process.\n\nDuring Mr. Uribe\u2019s tenure in the seat Mr. Londo\u00f1o hopes to occupy, he oversaw a brutal military campaign against the FARC, and led the campaign to reject the peace deal in an initial referendum in October 2016. Mr. Uribe has denied involvement in attacks against former FARC members.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore seasoned politicians said that such attacks were not entirely unexpected in a country where war had been the norm and anger against the rebels remained.\n\n\u201cI think that no one expected that the political transition from FARC\u2019s guerrilla organization to this new movement would be simple or easy,\u201d said Iv\u00e1n Cepeda, whose father, Manuel, was killed in 1994 during the attacks against the FARC\u2019s Patriotic Union party.\n\nHowever, Mr. Cepeda said it was important to distinguish between the protests of angered war victims and \u201cmethods which are frankly done to incite violence,\u201d which he said he suspected had been organized by supporters of Mr. Uribe\u2019s party.\n\nMr. Londo\u00f1o, the FARC\u2019s presidential candidate, has been running on an anti-poverty platform. He began his campaign last month in a downtrodden Bogot\u00e1 neighborhood.\n\nBespectacled and wearing a suit and tie, he is a far cry from the guerrilla in the jungle fatigues he once donned, and he has represented the FARC\u2019s willingness to move from armed struggle to politics.\n\nYet the rebels\u2019 appetite for politics has also offended some.\n\nIn August, the group established its political party, choosing a slight alteration in its name that allowed the former guerrillas to retain the same acronym they used during the war. The move enraged many victims groups who said its leadership appeared unapologetic.\n\nThen in November, Mr. Londo\u00f1o, who had previously promised not to run for president, reversed himself. His approval rating in polls is barely 2 percent, and many Colombians see him as a terrorist.\n\n\u201cHe was the face of the insurgency and the most emblematic representative of everything that Colombians hate about the FARC,\u201d said Cynthia J. Arnson, an analyst at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, in Washington.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Villarraga, the director of the democracy center, said he hoped Colombians would overcome their anger toward leaders like Mr. Londo\u00f1o and defended his right to campaign.\n\n\u201cAll politicians, institutions \u2014 and even opinion makers \u2014 we need to be circling around the FARC now because it is a product of the peace process,\u201d he said. \u201cWe must absolutely have all of the political parties, including the FARC.\u201d\n\nBut some presidential candidates seemed uninterested in that aspiration.\n\n\u201cWhat can they expect?\u201d asked Germ\u00e1n Vargas Lleras, a candidate who had been vice president while the peace accords were negotiated, in an interview on the W Radio network. \u201cThat after 40 years of kidnappings and killings they get received with hugs?\u201d", "title": "Colombian Rebels Suspend Election Campaign, Putting Peace Into Limbo", "authors": ["Nicholas Casey"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "The reason for that may be that \u201cboth Fox and Disney have reasons for wanting to possess all of Sky,\u201d writes Chris Hughes of Bloomberg Gadfly. \u201cFox may want full ownership as an insurance policy against the sale to Disney failing. And Disney\u2019s desire to buy Fox\u2019s current stake in Sky suggests it likes the asset, wants more of it and would want to prevent Comcast owning it.\u201d In fact, Robert Iger, Disney\u2019s chief executive, has called Sky the crown jewel of his company\u2019s purchase of Fox assets.\n\nReaction\n\n\u2022 Frank Louthan, an analyst at Raymond James: \u201cThe potential for Fox to return and make a competing bid remains high, in our view, as our European investment team believes Sky is the best-in-class European leader in Pay-TV.\u201d\n\nA brief explanation of British takeover rules.\n\nWhen is an offer an offer can be a fine point under Britain\u2019s complicated takeover rules.\n\nOn Tuesday, Comcast announced a \u201cpossible all-cash offer\u201d to acquire Sky, the British satellite broadcaster, for about $31 billion .\n\nSky and 21st Century Fox, which has been trying to acquire the 61 percent of Sky that it does not already own for more than year, both responded that \u201cno firm offer\u201d had been made.\n\nThat may seem like an odd distinction when Comcast, the owner of NBCUniversal, announced publicly how much it is willing to pay for an asset to kick off negotiations.\n\nBut, that comes down to Britain\u2019s extensive takeover code, which spans more than 400 pages, and can often trip up American companies not used to operating under those rules.\n\nThe public disclosure of merger talks is triggered under the code when a number of factors occur, such as rumors in the market that a deal is in the works or \u201cuntoward movement\u201d in a takeover target\u2019s stock price.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMaking a public announcement then starts a countdown clock for a potential acquirer to announce a formal offer under the rules, known as a so-called firm intention to make an offer.\n\nThe rules are intended to make sure all shareholders are treated fairly and have access to the same information about a deal and to establish an orderly framework for takeovers.\n\n- Chad Bray\n\nPhoto\n\nComcast takes on Rupert Murdoch\n\nWe\u2019d waited to see if Brian Roberts, Comcast\u2019s chairman and C.E.O., would challenge Walt Disney for control of 21st Century Fox. Instead, he plans to disrupt Mr. Murdoch\u2019s bid for full control of Sky, the British satellite broadcaster.\n\nWhat Comcast is offering: \u00a312.50, or about $17.50, a share for all of Sky\n\nWhat Fox is offering: \u00a310.75 a share for the 61 percent of Sky that it doesn\u2019t own\n\nBehind the maneuvers\n\nComcast had worked on its own offer for Fox, with the chance to expand internationally through Sky being a big reason for bidding. But the Murdochs and their advisers believed that it would be difficult for Comcast to win U.S. regulatory approval.\n\nHowever, Fox\u2019s bid for Sky has been held up by questions by British regulators about whether Mr. Murdoch was fit and proper to control a major broadcaster in the U.K. That presented Comcast\u2019s opportunity.\n\nWhat Mr. Roberts said in Comcast\u2019s regulatory statement: \u201cWe already have a strong presence in London, and Comcast intends to use Sky as a platform for our growth in Europe.\u201d\n\nWhom to thank for the Comcast bid\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Paul Richards of the media research firm Numis told the FT that Comcast\u2019s bid is a \u201cvery strong competitive offer.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Alex DeGroote at Cenkos Securities told Bloomberg, \u201cThe market was anticipating another approach and will be pleasantly surprised.\u201d\n\nMarket reaction\n\nComcast investors don\u2019t seem pleasantly surprised. Shares of Comcast are down 5.2 percent. Sky\u2019s stock popped nearly 20 percent and is now trading above Comcast\u2019s offer.\n\nHow will Powell discuss loose fiscal policy?\n\nWhen Jerome H. Powell, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve, appears before the House Financial Services Committee on Tuesday, we may see if he has mastered the art of stern but subtle disapproval.\n\nCongress has recently enacted tax cuts and spending increases that could stimulate the economy at a time when the Fed may want to tamp things down a bit.\n\nA tug of war could end up occurring between elected politicians wanting a boom to continue and a central bank that is concerned about government deficits and inflation. It is highly unlikely that Mr. Powell or any other Fed official would want to get drawn into a direct, public fight with members of Congress or the administration of President Donald Trump.\n\nSo, how might Mr. Powell express concern about loose government fiscal policies? He can talk about Congress\u2019s stimulus as just one of many factors that can have an impact on the Fed\u2019s mission of creating the economic conditions for maximum employment and stable prices. In other words, he could depersonalize any tensions, and imply that concern about spending and deficits is just the Fed doing its job. And in his prepared testimony for the hearing, Mr. Powell noted the stimulus from fiscal policy.\n\n\u201cIn gauging the appropriate path for monetary policy over the next few years, the F.O.M.C. will continue to strike a balance between avoiding an overheated economy and bringing P.C.E. price inflation to 2 percent on a sustained basis. While many factors shape the economic outlook, some of the headwinds the U.S. economy faced in previous years have turned into tailwinds: In particular, fiscal policy has become more stimulative and foreign demand for U.S. exports is on a firmer trajectory.\u201d\n\n(F.O.M.C. is the Federal Open Market Committee, the committee that sets monetary policy, while P.C.E. price inflation is the Fed\u2019s preferred measure of prices, derived from a survey of personal consumption expenditures conducted by the Bureau of Economic Analysis.)\n\nUpdate from the hearing\n\nIn this testimony before the House committee on Tuesday, Mr. Powell took some questions about the recent loosening of fiscal policy, and how the Fed might respond.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe followed the careful path outlined above. On the one hand, he noted that government finances can have an impact on economic conditions, saying: \u201cFiscal policy changes can have an effect.\u201d He also said: \u201cWe really need to get on a sustainable fiscal path, and the time for doing that is now.\u201d\n\nOn the other hand, Mr. Powell said the Fed did not want to directly interfere in government spending decisions. \u201cWe don\u2019t do fiscal policy at the Fed,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nAmazon is buying doorbell maker Ring.\n\nThat\u2019s according to GeekWire and confirmed by CNBC.\n\nThe details\n\n\u2022 \u201cRing has raised $209 million so far and was last valued at $760 million, according to Pitchbook.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Amazon\u2019s Alexa Fund, which invests in startups that make Alexa compatible devices, was an investor.\n\n\u2022 Amazon plans to have Ring operate as a separate business, much as Zappos and Twitch do.\n\nPhoto\n\nTake another executive\u2019s name off the 2020 list.\n\nHoward Schultz, the founder and executive chairman of Starbox, said during an interview with Fox Business that he is not running for president. Here\u2019s the transcript via Dan Primack of Axios\n\nFBN\u2019s Maria Bartiromo: Are you going to run for president in 2020, Howard? Schultz: \u201cNo I\u2019m not...\n\nMs. Bartiromo, then, followed up with:\n\nBartiromo: \u201cYou are always seeing your position as a responsibility to bring people together. I know that, so just to clarify, you said you are not going to run for president? Schultz: \u201cI said I am doing everything I possibly can as a private citizen to advance the cause of the country.\u201d Bartiromo: \u201cIt sounds like you are running for president, Howard.\u201d Schultz: \u201cNo I didn\u2019t say that. Come on, Maria.\u201d\n\nMr. Schultz is one of a number of business executives and celebrities long speculated to be considering a run for president in 2020. The list has included Oprah Winfrey, Mark Cuban, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan, Bob Iger of Disney and Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook.\n\nOn other topics\n\n\u2022 Taxes: \u201cWe are robbing from the future of young people in America who ultimately are going to have to pay for a $21 trillion tax deficit,\u201d Mr. Schultz said.\n\n\u2022 Real Estate: \u201cOver the last few weeks, I have been in a number of U.S. cities and observed firsthand the abundance of empty storefronts across the country, in prime A1 locations. We are at a major inflection point as landlords across the country will be forced (sooner than later) to permanently lower rent rates to adjust to the \u2018new norm,\u2019\u201d Mr. Schultz said.\n\nPhoto\n\nDelta finds risks to taking on the N.R.A.\n\nThe tweet from Lt. Gov. Casey Cagle of Georgia, Delta\u2019s home state, shows that it isn\u2019t easy for companies to find a balance between those who want corporate America to push for more gun control and those who think conservatives are being unfairly maligned.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy eliminating discounted fares for N.R.A. members, the airline has stirred up Georgia Republican opposition to a lucrative tax break that had substantial support only days ago.\n\nAlso in that category: FedEx, which is keeping its discounts for N.R.A. members while expressing support for banning assault rifles for civilians.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. (CNBC)\n\nPhoto\n\nWill Broadcom\u2019s bid for Qualcomm fail on national security grounds?\n\nThe government panel known as Cfius, which reviews deals for national security reasons, has taken the rare step of looking at a potential combination before the chip makers have even agreed on a deal, Reuters reported, citing unnamed sources. Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, urged the review.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf Cfius intervenes, it would sidestep Broadcom\u2019s move to relocate its headquarters to the U.S., which critics said was aimed in part at preventing such a review. (Broadcom\u2019s C.E.O., Hock Tan, said the redomiciling would happen even if the deal didn\u2019t go through.)\n\nMore from Diane Bartz of Reuters:\n\nPart of the CFIUS\u2019 current concern, which is echoed in Cornyn\u2019s letter, could lie in the fact that Broadcom has failed to strike a deal with Qualcomm and has resorted to what is essentially a hostile takeover by putting forward a slate of six Broadcom nominees for Qualcomm\u2019s 11-member board.\n\nMore in the chip battle: Qualcomm says that it\u2019s willing to keep talking, but Broadcom called the outreach \u201cfeigned engagement.\u201d Qualcomm reportedly wants more than $90 a share; the current offer is $79 a share.\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 The investment decisions of SoftBank\u2019s Masa Son befuddle even his own directors. It\u2019s not just the Chinese government\u2019s fears of overspending by homegrown businesses, but also growing skepticism from officials in the United States and elsewhere.\n\nMore from Alexandra Stevenson of the NYT:\n\n\u201cRegulators will naturally be somewhat concerned by the reality that often there is an asymmetry of information about the Chinese firms operating internationally,\u201d said Jeremy Stevens, an economist for Standard Bank Group in Beijing. \u201cThis event further underlines this truth,\u201d he added.\n\nMore on Anbang: Is its takeover China\u2019s \u201ctoo big to fail\u201d moment?
