Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Comcast Leaves Fox With Few Good Options: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Comcast may have found a way to disrupt Walt Disney Company\u2019s plan to buy most of 21st Century Fox: topping Fox\u2019s bid to buy the British satellite broadcaster Sky with its own $31 billion takeover offer.\n\nThe bid, plans for which were announced on Tuesday, seizes upon 21st Century Fox\u2019s difficulties buying the piece of Sky that it does not already own. British regulators have expressed repeated concerns about giving Rupert Murdoch and his family more control over the country\u2019s media, stretching the approval process out over more than a year and forcing 21st Century Fox to offer more concessions.\n\nComcast has said that buying Sky would help it expand in Europe, where the broadcaster has 23 million customers and owns rights to show the English Premier League and other professional soccer leagues. Disney, too, has been keen on expanding internationally, with the British company serving as an important part of its $52 billion plan to buy a significant portion of 21st Century Fox.\n\nWhoever prevails, it will shake up Disney\u2019s plans. Either 21st Century Fox will have to pay more for Sky, or Disney will lose a valuable international property to Comcast.", "title": "Comcast Seeks Control of Broadcaster Sky, Countering Murdoch and Disney", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nComcast boss Brian Roberts is driving a wedge between Walt Disney and 21st Century Fox. The United States cable company\u2019s 22 billion pound ($31 billion) offer for Sky, the British pay-television group, leaves Rupert Murdoch, Fox\u2019s chairman, with two unappealing options: enter a bidding war for Sky, or rethink his deal to sell Fox\u2019s entertainment assets to Disney.\n\nSky\u2019s investors owe a big thank you to a store employee near the group\u2019s London head office. Mr. Roberts\u2019 interest in the broadcaster firmed up after an hourlong demonstration of its flagship Sky Q TV product during a trip at the end of last year. Comcast is offering \u00a312.50 a share in cash for Sky, comfortably beating Fox\u2019s bid of \u00a310.75 per share for the 61 percent of the company it does not own.\n\nComcast\u2019s slim operations in Britain mean the bid should raise few competition concerns. 21 Century Fox, by contrast, has been told by regulators that its bid risked giving the Murdoch clan too much influence over Britain\u2019s news agenda. It\u2019s now waiting for the publication of a final report that will detail regulators\u2019 recommended remedies, such as a separate editorial board for Sky News. Media Secretary Matt Hancock will have the final say in the summer.\n\nComcast reckons its expertise funneling television shows, sports and movies directly to homes makes it a better owner for Sky. How the $183 billion group\u2019s own shareholders will benefit is unclear: Comcast\u2019s offer contains lots of detail about supporting creative industries and young people in Britain, but little about financial returns. That may be because Mr. Roberts\u2019s real objective is to upset a $52 billion all-stock tie-up that Disney and Fox announced in December. Comcast still covets Fox\u2019s assets, Reuters reported earlier this month. Bob Iger, Disney\u2019s chief executive, has described Sky as Fox\u2019s \u201ccrown jewel.\u201d\n\nComcast\u2019s offer will go ahead if just over 50 percent of Sky shareholders accept it. That means Fox\u2019s 39 percent stake will not be enough to block the deal. Mr. Murdoch, therefore, has two options: revise the terms of the Disney sale to exclude Sky, or enter into a bidding war with Mr. Roberts. Sky shares jumped by a fifth on Tuesday morning and now trade almost 7 percent above Comcast\u2019s bid. Investors have placed their bets.", "title": "Comcast\u2019s Bid to Spoil the Disney-Fox Party", "authors": ["Liam Proud"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nComcast may be the spoiler in a Disney-Fox show. The cable firm is considering whether to try to thwart the Mouse House\u2019s $52.4 billion purchase of parts of Rupert Murdoch\u2019s empire. The story has many moving parts, and the Walt Disney Company may yet have to raise its game.\n\nComcast, led by Brian Roberts, initially bid around $60 billion when Mr. Murdoch first indicated that he was willing to part with cable networks like National Geographic and FX, movie studios, and Fox\u2019s businesses outside the United States. Disney clinched the deal in December with an all-stock offer that was about 15 percent less than what Comcast had put on the table.\n\nRegulatory concerns might have been a reason for Fox to take the lower offer. A tie-up with Comcast would look a lot like AT&T\u2019s $85 billion acquisition of Time Warner, which the Department of Justice sued to block. That said, watchdogs may yet take a dim view of Disney\u2019s plans too. Folding in Fox\u2019s film assets would reduce six large movie-studio players to five. And it\u2019s unclear how regulators will handle Disney\u2019s purchase of Fox\u2019s stake in their jointly owned video-streaming service, Hulu. Comcast, a third partner in Hulu, had to cede influence in the venture for seven years to be able to buy NBCUniversal.\n\nAntitrust concerns may, in any case, be a fig leaf. Fox\u2019s fate depends on what best suits the Murdoch family, which controls 21st Century Fox with nearly 40 percent of the voting shares. It has more chance of making its influence felt at an enlarged Disney than at Comcast, where a dual share structure firmly entrenches the Roberts family. Disney is also considering whether Mr. Murdoch\u2019s son James will have a role in the company.\n\nIf AT&T wins its case, Comcast has every reason to try its own offer again. If AT&T doesn\u2019t, Comcast might go for Fox\u2019s international assets like its European pay-TV operator, Sky. As for Disney, it might want to think about how much more firepower it has at its disposal, in case the Fox bid saga moves into a tense second season.", "title": "Comcast\u2019s Interest in Fox May Force Disney to Raise Its Offer", "authors": ["Jennifer Saba"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "HAMBURG, Germany \u2014 Ask the regulars seated at the sturdy, rectangular tables in the Staff Restaurant Billstedt, the cafeteria for workers in the basement of a municipal building in Hamburg, whether they have a favorite dish. They all give the same answer.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s all good,\u201d insisted nearly a dozen patrons, most of them over 60, packing four rows of five tables each, when asked about their favorite meal on a recent Wednesday.\n\n\u201cYou can get salads, soups, a proper meal and whatever you choose, it is good,\u201d said Karin Ahlf, sitting at a table along the back wall watching patrons arrive, hang up their coats on a row of hooks beside the door and head past the tables for the rack of melamine trays at the counter near the back.", "title": "Come for the Herring, Stay for the Chitchat: An Unlikely Haven for the Aged", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "And yet, as many unemployed Americans discovered the last time recession hit, government benefits that require recipients to hold a job become worthless when there is no work to be had.\n\nConsider what happened the last time around, when the bursting of the housing bubble pushed millions of workers out of their jobs. The Fed quickly slashed interest rates to zero. Months later it started buying billions of dollars\u2019 worth of bonds from financial institutions to lower long-term interest rates and encourage borrowing.\n\nThe Obama administration hurried to cobble together an economic stimulus package of more than $1 trillion to get money to families that needed it most. It expanded the eligibility for unemployment insurance to its longest duration ever, 99 weeks. It raised the earned-income tax credit for low-wage workers. It more than doubled the budget for food stamps \u2014 the poor\u2019s last line of defense.\n\nThe economy failed to snap back as the administration hoped. Unemployment remained at 9 percent or more for over two years. But the administration\u2019s intervention to bolster the nation\u2019s welfare programs made a decisive difference for millions who otherwise would have fallen through the cracks of the nation\u2019s threadbare safety net.\n\nUsing a broad definition of income and poverty that includes the effects of the complete array of government tools to support low-income families, Professors Hoynes and Bitler concluded that food stamps were critical to stem poverty.\n\nHad food stamps not been available, they estimated, the share of Americans under 65 living below the poverty line would have exceeded 11 percent in 2010, almost 1.5 percentage points more than was the case. The share of Americans in extreme poverty \u2014 with less than half the resources of the simply poor \u2014 would have exceeded 4 percent, about a third more than it turned out to be. Unemployment insurance had a roughly similar impact on poverty levels.", "title": "Come the Recession, Don\u2019t Count on That Safety Net", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Either way, Ms. Wolf, 32, has her work cut out for her.\n\nWashington journalists are a notoriously tough crowd; witness the stony silence that met Stephen Colbert after his blistering 2006 monologue about George W. Bush. The comedian Larry Wilmore, who appeared in 2016, prompted controversy when he used a racial slur in his remarks about Barack Obama.\n\nThe coziness of the event \u2014 where reporters hobnob with the politicians they cover \u2014 can be awkward, too, leading some journalists to stifle their laughter, lest they be caught on camera appearing too gleeful at the president\u2019s expense.\n\nBut the dinner can be a proving ground for comics. Hasan Minhaj, last year\u2019s entertainer, received high marks for his balanced performance, coming at the height of tensions between Mr. Trump and the press.\n\nMs. Wolf, who has also written for \u201cLate Night With Seth Meyers,\u201d recently signed a deal with Netflix to develop a weekly late-night talk show of her own. She gained notice last year for an HBO comedy special, \u201cNice Lady,\u201d that Jason Zinoman, the comedy critic for The New York Times, praised for its \u201csilly fart jokes tied to meaty social commentaries that spin out into unexpected personal confessions interrupted by nicely crafted one-liners.\u201d\n\nMargaret Talev, a White House reporter for Bloomberg News who is president of the correspondents\u2019 association, said that Ms. Wolf\u2019s \u201ctruth-to-power style makes her a great friend to the W.H.C.A.\u201d", "title": "Comedian Going to White House Correspondents\u2019 Dinner. What About Trump?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.\n\n\u2018ASIAN GRACEFULLY\u2019 at Magnet Theater (Feb. 9, 7 p.m.). The comedian Woody Fu stages this one-man show that draws on his personal experiences to explore those that are universal. Mr. Fu takes on topics like immigrant hoarders, Chinglish, what video game characters think about and how the straight Asian male is the most marginalized group on Pornhub.\n\n212-244-8824, magnettheater.com\n\n\u2018LAUGHTER IN THE CITY\u2019 at the 53rd Street New York Public Library (Feb. 15, 7 p.m.). Performers call the New York Public Library home for this particular installment of the regular comedy series, promising a cure for seasonal affective disorder. Damien Lemon, a regular on MTV2\u2019s \u201cGuy Code,\u201d headlines, joined by the comedian Michelle Buteau. Baratunde Thurston, a futurist humorist and cultural critic, hosts.\n\nlaughterinthecity.org", "title": "Comedy in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.\n\n\u2018BEAUTIFUL/ANONYMOUS\u2019 at the Bell House (Feb. 7, 8 p.m.). The comedian Chris Gethard, of the eponymous truTV live variety talk show and of \u201cBroad City,\u201d has a podcast wherein strangers call in anonymously and share stories, spill secrets or debate philosophy, and the rule is that Gethard can\u2019t be the one to hang up first. At this taping of the podcast, Gethard, a compassionate listener with an earnest curiosity, will engage with his callers in front of a live audience.\n\n718-643-6510, thebellhouseny.com\n\n\u2018FIFTY/CINCUENTA\u2019 at the Upright Citizens Brigade East Village (Feb. 7, 10:15 p.m.). This improv show is performed in both Spanish and English by a bilingual team. It takes its lead from an interview with an audience member about an experience they\u2019ve had in a Spanish-speaking country or with a Spanish-speaking person, building an improv set around the story. As the event description reads, \u201cEnjoy una noche filled with comedia para everyone!\u201d\n\n212-366-9176, east.ucbtheatre.com\n\n\u2018THE HARD TIMES LIVE\u2019 at Tender Trap (Feb. 2, 8 p.m.). The punk satire website Hard Times, known for headlines like \u201cNobody Sure if Post Rock Band Has Started Playing Yet\u201d and \u201cI Think America Would Be Safer if Every Adult Owned a Cinder Block on a Chain You Swing Around All Crazy,\u201d hosts this stand-up comedy showcase featuring writers for the Hard Times and others.\n\ntendertrapbk.com\n\n\u2018LITERATI: A COMEDY SHOW ABOUT BOOKS AND THE IDIOTS WHO WRITE THEM\u2019 at Caveat (Feb. 2, 9 p.m.). At this monthly event, a cast of comedians reads a selection of literature, real or imagined, in character and sometimes in costume. This time, performers from the Upright Citizens Brigade and Annoyance Theater join the spooky children\u2019s story writer R.L. Stine and the hosts, Colin O\u2019Brien and Michael Wolf.\n\n212-228-2100, caveat.nyc\n\nGEORGE SAUNDERS WITH DANA SPIOTTA at Murmrr (Feb. 6, 7:30 p.m.). This new regular literary and cultural series launches with a reading from the satirist and Man Booker Prize-winning author of \u201cLincoln in the Bardo,\u201d George Saunders, as well as a reading from and conversation with the author Dana Spiotta. Both will be available to sign books following the event.\n\nmurmrr.com\n\n\u2018YELLOW TAPE: A TRUE CRIME TRIVIA SHOW!\u2019 at Q.E.D. (Feb. 7, 9 p.m.). With countless podcasts, television shows and full-length documentaries devoted to the topic of true crime, fans of the genre are finding no shortage of ways to prove their devotion. At this true-crime trivia show, knowledge of unsolved mysteries, serial killers and criminal justice facts \u2014 normally not the kind of topics generally considered appropriate for casual dinner-party fodder \u2014 will serve teams well. A portion of the event\u2019s proceeds will be donated to the Innocence Project, which aims to exonerate those wrongly convicted.\n\n347-451-3873, qedastoria.com", "title": "Comedy in NYC This Week", "authors": ["Kasia Pilat"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "At times, that makes it seem as if he\u2019s doing a spoof, poking fun at the kind of hipster-in-a-bubble character he often lampoons on the IFC series \u201cPortlandia,\u201d currently in its eighth and final season. And there is a knowing wink here. But the more you watch, the more his set comes across as a genuine labor of love, comedy he hopes everyone likes, even though it really just caters to a small segment. And what\u2019s wrong with that?\n\nDrummers laugh, too, and material about them isn\u2019t exactly everywhere. You won\u2019t find any other stand-up special with imitations of Keith Moon, Meg White and Larry Mullen Jr.; or one that pokes fun at the lighting in instructional videos for drummers. And for those who don\u2019t know anything about this world, there is fun to be had observing this clubby atmosphere from the outside.\n\nMr. Armisen has long been a bridge between the comedy and music worlds, after his 11 years on \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d with a job as the bandleader on \u201cLate Night With Seth Meyers.\u201d On \u201cPortlandia,\u201d he has done sketches filled with musicians like one this year about a reunion of aging punk rockers, which starred Henry Rollins, Krist Novoselic (formerly of Nirvana) and the Fugazi drummer Brendan Canty. Some of \u201cStandup for Drummers\u201d operates as an entertaining history lesson, as when he plays a series of drum kits from different decades, describing how the instrument has changed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Armisen is much more seasoned as a sketch performer and actor than a stand-up and it often shows. His setups are repetitive, his transitions awkward and some of the jokes aren\u2019t fully formed. A bit about how he doesn\u2019t like blues isn\u2019t much more than that. \u201cAren\u2019t crazy people crazy?\u201d is a line that should be cut.\n\nBut someone with such diverse talents would be wasted toiling away at a comedy club. Mr. Armisen\u2019s jokes are at their best when they bleed into sketches, when they lean on characters rather than punch lines in his own voice. In one premise, he says that doo-wop was once considered as edgy and angry as heavy metal. Then he puts on some doo-wop music and imagines what a kid from the 1950s getting his mind blown would look like. His performance is all flailing limbs and coiled attitude, evoking a whole type in a few brief flourishes.\n\nIt\u2019s something Mr. Armisen specializes in \u2014 look at his brief appearance as Michael Wolff, the author of \u201cFire and Fury,\u201d on a recent episode of \u201cSaturday Night Live.\u201d The skit captures his devil-may-carelessness in a flip of the hand.\n\nPart of what makes him gifted at these caricatures is his perceptive ear for the eccentric ways people talk, pointing out oddball pieces of rhetoric and habits of speech. He also displays a gift for accents. At one point, he puts up a video of a map of America and goes state by state, demonstrating the accent of every major city in the country. It\u2019s a marvel, and not entirely off point, since local differences are the kind of thing bands on tour know.\n\nIt doesn\u2019t seem like a joke so much as a feat, and yet he\u2019s summing up entire regions with a slight change in intonation or affect. This is fairly subtle work, the kind that also reminds you that we\u2019re living in a big, complex country where even people in neighboring states talk differently.\n\nThere\u2019s something wonderful about the idea of trying to speak to everyone. But in our divided, siloed culture, who really believes that\u2019s possible? Just as politicians play to their base, comedians now find their specific audiences, and because of social media and podcasts, they can communicate with them more directly than ever.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe future of comedy is not in the size of your crowd, but in the depth of its passion. And the connection between performer and fan can be cemented with inside jokes, the shared, exclusive language of close friends. Something is lost in this shift away from monoculture and into aesthetic alcoves, but only the rigidly nostalgic will insist nothing has been gained.", "title": "Comics Select Their Audiences as Carefully as Their Jokes", "authors": ["Jason Zinoman", "On Comedy"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Originally intending to be a modern dancer, Ms. Herlitzius, once she turned her attention to opera, rose through the ranks of provincial German theaters in Wagner and Strauss roles, honing an intuitive sensibility for drama.\n\n\u201cThere was a director who encouraged me and trusted me and gave me some support,\u201d she said in a recent conversation of her earliest professional performance, in tiny Flensburg. \u201cAnd then he let me go.\u201d\n\nWild yet controlled, with her wide-open eyes and fearless voice, her biting articulation of the text, she\u2019s made a powerful impact in the last two decades. Yet \u201cshe was somewhat under the Met\u2019s radar,\u201d Peter Gelb, the company\u2019s general manager, said in an interview.\n\nThen came the director Patrice Ch\u00e9reau\u2019s searing \u201cElektra\u201d at the Aix Festival in France in 2013, with Ms. Herlitzius at its center, persuasively both wounded and wounding.\n\n\u201cIt was one of the greatest performances I\u2019d heard in my life,\u201d Mr. Gelb said. \u201cIt\u2019s what you dream about in terms of a tour de force of acting and singing. She was both terrifying and totally sympathetic.\u201d\n\nThe production was scheduled to come to the Met a few years later, but with Nina Stemme in the title role rather than Ms. Herlitzius. Other singers, better known to New York audiences, have been cast here as Br\u00fcnnhilde, another Herlitzius trademark, which she will sing in June at San Francisco Opera. The Met doesn\u2019t do nearly as much Wagner and Strauss as German houses, so there are far fewer Isoldes and Ortruds to go around.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo, Mr. Gelb said, \u201cI put her into the first thing we could think of\u201d: \u201cParsifal.\u201d He added that Ms. Herlitzius will return to the company as the Nurse in a planned revival of Strauss\u2019s \u201cDie Frau ohne Schatten\u201d in the 2020-21 season.\n\nHer goal, she said, is to draw the audience \u201cinto the scenery and onto the stage, to focus their energy and attention.\u201d That is Ms. Antonacci\u2019s gift, too \u2014 a presence that holds your eyes and ears, whether the mood is rage or quiet calm. Lincoln Center has hosted her a couple of times in recent years, but the recitals next week are being presented by New York City Opera. (She has had discussions with that company about staged productions, she said over coffee at her hotel, but there are no definitive plans, yet.)\n\nMs. Antonacci has never been content to do what\u2019s expected of singers. A smattering of \u201cCarmen\u201d and Cassandre in \u201cLes Troyens\u201d have been among her few forays into the standard repertory, and her plans these days are dominated by delicious rarities like Hindemith\u2019s \u201cSancta Susanna,\u201d Britten\u2019s \u201cGloriana\u201d and Charpentier\u2019s \u201cM\u00e9d\u00e9e.\u201d\n\nPreparing for \u201cGloriana\u201d was one of her aims in the program she will be performing at Zankel Hall with her longtime collaborator, the pianist Donald Sulzen, so she chose Britten\u2019s cycle \u201cOn This Island.\u201d She has made a calling card of Poulenc\u2019s \u201cLa Voix Humaine,\u201d including in New York, and next week adds his \u201cLe Travail du Peintre\u201d and \u201cLa Dame de Monte-Carlo.\u201d And she has long admired the elegant music of Boulanger, better known as one of the 20th century\u2019s great piano and composition teachers.\n\nWe are, in a way, lucky to still have Ms. Antonacci. In an interview six years ago, she claimed to be planning to retire six or seven years hence \u2014 but here she is, still learning new roles and songs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nReminded of that old promise, she laughed: \u201cI always say, yes, in four or five seasons. I have the same thoughts. But then the years pass. I\u2019m blessed with discoveries. I\u2019m still curious about everything.\u201d\n\nComing up for her is \u2014 like Ms. Herlitzius\u2019s first go at the Met \u2014 a highly belated debut at a major house. For Ms. Antonacci, it\u2019s the Vienna State Opera, in \u201cLes Troyens.\u201d\n\nShe said, with a wide smile, \u201cIt\u2019s like starting a new career.\u201d", "title": "Coming Next Week, on Back-to-Back Nights: Operatic Royalty", "authors": ["Zachary Woolfe"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Goode said that he had initially been resistant to the idea of working from film sources because of a \u201ccultural misunderstanding\u201d of the roles of theater and film. \u201cWe think either film is like theater with better special effects, or that theater is made by people who can\u2019t afford a film yet,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd you are setting yourself up for a disappointment one way or another because you can\u2019t re-enact what an audience loves about a film.\u201d\n\nHe added that he was also often skeptical of the motivations for choosing well-known films as sources for the stage. \u201cIt can be a way of hooking an audience who are already familiar with the material, and that can feel like convenience food; too much of the lifting is pre-done.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut \u201cJubilee\u201d \u2014 a dystopian fantasy in which Queen Elizabeth I is transported into a future where nihilist girl-gangs roam a decaying London \u2014 is hardly convenience food.\n\nMr. Goode said he had long been using \u201cJubilee\u201d as \u201can example of what film can show us about theater spaces,\u201d and began to think about transforming it into a stage work as the movie\u2019s 40th anniversary approached. \u201cThere is a literacy to our interactions with film and the screen today, and I think it has made theater artists more able to think critically around how film communicates,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a really different grammar to the novel.\u201d\n\nIn an interview in London, before the premiere of \u201cNetwork\u201d in November, Mr. van Hove said, \u201cI used to be a real film freak when I was young.\u201d And, he added, film scripts often dealt with themes he couldn\u2019t find in theater texts: \u201cVisconti\u2019s \u2018Rocco and his Brothers,\u2019 which I did a few years ago, is a fabulous script about immigration and integration. And I have never found a text as extreme on the subject of death as Bergman\u2019s \u2018Cries and Whispers.\u2019\u201d\n\nAsked why he thought film was such a popular theatrical source now, Mr. van Hove said that theater \u201cis very good at having an open mind.\u201d And perhaps, he added, his example has inspired others to follow suit. \u201cPeople are always predicting the death of theater,\u201d he said, \u201cbut I think it will be one of the most important art forms of this century if it keeps its identity as a live event. You can watch a movie at home now on a screen almost as big as in a cinema, so why leave your home? But live theater, with the engagement between audience and performers, is a different thing.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nChristiane Jatahy, the Brazilian director whose \u201cRules of the Game\u201d offers an update of the storied Renoir film, said in a telephone interview she thought that for the generation now in its 40s and 50s, cinema was a repository of memory and images. \u201cThe difference with books is that when you use this material, it\u2019s not only about the story, but the images the audience have from the film,\u201d she said. \u201cMaybe this challenge provokes ideas about creation, and this is interesting for directors.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Jatahy added that she thought it was important to make cinema itself part of the dramaturgy of her play. \u201cNot just to create images or set, but how to build the story,\u201d she said. \u201cIn the play, Robert, a protagonist in the film, is totally addicted to cameras and films his guests. So he is Renoir in a way.\u201d\n\nOur familiarity with images, the ubiquity of binge-watching, the daily bombardment of clips on social media; all of this perhaps feeds into a hunger for the human-scale thrills of theatrical magic. (Opera too is currently in love with the movies; a spate of new pieces \u2014 Thomas Ad\u00e8s\u2019s \u201cExterminating Angel,\u201d Missy Mazzoli\u2019s \u201cBreaking the Waves\u201d and Nico Muhly\u2019s \u201cMarnie\u201d among them \u2014 show a similar interest in cinematic source material.)\n\n\u201cWhen we watch film, we know everything can be C.G.I.-ed,\u201d said Mr. Beresford, whose adaptation of \u201cFanny and Alexander\u201d is being directed by Max Webster. \u201cIn theater, when you make people fly or disappear, there is a genuine marveling.\u201d\n\nMr. Beresford said he believed that the adaptations of film for the stage reflected the current confidence of the art form. \u201cSome people will tell you that it\u2019s a symptom of an impoverished, commercially driven theater, but I think theater has realized it can be a medium for big spectacle,\u201d he said, pointing to the work of Robert Lepage, Robert Wilson and Matthew Bourne. \u201cThe idea of theater cannibalizing film materials and the language of film is the sign of a confidence, I think. Theater is in a robust state; it\u2019s colonizing.\u201d", "title": "Coming Soon to a Stage Near You: Yesteryear\u2019s Movies", "authors": ["Roslyn Sulcas"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Sarah Blesener spent most of 2016 at Russian patriotic camps and schools photographing teenagers learning military tactics and love of country. She had hoped her images would spark conversations about the polarization and nationalist rhetoric that marked the last United States presidential campaign.\n\nThey did not.\n\nThe overwhelming response from Americans when her photographs were published last year centered on Russian nationalism and the moral dilemmas surrounding militarization of youth. The most common reaction, she said, was that \u201cother people are nationalists, but Americans are patriots.\u201d\n\nWith that in mind, Ms. Blesener, 26, turned to exploring the myriad programs that teach patriotic values and military skills to about 400,000 American children and teenagers. Many were similar to the Russian programs, though she said there was less military training in the United States. She eventually settled on 10 programs, including Utah Patriot Camp, the Border Patrol Explorer program, Young Marines and the Junior R.O.T.C. program.", "title": "Coming of Age Amid Patriotic Training", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTracing how women have been depicted in art history as objects of purity or desire, Diana Al-Hadid will exhibit new architecturally scaled sculptures riffing off timeworn female types at Madison Square Park in New York this May. Titled \u201cDelirious Matter,\u201d the show will be the first major outdoor public art project for Ms. Al-Hadid, a Syrian-born, Brooklyn-based artist, and will open in tandem with the presentation of her monumental 2012 sculpture \u201cNolli\u2019s Orders\u201d at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.\n\nKnown for her organic-looking plaster sculptures that can appear to be simultaneously eroding and growing, Ms. Al-Hadid is making two 14-foot-tall lacy wall fragments framed by hedgerows that create an outdoor room visitors can enter. One wall section is based on Hans Memling\u2019s painting \u201cAllegory of Chastity\u201d (circa 1475), in which a woman with arms folded politely seems bound at the waist by a mountain that also looks like her skirt. The facing segment is modeled on \u201cGradiva,\u201d a Roman bas-relief of a woman in midstride with swirling drapery that was elevated to a figure of fixation through the writings of Wilhelm Jensen and Sigmund Freud.\n\nPhoto\n\nUsing a signature process that she describes as \u201ca blend of fresco and tapestry,\u201d Ms. Al-Hadid painted her interpretations of these figures, which dissolve into drippy abstracted landscapes, using wet polymer gypsum tinted with pigment on her studio wall. Once dry, the material is peeled off and reinforced to make the free-standing walls.\n\n\u201cIf you look back at old masters, you can extract a lot about the role of women, either encased in a giant pile of fabric or lounging horizontally \u2014 dead or fainting or sleeping,\u201d said Ms. Al-Hadid. Three of her life-size headless figures on plinths, sited on smaller lawns around the park, will play off just such a woman in repose.\n\n\u201cDiana is a keen observer of historic works of art,\u201d said Brooke Kamin Rapaport, deputy director and senior curator of Mad. Sq. Art at the Madison Square Park Conservancy. \u201cThese figurative fragments pivot between ruin and regeneration.\u201d", "title": "Coming to Madison Square Park: Drippy Abstractions and Headless Figures", "authors": ["Hilarie M. Sheets"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Republicans framed the committee\u2019s vote on Monday night as a matter of transparency.\n\n\u201cObviously, the Democrats want to tell a side of the story that was different from the side we told,\u201d said Representative K. Michael Conaway of Texas, a senior Republican on the committee. \u201cAnd I think that\u2019s fair to let them have their say in the public arena.\u201d\n\nMr. Nunes\u2019s three-and-a-half-page memo centered on the F.B.I.\u2019s use of material from a former British spy, Christopher Steele, in the warrant application to spy on Mr. Page. Mr. Steele was researching possible connections between Russia\u2019s election interference and Trump associates, but the memo said that the F.B.I. had not disclosed to a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court judge that he was being paid by the Democratic National Committee and lawyers for Hillary Clinton\u2019s presidential campaign.\n\nDespite Mr. Trump\u2019s claims, the Republican memo did nothing to clear him of either collaborating with the Russians or obstructing justice \u2014 the two lines of inquiry being pursued by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III. The memo undermined an effort by some Republicans to cast doubt on the roots of the investigation by confirming that contacts between another former Trump foreign policy adviser, George Papadopoulos, and Russian intermediaries \u2014 not the material from Mr. Steele \u2014 were the primary factor in the opening of the investigation in July 2016.\n\nNevertheless, Democrats have denounced the document as a tactic to undermine the investigation and to protect Mr. Trump, and they have said it is riddled with errors and omissions.\n\nSpecifically, the Democratic memo is said to contend that the F.B.I. was more forthcoming with the surveillance court than Republicans had claimed. People familiar with the Democratic document said that it reveals that while the F.B.I. did not name the Democratic National Committee or Mrs. Clinton\u2019s campaign, the bureau disclosed to the court that the information it had received from Mr. Steele was politically motivated.", "title": "Committee Votes to Release Democratic Rebuttal to G.O.P. Russia Memo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMetLife didn\u2019t shoot anyone, but I just can\u2019t pay them,\u201d Clark Bacon, a research assistant at a children\u2019s hospital, said in an interview Friday morning, after posting about his frustration on the company\u2019s Facebook page. He had pledged to cancel his MetLife auto and home insurance package, for which he spends nearly $9,000 a year, after learning that the company offered N.R.A. members pre-negotiated discounts.\n\nFor companies like MetLife that are caught in the middle of these angry social media storms, actions tied to divisive social issues can be a lose-lose proposition. A year ago, Nordstrom first faced calls for a consumer boycott because it carried the Ivanka Trump line of clothing. But it quickly drew another round of boycott cries from the other side of the ideological spectrum when it quietly stopped selling her products.\n\nMarketing experts say it\u2019s difficult to determine whether calls for boycotts can truly have an impact on a company\u2019s business. Rather, they say, once-angry customers either forget or move on to the next event or debate.\n\n\u201cMemories fade. The intensity of the feelings that people have on this subject right now will feel different one month or five months from now,\u201d said Maurice Schweitzer, a professor of operations, information and decisions at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.\n\nIn the aftermath of nearly all of the mass shootings in the United States, there have been attempts to pressure lawmakers and companies that manufacture or sell guns to change. After the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting in 2012, both the California\u2019s state pension fund and the California teachers pension fund divested their stakes in gun manufacturers.\n\nAnd after a gunman used an accessory called a bump stock in a mass shooting in Las Vegas last October, two retailers, Walmart and the outdoors store Cabela\u2019s, removed the products from their websites.\n\nBut in the days since the Florida school shooting, the push for boycotts and meaningful change has mobilized faster than with previous mass shootings. Professor Schweitzer noted that reflected the fact that the survivors are teenagers who are well versed in the usage and power of social media.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Twitter, the hashtag #stopNRAmazon was a rallying cry aimed at pressuring Amazon to stop streaming content from NRATV, the gun group\u2019s online video channel. The effort quickly drew support from Hollywood as actors like Alyssa Milano, Denis O\u2019Hare, Evan Handler and Misha Collins posted on social media in support of the campaign; several noted that Amazon prohibits the sale of firearms on its e-commerce site.\n\nAmazon did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nLeading retailers including Cabela\u2019s, Walmart and Bass Pro Shops also came under renewed boycott calls on Twitter for selling guns or sponsoring N.R.A. events. The retailers did not respond to emails seeking comment.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStill, in some cases, the rapid assembly on Twitter and Facebook may have resulted in a speedy response. In less than 24 hours, at least eight companies that had offered N.R.A. members discounts or special deals announced plans to separate or end affiliations with the organization, including Hertz, Enterprise and Avis Budget; SimpliSafe, which gave N.R.A. members two months of free home security monitoring; and North American and Allied Van Lines.\n\n\u201cNorth American and Allied Van Lines no longer have an affiliate relationship with the N.R.A. effective immediately,\u2019\u2019 the company said in an emailed statement. \u201cWe have asked them to remove our listing from their benefits site.\u201d\n\nEven companies that do not have ties to the N.R.A. nevertheless rushed to distance themselves from the group. Wyndham Hotels said in a statement that it ended its relationship with the trade group in late 2017. Best Western Hotels & Resorts tweeted to dozens of customers that it \u201cdoes not have an affiliation with and is not a corporate partner\u201d of the N.R.A.\n\nEarlier this week, lists of companies that were part of the N.R.A. membership program began circulating over Facebook and Twitter. A Change.org petition asked 25 companies, including North American Van Lines and the hearing aid company Starkey Hearing Technologies, to break their connection with the N.R.A. The petition had more than 1,100 signatures by midday Friday.\n\nWith lists of companies circulating widely, Facebook users swarmed the profiles of Avis, MetLife and others, announcing their plans to end their patronage and switch to competitors.\n\nRob Bradford, a designer who travels frequently, said Friday morning he would take the $600 he spends each year renting vehicles from Avis to competing rental companies if Avis did not disavow the N.R.A.\n\n\u201cI know that boycotts work, especially in the age of social media,\u201d he said. \u201cI will go out of my way to avoid businesses associated with that group even if that means spending more money.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy Friday afternoon, Avis Budget Group, which owns the car rental companies Avis and Budget, said it had decided to end its discount partnership with the N.R.A., effective on March 26, according to a representative.\n\nLate Thursday, the First National Bank of Omaha, which calls itself the largest privately owned bank holding company in the country, said that it would not renew its contract with the trade group to issue an N.R.A.-branded credit card.\n\nThe card had been advertised as \u201cthe official credit card of the N.R.A.,\u201d and cardholders were offered a $40 credit with their first purchase.\n\nBut the move drew strong, even extreme, reaction on the bank\u2019s Facebook page.\n\n\u201cYou are doing the right thing by dropping the NRA,\u201d one user wrote. \u201cThey are a hate group with blood on their hands. Thank you for walking away from them.\u201d\n\nBut the opposing viewpoint was evident as well. \u201cI discontinued my account with you last night for discontinuing the relationship with the NRA,\u201d another user wrote. \u201cI will encourage all NRA members and gun supporters to do the same. There are 100 million gun owners and 5 million NRA members. Good luck.\u201d", "title": "Companies Cut Ties to the N.R.A., but Find There Is No Neutral Ground", "authors": ["Julie Creswell", "Tiffany Hsu"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Sometimes they walk with their close friends, the family across the street, with whom they started a progressive potluck dinner, where neighbors take turns holding monthly get-togethers of as many as 25 people to raise money for liberal causes. \u201cI couldn\u2019t think of a better group of people to fall in with up here,\u201d Mr. Hershberg said.\n\nEven with all the Rivertowns\u2019 charms, however, some prospective buyers have questioned their vibrancy.\n\nAlison Bernstein, founder of Suburban Jungle Realty, a company that helps those leaving New York find the right suburb, said there is a name brand associated with the Rivertowns, and nearly every couple leaving the city takes a look there. But some are surprised by how tiny the villages are, and how quiet their streets. They see a handful of restaurants in Irvington or Dobbs Ferry, spy a few mom-and-pop shops and wonder aloud if the place is too simple for their urbane tastes. \u201cThey\u2019ll look at us and say, \u2018This is it?\u2019\u201d Ms. Bernstein said.\n\nThat isn\u2019t a problem in Montclair, where there are big-name retailers like Anthropologie, Lululemon, the Gap and Whole Foods. There is also an indie movie theater, as well as numerous coffeehouses and more than one well-stocked independent bookstore. And makeup guru and local resident Bobbi Brown is opening a 32-room boutique hotel, The George Inn, there this month.\n\nLeslie Kunkin, an agent with West of Hudson Realty Group in upper Montclair who has lived in the area since 2000, said that clients choosing between the Rivertowns and Montclair tend to go with Montclair if they are not ready to let go of a city lifestyle. \u201cWherever you are in Montclair, there are always people walking,\u201d Ms. Kunkin said.\n\nPhoto\n\nPaul Molakides, who opened Boro6, a wine bar and restaurant in Hastings-in-Hudson, a year ago, admits that small-town life isn\u2019t for everyone, but he hardly misses having a retail chain store nearby. Mr. Molakides, a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Danny Meyer who trained at Eleven Madison Park, said he can\u2019t go to the grocery store without bumping into a patron, a neighbor or a friend.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut for Mr. Molakides and his wife, Jennifer, there is no better place \u2014 for them, their two children or their restaurant. From the large picture windows across from the village\u2019s hardware store, he can wave to friends strolling by on Warburton Avenue. \u201cWe all came up here with the same mentality: You can take us out of the city, but you can\u2019t take the city out of us,\u201d he said.\n\nIt is these new residents \u2014 with their vision and fresh energy, say local residents \u2014 that is beginning to change the look and feel of the Rivertowns. Dobbs Ferry is getting its first lifestyle boutique, At Land, where kombucha will be on tap alongside $300 wool sweaters. And while there is no movie theater in any of the villages, a new development in Dobbs Ferry along the Saw Mill Parkway, called Rivertowns Square, is catering to an upscale clientele with an iPic cinema, where \u201cfarm to glass\u201d cocktails are served, and an 18,000-square-foot Brooklyn Market that is set to open this year.\n\nSmall-town life has its perks, residents say. Sonya Terjanian, an advertising copywriter and novelist who is working to designate a historic district in Dobbs Ferry, and her husband, Pierre, a curator of arms and armor at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said they will often get a text from another parent saying their sixth grader is headed to the diner or to a friend\u2019s house. Here, parents can give their children more freedom to roam because someone always has an eye on them. \u201cI appreciate that,\u201d Ms. Terjanian said.\n\nBut for buyers looking for something between small-town life and a large urban-suburban township like Montclair, there is a happy medium: SOMA, an area named for Maplewood and neighboring South Orange, which suffers only in that it is perhaps a bit too charming. The thriving row of local businesses along Maplewood Avenue includes a well-stocked bookstore, Words, a well-curated home store, Perch Home, and a movie theater where the name over the marquee \u2014 Maplewood \u2014 is spelled out in art deco letters. The biggest controversy: allowing a Starbucks in town.\n\nJen Simon, 40, a freelance writer, said she and her husband, Matthew Trokenheim, a 45-year-old lawyer, ruled out the Rivertowns quickly when they were living in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. \u201cThey were expensive and felt too much like New England,\u201d she said, adding that they settled on South Orange because \u201cit was just so homey.\u201d They loved Montclair, too, but they were scared off by the size and by the prospect of entering the township\u2019s school lottery system for their two boys, who are now 8 and 5.\n\nMs. Simon and her husband bought a renovated house in 2014 across from the elementary school, where she has met many other liberal-minded mothers; groups of them boarded buses to attend the Women\u2019s March last year. \u201cWhat\u2019s unique about living here,\u201d she said, \u201cis that everyone really wants to be here. They\u2019re excited by social justice, and the people are just cool.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nResidents say that living in Maplewood inspires a commitment to building community \u2014 in the hippest of ways, of course. Locals formed the Maplewood Artist Collective to unite artists and organize events, and two mothers started Maplewood Mercantile, a 2,500-square-foot space offering a selection of vintage home goods, children\u2019s items and jewelry. And many people come together every summer for Maplewoodstock, a two-day outdoor music festival, while others mark their calendars for Rent Party, a live-music series that raises money to fight hunger.\n\nDavid Leibowitz, who moved to Maplewood seven years ago, recently started a Meetup group to find other local parents who \u201cstill go to rock shows.\u201d Within a day, there were 150 responses. Now he and a few previously unacquainted neighbors are forming a band.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Leibowitz, 46,who grew up on the Upper East Side, and his wife, Emily, 43, fell for the antique homes in Maplewood, but living there also made him appreciate that \u201cit\u2019s not a place where everyone is driving a BMW.\u201d\n\nStill, he is baffled that Maplewood has remained more affordable than parts of Westchester, including the Rivertowns. Mr. Leibowitz, who founded PicketFencer, a website that offers profiles of more than 600 suburbs within commuting distance of Manhattan, joked that it is the \u201cJersey stigma discount.\u201d (According to his website, the average home value in Maplewood is $538,000, while in Hastings-on-Hudson it is $725,400.)\n\nFor some people leaving Manhattan, he said, moving to a New York suburb is easier to digest than trading their city identity for a Jersey one: \u201cAs amazing as it is here, some people just can\u2019t do it.\u201d\n\nMary Kate Burke, 41, who moved to a Tudor in Maplewood with her 15-month-old daughter, Maya, and her husband, Shardul Kothari, 46, six months ago, said she worked through her stereotypes of Jersey quickly. \u201cWe found this progressive little pocket where it was diverse and family-oriented,\u201d she said.\n\nThey had been living in Washington Heights, and while the Rivertowns were only a few stops north, they seemed too posh for her family\u2019s tastes. Plus, her husband was working in Hoboken. \u201cThat commute just didn\u2019t make sense,\u201d she said.\n\nShe appreciates the diversity of her new hometown, where it is common to spot rainbow flags hanging from residents\u2019 front porches or to see two fathers pushing a stroller to town. \u201cNothing about Maplewood,\u201d she said, \u201cis cookie cutter.\u201d", "title": "Comparing Suburbs: Montclair in New Jersey vs. Dobbs Ferry in New York", "authors": ["Brooke Lea Foster"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Six weeks after Deborah Zwaschka-Blansfield had the lower half of her left leg amputated, she received some news from the nursing home where she was recovering: Her insurance would no longer pay, and it was time to move on.\n\nThe home wanted to release her to a homeless shelter or pay for a week in a motel.\n\n\u201cThat is not safe for me,\u201d said Ms. Zwaschka-Blansfield, 59, who cannot walk and had hoped to stay in the home, north of Sacramento, until she could do more things for herself \u2014 like getting up if she fell.\n\nHer experience is becoming increasingly common among the 1.4 million nursing home residents across the country. Discharges and evictions have been the top-ranking category of grievances brought to state long-term care ombudsman programs, the ombudsman agencies say.\n\nWhile nursing homes can discharge residents for a limited set of reasons, legal advocates say that home operators sometimes interpret those reasons in unjustified ways. Often, it\u2019s because the residents\u2019 more lucrative Medicare coverage is ending, which is what Ms. Zwaschka-Blansfield said happened in her case.", "title": "Complaints About Nursing Home Evictions Rise, and Regulators Take Note", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "One of the women who protested on the street last week by taking off her scarf, and who requested anonymity out of fear of being arrested, said that the report was helpful, but that it did not go far enough. Women are demanding full freedom, the 28-year-old woman said, adding that the report showed that many people agreed with that view.\n\nThis past week, dozens of women made the same symbolic gesture and shared their actions on social media: taking off their head scarves in public and waving them on a stick. They were emulating a young woman who had climbed onto a utility box on Dec. 27, removed her scarf and was subsequently arrested. Activists say she has since been released, but she still has not resurfaced in public.\n\nThe protests, while small in number, are nevertheless significant as a rare public sign that dissatisfaction with certain Islamic laws governing personal conduct may have reached a tipping point in Iran.\n\nThe first protest in December took place on a Wednesday and seemed connected to the White Wednesday campaign, an initiative by Masih Alinejad, an exiled Iranian journalist and activist living in the United States. Ms. Alinejad has reached out to Iranian women on Persian-language satellite television, through social media and through a website she runs called My Stealthy Freedom. On the website, women post images of themselves without head scarves, demanding an end to the compulsory head scarf law.\n\nThe Islamic head scarf, or hijab, is seen by Iranian ideologues as a pillar of the Islamic Republic of Iran. The law regarding the scarf has been enforced since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, and a head scarf is obligatory for every woman in the country, even tourists and visiting foreign dignitaries.\n\nAlthough women are subject to broader laws on matters like divorce and inheritance, the hijab is a highly public symbol of the rules imposed by Iran\u2019s clerical leaders. Rules are also imposed on men, who are not allowed to wear shorts in public.\n\nMany Iranians now resent such restrictions as the country has grown more secular, and are increasingly flouting them.", "title": "Compulsory Veils? Half of Iranians Say \u2018No\u2019 to Pillar of Revolution", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The test works by measuring the levels of proteins, known as UCH-L1, and GFAP, that are released from the brain into blood and measured within 12 hours of the head injury. Levels of these blood proteins can help predict which patients may have intracranial lesions visible by CT scan, and which won\u2019t. In a statement announcing the approval, the F.D.A. said that the brain trauma indicator was able to predict the presence of intracranial lesions on a CT scan 97.5 percent of the time, and those who did not have such lesions 99.6 percent of the time.\n\nThe possibility of testing an athlete on the sidelines could also be used in all sports, but particularly football, which includes high-speed collisions on every play. While professional and collegiate athletes have access to trainers and doctors, players on high school teams and in youth leagues often make do with a volunteer physician or an emergency medical technician, if at all.\n\nFar more athletes play football at younger ages. More than one million boys play football in high school, about the same as those who play baseball and basketball combined. Many more play football in youth leagues, including Pop Warner, one of the most established organizations.\n\nThese organizations have seen their insurance costs rise in part because parents of injured players have sued them for not doing enough to protect their children.\n\nPutting an athlete with a concussion back on the field can also have grave consequences. A player who suffers a concussion is susceptible to second-impact syndrome, which occurs when the brain swells after a second concussion, but before the first concussion has been diagnosed.\n\nThe F.D.A. approved the test for use in adults, but Henry Nordhoff, chief executive of Banyan Biomarkers, based in San Diego, the company that makes the device, said he thought it might also appeal to physicians evaluating children for concussions. While that would initially be an off-label use, the company plans to soon start a clinical trial evaluating injured children, Mr. Nordhoff said.\n\nThere is also a smaller device for the blood test in the works, which Banyan is working on with the French company bioM\u00e9rieux, and a hand-held one they are developing with Abbott Laboratories. The tests could eventually be used in other countries besides the United States. Worldwide, about 10 million people a year are treated for concussion-related injuries, according to bioM\u00e9rieux.", "title": "Concussions Can Be Detected With New Blood Test Approved by F.D.A.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "But then, at halftime, the Patriots went into the locker room and \u2014 as they always do \u2014 they figured out the opposition. They jiggered the defense; they re-aimed the offense. Suddenly the unstoppable running back Leonard Fournette was on his backside contemplating the heavens. Suddenly the quarterback Blake Bortles, who was having the game of his career in the first half, was transformed back to in the so-so game manager he has always been. And then Brady began to methodically rip the bad guys to shreds.\n\nThe other reason I have so fully embraced the Patriots is their dominance. In the world of sports, I\u2019ve become someone who likes empires. I like dynasties. I like operations that go on being great for a long time. Any team can ring the bell once. But to smack the gong again and again, that is truly something.\n\nMost people resent sports dynasties because they prefer up-and-comers. They pull for the underdog. They want David to beat Goliath. I suspect they do this because they want to think of themselves as upstarts, young and fresh and with a world of promise before them.\n\nBut there comes a time when you have to look at yourself not as an up-and-comer but as someone who has arrived \u2014 at least as far as you are going to. In the same way, there comes a time to embrace teams that have arrived and are proud of it and want to stay at their best.\n\nI had a friend who was once going through some hard times: Kevin, a high-school drinking buddy, a brawler with a saintly heart. Kevin was a die-hard Boston Red Sox fan. They lost and they lost and they lost. (This was many decades before the 2000s.) And Kevin went down and down.\n\nBut then one day in the 1980s, Kevin had a revelation. He looked at himself in the mirror and said: Enough is enough. Starting today, Kevin is a fan of the 22-time world champion New York Yankees. He felt a little better that day \u2014 and then slowly, over time, a little turned into a lot. He got his business together. He made some money. No matter how daunting the goal, Kevin now went for it. Did the switch of his allegiance to the Yankees have something to do with this? I think so.\n\nTo back a winner, you\u2019ve got to be willing to say you aspire to win yourself. You\u2019re not a beginner any more, not an upstart, not a pup. You\u2019ve maybe done a few things right in life and you\u2019re going to try to keep doing things right \u2014 and you\u2019re going to back a team that does the same. You\u2019re going to get behind Yankees baseball and North Carolina college basketball and you\u2019re going to look for a football team that wins and wins and wins.\n\nAnd if that\u2019s what you\u2019re looking for, what choice have you got? You\u2019re going to have to become a New England Patriots fan, too.", "title": "Opinion | Confessions of an Unapologetic Patriots Fan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Maureen Dowd: Donald Trump reminds you of your late pal Don Rickles.\n\nTim Robbins: Not at all. Immigrant rights advocates, losing faith in the legislative process, nervously turned their attention to the courts.\n\nOn Capitol Hill, both Democrats and Republicans said the future of the Dreamers \u2014 young undocumented immigrants who were brought here as children \u2014 may not be settled anytime soon. With Congress gone for a weeklong recess, there is no immediate opportunity for lawmakers to regroup after Thursday\u2019s defeat of three Senate bills, including one backed by President Trump.\n\nIn the House, Republican leaders are trying to corral support for legislation that takes an even harder line than a White House-backed bill in the Senate, which got only 39 votes on Thursday. But the House measure does not yet have enough support to pass, and even if it does, it will almost certainly be dead on arrival in the Senate.\n\nIn the Senate, some lawmakers \u2014 including Senator John Cornyn of Texas, the No. 2 Republican \u2014 have raised the possibility of pairing a simple provision protecting the Dreamers from deportation with funding for the president\u2019s proposed wall at the southern border with Mexico, and slipping that package into a large spending bill that must pass in late March.", "title": "Congress Struggles for Path Forward on Immigration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Some individual shootings have appeared politically motivated, at least in part. He wounded several people, including Representative Steve Scalise, a top Republican lawmaker, though only the gunman died in that shooting.\n\nMs. Tenney made her sweeping claim on the \u201cFocus on the State Capitol\u201d radio program hosted by Fred Dicker.\n\nMs. Tenney said she feared lawful gun owners \u201care going to be targeted now\u201d even though \u201cin their demographic they have the least amount of crimes of virtually any other demographic.\u201d\n\nMr. Dicker jumped in: \u201cBut they tend to be Republican. They tend to be white.
