In addition, the officers filed false reports that allowed some to pilfer vast amounts of overtime, doubling their salaries, and those who were convicted testified to seizing weapons that were subsequently sold on the street \u2014 a cardinal outrage in a city wracked by gun violence.\n\nMonday\u2019s convictions follow guilty pleas by six other officers in connection with the case, and as The Baltimore Sun reported last week, the officers and other witnesses have now implicated a dozen additional colleagues, so more charges could be in the offing.", "title": "Opinion | Corrupt Police Need Federal Oversight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Netanyahu has vehemently denied any wrongdoing and has vowed to fight on, saying that no police recommendation would prompt his resignation.\n\nHis longevity attests to his political agility and to his perfection of a campaigning and governing style in which he casts his political foes and critics as enemies of the broader body politic. Though he has formed previous governing coalitions with those to his left, his current government is often described as the most right-wing and religious in Israel\u2019s history. And he has presided over an increasingly bitter relationship with the Palestinians in the territories Israel has occupied for more than a half-century, whose hopes of soon gaining a state of their own have dwindled as Israeli settlements expand.\n\nBut while Mr. Netanyahu has prepared the public for this moment for months, and made strenuous efforts to discredit those investigating him, he has not prepared Israel or his government for the possibility that he may be unable to continue to lead. He has designated no successor, and no single member of his own coalition has emerged as ready to step into his shoes. Meanwhile, a centrist opposition, led by Yair Lapid of the Yesh Atid party, has been gaining strength.\n\nImage Arnon Mozes, publisher of the popular daily Yediot Aharonot, last year. Credit Reuters\n\nIn a twist straight out of a political thriller, a key witness against Mr. Netanyahu, according to Israeli news reports Tuesday night, turned out to be Mr. Lapid himself, who had been Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s finance minister in a previous coalition.\n\nAccording to a police statement about their recommendations, Mr. Netanyahu promoted the extension of a 10-year tax exemption to expatriate Israelis returning to the country, \u201ca benefit that has great economic value for Milchan,\u201d who has long worked in Hollywood. But the Finance Ministry blocked this legislation, saying it was against the national interest and fiscally unsound.\n\nThe Israeli law enforcement authorities have handled the cases with great caution, wary of the possibility of bringing down a prime minister who might then be proved not guilty in court, not least with Israel facing increasing security threats on its northern and southern frontiers.\n\nBut Israel\u2019s constant state of alert has led some critics to argue all the more that a prime minister so focused on fighting his own legal battles cannot be entrusted with fateful decisions of peace and war.", "title": "Corruption Charges Suggested for Netanyahu", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Man does not live by bread alone, it says in the Bible, and that is certainly true for some politicians accused of corruption. They also live by pasta, meatballs, rice balls, jam, tea and wine, among other comestibles. Food and drink as code words for bribes are hard-wired into the language of many cultures, and several criminal cases of late offer a spicy taste.\n\nA federal corruption trial is underway in New York for Joseph Percoco, a close ally and family friend of Gov. Andrew Cuomo. Among the allegations is that Mr. Percoco, with all the eloquence of Tony Soprano and his associates, referred to bribe money as boxes of \u201cziti.\u201d\n\nIn Pennsylvania, the mayor of Allentown, Ed Pawlowski, is fending off bribery, fraud and conspiracy charges. His federal case turns in part on whether recorded conversations about picking up \u201cmeatballs\u201d meant collecting payoffs or actually getting ready to eat. Then there\u2019s the approaching trial of a Maryland state senator, Nathaniel Oaks, who federal prosecutors say used \u201clollipops\u201d as code for illicit cash in $1,000 bundles.\n\nSounds almost like a meal with a few basic food groups: carbohydrates, protein, fats. It\u2019s the sort of menu that Harendra Singh might have considered for the restaurant he operated on city property in Long Island City, Queens.", "title": "Opinion | Corruption With a Chance of Meatballs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nOn a cold night not long before Thanksgiving, I was on the northbound platform at the Bryant Park subway station. I was pleased to see that the snazzy new countdown clock said that my Jamaica-bound F train would arrive in one minute.\n\nStill on the platform a few minutes later, I noticed that the countdown clock still said the train was due to arrive in one minute. It also said the time was 12:39 p.m. and the temperature was 51 degrees, about 12 hours later (or earlier) and 15 degrees warmer than it actually was.\n\nA man on the platform who spoke little English asked me why the \u201cone minute\u201d promise hadn\u2019t changed for so long. I tried to explain that the clock was entirely fouled up.\n\nSeveral days later I was in the same station, and the countdown clock was still assuring riders that the Jamaica-bound F was only one minute away. I sent a complaint to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority by email. In return, I received a tracking number and an invitation to follow up in 30 days if the problem had not been resolved.\n\nThree weeks later, in time for Christmas, it had been.", "title": "Countdown to Agony", "authors": ["Kenneth Paul", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The couple\u2019s daughter, who lives in the house\u2019s upstairs unit with her family and was inside during the attack, heard the struggle outside and found her parents bleeding, a neighbor said. The woman threw a blanket over a young daughter to muffle her cries as she sprinted to the neighbor\u2019s house and banged on his door.\n\nHer parents had been attacked, she told the neighbor, who gave only his first name, Tony. The neighbor rushed to her home and found Mr. Bonaparte lying outside in the stairwell to the couple\u2019s basement unit. He was alive but had stab wounds about his neck and head. He was unable to speak.\n\n\u201cBloody, like movie bloody,\u201d Tony said. \u201cHe couldn\u2019t talk. I think blood was in his lungs.\u201d\n\nEmergency responders loaded him into an ambulance and rushed him away. The couple\u2019s daughter told Tony that she believed her mother had fought the attacker and may have kept the intruder from reaching her family\u2019s second-floor home.\n\n\u201cGood people, hardworking people, well-respected people,\u201d Tony said of the couple.\n\nHe added that Mr. Bonaparte often dropped his wife off at their home in his car before circling the block for a parking space. \u201cThey were very loving to each other,\u201d Tony said.\n\nMr. Bonaparte owned a religious gift store, King Soloman Religious, on Rutland Road, about two miles from the couple\u2019s home.", "title": "Couple Stabbed to Death in Possible Robbery Outside Brooklyn Home, Police Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNew York State\u2019s highest court has tossed out a murder indictment against a man who sat on Rikers Island for more than six years awaiting trial, ruling the delay was caused by the Manhattan district attorney\u2019s office, which kept him locked up as it struggled to bolster its case against him.\n\nIn its split decision on Thursday, the New York Court of Appeals wrote in unusually pointed language that \u201cincarceration should generally follow conviction, not precede it.\u201d The court\u2019s decision, which cited the defendant\u2019s constitutional right to a speedy trial, was issued less than a month after a federal appeals court in New York vacated a marijuana distribution charge against a man from Cattaraugus, N.Y., who spent seven years in jail and never went to trial.\n\nThe state court\u2019s 4-to-3 ruling came in the case of Reginald Wiggins, who was charged in May 2008 with fatally shooting a 15-year-old boy at a Sweet 16 party on West 90th Street in Manhattan. Mr. Wiggins, who was 16 at the time, was denied bail and was sent to Rikers Island, where he was locked up for years as Manhattan prosecutors tried to get his co-defendant in the shooting, Jamal Armstead, to testify against him.\n\nMr. Armstead had also been charged with murder, accused by the prosecutors of trying to take the first shot at the victim and handing the gun to Mr. Wiggins when it failed to fire. Even though Mr. Armstead \u201crepeatedly indicated through his lawyer that he would never testify against\u201d Mr. Wiggins, the ruling said, prosecutors spent two-and-a-half years \u2014 from January 2009 to June 2011 \u2014 trying to secure his cooperation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn July 2011, the prosecutors decided to pursue their case against Mr. Armstead in a separate trial, hoping, as the court concluded, that if convicted he might testify against Mr. Wiggins in exchange for a lighter sentence. But Mr. Armstead\u2019s prosecution turned out to be a slowly unfolding disaster.", "title": "Court Dismisses Murder Charge Against Man Who Waited Six Years for Trial on Rikers", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is not justice but a joke,\u201d Mr. Sharif said in Lahore during one of several recent, fiery speeches that have been critical of the court.\n\nJustice Nisar, 64, who became chief at the end of 2016, defended the court\u2019s choice of cases.\n\n\u201cWe are being accused of accepting some cases, of being a part of an anti-democracy campaign, but the judges must not come under any pressure,\u201d Justice Nisar said in a speech. The judiciary, he said, should not let \u201canyone suffer from injustice.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Supreme Court and lower courts have responded to speech critical of the judiciary by pursuing a number of contempt citations.\n\nA governing party senator, Nehal Hashmi, was found guilty of contempt-of-court charges this month and sentenced to a month in jail. He had been accused of threatening violence against a panel set up by the Supreme Court to further investigate corruption allegations against Mr. Sharif. \u201cThose who are seeking our accountability, listen with open ears: We will not spare you,\u201d Mr. Hashmi told a party gathering, comments for which he later apologized.\n\nTwo government ministers have also been summoned to appear before the Supreme Court in contempt cases, and lower courts have issued contempt summonses to Mr. Sharif and his daughter and political heir, Maryam Nawaz, because of speeches critical of the judiciary.\n\nSome analysts say the political motives in the clash belong primarily to Mr. Sharif and his allies.\n\n\u201cFrom the moment Sharif was disqualified in July 2017, he has consistently baited the judiciary, knowing that the only route to renewal for him is in successfully tainting the judiciary,\u201d said Mosharraf Zaidi, a political analyst and newspaper columnist. \u201cAnd the only way for the judiciary to be tainted is to demonstrably seem like it has an agenda outside of dispensing justice.\u201d\n\nMr. Sharif and his allies have sought to tie the court\u2019s agenda to the military\u2019s, a link that has historical resonance. Mr. Sharif had long been at odds with the military, asserting that elected officials should take the lead in formulating foreign and security policy. His push for treason proceedings against a former dictator, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who had toppled Mr. Sharif\u2019s previous government in 1999, also rankled the military.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOther analysts fault the court. \u201cThe judicial activism is destroying the image of the judiciary and politicizing it more,\u201d said Matiullah Jan, a journalist and talk-show host who covers the Supreme Court.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt is unfortunate that both army and the judiciary are openly competing with the political government for popularity,\u201d Mr. Jan added. \u201cBoth competitors are trying to derive their authority from the public rather than the Constitution and law.\u201d\n\nThe judiciary in Pakistan has a history of being compliant to the military, giving it constitutional cover for undemocratic acts. But in 2007, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, a maverick, strong-willed chief justice, locked horns with Mr. Musharraf, igniting the grass-roots Lawyers\u2019 Movement that helped lead to his resignation.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Chaudhry left a mixed legacy, though, unable to make lasting reforms and accused of self-aggrandizement. Subsequent chiefs have also failed to make a dent in the problems: The Supreme Court itself has a backlog of more than 38,000 cases, a symptom of a strained national system in which cases can drag on for decades.\n\nCritics say that while Justice Nisar has been quick to take up cases related to the governing party and malfeasance by civilian authorities, he has sidestepped more delicate issues like the intelligence agencies\u2019 practices of enforced disappearances, intimidation and harassment of the military\u2019s critics.\n\nLast month, Justice Nisar decided to re-examine the case of Husain Haqqani, an outspoken critic of the military who failed to return from abroad for a judicial inquiry into charges of improperly seeking American assistance to head off a possible coup. Mr. Haqqani, citing security threats, has refused to return from the United States, which has no extradition treaty with Pakistan.\n\nThe chief justice has, however, shown no sign of pushing for the return of Mr. Musharraf, who fled the country in the middle of his trial on treason charges. (In 2016, Mr. Musharraf acknowledged that a former army chief, Gen. Raheel Sharif, helped to influence the courts so that he could leave the country.)\n\nFor now, it seems that the clashes between the judiciary and Mr. Sharif\u2019s party may only intensify.\n\n\u201cThere is an air of confrontation.\u201d said Ibn Abdur Rehman, 88, a leading human rights defender who suggests the court has overreached at times. \u201cThe judges should not start trying to solve the problems themselves.\u201d\n\nWhen Mr. Rehman appeared to give expert testimony recently before the Supreme Court, Justice Nisar said he wished he could invite the longtime activist to have a cup of tea.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cInstead of an invitation for tea,\u201d Mr. Rehman responded in a low voice, \u201cit is better to provide justice.\u201d", "title": "Court Takes an Activist Role in Pakistan. Not Everyone Sees It as Just.", "authors": ["Salman Masood"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "The Pennsylvania high court\u2019s actions have unfolded in a monthslong challenge to the existing congressional maps begun by the League of Women Voters. The court based its rulings on the State Constitution. The United States Supreme Court typically respects such decisions.\n\nSeparately, the United States Supreme Court is considering two challenges to partisan gerrymandering in Wisconsin and Maryland. Those cases were brought through federal courts, unlike in Pennsylvania. A major decision is expected later this year.\n\nIn drawing its maps \u2014 in part with the advice of a Stanford law professor, Nathaniel Persily, known for his expertise in legislative districting \u2014 the Pennsylvania Supreme Court rejected two competing maps drawn by Republicans and Democrats. The court said that unlike the offerings from partisan mapmakers, the districts it drew \u201cfollow the traditional redistricting criteria of compactness, contiguity, equality of population, and respect for the integrity of political subdivisions.\u201d\n\nThe court\u2019s maps split only 13 counties, compared with 28 counties that are divided under the maps currently in use, which were drawn in 2011 by Republicans in the Legislature. One of the current House districts is so tortured in its shape it earned the nickname \u201cGoofy Kicking Donald Duck.\u201d\n\nGov. Tom Wolf of Pennsylvania, a Democrat, who had exercised his power to veto a map offered by Republican lawmakers, welcomed the districts drawn by the court.\n\n\u201cI applaud the court for their decision and I respect their effort to remedy Pennsylvania\u2019s unfair and unequal congressional elections,\u201d Mr. Wolf said in a statement.\n\nElection law experts said the new map created an equal number of districts favoring Democrats and Republicans. \u201cIt appears to be tilted toward neither political party,\u201d Michael McDonald, an associate professor of political science at the University of Florida, said. \u201cIt looks more like a 9-to-9 division of the state.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDavid Wasserman, the House of Representatives editor of the Cook Political Report, wrote on Twitter that the map had not simply undone the Republican gerrymander. It also took into account the fact that Democrats tend to cluster in cities and college towns, \u201cactively helping Dems compensate for their natural geographic disadvantage.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome Republican incumbents instantly found themselves on shakier ground. Representative Ryan Costello\u2019s Sixth District, which had been Republican-leaning territory in Southeastern Pennsylvania, has morphed into a Democratic-leaning district, Mr. Wasserman wrote.\n\nAnd some open seats, like those currently held by the retiring Republicans Charlie Dent and Patrick Meehan, are now more likely to end up in Democratic hands, Mr. Wasserman said.\n\nThe question now is whether the map, issued in a 4-to-3 opinion that split along partisan lines, will hold.\n\nMr. McDonald, of the University of Florida, said opponents of the map have two potential legal avenues, although he described both as long shots. They could argue that under the Voting Rights Act the new map is unfair to minority candidates, particularly in the Philadelphia area \u2014 an argument that Mr. McDonald said would take a long time to prove, if it were possible at all.\n\nOr, he said, Republicans could challenge the map under the Elections Clause of the United States Constitution, which empowers state legislatures to set the rules for congressional elections.\n\nThis is an argument Republicans already brought to the Supreme Court, which rejected it. Mr. McDonald said challengers could seek to make the same case before a sympathetic federal judge, which would buy them time.\n\n\u201cDelay actually works in the favor of the Republicans,\u201d Mr. McDonald said. \u201cThey might be able to get the map held off till 2020.\u201d\n\nRick Hasen, a professor of law and political science at the University of California at Irvine, was also skeptical that there are plausible legal avenues for Republicans.\n\n\u201cIt is hard to see where Republicans go from here to successfully fight these maps,\u201d Mr. Hasen wrote on his blog.", "title": "Court-Drawn Map in Pennsylvania May Lift Democrats\u2019 House Chances", "authors": ["Trip Gabriel", "Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "ART AND FASHION have always been competitive siblings, bound by a shared DNA. Their kinship betrays natural similarities, a kind of simpatico for which we can forgive their inevitable entanglements: Both are process driven, both aesthetically minded. Both extol an insider\u2019s world, and both, increasingly, are impressed with celebrity and the commercial power that buttresses their existence. Still, fashion is inescapably made for the consumer, whereas art is a form of expression. The two realms have always been associated with each other \u2014 Coco Chanel designed the costumes for the Ballets Russes in 1924 because she was enamored of Diaghilev\u2019s circle and desired a closer association with Picasso, who was a frequent collaborator \u2014 and, depending on your perspective, have a relationship that is either inspiring or exploitative. Designers elevate themselves with art. Museums and institutions can boost attendance if they offer fashion. (125,000 visitors attended the O\u2019Keeffe show.) On occasion, this relationship is charming, even sublime, as with the 1965 color-blocked dress Yves Saint Laurent designed, inspired by Piet Mondrian\u2019s great Modernist paintings. There can exist, too, a chemistry that is unavoidable, as with the mixed-media artist Vanessa Beecroft, who, as her stature rose in the late \u201990s, began to use both professional models and designer clothes in her works. (Her 2002 installation of a nude women army in thigh-high Helmut Lang stiletto boots is an unforgettable image.) Sometimes, though, the relationship is overtly commercial, as with Maria Grazia Chiuri\u2019s recent appropriation of the writings of art historian Linda Nochlin at Dior, in which she presented models in T-shirts emblazoned with the title of Nochlin\u2019s landmark 1971 essay about gender inequality, \u201cWhy Have There Been No Great Women Artists?\u201d (The answer was not offered on the runway.)\n\nBy focusing on what remains from an artist\u2019s life \u2014 her dresses, her earrings, an envelope scrawled with her handwriting \u2014 museums suggest that style is an essential part of her practice. This isn\u2019t exactly wrong. Consider the grim-faced conceptual artist Yayoi Kusama, who wears bright red wigs and muumuus in prints that match her obsessive dot paintings. In 1968, she launched a fashion label, Kusama Fashion Company Ltd., sold at Kusama Corner in Bloomingdales, which was as much a conceptual lampooning of fashion as it was an earnest attempt at commercialism. Her dresses were wildly, hilariously inappropriate, with cutouts where breasts or a bottom would appear. They challenged the sartorial conventions expected of women to be beautiful, sexualized beings. Or consider what the master of color, Sonia Delaunay, once said: \u201cI always changed everything around me \u2026 I made my first white walls so our paintings would look better. I designed my furniture; I have done everything. I have lived my art.\u201d For women artists of an earlier generation, the world was not built to allow them to make art easily, if at all. And on an elemental level, these outfits suggest that creativity is labor. Before Lucien Freud began painting, he would tear a square from a white sheet, tucking it into his waistband like an apron. At the end of the day, he would discard it as a rag. The muumuus, the smocks, the striped shirts \u2014 all are uniforms that express both the artist\u2019s individuality as well as the tedious, cog-like process of producing art every day. But does this interpretation threaten to overshadow the work? There exist philosophies (the Romantics, the Aesthetics) that embrace art as life, and life as art. But when we allow art the privilege of speaking for itself, of being measured on its own terms, are we really only allowing it when it\u2019s made by men?\n\nNot always \u2014 especially as male artists have found a way into the domestic space. Donald Judd\u2019s New York home on Spring Street in Lower Manhattan is now a museum and odd public monument to the artist, seemingly preserved exactly as he left it upon his death in 1994, down to the flatware on the open kitchen shelves. Books that Judd read still line the library, pottery bowls he collected from Southern Italy are displayed around the house, even his fur coat hangs in one of the upstairs closets. He has a spectacular Dan Flavin sculpture that lights up the bedroom, and the most beautiful Frank Stella painting (\u201cGur II,\u201d 1967) that looks as if it were made exactly to Judd\u2019s specifications. These objects hint at his life, his friends. But like his sculptures \u2014 colossal geometric shapes without any sign of the human touch \u2014 the SoHo residence is surprisingly detached from the personal. As with Philip Johnson\u2019s Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., the Judd home is an homage to Minimalism (a term he rejected) and to the kind of art that Judd championed: industrialized, empty, colorful. You circle around Judd, but never find him.", "title": "Couture for Artists, Dead and Alive", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Every few years, with the regularity, if not quite the frequency, of the full-moon cycle, Southwestern style comes back in fashion. The look, which is composed of Native American, Spanish and \u201cAnglo\u201d influences (Spanish colonizers arrived in the American Southwest in the 1500s, and white ranchers and farmers came three centuries later), mixes cowboy boots, bolo ties, bolero hats, concho belts, Western shirts, silver and turquoise jewelry, Navajo prints, suede moccasins and fringe and leather everything. The line between cool and corny, chic and costumed, is treacherously fine.\n\nThe modern iteration of the look has its origins in early 20th-century Taos, N.M., which had become an artist\u2019s mecca that attracted a number of eccentric, independent women who popularized the region\u2019s sartorial customs. Among them was Mabel Dodge Luhan, the Lady Ottoline Morrell of the Southwest, who lived with her Taos Pueblo husband in an adobe house, entertaining guests such as D.H. Lawrence, Aldous Huxley and Georgia O\u2019Keeffe. A 1949 Louise Dahl-Wolfe photo shows Standard Oil heiress Millicent Rogers, an advocate for Native American rights and a collector of Native American art and jewelry, with an armful of silver bracelets, a turquoise necklace as thick as a lei and a long, crinkly-pleat \u201cbroomstick\u201d skirt, which was likely designed by Martha Reed, whose Martha of Taos label and shop was responsible for mainstreaming \u2014 or, well, appropriating \u2014 this classic Navajo style. The look spread beyond the region after World War II, when Americans began to travel cross-country, bringing souvenirs home with them. But it was Dennis Hopper \u2014 he moved to Taos in 1970, and bought the Dodge Luhan property three years later \u2014 who did much to promote the style\u2019s hippie outlaw spirit, wearing a fringe buckskin jacket in \u201cEasy Rider\u201d and a Chimayo vest in \u201cAmerican Dreamer.\u201d\n\nImage From left: Tod\u2019s and Versace spring/summer 2018. Credit Firstview\n\nIn its current incarnation, Southwestern style has been reimagined not by the usual homegrown suspects, like Ralph Lauren, but by European designers: C\u00e9line, Gucci, Chlo\u00e9, Louis Vuitton. On the spring runway, Tod\u2019s showed cowhide prints, clay-colored clothing and white leather moccasin booties. At Versace, regional elements were gilded with Euro glamour: gold belt buckles, gold-trimmed leather and a black Western-style pantsuit edged in gold filigree. The overall vibe was cowgirl meets Aspen divorc\u00e9e. In the design world, too, Southwestern accents, which were everywhere after the 1986 publication of \u201cSanta Fe Style\u201d \u2014 the best-selling Rizzoli coffee table design book \u2014 are once again ubiquitous\n\nSo why now? For one, bright tiles, fringe and Pendleton blankets are well suited to the Instagram era. It may also be that in a time of techno-overload and environmental uncertainty, designers are drawn to the earthy and elemental. And, of course, Europe has long been fascinated with the mythology of the American West (see classic mid-\u201960s Spaghetti Westerns). Finally, if there is a look that evokes an idealized American past, while also nodding to our original resistors and outsiders, it\u2019s this. As O\u2019Keeffe said of the jeans she took to wearing while painting in her Abiqui\u00fa, N.M., studio: \u201cI rather think they are our only national costumes.\u201d", "title": "Cowgirl Meets Aspen Divorc\u00e9e \u2014 on the Runway", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "SATURDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Saturdays (and Fridays) are traditionally themeless and an opportunity for constructors to open up their mental vaults a bit, withdraw and make use of some esoteric entries. Today\u2019s puzzle by Peter Wentz feels as if he cleaned out the bank.\n\nYou may or may not know about xwordinfo.com, an exhaustive resource for puzzle analysis (and vital reference for this column, natch). There is something called the \u201cFreshness Factor\u201d there, and it\u2019s wonderful; it\u2019s an attempt to quantify the uniqueness of the entries of a particular grid, on an algorithmic scale, I know, I know, but bear with me. Everything gets boiled down to a letter grade.\n\nIf you\u2019ve rappelled through the grid today, or come here in search of belaying assistance, I just want you to know that it\u2019s an A, and almost an A+, in terms of \u201cfreshness,\u201d which is in the 94th percentile. In this case, 39 of the puzzle\u2019s 68 words are either debuts, or unusual enough to be against the law in Scrabble (again, I know, but these are the rules). This is a full grade, 10 points, fresher than a normal Saturday.\n\nThis is all really just to say that there\u2019s some wild stuff in this grid. It\u2019s like one of those molecular gastronomy meals that comes in 15 courses and some of them are unrecognizable as food. It\u2019s not you, it\u2019s Mr. Wentz.", "title": "Crack, in a Way", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSUNDAY PUZZLE \u2014 For much of my life I considered the Sunday puzzle a multiday conquest, carrying the magazine around with me and dipping in and out whenever I felt inspired or got stuck on the train. The app came out and I gradually adopted its use for the rest of the week, but Sundays felt unwieldy, and I kept my paper habit. This year I\u2019ve resolved to do the streak \u2014 really do it, every day in 2018, no flaking \u2014 so I\u2019m working these on the phone from now on.\n\nThis is really just to say that I\u2019m an old hand at this game, but I frankly find it uplifting that on most Sundays, today included, I get the charge of discovering another clever verbal gymnastics routine that I never would have thought of myself. Today David Levinson Wilk has crafted a puzzle with a tightly defined theme, and a subtle secondary trick that requires one to recognize a homonym in the title and also do some letter deconstruction in the grid to completely get it.\n\nToday\u2019s Themes\n\nWe have a double whammy today, and the puzzle\u2019s title, \u201cCracking Wise,\u201d quite brilliantly alludes to both. For starters, you probably deduced the appearance of a humorous element, which is always nice, in my opinion \u2014 even when the jokes are corny, are any of us doing the puzzle in search of tragic material? So it\u2019s no surprise that seven across clues, at 23, 31, 50, 67, 86, 100 and 115, all have to do with the art of comedy, the knocking of the funny bone, the ol\u2019 ha ha ha, the wisecrack.\n\nIf you\u2019re so brilliant that you race through this puzzle using only the across entries, and fill in every theme answer without needing a single clue from the vertical crosses, then that\u2019s it for your theme, you poor brainiac (I am seriously doubting there being many of you in this boat). It turns out that there\u2019s a bonus trick in the title and the downs, one that you probably didn\u2019t see until you encountered one of the latter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs an example, let\u2019s take 23A, \u201cStop! You\u2019re killing me!\u201d, which was the first theme answer I figured out, although it wasn\u2019t before I\u2019d passed through the whole grid, popping entries in here and there. I needed several crosses to get to the answer \u2014 THATS HYSTERICAL \u2014 and got a bit stymied by 24D, \u201cPoison ivy, e.g.,\u201d when I\u2019d narrowed it down to the nonsensical \u201cyne.\u201d This is the time when that title\u2019s double meaning made itself apparent. We aren\u2019t just wisecracking, here, we\u2019re \u201ccracking wise\u201d \u2014 or cracking Ys. For what is a Y, really, except a letter I with a V on its head? Crack it apart, and you get VINE at 24D \u2014 perfect.", "title": "Cracking Wise", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Is a System Restore the same as a backup in Windows?\n\nA. While System Restore and backups can both help get your computer back to normal if something goes wrong, the two are different things. (The common technical advice to \u201crestore the system from a backup\u201d can also lead to confusion.)\n\nSystem Restore, which was introduced as a troubleshooting tool back in 2000 with the release of the Windows Millennium Edition (Window ME) operating system, allows users to create and save a \u201crestore point,\u201d or a snapshot of their Windows system files at a certain time. Later, if Windows begins to behave erratically because of a corrupted or damaged system file, you can use the restore point to go back to that moment in time when the computer was working properly.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Windows System Restore software automatically creates restore points each week, and makes fresh ones before installing software (like a system update or drivers for new hardware). As a precaution, you can also create a restore point manually.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the current version of Windows 10, you can do so by telling the Cortana assistant, \u201cOpen System Restore,\u201d or by entering \u201cCreate a restore point\u201d in the Start Menu\u2019s search box. (In earlier versions of Windows, go to the Start Menu to Control Panel, choose System and Security and then System. Click the System Protection link on the left side of the window.) Whichever way you arrive at the System Protection tab of the System Properties box, click the Create button at the bottom to name and save the new restore point.\n\nWhile System Restore is helpful when the Windows system itself is crashing and burning, the utility backs up system files \u2014 and not the documents, photos, music, videos and other content you have added to the computer. To preserve copies of your files ahead of potential catastrophes like accidental deletions or dead hard drives, get an external drive to use with the backup software included with Windows (or to use with a third-party backup program), or find an online backup service you like.", "title": "Creating a Point of Return for Windows", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Despite his longstanding position on law and order, delivered in a rhetorical style that can seem borrowed from \u201cWalker, Texas Ranger,\u201d President Trump in his State of the Union speech called for a reform of our prison system, committing his administration to helping \u201cformer inmates who have served their time get a second chance.\u201d Presumably he wasn\u2019t thinking only of Paul Manafort\u2019s future. Liberals look at the country\u2019s high incarceration rate and see the tragedy of racial animus; many on the right look at it and see the spreadsheet \u2014 another example of wasteful and ineffective government spending. Here there can exist a convergence of goals.\n\nAdvocacy around criminal justice reform in recent years has been increasingly fierce and successful. According to the latest government data, in 2016, the number of prisoners in state and federal correctional facilities fell for the third consecutive year. A movement to end or drastically curtail cash bail, and thus reduce the number of people held in pretrial detention for their inability to pay it, has swept across the country. New Jersey has nearly eliminated it altogether; in New York, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has proposed getting rid of cash bail for people facing misdemeanor and nonviolent felony charges. Even Alaska, which has voted for a Republican in the last eight presidential elections, has reformed bail.\n\nBut the fate of prisoners when they return home remains a confounding problem, apart from the obvious difficulties of getting work. This is largely because of a parole system that replicates and often magnifies the anxieties of poverty, which in many instances served as the catalyst for an engagement with crime in the first place. Too often, former prisoners find themselves incarcerated a second or third time, not because they have done anything particularly wrong or pose a threat to their communities, but because they are found to have violated stringent rules that have little to do with maintaining public well-being. Famously last year the rapper Meek Mill was given a two- to four-year prison sentence for violating his parole, for breaches including popping a wheelie on his motorcycle in a music video.\n\nJust this week a report from Columbia University\u2019s Justice Lab examined the way the issue has played out in New York City. For the four years ending on Jan. 1, the city\u2019s jail population declined by 21 percent, the result of decreases in the number of people held at Rikers Island, for the most part, before their trials begin. During the same period, though, one subgroup of the city\u2019s jail population grew: the number of people held on technical parole violations. That figure increased by 15 percent. Between 2016 and 2017, the average daily population of those in jail for such infractions climbed to 20 percent. As Vincent Schiraldi, co-director of the Justice Lab and a former probation commissioner put it, these are people who most of the time \u201chaven\u2019t even jaywalked or jumped a turnstile.\u201d", "title": "Criminal Justice Reform Empties Cells, Parole Fills Them Up Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "MAL\u00c9, Maldives \u2014 A political crisis in the Maldives deepened early Tuesday morning after a former president and two justices of the Supreme Court were arrested.\n\nThe president, Abdulla Yameen, declared a state of emergency on Monday evening and sent troops to surround the Supreme Court, which had provoked his ire last week when it overturned criminal convictions against nine of the president\u2019s opponents and ordered that those in jail be freed.\n\nSo far, Mr. Yameen has refused to release the political prisoners. And now it appears that he is escalating the standoff, which is worrying tourists, foreign governments and countless Maldivians.\n\nThe Maldives Independent, a news website, reported late Monday that special operations security officers had broken into the court, raising fears that the president\u2019s forces were going to arrest the Supreme Court justices who had holed up in their offices. Several dozen protesters were also converging on the court, and witnesses said the police were trying to chase away the crowd.", "title": "Crisis Consumes a Land of Pretty Islands, as Justices and Ex-Leader Are Arrested", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Berlin Film Festival opened on Thursday with the world premiere of Wes Anderson\u2019s \u201cIsle of Dogs.\u201d The stop-motion animated film follows a pack of mutts, voiced by Edward Norton, Bill Murray and Jeff Goldblum, who are exiled to a trash-strewn Japanese island after an outbreak of canine flu.\n\nThe film is the highest-profile feature in the 10-day festival, known as the Berlinale. Mr. Anderson also opened the 2014 event with \u201cThe Grand Budapest Hotel.\u201d\n\nEarly reviews of the \u201cIsle of Dogs,\u201d which opens in the United States on March 23, celebrated the use of animation in particular. Mr. Anderson\u2019s previous stop-motion film, \u201cFantastic Mr. Fox,\u201d was nominated for the Academy Award for best animated feature in 2010.\n\n\u201cGiven the heightened complexity of Anderson\u2019s cinematic environments, with their whirligig detailing and multitude of moving parts, animation was always a logical sidestep for America\u2019s most artisanal auteur,\u201d wrote Guy Lodge, a film critic at Variety. Mr. Lodge applauded the production designers Adam Stockhausen (who also worked on \u201cThe Grand Budapest Hotel\u201d and \u201cMoonrise Kingdom\u201d) and Paul Harrod, noting that even the garbage \u201clooks handpicked.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDavid Ehrlich, senior film critic at IndieWire, called the movie \u201cnothing if not Anderson\u2019s most imaginative film to date.\u201d Drawing a parallel between the film\u2019s setting and current global events, Mr. Ehrlich wrote that Mr. Anderson is at his best in times of disorder. \u201cAnderson has always been attuned to the beauty of magical idylls, to the violence of losing them, and (most of all) to the fumblingly tragicomic process of building something better from the rubble,\u201d he wrote.", "title": "Critics Lap Up Wes Anderson\u2019s \u2018Isle of Dogs\u2019", "authors": ["Anna Codrea-Rado"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "The interest is a fueled by the rising price of virtual currencies over the last year. But they have created a host of issues that are worthy of study even apart from the price, professors in a variety of fields said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor lawyers, virtual currency projects have challenged traditional legal categories and definitions of what constitutes a security or a commodity.\n\nRegulators have been caught flat-footed as entrepreneurs have raised billions of dollars by selling virtual currencies without going through the traditional fund-raising channels, taking advantage of the legal fuzziness surrounding them.\n\nFor economists and business school professors, Bitcoin and other digital tokens have raised questions about the nature of money. The first lecture in the Berkeley class, for example, considered the development of Bitcoin against the history of money.\n\nSeveral business school classes are also focusing on the decentralized methods of record keeping and decision making introduced by Bitcoin.\n\nBitcoin is given credit for creating the first blockchain, a ledger of transactions that is updated by a network of computers without relying on any central company or government.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany big companies are now looking at how blockchains independent of Bitcoin might be used to do things like track music royalties or cargo containers with input from the many parties involved.\n\n\u201cThe students in my class are from every possible discipline,\u201d said Campbell Harvey, a professor at Duke\u2019s business school, who is teaching a class with 231 students this semester. \u201cThey understand that this is going to disrupt many different areas of business, and they want to be the disrupters, not the disruptees.\u201d\n\nThe computer scientists, meanwhile, are digging into the cryptography that virtual currencies use to secure their wallets and transaction data, as well as the design of the distributed computer networks that make blockchains possible.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLast week, Stanford University hosted a three-day conference on the architecture and security of blockchain software, part of a new cottage industry in academic conferences and journals that have sprung up.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s assume that tomorrow the price of Bitcoin drops down to $2,\u201d said Nicolas Christin, a computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon, who is teaching a course on \u201cCryptocurrencies, Blockchains and Applications\u201d this semester. \u201cI still think it\u2019s very cool from a technical standpoint.\u201d\n\nProfessors and students alike said that aside from the academic possibilities, familiarity with blockchain technology was becoming much more useful on the job market.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe job site Indeed.com has reported a spike in job listings that mention the blockchain, and there is now an entire site, Crypto Jobs List, dedicated to opportunities in the young industry.\n\nVinny Tuminelli, a business school student sitting at the back of the Berkeley class, said that during an internship at Anheuser-Busch last summer, the blockchain had come up in an \u201cinnovation team\u201d he was on. When he met with his supervisor more recently, the topic came up again.\n\n\u201cMy original understanding was that it was just thrown out there as a buzzword,\u201d Mr. Tuminelli said. \u201cBut now it seems like it has some legs behind it, and people are putting real resources toward it.\u201d\n\nStudents appear to have caught on to the opportunity faster than their professors. Berkeley students have created a campus club that offers multiple courses on blockchain technology, taught by the students themselves.\n\nThe director of M.I.T.\u2019s Digital Currency Initiative, Neha Narula, said that when it didn\u2019t schedule a course for this semester, she got constant requests from students. So she put one together and is now co-teaching it.\n\n\u201cStudents are just fascinated with this area,\u201d she said. \u201cThey want to learn about it desperately.\u201d", "title": "Cryptocurrencies Come to Campus", "authors": ["Nathaniel Popper"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Warring between mayors and governors is as natural in New York as jaywalking. But the tough-guy act performed, each in his own way, by Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio is singularly corrosive because the welfare of nearly six million daily subway riders is at stake. It is shocking how little progress on bridging differences has been made since the governor declared a state of emergency seven months ago. It feels like \u201cGroundhog Day,\u201d only far less entertaining, with the same points made over and over.\n\nEach side seeks to bolster its case by hauling out documents so old and long-ignored that they are about as relevant to this emergency as the Dead Sea Scrolls. Each also has a knack for getting under the other\u2019s skin, needlessly so.\n\nMr. de Blasio\u2019s representatives stopped the M.T.A. board from approving, for now, a billion-dollar plan to spruce up 33 subway stations with countdown clocks, better lighting and other amenities. Frills, the mayor implied. Spoken like someone who doesn\u2019t appreciate how tired riders are of stations that look like the ruins of Stalingrad.\n\nFor his part, Mr. Cuomo has elbows sharper than Freddy Krueger fingers, and he keeps swinging them. He proposed creating special tax districts in neighborhoods where property values go up because of new transit projects like the Second Avenue subway. The goal would be to \u201ccapture\u201d increased property tax revenue to benefit the M.T.A.\n\nThe concept is not without merit: If real estate is worth more because a subway is nearby, why not peel off some of the wealth to keep the rails in shape? But in typical fashion, the governor went off on his own, suggesting this without first clueing in the mayor and his aides, who need that same revenue for their own budget. Naturally, they pushed back.\n\nUltimately, it is the governor who bears responsibility for the transit system and its governing board, which for too long sat by while money dribbled wastefully away. That was underlined by a recent Times series showing, for example, how a single mile of new track cost seven times the global average. How do we know Mr. Cuomo is where the buck stops? Because he said so himself, pointing to No. 1 when he asked, \u201cYou know who runs the M.T.A.?\u201d That was at the end of 2016, when he basked in the limelight as the man officially opening brand-new Second Avenue subway stations.", "title": "Opinion | Cuomo and de Blasio: Subway Chaos Is Your Shared Foe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBecause they are so poor and backward, we tend to be somewhat fascinated by any glimpse of North Koreans,\u201d Mr. Lee said. \u201cAnd when they are working so hard you tend to root for them because they are such an underdog in so many ways.\u201d\n\nHow has North Korea performed at past Olympics?\n\nNorth Korean athletes have competed on and off in the Games since 1964, when Han Pil-hwa won the silver medal in the 3,000-meter women\u2019s speedskating race. That was the first of only two medals that North Korea has won at any Winter Games. It did not send any athletes to the 2014 Games in Sochi, Russia.\n\nThe country has fared better at the Summer Olympics, winning a total of 54 medals in judo, weight lifting and gymnastics. At the Rio Games in 2016, North Korean athletes won seven medals.\n\nPhoto\n\nWho are North Korea\u2019s most successful athletes?\n\nNorth Korea has won a total of 16 gold medals. One of the most well-known winners is Hong Un-jong, who captured a gold medal for gymnastics vault at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. She also became an internet sensation after she posed for a selfie with the South Korean gymnast Lee Eun-ju at the Rio Games in 2016.\n\nWhen Kye Sun-hui won gold at the 1996 Atlanta Games, she was the youngest gold medalist ever in judo. She also won a silver medal in 2000 in Sydney, Australia, and a bronze at the 2004 Athens Games.\n\nNorth Korea does well in judo: At the 2012 London Games, An Kum-ae, then 32, was a surprise gold medalist in the women\u2019s 52-kilogram category.\n\nIt is also a weight lifting powerhouse. At the London Games, North Korea won three gold medals. At the Rio Games, North Korean weight lifters took home four medals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNorth Korea\u2019s women\u2019s soccer team is ranked 11th in the world, although the team was banned from the World Cup in 2015 after five players tested positive for steroids.\n\nWasn\u2019t Kim Jong-il said to be an amazing athlete?\n\nAccording to the state-controlled media in North Korea, Kim Jong-il, father of the current leader, Kim Jong-un, was such a naturally gifted sportsman that he bowled a perfect 300 on his first outing at Pyongyang Lanes in the North Korean capital and somehow shot five holes-in-one to come in 38-under par the first time he played golf. Who knows what he could have accomplished had he competed internationally in judo or weight lifting.\n\nAt international competitions, victorious North Korean athletes must say they owe their success to their leader and country.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat do we know about the North Korean athletic program?\n\nAnalysts who study North Korea say athletes are typically recruited as young children whose talent is spotted on the schoolyard. They are likely to be groomed similarly to athletes in other communist regimes such as China or the former Soviet Union. The military, the police and some factories also sponsor their own sports teams.\n\nBecause North Korea is such a poor country, its state sports system is probably underfunded compared with China or Russia, whose athletes have been accused of doping. (Russia has been nominally barred from Pyeongchang because of an elaborate state-run doping scheme.) When players on North Korea\u2019s women\u2019s soccer team tested positive for steroids in 2015, officials blamed traditional Chinese medicines made from musk deer glands given to players who had been struck by lightning.\n\nIn North Korea\u2019s sports program, family loyalty may be as important as athletic ability, said Toshimitsu Shigemura, a professor at Waseda University in Tokyo and an expert on North Korea\u2019s leadership.\n\nMr. Shigemura said that athletes tend to come from families that hew closely to state ideology and have good connections.\n\nThe regime also focuses on sports where it believes its athletes can excel internationally, including wrestling, martial arts and soccer.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDo the athletes get special treatment?\n\nAdmission to the elite level of sports is probably a way for athletes and their families \u201cto secure a decent lifestyle in North Korea,\u201d said Christopher Green, a North Korea analyst in Seoul, South Korea.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn Yong-hak, a Japanese-born ethnic Korean who played for North Korea\u2019s national men\u2019s soccer team between 2002 and 2012, said that when he practiced with the team in Pyongyang, \u201cthere was always meat, fish, rice, soup, vegetables and plenty of food.\u201d In a country where hunger is still common, such square meals would be a privilege of team membership.\n\nThose who bring glory to the regime may even be rewarded with cars or houses, but those prizes are probably very limited, said Hwangbo Young, 38, a former North Korean women\u2019s ice hockey player who defected to South Korea in 1997.\n\n\u201cThese cases are rare,\u201d said Ms. Hwangbo, \u201cand limited only to gold medalists of major international events like the Olympics or the World Cup games.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIf they don\u2019t do well, are they punished?\n\nRumors abound that athletes who fail to win in international competitions are exiled to coal mines or gulags, but there is little evidence of that.\n\nEven after teams underperform, their players reappear at subsequent international competitions, said Udo Merkel, a senior lecturer at the University of Brighton, where he specializes in sports sociology. \u201cSo I don\u2019t believe some of the stories that they are locked up in jail,\u201d Mr. Merkel said, \u201cbecause half a year later when they play the next qualifying match, you see the same names and players.\u201d\n\nIn 2010, for example, the North Korean men\u2019s soccer team lost, 7-0, to Portugal at the World Cup in South Africa \u2014 a game that was reportedly broadcast live in Pyongyang. According to Mr. An, the goalkeeper who allowed those seven goals is still on the team. There were reports, however, that the team was subjected to a public criticism session in Pyongyang that lasted six hours.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow can North Korea afford a sports program?\n\nSoon after Mr. Kim took over leadership of the country nearly six years ago, he \u201creally began to put money and political energy and time into developing an internationally competitive athletic prowess,\u201d said Katharine H. S. Moon, a professor of political science at Wellesley College.\n\nAccording to an analysis of North Korea\u2019s national budget announcements by Curtis Melvin, a senior fellow in the U.S.-Korea Institute at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, Mr. Kim has invested steadily in sports, giving it about 6 percent of the country\u2019s budget last year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince 2012, North Korea has built a new rink for ice and roller skating, soccer academies and a horseback riding club. It also renovated a large stadium in Pyongyang with volleyball, table tennis and basketball courts (the American basketball player Dennis Rodman famously crooned \u201cHappy Birthday\u201d to Mr. Kim in that stadium during a 2014 visit).\n\nJean H. Lee, a former Associated Press bureau chief in Pyongyang and now a global fellow at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington, said that when she visited the new skating rink in 2012, it was \u201cstate of the art and perfectly maintained.\u201d She said she saw Canadian and European-made ice resurfacers as well as high-end figure and hockey skates, suggesting that the regime had figured out how to skirt sanctions on luxury goods.\n\nMr. Kim also built the Masikryong Ski Resort, where some South Korean athletes practiced with their North Korean counterparts last week.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow much do the athletes get to see of the countries they visit?\n\nWhen the North Korean figure skating pair of Ms. Ryom and Mr. Kim trained over the summer in Montreal with the French Canadian coach Bruno Marcotte, they were taken shopping by Mr. Marcotte\u2019s wife, Meagan Duhamel, a champion figure skater.\n\nThe 12 North Korean women\u2019s ice hockey players who have been added to the roster of the South Korean team are probably getting glimpses of the comparative wealth of their South Korean teammates.\n\nCaroline Park, 28, a Canadian-born team member, said that when she and her teammates practiced with the North Koreans late last month, they ate together every day. Ms. Park said she noticed the North Koreans did not have cellphones.\n\nAnd even further afield, Han Kwang-song, a player for the North Korean national soccer team, is currently on loan to a professional team in Perugia, Italy. There, he is also getting a taste of social media: He has a private Instagram account, @han.k.s.32.\n\nHave any North Korean athletes ever defected?\n\nNo North Korean athletes have defected during the Olympics, although one defected in 1991 during a world judo championship in Spain. Ms. Hwangbo, the hockey player, defected to South Korea through China with her family in 1997.\n\nThe athletes are carefully screened before being allowed to participate in international events. Even if they wanted to defect, they will be closely watched by North Korean minders. In Pyeongchang, South Korean security forces will also be watching, as neither side will want the publicity of a defection undercutting the message of unity between the two Koreas. Even the women\u2019s ice hockey players are not staying in the same dorm as their South Korean teammates.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat is more, said Benjamin Young, a Ph.D. candidate at George Washington University who has written about the North Korean athletic program, the athletes \u201chave families in the North, and they are the most loyal and treated very well by the regime.\u201d", "title": "Curious About the Lives of North Korea\u2019s Isolated Athletes? Here\u2019s a Glimpse", "authors": ["Motoko Rich"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGANGNEUNG, South Korea \u2014 John Morris and Kaitlyn Lawes of Canada arrived here for the 2018 Winter Olympics as new curling partners. They had been at it for about a month, having teamed up just before the Canadian mixed doubles trials in January. They made it through that meat grinder, then arrived in South Korea hoping for gold.\n\nMorris and Lawes delivered for Canada on Tuesday, rolling to a 10-3 victory for a gold medal over Martin Rios and Jenny Perret of Switzerland. The Canadians were so dominant that the Swiss pairing conceded the match after six ends. Matches in mixed doubles are slated for eight ends.\n\n\u201cI think the experience we had this year is something we\u2019ll cherish for the rest of our lives,\u201d Morris said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMixed doubles was a new event at the Olympics \u2014 the International Olympic Committee voted to add it to the Pyeongchang Games in 2015 \u2014 but when the sport involves ice, brooms and granite rocks, Canada just seems to have a knack for it. Since four-person curling made its Olympic debut in 1998, Canada has never gone without a medal in any event.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMorris and Lawes, already gold medalists in team events for Canada at past Olympics, ensured that the trend continued.", "title": "Curling Mixed Doubles: Canada Easily Beats Switzerland for Gold", "authors": ["Scott Cacciola"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis attacker had no intention of leaving the machine usable,\u201d a team of researchers at Cisco\u2019s Talos threat intelligence division wrote in an analysis Monday. \u201cThe purpose of this malware is to perform destruction of the host\u201d and \u201cleave the computer system offline.\u201d\n\nIn an interview, Talos researchers noted that there was a nuance to the attack that they had not seen before: Even though the hackers clearly demonstrated that they had the ability to destroy victims\u2019 computers, they stopped short of doing so. They erased only backup files on Windows machines and left open the possibility that responders could still reboot the computers and fix the damage.\n\n\u201cWhy did they pull their punch?\u201d asked Craig Williams, a senior technical leader at Talos. \u201cPresumably, it\u2019s making some political message\u201d that they could have done far worse, he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTalos\u2019s findings matched those of other internet security companies, like CrowdStrike, which determined on Monday that the attacks had been in the works since at least December. Adam Meyers, vice president of intelligence at CrowdStrike, said his team had discovered time stamps that showed the destructive payload that hit the opening ceremony was constructed on Dec. 27 at 11:39 a.m. Coordinated Universal Time \u2014 which converts to 6:39 a.m. Eastern Time, 2:39 p.m. in Moscow and 8:39 p.m. in South Korea.\n\nAttackers clearly had a target in mind: The word Pyeongchang2018.com was hard-coded into their payload, as was a set of stolen credentials belonging to Pyeongchang Olympic officials. Those stolen credentials allowed attackers to spread their malware throughout the computer networks that support the Winter Games on Friday, just as the opening ceremony was timed to begin.\n\nSecurity companies would not say definitively who was behind the attack, but some digital crumbs led to a familiar culprit: Fancy Bear, the Russian hacking group with ties to Russian intelligence services. Fancy Bear was determined to be the more brazen of the two Russian hacking groups behind an attack on the Democratic National Committee ahead of the 2016 presidential election.\n\nBeginning in November, CrowdStrike\u2019s intelligence team witnessed Fancy Bear attacks that stole credentials from an international sports organization, Mr. Meyers said. He declined to identify the victim but suggested that the credential thefts were similar to the ones that hackers would have needed before their opening ceremony attack.\n\nOn Wednesday, two days before the ceremony, the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs made an apparent attempt to pre-empt any accusations of Russian cyberattacks on the Games. In a statement, released in English, German and Russian, the agency accused Western governments, press and information security companies of waging an \u201cinformation war\u201d accusing Russia of \u201calleged cyber interference\u201d and \u201cplanning to attack the ideals of the Olympic movement.\u201d\n\nThis was not the first Olympic opening ceremony that was a target for hackers. In the lead-up to the 2012 London Games, investigators uncovered attack tools and the blueprints to the Olympic stadium\u2019s building management systems on a hacker\u2019s computer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt appeared that hackers planned to take out the power to the stadium, said Oliver Hoare, who led cybersecurity matters for the London Games. But officials successfully prevented an attack.", "title": "Cyberattack Caused Olympic Opening Ceremony Disruption", "authors": ["Nicole Perlroth"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "The advice that she gave readers of The Village Voice and Playboy magazine was practical and bawdy \u2014 refined through the sharply profane voice of a woman seeking a good man, a bad boy or a great fling.\n\nIn \u201cSex Tips for Girls\u201d (1983), a collection largely of her Voice columns, she avoided the dry prose of clinical manuals that had turned her off to sex. \u201cI was thinking, \u2018O.K., I have to write cleanly,\u2019 and so I made it all jaunty and cheerful and made sure not to be slimy or weird and not salacious,\u201d she told Salon in 2002. \u201cIt was sort of like nursery school writing.\u201d\n\nSort of.\n\nShe advised women against engaging in taboo behavior when naked with men. Do not, she counseled, \u201claugh and point at the penile member,\u201d \u201csay that your husband did it exactly the same way,\u201d or \u201cimitate Joan Rivers.\u201d\n\nAnd she reminded her readers: \u201cSex is a perverse little devil and the minute you ignore it, it has a serious temper tantrum and tries every trick in the book to get you to notice. It clamors for your attention until it gets it, at which point it disappears.\u201d\n\nShe adapted \u201cSex Tips\u201d and \u201cBut Enough About You,\u201d a 1986 collection, into a play, \u201cA Girl\u2019s Guide to Chaos,\u201d which opened later that year off Broadway at the American Place Theater. The play is largely a conversation among four friends, one of whom, Cynthia (played by Debra Jo Rupp in the original production) realizes to her horror that she will have to start dating again.\n\n\u201cPlease, God, no, don\u2019t make me do it!\u201d she says. \u201cI\u2019ll be good from now on, I promise! I\u2019ll stop feeding the dog hashish! I\u2019ll be kind, thoughtful, sober, industrious, anything. But please, God, not the ultimate torture of dating!\u201d\n\nIn his review in The New York Times, Stephen Holden wrote, \u201cLike Dorothy Parker, Ms. Heimel is an urban romantic with a scathing X-ray vision that penetrates her most deeply cherished fantasies.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe play ran in several cities, including Chicago and Los Angeles.\n\nMs. Heimel published several more collections with evocative titles like \u201cIf You Can\u2019t Live Without Me, Why Aren\u2019t You Dead Yet?\u201d (1991) and \u201cGet Your Tongue Out of My Mouth, I\u2019m Kissing You Goodbye!\u201d (1993). Some of the material was derived from her column at Playboy, where she tried to explain women to the magazine\u2019s largely male readership.\n\n\u201cShe was in the missionary position at Playboy,\u201d she wrote of herself on the community discussion website The Well, \u201cholding high her feminist credentials amongst the stampeding bunnies.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a Times review of Ms. Heimel\u2019s book \u201cIf You Leave Me, Can I Come Too?\u201d (1995), Sarah Ferrell observed that Ms. Heimel \u201cwrites about the same things over and over and over,\u201d and so she wondered rhetorically if it was worth reading her latest collection. Yes, it was, she wrote.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s simple,\u201d she added. \u201cShe gets funnier, meaner and possibly even smarter, every time around.\u201d\n\nCynthia Joan Glick was born in Philadelphia on July 13, 1947, and grew up nearby in Overbrook Park and Cheltenham, Pa. Her father, Bernard, was a pharmacist and pharmaceutical salesman; her mother, the former Lynne Danan, was a secretary at the Temple University School of Medicine.\n\nAfter high school, Ms. Heimel told The Los Angeles Times in 1990, she left home, lived with hippies in Philadelphia for a time and then moved to Manhattan.\n\n\u201cShe just really wanted to get out of the house and leave my parents,\u201d Donna Evans, her sister, said in a telephone interview.\n\nMs. Heimel was not earning much when she moved to New York City and then, as a divorced mother, she started receiving welfare payments. (She kept the name Heimel from her first marriage.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the foreword to one of her books, her son, Mr. Ransom (who does not use the last name Heimel), wrote, \u201cWe stood on long lines, anxiously awaiting a fierce battle with a city employee over money for such luxuries as, oh, I don\u2019t know, food.\u201d\n\nHer path to a writing career began with a job as a paste-up artist in the advertising department of The Soho Weekly News in Manhattan. She then moved to paste-up on the editorial side and began pitching stories. Her first was about an anarchists\u2019 convention.\n\nShe learned to write by reading. \u201cShe was always reading something,\u201d Michael Longacre, a former creative director and managing editor of the paper, said in a telephone interview. \u201cShe was completely devoted to P. G. Wodehouse.\u201d\n\nShe wrote and edited at The Soho Weekly News, left briefly to work at Penthouse magazine, returned to the paper for a while and was then hired by The Voice. Her humorous advice column there was called \u201cProblem Lady.\u201d She also wrote a fashion column.\n\nWhen an incoming Village Voice editor fired her in 1997 \u2014 he called her writing \u201cpredictable\u201d before dismissing her \u2014 she told The New York Post, \u201cI feel like I\u2019ve walked into a Kafka novel where old stupid guys get to fire you.\u201d\n\nShe also wrote for New York magazine, The Daily News and Vogue.\n\nMs. Heimel moved to Los Angeles in the early 1990s and worked for one season on the writing staff of \u201cDear John,\u201d a sitcom that starred Judd Hirsch.\n\nIn addition to her son and her sister, she is survived by four grandchildren. Her marriages to Steven Heimel and Abe Opincar ended in divorce.\n\nReflecting in the mid-1990s about the backlash against feminism by both men and women, she wrote that each sex had to compromise.\n\nTo men, she wrote, \u201cThere must be no complaints when dinner is late or nonexistent, if dark roots show and the occasional leg is unwaxed.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo women, she said: \u201cWomen must stop wheedling and manipulating their men when they want a new sofa. We may not pout and toss our curls like little girls who need Daddy\u2019s permission or use sex as a power tool; we must be prepared to shoulder equal burdens or sacrifice all rights to equal opportunities.\u201d", "title": "Cynthia Heimel, Irreverent Writer About Sex, Dies at 70", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "A court in the Czech Republic ordered the release of a senior Kurdish official on Tuesday, despite an extradition request from Turkey, which wanted to try him as a terrorist, according to the official\u2019s lawyer and the Czech News Agency.\n\nThe official, Salih Muslim, the foreign affairs spokesman for the Movement for a Democratic Society, the political coalition that governs the Kurdish regions of northern Syria, was arrested in Prague early Sunday, at the conclusion of a high-level security conference to which he was invited by the Czech and American governments.\n\nTurkey has charged him with involvement in terrorist incidents in Turkey, and last month offered a $1 million reward for his arrest, as one of its most-wanted terrorism suspects. That coincided with Mr. Muslim\u2019s barnstorming around Europe over the past month, speaking out against Turkey\u2019s offensive against the Kurdish-held enclave of Afrin in northern Syria.\n\nIn televised remarks, Bekir Bozdag, a spokesman for the Turkish government, denounced Mr. Muslim\u2019s release as a political act. \u201cThis decision clearly means to support terror groups,\u201d he said. \u201cThis decision will also have an effect of negatively influencing Turkish-Czech relations.\u201d", "title": "Czechs Release Top Kurdish Official Despite Turkish Extradition Request", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "The sudden departure of Mr. Wilson, 45, who held the chancellor\u2019s position for only a year, delivered the latest setback to an urban school district at the center of the so-called education reform movement in the country. Mr. Wilson won praise, as well as riled many parents, at his last school district, the Oakland Unified School District in California, and was hailed when he was chosen to lead the District of Columbia schools.\n\nBut whatever good will Mr. Wilson had secured in the past year evaporated almost in an instant last week. That\u2019s when Ms. Bowser said the District of Columbia inspector general\u2019s office informed her that it was investigating whether Mr. Wilson violated district policy when his daughter recently bypassed about 700 students on a wait-list to enroll at Woodrow Wilson High School.\n\nMr. Wilson came under swift criticism after the investigation was made public last week. By the end of the week, a handful of public officials, including council members, said he had lost their support and needed to step aside. And on Friday, a top school district official, who had assisted the chancellor\u2019s transfer request for his daughter, resigned.\n\nAs pressure mounted over the weekend, Mr. Wilson spoke publicly on Monday about why he had his daughter moved from a school near their home to Wilson High, which has one of the highest graduation rates in the district.\n\n\u201cMy daughter was struggling socially and emotionally, engaging in behavior we had never seen before, certainly affecting her health,\u201d he told WTTG-TV, the Fox affiliate in Washington. \u201cI made the wrong decision in terms of how to go about it.\u201d\n\nWith Mr. Wilson\u2019s departure, Ms. Bowser will begin the search for the district\u2019s fourth chancellor in the past decade. In the meantime, she said, she has named Amanda Alexander, who had been overseeing elementary schools, as the interim chancellor.", "title": "D.C. Schools Chancellor Resigns Amid Outcry Over Daughter\u2019s School Transfer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "DC Entertainment, the home of Batman, Superman, Wonder Woman and a legion of other heroes, is planning two new graphic novel imprints aimed at younger readers. DC Zoom will feature stories for middle school readers, and DC Ink will focus on young adults. Books from the two divisions are scheduled to come out in the fall.\n\n\u201cWe wanted to go back to what we used to have in comic books: story arcs for younger readers,\u201d said Bobbie Chase, a vice president at DC and the executive editor for the new imprints.\n\nThough a few of the graphic novels will have creators who are already working in the comic book industry, the majority of the writers are a Who\u2019s Who of popular novelists for young readers.
