Then she turned to her grandmother, sitting nearby, and pointing at a bright green shearling said, \u201cD.V.F.\u201d \u2014 she calls her grandmother by her initials \u2014 \u201cthat would look good on you.\u201d\n\nMr. Jenden agreed.\n\nThis is actually his second tour with the brand. He was its creative director from 2001 to 2011 (Diane von Furstenberg is his daughter\u2019s godmother), and his return to the brand is one that he and she both characterize as a kind of \u201ccoming home.\u201d\n\nIndeed, there\u2019s history between the three: He and Talita worked together when she was nine years old and accompanied her grandmother to Florence for a DVF guest show at Pitti Uomo. He has watched her grow up. \u201cI\u2019ve known him all my life,\u201d she said.\n\nSo when Mr. Jenden came back and had to get a collection together in a hurry \u2014 \u201che plunged right in at the deep end,\u201d the elder Ms. von Furstenberg said, holding her nose to demonstrate a big leap \u2014 he said he had two women in mind: the grandmother and the granddaughter.", "title": "DVF Keeps it All in the Family", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Dai: Did you see any coasters for the HomePods or people walking into glass?\n\nJack: The meeting was off the record.\n\nDon\u2019t Believe What You See on the Internet\n\nJack: Well, another week, and another example of the big tech platforms promoting misleading or downright false information. On Wednesday morning, YouTube\u2019s No. 1 trending video was a clip that seemed to push a conspiracy theory that some survivors of the Parkland, Fla., school shooting who have called for stricter gun control are actually paid actors. The video, of a TV news broadcast that included Parkland student David Hogg, carried the description: \u201cDAVID HOGG THE ACTOR\u2026.\u201d\n\nDai: It\u2019s repugnant that anyone would keep pushing these conspiracy theories about kids who have already suffered so much, but this video was a little tricky. It was a video of a legitimate news story involving the student. It wasn\u2019t a false or doctored video, and the content itself didn\u2019t push a conspiracy. However, the title on the video framed this otherwise innocuous video as evidence of a broader conspiracy. Even the description isn\u2019t obviously inflammatory unless you understand the context of why this student is being called an actor. Man, YouTube can\u2019t bring on those 10,000 human checkers fast enough.\n\nYouTube took down the video before I had my morning coffee in California, but only after it attracted more than 200,000 views. YouTube said it has been trying to make changes so things like this don\u2019t happen, but \u201cin some circumstances these changes are not working quickly enough.\u201d\n\nJack: This example also highlights another issue with YouTube: Its video recommendations can push people to misleading videos and conspiracy theories. YouTube\u2019s video-recommendation engine is engineered to keep you on the site. It\u2019s pretty darn good at it. YouTube said recommendations fueled a 10-fold increase in use of the site from 2012 to 2016, to more than 1 billion hours a day.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter I finished watching the trending two-minute David Hogg video on Wednesday, YouTube immediately began playing a new recommended video: a clip of Mr. Hogg speaking to reporters with the title, \u201cDavid Hogg Can\u2019t Remember His Lines When Interviewed for Florida School Shooting.\u201d YouTube\u2019s recommendation algorithm seeks out videos that are drawing traffic, and company engineers admit that approach can tend to reward sensational and salacious videos.\n\nYouTube can also contribute to so-called filter bubbles by feeding you videos with perspectives similar to those in videos you already watched. That also means its recommendations can be an embarrassing window into your psyche. I mean, I wouldn\u2019t want to reveal my recommendations to thousands of readers, like clips from comically bad movies or 1990s pro wrestling.\n\nDai: Maybe that \u201890s wrestling knowledge will be useful when President Rock is in the White House.\n\nIssues at Facebook and Twitter, Too\n\nJack: It wasn\u2019t just YouTube that spread false information about the shooting. There were also Facebook posts claiming survivors were so-called crisis actors, which were shared thousands of times. And your reporting with Sheera Frenkel this week showed that Twitter accounts suspected to be Russian bots mobilized to tweet about the Parkland school shooting shortly after it happened, often pushing both sides of the gun-control debate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDai: The sad reality is that whenever these tragic events take place in the near future, it\u2019s going to be a test for these platforms to see how they weather the deluge of conspiratorial and false stories. It\u2019s gotten to the point where the first instinct for tech reporters is to search for key phrases on Google, YouTube, Facebook and Twitter. Much of the time, the results are disappointing.\n\nJack: Meantime, the executives that run these sites have been slow to acknowledge the severity of the problem. After federal prosecutors last week indicted 13 Russians and three companies for spreading misinformation online in an attempt to subvert the 2016 election, Facebook\u2019s vice president for advertising, Rob Goldman, posted a series of tweets that downplayed their impact.\n\nDai: Of course, he walked it back after President Trump amplified the comments to his followers, saying this was evidence that there was no collusion between his campaign and the Russians. Kevin Roose\u2019s column on this really brought it home. Those tweets from Mr. Goldman made it look like the company\u2019s P.R. strategy calls for prominent executives not named Zuckerberg to defend Facebook aggressively on social media \u2014 and it backfired in a major way.\n\nJack: Before we sign off, can I pass along this additional bit of good news about the internet? Twitter and Facebook are rife with impostor accounts, and \u2014 stop me if you\u2019ve heard this before \u2014 they are slow to crack down on them.\n\nDai: Sometimes this feels like Sisyphus and the boulder. Farhad will be back next week with answers from many readers about the types of technology stories they want to read. I\u2019m already preparing my five Logan Paul stories.\n\nDaisuke Wakabayashi writes about Alphabet and its many arms, including Google. Jack Nicas covers Apple. Both also write about broader technology trends and Silicon Valley. You can follow them on Twitter here: @daiwaka and @jacknicas", "title": "Dai and Jack\u2019s Week in Tech: Don\u2019t Trust the Internet", "authors": ["Daisuke Wakabayashi", "Jack Nicas"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to dance performances.\n\nSOLEDAD BARRIO AND NOCHE FLAMENCA at the Joyce Theater (Feb. 13-25). Led by Mart\u00edn Santangelo and his dancer-wife, the electrifying Soledad Barrio, this flamenco company returns to the Joyce with \u201c\u00cdntimo,\u201d a program that delves deep into relationships. The centerpiece is \u201cLa Ronde,\u201d Mr. Santangelo\u2019s series of duets inspired by the structure of Max Oph\u00fcls\u2019s 1950 film. The music, as usual, is live, and the performers include the Andalusian flamenco dancer Juan Ogalla and, of course, Ms. Barrio. It wouldn\u2019t be Noche Flamenca without her.\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org\n\nICE THEATER OF NEW YORK at National Sawdust (Feb. 9, 7 p.m.). Have you ever experienced synthetic ice? What about the pairing of Schubert\u2019s song cycle \u201cDie Winterreise\u201d with synthetic ice? Here\u2019s your chance: National Sawdust will be transformed into a skating rink for the one-night-only performance of \u201cWinterICE,\u201d a collaboration between the vocalist and composer Theo Bleckmann and the pianist Uri Caine with Ice Theater of New York. In it, the musicians present a reimagined version of \u201cDie Winterreise\u201d while figure skaters from the company, led by its artistic director, Moira North, glide to it.\n\n646-779-8455, nationalsawdust.org\n\n\u2018I LOVE BUTOH\u2019 at Triskelion Arts (Feb. 14, 8 p.m.). This presentation by Triskelion Arts, in association with Vangeline Theater and the New York Butoh Institute, features performances by the Japanese dancer Mari Osanai (\u201cBoundary\u201d) and the New York contemporary dancer and choreographer Madelyn Sher (\u201cI Love You I Miss My Friend and the Music Is Beautiful\u201d). Along with a serving of Butoh, the dance form that emerged in Japan after World War II, this program \u2014 in honor of Valentine\u2019s Day \u2014 offers a chocolate tasting.\n\n718-389-3473, triskelionarts.org/i-love-butoh\n\nNEW YORK CITY BALLET at the David H. Koch Theater (through March 4). This weekend features repeats of mixed bills \u2014 the all-George Balanchine program is especially stellar \u2014 but Peter Martins\u2019s full-length ballet \u201cRomeo + Juliet\u201d returns on Feb. 13 with a new male lead on opening night. As Romeo, Harrison Coll will dance opposite Sterling Hyltin\u2019s Juliet, with Joaquin De Luz as Tybalt, Daniel Ulbricht as Mercutio and Joseph Gordon as Benvolio. Other pairings include Tiler Peck with Zachary Catazaro and Lauren Lovette with Chase Finlay. Stay tuned for more debuts.\n\n212-496-0600, nycballet.com\n\nNEW YORK THEATER BALLET at Florence Gould Hall (Feb. 9-11, various times). Diana Byer\u2019s New York Theater Ballet presents two programs this weekend. Four dances fill out its promising REP program: Gemma Bond\u2019s \u201cOptimists,\u201d David Gordon\u2019s \u201cBeethoven/1999,\u201d Pam Tanowitz\u2019s \u201cDouble Andante\u201d and Antony Tudor\u2019s \u201cDark Elegies.\u201d But there\u2019s an option for the little ones too. The one-hour \u201cMother Goose,\u201d choreographed by Keith Michael for children ages 3 and up, brings the stories and characters to whimsical dancing life.\n\n212-355-6160, nytb.org", "title": "Dance in NYC This Week", "authors": ["Gia Kourlas"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to dance performances.\n\nALEXANDRA PIRICI at the New Museum (Feb 6-April 15 at various times). From now through early spring, the Romanian choreographer Alexandra Pirici fills the south galleries of the New Museum with \u201cCo-natural,\u201d described as an ongoing action that will be performed continuously during museum hours. There will be six performers in the space, but only five in person \u2014 the sixth, Farid Fairuz, will appear as a hologram, illustrating Ms. Pirici\u2019s interest in examining the tension between unity and fragmentation. Press materials describe the work as \u201cone monstrous, modular organism made of living and digital matter.\u201d\n\n212-219-1222, newmuseum.org\n\nDANA REITZ at New York Live Arts (Feb. 8-10 at 8 p.m.) Dance is often simplistically reduced to the pairing of movement and music. Choreographer Dana Reitz begs to differ: She has often choreographed in silence, and so she does in \u201cLatitude,\u201d a new work presented as part of the Lumberyard in the City Winter Festival. Ms. Reitz, who performs with Elena Demyanenko and Yanan Yu, is working with a score made of light, which she has also designed, having long considered light an equal partner in dance. Here, the three performers navigate the spotlights and shadows of the stage on a quiet journey of discovery.\n\n866-811-4111, newyorklivearts.org", "title": "Dance in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Weinrauch survived by posing as a gentile and at a social function found herself in a tense waltz with a Nazi officer, a dance that would save her life.\n\nHer disguise was later discovered and as she was about to be executed, the officer came upon her and instead \u2014 \u201cA bullet is too good for you\u201d \u2014 condemned her to three years of hell in Auschwitz and other concentration camps, she recalled.\n\nMs. Weinrauch would rarely venture onto a dance floor again until this flier appeared offering a free lesson from the Fred Astaire Dance Studio on West 72nd Street in Manhattan.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI wondered, \u2018Is there someone watching over me, giving me this?\u2019\u201d she recalled. \u201cI never had time in my life to dance, so I said, \u2018I\u2019m finally going to do something for myself.\u2019\u201d\n\nShe walked down to the studio from her West 86th Street apartment building.\n\n\u201cThe dancers were half \u2014 no, a quarter of \u2014 my age,\u201d said Ms. Weinrauch, who nevertheless was persuaded to stay by a young instructor, who showed her basic steps.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe said, \u2018There\u2019s really no age for dancing\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I got hooked.\u201d\n\nShe began hiring instructors to take her dancing. They were young and romantic and she loved it.\n\n\u201cWhen I dance, I forget what happened to me and it makes me feel for a few minutes or hours that I am happy,\u201d she said on a recent Friday evening in the spacious elegant Manhattan apartment where she has lived for 55 years.\n\nShe sipped a Campari and selected a necklace to go with the sparkling dress that hugged her svelte figure.\n\n\u201cI live on eggs, cheese and dark chocolate,\u201d she said. \u201cAfter the war, I promised myself that I\u2019d never be hungry and I\u2019d never go on a diet, because I starved for three years.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe grabbed an overcoat and took a yellow cab across town to St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church on Lexington Avenue and 76th Street where the Manhattan Ballroom Society holds Friday night dances in the spacious basement \u2014 one of several dances Ms. Weinrauch attends each week.\n\nHer dance partner, Slavi Baylov, 41, greeted her with flowers and led her onto the dance floor for a jaunty rumba followed by an elegant fox trot. Ms. Weinrauch danced a spry merengue. Then they tangoed and Mr. Baylov dipped her low and slow.\n\n\u201cShe has a joie de vivre, I guess because of what she\u2019s been through,\u201d he said. \u201cShe doesn\u2019t take any moment for granted.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSteve Dane, who runs the dance evenings, has designated Ms. Weinrauch the society\u2019s \u201cDancing Angel.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe\u2019ll be the last one off the dance floor,\u201d said Mr. Dane, whose playlist always includes Ms. Weinrauch\u2019s favorite song, \u201cFascination.\u201d She first heard the 1905 waltz in a cafe after a yearlong recuperation in a Swedish hospital during which she remained mute and hoarded food.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Weinrauch had survived a death march from Auschwitz in freezing conditions and was rescued by British soldiers liberating the Bergen-Belsen camp in April 1945.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe had been left for dead when a British captain noticed her in a pile of corpses, she said.\n\n\u201cHe said, \u2018That corpse is still warm. She\u2019s still alive,\u2019\u201d recalled Ms. Weinrauch, who weighed 60 pounds. \u201cI was skin and bones.\u201d\n\nAfter her recovery, she came to New York in 1947, became a doctor\u2019s assistant, and married Joseph Weinrauch, a German Jew who had helped his family escape the Nazis.\n\nThe couple avoided dancing during their 55 years of marriage because of his disdain for it. He went into a deep depression after their daughter died. Ms. Weinrauch called her death more painful than her Holocaust experience.\n\nAfter her husband died, \u201cI thought, \u2018I can give in to the sadness and feel sorry for myself, or I can dance,\u201d recalled Ms. Weinrauch, who does charity work helping other older people, speaks in schools and runs her errands by foot or public bus.\n\n\u201cThey know her at Barney Greengrass, they know her at Zabar\u2019s,\u201d said Dr. Arlene Heyman, 75, a psychoanalyst and author who lives in Ms. Weinrauch\u2019s building. \u201cShe\u2019s made a family on the Upper West Side for the family she lost, and she\u2019s having more fun now than she\u2019s ever had in her life.\u201d\n\nMs. Weinrauch agreed.\n\n\u201cWhen I dance, I\u2019m trying to capture the pleasure that I never had the chance to have,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s a lot to make up for.\u201d", "title": "Dancing Saved Her Life. Twice.", "authors": ["Corey Kilgannon", "Character Study"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor many people this winter\u2019s yo-yoing temperatures have brought with them an unwelcome annoyance: dandruff \u2014 itchy and flaky and vexing. And if you have a closet of black and navy clothing it\u2019s even more of a nuisance.\n\n\u201cThe cold weather tends to be an exacerbating factor,\u201d said Arielle R. Nagler, an assistant professor in the Ronald O. Perelman Department of Dermatology at NYU Langone Health. \u201cIt\u2019s the extremes of weather, and this weather has been extreme.\u201d\n\nDandruff shampoo isn\u2019t exactly the chicest product in the shower, but, a growing number of upscale brands are offering shampoos and treatments that are more glamorous than what you\u2019d typically find at your neighborhood Duane Reade. These products, many packaged in subtle bottles, are more herbaceous than medicinal. Sometimes the word \u201cscalp\u201d appears on the bottle instead of \u201cdandruff\u201d to address the issue more quietly.\n\nMost use an active ingredient that\u2019s also found in drugstore brands \u2014 salicylic acid, pyrithione zinc or coal tar \u2014 mixed with natural oils and conditioners. They\u2019re sold at fashionable department stores and boutiques, starting at about $20, which is considerably more expensive than a bottle of Selsun Blue. But there\u2019s no denying that using one feels indulgent.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s something to be said for that, for people who don\u2019t use like using a dandruff shampoo for whatever reason \u2014 it makes their hair feel sticky, or they just feel self-conscious,\u201d Dr. Nagler said. \u201cIf it gets people to wash their hair more frequently, that does a lot of good.\u201d\n\nSlide Show\n\nSachajuan Scalp Shampoo is typical of the trend. The formula blends ginger and rosemary with salicylic acid for a nondrying cleanser that\u2019s sudsy, with a pleasantly herbal scent. It\u2019s sold at Barneys New York and Net-a-Porter, among other places, and it has become one of Sachajuan\u2019s best-selling products.\n\nLike other products from Malin & Goetz, its Dandruff Shampoo comes in an unfussy white bottle. It\u2019s a creamy cleanser composed of, among other ingredients, eucalyptus and tea tree oil along with pyrithione zinc. The texture makes it feel a bit more treatment-like than some others of this kind, but it leaves hair feeling softer than may be expected.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRecipe for Men Anti-Dandruff Shampoo was introduced last month. It aims to combat flakes with peppermint oil, which gives off a refreshingly strong scent as you shampoo, and piroctone olamine, an antifungal compound that helps prevent the growth of a yeast that can lead to dandruff. It\u2019s sold at Bergdorf Goodman and other stores.\n\nLeonor Greyl Bain Traitant \u00e0 la Propolis is especially mild \u2014 it\u2019s billed on the bottle as \u201cGentle Anti-Dandruff Shampoo\u201d \u2014 so it is well suited for sensitive scalps. Although it\u2019s expensive ($46), it is popular. The company said sales have more than doubled since it was introduced three years ago.\n\nThis month, Oribe introduced a dandruff collection called Serene Scalp. It\u2019s unmistakably upmarket, with packaging in a muted shade of pink that\u2019s reminiscent of Gucci\u2019s latest perfume bottle. The shampoo is infused with Oribe\u2019s distinctive C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur scent, a perfume-y mix of bergamot, jasmine and sandalwood.", "title": "Dandruff Shampoos Have Gone Chic", "authors": ["Rachel Felder", "Skin Deep"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNEED TO KNOW\n\nBy Karen Cleveland\n\n290 pp. Ballantine. $26.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile a C.I.A. analyst named Vivian Miller is on the phone assuring her husband, a software engineer, that she can leave Langley to pick up one of their sick kids, she\u2019s also impatiently checking her computer as she downloads a highly classified new counterintelligence program. The couple are in financial straits, and Vivian needs a promotion. Coordinating with the F.B.I., she has designed an algorithm to pinpoint Russian \u201chandlers,\u201d the spies running the spies, a matter of heightened urgency since they\u2019ve recently become more aggressive. Two of her colleagues have already been \u201cpitched,\u201d apparently unsuccessfully. But the danger may lie closer to home: Using the new program, Vivian finds a file on the computer of one suspected handler that contains an unencrypted photo of her own husband. And the information is so secret not even her F.B.I. partner is allowed to see it.\n\nAll of this is persuasively conveyed in the opening pages of Cleveland\u2019s novel. And by Page 27, she\u2019s dangling the sort of secret normally reserved for an ending. But instead of easing up, she doubles down. Cleveland has worked for the C.I.A., so the tradecraft in \u201cNeed to Know\u201d is of special interest. When penetrating a computer, is an analyst really given a choice between clicking on \u201cactive\u201d or \u201cpassive,\u201d depending on whether she wants to mess around in there? It\u2019s possible \u2014 more likely, certainly, than a set of wedding guests unwittingly divided between C.I.A. operatives and Russian sleeper agents.\n\n\u201cNeed to Know\u201d won\u2019t pose any threat to John le Carr\u00e9 because it\u2019s all surfaces. But the surfaces are very shiny and lots of fun.\n\nTHE WIFE BETWEEN US\n\nBy Greer Hendricks and Sarah Pekkanen\n\n346 pp. St. Martin\u2019s. $26.99.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt first, it looks as if Hendricks and Pekkanen have written a book that\u2019s more romance than thriller. \u201cThe Wife Between Us\u201d alternates between two points of view. One belongs to a young and apparently innocent preschool teacher who has been swept off her feet by a rich man \u2014 a hedge fund manager, no less. The other belongs to the man\u2019s hard-bitten ex, a saleswoman at Saks resentfully catering to the spoiled matrons who used to be her peers. The rich man \u2014 lynchpin of the triangle \u2014 says laughably \u201cintellectual\u201d things and looks good in both a suit and a pair of jeans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough the sinister elements may begin on the pale side, they soon suggest all sorts of gaslighting and bluebearding. When the rich man first meets the teacher on an airplane, he strokes a lock of her blond hair and says: \u201cSo beautiful. Don\u2019t ever cut it.\u201d Later, seemingly out of the blue, he buys her a house. And he insists that their honeymoon destination be a surprise.", "title": "Dangers Close to Home: Four New Domestic Thrillers", "authors": ["Jacqueline Carey"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "How does it feel to write a plan that would kill tens of millions of people? I was in denial. I was part of a plan that should never have been made that was a crime against humanity. I once came to a disarmament press conference at the U.N., and Time had just had a picture on their cover of a terrorist, and I showed this picture from Time, and I said, \u201cIf I want to see a nuclear terrorist, I just have to look in the mirror.\u201d Now if you say, \u201cHow do I feel about that?\u201d Well, I feel terrible.\n\nHow surprised are you that there hasn\u2019t been a nuclear apocalypse yet? I am surprised. On the whole, we\u2019ve been incredibly lucky. It\u2019s something like a miracle, but miracles, I guess, do happen. Could we survive another 70 or 100 years without nuclear winter? It\u2019s unlikely, but it\u2019s not impossible. But no matter how small the likelihood is, I\u2019m working to try to double it.\n\nDo you think President Trump is utilizing the madman theory with North Korea, purposely making them think he\u2019s unstable, or is he just a madman? Oh, sure, he\u2019s very explicit about it. He says he cannot reject first use of nuclear weapons, because you\u2019ve got to keep it on the table. Well, that worried people, because he looks crazy, so people thought, Gee, he\u2019s not just using the theory here, he is unfortunately making a very credible threat. But since the mid-\u201960s the idea of initiating nuclear war by the U.S. has been nothing other than a madman theory. It\u2019s been insane to think of doing that.\n\nYou\u2019re most famous for leaking the Pentagon Papers, which are the subject of the movie \u201cThe Post.\u201d What do you think of how you were portrayed? Very, very well, because I was portrayed by a terrific actor who looks a lot as I did at the time, only better.\n\nThe charges against you were thrown out after it was discovered that Richard Nixon\u2019s \u201cplumbers\u201d broke into your psychoanalyst\u2019s office looking for dirt on you. Does it ever amaze you that after carrying out the biggest leak of government secrets in American history, you pretty much got off scot-free? It was a miracle. As I say, secular miracles do happen.", "title": "Daniel Ellsberg Thinks We\u2019re in Denial About Nuclear War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDanielle Alexandra Grunwald and Matthew Savage Aibel were married Feb. 3 at the Bowery Hotel in New York. Christopher Michael Quinlan, a friend of the couple who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated.\n\nThe bride, 32, is an associate in the real estate group of the New York law firm Stroock & Stroock & Lavan. She graduated from Williams College and received a law degree, cum laude, from Cornell.\n\nShe is the daughter of Linda J. Grunwald and Dr. Andrew M. Grunwald of Beechhurst, N.Y. The bride\u2019s father is an invasive cardiologist in Manhasset, N.Y., affiliated with NYU Langone Health.\n\nThe groom, also 32, is a litigation associate at the New York law firm Epstein Becker & Green. He graduated from Washington University in St. Louis and received a law degree from Fordham.\n\nHe is the son of Beverly Savage and James H. Aibel of Hoboken, N.J. The groom\u2019s mother is the executive director for Hudson County Court Appointed Special Advocates, a nonprofit organization that finds permanent homes for children in foster care. His father is a lawyer and managing director in the corporate programming office at the Bank of New York Mellon.\n\nThe couple met in December 2014 after having matched on multiple dating apps.", "title": "Danielle Grunwald, Matthew Aibel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "STEEL WORK: It might surprise you to learn that Danielle Steel \u2014 who has written 167 books and will publish six more in 2018 \u2014 spends between two and three years on each title. \u201cSometimes I just sit and stare into space and think about a book, or a twist in a book, or the kernel of an idea, and I follow the thought for a while and see where it goes, and try to envision it,\u201d she explains. \u201cI know when an idea is right for me when it just clicks, and I can tell in my gut it\u2019s \u2018the one.\u2019\u201d But she doesn\u2019t immediately dive into a manuscript. \u201cI make notes for a while before I start work on the outline. The notes are usually more about the characters. I need to know the characters really well before I start \u2014 who they are, how they think, how they feel, what has happened to them, how they grew up.\u201d\n\nSteel says the idea for her new book, \u201cFall From Grace\u201d \u2014 which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2 \u2014 was sparked by real-life conversations. \u201cI\u2019ve heard touching, poignant stories about women who were treated abominably by their jealous adult stepchildren after their husband\u2019s death, and I became intrigued with the idea of what happens to a woman who has lived in a golden cocoon and loses everything,\u201d she says. \u201cWhat\u2019s left? Who does she become? How does she survive? Who is she without all the trappings and protection? We all become somewhat spoiled when things are easy. Stripped of everything, who are we?\u201d\n\nAfter all these years, Steel continues to use the same 1946 Olympia typewriter she bought used when working on her first book. \u201cI am utterly, totally and faithfully in love with my typewriter,\u201d she says. \u201cI think I paid $20 for it. Excellent investment! And by now, we\u2019re old friends.\u201d She adds, \u201cI work for 20 hours at a stretch, glued to my desk, sometimes 24 hours straight. Thirty-six hours once, when I just couldn\u2019t leave the story.\u201d But the famously glamorous author \u2014 who attends the Paris fashion shows and frequently writes about her love of couture on her blog \u2014 rejects designer trappings when she works. \u201cWhen I\u2019m writing, it\u2019s \u2018schlubby\u2019 all the way,\u201d she says. \u201cMy favorite writing costumes are threadbare old cashmere nightgowns, so comfy to write in. \u2018Dressed up\u2019 would be an old sweatshirt and jeans. It\u2019s like taking a long road trip, you have to be comfortable to sit in one place for that long. My long hair is lumped in an elastic \u2014 it\u2019s comfy, comfy, comfy all the way. When I\u2019m finished working, it\u2019s like coming back from a camping trip: I\u2019m a mess! But the accomplishment feels great.\u201d", "title": "Danielle Steel: \u2018I Know an Idea Is Right for Me When It Just Clicks\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Last month, Mr. Carrabba spent a quiet evening at the Palm steakhouse in Manhattan, where he ordered fish and spinach. His hair was swept back with pomade, as it long has been, and he was wearing a hoodie advertising a Bethlehem, Pa., bakery called Vegan Treats. He was contemplative.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOver three hours he talked about retreating from the spotlight, the persistence of emo and accusations of sexual assault that have roiled the genre. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.\n\nIs Dashboard Confessional a specific mood, or a sound? When you write a song, how do you know it\u2019s a Dashboard song?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s the elusive nature of it, which in this case caused a seven- or eight-year delay between records. That it comes from some mysterious place is a little bit of an overstatement. That it comes at unpredictable times is probably the better way to place it.\n\nSo it\u2019s almost like... \u201cIt\u2019s cominnnng?\u201d\n\nYes, yes, it is. An unrelenting urge that sends me in a metaphorical dead sprint for a guitar. It\u2019s coming on and I\u2019ve just got seconds to catch it, or it\u2019s gone.\n\nDid that pose a problem when Dashboard reunited: \u201cO.K., we\u2019re ready as a band. The fans are ready. But, is the thing ready?\u201d\n\nYes, and it wasn\u2019t. If you were to have been my accountant at that time, you would say there might never be a better time than right this minute to release a record, but it just doesn\u2019t work for me that way. So the waiting game began. We did our tour and a year passed. I wrote, like, snippets and then I would stop. I\u2019d physically stop. I put the pencil and the paper down and said, \u201cStop it. You\u2019re just eager, you\u2019re eager to deliver.\u201d\n\nThen one day off tour I woke up one morning and I walked downstairs and I wrote a song, and it was evident from the first melodic idea that this was a Dashboard song. And the next morning I woke up and I bolted for my guitar. I realized, \u201cI\u2019m there.\u201d After all that time I\u2019d begun to wonder if they\u2019d ever come back, and when they came back they came back in rapid succession. The whole thing was a cavalcade and I just surrendered to it.\n\nIf they hadn\u2019t come and you just continued playing your back catalog in amphitheaters, would you have felt that something was missing?\n\nNo. I had decided that the worst thing that could happen was that I write an album that would hurt the legacy of the albums I\u2019d made already. But now that I have this record, I can say it\u2019s because I\u2019ve gotten in touch with that place again and there was more to be found there and I\u2019m willing to risk the whole legacy because it came from the same place.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen someone like Joe Mulherin from nothing,nowhere. says there\u2019s a home for you in what he does, does it make you feel the zeitgeist has come back around?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI feel like it\u2019s emblematic of the concurrent paths we happen to be on. I haven\u2019t stopped being an excessive consumer of music, old and new. There\u2019s nothing better \u2014 or frankly, worse \u2014 than I wish I had written that lyric. Phoebe Bridgers, she\u2019s the real deal. Dawes have that lyric which I think might be the most romantic thing ever said in a song if the listener that hears it is a massive music fan: \u201cMay all your favorite bands stay together.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s good.\n\nThose are the moments I\u2019m looking for. And with Joe, he\u2019s got a mountain of them. Phoebe\u2019s got a mountain of them. Julien [Baker]\u2019s got a mountain of them. I love that other people\u2019s songs can make me say, how much deeper can I go?\n\nYou don\u2019t really talk about your personal life, but you are married.\n\nYeah.\n\nYou\u2019ve been married to the same person all these years?\n\nYeah. My wife and I have navigated this really well. She\u2019s interesting and she loves me and she cherishes our relationship but she doesn\u2019t need me. She is self-actualized. She\u2019s a strong enough woman to handle the rigors of distance. If anything it was a difficult thing to navigate coming off the road.\n\nI feel like on this album I heard the word \u201cwe\u201d more than on previous records.\n\nI did, too, and I didn\u2019t know it until the record was done.\n\nMaybe this is a na\u00efve or oversimplified way of talking about Dashboard records, but I experience them as \u201cI,\u201d not \u201cwe\u201d records.\n\nWell, I was navigating the world by myself at that moment when I was writing most of the Dashboard songs. I\u2019m now not only navigating the world with my wife, but I\u2019m looking back, I\u2019m holding on fiercely to what I realize is so rare with this really strong circle of friends that I\u2019ve been lucky enough to have. Previously, I was at a point where I thought I was going through things alone. Now I\u2019ve just been in a place where I\u2019m no more certain about anything that life\u2019s handed me and the reasons for it, but I\u2019ve never been less alone.\n\nPhoto\n\nHave you come across any of the feminist reassessments of emo \u2014 stories about how women were marginalized in the scene as participants and also how the music often reduced them to objects?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI would say that I was never really that satisfied with the limited amount of women that were in the scene. Two of my favorite bands, Jejune and Rainer Maria, had women coleads. And I had women singing on all my records. But I\u2019m not deaf. A lot of the bands that followed our era, they were like degraded copies every six months, where I and everybody thought it was almost like hair metal or something like that, costumes some of them put on. And the stories and the feelings beneath them were incidental. I didn\u2019t relate to that. I think at that point it got pretty much, like, by the numbers and it was like, \u201cO.K., you pick on a girl.\u201d\n\nDid you reject it in the moment?\n\nYeah. I felt like it was gross. I thought it was opportunistic. I thought it was degrading.\n\nWere there bands you wouldn\u2019t tour with?\n\nYes. And it bummed me out and it broke my heart a little. And in that time, beforehand but especially once I started to notice it, I made a rule of trying as often as possible to have a female-led band or a band with a woman in the band on tour with us.\n\nYou toured with Brand New. What was your reaction to the allegations against Jesse Lacey? [In November, the singer was accused of sexual improprieties by a woman who said he solicited nude pictures from her when she was a minor. He released a statement apologizing for his behavior without directly addressing the allegation. No charges have been filed.]\n\nI think it is abhorrent, shocking.\n\nWere you surprised by it?\n\nI was surprised by it, because in this case, I never saw anything that would indicate that. I haven\u2019t spoken to Jesse about it, as we haven\u2019t really spoken that much in years. As part of the scene \u2014 I don\u2019t mean outside of it being a band they looked up to, I mean being one of the kids in it \u2014 I don\u2019t know how to not be offended by it. First, I was a fan in that scene, then I was somebody that people were fans of. I remained a fan in that scene too. We had a trust.\n\nThere was a morality to it.\n\nI felt that\u2019s what made us different than other scenes. We were the answer to the rock \u2019n\u2019 roll clich\u00e9, I thought.\n\nHave these topics been an active subject of conversation between you and your peers?\n\nWell, between me and my friends.\n\nWhat about people who are in the scene in some form or another?\n\nNo, it seems uncomfortable when I\u2019ve tried to talk to some of them about this. They seem as concerned, but I think that nobody knows how to come to grips with the idea that our scene was a place that something like this could happen. It\u2019s shameful. I don\u2019t want to believe that my part of the circle of fans were treated that way or felt that way at shows. I feel like we\u2019re there to take care of each other.\n\nThat\u2019s what the ethics of a scene really should be.\n\nLike if I see a fight break out, I\u2019ll stop the show and say, \u201cStop the fight. Is everyone O.K.?\u201d It\u2019s our responsibility \u2014 not just the bands, anybody that\u2019s proactive in the scene \u2014 it\u2019s our collective responsibility to say, in all situations, \u201cAre you O.K.?\u201d I just didn\u2019t know I had to say it about this stuff. I didn\u2019t know.", "title": "Dashboard Confessional, Emo\u2019s King of Pain, Rises Again", "authors": ["Jon Caramanica"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBERLIN \u2014 The architect David Adjaye, the musician and composer Zakir Hussain, the choreographer Crystal Pite and the author Colm Toibin are the new mentors in the Rolex Mentor and Prot\u00e9g\u00e9 Arts Initiative, which pairs distinguished cultural figures with emerging artists in their fields. The names of the new mentors, and of their prot\u00e9g\u00e9s, were announced in a public ceremony on Monday at the Staatsoper here.\n\nRolex also announced that funding will be increased to allow some changes to the Arts Initiative, which began in 2002. It now has a major-name roster of mentor and prot\u00e9g\u00e9 alumni, including David Chipperfield, Anish Kapoor, Mira Nair, Alejandro Gonz\u00e1lez I\u00f1\u00e1rritu, Alexei Ratmansky, Robert Wilson, Jessye Norman, Pico Iyer, Margaret Atwood, Nicholas Hlobo and David Aaron Carpenter.\n\nThe initiative has until now created yearlong pairings in seven fields: architecture, dance, film, literature, visual arts, music and theater. Starting in 2018, the program will expand to eight disciplines, but offer four at a time, each taking place over two years. Architecture, music, dance and literature will be the 2018-19 focus, while film, theater, visual arts and a \u201cwild card\u201d eighth discipline will run through 2020-21.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve realized after observing this for many years now that in many disciplines, the mentors and prot\u00e9g\u00e9s needed more time together,\u201d said Rebecca Irvin, the head of philanthropy at Rolex, in an interview. \u201cIt felt like they barely got going before it was over.\u201d Ms. Irvin added that the rigorous and time-consuming selection process for the prot\u00e9g\u00e9s meant that finding the final seven candidates for each cycle \u201cfelt like a rush.\u201d\n\nThe eighth discipline \u201ccould be design, cooking, photography or a multidisciplinary form,\u201d Ms. Irvin said. \u201cIt gives us the flexibility to be more experimental.\u201d\n\nThe program, which began in 2002, asks the mentor and prot\u00e9g\u00e9 to spend at least six weeks together during the mentoring period. The prot\u00e9g\u00e9s \u2014 this year Mariam Kamara (architecture), Khoudia Tour\u00e9 (dance), Colin Barrett (literature) and Marcus Gilmore (music) \u2014 must be professionals in each field. They each receive a stipend of 40,000 Swiss francs ($42,900) in addition to funds for travel and expenses. At the end of the mentoring period, each becomes a fellow of the Arts Initiative and is eligible for a further 30,000 Swiss francs ($32,300) for future projects, as well as additional funds for collaborative projects with other Arts Initiative fellows.", "title": "David Adjaye and Colm Toibin Among New Mentors in Rolex Program", "authors": ["Roslyn Sulcas"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe chef and restaurateur David Chang and the director Morgan Neville will discuss their new Netflix documentary series, \u201cUgly Delicious,\u201d which made its debut on Feb. 23. Rabbi Josh Buchin officiated at the couple\u2019s home. On Feb. 24, Rabbi Buchin, assisted by Cantor Basya Schechter, led the couple in an exchange of vows at Flora Farms, a restaurant and events space, in San Jos\u00e9 del Cabo, Mexico.\n\nThe couple met at N.Y.U., from which they graduated and from which Mr. Loft also received a law degree.\n\nMr. Fishman (left), 32, is a managing director and partner for Global Gateway Advisors, a communications consultancy in Brooklyn.\n\nHe is the son of Naomi S. Fishman and Dr. Norman Fishman of Creve Coeur, Mo. Mr. Fishman\u2019s mother is a Jewish educator and museum curator in Creve Coeur. His father is an endocrinologist in private practice and the chief of endocrinology at St. Luke\u2019s Hospital in Chesterfield, Mo.", "title": "David Fishman, Kolby Loft", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Here is the interview with Jesmyn Ward, the author of \u201cSing, Unburied, Sing,\u201d which was the January pick for the Now Read This book club.", "title": "Previous Now Read This Book Club Picks, Author Interviews and Discussion Questions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "In the 1980s, Mr. Poindexter trained Kenyan radio and television personnel to produce soap operas for the government-run Voice of Kenya. In one episode of the show \u201cTushauriane,\u201d or \u201cLet\u2019s Discuss It,\u201d which made its television debut in 1987, a teenager marries an elderly polygamist in her village, becomes pregnant, has a miscarriage and becomes pregnant again. The series\u2019 intent was to persuade couples to use family planning.\n\n\u201cThis is not, first of all, drama, but value reinforcement,\u201d Mr. Poindexter told The Times in 1987.\n\nIn a telephone interview, Mr. Ryerson cited one study about the effect of a series on Radio Tanzania in the 1990s that was broadcast as a result of Mr. Poindexter\u2019s work. It found a 32 percent increase in first-time use of family-planning clinics in the area where the show was broadcast, and 41 percent of the study\u2019s respondents named the show as the reason.\n\nDavid Oldham Poindexter was born on Jan. 30, 1929, in Hood River, Ore., about 60 miles east of Portland. His father, Dean, was a Methodist minister whose postings around the state kept the family moving. His mother, the former Anna Porter, was a homemaker.\n\nDavid Poindexter earned a bachelor\u2019s degree from Willamette University in Salem, Ore., and a master\u2019s in theology from Boston University, following his father into the ministry.\n\nAfter eight years as the pastor of a Portland church, he joined the National Council of Churches in Manhattan as director of its broadcasting and film commission. The post brought him into contact with Hollywood executives. In 1970, he moved to the Population Institute in Washington as the director of its communication center.\n\nMr. Poindexter said he became interested in overpopulation in the late 1960s when he watched Paul Ehrlich, the author of the best-selling 1968 book \u201cThe Population Bomb,\u201d in an appearance on \u201cThe Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson.\u201d Mr. Poindexter compared Mr. Ehrlich to Paul Revere.\n\n\u201cOnly this time, the message was, \u2018The people are coming,\u2019 and it began to galvanize the country,\u201d he said in a speech in 2008 at the Norman Lear Center, part of the Annenberg School for Communications at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles.", "title": "David Poindexter, 89, Who Used Media to Preach Family Planning, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGraydon Carter and Jeff Klein, the owners of the Monkey Bar in Midtown Manhattan since 2009, have installed David Tanis as the new chef at the venerable restaurant and watering hole.\n\nMr. Tanis, who was the head chef at Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., for many years and was also the chef at Cafe Escalera in Santa Fe, N.M., is a frequent contributor to The New York Times, where he writes the \u201cCity Kitchen\u201d column for the Food section. He is also the author of four cookbooks.\n\nMr. Klein said they expected refinement and subtle changes at the Monkey Bar with Mr. Tanis in charge. The restaurant now has a rather conventional menu featuring staples like shrimp cocktail, steak tartare, wedge salad, rack of lamb and a burger.\n\nMr. Tanis said his food \u201cwill be straightforward and simply presented.\u201d He added that the menu would evolve, but would veer away from steakhouse fare and emphasize more salads, fish and vegetables with a seasonal focus using sustainable ingredients.\n\nMr. Tanis\u2019s chef de cuisine is Mason Lindahl.\n\nThe Monkey Bar, 60 East 54th Street (Madison Avenue), Midtown East, 212-288-1010, monkeybarnewyork.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "David Tanis Is Appointed Chef at Monkey Bar", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. \u2014 David Wright, the Mets\u2019 captain and longest-tenured player, understands the odds are probably against him. He is 35 and has not played in a major league game since May 2016. He has appeared in only 75 games since the start of the 2015 season.\n\nSince then, he has had three surgical procedures \u2014 for his neck, back and shoulder \u2014 and he remains affected by spinal stenosis, a chronic narrowing of the spinal canal that is at the center of his physical breakdown.\n\nAnd even though he is still rehabilitating in the wake of his most recent operations \u2014 for his shoulder last September and for his back a month later \u2014 he has not given up on the idea that he can still make a comeback, that there is still another chapter left in a career that was once so crammed with success.\n\nBut after so many physical setbacks, Wright is also acknowledging that that chapter may never happen, that his body, in the end, can take only so much.", "title": "David Wright Still Wants to Play, but Admits It May Not Happen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "In 1971 he was co-author, with Marcy Benstock, of \u201cWater Wasteland,\u201d a lengthy report by Mr. Nader\u2019s Center for the Study of Responsive Law that found that the nation\u2019s water pollution control efforts had failed miserably. Mr. Zwick then became involved in drafting the Clean Water Act of 1972, landmark environmental legislation that was subject to all sorts of pressures \u2014 from industries whose polluting practices it sought to curb, from local officials worried about federal intrusion, and more.\n\n\u201cDave had to figure all this out,\u201d Mr. Nader said. \u201cIt was a big, multi-hundred-page bill.\u201d Mr. Nader said Mr. Zwick had been vital to keeping the bill free of loopholes that would have allowed industry to continue polluting.\n\n\u201cThey couldn\u2019t mess that much with the water act,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was very tightly drafted.\u201d\n\nThe results, years later, were cleaner waterways and water supplies.\n\n\u201cBy any measure, this landmark legislation has been hugely successful,\u201d Carol M. Browner, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency at the time, said at a 1987 commemoration of the 25th anniversary of the act. \u201cOnce-dead rivers, lakes and estuaries are now pulsating with life. People are returning to them \u2014 to swim, to fish, to ply the waters in their boats and to relax on their shores.\u201d\n\nMr. Zwick was also instrumental in securing passage of the Safe Drinking Water Act of 1974. But he was not content merely to push his causes in Congress. Even as he was helping to shape the 1972 legislation, he and several others founded what became Clean Water Action. (It was originally called the Fishermen\u2019s Clean Water Action Project because of the involvement of fishing groups.)\n\nThe organization developed a grass-roots lobbying style to counter big-business interests, an approach that includes sending canvassers door to door.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cDavid taught a generation of activists who taught a generation of activists who will teach the next generation of activists,\u201d Clean Water Action said in a blog post memorializing his career.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDavid Reynolds Zwick was born on May 1, 1942, in Rochester. He was not the typical Harvard Law student: He had earned a bachelor of science degree at the United States Coast Guard Academy in 1963, then served for four years in the Coast Guard, 18 months of that in Vietnam, where his assignments included captaining patrol boats in the Mekong Delta.\n\nAt Harvard, he earned a master\u2019s degree in public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government even as he was earning his law degree and working with Mr. Nader.\n\n\u201cZwick is a phantom on campus,\u201d The Harvard Law Record wrote in 1972. \u201cHe is constantly commuting between HLS, his Kennedy School classes and his office in Washington.\u201d\n\nIn an interview for that article, Mr. Zwick articulated his concern that the \u201cconcept of citizenship has never extended beyond voting\u201d \u2014 that ordinary citizens viewed the ballot as their only source of input, while industry and other deep-pocketed players pressed their causes year-round through an army of lobbyists.\n\n\u201cIn a very real sense we have a democracy for the rich and a republic for the poor,\u201d he said.\n\nHe made sure Clean Water Action was not just an inside-the-Beltway operation.\n\n\u201cDavid was very clear that just working the halls of Congress wasn\u2019t enough to win strong environmental laws, and so Clean Water Action opened field offices around the nation in strategically important states,\u201d Robert Wendelgass, the organization\u2019s current president, said by email. \u201cThese were long-term investments that paid off not just in terms of strong federal laws, but also in strong state and local laws and safeguards.\u201d\n\nMr. Zwick would take a break from Clean Water Action from time to time to put his ideas and expertise to use in other areas, including helping to form the Illinois Public Action Council, a watchdog group, in 1975 and creating an educational effort, Citizens Campaign, in 1979 to teach grass-roots organizing. He pushed the organizations he worked with to take a broad view of their causes.\n\n\u201cDavid had a key focus and belief that Friends of the Earth and the environmental movement needed to expand and include ideas of social, racial and economic justice into our mission and campaigns,\u201d Erich Pica, the president of Friends of the Earth, said by email. \u201cHe helped to lead the board\u2019s work in this area.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Zwick stepped down as Clean Water Action\u2019s president in 2007 but continued to consult for various organizations.\n\nHis marriage to Wendy Weingarten ended in divorce. His survivors include three children, Winnie, Ruth and Jack.\n\nMr. Nader called Mr. Zwick \u201ca major figure in our country on water pollution enforcement,\u201d though he was not well known to the general public.\n\n\u201cHe just learned, and built, and learned,\u201d Mr. Nader said, \u201cand he didn\u2019t care if he got any credit.\u201d", "title": "David Zwick, a Leading Clean-Water Advocate, Dies at 75", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 European Parliament members have joined the chorus of skeptics about daylight saving time who argue that the practice of springing our clocks forward and then turning them back every year does more harm than good.\n\nThe European assembly voted 384 to 152 on Thursday on a resolution calling for the European Commission, the European Union\u2019s executive arm, to evaluate the current system and \u201cif necessary, come up with a proposal for its revision.\u201d\n\nThe resolution was nonbinding but echoed global concerns about the possible hazards of changing the clocks. Increasingly, health experts have questioned whether it\u2019s worth the hassle to switch year after year.\n\n\u201cNumerous studies have failed to reach a conclusive outcome but indicate negative effects on human health,\u201d the European Parliament members wrote in their proposal, which was debated for an hour on Thursday.", "title": "Daylight Saving Time: What\u2019s It Good For? European Lawmakers Ask", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "A chorus of Democratic lawmakers have joined the education secretary, Betsy DeVos, in calling for Congress to act after a gunman killed 17 people at a high school in Parkland, Fla.\n\nIn a letter on Friday, all 17 Democrats on the House Education Committee urged Representative Virginia Foxx, the committee\u2019s chairwoman, to convene hearings on school shootings, describing them as a \u201cpublic health epidemic.\u201d The panel has not addressed the issue since February 2013 \u2014 two months after a shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut left 20 first graders and six adults dead, they said.\n\n\u201cWednesday\u2019s preventable tragedy at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, resulted in the deaths of at least 17 students and faculty,\u201d the letter said. \u201cSadly, since the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School five years ago, more than 430 people have been shot in over 230 school shootings.\u201d\n\nThe letter adds pressure on Congress to address the pervasiveness of school shootings across the country, an issue that Ms. DeVos raised during an interview on Thursday with the conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt.", "title": "DeVos and Democrats Urge Congress to Hold Hearings on School Shootings", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Here are the details:\n\nUnderwriters: Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, Deutsche Bank, Allen & Co. BofA Merrill Lynch, RBC Capital, Jefferies, Macquarie Capital, Canaccord Genuity, JMP Securities, KeyBanc Capital and Piper Jaffray.\n\nExchange: Nasdaq\n\nCapital structure: Class B shares will have 10 times the voting power of Class common shares. The holders of Class B shares will continue to control the company after it goes public. Last summer the FTSE Russell and Standard & Poor\u2019s said most newly public companies with dual or multi-class capital structures would not be included in their indexes.\n\nBig shareholders: Drew Houston, the co-founder and chief executive, has 24.4 percent of the voting power, while venture capital firm Sequoia Capital has 24.8 percent. Mr. Houston and Arash Ferdowsi, a co-founder, have a combined voting power of 34.3 percent, which is greater than 32.3 percent for the three outside investors listed in the offering document.\n\nExecutive compensation: Mr. Houston\u2019s total pay last year was more than $110 million, including more $109 million in stock awards. His base salary was $400,000. Mr. Ferdowsi\u2019s total compensation was $47.3 million.\n\nThe financials: In 2017, Dropbox lost $112 million but its cash flows totaled $330 million. The reasons for the difference: Dropbox had large noncash expenses, like stock compensation and depreciation and amortization.\n\nBut revenue growth is slowing. Dropbox took in $1.1 billion of revenue in 2017, a 31 percent increase from $845 million in 2016. The company\u2019s revenue surged by 40 percent in 2016.\n\nDropbox will have to convince investors that it can add new paying users at a fast clip. It had 11 million paying users in 2017, up 25 percent from 2016. But that was a significantly slower pace than the 35 percent increase in 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn theory, Dropbox could squeeze more revenue out of each user, but it has not managed to do that in recent years. Revenue-per-user was $111.91 last year, not that different from $110.54 in 2016 and $113.54 in 2015.\n\nValuation: Early investors in unicorns are obviously betting that their stake will be worth more when the company goes public. But Dropbox\u2019s investors might be disappointed. The Wall Street Journal is reporting that the offering will value Dropbox at $7 billion to $8 billion. That is below the implied $10 billion valuation for Dropbox when it raised money in 2014, the Journal reported.\n\nShira Ovide at Bloomberg\u2019s Gadfly uses a valuation for Box, a public company that stores and manages content in the cloud, as a guide for how much Dropbox might be worth on the stock market. Ms. Ovide\u2019s conclusion is not encouraging.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis and Stephen Grocer\n\nPhoto\n\nWill Wall Street act if Washington won\u2019t?\n\nA series of companies has severed their relationship with the National Rifle Association after the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., following pressure from customers. Andrew highlighted how financial companies could limit the sale of guns in his column on Tuesday, causing debate on both sides and prompting petitions to begin circulating.\n\nOn Thursday, the First National Bank of Omaha said it would not renew its agreement to issue an N.R.A.-branded Visa card. \u201cCustomer feedback has caused us to review our relationship with the N.R.A.,\u201d the bank said.\n\nAnd Enterprise, which owns two other rental car brands, Alamo and National, said it would stop offering a special discount for N.R.A. members.\n\nAndrew notes:\n\nIt took real leadership for Clark Lauritzen, First National Bank\u2019s president, to make this decision. Will other C.E.O.\u2019s who talk about social responsibility follow suit? Mr. Lauritzen\u2019s bank is privately held by his family, so it may have been easier for him to take such a stand. Visa tried to distance itself from all of this by saying, \u201cVisa co-branded cards do not represent an endorsement by Visa of that cause or organization.\u201d But it also appears unwilling to sign on to the idea I proposed that it prevent customers from using its network to buy assault weapons, high-caliber magazines and bump stocks when it said in its statement about First National Bank ending its deal with the N.R.A., \u201cWe strive to make our payment services available to all people in all places, for uses consistent with local, national, and international laws.\u201d\n\nThe context\n\nGroups have previously pushed the investment industry to dump gun stocks, with limited impact.\n\nPension funds, including those for public-school teachers in at least a dozen states, own shares in gun makers. And major money managers such as BlackRock and Vanguard are indirectly some of the biggest holders of gun stocks through exchange-traded funds. BlackRock says it can\u2019t divest shares of a company in an index, but with $6 trillion under management, it is often effectively the biggest investor in such businesses.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLawmakers in New Jersey moved this week to restrict the state\u2019s public pensions from investing in the shares of gun manufacturers. BlackRock said it planned to reach out to weapons makers \u201cto understand their response\u201d to the shootings.\n\nMore on gun controls\n\n\u2022 Two gun safety groups are joining with Tom Steyer, the billionaire Democratic activist, in a drive to register high school students to vote. (Politico)\n\n\u2022 President Trump embraced an N.R.A. position to arm some teachers. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Democratic governors from four northeastern states joined forces to restrict the movement of illegal guns and share information about residents barred from owning firearms. (WSJ)\n\nPhoto\n\nBritain wants its cake in Brexit talks.\n\nTop members of the British government met Thursday to agree on what sort of relationship they want to have with the European Union after Britain leaves the bloc. The B.B.C. has details of the meal that was served at the meeting, held at the official country retreat of Prime Minister Theresa May: A cream of sweetcorn soup with a ham hock croquette, a Guinness short rib of Dexter beef with onions and parsnip mash, and a lemon tart with raspberry sorbet and fresh raspberries.\n\nThe menu is a reminder of how often food is used to help understand Brexit.\n\nCherries: The British government\u2019s position seems to be that it wants to abide by some European Union rules that would be advantageous for trade, while discarding others. In the Brexit debate, Britain\u2019s attempts to pick and choose is commonly described as cherry-picking, and top officials of the European Union have said they won\u2019t let Britain take this approach. And for Britain to ask for three baskets of cherries is likely just too much for the European Union to stomach.\n\nWhy?\n\nCake: The rationale for not letting Britain take an \u00e0 la carte approach is that it allows the country to have its cake and eat it. Underpinning the European Union is the belief that the benefits of being more closely integrated are often obtained through compromises that all member countries must make. And to supporters of the bloc, Britain\u2019s desire to opt in for some things and not others corrodes that community spirit.\n\nThe cake and cherries rhetoric thrown around in the Brexit debate suggest there is little middle ground between the European Union and Britain. But an alternative way to view the tensions is that so much trade goes on between Britain and the bloc, and others ties are so deep, that both sides will ultimately strike a new relationship that retains much of the existing one. As analysts at Nomura wrote earlier this week:\n\nIn terms of the bespoke deal issue, we think it is not credible to say the U.K. can only take an off-the-shelf Norway / Switzerland / Turkey / Ukraine / Canada / Mexico deal. They were all bespoke deals when they were made. The idea that the world\u2019s seventh largest economy, an ex-member and a country that will still have strong institutional, economic and geographic ties to the E.U. should not get a bespoke deal is not reasonable, in our view.\n\nAnd the Sun newspaper is reporting that some in European Union may actually want to throw Britain a few cherries. The Sun\u2019s Nick Gutteridge, who often has fresh insights from Brussels, has details of a paper drafted by the Belgian government:\n\nThe paper, produced by the Belgian government for a meeting of diplomats last week, will prove a huge boost to British negotiators and gives new insight into E.U. thinking.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nOne reason the Treasury balked on Dodd Frank\u2019s bank resolution regime.\n\nPresident Donald Trump\u2019s \u201cAmerica First\u201d agenda seems to have met its match in the obscure world of international financial regulation.\n\nOn Thursday, we wrote about the Treasury Department\u2019s decision to retain the process for winding down a failing bank that was introduced under the Obama administration.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA big reason the Treasury held back: The concerns of foreign regulators.\n\nAs the Treasury\u2019s proposal stated, an alternative to the Obama-era wind-down is a new form of bankruptcy for large financial firms, called Chapter 14. The Treasury favors using Chapter 14 where possible, but it opted to keep the current resolution mechanism. This disappointed Republicans who want Chapter 14 to replace the the current process. But foreign regulators pushed back against a bankruptcy-or-nothing approach. Specifically, the Treasury noted, foreign regulators have expressed doubts about whether they could coordinate effectively with a United States bankruptcy judge when winding down a big American bank that has large amounts of business overseas.\n\nOn that point, the Treasury could have pushed back. It could have told foreign governments that Chapter 14 judges would, in fact, be up to the task of handling international cases. Indeed, the Treasury in its paper said it expected the judges to have such competency:\n\nFurther, these judges, once designated, could engage in planning and coordination exercises, including cross-border efforts (e.g., the crisis management groups discussed above).\n\nInstead, fearing higher costs for United States banks, the Treasury apparently gave the concerns of foreign regulators considerable weight and took an internationalist approach.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nGeely has become Daimler\u2019s biggest stakeholder.\n\nThe Chinese manufacturer has built up a $9 billion stake, or just under 10 percent, in the German automaker and parent of Mercedes-Benz.\n\nFrom Bloomberg:\n\nThe investment in the parent of Mercedes-Benz furthers Hangzhou-based Geely\u2019s foray into the European premium automotive market and ends months of speculation. The Chinese company, controlled by billionaire Li Shufu, already owns Volvo Cars AB, whose refreshed line-up of vehicles have made it a popular alternative to the German luxury stalwarts.\n\nGeely also gained control of British sports-car maker Louts Cars last year.\n\nPhoto\n\nChina now controls the Waldorf Astoria\n\nThe government in Beijing seized control today of Anbang Insurance Group, the troubled Chinese company that owns the iconic New York hotel.\n\nThe details\n\n\u2022 The Chinese insurance regulator said Anbang had violated regulations, putting into question its ability to pay claims.\n\n\u2022 A group that includes China\u2019s central bank, its securities and banking regulators, the country\u2019s foreign exchange regulator and other government agencies will oversee Anbang for a year.\n\n\u2022 The takeover could be extended if Anbang fails to complete an equity restructuring and resume operations.\n\n\u2022 The company\u2019s former chairman was charged with financial crimes.\n\nThe context\n\nAnbang came under scrutiny for its opaque ownership structure and for the political ties of its former chairman as it embarked on a period of frenzied deal making.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Anbang and the other Chinese deal makers, which had borrowed heavily to fund their shopping sprees, soon drew attention from officials. State media labeled them \u201cgray rhinoceroses\u201d \u2014 big problems that are ignored until they start moving fast.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Quentin Webb of Breakingviews writes that the seizure is the boldest move yet in Beijing\u2019s battle against financial excess, and the new precedent could be a worrying omen.\n\n\u2022 Anbang\u2019s size and entanglements are comparable to Lehman Brothers or A.I.G. before the global financial crisis, and the insurer was always going to crash and burn if left untouched, writes Nisha Gopalan in Bloomberg Gadfly. Beijing\u2019s intervention deserves a round of applause, she adds.\n\nMore on Chinese deal makers\n\n\u2022 Financial strains at another buyer, HNA, have prompted its subsidiary, the Irish aircraft leaser Avolon, to rewrite its bond documentation to try to reassure investors. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Fosun has acquired Lanvin, France\u2019s oldest surviving couture house, after a fierce bidding war. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nGeneral Mills is to buy pet-food maker\n\nThe deal values Blue Buffalo at about $8 billion and bolsters an area for General Mills, which owns brands including Cheerios, Lucky Charms and Yoplait, that has become increasingly popular: natural foods for pets\n\nThe transaction is the latest as food makers, such as Mars and Danone, seek to acquire more organic and natural brands.\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Standard Life Aberdeen has agreed to sell what was left of its insurance business to Phoenix Group for about $4.5 billion. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nHow one tweet cost Snap $1.4 billion.\n\nShares of the social media company tumbled 6 percent on Thursday after Kylie Jenner tweeted that she no longer opened Snapchat.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tweet comes as Snap faces growing criticism from users about the redesign of its app.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\nFor tech companies like Snap and Twitter, Jennifer Saba of Breakingviews argues, celebrities \u201cought to be included as an intangible asset, to be written down when the celebrity stops being a customer \u2014 or stops being a celebrity.\u201d\n\nRelated\n\nEvan Spiegel, Snap\u2019s chief executive, received $638 million in total compensation in 2017. (CNNMoney)\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Altered images used by Russians to spread disinformation ahead of the 2016 U.S. election have exposed flaws in efforts by social media companies to stop such practices. (BBC)\n\n\u2022 Spotify\u2019s listing will put pressure on the music-streaming company to to reduce its reliance on music labels. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Airbnb unveiled its Plus service, which features properties that are guaranteed to meet a 100-point quality checklist. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The lesson of the video-game company Rovio\u2019s profit warning: Companies in high-risk industries with volatile earnings should think hard before going public. (Lex)\n\nPhoto\n\nI.C.O.s create a headache for virtual currencies\n\nWhat rights do shareholders get if a company goes for an initial coin offering?\n\nHere\u2019s The Information\u2019s Alfred Lee:\n\nConcerned about potential threats to share value and regulatory risks, venture capitalists are asking for rights to receive or buy cryptocurrency in the event of an offering. In some cases, several prominent investors and attorneys told The Information, venture capital firms are seeking to veto cryptocurrency offerings altogether.\n\nRelated\n\n\u2022 The crash in cryptocurrencies hasn\u2019t dented the popularity of initial coin offerings. (WSJ)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Bitcoin is at $10,234.30. (coinmarketcap.com)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhy do college endowments keep hold of poorly performing investments?\n\nWith their average returns dragged down by the weak performance of hedge funds, venture capital and private equity, you would think endowments would be fleeing these so-called alternative investments, which are costly and mostly illiquid, as some large pension funds have done.\n\nThat\u2019s the NYT\u2019s James Stewart, who tries to unpick the puzzle.\n\nSeparately, a group of Harvard graduates has a plan to bolster the university\u2019s straggling endowment.\n\nPhoto\n\nChanges are afoot for failing banks\n\nThe Treasury Department has proposed a regulatory move that would increase the likelihood that a failing bank would end up in bankruptcy rather than going through a resolution process overseen by the government.\n\nThe tweak would still keep the emergency structures introduced as part of Dodd-Frank as an option.\n\nFrom the NYT\u2019s Peter Eavis:\n\nCrucially, the Treasury also wants to keep the emergency government loan. But the Treasury\u2019s proposal does introduce an important and innovative change. It calls for a special type of bankruptcy regime for large financial firms, called Chapter 14. This new regime envisions having a set of specialist judges, working with regulators in the United States and around the world, who could plan for and oversee the bankruptcies of large banks.\n\nThe banking flyaround\n\n\u2022 Royal Bank of Scotland reported its first annual profit in a decade, after a grueling turnaround effort. That could make it easier for the British government to sell down its stake. (LSE)\n\n\u2022 Behind John Flint\u2019s bookish image lurks a ruthless streak that has helped him to rise to the role of chief executive at HSBC. (FT)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe revolving door\n\n\u2022 Dina Powell is talking to Goldman Sachs about returning to the firm in a global role, according to unnamed sources. (WSJ)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Kumar Galhotra, who has been running marketing and the Lincoln brand for Ford, will take over as head of North American operations after the abrupt departure of Raj Nair.
