(WSJ)\n\n\u2022 A federal judge criticized deferred prosecution agreements, which allow companies to avoid prosecution by paying a fine. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 The Japanese airbag maker Takata reached a $60 million deal to settle consumer protection claims in the U.S. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Hewlett Packard Enterprise\u2019s sales of storage and networking devices did well enough over the holiday quarter that it raised its annual profit targets. (WSJ)\n\nKnow someone who would enjoy this newsletter? Tell them to sign up here.\n\nYou can find live updates throughout the day at nytimes.com/dealbook.\n\nWe\u2019d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "DealBook Briefing: Dropbox Files to Go Public", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "But Monday\u2019s plunge was far less impressive on a percentage basis. The Dow\u2019s fall ranked as its 100th biggest, while the S. & P. 500\u2019s slide was the 127th biggest in the index\u2019s history, according to S & P Dow Jones Indices.\n\nHere is how Monday\u2019s sell-off stacks up against two other major tumbles.\n\nSept. 29, 2008\n\n\u2022 Dow: Down 777.78 points, or 6.98 percent\n\n\u2022 S. & P. 500: Down 106 points, or 8.81 percent\n\nJust weeks after Lehman Brothers failed in September 2008, lawmakers in the House defied President George W. Bush and rejected a $700 billion economic rescue plan. The vote sent markets tumbling to what was the biggest point loss in either index\u2019s history.\n\nBut points are not the best way to compare the magnitude of a stock index\u2019s declines across eras. As the stock market has risen, big point moves have translated into increasingly smaller percentage changes. The Dow and the S. & P. 500 have more than doubled from their closes on Sept. 29, 2008.\n\nOct. 19, 1987\n\n\u2022 Dow: Down 507.99, or 22.61 percent\n\n\u2022 S. & P. 500: Down 57.86, or 20.47 percent\n\n\u201cBlack Monday\u201d was a petrifying moment \u2014 an even bigger decline in both points and percentage than the stock market crash of 1929. But unlike the 1929 crash, the slide in 1987 did not contribute to a wider economic slump. The stock market recovered its losses by early 1989.\n\nBut the plunge did prompt regulators to introduce special brakes that kick in when the market falls too far, too fast. Stock markets, though, remain vulnerable to the sort of confusion and fear that one prominent economist said last year was a potent force in 1987.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer and Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nKenneth C. Griffin sees warning signs for stocks.\n\nAs the U.S. stock markets look wobbly for the first time in nearly two years, at least one major investor is sounding a bearish tone.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a Jan. 31 letter to investors, Kenneth C. Griffin, founder of the Chicago hedge-fund firm Citadel, wrote that even though the broader economic backdrop continues to be positive, he sees several warning signs that could turn stock prices downward.\n\nThe end of the Federal Reserve\u2019s efforts to stimulate the U.S. economy is one factor, Mr. Griffin wrote, that could pressure stocks. But the prospect of inflation, or a rapid rise in the prices of goods and services, is making him especially nervous.\n\n\u201cWe are particularly concerned about the nascent signs\u201d of rising inflation in a variety of countries, he wrote. As a result, he added, money managers at Citadel, which runs a variety of hedge funds, are \u201ccarefully positioning\u201d for a surprise, sharp upturn in inflation.\n\nMr. Griffin added that he is also concerned about geopolitical risks, writing that his money managers need to be able to handle negative events if they do occur, \u201cincluding a trade policy misstep or a military conflict.\u201d He did not elaborate.\n\nIn an interview with CNBC in November, Mr. Griffin said the stock market was in the \u201cseventh inning\u201d of a rally. He said through a spokesman on Monday that he still thinks there are several innings to go before a downturn begins and that he is more bearish on bond prices than stocks at the moment.\n\n\u2014 Kate Kelly\n\nHere\u2019s a reason to be positive on stocks: Corporate America is reporting strong earnings.\n\nWith 50 percent of the companies in the S.&P. 500 having reported results, profits are on pace to grow 13.4 percent, according to FactSet. If that growth rate holds through the end of earnings, it would mark the third quarter in the past four that S.&P. 500 companies have reported a double-digit profits increase.\n\nThe numbers\n\n\u202275 percent of companies are reporting earnings above estimates, above the five-year average.\n\n\u2022 Companies that are beating estimates are doing so by a 4 percent margin, below the five year average.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u202280 percent of companies have reported revenue above estimates, a record high.\n\n\u2022 All 11 sectors are reporting earnings growth.\n\nPhoto\n\nWill Wells Fargo miss out on the banking party?\n\nA Federal Reserve regulatory action, announced Friday evening, placed a cap on the amount of assets (loans and securities) that Wells Fargo can hold. The Fed took this action in response to misconduct at the bank that involved deceiving its customers. The cap will be in place until the Fed is satisfied that the bank has made sufficient improvements in its operations and corporate governance.\n\nWells Fargo\u2019s stock is down more than 7 percent Monday, suggesting that investors believe the growth cap will have some bite. With the economy strengthening and interest rates rising, banks can expect to earn higher profits as they make more loans and suffer fewer losses from defaults. Indeed, this optimistic scenario has helped send bank stocks on a tear in recent months. Now, the question is to what degree Wells Fargo will have to sit out the good times.\n\nWells Fargo executives on Friday suggested that the cap would have limited financial impact, saying it would reduce this year\u2019s net profits by $300 million to $400 million, which works out at less than 2 percent of 2017\u2019s earnings. One reason the earnings hit might be small is that the bank can stay within the cap by selling short-term, lower-risk investments that don\u2019t earn much. Another way the bank intends to limit the negative impact is by reducing the amount of deposits on which the bank pays out a relatively high interest rate.\n\nCrucially, Wells Fargo said that it hopes to increase the size of its loan book. The hope is that, by shedding the low-risk investments, the bank will create the room to make more mortgages, credit card loans and loans to businesses, while staying within the limit.\n\nBut it may not turn out to be as straightforward as that.\n\nThe growth cap comes after a lackluster year for Wells, which reduced its loans 1 percent last year, compared with an increase of 3.5 percent at Bank of America. Investors waiting for catch-up growth at Wells may have to wait still longer. Also, much depends on whether Wells Fargo can now satisfy the Fed\u2019s concerns. Any indication that the bank is struggling to comply with the regulator\u2019s demands could set off more turmoil at the bank. There is also a possibility that the tactic of shedding of low-risk investments while making more loans could increase the overall risk of Wells Fargo\u2019s balance sheet.\n\nBrian Kleinhanzl, a banks analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, wrote on Sunday that the Fed\u2019s action will \u201cmean Wells will have a harder time maintaining market share and will have to compete more on price or credit terms versus peers,\u201d adding, \u201cWells will also have to maintain the balance sheet while other banks are growing, and we view this as defensive versus peers.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nBroadcom puts more pressure on Qualcomm\n\nIn raising its takeover bid to about $121 billion just now, Broadcom is hoping to allay concerns about its takeover bid and its quest to create a behemoth in computer chips.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat Broadcom is offering:\n\n\u2022 A takeover price of $82 a share, up from its original offer of $70\n\n\u2022 A \u201csignificant\u201d breakup fee if a deal were to be halted for antitrust reasons\n\n\u2022 A \u201cticking fee\u201d that Broadcom would pay in cash if a deal took more than a year to close\n\nIt said the new \u201cbest and final\u201d offer would be withdrawn if Qualcomm either pushed its annual shareholder meeting back from March 6 (when Broadcom hopes to unseat the entire board) or if it paid more than $110 a share for NXP Semiconductor.\n\nThe context: Qualcomm recently reported a 96 percent drop in operating income amid a royalty dispute with Apple. That has given Broadcom some pause, but not enough to make it walk away.\n\nWhat\u2019s next: This offer isn\u2019t likely to tempt Qualcomm. It has a better chance of tempting investors, who might then press the chip maker into negotiations.\n\nStocks aren\u2019t the only asset selling off recently.\n\nBitcoin is down 14 percent Monday to $7,360. That\u2019s a more than 60 percent decline from its high of $19,511 hit on Dec. 8.\n\nOther cryptocurrencies are falling as well. Ripple, Ethereum and Litecoin are all down Monday.\n\nHow far can Bitcoin fall?\n\nSimon Tobler, a trader at Swiss-based Crypto Finance AG, told Bloomberg: \u201cIf we don\u2019t hold the $8,000 level, Bitcoin may fall to $5,000, where the next big support is. The market is lacking big buyers.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHow worried should JPMorgan clients be about health care?\n\nEver since the bank announced a partnership with Amazon and Berkshire Hathaway to create a new health care company, it appears that many have been very worried.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMore from Anna Wilde Mathews, Dana Cimilluca and Emily Glazer of the WSJ:\n\nIn a reflection of the sensitivity of the subject, JPMorgan Chief Executive James Dimon hit the phones Tuesday to assuage clients\u2019 concerns, people familiar with the matter said. So did some of the firm\u2019s health care bankers, who get paid handsomely to help clients with mergers and other deals and worry the move could cost them business.\n\nOne response: Ultimately, Mr. Dimon, Jeff Bezos and Warren Buffett are working on a sort of group-purchasing venture, according to some of JPMorgan\u2019s bankers. That\u2019s far less transformative than some on Wall Street had hoped \u2014 or feared.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow much more will Wells Fargo have to do?\n\nOn Janet Yellen\u2019s last day atop the Fed (see below), the regulator demanded that Wells Fargo replace four directors and capped the bank\u2019s growth. The goal: to send a message.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Emily Flitter, Binyamin Appelbaum and David Enrich:\n\nThe settlement is an attempt by the Fed to impress upon banks that their boards of directors should be vigorous, independent watchdogs \u2014 and if they fail, there will be consequences. That reflects a shift from regulators\u2019 historically hands-off approach to corporate boards, and the boards\u2019 role is likely to grow in importance as regulators appointed by President Trump and Republicans in Congress generally loosen the reins on big banks.\n\nBehind the scenes: Wells Fargo executives were irate that the Fed\u2019s announcement trumpeted the replacement of the banks\u2019 directors, and that it implied the boardroom changes came at the Fed\u2019s instruction.\n\nThe big question: Will Wells Fargo have to do more than it just agreed? Gillian Tan of Gadfly suggests that Timothy Sloan, who became the bank\u2019s C.E.O. after the scandals, may have to go.\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 Paul Ryan deleted a tweet crediting the tax overhaul for a secretary\u2019s $1.50-a-week pay raise. He\u2019s still being mocked for it. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The federal government is set to nearly double its borrowing this fiscal year, to $955 billion. (WaPo)\n\n\u2022 Democrats on the House Intelligence Committee plan to push for the release of their own memo rebutting the one by Representative Devin Nunes about the surveillance of a Trump campaign aide. Mr. Nunes said he, too, had more memos to release.\n\n\u2022 Senator Dick Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, said that Congress is unlikely to reach an agreement to protect the immigrants known as Dreamers this week, despite a Feb. 8 government funding deadline. But John McCain and Chris Coons plan on introducing a bipartisan immigration bill anyway.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Jeff Sessions\u2019s silence in the wake of President Trump\u2019s attacks on the Justice Department has weakened morale there. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nJanet Yellen\u2019s exit interview\n\nThe now-former Fed chairwoman told PBS NewsHour that while she didn\u2019t agree with Alan Greenspan that there were bubbles in the stock and bond markets, she did see reasons for concern.\n\nFrom her interview with Judy Woodruff:\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to label what we\u2019re seeing a bubble \u2014 as a bubble. \u201cBut I would say that asset valuations generally are elevated, and this is a characterization that we have offered up, for example, last summer in our monetary policy report.\u201d\n\nAlready, investors appear more cautious, faced with a tight-looking labor market and central banks potentially preparing to raise rates and take away the easy-money punch bowl.\n\nToday\u2019s update: Both Asian and European stock markets continued Friday\u2019s declines.\n\nMore from Ms. Yellen: She also spoke about being the first Fed chair in history not to be renominated after a full term. \u201cWell, I would have liked to serve an additional term, and I did make that clear. So, I will say that I was disappointed not to be reappointed,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nStarboard attacks Mellanox over stock sales\n\nStarboard Value, the activist hedge fund, has taken up a new line of attack as it pushes for change at the chip maker Mellanox. It is accusing top executives and board members of not having enough faith in their company.\n\nThe criticism: Starboard says Mellanox management and directors have sold shares more than 370 times since the company\u2019s I.P.O., while buying its shares on the open market just once.\n\nThe bigger picture: Starboard is trying to unseat Mellanox\u2019s entire board, arguing that the company needs either to improve its business, including by being more focused in its research spending, or to consider selling itself.\n\nPhoto\n\nInstead of Viacom, should CBS strike a deal with Amazon?\n\nHere\u2019s a summary of the case for that, put forth by Ed Lee at Recode:\n\n\u2022 Getting bigger by merging with another media company doesn\u2019t solve CBS\u2019s problems. Selling to a tech giant with great online distribution does more.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Amazon\u2019s exceptionally deep pockets would let CBS bid for expensive must-watch content like sports rights amid tougher competition.\n\nThe very big question: Would Shari Redstone, who with her father controls both CBS and Viacom, allow a deal that didn\u2019t involve both companies?\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Is debt driving Dell\u2019s deliberations about a potential I.P.O. or deal with VMware? Maybe less than you\u2019d think. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Soho House, the operator of trendy members\u2019 clubs, has hired Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase to lead a planned I.P.O. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Does the deal boom signal a top for the debt markets? (FT)\n\n\u2022 The Carlyle Group, Bain Capital and Apollo Global Management are among those jockeying for Akzo Nobel\u2019s chemicals unit, according to unnamed sources. (FT)\n\n\u2022 GlaxoSmithKline and Reckitt Benckiser were the only bidders for Pfizer\u2019s consumer unit, according to unnamed sources. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nSamsung\u2019s heir walks out of prison\n\nA South Korean appeals court reduced and suspended Lee Jae-yong\u2019s sentence for bribery and corruption.\n\nA lawyer for Mr. Lee said that his client would appeal to South Korea\u2019s Supreme Court to be declared innocent of the remaining charges. Prosecutors haven\u2019t yet said if they\u2019ll appeal. But critics of the country\u2019s conglomerates had hoped that Mr. Lee\u2019s original, unusually long sentence \u2014 five years \u2014 would herald tougher regulation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe context: Samsung has done fine with Mr. Lee in jail: Its electronics operation is earning gangbuster profits and its semiconductor business is well positioned to keep minting money.\n\nWhere is Bitcoin today?\n\nAt $7,783, says CoinMarketCap, down another 12 percent over the past 24 hours. Other big virtual currencies are down, too.\n\nNot helping: Credit card issuers including JPMorgan, Bank of America, Citigroup and Lloyds are now blocking purchases of virtual currency.\n\nHow Bell Pottinger, a pioneer of shameless P.R., died\n\nIt helped create the template for London P.R. firms catering to foreign governments. But it went bankrupt in a tale of corporate skulduggery \u2014 working for the wealthy Gupta family of South Africa and inflaming racial tensions there \u2014 that seems lifted from \u201cHouse of Cards.\u201d\n\nMore from David Segal of the NYT:\n\n\u201cIn my years of running the P.R.C.A., I have never seen anything worse, never seen anything equal to it,\u201d Francis Ingham, director general of the trade association, said in an interview. \u201cThe work was on a completely new scale of awfulness. Bell Pottinger may have set back race relations in South Africa by as much as 10 years.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 Uma Thurman has opened up about what she described as sexual misconduct toward her by Harvey Weinstein. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Five women of different ages and professions gathered to discuss experiences of the gender wage gap: \u201cThat was the most humiliating experience that I have ever had.\u201d (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nQuote of the day\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of entrepreneurs [in Silicon Valley] developing the next app for clothes shopping who say, not ironically, that \u2018We are changing the world.\u2019 You\u2019re not changing the world.\u201d\n\n\u2014 J.D. Vance, venture investor and memoirist, in a lunch interview with the F.T.\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 Unilever brought deodorant to China dreaming of a market with 2.6 billion armpits, but struggled against beliefs that it\u2019s healthy to sweat. Other companies have hit similar cultural difficulties. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Early employees of Google and Facebook are among the founders of the Center for Humane Technology, which will challenge the companies they helped to build. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Amazon has trained markets to give it leeway. They appear to accept that it has a strategy for Whole Foods that will take time. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 New York Times reporters bought the same ingredients for Super Bowl meatballs at a Whole Foods 365 store and a Walmart. Both the price and the outcome were different. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Greg Coffey, the star hedge fund trader known as \u201cthe Wizard of Oz\u201d who retired five years ago, is raising $2 billion for a new fund focused on emerging markets, according to anonymous sources. (FT)\n\nWant this in your own email inbox? Here\u2019s the sign-up.\n\nYou can find live updates throughout the day at nytimes.com/dealbook.\n\nWe\u2019d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "DealBook Briefing: How Monday\u2019s Stock Plunge Ranks?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The culprit? The Model 3, Tesla\u2019s first mass-market car. Many of the costs associated with the Model 3 are being booked in the income statement but difficulties in producing the car mean sales are low. As a result, the gross margin on the Model 3 was negative and is expected to remain so in the first quarter of 2018, Tesla said. The company did not specify how negative the gross margin on the Model 3 was.\n\nTesla tried to be reassuring. The company said it was on track to produce 5,000 Model 3s by the middle of 2018. The company had pushed back when it would hit this 5,000 vehicle target last month. But Tesla did not sound overly confident about achieving its Model 3 milestones. The company said:\n\n\u201cIt is important to note that while these are the levels we are focused on hitting and we have plans in place to achieve them, our prior experience on the Model 3 ramp has demonstrated the difficulty of accurately forecasting specific production rates at specific points in time.\u201d\n\nCash flow may not be as impressive as it looked. In the fourth quarter, Tesla brought in $510 million of operating cash flow, a big turnaround from an outflow of $301 million in the prior three months. How did Tesla pull this off? The company said the increase was achieved in part by doing a better job collecting the money it is owed and by reducing its inventory of finished vehicles. But the company\u2019s balance sheet showed a nearly $500 million increase in short-term liabilities in the fourth quarter. In other words, the amounts Tesla owes its customers and suppliers went up. It may be tough to keep generating cash flow in this fashion.\n\nIt wouldn\u2019t be a Tesla call without something for the bulls: Elon Musk said on the call that \u201c2018 is likely to be a very big year for Tesla\u201d and that he is optimistic Tesla will be GAAP profitable. \u201cIt\u2019s not certain, but I\u2019m cautiously optimistic,\u201d Mr. Musk said.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nAthenahealth names Jeff Immelt as chairman.\n\nSince stepping down from General Electric last year, Jeff Immelt has certainly been keeping busy. He interviewed for the Uber C.E.O. position and joined the venture capital firm New Enterprise Associates as a partner.\n\nNow he is adding \u201cchairman of a fast-growing health company\u201d to his titles.\n\nAthenahealth, a provider of electronic medical records software, announced Wednesday that it has hired Mr. Immelt as its chairman, capping a monthslong search for the position.\n\nThe context\n\nThe move adds a veteran corporate chieftain to oversee the fast-growing company, particularly as it seeks to prove that it\u2019s capable of maturing.\n\nAthenahealth had been under pressure last year from Elliott Management, which disclosed a 9.2 percent stake in the company last spring and pressed for operational changes. Jonathan Bush, the company\u2019s founder and C.E.O. (and a cousin of George W. Bush) credited the activist investor with helping him realize that a shake-up was necessary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe company beat earnings and revenue estimates in its fourth quarter.\n\nFor Mr. Immelt, joining Athenahealth is in keeping with his interest in the health care business, a focus of his at G.E.\n\nWhat the principals say about the appointment\n\n\u2022 \u201cI literally feel like I just scored a decade\u2019s worth of guitar lessons from Elvis,\u201d Mr. Bush said in a telephone interview.\n\n\u2022 \u201cI\u2019m convinced that this platform at Athenahealth can be one of the transformational platforms for health care,\u201d Mr. Immelt said, adding, \u201cI\u2019m a junkie for the industry.\u201d\n\nThe big question\n\nCan a founder who has run the company since its beginning take direction from an outsider? Mr. Bush said that with Mr. Immelt, the answer is yes.\n\n\u201cI feel like I\u2019m doing less marriage counseling with 12 adults,\u201d Mr. Bush said of his board, adding that Mr. Immelt would be a partner to take advice from (and occasionally whine to).\n\nAn outside perspective\n\n\u201cWhat Jeff brings is an understanding of scale on a couple of dimensions, not only in terms of people and processes but also how you think about scaling with your partners.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Henry Ellenbogen of T. Rowe Price, one of Athenahealth\u2019s biggest shareholders, said in a phone interview.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nSenate leaders reach a deal to raise spending.\n\nThomas Kaplan of the NYT reports that Senators Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, and Chuck Schumer of New York, his Democratic counterpart, have struck a far-reaching agreement that would add hundreds of billions of dollars to military and domestic programs over the next two years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe deal would:\n\n\u2022 raise the spending caps by about $300 billion over two years, according to a congressional aide.\n\n\u2022 increase the limit on military spending by $80 billion in the current fiscal year and $85 billion in the next year, which begins Oct. 1, the aide said.\n\n\u2022 increase the limit on nondefense spending by $63 billion this year and $68 billion next year.\n\nThe bigger picture\n\n\u201cThe deal will cause federal budget deficits to grow even larger, on top of the effects of the sweeping tax overhaul that lawmakers approved in December. But because the agreement gives both parties what they wanted most, the deficit impact appears to be of little concern. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders and Speaker Paul D. Ryan all quickly embraced it.\u201d\n\nCritics corner\n\n\u2022 Hard-line conservatives were unsparing in their assessment of the deal.\n\n\u2022 Representative Nancy Pelosi, the leader of House Democrats, said she could not agree to any budget deal that was not accompanied by a debate over legislation to protect the fate of young immigrants brought to the country illegally as children, known as Dreamers.\n\nPhoto\n\nHas Snap finally snapped its losing streak?\n\nShares of the messaging and media company surged nearly 40 percent to $19.49 in recent trading. That\u2019s their highest level since June and well above its initial public offering price of $17 a share.\n\nThe jump comes after the company reported results after the close on Tuesday. David Streitfeld of the NYT writes:\n\n\u201cRevenue was $286 million, up 72 percent from a year earlier and about $30 million more than analysts had expected. Daily users rose nine million to 187 million, the best growth in over a year. The retention rate of new Android users, a special focus for Snap, jumped nearly 20 percent over the previous year.\u201d \u201cThe company lost $350 million in the quarter, or 13 cents a share, which was narrower than the loss of 16 cents that was expected by analysts. And it also contrasted with the carnage of the prior quarter, when Snap recorded a net loss that was twice the forecast.\u201d\n\nThe bigger picture\n\nThe results have helped quell some of the concerns about the company\u2019s slowing revenue and user growth in the face of increased competition from the likes of Facebook.\n\nCritics corner\n\nRoss Sandler of Barclays: \u201cWe think shares could continue to grind higher as the narrative changes from 2017\u2019s \u2018FB is going to crush SNAP\u2019 to 2018\u2019s \u201cusers and revenue accelerate and the platform is under-monetized\u201d. Shares are expensive (8.3x our FY19 revenue estimate), but everything is accelerating, and as we\u2019ve seen repeatedly in consumer internet, these inflection points are not likely one-quarter events.\u201d\n\nDaniel Ives of GBH Insights: \u201cThis eye popping top-line beat was a \u2018shocker\u2019 and was a stark contrast to the overwhelming bear sentiment heading into the 4Q print and speaks to a company with strong growth prospects, albeit clear business challenges ahead to iron out in 2018. After much pain that investors have endured since SNAP went public, this quarter was finally a breath of fresh air that gives new life to the SNAP turnaround story in 2018.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTrump: Investors are making a mistake.\n\nPresident Trump, who has taken credit for a rising stock market as a measure of his own success, complained on Twitter Wednesday that \u201cgood (great) news\u201d in the economy led to an abrupt decline in stock prices, his first comments about the stock market since its sharp drop earlier this week.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the early-morning tweet, Mr. Trump lamented that in the \u201cold days,\u201d stocks would rise on good economic news, saying \u201cToday, when good news is reported, the Stock Market goes down. Big mistake.\u201d The tweet did not elaborate on what he meant by the \u201cold days\u201d or explain further his analysis of why stocks plummeted on Friday and Monday.\n\nUntil Wednesday\u2019s tweet, the president had been unusually silent about the stock market, which has been rocked by volatility, including a decline in the Dow Jones industrial average of almost 7 percent over two days. At one point on Monday, the Dow was down almost 1,600 points, or about 6 percent of its total value, the markets plunging at the same moment as Mr. Trump was giving a speech in Blue Ash, Ohio. It closed that day down 1,175 points.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s assertion that the fall was pegged to good economic news stems from Friday\u2019s job report, which showed wages beginning to rise as the economy nears full employment.\n\n\u2014 Michael D. Shear and Alan Rappeport\n\nThe bigger picture\n\n\n\nWelcome to the end of easy money, as strengthening economies lead to higher wages and tighter unemployment \u2014 and potentially to central bankers raising interest rates.\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s tax cut was meant to supercharge growth in an economy already doing fine. (Though Eduardo Porter notes that productivity is low and new business formation has slowed.) Economists and analysts are increasingly worried that the tax overhaul will do the opposite of what it was intended to.\n\nPhoto\n\nWe still have questions about Wynn Resorts\u2019 board\n\nSteve Wynn resigned yesterday as the C.E.O. of Wynn Resorts after allegations of sexual misconduct. Those accusations have created an important test for corporate America.\n\nIn recent months, many powerful men have had to step down from senior positions as they have faced accusations of sexual harassment, but none were the head of a public company like Mr. Wynn. How would the board, shareholders, regulators, customers and unions react?\n\nWe now know something about the shareholder perspective: Shares in Wynn Resorts were up 7 percent in early-morning trading today. Regulators in Nevada, Massachusetts and Macau are still conducting their own investigations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the biggest unresolved question remains the board and its conduct.\n\nThe board set up a committee of independent directors to carry out an investigation after the WSJ article, but it was not clear how rigorous it would be. The board did not have a track record for holding Mr. Wynn accountable.\n\nIn an email exchange with me, Lucian Bebchuk, a Harvard law professor and an expert in corporate governance, asked why the board did not suspend Mr. Wynn from his position pending the investigation, or demand that he not interact with Wynn Resorts employees, a step that would have limited his ability to influence the board investigation.\n\nIn fact, the board, in its statement, sounded somewhat saddened by Mr. Wynn\u2019s departure, saying it had \u201creluctantly\u201d accepted his resignation.\n\nOne remaining way to assess the board\u2019s resolve will be Mr. Wynn\u2019s separation agreement, which is not yet finalized.\n\nWhen the WSJ article was published, Mr. Wynn denied the accusations of sexual misconduct, calling them \u201cpreposterous.\u201d On Tuesday he said, \u201cI have found myself the focus of an avalanche of negative publicity.\u201d\n\nIt is not clear why Mr. Wynn decided to step down. It may have been pressure from gaming regulators. Customers might have been pulling back.\n\nMr. Wynn may have wanted to preserve the value of his own stake in Wynn Resorts. But as it stands, it does not look like the board was a strong force.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nMisconduct claims take down an S. & P. 500 C.E.O.\n\nSteve Wynn has stepped down from his $17 billion casino empire, a little over a week after allegations of forced sex and other sexual misconduct claims emerged in a WSJ investigation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere had been little sense at Wynn Resorts over the last week that the man who made modern Las Vegas was on his way out:\n\nTop executives spent hours with Mr. Wynn going over plans for a new casino he would like to build in Las Vegas, according to a person familiar with the matter, while the company\u2019s general counsel hopped on a call with other executives to discuss the Vegas Strong Fund, a nonprofit formed in the aftermath of last year\u2019s mass shooting on the Las Vegas Strip, according to a person familiar with the call.\n\nHe also attended the company\u2019s 1,500-guest Super Bowl party on Sunday, the WSJ says.\n\nIn a statement, Mr. Wynn blamed his exit on \u201ca rush to judgment\u201d that took \u201cprecedence over everything, including the facts.\u201d\n\nThe intrigue: The company\u2019s news release reads almost like a corporate eulogy, calling Mr. Wynn a \u201cbeloved leader and visionary.\u201d So why the sudden exit? (Our colleague Peter Eavis will weigh in on DealBook this morning.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe big questions\n\n\u2022 Do other S. & P. 500 C.E.O.s now have something to fear?\n\n\u2022 And is the Wynn empire \u2014 from Las Vegas to Macau to, soon, Massachusetts \u2014 now ripe for a takeover or breakup?\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 \u201cWhile there are plenty of jobs for women as waitresses and croupiers, far too few rise to the levels at which they have the power to make a change,\u201d David Fickling writes. (Gadfly)\n\n\u2022 \u201cIt\u2019s easy for a company in turmoil, especially one so closely associated with a celebrity founder that has effectively been forced out, to become prey,\u201d Jeff Goldfarb writes. (Breakingviews)\n\nPhoto\n\nPatrick Soon-Shiong becomes the next billionaire news mogul.\n\nThe billionaire Los Angeles doctor joins Jeff Bezos, Sheldon Adelson and Warren Buffett after he reached a deal to buy the L.A. Times and the San Diego Union-Tribune from Tronc for nearly $500 million. The deal price includes the assumption of $90 million in pension liabilities.\n\nLAT staff have chafed at the decisions of Tronc and its chairman, Michael Ferro. More from Sydney Ember of the NYT:\n\nMany employees at The Times have of late adopted the mantra \u201canyone but Ferro,\u201d but it is also not clear what decisions Dr. Soon-Shiong, who largely made his fortune selling generic drugs and developing a new type of cancer drug, will make as the paper\u2019s owner.\n\nSeparately, Tronc said it is reorganizing its Tribune Interactive business. The company said Ross Levinsohn, the publisher of the Los Angeles Times who was put on leave after National Public Radio published a report that detailed allegations of sexual harassment against him when he was at other companies, will be reinstated and named the chief executive of Tribune Interactive.\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 SoftBank said it had spent $40 billion from its roughly $106 billion Vision Fund and Delta Fund, and that it plans to spin out its Japanese mobile unit.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Google is expanding its New York headquarters, agreeing to buy the building across the street \u2014 which is home to Chelsea Market \u2014 for more than $2 billion. (Real Deal)\n\n\u2022 An activist investor, Blackwells Capital, urged the supermarket chain Supervalu to break itself up, and plans a proxy fight. (WSJ)\n\nPhoto\n\nInvestors Sell C.B.O.E.\n\nAs the stocks calmly glided higher in 2017, investors from hedge fund titans to day traders poured billions in to bets that volatility would continue to fall.\n\nThose wagers blew up this week.\n\nNow investors are selling the exchange company behind the trading in volatility.\n\nShares of the C.B.O.E. Global Markets, whose volatility index facilitated those wagers, are down 17 percent since the start of the sell-off. Thursday they are off 3 percent.\n\nThe reason? Concern that demand for VIX futures could drop after a blowup in some popular products that use them to bet on falling volatility in the stock market, writes MoneyBeat\u2019s Ben Eisen.\n\nCritics corner\n\nKenneth Worthington, JPMorgan Chase: \u201cGiven VIX has been a key growth driver of CBOE, we also see the potential for a deterioration in CBOE valuation.\u201d\n\nAlexander Blostein, Goldman Sachs, via CNBC: \u201cWhile we remain optimistic around the firm\u2019s longer-term growth prospects... we expect the unwind in VIX exchange-traded products (including any potential further unwind of these products) to weigh on Cboe\u2019s VIX futures franchise, creating headwinds to the firm\u2019s top-line growth and potentially the stock\u2019s valuation.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBlame the VIX/machines/debt?\n\n\u2022 Analysts took a closer look at the \u201cinverse VIX\u201d trade \u2014 bets on a continued fall in the popular Wall Street volatility index that went very sour on Monday and forced a lot of selling.\n\n\u2022 Steven Mnuchin suggested yesterday that algorithms might be behind the whipsawing: \u201cI have heard from others that it has played a role, as there\u2019s more programmed trading, this tends to have volatility in both directions.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Carl Icahn said exotic investment funds and lots of leverage had made the markets a \u201ccasino on steroids.\u201d\n\nThink about the deals: A Turkish franchisee of Burger King restaurants postponed its market debut yesterday, while deal makers worry that a steady stream of big mergers will dry up.\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump called for a government shutdown if Congress did not address illegal immigration, even as lawmakers work on a two-year budget deal. John Kelly, his chief of staff, derided Dreamers who did not register for protected status.\n\n\u2022 The White House says it will explain the \u201cprinciples\u201d of its infrastructure plan on Monday. (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 The U.S. had a record trade deficit with China last year, potentially encouraging a tougher line from the Trump administration. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump wants the Pentagon to hold a big \u2014 and rare \u2014 military parade in Washington this year. (WaPo)\n\nPhoto\n\nHow a fight over Airbnb\u2019s I.P.O. plans led to a shake-up\n\nOn one side: Brian Chesky, the home rental giant\u2019s co-founder and C.E.O., who wants it kept private a while yet.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn the other, supporting an I.P.O. this year, according to Bloomberg\u2019s unnamed sources: the C.F.O. Laurence \u201cL.T.\u201d Tosi and the Airbnb investors General Atlantic, Glade Brook Capital, TCV and TPG.\n\nMore from Olivia Zaleski:\n\nDespite pledging support for Chesky\u2019s desire to keep Airbnb private, Sequoia Capital partner Alfred Lin, along with Jeff Jordan of Andreessen Horowitz, wanted to explore the possibility. In December, they asked Michael Grimes, the head of global technology investment banking at Morgan Stanley, to present options for going public, said people close to the bank.\n\nUltimately, Mr. Tosi \u2014 who didn\u2019t see eye to eye with Mr. Chesky on other issues and generally did not fit in at Airbnb \u2014 resigned.\n\nAn Airbnb spokesman denied there was ever any intent to pursue an I.P.O. this year.\n\nBonus trivia: Mr. Tosi set up a hedge fund of sorts at Airbnb, which was responsible for 30 percent of Airbnb\u2019s cash flow last year and made about $60 million.\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Goldman Sachs\u2019s retail arm is in talks to offer financing for Apple customers, unnamed sources say. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Snap bolstered revenue and user growth in the fourth quarter, and investors rejoiced. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 At the Uber-Waymo trial, Travis Kalanick kept calm and talked about his \u201cjam sesh\u201d with the autonomous-driving engineer at the center of the dispute. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Senators criticized Uber for how it handled a 2016 data breach. Meanwhile, the company is hoping to offer air taxis by 2025, through a deal with Bell Helicopter, and is giving its U.S. riders exclusive Winter Olympics content.\n\n\u2022 A pollster hired by Facebook to track public sentiment about Mark Zuckerberg said he left after coming to believe the company wasn\u2019t good for society. (The Verge)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 European regulators are closely examining Apple\u2019s bid for the music app Shazam. And Apple might give rebates to users who bought iPhone battery replacements before it discounted them.\n\nPhoto\n\nRegulators are coming for Bitcoin\n\nThe S.E.C. and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission told senators that Congress should consider expanding federal oversight of cryptocurrency trading.\n\nAnd Agustin Carstens, the head of the Bank for International Settlements, said central banks must be prepared to intervene, calling digital currencies a \u201ccombination of a bubble, a Ponzi scheme and an environmental disaster.\u201d\n\nMr. Carstens also argued that cryptocurrencies were freeloading on existing financial infrastructure and the legitimacy that came from being linked to it.\n\nOn a positive note, while Bitcoin is at about $8,000 this morning, things could get far worse, according to Goldman Sachs:\n\nMost digital currencies are unlikely to survive in their current form, and investors should prepare for coins to lose all their value as they\u2019re replaced by a small set of future competitors, Goldman\u2019s Steve Strongin said in a report dated Feb. 5.\n\nRevolving door\n\n\u2022 Slack named a longtime executive, Allen Shim, as its C.F.O., another step on the road to a listing. (Slack)\n\n\u2022 AIG has hired Caroline Krass, a partner at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher and a former general counsel of the C.I.A., as deputy general counsel. (AIG)\n\nPhoto\n\nQuote of the day\n\n\u201cCrazy things can come true.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Elon Musk, after SpaceX successfully launched its Falcon Heavy rocket (carrying a cherry red Tesla roadster) from Cape Canaveral, Fla. yesterday. David Bowie\u2019s \u201cLife on Mars\u201d played at the end of the webcast.\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 A livery driver who had written about being a casualty of the gig economy killed himself outside City Hall in Lower Manhattan on Monday. It has caused outages for nearly a week. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "DealBook Briefing: Tesla\u2019s Mass Market Hopes May Remain Elusive", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "A deal could be announced as soon as Wednesday but could still fall apart, the people said. Tronc is likely to use the sale proceeds to pay down its debt.\n\nDr. Soon-Shiong, the founder, chief executive and chairman of NantHealth, a health care company, was in a public feud last year with Michael W. Ferro Jr., Tronc\u2019s nonexecutive chairman, as they vied to increase their stakes in the company in apparent attempts to outmaneuver each other for control.\n\n\u2014 Sydney Ember\n\nIt\u2019s Turnaround Tuesday\n\nAfter days of sometimes wild moves in stock markets, investors on Wall Street refocused on the ongoing strength in the American economy as shares of consumer companies helped lead broad indexes higher.\n\nA sometimes-panicky global market sell-off \u2014 begun Monday when the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index lost more than 4 percent, its worst decline since August 2011 \u2014 dissipated through the day, and the S.&P. 500 ended Tuesday\u2019s session up by about 1.7 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average gained about 2.3 percent.\n\nThe consumer discretionary sector of the S.&P. 500 jumped by more than 2 percent, pulled higher by strength in well-known consumer-facing companies like Amazon, Netflix and Home Depot. General Motors also rose after reporting strong earnings and strong demand for its pickup trucks and SUVs.\n\nInvestors appeared to reassess whether the previous day\u2019s violent decline\u2014the S.&P. suffered its worst decline since August 2011\u2014reflected actual fundamentals or was merely a long-overdue outbreak of investor jitters.\n\nFor months, markets seemed to sleepwalk higher, as measures of volatility\u2014the ups and downs of stock prices\u2014hit historically low levels. Investors appeared to grow accustomed to an economic backdrop in which growth and inflation remained lackluster, a state of affairs that ensured powerful global central banks would continue to support markets with a range of policies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the peaceful climb ended over the past week amid worries that solid economic growth in the United States and abroad could be showing early signals of growing inflation pressure. Those concerns drove yields on long-term Treasury bonds sharply higher in recent weeks, as economic data\u2014such as the U.S. jobs report on Friday\u2014showed wages growing at their fastest clip in years.\n\n\u2014 Matt Phillips\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nDisney easily exceeds Wall Street\u2019s expectations.\n\nThe Walt Disney Company on Tuesday became the latest prominent company to report solid earnings amidst the market turmoil. The strong numbers support the belief that plunging stock markets do not reflect weakness in the real economy.\n\nDisney made $1.89 per share in the last three months of 2017, after excluding a tax benefit. That number is 22 percent higher than the $1.55 per share earnings in the same period of 2016. It is also well in excess of the $1.61 per share that Wall Street analysts had forecast for the latest quarter.\n\nDisney did best in its parks and resorts business, which reported $1.35 billion of operating income, which was 21 percent higher than the year-earlier period. The earlier period\u2019s results were somewhat depressed by the impact of Hurricane Matthew, Disney said. In its press release, the company noted that higher profits at its domestic parks and resorts were driven by an increase in guest spending and an increase in attendance, which underscores consumers\u2019 willingness to spend more. On the other hand, the company said parks and resorts are dealing with higher labor costs and other expenses. That may not be lost on investors who are starting to see inflation as a threat to stock prices.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nSnap jumps 20 percent after earnings.\n\nThe company reported earnings after the close that easily beat analysts\u2019 expectations.\n\nThe Numbers\n\n\u2022 Snap reported revenue rose 72 percent to $285.7 million, easily exceeding the $252.9 million expected by analysts.\n\n\u2022 The company lost 13 cents per share, below estimates of 16 cents a share.\n\n\u2022 Snap added 8.9 million daily active users for a total of 187 million, compared to the 184.2 million estimated.\n\nThe Context\n\nSnap\u2019s shares have struggled since its initial public offering in March 2017. The stock fell below its I.P.O price of $17 a share last summer and has remained below that level since. If Snap\u2019s after-hours gains hold up on Wednesday, the stock will be on the cusp of crossing back over its I.P.O. level.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nReasons not to worry about the recent sell-off.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe stock market\u2019s slide over the past week has given investors plenty of anxiety.\n\nStocks have lost roughly $4 trillion in value. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S.&P. 500 endured their worst point declines in their histories Monday and their largest percentage drops since 2011. C.B.O.E. Volatility Index surged more than 100 percent Monday, the biggest increase in its history.\n\nBut there are reasons investors shouldn\u2019t get too concerned.\n\n1) Heading into the final hour of trading, the markets have rebounded strongly. The Dow has jumped 2 percent, while the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite are up 1.6 percent and 1.9 percent. That suggests that worst of the sell-off may be passed.\n\n2) The outlook for economic growth is strong in the United States. The American economy grew 2.6 percent in the fourth quarter and the Atlanta Fed\u2019s GDPNow tracker forecasts a 4 percent rise in the first quarter.\n\n3) Corporate America\u2019s bottom line is growing. With 50 percent of the companies in the S.&P. 500 having reported results, profits are on pace to grow 13.4 percent, according to FactSet. If that growth rate holds through the end of earnings, it would mark the third quarter in the past four that S.&P. 500 companies have reported a double-digit profits increase.\n\n4) The sell-off comes after a big run-up in stocks. Until Monday, the Dow and the S.&P. 500 hadn\u2019t endured a pullback of 5 percent in more than 400 sessions. Since 1929, a 5 percent decline happens every 92 days on average, according to Goldman Sachs. So stocks were arguably due for a selloff. But it should be noted that after Monday\u2019s declines the Dow was at levels last seen in, well, mid-December and was up more than 30 percent since the 2016 election.\n\nStrategists over at Goldman Sachs wrote:\n\n\u201cThe stock market correction appears to be more technical and positioning-driven rather than fundamentally-based.We believe the fundamental drivers of the equity market remain intact and reiterate our S&P 500 year-end 2018 forecast of 2850.\u201d\n\nSpaceX successfully launches its Heavy Falcon rocket.\n\nThe company, founded by Elon Musk, achieved a new milestone with a successful test launch of its Falcon Heavy rocket, the most powerful rocket in operation in the world today.\n\nHere\u2019s a video of the launch:\n\nWill the Mouse help keep the bear at bay?\n\nWhen stock markets are plunging, sober-minded investors try to gauge the underlying strength of bellwether companies, to see whether all the selling is justified.\n\nThat is why many eyes will be on the earnings of the Walt Disney Company, which reports after the close of regular trading Tuesday. If the company releases stronger-than-expected results for the three months through the end of December, it will reinforce a general sense of optimism about corporate America .\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStellar results from Disney would add to a strong earnings report on Tuesday from General Motors, which helped push the company\u2019s shares 3 percent higher. Micron Technology, a large maker of computer chips, on Monday upped its outlook for the current quarter. Its shares soared 7.7 percent on Tuesday.\n\nThough Disney is not a high growth company, its results offer insight into the strength of consumer spending. As a result, if the company reports earnings that are below the forecasts of Wall Street analysts, it may add to the unease among investors..\n\nThe numbers to watch: Analysts expect Disney to earn $1.61 per share, and take in $15.44 billion in revenue in the quarter, according to data from Bloomberg.\n\nOf course, a lot more companies are going to have to report strong earnings to convince investors to jump back into the stock market. One of the reasons that stocks rallied in recent months is that analysts are expecting a 20-percent plus jump in profits in 2018, an eye-popping rise. The more large companies that hit their numbers in this earnings season, the more likely the stock market will find a floor.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nClayton: \u201cThere\u2019s nothing that came out of this that concerns me.\u201d\n\nAt a hearing of the Senate banking committee on Tuesday, Senator Richard Shelby of Alabama asked the heads of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission about the market turmoil.\n\n\u201cIs this perhaps more than an ordinary correction?\u201d Mr. Shelby asked.\n\nJay Clayton, the chairman of the S.E.C. said that he could not tell what had caused the big declines, but he said that the market infrastructure had held up well under the strain of heavy trading.\n\n\u201cAs I sit here today, there\u2019s nothing that came out of this that concerns me,\u201d Mr. Clayton said.\n\nChristopher Giancarlo, the chairman of the C.F.T.C. said that his staff had a late night on Monday checking in with all the exchanges, and had not heard anything that concerned them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe system worked as it was designed to do,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2014 Nathaniel Popper\n\nIs algorithmic trading to blame for Monday\u2019s plunge?\n\nFollowing a House Financial Services Committee hearing, Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, said that he has been in touch with market participants this week and that they are reacting in an orderly fashion and that there are no liquidity problems. He said it was possible that algorithmic trading was partially responsible for the recent volatility in the stock market.\n\n\u201cI have heard from others that it has played a role, as there\u2019s more programmed trading, this tends to have volatility in both directions,\u201d he said.\n\nDespite that volatility, it does not appear that the Trump administration is ready to give up on the stock market as a measure of its success.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve always been looking at the long-term impact of the stock market, it\u2019s still up over 30 percent since the election and we continue to think American is a great place to do business,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said. \u201cWe couldn\u2019t be happier with companies\u2019 response with more and more investments in the U.S.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Alan Rappeport\n\n\n\nSteven Mnuchin isn\u2019t concerned about the stock market turbulence\n\nAsked about the roiled stock market at a House Financial Services Committee hearing on Tuesday, Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, said that the Trump administration was not concerned and that it remains focused on the long-term trajectory of the economy.\n\n\u201cWe are very focused on long-term economic growth, and we believe that the policies that we have enacted, including tax reform are very positive for long-term economic growth,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said.\n\nHe said that he was closely monitoring for orderly market functioning and that there were \u201cno systemic issues\u201d that were reported to him.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m happy to report I got the green lights,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said.\n\nThe Treasury secretary said that given how much the market has rallied in the last year, he does not think the recent drop in prices raises financial stability concerns.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked if the Trump administration will take the blame for the recent drop in stocks after taking credit for the rally, Mr. Mnuchin demurred.\n\n\u201cI think we\u2019ll still claim credit for the fact that it\u2019s up over 30 percent since the election,\u201d he said of the stock market.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2014 Alan Rappeport\n\nBlame it on the VIX\n\nWhen stock markets sell off as they have the past two trading sessions, there is often more than one cause. But one popular trade is taking a lot of blame for Monday\u2019s plunge: short volatility.\n\nInvestors had piled money into exchange-traded products designed to rise when the C.B.O.E. Volatility Index, or VIX, falls. The VIX, known as the market\u2019s fear gauge, measures how volatile investors expect stock markets to be in the month ahead. Those wagers paid off handsomely, rising 180 percent last year as the VIX plumbed historic lows.\n\nThat quickly reversed Monday. The VIX surged 117 percent in its biggest one-day jump on record and two short volatility exchange-traded product \u2014 VelocityShares Daily Inverse VIX Short-Term Exchange Traded Note, XIV, and Next Notes S&P 500 VIX Inverse ETN \u2014 endured heavy selling.\n\nThe selling led Credit Suisse to say it is going to buy back XIV and after the bank has done that it will no longer exist. Nomura also said its Next Notes \u201cwould be redeemed at a steep discount to their closing price on Monday in Asia, crystallizing large losses for investors,\u201d the WSJ reported.\n\nFrom Barclays:\n\n\u201cIn our opinion, the significant spike in the VIX index and futures yesterday was technical in nature and does not necessarily indicate a true increase in risk perception.\u201d\n\nFrom Morgan Stanley:\n\n\u201cThe near bankruptcy of the inverse VIX ETPs will be a very negative headline, and the several billion dollar loss for holders, largely retail, will scare some out of the market or force liquidations of other products to raise cash.\u201d\n\nFrom Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research:\n\n\u201c Assuming volatility-related ETFs really are a market structure \u201cAchilles heel\u201d, this will take days if not weeks to play out, and there could be other problems waiting in the wings.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nPhoto\n\nThe big questions about another market drop\n\nStock markets around the world appear headed down for a third straight trading day, after yesterday\u2019s 4 percent drop in the S.&P. 500. Here are the latest numbers:\n\n\u2022 Hong Kong\u2019s Hang Seng fell 5 percent.\n\n\u2022 Japan\u2019s Nikkei was down 4.7 percent.\n\n\u2022 The U.K.\u2019s FTSE 100 was down 2 percent.\n\n\u2022 Wall Street\u2019s \u201cfear gauge,\u201d the VIX, is at its highest level in two and a half years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd here\u2019s some more context from our colleague Peter Eavis.\n\nThe technical question: Has computer-driven unwinding of \u201cGoldilocks\u201d trades tied to peaceful market rises played a role here?\n\nThe economic question: Economies are growing around the world, which is likely to mean rising wages and then, perhaps, inflation. So will central bankers have to raise rates more than previously expected?\n\nThe political question: What does this mean for President Trump, who has touted stock market gains as a measure of his success?\n\nMore from Ben White of Politico:\n\n\u201cThis is a risk that the president clearly set himself up for,\u201d said Charles Gabriel of Capital Alpha Partners, a Washington research firm. \u201cUntil now, Trump\u2019s had kind of a free ride in this market and taken so much credit for it, even though so much of it was due to easy-money policies from Janet Yellen and the Fed. Now she\u2019s out the door and volatility is back.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s another way of thinking about Mr. Trump\u2019s role, Andrew writes in his latest column:\n\nInvestors believe his policies to stoke growth are going to work so well that they will overheat the economy, and force the Federal Reserve to try to slow things down.\n\nBut don\u2019t expect action from the newly sworn-in Fed chairman, Jay Powell \u2014 at least, not yet.\n\nA bit of humor, courtesy of our colleague Binyamin Appelbaum:\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nVirtual currency prices are falling, too\n\nWhere Bitcoin was this morning: $6,628, down almost 16 percent over the past 24 hours, according to CoinMarketCap. Ethereum\u2019s Ether and Ripple\u2019s XRP fell by double digits, too.\n\nWhat\u2019s happening: Regulators are clamping down on digital money, and scams and hacks are eroding trust in it.\n\nMore from Nathaniel Popper of the NYT:\n\n\u201cCryptocurrencies are almost a perfect vehicle for scams,\u201d said Kevin Werbach, a professor at University of Pennsylvania\u2019s Wharton School. \u201cThe combination of credulous buyers and low barriers for scammers were bound to lead to a high level of fraud, if and when the money involved got large.\u201d\n\nNext: The heads of the S.E.C. and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission are to talk Bitcoin with the Senate Banking Committee today.\n\nPhoto\n\nWill we avoid another government shutdown?\n\nThe House appears ready to vote on a stopgap bill; funding would otherwise expire at 12:01 a.m. on Friday.\n\nWhat it does: Pairs short-term funding for the government with long-term funding for the military.\n\nWhat it doesn\u2019t do: Include the increase in domestic spending demanded by Democrats, particularly Senate Democrats. Nor does it address immigration, which caused last month\u2019s shutdown (though Senators John McCain and Chris Coons have a bipartisan proposal on that).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExpect more give-and-take between the two sides of Congress:\n\n\u201cI think everyone understands that this will probably end up being a Ping-Pong situation, and we\u2019ll see where the ball lands,\u201d said Representative Carlos Curbelo, Republican of Florida.\n\nElsewhere in policy\n\n\u2022 Most of President Trump\u2019s legal team wants to avoid letting Robert Mueller question him. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump flippantly suggested that Democrats who sat through his State of the Union address stone-faced were guilty of treason. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The House Intelligence Committee voted unanimously to release a Democratic memo tied to the investigation of a Trump campaign aide. Now it\u2019s up to the White House. (Politico)\n\n\u2022 China is investigating U.S. sorghum exports, a move that threatens a widening trade standoff. (NYT)\n\nWill Comcast try to top Disney\u2019s bid for Fox?\n\nIt depends whether AT&T\u2019s bid for Time Warner goes through. Comcast dropped out of the running for Fox once it became clear that Rupert Murdoch would prefer a tie-up with Disney, but it is studying whether to rejoin the fray, CNBC reported.\n\nMore from Alex Sherman of CNBC:\n\nAn unsolicited offer at a premium to Disney\u2019s bid could persuade enough Fox shareholders to vote against Murdoch. His family controls 39 percent of Fox\u2019s Class B voting shares but owns only 17 percent of all outstanding shares. Comcast executives suggested to Murdoch last year they would be willing to pay significantly more for Fox\u2019s assets than what Disney was offering, said the people. Murdoch still went with the Disney offer, in large part due to regulatory concerns with Comcast.\n\nElsewhere in the deal world\n\n\u2022 Archer-Daniels Midland is in advanced talks to buy Bunge, unnamed sources say. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Kroger agreed to sell its convenience store business to the British investment firm EG Group for $2.15 billion. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Alibaba and an arm of the Chinese government have bought roughly 13 percent of Dalian Wanda\u2019s movie business for $1.2 billion. (Bloomberg)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Midstates Petroleum offered to merge with SandRidge Energy in an all-stock deal that would create a nearly $1 billion oil company. (Reuters)\n\n\u2022 Viacom is near a deal to buy the online video conference VidCon, unnamed sources say. (Variety)\n\n\u2022 Elliott Advisors continued to push BHP Billiton to simplify its dual-listed corporate structure. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Walmart has bought a virtual reality start-up, Spatialand, for its Store No. 8 incubator unit. (Recode)\n\nPhoto\n\nA deep dive into Silicon Valley\u2019s bro culture\n\n\u201cI talked to women engineers at Uber who were getting invited to strip clubs and bondage clubs in the middle of the day. The middle of the day! And often they would go because that\u2019s just what everyone was doing.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s what Emily Chang of Bloomberg said about her reporting for \u201cBrotopia,\u201d her forthcoming book about the lopsided power dynamics in Silicon Valley. (NYT)\n\nThe misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 Steve Wynn and his legal representatives set up a limited liability company solely to handle settlement funds, including $7.5 million for a manicurist who accused him of sexual assault. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Laurent Potdevin resigned as C.E.O. of Lululemon because, the company said, he had failed to \u201cexemplify the highest levels of integrity and respect for one another.\u201d (NYT)\n\n\u2022 A partner at the international law firm Baker McKenzie lost his job after allegations surfaced that he had sexually assaulted a female colleague. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Even with generous social policies, women in Scandinavia are still paid less than men, because they spend more time on child-rearing. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBattery Ventures raises $1.25 billion in new funds\n\nThe venture firm, which has invested in the likes of Groupon, Dollar Shave Club and Nutanix, has closed both its 12th venture fund, at $800 million, and its latest side fund for later-stage deals, at $450 million. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "DealBook Briefing: Tronc Nears Deal to Sell Los Angeles Times", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Match Book,\n\nI need an author I can read front to back, or one who has written five books that I\u2019ll want to read without stopping.\n\nI was an English major in college, so I guess what I like is literary fiction. My four favorite books are \u201cBlood Meridian,\u201d by Cormac McCarthy, \u201cMoby-Dick,\u201d by Herman Melville, \u201cInvisible Man,\u201d by Ralph Ellison, and \u201cContinental Drift,\u201d by Russell Banks \u2014 in that order.\n\nI\u2019ve read everything by Colson Whitehead, so the algorithms led me to Percival Everett\u2019s \u201cErasure,\u201d but it just didn\u2019t click. I\u2019ve read most of T. C. Boyle, but he\u2019s just writing the same book over and over now; and I stopped liking Russell Banks\u2019s work a while ago. (I understand his wanting to try different things, but how could the man who wrote \u201cThe Sweet Hereafter\u201d also produce \u201cRule of the Bone\u201d?)\n\nI don\u2019t just stick to Americans (I love Ian McEwan\u2019s writing from the last few years) or men (I\u2019ve read all of Donna Tartt\u2019s fiction and most of Annie Proulx\u2019s). Now that I\u2019m older, I\u2019m thinking about going back to Saul Bellow (I grew up in Hyde Park), because back when I started to read his books, I\u2019d always just put them down in favor of something by Philip Roth. I\u2019m just starting my second Magnus Mills novel, so we\u2019ll see about him.", "title": "Dear Match Book: Authors I Can Binge-Read", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The Lives of the Poets\n\nPoets were kids once, too. In \u201cThe Invisible Ladder,\u201d Liz Rosenberg\u2019s thoughtfully edited anthology of contemporary American poetry for children, she makes sweetly explicit the profound connection between grown writers and young readers. At the start of each section, then-and-now snapshots of each writer featured \u2014 from Robert Creeley and Cornelius Eady to Rita Dove and Li-Young Lee \u2014 reveal the poet as both child and adult. But it\u2019s the inclusion of these writers\u2019 sophisticated work \u2014 about teenage jobs, music, nature and parents, not written expressly for children \u2014 that honors young readers\u2019 abilities to parse complex ideas.\n\nAnother ingenious mix of biography and verse, \u201cOut of Wonder,\u201d will appeal to the teacher in you. In this picture book, vividly illustrated by Ekua Holmes, the authors Kwame Alexander, Chris Colderley and Marjory Wentworth craft poems in the styles of 20 poets from around the world \u2014 Robert Frost, Terrance Hayes, Rumi and Maya Angelou among them. The lovely, imitative lines offer evocative introductions to the work by these celebrated poets, and function as writing prompts, too.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo Take Us Lands Away\n\n\u201cOut of Wonder,\u201d which includes a tribute to Emily Dickinson, would pair well with \u201cPoetry for Kids: Emily Dickinson,\u201d edited by Susan Snively and delicately illustrated by Christine Davenier. Some of the poet\u2019s darting, playful, exuberant lines can be found in four seasonal sections, which include some of her most beloved poems (like \u201cThere\u2019s a certain slant of light\u201d and \u201cThere is no frigate like a book\u201d) as well as less familiar ones on several of her favorite subjects: botany, faith and language. Italicized notes at the bottoms of the pages define unfamiliar vocabulary, and a section at the back titled \u201cWhat Emily Was Thinking\u201d provides enlightening context. (Both explanatory features appear in the series\u2019s other books, on Carl Sandburg and Walt Whitman.)\n\nLiterary Samplers\n\nCarefully curated anthologies, each with a narrow focus, would make fine resources for your project. In \u201cBeastly Verse,\u201d JooHee Yoon\u2019s riotous illustrations make even old favorites about animals (both real and imagined) new. The wildest of the bunch, including \u201cThe Tiger,\u201d by William Blake, \u201cEletelephony,\u201d by Laura E. Richards, and \u201cHumming-bird,\u201d by D. H. Lawrence, can\u2019t be tamed by a single spread; page flaps open to allow animals to prowl, make mischief and fly.\n\nFor times when your notebook isn\u2019t close at hand, you\u2019ll want to introduce your granddaughter to the singular delights of memorization. \u201cForget-Me-Nots,\u201d a sizable treasury selected by Mary Ann Hoberman and joyfully illustrated by Michael Emberley, starts short. Even the longest poem on the first spread after the introduction \u2014 \u201cPrimer Lesson\u201d by Carl Sandburg \u2014 could be learned in an afternoon. The challenge to commit verse to memory grows in later sections, though rhyming and silliness give the longer poems a mnemonic boost.\n\nStretch the Rules\n\nOnce you\u2019ve played with some words you\u2019ll want to master some forms. \u201cSeeing Into Tomorrow,\u201d a collection of 12 delicate, late-in-life nature haiku by Richard Wright, is exquisitely illustrated in a photo collage by Nina Crews. The structure of Marilyn Singer\u2019s reverso poems is less easily repeated. Her dramatic and satisfying \u201cEcho Echo,\u201d inspired by Greek myths and illustrated by Jos\u00e9e Masse, gives different perspectives in adjacent, top-to-bottom mirror poems. And, for a more immediate though no less complex wordplay, turn to Paul Fleischman\u2019s exquisite book of read-aloud verse, \u201cJoyful Noise.\u201d The insect-themed compositions unfold in rich counterpoint meant for two readers. After exchanging lines of verse while you are apart, I imagine that it will be poetic to hear your voices together.\n\nYours truly,\n\nMatch Book\n\nDo you need book recommendations? Write to matchbook@nytimes.com.\n\nCheck out Match Book\u2019s earlier recommendations here.", "title": "Dear Match Book: Poems for Young Readers", "authors": ["Nicole Lamy", "Match Book"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDear Match Book,\n\nI am 28 years old, and I grew up in a conservative Christian home in Alberta, Canada. Even now I would still consider myself a little right of center. I didn\u2019t grow up a reader, but I always wanted to be one. Over the last 10 years, I\u2019ve made an effort to spend more time between book covers.\n\nI often try to read the award-winning novels that everyone talks about, but usually I end up hating them. Some of these titles include \u201cThe Goldfinch,\u201d by Donna Tartt (it dragged); \u201cThe Book of Joan,\u201d by Lidia Yuknavitch (too out there); and \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale,\u201d by Margaret Atwood (it felt like work).\n\nSome of my favorite books are \u201cThe Time Traveler\u2019s Wife,\u201d by Audrey Niffenegger; \u201cGone Girl,\u201d by Gillian Flynn; and \u201cThe Book of Strange New Things,\u201d by Michel Faber. I also love John Green\u2019s work. I\u2019m currently reading Mohsin Hamid\u2019s \u201cExit West,\u201d and I love it. The book made me see refugees as I should have always seen them: as fellow humans.\n\nI want to develop my taste so that I can enjoy more literary fiction, but it\u2019s been a challenge to find something I really enjoy. What books can you recommend that are literary, but also plot driven and easy to digest?", "title": "Dear Match Book: Seeking Literary Page-Turners", "authors": ["Nicole Lamy", "Match Book"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Match Book,\n\nI am 13 years old and I enjoy reading realistic fiction. One of my all-time favorite books is \u201cAristotle and Dante Discover the Secrets of the Universe,\u201d by Benjamin Alire S\u00e1enz. A close runner-up is \u201cLiars, Inc.,\u201d by Paula Stokes. A third book I\u2019ve read recently and loved is \u201cEvery Last Word,\u201d by Tamara Ireland Stone. I do not enjoy reading nonfiction or fantasy.\n\nCHARLES BRAININ\n\nBROOKLINE, MASS.\n\nDear Match Book,\n\nI am 12 years old and I\u2019d have to say that my all-time favorite book is \u201cYou in Five Acts,\u201d by Una LaMarche.
