They said Mr. Paxton and his leadership team ignored their complaints and in some cases retaliated against them.\n\nThe department initially denied the reports of manipulation at the hospital. A department spokesman did not respond to requests for more information.\n\nIn Washington, Dr. Shulkin has pushed to make data a bigger part of the veterans health care system. This fall he set up a command center where a wall of screens tracks key metrics at hospitals across the country, such as infection rates and nurse staffing, in real time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough Roseburg showed how those metrics could be gamed, Mr. DeFazio said he had faith that Dr. Shulkin, a longtime physician and hospital administrator, was capable of making improvements.\n\n\u201cHe has my confidence,\u201d Mr. DeFazio said. \u201cHe has an expertise in health care we have not seen in former secretaries.\u201d\n\nMr. Paxton will be reassigned as assistant director of the veterans hospital in Huntington, W.V. Learn more about the book club here.\n\nBelow are questions to help guide your discussions as you read the book over the next month. The questions are broken down by week, or divided into four parts to match your reading speed. If you\u2019re not on Facebook, you can also submit your own questions for Grann about the book here.\n\nWeek One\n\n1. Before starting \u201cKillers of the Flower Moon,\u201d had you ever heard of the Osage murders? If so, how did you learn about them, and what did you know? Do you think this history should be taught in schools?\n\n2. As Silicon Valley giants move deeper into Hollywood and the traditional television business unravels, Disney is trying to reinvent itself \u2014 buying most of 21st Century Fox, building two streaming services, pouring billions into theme park expansions focused on its \u201cStar Wars\u201d franchise \u2014 in pursuit of a new growth trajectory. But things may get a little messy in the meantime.\n\nDisney reported mixed quarterly earnings on Tuesday as losses associated with the development of the planned streaming services \u2014 the first of which, arriving in the spring, will involve ESPN and cost $4.99 a month \u2014 hurt Disney\u2019s cable television division, where operating income fell 1 percent to $858 million. Disney\u2019s movie studio also reported weaker results, as did the company\u2019s consumer products business.\n\nOn the bright side, operating income increased 21 percent, to $1.35 billion, at Walt Disney Parks and Resorts because of higher attendance and ticket prices at Walt Disney World in Florida and Disneyland Paris, among other properties. (Disney is expected in the coming week to increase ticket prices again, particularly for peak vacation times, as a way to spread out attendance.) Disney Cruise Line also had a strong quarter.", "title": "Disney Reports Mixed Earnings and a Full Project Pipeline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDisney said Monday it would donate $1 million of the proceeds from \u201cBlack Panther\u201d to STEM programs at the Boys & Girls Clubs of America, in a nod to one of the movie\u2019s key themes: how technology can empower young people from marginalized communities.\n\nThe blockbuster film is set in Wakanda, a country whose surplus of the fictional metal vibranium has enriched it tremendously. Many of the technologies in the film are invented or controlled by Shuri, the sister of T\u2019Challa, the Black Panther and Wakanda\u2019s king. Shuri, 16, plays a similar role to \u201cQ\u201d from the James Bond films, providing her brother and the kingdom with vibranium-powered vehicles, weapons and other innovations.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a statement, the chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, Robert A. Iger, said it was thrilling to see how much the technology in the film had excited young audiences.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s fitting that we show our appreciation by helping advance STEM programs for youth, especially in underserved areas of the country, to give them the knowledge and tools to build the future they want,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe $1 million pledged by Disney is only a fraction of the money that the film has brought in. In less than two weeks in theaters, \u201cBlack Panther\u201d made more than $700 million worldwide, making it one of the fastest grossing films ever.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a Twitter thread on Tuesday, the journalist Gene Demby, who writes and hosts a podcast about race for NPR, was dismissive of Disney\u2019s contribution, calling it a \u201crounding error.\u201d He wrote about how Disney has benefited from enthusiasm about the merits of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d and its representation of black people.", "title": "Disney to Donate $1 Million of \u2018Black Panther\u2019 Proceeds to Youth STEM Programs", "authors": ["Jonah Engel Bromwich"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "As we reporters strained to hear, Mr. Obama quizzed his military escort about the location of the demarcation line between North and South, and the size of the North Korean village where the giant flag was flying.\n\nStill, as president, Mr. Obama showed less interest in North Korea than in other foreign hot spots. After the Leap Day deal fell apart, his administration settled for a strategy of steadily tightening economic sanctions on Pyongyang that it called \u201cstrategic patience.\u201d Critics, President Trump chief among them, say that Mr. Obama merely kicked the can down the road.\n\nMr. Biden\u2019s visit in December 2013 was more upbeat. A few hours before he arrived, the North Koreans released Merrill Newman, a Korean War veteran from California who had been detained for 42 days during a tour of the country. While Mr. Biden had no direct role in negotiating the tourist\u2019s release, the North Koreans seized on his presence to make a gesture.\n\nThe atmosphere had reverted to tension when President Trump set out for his first visit to the DMZ in November. My colleague Julie Hirschfeld Davis was in one of the helicopter seats that morning. Reporters had been tipped off to the trip the night before. But the veil of secrecy was so heavy, she recalled, that the press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, was under orders not to say the destination out loud.\n\n\u201cThis is where we\u2019re going,\u201d she told the press corps, holding up a sheet of notebook paper on which she had scrawled \u201cDMZ.\u201d\n\nIn the end, Mr. Trump never got there. Dense fog blanketed Marine One as it approached the border, and a few minutes before landing, the pilots decided to turn back. \u201cThis did not work out as planned,\u201d a deflated Ms. Sanders said afterward.\n\nIt was hard not to see it as a metaphor for a president who has struggled since he took office to figure out how to deal with North Korea.\n\nMeet Mark and hear about the experiences and insights of other New York Times correspondents who have covered North Korea at our event \u201cLife With a Nuclear North Korea\u201d on Monday, Feb. 26, from 6:30 p.m. to 7:45 p.m. at Newseum, 555 Pennsylvania Avenue Northwest, Washington, D.C. Mark will moderate a conversation with Helene Cooper, David Sanger and Jake Sullivan, a former national security adviser to Vice President Biden and a top policy adviser to Secretary Clinton.", "title": "Dispatches From the DMZ: My Three Trips to the Last Cold War Frontier", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nThere is an easy solution to Russia\u2019s, or anyone\u2019s, hacking of our voting system. There is no reason for any voting machine, vote tallying or vote totals transmission and storage to be connected to the internet. It is just for our convenience and America\u2019s desperate need for immediate answers.\n\nAs a young boy in New York City, I would go around voting precincts with my father, a party official and twice a candidate for office. Voting machines had small mechanical levers next to each candidate\u2019s name, and the voter just pulled levers down to vote. The votes were tallied by simple mechanical counters in the back of the machine that you could see when a police officer unlocked it in the presence of a representative from each party.\n\nThe totals were officially recorded on paper and called in by each precinct election captain. Of course it took a few hours, and we now have many more voters and would therefore need hundreds more Election Day volunteers. But isn\u2019t that worth protecting our democracy?\n\nThis incessant drive to automate everything and put it all online is condemning our system of government to control by anyone with brains and a computer.", "title": "Opinion | Ditch the Online Voting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Q. It seems like my hangovers are much worse now that I am older, 42, to the point I can\u2019t even have one drink without feeling listless the next day. What can I do, besides drinking water while drinking alcohol, to improve the situation?\n\nA. The real \u201cproblem\u201d might be that you\u2019re drinking less as you age, which reduces your tolerance for alcohol, said Lara Ray, a professor of clinical psychology at the University of California, Los Angeles, who researches alcoholism. Someone with the self-image of a partying twentysomething but the lifestyle of a responsible 42-year-old may simply have lost the tolerance for a lot of alcohol, she said.\n\n\u201cAge may be a proxy for regularity of drinking,\u201d Dr. Ray said. \u201cIf you haven\u2019t gone to a party for two to three weeks, it might be less about being 40 and more about your drinking history.\u201d\n\nAlso, as we age, we lose muscle mass, replacing it with fat. The same drink will cause more intoxication in a body with a higher fat content compared with a leaner one, she said. But this tends to be true more for people over 65 than over 40, she said.", "title": "Do Hangovers Get Worse as We Age?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. Can I get enough vitamin D from sunlight, even if I live in a place with little sunlight during the winter?\n\nA. Most people can make enough vitamin D from sun exposure during the summer, but for many, synthesis can be inadequate in the winter. A 2016 study led by researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimated that 14 to 18 percent of Americans have inadequate vitamin D, although what constitutes a healthy blood level is subject to debate.\n\nSynthesis of vitamin D, which is critical for bone health, requires exposure to ultraviolet-B rays from the sun. In the summer, when the sun is directly overhead, vitamin D synthesis can be very efficient. For someone with light skin in a temperate climate at midday, \u201c10 minutes a day of exposure to 10 percent of your body\u2019s surface area, such as your arms and face, will give you what you need,\u201d said Dr. Bess Dawson-Hughes, director of the Bone Metabolism Lab at the USDA Nutrition Center at Tufts University. Closer to the Equator, even less time is required.\n\nThat\u2019s a rough estimate, though, and many factors can interfere with vitamin D synthesis. People with darker skin need two to three times the sun exposure to make the same amount of vitamin D, and synthesis also declines with age, Dr. Dawson-Hughes said. Environmental factors like clouds, ozone and air pollution can likewise decrease vitamin D production, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile a little sun exposure can be good for vitamin D status, too much can increase the risk of skin cancer, cautioned Dr. Jean Y. Tang, associate professor of dermatology at Stanford University. \u201cYou\u2019ve got to do it in a very safe way, where you get enough sun to make the vitamin D, but not so much sun that you cause erythema, or redness, and a sunburn,\u201d she said.", "title": "Do I Get Enough Vitamin D in the Winter?", "authors": ["Alice Callahan", "Ask Well"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Cheryl Strayed: While a face-lift may temporarily give you a slightly more youthful look, I caution you against thinking it will appreciably alter your resemblance to your mother, Mini Mom. It won\u2019t. Face-lifts simply don\u2019t do that. You may see your mother in the mirror, but you\u2019re gazing at your own face. This is how you look at 50. Like many women, you don\u2019t like what you see not because there\u2019s anything wrong with your appearance, but because we live in a culture that holds a relentlessly narrow view of female beauty while placing the utmost importance on it. Though I don\u2019t judge people who opt to surgically alter their faces for the reason you cite, I can\u2019t deny that I find it pretty sad. It\u2019s a decision born of shame and self-loathing, and it\u2019s one that could only be made in a culture that degrades women. What if, instead of changing the face the world sees, you change the way you see your face in the world? What if, instead of risking your life (and you would be risking that) to look 10 years younger, you risked standing strong against the sexism and ageism 50-year-old women endure because they are female and 50?\n\nSA: I agree with Cheryl that cosmetic surgery has a certain air of Dorian Grayish sorrow about it. But I\u2019m not sure that \u201cstanding strong against sexism and ageism\u201d alone will address what you feel when you look in the mirror, Mini Mom. Your struggle also resides in standing strong against your mother, and the looming shadow of her cruel behavior. It\u2019s worth noting that her verbal abuse toward you is almost certainly displaced self-loathing. Don\u2019t fall into the same trap. Your job is to figure out how to love and accept yourself. That, I suspect, is what will make you feel truly distinct from your mother.\n\nCS: On the contrary, I think standing strong against sexism and ageism is the only thing that will eventually allow you to feel O.K. in your skin, Mini Mom. A face-lift is a temporary fix for something you\u2019ll have for the rest of your life: an aging face. Having surgery will allow you to feel better about your appearance only until you age more and feel miserable about how you look again. Changing your perspective about what your \u201ccute self\u201d looks like is a mental shift that will be with you forever. You\u2019ve already done important work of this nature when you learned how to give your abusive mother less access to you \u2014 and therefore less power over you. I\u2019m suggesting you do the same with our society\u2019s beauty standards.\n\nSA: Cosmetically speaking, there are less radical ways of altering your appearance so you don\u2019t look \u201cjust like\u201d your mom (i.e. hairstyle, makeup, clothing). But ultimately, the goal should be to accept that, however you look, you are distinct from your mother. As much as I applaud Cheryl\u2019s firmer stance here, I tend to see the line between cosmetic measures that trigger personal empowerment, and those that arise from cultural judgment, as subjective and awfully blurry. Some women feel better about themselves if they wear makeup, or lose weight, or shave their legs \u2014 even though they do those things, at least partly, in response to an internalized (patriarchal) set of ideas about what makes women desirable. Rather than judging what they want to do, I\u2019m more interested in why.\n\nCS: I\u2019m 49. I know your struggle, Mini Mom, because it\u2019s also mine. I\u2019m entirely aware that it\u2019s a lot harder to alter your mind than it is to alter your face, and unlike surgery, it\u2019s not something that will happen in a day. But with intention and effort, coming to accept \u2014 and even love \u2014 your body is possible. A face-lift won\u2019t obliterate the fears you have about your beauty as you age, but seeing beauty in a new way will. The best way out of a hole isn\u2019t to dig deeper. It\u2019s to climb out.", "title": "Do I Hate My Mom, or My Face?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. When well, my oral temperature is almost always about a degree lower than 98.6. When I\u2019m sick I can have what constitutes a \u201cfever\u201d (that is, over 99), but sometimes I feel feverish at 98.6 or even lower. Is the latter really a fever?\n\nA. Doctors are often quick to dismiss the concerns of patients who feel feverish but have \u201cnormal\u201d temperatures, saying something like, \u201cYou only have a temperature of 99 point something. That\u2019s not a fever.\u201d\n\nBut if you feel as if you have a fever, you probably do. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a fever is present when the patient \u201cfeels warm to the touch or gives a history of feeling feverish.\u201d The C.D.C., however, also offers an alternative temperature-based definition of fever, with a threshold of 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe Infectious Diseases Society of America acknowledges that \u201cthe definition of fever is arbitrary\u201d but likewise goes on to cite various definitions, including 1) an oral temperature of 100 or greater, 2) repeated oral temperatures of 99 degrees or greater, and 3) an increase in temperature of more than 2 degrees over the patient\u2019s baseline.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMuch of what we know about fever and \u201cnormal\u201d temperatures comes from research in the 1860s by Dr. Carl Reinhold August Wunderlich, the German physician who recorded over a million temperature readings in 25,000 patients. His landmark work led to the adoption of 98.6 as the definition of the average normal temperature.", "title": "Do I Have a Fever? My Temperature Is 98.6 but I Feel Feverish", "authors": ["Richard Klasco", "Ask Well"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Lacking such godlike insight, though, we can\u2019t know whether the state school or the \u201chighly selective\u201d school will serve her better. Heartily encourage your daughter to consider the sort of school you think would be preferable for her, if not doing so will leave you feeling guilty. But know that your sense of guilt is unwarranted.\n\nI used to work at a small architecture firm where I quickly gained lots of responsibility. One day, a client asked me to work with him on a project. I told him I had an exclusive agreement with my bosses, but when I left I would be free to do so. Shortly before my last day, one of my bosses asked what I was going to do next. I replied that I was in talks with one of the firm\u2019s clients for a project outside the firm\u2019s line of work. My boss became angry and asked if I thought it was right to talk to her client. I replied I saw no problem as I had already quit and was not stealing work. I was fired on the spot for \u201cpersonal, not professional, betrayal.\u201d Did I do anything wrong? Name Withheld\n\nThere\u2019s evidently an understanding in your line of work that you won\u2019t \u201csteal\u201d clients from firms that employ you. But that understanding isn\u2019t clear enough to avoid disagreements among architects as to what is and isn\u2019t O.K. From the way you describe the situation, it sounds as though you had no reason to think you were doing something wrong; otherwise you would have kept your plans from your boss. Indeed, her response \u2014 that the betrayal was \u201cpersonal, not professional\u201d \u2014 tends to confirm that you hadn\u2019t violated any professional norms. And in a decent business, you don\u2019t fire people for personal reasons anyway.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs for personal norms: The client called you, and I can\u2019t think of any personal obligations that were breached when you agreed to talk to someone about a project outside your former employer\u2019s expertise and after you left the firm. Are you sure you\u2019ve told me everything relevant to her response? If you have, count yourself lucky that you were already leaving.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile working in a country that recently experienced a large-scale genocide, I was befriended by a survivor who lost most of his family. Over a few months, Alex, as I\u2019ll call him, offered invaluable insights, shared the story of his survival, helped me gain access to a local tribunal and was an excellent interpreter. He treated me as an honored guest and brought me to the village where he grew up. I thought of him almost as a brother. He didn\u2019t ask for money; still, I gave him a modest but not insignificant \u201cgift\u201d before returning home.\n\nWe exchanged email for about a year, during which he wrote that he had become \u201cunstable.\u201d After a bomb exploded outside his workplace, he began writing of increasingly implausible threats, culminating in a request for significant financial help to flee the country. He asked me to contact some American friends he had also worked with; these friends told me that Alex had requested money from them too. They said they had raised a considerable sum for him to attend university but learned that he never enrolled. I broke off the correspondence when Alex indignantly and implausibly denied all this.\n\nA few years later I received an email sent to scores of other recipients, offering his services as a guide and interpreter. I felt I had an ethical obligation to share my experience in a \u201creply all\u201d note. I said that I highly recommended Alex as a guide and interpreter but would not make any advance payments to him. The question of whether this was the right thing to do still haunts me. Name Withheld\n\nYou\u2019re worried about undermining the opportunities of someone who has been through a horrendous experience and who, despite that, was enormously helpful to you. Alex has, so to speak, credit in the moral bank. But you also have reason to believe that he has sought significant sums under false pretenses. So, in money matters, he\u2019s sketchy. His moral credits have secured some durable measure of good will from you, but they don\u2019t entitle him to freedom from the consequences of this bad behavior. And the people you tipped off were also entitled to protection from being scammed. You told them the truth: that he was excellent at one thing and not to be trusted with another. Given his record, that\u2019s what people doing business with him needed to know.", "title": "Do I Have to Spring for My Kid to Go to an Elite College?", "authors": ["Kwame Anthony Appiah", "The Ethicist"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "You\u2019re rightly concerned about lying to your father. That\u2019s a bad thing in itself, and it\u2019s a betrayal of trust. Still, the obligation to be honest could be trumped if the consequences to you of answering him truthfully were substantial. At the same time, there are other possibilities than a straight-out lie. One would be to reply that, yes, you have been assaulted but that you don\u2019t want to discuss the details with him and you would like him to respect your privacy. Yet, many parents wouldn\u2019t be able to rest being told only this much, and you would have to feel confident that your father would.\n\nAnother approach would be to say that you will tell him what happened, but only if he promises not to tell anyone else. You know him and can judge whether he would find it possible to keep that promise and what it would cost him in terms of self-restraint. If you underline the fact that it was the son who was responsible, not his parents, he may be able to maintain his relationship with them even if he knows what happened. So you have much to consider.\n\nA close friend of mine recently split with her partner. I found out that since their breakup, he has been sleeping with another person in our social circle. My friend and I are not close to this woman, but we do see her from time to time. I know that during their breakup, my friend expressed to her partner a wish for this exact situation not to occur. I have been wondering if I should tell my friend that this is happening. I worry that it would only cause her pain after an already-painful breakup, but I also feel dishonest in keeping it from her. I am also concerned that she will find out about it regardless, perhaps in a way that is more hurtful than coming from me, someone she trusts. What is the right thing to do? Name Withheld\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPeople don\u2019t have a right to determine whom an ex sleeps with. It was fine for your friend to tell her partner that she didn\u2019t want him to sleep with a mutual acquaintance, but unless he seriously pledged not to do so, he wasn\u2019t under any obligation to comply. What you\u2019ve learned is not that he has done something wrong but simply that he has done something that she didn\u2019t want him to do. Given that they\u2019re no longer a couple, she doesn\u2019t have a right to know.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt would be one thing if she had explicitly asked you about this or if, by keeping your counsel, you were acting in a way detrimental to her interests. You mention the possibility that she could learn it, more painfully, from someone else \u2014 but you don\u2019t say whether that\u2019s very likely. If the issue doesn\u2019t come up and the only effect of telling her would be to upset her, you\u2019re entitled to let it slide.\n\nIt is tempting to find high-minded reasons to pass on gossip. On the whole, though, the truths you should feel obliged to convey to her are about matters of real importance in her life, not just anything that she would like to know. And the sexual adventures of an ex, despite what she may currently feel, don\u2019t qualify.\n\nThere\u2019s the risk, of course, that she\u2019ll find out and then ask you if you knew. At that point you would owe it to her to say that you did know and considered telling her but decided that you wanted to spare her the distress. The strength of your relationship would be tested by its ability to withstand this revelation.\n\nMy friend recently took a job at a nonprofit organization providing services to adults with developmental disabilities. From the start, there were issues: Instead of providing staff members (who work from home) with laptops and phones, the center requires them to use their personal equipment and \u201ctake it off your taxes.\u201d Same with using personal cars for business. While the New Jersey rate for mileage reimbursement is 31 cents, the organization only reimburses 14 cents. Payroll is consistently late, and expenses have not been paid for three months. Now my friend, who has serious health issues, was told by her doctor that her employer-sponsored health insurance was canceled for nonpayment of premium. My friend pays into her health insurance each week by a payroll deduction. She needs a CT scan and cannot pay for one out of pocket. She called human resources several times, but they always say that they are working on the issues, with no result. My friend is sick and worried about her future. Should I report the organization? Whom do I report them to? My friend cannot afford to do without the money they owe her or her health insurance. Name Withheld\n\nBeing a nonprofit with an admirable cause doesn\u2019t entitle an organization to violate its obligations to its employees. You might call the office of your state\u2019s attorney general and ask where you should report these problems. (In New Jersey, you will probably be referred to the Department of Labor.) But first consult your friend. Exposing her employers in this way risks her relationship with them, even if she isn\u2019t the one who does the reporting. She\u2019s entitled to know what you have in mind.\n\nI am a medical resident at an academic hospital. About two years ago, I received a small grant from a trainee-subsidized patient-care fund to provide two iPads to pediatric psychiatry patients who spend many hours in our emergency department awaiting placement. I purchased the iPads and software but ran out of time and steam as I encountered various logistical and practical obstacles. I am now about to graduate from the program; I have tried to find another trainee to whom to hand off the project, with no success. What is my moral obligation regarding what to do with these iPads? Can I just donate them somewhere? Can I take one home for my kids? Am I required to try to resell them and return the money to the patient-care fund? Name Withheld\n\nLet\u2019s start with the fact that you took money to do something you haven\u2019t done. At the very least, you should inform the fund administrators, apologize and refund the money. Only after you\u2019ve discharged your duty to the fund can you think about what to do with the iPads. Reselling them now won\u2019t allow you to recover the full amount, of course, because they\u2019ll have declined in value. If you\u2019ve managed to make the fund whole and still have the devices, though, what you do with them is up to you. So you can certainly donate them to anyone you like ... including your children.", "title": "Do I Have to Tell My Father About My #MeToo Experience?", "authors": ["Kwame Anthony Appiah", "The Ethicist"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Among Israeli Jews, 65 percent say remembering the Holocaust is an essential part of their Jewish identity, more than living in Israel or working for justice and equality. That Israeli teenagers spend a hefty part of their schooling preparing for a trip to death camps in Poland suggests that the next generation will feel similarly.\n\nA healthy society cannot be defined by the memory of a tragedy. A healthy culture does not make a trip to where it was almost eliminated its main point for pilgrimage. Jewish youngsters would do better to focus their energies on the site that all generations of Jews have wanted to make pilgrimages to: Jerusalem. Auschwitz should not be elevated to sacredness.\n\nAltering Israel\u2019s historical education will also help to change the perception in the country that the Jewish state is here only because of the horrors of Nazism. Israel\u2019s existence should not be seen as compensation for the butchery of Jews in Europe. But pilgrimages that connect Poland and Israel, or those using Poland as a tool with which to bolster the commitment of young Israelis to their own country, send exactly this message. There is a tragedy, and then rebirth.\n\nBut there is no resurrection. The dead are still dead. The Jewish culture that was destroyed in Poland and across Europe will never re-emerge. Israel is not a compensation for Auschwitz, and its marching teenagers, with their flags and their songs, with their we-are-still-here spirit, spite only the ghosts.\n\nWhen I was growing up, in the 1970s, there were no trips to Poland. My high school Holocaust education did not include a gut-wrenching visit to Auschwitz. Nonetheless, I remember the murder of Europe\u2019s Jews by the Nazis. I think about it, like many Israelis, almost daily. When I say that we should end the teenage Holocaust tourism to Poland, I am not calling for forgetting. I do not want to trivialize or marginalize that history or tell Jews that they need to \u201cget over it.\u201d\n\nWhat I believe we Israelis need is a realignment. We need to remember the dead without forgetting them or forgiving their butchers. We need to draw the proper lessons from the Holocaust \u2014 one of which is that there is no merit in dying and Jews must be proactive in our quest to keep living. So let\u2019s not confuse ourselves by making Auschwitz the axis of our culture and the culmination of our civic religion. Let\u2019s keep our March of the Living where it belongs: here, in Israel.", "title": "Opinion | Do Israeli Students Need to Visit Auschwitz?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "And yet there is a wealth of research showing that \u201capproval\u201d is largely, if not entirely, beyond a president\u2019s control. In 2002, the political scientists Robert S. Erikson, Michael B. Mackuen and James A. Stimson found that more than half of the variance in a president\u2019s approval ratings could be explained by either the performance of the national economy or by big events like international crises, assassination attempts and scandals \u2014 factors over which a president may not exert much influence at all. Jimmy Carter gained 20 points when Iranian student demonstrators occupied the United States Embassy in Tehran. Ronald Reagan picked up seven after being shot.\n\nNone of this has dissuaded presidents from trying to influence their own approval ratings. Reagan was the first to bring a public-opinion expert, Richard Wirthlin, onto the White House team. Wirthlin\u2019s firm went on to test public opinion for George H.W. Bush in the lead-up to the Persian Gulf war; Dick Cheney, at the time Bush\u2019s defense secretary, would later grumble in his memoirs that Colin Powell, then the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, \u201cseemed more comfortable talking about poll numbers than he was recommending military options.\u201d As the war approached its conclusion, crowds of supporters were ushered onto the White House lawn with signs trumpeting Bush\u2019s approval rating: \u201cWE \u2665 GEORGE \u2014 91%.\u201d\n\nThe war crystallized fears of what the political scientists Paul Brace and Barbara Hinckley described, in the 1992 book \u201cFollow the Leader,\u201d as \u201ca public-relations presidency: a pattern of action in the White House that gives high priority to public support.\u201d (The idea had enough popular credence in the 1990s to serve as the premise for the 1997 film \u201cWag the Dog,\u201d in which an administration fakes an entire war to rally the masses.) There was, Brace and Hinckley warned, a tension between a genuinely successful presidency and a momentarily popular one \u2014 \u201can uneasy balance at best between being liked and being president.\u201d\n\nTrump might seem like the logical conclusion of the public-relations presidency, but he complicates the idea at least as much as he confirms it. For someone who cares so singularly about approval, he almost never pursues it in any rational fashion; he routinely does the opposite of what a majority of the electorate claims to want, from leaving the Affordable Care Act alone to logging out of his Twitter account. And Trump\u2019s low approval numbers, which could easily have been a death sentence for another president\u2019s agenda, have not much impeded his legislative progress. Taking stock of this, a recent Politico headline asked, \u201cHas Trump made approval polls meaningless?\u201d\n\nA more plausible explanation is that the diminished meaning of political approval is what made Trump. Partisanship has always factored heavily into presidential approval, but in recent decades it has come to eclipse all other variables in Gallup\u2019s data. The last president to hold more than 40 percent approval from opposition-party voters in the early days of his presidency was George H.W. Bush. In his first three months in office, Trump received the lowest-ever approval rating among opposition-party voters (9 percent) and the third-highest-ever among his own partisans (87 percent). In a Huffington Post poll in April, 40 percent of respondents \u2014 63 percent of those who disapproved of Trump and 24 percent of those who approved of him \u2014 said there was almost nothing Trump could do to change their minds about him.\n\nThis question becomes less and less hypothetical every time Trump barrels through another taboo that previously bound the modern American presidency: firing an F.B.I. director who was investigating him, hesitating to censure white supremacists, casually accusing his critics of treason. Trump sees an approval rating maddeningly stuck around 40 percent, while most of the country \u2014 57 percent of it, if you credit Gallup \u2014 wonders: Really, still 40 percent? These numbers used to seem to say something, however vague, about a presidency and where it was headed. Now they tell us something about us, and it is maybe more than we would like to know.", "title": "Do Trump\u2019s \u2018Approval\u2019 Numbers Tell Us About Him, or About Us?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Becoming the most decorated Winter Olympics athlete in history requires snow, fortitude, technique, squats, more squats, a team of dedicated physiologists, a stable body weight, running shoes, high-intensity intervals, about 940 annual hours of exercise \u2014 much of it conducted at a surprisingly light intensity \u2014 and a willingness to substantially shake up training when it is no longer working well.\n\nThose are the findings of a new study published in Frontiers of Physiology that analyzed 17 years\u2019 worth of records about the workout routines of the Norwegian cross-country ski racer Marit Bjorgen, who will turn 38 in March.\n\nMs. Bjorgen won five medals at the Pyeongchang Games, making her the most winning athlete there, for a career total of 15 medals, eight of them gold.\n\nShe also appears to have led a thoroughly examined life, keeping scrupulous, detailed diary entries about each of her workouts from the time she became a senior-level athlete at age 20.", "title": "Do You Have What It Takes to Be an Olympian?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The global financial markets are not in crisis. Though some pundits stoked panic with their coverage of several days of market plunges before Tuesday\u2019s leap, stock prices are still near their record highs, the economy is creating jobs and many workers are finally getting decent raises after years of stagnant wages.\n\nWhich doesn\u2019t mean that there\u2019s nothing to worry about. In recent months, time after time, both the current administration and its allies in Congress have called into question their credibility and competence to manage the economy or handle a financial crisis if one were to occur. President Trump has repeatedly patted himself on the back for a surging stock market, seemingly unaware that stocks can go down, not just up. His Treasury Department in December released a one-page analysis that made outlandish economic assumptions to justify giant tax cuts for corporations and wealthy families. Republican lawmakers in Congress went even further, attacking the Congressional Budget Office and Congress\u2019s Joint Committee on Taxation, both nonpartisan, because those analysts had the temerity to warn that the tax law would add to the federal deficit.\n\nMr. Trump wants everyone to know that his election delivered a booster shot to the economy and stocks. \u201cThe reason our stock market is so successful is because of me,\u201d he told reporters in November. Truth is, the president was just lucky enough to have inherited a growing economy and a rising stock market. Though his tax cuts were an expensive gift to investors, he has not been in office long enough to have fundamentally changed that trajectory. But his erratic behavior and poor policy choices are clearly worrying the majority of Americans who disapprove of the president.\n\nOne reason some investors have become nervous recently is they fear that the tax cuts, which Mr. Trump and Republican lawmakers sold as a way to stimulate the economy, could end up hurting the economy in the not so distant future. The tax law and a push by the Trump administration to increase military spending will reduce federal revenue and force the Treasury to borrow more money when the economy is close to full employment. This could stoke inflation and prompt the Federal Reserve to tighten monetary policy. That, in turn, would slow the economy.", "title": "Opinion | Do You Think Donald Trump Is Ready for a Real Financial Crisis?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Notes:\n\nTeachers: The related article, and the excerpt below, discuss sexual activity and pornography using graphic language. Please preview these materials before sharing them with students to make sure they are appropriate for your class.\n\nStudents: Please post only your first name if you respond to this question on our site.\n\nHave your sex education classes ever addressed pornography? If so, what have they taught about it?\n\nIn a survey with a related quiz headlined \u201cDo You Think Porn Affects the Way Teenagers Think About Sex?,\u201d The New York Times Magazine reports:\n\nIn this week\u2019s cover story, Maggie Jones talks to high-school students, many of whom are in an after-school program known as Porn Literacy in Boston, to find out what young people think about porn. Jones also looks into the research on porn and adolescents, including surprising initial data from a recent large national survey conducted by Indiana University.\n\nThe survey\u2019s findings include:\n\nNinety-three percent of males and 62 percent of females in college reported having seen porn as adolescents, according to a 2008 study from the University of New Hampshire. Indiana University\u2019s research indicates that twice as many teenagers watched porn as their parents assumed. \u2026 Only 24 states mandate sex education, and only 13 require that it be medically accurate. One teenager Maggie Jones spoke with said the only sex ed he received was from the school\u2019s gym teacher, who sweated as he spoke, \u201cand it was all about it being bad and we shouldn\u2019t do it.\u201d \u2026 Many of the teenagers Maggie Jones spoke with believed that porn was realistic before they went through the Porn Literacy program. \u201cThere\u2019s nowhere else to learn about sex,\u201d one high-school student said. \u201cAnd porn stars know what they are doing.\u201d\n\nStudents: Complete the rest of the survey and, if you want, read the related article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 According to the article, what ideas about masculinity, femininity, sex and relationships do teenagers learn from pornography?\n\n\u2014 How do you feel about these messages? In your opinion, are they helpful or harmful? Why?\n\n\u2014 Do you think porn affects the way teenagers think about sex? Why or why not?", "title": "Do You Think Porn Influences the Way Teenagers Think About Sex?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Do you and your siblings, cousins or friends who are a few years younger or older than you love the same songs? What about your parents or other adults: do you share the same favorite musical artists?\n\nWhat would you say in response to a study that found the \u201dstrongest adult musical preferences\u201d set in by age 13 for girls and 14 for boys?\n\nIn the Op-Ed \u201cThe Songs That Bind,\u201d which is about a research project designed to \u201csee to what extent the year we were born influences the music we listen to, the extent to which different generations are bound to disagree on music,\u201d Seth Stephens-Davidowitz writes:\n\nConsider, for example, the song \u201cCreep,\u201d by Radiohead. This is the 164th most popular song among men who are now 38 years old. But it is not in the top 300 for the cohort born 10 years earlier or 10 years later. Note that the men who most like \u201cCreep\u201d now were roughly 14 when the song came out in 1993. In fact, this is a consistent pattern. I did a similar analysis with every song that topped the Billboard charts from 1960 to 2000. In particular, I measured how old their biggest fans today were when these songs first came out. It turns out that the \u201cCreep\u201d situation is pretty much universal. Songs that came out decades earlier are now, on average, most popular among men who were 14 when they were first released. The most important period for men in forming their adult tastes were the ages 13 to 16. What about women? On average, their favorite songs came out when they were 13. The most important period for women were the ages 11 to 14. Granted, some results of my research are not surprising. One of the facts I discovered is that Coolio\u2019s \u201cGangsta\u2019s Paradise\u201d is extremely unpopular among women in their 70s. Thank you, Big Data, for uncovering that nugget of wisdom! But I did find it interesting how clear the patterns were and how much early adolescence matters. The key years, in fact, match closely with the end of puberty, which tends to happen to girls before boys. This also adds one more piece of evidence to the growing scientific consensus that we never really leave middle school and high school. For both men and women, their early 20s were half as influential in determining adult musical tastes as their early teens.\n\nStudents: Read the entire Op-Ed, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What is the most surprising and least surprising things you learned from reading about the study conducted by Mr. Stephens-Davidowitz?\n\n\u2014 What was your favorite song when you were 13 or 14? Do you think you\u2019ll always love it?\n\n\u2014 Why do you think the early teen years are so significant for forging a lifelong taste in music?", "title": "Do You Think You\u2019ve Already Forged Your Lifelong Taste in Music?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Women with this form of ovarian cancer were sharing news and tips online in a closed Yahoo group. Dr. Levine asked to become part of the group and began joining the discussions. There he discovered patients who had persuaded doctors to give them an immunotherapy drug, even though there was no reason to think it would work.\n\nThe women reported that their tumors shrank immediately.\n\nThe idea behind immunotherapy is to dismantle a molecular shield that some tumors use to avoid an attack by the body\u2019s white blood cells.\n\nThe immune system sees these tumors as foreign \u2014 they are fueled by hundreds of genetic mutations, which drive their growth and are recognized by the body. But when white blood cells swarm in to attack the cancer cells, they bounce back, rebuffed.\n\nImmunotherapy drugs pierce that protective shield, allowing the immune system to recognize and demolish tumor cells. But the new drugs do not work against many common cancers.\n\nThose cancers are supported by fewer genetic mutations, and experts believe that the tumor cells just do not look threatening enough to the body to spur a response. So the immune system leaves them alone.\n\nLung cancer, a genetic type of colorectal cancer and melanoma have huge numbers of mutations, and immunotherapy drugs often are successful in treating them. Cancers of the prostate, pancreas, breast, ovaries \u2014 and most other tumors \u2014 carry few mutations.\n\n\u201cThese are the cancers that rarely respond,\u201d Dr. Pardoll said.\n\nThe idea that the drugs might work against something like hypercalcemic ovarian cancer, which is fueled by just one genetic mutation, just made no sense.", "title": "Doctors Said Immunotherapy Would Not Cure Her Cancer. They Were Wrong.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Despite his reputation, Dr. Lown was treated like just another widget on the hospital\u2019s conveyor belt. \u201cEach day, one person on the medical team would say one thing in the morning, and by the afternoon the plan had changed,\u201d he later told me. \u201cI always was the last to know what exactly was going on, and my opinion hardly mattered.\u201d\n\nWhat he needed was \u201cthe feeling of being a major partner in this decision,\u201d he said. \u201cEven though I am a doctor, I am still a human with anxieties.\u201d\n\nThe medical team was concerned that because Dr. Lown was having trouble swallowing, he was at risk for recurrent pneumonias. So we restricted his diet to pur\u00e9es. Soon the speech therapist recommended that we forbid him to ingest anything by mouth. Then the conversation spiraled into ideas for alternative feeding methods \u2014 a temporary tube through the nose followed, perhaps, by a feeding tube in the stomach.\n\n\u201cDoctors no longer minister to a distinctive person but concern themselves with fragmented, malfunctioning\u201d body parts, Dr. Lown wrote in \u201cThe Lost Art of Healing.\u201d Now, two decades later, he\u2019d become a victim of exactly what he had warned against.\n\nAs the intern and the perpetrator of the orders, I felt impossibly torn and terribly guilty. So after Dr. Lown was discharged the next week, I kept in touch, hoping to continue this important conversation.\n\nWe have since spent time together at his home, where he is back to living peacefully and swallowing carefully (no alternative feeding methods necessary).\n\nI had known Dr. Lown as a doctor and a patient; now I got to know him as an activist. We agreed that the health care system needed to change. To do that, Dr. Lown said, \u201cdoctors of conscience\u201d have to \u201cresist the industrialization of their profession.\u201d\n\nThis begins with our own training. Certainly doctors must understand disease, but medical education is overly skewed toward the biomedical sciences and minutiae about esoteric and rare disease processes. Doctors also need time to engage with the humanities, because they are the gateway to the human experience.", "title": "Opinion | Doctors, Revolt!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s true, as Ms. Glover notes, that no one predicted the ascent of Mr. Trump. But the shift of the Republican Party toward nativist populism was already evident in the immigration reform debate of 2007, if not much earlier on the airwaves of conservative talk radio. By contrast, there is little evidence of a burgeoning anti-Trump electoral force on the right that will stun the nation in 2020.\n\nABE SILBERSTEIN, BROOKLYN\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nNo, we do not need a third party. We need a large number of committed independents in Congress who can vote the will and needs of the people rather than for an ideological program. Any third party would quickly enrobe itself in an agenda that would soon become as inflexible as that of the two existing parties. Truly independent members making up a mere 10 percent of both houses would be able to hold the parties to their duty.\n\nROBERT DUCHAINE, BUCKLEY, WASH.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRegarding Juleanna Glover\u2019s premise that maybe it\u2019s time for another third-party candidate, I defer to modern history and suggest not.\n\nIn 2000, Ralph Nader pulled just enough votes from Al Gore and altered our country dramatically, especially on environmental issues, where the two stood on the same side. And just eight years earlier, George H. W. Bush lost as an incumbent to Bill Clinton in large part because of a more serious third-party challenge by Ross Perot. In both cases, third-party candidates harmed the chances of the candidates most politically like them.\n\nBut in Ms. Glover\u2019s hypothetical list of third-party maybes, I was surprised not to see Michael Bloomberg\u2019s name. He is the only candidate I can think of who would appeal to those who vote for business savvy, strength and safety, as well as progressive issues. That said, I would still give his chances better odds as a major-party candidate.", "title": "Opinion | Does America Need a Third Party?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 Defamation\n\nWithout any equivalent to the American First Amendment, freedom of speech in Australia is more negotiable and often subject to litigation.\n\nSuing for defamation is relatively easy in Australia, with presumptions favoring those who sue. Journalists, media organizations \u2014 and increasingly anyone who publishes on social media platforms \u2014 routinely lose in court or expect to lose and settle. The costs can be high, even prohibitive, stamping out some stories before they are ever written.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t get the idea that the defamation field is balanced. It is heavily weighted in favor of plaintiffs,\u201d wrote Peter Bartlett and Sam White, two well-known media lawyers, in a recent press freedom report. (Full disclosure: Peter is our lawyer). \u201cThe vast majority of cases are settled,\u201d they wrote, \u201cnot on the merits of the claim, but on a purely commercial basis. The cost of going to judgments is just too great.\u201d\n\nNow, it may be that there are strong arguments for restricting information and limiting journalism \u2014 arguments that I, as a journalist, may have a harder time fully agreeing with.\n\nBut regardless of whether you think our tribe is full of sensationalists to be protected against or heroes to be lauded, it\u2019s worth asking: Why are governments increasingly so insecure about letting us all see what they are up to?\n\nAs my colleagues Max Fisher and Amanda Taub from the Interpreter recently asked: Is there something wrong with democracy, something that has made its principles and freedoms lose their appeal?\n\nAs always, your thoughts are welcome, in our Facebook group and by email: nytaustralia@nytimes.com.\n\nOn that happy note, here are some examples of journalism worth fighting for, and smiling at, along with a weekly recommendation that crosses generational lines.", "title": "Does Australia Prefer Secrecy to Transparency?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "It seems like a noble pursuit: Eric T. They sit on park benches\n\nreading the newspaper and working the crossword puzzle.\n\nThey do what the dogs do in France.\n\nThey paint Modern art in the grass.\n\nThey write literature and bark at the birds.\n\nI\u2019m certain the dogs on the Upper West Side\n\nfeel superior to children.\n\nWho else would be so gratified that we hide\n\ntheir droppings in a tissue and daintily deposit\n\nin into the waste container on the corner?\n\nThe dog owner is granted a wish every time\n\nThey drop the stinky rose petals into the basket.\n\nWe tend to wish for wisdom, maybe a few stock tips.\n\nNothing extravagant. There are those who wish\n\nfor love, beauty, wealth.\n\nThe devoted dog owner prefers to wish\n\ntheir dog could talk, tell about its hopes\n\nand dreams. LUCIE, Fla. \u2014 By Mickey Callaway\u2019s estimate, he has used the word \u201caccountable\u201d thousands of times since taking over as the Mets manager last year, whether in interviews with the news media or in conversations with players. On Friday, before managing for the first time in a game, albeit a spring training exhibition, Callaway showed what he meant.\n\nDominic Smith, 22, a rookie first baseman who lost 35 pounds in the off-season and is vying to impress team officials, showed up late for an 8:45 a.m. team meeting before Friday\u2019s game against the Atlanta Braves. The penalty from Callaway: Smith was scratched from the starting lineup.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a little shocking,\u201d Callaway said. \u201cHe\u2019s trying to win a job.\u201d\n\nPunctuality was the No. 1 rule Callaway discussed in his first team meeting about expectations for the season. After a Friday morning visit to the manager\u2019s office, Smith described Callaway as \u201cpretty fair\u201d about the punishment.\n\n\u201cHe asked what I thought the decision should be, and I agreed with him,\u201d Smith said. \u201cThat\u2019s the only way it should be. He was 84.\n\nThe Dallas County medical examiner confirmed the death but did not specify the cause.\n\nMr. Carter founded the Mavericks with Norm Sonju, the team\u2019s first president. He sold his majority interest to a group led by Ross Perot Jr. in 1996 but kept a minority stake.\n\nThe Mavericks were a model franchise in their early days, quickly becoming a contender and reaching the Western Conference finals in 1988 before losing to the Los Angeles Lakers.", "title": "Don Carter, 84, Who Brought the N.B.A. to Dallas, Is Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Donald Lynden-Bell, a British theoretical astrophysicist who pioneered research into cosmic quirks like quasars and black holes and with colleagues contradicted the prevailing premise that the universe is expanding evenly, died on Feb. 6 at his home in Cambridge, England. He was 82.\n\nHis death was announced by the University of Cambridge, where he was a professor from 1972 until he formally retired in 2001.\n\nDr. Lynden-Bell, an expert in applying mathematical formulas to physics, was a past president of the Royal Astronomical Society and the first director of the Institute of Astronomy at Cambridge.\n\nHe shared the 2008 Kavli Prize for Astrophysics with Maarten Schmidt, a Dutch astronomer who first identified bright and powerful quasi-stellar radio sources, or quasars. Dr. Lynden-Bell, who explained their motion and energy source, shared $3 million in prizes with Dr. Schmidt and five other scientists.", "title": "Donald Lynden-Bell, Quasar and Black Hole Expert, Dies at 82", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 After days of controversy over whether he would blur the lines between American foreign policy and his family\u2019s real estate business during a trip to India to sell condos, Donald Trump Jr. on Friday abandoned plans to give a policy speech and instead gave an interview with an Indian journalist, sticking to safe topics.\n\nHis remarks in the interview \u2014 about his father\u2019s successful 2016 presidential campaign, how little the family sees him now, and India\u2019s great entrepreneurial spirit \u2014 were so anodyne that when the Bollywood star Shah Rukh Khan entered the room near the end of the interview, people lifted their phones to take photos of the actor and stopped paying attention to the oldest child of America\u2019s president.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m here as a businessman,\u201d Mr. Trump told a crowd of about 2,000 business and political leaders, who were gathered for the annual business conference hosted by India\u2019s most powerful media company, The Times Group. \u201cI\u2019m not representing anyone.\u201d\n\nBut his efforts to distance himself from administration policy were met with some skepticism.\n\n\u201cThough he claims that it\u2019s not an official speech, we take it as an official statement,\u201d said P. V. Sunil, a managing director of a company that builds malls and cinema complexes in India and Singapore. \u201cHe speaks to his father more than anyone here.\u201d", "title": "Donald Trump Jr. Retreats From Foreign Policy on India Trip", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "There has been some discussion about the president being good at golf, which I find annoying. I can\u2019t have him play my favorite sport and also be good at it. But when you watch him play, as you can on YouTube, you see that he has what you\u2019d call a \u201cterrible\u201d swing and a \u201cvery bad\u201d putting stroke.\n\nIt\u2019s possible he is good compared with bad golfers, but he is certainly bad compared with good golfers. Yet he speaks about his game very confidently, saying things like, \u201cFor me, the golf swing is clearing the hips, getting them out of the way.\u201d I played golf in college and hip clearance never once came up. It\u2019s kind of like if Tom Brady said he throws the football well because he flicks his wrist right at the end.\n\nThe most confusing aspect of President Trump as golfer is that golf is the ultimate test of integrity and humility. There are no referees, so it\u2019s on you to count your own strokes. Golfers develop a very strict honor code and a moral obligation to themselves and their playing partners to be 100 percent honest. And if golf is nothing else, it is humbling \u2014 when you hit your ball into a lake, there is simply no denying it (fake water!) and no one to blame but yourself (liberal wind!).\n\nBut the president appears to have skipped those lessons, and he tends to behave like the one guy at the course who is hand-wedging the ball out of the trees. Golfers like this do exist, but no one wants to play with them. People like this get asked to play once and then never get invited back: \u201cRemember that guy who parked his golf cart on the greens?\u201d \u201cYeah, the guy who left his Aerosmith ringtone on full blast and picked up every putt inside 10 feet?\u201d You don\u2019t have to be invited to play, though, when you own the course.\n\nYou can get an idea of the way the president manipulates truth by looking at how he talks about golf. In 2013, he tweeted, \u201cJust won The Club Championship at Trump International Golf Club in Palm Beach \u2014 lots of very good golfers, never easy to win a C.C.\u201d But he didn\u2019t win that year; Tom Roush did. Apparently, Mr. Trump won the senior division that year. No golfer in their right mind would confuse the club champion with the senior division winner.", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump Makes Golf Look Bad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Among the numerous harebrained ideas in President Trump\u2019s budget proposal this week, one stands out as especially pernicious: a scheme that would slash an essential antipoverty program and put fresh food further out of reach for 46 million low-income people, or one in seven Americans.\n\nThe Trump administration wants to cut the budget of the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, popularly known as food stamps, by nearly 30 percent over a decade. It plans to accomplish this, in large part, by giving low-income families boxes of pasta, cereal and other nonperishable foods, rather than giving them the full amount of their benefit on electronic cards, as the SNAP program works today. Those cards can be used at about 260,000 retail stores and farmers\u2019 markets nationwide to buy a wide range of fresh and packaged food, allowing recipients to shop with their families\u2019 preferences and dietary needs in mind.\n\nThe administration argues that its proposal, which also would make it harder for adults living without children or other dependents to benefit from the program if they aren\u2019t employed, is \u201cdesigned to improve nutrition and target benefits to those who need them, while ensuring careful stewardship of taxpayers\u2019 money.\u201d\n\nIf Mr. Trump and his aides actually cared about improving nutrition and the lives of low-income Americans, they would be trying to put more money into SNAP, not less. The program has done a heroic job of reducing poverty and improving the lives of millions of people. Studies have found that the program\u2019s beneficiaries are less likely to report not having enough to eat. They are also less likely to take sick days and are shown to spend less on health care compared with similar people who do not benefit from the program. Further, children who grow up in families enrolled in SNAP are more likely to graduate from high school and be economically self-sufficient as adults.", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump Raids the Pantry of Poor Americans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Grassley is no one\u2019s idea of a justice reformer, but he supports the bill because, he said, it \u201cstrikes the right balance of improving public safety and ensuring fairness in the criminal justice system.\u201d\n\nSo what has this administration done right? The list is short and uninspiring. In October, Mr. Trump declared the epidemic of opioid abuse a national emergency, which could be a good step toward addressing it \u2014 but he\u2019s since done almost nothing to combat a crisis that killed more than 64,000 Americans in 2016.\n\nIn his State of the Union address last month, Mr. Trump promised to \u201cembark on reforming our prisons to help former inmates who have served their time get a second chance.\u201d It\u2019s great if he really means that, but it\u2019s hard to square his assurance with his own attorney general\u2019s opposition to a bill that includes recidivism-reduction programs intended to achieve precisely this goal.\n\nPerhaps the most insidious part of the Trump administration\u2019s approach to criminal justice lies in its efforts to link crime to its broader crackdown on immigration. In a speech last month, Mr. Sessions said undocumented immigrants are far more likely than American citizens to commit crimes, a claim he found in a paper by John Lott, the disreputable economist best known for misusing statistics to suit his own ideological ends. In this case, it appears Mr. Lott misread his own data, which came from Arizona and in fact showed the opposite of what he claimed: Undocumented immigrants commit fewer crimes than citizens, as the vast majority of research on the topic has found.\n\nBut no matter; Mr. Trump and Mr. Sessions don\u2019t need facts to run their anti-immigrant agenda, which has already resulted in more than double the number of arrests of immigrants with no criminal convictions as in 2016, as the Brennan Center report noted. Soon after taking office, Mr. Trump issued an executive order cutting off federal funding to so-called sanctuary cities, jurisdictions that refuse to cooperate with federal immigration officials. A federal judge blocked the order in November for violating the Constitution.\n\nThe rhetoric from the White House and the Justice Department has emboldened some state and local officials to talk tougher, even if just as ignorantly, about crime. The good news is that it\u2019s not working as well anymore. In Virginia\u2019s race for governor last fall, the Republican candidate, Ed Gillespie, attacked his opponent, Ralph Northam, with ads blaming him for violence by the MS-13 gang.\n\nIt was a despicable stunt, its fearmongering recalling the racist but effective Willie Horton ad that George H. W. Bush ran on in his successful 1988 presidential campaign. Thankfully, Virginia\u2019s voters overwhelmingly rejected Mr. Gillespie, another sign that criminal justice reform is an issue with strong support across the political spectrum. In the era of Donald Trump, candidates of both parties should be proud to run as reformers \u2014 but particularly Democrats, who can cast the issue not only as a central component of a broader progressive agenda, but as yet another example of just how out of touch with the country Mr. Trump and his administration are.", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump and the Undoing of Justice Reform", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "(Want to get this briefing by email? They just kill them.\u2019\u201d\n\nFor Trump, toughness obviates restraint. It precludes mercy. It isn\u2019t calibrated but it has a caliber, because toughness means packing heat. [Reuters]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Our correspondent\u2019s journal on how migration has changed the Italian town she grew up in was so well received, she took the time to translate it into Italian. [The New York Times / in Italian]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Pasta with bacon, cheese, lemon and pine nuts feeds many tastes with a single dish.\n\n\u2022 \u201cAll natural\u201d sounds great on a food label, but it doesn\u2019t always mean what you think it means \u2014 and it\u2019s not necessarily better for you, either.\n\n\u2022 How to fit in some exercise while you travel.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nVideo\n\n\u2022 Our latest Op-Doc video, by a French filmmaker, offers an intimate portrait of an Inuit child, who is torn between his native identity and a modern education.\n\n\u2022 Mario Vargas Llosa is a literary and political colossus across the Spanish-speaking world. His words, according to our Magazine, have never felt more relevant than in our era of populism.\n\n\u2022 Russian meddling in the race for the Oscars sounds like a bad joke, but there are suspicious social-media campaigns against two documentaries that the Kremlin is not fond of.\n\n\u2022 The Broadway theater that will house the eighth (and the only theatrical) installment of the Harry Potter franchise has been rebuilt in the hope that it will run there for many years. J.K. Rowling said she was worried about the competition.\n\n\u2022 Asia\u2019s only legal greyhound racetrack closes this year. It\u2019s unclear what will happen to its 650 greyhounds, but there\u2019s a plan to fly them to Portugal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Behind an old door on a quiet street in Paris, Philippe Anthonioz creates his increasingly monumental sculptures (and furniture).\n\n\u201cIf there is no romance in the environment,\u201d he said, \u201cit\u2019s hard to make good things.\u201d\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s easy to spot members of the Dutch delegation at the Winter Olympics as they travel around on orange bicycles, 132 of which were shipped to South Korea by boat.\n\nThe bikes are helping athletes feel at home. In the Netherlands, bikes outnumber people, 22.5 million to 18 million.\n\nBut the Netherlands wasn\u2019t always a biker\u2019s haven. In the 1950s and \u201960s, as people started buying more cars, two-wheelers were beginning to be pushed off the road.\n\nLiterally. Bicycle deaths, like traffic deaths as a whole, increased.\n\nIn 1971, about 3,300 people died in traffic accidents, including 400 children. Activist groups sprang up. Stop de Kindermoord (Stop the Child Murder) was among the most prominent.\n\nThe number of traffic deaths has dropped since that period. In 2016, the Netherlands saw 629 traffic deaths, about a third of which were bike deaths. Only 12 were children.\n\nPart of the success story: the country\u2019s bike lanes, a network now measured at about 22,000 miles (or 35,000 kilometers).\n\nClaire Moses contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning, or to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBrowse our full range of Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Donald Trump, Syria, Champions League: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Patrick Boehler"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The proposal would raise military spending by 14.1 percent while cutting funding for the State Department \u2014 the agency that has a mandate to resolve problems without going to war \u2014 by 26.9 percent. It would cut the Department of Health and Human Services by 20.3 percent and the Department of Education by 10.5 percent. It calls for (yet again) the repeal of the Affordable Care Act and proposes cutting food stamps by $213 billion, or around 30 percent, over 10 years. Medicare and Medicaid, which benefit one-third of Americans, are targeted for cuts of hundreds of billions of dollars.\n\nIf Congress adopted Mr. Trump\u2019s proposal, millions of people would stand to lose health insurance, subsidized food, low-cost housing and other benefits. The result would be to greatly increase poverty and hunger in America.\n\nThis is surely not what most of Mr. Trump\u2019s working-class supporters imagined during the primary and general election campaigns. In May 2015, Candidate Trump tweeted, \u201cI was the first & only potential GOP candidate to state there will be no cuts to Social Security, Medicare & Medicaid.\u201d And in an April 2016 ad that ran in Pennsylvania he promised to \u201csave Social Security and Medicare without cuts.\u201d\n\nBut wait, there\u2019s more. Another of Mr. Trump\u2019s promises was to build the \u201cgleaming new roads, bridges, highways, railways and waterways all across our land,\u201d a promise that he referred to as recently as his State of the Union address in January. Yet his budget recommends slashing funding for Amtrak and grant programs that help local and state governments pay for highway and transit projects. Over all, the administration wants to reduce the Department of Transportation\u2019s budget by nearly a fifth. The budget would also effectively cut the Highway Trust Fund by $122 billion over a decade.\n\nNo doubt Mr. Trump will claim he is still serious about infrastructure by pointing to a separate infrastructure proposal he announced on Monday. In that document, the administration says it will bolster investment by $1.5 trillion over 10 years. But the math simply doesn\u2019t add up. The White House suggests that the federal government would put up only $200 billion, which would be enough to get state and local governments and the private sector to supply the rest of the money. But where would most cities and states find those funds? Already strapped, many will struggle to raise new tax revenue, because the Republican tax law limited the deductibility of state and local taxes. The private sector might be interested, but only in projects like toll roads that produce a steady and rich source of income.\n\nIt will be tempting for some to dismiss Mr. Trump\u2019s budget as a marketing stunt by his budget director, Mick Mulvaney, who was earlier a Tea Party zealot in Congress. After all, Congress last week passed, and Mr. Trump signed, a two-year bipartisan budget that authorizes a significant increase in domestic, as well as military, spending.", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump\u2019s Nasty Budget", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Amanda Munz\n\nAge 27\n\nHometown Lindenhurst, N.Y.\n\nNow Lives Still in Lindenhurst, in the same four-bedroom home that she shares with her parents. \u201cThat\u2019s start-up-charity life for you,\u201d Ms. Munz said.\n\nClaim to Fame Ms. Munz is the founder of the Fashion Foundation, a nonprofit that solicits excess samples from fashion houses and designers, sells them online and at a store in Farmingdale, N.Y., and uses the proceeds to buy school supplies for underprivileged students in the New York City area. \u201cThis is my baby,\u201d she said. \u201cI really think this can be the go-to nonprofit for the fashion industry.\u201d\n\nBig Break In 2015, after interning at Swimwear Anywhere, where she saw lots of unused samples thrown away, she formed the Fashion Foundation in a spare room in her parents\u2019 house. It was slow going until she met the designer Rebecca Minkoff at a SoHo fund-raiser for the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society in 2016. A week later, Ms. Minkoff donated 20 boxes of unsold merchandise. \u201cRebecca physically pushed me out of my home office,\u201d she said. \u201cSaying her name gives me so much credibility.\u201d Since then, donations have also come from Calvin Klein, Vera De Nero and Aimee Lynn Apparel.\n\nLatest Project For New York Fashion Week, her foundation teamed with Nolcha, which mounts runway shows for emerging designers, and Mac Duggal, a label known for its prom dresses, to auction off tickets to their runway shows.
