Her lips trembling, she stood ramrod-straight as she gave a salute.\n\nBeckoned by the president, the girl was lifted into the air and toward the stage to meet with him. But she looked hesitant, and eventually began crying, as the president went on to say that she would be honored if she were killed in combat.\n\nVideo clips of the encounter between the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and the first grader, Amine Tiras, ricocheted across the internet over the weekend. While Turkish news agencies focused on the girl\u2019s emotions \u2014 portraying her as brave and resolute \u2014 some online commentators said she had been used as a political prop and called it inappropriate.\n\nAt the very least, the themes of military service, patriotism and martyrdom seemed rather mature for a first grader.", "title": "Erdogan Tells a Weeping Girl, 6, She\u2019d Receive Honors if Martyred", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFrom my perspective, success is if you break a trifecta,\u201d Mr. Holder said, adding: \u201cI don\u2019t think that in December of 2018, you measure success only by whether you have assumed control of a particular state.\u201d\n\nBecause of the broad authority Republicans hold in many states, and the favorable maps many Republican lawmakers have drawn for themselves, Mr. Holder said his group would spend money wherever Republicans appear to be vulnerable. In Ohio, that will mean pursuing not only the governorship but also the offices of state auditor and secretary of state, both of which play a role in shaping legislative maps. In Wisconsin and Florida, Mr. Holder\u2019s group will help Democrats compete for the governorship and the State Senate majority.\n\nIn North Carolina, where there is a Democratic governor, Roy Cooper, but Republicans have control of the legislature by vast margins, the redistricting committee hopes to shave seats off the current Republican supermajorities.\n\nMr. Holder said he would campaign aggressively himself in some of these races, beginning with an election for the Wisconsin Supreme Court this spring. Both he and Mr. Obama will focus heavily on mobilizing African-American voters, Mr. Holder said.\n\nThe strategy has the potential to inject a new volume of money, on the Democratic side, into typically low-profile elections. Mr. Holder said the group has raised more than $16 million out of a previously announced $30 million goal, but it has not disclosed how much cash it has on hand.\n\nThe tug of war over congressional maps has begun years before the 2020 census, which will collect the data used for reapportioning seats in Congress. Democrats have already sued to throw out congressional maps in several states and the United States Supreme Court is expected to consider a number of cases this year involving gerrymandered maps.\n\nRepublican leaders have long described control of the redistricting process as one of the party\u2019s prized assets. Representative Steve Stivers of Ohio, the party\u2019s campaign chairman in the House, said in an interview with Politico that \u201cthe congressional lines\u201d were one of the Republicans\u2019 great advantages in 2018.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Republicans have also stressed that it is not gerrymandering alone that has kept them in power in the states. \u201cRepublicans won because they were better candidates with better visions for the people of their states,\u201d said Matt Walter, president of the Republican State Leadership Committee, which spends millions in state legislative elections.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Walter has warned that Mr. Holder\u2019s group represents a new force in state-level politics, and urged Republicans to prepare for better-funded Democratic efforts than in the past.\n\nBut absent Supreme Court intervention, Democrats may face an arduous, yearslong campaign to peel back Republicans\u2019 overwhelming advantage in the states. A model for Democratic efforts, several strategists said, might come from Pennsylvania, where an all-Republican government implemented an elaborately gerrymandered map after the 2010 elections. Democrats later captured the governorship and the State Supreme Court, which recently voided the existing district lines and forced an icy standoff between Republican legislative leaders and Gov. Tom Wolf, a Democrat, over the creation of a new map.\n\nMr. Wolf said in an interview on Monday that he was optimistic Republican leaders would ultimately agree to redraw a \u201cfair map\u201d with his input. Mr. Wolf, who is running for re-election in 2018 in a race Mr. Holder\u2019s group intends to target, said Pennsylvania could be a case study in bipartisan redistricting: \u201cIf I do it right, it is a model.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Wolf cautioned Democrats in other states not to twist electoral lines to their advantage and urged the few gerrymandered blue states to abandon their partisan maps. In states like Maryland and Illinois, Republicans have denounced Democrats for warping district maps even as Democrats denounce gerrymandering on the national level.\n\nBeyond the traditional swing states, Mr. Holder said his group is eyeing some more daunting targets, including Georgia\u2019s open governorship and the Texas Legislature, where Democrats hope to chip away at huge Republican majorities. And the group is monitoring a number of state-level ballot initiatives that could put anti-gerrymandering laws up for a vote this year.\n\n\u201cIn some ways, that\u2019s the best way to do it,\u201d Mr. Holder said of referendums, \u201cbut state constitutions don\u2019t allow that to happen in all 50 states.\u201d", "title": "Eric Holder\u2019s Group Targets All-G.O.P. States to Attack Gerrymandering", "authors": ["Alexander Burns"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nEric Hosmer was a reigning World Series champion when he took the field at Petco Park in San Diego for the 2016 All-Star Game. Hosmer, who had helped lead the Kansas City Royals to the title, smacked an opposite-field home run in his first at-bat and a run-scoring single in his second. He was named the game\u2019s most valuable player and seemed right at home.\n\nNow, Hosmer will stay in San Diego for a while. He reached an eight-year, $144 million agreement to join the Padres late Saturday night, ending a sparkling seven-year run with the Royals by scoring the most lucrative free-agent deal of this off-season.\n\nThe market has been unusually slow for free agents, but Hosmer, a 28-year-old first baseman with four Gold Glove Awards, was widely believed to be the prize of this class. While he had to wait until spring training was underway \u2014 Padres position players officially reported on Sunday \u2014 he finally found the eight-year deal he was seeking.\n\nThe agreement, first reported by the San Diego Union-Tribune, was confirmed by two people in baseball who were granted anonymity because Hosmer must pass a physical for the contract to be official. Hosmer, who batted .318 with 25 homers last season, will earn $105 million over the first five years of the deal, and then could exercise an opt-out clause.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe total value of Hosmer\u2019s contract eclipses the six-year, $126 million deal the Chicago Cubs agreed to last week with starter Yu Darvish. Center fielder Lorenzo Cain, Hosmer\u2019s former teammate with the Royals, has the third-richest deal this winter, signing for five years and $80 million with the Milwaukee Brewers.", "title": "Eric Hosmer Joins the Padres, Jolting a Quiet Free-Agent Market", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 Ester Ledecka warded off the late afternoon cold on Saturday in a Czech Republic team jacket that was white on one side and gold on the other. It could be worn either way, which made it as versatile as Ledecka, who made history Saturday with her victory in the women\u2019s snowboarding parallel slalom.\n\nLedecka, who had won an Alpine skiing event, the women\u2019s super-G, in an upset a week earlier, became the first woman to win a gold medal in two different sports in a single Winter Games.\n\nNot only did Ledecka defeat Selina Joerg of Germany in the final, she also nudged out Jorien ter Mors of the Netherlands, who had become the first woman to earn medals in different sports in a single Olympics while Ledecka waited to compete in snowboarding. Ter Mors earned gold in the 1,000 meters in long-track speedskating and added a bronze in the 3,000-meter relay in short-track.\n\n\u201cI was dreaming about this moment since I was a little child,\u201d said Ledecka, whose margin of victory in her six runs was at least four-tenths of a second. \u201cA lot of people were telling me that it is not possible to do both sports and to be on a high level in both sports and today I proved it is possible.\u201d", "title": "Ester Ledecka Makes History With Gold Medals in Snowboarding and Skiing", "authors": ["Karen Crouse", "On Olympics"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "TARTU, Estonia \u2014 Computer technology has given Tonis Leissoo a chance to honor his homeland and its turbulent history through watchmaking.\n\nWith no formal training as a horologist, Mr. Leissoo, 33, turned to Photoshop, computer-assisted design software and 3-D printing to realize a lifelong obsession with watches, using the digital tools to execute ideas and designs he had thought about since childhood.\n\nIn 2016, he introduced his first watch: the Woitleja, a military-style mechanical model with a black enamel face by Roman Tavast, a local specialist. Its chunky case was cut from corrosion-resistant bronze and housed a Unitas 6497-2 movement by the Swiss specialist ETA.\n\nWoitleja, the Estonian word for freedom fighter, was the name of the artillery car on one of the armored trains used by citizens of the small Baltic country in its 1918 War of Independence. The conflict broke out when Estonia declared sovereignty, which it managed to retain through the two-year war with German and Russian forces.", "title": "Estonia\u2019s History, in Watches", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "What was your reaction to Laura Ingraham\u2019s \u201cShut up and dribble\u201d monologue on Fox News that received a backlash?\n\nI spent quite a bit of time on this exact topic in \u201cWe Matter.\u201d This is the notion of an athlete\u2019s place. Especially a black athlete\u2019s place: \u201cYou should just be grateful,\u201d \u201cHow dare you complain,\u201d and \u201cWho are you to speak on this subject?\u201d You heard that criticism back in the day with Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Bill Russell, Muhammad Ali and John Carlos.\n\nYou heard it after Colin Kaepernick took a knee. Now you\u2019re hearing it with LeBron James and Kevin Durant. It\u2019s not just Laura Ingraham who feels this way. There\u2019s a large segment she was speaking for. If you look at the words she chose: \u201cbarely intelligible\u201d and \u201cungrammatical.\u201d Right there, she was attempting to insult their intelligence as if they don\u2019t have the qualifications to speak on this subject.\n\nThe line that stood out to me the most was \u201cMust they run their mouths like that?\u201d\n\nOf course. It\u2019s the same thing. That\u2019s the whole \u201cShut up and play.\u201d This is not a new thing though. She, of course, verbalized it. But this is something that happens whenever an athlete speaks out.\n\nPhoto\n\nYou briefly overlapped with Michael Jordan when he made his second comeback with the Wizards. He is famously reported to have said \u201cRepublicans buy sneakers, too,\u201d when it came to political activism. Did you clash in the locker room?\n\nNot at all. People have a certain perception of Michael Jordan, and I would just say the perception is not accurate. That\u2019s all. Just from being there with him, I never got any type of resistance from him.\n\nThat\u2019s a phrase that\u2019s going to haunt him for the rest of his days, whenever the topic of athletes and activism comes up. He\u2019s not quite what people think he is and that\u2019s what my interactions with him for two years were as well. We\u2019ve had great discussions about different things and he respects other opinions. I wish other people could see the Michael Jordan that I saw.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf Jordan were in the league today, would he be politically active?\n\nIt\u2019s hard to say that because it\u2019s a different time. Back then, there was kind of a lull with athletes and activists. People weren\u2019t speaking out as much. But then you\u2019ve seen a resurgence as of late. I think a lot of that has to do with police killings and the things that were visible on social media.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn your book, you encourage athletes to speak out. What was the dynamic with your teammates like? Did you ever receive any pushback?\n\nI tell people all the time: If they would\u2019ve heard the conversations that we had in the locker room, they would\u2019ve been surprised. We had so many political conversations around a current event and everybody had opinions. From around the N.B.A., I would get nods of support. I\u2019d be playing against a certain player and they\u2019d be on the free throw line. They\u2019d tell me, \u201cHey, I read what you said at that rally. That\u2019s good stuff!\u201d Some media people didn\u2019t like it. It depended on what side of the fence they were on with whatever I was saying. I never got any pushback from management or coaches.\n\nYou write about an interesting conversation you had with the sociology professor Michael Eric Dyson comparing activism of athletes from decades ago to now. He suggests that athletes in the past engaged in \u201csocial protest,\u201d while today the top athletes are more likely to engage in \u201csocial charity.\u201d Do you agree?\n\nWe were going back and forth and came to some common ground. This is the thing. Everybody back in the 1960s was not Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Bill Russell. There\u2019s sometimes been a romanticizing.\n\nThere\u2019s always a risk when you do speak out. It might be a different type of risk. Back in the sixties, there was a threat to your life on a whole different level. People love Muhammad Ali now. But back then? When he said he wasn\u2019t going to go in the Army? He was hated. People think that Colin Kaepernick is hated right now. They can just imagine it times one hundred with Ali.\n\nDo you feel, given the platform, that there is an obligation for athletes to be politically active?\n\nI don\u2019t feel that anybody should be forced to do something that they don\u2019t want to do. I think it\u2019s kind of unfair to tell somebody to take on a fight that isn\u2019t their fight or they\u2019re not passionate about it. I don\u2019t think that\u2019s necessarily fair but I do love when athletes speak out, of course, and I think they should get support.", "title": "Etan Thomas: Now a Different Kind of Player", "authors": ["Sopan Deb"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia \u2014 Ethiopia will release 746 more prisoners, including a journalist and a senior opposition official who were jailed for conspiracy to commit terrorist acts, the attorney general\u2019s office said Thursday.\n\nThe decision follows a series of changes announced by the government to try to reduce tension in Ethiopia, which has been hit by unrest since 2015.\n\nNearly 6,000 prisoners have been freed since January. Most were detained in connection with mass protests that broke out three years ago in the country\u2019s Oromia and Amhara regions, where people have complained that they have been neglected by the central government and victimized by land grabbing.\n\nOn Thursday, the attorney general\u2019s office published a list of 746 inmates for pardon, including the journalist Eskinder Nega and the opposition politician Andualem Arage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe names of the prisoners have been forwarded to President Mulatu Teshome, who has the power to grant their freedom, the state-affiliated Fana Broadcasting Corporation said.", "title": "Ethiopia to Free 746 Prisoners", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Africa\u2019s second-most populous country and an important United States ally in the fight against terrorism, Ethiopia is a regional powerhouse with grand economic plans. But it has experienced violent clashes for more than two years, with protesters calling for economic and political reform. Implementation of the government\u2019s agenda has been slow, and tensions have escalated as the public\u2019s patience has waned.\n\nIn a move many believed was designed to release some of that tension, Mr. Hailemariam announced in January that the country would free some prisoners, including opposition politicians. Several hundred were freed, but the government continued to hold some of the most high-profile prisoners, including the journalists and Mr. Bekele.\n\nObservers have said that the government\u2019s reluctance to free prominent prisoners illustrated divisions within the ruling party over the release program specifically and of the march toward reform generally.\n\n\u201cThere are elements within the ruling party who don\u2019t want to do that, who want to resist it at every turn,\u201d said Hassan Hussein, an Ethiopian analyst and professor at St. Mary\u2019s University in Minneapolis.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe said the government and members of the opposition, especially the political party of the Oromia people, had disagreed about the conditions for releasing prisoners.\n\nTo accelerate the process, Oromia opposition members inside and outside Ethiopia called for a boycott on Monday. Shops and banks in the province of Oromia were closed, and those who did not join the street protests largely stayed home, residents said. Activists said as many as 20 people were killed.\n\nThe boycott was officially canceled after Mr. Bekele was released on Tuesday, but Mr. Hallelujah said the protests had continued in many places.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s easy to call a protest, but it\u2019s very difficult to call it off,\u201d he said. \u201cIt takes its own life and its own course.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is precisely what appears to have spooked the most powerful member of the four-party coalition, which has been facing down more than two years of demonstrations in the country\u2019s most sensitive regions. The government cracked down against the protesters, and at least 669 people have been killed, according to the Ethiopian Human Rights Commission.\n\nThe ruling coalition, which has run the country since 1991 and controls every seat in Parliament, is also fracturing from within. Two of its marginalized members, representing the regions where the protests began, joined forces to contest the power of the coalition\u2019s dominant member \u2014 an unexpected alliance of former enemies that, observers say, appears to be succeeding in challenging power.\n\nMr. Hailemariam\u2019s resignation appears to be the latest chapter in that political saga. \u201cI think his resignation probably is because of those differences among the coalition groups,\u201d said Girma Seifu, an opposition politician who was once the only lawmaker who was not a member of the ruling coalition.\n\nMr. Hailemariam came into office in 2012, after the death of Meles Zenawi, whom Mr. Hallelujah described as a \u201cbigger than life figure.\u201d Mr. Meles had ruled with a heavy hand \u2014 and, some say, a micromanager\u2019s scrutiny \u2014 since 1995. But Mr. Hailemariam gave little indication that he had either the wide-angle vision or the close-up attention of his predecessor.\n\n\u201cReplacing him is difficult by itself,\u201d Mr. Hallelujah said of Mr. Meles. \u201cBut for many people, Hailemariam didn\u2019t have the charisma, the competence, the political capital or the political clout to be a consequential or a meaningfully effective prime minister.\u201d\n\nMr. Seifu, the opposition politician, said the ongoing protests, and the government\u2019s need to bow to some opposition demands in order to maintain its grip on power, were also signs of the prime minister\u2019s weakness.\n\n\u201cYou could say the government is not enjoying the protests,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cIn his first three years, we can give him an excuse,\u201d Mr. Seifu added, \u201cbut in the past two years, when he is expected by party to build new vision and give guidance and leadership to the country, he didn\u2019t demonstrate this capacity.\u201d", "title": "Ethiopia\u2019s Prime Minister Resigns Amid Political Turmoil", "authors": ["Jina Moore"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Bouchard, 23, won the liability phase of the trial on Thursday, though the jury said that she bore 25 percent of the comparative negligence for her injury. That meant that the U.S.T.A. would have had to pay Bouchard only 75 percent of whatever value the jury assigned to her damages.\n\n\u201cI feel vindicated that I got the verdict yesterday,\u201d Bouchard said. \u201cJust relief and happiness right now.\u201d\n\nAfter each side\u2019s lawyers made lengthy opening arguments in the damages phase of the trial at the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, proceedings were suspended for four hours as the legal teams, Bouchard and representatives from the U.S.T.A. met.\n\nBenedict Morelli, Bouchard\u2019s lawyer, initially said he was ready to put her on the stand after the hours of talks had not yielded a resolution. She testified Wednesday in the liability phase of the trial. But in the corridors of the courthouse, Morelli appeared to persuade Bouchard, who was alongside her mother, Julie Leclair, to take the deal the U.S.T.A. had offered.\n\n\u201cWhen people attack you and attack your name, you get affected by that,\u201d Morelli said of Bouchard\u2019s hesitation. \u201cWhen you\u2019re resolving it, you want to make sure you can live with it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s pleasantly living with it,\u201d he added.\n\nLeclair began to cry as she expressed her relief at the settlement.\n\n\u201cJust relieved that it\u2019s over,\u201d she said. \u201cWe try to put it out of our minds, but it\u2019s been a tough two years. Tough on her, tough on the whole family, and I\u2019m just glad it\u2019s over.\u201d\n\nThe opening arguments of the damages phase set up what could have been fascinating, speculative arguments about how Bouchard\u2019s career might have proceeded had the injury not occurred.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe reached the fourth round of the 2015 U.S. Open before being forced to withdraw. Morelli contended that Bouchard, then No. 25 in the world, was likely to win her next two matches and make the semifinals, because she was ranked ahead of the women who would have been her opponents, No. 43 Roberta Vinci and No. 40 Kristina Mladenovic.\n\nHe further argued that Bouchard would have had a chance to win against top-ranked Serena Williams in the semifinals, mentioning that \u201cGenie has beaten Serena Williams in the past.\u201d He did not disclose that that win had come at the Hopman Cup exhibition event, which is not counted in head-to-head records.\n\nAlan Kaminsky, the U.S.T.A.\u2019s lawyer, countered by pointing out that Bouchard\u2019s results had been poor throughout the 2015 season. He noted that she had lost, badly, to Vinci just one week before the Open and that she had a losing record against Mladenovic.\n\n\u201cThe chances of her winning the U.S. Open that year were extremely not good,\u201d Kaminsky said.\n\nThe U.S.T.A. also appeared ready to dispute the nature of Bouchard\u2019s injury itself, rebutting the diagnosis of a concussion. (At the time of her withdrawal from the tournament, Open officials announced that a concussion was her official reason.)\n\nKaminsky said that numerous magnetic resonance imaging exams were found to be negative for a concussion.\n\n\u201cShe did have a bang to the head, and was treated properly for that,\u201d he said.\n\nKaminsky also countered Bouchard\u2019s assertion that she had lost millions in possible endorsement deals because of the fall, saying she \u201cdid not lose one endorsement deal\u201d after the accident.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhen you hear how much money Ms. Bouchard has made from endorsements, you\u2019re not going to believe it,\u201d Kaminsky told the jury. \u201cIt\u2019s staggering.\u201d\n\nThe jury did not end up hearing that information, which Bouchard had been eager to keep private. She had filed a motion, which was denied, seeking to remove reporters from the courtroom for testimony regarding her endorsements.\n\nBouchard had also wanted her social media posts to be kept out of the trial, arguing that they painted a misleadingly sunny portrait of her life since the injury. Judge Ann M. Donnelly ruled against that request, too, saying that the court is public and that social media is an admissible record of her state of mind pertaining to various claims of emotional damages and psychological suffering.\n\nBouchard\u2019s next tournament is expected to be in Indian Wells, Calif., in March. She is currently ranked 116th, well outside the cutoff for the main draw, but she said she was hoping to receive a wild card.", "title": "Eugenie Bouchard and U.S.T.A. Reach Settlement", "authors": ["Ben Rothenberg"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Prodi said the funds he had been paid by Mr. Gusenbauer did not come, to his knowledge, from Mr. Manafort.\n\nThe compensation from Mr. Gusenbauer was a result of the \u201cnormal private relations I had with him,\u201d Mr. Prodi said, but \u201cnot any money from external sources.\u201d He added: \u201cI tell you I have never been paid from any lobby group in America.\u201d\n\nIn a statement to the BBC, Mr. Gusenbauer, who led Austria from January 2007 to December 2008, denied any involvement in Mr. Manafort\u2019s work in Ukraine but acknowledged that he had met him twice and talked to European and American politicians about Ukraine, as Mr. Prodi had also done.\n\nIn Europe, only Austria and Germany refer to their head of government as chancellor.\n\n\u201cI always had the point of view that it was important to move Ukraine closer to Europe,\u201d Mr. Gusenbauer told the BBC. \u201cIt would have been extremely positive if Ukraine could have agreed\u201d to closer ties, he said. \u201cI was talking to E.U. and U.S. politicians to make that point clear.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Gusenbauer added: \u201cI stopped this activity when I had the impression that Ukraine was moving in the wrong direction.\u201d\n\nIn an interview on Saturday with the Austrian Press Agency, Mr. Gusenbauer said that he had been \u201cremunerated\u201d for his work on behalf of Ukraine, but he did not say by whom. He added that he had never worked for Mr. Yanukovych and that he had only met Mr. Manafort two or three times.\n\nMr. Gusenbauer met several members of Congress in June 2013 on behalf of Ukraine, according to a federal filing last year by Mercury Public Affairs, a political strategy group that Mr. Manafort had hired.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Prodi recalled meeting members of Congress interested in Ukraine, but said he had not heard of Mercury. Asked who scheduled the meetings in Washington, Mr. Prodi said, \u201cI imagine it was Gusenbauer.\u201d\n\nA second Washington lobbying firm hired by Mr. Manafort, the Podesta Group, also said last year that it had \u201carranged meetings and media opportunities\u201d for visiting European leaders regarding Ukraine, starting in 2012, including for Mr. Gusenbauer, Mr. Prodi and two former presidents, Aleksander Kwasniewski of Poland and Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine.\n\nMr. Manafort did not inform the Washington lobbyists with whom they worked that the European politicians were being paid for their efforts, according to people familiar with the work done by the two firms, who said the lobbyists had presented the European politicians as unbiased validators of Mr. Yanukovych\u2019s efforts.\n\nThe group of senior former politicians, according to the indictment, was informally called the Hapsburg Group, after the Austro-Hungarian dynasty, the Habsburgs. The plan, according to the indictment, was for the group to \u201cappear to be providing their independent assessments of Government of Ukraine actions, when in fact they were paid lobbyists for Ukraine.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the interview on Saturday, Mr. Prodi said that he had never heard of any Hapsburg Group. \u201cIt was Gusenbauer heading the group; we did all our efforts to have peace in Ukraine,\u201d Mr. Prodi said, saying that the group of \u201cexperts and former politicians\u201d had met at several conferences but soon disbanded when it became clear that \u201ca stronger relationship with the European Union was impossible.\u201d\n\nIn 2012 and 2013, Mr. Yanukovych was trying to negotiate an \u201cassociation agreement\u201d with the European Union, which was made difficult by his jailing of political opponents, like Yulia V. Tymoshenko, Valery Ivashchenko and Yuri V. Lutsenko in 2011 and 2012.\n\nEuropean officials were keen to secure the agreement, and tried to get Mr. Yanukovych to release the detainees, arguing that their captivity was damaging his reputation and making closer ties to Brussels hard to swallow.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Prodi said that Mr. Gusenbauer was the \u201ccoordinator\u201d of a group of like-minded liberal and center-left politicians on the issue.\n\nMr. Kwasniewski and Patrick Cox of Ireland, a former president of the European Parliament, said that they were working at the suggestion of the parliament\u2019s president at the time, Martin Schulz of Germany, to get Mr. Yanukovych to release political opponents from jail to improve his standing with the Europeans as they debated the association agreement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked if the money Mr. Gusenbauer received came from Mr. Manafort, Mr. Prodi seemed skeptical but said that he didn\u2019t know. \u201cGo ask Gusenbauer,\u201d he said, adding that he thought that it was more likely that the money came from European businessmen interested in keeping Europe and Ukraine close.\n\nIn an interview on Saturday, Mr. Cox said he had worked with Mr. Kwasniewski, Mr. Schulz and others to try to convince Mr. Yanukovych to release the jailed political opponents.\n\nMr. Cox said that he had never heard of the Hapsburg Group, had never been paid by anyone for his efforts in Ukraine, and had had no dealings with Mr. Manafort. But in 2012, he said, he had been invited by Mr. Schultz to go to Ukraine with Mr. Kwasniewski, the first of some 25 trips, all done \u201cpro bono,\u201d Mr. Cox said, to try to get the detainees released.\n\n\u201cThe view in Western capitals was that these were the victims of selective justice,\u201d Mr. Cox said. After meetings with Mr. Yanukovych and prosecutors, Mr. Cox and Mr. Kwasniewski were successful in obtaining the release of Mr. Ivashchenko and Mr. Lutsenko, who is now Ukraine\u2019s prosecutor-general.\n\n\u201cWe were not successful with Yulia Tymoshenko,\u201d who was Mr. Yanukovych\u2019s prime political opponent at the time, Mr. Cox said. \u201cBut we did ensure that Charit\u00e9 hospital in Berlin would have access to her in prison and she not be subject to further trials,\u201d he added.\n\nMr. Cox made clear his distaste for Mr. Yanukovych, adding: \u201cI wouldn\u2019t lobby for him.\u201d\n\nIn an interview on Saturday, Mr. Kwasniewski said, \u201cI did meet Manafort two or three times during our mission in Ukraine in 2012 and 2013, but that\u2019s it. At the time, he was an adviser to President Yanukovych, whom I also met, and it was only natural that our paths had to cross a couple of times.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cThe last time I saw Manafort was probably around the fall of 2013. He never paid us. I never had any financial relationship with him, and I never heard of the Hapsburg Group.\u201d\n\nThe release of some of the detainees did help Ukraine\u2019s relationship with Brussels, but then Mr. Yanukovych rejected the association agreement, in favor of a free-trade relationship with Russia.\n\nThat, in turn, started the demonstrations that led to Mr. Yanukovych\u2019s downfall, the Russian seizure of Crimea and the current conflict in eastern Ukraine.", "title": "European Ex-Officials Deny Being Paid by Manafort to Lobby for Ukraine", "authors": ["Steven Erlanger", "Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Korn invites senior West Wing advisers such as Jared Kushner, Ivanka Trump and Kellyanne Conway to visit the groups, which range from 20 to 100 guests and are often tied to specific faith-related legislation, executive orders and court appointments. Ms. Trump recently sat in on a meeting with female faith leaders that Mr. Moore and Mr. Jeffress attended.\n\n\u201cWe are the front door to the White House,\u201d Ms. Korn said, echoing Mr. Moore\u2019s words.\n\nMr. Jeffress, another core member from the campaign board, has been one of Mr. Trump\u2019s most reliable evangelical advocates, regularly appearing with him in Trump Tower in New York and then in the White House.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t look into the president\u2019s heart to know if he really personally believes these positions he\u2019s advocating, or whether he thinks it\u2019s smart politics to embrace them because of the strong evangelical influence in the country,\u201d Mr. Jeffress said in an interview. \u201cBut frankly, I don\u2019t care. As a Christian, I\u2019m seeing these policies embraced and enacted, and he\u2019s doing that.\u201d\n\nMr. Jeffress, who once said President Barack Obama\u2019s politics could lead to the rise of the Antichrist, said the issues that evangelicals discuss at the White House \u201cgo beyond what most assume,\u201d including opioid abuse and criminal justice overhaul. He and Mr. Moore are sympathetic to the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, known as DACA, that shields young undocumented immigrants, which is often viewed as a progressive cause.\n\nWhen he is in the Oval Office with faith leaders, Mr. Moore said, they try to \u201cpersonalize\u201d issues for Mr. Trump, including in a recent discussion on DACA, when the group told the president that he should view the issue as a father and grandfather.\n\nMr. Moore, who has spent time in Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq, Bahrain and Israel speaking out against religious persecution, said that evangelical advocacy in the White House also helped expedite the confirmation of former Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas as ambassador for international religious freedom, a post for which he and the core group of evangelical voices in the White House had long pushed.\n\nEvangelicals voted heavily in Mr. Trump\u2019s favor in the presidential election and, polls show, continue to back him.", "title": "Evangelicals, Having Backed Trump, Find White House \u2018Front Door Is Open\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey have apparently followed the lead of their allies in Washington who are unable to do anything when it comes to sensible gun control,\u201d said Senator Andrea Stewart-Cousins, who leads a group of nearly two dozen Democrats in Albany\u2019s upper chamber. \u201cI was hoping that New York, would be, at least, an example.\u201d\n\nThe vote was by no means assured, given the dynamics of the Senate, where the Republicans hold control through their collaboration with nine renegade Democratic senators, eight of whom comprise the Independent Democratic Conference.\n\nThe Democratic maneuver began with Ms. Stewart-Cousins\u2019s deputy, Senator Michael Gianaris of Queens, trying to get the amendments considered and calling for the Senate to act.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe have to cross a line in our thinking, not only in this state but in the country,\u201d Mr. Gianaris said, adding that it was \u201cmind-boggling to me that we could watch our children die and we\u2019re sitting here making excuses.\u201d\n\nTwenty-nine Democrats, including all eight members of the Independent Democratic Conference, voted to consider the amendments, falling short of the 32 needed for passage. Mr. Gianaris failed to persuade a single Republican to consider the measure; more important, he also failed to lure Simcha Felder, a Brooklyn Democrat, to his side.\n\nMr. Felder said that he felt the bills were being rushed to the floor in piecemeal fashion.\n\n\u201cI do believe that its better to do something that\u2019s as important as this in a very comprehensive way,\u201d said Mr. Felder, who has sponsored a bill to put armed guards at schools, something he says he wished would have been taken up sooner.\n\n\u201cI think \u2018now\u2019 is a very broad term,\u201d he continued, adding, \u201cThere\u2019s a balance between doing something expeditiously or doing something immediately that\u2019s not really conclusive, not comprehensive.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Independent Democratic Conference and Ms. Stewart-Cousins\u2019 group of mainstream Democrats have tentatively pledged to form a new majority in April, after two special elections to fill seats vacated by Democrats. (That plan still depends on Mr. Felder, who has repeatedly said he is loyal to no party.)\n\n\u201cThose who stand on the wrong side of history on this issue will be judged harshly,\u201d Mr. Gianaris said. \u201cStarting with this election.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
