View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nScott Reif, a spokesman for the Senate Republicans, questioned Mr. Gianaris\u2019s foresight. \u201cEvery two years Senator Gianaris predicts our demise and he\u2019s been wrong every single time,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re going to win in November because we\u2019re actually delivering on the issues that middle-class families care about: affordability, opportunity, and yes, security.\u201d\n\nJust before the push for a vote, the Republican leader of the Senate, John J. Flanagan of Long Island, issued a statement, suggesting a variety of measures aimed at increasing school safety, including more funding for security cameras, armed guards at schools, panic buttons, \u201chardening of school doors,\u201d and \u201ca much stronger response to the mental health issues at the heart of much of this violence.\u201d\n\n\u201cEvery responsible option is on the table, and wherever we think we can make a difference, we will act,\u201d Mr. Flanagan said, saying the Senate could consider new legislation by next week.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cSchools must be safe havens, where students can learn and teachers can teach. In New York, they will be,\u201d he said. Mr. Flanagan\u2019s statement did not mention the word \u201cguns.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuomo, who pushed through a broad package of gun control measures known as the SAFE Act in 2013 after the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., offered measured support for the Senate Democrats\u2019 attempt. The 2013 law banned the sale of assault rifles and required registration of such rifles already owned at the time of its passage.\n\n\u201cWhile we need to review the specific legislation, these are all concepts we support as ways to strengthen the strongest gun safety laws in the nation,\u201d said Rich Azzopardi, a spokesman for the governor.\n\nThe governor, a second-term Democrat seeking re-election in the fall, had been more forceful earlier Wednesday on a conference call with reporters, criticizing Republicans in Washington and other states for their \u201cincremental\u201d approach to gun control, including raising the age for buying some weapons, calling it \u201creprehensible political pandering.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut he also conceded that \u201ca state law cannot solve this problem,\u201d and called on his fellow Democrats in Washington to \u201cput a real gun bill on the table,\u201d including new background checks, a mental health database, and a ban on military-style assault weapons, like the one used at Marjory Stoneman Douglas.\n\nMr. Cuomo also openly mocked ideas like arming teachers or placing more security officers at schools.\n\n\u201cThat worked phenomenally well in Florida, right?\u201d said Mr. Cuomo, apparently referencing a Broward County sheriff\u2019s deputy who did not enter the high school after the shooting started, and saying he was bewildered by the idea of \u201cshootouts in classrooms.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an N.R.A. answer,\u201d he said. \u201cTheir answer is always the same: more guns.\u201d\n\nMs. Stewart-Cousins seemed disheartened by the lack of action on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cTo just do nothing, to continue to do nothing, day after day, week after week, year after year, in the face of things that we really all know are terrible tragedies, that we can do something about,\u201d Ms. Stewart-Cousins said. \u201cIt\u2019s just really unacceptable.\u201d", "title": "Even After High School Massacre, Albany Demurs on Gun Control", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "In a few weeks, his dwindling legal cannabis supply will run out, and it could take up to seven months to get more. His only option will then be to leave the country with his mother to get marijuana, his fifth such trip in four years.\n\nMr. Carter lives at home with his parents. His mother, Lanai Carter, keeps a baby monitor in his room, listening for sounds of a seizure. But in recent months, while routinely using cannabis, Mr. Carter has gotten his first taste of independent adulthood: attending a hip-hop concert, taking road trips with friends and dating.\n\nHis teenage years were spent on long, expensive overseas trips for treatment and trying to navigate Australia\u2019s complex medical marijuana bureaucracy. In 2014, when Parliament was still discussing how to regulate medicinal marijuana, Mr. Carter and his mother went public with their story.\n\n\u201cNothing seemed to be moving,\u201d Ms. Carter said from the family\u2019s home in Loganholme, a town 18 miles from Brisbane, of those years before legalization. While traveling for her son\u2019s cannabis treatment, Ms. Carter began lobbying. That meant pushing her son more and more into the spotlight.\n\nMr. Carter has appeared twice on the Australian version of \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d and been featured in reports by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Buzzfeed and the radio station Triple J.\n\nIt is \u201cfrustrating\u201d that Mr. Carter \u201cis well known, but it still hasn\u2019t got him anywhere,\u201d said Lucy Haslam, a medical marijuana activist. Ms. Haslam\u2019s son, Dan, was a central figure of the legalization movement until he died from cancer in 2015, at 25.", "title": "Even Australia\u2019s Medical Marijuana Poster Boy Can\u2019t Get the Drug", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Katrantzou had given some thought to armor, and the shield that clothing can be for its wearers, hence her carapace-like tailored jackets, some tipped with metal spikes; their patterns ran to 83 separate pieces in some cases, versus the usual 20. But the majority of her collection retreated into history. A retrospective of her work on display until March 18 at the Dallas Contemporary museum set her thinking back through her archive and the influences in it. She borrowed and combined elements from two \u2014 Victoriana and the Bauhaus, strange bedfellows \u2014 and doubled down on the elaborate printing and embellishment that has become her signature. It fits her work in the context of the museum, though it is sometimes hard to imagine her armor out in the world.\n\nA similar issue dogs Erdem Moralioglu, who often designs by gazing backward. At his show at the National Portrait Gallery on Monday (closed for the occasion, to some consternation), velvet frocked, brocaded women in net veils glided through galleries; they might just as well have come off the walls. Mr. Moralioglu\u2019s icon and inspiration was Adele Astaire, the older sister of Fred Astaire (\u201cand actually, the much more talented one,\u201d Mr. Moraloglu said). Lady Charles Cavendish after her marriage, she was a \u201820s vaudeville showgirl, dance partner to her brother (before Ginger Rogers) and portrait subject of Cecil Beaton.", "title": "Even in the #MeToo Moment, Sex Stays on the Runway", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.\n\nBLACK GOTHAM EXPERIENCE at the Museum of the City of New York (Feb. 10, 11 a.m.-5 p.m.). African-Americans were part of New York history long before there was a New York \u2014 or even an America as we know it. This intergenerational celebration examines black life in New Amsterdam as well as in 19th-century black settlements like Seneca Village (in what is now Central Park) and Weeksville (in what is now Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn). The program begins with performances of two monologues from \u201cUnheard Voices,\u201d a theatrical work from the American Slavery Project that imagines the lives of those interred in the African Burial Ground in Lower Manhattan. At 1 p.m., a resource fair starts, featuring organizations that explore black culture, and the Studio Museum in Harlem will begin an activity in which children identify and decorate historically black communities on a map. They can also take part in a scavenger hunt, looking through the galleries for images and artifacts. (Registration is recommended.)\n\n212-534-1672, mcny.org\n\nBLACK HISTORY MONTH PROGRAMS at the Staten Island Children\u2019s Museum (Feb. 10-11). The African-American past is filled with unsung heroes, many of them female. This weekend the museum will honor the achievements of several groundbreaking black women its young visitors may not have heard of. On Saturday, from noon to 1 p.m., \u201cCosmic Computer Women,\u201d a science workshop, will focus on Dorothy Vaughan, Mary Jackson and Katherine Johnson, the NASA mathematicians featured in the film \u201cHidden Figures.\u201d Children will play math games as they learn about these women\u2019s contributions. On Sunday, from 1 to 4 p.m., small fashion fans can make paper dolls in \u201cTr\u00e8s Chic! Cutout Clothes,\u201d a program celebrating the work of the designer Tracy Reese, who helped dress Michelle Obama, and the model Chantelle Brown-Young, known professionally as Winnie Harlow, who became a cover girl despite a skin condition and childhood bullying.\n\n718-273-2060, sichildrensmuseum.org", "title": "Events for Children in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.\n\nANNA & ELIZABETH FAMILY CONCERT: AN IMBOLC CELEBRATION at Irish Arts Center (Feb. 3, 2-4 p.m.). And what, you may ask, is Imbolc? It\u2019s an ancient Celtic festival celebrating the change from winter to spring. While the season may not feel as if it were turning yet, things at this concert definitely will: Anna Roberts-Gevalt and Elizabeth LaPrelle accompany their Appalachian folk tunes and colorful ballads with what are known as crankies, scrolling story boards that unfurl with hand cranks. Young listeners can get in on the act, too: They will make candles for the concert and crankies to take home.\n\n866-811-4111, irishartscenter.org\n\nBAMKIDS FILM FESTIVAL at BAM Rose Cinemas (Feb. 3-4, starting at 10 a.m.). Once again, it\u2019s that time when producers and directors thank the academy. But the filmmakers showcased this weekend won\u2019t be grateful for the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, but for the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where their work will appear in the BAMkids Film Festival, arriving with 76 films from 31 countries. While some of the festival\u2019s eight shorts programs are sold out, cinephiles ages 5 through 11 have abundant options. They include \u201cShortstack: Puppets on Film,\u201d curated by the Jim Henson Foundation and starring characters like avocados and fish sticks; \u201cShort Docs: My Story, My Way,\u201d whose offerings examine the lives of children in America, Europe and Africa; \u201cThe Nature of Things,\u201d a series of animated adventures; and \u201cReel Rascals Sr.: Pack Your Bags!\u201d whose cinematic heroes all make discoveries. The festival\u2019s feature, \u201cFloyd Norman: An Animated Life\u201d (on Saturday only), celebrates a pioneer with a pen: Disney\u2019s first African-American animator. In addition to the screenings, young visitors can experience magic , puppetry, juggling and even virtual reality.\n\n718-636-4100, bam.org/kids\n\n\u2018CONSTELLARIUM\u2019 at Access Theater (Feb. 2-18). It may be hard for many American children to imagine the life of a refugee. In this production from Rebel Playhouse, however, all audience members are cast in that role. Recommended for theatergoers 5 and older, the play, accompanied by music, unfolds on the planet of the title, a kind of interstellar camp for the displaced. Earth has been destroyed, and its former inhabitants have to learn how to cooperate and not repeat past errors. Young space travelers must also confront the power of Constellarium\u2019s president, portrayed by the show\u2019s playwright, Arif Silverman. (Optional children\u2019s workshops follow the weekend matinees.)\n\n785-393-9119, rebelplayhouse.org\n\nGREEN BEAN BASH at 583 Park Avenue (Feb. 3, noon-3 p.m.). Who knew that vegetables could be this much fun? This annual benefit for the Horticultural Society of New York aims to introduce children to both edible greenery and green practices. In addition to boogieing with the event\u2019s mascot, Mr. Green Bean, young guests can make projects like their own slime, pickles, tea, flower crowns and jam, as well as plant a take-home succulent in a cactus lab. There\u2019s fun for nonvegetarians, too, including a carnivorous-plant demonstration and an edible-bug cafe.\n\n212-757-0915, Ext. 101; the hort.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHOOT AND HOWL WEEKEND at Wave Hill (Feb. 3-4, 10 a.m.-4 p.m.). This public garden in the Bronx is inviting families to meet some wild (and we do mean wild) New Yorkers: owls and coyotes. Live coyotes won\u2019t appear (at least not officially), but children can see hidden-camera footage of them and play a game that\u2019s rooted in their behavior; those 12 and older are also invited to talks about the species. Live owls, however, will attend: They\u2019ll star in presentations about their adaptations, and young visitors can dissect their sterilized pellets (regurgitated balls of undigested fur, teeth and bones). The weekend family art project will involve making paper puppets and scenes of the animals, and on Saturday only, the Gotham Coyote Project will visit with a dog trained to detect urban coyotes\u2019 scat. (The schedule for individual events is on the website.)\n\n718-549-3200, wavehill.org\n\nJUDY BLUMESDAY \u2014 KIDS! at Symphony Space (Feb. 4, 3 p.m.). Are you there, young readers? It\u2019s she, Judy. That would be Judy Blume, who is celebrating her 80th birthday with this salute to her long literary career, which includes books like \u201cSuperfudge,\u201d \u201cBlubber\u201d and \u201cAre You There, God? It\u2019s Me, Margaret.\u201d This installment of the Thalia Kids\u2019 Book Club, for ages 8 and older (there is a separate evening event for adult fans), is to include readings by an actress; a discussion with contemporary authors and Debbie Ridpath Ohi, an illustrator for Ms. Blume\u2019s works; a brief creative writing project; and a question-and-answer session with Ms. Blume herself.\n\n212-864-5400, symphonyspace.org", "title": "Events for Children in NYC This Week", "authors": ["Laurel Graeber"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Perhaps you read this week that Donald Trump has replaced James Buchanan as the worst president in the history of the United States.\n\nThis was in a survey of experts in presidential politics \u2014 people who have an opinion about whether Chester A. Arthur was better than Martin Van Buren. Trump came in last, with a score of 12 out of 100.\n\nChoose the best way to look at this:\n\nA) Why are you reminding me about that man? Why can\u2019t we talk about \u201cBlack Panther\u201d?\n\nB) Never thought I\u2019d reminisce about the good old days with Richard Nixon.\n\nC) Hey, at least it\u2019s a story \u2014 nobody\u2019s ever going to ask you what it was like living under Gerald Ford.", "title": "Opinion | Everybody\u2019s Better Than You-Know-Who", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "As a child, I learned during our shortest month about Martin and Malcolm, Harriet and Sojourner. At home and in school they told of Benjamin Banneker\u2019s almanacs, Madam C.J. Walker\u2019s hair products and subsequent wealth, George Washington Carver\u2019s peanuts, Crispus Attucks\u2019s heroism in dying first, and even what Dr. Ben Carson did with those conjoined twins.\n\nBlack History Month has taken these mortals from heroes to idols, out of both pride and desperation. The resulting highlight reel of black triumph is pure historiography, a particular formulation of the story of black America. Its chronology supports the misleading narrative that a few exceptional people and their acts are the de facto history of black America, rendering the stories of the ordinary as invisible.", "title": "Everyday Excellence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "TEL AVIV \u2014 It is hard to spend a week in Israel and not come away feeling that Israelis have the wind at their backs.\n\nThey\u2019ve built an awesome high-tech industry, and everyone\u2019s kid seems to work for a start-up. Even Israeli Arabs have caught the bug \u2014 the number studying for B.A. degrees at Israeli universities rose 60 percent in the last seven years, to 47,000. Regionally, the Arabs and Palestinians have never been weaker, and under President Trump, Israel has never had a more unquestioningly friendly United States. Trump recognized Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital, asking Israel for nothing in return. The Arab states barely made a peep.\n\nAlas, though, all of this wind has whetted the appetite of Israel\u2019s settlers and ruling Likud Party to go to extremes. Reuters reported on Dec. 31 that the \u201cLikud Party unanimously urged legislators in a nonbinding resolution \u2026 to effectively annex Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank, land that Palestinians want for a future state.\u201d\n\nSure, the world would scream \u201capartheid,\u201d but Israeli rightists shrug that the world will get used to it. Nikki Haley will cover for Israel at the U.N. Sheldon Adelson will keep Trump and the G.O.P. in line. And the Arab regimes, which need Israel to counter Iran, will look the other away. It always plays out that way, and the settlers see that, so, they ask, why wait? They think they can annex the West Bank without giving Palestinians citizenship; they\u2019ll just let the Palestinians vote in their own elections.", "title": "Opinion | Everyone Is Going All the Way", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mass-start speedskating was one of four new events at the 2018 Olympics. It debuted on the World Cup circuit during the 2011-12 season. Other events in long-track speedskating are pure time trials, wherein athletes, in pairs, race the clock and know where they\u2019ve finished only after everyone has finished skating.\n\nMass start puts up to 28 skaters on the ice at the same time to race 16 laps around the 400-meter oval. Competitors are not restricted to their lanes, as in other long-track events. Skaters therefore have to think about much more than pure speed. They make tactical decisions about whether to stick with the pack or make a breakaway move. They draft one another and try to read their intentions.\n\nPhoto\n\nSome say it resembles short-track speedskating on a long-track oval. Some say it feels more like a running or cycling race. Mantia said mass start was something casual spectators might enjoy more than the other long-track events, which unfold in stop-and-start increments and often can be anticlimactic.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been doing long-track for about six years now, and I love the sport, but it\u2019s a little tough to watch sometimes,\u201d Mantia said in an interview before the Games.\n\nBut mass-start races are different, he added. \u201cIt\u2019s 16 laps, but it keeps you engaged the whole time. There\u2019s always something going on, and you know as soon as the race finishes, first is gold, second is silver and third is bronze. It\u2019s simple. It\u2019s relatable.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the interview, Mantia said he still sometimes struggled with the mental side of long-track speedskating: the feeling of intense solitude on the ice, the inevitable ebb and flow of confidence and self-doubt. He said he had made progress in those areas with the help of sports psychologists.\n\nBut mass start, he said, has always been a refuge.\n\n\u201cOnce I started doing mass starts, I was like, O.K., that all goes out the window,\u201d Mantia said before the Olympics. \u201cEven if everything else goes completely terrible, and falls short of all expectations, I still race and win in mass start.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s always kind of the ace up my sleeve,\u2019\u2019 he added.\n\nTeammates said Mantia\u2019s background in in-line skating in Florida, before switching to ice, instilled in him the proper instincts to navigate the more hectic and unpredictable mass-start competition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEvery race in in-lines, or almost every race, is a mass start,\u201d said Mitchell Whitmore, who finished 10th in the 1,000 on Friday. \u201cSo it\u2019s just second nature to him, strategy-wise.\u201d\n\nAmerican long-track speedskaters won numerous medals combined at the 2002, 2006 and 2010 Games before being shut out at the Olympics four years ago in Sochi, Russia. Outside expectations seemed to have been lowered accordingly before these Games \u2014 for everything except the mass start.\n\nMantia won gold in the mass start at the 2017 world championships here in Gangneung, and Bergsma finished with the bronze. One year later, they were ready to try again.", "title": "Everyone Onto the Ice, Including an American Hoping for Gold", "authors": ["Andrew Keh"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Very few kids take action to solve the first problem they see, but eventually they come back having conceived and owning an idea. They organize their friends and do something. The adult job now is to get out of the way. Put the kids in charge.\n\nOnce a kid has had an idea, built a team and changed her world, she\u2019s a changemaker. She has the power. She\u2019ll go on to organize more teams. She will always be needed.\n\nDrayton asks parents: \u201cDoes your daughter know that she is a changemaker? Is she practicing changemaking?\u201d He tells them: \u201cIf you can\u2019t answer \u2018yes\u2019 to these questions, you have urgent work to do.\u201d\n\nIn an earlier era, he says, society realized it needed universal literacy. Today, schools have to develop the curriculums and assessments to make the changemaking mentality universal. They have to understand this is their criteria for success.\n\nAshoka has studied social movements to find out how this kind of mental shift can be promoted. It turns out that successful movements take similar steps.\n\nFirst, they gather a group of powerful and hungry co-leading organizations. (Ashoka is working with Arizona State and George Mason University.) Second, the group is opened to everybody. (You never know who is going to come up with the crucial idea.) Third, the movement creates soap operas with daily episodes. (The civil rights movement created televised dramas with good guys and bad guys, like the march from Selma.)\n\nI wonder if everybody wants to be a changemaker in the Drayton mold. I wonder about any social vision that isn\u2019t fundamentally political. You can have a nation filled with local changemakers, but if the government is rotten their work comes to little. The social sector has never fully grappled with the permanent presence of sin.", "title": "Opinion | Everyone a Changemaker", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "THE JUNIPER TREE\n\nBy Barbara Comyns\n\n177 pp. New York Review Books. Paper, $14.95.\n\n\u201cI have few happy memories of my mother,\u201d the narrator tells us early on in \u201cThe Juniper Tree,\u201d this reimagining of a famously savage Grimm fairy tale. \u201cNot that she hurt me physically, the hurt was mental.\u201d As Barbara Comyns\u2019s novel unfolds, the hurt that mothers inflict and the hurt that mothers suffer keep piercing through the ordinary fabric of daily life, and some of the wounds (though not all of them) are mental.\n\nComyns, a British writer who died in 1992, was no self-declared feminist, yet she takes up here the voice of one of the most wicked stepmothers in the fairy tale canon, and not only understands her, but makes her the sympathetic heart of the story. This is not easy. Just listen to the closing song of the Grimms\u2019 version, which became Comyns\u2019s epigraph: \u201cMy mother she killed me,/My father he ate me,/My sister, little Marlinchen,/Gathered together my bones,/Tied them in a silken handkerchief,/Laid them beneath the juniper tree,/Kywitt, Kywitt, what a beautiful bird I am.\u201d Comyns\u2019s hapless heroine\u2019s vicissitudes follow the original story closely as she updates and rationalizes the extreme, weird sequence of murder and revenge.\n\nThe original \u201cJuniper Tree\u201d first appeared in 1812, in the first edition of \u201cChildren\u2019s and Household Tales.\u201d Unlike many stories the Brothers Grimm collected from oral sources, this one was written and sent to them by the German Romantic painter Philipp Otto Runge, who specialized in capturing the wild energy of children\u2019s imaginations. He conjured dreamlike, metaphysical fairy realms, as well as portrayed real-life subjects as radiant beings. With \u201cThe Juniper Tree,\u201d he passed on a literary masterpiece of gory fantasy, level and cool and laconic, structured with musical repetition and told with a masterly deadpan command of the horrible.\n\nComyns steps with intense identification into the persona of a woman who, in the Grimms\u2019 telling, decapitates her stepson by dropping the lid of a trunk on his head in a moment of rage and then cooks him in a stew. In Comyns\u2019s version, she is called, with a touch of ominousness, Bella Winters. Her face is badly scarred on the left side, after a car accident \u2014 with Comyns\u2019s perfectly pitched insight into male monstrosity, she recounts how Bella\u2019s lover Stephen, who was at the wheel, blamed her, though she was fast asleep at the time, for distracting him. Soon after this, Bella has a baby. When she first sees the little girl, she thinks there must have been a mistake, since she barely remembers the black lover in a crimson velvet jacket whom she slept with one night after a party when she was on the rebound from Stephen. But she soon grows to love her biracial daughter, gives her the nickname Tommy, and they eke out their survival in a dreary bed-sit infested with cockroaches, heated only by puny gas fires that require feeding with coins, of which Bella never has enough. She is helped by \u201cillegal immigrants\u201d like the \u201cgirl from the Canaries\u201d who \u201cunbuttoned her blouse and gave me one of the steaks that were plastered there. \u2026 They were always offering to babysit, only I had nowhere to go while they sat.\u201d", "title": "Evil Stepmother, Reimagined", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Like \u201cWaterbearer,\u201d many other works of Simpson\u2019s from that period \u2014 including \u201cTwenty Questions (A Sampler)\u201d (1986), \u201cFive Day Forecast\u201d (1988) and \u201c7 Mouths\u201d (1993) \u2014 are both figurative and fragmentary. Evenly lit, crisply photographed, they look like pictures from an illustrated medical dictionary, indexical images of heads, torsos and mouths that are detached from context. Even in a work like \u201cFigure\u201d (1991), the figure in question, sheathed in a black dress and set in the black infinity of no particular place, feels like a fragment, as though she had been extracted from a group photo or a furnished room. The texts accompanying her, eight engraved plastic plaques, read like excerpts from a language primer: \u201cfigured the worst,\u201d \u201che was disfigured,\u201d \u201cfigured there would be no reaction\u201d and so on. Here, not only has the story been winnowed down; it is in fact completely gone. There\u2019s no story. We are left with only the tensions of concrete poetry.\n\nSometime in the mid-1990s, Simpson began to detect clich\u00e9d responses to her work. At the same time, her own thinking was evolving. What does an image of a black woman mean? A commentary on race? An assertion about gender? Simpson branched out from figure-based images and began to experiment more with varied subject matter \u2014 landscapes and inanimate objects like wigs \u2014 and also with unusual quasi-sculptural material like felt and standing screens. A series of monumental multisectional images, several of them landscapes, collectively titled \u201cPublic Sex\u201d (1995-1998) and featuring no figures at all, addressed the provocative title only obliquely. These pictures, made over many years, contain what the scholar and curator Okwui Enwezor calls \u201cthe rumor of the body.\u201d Mysteries of a jagged and deadpan sort, they would go on to influence the noirish tone of Simpson\u2019s later film work.\n\nPhoto\n\nSimpson began to set ever more intricate conceptual layers between her initial inspiration for a work and the finished product. The idea for \u201c9 Props\u201d (1995) began during a residency at the Pilchuck Glass School in Washington. With the aid of artisans at the school, she fabricated a series of dark vessels modeled on vases and other objects used in the portrait work of the pioneering Harlem photographer James Van Der Zee. But these vessels were not the final work. She shipped them back to New York and then photographed them against a plain background. And that still was not the work. Further intervention followed: She turned those photographic images into nine lithographs, which she printed on felt. Finally, she wrote captions below each lithographed vessel, describing the context in which it originally appeared. One of them, for instance, reads:\n\nDinner Party with boxer Harry Wills, 1926 James VanDerZee Harry Wills a k a \u201cThe Black Panther,\u201d boxer, businessman- sits with seven other men and women, mostly women with champagne glasses raised as a woman on his left makes a toast in his honor. There are three bottles of champagne, a crystal decanter, a bottle of port, an arrangement of flowers and fruit, and before each guest an untouched china place setting.\n\nPhoto\n\nFrom multiple directions, the work gestures at what cannot be seen: the original placement of the vessels that inspired Simpson\u2019s own, the people in the photographs by James Van Der Zee, the social life of Harlem evoked by his photographs and the complexity of manners and class implied by them. All that vanished world of culture and experience is reduced to an elegant grid, as simple as an antiquarian\u2019s catalog, a thought picture that demands calm engagement and imaginative intervention on the viewer\u2019s part. Without being representational, it is about race; but race is not off in some category by itself, hemmed in only by questions of skin color, separate from life.\n\n\u201cRepresent!\u201d in the black American sense means standing up for your people, expressing solidarity and letting a shared ethos underwrite your presence and work. It is an exhortation, a greeting and a farewell. The word also has more conventional associations. In the visual arts, it is contrasted with the abstract or the symbolic. To represent, in this more common sense, is to make work that visually corresponds to realities out there in the world: to illustrate uncomplicatedly. This second sense of \u201crepresent\u201d is enjoying a vogue in the art world. Realism is back. This is welcome: after so long an absence of black figures and black faces in art museums, they are now being seen more frequently. Many artists, black and otherwise, are depicting the black body. It is necessary and often successful. Just as often, it fails when it is little more than a clumsy shorthand for socially concerned art, unobjectionable and unimpressive.\n\nA strong appeal of Simpson\u2019s work is that she has always embraced the inherent complexity of blackness, her own blackness as well as the blackness that runs ineluctably through American history. She does not reject representational depictions, but neither does she feel the need to confine herself only to \u201crace\u201d work. When an artist uses a black model, she is presenting a human question by foregrounding a human presence. Is a white man a person while a black woman is and can only be a gendered and racialized subject? As the scholar Kellie Jones has pointed out, nonwhite bodies are often thought of as \u201cnot neutral enough for the dispassionate formulas thought to constitute conceptual practice.\u201d If a black woman\u2019s race and gender are the only things apparent to certain viewers, Simpson seems to say, the ethical responsibility to escape those shackles is the viewer\u2019s.\n\nFreedom is Lorna Simpson\u2019s starting point and her permanent theme. A humane current animates all of her work, a current that neither sidesteps nor confines itself to race. Her work is simultaneously about the \u201cneutral\u201d space of ideas and the particularized experience of the body. \u201cMontage\u201d is photographic and painterly, a riff on a pair of found photographs, sequenced to look like a giant strip of film. It deals with dreams and nightmares, ambiguities and vulnerabilities. At its heart is what Simpson calls \u201cthe push and pull of photography\u201d: the stuttering potential inherent in mechanical reproduction and the imperfect registrations that mirror subconscious life. It is a rapid response to the current political climate, situating a crucial part of it in the most intimate space of all, where the hectoring \u201cthey\u201d is temporarily held at bay in favor of the puzzled \u201cI.\u201d In your own sleeping bed, images persist and words are hard to come by. It is the art we need now: rich, allusive, tongue-tied and unanswerable.", "title": "Evoking What Can\u2019t Be Seen", "authors": ["Teju Cole", "On Photography"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Howe\u2019s testimony has been eagerly anticipated ever since federal prosecutors announced in 2016 that he had pleaded guilty and was cooperating with authorities in an investigation of Joseph Percoco, a former senior aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and one of his closest friends. (Mr. Cuomo has not been accused of any wrongdoing.)\n\nThe government has charged that Mr. Percoco, one of four men on trial, accepted more than $300,000 in bribes from Mr. Howe\u2019s clients in return for taking official actions on their behalf.\n\nMr. Howe, who had lobbied in Albany and Washington, has longstanding ties to the Cuomo family. He worked in the administration of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the current governor\u2019s father, and he also worked under Andrew Cuomo when he served as secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development under President Bill Clinton.\n\nDefense lawyers\u2019 attacks on Mr. Howe in Mr. Percoco\u2019s trial began early and relentlessly, as they warned the jury that Mr. Howe could not be believed \u2014 a common defense tactic to try to weaken the credibility of a key witness.\n\nA prosecutor, Robert L. Boone, clearly expecting the attacks, told the jury \u2014 even before the defense did \u2014 that Mr. Howe was a criminal who had pleaded guilty to eight felonies, many of which related to him telling lies.\n\n\u201cHe has lied to his employer, he has lied to the I.R.S. and he\u2019s even lied to the defendants. He will tell you all about it,\u201d Mr. Boone said in his opening statement, adding that Mr. Howe had cooperated and was testifying \u201cin hopes of getting a lower sentence.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Boone signaled that the government would offer other, supportive evidence for Mr. Howe\u2019s testimony.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe charges to which Mr. Howe pleaded guilty include extortion, wire fraud and conspiracies to commit honest services fraud and bribery. Six of the counts carry maximum prison sentences of 20 years each, but if Mr. Howe completes his cooperation successfully, prosecutors say they will write to the judge and seek leniency on his behalf.\n\nIf, on the other hand, Mr. Howe lies on the witness stand, the government could rip up his deal, and he could face years in prison \u2014 a possibility that Mr. Howe\u2019s lawyer, Richard J. Morvillo, seemed to allude to in addressing Judge Valerie E. Caproni last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI spent countless hours with him impressing upon him not only the obligation but the wisdom of his coming to tell the truth,\u201d Mr. Morvillo said, even as he acknowledged that his client had a \u201chistory of not always telling the truth.\u201d\n\nWhile cooperating witnesses, with their fonts of insider knowledge and their eagerness to share it, can hold the key to a successful prosecution, they can just as well contribute to its unraveling.\n\nIn the same courthouse, in October, nine floors above the courtroom where Mr. Percoco is being tried, prosecutors leaned heavily upon Jona S. Rechnitz in building their case against Norman Seabrook, the powerful former chief of New York City\u2019s correction officers union.\n\nMr. Rechnitz, a wealthy real estate scion who had agreed to cooperate with the government after pleading guilty to fraud conspiracy, spent days on the witness stand, describing for the jury how he had facilitated bribes between Mr. Seabrook and a hedge fund financier.\n\nBut defense lawyers excoriated Mr. Rechnitz in terms virtually identical to those that Mr. Percoco\u2019s lawyers have hurled at Mr. Howe. They called him a felon, a con man and a pathological liar.\n\nThose disparagements, coupled with Mr. Rechnitz\u2019s smug and combative demeanor on the witness stand, may have weighed upon at least some members of the jury, which ultimately could not reach a verdict. After the mistrial was declared, one juror told reporters he had found Mr. Rechnitz to be a \u201cstraight-up liar.\u201d (The government has said it would retry Mr. Seabrook.)\n\nAll the anticipation that has preceded Mr. Howe\u2019s testimony \u2014 just the mention of his name last week seemed to make some courtroom spectators sit up straighter \u2014 has almost overshadowed the men actually on trial.\n\nMr. Morvillo, Mr. Howe\u2019s lawyer, suggested as much in a recent letter to the judge, in which he referred to the defense\u2019s attacks on Mr. Howe during opening statements.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThose openings offered false narratives based on \u2018alternative facts,\u2019\u201d Mr. Morvillo wrote, \u201cand have tried to turn this into a trial of Mr. Howe.\u201d", "title": "Ex-Albany Insider Is Expected to Tell All, if He Can Be Believed", "authors": ["Benjamin Weiser", "Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 In a child sex abuse scandal that has rocked English soccer, a former youth coach and talent scout who worked for a number of well-known teams was convicted on Tuesday of 36 counts of sexually assaulting boys aged 8 to 15, from 1979 to 1990.\n\nThe case against the former coach, Barry Bennell, began in late 2016, when Andrew Woodward became the first professional player to say publicly that he had been molested by a coach, accusing Mr. Bennell. But the scandal widened, as other allegations were made against Mr. Bennell, and then against other well-known coaches and scouts, until those stepping forward to say they had been victimized numbered in the hundreds, including dozens of former professionals.\n\nSoccer has taken its place among the institutions tarnished by the disclosure of systematic sexual exploitation, including the Roman Catholic Church, the news media and Hollywood. In Britain, the case of Mr. Bennell came after revelations that Jimmy Savile, a longtime host of BBC television shows who died in 2011, had molested dozens of children.\n\nFrom the late 1970s to the early 1990s, Mr. Bennell, now 64, worked for several well-known professional teams \u2014 including one, Manchester City, that plays in the upper echelon of the game \u2014 as a scout and sometime coach for youth programs. The work gave him access to boys who lived away from their parents at times.\n\nProsecutors said that he equipped his home with video games, exotic animals and fast food to make it attractive to boys, and that he abused them there and in his car.\n\nTwice in the 1990s and again in 2015, Mr. Bennell \u2014 who has changed his name to Richard Jones \u2014 was convicted of multiple counts of sexually abusing youth players and sent to prison. The latest revelations were surprising less in that additional long-ago victims might be found than in the numbers and prominence of some of them.\n\nThe jury in Liverpool Crown Court on Tuesday found him not guilty of three charges, and they will continue deliberating on seven others.", "title": "Ex-Coach for English Soccer Teams Convicted of Molesting Child Players", "authors": ["Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOut of abundance of caution, and because the safety of our students, faculty, and staff is our top priority, we made the decision to close school today,\u201d the school said in a statement. \u201cWe are working closely with law enforcement and will share more information when we are able.\u201d\n\nMartin\u2019s photo also included the hashtag #MiamiDolphins, the team that drafted him out of Stanford in 2012.\n\nIn 2013, Martin left the team after seven games because he said that another offensive lineman, Richie Incognito, had repeatedly bullied him and used racist language.
