The road was littered with debris.", "title": "Five Die as Stolen Car and Oil Truck Crash on Long Island", "authors": ["Rick Rojas", "Arielle Dollinger"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "For years, the 11th and 12 arrondissements, two formerly quiet, working class neighborhoods in eastern Paris, have been the preferred location for the French capital\u2019s best young chefs. Why? Affordable apartments assure a hungry young clientele for the new restaurateurs who choose the area for its low-rent commercial spaces. Now a growing number of the city\u2019s fledgling cooks are setting up shop in another atmospheric old working-class quarter: Montmartre, a hilltop district in the 18th arrondissement best known for the Sacre Coeur basilica and the artists who once lived and worked here \u2014 Toulouse-Lautrec, Utrillo and Modigliani, among others. Today, most of the action is on the back of La Butte (the mound, in French), as the locals call this spot in the center of Montmartre. Here on the north-facing slope of the district, arty younger Parisians who\u2019d rather spend their money on good food than rent are flocking to a wave of excellent new and reasonably priced casual restaurants, including one that was just awarded a Michelin star.\n\nL\u2019Arcane\n\nAside from the miniature Jeff Koons-style sculptures adorning the tables, this year-and-a-half old place on a quiet side street looks like countless unremarkable middlebrow neighborhood restaurants in Paris. The locals know better, since young chef Laurent Magnin\u2019s superb contemporary French cooking had made it one of the capital\u2019s most exciting dark-horse tables. In early February, though, it won a star in the 2018 Michelin Guide to France, so the secret is out. Still, the snag for some may be that there\u2019s no a la carte menu here. Instead, they only serve multicourse, blind tasting menus, although food phobias and allergies are respected. The menu changes often but dishes like risotto garnished with veal-stock lacquered crayfish; grilled sea bream with peanut sauce and a deconstructed paella are as beautiful to taste at as they are to behold. Good value for the money, and open for both lunch and dinner on Saturdays, too.\n\n39 rue Lamarck, 18th Arrondissement, restaurantlarcane.com", "title": "Five Places to Go in Montmartre", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "For decades, drivers in Portland, Me., sped by Thompson\u2019s Point, a forlorn peninsula jutting into the Fore River just west of I-295. Described as \u201cthe biggest dump in Portland\u201d in the local independent monthly The Bollard in 2011, the area is today the city\u2019s most unlikely hot spot. In 2015, a new outdoor concert venue began staging shows on the riverbank; this past summer \u2019s slate of 14 performances included Wilco, the XX and Alabama Shakes. And nearby, an abandoned brick warehouse has been transformed into an entertainment row, with food-and-drink establishments alongside a peculiar cryptozoology museum and a circus school. One more reason to stop: a new ice skating rink open through March 4.\n\nBissell Brothers\n\nIn June 2016, this cult craft brewery relocated to an enormous facility with colorful murals splashed on the walls, steel tanks in the back and ample, two-level taproom seating. Expect lines out the door during releases of their hard-to-find, limited edition I.P.A.s, which attract fans from across the Northeast.\n\n4 Thompson\u2019s Point #108; bissellbrothers.com.", "title": "Five Places to Go in Portland, Me.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nOn a cold, clear Saturday morning in January 1961, I and a few of my friends from Junior High School 180 took the Green Bus Line from Rockaway Beach to Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues for a day of bowling and pizza.\n\nWhen our adventures were done, we headed back to the same intersection to catch the bus home. Across Nostrand Avenue, I spotted my Grandpa Izzy, who lived nearby, walking against the powerful wind. His hands were busy securing his hat to his head and protecting his newspaper (The Jewish Daily Forward, no doubt) from the oncoming gusts.\n\nI considered running across the avenue to say hello, but it was bitter cold and the bus was due to arrive soon. And how much could I get across in a few seconds to a man who barely spoke English and probably didn\u2019t want to delay getting to his warm apartment on Farragut Road.\n\nSo onto the bus I went for the return trip across the Marine Parkway Bridge.\n\nIt was the last time I saw Grandpa Izzy. He died two weeks later.", "title": "Flatbush and Nostrand, January \u201961", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "A comparable property in fancier Bronxville might have fetched $950,000, Mr. Keery said, adding that his new neighbors, who own bars, run coffee businesses and produce television shows, are all pleasantly social.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe are like the best-kept secret in Westchester,\u201d he said.\n\nAmong developers, Fleetwood might be more of an open secret. In the last couple of years, as housing costs have mounted in Manhattan and Brooklyn, builders have begun planning luxury rentals, betting priced-out New Yorkers will be willing to come north.\n\nBut in a place that seems to embrace the status quo \u2014 reflected in a housing stock with a solidly early-20th-century look \u2014 the arrival of something sleek and new has ruffled some feathers. \u201cThe issue has put a strain on our organization,\u201d said Michael Justino, president of the Fleetwood Neighborhood Association, a nonprofit founded in 1998.\n\nSpecifically, some residents are miffed about an $85 million plan to put a 16-story, 249-unit tower on Broad Street West, in Fleetwood\u2019s busy shopping district. The project, from the Bluestone Organization and other developers, began demolitions in January, but only after lawsuits had delayed the project for years.\n\nSupporters of projects like Broad Street say they promise to add a jolt of youthful energy to a population that is aging. But critics say shoehorning hundreds of new residents into dense blocks will worsen congestion.\n\nSteering clear of any controversy, the association has stayed neutral. \u201cWe will see what happens,\u201d said Mr. Justino, 62, who works in the construction machinery business and has lived in Fleetwood since 1986, when he bought a stone-and-stucco house for $250,000.\n\nFor others, both sides have merits. Carmen Leon, 66, a psychiatrist who moved to Fleetwood in 2013 from Riverdale, in the Bronx, admits that the wealthy tenants that high-end apartments attract are likely to spur an increase in prices of groceries at local stores.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen again, the shopping district, dotted with vacancies, could use more places like Casa Cubana, a bistro where Dr. Leon likes to enjoy a glass of sangria. \u201cThe competition could be good,\u201d she said.\n\nMETRO-NORTH 1/2 mile Westchester County HUTCHINSON RIVER PKWY Bronxville BRONX RIVER PKWY. 22 Hunt Woods Park Fleetwood station GRAMATAN AVE. Fleetwood N.FULTON AVE. Bronx R. Mount Vernon New york CONN. E. THIRD ST. Fleetwood N.J. Source: Fleetwood Neighborhood Association New York City\n\nBut Dr. Leon \u2014 who lives in a two-bedroom, two-bath co-op that she bought last year for $223,000 and shares with her son, Matthew Sowley, 26 \u2014 has no plans to leave. \u201cThis neighborhood,\u201d she said, \u201cis a hidden paradise.\u201d\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Find\n\nWith essentially the same borders as the 10552 ZIP code, Fleetwood covers about one and a half square miles and has a population of slightly fewer than 20,000, according to census figures analyzed by the Queens College department of sociology.\n\nGenerally considered the most affluent section of Mount Vernon, a city that has struggled with poverty, crime and blight, Fleetwood is not easy to characterize broadly. At the southern end is a hodgepodge of Arts and Crafts bungalows, Dutch colonial-style homes and midcentury Capes on small lots. Worn multifamily homes pack streets like North Fulton Avenue.\n\nWhat seems to be one of the biggest collections of co-ops outside New York City crams this area, too. The red-brick, U-shaped Westchester Gardens on Gramatan Avenue, set back from the sidewalk by lawns, is the oldest, from 1924; it went up soon after Fleetwood\u2019s passenger railroad stop was built.\n\nOther co-ops, with Tudor facades, are tucked here and there, like Grand Gardens, on West Grand Street, with apartments that offer archways, moldings and eat-in kitchens.\n\nNorth of the Cross County Parkway, which slashes through, there is a different feel. Single-family homes sit on larger lots, and some streets end in hushed cul-de-sacs. It can be tough to tell where Fleetwood ends and the village of Bronxville begins; there are few signs, and the rich housing stock seems nearly identical.\n\nNeighborhoods within neighborhoods include Pasadena Park, with postwar colonial-style homes and raised ranches, and Aubyn Manor, where you can find historic Tudors. But these place names live on mostly through brokers.\n\nPhoto\n\nBesides that Broad Street tower, planned complexes include a $48 million, five-building rental complex with 179 apartments on MacQuesten Parkway. The first building will open in spring 2019, said Sam Mermelstein, director of development for Enclave Equities, the developer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd this winter, Mount Vernon\u2019s zoning and planning boards approved a 44-unit complex for East Broad Street.\n\nIf the architecture is diverse, so is the populace. Non-Hispanic white people represent 38 percent; non-Hispanic black people, 39 percent; and Hispanic people, 18 percent, according to the Queens College sociology department.\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Pay\n\nOn Feb. 20, there were 67 houses, condos and co-ops listed for sale on Zillow. At the high end was a five-bedroom Georgian from 1932 at $1.29 million; the least expensive was a one-bedroom co-op at $125,000.\n\nPrices seem to have declined slightly in the past year. In December 2017, the median list price was $150,000, according to Zillow, but the median in December 2016 (the oldest month for which Zillow has data) was $162,000. The high point was in May 2017, when the median was $195,000, according to Zillow, which measures the median on a month-by-month basis.\n\nRenters account for 43 percent of all households, high by suburban standards. An upscale option is the Princeton, on North Terrace Avenue: Studios are about $1,450 a month, and one-bedrooms, $1,800. Less-expensive options include Colonial Village, a red-brick complex where a studio was listed on Zillow for $1,250.\n\nThe Vibe\n\nA park on Broad Street West with climbing equipment, benches and a gazebo doubles as a village green. Concerts, movie nights and a Halloween party, hosted by the neighborhood association, take place there. A half dozen blocks away is Hunt Woods, a park popular with dog walkers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNight-life options include Bayou Restaurant, a Cajun standby, and Maggie Spillane\u2019s Ale House, with outdoor rooftop seating. Other storefronts offer a pharmacy, dry cleaners, bagel shop, liquor store, nail salon and flower shop, as well as Harvest Field Market, known for its organic produce.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Schools\n\nMany students are zoned for the Pennington School, which offers prekindergarten through eighth grade for about 330 students. On state English exams last year, 32 percent of students met standards, versus 40 percent statewide, according to state figures; on state math exams, 26 percent met standards, versus 40 percent statewide.\n\nMount Vernon High School enrolls about 1,400 students and has a 66 percent graduation rate, state figures show, compared with an 80 percent graduation rate statewide. On SAT exams last year, students scored an average of 413 on the reading and writing section, and 399 on the math section; statewide averages were 528 and 523, respectively.\n\nThe Commute\n\nMetro-North\u2019s Harlem line serves Fleetwood. Eight trains depart for Grand Central between 7 a.m. and 9 a.m., with the quickest, at 8:06 a.m., taking 28 minutes. Monthly fares are $239.\n\nA narrow staircase runs to the station from Locust Street, or commuters can park at the station for $150 a month. There is no wait list for permits.\n\nWestchester County\u2019s Bee Line bus system also has several routes. And highways are never far.\n\nThe History\n\nFrom 1904 to 1914, Bronxville\u2019s Siwanoy Golf Club occupied a 95-acre site in Fleetwood. The subsequent owner, a Manhattan banker named Jesse Winburn, sought to turn it into a golf course for men only. But in 1925, Westchester County took 34 acres, for $142,800, to create the road that became the Cross County Parkway, according to The New York Times.\n\nMr. Winburn thought women had killed his plans, or those \u201cwho didn\u2019t like the idea of not getting to play golf on a course they had used when it was occupied by Siwanoy,\u201d he told The Times. The remaining 61 acres were sold as building sites. Fairway Street\u2019s name is believed to honor the sporty past.", "title": "Fleetwood, Mount Vernon: Westchester County\u2019s \u2018Best-Kept Secret\u2019", "authors": ["C. J. Hughes", "Living In"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMariele Marki lives on the fifth floor of House 39, a new rental building on East 39th Street in Manhattan that is awash in indulgent amenities. The apartment building also has a perfectly nice elevator that stops on all 36 floors. But after walking her dog, Ms. Marki, a marketing consultant who is 26, often takes the stairs to her apartment \u2014 starting with the sculptural staircase that spirals up the double-height lobby to the second floor, where she can grab a coffee from the lounge before continuing up on the fire stairs.\n\n\u201cEvery little bit helps keep you a little more fit,\u201d she said.\n\nHammams and wine cellars top many amenity lists for new developments, but staircases? In upscale buildings that go all out to pamper residents, a feature that requires exertion might seem counterintuitive. But over a century and a half after the modern elevator was invented, many developers, architects and designers are bringing staircases to the fore, to add drama, evoke a bygone era, and activate common areas \u2014 or activate residents themselves.\n\nAnd developers are going to considerable lengths to do so.\n\nHouse 39\u2019s spiral, for instance, is 17\u00bd-feet tall, and the Canadian company that manufactured it had to trench the floor of its factory to accommodate the height. Rockwell Group, designer of the building\u2019s interiors, took inspiration for the form from House 39\u2019s curved glass facade, and specified a curved glass balustrade. David Rockwell, the firm\u2019s founder \u2014 and a self-avowed \u201cstair fan\u201d \u2014 is particularly enamored of the staircase\u2019s mirror-polished bronze underside, which reflects movement and contributes to what he described as the lobby\u2019s dynamism.\n\nWinston Fisher, a partner in Fisher Brothers, the building\u2019s developer, said the cost for the set of the steps \u2014 about $1 million \u2014 was worth it. \u201cWe wanted something cool and artistic and stylish and memorable,\u201d he said.", "title": "Flights of Fancy and Function", "authors": ["Jane Margolies"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "For our story on women artists in museums, five designers created working uniforms for female artists from history, exclusively for T. To accompany the piece, the Brooklyn-based floral artist Joshua Werber created a headpiece to complement each design \u2014 and modeled them himself. \u201cIn designing the headpieces to accompany the uniforms for this story, the sketches and source materials were the primary inspiration,\u201d he said. \u201cSpecific references to the artists\u2019 work and the intentions set by the designers influenced the shapes, forms and styles.\u201d Click through our slide show to see Werber\u2019s floral designs.", "title": "Floral Headpieces, Inspired by Female Artists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Howard Finkelstein, the Broward County public defender, whose office is representing Mr. Cruz, said the report was further evidence that Mr. Cruz needed serious help long before the shooting but did not get enough of it.\n\n\u201cThis kid exhibited every single known red flag, from killing animals to having a cache of weapons to disruptive behavior to saying he wanted to be a school shooter,\u201d Mr. Finkelstein said. \u201cIf this isn\u2019t a person who should have gotten someone\u2019s attention, I don\u2019t know who is. This was a multisystem failure.\u201d\n\nThe state agency investigated whether Mr. Cruz intended to harm himself in September 2016, when he made the alarming social media posts after an argument with his mother. Mr. Cruz, who had depression, was upset over a breakup with a girlfriend, his mother, Lynda Cruz, told investigators. The report does not say who called in the complaint, which was given \u201cimmediate\u201d priority.\n\nThe report shows that investigators closed the case about two months later. The agency determined that the \u201cfinal level of risk is low\u201d \u2014 an analysis that one of Mr. Cruz\u2019s counselors at his school felt was premature \u2014 because his mother was caring for him, he was enrolled in school and he was receiving counseling. By the time of the shooting, however, Mr. Cruz had lost at least two of those elements: His mother was dead, and he had left Stoneman Douglas High School. It is unclear if he was still seeing a counselor.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mr. Cruz, 19, showed up at Stoneman Douglas and unleashed more than 100 rounds from a semiautomatic AR-15 rifle he purchased last February, five months after the state investigation closed. As of Saturday evening, two Broward hospitals were still treating four patients in fair condition, according to Jennifer Smith, a spokeswoman.\n\nThe office of Mr. Finkelstein, the public defender, suggested that it had offered prosecutors a guilty plea in exchange for a life sentence without the possibility of parole.\n\n\u201cEverybody knows he is guilty. What we are saying is, let\u2019s put him away for life,\u201d Mr. Finkelstein said. \u201cWe are not saying the death penalty is not justified; we are saying, let\u2019s not put this community through the trauma and pain of a trial knowing that, three years down the road, one juror could keep him from being put to death.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Florida, the death penalty requires a decision by a unanimous jury.\n\nMichael J. Satz, the state attorney, said prosecutors would announce their position on the death penalty \u201cat the appropriate time.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis certainly is the type of case the death penalty was designed for,\u201d Mr. Satz said in a statement. \u201cThis was a highly calculated and premeditated murder of 17 people and the attempted murder of everyone in that school.\u201d\n\nMr. Cruz\u2019s school disciplinary records show he attended at least six schools, including Cross Creek School, a school for students with emotional problems; Dave Thomas Education Center, an alternative high school for at-risk youth; and an adult education center. He was first identified as developmentally delayed in 2002, when he was 4 years old.\n\nIn incidents that began in 2012, when Mr. Cruz was 13, he was disciplined for being disobedient and unruly. In 2013, the records suggest, he was counseled for making a false 911 call.\n\nHe was suspended several times in the 2016-17 school year, his last year at Stoneman Douglas, and was frequently reported for prolonged and unexplained absences. In September 2016, he was suspended for two days for fighting, only to return and get suspended again nine days after the fight, this time for hurling profane insults.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat same month, the Department of Children and Families began its investigation into Mr. Cruz. The investigation, first reported by The Sun-Sentinel of South Florida on Friday, was obtained by The Times on Saturday. The state agency had petitioned a court on Friday to make the confidential records public, but the court has yet to do so.\n\n\u201cMental health services and supports were in place when this investigation closed,\u201d Mike Carroll, the secretary of the Department of Children and Families, said in a statement. Mr. Cruz was investigated as an adult, and the investigation appeared aimed at determining whether he was being neglected.\n\nAgency investigators identified Mr. Cruz, who had turned 18 a few days earlier, as a \u201cvulnerable adult due to mental illness.\u201d In addition to depression, Mr. Cruz had autism and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, the report said. He was regularly taking medication for the A.D.H.D. It was unclear whether he was taking anything for the depression, according to the report.\n\nAfter the argument with his mother, an investigator visited the family\u2019s home in Parkland, which was clean, clutter-free and did not present any foul odors. The investigator did not see the cuts on Mr. Cruz\u2019s arms: He was wearing long sleeves.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMr. Cruz stated that he plans to go out and buy a gun,\u201d the report states. \u201cIt is unknown what he is buying the gun for.\u201d\n\nHis mother denied that she and her son had argued. She told the investigator that Mr. Cruz did not have a gun, though he did have an air gun she would take away from him when he did not follow rules about shooting only at backyard targets.\n\nHis mother, who died in November, told investigators she attributed Mr. Cruz\u2019s behavior to \u201ca breakup with a girl.\u201d Ms. Cruz \u201cstated that she and the girl\u2019s mother told the kids they had to end the relationship because it was unhealthy for everyone,\u201d the report said. Neither the girl nor her mother are named in the report.\n\nA year before, it was discovered that Mr. Cruz had a Nazi symbol and a racial slur on his book bag. His mother said that when she confronted her son about it, Mr. Cruz purported to not know what the sign meant, and she said the family had never expressed negative sentiments toward people of other races. She made him clean it off his bag.\n\nThe report noted that a mental health center had been contacted in the past to detain Mr. Cruz under Florida\u2019s Baker Act, which allows the state to hospitalize people for several days if they are a threat to themselves or others. The center determined that he was not such a threat. Had Mr. Cruz been involuntarily committed, state law could have prohibited him from buying a firearm.\n\nThe mental health counselor, from Henderson Behavioral Health, had also visited Mr. Cruz at home and had him sign a safety contract.\n\nDespite the assessment, a school counselor remained concerned.\n\n\u201cShe said Henderson found him stable enough not to be hospitalized,\u201d the Department of Children and Families investigator wrote of the school counselor. \u201cShe stated that the concern she and the other staff had was to ensure that the assessment of Henderson was not premature.\u201d\n\nHenderson Behavioral Health would not comment on Saturday. Neither the mental health counselor nor the school counselor could be reached.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to the report, investigators also tried to speak to a school police officer, who declined to cooperate.\n\nThe Department of Children and Families would have had no way to know if Mr. Cruz\u2019s behavior became more erratic after losing his mother because the agency is not automatically notified of a caretaker\u2019s death, said George Sheldon, a former department secretary.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to second-guess because we don\u2019t know everything that the department knew at the time, but clearly this young man was showing serious signs of a mental health disorder, something that does not pop up overnight,\u201d said Mr. Sheldon, who left the department in 2011 and now oversees a nonprofit foster-care agency in Miami. \u201cHe was troubled and about to explode. And the results were devastating.\u201d", "title": "Florida Agency Investigated Nikolas Cruz After Violent Social Media Posts", "authors": ["Audra D. S. Burch", "Frances Robles", "Patricia Mazzei"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAn aide to State Representative Shawn Harrison of Florida was fired on Tuesday after claiming falsely that two students at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School were \u201cactors that travel to various crisis when they happen,\u201d a common far-right conspiracy theory after mass shootings.\n\nMr. Harrison\u2019s district secretary, Benjamin Kelly, made the assertion in an email sent from his state account to a Tampa Bay Times reporter, Alex Leary. Mr. Leary, who posted a screen shot of the email on Twitter, had written about far-right attacks on the students fighting for new gun laws in response to the shooting at their school last week, which killed 17 people.\n\nMr. Kelly\u2019s email referred to Emma Gonz\u00e1lez, 18, and David Hogg, 17, two seniors who have been outspoken in the days since the shooting. The Broward County superintendent, Robert W. Runcie, confirmed to The Tampa Bay Times that they were Stoneman Douglas students.\n\nRichard Corcoran, the speaker of the Florida House, announced Tuesday evening that he had fired Mr. Kelly at Mr. Harrison\u2019s request. Mr. Harrison confirmed the firing in his own statement on Twitter, shortly after voting against consideration of a bill that would have banned assault rifles like the one used in the Stoneman Douglas shooting. Rick Scott, a Republican and an ardent supporter of gun rights, shouting, \u201cShame on you! Shame on you! Shame on you!\u201d On an upper floor, they gathered outside the office of the powerful speaker of the Florida House, Richard Corcoran. \u201cFace us down! Face us down! Face us down!\u201d\n\nAnd on the House floor, Alondra Gittelson, who survived the attack at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, confronted Mr. Corcoran, a Republican, demanding to know why \u201csuch a destructive gun\u201d \u2014 the AR-15 rifle \u2014 is widely accessible.", "title": "Florida Republicans Face Mounting Pressure to Act on Gun Control", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "CORAL SPRINGS, Fla. \u2014 Cadet Peter Wang dreamed of attending the United States Military Academy at West Point one day, but he never got the chance. The 15-year-old was shot down last week at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School as he held open a door so others could escape.\n\nAs he was laid to rest on Tuesday, West Point issued his family a ceremonial letter of acceptance. \u201cOne of U.S.M.A.\u2019s priorities is to develop leaders of character who are committed to the values of duty, honor and country,\u201d the academy wrote on Twitter. \u201cPeter Wang\u2019s actions on February 14 are an example of those principles, and the academy honors his dream of being a West Point cadet.\u201d\n\nThe 17 people killed in the shooting rampage included three members of the school\u2019s popular Junior Reserve Officers\u2019 Training Corps: Mr. Wang, Martin Duque and Alaina Petty. Fellow students say the cadets acted valiantly, helping to usher others to safety. All three have been posthumously awarded the Medal of Heroism by the Army.\n\nThe accused gunman, Nikolas Cruz, 19, had also been a Junior R.O.T.C. cadet.\n\nThe corps is one of the high school\u2019s largest clubs, with nearly 300 students who take courses in subjects like military drill, leadership and shooting. Their maroon polo shirts were a familiar sight around the school campus. Mr. Cruz may have counted on that. The police say he was wearing his maroon polo shirt when he was arrested, after having slipped away unnoticed after the rampage.", "title": "Florida School\u2019s R.O.T.C. Lost 3 Cadets; Suspect Was a Member", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "PARKLAND, Fla. \u2014 For the latest on the Florida school shooting, read Friday\u2019s live updates.\n\nDavid Hogg stood in the Florida sun on Thursday, not far from his now shuttered school, and described the events of the day before.\n\nMr. Hogg, 17, a lanky senior at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School and the student news director there, was in his environmental science class when a single shot rang out, echoing down the hallways.\n\nHis teacher pulled the door shut, but soon the fire alarm began to blare. Then, he said, came the sound of thousands of student footsteps, and Mr. Hogg and his classmates raced out the door, joining a giant wave of teenagers.\n\n\u201cThere was a tsunami of people running in one specific direction away from something,\u201d he said, \u201cand that\u2019s what we were doing. It was almost like there was a shark coming along and we were a school of fish. And we were running from that armed man.\u201d\n\nA janitor appeared and began to wave. \u201cStop, stop!\u201d he said. \u201cGo over here!\u201d\n\nThen the school chef opened a door to her office, Mr. Hogg said, and hurried the teenagers in \u2014 first 10, then 20, then some 30 or 40 students crowded in the office. They shut off the lights. And then students turned to their phones, and began the horrifying experience of watching a school shooting unfold at their own school \u2014 through the news apps on their phones.\n\nWhile they were hiding, Mr. Hogg proceeded to interview his classmates on camera about their beliefs on gun policy.\n\nMr. Hogg\u2019s younger sister, 14, was also in the building. Two of her best friends were among the 17 people who died, he said.\n\n\u201cOn a national scale, I\u2019m not surprised at all,\u201d he said of the shooting. \u201cAnd that\u2019s just sad. The fact that a student is not surprised that there was another mass shooting \u2014 but this time it was at his school \u2014 says so much about the current state that our country is in, and how much has to be done.\u201d\n\nThe violence must stop, he said, issuing a call to pressure lawmakers to act to make schools safer.\n\n\u201cWe need to do something. We need to get out there and be politically active. Congress needs to get over their political bias with each other and work toward saving children\u2019s lives.\u201d\n\nIn an interview with CNN earlier on Thursday, Mr. Hogg expressed his frustration with politicians in simpler terms: \u201cWe\u2019re children,\u201d he said. \u201cYou guys are the adults.\u201d", "title": "Florida Shooting Survivor Wants Action: \u2018We\u2019re Children. He initially inspired hope among South Africa\u2019s poorest before coming to symbolize corruption.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. The healthy food movement has been absorbed into the mainstream.\n\nBut even as capitalism has ingeniously integrated the hippie culinary ideals of the 1960s, the big countercultural idea about food \u2014 that our eating has moral, ethical and political implications \u2014 remains potent, Michael Pollan writes in his review of \u201cHippie Food,\u201d a book by Jonathan Kauffman.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. (Videos from inside the school captured the terror.)\n\nA \u201ctroubled kid\u201d who showed off his firearms and bragged about killing animals, the suspect had been expelled last year. Here\u2019s what we know about Nikolas Cruz, including his trail of disturbing social media posts.\n\nBitter political debates rage about why mass shootings are so stunningly frequent in the U.S. We tracked the 200 school shootings that have occurred since 2012, when a young man killed 20 young children and six adults at an elementary school \u2014 with the same style of legally-purchased rifle used in Florida.", "title": "Florida Shooting, South Africa, Olympics: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAngst,\u201d he said. \u201cI just \u2014 there is so much emotion. I\u2019m really really sad. It\u2019s a very sad situation. Kids shouldn\u2019t have to worry about that. It\u2019s already tough enough being a teenager, without worrying about things like that.\u201d\n\nDid he plan to vote in favor of any bills that would do anything about that?\n\n\u201cYou know, I think it\u2019s too early to say.\u201d\n\nWhy?\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just too early to say.\u201d\n\nInside, the students divided into groups of 10. Senator Lauren Book, a Democrat, had helped the students arrange meetings with lawmakers in both parties, and the groups were supposed to meet with some 70 elected officials.\n\nGroup Six crammed into the elevator with two parent chaperones. They met with Representative Patricia H. Williams, a Democrat, and Senator Debbie Mayfield, a Republican. Ms. Mayfield said that changes were needed, perhaps including raising the minimum age to buy powerful weapons, but she rebuffed criticism from a student, Daniel Bishop, 16, that such a change would not actually prevent deaths.\n\n\u201cWe can\u2019t stop crazies,\u201d she told the group.\n\nAfterward, Amanda De La Cruz, 16, looked distraught. \u201cI want the ban on semiautomatic weapons,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t care about the crazies.\u201d\n\nThen they headed to the House floor, where the powerful speaker of the House, Richard Corcoran, a Republican, had agreed to take their questions.\n\nStanding at the front of the chamber, he promised to unveil what he said would be the most sweeping gun reform package in the nation\u2019s history by Thursday or Friday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen a 16-year-old student named Alondra Gittelson raised her hand.\n\n\u201cI just want to know why such a destructive gun is accessible to the public \u2014 why that gun, the AR-15, that did so much damage, how is an individual in society able to acquire such a gun?\u201d\n\nMr. Corcoran responded that he would not be in favor of banning weapons like the one used in the attack on the students.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think that if you look, it\u2019s widely used in multiple different hunting scenarios,\u201d he said. \u201cI know people who go out and they\u2019ll do boar hunts and they\u2019ll use them.\u201d\n\nHe continued: \u201cYou can disagree, but what I tell my kids \u2014 and being in elected office, you have to be very, very, very careful how much authority and power you bring to government. The greatest atrocities known to mankind have been committed by governments.\u201d\n\n\u201cI understand your question,\u201d he added. \u201cAnd we\u2019ll look at it, but I\u2019ll just be honest with you: Me personally I don\u2019t believe that\u2019s the solution.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfterward, Ms. Gittelson observed that Mr. Corcoran had said exactly what her stepfather had predicted he would say.\n\nAround noon, hundreds of people converged on the capitol in support of the Stoneman Douglas students. Then, in the afternoon, the tone inside the capitol changed, as protesters flooded the building.\n\nThe morning had been filled with impassioned but respectful conversation between the Stoneman Douglas students and lawmakers. But as the day wore on, college students and others packed the hallways carrying signs and boxes of petitions.\n\nOn one floor, they crowded the doorway of the office of Gov. Rick Scott, shouting \u201cShame! Shame! Shame!\u201d On an upper floor, they gathered outside Mr. Corcoran\u2019s office: \u201cFace us down! Face us down! Face us down!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs the students pressed lawmakers in Tallahassee, cries for stricter gun control measures swelled on sidewalks and football fields around the country.\n\nBack in South Florida, students formed an enormous heart on an athletic field at Coral Springs High School and then walked to Stoneman Douglas High School, about five miles away, where more than 1,000 students gathered.\n\n\u201cSeventeen lives are more important than gun rights,\u201d said Christopher Lormeus, 18, who had walked from Coconut Creek High School, six miles away.\n\nNear Tampa, thousands of students left their classrooms and stood silently for 17 minutes, according to The Tampa Bay Times.\n\nThe protests stretched far beyond Florida. In Montgomery County, Md., students left their high schools, walked to the Metro, and rallied in front of the Capitol, holding signs with slogans like, \u201cProtect kids not guns.\u201d\n\nThey walked out of Simon Kenton High School in Kentucky, according to the Enquirer, chanting \u201cnever again,\u201d and filed out of Mesa High School in Arizona, hoping to support the Parkland students. \u201cThis is our mark in history,\u201d one student said, to whoops and cheers.\n\nBut at Needville High School, about an hour outside Houston, administrators threatened any student who protested during school hours with a three-day suspension.\n\n\u201dLife is all about choices and every choice has a consequence whether it be positive or negative,\u201d Curtis Rhodes, the superintendent, said in a statement posted on Facebook. \u201cWe will discipline no matter if it is one, 50, or 500 students involved.\u201d", "title": "Florida Students Began With Optimism. Then They Spoke to Lawmakers.", "authors": ["Julie Turkewitz"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "The gathering on Sunday was the beginning of what Broward County school officials have called a \u201cphased reopening\u201d of the school where 17 students and staff members were killed. Teachers and the rest of the staff will return to work on Monday and Tuesday; the students will come back for classes starting on Wednesday.\n\nInitially, the school day will last only until 11:40 a.m., and many students said they expected to do little else on those first few days besides discuss the shooting; gun control; mental health issues; and the long, complicated path toward healing that lies ahead for them, their families and their town.\n\nHow do you pick up with English projects and science lessons, students wondered, when the study partners who helped you make Romeo and Juliet masks and write an essay on climate change are dead?\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re just not there,\u201d said Lourdes Konwufine, 15.\n\nLeah Ronkin, 16, said she went to the drama room where she had hidden in a closet during the massacre. She retrieved her backpack, her lunchbox and a white teddy bear her boyfriend had given her for Valentine\u2019s Day.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like the first day of school,\u201d she said, \u201cbut it\u2019s not normal at all.\u201d\n\nSome students said that they dreaded returning, and that wandering around Stoneman Douglas again on Sunday felt surreal. Their school was now a place filled with grief counselors, comfort dogs, and posters of sympathy and solidarity from high schools across the country.\n\nThe three-story freshman building, where most of the bloodshed occurred, remained fenced off and closed, and it will not reopen for classes. School officials, parents and students have called for it to be demolished, with a memorial built in its place.\n\nSome students said they felt happy to be back, and were buoyed by the support of their friends. Others said the echoes of that day were inescapable.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt makes you feel kind of empty inside,\u201d said Ryan Senatore, 15. \u201cWalking back in where 17 lives passed \u2014 it\u2019s a disgusting feeling. It\u2019s never going to be the same. Never.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRyan LoFurno, 16, went into a physics classroom to get his backpack and car keys. His parents walked in with him, and said they were struck to be standing where their son had hidden in a corner as gunfire exploded in the next building.\n\n\u201cThis is where he was,\u201d said Ryan\u2019s mother, Denise. \u201cHe was closer than I thought.\u201d\n\n\u201cA lot closer,\u201d said his father, Anthony.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSeveral parents said on Sunday that they were not worried about sending their children back to Stoneman Douglas, which is now ringed by official vehicles. But as they walked into the school, some said they were growing angrier over reports that have raised questions about the Broward County Sheriff\u2019s Office, including how its officers responded to the shooting and how earlier warnings about the suspected gunman were handled.\n\nSheriff Scott Israel defended his actions as \u201camazing leadership\u201d on Sunday during a tense interview broadcast on CNN. The sheriff, a Democrat who won re-election to the post easily in 2016, said he would not resign, despite growing criticism of his deputies\u2019 actions.\n\nThe speaker of the Florida House of Representatives and dozens of other Republican lawmakers on Sunday called on Gov. Rick Scott, also a Republican, to use his authority to suspend the sheriff from office.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe governor\u2019s office announced that state officials would conduct an investigation of the law enforcement response to the shooting. Sheriff Israel\u2019s office said it welcomed the governor\u2019s move and would cooperate with the investigation.\n\nSheriff Israel said he should not be held responsible for the armed deputy assigned to the school, who failed to enter the building to confront the gunman while the massacre was in progress. That deputy has resigned, and the sheriff said he would investigate whether others arriving on the scene also held back.\n\n\u201cDeputies make mistakes,\u201d the sheriff said on the CNN program, \u201cState of the Union.\u201d \u201cPolice officers make mistakes. But it\u2019s not the responsibility of a general or the president if you have a deserter.\u201d Sheriff Israel added, \u201cYou don\u2019t measure a person\u2019s leadership by a deputy not going in.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Parkland, several students said they had to steel themselves to re-enter the school on Sunday. They spoke of feeling panicky and queasy, and of asking parents and older siblings to accompany them.\n\nTyjanai Thomas, 15, said that she had seen her freshman geography teacher gunned down, and that she was focusing on staying calm. On the sidewalk outside, she held tight to a pearl pendant that hung on a silver chain around her neck \u2014 a gift from her godmother, she said. She wondered whether she could handle three more years in this place. Sunday would be the first test.\n\n\u201cAt some point, we\u2019ve got to face reality,\u201d she said.\n\nAnd then she walked back into Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.", "title": "Florida Students Return, Gingerly, to Their Scarred High School", "authors": ["Jack Healy", "Patricia Mazzei"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "The decision on Monday was expected, as no appeals court has yet ruled on the issue.\n\n\u2022 The move meant that the immigrants, often called Dreamers, could remain in legal limbo for many months unless Congress acts to clarify their status.\n\nChina\u2019s new authoritarian era\n\n\u2022 The Communist Party\u2019s push to abolish term limits for President Xi Jinping is the latest sign of the world\u2019s decisive tilt toward government by strongman.\n\nOne reason for the shift is that few countries have the standing or authority, morally or otherwise, to speak out.\n\n\u2022 Xi Jinping Thought, the president\u2019s political philosophy, will soon be enshrined in China\u2019s Constitution. Franklin Graham, Billy Graham\u2019s eldest son, explaining his unstinting support of President Trump, which has made Mr. Graham a polarizing figure in his father\u2019s movement.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\nThe Leaning Tower of Pisa has had its distinctive tilt since shortly after construction began in the 12th century, but it was on this day in 1964 that the Italian government decided things had gone too far.\n\nDespite its location in the Piazza dei Miracoli (the Square of Miracles), the tower had become one miracle that needed a little human help to survive.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo prevent the loss of a national treasure \u2014 and a tourism gold mine \u2014 the authorities in Italy asked for suggestions on how to stabilize the tower\u2019s slowly increasing lean.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPeople had long offered advice about fixing the tower, however.\n\nThe Times reported in 1972 that, in the previous 60 years, more than 200,000 people had sent letters to the mayor of Pisa with their thoughts on how to save the monument.\n\nAnd previous attempts had gone awry, most notably one by the Italian dictator Benito Mussolini in 1934.\n\nMussolini decided a leaning tower wasn\u2019t a fitting symbol for his country, so he had holes drilled through the floor and tons of concrete poured into the foundations.\n\nIt promptly lurched another few inches toward the ground.\n\nThe tower was finally stabilized in 2001, after an 11-year, $26 million restoration project.\n\nAnna Schaverien contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. More than a dozen Russians and three companies were charged with interfering in the 2016 elections, underscoring the conclusion that Russia is engaged in a virtual war against the U.S.\n\nIt was the first indictment in connection with election meddling secured by the special counsel in the Russia investigation, Robert Mueller, above. President Trump claimed personal vindication, writing on Twitter that there was \u201cno collusion!\u201d\n\nProsecutors said that Facebook and Instagram were the most frequently used tools for Russian operations that aimed to sow political discord.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. The Senate blocked three measures \u2014 including one backed by President Trump \u2014 to resolve the fate of the young people known as Dreamers.\n\nWhat will happen now is unclear. The program that was protecting an estimated 690,000 people from deportation was rescinded by Mr. Trump, and it will expire on March 5. Above, a protest in Washington last month.\n\nCongress is in recess this week, and immigrant rights advocates are turning their attention to the legal arena. Two federal courts have blocked the administration from ending the program, but the White House wants those rulings overturned.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Supreme Court convened a closed-door conference on Friday to discuss whether to take up the issue immediately.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. Cyril Ramaphosa, above, took over as president of South Africa. He had been deputy president and is one of the richest men on the continent.\n\nHe succeeds Jacob Zuma, who resigned after nearly nine years as president. Mr. Zuma, once known as a charismatic anti-apartheid hero, had come to symbolize the corruption that flourished during his time in office.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. Our correspondent on the ground in northern Syria met some of the fighters for the Syrian Democratic Forces. The American-backed group, which includes Kurds and Arabs, drove the Islamic State out of a large section of northeastern Syria.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re very proud,\u201d said Shervan Derwish, above. \u201cWe did something for our people, and for the world.\u201d\n\nSecretary of State Rex Tillerson was in Turkey, where he met with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan to discuss the diplomatic crisis between their countries over Turkey\u2019s military operations against Kurdish forces in Syria.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. What does \u201cnatural\u201d mean, exactly? The term is on more and more products these days, from fruit juice to shampoo to baby wipes.\n\nThe problem, consumer groups say, is that there is no legal or regulatory definition of what \u201cnatural\u201d is. That has spurred hundreds of lawsuits.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe debate echoes the tussling over the term \u201corganic\u201d in the 1990s. (The Department of Agriculture did eventually create a definition and certification process.)\n\nAnd we haven\u2019t even gotten to \u201chealthy\u201d yet.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Rick Gates, above, once the deputy chairman for the Trump campaign, agreed to cooperate with the special counsel\u2019s inquiry into Russia\u2019s interference in the 2016 election.\n\nHe pleaded guilty to financial fraud and lying to investigators, and may be offering incriminating information about his longtime business associate, Paul Manafort, who served as chairman of the Trump campaign.\n\nHere\u2019s a breakdown of the more than 100 charges filed in the inquiry so far. No one outside of the special counsel\u2019s office knows for sure where it\u2019s heading. But our White House correspondent writes that the flurry of recent action seems to be inexorably leading to a larger target.\n\nSeparately, the House Intelligence Committee released a redacted Democratic memo rebutting Republican claims of surveillance abuses by the F.B.I. It had been blocked by President Trump two weeks ago. (You can read it here.)\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. The Supreme Court will hear a case on Monday that could cripple public-sector unions.\n\nThe legal question: Should state government employees in Illinois have to pay their union for representing them in collective bargaining?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nConservative groups say the First Amendment bars forcing government workers from having to pay anything, and the court has signaled that it agrees. Labor leaders like Randy Clover, above, say the case is an effort to diminish the protections that unions provide to their members.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. The U.N. Security Council voted on Saturday in favor of a 30-day cease-fire in Syria, after days of government bombardment on a besieged Damascus suburb, above, left hundreds of civilians dead.\n\nA pause in fighting would allow humanitarian aid to reach eastern Ghouta, and allow for the evacuation of civilians. Residents there are hiding in basements and makeshift bomb shelters amid a brutal aerial assault by the government.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. As climate change pushes seas higher, threatening coastal areas across the globe, nations are grappling with an existential question: Which communities should be protected, and which should be left to the tides?\n\nIn a special report with NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune, we examined the struggles of south Louisiana, the epicenter of land loss in America. Above, the community of Jean Lafitte, where the question is not whether it will succumb to the sea. It\u2019s when.\n\nFor more coverage of climate change, sign up for our newsletter, Climate Fwd:.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Above, Mr. Trudeau and his family at the Golden Temple in Amritsar.\n\nDonald Trump Jr. was also in India, promoting luxury condos. His trip was dogged by controversy over the possibility of blurred lines between commerce and government.\n\nAnd Ivanka Trump is in South Korea, where she led the American delegation at the closing ceremony of the Winter Olympics. Kim Yong-chol, the head of North Korea\u2019s delegation, expressed willingness to speak with the U.S., according to the South Korean president\u2019s office.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Norway finished the Games with by far the most medals of any country: 39, 14 of them gold. It is the greatest performance in the history of the Winter Games. And it has left some Norwegians worrying whether they are winning too much.\n\n\u201cWe always want to win,\u201d a Norwegian sports commentator explained. \u201cBut modesty is a big part of the culture here.\u201d\n\nThe U.S. has 23 medals, nine of them gold. Nearly a dozen special elections are being held around the U.S. this year to fill seats suddenly left open by the #MeToo reckoning. Above, a rally in Las Vegas last month.\n\nYet the candidates \u2014 many of them women \u2014 running to replace these disgraced men are hesitating to put the issue of sexual harassment front and center in their campaigns. The Syrian government, with its Russian and Iranian allies, is fighting to regain control of western Syria, whatever the cost.\n\nViolence that has been rising over weeks has intensified. Syrian and Russian planes struck a rebel-held enclave of some 400,000 people near Damascus, above, in one of the worst bombardments in years. Nearly 100 people were reported killed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Turkish jets and artillery attacked pro-government militias for a second day, keeping them from reaching the northwestern city of Afrin to reinforce Kurdish militias.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. The mushrooming corruption scandal plaguing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, above, took a surprising new turn.\n\nOne of his closest advisers was accused of trying to bribe a judge to drop a criminal investigation involving Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s wife. The police arrested several of Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s friends and confidants, and top executives of the country\u2019s biggest telecommunications company.\n\nMr. Netanyahu released a video calling the accusations against him \u201challucinatory\u201d and \u201cbaseless\u201d and part of a \u201ccampaign of persecution\u201d that had been \u201cgoing on for years.\u201d\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. American officials have rebuffed requests from Mexico to help investigate the use of government spying technology against innocent civilians.\n\nThere\u2019s concern that Mexico wants to use the U.S. as a cover in a sham inquiry, American officials told us. Above center, President Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto.\n\nWe broke the story last year that the Mexican government had been using the technology to spy on prominent human rights lawyers, academics and journalists. Our Mexico bureau chief and technology writer explained how they got the scoop.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Anyone who has ever been on a diet knows that the standard prescription for weight loss is to reduce calorie intake. But a new study may turn that advice on its head.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt found that people who cut back on sugar, refined grains and processed foods, and ate more vegetables and whole foods \u2014 without worrying about portion sizes \u2014 lost significant amounts of weight over the course of a year. Above, a very healthy meal of quinoa and vegetables.\n\nA health expert we talked to said the study showed a \u201croad map to reducing the obesity epidemic\u201d by focusing on food quality, not calorie-counting.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Winners of gold, and more than gold.\n\nThe unified Korean women\u2019s hockey team closed out its Olympic run without a single win. For many, that was hardly the point. Our photographer Chang Lee, whose own life has been shaped by the division in Korea, cried as he shot the opening ceremony. Check out his images of the Games.\n\nOn Tuesday night\u2019s broadcast, Lindsey Vonn will vie for her second Olympic gold in the women\u2019s downhill. Our interactive graphic shows the price her body has paid for her quest.\n\nHere\u2019s our full coverage, plus the medals table, results and schedule.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. The countdown to the Oscars has begun. The ceremony will be held on March 4.\n\nWe talked to Yance Ford, above, the first transgender director to receive an Oscar nomination, for his documentary \u201cStrong Island.\u201d\n\nThe film is a brutal, intimate portrait of the unraveling of his tight-knit family following the death of his brother, William Ford Jr., in Suffolk County in 1992, and an all-white grand jury\u2019s decision not to indict the white man who shot him.\n\n\u201cIf my nomination helps people at all think about the transgender folks in their lives, in their communities, and treating them as humans and equals deserving of protection, I\u2019m happy,\u201d he said.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Finally, a vast swath of Patagonia \u2014 home to pumas, condors, flamingos and endangered deer species \u2014 is getting new protections.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPresident Michelle Bachelet of Chile recently announced the creation of a 10-million-acre national park system stretching all the way south to Cape Horn, where the tip of South America splinters into fjords and canals.\n\nIt\u2019s the brainchild of Kristine McDivitt Tompkins and her husband, Douglas Tompkins, who founded The North Face and Esprit clothing companies. They had paid $345 million \u2014 much of their fortune \u2014 to buy so much land that some Chileans became worried about national security.\n\nPlease enjoy the view.\n\n____\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. Above, Pope Francis in Rome on Wednesday.\n\nOur correspondent visited a stronghold of Catholicism in China\u2019s southeast to gauge how the possible deal is being seen by the faithful. Many Chinese Catholics feel a sense of powerlessness, he writes, \u201cas if awaiting a storm that they cannot control.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis is something higher-ups will decide,\u201d said a shopkeeper near a holy mountaintop cave. \u201cWe believers just go to church and pray.\u201d\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Farewell, Year of the Rooster \u2026\n\nToday is Lunar New Year\u2019s Eve, awaiting the arrival of the Year of the Dog.\n\nThe holiday can be serious and poignant, and also funny. During a recent New Year\u2019s travel rush in southern China, for example, a woman climbed into an X-ray scanner because she could not bear to part with her handbag.\n\nAnd astrologers in China were quick to forecast the highs and lows ahead for President Trump, who was born in 1946, a Fire Dog year. Shares in PNB closed down 10 percent, erasing nearly one-third of its market value.\n\n\u2022 President Trump, who has vowed to pressure China on trade, said the U.S. was likely to impose restrictions on imported metals. A common thread: \u201cMarriage is changing because women are changing.\u201d\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nCanada has one of the world\u2019s most recognizable flags, but the banner is only 53 years old and took far longer to create.\n\nThe red-and-white flag, featuring a silhouette of a maple leaf, was raised for the first time on this day in 1965.\n\nPreviously, Canada had flown the Union Jack as a member of the British Commonwealth. An unofficial flag known as the Canadian Red Ensign, bearing the Union Jack and the Royal Coat of Arms of Canada, had been used on government buildings.\n\nA national maple leaf flag was first suggested in 1895, but it wasn\u2019t until 1964 that the Canadian Parliament approved it.\n\nPrime Minister Lester Pearson had proposed a \u201ctruly distinctive\u201d flag that represented all the cultures in Canada, not just its French or British colonial identity. A committee evaluated thousands of designs featuring national symbols (a beaver wearing a Mountie hat was among those rejected).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe flag was bitterly debated, especially by Mr. Pearson and his predecessor, the opposition leader John Diefenbaker. (Mr. Diefenbaker called the maple leaf motif \u201ca flag without a past\u201d and wept when it was inaugurated.)\n\nBut even though its tree doesn\u2019t grow nationwide, the maple leaf was considered a neutral symbol.\n\n\u201cIt was the perfect, perhaps the prototypical, Canadian compromise,\u201d the historian Rick Archbold wrote.\n\nJennifer Jett contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Such changes are the focus of proposed legislation that the National Rifle Association supports.\n\nCrooked deals pay for a war machine\n\n\u2022 In a nearly four-year war against rebels armed by Russia, Ukraine\u2019s defense spending has soared, from around 2.5 percent of its gross domestic product in 2013 to more than 5 percent this year, when it will total around $6 billion.\n\nBut the money that has rejuvenated Ukraine\u2019s military has opened avenues for the graft and cronyism that many see as the country\u2019s biggest enemy.\n\n\u2022 \u201cIt serves no purpose for Ukraine to fight for its body in Donbas if it loses its soul to corruption,\u201d Secretary of State Rex Tillerson warned last year, referring to regions seized by Russian-backed separatists.\n\nAn Obamacare dilemma\n\n\u2022 One tension at the heart of the Affordable Care Act is that, while it aims to provide health coverage for all, it is far more generous to the poor and near-poor than to the middle class.\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s efforts to undermine the law have helped deepen the resentment that many of those who don\u2019t qualify for government assistance feel for those who do.\n\n\u2022 Such feelings help explain why the only government programs with broad support are those that help everyone: Social Security and Medicare.\n\nPhoto\n\nAn exceptionally deadly day in Syria\n\n\u2022 In researching the Miami River, she became interested in the Everglades and persuaded her publisher to let her write about them instead.\n\n\u201cThe Everglades: River of Grass\u201d was published in 1947. An environmental classic, the book changed the way the U.S. viewed its wetlands, as important ecosystems and surge buffers rather than as worthless swamps that are more useful when drained.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite Mrs. Douglas\u2019s warning that \u201cThere are no other Everglades in the world,\u201d development has continued to encroach.\n\nThe school now in the news opened in 1990, commemorating her 100th birthday. She died eight years later, in the same Miami cottage in which she\u2019d lived since 1926.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning.
