It was unclear on Tuesday to what extent Mr. van der Zwaan is cooperating, but his plea agreement does not compel him to do so.\n\nMr. van der Zwaan\u2019s gilt-edged life was based in London, where he worked for Skadden and lived with his wife after they were married last summer in a lavish English countryside wedding featured in the Russian edition of Tatler magazine. A 2006 law school graduate of King\u2019s College London, he speaks four languages: Russian, Dutch, English and French.\n\nHis father-in-law, German Khan, who was born in Ukraine, is an owner of Alfa Group, Russia\u2019s largest financial and industrial investment group. He was on a recent Treasury Department roster of prominent Russian officials and oligarchs.\n\nTuesday\u2019s court hearing left many questions unanswered about Mr. van der Zwaan, including why he failed to be forthcoming to federal investigators about his communications with Mr. Gates and a second person who was identified by prosecutors only as \u201ca longtime business associate of Manafort and Gates in Ukraine.\u201d\n\nMr. van der Zwaan\u2019s lies involved a 2012 report prepared by Skadden and used to defend Mr. Yanukovych, then the Russia-aligned president of Ukraine, from international criticism over the prosecution and incarceration of one of his political rivals, former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko. State Department officials criticized the report, which purported to be the result of the law firm\u2019s independent research, as a misleading account of the actions of Mr. Yanukovych\u2019s government.\n\nMr. Mueller\u2019s team scrutinized the report as part of its examination of the business dealings of Mr. Manafort and Mr. Gates in Ukraine, where Mr. Manafort worked for about a decade as a political consultant before he joined the Trump campaign. Among other charges, both men have been accused of \u201cusing one of their offshore accounts to funnel $4 million to pay secretly\u201d for the report. It is unclear how much, if any, of that money went to Skadden or other firms with which they worked.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Ukrainian authorities had begun their own investigation into payments for the report after Mr. Yanukovych fled Ukraine for Russia amid a popular uprising in 2014.\n\nMr. van der Zwaan told the special counsel on Nov. 3 that he had not spoken to Mr. Gates since mid-August 2016, even though Mr. Gates had called him the following month instructing him to get in contact with an unidentified mutual acquaintance, court papers show.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe also told prosecutors that he had not talked to that same acquaintance since 2014, even though he called that person in September 2016 to discuss possible criminal charges against Mr. Manafort, a law firm and a former Ukrainian justice minister. The phone conversation, conducted in Russian, was important enough that Mr. van der Zwaan recorded it, according to court papers. Mr. van der Zwaan followed up by calling Mr. Gates, recording that conversation as well.\n\nOne of those conversations involved payments that were described as \u201cthe tip of the iceberg,\u201d Andrew Weissmann, a prosecutor in Mr. Mueller\u2019s office, said in court. He did not elaborate.\n\nMr. van der Zwaan also acknowledged that he lied when he told investigators that he had only a \u201cpassive role in the rollout of the report,\u201d according to court papers. In fact, prosecutors said, he had discussed with Mr. Gates and others how to publicize the report to make it appear less damning to Mr. Yanukovych\u2019s government, including describing any mishandling of Ms. Tymoshenko\u2019s prosecution as no more than \u201cprocedural\u201d errors. Part of the strategy, Mr. Weissmann said in court, was to give an advance copy of the report to The New York Times.\n\n\n\nThe law firm\u2019s work was being investigated by Ukraine\u2019s top prosecutor, which asked the Department of Justice for help in questioning eight lawyers named as authors of the report, including Mr. van der Zwaan, according to documents reviewed by The Times.\n\nAmong the others were Gregory B. Craig, who served as President Barack Obama\u2019s White House counsel, and Clifford M. Sloan, who also worked in the Obama administration. Both Mr. Craig and Mr. Sloan declined to comment.\n\nThe Ukrainian officials claimed that Mr. Yanukovych\u2019s government circumvented contracting rules by initially agreeing to pay Skadden a fee that was less than the threshold for competitive bidding \u2014 reportedly about $12,000 \u2014 then later paying the firm a total of nearly $1.1 million.\n\nLast year, the law firm refunded $567,000 to the Ukrainian government. The firm said the refund represented \u201cthe balance of Ukraine\u2019s payment, which had been held in escrow for future work.\u201d\n\nA sentencing hearing for Mr. van der Zwaan was set for April 3.\n\nThe charges against him were the seventh criminal case that Mr. Mueller\u2019s team has brought since October. Last week, the special counsel\u2019s office indicted 13 Russians and three companies on charges of interfering in the 2016 United States election with a sophisticated influence campaign on popular social media platforms. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlthough he is a longtime advocate for dialogue, President Moon has not yet decided whether he would meet with Kim Jong-un. He said he would meet the North Korean leader only if he was assured that their meeting could produce progress in helping end North Korea\u2019s nuclear weapons programs.\n\nKim Yong-chol, who will lead Sunday\u2019s delegation, is expected to meet with Mr. Moon to discuss the details of a potential summit meeting.\n\nUntil now, North Korea has refused to discuss its pursuit of nuclear weapons with the South, insisting that it was an issue between Pyongyang and the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Moon is also eager to persuade the United State and North Korea to talk to each other to defuse tensions over the North\u2019s nuclear weapons and missile programs. So far, neither the United States nor North Korea have expressed much interest in dialogue.\n\nKim Yong-chol is a familiar figure to South Korean negotiators. In 2014, Mr. Kim, who is also a military general, led a delegation to discuss ending hostilities after North and South Korean soldiers exchanged fire across the border.\n\nIn 2010, when two North Korean agents were caught in the South while on a mission to assassinate a high-ranking defector from the North, they said they were dispatched by Mr. Kim\u2019s General Bureau of Reconnaissance, the North\u2019s main spy agency, South Korean officials said. He served in the State Department and the White House Council on Environmental Quality, both under former President George W. Bush.\n\nIn the aftermath of the 1997 Kyoto Protocol , the first United Nations-led climate agreement (which the United States signed but did not ratify), he had a hand in helping the Bush administration outline what a climate deal would need to look like to win American support. It was an effort, he said, that would help shape his outlook on the Paris deal.\n\nThe Senate in 1997 unanimously rejected the Kyoto Protocol because it demanded legally binding emissions cuts from industrialized countries while allowing developing nations to act voluntarily. For any future deal to be acceptable, Congress instructed, it would need to hold all countries equally legally accountable for cutting greenhouse gas emissions. Emissions goals offered by nations would need to be voluntary and \u201cbottom up\u201d \u2014 that is, not dictated by the United Nations but rather devised domestically so they could be enforceable at home.\n\nThose are essentially the parameters of the Paris agreement that the Obama administration negotiated with nearly 200 nations and finalized in 2015. \u201cIt\u2019s a climate policy based on U.S. national interest that the Bush team started and the Obama team kept,\u201d Mr. Banks said.\n\nHe called Mr. Obama\u2019s emissions pledge \u201cawful,\u201d describing it as unrealistically high. He also criticized the Obama administration for failing to consult with Congress or industry in devising it. But, he said, \u201cI think probably the United States got the best deal it could as a framework.\u201d\n\nDemocrats and others who shaped the Paris agreement under the Obama administration argued the target was the same one the House of Representatives approved as part of climate legislation in 2009. As for the terms of the accord, they agreed with Mr. Banks, up to a point. The Obama administration was able to convince other countries to embrace the Bush-era terms, they said, precisely because it put forward an ambitious target that showed the world that America, the biggest emitter of greenhouse gases in history, was serious about tackling climate change.", "title": "Former Trump Aide Calls Paris Climate Accord \u2018a Good Republican Agreement\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Geddert has insisted he had \u201czero knowledge\u201d of Nassar\u2019s crimes. The expectation, however, is that Fosun will put a minimum of \u20ac100 million ($122 million) into the ailing house, much of which would cover outstanding losses and unpaid salaries.\n\nThe Chinese conglomerate, which is controlled by the billionaire Guo Guangchang and owns the French tourism group Club Med, along with the brands Folli Follie, St. John and Caruso, recently entered into acquisition talks with the Italian lingerie brand La Perla.\n\nPhoto\n\nLanvin\u2019s current owner and president, Shaw-Lan Wang, who is based in Taiwan and previously held 75 percent of the company, will lose control and become a minority shareholder. The Swiss businessman Ralph Bartel will retain a minority stake.\n\nUntil this week, the fortunes of Lanvin had been in a desperate state. Founded by Jeanne Lanvin in 1889, the house had enjoyed a 21st-century revival during the 14-year tenure of the creative director Alber Elbaz, who had forged a loyal client base with collections full of shimmering, jewel-toned cocktail frocks and velvet tuxedos.\n\nBut after the acrimonious ousting of Mr. Elbaz by Ms. Wang in October 2015, the company quickly tipped into chaos, with the departure triggering walkouts and the workers\u2019 council suing Lanvin\u2019s management.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA second creative director, Bouchra Jarrar, lasted just 16 months, while a debut collection in September by the brand\u2019s latest hire, Olivier Lapidus, who had outlined his intention to turn Lanvin into the \u201cFrench Michael Kors,\u201d received dire reviews.\n\nA write-up by the chief fashion critic at The New York Times, Vanessa Friedman, was headlined \u201cHow to Wreck a Brand in 3 Years.\u201d\n\nPredictably, Lanvin\u2019s sales plummeted. In 2016, revenues fell 23 percent to \u20ac162 million and the company posted its first loss in more than a decade, of \u20ac18.3 million. Three people with knowledge of the finances say the losses widened further still in 2017, prompting Ms. Wang to seek fresh investment in order to prevent the company\u2019s collapse.\n\nHungry investors had circled Lanvin before, spying an opportunity to grow a brand whose financial performance had never quite matched the luxury halo it possessed in a buoyant market.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2014, for example, Ms. Wang rejected a bid by Mayhoola of around \u20ac400 million. The patchwork of state law means that states cannot necessarily restrict gun sales to everyone on another state\u2019s no-gun list. And gun control advocates said states are already supposed to report to the national background check system people prohibited from owning guns under the parameters of state law, and not only those restricted by federal law.\n\nBut officials working on the coalition said the agreement would reinforce and expand what they share, including the names of people, for example, who have been voluntarily hospitalized for mental illness and are prohibited by some states from owning guns.\n\nThe agreement seemed poised to heighten the monitoring of people with mental illness, raising concerns among mental health advocates about unnecessarily stigmatizing people and discouraging them from seeking care. New York, for example, keeps a no-guns database that has grown to 77,447 names of people whom mental health professionals have reported as being a danger to themselves or others.\n\nNew York will now share that database with the other three states, Alphonso David, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s chief counsel, said in an interview. It is not clear how the other states would act on it, given that the law in Connecticut and New Jersey, for example, expressly forbids firearm purchases only by people who have been committed to a mental health center.\n\nBut some states give their licensing authorities discretion to ban people they deem a risk to public safety, and Mr. David said they could use New York\u2019s database as an investigative tool to make their own determination.", "title": "Four Northeast States Pledge to Share Gun Safety Data", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nI Need a Nutritious Documentary\n\nA scene from \u201cNova: First Face of America.\u201d Roberto Chavez Arce/PBS\n\n\u2018NOVA: First Face of America\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Wednesday at 9 p.m., on PBS (check local listings).\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis hourlong documentary explains the story of a 13,000-year-old human skull discovered in an underwater cave in Mexico, combining the history of human migration to the Yucat\u00e1n with the contemporary science that discovered and recovered the skull. The mechanics of the exhumation are fascinating (even if the cave-diving footage gave me that spooky hollow-noodle feeling in my legs), and there\u2019s something haunting and beautiful about trying to know about the life of a specific teenage girl who died thousands of years ago.\n\nI Need a Bingeable In-Between Show\n\nA scene from \u201cFace Off.\u201d SyFy\n\n\u2018Face Off\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now, on Now, on Hulu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWe\u2019re in a weird, slightly dead zone between winter returns and the start of midseason shows, which arrive mostly in March. If you want something to carry you through that\u2019s low-impact but still addictive, there\u2019s \u201cFace Off,\u201d which is streaming again, this time on Hulu.\n\n\u201cFace Off\u201d is like \u201cProject Runway,\u201d but for special-effects makeup \u2014 sometimes fantasy, more often horror or sci-fi. Unlike other reality-contest shows, everyone on \u201cFace Off\u201d is nice to one another. They speak openly about how they did, in fact, come here to make friends, and they help one another in the work room and freely offer constructive feedback and emotional support.\n\nI\u2019ve recommended \u201cFace Off\u201d in this newsletter a lot, but that\u2019s only because I like it so much. Even if reality-contest shows are not typically your jam, this is much closer to the wholesomeness of \u201cThe Great British Baking Show\u201d than to the manufactured conflict of \u201cTop Model.\u201d\n\n0\n\nGive Me Makeovers\n\nFrom left, Karamo Brown, Jonathan Van Ness, Tan France, Antoni Porowski and Bobby Berk in \u201cQueer Eye.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Queer Eye\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Starting Wednesday, on\n\nStarting Wednesday, on Netflix Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe Bravo classic \u201cQueer Eye for the Straight Guy\u201d has been revived on Netflix, with a new \u201cfab five\u201d doling out makeovers; a new home base, in Atlanta; and a slightly altered name. Otherwise, the show is largely the same: A bumbling, sometimes shabby man is in need of a style reboot to address his perceived shortcomings in fashion, self-care, cooking, domesticity and culture. The experts descend, gently tease the dude, coax him through their rituals, have some kind of teary heart-to-heart about sources of shame or grief and then send their living project back to his life.\n\nNew \u201cQueer Eye\u201d is a funny, often moving makeover show. It is not, however, quite the justice vehicle it seems to believe it is. An episode that attempts to address police violence against black people is jarring and incongruous, and for all the ways that the show could conceivably celebrate outsiderness, the experts seem to have an extremely narrow vision for what is acceptable, attractive and expressive. (Not everyone wants to host parties! Let a hermit live! Sheesh.) That said, I shed honest tears at every episode I watched.\n\nOne Comedy, Please\n\nFrom left, Christa Miller, Busy Philipps, Dan Byrd, Josh Hopkins and Courteney Cox in \u201cCougar Town.\u201d Adam Taylor/ABC\n\n\u2018Cougar Town\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now, on\n\nNow, on Hulu Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFor a show that was on for six seasons (three on ABC, three on TBS), \u201cCougar Town\u201d always seemed to fly under the radar, thanks in part to a terrible title but also maybe because of its happy non-premise. It\u2019s just a group of people who hang out and are goofballs. Courteney Cox stars as Jules, who\u2019s amicably divorced from Bobby (Brian Van Holt) and mom to a teenage son, Travis (Dan Byrd). Her best friends are the ditsy Laurie (Busy Philipps) and the more acerbic Ellie (Christa Miller), who is married to Andy (Ian Gomez). Grayson (Josh Hopkins) is Jules\u2019s neighbor and eventual love interest.\n\nThat\u2019s \u2026 sort of it. Early on, the show tried to feature more of Jules\u2019s dating life before admitting that it is its best self when spending downtime among its main characters. \u201cCougar Town\u201d toys with the silly rituals of friendships, the in-jokes and the dumb, invented games that embody social intimacy. If you like \u201cHappy Endings,\u201d try this.", "title": "Four TV Shows to Watch This Week", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "School administrators knew that Mr. Lyman had behaved inappropriately, the letter said. Lisa Trask, a spokeswoman for Beaver, said that administrators had been told twice that Mr. Lyman had crossed crucial boundaries. In one instance, administrators were told that Mr. Lyman had asked a female student to \u201cgo on what would have amounted to a date (which did not occur).\u201d\n\nImage Frederic Lyman in the summer of 1980, shortly after he left the Beaver Country Day School, where he engaged in sexual misconduct. The Massachusetts school\u2019s administration knew of his behavior, but did not warn potential employers.\n\nNonetheless, administrators let Mr. Lyman finish out the school year and appear to have made no effort to alert potential employers. By allowing him to slip unimpeded from one school to the next, a practice known as \u201cpassing the trash,\u201d Beaver administrators placed more children at risk. Investigations at the schools where he went on to teach found that he saw those opportunities, and pounced.\n\nMr. Lyman began his private school teaching career at Andover in 1978. Investigators at that school found he had \u201cengaged in unwanted intimate touching\u201d with a student.\n\nAt Choate, where he taught after Beaver, an investigation found that he had abused two students, having sex with then, and giving one of them herpes. Choate administrators discovered his behavior and forced him to leave the school. But they sent him on his way with a letter of recommendation, that helped him get a job at another private school, Kent Denver. Kent Denver released a report this summer that he had asked students on dates and propositioned them for sex.\n\nAfter it learned of his behavior, Kent \u201cactively discouraged\u201d him from working in other schools and denied him a recommendation. Mr. Lyman subsequently left teaching.\n\n\u201cAs a young teacher, I made serious mistakes that I will regret for the rest of my life,\u201d Mr. Lyman said in an email. \u201cI cannot change what I did, I can only say that I am deeply sorry for my actions and the pain they have caused to others.\u201d", "title": "Fourth School Reveals a Teacher\u2019s Abuse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFox News on Friday removed an incendiary op-ed article by one of its top executives, after the piece drew criticism for mocking American Olympic officials who had emphasized the diversity of this year\u2019s team of athletes. The column suggested, sarcastically, that the United States Olympic Committee adopt a new motto: \u201cDarker, Gayer, Different.\u201d\n\nThe piece, published on Wednesday and written by John Moody, an executive vice president and executive editor of Fox News, caused an uproar on social media. Some of the network\u2019s employees expressed dismay that Fox News had allowed the article to be published on its website.\n\n\u201cJohn Moody\u2019s column does not reflect the views or values of Fox News and has been removed,\u201d the network said in a statement.\n\nMr. Moody, a Time magazine alumnus who was one of the network\u2019s earliest senior news managers, was close to Roger E. Ailes, Fox News\u2019s former chairman. Mr. Moody\u2019s role at Fox News has dwindled over the years; despite his lofty title, he has little formal oversight over the channel\u2019s day-to-day coverage.\n\nThe column, however, returned Mr. Moody to the spotlight. Its headline, \u201cIn Olympics, let\u2019s focus on the winner of the race \u2014 not the race of the winner,\u201d prefaced a critique of American Olympic officials who had praised the diversity of the squad headed to this month\u2019s Winter Olympics in South Korea.\n\n\u201cNo sport that we are aware of awards points \u2014 or medals \u2014 for skin color or sexual orientation,\u201d Mr. Moody wrote.\n\n\u201cWere our Olympians selected because they\u2019re the best at what they do,\u201d he added, \u201cor because they\u2019re the best publicity for our current obsession with having one each from Column A, B and C?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Grynbaum"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Fox News viewers \u201cvalue our product so much, they go to hotels and if they can\u2019t have Fox, they send us emails. They go on cruises, and if they can\u2019t have Fox, they send us emails,\u201d Mr. Finley said. \u201cThis is a way for us to meet that demand.\u201d\n\nWhether the venture would be a moneymaker is up in the air.\n\nFox News reaps more than $1 billion in annual profit, providing ample funds to hire a new team for Fox Nation, which is not expected to initially carry advertising. Mr. Finley declined to estimate his start-up costs, and streaming services in conservative media have had a mixed record of success.\n\nThe Blaze, a web-only service founded by the host Glenn Beck in 2011 after he left Fox News, struggled to attract interest and eventually morphed into a more traditional network distributed by cable and satellite providers. Bill O\u2019Reilly, who was fired by Fox News in April, started a subscription service on his website that has earned little attention.\n\nMr. Finley said Fox Nation was not comparable to a personality-driven product. \u201cThis is not starting from scratch here,\u201d he said. \u201cGlenn Beck had a ton of viewers when he was here on Fox. When he left, it didn\u2019t seem to me that they followed him. People are loyal to the Fox brand.\u201d\n\nThe median Fox News viewer is 65 years old, according to Nielsen, but the network points to its website traffic and heavy presence on Facebook and other social media platforms as evidence that a web-only service can appeal to its audience.\n\nAmong Fox News\u2019s main rivals, MSNBC has no stand-alone product. CNN has a streaming service, CNNgo, which offers some free original programming, but it otherwise requires an existing cable or satellite subscription. Jeff Zucker, CNN\u2019s president, said in December that he was considering a digital product for the channel\u2019s \u201cGreat Big Story\u201d brand, which is aimed at younger viewers.\n\nFox News, though, is facing some new competition on its conservative flank. Peter Thiel, the technology investor and Trump supporter, is said to be interested in creating a right-leaning media organization based in Los Angeles.", "title": "Fox News Plans a Streaming Service for \u2018Superfans\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPARIS \u2014 France unveiled a tough new anti-Islamist policy for its prisons and schools on Friday, confronting a lingering threat that is likely to intensify as radicalized fighters return from Syria.\n\nFor now perhaps the greatest menace is in the country\u2019s prisons, and it is there that the government of President Emmanuel Macron is concentrating its fire with the changes announced on Friday aimed at isolating hundreds of radicalized inmates. Over 1,600 inmates are jailed on terrorism charges or have been identified as radicalized.\n\nThe government now wants to separate and isolate them from other inmates \u2014 a shift from past strategy in which they were more likely to be dispersed among other prisoners. But officials now say that approach instead spread radicalism and threatened the security of guards, who went on a nationwide strike after a violent rampage by a jihadist inmate in January. The changes are in part a response to the strike, which paralyzed France\u2019s prisons.\n\nIn addition to the prison measures, France will more closely scrutinize the licensing of certain types of private, religiously oriented schools, often identified with the spread of radicalization. Some 74,000 students attend these schools.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIslamist radicalization threatens our society, and not only when it leads to violence,\u201d Prime Minister \u00c9douard Philippe said Friday in Lille while announcing the new measures.", "title": "France Toughens Stance in Combating Radicals in Prisons and Schools", "authors": ["Adam Nossiter"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Francesco Risso, the creative director of Marni, lists the Italian director Pier Paolo Pasolini and Disney cartoons among his many inspirations. In his two years at the Italian brand, where he arrived from Prada, he has quickly developed a signature aesthetic of playful eclecticism. His collections are bohemian, romantic and sometimes a little perverse.\n\nWhile Risso\u2019s designs may evoke bygone eras and even childhood \u2014 as with the trailing blanket cape from his most recent men\u2019s wear collection \u2014 they are not nostalgic. \u201cI\u2019m driven by a concept I call \u2018retrovolution,\u2019 \u201d the designer says. \u201cIt\u2019s about taking everything you\u2019ve learned in the past about tradition and moving beyond it.\u201d T challenged Risso to document his world and creative approach in Polaroid and the result is the 10 dreamlike images below, which the designer explains as follows:\n\n\u201cLife is built on encounters: One way or another all of them stay with me. They are the population of my soul, of my mind, disguises of my face or of my friend\u2019s or of my love\u2019s. Animals in the jungle of imagination keep me company as family jewels and strike my eye when I forgot about them, about me. A child playing, an explorer discovering, a young boy listening and a man telling.\u201d", "title": "Francesco Risso Shares a Glimpse Into His Creative World \u2014 in Polaroids", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "A TASTE OF PARIS\n\nA History of the Parisian Love Affair With Food\n\nBy David Downie\n\n280 pp. St. Martin\u2019s. $26.99.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cExcitement isn\u2019t a state of being I enjoy while dining,\u201d Downie confides. He\u2019s describing an evening meal at the sweetly sedate and horribly expensive Paris restaurant La Tour d\u2019Argent. In a book that skillfully combines culinary history with reports from some of the city\u2019s most tasteful arrondissements, he adopts the conceit of a historian\u2019s walking tour, conflating past with present in gorgeous style.\n\nStarting on the \u00cele de la Cit\u00e9, Downie compares it to a ship anchored midstream in the Seine, \u201ca floating Holy of Holies in the flow of Paris history.\u201d Strolling on, telling tales of Charles V\u2019s knife-wielding master cook Guillaume Tirel (nicknamed \u201cTaillevent\u201d for the swiftness with which he could slice up a daily court feast of 300 chickens, 36 suckling kids, 300 pigeons, 36 gosling geese, 11 sheep and 3 sides each of beef, veal and pork), Downie arrives unbloodied at the feet of Marie de M\u00e9dicis. Describing this frail Italian princess, who ballooned into a gargantuan widow after the demise of Henri IV, Downie notes that Rubens captured her girth \u201con enough canvas to sail fleets of galleons.\u201d Was the subject of \u201cthese sumptuous smorgasbords of color\u201d not just a glutton, he wonders, but also \u201cthe prototypical narcissist\u201d?\n\nBloated royalty offers plenty of succulent targets for Downie\u2019s knifelike pen. Louis XVI, pausing on his abortive flight from Paris to devour a dish of pig\u2019s trotters in which \u201cthe bones burst like bonbons, flooding the mouth with warm, liquefied marrow,\u201d cooked his final goose when he demanded \u2014 and ravenously shredded \u2014 an entire roast chicken while facing his scornful accusers in court. Quoting Dumas, Downie tartly remarks that the king put his own twist on Descartes: \u201cI am so I eat.\u201d\n\nPerhaps Downie takes food a bit too seriously. Balzac is scolded for being \u201can ecstatic, compulsive gorger and borderline glutton\u201d who devoured \u201ccongealed cold cuts and other toxic snacks.\u201d Not so our dapper author, savoring a tasteful supper facing the colonnade of the Louvre at Le Fumoir: \u201cHow delicious my appealingly plated but very old-fashioned roast pork loin with mustard sauce \u00e0 l\u2019ancienne. How polite and professional the service. How affordable the more than potable Ch\u00e2teau Haut-Musset Lalande-de-Pomerol.\u201d\n\nEATING ETERNITY\n\nFood, Art and Literature in France\n\nBy John Baxter\n\n267 pp. Museyon. Paper, $19.95.\n\nPhoto\n\nEntertaining, wide-ranging and gorgeously illustrated, \u201cEating Eternity\u201d \u2014 despite its weird title \u2014 is a book you\u2019ll want to lend to a friend. (But insist on its return.) As generous with his anecdotes as with his apt quotations (rejoice in Brillat-Savarin\u2019s \u201ca meal without wine is like a day without sunshine\u201d and Moli\u00e8re\u2019s \u201cI live on good soup, not fine words\u201d), Baxter broadens gastronomy into the fields of art and literature. The results are beguiling. Who ever suspected that Proust\u2019s famous madeleine almost lost out to a plain slice of \u201cpain grill\u00e9\u201d? Or that Chez Voisin\u2019s 1870 siege menu of antelope, cat and rat also offered its famished clients the impeccable liquid refreshment of Chateau Mouton Rothschild and Chateau Palmer?\n\nSome of the best treats provided by Baxter\u2019s delightful book are his startling asides. Comparing Picasso\u2019s utter indifference to haute cuisine with Matisse\u2019s daintier palate, he embellishes a description of Matisse\u2019s penchant for brandade de morue with unexpected advice: that the repeated washing of the codfish was best achieved, some housewives found, by a day\u2019s soak in the cistern of a flush toilet. He also informs us that Alexis Soyer, the 19th-century father of modern celebrity cooking, couldn\u2019t tolerate clothing cut on straight lines. And that wasn\u2019t all: His visiting cards, cigar case and even the handle of his cane had \u201cslightly oblique inclinations.\u201d\n\nOne grumble: Why is it that such an insider\u2019s guide fails to point out the virtues of traveling outside the familiar tourist precincts? It\u2019s there that some of the tastiest and least expensive food in Paris is to be found, but perhaps a dedicated gourmand is reluctant to share with visitors what to Parisians is an open secret. Then again, it\u2019s also true, as Baxter briefly reminds us, that McDonald\u2019s has met with great success in France. The French gave America the Statue of Liberty. It seems they like the \u201cmerci\u201d they received in return.", "title": "France\u2019s Love Affair With Food", "authors": ["Miranda Seymour"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "That is a paltry ratio \u2014 less than 3 percent \u2014 even compared with other countries.\n\nOf the 195 Michelin-starred restaurants in Spain, only 19 have female chefs, according to the guide\u2019s publisher, Groupe Michelin. There are only 20 women chefs at the 166 starred restaurants in the United States, the publisher said. Italy has the most, with 44 out of 365, or about 12 percent.\n\nGender imbalance in the kitchen is as French as foie gras and as traditional as a postprandial coffee. France has long enshrined the practice in which women cook at home for the family while men acquire fame and wealth as chefs in famous restaurants.\n\n\u201cThe first is a lonely work at home for a limited circle,\u201d said Franck Pinay-Rabaroust, editor in chief of the gastronomic information site Atabula and a former writer for the Guide Michelin. \u201cFor the second there is an organization, a brigade to direct.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMale domination of professional French cooking goes back to the Middle Ages.\n\n\u201cThe court was itinerant and when kings were traveling with their staff, in general, it was rather men who followed,\u201d said Patrick Rambourg, a historian and specialist on French gastronomy. \u201cWhen you have this historical model for so long, it can move but, we need to give it more time.\u201d\n\nThe Guide Michelin says none of this matters: it\u2019s only about the food.\n\nGender is \u201cnot something we take into account,\u201d Michael Ellis, the international director of the guides, told Agence France-Presse. \u201cOur inspectors are there to check the quality of the cuisine.\u201d\n\nGuide Michelin declined to provide further comment.\n\nBut the guide is inextricably part of tradition, and reflects the prevailing norms. In its 118-year history, the guide has awarded its top honor, three stars, to only four female chefs, from Eug\u00e9nie Brazier, the chef at La M\u00e8re Brazier restaurant in Lyon in 1933, to Anne-Sophie Pic, the most recent woman to win a star, in 2007.\n\nSome who study France\u2019s culinary tradition explain the absence of women from professional kitchens by pointing to physical demands, like the ability to wield a heavy cooking pot or wrestle an animal carcass. Having children is also cited as a reason, since combining a family life with a restaurant schedule is challenging.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cToday in cuisine, we hardly see a woman take a chief position because the rhythm is extremely tough,\u201d Mr. Pinay-Rabaroust said. \u201cThey have to work twice as much to show they are equal to men.\u201d\n\nMs. Fr\u00e9diani hopes to change that. While making her 2017 documentary, \u201cThe Goddess of Food,\u201d she discovered that there were many female chefs out there. She and her friends are now trying to come up with their own list of restaurants owned by female chefs in France.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter an appeal sent through social media, they received about 200 names. \u201cThe idea is to publish it openly,\u201d she said. \u201cSo we can no longer say that there are no female chefs in France.\u201d\n\nFrance\u2019s equivalent of the \u201cMe Too\u201d movement, \u201cBalance Ton Porc\u201d or, roughly, Out Your Pig, has opened a breach for French women not only to speak out against sexual misconduct, but also to demand more parity in the workplace. Ms. Fr\u00e9diani sees the battle for gender equality in restaurant kitchens as part of that larger struggle.\n\n\u201cWhen we fix the issue in gastronomy,\u201d she said, \u201cit will help many women in every field.\u201d\n\nIt is a battle chefs like Coline Faulquier, who owns the restaurant La Pergola in Marseille, are prepared to join.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe are not required to become men, but we have to mentally harden ourselves,\u201d she said.\n\nShe does everything a male chef does except she has one more person to manage, her four-year-old son.\n\nHis father helps her but, even so, she said, juggling motherhood with the demands of running a restaurant is a daily \u201crace against time.\u201d She closes her restaurant at night from Monday to Thursday, and crosses town every day to pick her son up at school before serving the lunch to patrons at noon.\n\nBut like every passionate chef, she is ambitious. \u201cI will give myself the means,\u201d she said, aiming for the Michelin star.\n\nFanny Rey, who won her first Michelin star last year, has tried to change the kitchen culture at the restaurant she owns with her partner in Saint-R\u00e9my-de-Provence by hiring and training women. Her restaurant employs three women in the kitchen and three in the dining room.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd she has trained five women as chefs at her restaurant.\n\n\u201cTo me, it has always been important to be surrounded by women,\u201d she said.\n\nShe says there are many talented female chefs who deserve exposure but may not get it because they are not head chefs.\n\nOne of them is Jessica Prealpato, the head pastry chef at the three-star Restaurant Alain Ducasse at the Plaza Ath\u00e9n\u00e9e in Paris. Mr. Ducasse\u2019s restaurants have a total of 19 Michelin stars.\n\n\u201cWhen I arrived, obviously it was tough, because I put pressure on myself,\u201d she said.\n\nWhen she told Mr. Ducasse about her plans to have her first child, she found him understanding. He was willing to arrange her schedule to accommodate a family life \u201cbecause he told me he needs me and my creativity,\u201d she said.\n\nThe tradition may be changing gradually but there are signs of change.\n\nFerrandi, a prestigious institution that prepares mostly young people for careers in gastronomy and hospitality management, says that 56 percent of its students this year are women. Women make up 79 percent of those working toward a bachelor\u2019s degree in pastry making.\n\nIt is those women Ms. Fr\u00e9diani hopes to reach.\n\n\u201cBy showing them that women chefs are there, that they do exist,\u201d she said, \u201cI think it will motivate them to dream big, to dare to make their dreams come true.\u201d", "title": "France\u2019s New Michelin Guide: More Fraternit\u00e9 Than \u00c9galit\u00e9", "authors": ["Assia Labbas"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "The state of the economy in 2012 was exactly the kind of situation in which running budget deficits is actually a good thing, because they help sustain overall spending. By contrast, there is no comparable case for deficits now, with the economy near full employment and the Fed raising interest rates to head off potential inflation. (Maybe the Fed is moving too soon, but the contrast with 2012 is still extreme.)\n\nIf anything, we should be using this time of relatively full employment to pay down debt, or at least reduce it relative to G.D.P. \u201cThe boom, not the slump, is the time for austerity at the Treasury,\u201d wrote John Maynard Keynes. But Republicans have turned that sage advice on its head. They are providing more stimulus to an economy with 4 percent unemployment than they were willing to allow an economy with 8 percent unemployment.\n\nThere have been many \u201cnews analysis\u201d pieces asking why Republicans have changed their views on deficit spending. But let\u2019s be serious: Their views haven\u2019t changed at all. They never really cared about debt and deficits; it was a fraud all along. All that has changed is the fact that a Republican now sits in the White House.\n\nHow do we know Republicans were never sincere about the deficit? It was obvious, even at the time, to anyone who looked at their fiscal proposals. These proposals always involved giant tax cuts for the wealthy \u2014 funny how that worked \u2014 offset by savage cuts in social benefits. Even so, assertions that deficits would go down depended entirely on assuming lots of revenue from closing unspecified loopholes and huge savings from cutting unspecified government programs. In other words, even at the peak of their deficit-hawk posturing, all Republicans really had to offer was redistribution from the poor to the rich.\n\nHowever, pretending to care about the deficit served several useful political purposes. It was a way to push for cuts in social programs. It was also a way to hobble Obama\u2019s presidency.", "title": "Opinion | Fraudulence of the Fiscal Hawks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "One sympathetic observer was struck by Douglass\u2019s \u201cpeculiar wit, sarcasm, drollery, dramatic intensity, and, more than all, his noble moral earnestness, set in strong relief by an indefinable and touching sadness of tone and mien.\u201d\n\nHis stock speeches championed giving everybody an equal opportunity. \u201cProperly speaking,\u201d he argued, \u201cthere are in the world no men as self-made men. That term implies an individual independence of the past and present which can never exist.\u201d\n\nAlthough Douglass never lived there, Brooklyn was home to leading abolitionists, black and white, including James and Elizabeth Gloucester (at whose home John Brown stopped on his way to Harpers Ferry), Lewis Tappan, Theodore Tilton (who was a 22-year-old journalist when Douglass recruited him to his newspaper, The North Star), William J. Wilson and Henry Ward Beecher (the brother of Harriet Beecher Stowe, the author of \u201cUncle Tom\u2019s Cabin\u201d).\n\nSeveral influential black-run newspapers were also based in Brooklyn, including The Ram\u2019s Horn. Douglass urged its editor to \u201cblow away\u201d on his horn, predicting that its \u201cwild, rough, uncultivated notes may grate on the ear of the refined,\u201d but would \u201cbe pleasurable to the slave, and terrible to the slaveholder.\u201d\n\nDouglass\u2019s name was listed on the paper\u2019s masthead (as it was in The National Anti-Slavery Standard published across the river in Manhattan).\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nReviewing his 1845 memoir, a \u201cNarrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass,\u201d in The New York Tribune, Margaret Fuller gushed: \u201cWe wish that every one may read his book and see what a mind might have been stifled in bondage \u2014 what a man may be subjected to the insults of spendthrift dandies, or the blows of mercenary brutes, in whom there is no whiteness except of the skin, no humanity except in the outward form, and of whom the Avenger will not fail yet to demand \u2014 \u2018Where is thy brother?\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Brooklyn\u2019s loudest voice was The Daily Eagle, a Democratic newspaper whose editorials advanced the Southern sympathies of New York\u2019s financiers, manufacturers and maritime moguls.\n\nThe Eagle, in its own policies and the letters it published, at worst demonized Douglass, declaring in 1856 that \u201cthe doctrines of this fellow are that slaves should not only run away but murder their employers before starting,\u201d and at best dismissed him, describing the known writer and social reformer as \u201cpossessed of extraordinary shrewdness for one of his race.\u201d\n\nIn 1858, following the death of Dred Scott, namesake of the Supreme Court ruling declaring that slaves were property rather than people, The Eagle all but predicted that Douglass\u2019s legacy would be forgotten.\n\n\u201cFred Douglass, the smartest darkey we have produced, will leave no name beyond his generation, but Dred Scott, a poor simple minded old Negro,\u201d The Eagle said, \u201cwill live in the annals of this great nation, as connected with a great constitutional principle.\u201d\n\nOnce the Civil War began, however, The Eagle was a bit more accepting of Douglass, saying that \u201che discusses the slavery question in a far more rational manner than most of his white co-laborers of the cause.\u201d\n\nBy 1895, the year Douglass died, The Eagle was beyond forgiving. \u201cIt was not because he advanced the interests of the Negro that men will honor his memory today,\u201d The Eagle editorialized, \u201cbut because by advancing the interest of the Negro he raised the level of all mankind and made the whole world better by living in it.\u201d", "title": "Frederick Douglass in Brooklyn", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "The 200th birthday of one of America\u2019s greatest thinkers, Frederick Douglass, is being celebrated this month. Douglass is remembered as many things: a fugitive slave who gained his freedom, an abolitionist, an advocate for women\u2019s rights, a gifted writer and orator. But we should also remember him as someone whose insights about scientific theories of race are every bit as relevant in our era as they were when he wrote them.\n\nWhen Douglass rose to prominence, in the 1840s, he was living in a world just as excited and anxious about his era\u2019s new inventions, like the railroad and the telegraph, as we are about modern-day innovation. But he understood that the ends to which science could be used were forever bound up with the moral choices of its practitioners. \u201cScientific writers, not less than others, write to please, as well as to instruct,\u201d he wrote in 1854, \u201cand even unconsciously to themselves (sometimes) sacrifice what is true to what is popular.\u201d\n\nThat statement was part of a lecture in which he attacked one of the most prominent scientific fields of the antebellum era: ethnology, or what was sometimes called \u201cthe science of race.\u201d Though often dismissed today as pseudoscience, at the time Douglass was writing, it was considered legitimate. The most accomplished scientists engaged in it, and the public eagerly consumed it.\n\nEthnology was not embraced just by Southerners who supported slavery. Its most important theorists lived in the North: one, Louis Agassiz, taught at Harvard; the other, Samuel George Morton, was president of one of the nation\u2019s leading scientific societies, in Philadelphia.", "title": "Opinion | Frederick Douglass\u2019s Fight Against Scientific Racism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Taylor also curated and organized exhibitions and coordinated \u201cDeconstructivist Architecture\u201d at the Museum of Modern Art in 1988. That exhibition, which was overseen by the architect Philip Johnson, included work by Frank Gehry, Rem Koolhaas, Peter Eisenman, Zaha Hadid, Daniel Libeskind, Coop Himmelblau and Bernard Tschumi.\n\n\u201cIt was a very trendy show, but it was totally prescient because everybody who participated in the show became who they are today,\u201d Ms. Taylor said in an unpublished interview last month with Solange Fabi\u00e3o, an artist and design architect.\n\nReviewing the exhibition for The New York Times, the architecture critic Paul Goldberger wrote that it was \u201cvisually spectacular, densely packed with models that seem intended as much to startle the eye as to engage it.\u201d\n\nIn 1993, Ms. Taylor opened TZ\u2019Art, a gallery in SoHo, with a partner, Tom Zollner. He left after five years, and it then became the Frederieke Taylor Gallery, which is now on East 29th Street in Manhattan.\n\n\u201cHer gallery is a window into a very adventuresome, exploratory presentation of the intersection between art and architecture,\u201d said Barry Bergdoll, chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art. \u201cShe had a really fresh eye and a real talent for cultivating interesting people. You could count on the gallery to show the unexpected.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong the artists, sculptors and architects whose work Ms. Taylor exhibited were Lisa Sigal, Thomas Zummer, Mel Chin, Raimund Abraham, Long-Bin Chen and Ms. Monk. \u201cIn 2015,\u201d Ms. Monk said, \u201cwhen I got the National Medal of Arts from President Obama, I brought only three people, and one of them was Frederieke.\u2019\u2019\n\nFrederieke Sanders Taylor was born on May 3, 1940, in Schiedam, the Netherlands. Her father, Pieter Sanders, was a lawyer who was a principal drafter of the United Nations\u2019 rules on international commercial arbitration awards, and her mother, the former Ida Sanders, was a social worker. Both collected art; her father\u2019s best friend was the Dutch modernist architect Jaap Bakema.\n\nAt age 10, Frederieke used birthday money from her grandfather to buy her first piece of art: an original print by M. C. Escher.\n\nFor a time during World War II, her father was held in a Nazi prison camp for notable people, though he was not Jewish. After his release, he hid in a crawl space behind a bookshelf in the family\u2019s home. Her mother was forced to wear a yellow star to signify that she was Jewish.\n\nMartien Halvorson-Taylor said in a telephone interview that when Dutch collaborators came searching for Mr. Sanders and peeked inside the piano at their home, young Frederieke \u201cgiggled because \u2018they think that Papie is in the piano.\u2019 \u201d\n\nAfter Ms. Taylor\u2019s junior year at Leiden University in the Netherlands, where she studied Chinese literature and language, she met her future husband, Willard Taylor, at a French-language school in Besan\u00e7on, France. She transferred in 1962 to Yale University, where Mr. Taylor was studying law. She earned an M.A., also in Chinese literature and language.\n\nShe thought her education might lead to a career as a diplomat. But her personal interest in art turned into her vocation.\n\nIn addition to Ms. Halvorson-Taylor, Ms. Taylor is survived by another daughter, Severn Taylor; five grandchildren; and her brothers, Pieter and Martijn. Her marriage to Mr. Taylor ended in divorce.\n\nAt a fund-raiser in 1971, Ms. Taylor paid $600 for a wall painting by the modern artist Sol LeWitt that depicted interlocking circles. The organizers wanted her to relinquish her winning bid \u2014 in the hope that someone would pay more \u2014 but she would not.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe held onto the painting until last year, when she sold it and other works to bankroll a foundation, FST StudioProjects Fund, to help young artists pay their studio rent.", "title": "Frederieke Taylor, Gallery Owner With Eclectic Taste, Dies at 77", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Barely 50 years ago, it was an unpopular truth that there was absolutely nothing unnatural about the love that went by the horrible name of \u201cmiscegenation.\u201d Other unpopular truths one could mention include gay rights, women\u2019s suffrage, and evolution. These truths could only have made their debut in the public square, and eventually gained broad acceptance, under the armed guard, so to speak, of the First Amendment.\n\nBut not just the First Amendment. In addition to a legal sanction, free speech has flourished in the United States because we have had a longstanding cultural bias in favor of the gadfly, the muckraker, the contrarian, the social nuisance. For over a century, editors and publishers and producers \u2014 at least the more enlightened ones \u2014 have gone out of their way to make allowances for opposing points of view.\n\nThey do so not because they have no strong convictions of their own, but rather out of a profound understanding that the astute presentation of divergent views makes us more thoughtful, not less; and that we cannot disagree intelligently unless we first understand profoundly. They do so because they believe that social progress depends on occasionally airing outrageous ideas that, on close reflection, aren\u2019t outrageous at all. They hold firm to the conviction that moving readers out of their political or moral comfort zones, even at the risk of causing upset, is good for mind and soul. Ultimately, they do so because we will not be able to preserve the culture and institutions of a liberal republic unless we are prepared to accept, as Judge Learned Hand put it in 1944, that the \u201cspirit of liberty is the spirit which is not too sure that it is right\u201d \u2014 and must therefore have the willingness to listen to the other side.\n\nThis was what Adolph Ochs knew in 1896, when he promised that under his stewardship The New York Times would \u201cinvite intelligent discussion from all shades of opinion.\u201d The Times, like other papers, may not have always lived up to that promise as well as it might have done. But as some of you may have noticed, it most emphatically is now, to the loud consternation of many of our readers.\n\n* * * * * *\n\nI do my best to appreciate the concerns of these readers. I understand that many of them \u2014 many of us \u2014 believe the 2016 election marked a political watershed in which liberties we have long taken for granted are being attacked and possibly jeopardized by a president whose open contempt for a free press has few precedents in American history. I understand the justifiable fear these readers have for a White House in which the truth is merely optional, and in which normal standards of courtesy or decency have lost the purchase they previously had under Democratic and Republican administrations alike.\n\nI also understand that these readers see The New York Times as a citadel, if not the citadel, in standing up to this relentless assault by the president and his minions. I think they are right. The country needs at least one great news organization that understands that the truth is neither relative nor illusory nor a function of the prevailing structure of power \u2014 but also that the truth is many-sided; that none of us has a lock on it; and that we can best approach it through the patient accumulation of facts and a vigorous and fair contest of ideas.\n\nThat, at any rate, is what I think we are trying to do at The Times, and I can only hope that more people will see its virtue as time goes by. That obviously demands good and consistent communication on our part. But, to return to my theme today, it also requires intelligence on the part of our readers.", "title": "Opinion | Free Speech and the Necessity of Discomfort", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "This American brother and sister, revered for their precision and joie de vivre, are elite athletes. But when they pressed together in head-to-toe camel spins \u2014 each holding onto the other\u2019s extended free leg and waist to the lyric \u201cPara-para-paradise\u201d \u2014 it gave me pause. I couldn\u2019t have skated to that with one of my brothers. (And I know that reading this, they are relieved.)\n\nMs. Virtue and Mr. Moir, this season\u2019s sentimental favorites \u2014 they won silver four years ago and reunited for what was likely their last stab at the gold \u2014 burn with a seething rapture that has become performative, distractingly so. I\u2019ll never tire of their skill \u2014 their consummate speed and control \u2014 but this year, as they swept across the ice with gaping mouths to music from the \u201cMoulin Rouge\u201d soundtrack, they ran my red light.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s true that skating isn\u2019t pure dance. It is, though, extraordinary in its own right and can possess the quiet sophistication, musicality and nuance of dance. With Ms. Papadakis and Mr. Cizeron, skating has room to grow. They aren\u2019t merely ice dancers: They dance on the ice, showing how it\u2019s capable of becoming a living canvas, one that curves toward the skater as the skater curves back into it.\n\nIn ice dance, there are no lifts above the head, no heroic jumps. Its power is rooted in a blade\u2019s deep etchings, the angle of plush knee bends and, despite those awkward boots, toes that point and extend the length of a leg to create fluent line. Arms lengthen from the back with fingers that grow along with them. If, in pairs and singles skating, it seems like the air is increasingly being sucked out of routines to make room for more jumps \u2014 it\u2019s worse when they\u2019re crammed into the second half in order to score more points \u2014 ice dance pushes skating to a more poetic place.\n\nHow can skaters bring emotion to a blade? How does their musicality play into a seemingly simple essence of motion? A skater moves forward and backward on the inside or outside edge of a blade. In ice dance, this is not rushed but emphasized in strokes that lean and bend to propel a skater from one side of the rink to the other.\n\nIn the singles and pairs world, pristine edges can be forsaken for jumps and lifts, but one skater who pays attention to the details in between is the American Adam Rippon. He has become a media sensation for his outspokenness, but what I love most about him is his skating. He moves like silk. He cares about line; his spins have an endearing lightness, as the arch of his back in his layback \u2014 arguably the most beautiful spin in skating \u2014 attests.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe skates for himself, the same way Ms. Papadakis and Mr. Cizeron skate \u2014 as if they are in their own world. When I watch them, my mind goes to a Jerome Robbins quote about \u201cDances at a Gathering,\u201d his sublime 1969 ensemble ballet. \u201cYou should never dance anything for the audience,\u201d he said. \u201cIt ruins it if you do. You should dance only to each other. As if the audience weren\u2019t there. It\u2019s very hard.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn figure skating, it\u2019s a radical idea. But in their free skate program, set to Beethoven\u2019s \u201cMoonlight\u201d Sonata, Ms. Papadakis and Mr. Cizeron expanded the idea of virtuosity with the way they completely tuned in to each other. Often in ice dancing, you keep your eye on the woman; the man, as in the case of Mr. Moir, is there, in part, to show off the woman \u2014 to spark her fire.\n\nBut the lyrical and musical Ms. Papadakis and Mr. Cizeron are more of a slow boil. Moving as one, they are gossamer as they transform the ice into air. Their free dance unfurled gradually and hypnotically, building to feverish spin sequences. One, in which Mr. Cizeron rotated in a sit spin while holding Ms. Papadakis\u2019s extended leg as she opened her right shoulder and head to the ceiling, was a spectacle of position and daring.\n\nAs soon as the piano became subdued and dreamy, their flurry of footwork returned to the quiet hush of the start. As they glided across the ice in whispering strokes, it seemed as if they were no longer skating in an arena, but on a pond. In that moment, at once bracing and luminous, the Olympics turned from being a competition into a performance. This year the silver was the gold.", "title": "French Olympic Ice Dancers Make Skating as Ethereal as Ballet", "authors": ["Gia Kourlas"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Many consumer reviews of Newark generally, and Terminal A in particular, are scathing. \u201cLet me just say that Terminal A is hell on earth,\u201d wrote one traveler on the airport review site Skytrax.\n\nNo one, including the airport\u2019s owner and operator, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, defends the terminal. \u201cThe Port Authority recognizes that Newark\u2019s Terminal A, which opened in 1973, can no longer adequately serve today\u2019s passengers,\u201d a spokeswoman acknowledged.\n\nTerminal A is scheduled to be demolished, which is why it\u2019s gotten little or no investment. Ground was broken for a new terminal last summer, and in December the Port Authority approved $496 million for early-stage development. It\u2019s expected to ask for more funding as soon as next week, and the project is estimated to cost $2.3 billion. But even if all goes according to plan, the new terminal isn\u2019t expected to be fully operational until 2022.\n\nThe Port Authority has been mired in scandal since at least 2013, when the Fort Lee lane-closing scheme exposed political machinations by appointees of New Jersey\u2019s then-governor, Chris Christie. Rick Cotton, a veteran civil servant and infrastructure expert whom New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo named as the authority\u2019s executive director last year, has pledged reforms.\n\nPhoto\n\nNewark\u2019s Terminal B, which received a $350 million update in 2014, and Terminal C, which was built by United Airlines and is operated under a long-term lease by the company, are far better, though both attract plenty of complaints from travelers.\n\nA major issue for the New York area\u2019s airports is that the Port Authority is allowed to divert revenues collected from airline passengers to nonairport uses, like the PATH train and the new Oculus station at the World Trade Center, a project that went grossly over budget. Federal law bans such redirections elsewhere, but the Port Authority was one of several airport operators that were exempted.\n\n\u201cIf Newark airport kept all the money it generated from landing fees it could be a world-class airport,\u201d said Tom Wright, president of the Regional Plan Association, an independent urban research group that focuses on infrastructure and public policy in the New York area. But doing so would starve other Port Authority needs, such as mass transit, he added.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nImproving Newark and the rest of America\u2019s airports needn\u2019t add to the federal deficit. Airports can fund capital improvements by levying fees on passengers and airlines. Airlines typically oppose that, and federal law currently caps such fees, known as passenger facility charges. Efforts to raise the cap, which hasn\u2019t been increased in 15 years, have gone nowhere in Congress.\n\n\u201cIt makes no sense that the fees would be the same for Des Moines and Newark, given their vastly different mass transit needs,\u201d said Mr. Wright.\n\nAfter a 10-minute walk in Terminal A, I boarded the AirTrain for what is supposed to be an 11-minute trip to the Newark Airport train station. That seemed ample time to make the next New Jersey Transit train to Manhattan, due in 20 minutes.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNothing about the AirTrain inspires confidence. It moved along the monorail at what felt like a snail\u2019s pace, shuddering at every curve. Twice it inexplicably stopped for extended periods. During the second of these stops, within sight of our destination, I watched in frustration as my train to Manhattan came and went.\n\nComplaints about the AirTrain have been mounting for years, and the Port Authority has conceded it\u2019s \u201cunreliable.\u201d It has been periodically shut down for repairs, and passengers have had to be evacuated after being stuck on board.\n\nThough the AirTrain is less than 25 years old, and cost $769 million ($1.3 billion adjusted for inflation) to build, the Port Authority concluded it must be demolished and replaced. The current capital plan calls for $385 million in repairs to the existing AirTrain, and $40 million for planning its replacement, but doesn\u2019t include the cost of the new train system. The planning proposal anticipates \u201csubstantial completion\u201d in 2022, though that seems overly ambitious.\n\nOnce I reached the station, I learned that the next New Jersey Transit train wouldn\u2019t arrive for 50 minutes. When I went to the enclosed (and presumably heated) waiting area, it was empty, and entry was barred by a guard at the door.\n\nPhoto\n\nA Port Authority official said the area was closed because of an unattended bag. Some time after I left, it reopened when a police dog certified in bomb detection determined the bag was harmless.\n\nA New Jersey Transit spokeswoman, Nancy Snyder, explained that weekend service from Newark Airport is \u201climited\u201d because of Amtrak maintenance work. Only three trains run per hour, clustered within the first 20 minutes of the hour, she said, and I evidently missed the last of those.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe number of New Jersey Transit trains is also constrained by tunnel capacity under the Hudson River. Although a new rail tunnel has been one of the country\u2019s top infrastructure priorities for years, in January the Trump administration cast doubt on the federal government\u2019s commitment to fund half the cost of the first phase of the project, estimated at $11 billion. (New York and New Jersey have pledged to pay the rest.)\n\nIn 2010, of course, Mr. Christie famously canceled a project for a new Hudson River tunnel, citing cost overruns, a decision whose reverberations continue to be felt by New Jersey\u2019s beleaguered commuters.\n\nThe train, when it finally arrived, was packed. I found a seat, but other passengers were standing. Mr. Christie\u2019s successor as governor, Phil Murphy, has called New Jersey Transit a \u201cnational disgrace\u201d and has pledged better funding and improvements.\n\nOnce we reached Penn Station, the escalator leading from the platform was broken, creating a logjam at the narrow stairways as passengers struggled with heavy luggage.\n\nMs. Snyder said that New Jersey Transit maintains nine escalators on the Seventh Avenue side of Penn Station and that, as of this week, all were functioning. But she recommended passengers use the Eighth Avenue side of the station, which offers better access to and from platforms.\n\nAfter I passed through Penn Station (no further comment needed) the final indignity was a broken escalator leading to Seventh Avenue, which is Amtrak\u2019s responsibility. The 39 escalators in Penn Station maintained by Amtrak, many of them dating to the 1960s, are notorious for malfunctioning. They can take months to repair, as The Wall Street Journal reported in 2015.\n\nLast year, referring to commuters\u2019 \u201csummer of agony,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said conditions at Penn Station had become \u201cintolerable\u201d and sent a letter to the White House asking Mr. Trump for emergency funding. The governor also called for removing the station from cash-starved Amtrak\u2019s jurisdiction as part of a \u201clong-term solution.\u201d\n\nOther than acknowledging receipt of the letter, the White House hasn\u2019t responded.", "title": "From (Crumbling) Airport to (Broken) Escalators: An Infrastructure Odyssey", "authors": ["James B. Stewart", "Common Sense"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The budget deal in Congress is billed as a measure to grant stability to a government funding process that has lurched from crisis to crisis \u2014 but it is also stuffed with provisions that will broadly affect the nation\u2019s health care system, like repealing an advisory board to curb Medicare spending and funding community health centers.\n\nMany of the provisions have been in gestation for months, even years in some cases. Some will save money. Many will cost money \u2014 potentially a lot of money.\n\nAmong the more significant provisions is one that would eliminate a powerful 15-member panel, known as the Independent Payment Advisory Board, created by the Affordable Care Act to control the rising costs of Medicare.\n\nPresident Barack Obama and his first budget director, Peter R. Orszag, as well as some health economists, championed the board as one of the most significant cost-control provisions in the 2010 health law. The board was to recommend specific savings if Medicare spending per beneficiary was projected to grow faster than certain benchmarks. Congress could have stepped in to block the recommendations, but they did not need congressional approval to take effect.", "title": "From Clinics to Child Insurance, Budget Deal Affects Health Care", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Freedom is a conceit well suited to a collection of essays. Aldous Huxley called the essay \u201ca literary device for saying almost everything about almost anything\u201d \u2014 and this is Smith\u2019s approach. She writes about her lower-middle-class upbringing by way of the second bathroom in her childhood home: \u201cThe spare room, the extra toilet \u2014 these represented, for my parents, a very British form of achievement.\u201d She mourns her father while celebrating the exhilarating democracy of Italian public parks, and she explores Justin Bieber as love-object through the philosophy of Martin Buber. The essay form\u2019s freewheeling nature arguably accounts for its current popularity. Readers, hip to the conventions of storytelling \u2014 we fill our commutes with podcasts and fetishize long-form narratives \u2014 are drawn to the essay, which lends itself to the unexpected and original. Behind the best contemporary essays you can sense the writer\u2019s beating heart.\n\nImage\n\nSmith\u2019s style is casual, discursive, but not collagelike in the current fashion, intimate without being overly personal. Taking her children to \u201cThe Polar Express 4-D Experience\u201d on the same day she sees Charlie Kaufman\u2019s puppet film, \u201cAnomalisa\u201d \u2014 while carrying a pocket book of Schopenhauer around \u2014 yields \u201cWindows on the Will: \u2018Anomalisa,\u2019\u201d an essay that examines Kaufman\u2019s film through its Schopenhauerian fixation on human suffering (the easier to dramatize with puppets): \u201cthe inevitability of it, and the possibility of momentary, illusory relief from it.\u201d Similarly, in \u201cMan Versus Corpse,\u201d the discovery of a \u201cforlorn little hardbacked book\u201d about Italian masterpieces on a table in her lobby leads to a close reading of Luca Signorelli\u2019s painting \u201cNude Man From the Back Carrying a Corpse on His Shoulders,\u201d which in turn opens up into a rambling discussion of existence, inequality (\u201cthe unequal distribution of corpses\u201d), Rothko, Warhol (\u201can enthusiastic proponent of corpse art\u201d), iPhones and her own inability to imagine herself as a corpse, before ending at a dinner party with talk of Knausgaard and his multivolume \u201ccathedral of boredom.\u201d\n\nIt is exquisitely pleasurable to observe Smith thinking on the page, not least because we have no idea where she\u2019s headed. \u201cNotes on Attunement,\u201d her well-known essay on Joni Mitchell, recounts the sudden epiphany that took her from \u201cJoni Mitchell-hating pilgrim\u201d to a fan who weeps with joy at her music, touching on Wordsworth, connoisseurship, Seneca, Kierkegaard and the inconsistency of the self along the way. At times she reminds me of a musician jamming, or one of those enviable cooks who can take five random ingredients lying around the kitchen and whip up a meal. Her loose, roving essays cohere because they are rooted in her sensibility, in what Elizabeth Hardwick called \u201cthe soloist\u2019s personal signature flowing through the text.\u201d\n\nHow to characterize Smith\u2019s sensibility? Above all, she\u2019s allergic to dishonesty, hypocrisy, sanctimony, cant. \u201cFor many people in London right now,\u201d she writes in \u201cFences: A Brexit Diary,\u201d \u201cthe supposedly multicultural and cross-class aspects of their lives are actually represented by their staff \u2014 nannies, cleaners \u2014 by the people who pour their coffees and drive their cabs, or else the handful of Nigerian princes you meet in private schools.\u201d She takes a wide-lens, Olympian view, often empathizing with both sides of an issue \u2014 her arguments can thus be difficult to pinpoint \u2014 but she is ultimately pragmatic. \u201cOne useful consequence of Brexit,\u201d she writes, \u201cis to finally and openly reveal a deep fracture in British society that has been 30 years in the making.\u201d\n\nAt root she believes that art is a realm where knotty issues can be safely explored, and that we should not draw neat boundaries around its subjects. Such is the argument of her much-discussed essay on \u201cGet Out,\u201d which first appeared in Harper\u2019s: It\u2019s a fantasy that \u201cwe can get out of each other\u2019s way, mark a clean cut between black and white,\u201d she concludes in that essay, which also examines the controversy over the white artist Dana Schutz\u2019s painting of Emmett Till. In an open letter, the artist Hannah Black had asked the Whitney Biennial to remove and destroy the painting, on the grounds that Schutz had no right to depict black suffering; the request, Smith writes, was \u201cthe province of Nazis and censorious evangelicals.\u201d The problem with such racial essentialism, she suggests elsewhere in this collection, is that it can run both ways. See the narrow, patronizing tendency to \u201cascribe to black artists some generalized aim,\u201d like \u201cinserting the black figure into the white canon.\u201d This trivializes the formal and technical concerns of the artist, Smith writes, \u201cthe unique problem each art work poses.\u201d", "title": "From Justin Bieber to Martin Buber, Zadie Smith\u2019s Essays Showcase Her Exuberance and Range", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 When KFC found itself in an extra-crispy predicament this week when it was unable to provide the one thing customers expect from the restaurant chain \u2014 chicken \u2014 it had two choices: Laugh or cry.\n\nApparently, it has chosen the former.\n\nA mischievously contrite ad in Britain on Friday featured an empty chicken bucket with the image of Colonel Sanders. Below his smiling face, the letters that make up the company\u2019s name were displayed in their typical typography, but they had been transposed to suggest a four-letter word that is associated with profanity, not poultry.\n\nIf a vowel was missing, the meaning was clear, expressing a sentiment held by both the restaurant and its customers, as problems with a new supply chain forced the closure of nearly two-thirds of KFC\u2019s British branches this week.\n\nBritain\u2019s culinary reputation might have been built on a foundation of fish and chips and cucumber sandwiches, but the country has developed an extraordinary fondness for poultry slathered in batter and fried in oil.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo the closure caused no small amount of grief and rage in a country where fried chicken \u2014 whether at KFC or at one of its many imitators, like Chicken Cottage, Tennessee Fried Chicken and Dixie Chicken \u2014 is never far away.\n\nThe police were forced to tell people that chicken shortages at KFC were not really a law-enforcement matter. At least one lawmaker said he had been contacted by angry (or perhaps just hungry) constituents. And a video of a peeved customer complaining that \u201cI\u2019ve had to go to Burger King\u201d was widely viewed.", "title": "From KFC, a 3-Letter Apology for Its U.K. Chicken Crisis", "authors": ["Michael Wolgelenter"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m a designer and I happen to do movies,\u201d the 41-year-old said over tea at her Milan apartment, looking the epitome of cool in a khaki jumpsuit, her tousled black hair pulled into a low-slung ponytail. \u201cMovies,\u201d she said, \u201callow me to step outside of the knitwear category. I get to create a world from A to Z.\u201d\n\nMs. Piersanti\u2019s path from Italy to Hollywood was somewhat circuitous. Born in Rome, to an Italian family, she moved to Paris at the age of 7, and then to Los Angeles as a teenager. \u201cI didn\u2019t speak English; it was such a culture shock,\u201d she remembered. New York was next, where she studied fashion design at Parsons before dropping out to start her career at Miu Miu, in Milan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI decided to focus on knitwear early on,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s three-dimensional and experimental. You\u2019re actually creating new fabric.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe and Mr. Guadagnino met in Milan through friends, and he asked her to help with \u201cA Bigger Splash\u201d because traditional costume design \u201ccame with a sense of detachment from reality I couldn\u2019t understand,\u201d the film designer said. \u201cHer knowledge of every tribe and social identity is so deep that I felt it was a no-brainer.\u201d It was a challenging first film job with a seven-week deadline \u2014 not that any of that fazed Ms. Piersanti.", "title": "From Knitwear to \u2018Call Me by Your Name\u2019", "authors": ["Kerry Olsen"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "In El Paso\n\nMuch of El Paso\u2019s identity is rooted in its remoteness. It is in a different time zone than most of Texas. It is closer to the capitals of three other states \u2014 Arizona, New Mexico and Chihuahua \u2014 than it is to Austin. It is surrounded by mountains and desert that offer few clear distinctions as to where the city in Texas ends and the one in Mexico begins.\n\nI was born and raised here. My mom\u2019s house is in the Austin Terrace neighborhood and my father\u2019s house was two blocks from the eastern foothills of the Franklin Mountains, in a part of the city that used to be called Chivas Town (so named because it was where goat farmers lived before the neighborhood was incorporated by the city).\n\nAfter moving away for school and work for a number of years, I realized I had not taken advantage of what the Franklin Mountains had to offer.
