So when I came back, I set out to explore the hiking trails and mountain peaks my friends brag about on social media during their bike rides and other excursions.\n\nImage\n\nThe mountains have rugged options for outdoor entertainment\u2014they\u2019re one of the premier spots for paragliding in the United States\u2014and the Wyler Aerial Tramway takes hikers and other visitors to Ranger Peak, 5,632 feet above sea level. From the top, Fort Bliss is visible just beyond the middle-class neighborhoods of Central and Northeast El Paso.\n\nThe base, one of the largest in the country, is home to the First Armored Division of the United States Army and spreads across Texas and New Mexico on more than a million acres of federally owned land. Its history is on view at the Old Ironsides Museum on the base, which features exhibits about the history of the base and the division, and rationing efforts by Americans during World War II. A plaque next to an Abrams M1 tank honors Sgt. Israel Devora Garcia, who was born in Zacatecas, Mexico, and raised in nearby Clint, Tex. He died in combat operations in Iraq in 2006. (Admission to the museum is free. Visitors must get a pass to the base before entering; it\u2019s easy but can be time-consuming on weekends.)\n\nFort Bliss is one reason so many El Pasoans are so patriotic (one of the city\u2019s main highways, Route 54, was designated the Patriot Freeway during the first Gulf War).", "title": "From Museums to Mountains, Pride and Patriotism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "More comforts means higher prices: the average nightly rate of an Airbnb Plus home is $200, compared with the $100 average rate per night for a standard listing.\n\nMr. Chesky said that the quality standards were established after a team of employees interviewed several hundred of Airbnb\u2019s top-rated hosts. \u201cWe asked them what they did to earn those ratings and discovered that they all had well-stocked homes and delivered a consistent experience to their guests,\u201d he said.\n\nAspiring hosts must apply to have their homes accepted into Airbnb Plus, and once they do, the company will send a local photographer \u2014 many of whom are Airbnb hosts themselves \u2014 to inspect their properties and determine if they meet the required standards.\n\nAirbnb\u2019s lack of quality control has at times been problematic for the company, according to Dr. Rummy Pandit, the executive director of the Lloyd D. Levenson Institute of Gaming, Hospitality and Tourism at Stockton University in New Jersey. \u201cIt is such a large and dispersed network that there have been challenges in managing a level of standardization,\u201d he said. For this reason, Dr. Pandit said, the new Plus brand is a smart business move. \u201cThere is an untapped segment of travelers who haven\u2019t used Airbnb because they don\u2019t like surprises, but now, they may be open to booking a stay through the site,\u201d he said.\n\nIn addition to Airbnb Plus, the company\u2019s main site now will have four new property types \u2014 boutique hotels, bed-and-breakfasts, vacation homes and distinctive properties such as tree houses and yurts. These are in addition to the three it already has \u2014 shared spaces, private rooms and entire homes. The listings in these categories are already on the site, but classifying them makes them easier for travelers to find, Mr. Chesky said. Collections, properties suited for a certain demographic of travelers like families and honeymooners, is also debuting today.\n\nNext up, in late spring, Airbnb will introduce Beyond by Airbnb, a collection of high-end homes for luxury-seeking travelers. This is following its purchase last year of the home rental company Luxury Retreats. \u201cWe\u2019re still affordable, but we want to offer another tier of homes to travelers who want a more upscale experience,\u201d Mr. Chesky said.\n\nHomeAway, another home rental company, has listings of more than two million homes in 190 countries and launched a high-end division, Luxury Rentals from HomeAway, in 2013 with 4,000 listings. That number has since grown to more than 11,400 listings in 80 countries.", "title": "From New Airbnb Plus, Properties With More Amenities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia \u2014 Life in Saudi Arabia has long been defined by the oil that flows from the kingdom. Over decades, the vast wealth it pumped out paid not just for gleaming towers and shopping malls but also for a government sector that employs a majority of working Saudis.\n\nNow, Saudi Arabia is trying to tie its future to another natural resource it has in abundance: sunlight.\n\nThe world\u2019s largest oil exporter is embarking, under Prince Mohammed bin Salman, on an ambitious effort to diversify its economy and reinvigorate growth, in part by plowing money into renewable energy. The Saudi government wants not just to reshape its energy mix at home but also to emerge as a global force in clean power.\n\nReaching that goal is a big if. But the strategy is finally making progress after fits and starts.\n\nRiyadh on Monday tapped ACWA Power, a Saudi energy company, to build a solar farm that would generate enough electricity to power around 40,000 homes. The project will cost $300 million and create hundreds of jobs, according to Turki al-Shehri, head of the kingdom\u2019s renewable energy program.", "title": "From Oil to Solar: Saudi Arabia Plots a Shift to Renewables", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "William G. Douglas, a longtime reporter covering Washington politics for the McClatchy news service and the co-host of its Majority Minority podcast, somehow finds time in the 24-hour news cycle to write regularly about diversity in hockey in his popular blog, The Color of Hockey.\n\nMr. Douglas fell for the game at an early age while growing up in Philadelphia. When the United States men\u2019s hockey team plays its first game at the Pyeongchang Olympics, on Wednesday against Slovenia, Mr. Douglas will be there, keeping a close eye on Jordan Greenway, the first African-American to play for the team.\n\nTell us more about your blog and how it came to be.\n\nI started The Color of Hockey in December 2012. It was born of the Stanley Cup playoffs series in 2012 between the Washington Capitals and the Boston Bruins. In that series, the Capitals forward Joel Ward, who now plays for the San Jose Sharks, scored the Game 7 overtime goal that eliminated the Bruins from the playoffs. The goal unleashed a torrent of racist social media posts aimed at Ward, who is black, from so-called Bruins fans. I had thought that we were beyond that in hockey, but I was wrong. So I decided to start the blog to help educate people \u2014 white and minority \u2014 that folks of color have a hockey history and a place in the game. I like to say that The Color of Hockey is about the history and growing impact of people of color in the game.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat\u2019s your own playing history?\n\nI\u2019m a goaltender who still plays about once a week, or as my work/family schedule allows. I started playing when I was 12 or 13 years old, growing up in Philadelphia. I was home sick watching T.V. and came across the 1972 Summit Series between Team Canada and the Soviet Union. I liked what I saw, but I really didn\u2019t know what hockey was. So I looked it up in the encyclopedia. When I got well, I saved my allowance and bought a pair of skates. After I got proficient on blades, I saved more and bought goalie equipment. I taught myself to play the position, watching N.H.L. goalies on T.V. and reading Jacques Plante\u2019s book on goaltending. I joined a bantam hockey team out of West Philadelphia that played at the University of Pennsylvania\u2019s Class of 1923 rink. I progressed and played one season of Junior B-level hockey for a team that was called Red Lion and belonged to a league called the Junior Mid-Atlantic League. We weren\u2019t very good as a team, but I learned a lot about goaltending because I saw a ton of shots.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy day you\u2019re a reporter and podcaster, how do you find the time to do all this?\n\nThat\u2019s an interesting question. My 19-year-old twin daughters ask me when I sleep. I tell them \u201cI don\u2019t know.\u201d I blog as time allows \u2014 at least once a week, usually writing posts on the weekend while watching hockey on T.V. And sometimes my political work and hockey merge. I occasionally play pickup hockey with Capitol Hill staffers and lobbyists. I used to play morning pickup with a group that included the then-Sen. John Kerry of Massachusetts.", "title": "From Olympic Press Box, Chronicling the Changing Color of Hockey", "authors": ["Melissa Hoppert"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "There are plenty of tasty reasons to let your appetite determine your destination this year. From festivals celebrating familiar foods to those where you can try more unusual ones, and events where both culinary world superstars and lesser-known chefs cook for the crowds, traveling in the coming year promises to be a palate-pleasing proposition.\n\nPerugia, in Italy\u2019s Umbria region, will host the 25th edition of Eurochocolate (Oct. 19 to 28), an event that draws a million people over the course of 10 days. Visitors can try chocolates from more than 100 European producers and also sample chocolate-based desserts prepared by notable pastry chefs, who serve crepes, cookies, cakes and ice cream.\n\nThe Espelette Pepper Festival (October) in Espelette, France, situated in the picturesque Basque countryside, is turning 50 this year, and celebrates the end of the espelette pepper harvest. There\u2019s a market where local purveyors sell the pepper as well as other regional products, and restaurants throughout the town have special menus showcasing it.\n\nAustralia has no shortage of food festivals, but the second annual Taste of Kakadu (May 18 to 27), in Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory, may be the most adventurous. Festivalgoers can discover the bush cuisine that the aboriginal people have eaten for more than 65,000 years \u2014 there\u2019s emu, chorizo, barramundi, magpie goose and more. The scheduled group bush walks are the ideal antidote to all the eating.", "title": "From Peppers to Pork Pies, the Most Interesting Food Festivals of the Year", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRafael Ocasio Barreto refused to leave Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria tore through his part of San Juan, Ca\u00f1o Martin Pe\u00f1a, flooding streets with dirty water, toppling power lines and destroying houses. He soldiered on for two weeks, although he was just as devastated as his community. Finally, his friends forced him \u2014 wearing just the clothes on his back \u2014 to get on a plane to the States.\n\nThe Federal Emergency Management Agency resettled him at a suite motel in Queens, not far from La Guardia Airport. A tiny Puerto Rican flag adorns his living room, as if he was claiming this corner of Northern Boulevard. In a bedroom, plump winter coats and new sneakers are piled atop the bed. The kitchen is stocked with food. Just as he cared little for material possessions in Puerto Rico, these items are not for him, but to share with other uprooted Puerto Ricans also staying at the motel as they await the next steps when FEMA stops covering their hotel costs on Feb. 14.\n\n\u201cI have to give them a hand so they can confront this new life,\u201d Mr. Ocasio Barreto said last week. \u201cIn Puerto Rico, even with all its dire needs, you can get someone to help. Here, that really doesn\u2019t exist. Here, it\u2019s about individualism. You feel the racism. It\u2019s not the affection you felt back home. Fortunately, even in this motel, I have found Dominicans, Hondurans and Ecuadoreans who identify with us and extend their hand like a brother nation.\u201d\n\nPerhaps it was because he saw too much and felt too much that he made the reluctant trip north. Mr. Ocasio Barreto, 48, had been living in Ca\u00f1o Martin Pe\u00f1a, where he worked with a public-private coalition of eight local communities to address the needs of residents and the environment. More than a century ago, squatters descended upon the area\u2019s mangroves, using debris and castoffs for landfill as they built shacks. Over decades, the mangroves almost vanished as tens of thousands of people settled the area, which mostly lacked proper sewage systems.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe hurricane made a tough life worse, and Mr. Ocasio Barreto conducted daily surveys to see what people needed. \u201cBefore I left in the morning, I would cry,\u201d he said, his voice cracking. \u201cThen I\u2019d leave the house with my Superman chest puffed out, like nothing affected me. But I saw so many people who had nothing, children crying, old people with infections from the dirty water, and all I could give them was a hug. And when I got home, I\u2019d cry again.\u201d", "title": "From San Juan to New York, He Offers Help and Hope for the Uprooted", "authors": ["David Gonzalez", "Side Street"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Lauren Ridloff was born with long, elegant fingers, prompting her musician father and artist mother to predict she\u2019d grow up to do something creative with her hands. This spring, Ridloff, who was also born deaf, will use them to sign onstage opposite Joshua Jackson in \u201cChildren of a Lesser God,\u201d Mark Medoff\u2019s 1979 play about a tumultuous romance between a deaf woman and a hearing man. That Ridloff\u2019s first theater acting job, apart from a star turn in a Gallaudet University high school production of \u201cThe Wiz\u201d 23 years ago (and a trial run of the show in the Berkshires last summer), will be as a Broadway lead, is a testament to her presence. \u201cI\u2019ve been in a room with Viola Davis and Denzel Washington, and she has that,\u201d says director Kenny Leon.\n\nBefore she was cast in the revival, the 39-year-old Ridloff, who grew up in Chicago\u2019s Hyde Park and now lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was hired to tutor Leon in sign language. \u201cThis is my own prejudice coming out,\u201d the director says, \u201cbut I walked in expecting to find an introverted white lady in her 60s, and ended up with this beautiful young multiracial woman brimming with confidence.\u201d The pair met for an hour every week for a year \u2014 at this point Ridloff had left her job teaching at a Manhattan elementary school to focus on her two sons, now 4 and 6. \u201cWe started with simple words \u2014 coffee, juice \u2014 and I taught him about deaf culture, what\u2019s appropriate and a few spots where the play shows its age a bit,\u201d Ridloff tells me via an interpreter. \u201cThen Kenny asked if I would come in to advise on deaf talent, and I went, innocently unaware that I was up for the role.\u201d", "title": "From Sign-Language Tutor to Lead Actress", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIn Response to Florida Shooting, Trump Focuses on Mental Health Over Gun Restrictions\u201d (nytimes.com, Feb. 15):\n\nPresident Trump has the gall to put out a statement regarding the horrific shooting in Florida that is a boldfaced lie. He said, \u201cWe are here for you \u2014 whatever you need, whatever we can do, to ease your pain.\u201d\n\nNot a word about gun control, only mental illness.\n\nThe statement is an insult to the intelligence of the American public. The shooter had an AR-15 rifle, precisely the kind of weapon that should not be in the hands of anyone other than military personnel in combat or combat training.\n\nMental health, while always a factor, is irrelevant when it comes to the availability of weaponry like this, which in the hands of anyone poses a high risk of violence.\n\nThis is insane. I fear that like all the other school shootings and mass killings this country has faced in the last year, this one will roil in social media for a couple of days and then disappear in a morass of political idiocy pandering to the National Rifle Association.", "title": "Opinion | From Trump, Nothing About Gun Control", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "In the early \u201980s, the embodiments of downtown N.Y.C. culture Cookie Mueller and Glenn O\u2019Brien co-wrote the play \u201cDrugs,\u201d a tragicomedy about two roommates and life-altering substances through the decades. It never made it to the stage (other than a one-time-only public reading at La Mama), becoming part of that era\u2019s blurry subcultural lore, although its existence was mentioned in the 2014 Mueller biography \u201cEdgewise.\u201d T\u2019s senior art director and a co-founder of the Kingsboro Press, Daniel Wagner, took note. \u201cIn the grand scheme of things, Cookie doesn\u2019t have a lot of longer works published,\u201d he says. Along with Seth Zucker of For the Common Good (a like-minded independent publishing practice) and Kingsboro\u2019s other co-founder, Megan Plunkett, he tracked down the manuscript. \u201cWe thought it would be exciting to read, since she\u2019s such a evocative writer, and exciting to resurface, because she\u2019s such a beloved underground figure,\u201d Wagner says.\n\nImage A video still from the October 2016 reading of \u201cDrugs.\u201d Credit Courtesy of For the Common Good and the Kingsboro Press\n\nThe trio received the text and a foreword from O\u2019Brien, reformatted it, designed a cover and produced a limited run of 500 copies. Then in October 2016, half a year before he died, O\u2019Brien assembled a cast to read \u201cDrugs\u201d at Anthology Film Archives on the Bowery; O\u2019Brien narrated and the director Josh Safdie, the artists Dustin Yellin and Jonah Freeman and the actor Leo Fitzpatrick were among the players. \u201cWe also did a couple of book fairs and it was sold in a few shops,\u201d Wagner adds. \u201cThen, it was gone.\u201d\n\nNot for good, though. Raf Simons somehow came across the book and contacted Wagner and co. this past fall, asking to collaborate. Simons was drawn to the graphic look of the cover and the shock of its two color-ways, bright orange and yellow, and he also counts himself as a fan of both Mueller and O\u2019Brien. Last night, the designer\u2019s iteration of \u201cDrugs\u201d walked the runway during his fall/winter 2018 men\u2019s wear show, called \u201cYouth in Motion.\u201d Models wore sleeveless and deconstructed hoodies bearing the play\u2019s name and authors, and a selection of pants, scarves and jackets incorporated patches that riffed on the original design. \u201cIt\u2019s exciting to see the book take on a life outside the play,\u201d says Wagner, who was in attendance. \u201cAnd we are huge fans of Raf\u2019s work, so it was an honor.\u201d", "title": "From a Cult Biography to the Raf Simons Runway", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Wake up before sunrise, head to the prairie and start moving.\n\nNo, this was not your ordinary rehearsal process.\n\nBut nothing\u2019s ordinary when it comes to the contemporary choreographer and improviser Jennifer Monson who has been creating daring works in New York\u2019s experimental downtown dance scene since the 1980s. Ms. Monson, 56, has long been drawn to the natural world, too. In 2000, she changed her choreographic course and began exploring the relationship between movement and the environment. For her five-year \u201cBird Brain\u201d project, for instance, she and her dancers \u2014 performing outside \u2014 followed the migrational path of birds and gray whales.\n\nFor her latest project, she resumed outdoor dancing \u2014 at dawn \u2014 in preparation for her new work, \u201cbend the even,\u201d which is at the Chocolate Factory this week. That process opened up a new universe of movement, sound and light. In the finished production, all three elements are treated equally with the hope that, together, they will produce an otherworldly, sensorial fourth element.\n\nIn \u201cbend the even,\u201d moments of stillness contrast with bursts of sweeping movement that brush the dancers\u2019 bodies across the stage as the musicians, Jeff Kolar and Zeena Parkins \u2014 he plays electronics; she, the harp \u2014 perform live, both from the audience and onstage. The lighting is by Elliott Cennetoglu, also onstage.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Monson\u2019s dancing partner is Mauriah Kraker, a graduate student at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Ms. Monson is on the faculty there, splitting her time between New York and Illinois, where she started outdoor rehearsals a year ago.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Monson wants to hold on to the feeling of being outdoors, but also to give it a concrete base. \u201cIt\u2019s researching the basics of the physics of sight and sound and movement,\u201d she said in an interview at the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, Queens. \u201cI\u2019ve had to question a lot of my own assumptions about what development is or what composition is, and this piece has let me resist some of my patterns and just let something emerge out of the way we\u2019re working together.\u201d", "title": "From the Prairie to the City, Dancing to Invoke the Dawn", "authors": ["Gia Kourlas"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Eighty percent of those steps have been taken while wearing a backpack filled with two cameras, at least three lenses, chargers, extra batteries, hand warmers, power bars, ice crampons, sunscreen and usually a bottle of water.\n\nImage A quick check of my activity app indicated that I had clocked 14,957 steps and been standing for 17 hours!\n\nOnce in position on the mountain, it\u2019s a waiting game. You try everything to keep warm. I pasted toe warmers onto my smart shirt near my kidneys. (All your blood goes through your kidneys.) I learned this from a group of Japanese photographers at my first Olympics in Albertville, France, in 1992. I also like to put two toe warmers in each boot \u2014 one on the top of my toes and one on the bottom.", "title": "From the White House to the Slopes: A Times Photographer\u2019s Olympic Trials", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLush food photography is often enough to sell a cookbook. But it was the scenic majesty of Alaska, as captured by the author and photographer Maya Wilson in \u201cThe Alaska From Scratch Cookbook,\u201d that did it for me. Ms. Wilson, a blogger and chef, explains why she\u2019s in Alaska (where it\u2019s cold and supplies are limited), and not in California, land of tacos and avocados, and how food can provide warmth no matter where. Finding ground moose, reindeer sausage and birch syrup may be a challenge, though she gives substitutes. But her salmon recipes, like one for seared fish on a bed of kale and quinoa, appreciate the local catch, as does a simple and excellent dish of halibut in Thai curry and another for black cod with bok choy. Those recipes, along with one of the best flourless chocolate cakes I have ever made, give this book my smeared-page award: \u201cThe Alaska From Scratch Cookbook\u201d by Maya Wilson (Rodale, $27.99).\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "From the Wilds of Alaska, Recipes for Adaptation", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner", "Julia O'Malley"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "To her surprise, the reception in 2002 was very different. The Times art critic Roberta Smith gave \u201cThe Dinner Party\u201d a commendatory review, repositioning its standing in the art world. \u201cIt\u2019s almost as much a part of American culture as Norman Rockwell, Walt Disney, W.P.A. murals and the AIDS quilt,\u201d she wrote.\n\n\u201cI couldn\u2019t believe my eyes,\u201d Ms. Chicago said in an interview with The Times when asked about her reaction to Ms. Smith\u2019s 2002 write-up.\n\nFor her part, Ms. Smith says she \u201cdidn\u2019t set out to correct\u201d any previous receptions of Ms. Chicago\u2019s work, including Mr. Kramer\u2019s. \u201cThe thing that I\u2019m most conscious of is wanting people to have an interesting experience when they take my word that they should go see something,\u201d she says.\n\nMs. Smith describes her process of writing art criticism as one involving a complicated relationship between her own personal reactions, interests and opinions, her and her editors\u2019 satisfaction with her writing, and a tangential awareness of the power and authority she wields as an art critic for The Times, a role she began in 1986. \u201cAt The Times I felt like I was being handed \u2014 I hate to use this metaphor \u2014 but that I was being handed this really big kind of gun, and that if I weren\u2019t careful I would take people out. And so I got kind of careful for a while,\u201d Ms. Smith said, adding that eventually, her caution subsided. In its place, she says, was the sense that choosing to write about a show, whether positively or negatively for The Times, meant it would get noticed.\n\nHow much does a Times art review matter for an artist? Some, like Yayoi Kusama for instance, get noticed whether they\u2019re in The Times or not \u2014 and there are hundreds of thousands of posts about her art on Instagram to prove it.\n\nThat is a different kind of notice from a critic\u2019s review, however. The Times art critic Jason Farago said there have been substantial shifts in art media and the general news media since Mr. Kramer\u2019s time. Notably, exhibitions that may have received half a dozen reviews from experienced critics in the press now may get only one. \u201cSo although digital media may have made it easier than ever for a show to get \u2018exposure,\u2019 a review in The Times carries greater weight insofar as reviews themselves are fewer than ever,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd because my colleagues Roberta Smith and Holland Cotter have earned their spurs as voices worth paying particular attention.\u201d\n\nAs for Ms. Chicago, she said that despite the art media\u2019s early disparagement of her work, her way of overcoming the disappointment was to go into her studio and continue making art. She found a supportive community in Southern California\u2019s Ferus boys, notably the American artist and sculptor Billy Al Bengston, from whom she said she learned quite a bit.\n\n\u201cEarly on, he told me: \u2018Never read reviews. Just count the column inches and the number of pictures,\u2019 advice I heeded for many years. And given the vicissitudes of my career, it was really good advice.\u201d", "title": "From \u2018Vicious\u2019 to Celebratory: The Times\u2019s Reviews of Judy Chicago\u2019s \u2018The Dinner Party\u2019", "authors": ["Kasia Pilat"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Citing his 26 years working in the regular court-martial system, he also described himself as \u201cshaken\u201d by the experience and portrayed Mr. Nashiri\u2019s onetime defense lawyers as pursuing a \u201crevolution to the system\u201d by defying judicial orders.\n\nEarlier this week, he had weighed having United States marshals seize two of Mr. Nashiri\u2019s former lawyers \u2014 both civilian employees of the Pentagon \u2014 to force them to appear by video link from Virginia after they failed to comply with subpoenas, but decided against it.\n\nOn Friday, he argued that in his efforts to get Mr. Nashiri\u2019s defense lawyers back to work on the case, \u201cI\u2019m not ordering the Third Reich to engage in genocide \u2014 this isn\u2019t My Lai.\u201d And he said he was weighing imminent retirement.\n\nThe latest trouble began in June, when Mr. Nashiri\u2019s defense team discovered something in a room where they talked with their client. The details remain classified, but after Colonel Spath rejected the notion that there was a problem and tried to proceed, the civilians on Mr. Nashiri\u2019s defense team quit in October, saying they had an ethical conflict.\n\nThat left only a junior, uniformed defense lawyer, Lt. Alaric Piette of the Navy. Lieutenant Piette has continued to appear in court but has not participated, arguing that he was unqualified and that the presence of a \u201clearned counsel,\u201d or death penalty specialist, is necessary \u2014 a contention Colonel Spath rejected.\n\nColonel Spath in November declared Brig. Gen. John Baker, who oversees military commissions defense lawyers, in contempt of court for refusing to order the two civilian Pentagon employees to resume work on the case. The general argued that he had the authority to dismiss them without the judge\u2019s consent \u2014 another contention Colonel Spath rejected.\n\nColonel Spath ordered General Baker confined to a the most modest of gun measures, Congress is simply incapable of a response.\n\nWhat was striking in the aftermath of the carnage at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School is that, now, even the victims and survivors are willing to call their leaders out.\n\n\u201cMy message to lawmakers in Congress is please, take action,\u201d David Hogg, a student at the school, said as he looked directly into CNN\u2019s camera on Thursday.\n\n\u201cAny action at this point instead of just complete stagnancy and blaming the other side of the political aisle would be a step in the right direction,\u201d he added.\n\nMelissa Falkowski, a teacher at the school, told CNN, \u201cIt\u2019s very emotional because I feel today like our government, our country, has failed us and failed our kids and didn\u2019t View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs attention faded, that influential organization and Republican leaders changed course, arguing that the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives would be best positioned to deal with the problem through existing regulation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince then, Justice Department officials have publicly and privately indicated that they think they do not, in fact, have the authority to regulate the devices. With the department\u2019s official review still underway, that has effectively suspended the proposal.\n\nSenators once again coalesced around another modest bipartisan fix in December, after discovering a lapse that allowed the gunman in Sutherland Springs to buy his weapons despite a domestic violence conviction. Their proposal incentivizes state and federal agencies to report criminal offenses and other information to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System.\n\nThe House passed the measure last December, but only after it was attached to a dramatic expansion of the right to carry concealed firearms virtually anywhere in the country \u2014 long sought by Republicans and the National Rifle Association. That concealed-carry legislation is a nonstarter in the Senate, and the background check bill has yet to see a vote. None was planned.\n\nMr. Cornyn, one of the bill\u2019s lead authors, took to the Senate floor on Thursday to urge its consideration.\n\n\u201cI personally am unwilling to face another family member who\u2019s lost a loved one as a result of one of these mass shootings that could be prevented by making sure the background check system works as Congress intended,\u201d he said.\n\nNeither Mr. Ryan nor Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, said anything on Thursday that suggested that would soon change.\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s be honest, I have not heard anyone explain how an improved background check system would necessarily have prevented a particular incident,\u201d said Senator Patrick J. Toomey, a Pennsylvania Republican who helped write a bill mandating near-universal background checks after the slaughter at Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012. \u201cAnd so to the extent to which we really don\u2019t have a solution for these appalling massacres, I think that makes it harder to get traction for some ideas that I think are constructive ideas.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Parkland, where students, teachers and parents gathered again on Thursday to mourn, there was little patience for such thinking. Lyliah Skinner, a student who survived the shooting, rejected politicians\u2019 thoughts and prayers and called for action.\n\n\u201cIf they\u2019re not able to purchase their first drink of alcohol, then how are we allowed to buy guns at the age of 18 or 19?\u201d she asked, adding, \u201cObviously whatever we have going on, it\u2019s not working.\u201d\n\nGov. Rick Scott of Florida, a Republican, spoke of the importance of keeping guns from the dangerously mentally ill. A law enforcement official said they needed more police.\n\nRobert W. Runcie, the Broward County superintendent, took on lawmakers more directly.\n\n\u201cStudents have been reaching out to me, reaching out to staff, probably board members and others saying that now \u2014 now is the time for this country to have a real conversation on sensible gun control laws,\u201d he said.", "title": "Frustration Grows as Congress Shows Inability to Pass Even Modest Gun Measures", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos", "Thomas Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "The National Funeral Directors Association, a trade group, said it left the decision about whether to post price information online to its members. Walker Posey, a spokesman for the association and a funeral director in North Augusta, S.C., said directors wrestled with how to convey differences in personal service, not just price, that can affect a customer\u2019s experience.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to communicate value with just a number,\u201d he said.\n\nOne funeral home, for instance, may charge a lower price, Mr. Posey said, but that doesn\u2019t indicate whether the home\u2019s vehicles are clean, whether the reception area is well maintained or whether the embalmer is skilled. \u201cWill Mom look good?\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a reason why people should look deeper than the cost on a price sheet,\u201d Mr. Posey said, adding that he was working on a website tool for his funeral home that would provide online pricing information \u201cin context.\u201d\n\nService Corporation International, the largest chain of funeral service providers in North America, said it fully complied with the Funeral Rule. \u201cIn the U.S., we are posting prices online in certain markets,\u201d the company said in an email. \u201cHowever, we strongly believe in the importance of having a personal conversation with families to understand how they envision honoring their loved ones.\u201d\n\nLois Greisman, associate director of marketing practices with the F.T.C., said that in the past, people tended to choose the same funeral home used by relatives or one recommended by their house of worship or hospital. But as society becomes more mobile, she said, and families disperse across the country, online shopping for funeral services is likely to become more common.\n\nHere are some questions and answers about funeral prices:\n\nWill the federal Funeral Rule be updated to address online pricing?\n\nThe F.T.C. is scheduled to review the rule in 2019, a commission spokesman said. The Consumer Federation of America and the Funeral Consumers Alliance petitioned the commission for early review and asked it to require online price disclosure, but it\u2019s unclear if that will occur. Several new commissioners have been nominated and await confirmation, according to a news release late last month.\n\nHow can I comparison shop for funeral services?\n\nThe F.T.C., which explains the Funeral Rule on its website, suggests gathering information in advance, if possible, to compare prices and services without the pressure to make a decision quickly.", "title": "Funeral Homes Slow to Put Prices Online", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Since the legendary chaos of 1970s and \u201980s, New York has evolved to the point where the city\u2019s \u201cDisneyfication\u201d is taken as a matter of public record. This is not true, or at least it\u2019s not the whole story. The attacks of Sept. 11 and the Great Recession hit the city hard \u2014 as did a tourist-friendly Times Square. And yet New Yorkers remained and innovated. This era\u2019s influencers, more diverse in gender and race than the lions of the past, reflect how the city\u2019s power base has evolved. Here is a partial list of standouts \u2014 subject, as always, to change.\n\nImage Michelle Alexander Credit Richard Shotwell/Invision, via Associated Press\n\nTHE ACTIVIST\n\nMichelle Alexander, a scholar and civil-rights litigator, exposed the warehousing in prisons of African-Americans in her 2010 book, \u201cThe New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness,\u201d and as a professor at Union Theological Seminary.\n\nTHE POWER COUPLE\n\nBeyonc\u00e9 is Houston-bred, but her songs have New York moxie. She is often courtside at Knicks games with husband, Jay-Z, who gave a generation a new soundtrack to the city with \u201cEmpire State of Mind.\u201d", "title": "Future Lions of New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is coming, this is real,\u201d Stephen K. Bannon, Mr. Trump\u2019s former chief strategist, said recently about the female-fueled wave of liberal energy.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s remarks illustrated a broader problem: Republican congressional leaders and strategists have pleaded with lawmakers and candidates to stay focused on economic growth and December\u2019s tax cuts, a message they hope will be their salvation before the elections in November. But that may be little more than fantasy in a campaign that will turn more on the president\u2019s conduct than any policy issue.\n\n\n\nHis comments on Friday, the first he had offered since images emerged of one of Mr. Porter\u2019s former wives bearing a black eye, were the culmination of a week\u2019s worth of politically ill-advised steps that suggest that the president and his lieutenants cannot stop themselves from blunting positive political momentum. By the weekend, Mr. Trump\u2019s State of the Union address, strong employment and wage figures as well as the onset of tax cuts seemed washed away by the latest White House controversy.\n\nThe frustration in the Republican political class is bursting forward.\n\n\u201cFor members or anybody else who cares about keeping control of Congress, if you find yourself talking about anything but the middle-class tax cut, shut up and stop talking,\u201d fumed Corry Bliss, who runs the primary House Republican \u201csuper PAC,\u201d the Congressional Leadership Fund. \u201cAny time spent on TV talking about anything but how we\u2019re helping the middle class is a waste of time and does nothing to help us win in 2018.\u201d\n\nRepublicans have grown accustomed to the president\u2019s lack of discipline and inability to reliably carry a message. But operatives overseeing the midterm effort and some lawmakers facing difficult re-elections are growing more alarmed that Mr. Trump\u2019s fixation on the Russia inquiry, personal slights and personality clashes inside and outside his White House are only encouraging his congressional and conservative news media allies to swerve off message.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe party has finally gotten some good signs. The president\u2019s approval ratings have been inching up in recent polling, fewer voters are indicating a preference for a Democratic Congress and some polls show Mr. Trump starting to get more credit for the booming economy than former President Barack Obama.\n\nBut even as voters begin to see more take-home pay, companies add jobs and employees receive bonuses, their votes are not necessarily going to drift to the Republicans in November. Many Americans are still uncertain that they will benefit from the tax measure, Mr. Bliss conceded. He cited a wave of private polling and focus groups that his organization has conducted this year revealing much of the electorate to be skeptical that they would receive a tax cut from the bill, which was signed into law in December.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is in part because of what mainstream Republicans describe as a destructive cycle of incentives: Mr. Trump reacts to Fox News segments about the Russia investigation or another controversy, encouraging more such coverage and prompting House conservatives from largely safe seats to make their own incendiary comments, which win them television invitations and attention from the president. Such notoriety might help those lawmakers in their deep red districts, but they do nothing for the party\u2019s overall political standing.\n\n\u201cThese guys are performing for the president when they go on TV,\u201d said Jason Roe, a longtime Republican strategist who is consulting on a series of at-risk House districts in California.\n\nRepresentative Matt Gaetz of Florida, a first-term Republican who is one of Mr. Trump\u2019s most visible champions outside the White House staff, all but said as much.\n\nMr. Gaetz, who used the State of the Union speech to snag a selfie with Mr. Trump in the House chamber, has said the president is \u201cabout as popular in my district as oxygen.\u201d He acknowledged that the tax bill was far more politically urgent than arguments about Russia and conceded that his on-air denunciations of Mr. Mueller served no electoral purpose. But for good measure, he said, he has been urging colleagues to warn voters in 2018 that Democrats could impeach Mr. Trump.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe also boasted that he had found a particular audience for his cable news forays: Mr. Trump, he said, \u201ccalls me frequently and shares his thoughts on my television appearances.\u201d\n\nFar less visible are Republican lawmakers such as Representative Mimi Walters of California, who is facing a difficult campaign in an Orange County district where lobbing rhetorical bombs at the F.B.I. will do little with her centrist constituents but drawing attention to Disney\u2019s bonuses could bear fruit.\n\n\u201cWe talk about this all the time \u2014 we have got to get the message out on taxes,\u201d Ms. Walters said.\n\nCampaign veterans and Capitol Hill aides say part of the challenge, particularly in the House, is that many Republican lawmakers had until last year been in office only with a Democratic president and therefore are well practiced at oppositional politics but know little about trumpeting a positive message.\n\nPhoto\n\nParty officials have for weeks sought to drive home to lawmakers and Mr. Trump how crucial it is that they sell the tax law, bluntly warning that it will take an ambitious campaign to transform the measure into an unambiguous political winner. Strategists have written memos for public consumption and published op-eds emphasizing the need to go on offense. Senior lawmakers have used private meetings to implore the president and their colleagues to stay focused on taxes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt a gathering last month at Camp David, House Republican leaders invoked the example of Mr. Obama to Mr. Trump, who is often eager to act differently than his predecessor. The lawmakers told the president that Democrats suffered such deep losses in 2010 in part because Mr. Obama did not make a sufficient case for his economic stimulus measure, Republicans in attendance said.\n\nLast week at a congressional Republican retreat in West Virginia, Representative Steve Stivers of Ohio, the head of the House campaign arm, opened and closed his presentation to lawmakers with \u201cthree takeaways,\u201d according to a Republican in attendance: \u201cBe ready, sell tax reform and run a campaign.\u201d\n\nRepresentative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington, another member of the leadership, has even created a kit for lawmakers about how to stage district events to \u201ctell the story of the tax cuts and jobs,\u201d offering a \u201cGipper of the Week\u201d award to Republicans who do top-flight communications works (the award: a jar of jelly beans, a favorite of Ronald Reagan\u2019s).\n\nDavid Winston, a veteran Republican pollster, made a presentation at the retreat arguing that many voters remained highly flexible in their views of the tax law, giving Republicans a chance \u2014 but so far, only a chance \u2014 to close the sale. But in an interview, Mr. Winston, who advises Speaker Paul D. Ryan, warned that the party could not trust public opinion on the law to continue improving on its own.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a need to make people aware of what\u2019s in the legislation,\u201d Mr. Winston said. \u201cThere is a large portion of the electorate that is aware of it, but there\u2019s probably a larger portion of the electorate that\u2019s not.\u201d\n\nMr. Ryan has been uneasy about the attention devoted to the release of the House Intelligence Committee\u2019s memo about the F.B.I. Instead, the speaker has mapped out a series of visits to businesses affected by the tax law to showcase his preferred 2018 message by example.\n\nIn a revealing sign of the party\u2019s anxiety about Mr. Trump, the Republican National Committee has taken to trumpeting the \u201cTrump tax cuts\u201d and has urged campaigns and other Republican committees to credit Mr. Trump explicitly and often with enacting the new law, but has faced skepticism from Republicans wary of introducing Mr. Trump\u2019s name into competitive elections.\n\nMr. Trump himself underscored the risk involved in tying him, as a personality, to the Republican economic agenda during a visit to Ohio this week. His speech was intended to showcase the health of the economy, but he veered into an extended digression about his recent address to Congress and accused Democrats of \u201ctreason\u201d for refusing to clap at points. The economic message was lost.\n\nThe conundrum, several strategists and lawmakers conceded, is that Mr. Trump\u2019s legal and culture wars are more politically galvanizing to the party\u2019s conservative base than Ryanesque sermons on the free enterprise system.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe G.O.P. base just doesn\u2019t eat that up the way it does trending memo hash tags and firing-Mueller conspiracies,\u201d Nick Everhart, a Republican strategist based in Ohio, said of the party\u2019s economic message. \u201cThus, it\u2019s no surprise members of Congress in super-red districts, immune to the perilous political environment we\u2019re headed toward, put themselves and feeding the base first.\u201d", "title": "G.O.P. Squirms as Trump Veers Off Script With Abuse Remarks", "authors": ["Jonathan Martin", "Alexander Burns"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Yes, President Trump is vile. That\u2019s a given.\n\nYes, we should focus on the Robert Mueller investigation, particularly since Trump, his congressional cohort and the purely propagandistic Fox News are treating that investigation as an existential threat and actively working to discredit not only Mueller but the entire F.B.I.\n\nYes, we should focus on Trump\u2019s misogyny and patriarchy, which continue to manifest in his assemblage of a group of advisers and confidants who include among them a shockingly high number of men who have been accused of assault \u2014 sexual or not \u2014 against women. Trump himself has been accused of this violence and even admitted to a pattern of sexual assault on tape, but now denies it. Perhaps because of that, he has developed a pattern of response when new accusations of abuse are revealed: Believe the men and discount the women.\n\nYes, we should focus on Trump\u2019s breaking of custom and convention, his racism and his reactiveness, his Barack Obama obsession and his autocratic impulses.\n\nBut while we are focusing on Trump and what he has wrought, it would behoove us to also focus on the titanic moves by the right to literally realign society for the long haul: stacking the courts with virulent conservatives, suppressing voter access, reducing the inflow of immigrants who might lean Democratic, gerrymandering districts, punishing states that lean Democratic in presidential elections and returning to a failed drug policy that disproportionately jails black and brown people.", "title": "Opinion | G.O.P. Visions of Tectonic Realignment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Another uptick in interest rates also seemed to dampen what had started out as a relatively decent day for stocks. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose to 2.84 percent after lackluster demand in an auction of $24 billion worth of the benchmark government bonds. Yields on 10-year Treasuries, which serve as the foundation for a range of consumer borrowing rates, are near their highest levels since January 2014.\n\nThe steady climb in interest rates has gained pace in 2018. And it has become a concern for investors who believe the low interest rates since the financial crisis have been a cornerstone of the long bull market for stocks. Interest rates on shorter-term Treasury bonds, such as the two-year note, have also risen sharply.\n\nThose shorter-term bond yields tend to be sensitive to changing expectations surrounding monetary policy, another source of worry in recent days.", "title": "Gains on Wall St. Subside as Global Investors Grow Cautious", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMuseums hold a very quiet but authoritative position,\u201d Ms. Boyce said, adding that curators are usually far from the public eye when they make decisions about which pieces go on display and which stay in storage.\n\n\u201cTo interrupt that is seen as an act of vandalism somehow, or as something that is challenging those power structures,\u201d she said.\n\nCurators and staff members at the museum did not respond to requests for comment this weekend. But Clare Gannaway, the contemporary art curator there, told BBC Radio 4 that the decision arose from staff conversations about gender representation and that it was meant to set off debate.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve picked this painting quite provocatively because it is quite a popular one,\u201d she added.\n\nAs movements like #MeToo and #TimesUp prompt new conversations about harassment and abuse, gender inequality, and the representation of women in art, the removal of \u201cHylas and the Nymphs\u201d seems to have struck a nerve. Ms. Boyce said that in discussions about which piece of art to remove, museum volunteers had shared stories of guests making inappropriate comments, sometimes in reference to the Victorian paintings of naked women.\n\n\u201cHaving heard the effects that it\u2019s having on the people who have to work with it all the time, I think we need to have a conversation about it,\u201d she said.\n\nThis is not the first time Ms. Boyce has experimented with how art and observers interact. In 1995, she staged an exhibition in which people had to use peepholes to see ethnographic artifacts at the Brighton Museum.", "title": "Gallery Wanted to Provoke Debate by Removing Naked Nymphs Painting. It Succeeded.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Curling is a game played on a sheet of ice in which the athletes use brooms to guide polished granite rocks toward a target. Its roots date to 16th-century Scotland.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut it was not until 2006 that one of South Korea\u2019s first curling facilities was built \u2014 here in Uiseong. A former government official had seen the sport while traveling in Canada and thought it would appeal to a wide range of people. So the county cobbled together the funds to build the Gyeongbuk Uiseong Curling Centre.\n\nKim Joo-soo, the current county mayor, said in an interview at his office that four friends (including two sisters) from Uiseong Girls High School soon became regulars. They thought it was a fun after-school activity.\n\nNobody knew they would become Olympians.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re sisters and they\u2019re friends,\u201d Kim said, \u201cso their communication is so important. You can tell that teamwork is a big factor in their success.\u201d\n\nAnother factor: the sterling play of Kim Eun-jung, 27, who goes by the nickname Annie and operates as the team\u2019s skip, which means she orchestrates the team\u2019s strategy and throws the most important shots. Some of those shots already have led the South Koreans past powerhouses like Canada, Switzerland and Britain, sealing a berth in Friday\u2019s semifinals.\n\nKim Eun-jung, who wears eyeglasses that have become the most iconic fashion accessory at the Games, plays with a sort of poker-faced intensity that has made for internet memes. But her teammates, who have fun nicknames like Steak, Sunny and Pancake, have become nearly as recognizable to a growing number of fans across the country. They are Kim Kyeong-ae, 24, and Kim Yeong-mi, 26, who are sisters; and Kim Seon-yeong, 24. A fifth player, Kim Chohi, is the team\u2019s alternate. (Her nickname is ChoCho.)\n\nTheir path to Olympic stardom was not without obstacles. In recent years, the Korean curling federation was roiled by a sexual abuse case that involved a former coach and by the misappropriation of training funds. But the players on the current team persevered, and banners featuring their faces and the Olympic rings are now scattered across Uiseong.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re inspiring a lot of young kids to participate in winter sports, and not just curling,\u201d said Do Ki-min, 29, who got an excused absence from work at the county office so he could watch Tuesday\u2019s match at the high school. \u201cMy boss is here, too.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nKim Sung-hee, the woman who lost her voice from cheering too hard, said she was from the same neighborhood as the two sisters on the team. She had been watching their matches at a community center, she said. But as the wins kept piling up, it was starting to get pretty crowded.\n\nAhead of Tuesday\u2019s match, an announcement was posted on the county\u2019s official website that a viewing party would be held at the high school. Word spread around the county. Lee Jung-yong, an actor and entertainer from Seoul, was brought in to rev up the crowd \u2014 but that hardly seemed necessary.\n\nAs Kim Sung-hee watched Kim Eun-jung and her teammates rough up the Americans, she cited one other possible reason for the team\u2019s success.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Cartoon garlic bulbs smile from billboards. Garlic statues dot the countryside. Kim Joo-soo, the mayor, deemed it the finest garlic in the world.\n\n\u201cWe think so,\u201d he said.\n\nIt is all because of a volcano that erupted 70 million years ago, he said, and left ash that enriched the soil.\n\nNow, all these millenniums later, the city has sprouted something new.", "title": "Garlic Girls Take Over the Olympics, and Their Hometown Is Loving It", "authors": ["Scott Cacciola", "Chang W. Lee"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "SYDNEY, Australia \u2014 They were there for the Sissy Ball, a vogue-style dance-off that was last weekend\u2019s contribution to the Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras, a two-week gay pride festival that will culminate in a parade this Saturday.\n\nBut as dozens of gay and transgender dancers popped and sashayed on the catwalk before a cheering crowd, the ball\u2019s M.C. reminded everyone what made the bash possible.\n\n\u201cShout out to Red Bull!\u201d he yelled.\n\nRed Bull, the energy drink producer, is one of dozens of companies sponsoring and participating in Mardi Gras this year. Others include Netflix, Absolut, Airbnb and Tinder. The retail bank ANZ has decorated automated teller machines around Sydney, which it calls \u201cGAYTMs.\u201d", "title": "Gay Mardi Gras in Sydney Goes Corporate, Clashing With Activist Roots", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nIn \u201cIs America Growing Less Tolerant on L.G.B.T.Q. Rights?\u201d (Op-Ed, nytimes.com, Jan. 29), Jennifer Finney Boylan highlights declining support for L.G.B.T.Q. people as reported in Glaad\u2019s Accelerating Acceptance survey. She attributes this growing \u201cuncomfortability\u201d to the Trump administration\u2019s anti-L.G.B.T.Q. rhetoric, which is felt most acutely by L.G.B.T.Q. youths.\n\nThe Trevor Project, which works to prevent suicide among these youths, reports that calls to its hotline doubled the day after Donald Trump\u2019s election and have continued to rise.\n\nBut we are not helpless. Every American has the power to make our society more inclusive and affirming. We have to change the culture.\n\nFamily rejection can be crippling, leading to negative outcomes, from homelessness to drug abuse. Lesbian, gay and bisexual youths who are rejected by their families are eight times more likely to attempt suicide than peers with supportive families. Trans and gender-nonconforming youths are at even higher risk.", "title": "Opinion | Gay in the Trump Era", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHeadliner\n\nGEM The kitchen whiz-kid Flynn McGarry, who has been coming up with tasting menus for a cult following at pop-ups in Los Angeles and New York since he was 12, is aiming for permanence. He\u2019s now 19, as slight as a reed, with hair like a tangle of spiralized carrots. His restaurant, in a pair of narrow storefronts on the Lower East Side, consists of the Living Room, an all-day cafe serving coffee, tea and pastries from morning until 5 p.m., which has just opened. In two weeks, the adjacent Dining Room will follow, with $155 (including tip) set-menu dinners. \u201cMy idea is to make it like a dinner party,\u201d he said. So guests start with a glass of Champagne and hors d\u2019oeuvres in the cafe before proceeding to the main room, with its simple wood tables and open kitchen, for an appetizers, followed by a couple of family-style platters of pasta and meat, like a lamb feast, with side dishes. Appetizers might include peanut Ritz Crackers with foie gras, king crab with leeks and grapefruit, and slow-roasted sunchokes with pumpkin seed oil and apple. Mr. McGarry describes Daniel Humm of Eleven Madison Park and Ari Taymor of Alma in Los Angeles as mentors. \u201cThey let me work in their kitchens, but gave me real responsibilities and taught me the business side, instead of just having me pluck herbs,\u201d he said. His Ritz Crackers are just the sort of thing Mr. Humm might serve: 116 Forsyth Street (Broome Street), no phone, gem-nyc.com.\n\nOpening\n\nBASTA Here\u2019s another entry in the growing inventory of Israeli dining options from the chef Raz Shabtai, who grew up in Tel Aviv, learned to cook from his grandmother and worked at restaurants in Israel and with Meir Adoni at Nur in New York. His kosher (dairy) Mediterranean restaurant features charred eggplant carpaccio, shakshuka, several seafood preparations and North African dishes like fish with couscous. Long tables are set in a room with a brick oven for bread and pizza, an open kitchen, and vintage artifacts and fresh produce on display: 62 East 34th Street, 917-261-7352.\n\nMALA PROJECT Amelie Kang\u2019s East Village take-no-prisoners Chinese restaurant featuring dry pots dense with ingredients, is venturing to Midtown Manhattan, near Xi\u2019an Famous Foods. It will offer a number of dishes for the lunch crowd with lamb or chicken-based combinations. (Opens Wednesday): 41 West 46th Street, 917-261-7520, malaproject.nyc.\n\nBOUCHERIE PARK AVENUE SOUTH The meat-focused brasserie that opened in the West Village in late 2016 will welcome a sibling near Union Square. It\u2019s a big place, like the original, finished in the Belle \u00c9poque style and serving French bistro fare. New, at this location, is a counter that specializes in charcuterie. (Wednesday): 225 Park Avenue South (18th Street), 212-353-0200, boucherie.nyc.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTHE HARROW A former hardware store is now this new American restaurant with the chef Eric Thomas, formerly at Nice Matin, in the kitchen. Lobster pierogi, duck magret and a vegan Pavlova dessert with meringue made of aquafaba are some of his specialties. (Thursday): 720 10th Avenue (50th Street), 212-757-6977, theharrownewyork.com.", "title": "Gem, From 19-Year-Old Chef Flynn McGarry, Opens in the Lower East Side", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Off The Menu"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "His philosophy could be reduced to two axioms:\n\nFirst, autocracies are vulnerable to being undermined because \u201cdictators are never as strong as they tell you they are,\u201d he said in Mr. Arrow\u2019s film, \u201cand people are never as weak as they think they are.\u201d\n\nSecond, while limited violence against dictatorial governments may sometimes be inevitable, violence provokes more violence, a strategy that gives dictators an advantage.\n\nWhile Gandhi\u2019s death in 1948 galvanized a young Dr. Sharp to begin preaching nonviolence, he was no pacifist. He admired Gandhi less for his ethical commitment to the cause than for his rejection of passive submission and his tactical success with nonviolent alternatives.\n\nCharacterized variously as the \u201cMachiavelli of Nonviolence\u201d and the \u201cClausewitz of Nonviolent Warfare,\u201d Mr. Sharp argued that nonviolent resistance draws its strength from basic human nature.\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t build on the capacity of people to love each other and turn the other cheek,\u201d he told The Boston Globe in 1983, \u201cbut on people\u2019s capacity to be stubborn and cussed, and we\u2019re all good at that.\u201d\n\nDr. Sharp worked out of his East Boston townhouse (where he cultivated rare orchids); it had doubled as his institution\u2019s cramped headquarters since funding began withering in 2004. The tipping point was a fallout with his chief benefactor, Peter Ackerman, a Wall Street investor, who began another organization to promote nonviolence.", "title": "Gene Sharp, Global Guru of Nonviolent Resistance, Dies at 90", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Young singers who win the George London Awards not only take home $10,000 but also join an illustrious group of past recipients, including Ren\u00e9e Fleming, Joyce DiDonato and Matthew Polenzani. This year\u2019s group of six winners was awarded after the finals on Friday at the Morgan Library & Museum: Lawson Anderson, bass-baritone; Raehann Bryce-Davis, mezzo-soprano; Rihab Chaieb, mezzo-soprano; Emily D\u2019Angelo, mezzo-soprano; Lauren Margison, soprano; and Benjamin Taylor, baritone.\n\nThe winners range from 23 to 31. Seventy-two singers were granted auditions organized by the George London Foundation, out of over 150 applicants, and 17 were chosen to compete in the finals.\n\nFor Ms. Bryce-Davis, 31, the victory completed something of a full-circle journey: She applied to the competition seven years ago without knowing its pedigree, and was promptly told by her teacher to withdraw. \u201cShe broke it down for me: \u2018I appreciate how eager you are, but you are in no way ready for something on this level.\u2019 I was quite bitter,\u201d Ms. Bryce-Davis said in an interview.\n\nShe spent several years performing in Europe before deciding she was ready to return. She impressed the judges by performing the climactic moment from Gounod\u2019s rarity \u201cSapho,\u201d in which the heroine hits a high B flat right before she commits suicide by jumping into the ocean.", "title": "George London Awards Given to Six Young Singers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "George S. Kaufman, a real estate magnate whose transformation of a derelict movie studio in Astoria, Queens, helped revive film and television production in New York, died on Feb. 20 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 89.\n\nThe cause was heart failure, said his wife, Mariana.\n\nIn 1982, Mr. Kaufman, the scion of a century-old New York real estate family, led a group of investors in rescuing the Queens complex, which had opened in 1920 as the cavernous home of what became Paramount Pictures.\n\nHe developed the site into 500,000 square feet of studios, production facilities, offices, service space and a backlot, drawing television and movie producers eager to film in New York.", "title": "George S. Kaufman, Who Revived Astoria Studios, Dies at 89", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "A spokeswoman for Gov. Nathan Deal, who had said the tax bill was necessary to encourage airlines to open direct routes from Georgia to destinations around the world, did not return an email seeking comment.\n\nOther Republicans in the State Legislature also on Monday pulled back their support for the bill, which would grant a $50 million sales tax exemption on jet fuel, primarily benefiting Delta. Among the new critics was the House speaker, David Ralston, who said on Monday that he was disappointed with Delta and wished it had announced the decision before the House approved the tax bill on Thursday. The legislation moved the next day to the Senate, where it seemed to have broad support.\n\nBut on Saturday, that support all but evaporated after Delta announced it had eliminated a discount fare program for travelers to attend the N.R.A.\u2019s 2018 annual meeting in May. The airline, which had come under growing pressure from its customers and others to cut ties with the gun group, said its decision \u201creflects the airline\u2019s neutral status in the current national debate over gun control amid recent school shootings.\u201d\n\nDelta said in a statement on Saturday that it supported the Second Amendment but has refrained from political issues before. The airline noted that it withdrew financial support of a New York production of \u201cJulius Caesar\u201d last summer because it depicted the assassination of a Trump-like Roman ruler.\n\nIn the days after the shooting massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., more than a dozen companies, including MetLife Insurance, Symantec and Enterprise, cut ties with the N.R.A. Many were being threatened with boycotts over the deals and discounts they had offered to the gun group\u2019s members.", "title": "Georgia Republicans Vow to Kill Airline Tax-Cut Bill After Delta Ends N.R.A. Discount", "authors": []}
